title: John G. Riddell Is Dead at 62; Philadelphia Investment Chief
description: John Graham Riddell, president of the Philadelphia Investment Company, which specializes in real estate and oil properties, died of a heart attack on Friday at the Merion Golf Club in Ardmore, Pa. He was 62 years old and lived in Rosemont, Pa.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $8,400 for the quarter and $20,300 for the 6 months. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,040 for the quarter and $15,000 for the 6 months.

title: SMALL WEEKLY SEEKS TO BE A STRONG LIBERAL VOICE IN CATHOLIC LIFE
description: At the entrance to the editorial offices of the National Catholic Reporter here, a message is blocked out in white letters against a black felt background.

title: I.B.M.-Digital Pact at M.I.T.
description: The nation's two largest computer manufacturers, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation, have agreed to provide $50 million in equipment and personnel to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: MERCANTILE BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Commerce Union Fills Its Top Post
description: When Japanese bankers used to call on the Commerce Union Bank in Nashville, they would occasionally shift from English into Japanese to make unflattering comments about the bank and Tennessee.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Aging Jalopy Is Back on Wheels

title: ASKEW, THE DARKEST HORSE, CALLS POLLS 'IRRELEVENT'
description: Supporters of Reubin Askew's Presidential candidacy say he is running ''against the grain.'' Detractors say he is running on empty. The former Florida Governor says reporters should quit worrying about where he is running in the polls.

title: A TACTIC GOES WRONG
description: W hen Mike Stahr saw the 6-foot-3-inch figure of Charlie Marsala striding past him at the 440-yard mark at Randalls Island on Monday, he happily noted to himself that everything was going according to plan.

title: Rome Report Acquired
description: The Rome Report, a media measuring company, has been acquired by Interactive Market Systems, also in the business, for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock, and will become a wholly owned subsidiary of I.M.S.

title: RATHER AGAIN DEFENDS CBS IN SUIT
description: Dan Rather defended the accusations linking a doctor to an insurance-fraud scheme in a controversial segment of ''60 Minutes,'' testifying today in a slander suit against CBS that ''if it looks like a duck, walks like a duck and quacks like a duck, you've got a duck.''

title: Britons Protest at U.S. Base
description: About 500 protesters tried to blockade a United States air base near here today, and 26 demonstrators were arrested. The protesters, who want Britain to get rid of its nuclear weapons, sat down in front of the 11 gates at the base near Oxford in what organizers said was the first part of a four-day demonstration. But they were unable to stop traffic or employees from entering or leaving the base.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Children's World
description: Directors of Children's World Inc., which operates 123 educational day care centers in this country, have agreed that the company can be acquired by Grand Met, USA Inc., a subsidiary of the British company Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., through a tender offer of $13 a share, expiring June 27. Grand Met has already acquired 688,940 shares, or 25 percent of the 2.7 million Children's World shares outstanding, from five shareholders. The total transaction is valued at about $35 million on the basis of $13 a share.

title: AM CABLE TV reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: Pennzoil Funds
description: The Pennzoil Company said it had arranged for a one-year extension of its $2.5 billion financing commitment from a group of 29 United States and foreign banks led by Citicorp. The company said the commitment is payable solely out of production from proved domestic oil, natural gas and sulfur reserves. Pennzoil said it might take down all or part of the financing through July 31, 1984.

title: Philip Morris Receives Architectural Award
description: The first Architectural League award has been presented to Philip Morris Inc. for its ''enlightened corporate support of the arts and dedicated commitment to art and architecture in the public realm.'' The award, an eight-inch-high marble arch, was presented in a ceremony at the company's new world headquarters at 42d Street and Park Avenue.

title: Play-Jour Agency
description: Richard & Edward's, the ad agency that is seeking its fortune in the leisure time field, has become the agency for Play-Jour Inc., marketers of the Japanese-made Capsela motorized construction sets.

title: Economic Scene; U.S. Bailouts: Caution Urged
description: WASHINGTON IT is now clear that the Chrysler Corporation, which made more money in the first three months of this year than in any previous quarter in its history, has joined Lockheed in successfully escaping a brush with corporate oblivion.

title: 76ERS WIN N.B.A. TITLE WITH SWEEP OF LAKERS
description: In the spring of 1977, the Philadelphia 76ers, after having been defeated in the National Basketball Association championship series by the Portland Trail Blazers, tried to appease their fans with the slogan: ''We Owe You One.'' Tonight, they paid the debt.

title: MILTON YOUNG OF N. DAKOTA, SENATOR FOR 36 YEARS, IS DEAD
description: Milton R. Young, who represented North Dakota in the United States Senate for 36 years and, according to his Congressional Directory biography, held the record for the longest continuous service by a Republican Senator, died of cancer yesterday in Sun City, Ariz. He was 85 years old.

title: JUSTICE SYSTEM STIFLED BY ITS COSTS AND ITS COMPLEXITY, EXPERTS WARN
description: Prominent lawyers, judges and scholars warn that the nation's system of justice is choking on its own complexity and costliness as swollen caseloads place ever-greater demands on it.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 1, 1983; The Economy
description: The leading economic indicators rose 1.1 percent in April, their 10th consecutive monthly increase, the Commerce Department reported. The gain was seen as further evidence that recovery continues to gain momentum. Indeed, private and Government experts now believe the recovery will be stronger than the Administration had forecast. (Page D1.)

title: ARTIFICIAL TURF: AN EQUALIZER?
description: T he grass fields of world soccer stadiums are more carefully groomed than the lawns of palaces and parliaments. Those fields are the showcases for the jewels of the national sport in dozens of countries.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
description: b-Net loss

title: MARATHON WITH 1,000 HILLS
description: For 5,867 South African masochists who ran today in the annual Comrades Marathon, with little doubt the world's most punishing long-distance race, it was an ''up'' year.

title: GEORGE YACOUB
description: George Yacoub, the former spokesman for the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus after the Turkish invasion of the island, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 60 years old.

title: Laura McCoy, Started Black Girl Scout Troop
description: Laura Belle McCoy, founder of the first black Girl Scout troop in the United States, died Friday at the Masonic Home and Hospital in Wallingford, Conn. She was 93 years old and a former resident of New Haven.

title: FOES PAINT A RIGHTIST THATCHER FUTURE
description: The British general-election campaign has entered a new phase, with the opposition parties now warning the voters of the dangers of a landslide Tory victory by suggesting that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has a hidden radical agenda for a second term.

title: SALVADOR REBELS SAID TO OVERRUN COMMUNICATIONS BASE ATOP PEAK
description: Leftist guerrillas overran a military communications base in the northern province of Morazan today, according to a military source.

title: MINSTAR INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes income tax benefits of $693,000 for the quarter and $1,516,000 for the 9 months, and the sale of assets of $500,000 for the quarter and $1,750,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a tax credit of $73,000 for the quarter and 9 months, expenses absorbed by the company's owmobile group of $107,000 for the quarter and $437,000 for the 9 months, and the sale of assets of $1,100,000 for the quarter and $1,800,000 for the 9 months.

title: Town's Policewoman Is Still on Duty at 72
description: At 72 years of age, Martha Carper is still packing a gun and enforcing the law. Mrs. Carper, a mother of three, was 68 when Mayor Paul Beighle first asked her to trade her job in a restaurant for a badge because the Police Department was ''real short-handed.''

title: Director Will Retire At Hirshhorn Museum
description: Abram Lerner, the founding director of the Hirshhorn Museum, will retire next May, it was announced yesterday by S. Dillon Ripley, secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, of which the Hirshhorn is a part.

title: FERRY AT TOUR'S END
description: ''THE question American interviewers always ask me is why Roxy Music isn't bigger commercially over here,'' said Bryan Ferry. The stylish, steely-eyed singer was sitting on the couch in his suite in the Carlyle Hotel, having decided to spend a few days unwinding in New York after concluding Roxy Music's first American tour in several years with two nights at Radio City Music Hall.

title: C.A.B. TALK OF 'SUNSET' IS HEARTFELT
description: When people at the Civil Aeronautics Board speak of the sunset, as they do regularly, they are not waxing poetic. They are using the setting sun as a metaphor for the shuffling of papers, emptying of file cabinets and career changes that come with airline deregulation and the agency's impending demise.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Yorkiana

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN IN U.S. INQUIRY INTO RACKETEERING
description: A Justice Department task force believes it has made a breakthrough in its battle against organized crime and corruption in Puerto Rico with the agreement of a suspect in a kidnapping case to testify on 53 crimes, including murders, kidnappings and hijackings.

title: Second Person Found Dead At US Festival Campground
description: A second death at an US Festival campground today further marred the three-day rock concert, which attracted larger crowds but also caused more arrests and medical problems than last year's event.

title: Seismic Signals in Siberia
description: The Energy Department said today that seismic signals, presumably from a Soviet underground nuclear explosion, occurred at 11:34 P.M. Sunday. The apparent nuclear test, recorded by sensors of the United States Atomic Energy Detection System, took place in the Semipalatinsk area of Siberia, a department spokesman said.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Rise in Food Costs

title: FEARS ON CRIMINAL JUSTICE SPUR CITIZENS TO MONITOR THE COURTS
description: Indications of widespread public distrust of the role of the courts in criminal justice have appeared in a variety of forms in California in the last year.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: R.R. Donnelley
description: The nation's largest commercial printer, the R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company, announced that it had begun a satellite communications printing service linking its facilities in New York and London, allowing materials to be printed almost simultaneously in those two cities. Donnelley said it believed the major users of the service would be financial institutions.

title: International Pact On Planes Studied
description: Three European companies and an American company agreed to consider jointly developing a military and civilian transport plane, the French company Aerospatiale announced at the Paris Air Show.

title: CBS-CHINA TV PACT ANNOUNCED
description: CBS Inc. will provide 64 hours of programming and advertising to Chinese television annually, the company announced yesterday. The arrangement represents the first regular scheduling in China of commercial American network television shows, according to John Eger, general manager of CBS Broadcast International.

title: A PLAN TO BURDEN THE SICK AND POOR ELDERLY
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS INCREASED 0.7% IN MAY
description: The prices that farmers get for raw products rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in May from April, the fifth consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WHAT'S the Celebrity Capital of the United States? Some say New York, some say Los Angeles. The debate took a new turn recently when the Greenland brothers - Drew of New York and Seth of Los Angeles - squared off in a contest of random celebrity sightings. It was agreed that whoever came up with the greater number of famous faces over a period of four months could claim the title for his hometown.

title: Montedison To Expand
description: Montedison S.p.A., it was learned yesterday, will announce it has made a major move to expand its health sciences operations in the United States through the formation of Erbamont N.V., which includes all of the health-sciences and pharmaceuticals operations of the Milan-based Montedison.

title: Flame Industries' Chapter 11 Filing
description: Flame Industries, which said it hoped to work out its cash flow problems, filed late last week for court protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: REEF ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: PRIDE AND POLITICS FAN KASHMIR'S SEPARATIST FIRES
description: Scratch a citizen of Kashmir, it is said here, and you will most likely find a nationalist who, if his deepest feelings were known, would prefer to see his Himalayan land become an independent country

title: Careers; Job Advice Helpful at High Level
description: THE Beam of Drake Beam Morin Inc., an outplacement concern, and the Heidrick of Heidrick & Struggles Inc., a management recruiting concern, have left to start new enterprises. Both of them offer a new twist.

title: SEAGULL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DOCUMENTARY ABOUT A BROTHEL
description: IN ''Soldier Girls,'' his documentary about female G.I.'s enduring the rigors of basic training, Nick Broomfield offered a relaxed, insightful view of his young subjects and their peculiar camaraderie. In ''Chicken Ranch,'' Mr. Broomfield, along with his co-director, Sandi Sissel, attempts something similar in a very different setting.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Official Menus Judicial Variety

title: YOGURT THE EASY WAY
description: FOR those who enjoy yogurt as much as I do, as a snack by itself or as an ingredient in cooking, preparing your own makes great sense. The better commercial yogurts - excluding those sugar-laden, gelatinous versions that taste like dessert custard - cost 60 to 80 cents for an eight-ounce container. For about the same price you can make five containers at home using a quart of milk. Besides being much fresher, the homemade product can be controlled to suit your preferences for texture and tartness.

title: Big Gain for Davis
description: That little investment Al Davis made in an Oakland shopping center back in 1974 may have raised eyebrows in the National Football League, but it has apparently been a bonanza for Davis. According to documents obtained by The Chicago Tribune, Davis, the managing general partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, invested just $5,000 in the project and has already reaped $1 million in tax savings.

title: ATARI EXPECTED TO SHIFT OFFICERS AND DIVISIONS
description: Atari Inc., the troubled video game subsidiary of Warner Communications, is expected to announce today a major restructuring of its management and the consolidation of its home video game and home computer divisions.

title: OAKWOOD PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings are restated to reOflect a share reclassification that took effect in April. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: SOUTHEASTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes realized gains on marketable securities of $43,000 for the quarter and $924,000 for the year. c-Net loss. d-Includes a realized gain of $19,318,000 on marketable securities. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect aggregate stock distributions declared through May 27, 1983.

title: Judge in Texas Blocks Brucellosis Quarantine
description: A Federal judge, unimpressed with the Agriculture Department's claim of an emergency in the state's brucellosis program, today blocked a quarantine on Texas cattle that was to scheduled to take effect at midnight.

title: Market Place; Copper Shares' Price Outlook
description: NEARLY two months ago, David Healy of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. accorded a ''neutral'' rating to copper issues. ''At least for now,'' the analyst told his clients, ''these stocks seem uninteresting, and we would suggest other areas for new investment.''

title: COURSE ON ANTI-COMMUNISM UPHELD FOR FLORIDA'S SCHOOLS
description: Amid cheers, jeers and scattered choruses of the national anthem, the Florida House killed an attempt today to do away with an ''Americanism versus Communism'' course that had been a required part of the state's high school curriculum for more than two decades.

title: JACK DEMPSEY, 87, IS DEAD; BOXING CHAMPION OF 1920'S
description: Jack Dempsey was one of the last of a dwindling company whose exploits distinguished the 1920's as ''the golden age of sports.'' His contemporaries were Babe Ruth in baseball, Red Grange and the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame in football, Bobby Jones and Walter Hagen in golf, Bill Tilden, Helen Wills Moody and Suzanne Lenglen in tennis, Johnny Weissmuller and Gertrude Ederle in swimming, Paavo Nurmi in track, Man o' War, the racehorse, and Earl Sande, the jockey. But none of the others enjoyed more lasting popularity than the man who ruled boxing between 1919 and 1926.

title: Vaulters' Circle
description: From the way that Abilene Christian University has prospered in the pole vault, one might guess that the Wildcats have discovered a secret.

title: Coast Woman Sentenced To 52 Years in 2 Slayings
description: Carol Bundy, the companion of the convicted slayer Douglas Clark, was sentenced to 52 years to life today for killing her former lover and a prostitute.

title: FED POLICY: ADMINISTRATION AIDE WARY
description: A senior Administration official said today that the Federal Reserve Board would have to tighten its monetary policy if the growth of the nation's basic money supply continued to exceed Fed targets in June.

title: Satmars Attack Lubavitcher Rabbi
description: A Lubavitcher rabbi was attacked by members of the Satmar, another Hasidic group, who cut off his beard, the police said yesterday. The leaderships of both groups expressed shock at the incident, which occurred last Friday in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The problem hasn't been monster storms, just a steady diet of regular ones.'' - Robert Dickson, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service. (D19:1.)

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Thrift Units Post Gains
description: Americans deposited $4.4 billion more than they withdrew from the nation's savings and loan associations last month, down a bit from March's total but still the thrift institutions' best April on record, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: THEATER: 2 EVENINGS OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: THE Ensemble Studio Theater's ''Marathon 1983'' hits its stride in the final two evenings of its four-part festival of new one-act plays. Series A and B were disappointing, but Series C and D deepen one's regard for the short theatrical form and for the artistry of the Ensemble Studio's team of playwrights, actors and directors.

title: NAKASONE SEES SHIFT IN INDUSTRY
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan said last night that advanced nations must look for future economic growth to the industries supporting an ''information society.''

title: Japanese Economy
description: Japan's gauge of future economic activity rose in March to the highest level in six months. The Government said that the gauge, which measures machinery orders, stock prices, overtime work hours and other indicators of economic activity, rose to 70 in March from 20 in February.

title: Spivey Falls Short
description: Jim Bunning, the former Phillies pitcher, won the Republican nomination for Governor of Kentucky last week, but Bill Spivey, the 7-foot former Kentucky basketball star, did not fare so well in his race for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor.

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 23.
Soldiers Sue the Army Over Marijuana Test
description: A lawsuit filed today on behalf of thousands of current and former soldiers charges that the Army's urinalysis testing to identify marijuana smokers was inaccurate and violated soldiers' constitutional rights.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX UP BY 1.1% IN APRIL
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.1 percent in April, the Commerce Department reported today. It was the 10th consecutive monthly increase and further evidence that the economic recovery continues to gain momentum.

title: STATE SUES U.S. OVER NO-FAULT INSURANCE DISCOUNTS FOR AGED
description: New York State moved yesterday to block a new Federal regulation that would eliminate no-fault insurance discounts received by 600,000 elderly and disabled automobile owners in the state who are covered by Medicare.

title: COURT AGREES TO A REVIEW OF AIR RULES
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to review a key aspect of the Environmental Protection Agency's so-called ''bubble'' policy for controlling new sources of air pollution.

title: PERU SENDS FORCES TO COMBAT REBELS
description: The Government, acknowledging that some guerrilla forces had moved from southern Peru to an area 110 miles northeast of here, said today that a contingent of paramilitary civil guards had been sent there to crush the uprising.

title: Staying Apart
description: A Minneapolis television station, KSTP, reported yesterday that the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League had finally found a new coach: Bill Mahoney, who had been with Detroit's farm system.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HALF A LOAF

title: SHAER SHOE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Missouri Supreme Court Rejects Execution Delay
description: The Missouri Supreme Court today rejected a motion to delay the execution of a convicted killer, Gerald Smith, who is scheduled to die in the gas chamber June 10.

title: Advertising; Children's Computer Magazine
description: eyed, cool-headed young people who dote on computers. Microkids: The Magazine for Kids Who Love Computers, will be introduced by Warner Software in October. The magazine, which will come out every two months, will be aimed at 10- to 16-year-olds, with a cover price of $2.95 and a printing of 150,000 copies.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: The Reagan Administration will begin talks with the Soviet Union in London Wednesday aimed at regaining grain sales to the Russians that were lost after the 1980 United States curtailment.

title: NEW LOOK AT LAMB: BEYOND THE STEW
description: THE American passion for red, full-flavored meat is a distinctly halfhearted affair: though we are smitten with beef, we hardly give lamb a tumble by comparison. Yet by any reasonable standard, that shouldn't be the case. Lamb is just as red and twice as flavorful; on sale, it can be less expensive, and in the kitchen, there are dozens of dishes that can be made with it.

title: Hudson's Bay Deficit
description: The Hudson's Bay Company, a diversified consumer products and natural resources concern and operator of Canada's largest department store chain, reported yesterday that it had nearly halved its deficit in the first fiscal quarter of 1983 ended April 23, to $36.6 million, from $69.9 million. Revenues, the company said, increased 1.7 percent, to $894 million, from $879 million.

title: SPRING STORMS TIED TO WARM CURRENT
description: The National Weather Service said yesterday that the current rainy spring, which has caused deaths, floods, mud slides and general coast-to-coast havoc may go down as one of the wettest on record for many parts of the country.

title: REAGAN PREDICTING BETTER SOVIET TIES IN WAKE OF PARLEY
description: President Reagan, assessing the results of the seven-nation summit conference that ended Monday night, predicted today that Soviet-American relations would improve because of the support he had received for his Administration's positions on arms control.

title: Uganda Rebels Reported To Ravage Refugee Camp
description: Guerrillas armed with guns, knives and spears attacked a refugee camp, killing about 110 people including women and children, the Roman Catholic-backed newspaper Munno reported today.

title: HUDSON'S BAY CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes a $14,485,000 gain on sale of Dome Resources shares. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: South Korea Detains 3 Prominent Activists
description: About 200 plainclothes policemen stormed a civil rights organization's headquarters in Seoul today and detained three leading South Korean dissidents, witnesses said.

title: GRUMMAN'S NAVY QUANDARY
description: When officials of the Grumman Corporation learned that the Navy was thinking of ordering a temporary halt in the production of F-14 Tomcat jet fighters and A-6 Intruder attack aircraft, they found some good in what looked at first like unadulterated bad news: The Navy plan carried a commitment to equip future F-14's with more powerful engines, something Grumman had long been advocating.

title: STEINBRENNER IS SUSPENDED FOR ONE WEEK
description: George Steinbrenner has been suspended for the second time in his 11 seasons as principal owner of the Yankees. This time, in an unprecedented move, the suspension was imposed yesterday by the American League president, Lee MacPhail, for Steinbrenner's repeated public harangues of league umpires.

title: Dome Gas Plant Delay
description: Public hearings on an application by Dome Petroleum Ltd. to build a natural gas liquefaction plant in northwestern British Columbia have been postponed from July 5 to Oct. 17.

title: Cosmos Fine Rijsbergen
description: Wim Rijsbergen, who stalked angrily off the field during the Cosmos' 4-1 victory over Fiorentina at Giants Stadium on Monday, was fined yesterday by General Manager Tom Werblin.

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 23.
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $700,000 for restructuring manufacturing operations.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 4 Killed in Florida Air Crash
description: Four Bahamian men were killed tonight when their twin-engine plane crashed near a busy highway just after it took off from Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport, the authorities said. The pilot and three passengers had arrived this morning from Freeport and were headed back when the crash occurred. The identities of the victims were not immediately released.

title: BLOCK DRUG CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $1,800,000 due to a change in the tax law of the United Kingdom, and a gain of $630,000 on the sale of a building.

title: QUANEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE eggplant, a vegetable that has an important place in my kitchen, is still somewhat neglected in everyday American cooking. I have been told that it was unknown in this country until it was introduced by Thomas Jefferson; even today it is more unfamiliar than it should be.

title: MOSCOW AND THE SUMMIT
description: What will the Russians make of the Williamsburg summit meeting of the industrial nations? In the economic field, they probably wish they had our problems rather than their own. In the strategic field, they are now confronted with a fundamental decision on the future of the arms race.

title: Jersey Delays Rise On Car Insurance
description: An automobile insurance rate increase scheduled to start Wednesday for all 3.8 million insured motorists in New Jersey was delayed indefinitely today by Insurance Commissioner Joseph F. Murphy.

title: Alzheimer's Disease Deaths Put at 120,000 a Year in U.S.
description: Alzheimer's disease, once ignored by doctors who mistook its symptoms for the natural process of aging, is the nation's fourth leading cause of death, scientists said today.

title: Surrender Delayed For Margiotta
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau Republican leader who was to begin a two-year prison term today for an insurance-kickback conviction, was given two more weeks of freedom when a Federal judge extended his surrender date to June 15.

title: INTEREST RATES PUSH HIGHER
description: Renewed calls for the Federal Reserve to tighten the reins on credit, plus concern over extensive Treasury borrowing, further depressed a weakened credit market yesterday, pushing prices down and yields up.

title: Foreclosure Cases at High
description: A record number of American homeowners were facing mortgage foreclosure on March 31, but new foreclosures that started in the first quarter were down for the first time in 18 months, a bankers' group reported today.

title: Dooley in Dissent
description: The athletic directors of the Southeastern Conference, meeting at Tarpon Springs, Fla., have proposed adding a 12th game to the football season, and will forward their recommendation to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which limits each college to 11 regular-season games on the mainland. But at least two S.E.C. coaches have registered a minority opinion.

title: CHINA QUAKE FORECASTS FOUND BASED ON GUESSES
description: When Chinese seismologists were apparently successful in predicting three earthquakes that occurred in 1975 and 1976, scientists around the world took hope. They thought they might learn from the Chinese how to make reliable earthquake predictions so that endangered cities could be evacuated.

title: MORRISON PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Joseph M. Majczek, 73; Conviction Led to Film
description: Joseph M. Majczek, whose wrongful 1933 murder conviction in the still-unsolved death of a policeman was the basis for the movie ''Call Northside 777,'' died Sunday after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STREET VENDOR PROBLEM
description: ALONG crowded downtown streets in cities all around the country, vendors in growing numbers are peddling everything from scents to souvlaki, from cassettes to grapes.

title: FUTURES: VOLUME UP, NET LAGS
description: Even though commodity futures trading volume is soaring, brokerage houses are finding that they are not benefiting as much as they would like from the increased activity.

title: WINE TALK
description: WHICH is more important to good wine - the soil in which the grapes are grown or the climate? You might think both but in Europe, certainly in France, the soil comes first. ''It is the soil, the soil and finally the soil,'' says Jean-Paul Gardere, the manager of Chateau Latour in Bordeaux.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Summer is travel time for most Americans, so here are some new products that are designed to make the going smoother, whether by plane, train or bus or in the family car.1. Diary for a Serious TripThe Smithsonian Travel Log is a wonderful gift for someone heading on a very special vacation - a first trip to Europe or Africa, for example. It is a wine-colored, leather-bound diary illustrated with color reproductions of art works on a travel theme that come from the collections of the Smithsonian Institution. The book measures 4 by 6 1/2 inches and includes sections for names and addresses and for keeping track of gifts and postcards. Published by Universe Books, it sells for $7.95 at the Travellers Bookstore, 22 West 52d Street.2. Two-in-One BagThe bag in a bag by Ventura consists of two bags in one: a 24-inch semistructured bag into which is strapped a 21-inch soft-sided bag, folded flat. On a long trip the smaller bag can come out for use on weekend excursions. On a shopping trip it can be used to hold purchases. The larger bag is equipped with wheels and a pull strap. Both are made of a weather-resistant fabric called TarpCloth that has been used only for such outdoor wares as sail covers, tents and awnings. The colors are wine, green, blue, brown and gray, all trimmed with pale gray leather. $225 at Altman's next week.3.

title: ADI APPLIANCES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: ILL-CHOSEN YARDSTICK OF U.S. MEDICAL CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: * Belgium is raising $50 million through a maximum seven-year, floating-rate Euronote, the lead manager, Sparebanken Oslo Akershus, said. The issue, which pays 1/4 percent over six-month London Eurodollar deposit rates, is essentially a private placement through Nordic banks.

title: TWIN RICHFIELD OILS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Colorado Bond Yields Range From 6%-10.1%
description: A $344.9 million refunding revenue bond issue for the Lower Colorado River Authority was tenatively priced yesterday by the First Boston Corporation, with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1984 to 10.1 percent in 2007.

title: BPI RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes losses on discontinued operations of $197,000 and $580,000, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, losses on a subsidiary, Brent plorations Inc., of $577,000 for the quarter and $1,269,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary gain of $5,946,000 on the conversion of debt to common shares, for the quarter and 6 months. c-The year-earlier results were not available because the company had restructured its accounting. The company was formerly Brent Petroleum Industries Ltd.

title: 'JEDI' EARNS $41 MILLION IN SIX DAYS
description: Breaking another box-office record almost every time its name flashes across the screen, ''The Return of the Jedi'' has earned $41,131,399 during its first six days. In less than a week, the third movie in George Lucas's ''Star Wars'' saga has grossed nearly $10 million more than its $32.5 million cost.

title: Steel Output Down 4.1%
description: Steel production fell 4.1 percent last week, to 1.63 million tons, from 1.7 million tons a week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute says. It was 56.3 percent of capacity, down from 58.7 percent. So far this year, output totaled 32.39 million tons, off 7.5 percent from 34.99 million tons.

title: Accounts
description: * McGraw-Hill Continuing Education Center of Washington, D.C., to Erhlich-Manes & Associates.

title: Redbird Fever
description: Last year, the Louisville Redbirds of the American Association set a minor league attendance record of 868,414 for 64 dates. This season the Redbirds' attendance continues to grow.

title: EXCEL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Miles Shifts Vitamins To Tatham-Laird
description: Miles Laboratories Inc., Elkhart, Ind., announced yesterday that it had shifted all of its adult vitamin advertising from J. Walter Thompson/ U.S.A., New York, to Tatham-Laird & Kudner, Chicago.

title: Woman Kills Former Husband And Then Herself on 60th St.
description: A Staten Island man was shot to death outside a parking garage on the upper East Side last night by his former wife who then killed herself, the police reported.

title: So Close To Heaven; FIRST OFFERING 281 GARTH ROAD ... IN THE HEART OF THE GOOD LIFE ...  *Short walk to Scarsdale - From a real estate ad in The New York Times
description: The air is languorous in the spring at 281 Garth Road and in the fall it has a crisp tang and tastes faintly of fresh cider and hickory smoke. It is the air of the good life, in whose heart you will reside, and Scarsdale is only a short walk away.

title: IRT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Arkansas School Aid Plan Is Held Unconstitutional
description: The Arkansas Supreme Court ruled today that the state's method of distributing state aid to public schools was unconstitutional because it violated the equal protection requirement.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

title: JACK NELSON, HEAD OF A CLEARINGHOUSE FOR STOCK EXCHANGES
description: Jack Nelson, president and director of the National Securities Clearing Corporation in Manhattan, died of cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 49 years old.

title: 3 MORE OFFICERS FACING CHARGES IN STATE INQUIRY
description: Three present and two former police officers in the 10th Precinct in Manhattan have been indicted by a special state grand jury investigating allegations of police corruption.

title: Cernan Quits as Head Of Air One, New Carrier
description: Eugene A. Cernan, the former astronaut, has resigned as chairman of the board of Air One, a new airline that began flying out of St. Louis at the beginning of April and caters mostly to business travelers.

title: GEODYNE RESOURCES INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
Q&A
description: Q. I am on a salt-free diet and am bothered by recipes using eggplant that call for salting before cooking. Do you find this essential?

title: New Party in Turkey Is Quickly Abolished
description: The ruling military authorities closed down a new political party today and ordered 14 politicians, including a former Prime Minister, Suleyman Demirel, to be placed in preventive custody under a martial law commander in northwest Turkey.

title: OEA INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 100 percent stock dividend distributed Dec. 3.

title: MANILA TO GET $900 MILLION IN ACCORD ON BASES
description: A newly negotiated accord governing the use of American bases in the Philippines for the next five years includes a compensation package of $900 million in aid to the Philippines, American officials said today. The agreement, which is to be signed at the presidential palace here on Wednesday, also calls for closer consultations on base operations and weapons levels.

title: PLANE CARRYING 86 NEARLY LOST FUEL
description: The crew of a Republic Airlines DC-9 jet radioed that they had ''zero fuel'' left but made a safe emergency landing Saturday at Luke Air Force Base 22 miles northwest of Phoenix, the flight's destination, Government investigators said.

title: BONN BALKS AT WEINBERGER'S ARMS PLANS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, on a weeklong visit to Western Europe, is encountering unusually stiff resistance to increased military spending from allied governments strapped by recession and high unemployment.

title: REAGAN POWER TO CHANGE RIGHTS PANEL QUESTIONED
description: Lawyers in and out of the Government said today that President Reagan might lack the legal authority to dismiss members of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, as he is trying to do.

title: Freddie Mac Issue Record $1 Billion
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation yesterday announced a $1 billion issue of collateralized mortgage obligations that would be the largest mortgage-related public debt issue to come to market in the United States.

title: HIGH COURT BARS REVIEW OF A CASE ON BLACK JURORS
description: The United States Supreme Court refused today to decide whether a black defendant in a robbery case was denied a fair trial by an all-white jury in Brooklyn after the prosecutor used peremptory challenges to remove all seven blacks from the group of prospective jurors.

title: Turner Is Cleared In Agent's Suit
description: A Federal jury deliberated only an hour today before ruling in favor of Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Braves, in a defamation suit brought by Bucky Woy, a sports agent.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: There is a kind of urban road race that takes place on the streets of Manhattan every day. It is called getting from here to there. There are rules, but many of the competitors do not pay any attention to them. People in automobiles run red lights and people on bicycles run red lights and people on foot quite literally run red lights. No one wins. They just start over again each day, if they are lucky.

title: KOSHER FLOUR SALES KEEP OLD MILL ALIVE
description: GEORGE SMITH, who hails from a long line of German Protestant farming folk, looks as natural on a tractor as a toadstool does on a tree stump. He doesn't look at all like an expert on Orthodox Jewish dietary law.

title: Townsend M. McAlpin Dies; Retired Partner of Law Firm
description: Townsend Martin McAlpin, a former partner of the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord, died of a stroke Monday in a Southampton, L.I., nursing home. He was 79 years old and had lived in Eastport, L.I.

title: Canadair Lawsuit Names Avco Corp.
description: Canadair Ltd. of Montreal has filed a $109.6 million lawsuit against the Avco Corporation, the United States manufacturer that supplies engines for its Challenger 600 business jets, charging that the power plants failed to meet performance specifications.

title: WASHINGTON POWER MISSES A PAYMENT
description: As expected, the Washington Public Power Supply System edged closer to default today on $2.25 billion in bonds floated to construct two nuclear reactors when it missed a monthly payment. Construction of the plants has been halted because the need for power was overestimated and the plants were too expensive to build.

title: HARLEM BROWNSTONE RENOVATION: NO STATE-ERECTED
description: HURDLESTo the Editor:

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF SOTHEBY'S - AS IS
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAL FLEET INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: COMTECH TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
New Move Is Made To Keep the Jets
description: In the latest move to try to keep the Jets from leaving New York and moving to Giants Stadium when their lease is up after this season, the Mets have offered to allow them to play exhibition games at Shea Stadium.

title: JARUZELSKI SYAS POLISH PARTY IS STRONGER THAN A YEAR AGO
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski defended his stewardship of Poland's Communist Party today against criticism from within his ranks and from Moscow.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Sports section Sunday about Larry Holmes gave incorrect dates for ABC's telecasts of the two recent heavyweight title fights. The Holmes-Tim Witherspoon fight will be shown Saturday and the Michael Dokes-Mike Weaver fight on June 11.

title: COMTERM INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Reggie Jackson, though slumping this year, should be pumped up to face his old teammate Ron Guidry, against whom he launched a couple of huge homers last season.

title: FULFILLING DREAMS
description: Hav e you thought about living out your dreams? I have - and some months ago I actually lived one out, a dream that had haunted me for almost two decades. My dream had to do with music, specifically, the ''Resurrection Symphony'' by Gustav Mahler.

title: Falwell Group Reports Role in Telethon Calls
description: Moral Majority sent letters to 100,000 supporters last week ''suggesting'' that they call Democratic Telethon officials in support of President Reagan, a spokesman for the group said today.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-After a tax credit of $280,000. c-Net income includes a tax credit of $187,000.

title: Coaching Job for Pardee
description: Jack Pardee, a former head coach of the Chicago Bears and the Washington Redskins, yesterday signed a five-year contract as coach of the Houston Gamblers, the newest expansion franchise that will play next year in the United States Football League. Pardee, who spent 15 years as a linebacker for the Los Angeles Rams and the Redskins before turning to coaching in 1973, has been working for an oil service company in Midland, Tex., since leaving his last coaching position, as an assistant with the San Diego Chargers. In his five years as a head coach in the National Football League, he compiled a 44-46 record.

title: OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GOLDALE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. c-Net loss after a loss of $2,852,834 from discontinued operations.

title: BOARD ON SAFETY IN PUBLIC TRANSIT VOTED IN ALBANY
description: The Assembly passed a bill today establishing a Public Transportation Safety Board to monitor safety plans and investigate accidents on public transportation systems. The bill, passed last week by the State Senate, now goes to Governor Cuomo.

title: KEY FAULKNER TALE IS PUBLISHED AT LAST
description: Through a combination of luck and persistence, a short story written in longhand by William Faulkner in 1926 that foreshadowed some of his greatest work has finally been deciphered and will appear in print for the first time June 9. Experts consider the story a key to the most important books written by the then-struggling future Nobel laureate in literature.

title: BEE WASTE IS SUSPECTED AS 'YELLOW RAIN' SOURCE
description: One of the nation's leading experts on chemical and biological warfare presented evidence today that the ''yellow rain,'' a substance that the United States Government contends is being sprayed as a toxic weapon by Communist planes in Southeast Asia, may be little more than bee excrement.

title: 85 Are reported Killed In Afghan Rebel Attacks
description: Afghan rebels, pounded for weeks by a Soviet and Afghan Government military offensive, hit back last week, killing about 85 soldiers in two major attacks, a Western diplomat said today.

title: WATER SUPPLY FOR NEW YORK IS AT CAPACITY
description: The New York City reservoir system is at capacity today, and this is of more than passing interest to officials who monitor the city's water supply.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING DARLINGTON INTERNATIONAL RACEWAY - Named Walter (Red) Tyler Jr. as president. BASEBALL

title: U.N. COUNCIL EMPOWERS PEREZ DE CUELLAR TO SEEK NAMIBIA'S FREEDOM
description: The Security Council called unanimously on Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today to help win independence for South-West Africa from South Africa.

title: Novelist Is Injured In L.I. Auto Crash
description: John Knowles, the novelist, was critically injured Sunday in a two-car accident, the police said. Mr. Knowles, 56 years old, whose best-known book is ''A Separate Peace,'' was charged with driving while intoxicated, according to the Southampton Police Chief, Conrad Teller.

title: UNIVERSAL COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CONNORS AND LENDL ARE UPSET
description: Even here in his home country, Christophe Roger-Vasselin is known hardly at all. If he ever doubted that, today was proof as the fans at Roland Garros Stadium could not figure out his first name when the time came to urge him on in his quarterfinal match against Jimmy Connors.

title: Bulls Want Loughery
description: Kevin Loughery, the coach of the Atlanta Hawks in the National Basketball Association, has been offered the job of coaching the Chicago Bulls, but has not made up his mind whether to accept, according to the Bulls' general manager, Rod Thorn. ''We'd like to have him,'' said Thorn, who has permission from the Hawks to talk to Loughery, and did so last week.

title: Make Legal Services Legal
description: President Reagan persists in his malign neglect of legal services for the poor. He ignores his duty, in law, to nominate 11 directors for the Legal Services Corporation, which manages poverty law projects across the country. And for the third year in a row, he has asked Congress to stop funding the corporation. The President is entitled to his personal view of the law, but he also has an obligation to execute it faithfully.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: IN developing countries, where sanitation and personal hygiene often leave something to be desired, diarrhea is the leading cause of childhood death and stunted development and a frequent hazard to foreign travelers. Even in the United States and other advanced countries diarrhea is a significant cause of illness, among Americans second only to respiratory infections.

title: TV: DIVORCE AND CHILDREN IN THE MIDDLE
description: ''DIVORCE: KIDS IN THE MIDDLE'' is something like an animated manual, a how-to guide to a successful divorce for people who have children. It is also a kind of docudrama - real parents, real children, real life, so to speak, caught live by a camera. It will be seen on WNEW-TV, Channel 5, at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: The year-ago figures were restated to correct method of applying overhead to inventory and accounting for progress billings.

title: Benefit Rules Changed For Black Lung Illness
description: The Labor Department issued new regulations today that tightened eligibility for monthly Federal black lung benefits to coal miners and their survivors.

title: AGAIN, THE PERONIST ALLIANCE
description: June 4, 1943. The Peronist phase in Argentina begins. Army troops advance on Buenos Aires from their barracks 30 miles outside of the city, occupy the presidential palace, the Casa Rosada, and proclaim that they will save the country from decadent, corrupt democracy. Before long, a virile-looking colonel with an attractive smile, Juan Domingo Peron, establishes a new ideology in Argentina - a country with an immigrant, progressive working class and a conservative bourgeoisie captivated by European culture. According to the young colonel, an alliance of the army and working class is the only way to save Argentina from total collapse. The army will help organize new labor unions, and the workers, until then politically powerless, will occupy a place of their

title: C.I.A. DIRECTOR TRADED HEAVILY IN STOCKS IN 1982
description: William J. Casey, who has access to the government's most secret economic data as director of the Central Intelligence Agency, traded heavily in the stock market last year, buying and selling several million dollars' worth of stocks and other securities, according to his financial disclosure form, released today.

title: Rise in Value of Mark
description: The value of the West German mark has risen against virtually all major world currencies except the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc since the end of 1972, according to figures released today by the Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank. The bank said its measure of the value of the mark as of May 13 stood at 173.9 against currencies of the European Monetary System and 164.5 against currencies of 23 trading partners. The mark stood at 100 at the end of 1972.

title: LIFE
description: DENNIS JOYCE is a 30-year-old Con Edison employee whose work consists mainly of reading meters and turning them off and on. ''There is no challenge,'' he says of his job. ''It is mundane.''

title: 4 Youths Acquitted In Sexual Assault
description: A Superior Court judge today acquitted four Passaic youths of charges of juvenile delinquency stemming from a reported sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl last month.

title: Back to Earth From Williamsburg
description: You might think that when seven leaders of seven sovereign countries claim to have reached accord on ten contentious issues in one weekend they have found the long-lost key to international collaboration. But they reached no such thing.

title: HEAVYWEIGHT CHAMPION IN 1920'S
description: Jack Dempsey, who held the heavyweight boxing title from 1919 to 1926 and then, during his long retirement, set a standard of dignity rarely equaled by a former champion, died yesterday. He was 87 years old and had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: People
description: * Neal B. Davis and Edmond C. Froelich have been elected executive vice presidents of Griswold Inc., Cleveland.

title: DOW DROPS BY 16.16, TO 1,199.98
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday because of spreading concern that interest rates may soon move higher. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 16.16 points, to 1,199.98, after being down only 5 points at noon. The decline was broad, with stocks that fell on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbering those that rose by an almost 3-to-1 ratio. The worst performers were some of the technology, blue-chip and precious metals issues. Official's Comment a Factor

title: JUSTICES REFUSE TO HEAR APPEALS IN 7 ABSCAM CASES
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear the appeals of four former members of the House of Representatives and three other men who were convicted after the Justice Department's Abscam investigation.

title: Caribbean Left-Wing Leader Received Coolly in; Washington
description: The leftist leader of the Caribbean island of Grenada came to Washington today to seek a ''dialogue'' with the Reagan Administration and ''personally clear up the misconceptions that exist'' with the United States.

title: CREDIBILITY OF A KEY WITNESS ASSAILED AT TRIAL ON LAB TESTS
description: Under cross-examination today in the trial of four Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories officials, a laboratory technician said that the Government's key witness against the officials, Philip Smith, had told him to lie in recording the hours worked on research and the number of animals in the studies.

title: A SURPRISING INTERPRETATION ON REHABILITATION CREDITS
description: Developers have been a bit slow in catching on, but a little-known Internal Revenue Service interpretation that affects part of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 may permit them to get a tax credit for rehabilitating an old building even if they tear down the exterior walls and keep just the framework. This can in no sense be called historic preservation, as those words are usually understood, but it is a way to retain the economic usefulness of older structures in downtown areas.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Official Menus New Leaf on Pages

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
GAYLORDS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
147 Motorists Held As Being Drunk
description: A total of 147 motorists were arrested between 6 P.M. Friday and midnight Monday and charged with driving while intoxicated or impaired by alcohol, city officials said yesterday.

title: Southland Tax Inquiry
description: John M. Fedders, enforcement chief for the Securities and Exchange Commission, today offered to explain publicly his involvement with the Southland Corporation.

title: CORRECTION
description: A society-page headline on Sunday incorrectly identified the bridegroom of Cynthia Clarke Brown. He was Douglas Edward Seiler.

title: IN QUEENS, A MEDLEY OF LATIN FLAVORS
description: IT is 6 o'clock on a balmy evening, and Jackson Heights is jumping. All along Roosevelt Avenue, in the shadow of the elevated train tracks, the end of another school and workday in Queens is being celebrated with characteristic Latin elan. Salsa music seems to cascade from every other storefront, and a half-dozen strutting teenagers, infected by the beat as they pass by, break into a whirl of loose-limbed dancing. A moment later, they calmly resume their stroll toward the next sidewalk ballroom.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN COURT EASES BLACK RESIDENCY RULES
description: South Africa's highest court has ruled that black migrant workers who have held jobs for 10 consecutive years in areas legally deemed to be white cannot be prevented from living there permanently in separate black townships if they choose to do so.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK, NATOMAS PLAN TO MERGE
description: Ending eight days of suspense, the Diamond Shamrock Corporation of Dallas and the Natomas Company of San Francisco announced yesterday that the two big energy companies would merge.

title: BRIEFING
description: Ambassador Stone's Trip

title: RIGHTS OF A SPOUSE CURBED IN TAX SALE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, by 5 to 4, that a Federal judge may order the sale of a married couple's home to satisfy one spouse's unpaid Federal tax obligation, even if the other spouse owed no taxes and had a ''homestead'' right under state law to remain in the house for life.

title: FOSTER CARE REQUIRES MORE OF THE FAMILY COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt EXILED IN PARADISE. German Refugee Artists and Intellectuals in America from the 1930's to the Present. By An- thony Heilbut. 506 pages. Viking. $20.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILIATES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: Top 3 Seeded Teams Gain Quarterfinals in Reisinger
description: The quarterfinals of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship began last night at the Beverly East Club, Lexington Avenue and 50th Street, and will continue tonight.

title: 2 Workmen Burned in a Blast At a Municipal Landfill on L.I.
description: Two workmen were severely burned yesterday morning when an explosion, perhaps sparked by a cigarette, erupted at the Town of Babylon landfill in Suffolk County.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $523,000 for the quarter and $1,430,000 for the year.

title: Southland Plans Dallas Complex
description: The Southland Corporation said it planned to build a $400 million, 3.5-million-square-foot office complex near downtown Dallas. The complex will have two 50-story towers in a 21-acre quadrangle. Construction is to begin next year and occupancy is expected in 1986 and 1987.

title: PEPSICO SCRUTINIZED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has been investigating top officials of Pepsico Inc. since February for possible fraud, according to court documents.

title: Syria Sponsoring Talks On Rift Within P.L.O.
description: Syria has started talks to try to prevent dissent within Yasir Arafat's mainstream Fatah group from tearing apart the Palestine Liberation Organization, Palestinian officials said today.

title: Article 204791 -- No Title
description: A Queens man who spent 24 years in New York prisons for a murder state officials have since conceded he did not commit was awarded $1 million in compensation yesterday by the State Court of Claims.

title: Burger King Selects 3 To Head New Divisions
description: The Burger King Corporation, which has been revamping its management structure, named three executives yesterday to head new divisions.

title: 4,000 Sierra Leone Refugees Reportedly Cross Into Liberia
description: Nearly 4,000 refugees from Sierra Leone have fled to Liberia to escape political violence in the last 11 days, Government officials said.

title: SENIORS IN HIGH SCHOOL FACE TOUGH JOB LESSON
description: Max Heinz does not know what he wants to do when he grows up. And he is not in any great hurry to find out, at least not yet. ''I may buy a motorcycle and go out to California to visit my cousins,'' the 16-year-old high school senior said the other day, as he sat in his guidance counselor's office at Grover Cleveland High School in Queens and pondered his immediate future.

title: VANDALIZED SCHOOL'S ALARM EXAMINED
description: The security system at a Brooklyn elementary school that was vandalized over the Memorial Day weekend may have malfunctioned, school officials said yesterday.

title: A.O. Smith Corp.
description: Half of the 200 people who were hired by a factory after lining up in subzero January temperatures with thousands of other applicants have quit their jobs, company officials said. Some job seekers had driven more than 300 miles after the A.O. Smith Corporation, a manufacturer of auto frames, placed a routine advertisement of openings for 200 welders and press operators.

title: 5 IN ROW FOR YANKS
description: Perhaps it is no coincidence that Ken Griffey's sudden success with runners in scoring position matches the Yankees' success in their last five games.

title: FEDERATED DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Restraint and Musing By the Mayor

title: Military Analysis
description: American and other Western intelligence analysts have concluded that the most dangerous element in any possible military confrontation between Syrian and Israeli forces in Lebanon is what they see as the Palestine Liberation Organization's desire to prove to itself and to Israel that it must be recognized as a key player in the Middle East. Such an effort by the P.L.O. is believed to be behind its increasing attacks on Israeli patrols and the firing of two mortar shells at United States Marine positions near Beirut International Airport on Monday.

title: COMPUSHOPS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss. The company went public on May 12.

title: U.S. HELD LIABLE IN BEATING OF 'FREEDOM RIDER' IN 1961
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Government was liable for failing to prevent a 1961 attack on civil rights workers in Birmingham, Ala., that the Federal Bureau of Investigation knew was going to take place.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 1, 1983
description: International The President assessed the results of the weekend summit conference of major industrial democracies in an interview with eight correspondents in Williamsburg, Va. Mr. Reagan predicted that American-Soviet relations would improve because of the support he received from the six other Government leaders for his arms control policies and the deployment of American missiles in Europe this year. (Page A1, Column 6.) Increased military spending is strongly opposed by West European governments pressed by recession. At a news conference with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, Manfred Worner, the West German Defense Minister, said that ''close financial limits'' would prevent Bonn from contributing financially for relocating American troops in West Germany or improving NATO's conventional weapons. (A3:4-6.)

title: PLAYERS QUERY KUHN ON SECURITY MOVE
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association, concerned over a recent decision by the commissioner's office to intensify monitoring of players' activities off the field, has asked Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for more information on why the decision was made.

title: Torres May Head State Commission
description: Jose Torres, the former light-heavyweight boxing champion, is considered the front-runner to replace Jack Prenderville as the chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. of Greenwich, Conn., said it had agreed in principle to acquire Voyager Group Inc. for $45 million in cash.

title: Southwestern Bell
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Southwestern Bell subsidiary said it would soon file with the Texas Public Utility Commission for a rate increase that could be more than $1 billion.

title: C.I.A. REPORTED BLOCKED IN PLOT ON SURINAMESE
description: The Reagan Administration dropped a plan this year to overthrow the Government of Suriname, the former Dutch colony in South America, after Congressional committees objected, Administration officials said today.

title: WILSON BENCHED
description: The tailspin deepened for the Mets tonight when Bill Laskey pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 2-1 victory over them and won his seventh straight game.

title: PROPERTY INVESTORS OF COLORADO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes extraordinary items of $251,000 and $57,000. c-Net loss.

title: DANCE: THARP PREMIERE GIVEN BY BALLET THEATER
description: AT American Ballet Theater's performance on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, the New York premiere of Twyla Tharp's ''Once Upon a Time'' came immediately after Jiri Kylian's ''Torso,'' and that scheduling of works had the unexpected effect of making ''Once Upon a Time'' seem a happy version of ''Torso.''

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ANADITE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 20.
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $596,000 from the sale of the company's minority equity interest in an Italian joint venture. c-Net income.

title: LEISURE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income after an extraordinary gain on exchange of debentures of $234,000, or 6 cents a share. The latest year loss includes an additional charge to operations resulting from the company's early compliance with provisions of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 67.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Foreign exchange losses of $7.5 million are included in the latest quarter results compared to $14.2 million in the year-ago period.

title: SALES OF NEW HOMES OFF 4%
description: Sales of new single-family houses in April fell 4 percent from the month before, the Government reported today, but the rate was still substantially higher than last year.

title: COCAINE HOTLINE DRAWS A THOUSAND CALLS A DAY
description: William Lindeman, one of eight counselors working on the Cocaine Hot Line at the drug-abuse unit in Fair Oaks Psychiatric Hospital, told a caller that he had to make his wife realize she was addicted to cocaine and that it was destroying their marriage.

title: McCaffery & Ratner
description: Three new accounts are being reported by McCaffery & Ratner, the biggest of which is a mystery account with a $5 million opening budget that is identified only as a fragrance and cosmetics line. The others are Newcomb Securities, for a new financial service, and Pierre Cardin's men's shirts and sportswear collection, with about $1.5 million in billings, previously served by Warsaw Communications.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company announced the sale today of nearly $1 billion worth of planes, including 10 to Singapore Airlines, which has been the object of an intense sales campaign between the Seattle-based aerospace giant and Airbus Industrie, an European consortium.

title: The U.N. Today; June 1, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. on question of Namibia. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: No Headline
description: Topics Official Menus American Cuisine

title: It's an Outrage
description: What's an editorial page for if not to denounce the insufferable? It might even do some good; you never know who reads the paper. And the most insufferable subject today is plainly the rain.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Even Before the Race, The Race Is On

title: MARKS & SPENCER CANADA INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes foreclosure costs of $11,000.

title: TV: DABNEY COLEMAN STARS IN SERIES
description: DABNEY COLEMAN is the kind of gifted actor who always seems to be teetering on the verge of becoming a star. On television, he was hilariously unforgettable as the earnest Merle Jeeter in ''Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman.'' In the movies, he stole most of ''9 to 5'' right out from beneath the dynamite presences of Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton. More recently, he made distinctive contributions to ''On Golden Pond'' and ''Tootsie.'' He is clearly, as they say in the business, a talent.

title: Estimate on Saudi Oil
description: John Kelberer, chairman of the Arabian American Oil Company, estimated Saudi Arabian recoverable reserves as being in excess of 165 billion barrels, using present oil exploitation techniques.

title: LIVING OVER THE STORE
description: ''IT'S changed my life,'' said Mary Emmerling, who waited two years for a rental apartment to become available in the same building as her shop, the American Country Store on Lexington Avenue near 70th Street. ''Not only do I save an hour a day in commuting time, but if I need an extra chair for the apartment, I simply run downstairs and borrow one from the store.''

title: FORUM GROUP INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $267,403 from discontinued operations. c-Includes a gain of $20,007 from discontinued operations.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Borden Inc. has elected R.J. Ventres an executive vice president and also president of its chemical division.

title: Topics; Literature and Life; Gentleman Mauler
description: It would have taken a collaboration between John Dos Passos and Red Smith to dream up the life of William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey. It began like that of the uprooted Americans who wander through the glorious scenery and the corrupt capitalism of Dos Passos' ''U.S.A.'' Then this itinerant farmhand, shipyard worker and barroom brawler suddenly became wealthy by virtue of the speed of his right hand.

title: EARLY CHINA TALKS PROPOSED BY NIXON
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon, asserting that Chinese leaders had ''misunderstood and misjudged'' President Reagan's views on the Taiwan issue, called today for an early meeting between Mr. Reagan and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China to create better trust between Peking and Washington.

title: Butcher Bank Studied For Reported Shredding
description: Federal authorities are investigating allegations that commercial loan documents were shredded at the City and County Bank of Knox County shortly before regulators closed and sold the bank last week, Government officials said today.

title: DISTRIBUCO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income The year-ago quarter and year share earnings reflect a 20 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 27, 1982.

title: Michigan Issue To Yield 7.75%
description: Blyth Eastman Paine Webber tentatively priced a $55 million Michigan higher education student loan revenue bond issue at par to yield 7.75 percent.

title: Hunter Concert Offers Music by Louise Talma
description: The composer Louise Talma has, in the course of her career, been honored with two Guggenheim Fellowships, a Fulbright Grant, assorted smaller prizes and election to the American Academey and Institute of Arts and Letters. The 76-year-old composer also received an honorary doctorate from Hunter College on Wednesday, and on Tuesday night, the school, where she has taught for more than 50 years, presented a concert of her music in its Playhouse.

title: BABIES GET IN TOUCH WITH NATURE
description: BARBARA ZIMMERMAN paused only briefly under the swaying branch of the European beech, but the pause was long enough. Before she could push by, Aaron, her 8 1/2-month-old son, had reached up from his stroller, snatched off a leaf, looked at it briefly and popped it into his mouth.

title: PUNITIVE DAMAGES RULED OUT IN CBS CASE
description: An investigator for the Los Angeles District Attorney's office testified today that he was aware of fraudulent medical reports being issued by the office of the doctor who is suing Dan Rather, CBS, and two production executives for slander because of a ''60 Minutes'' broadcast which linked him to an insurance-fraud ring.

title: BOOK PORTRAYS KISSINGER AS A DOUBLE-DEALER IN '68
description: Henry A. Kissinger is described in a new book as so eager to have a high office in Government in the late 1960's that he offered confidential advice to both the Democrats and the Republicans in the 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: GOOD NEIGHBORS NEED 'BUSY' LAMPPOSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Reputed Louisiana Chief Of Mafia Taken to Jail
description: The reputed Mafia boss Carlos Marcello was taken to a prison hospital in Missouri today, one day after a Federal appeals court rejected a bid to overturn his 1981 racketeering conspiracy conviction.

title: REAGAN IN TRIBUTE TO DEMPSEY
description: The coffin was draped in an American flag and surrounded by flowers. It rested in a spotlighted corner of the second-floor chapel at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home on Madison Avenue and 81st Street, and there were not many visitors when the wake began yesterday for the great American hero.

title: MISGUIDED CAMPAIGN FOR A MARGIOTTA PARDON
description: To the Editor:

title: New Balconies Fall And Injure Worker
description: Portions of balconies on the top three floors of a CBS News building under construction on 56th Street near 10th Avenue collapsed yesterday, injuring a construction worker.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Hale Irwin and David Graham, both former winners of the United States Open, have joined the field for the Westchester Classic tournament next week. ... Frank Hannigan, director of special projects for the United States Golf Association, has been named senior executive director of the group, succeeding Harry W. Easterly, who retired earlier this year. ... Randy Lee Moore, 22, the son of the former world light heavyweight boxing champion Archie Moore, has signed a free-agent contract with the Los Angeles Rams. Moore, a 6-foot, 173-pound wide receiver, caught 28 passes for 512 yards and four touchdowns at Lincoln University in Jefferson City, Mo., last fall.

title: Trucker Dies as Gunman Blasts a Police Station
description: A gunman raked the the police station here with fire from a semiautomatic rifle today, killing a truck driver who had stopped to ask directions, the police said.

title: DOW ANNOUNCES PROGRAM TO ALLAY FEAR ON DIOXIN
description: The Dow Chemical Company today announced a research and public relations campaign to allay concern about dioxin contamination here.

title: HERS
description: year-old who has always been an A student in every subject from algebra to English, recently informed her parents that she intended to drop physics and calculus in her senior year of high school and replace them with a drama seminar and a work-study program. She expects to major in art or history in college, she explained, and ''any more science or math will just be a waste of my time.''

title: ANDREA RIZZOLI, 69, PUBLISHER
description: Andrea Rizzoli, son of the founder of the Rizzoli publishing empire in Italy, died in a Nice hospital of heart failure Tuesday after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard REPRESENTATIONS OF REVOLUTION (1789-1820). By Ronald Paulson. Illus- trated. 398 pages. Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: DOLE SEEKS TO BAR BIG TAX RISES
description: Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas and chairman of the Finance Committee, threatened today to bottle up revenue legislation this year if the House-Senate conferees on the Congressional budget resolution called for ''huge tax increases'' and ''little or no spending reduction.''

title: Dome Extension
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had reached agreements for extending the schedules for principal repayments under various loan agreements.

title: DR. AARON STEIN
description: Dr. Aaron Stein, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and an attending psychiatrist at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
OPERAS: TRUE TO ORIGINAL FORM OR REINTERPRETED?
description: WHEN Terence A. McEwen, the new general director of the San Francisco Opera, loudly announced that he would start his Summer Festival 1983 with a ''Romantic'' staging of ''Das Rheingold'' and ''Die Walkure,'' some traditionalists started to drool. An entire generation, after all, has grown up not on interpreted Wagner but rather on reinterpreted Wagner, in which the composer's ideas are changed at the whim of a director who thinks he has a special message to convey. Wagner's original Romantic stagings have long been discarded by the major opera houses of the world.

title: REMOVING STAINS FROM FURNITURE
description: On a scale ranging from 1 to 10 in rating the degree of difficulty, removing dark or black stains from furniture ranks about 9. Sometimes removing such stains is impossible, but there is no reason why an attempt should not be made, particularly if the affected piece is ordinary but useful. Really valuable furniture should be sent to a professional.

title: TRAVELODGE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Travelodge International Inc. is part of Trusthouse Forte PLC of London.

title: Bonn Steel Quotas
description: The West German steel industry wants its share of steel output raised considerably when the European Economic Community sets new quotas this month, a senior industry official said today. Ruprecht Vondran, executive director of the powerful West German Iron and Steel Association, said there were strong indications that the Bonn Government would back this demand.

title: The Legendary Champion
description: U p in the ring at Madison Square Garden before the first Ali-Frazier fight, in 1971, some famous boxers, past and present, were being introduced. One by one, each took a bow, basking in the applause. Strangely, the familiar face in the front row had been overlooked by the ring announcer, but not by the people there who were now demanding that he be recognized.

title: People
description: * Paul Brickman joining Brand Advertising, Chicago, as executive vice president.

title: 15th-Century Fresco May Visit Met Museum
description: The Madonna del Parto, a priceless 15th-century fresco, will be shipped for three months to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art - if experts decide there is no risk involved.

title: Quilts Old and New
description: Contemporary Quilts: An exhibition of contemporary quilts, ranging from an 18-inch square to an 8-foot square, opens Monday in the Steuben Hall Gallery at Pratt Institute, 379 DeKalb Avenue, Brooklyn, 212-636-3486. Hours: 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Monday through Friday. Through July 2; free.

title: VIETNAM WAR LESSON FIT FOR THE SALVADOR SCENE
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan at Helm
description: ''When I raced powerboats before, it had no true purpose,'' the oldest son of President Reagan said yesterday. ''Now I'm raising funds for worthwhile causes.''

title: MISLEADING CLAIMS OF ENERGY DEVICES
description: A MANUFACTURER says that a ''solar furnace'' will provide 45 to 90 percent of a home's heat. The maker of plastic storm windows contends that his product will reduce a home's heat loss by more than 98 percent. The producer of a valve for car engines says it will save consumers $200 a year in gasoline costs.

title: SALT LAKE CITY SHOPPERS COPING WITH A NEW RIVER DOWNTOWN
description: More than a century ago, Mormon settlers, led by their prophet Brigham Young, made plans for a city here, with fresh water from the nearby mountains and lowlands suitable for farming.
