Mindful of the long and clumsy ox-drawn wagons necessary to downtown commerce, Prophet Young took it upon himself to design streets wide enough for successful maneuvering.

title: Alabama Wins Challenge To Use of Electric Chair
description: Two Federal district judges dismissed a court challenge to Alabama's use of the electric chair today despite testimony that it ''may not work in the future.''

title: West African Music Played at Soundscape
description: Friday evening's concert of West African music at Soundscape was a pretty, exciting affair. The percussionist Ladji Camara, from Guinea, opened the show, strutting around the old loft space in a brightlycolored headdress, beating on a spangled drum.

title: MAISLIN INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect the acquisition of EAF International Inc. in December 1982.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Saperstein's, 1903-1983

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
N.C.A.A. Seeking Another TV Plan
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, whose control of football telecasts has been restricted by the Federal courts, plans to put together a contingency television plan in competition with the College Football Association, subject to court approval.

title: TRAFFIC VIOLATIONS: MOST TICKETS STICK
description: To the Editor:

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: MURCER HITS HOMER
description: Only by announcing his retirement immediately afterward could Bobby Murcer have made a more dramatic impact at Yankee Stadium last night. Murcer, who is nearing the end of a major league career that began in 1965, hit a home run in the sixth inning that propelled the Yankees to a 3-0 victory over the California Angels behind the fivehit pitching of Ron Guidry.

title: 2,250 EARN DIPLOMAS AT HUNTER
description: The founder-director of the Children's Defense Fund, addressing graduates at Hunter College's 151st commencement yesterday, urged them to work to change the priorities set by the Reagan Administration and Congress.

title: TAPPING ALBERTA'S OIL SANDS
description: Beneath northern Alberta lies an oilman's dream: three times more oil than the Middle East has - and not a chance of drilling a dry hole.

title: RILEY RATES 76ERS AMONG THE BEST EVER
description: Pat Riley was a member of the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers, a team that won a record 33 straight games in the regular season and went on to win the National Basketball Association title with a mark of 12-3 in three playoff series.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for year to March 27.
description: b-Includes a gain of $48,000 from the sale of property and a tax credit of $149,000. c-After a gain of $79,000 from the sale of property, a tax credit of $54,000, and a loss of $155,000 from the disposal of locations.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: GAMING & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TURKEY, IN WARNING TO POLITICIANS, THREATENS TO DELAY '83 ELECTIONS
description: President Kenan Evren warned today that the general elections scheduled for Nov. 6 might be postponed if veteran political leaders persisted in trying to get back into power through new political organizations.

title: I.M. PEI REFLECTS ON HIS PRIZE AND HIS ARCHITECTURE
description: I.M. Pei, who will be honored tonight at the Metropolitan Museum of Art as the 1983 recipient of the Pritzker Architecture Prize, was talking fondly about constraints. ''Infinite possibilities exist within discipline,'' he said in his office the other day. ''There are endless mysteries within a set of rules.''

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss after income of $51,000 from discontinued operations.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
KOCH TO CONSIDER CONVERTING OLD SCHOOL INTO AIDS CENTER
description: Mayor Koch, responding to requests from city officials and homosexual groups, said yesterday that he was considering converting a former Manhattan high school into a health center for AIDS victims.

title: Back to the Ring?
description: Chuck Fairbanks has a soft spot for players from the University of Oklahoma, where he enjoyed his greatest success as a football coach from 1967 to 1972. Therefore, there was a spot on the New Jersey Generals' roster for Steve Williams, a rookie from Oklahoma whom Fairbanks would try to develop as a defensive nose tackle.

title: VICE PRESIDENT GETS NEW XEROX DUTIES
description: William F. Glavin's star, which has been on the rise at the Xerox Corporation, rose higher yesterday and gained in magnitude. The company announced at its Stamford, Conn., headquarters, that Mr. Glavin, 51 years old, would join David T. Kearns, 52, president and chief executive, and C. Peter McColough, 60, chairman, in a newly formed corporate office.

title: MT. SINAI STUDENTS TO TRAIN AT NURSING HOME
description: Mount Sinai medical students will soon be treating nursing-home patients as part of their training under a new program to improve the care of the elderly, officials of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Jewish Home for the Aged announced yesterday.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE 'DAVIDSBUNDERTANZE'
description: ALTHOUGH many of George Balanchine's ballets pay tribute to the joys of life, he never avoided such themes as grief, madness and death itself. Thus, three years ago, he choreographed one of his gloomiest yet most poignant creations, ''Robert Schumann's 'Davidsbundlertanze.' '' That title may sound noncommital, but the ballet is charged with feeling.

title: CARTER HAWLEY CHIEF ADDS POST ON BOARD
description: Philip M. Hawley, 57, president and chief executive of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., was named chairman, chief executive and chairman of the board's executive committee yesterday.

title: Advertising; Y.& R.'s British Expansion
description: YOUNG & RUBICAM INC., the largest American advertising agency, and Collett Dickenson Pearce, one of the leading agencies in Britain, said yesterday that Y.& R. had taken a substantial minority interest in the British company and would assist it in an international expansion.

title: Seafirst Gets Eurodollars
description: The Seafirst Corporation said today that it had been forced to turn increasingly to Eurodollar sources for its financing needs because its large losses have eroded confidence of institutional sources in the United States.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Benjamin Oren, Pianist, At the Goodman House
description: The pianist Benjamin Oren offered a disappointing recital at the Abraham Goodman House on Monday night. Mr. Oren has musical instincts and he shapes isolated phrases with care and sensitivity. But he is a sloppy technician, with a tendency to approximate passages of contrapuntally challenging material.

title: 'PHYSICIAN EXTENDERS' READY TO FILL A GAP THAT DIDN'T DEVELOP
description: To the Editor:

title: BRADFORD NORTH: A SYMBOL OF LABOR PARTY ANIMOSITIES
description: The Independent Labor Party was born 90 years ago in this old industrial city on the Yorkshire moors, but in the last few years Bradford has become a vivid symbol of the animosities that have shattered Labor's unity.

title: EL NINO'S WRATH
description: The gravest question facing the whole world today is: Who or what is tampering with El Nino, and to what purpose? El Nino De Navidad - Spanish for ''the Christ child,'' because of its appearance each year around Christmastime - is the warm current that flows down the Pacific coast of South America, periodically playing havoc with fishing and even reversing the direction of trade winds. Most years, this ''Southern Oscillation'' is pushed back out to sea by the icy Humboldt current, in which anchovies gambol; not last year or this.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AGOOD vise, solidly mounted, and a sturdy workbench are essential parts of a home workshop. But because not everyone has a proper workshop, portable workbenches, complete with built-in vises, have become popular.

title: Lanfranco Rasponi Memorial
description: A memorial service for Lanfranco Rasponi, who died April 9 in Rio de Janeiro, will be held tomorrow at 12:10 P.M. at Our Lady of Peace Church, 237 East 62d Street. Mr. Rasponi, a writer on society and the performing arts who had the hereditary title of count, was the author of three books - ''The International Nomads,'' ''The Golden Oases'' and '' The Last of the Prima Donnas'' - and was a publicity agent for prominent Italian opera singers and such New York restaurants as the Colony and the Quo Vadis in the 1940's and 50's.

title: Iran and Iraq Duel Along a 300-Mile Front
description: Iraq and Iran traded heavy artillery fire along their 300-mile battlefront, the two countries said in communiques monitored here today.

title: FACTORY ORDERS GAIN 2.1%
description: Orders to factories for new manufactured goods rose 2.1 percent in April, the fifth increase in the last six months, the Commerce Department reported today. The report also said inventories rose for the first time since February 1982.

title: New York Run of 'Fen' Extended Till July 3
description: ''Fen,'' Caryl Churchill's play that opened at the Public Theater Monday to favorable reviews, has been extended through July 3. The play, which was brought to New York from London as part of the Britain Salutes New York celebration, was supposed to have closed next Sunday.

title: Braniff Creditors Split Over Revival
description: Braniff International's secured creditors are divided over an attempt by Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, to use about 30 of Braniff Airway's planes to restart the airline, several secured creditors said yesterday.

title: GOOD NEIGHBORS NEED 'BUSY' LAMPPOSTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan Urges U.S. Investors To Back Latin America Policy
description: President Reagan, denying that there had been any change in his policy in the Central American nations, today urged corporate investors to support his program.

title: A CITYWIDE CONTEST FOR WINDOW BOXES
description: You're not alone if you never heard of a ''soil scholarship.'' That is what Paul West of the Green Guerrillas calls the volunteer city gardening group's offer of a ''free bag of soil'' to qualifying participants in their first citywide window-box contest.

title: Welch Hurls 1-Hitter
description: Bob Welch allowed one hit - a clean single to right field by Von Hayes with two out in the fourth inning - and Pedro Guerrero singled in a run tonight to lift the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 1-0 victory over Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: New Peso Unit For Argentina
description: Argentina introduced a new monetary unit today for the second time in less than 14 years. The new ''Argentine peso'' has a value at 10,000 old ''pesos.''

title: Caroline Bradley, Top Rider, Collapses and Dies at Show
description: Caroline Bradley, Britain's top female equestrian, collapsed at a show-jumping event today and died soon afterward.

title: Clorox Seeking Du Pont Paints
description: The Clorox Company said it was planning to buy American rights to make Lucite house paints from the Du Pont Company. It refused to say how much it would pay, but Wall Street sources said that, based on 1982 Lucite sales of about $60 million, it probably would pay between $50 million and $60 million.

title: N.H.L. to Weigh Blues' Situation
description: The National Hockey League's board of governors has scheduled a meeting here for next Tuesday, during the league's annual congress of executives, to discuss the St. Louis Blues' situation.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Geoff Zahn, who shut out the Yanks on the West Coast last week, tries to duplicate the feat. His opponent is Dave Righetti, seeking his eighth victory. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. Mike Torrez, a loser in four of his last five starts, goes against Fernando Valenzuela, who was 3-0 against the Mets last season and has a career record of 4-0 against them. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 10:30 P.M.) Soccer Cosmos vs. Sao Paulo of Brazil, Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup, second round, at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. The Cosmos scored a 4-1 victory over Fiorentina in the first round, and Sao Paulo lost to the Sounders, 4-2, in Seattle. The round-robin tournament concludes Sunday with a doubleheader at Giants Stadium. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; WRTN-FM, 93.5; 9 P.M.) Mexico vs. Australia, opening game of World Youth Championship, at Mexico City. The United States has one of the 16 teams in this tournament, which features some of the best junior players in the world. (Television - Channel 47, 10 P.M.) Other Events Boxing: Tyrone Crawley vs. Edwin Curet, lightweights, 10 rounds, at Resorts International, Atlantic City; first preliminary, 8 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Golf: Westchester Amateur, final, at Brae Burn Country Club, Barnes Lane, Purchase, N.Y., 8:30 A.M. Harness Racing: Meadowlands Race Track, 8 P.M. (Television -MSG Cable, midnight, tape); Yonkers Raceway, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 11:30 P.M., tape); Monticello Raceway, 8 P.M. Rowing: Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships, opening day, at Lake Onondaga, Syracuse.

title: RACCOONS CAUSING RABIES OUTBREAK
description: Health officials in four Middle Atlantic states and the District of Columbia are battling an outbreak of rabies, carried mostly by raccoons.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income. The share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: Suicide From Empire State
description: A 23-year-old New Jersey man leaped to his death from the observation deck of the Empire State Building yesterday morning. The police said the man, Jerry Larkin of Mount Holly, climbed the protective fence on the 86th floor shortly after 10 o'clock and was killed instantly when he struck the pavement on East 33d Street.

title: BLACK SECT BARS RETURN TO ARIZONA AFTER SHOOTOUT
description: Members of a fundamentalist church involved in a shootout with law-enforcement officers last October have decided not to return to their homes in the rural community of Miracle Valley, southeast of here.

title: Japan High-Risk Loans
description: The outstanding balance of high-risk loans by 16 leading Japanese banks to 25 borrower countries stood at 5,327.70 billion yen, or about $21.3 million, on March 31, banking sources said today. The amount represented 24.3 percent of the outstanding balance of their overseas lending, an estimated 21,912.40 billion yen.

title: Premier Back in Lebanon
description: Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan returned home after three days in Paris today and said he was satisfied with his talks with President Francois Mitterrand and Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy. He gave no details.

title: GLOSSER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The results for the latest quarter include a pre-tax provision of $180,000 for cost associated with a store closing.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings figure is restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in January.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 2, 1983; The Economy
description: Senator Bob Dole threatened to bottle up revenue legislation this year if budget conferees call for big tax increases and small spending cuts. A House-Senate group will meet for the first time next week in an effort to resolve wide differences between the two houses' budget resolutions. (Page D1.)

title: MASSMUTUAL MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes a gain of $58,220 from certain debt extinguishments.

title: GORES, FATHER AND SON, A TRADITION OF ACTIVISM
description: More than a dozen years ago, when he was fighting the antiballistic missile and questioning the Vietnam War, Senator Albert Gore paused to reflect on how he approached the business of Capitol Hill. ''You can't fight every one of these things,'' he said. ''I allow myself just three major issues a year, but on those three I try to count for something.''

title: ANALOGIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Atari Shifts Confirmed
description: Warner Communications' Atari subsidiary yesterday confirmed a restructuring of its management and a consolidation of its home video game and home computer divisions. The move is seen as an effort to streamline its unprofitable operations and better coordinate product planning.

title: New Faces or New Smoke?
description: President Reagan plainly needs a more effective, coherent strategy in Central America. And before he mortgages all hemisphere policy to tiny El Salvador, he also needs a new sense of perspective. Important as it may be not to ''lose'' the Salvadoran civil war to leftists, stability and democracy are more seriously at risk in Brazil, Argentina, Chile and other places. To redirect the Administration's energies is a tall order, calling for talents very like those of Anthony Motley, Mr. Reagan's new choice as head of Latin American affairs at the State Department.

title: Chernenko Is Back, But He Seems Unwell
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, a member of the Politburo who was regarded as a contender for the Soviet leadership after the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, has returned to the public eye after an absence of two months, but his appearance at funeral ceremonies for another member of the Politburo suggested he is suffering from continuing health problems. During his absence from public view, Mr. Chernenko's office said he was suffering from pneumonia.

title: Globe Cartoonist Suspended
description: Paul Szep, The Boston Globe's political cartoonist, has been suspended for two weeks without pay for a cartoon Friday showing Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, uttering a Russian obscenity to President Reagan. The cartoon showed Mr. Reagan, on the phone to Mr. Andropov, saying, ''Hey, Yuri, guess who's getting a new MX missile system to help arms reduction and world peace?'' Mr. Andropov's response was a Russian obscenity. Mr. Szep won Pulitzer Prizes for cartoons in 1974 and '77.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Forms of Recognition

title: OIL PRICES STABILIZING IN CALM MARKET
description: In the 10 weeks since the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries cut its basic crude oil price by $5 a barrel, industry officials have become increasingly convinced that the new level will hold for at least a year.

title: Dr. Edward Reich Dies at 80; Official of Consumers Union
description: Dr. Edward Reich, a former vice president and treasurer of Consumers Union, died Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 80 years old, and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: VULCAN INDUSTRIAL PACKAGING LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $293,000 in a joint venture.

title: BELGIUM'S CHARLES, EX-REGENT, IS DEAD
description: Prince Charles, who served as the Belgian regent after World War II, died tonight, the royal palace announced. He was 79 years old.

title: Volvo Truck Deal
description: Volvo has signed an order to deliver about 6,000 heavy trucks, worth an estimated $145 million, to Iran over the next 18 months, an official of the Swedish automotive, food and energy group said. The order would triple Volvo's deliveries of about 2,000 trucks sent to Iran last year, a Volvo spokesman said.

title: Topics; Literature and Life; Sunken Prize
description: For 130 years a three-masted British ship, the Breadalbane, has been sitting 340 feet beneath the Arctic ice. Three years ago sonar found it, and last month a diver finally reached it.

title: Surge At the Center
description: Something is happening on the way to Margaret Thatcher's predicted landslide in the British election. The centrist Alliance of the Liberal and Social Democratic Parties have suddenly come to life, worrying both Conservatives and Labor.

title: THE LOYALIST WHO WAS GROOMED TO LEAD ALBANY
description: When Thomas M. Whalen 3d talks about ''the Mayor,'' he still means Erastus Corning 2d, the man who governed this city longer than anybody else, 41 years.

title: Church & Dwight Settles Lawsuit
description: The makers of Arm and Hammer Baking Soda have agreed to pay $25,000 to settle a lawsuit charging the firm short-weighted at least a million boxes of the product, the Los Angeles district attorney's office said.

title: G.& W.'S NET RISES SHARPLY
description: Gulf and Western Industries, primarily citing gains on securities, reported yesterday that earnings in the third fiscal quarter of 1983 more than doubled, while revenues edged up 1.6 percent.

title: Grenada Leader Renews Plea on U.S. Ties
description: Renewing an appeal for normal relations with the Reagan Administration, Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada said today that his country ''constitutes no threat to the United States nor indeed to any other country.''

title: U.S. PLANS TO SHIFT ARMS BID TO SOVIET IN GENEVA PARLEY
description: Bolstered by the political solidarity of the Williamsburg meeting, the Reagan Administration signaled its intention today to revise its proposal to the Soviet Union for cuts in strategic nuclear arms.

title: Kuhn Still Has Hopes
description: His term of office expires this summer and the major league owners have voted not to renew his contract, but Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, still hopes to win the support of the necessary three-quarters of the 26 owners and keep his job. ''I would like to come back when my term expires on Aug. 12,'' Kuhn told a Cleveland Indians' booster club luncheon yesterday.

title: Searle May Sell Its Optical Group
description: G.D. Searle & Company, one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies, announced that it was studying the possible sale of its Searle Optical Group, operator of its retail optical eyewear business.

title: Anna Seghers, Novelist, 82; 1942 Work Made Into Movie
description: Anna Seghers, author of the novel ''The Seventh Cross,'' died today in East Berlin. She was 82 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Yale Law Chair To Honor Harris
description: The late Sam Harris, a Yale graduate and New York lawyer, was honored Tuesday when the Yale Law School announced the establishment of a professorship in his memory.

title: U.S. PLANS TO SEND MEDICAL TEAM ON 'HUMANE' MISSION TO SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration is planning to send up to 25 military medical corpsmen to El Salvador, White House officials said today.

title: Cowens Wants to Play
description: Trying for a comeback with the Milwaukee Bucks after a two-year retirement didn't work out so well for Dave Cowens.

title: Vandalized School Resumes Classes
description: Children returned to classes this morning at a Brooklyn elementary school extensively damaged by vandals over the Memorial Day weekend. Felix Vazquez, the principal of the school, Public School 377 in the Bushwick section, said it reopened at 8:40 A.M., its normal time. Mr. Vazquez said that a repair crew had been working around the clock, but that some repairs would take a few more days to finish. Nearby residents have raised a reward of $1,000 for the arrest of those responsible for the damage.

title: Decision File; Water Still Scarce, G.A.O. Reports
description: ''With all this flooding going on recently, it's a tough time to think about water conservation,'' said Robert S. Procaccini, an auditor with the General Accounting Office.

title: WALLACE COMPUTER SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago results are restated to reflect a February acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests and a 2-for-1 stock split in April 1983.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS PRESS ARMS ISSUE
description: The Communist Party, judging the Williamsburg declaration on nuclear missiles to be too inflexible, has decided to step up its opposition to the installation of missiles in Italy and make it one of its main issues in the campaign for the June 26-27 elections.

title: BUILDING SPENDING RISES 0.4%
description: Construction spending rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April after two monthly declines, the Government reported today. The April rate was 9.7 percent above that of a year earlier.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
GARBAGE CAN HOLDER
description: THERE are several mechanisms to keep the kitchen waste can out of sight in a cabinet and yet retrieve it easily when it is needed. The devices are simple to install.

title: ADVERTISING
description: With the recent growth of magazines, hefty publications are hardly unusual anymore. But what Ziff-Davis Publishing Company issues Friday definitely will be a first.

title: Director at Compton Moving to Wells, Rich
description: Neve Richard Savage, the 38-year-old member of the board and management director of Compton Advertising who oversees the agency's Procter & Gamble, Dannon, and Union Underwear accounts, is joining Wells, Rich, Greene/Worldwide in the new post of chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene Ltd., London.

title: Ruling Aids Conrail Survival
description: Conrail, the Government-owned freight railroad, won a key agency's judgment today that it could be profitable, a major step toward its being maintained as a single unit instead of broken up.

title: RUSSEL WRIGHT: MODERNITY REDISCOVERED
description: IN the realm of ordinary domestic objects, the late 1930's, 1940's and 1950's were decades whose designs are attracting new attention. And in terms of sheer output for those years there was no more prolific and important designer than Russel Wright.

title: Musick's Monument In 15th-Century Concert
description: Musick's Monument, an early-music ensemble of three singers and three instrumentalists, attempted to evoke the musical world of Henry VIII at Grace and St. Paul's Church Sunday night. There were items secular and religious, all of which might have been familiar to Henry and his court.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Jockey to Appeal
description: Attorneys for the jockey Jacinto Vasquez said yesterday that they would petition the State Court of Appeals to overturn a one-year suspension imposed against the rider in a bribery case. On Tuesday, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan unanimously rejected Vasquez's appeal of the suspension, imposed last year by the State Racing and Wagering Board.

title: Borg on Tennis
description: Bjorn Borg, who seldom had much to say when he was competing, makes his television debut in Paris this weekend and will be doing his work from the stands rather than the broadcast booth.

title: Technology; As Computers Eliminate Jobs
description: AUTOMATION is not dehumanizing, at least not for those who buy what automatons make, says Michael Dertouzos, director of the Laboratory for Computer Science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He likes to say, in fact, that it is inherently ''re-humanizing'' because it permits the manufacture of low-cost, high-quality goods of enormous variety with capital equipment that need not be replaced, only reprogrammed.

title: Dirty Tricks: Still Dirty
description: Watergate had its pluses and one of them was to demonstrate to partisan operatives, whether sophomoric or sneaky, that Americans frown on dirty tricks in politics. Or so we thought.

title: Jersey Overhauls Teacher Seniority
description: The State Board of Education today approved a Kean administration plan for the first overhaul of the teacher seniority system since it was begun in the 1950's.

title: Sports Illustrated's Publisher in New Post
description: Philip G. Howlett, publisher of Sports Illustrated and a vice president of Time Inc., has been appointed executive vice president of Time Inc.'s magazine group. Robert L. Miller, general manager of Sports Illustrated, has been named its publisher.

title: ROCKLAND ISN'T PLAYING 'NUCLEAR CHICKEN'
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN PAUL, DON'T VISIT
description: The Pope's second visit to Poland could turn out to be hurtful -for the Polish people, for the Polish church, for the Pope's prestige and for the values the West represents. In fact, the visit is likely to be useful mainly to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's regime.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON PLAN TO INCREASE THE CITY BUDGET
description: After long and sometimes bizarre negotiations at City Hall, a tentative deal was struck this morning to add between $68 million and $75 million to New York City's budget for the next fiscal year.

title: F.N.N. Adds Hours
description: The Financial News Network, the national business and financial television news service, said yesterday that it is expanding its daily programming schedule to 12 hours from 7 hours, starting July 18. Norman W. Potter, F.N.N. president, told a press conference that ''10 hours in the new program day will be live programming with timely issues and trends by leading economists and business observers.'' He said that the objective of the new programming is to ''make many more viewers tune in on a regular basis.''

title: STAGE: 'THE BIRDS' BY ARISTOPHANES
description: THERE is a good time to be had in the current presentation of ''The Birds,'' an ancient but not timeworn comedy by Aristophanes that opened in Athens in 414 B.C. and is now enjoying, in every sense, a revival, in English by the Greek Theater of New York.

title: Execution Date Postponed
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the Supreme Court today postponed the scheduled June 10 execution in Missouri of Gerald Smith, convicted of beating to death a woman he accused of giving him a venereal disease.

title: UTAH TOWNS DIG OUT AFTER MUD SLIDES
description: Water and mud cascaded out of Stone Creek Canyon in a 30-foot-high wave late Tuesday and slammed into Bountiful, a suburb 10 miles north of Salt Lake City.

title: FUJITSU LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: The results are in U.S. funds. The yen figures were converted to U.S. dollars at $1 equals 239 yen, the rate of exchange on March 31, 1983.

title: HARVARD GIFT PLAN URGES DIVESTITURE
description: A group of undergraduates at Harvard University contend that they have demonstrated the value of a new technique to put pressure on universities to rid themselves of their investments in companies that conduct business in South Africa.

title: RUMASA: DEBT FIGURE GROWS
description: The losses, debts and fiscal irregularities of the Rumasa company in recent years have been even greater than they appeared to be three months ago when the Spanish Government dramatically seized control to save it from collapse, according to stateappointed administrators.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ATRIUM CONCERT

title: Thais Order Ouster Of Group of Americans
description: Thailand ordered a group of Americans deported today because of their reported forays into neighboring Laos.

title: Addendum
description: * Modern Maturity magazine increasing its circulation rate base 4.9 percent, to 8.5 million, from 8.1 million, effective June 1.

title: LATIN ENVOY: MR. SIMPATICO
description: Former Senator Richard Bernard Stone, who was sworn in yesterday as President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, is remembered by a former member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's staff for his ''remarkable ability to appear simpatico with the culture and politics of whoever he was talking with.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will bring our sons home from Lebanon. Both the Syrians and the terrorists will leave.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Move on Postal Rates

title: NORTHLAND BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
G.M., Ford Offer 8.8% Financing
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company said they will offer 8.8 percent financing for most of their small cars and small trucks, replacing 9.9 percent financing programs that expired this week.

title: SAN FRANCISCO FIRE RAISES ANXIETY ON OLD DEVICES WITH PCB'S
description: Since a fire contaminated portions of a downtown high-rise building with toxic chemicals, health officials have expressed concern that hundreds of electrical transformers in San Francisco pose similar risks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Latest From China

title: BEGIN SAYS ISRAEL IS NOT PREPARING TO ATTACK SYRIANS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that Israel was not planning to attack Syrian forces and that tension along the cease-fire line in Lebanon had eased in recent days.

title: AUDIT CRITICIZES FIREMEN'S FUNDS OVER TWO LOANS
description: Two loans from health-benefit funds of the Uniformed Firefighters Association were made in disregard of investment practices of similar city funds, according to an audit issued yesterday by the New York City Comptroller's office.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on May 24 about Yale University's commencement incorrectly identified Bernard M.W. Knox. He is director of the Center for Hellenic Studies, administered by the trustees of Harvard University.

title: INDIAN TRIBAL CHAIRMEN ASSAIL REAGAN
description: The National Tribal Chairmen's Association, which says it represents leaders of 166 Indian tribes throughout the United States, today challenged President Reagan to live up to his promises that the tribes would be freed of Federal restrictions and allowed a greater role in running their own affairs.

title: Teenoso Is a Winner in Epsom Derby
description: Teenoso, the favorite ridden by the British jockey Lester Piggott, scored an impressive three-length victory on a rain-drenched course in the Epsom Derby today.

title: Government Plan to Abolish Some Raises Is Called Illegal
description: The United States Comptroller General, disagreeing with a Reagan Administration official, says a plan to abolish automatic pay raises for some Federal employees is illegal.

title: COLLINS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SEARCHING FOR SHEETS FOR AN ODD-SIZED BED
description: WHEN it comes to sheets, American dreams are made on the regular sizes - twin, full, queen and king. If you sleep on a bed of a different size, you probably have shopping nightmares.

title: ERASTUS CORNING AND HIS ERA ARE LAID TO REST IN ALBANY
description: Erastus Corning 2d, who spent all of his 73 years as a citizen of Albany and the last 41 as its Mayor, was buried today, and with him was interred a style of government that was a piece of the nation's political history.

title: U.S. SHARE OF DEBT MARKET UP
description: Treasury borrowings continued to dominate the financial markets, absorbing a record share of the nation's investment funds in the first quarter, according to a Federal Reserve report.

title: DANCE: CANADIANS OFFER A PREMIERE
description: BACK home in Montreal, where Les Grands Ballets Canadiens is based, they call the company simply ''Les Grands.'' That seems an appropriate nickname on several counts, considering the range of repertory that the Canadians have presented in their season at City Center, which ends Saturday. The new, third program presented by the company Tuesday was strictly petit stuff.

title: MAREE RUNS ON INNER STRENGTH
description: S ydney Maree smiled, a wide-mouthed grin seldom seen during his intense sub-four-minute duels with Steve Scott, Steve Ovett, Steve Cram and other world-class milers.

title: Rijsbergen Benched
description: Coach Julio Mazzei of the Cosmos had urged a week's suspension for Wim Rijsbergen, the defender who walked off the field during the 4-1 victory over Fiorentina Monday.

title: Bridge: Gruenther Won Headlines Long Before World War II
description: The world at large knew Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, who died this week at 84, as a leading figure in the Allied military effort in World War II, as head of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and in other capacities.

title: Soviet Says Colorado Beetle Imperils Some Latvian Crops
description: The Soviet Baltic state of Latvia has been hit by a plague of Colorado beetles that poses a serious danger to potato and tomato crops, according to a report reaching here today.

title: Antitrust Suit Against Bell
description: A Massachusetts telephone company filed a Federal antitrust lawsuit today charging the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and two of its affiliates with illegally dominating the market for phone equipment.

title: U.S. REJECTS IDEA THAT BEES ARE SOURCE OF 'YELLOW RAIN'
description: The State Department today dismissed as false a new scientific theory that ''yellow rain'' was little more than bee excrement.

title: Martinelli to Face Primary Challenge
description: A Westchester County Legislator, Carl J. Calvi, said today that he would challenge Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli in a Republican mayoral primary next September.

title: News Analysis
description: The Federal Reserve, according to one of its top officials, is ''sitting on its hands,'' a policy prescription that at best will allow interest rates to stay about where they are for now.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS HAIL SIMPLER AIR FARES
description: Ken Griffin, a travel agent at the Englewood Travel Service in New Jersey, turned to his computer screen and requested the fares available from Eastern Airlines on the Newark-to-Atlanta route. Three coach fares and two Super Saver fares appeared, each with different restrictions.

title: One Mediterranean Fruit Fly Is Found Near Miami Airport
description: A Mediterranean fruit fly was found in a trap near Miami International Airport, but the fly was infertile and no others have been found, officials said today.

title: U.S. GIVING PERU AND BOLIVIA MILLIONS IN FOOD
description: The United States has pledged $48.6 million worth of food to Peru and Bolivia because of severe flooding and drought there.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ruckelshaus in Town

title: PHYSICISTS CONFIRM DISCOVERY OF Z-ZERO, A KEY SUBATOMIC PARTICLE
description: Leaders of an international research team today confirmed the finding of a key sub-nuclear particle, a major step toward the building of a single theory to explain all forces in nature.

title: OUSTER AT N.A.A.C.P. IS LAID TO 'BIZARRE BEHAVIOR'
description: The chairman of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is quoted as saying that she suspended the organization's executive director last month because of his ''bizarre behavior'' at a recent meeting.

title: ALEXANDER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: The year-ago results are restated for an accounting change.

title: 42 in Alabama Charged In Food Stamp Fraud
description: Federal agents used food stamps to buy anything from marijuana to a mink coat in a three-agency investigation that resulted today in indictments against 42 people. They are charged with food stamp fraud.

title: MARCADE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a tax benefit of $270,000. c-After a tax benefit of $431,000.

title: MGM/UA Credit
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has arranged a refinancing agreement with its banking group for a new line of $250 million in credit. The new seven-year plan covering unsecured debt will carry interest for the first three years at no more than the prime rate.

title: COLE NATIONAL PRESIDENT JOINS DAYTON-HUDSON
description: Boake A. Sells, president and chief operating officer of the Cole National Company, has joined the Dayton-Hudson Corporation of Minneapolis as a vice chairman in charge of its specialty merchandisers and the development of new specialty strategies.

title: 1,065 Pounds of Cocaine Seized on Ship in Miami
description: Customs agents said they had seized 1,065 pounds of cocaine aboard a freighter that arrived here from Costa Rica.

title: SEAVER LOSES FIFTH AS GIANTS TRIUMPH
description: Not even Tom Seaver could stop the slide of the Mets tonight, as Atlee Hammaker and Jim Barr pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory that sent the Mets to the seventh loss in their last eight games.

title: ONE OF FOUR VICTIMS OF L.I. PLANE CRASH
description: Fred Peters, a nationally known negligence lawyer who last year won a $29,220,000 medical malpractice award for a Brooklyn child, was killed Monday when the plane he was piloting crashed in fog and rain near Republic Airport in East Farmingdale, L.I. Mr. Peters was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Columbia Bond Issue Will Yield 6% to 10.17%
description: An $88.2 million bond issue for Columbia University was tentatively priced by the lead underwriter, Dillon, Read & Company, yesterday with yields ranging from 6 percent to 10.17 percent.

title: THE PRACTICAL GARDENER
description: PLANT growth is lush. The grass has never been greener and gardeners should be reaping the rewards of their April and May planting. But annual and perennial flowers and the vegetable patch are in need of warm sunshine. Long steady doses of it should set things right to form summer's blossoms and ripen the first vegetables. Ubiquitous Slugs

title: Bell and G.& W. Offer Talking Alarm System
description: The talking, telephoning home security alarm is here. Two companies this week are announcing products that will monitor alarms in a home and automatically dial a phone number and speak a message to the person at the other end when the alarm has been tripped.

title: I.B.M. Products
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would introduce a new microprocessing chip and several pieces of software to enhance the educational uses of its personal computer. I.B.M. said that the ''Private Tutor'' program, retailing for about $50, would make it possible for teachers to write lessons, drills or quizzes on the computer.

title: GULF & WESTERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1,121,000 for the quarter and $4,518,000 for the 9 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $5,606,000 for the quarter and $5,462,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months net income include gains of $29.9 million and $81.3 million, respectively, from the disposition of investments and securities compared to gains of $9.1 million and $6.7 million for the year- earlier quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: TRADE DEPT. PLAN ISSUED BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration sent to Congress today a detailed proposal to create a Department of International Trade and Industry to help the nation ''rightfully develop its international trading opportunities and defend its international trading rights.''

title: Holiday Inns Workers Get Campaign Preview
description: A new Holiday Inns campaign begins today on the three major television networks and in radio and print media with the theme line: ''A Better Place to Be.'' Conceived by Kenyon & Eckhardt of New York, the campaign emphasizes the chain's new hotels and major innovations.

title: 2 Seek Charters For Jersey Banks
description: Merrill Lynch & Company and Federated Investors Inc. of Pittsburgh, a subsidiary of Aetna Casualty and Surety, are seeking New Jersey bank charters, according to the state's banking commissioner, Michael M. Horn.

title: WALKER-SCOTT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Market Place; Bleak Outlook For Oil Drillers
description: OFFSHORE drilling companies won top honors among 96 groups monitored by Standard & Poor's by advancing 6.7 percent in the week ended May 25. But Arthur L. Smith of Oppenheimer & Company regards this rebound as ''a trading rally'' and recommends that investors with holdings in the eight offshore drillers followed by his firm either reduce or eliminate their stock positions.

title: PICO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
DYLEX LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CUT IN FARE TO $1.50, END OF GUARDS URGED FOR 'TRAIN TO PLANE'
description: The New York City subway system's five-year-old JFK Express would lose its exclusive character and run much like any other city subway train under a proposal advanced yesterday by the Transit Authority.

title: MINE UNION LEADER CONVICTED IN BLACK LUNG BENEFITS CASE
description: After a weeklong trial marked by surprise arrests, Fred Carter, a leader in the United Mine Workers union, has been convicted in Federal Court on charges that he illegally accepted fees to represent coal miners seeking black lung benefits.

title: ALO-SCHERER HEALTHCARE reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax benefit of $228,000. Because of the merger of Aloe Creme Laboratories Inc. and Scherer Laboratories Inc., which was consummated in July 1981, the latest year's results are compared with only eight months in 1982.

title: REBELLION IN P.L.O. IS SAID TO SPREAD
description: A leading civilian member of Al Fatah, Yasir Arafat's guerrilla group, said today that he and about two dozen other leaders in the group had joined a rebellion against Mr. Arafat.

title: Adrenal Cells Shifted to Brain
description: Using a hollow needle, Swedish surgeons have transplanted adrenal gland cells into the brain of a 45-year-old woman in an attempt to cure her of Parkinson's disease, one of her doctors said today.

title: Howard Johnson Cutback in Queens
description: The Howard Johnson Company said that it would close, by this fall, a manufacturing plant and a warehouse in Queens Village.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, a report yesterday on a Federal court ruling in a 1961 civil rights case misstated a finding by another Federal judge last Friday. The earlier ruling held that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had not been required to act to prevent a 1965 assault in Alabama in which a civil rights worker was killed.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Alfred Brendel Finishes Beethoven Sonata Cycle
description: It is seemingly impossible for Beethoven devotees to hear too much of his music. On Tuesday night, Alfred Brendel played the seventh and last recital in his Beethoven piano sonata series at Carnegie Hall, and more listeners wanted to attend it than could be accommodated, even with the addition of 150 seats on the stage.

title: Reagan Promotes Two Aides To Higher White House Posts
description: President Reagan today promoted Michael A. McManus, who was in charge of the arrangements at the Williamsburg economic summit meeting last weekend. Mr. McManus, 40 years old, was given the title of assistant to the President and deputy to Michael K. Deaver, the deputy White House chief of staff.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Arkansas Power and Light Co. filed for up to $100 million of first mortgage bonds, with terms and underwriters to be determined later.

title: Positioning for Final Sprint Key to Race
description: A strong field of racers and the slopes and curves of Central Park combined to make yesterday's national women's criterium bicycle championship a positional race, emphasizing teamwork and razor-sharp tactics as well as speed and power.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 2, 1983
description: International A shift in U.S. arms control proposals was signaled by the Reagan Administration for the Geneva talks with the Soviet Union on strategic weapons, but officials said that agencies were divided over the details of the new American negotiating position. President Reagan has scheduled a meeting next Tuesday to resolve the issue. (Page A1, Column 6.) Peru's Government is challenged by a small but growing group of leftist insurgents. The Government has declared a 60-day state of emergency and yesterday more than 500 people were taken into custody for questioning. The army under the elected Government reported that 823 people have been killed this year in clashes involving the insurgents. (A1:1-2.)

title: Successful Operation
description: He overcame a childhood kidney disorder to build himself into a 370-pound Olympic weight-lifting champion, but Paul Anderson, who won a gold medal in 1956, has been plagued by recurring kidney problems in recent years.

title: HOW WASHINGTON GREW AND GREW
description: When Thomas Jefferson and Alexander Hamilton struck their deal to build the nation's capital on the banks of the Potomac, neither could have imagined that it would one day encompass 3,976 square miles and reach the Pennsylvania border to the north, the Chesapeake Bay to the south and the Appalachian Trail to the west.

title: Reagan Helps Red Cross
description: President Reagan helped the American Red Cross open a fund-raising drive today for its disaster relief fund, which has been depleted because of floods, mudslides, earthquakes and other natural disasters. In a ceremony in the Oval Office, Mr. Reagan turned over a personal check, amount undisclosed, to Jerome H. Holland, chairman of the Red Cross, and Richard Schubert, its president.

title: PERU ARRESTS HUNDREDS IN AN EFFORT TO STAMP OUT GROWING INSURGENCY
description: Hundreds of people were taken into custody for questioning today as the police hunted for members of a small but growing guerrilla insurgency that has prompted the Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry to declare a 60-day state of emergency.

title: House Leader Says His Panel Will Hold Hearings on Helms
description: The chairman of a House Ways and Means subcommittee says his panel will hold public hearings into reports that Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, tried to exert political influence over a Treasury Department decision on imported tobacco tariffs.

title: FOR PRATT & WHITNEY, THE LAYOFFS CONTINUE
description: The waiting, Dee Johndro said, was the worst part. In the end, she felt almost perverse relief at being laid off.

title: Thompson Recovering
description: David Thompson, the Seattle SuperSonic guard who has been undergoing treatment for a drug problem at a Denver hospital, had a recent visit from his coach, Lenny Wilkens, who came away encouraged that Thompson was well on his way to recovery. Wilkens, who said he was told by doctors that Thompson had been making progress, was even more encouraged by what he saw.

title: E.E.O.C. CHIEF CITES TROUBLE IN RESOLVING SOME JOB BIAS CASES
description: The opinion that the Reagan Administration will not enforce civil rights laws is so widespread that some employers are surprised they face penalties for job discrimination, Clarence Thomas, chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, says.

title: CORRECTION
description: We gave the wrong address yesterday for the New York Commission on Judicial Nomination.

title: SOME AT CBS CRITICAL OF REPORTS ON SLANDER TRIAL
description: For three days during the last week, Dan Rather found himself in the unusual position of sitting before television cameras as a newsmaker instead of a news anchor.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
PRICES ARE SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Yields declined yesterday and prices rose modestly amid signs that the Federal Reserve has not tightened credit availablity. Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said in testimony before the House subcommittee on domestic monetary policy that the Fed should be ''especially prudent in designing monetary policy in the period ahead.''

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
DANCE: DRAMATIC BALLET
description: ANTONY Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas,'' one of the finest of all contemporary dramatic ballets, returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. That same program also exemplified the company's eclecticism by featuring a guest artist from Vienna in the divertissements from ''Raymonda,'' a new cast in a modern-dance work and a scintillating rendition of a classical pas de deux.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Floral Homage to a Fable

title: NAVY KEEPS SITE ON S.I. IN RUNNING FOR NEW BASE
description: The Navy has told the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey that two of the three sites it had offered as the home port for a fleet were unlikely to be selected.

title: STOCKS POST MINOR CHANGES
description: Stock prices ended with mostly minor changes yesterday after dropping sharply on Tuesday amid growing concern that interest rates will begin moving upward soon.

title: Surrender Date Set for 7 in Abscam
description: Four former members of Congress and three other men will be asked to surrender June 21 to begin serving prison sentences for their convictions stemming from the Abscam investigation of political corruption, the Justice Department said yesterday.

title: Continental to Buy Big Stake in CCL
description: The Continental Group announced yesterday that it would exchange the equity of its Canadian packaging business with CCL Industries of Toronto for $130 million (Canadian) in cash and the right to buy a minority interest in CCL.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
8 CONQUERORS OF EVEREST RELIVE THEIR HIGH POINT
description: Men wear out faster than mountains, and the party of climbers that picked its way over the misty, treeless ridges of Wales this afternoon was showing signs of age.

title: DANNERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PENTAGON AIDE SAYS SHODDY WORK ADDS 10 TO 30% TO MILITARY COSTS
description: Deputy Secretary of Defense W. Paul Thayer told a gathering of military contractors today that they could cut 10 percent to 30 percent from their costs if they made weapons and equipment right the first time.

title: SOME STORES THAT DO CUSTOM WORK
description: Following are some of the concerns that custom-make linens for oddsize beds and mattresses. Some will give estimates over the phone if you provide the correct measurements of the mattress. For fabric, the customer may either provide ready-made sheets or buy the material at the store.

title: MCENROE BEATEN BY WILANDER
description: John McEnroe used the word that athletes shun to describe his quarterfinal loss today to Mats Wilander in the French Open tennis championships.

title: A Better Life For Dick Vermeil
description: Last Jan. 10, Dick Vermeil resigned as head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League. He described himself as ''emotionally burned out'' after a season in which his team, which had won the National Conference championship in 1980, lost six of nine games.

title: Reliever Loses 4th in 6 Days
description: Rick Lysander, a reliever for the Minnesota Twins, lost his fourth game six days as the Baltimore Orioles earned a 6-3 victory tonight.

title: Rates Up At Banks
description: Interest rates on banks' money market deposit accounts rose nationwide in the latest reporting week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: Electronic Data's Iran Settlement
description: Millionaire H. Ross Perot said he and his company, the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, had settled all its claims against Iran for $16.5 million.

title: I.M.F. Loan For Ecuador
description: The International Monetary Fund has approved a loan for Ecuador for the equivalent in special drawing rights of $170 million, Abelardo Pachano, Central Bank manager, said today.

title: SOVIET SAID TO SEEK AFGHAN PEACE
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan said in an interview published today that the Soviet Union might be serious about reaching a settlement in Afghanistan and withdrawing its troops.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Combat Won't Lower Utility Rates
description: Sensing public anger against rising electricity, gas and telephone bills, New York's Governor Cuomo wants to strengthen the voice of consumers at the state's Public Service Commission. That may be an adroit response to a political problem. But the underlying economic premise, that more consumer-oriented regulation would lower utility rates, is a dangerous simplification.

title: THE ART OF GATHERING SHELLFISH
description: T his is an excellent time, before vacationers assault the beaches, to gather shellfish for the table. In some areas, clams and mussels that were too small last year have reached appropriate size.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Accounts
description: * Xerox Education Publications to BBDO Direct.

title: ADJUSTING THE DOLLAR
description: The preparations for the Williamsburg summit meeting had the useful side effect of propelling the usually obscure subject of international exchange rates into the headlines of American newspapers. The recent sharp rise in the international value of the dollar is the fundamental cause of the very tough competition now faced by American exporters and by American firms that compete with imports from abroad. It is important to understand why the dollar has risen and what must be done to return it to a more competitive level.

title: OPERATOR OF ILLICIT CLUB TELLS OF GRAFT TO NEW YORK POLICE
description: A co-owner of an illegal after-hours club in Manhattan told of payoffs to city police officers in testimony yesterday at the first Federal trial growing out of an undercover investigation into police conduct.

title: FITCH PICKED TO COACH ROCKETS
description: Five days after his surprise resignation as the coach of the Boston Celtics, Bill Fitch was involved in another surprise yesterday when the Houston Rockets named him their coach.

title: The U.N. Today; June 2, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Disarmament Commission, Com- mittee of the Whole - 10:30 A.M.

title: PRESIDENT OF MOBIL APPEALS IN POST LIBEL CASE
description: William P. Tavoulareas, president of the Mobil Oil Corporation, announced today that he would appeal ''all the way to the Supreme Court'' if necessary in his effort to win a libel judgment against The Washington Post.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CONSERVATIVES PLAN 2 AWARDS
description: With the avowed aim of providing visibility to conservative intellectuals, two new annual literary prizes of $15,000 each have been established to ''reward high talent that has not found favor in the reigning cultural climate.''

title: HOME BEAT
description: SHE began making them as personalized gifts for birthdays and weddings; but Bess Schuyler, who is shown at right, soon decided to branch out and produce a more extended collection of ceramic clocks that might, because of their food and floral motifs, be considered borderline kitsch.

title: PENTAGON OFFICIAL PREDICTS SHORTAGE OF MANPOWER
description: The Defense Department's senior manpower official, Assistant Secretary Lawrence J. Korb, said today that the armed forces would be short by 50,000 people next year because of Congressional restrictions.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
JEWELER TIED TO CBS SLAYINGS ACCUSED OF BID TO KILL LAWYER
description: A Manhattan jewelry manufacturer suspected of heading a conspiracy that resulted in the slayings of two Federal witnesses and three CBS technicians was charged yesterday with trying to have a lawyer killed.

title: The '82-'83 Season: Empty seats and red ink.
description: THE 1982-83 Broadway season has finally come to an end, not with a bang but a whimper - the sound of teary-eyed producers reacting to the glut of red ink on their financial reports. According to the League of New York Theaters and Producers, the industry's trade association, both paid attendance and gross receipts were down sharply. Attendance, the key indicator of the health of the industry, dropped 16.8 percent, from 10.1 million tickets sold a year ago to 8.4 million for the 1982-83 season. Gross receipts fell 6.3 percent. Receipts dropped from a total of $223 million last year to $209 million, even though they were buoyed by a rise in ticket prices.

title: YANKEES SQUANDER BIG LEAD
description: The Yankees, for a week the hottest team in the American League, found a particularly dismal way to end their six-game winning streak last night. They squandered a 7-1 lead and lost to the California Angels, 9-8.

title: Seafirst Merger Nod
description: The Seafirst Corporation said today that Washington State's Supervisor of Banking had approved its plan to merge with the BankAmerica Corporation. Approval is also needed by July 2 from Seafirst shareholders. Seafirst also disclosed an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry regarding its financial disclosures.

title: SEQUEL TO 'PSYCHO'
description: AFTER 22 years, Norman Bates has come home and Alfred Hitchcock, though dead, seems to have just stepped out for a minute. There are Hitchcock reminders all over the landscape of ''Psycho II,'' though the great man himself is nowhere to be seen.

title: Rohrl Wins Rally
description: Walter Rohrl of West Germany, the world auto-rally champion, and Christian Geistdorfer, his co-driver, today won the Acropolis Rally. The grueling 1,427-mile event was held on mountainous dirt roads in central and southern Greece.

title: SENATOR WHO DEFEATED MAGNUSON WORKS TO ESCAPE HIS SHADOW
description: The Rotarians had finished their salmon patties and the afternoon's speaker, Senator Slade Gorton, was at the rostrum in the Ballard Elks Club Lodge on Shilshole Bay. As a stream of trawlers, halibut schooners and Alaska king crab boats moved in the drizzle across the picture windows, Senator Gorton spoke of ''fiscal priorities,'' ''entitlements'' and ''the budget process.''

title: U.S. SECURITIES: MORE QUOTES
description: Modern communications is making it easier for investors and small securities firms to get an inside view of Government securities prices that were once the exclusive domain of firms specializing in that market.

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $5,142,000. c-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday, accompanying an article on productivity, misidentified two men. William J. Baumol was on the left and Edward N. Wolff on the right.

title: 2D POLICY REVERSAL AT CITIBANK
description: For the second time in recent weeks, Citicorp has antagonized some New York customers and has reversed itself. The incident involves the bank's efforts to attract deposits from around the country. To do so, its banking subsidiary in South Dakota has been conducting a mail campaign offering a 10 percent yield on its federally insured money market accounts. In contrast, Citibank in New York has been offering only 8.6 percent.

title: Marathon Plans Gas Development
description: Marathon Oil U.K. Ltd., a unit of the United States Steel Corporation, announced that it would begin a $2.7 billion development in the North Brae field in the British sector of the North Sea in 1987.

title: CANADIAN FASHION TAKES A BOW IN WASHINGTON
description: ''I didn't see a sequin before I came to Washington,'' said Sondra Gotlieb. ''I never thought about fashion - in Ottawa everyone always dressed down.''

title: U.S. CALLS MIDEAST ENVOYS HOME FOR A TOP-LEVEL REVIEW OF POLICY
description: The Reagan Administration has recalled Philip C. Habib, the Middle East special envoy, and several ambassadors for a high-level policy review next week on what the United States should do to end the impasse that developed after Syria's refusal to withdraw its forces from Lebanon.

title: MARTIN IN 'MAN WITH 2 BRAINS'
description: WHERE would a man with two brains keep the extra one? Why, in a jar, of course - a jar covered with a straw hat and decorated with a fake mouth, so that it can be taken for romantic rowboat rides and, when the moment is right, given a shy kiss on the lid.

title: Western Union
description: The Federal Communications Commission has authorized Western Union to provide a faster telex service that employs new technology, the company announced. The system, called Teletex, will connect 25 United States cities and link the country with West Germany, where the technology was developed. Service is to begin later this month, pending approval of a rate schedule.

title: Martin Marietta
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said its issue of 1.8 million shares of common stock were purchased by Goldman, Sachs and Kidder, Peabody for $55 per share. The net proceeds are to be used to purchase enough shares of its common now held by the Allied Corporation to reduce Allied's holding to 20 percent, from 39 percent.

title: WARM SEASON MASKS BUT DOESN'T END PROBLEM OF THE HOMELESS
description: He is 20 to 40 years old and he once held a marginal job with marginal skills. If he had a family he has probably shed it, and his last home was with a friend or relative who recently threw him out.

title: REMOVE CUSTODY FROM THE HEAT OF DIVORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO RACE PLAN FOR FLUSHING MEADOWS PARK IS PUT OFF FOR YEAR
description: The promoters of the New York Grand Prix auto race said yesterday that they were dropping plans to hold the event this September in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, but intended to go ahead with the race next year.

title: UNITED TIRE & RUBBER CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: BRAZILIANS RALLY TO TOP COSMOS
description: Sao Paulo took advantage of some serious lapses by the Cosmos tonight and defeated the North American Soccer League champions, 3-2, in a second-round match of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup.

title: Steel Ruling Faults Imports
description: The International Trade Commission found today that some stainless steel imports from Europe were hurting the American steel industry.

title: A NIGHT AT THE BALL PARK IN THE BRONX
description: D octor J had his championship; the Stanley Cup was shuttling from den to den on Long Island; the real football season was still three months away; Sao Paulo was one night away from invading the Cosmos; the Belmont was 10 days away. Plus, Reggie Jackson was in town, and it was already June. It seemed like a good idea to go to the ball park on Wednesday night.

title: HOW A SINGLE DISEASE HAS BECOME A POLITICAL CAUSE
description: The Senate recently adopted a resolution designating November as National Alzheimer's Disease Month, an action that, like many such commemorative gestures, went largely unnoticed.

title: NATIONAL SHOES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $461,000. c-Includes an extraordinary credit of $184,000.

title: SOME CUTS IN FUNDS REVERSED IN HOUSE IN $54 BILLION BILL
description: In an attempt to reverse some of the budgetcutting moves of the last two years, the House today voted to appropriate $54.4 billion for the Department of Housing and Urban Development and several independent agencies, including the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The company said that in the year- ago first quarter it had a pro forma net loss of $6.8 million on sales of $354.6 million reflecting the results of Basco Inc. and Modern Merchandising Inc., which were acquired since the year- earlier period.

title: INTER-PROVINCIAL DIVERSIFIED HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $87,000.

title: GREAT WESTERN SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an operating loss carryforward of $20,500.

title: NEC Equipment
description: The NEC Corporation said it would produce optical-fiber communication equipment at the Fairfax, Va., plant of its United States subsidiary, NEC America Inc., beginning in September.

title: Reynolds Units To Start Again
description: The Reynolds Metals Company said its Reynolds Aluminum Company planned to reactivate three aluminum potlines with a combined capacity of 74,000 tons per year.

title: B.P. to Drill Off China
description: The British Petroleum Company's oil exploration subsidiary plans to start drilling off the coast of China in November. The official New China News Agency quoted company executives as saying three offshore rigs would be in action by next April.

title: ART: OTTOMAN EMPIRE HASN'T DIED, IT LIVES ON AT GREY GALLERY
description: ''IT is sad,'' an ancient Chinese poet wrote, ''when empires die.'' But die they do - and with a cautionary completeness. Often it is art alone that keeps them alive, and never more so, perhaps, than in the case of the Ottoman Empire. From 1453, when Mohammed the Conqueror captured Constantinople, until the death in 1566 of Suleiman the Magnificent, the Ottoman Empire was as splendid a thing of its kind as the world had ever seen.

title: Digging Continues In Slaying Inquiry
description: Digging for bodies and clues in the investigation of Richard Biegenwald has failed to uncover new evidence, authorities said today.

title: CHRYSLER DROPS BOND AS TOO COSTLY
description: The Chrysler Corporation, discouraged by high interest rates from entering the bond market, reported yesterday that it had canceled a plan to sell $200 million in bonds to help repay $400 million of its federally guaranteed loans.

title: A.M.C.'s Rate Program
description: The American Motors Corporation today announced that it would extend purchase incentive programs on two jeep models and its popular Renault Alliance until June 30.

title: ASKS BETTER TIES
description: Yuri V. Andropov said today that the Soviet Union had a ''sincere and fervent desire'' to restore normal relations with the United States and was ''ready and interested in seeking joint initiatives'' to that end.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-After tax benefits amounting to $258,000. c-Net income. The latest quarter includes results for 14 weeks compared with 13 weeks in year-earlier period. The latest year includes results for 53 weeks compared with 52 weeks a year earlier.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SNAPSHOTS of them in other, younger days were taped on the hallway w alls as they filed into Martha Weinman Lear's Fifth Avenue apartmentt o remember their times at Collier's magazine, which published its l ast edition in December 1956.

title: KAI G. WINKELHORN
description: Kai G. Winkelhorn, a former vice president of Goldman, Sachs & Company, investment bankers, died of a stroke Wednesday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and also had a home in Cornwall, Conn.

title: BALLET: CANADIAN 'PARADISUM'
description: IT isn't every ballet whose leads can be danced interchangeably by males or females. But then James Kudelka's ''In Paradisum,'' performed by Les Grands Ballets Canadiens on Wednesday at City Center, is an unusual work.

title: The Mets Must Learn To Think
description: LOS ANGELES B efore opening their series tonight against the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Mets skipped batting practice and held a team meeting, instead. It wasn't that the Mets didn't need batting practice. At .226 they had the worst batting average in the National League. In San Francisco, they scored three runs in three days and lost three games. But Manager George Bamberger was convinced that something more important than hitting was missing: thinking.

title: Fuller to Lecture
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, father of the geodesic dome, will appear in a forum tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at Hunter College, 69th Street, east of Park Avenue.

title: Manager Charged In Umpire Assault
description: The manager of a South Korean professional baseball team was arrested today on charges of assaulting an umpire and another official, the police said.

title: THE SELLING OF THE 256K RAM
description: The race for the next generation of computer memory chips has entered the first turn, and Japanese producers are out in front of their American counterparts.

title: LATE RALLY LIFTS DOW BY 9.23
description: The stock market, aided by a late rally, rose moderately yesterday in somewhat heavier trading. The best gainers were some of the technology and retail issues.

title: SHELTERS AND STREETS DRAWING MORE 'THROWAWAY KIDS'
description: Tiffany is 15 years old, a tall, delicate 10th grader who wants to be a hairdresser and likes to wear blue eyeshadow. In the quiet of a large green house a few blocks from the State Capitol, she described the last time she saw her father, a few Fridays ago, when he dragged her by the hair into the kitchen and slammed her head against the refrigerator door.

title: MOZAMBIQUE FINDS ITS FREEDOM IS FULL OF THISTLES
description: When they were guerrillas fighting Portuguese colonial dominance, the people who rule Mozambique these days adopted a slogan that combined determination with optimism. ''The struggle continues,'' they said. ''Victory is certain.''

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: Strictly an Observer
description: Harvey Martin, the Dallas Cowboys' defensive end who was identified in a recent drug trial as an occasional client of a cocaine dealer, said he had spent a week going through a drug and alcohol rehabilitation program in Minnesota, but not, he insisted, because he had a drug problem. ''I was up there to evaluate the program, not to be evaluated,'' said Martin, who explained that he had been sent to observe the program by Coach Tom Landry as an official representative of the team. Martin, who has consistently denied allegations that he had purchased cocaine, insisted that he had ''no problems'' with drugs and said he had participated in the program and submitted to chemical tests because that was the best way to evaluate it.

title: Bausch & Lomb
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. announced that it had begun marketing its first gas-permeable hard contact lens in Canada and would apply soon for permission to sell it in the United States.

title: Advertising; New Tack At Midway Airlines
description: BUSINESS travelers, squeezed in their seats, may begin to relax with some of the special attention that airlines are paying them. Midway Airlines yesterday unfolded a $3.5 million print-and-broadcast program to advertise Midway-Metrolink, a business-class service that starts June 20. At first, the ads will emphasize the Chicago-New York route, but the budget will cover three additional markets later this year and more in 1984.

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: Assets of money market mutual funds declined $779 million last week, to $169.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: 6 Bodies Exhumed In 1981 Jersey Fire
description: The bodies of six people in one family who died in a Paterson, N.J., apartment fire have been exhumed, the police said today.

title: WHAT'S SPECIAL ON 5TH AVENUE'S MUSEUM MILE
description: NEW YORK'S - and quite possibly the world's - most civilized stretch of boulevard is the section of Fifth Avenue from 82d to 104th Street known as Museum Mile, which takes in no fewer than 10 of the city's prized cultural institutions. It begins with the mighty bulk of the Metropolitan Museum, where global art history is on formal parade, and ends with the humbler but feisty El Museo del Barrio, which focuses on the art of Puerto Rico and Latin America.

title: Manville Planning Asbestos Unit Sale
description: The Manville Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell Johns-Manville Canada, which accounts for virtually all of its asbestos-fiber business, to a Canadian group.

title: Chrysler Fills Executive Post
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it had named Bennett E. Bidwell executive vice president for sales and marketing. Mr. Bidwell, 56 years old, has been president and chief operating officer of the Hertz Corporation, a subsidiary of the RCA Corporation, since 1981. His move to Chrysler had been widely expected.

title: Report on Oil Reserves
description: The known oil reserves of Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, will last 68 years at current production levels, a report by the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries said today.

title: BAXTER REJECTS CALL TO CURB MERGERS
description: The chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division said yesterday that corporate mergers were healthy for the economy and that very few new rules were needed to assure orderly tender offers.

title: NATIONAL TRUST CO (TORONTO, ONT) reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $181,000 for the quarter and a special gain of $2,340,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes gains of $12,454,000 for the quarter and $12,281,000 for the 6 months.

title: CRUISES ON NEW YORK WATERS
description: IT'S shorter than a vacation, yet longer than a movie or a trip to the zoo. It's often a cooling experience and sometimes a humbling one that generates energy and fresh thoughts. And in a water-bounded city like New York, it is usually only minutes away.

title: NEWS WITH A BUSINESS POINT OF VIEW
description: Getting right to its mission, ''BizNet News Today,'' the United States Chamber of Commerce's daily television news program, opened this morning's broadcast with reports about orders for factory goods and the Reagan Administration's proposal to reshape the Department of Commerce into a Department of International Trade and Industry.

title: Survey Shows Split on Issue Of Treating Deformed Infants
description: The public is evenly divided on the question of whether a seriously handicapped or deformed newborn should be allowed to die, according to a Gallup poll.

title: U.S. Posts Salvador Reward
description: The United States posted a reward today for information leading to an arrest in the killing of Lieut. Comdr.

title: BASS-BARITONE AT MET OPERA
description: Donald Gramm, a distinguished, aristocratic American bass-baritone, died of a heart attack in his dermatologist's office yesterday morning in Manhattan. He was 56 years old.

title: INDEXING WORSENS DEFICITS
description: The thorniest fiscal issue of the day - whether at the Williamsburg summit conference, in Washington or the third world - is how America can bring its huge Federal budget deficits under control and, thus, to clear the path to lower interest rates, a less overvalued dollar and sustained economic expansion.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
HOLISTIC SERVICES CORP reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: b-After loss on discontinued operations of $516,496, loss on sale and abandonment of assets of $810,778 and a extraordinary gain of $1,790,798 from debt reduction and restructuring. c-Net loss The year-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued retail chain concessions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Expensive Cars And More Modest Ones

title: TRIPLE PLAY BY CUBS HELPS BEAT PIRATES
description: Ryne Sandberg's two-run homer with two outs in the eighth inning today lifted the Chicago Cubs to a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: U.S.-ISRAELI TALKS ON NAZIS DELAYED
description: Mark Richards, Deputy Assistant Attorney General of the United States, refused today to attend an official meeting in the office of Israel's Attorney General, Yitzhak Zamir, because the office is in East Jerusalem.
