The two were to discuss the possibility of Israel's accepting for trial in Israel several former Nazis and Nazi sympathizers now living in the United States.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 3, 1983
description: International Increased American involvement in Central Ameria is being weighed by senior Reagan Administration officials, who are convinced that the United States military presence there is too small to realize the policy goals set by President Reagan. Senior national security officials are reviewing a range of options that include a modest increase in the number of military advisers in El Salvador, a substantial expansion of United States military cooperation with Honduras and a renewal of military aid to Guatemala. (Page A1, Column 6.) The new Ambassador to El Salvador is to be Thomas R. Pickering, a career Foreign Service officer. The choice was announced by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. (A11:1-3.)

title: AUSTRALIAN AFFAIR
description: INTO the annals of really rotten movie ideas comes ''Norman Loves Rose,'' an Australian Jewish domestic comedy about an infertile young couple and the wife's unusual solution to their problem. After taunting her husband about his inadequacy for a while, she begins an affair with his smarmy, unctuous, 13-year-old brother. A lighthearted theme song attributes the virility of little Norman, who's still in kneepants, to chicken soup.

title: OPTOMETRY DOCTORS HINDERED BY STATE LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS AND TONY AWARDS ON SUNDAY
description: SUNDAY appears to have a monopoly on most of this weekend's nonrerun action on television, including two presentations that will be broadcast live. At 9 P.M., Channel 2 will carry the 37th bestowing of the Tony Awards at Broadway's Uris Theater. These ceremonies, always produced for television by Alexander H. Cohen, are generally recognized as the class act among awards shows. This year, the unifying theme will be a salute to the music and lyrics of George and Ira Gershwin, whose songs are featured in ''My One and Only.'' After the show, the Uris will be renamed the Gershwin, one of the nicer things to happen to a Broadway theater in recent years.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
REGALPOLITIK
description: Although pretty well every other British institution has declined in quality during the 30 years since Queen Elizabeth's coronation, the monarchy itself has gone from strength to strength. Some sourpusses put this down to British escapism: from a real world too unpleasant to face into a dream world of make-believe. Unwilling to come to terms with the democratic present, we take refuge, so to speak, in the monarchical past. Nonsense.

title: MRS. LLOYD GAINS FRENCH FINAL
description: Chris Evert Lloyd beat Andrea Jaeger, 6-3, 6-1, and Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia beat Jo Durie of Britain, 3-6, 7-5, 6-2, today to set up the women's final at the French Open tennis championships.

title: CANADIAN IMPERIAL BANK OF COMMERCE reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
LAB ANIMALS' USE MAY BE CUT
description: A drastic reduction in the number of laboratory animals used in medical and drug safety tests may be possible because of recent advances in test-tube experiments, a group of scientists reported yesterday.

title: 6 Youths Arrested As School Vandals
description: Six youths between the ages of 11 and 17 were arrested yesterday and accused of burglarizing and vandalizing a Brooklyn elementary school last weekend.

title: ERNEST GRAVES, ACTOR IN CLASSIC REPERTORY HAD LEFT PLAY TOUR
description: Ernest Graves, a classical actor whose career spanned four decades, died of cancer Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Harlem Dancers Hold Open House on Sunday
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem will hold an ''open house'' on Sunday at 3 P.M. at its headquarters, 466 West 152d Street, with dancers performing, then serving as hosts with Arthur Mitchell, company director, at an international dinner. The gala is being presented to help raise a $2.4 million matching-fund requirement for a challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: PLAN DROPPED FOR PARLEY IN PARIS ON THE RIGHTS OF THE PALESTINIANS
description: Sponsors of a conference on Palestinian rights bowed to French pressure tonight and abandoned a plan to hold it in Paris.

title: METAL ARTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SUMMER '83: A SEARCH FOR THE RAINPROOF PASTIME
description: April showers brought May downpours, and now that it's June, residents of the New York area are looking to summer with trepidation. ''People now just assume it's going to rain on weekends this summer, and they are making plans around it,'' said Donald Beckwith, co-owner of a Brooklyn catering concern called Remember Basil. Mr. Beckwith said nearly every outdoor party his company plans to cater this summer will be held in a tent. ''In past years a lot of people took chances that the sun would shine and didn't have a tent,'' he said. ''Not this year.''

title: U.S. Warns on Travel To Two Latin Nations
description: The State Department said today that it is maintaining two traveler advisory warnings to American citizens who may be considering trips to El Salvador or Nicaragua.

title: COURT BRIEF IMPLICATES LAWYER IN ESCAPE BY WILLIAM MORALES
description: Federal prosecutors have filed court papers in which an informant indirectly implicated a lawyer for William Morales in the terrorist's 1979 escape from a Bellevue Hospital prison ward.

title: IN FINAL ACCORD, $69 MILLION IS ADDED TO THE CITY BUDGET
description: New York City's budget for next year took final form last night as Mayor Koch announced an angreement between his administration, the City Council and the Board of Estimate on $69.91 million in spending additions.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: JAZZ: STEVE ALLEN LEADS BAND
description: DURING the last 15 months, Steve Allen, whose normal habitat is California, has been spending an unusual amount of time in New York displaying his various talents. Last year in March he was at Michael's Pub with a trio, playing the piano and singing songs, some of which he wrote.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: McDermott Posts Loss in Quarter
description: McDermott International, which makes specialized offshore platforms and marine pipelines, reported it had a loss of $5.1 million in its fourth fiscal quarter, compared with earnings of $45.1 million, or $1.22 a share, in the last year's fourth quarter.

title: DRIVE
description: Two weeks ago, about 7 in the evening, the phone rang at the Bayport home of Peter F. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive. The caller, speaking in confidential tones, would not give his name, but said that he worked at the Shoreham nuclear power plant, that there was a crack in the middle diesel engine, and that the County Executive ought to look into the matter.

title: 16 Turkish Politicians Are Now in Custody
description: Former Prime Minister Suleyman Demirel and other politicians ordered detained in Turkey's latest political crackdown were taken into custody today at a military base near this Dardanelles port.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in May 1983.

title: ART: THE VISUAL JUDO PRACTICED BY LES LEVINE
description: LES LEVINE is a sculptor whose medium is the media, i.e., anything from billboards to video. But he uses media to stimulate his viewer's thought processes rather than to numb them, and in so doing seems to test their sense of morality.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 3, 1983; The Economy
description: Leading retailers reported substantial sales gains in May, an encouraging sign for recovery. Sales of durable goods were especially strong, the stores said, indicating consumer confidence. (Page D1.)

title: Sun Banks Deal
description: Sun Banks Inc., Orlando, Fla., said it had signed a definitive agreement for its proposed acquisition of Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami. Flagship stockholders will receive either $35 cash or between 1.05 and 1.35 shares of Sun Banks common stock for each share held, depending on the stock price when the merger is completed. Sun Banks said it would acquire 55 percent to 60 percent of Flagship's stock for stock, and the rest for cash.

title: Sanko Orders 22 More Ships
description: The Sanko Steamship Company said today that it had ordered 22 more bulk carriers of 20,000 to 40,000 tons each from 13 Japanese shipyards, with delivery to be completed by early 1986.

title: STUDY LINKS DIOXIN TO IMMUNE FAILURE
description: A confidential study by a British scientist indicates that the toxic chemical dioxin causes a long-term breakdown in the human body's immune system, a Congressman who released the study and an Environmental Protection Agency scientist said today.

title: Jury Acquits Farmer In Seizure of Soybeans
description: A Federal district court jury deliberated 30 minutes today and then acquitted Wayne Cryts, a Missouri farmer, of criminal contempt of court.

title: ASTORIA FESTIVAL WITH AN ETHNIC BEAT
description: Lambs will be roasting in a barbecue pit in one corner of an Astoria beer garden tomorrow. Elsewhere, people will be testing rusty dance steps or learning new ones. Some visitors to the eighth Queens Ethnic Music and Dance Festival will be chatting with musicians about their songs and instruments; others will be near the stage listening to Yugoslav accordions or to a Cretan rebec or an Italian marranzano or to Central Asian singing. The daylong event will be a combination picnic, concert, workshop and dance party. Is this any way to hear virtuoso musicians playing in centuries-old traditions?

title: AT 3 COMMENCEMENTS, RECOGNITION AND ADVICE
description: Three thousand graduates shared the day with three Queens natives - a Governor, a paleontologist and a 79-year-old ''one-man athletic association'' - yesterday at the 59th commencement exercises of Queens College.

title: A Risky Choice For a Nickname
description: Jerry Argovitz, a principal owner of the franchise that will represent Houston in the United States Football League next year, isn't embarrassed at the selection of ''Gamblers'' as the team's nickname.

title: Rebel Raids in Peru Reported at 2 Towns
description: The police said that insurgents carried out bomb attacks in two towns in central Peru today, and President Fernando Belaunde Terry called on his Center Party for extra efforts to defend democracy in the current national emergency.

title: Europe Auto Forecast
description: Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said today that car sales in Europe would rise to 11.5 million in 1985 and 13 million by 1990 from about 10 million at present. He told a conference on motor components that he expected G.M. to maintain its 11.2 percent share of the European market.

title: CAREER DIPLOMAT CHOSEN TO BE ENVOY TO SALVADOR
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced today that Thomas R. Pickering, a career Foreign Service officer, would be nominated to replace Deane R. Hinton as Ambassador to El Salvador.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: TOUGHING IT OUT AT HARVARD. The Making of a Woman M.B.A. By Fran Worden Henry. 253 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: I.M.F. Aid for Ecuador
description: The board of directors of the International Monetary Fund has approved a standby loan for Ecuador for the equivalent in special drawing rights of $170 million, the country's central bank said today.

title: CLOSING ARGUMENTS BEGIN IN CBS CASE
description: The attorney for a doctor who was linked to insurance fraud in a 1979 segment of ''60 Minutes'' said today that Dan Rather, CBS and two production executives who are being sued for slander were ''totally irresponsible'' in not contacting his client before the segment was broadcast. The physician, Dr. Carl A. Galloway, has filed suit over the broadcast.

title: Trial Opens for 5 Men In Massachusetts Rape
description: Trial began today for five men whose guilty pleas to charges of raping a woman were voided after the Governor protested that a judge was too lenient when he suspended their sentences.

title: WHEN CO-OPS IN CITY DECIDE TO PAY OFF THE MORTGAGE
description: During the late 1970's, as rising interest rates made refinancing a mortgage far more expensive than it had been, many cooperatives decided to increase residents' carrying charges and pay off the mortgage.

title: Caressa Picks Chalk
description: Chalk, Nissen, Hanft has stepped into a new account. The agency has been appointed by Caressa Inc., a Miami-based maker of women's shoes, to handle its $1.2 million account.

title: Oyster Creek Plant Facing U.S. Fine
description: Federal officials recommended yesterday that the operators of the Oyster Creek nuclear generating station be fined $40,000 for failing to adequately safeguard the plant against intruders.

title: HRT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-After a tax credit of $588,000.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: $4 Million to Replace Plaza

title: Economics Is Security
description: On their return from the Williamsburg summit meeting, President Reagan's guests said it went better than expected. That tells more about the clash that was expected than about the results.

title: FIRM'S TIES TO FEDDERS DISCLOSED
description: The former law firm of John M. Fedders, who is now the enforcement chief for the Securities and Exchange Commission, is paying his legal fees in connection with his involvement in a bribery case against the Southland Corporation, according to a financial disclosure statement filed this week.

title: ZSA ZSA GABOR IN A DISPUTE OVER MOVING OF HANDICAPPED
description: A group of handicapped people, some in tears, abruptly left a dinner theater here after Zsa Zsa Gabor refused to keep performing unless they moved from tables near the stage, according to their escort. Miss Gabor today denied that she had asked anyone to move.

title: COULD IT EVER HAPPEN?
description: Given the anxieties about nuclear war that have spread steadily in the last few years, the new film ''WarGames'' will undoubtedly scare the daylights out of many moviegoers.

title: KISSINGER SAYS ASSERTIONS OF DOUBLE-DEALING ARE 'SLIMY LIES'
description: Henry A. Kissinger denied today that he had offered his services to both sides in the Presidential campaign of 1968.

title: A Bill to End Runoffs In City Primaries Dies
description: A State Assembly committee killed a bill today that would have eliminated the need for a runoff election in the primaries for mayor, comptroller and council president of New York City in 1985.

title: F.B.I. to Instruct Baseball on Perils
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Drug Enforcement Administration announced today that a program to warn athletes of the impact that bribery, gambling and drugs have on professional sports was being extended to major league baseball.

title: Bridge: Top-Seeded Russell Team Gains Reisinger Semifinals
description: The semifinals of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship began at the Beverly East Club in New York last night with the top-seeded team headed by Cliff Russell of Miami Beach opposing a foursome led by Bob Jones of New York.

title: Snack Attack
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is even taking the fun out of the baseball clubhouse, according to the doctor who set up the first food program for the nation's astronauts. It all started when Steinbrenner ordered that salads, fruits and juices be served to his players in the clubhouse instead of the customary doughnuts, pastries and candies.

title: CHECKS ON FREEDOM
description: To the Editor:

title: Pact Reached to Buy Homes at Dioxin Site
description: State officials approved an agreement today to relocate 11 families and buy their homes in rural Missouri where soil mixed with the toxic chemical dioxin was used as fill for building houses.

title: Bucs Get Thompson
description: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers, who have had trouble coming to terms with their free-agent quarterback, Doug Williams, bolstered their bargaining position yesterday by acquiring Jack Thompson, the Cincinnati Bengals' backup quarterback. The Buccaneers, who gave up a firstround draft choice for Thompson, are understood to have offered Williams a $400,000 salary, or about half his reported asking price.

title: AT 3 COMMENCEMENTS, RECOGNITION AND ADVICE
description: Students receiving master's and doctoral degrees yesterday from the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York were told that the achievement of excellence in education should be used to better mankind, not as an end in itself.

title: OFFICER TESTIFIES HE TURNED THIEF ON JOINING FORCE
description: A New York City police officer testified yesterday that he became ''a thief'' within two months after he joined the Police Department 15 years ago.

title: F.C.C. Backs Sale of Sprint
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved the $750 million purchase by the GTE Corporation of the Southern Pacific Company's long-distance telephone and satellite subsidiaries, including the Sprint long-distance telephone network.

title: Economic Scene; Who Pays for Bankruptcies?
description: DETERMINING what is in the consumer's interest often is not so easy as it seems. The bankruptcy laws are a good example. The Senate recently passed a bill that would make significant changes in the 1979 revision of Federal bankruptcy law, which was based on the premise that debtors should be enabled to have a ''fresh start'' by being relieved of all their debts.

title: BACTERIA FOUND TO THRIVE IN HEAT OF VOLCANIC VENTS ON OCEAN FLOOR
description: Bacteria found at volcanic vents on the ocean floor are capable of living and multiplying at temperatures as high as 482 degrees Fahrenheit, more than twice as hot as conditions in which life had previously been known to be possible, according to a report published yesterday by two American biologists.

title: BRIAN TORFF, A BASSIST WITH A DUAL MUSICAL LIFE
description: BRIAN TORFF may be the only jazz musician ever to give the leader of the group he was playing in a full year's notice that he was leaving. The recipient of this long-term warning was the pianist George Shearing, with whom Mr. Torff had been playing bass for three and a half years.

title: Ralph Davidson Weds Lou Rosen
description: Ralph P. Davidson, chairman of Time Inc., and Lou Hill Rosen were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Charles Amstein.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. Healey's attack was quite extraordinary. I suppose it just demonstrates the panic in Labor ranks.

title: CUOMO SEEKING DIRECT CONTROL OVER M.T.A. BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo today proposed adding three members to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority so that the Governor would control a majority of the board. The agency oversees the operation of subways, buses and commuter railroads in the New York region.

title: Becker Creates 3-Member Office
description: A.G. Becker Paribas Inc., the New York securities firm, announced yesterday that it had created a three-member executive office headed by Herve M. Pinet, chairman and chief executive.

title: The Worm and the Apple; SUBWAY SMOKE, CIVIC SPIRIT; Pot Patrol
description: It's a violation of New York City's health and environmental codes to smoke in the transit system, but enforcement is a joke. Now the joke isn't funny: two transit policemen were shot recently as they tried to stop people from smoking on the subway.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM PLC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: FRISBEE TEAM'S FORTUNE SOARS AT BRONX SCIENCE
description: Lawrence Gardner is crazy about Frisbees. He is crazy about throwing overhands, underhands, triggers, hammers and buzz saws. He loves to see a teammate sprinting into the end zone, his hand outstretched, and to throw a Frisbee at 30 miles an hour precisely into his palm.

title: Jersey Hospital Bonds Yield 5.5% to 10.33%
description: A $64.7 million issue of New Jersey Health Care Facilities Financing Authority revenue bonds for the Overlook Hospital Association was tentatively priced yesterday by Goldman, Sachs & Company, the lead underwriter, with yields ranging from 5.5 percent in 1984 to 10.33 percent in 2013.

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE VOTES, 19-17, BILL TO INCREASE TAXES $265 MILLION
description: A total of $265 million in new and higher taxes was approved today by the State Senate, 19 to 17. The legislation also calls for a nonbinding referendum next November on a personal income tax. The bill goes to the House of Representatives, which is divided over what taxes to increase to pay for a proposed $3.6 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: Hanoi to Hand Over More American Dead
description: Vietnam will turn over to the United States on Friday ''a number of remains'' of United States servicemen listed as missing in action during the war in Southeast Asia, a Vietnamese Embassy spokesman said today.

title: G.A.O. SAYS $21 BILLION IN NAVY AND AIR FORCE JETS ARE UNNEEDED
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said today that the Air Force and Navy could not adequately justify up to $21 billion worth of training and backup combat jets they planned to buy.

title: French Academy Elects Former Head of Senegal
description: President Leopold S. Senghor, the former President of Senegal, and Jacques Soustelle, the anthropologist, were elected today to the French Academy, the prestigious 350-year-old literary institution whose members are known as ''immortals.''

title: Pershing 2 Test Is Success
description: The 12th Pershing 2 was successfully launched today on a 1,000-mile journey to evaluate its performance on a long-range flight, officials with the United States Army Missile Command said.

title: FOOD CENTER IS SHUT
description: Governor Kean announced today that hazardous levels of dioxin had been found at the former Newark site of a company that manufactured Agent Orange.

title: Bandshell Talent Show
description: Some 30 youngsters, aged 6 to 18, will sing, dance, act and play musical instruments at a talent show sponsored by the Department of Parks and Recreation tomorrow from 1 to 4 P.M. at the Central Park Bandshell, 72d Street, off Fifth Avenue.

title: RETAIN TAX INDEXING
description: In 1981, Congress stipulated that, starting in January 1985, the personal income tax system would be indexed to offset ''bracket creep'' - the tendency of inflation to push people into higher tax brackets. Although indexing is an eminently reasonable method of protecting taxpayers from everincreasing tax rates, Congress is now considering its repeal.

title: Dollar and Deficit, Both Too Strong
description: Now it's not just the French who are hollering about the dollar being too strong. The West Germans are hollering. The desperately poor third-world countries are hollering. So are businessmen, politicians, economists here and worldwide - and all for good reason. The strong dollar hurts everywhere, and Washington doesn't seem to care.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; LAKER LEADERSHIP SPLIT ON ABDUL-JABBAR
description: An internal struggle is developing in Los Angeles over the future of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, now a free agent, who has asked for a twoyear contract worth $2 million annually.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dino Zoff, the 40-year-old goalkeeper who led Italy to victory in last year's World Cup, announced his retirement from Turin's Juventus team. ... Sally Little, who abandoned the women's golf tour a month ago because of a knee injury, said surgery would keep her out another three months. ... Dave Cowens of the Milwaukee Bucks had surgery for a torn tendon in his right knee and will wear a cast for about four weeks.

title: Jobless Rate in Belgium
description: The unemployment rate in Belgium fell to 11.9 percent in May from 12.1 percent in April, the Labor Office reported today. The rate was up from 10.7 percent in May 1982, however.

title: Liuzzos, Who Sued U.S., Are Told to Pay Costs
description: Viola Liuzzo's children, who lost their suit against the Federal Government in the Detroit civil rights worker's 1965 murder in Alabama, have been ordered to pay the Government's court costs.

title: Hewlett-Packard Head 'Doing a Little Work'
description: David Packard, co-founder of the Hewlett-Packard Company, likes to keep his hand in. Yesterday, for example, he was in New York at a show of company computer products ''doing a little work,'' as he put it.

title: REAGAN ENVIRONMENT POLICY SHARPLY ATTACKED BY CARTER
description: Former President Jimmy Carter accused the Reagan Administration today of ''a deliberate, across-the-board abandonment of United States leadership on environmental, resource and related global issues.''

title: REITMAN'S LTD (CANADA) reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Margeotes Accounts
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss has picked up two new accounts worth about $2.5 million in billings.

title: Carrie Fisher recalls pain and joys.
description: IN ''Return of the Jedi,'' they've taken away Carrie Fisher's soldier suit and given her a starlet's uniform, a bikini that reveals most of her 95 pounds - 95 shapely pounds, though oddly enough, Miss Fisher has never thought she was pretty.

title: Friday; DO-IT-YOURSELF HEROES
description: Whoever attends ''Artery'' at the Performing Garage, 33 Wooster Street in SoHo, will be the hero of the drama. Each member of the audience wears a headset and, after instructions from a narrator on tape, walks through 20 small rooms or scenes with automated lighting and sculptural design. The tape includes music and sound effects, and the participant gets to break into a house, steal diamonds and spend a romantic night at a Pismo Beach, Calif., motel, all in 50 minutes. It's the work of Chris Hardman's Antenna Company from Sausalito, which presented ''Vacuum'' at the Garage last year. Individual reservations, three minutes apart, are required: 966-3651. Presented between 7 and 10 P.M. weekdays, 1 and 10 weekends, through June 19. Tickets: $7 and $8. SOUTHWEST AT WHITNEY

title: Rates Increased For Jersey Utilities
description: The State Board of Public Utilities has put into effect higher summer rates for most of New Jersey's electricity customers under a program designed to encourage energy conservation.

title: Endorsement for Mondale
description: Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin, today endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic nomination for President.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Land-Locked And Frustrated

title: Marie de La Grange Hyde, 64, Ex-Editor for War Information
description: Marie de La Grange Hyde, an editor in the United States Office of War Information during World War II, died yesterday after a long illness at her home in Manhattan. She was 64 years old.

title: Polish Primate Accuses Regime of Rights Abuses
description: The Polish Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, publicly accused the authorities today of abusing human rights, and called for forgiveness from all sides in Poland.

title: F.C.C. Clears Satellite TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission cleared the last regulatory roadblock today for the start of a type of satellite-to-home television service this fall.

title: Rules on Eligibility Kept For Olympics
description: The International Olympic Committee president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, said today that ''real professionals'' had no place in the Olympic Games as the I.O.C. announced agreement to maintain the status quo on athletes' eligibility in all sports but soccer.

title: Scuffle Disrupts A Brink's Hearing
description: A brief fight between sheriff's deputies and court officers and supporters of the suspects in the 1981 Brink's armored car robbery in Rockland County erupted yesterday in State Supreme Court here and spilled into a hallway, officials reported.

title: DeLorean Motor
description: Some 400 unsecured creditors of the DeLorean Motor Company owed more than $50 million are asking a Federal bankruptcy judge to liquidate the company to prevent its founder, John Z. DeLorean, from gaining control of the company, Sheldon Toll, a lawyer said. A hearing on the request will be held June 13.

title: RENAULT TO DOUBLE STAKE IN MACK TRUCKS, TO 45%
description: Renault Holding, the French auto company, is to pay $100 million to more than double its stake in Mack Trucks Inc. and take over its management from the Signal Companies, Renault and Signal said yesterday.

title: F.H.A. OUT OF STEP
description: To the Editor:

title: Javelin Mark Set In N.C.A.A. Meet
description: Einar Vilhjalmsson, a University of Texas sophomore from Reykjavik, Iceland, set a meet record in the javelin throw during qualifying today at the National Collegiate Athletic Association Outdoor Track and Field Championships.

title: STAGE: EARTHLY ODDITIES IN 'CHRISTMAS ON MARS'
description: AS the lights come up on Harry Kondoleon's ''Christmas on Mars,'' at Playwrights Horizons, we hear the traffic noise of a city's streets. A few minutes later, an actor enters the play's set, a vacant apartment, and closes the windows to shut out the blare. It's not just a casual gesture. Once the windows close, Mr. Kondoleon, a young writer with a fierce desire to be himself, ushers us into his own hermetically sealed world - one in which the reality beyond his play's four walls will never again intrude. That world may not be Mars, but it certainly is weird.

title: Only 200 Youths in San Diego Apply for 732 Summer Jobs
description: Only 200 youths have applied for 732 summer jobs offered under a federally financed San Diego County program, and the deadline for applications is Friday, an official says.

title: Art Archives losing chief.
description: MORE than anyone else, William E. Woolfenden, who will retire at the end of this month as director of the Smithsonian Institution's Archives of American Art, has built this repository into one of the world's most important research centers for American art. Under his guidance, the archives, founded 29 years ago in Detroit by Edgar Richardson, then director of the Detroit Institute of Arts, and the collector Lawrence Fleischman, now head of the Kennedy Galleries, has assembled 400,000 photographs and more than 10 million primarysource documents. ''We have a whole range of things,'' Mr. Woolfenden said the other day, ''from Copley's letters, to documents of Louise Nevelson, to information about some of the little galleries that came and went in SoHo.''

title: FINANCE NEW ISSUES;
description: A $50 million bond issue for the Kentucky State Property and Building Commission, won in competitive bidding Wednesday by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company and priced with yields from 6.50 percent to 10.39 percent, was sold out yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; June 3, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: High-Level Committee on the Re- view of Technical Cooperation Among Developing Countries - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Worm and the Apple; SUBWAY SMOKE, CIVIC SPIRIT; Unloved Parade
description: It isn't true that everyone loves a parade, but it is certainly true that New Yorkers who like to march in parades love to do so up and down Fifth Avenue. Parades up the avenue became so numerous - and annoying to those who shop there regularly or need to cross it - that in 1972, Mayor John Lindsay called a halt to the issuance of any new Fifth Avenue parade permits.

title: PUBLISHING: THE JOE BONANNO BOOK AND QUESTIONS OF ETHICS
description: JOSEPH BONANNO was sentenced to five years in prison in 1981 for obstruction of justice, but he is not yet behind bars, and in the meantime he has received a number of important visitors at his home in Tucson, Ariz. Among them have been a crew from ''60 Minutes,'' which featured Mr. Bonanno twice recently, and interviewers from magazines and newspapers.

title: Congress Cons Itself
description: In a clear triumph of empty optimism and political fear - both of which President Reagan artfully stimulated - Congress has approved the MX, an act as innocent of logic as President Reagan's decision to call this 10-headed monster ''the Peacekeeper.''

title: 2 Are Acquitted After Police Trial
description: A police sergeant and a detective have been acquitted of administrative charges that they took money and solicited clothing from a garment manufacturer and committed other improprieties.

title: COMMUNISTS CRITICIZE AGREEMENTS MITTERRAND MADE AT WILLIAMSBURG
description: The head of the French Communist Party today criticized the policy statements agreed to at the Williamsburg meeting by President Francois Mitterrand, raising new doubts about how long the Communists would remain in coalition with Mr. Mitterrand's Socialists.

title: News Analysis
description: The continuing rebellion by some Palestine Liberation Organization units in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern valley, appears to be a result of a number of errors by Yasir Arafat in the last year and has seriously shaken his status as leader of a unified Palestinian guerrilla movement.

title: STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
Creditanstalt Names 2
description: The big Austrian bank, Creditanstalt-Bankverein, has established a full service branch in New York City and has named an American and an Austrian as general managers.

title: Glandor Akai Wins Benz Devon
description: Glandor Akai, ridden by Barney Ward of Brewster, N.Y., won the $15,000 Mercedes Benz Devon Grand Prix tonight at the 87th annual Devon Horse Show. The horse sped over seven fences cleanly to win a jump-off in 36.311 seconds. Boing, ridden by Leslie Burr of Wesport, Conn., was second in the jumpoff in 38.077 seconds.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Jay Howell of the Yankees shows promise of being a successful pitcher, if he can ever stay free of the problem he has with finger blisters.

title: 3 Die in Coast Tanker Crash
description: A tire blew out on a tanker truck, sending it across the center divider of a California freeway and crashing into two other trucks and at least two cars before exploding, the authorities said. The California Highway Patrol said that at least three people were killed in the accident, which occurred on California 57 about 25 miles southeast of Los Angeles.

title: NON-MEDICAL SOLVERS OF HEALTH PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Jazz Quartet at Mikell's
description: The vibraphonist Milt Jackson, formerly of the Modern Jazz Quartet, and the bassist Ray Brown will lead a quartet that also includes Cedar Walton on piano and Mickey Roker on drums. The group is appearing tonight and tomorrow at Mikell's, 760 Columbus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). There is a $7 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Burns Scores Ace, Leads on 64
description: George Burns scored a hole-in-one on his way to a 64 and a four-stroke lead today in the first round of the $400,000 Kemper Open golf tournament. His eight-under-par effort matched the record on the Congressional Country Club course.

title: OPERATING INCOME OFF 75% AT BALDWIN' MGIC
description: The MGIC Investment Corporation, a major source of revenue for the Baldwin-United Corporation, reported a 75 percent decline in operating income in the first quarter, to $7.1 million. It cited unexpectedly large losses from its residential insurance business. Revenues declined by nearly 40 percent, to $160.6 million.

title: Tennessee Banks
description: The failure of five Tennessee banks last week will cost the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation nearly $80 million for bad loans not assumed by the banks' new owners, the agency said. The Feb. 14 collapse of the United American Bank of Knoxville, which led to last week's failures, will cost at least $90 million.

title: Italy Vetoes Shipment Of Fresco to New York
description: The Italian Culture Minister has vetoed the shipment of a priceless 15th-century fresco to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for a three-month exhibition.

title: ONE DAY, ONE WITNESS, ONE HEARING
description: On the day Louise S. Glickman came to testify on Capitol Hill, more than 40 subcommittees held hearings. The topics ranged from the MX missile to the future of robots. The witnesses numbered in the dozens.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Monday misidentified the pianist performing during the conclusion of Brooklyn Bridge centennial celebrations. He was Stephen Chapin.

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CONCERT: 'HORIZONS '83,' NEW MUSIC
description: AFTER an unusual amount of conceptual huffing and puffing, the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' new-music series got under way at Avery Fisher Hall last night with a two-and-a-half-hour concert, mostly under the baton of Raymond Leppard.

title: Tenneco Is Sued
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said that it had followed others and sued Tenneco Inc. for $100 million for breach of gas contracts. Tenneco has reduced its volume of purchased gas, much of it at prices above current market levels.

title: BROWN PACES ROW
description: Brown University's varsity heavyweight crew underlined its status as the crew to beat for this year's Intercollegiate Rowing Association title by winning its opening-round heat in the fastest time of the day, 6 minutes 31 seconds.

title: DOMINION STORES LTD (CANADA) reports earnings for year to March 19.
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,208,000 resulting from a funding excess on the termination of the Quebec employees' pension plan. c-Includes a gain of $21,805,000 from the sale of Quebec retail operations. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock Exchanges.

title: NATO AFFIRMS '83 MISSILE DEPLOYMENT
description: Defense ministers of Atlantic alliance countries today affirmed a pledge to begin deploying American medium-range missiles in Europe next December if an American-Soviet agreement on limiting such arms is not reached by then.

title: The Sting in the Tale of Yellow Rain
description: President Reagan and both of his Secretaries of State have denounced the Soviet Union for supplying a toxin weapon to its Vietnamese allies in Laos and Cambodia. Citing samples of toxincontaining ''yellow rain,'' they suggested violation of two treaties against such weapons, with ominous implications for other arms control agreements. But study by a Harvard biologist raises the possibility that those trumpeted spots of yellow rain are merely the mold-ridden excreta of bees.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Tosco Debt Pact
description: The Tosco Corporation said it had agreed to restructure its bank debt, increasing its credit line by $70 million. It said the interim credit agreement, which expires on Jan.1, 1985, brings its total bank credit facilities to about $775 million. Tosco said it, in turn, was pledging some assets as security and was issuing to the banks six-year warrants to purchase 2.25 million common shares at $12.50 a share.

title: Israeli Eclectics
description: Habrira Hativ'it (''The Gathering''), an eclectic group from Israel that mixes Middle Eastern music with jazz, rock and folk traditions, will perform tomorrow night at 8 at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue (427-6000). Tickets are $10 and $12.

title: Market Place; Writing Calls In Bull Market
description: IN options trading, writing covered calls is a strategy often recommended to investors who seek additional income from their equity portfolios and some downside protection against price declines. Using this method, a person writes - or sells - a call option on stock that is owned outright. The writer immediately pockets the premium, or the price of the option.

title: Segregationist Gives Up To Serve Bombing Term
description: J.B. Stoner, a white supremacist who had been a fugitive for five months, surrendered to the authorities today to begin serving a 10-year sentence for the 1958 bombing of a black church.

title: The Worm and the Apple; SUBWAY SMOKE, CIVIC SPIRIT; Plugging Hard
description: A pedestrian for whom falling while crossing the street had been a daily embarrassment realized recently that she hadn't been doing so much falling down lately. Nor had her cab rides included the inevitable abuse: a quick descent into the springs of the seat followed by a quick ascent to the roof.

title: Marking a Milestone
description: It was on Aug. 4, 1954, that Roger Bannister and John Landy, then the only men to have broken the four-minute mile, raced each other in the British Empire Games in Vancouver, British Columbia. On Wednesday, both men paid a visit to Empire Stadium, the site of the historic race.

title: AT 3 COMMENCEMENTS, RECOGNITION AND ADVICE
description: The head of the Paine Webber securities concern, who left Bernard M. Baruch College of the City University of New York without a degree more than 30 years ago, gave graduates of the school yesterday some advice in their pursuit of career opportunites.

title: Errant Satellite Moved Higher
description: An off-course communications satellite was boosted another 202 miles today as space agency engineers continued their efforts to move it toward a stable earth orbit of 22,234 miles.

title: Judge Denies Pepsico Bid
description: A request by Pepsico Inc. that it be given ''timely notice'' when the Securities and Exchange Commission subpoenaed witnesses to testify in a Government investigation of top company officials was denied yesterday by Judge Abraham D. Sofaer in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: PARLIAMENT IN GREECE ENACTS CONTESTED LABOR BILL
description: A hotly disputed Greek Government bill that prescribes how strikes can be called in statecontrolled enterprises was enacted by Parliament early today as thousands of workers protested outside.

title: Brokers' Net Rose in 1982
description: The securities industry, benefiting from the soaring stock market and record volume, profited handsomely in 1982, but expenses also increased at a surprising level, the Securities Industry Association said yesterday in its annual review.

title: TOO RARE A LITHOGRAPH
description: To the Editor:

title: POP JAZZ
description: ''I SING just to know that I'm alive - I play just to feel that I'll survive,'' Nina Simone proclaims in the opening cut of her newest album, ''Fodder on My Wings.'' Recorded in Paris a year ago last January, the record is one of the most joyous albums in the tempestuous career of a peripatetic pop diva who is not renowned for her serenity.

title: BRIEFING
description: Opening in Hungary?

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 50 Years at Fieldston

title: E.F. HUTTON TO START A VIDEOTEX SERVICE
description: E.F. Hutton & Company announced a new service yesterday that will give clients with home computers access to their accounts and to selected investment information. Hutton thus becomes the first brokerage to offer such a service, although other major firms are studying the possibility.

title: BALLET: HARLEM DANCE TROUPE
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM celebrated its new status as resident dance company of City College's Aaron Davis Hall on Wednesday with one of the ''arts exposure'' programs for which it has become known. Schoolchildren filled the attractive campus theater for a 90-minute performance and lecture-demonstration that touched on plies, partnering, lighting gels and the ballet steps that lurk in the latest social dances.

title: Ripple Effect
description: With at least 7 of the 23 teams in the National Basketball Association committed to begin next season with new head coaches, the general counsel of the players' association foresees the ''the largest player turnover in league history'' during the off-season.

title: Sheeler work sets a record.
description: CHARLES SHEELER'S 1931 ''Classic Landscape,'' an idealized panorama of the Ford plant at River Rouge, Mich., sold yesterday for $1.8 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a Sheeler or for any 20th-century American painting. The painting, a synthesis, not a realistic representation of the scene, and regarded as one of the most important works by the Precisionist artist, was purchased by three dealers - Kennedy Galleries and Hirschl & Adler Galleries of New York and Meredith Long of Houston at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street,

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to May 2.
HOW TO GET AN EDGE ON A MUDDY TRACK
description: There's one bettor in New York who wears his system for playing the races on his license plates. They read ''CAULKS.'' He has known for a number of years what several recent big races have demonstrated to the casual fan: On a muddy track, watch out for a horse wearing mud caulks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Certain Lack of Interest

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Monday about executive etiquette referred incorrectly to Henry Cabot Lodge. He is 80 years old.

title: LABOR MAKES ISSUE OF FALKLAND WAR
description: The Labor Party has injected the Falkland war into the general election campaign, with a personal attack on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher that brought swift condemnation.

title: DEALERS' BOND RALLY FALTERS
description: A rally in bond prices, begun by professional dealers yesterday, faltered late in the day as institutional investors refused to join the buying spree.

title: JUDGE FEARS BELL UNITS COULD LACK STRENGTH
description: Judge Harold H. Greene of Federal District Court, who will rule on American Telephone and Telgraph Company's final divestiture plan, raised concerns today that A.T.& T.'s 22 local phone subsidiaries would lack the marketing and financial muscle to operate effectively once they are divested.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Celtics in Connecticut?
description: Harry Mangurian, the owner of the Boston Celtics, said yesterday that the announcement that he wants to sell the club had produced ''a lot of interest in the team,'' but he declined to comment on a published report that a group of Connecticut businessmen had made a lucrative offer to have the Celtics play half their home games at the Hartford Civic Center. According to the report in The Boston Globe, the Connecticut group has offered to guarantee the sale of more than 10,000 season tickets and to conclude an arrangement with the Civic Center that would generate more revenue for the Celtics than their arrangement with the Boston Garden.

title: PETRO-SUN INTL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: D.D.B. Is Big Winner At Awards Ceremony
description: It was another awards ceremony yesterday for the advertising business, and the American Marketing Association's 14th annual awards singled out Doyle Dane Bernbach as the recipient for the largest number of Effies, 11. D.D.B. got three gold plaques for retail consumer advertising, home entertainment/furnishings and household goods. The agency also picked up four silver awards and four merit awards.

title: Olympic-Bound
description: James Patrick, the all-America defenseman from the University of North Dakota who was the Rangers' No. 1 draft choice in 1981, has decided to play for the Canadian Olympic team next February instead of turning pro with the Rangers for the coming season.

title: REAGAN AIDES LOOK TO A LARGER ROLE IN LATIN CONFLICTS
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials, convinced that the United States military presence in Central America is too small to realize the policy goals proclaimed by President Reagan, are considering an increase in American involvement.

title: 'WARGAMES,' A COMPUTER FANTASY
description: ''WARGAMES,'' this week's only suspense film by John Badham, the director of ''Blue Thunder,'' is an entertaining movie that, like a video game once played, tends to disappear from one's memory bank as soon as it's finished.

title: FRAZIERS MAKE BUGNER A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: He had not spoken to Joe Bugner in the 10 years since he beat him in London, but now, though they were in separate television studios, Joe Frazier was hooked up to his old English rival. It made the 39-year-old Frazier want to sing:

title: Japanese Art Deco; reply to a Romeo.
description: appreciated restaurant near Carnegie Hall, closed about a year and a half ago. Last January, it reopened on Broadway, between 76th and 77th Street, another area where it will be a boon. The new is much handsomer than the old, even though tables are a bit too close for privacy. It is all white and gleaming, a combination of Japanese and Art Deco motifs, and a striking red-lacquer screen effect dramatizes the lively sushi bar.

title: EDUCATION: 'BACK' IS THE WRONG DIRECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE AND SCHOOLS GET NEW FUNDS
description: New York City's $16.7 billion budget for the next fiscal year was adopted yesterday after three days and two nights of negotiations that produced more money for public schools, police officers, street cleaners, parks and libraries.

title: OUR NONVINTAGE PORTS: SNUG (SMUG?) HARBORS
description: Cit ies all along the East Coast, it appears, have developed an overreaching condition that is known by those who specialize in such matters as the ''harbor complex.'' The syndrome is manifested in a desire to ''restore the dilapidated waterfront district.'' Keys to the syndrome are the use of words like ''invigorate'' and ''revitalize'' when speaking not of the spirit but of things like piers, wharves and cobblestone streets. Allowed to run its course, the condition results in the loss of the quiet and solitude of a few square blocks of forgotten harbor and its replacement by a carnival of ersatz charm, a ''harborplace'' of glass-enclosed bistros, condominiums and boutiques into which no sailor worth his salt would set sail or foot.

title: Zsa Zsa Gabor Contract Canceled After Incident
description: Zsa Zsa Gabor's contract to perform at a dinner was terminated Thursday night after a group of handicapped people said that Tuesday night she had asked that they be moved out of front-row seats. Miss Gabor, reached earlier Thursday at her hotel in nearby Downington, denied she had ordered the move.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The 10th Precinct station house is on West 20th Street, a gray stone building six stories high amid the fire escapes and window boxes of Chelsea.

title: Sports of the Times; The Toughest Man in the World
description: I t was a cool fall Sunday afternoon a couple of years ago, and an elderly man was walking down Second Avenue near 53d Street in Manhattan.

title: Foreign Study
description: Kevin Ryan's basketball statistics in his senior year at Colgate University - an average of 11 points and 6 rebounds a game - were not impressive enough to attract attention in the 1982 National Basketball Association draft. But they did interest Sparta Bertrange, a team in Luxembourg's National Division.

title: Dr. Bernard Bernstein Is Dead; Founded Chiropractors Group
description: Dr. Bernard Bernstein, founder and first legislative secretary of the Federation of Licensed Chiropractors of New York, died of congestive heart failure Friday at Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FLOOD VICTIMS RETURN HOME
description: Clear skies and cool breezes moved over northern Utah today, allowing hundreds of flood victims to return to their homes in communities devastated by mud slides.

title: WASHINGTON HAILS ANDROPOV APPEAL FOR WARMER TIES
description: The State Department today welcomed an appeal from Yuri V. Andropov for improved relations and asserted that if Moscow was ready ''to take concrete steps'' it would ''find a ready partner'' in the Reagan Administration.

title: Who Wires New York
description: When New York awarded its first cable TV franchise in 1970, covering part of Manhattan, no advanced degree was needed to fathom its purpose. The company agreed to pay the city for the right to run cables under the streets, expecting that subscribers would pay to have their TV sets wired for better reception of the normal broadcasts. But as home movies and other distinct cable services appeared, with the prospect of as many as 100 simultaneous offerings, officials gagged on the task of choosing the citywide system they wanted.

title: DANCE: CLASS OF '83 PERFORMS
description: There are few things as charming as the freshness that young, new performers bring to the stage. That freshness and the level of technique and presence, particularly among the ballet majors, made the 1983 graduation performance of the dance division of New York's School of Performing Arts one of its most enjoyable. It was held Thursday at the Norman Thomas High School auditorium.

title: Sports People; Finally, a Day for Mays
description: When Willie Mays left the San Francisco Giants in 1972 to finish his career with the Mets, the Giants retired his number, 24, but did not have a ceremony to mark the retirement. Now, a ceremony has been scheduled for Candlestick Park on Aug. 20 and, according to Mays, it's about time.

title: CHARGES IN BOMB SLAYING OF MOTHER DROPPED
description: Murder charges against a 29-year-old Brooklyn man, accused of killing his mother by mailing her an explosive device in a hollowedout cookbook, were dropped yesterday.

title: EXPERT ON UROLOGICAL CANCERS
description: Dr. Meyer M. Melicow, an award-winning leader in the identification of urological cancer and Given Professor Emeritus of Uropathology Research at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died of cancer yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports People; Rules of the Game
description: Ohio State yesterday declared its starting quarterback, Mike Tomczak, ineligible for collegiate competition because he posed for a department store ad in a Columbus magazine.

title: Senator Dole Suggests Plan on Nuclear Arms
description: Senator Robert Dole suggested an arms reduction plan today that would freeze the Soviet and United States nuclear arsenals well below current levels.

title: 'INVISIBLE MARKETING' HELPS 'FLASHDANCE' SELL
description: In the movie industry, every season has its unexpected hit. The surprise this spring was Paramount Pictures' ''Flashdance,'' an R-rated movie about a girl who wants to dance her way out of Pittsburgh.

title: Pops in Queens
description: The Queens Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of David Katz, will perform a free concert, the first of five in a ''Pops in the Parks'' series, tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park (between the Unisphere and the tennis center). The Peruvian mezzosoprano Cecilia Angell will be the guest artist.

title: West Side 'Mikado'
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players are presenting ''The Mikado, or the Town of Titipu'' through June 12 at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street.

title: KOHL DEFENDS U.S. ON ARMS CRITICISM
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl met today with Paul H. Nitze, the American negotiator at the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles, and later said through a spokesman that he believed the United States was seriously and responsibly seeking an accord with the Soviet Union.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 4, 1983
description: International The State Department welcomed an appeal by Yuri V. Andropov for improved relations. The State Department said that if Moscow was ready ''to take concrete steps'' it would ''find a ready partner'' in the Reagan Administration. The Soviet leader made his appeal at a meeting Thursday in Moscow with W. Averell Harriman. (Page 1, Column 6.) Unease is growing in Argentina over a series of threats, beatings and, in some cases, killings, by politically extremist underground groups. An abiding fear in the country is that the violence might undermine national elections scheduled for October by the military Government. (1:5.)

title: CAR STEREO THEFT: SYMPTOM OF URBAN MALAISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico Tied, 1-1
description: The national junior teams of Mexico and Australia played to a 1-1 tie Thursday night in the opening match of the World Youth Soccer Championship.

title:
Patents;
Protection For Data in Computers
description: WASHINGTON TWO computer scientists at the National Bureau of Standards in Gaithersburg, Md., have patented a system for protecting computerized data. Miles E. Smid and Dennis K. Branstad were granted patent 4,386,233 this week for a method of scrambling and unscrambling the information within a computer.

title: Chicago Mayor's Team Urges Reorganization of Agencies
description: A report released today by Mayor Harold Washington's transition team proposes changes to eliminate waste and inefficiency in most city departments. One of the report's authors said it could cut the city budget 10 percent.

title: Around the Nation; Hunters Hired by Navy Shoot 50 Goats on Island
description: Three hunters hired by the Navy killed about 50 of the 200 goats left on an island used for target practice today. The island is about 65 miles off the Southern California coast.

title: A BOARD OF ESTIMATE WORTH ABOLISHING
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: R Revised.* Seasonally adjusted. + Over $100,000.** Excluding acceptances.n.a. Not available.

title: Simpson Shoots 68, Leads Kemper by 2
description: Scott Simpson slipped past George Burns with a no-bogey 68 and took a two-stroke lead today in the second round of the $400,000 Kemper Open.

title: 4 NORTHWEST UTILITIES IN A-PLANT BID
description: Managers of the four largest private utilities in the Pacific Northwest are seeking a way to keep construction moving on a nuclear plant that the Washington Public Power Supply System has said it would mothball.

title: Bridge:; U.J.A.-Federation Event Has Its Usual Good Start
description: In recent years the world's most successful charity game has divided in two. The first half of the game, the U.J.A.-Federation event, was for players in New York City and Westchester County, and was played recently at the Harmonie Club in New York. The second half, for Long Island players, will be at the Glen Oaks Country Club on Aug. 11.

title: PROPER HOME FOR THE STRAVINSKY ARCHIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: DOCTORS BATTLE NURSES OVER DOMAINS IN CARE
description: Gretchen Nicol, a nurse-practitioner who completed advanced studies in a federally financed program at Ohio State University, has examined hundreds of women for early-warning signs of cancer, working in clinics, a doctor's office and as an Air Force Reserve officer.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: The African National Congress, a New York-based group pressing for racial equality in South Africa, where the organization is banned, called for a boycott of the June 16 junior middleweight title fight between Davey Moore and Roberto Duran at Madison Square Garden because Bob Arum, the bout's promoter, has staged several fights in South Africa. ... Pat Hallacy, a professional boxer, was sentenced to 3 to 10 years in prison for his conviction May 4 of breaking a man's jaw in a brawl last New Year's Eve. ... In a new effort to fill the vacant World Boxing Council welterweight title, Milton McCrory, the undefeated No. 1 contender, and Colin Jones, the European champion, will meet in Las Vegas sometime in August, according to the promoter, Don King. The boxers fought to a draw in March. ... Jake Gonos, Florida State's assistant football coach, who was charged with possession of cocaine last Saturday, has resigned. ... Bill Mahoney, a former Canadian college coach who has been coaching a Detroit hockey farm club in Adirondack, N.Y., was signed to a two-year contract to coach the Minnesota North Stars.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 18. 1. Bee excrement. The State Department dismissed the theory as false. 2. Meteorologists think that El Nino, a fickle Pacific Ocean westto-east countercurrent that has been much stronger than normal in the past year, may be chief cause off the recent heavy precipitation.

title: POP SONGS: MARION COWINGS
description: The singer Marion Cowings wore white tie and tails with a white carnation Thursday at Lush Life, and he sounded every bit as suave as he looked.

title: Abby Weed Grey, Art Patron And Founder of Study Center
description: Abby Weed Grey, art collector, patron and founder of the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, died Thursday in St. Paul, Minn., of cancer.

title: Around the World; Communists Are Victors In West Bengal Voting
description: NEW DELHI June 3 - The ruling Marxist Communist Party in West Bengal State, despite a strong challenge from the Congress Party of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, has captured a majority in elections for about 56,000 village council seats in the eastern Indian state.

title: John W. Carncross, 82, Dies; Former Professor at Rutgers
description: John W. Carncross, an agricultural economist and professor emeritus at Rutgers University, died Thursday of a heart ailment at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune. He was 82 years old and lived in Manasquan, N.J.

title: De Gustibus; GARLIC: A LITTLE CAUTION PAYS DELICIOUS DIVIDENDS
description: Touted throughout history as a healer and a preventative, an aphrodisiac and a talisman, garlic is valued primarily and most practically as a culinary sachet.

title: CORDELIA CRANE WED TO DAVID RITCHIE, AN OILMAN
description: The marriage of Cordelia Houghton Crane to David Morton Ritchie took place yesterday in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in Manhattan. The Rev. Bruce Forbes performed the ceremony.

title: ANNOUNCEMENT DUE
description: The New York Stock Exchange, acting on a request by Norton Simon Inc., halted trading yesterday in shares of the big consumer products company pending a ''significant announcement.''

title: LAWYER FEE IN CBS CASE IS UNDER INQUIRY BY U.S.
description: A $15,000 payment to the lawyer who represented the man convicted of murdering a Federal witness and three CBS employees is being investigated by the Justice Department, the United States Attorney in Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Pilot Is Killed in F.A.A. Test
description: An unidentified pilot was killed today when his single-engine plane crashed into a runway while demonstrating aerial maneuvers for a competency certificate from the Federal Aviation Administration, the authorities said.

title: Threat of Forced Trust Faces Director of C.I.A.
description: Senator Carl Levin said today that he would propose a law requiring William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, to put his assets in a blind trust if Mr. Casey did not do so voluntarily.

title: Blues Given To N.H.L.
description: The Ralston Purina Company, which owns the St. Louis Blues, announced today that it had turned the team over to the National Hockey League to operate, sell or ''dispose of in whatever manner the league desires.''

title: NEW YORK LOVES REVENUES
description: Despite the first telltale signs of economic recovery, 714,000 New Yorkers still are out of work. Mario Cuomo's campaign promise to convene a blue-ribbon Job Opportunity Board should remain a special priority. In a 50-page campaign paper, Mr. Cuomo recommended that the board include business, labor and government leaders, and that it be charged with proposing immediate steps to create jobs and expand economic opportunity.

title: Sports People; Soccer Furor
description: As a star for Flamengo for 12 years, Zico has been a major figure in Brazilian soccer.

title: Letter: On Child Services; A Foster Care System Needs Flexibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Midwest Financial
description: The Midwest Financial Group Inc., Peoria, Ill., announced that it had agreed to acquire the Corn Belt Bank of Bloomington, Ill., which has assets of about $140 million.

title: YOU GET NYET IF YOU DON'T SPEAK RUSSIAN IN SOVIET
description: ''Speak Russian, please,'' the ticket agent said, turning away from the swarthy traveler standing at his window. The traveler, unable to make himself understood in his native Kazakh, ceded his place at the head of the line and walked away disconsolately.

title: 4 Gain in Rowing
description: Princeton, Syracuse, Northeastern and Pennsylvania qualified their varsity heavyweight crews this morning in the repechage, or second-chance heats, and earned places in Saturday's grand final of the 81st Intercollegiate Rowing Association championships. In doing so, they will join Brown and Navy, two winners on Thursday, in the final.

title: John E. Allison Is Dead at 36; A Rockland County Legislator
description: John E. Allison, the majority leader of the Rockalnd County Legislature since 1981, died Thursday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y., after suffering a brain hemorrhage. He was 36 years old and live in New City, N.Y.

title: TECHNOLOGY ISSUES LEAD STOCK HIGHER
description: Favorable economic news helped the stock market post a moderate gain yesterday with some of the technology issues spearheading the advance.

title: Report Urges Uniform Rules To Govern Hazardous Cargo
description: The National Research Council has called on the Government to simplify its regulations for transporting hazardous materials, saying the current system ''may in fact discourage the very safety it proposes to assure.''

title: GRADUATIONS HELD AT THREE SCHOOLS
description: The president of New York University told students at the university's 151st commencement yesterday that education was important not only for a vigorous economy and national security, but also for assuring the country's freedoms and defining its culture.

title: Non-Bell Phone Concerns Expand
description: The nation's 1,432 independent telephone companies will spend a record $5.1 billion this year expanding and modernizing their phone systems, the United States Independent Telephone Association estimated.

title: Nicaraguan Seeks U.S. Visa
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge, recently denied an entry visa by Washington, has applied again so he can make a lecture tour of United States' universities, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: MORE TEACHERS TURN TO MOONLIGHTING, CITING A NEED TO SUPPLEMENT SALARIES
description: Murray Sherman teaches third grade at Public School 335 in New York's Bedford-Stuyvesant section. He sells mattresses evenings and weekends.

title: Players; SKATING BACK TO FORM IS NO EASY MANEUVER
description: T he sign on the inside of the office door read: ''It's a jungle out there.'' Elaine Zayak now knows why. Last March, a doctor put her injured right leg in a cast and said no skating for six weeks. Then when the 1982 world champion finally returned to the ice last month, she was forced to start from scratch and had difficulty completing even a routine double axel.

title: WILANDER PLAYS NOAH IN FINAL
description: Yannick Noah outplayed Christophe Roger-Vasselin, and Mats Wilander outlasted Jose Higueras today to set up a French Open final Sunday that pits fire against ice.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief item in the Finance/ New Issues listing of Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the number of shares in a proposed stock offering by the American Can Company. It is two million shares.

title: Technology to China
description: The Pentagon says that it is reviewing its regulations on the transfer of technology in line with President Reagan's directive calling for a more liberal approach to trade with China.

title: GTE Takeover Hits Snag
description: A Federal judge ordered the GTE Corporation today to explain how it proposed to consummate its purchase of the long-distance telephone and satellite subsidiaries of the Southern Pacific Company.

title: TV: 'VANISHING AMERICA,' THE FAMILY FARM
description: The American farmer is in economic difficulty. In fact, it sometimes seems that the American farmer has been in economic difficulty for most of the life of the republic. Consequently, ''Vanishing America,'' an ABC documentary, is not up to anything particularly new when it restates the farmer's case, although in its restatement there is considerable lyricism. The documentary, a proper blending of style and substance, will be seen tomorrow at 7 P.M.

title: POP SINGER: ELLIOT MURPHY
description: Elliot Murphy, the talented folk-oriented singer and songwriter from Long Island, is still trying to live down the ''new Bob Dylan'' label that was pinned on him by some overzealous rock critics in the mid-1970's. A suburban social commentator whose songs blend rock lore and literary mythology, Mr. Murphy was recorded and abandoned by three record companies before his talent had a chance to blossom.

title: Around the World; Classroom Gun Rampage Leaves 6 Germans Dead
description: A man waving two pistols burst into a classroom of sixth-graders today and sprayed bullets around the room, killing three children, their teacher and a policeman before killing himself.

title: PANEL QUESTIONS EMBRYO RESEARCH
description: A special committee of scientists convened by Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Me., has recommended that Dr. Karl Illmensee and Dr. Peter C. Hoppe repeat some of their widely publicized experiments with mouse embryos to confirm the legitimacy of the original findings.

title: CBS SLANDER CASE GOES TO JURY IN LOS ANGELES
description: The monthlong trial involving a doctor who sued Dan Rather and CBS for slander over a segment of ''60 Minutes'' that linked him to insurance fraud went to the jury today.

title: 20th-Century Music Bill
description: Scott Wiley, guitarist, and Michael Chang, tenor, will present a program of 20th-century music composed for voice and guitar tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Abraham Goodman House. Tickets cost $8; the box office number is 362-8719.

title: GRADUATIONS HELD AT THREE SCHOOLS
description: Bill Blass, the designer, told the graduating students of the Fashion Institute of Technology yesterday that they had chosen their careers well. ''The fashion industry has never been better,'' Mr. Blass said at the school's commencement, at Radio City Music Hall.

title: WOOING THE BUSINESS FLIER
description: When Alan S. Haisser stepped off a recent Air One flight from St. Louis to Newark, he was a satisfied customer. He had eaten well, he said, and he had been comfortable in a wide leather seat. ''They're trying very hard,'' he said of the new airline's service.

title: 1,500 POLICEMEN STAGE PROTESTS IN STREETS OF PARIS
description: About 1,500 policemen protested in the streets here today against what they said was laxity on crime on the part of Government officials.

title:
PATENTS;
Static Discharge Unit Prevents Copier Jams
description: A static discharge device invented by a staff member at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., has proved of value to operators of copying machines.

title: Ford Shelves Plans For Portugal Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had shelved plans for a $1 billion assembly plant in Portugal because of slow growth in car sales in Europe.

title: LIBRARY STILL FIGHTING FOR STRAVINSKY PAPERS
description: Although a 30-day deadline to match an offer by a Swiss collector expired last Saturday, the New York Public Library is still trying to find an angel or two, with a million or two, to insure that the Igor Stravinsky archives remain in the library's performing arts branch at Lincoln Center.

title: Oh My!  Key Lime Pie
description: The reason you haven't heard from me until now about the Williamsburg summit conference is that when they told me it was to be held in Colonial Williamsburg I decided to cover it Colonial style.

title: Norstar's Maine Bank
description: Norstar Bancorp, a bank holding company based in Albany, has acquired Northeast Bank Shares Association of Portland, Me. for $86 million.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article and a map Wednesday describing the nation's weather inaccurately detailed the amount of rain in the United States this spring.

title: MEG CORROON WEDS T.I. SHERIDAN 3D
description: Margaret V. Corroon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Corroon of New York, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Thomas I. Sheridan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheridan Jr. of New York and Windham, N.Y. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: GOVERNOR'S PLAN FOR THE M.T.A. MEETS CRITICISM
description: Key portions of Governor Cuomo's plan to give the Governor control of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority were criticized yesterday by both Mayor Koch and the agency's chairman, Richard Ravitch.

title: Briefing
description: Option Play for Dawkins?

title: Gulf Oil Sues Tenneco Inc.
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has filed suit against Tenneco Inc., saying it would suffer more than $100 million in damages if long-term natural gas contracts were broken.

title: Judge Loses Wallet To Fake Policeman
description: A man posing as a police officer grabbed a wallet out of the hands of a Criminal Court judge as the judge sat in his car in midtown yesterday, the police said. The thief escaped after commandering a taxicab at knifepoint.

title: CAMPAIGNING IN BRITAIN: NO FRILLS AND NO GLAMOUR, JUST $6,633.72
description: At 7:50 this morning Keith Best, the Member of Parliament for Ynys Mon, was sitting in shirt-sleeves at the kitchen table in his modest row house at Holyhead in northwestern Wales, painstakingly cutting out newspaper articles about himself for reproduction in his final campaign broadside.

title: DISPUTE; News Analysis
description: Industry and Government specialists were withholding judgment yesterday on just what caused the fire Thursday aboard an Air Canada DC-9 that claimed 23 lives. They tended to agree, however, that the accident would, and should, lead to a thorough reassessment of what the Federal Aviation Administration has been doing to minimize the chances of such disasters. The issue has been a point of contention for a number of years.

title: Around the World; Lebanon Starts Effort To Gain Arab Backing
description: The Lebanese Government began new efforts today to gain backing from Arab countries in trying to persuade Syria to withdraw its troops from Lebanon.

title: 'TOO CLOSE' AND 'FAME' GET NEW LIFE
description: Two prime-time series canceled by ABC and NBC this spring are expected to return on ad hoc networks of independent and networkaffiliated stations next fall, the producers of the shows have announced.

title: SPERRY PLANS TO BUY 15% OF TRILOGY LTD.
description: The Sperry Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a 15 percent equity interest in Trilogy Ltd., a Cupertino, Calif., computer company formed by Gene M. Amdahl and his son, Carlton, to develop powerful computers using advanced semiconductor technology.

title: Your Money; Bank-Backed Bond Funds
description: THE large number of categories of unit trusts being sold to individuals became even larger this year with the introduction of a new kind: bank-guaranteed bond funds.

title: Peter Gibbons, a Camerman And Special-Effects Inventor
description: Peter Gibbons, a Hollywood cameraman, teacher and special-effects inventor, died in Santa Monica, Calif., on May 27. He was 70 years old.

title: REAGAN SAYS WOMEN HAVE KEY ROLE
description: President Reagan, in an attempt to bolster his political standing with women, is insisting that his Administration involves the leadership of women ''in a more significant way than any other before it.''

title: Non-Linear Shows New Computer
description: Non-Linear Systems, which manufactures Kaypro transportable computers, announced a new model and cut the price on its Kaypro II computer.

title: NATIONWIDE BANKING: BARRIERS FALL
description: Nationwide banking is quickly becoming a reality for American consumers. The latest wrinkle has been efforts by major banks in New York and California to solicit deposits from individuals across the country through advertising and mail campaigns.

title: 3 KILLED IN ARKANSAS FIGHT BELIEVED TO INVOLVE FUGITIVE
description: Gordon W. Kahl, a fugitive tax protester wanted in the slayings of two United States marshals in North Dakota, was believed killed tonight in a gun battle with lawenforcement officers in the hills of northern Arkansas, the authorities said.

title: Trump For Mayor
description: It was only a small item in the paper. About a year ago. And then a small follow-up item last Sunday. They were so unremarkable in size that you probably missed them both. But they contained stunning news.

title: MEDICAL DETECTIVES HUNT CLUES TO AIDS OUTBREAK
description: Late on the afternoon of Friday, May 13, a phone rang in Dr. Polly Thomas's cubicle on the third floor of Department of Health headquarters. A nurse was calling to say that three days earlier a 26-year-old New York City sanitation worker, a father of three, had been hospitalized, suffering from a severe lung infection linked to Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome.

title: Danish North Sea Find
description: Indications of hydrocarbons have been found in a Danish North Sea region, a spokesman for the Danish Underground Consortium said today. The section is near Denmark's Gorm oil and gas field, which went into operation in mid-1982 and has estimated oil reserves of 100 million tons, the spokesman said.

title:
PATENTS;
Two Bell Improvements In Light-Wave Systems
description: Two inventions in light-wave communications, in which pulses of light carry information through glass fibers, were patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. The inventions are expected to make light-wave communications more reliable and efficient.

title: CAR STEREO THEFT: SYMPTOM OF URBAN MALAISE
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S BELEAGUERED LEADER DENOUNCES PARTY'S INFIGHTING
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski has conceded the existence of a bitter behind-the-scenes power struggle within Poland's ruling Communist Party.

title: POLITICAL VIOLENCE ALARMS ARGENTINA
description: Extremist underground groups have been stirring unease here in recent months by resorting to a growing number of threats, beatings and, in some cases, killings.

title: NEW LAW SIGNED TO EXTEND TERM IN VIOLENT CRIME
description: Governor Cuomo has signed into law a bill that allows judges to sentence people who commit a series of violent crimes to up to 50 years in prison.

title: NEW YORK'S JOBLESS AND JOB RATES BOTH DOWN
description: Unemployment rates in New York City, New York State and New Jersey fell in May, but the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday that the drop did not indicate new strength in the local job market.

title: AIR FORCE TRIBUNAL STRIKES DOWN MILITARY DEATH PENALTY PROVISION
description: The highest court in the Air Force held today that ''the military system for imposing the death penalty'' for premeditated murder was unconstitutional.

title: SMOKING AT OFFICE RESTRICTED BY A NEW SAN FRANCISCO LAW
