description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein today signed into law a city ordinance to regulate ''smoking in the office workplace.'' She said it could lead to a prohibition of smoking in some offices, including her own.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The City Reaches Out

title: BRIEFS
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc. and Southern Banks of Florida Inc. announced an agreement to merge Southern, owner of High Springs Bank in Alachua County, into Barnett. High Springs has assets of $43 million; Barnett has 236 offices statewide and consolidated assets in excess of $8 billion.

title: LATE MAY CAR SALES ROSE 17.7%
description: The nation's three largest auto makers reported today that their sales for the final third of May jumped 17.7 percent from a strong period last year.

title: U.S. Warns American Air
description: The Justice Department has warned American Airlines that the Government would ''closely scrutinize for possible antitrust violations'' any attempt to buy the remainder of Braniff International's planes, the airline confirmed today.

title: WEIR TAKES HAMMER THROW
description: Robert Weir started Southern Methodist off in its bid for a team title at the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships today with a meet record in the hammer throw. Meanwhile, Oregon's Dean Crouser and Joaquim Cruz produced meet records in the men's events.

title: Joy Manufacturing
description: The Joy Manufacturing Company announced that it would permanently close its Wheeling, W.Va. couplings and fittings plant on Sept. 3 because of low market demand, depressed priced levels and ''uncompetitive labor costs,'' and said that about 160 employees would be affected. Joy said it would continue to supply couplings and fittings from its other manufacturing plants.

title: A Primary Interest in New Jersey
description: New Jersey's drivers pay the highest automobile insurance premiums in the nation, or, like 300,000 of them, violate the law that requires coverage. The reason for the high rates is that the state lacks a sensible no-fault system to guard against excessive damage awards. The Legislature debated a reform for more than six years, but has done nothing except create a more sensible plan for insuring high-risk drivers.

title: BRITAIN'S AILING WOOLWORTH MAPS SHIFT
description: Britain's Woolworth, once a flourishing discount chain, has fallen victim to changing customer tastes. With more money in their pockets, Woolworth's customers - no longer the hard-pressed, bargain-hungry workers of years past - have been turning in droves to stores selling better quality goods at competitive prices.

title: HONDURAS SAID TO SEEK LARGER U.S. ROLE
description: The chief of the Honduran military is scheduled to visit Washington next week for talks with the Reagan Administration that will include discussions about a larger American military role in his nation, Defense Department officials said today.

title: State Strengthens Ban On Nude Sunbathing
description: New York is banning nude sunbathing at beaches and other public places. Sunning without a bathing suit is already illegal, if sometimes tolerated, in most jurisdictions and banned under state parks regulations.

title: Texas Advances
description: OMAHA (AP) - Texas used an eight-run eighth inning, a record-tying performance from Mike Trent and the pitching of Calvin Schiraldi to defeat James Madison, 12-0, in the first-round of the College World Series. Schiraldi (13-3) tossed a five-hitter and struck out five to advance Texas into Monday night's winners'-bracket game against Oklahoma State, which later beat Stanford, 3-1.

title: Head of TV Concern Was Among Victims
description: George Curtis Mathes Jr., who personally marketed his television sets in commercials as the most expensive but ''darn well worth it,'' was among those killed Thursday in the fire aboard Air Canada's Flight 797 at the Greater Cincinnati Airport.

title: REOPENING OF BREWERY LIFTS HOPES
description: There is no place to buy a loaf of bread in this gardenlike community 13 miles northwest of Syracuse. There are no schools. There is no post office. There is plenty of beer.

title: HOWARD NAMES
description: George Bamberger resigned as manager of the Mets today, saying ''I probably suffered enough.'' He was replaced by his first-base coach, Frank Howard.

title: MOSCOW DEFENDS MONGOLIA ON REPATRIATION OF CHINESE
description: A report published today by Tass, the Soviet press agency, said Mongolia had forcibly repatriated some Chinese residents to China.

title: CAR STERO THEFT: SYMPTOM OF URBAN MALAISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorists Warned Of a Traffic Jam
description: The specter of a gridlock prompted the city's Police Department to issue a special traffic advisory yesterday to motorists to avoid the vicinity of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park between 10 A.M. and 8 P.M. during the Queens Festival there today and tomorrow.

title: Coral Petroleum's Chapter 11 Filing
description: Coral Petroleum Inc. filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Burnett Guffey Is Dead at 78; Cameraman Won Two Oscars
description: Burnett Guffey, who won two Academy Awards for cinematography in ''From Here to Eternity'' and ''Bonnie and Clyde,'' is dead at the age of 78.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on May 13 incorrectly reported the importance of tourism in Israel's foreign exchange earnings. It accounts for 8 percent of them.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 39. 1. A leading expert on chemical and biological warfare thinks ''yellow rain,'' a substance the United States contends is being sprayed as a toxic weapon by Communist planes in Southeast Asia, may actually be another substance, of which a microscopic sample is pictured above. What substance is it, and what was the U.S. Government's response?

title: Ryder Systems
description: Ryder Systems Inc., which provides highway transportation, distribution and business services in the United States, Canada and Britain, announced it had sold all its holdings in Frank B. Hall & Company in a single block at $31 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. It had been acquiring Hall shares for several years and had more than a million shares. Hall, which had sued to stop Ryder acquiring its shares and had acquired Jartran, a truck rental company, last year in an apparent effort to block Ryder from acquiring more shares, said it had no comment on the sale.

title: DEREGULATION: A PUZZLE FOR CONSUMERS
description: Ten years ago a traveler who wanted to fly from New York to Los Angeles could choose from among six airline fares. Today he is confronted with more than 200.

title: McDonnell Deal
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation won a $633.9 million Navy contract for 79 F/A-18 fighter aircraft and 5 F/ A-18 trainer aircraft, the Defense Department said.

title: NETS REBUFFED ON ALBECK BID
description: The Nets, who are trying to hire Coach Stan Albeck away from the Spurs, lost a round in a San Antonio courtroom yesterday but said they planned to pursue further litigation in New York.

title:
PATENTS;
A Method of Blocking Corrosion in Uranium
description: A method of producing corrosion-proof uranium has been invented in the Union Carbide Corporation's nuclear division at Oak Ridge, Tenn.

title: Around the World; Dubai Bans Fish Imports Because of Oil Slick
description: The United Arab Emirate of Dubai banned fish imports from other Persian Gulf countries today, saying it had found evidence the fish were contaminated by oil leaking from Iran's war-damaged Nowruz offshore field.

title: ARGENTINA TO RESUME INTEREST PAYMENTS
description: The Argentine Government has agreed to resume payment of interest on $20 billion of public sector foreign debt, Ulbaldo Aguirre, director of Argentina's central bank, said yesterday. The payments, which are scheduled to begin this month, had been suspended for nearly a year.

title: Sports People; Jet Choice Goes West
description: Yesterday, less than a month after the Jets' sixth-round choice, Vincent White, a running back-wide receiver from Stanford, defected to the Denver Gold of the United States Football League, the club lost an even better pass-catching prospect to the new league. Jojo Townsell, the U.C.L.A. wide receiver who had been the Jets' thirdround selection, signed a multiyear contract with the Los Angeles Express.

title: View on Money Supply
description: Lyle Gramley, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that he would be concerned if the recent rapid growth in the United States money supply continued as the economic recovery proceeded.

title: SALVADOR PHOTOS INDICATE MASSACRE
description: United States military officials displayed photographs here today to support their statements that up to 42 Salvadoran soldiers were put to death May 25 after surrendering to a guerrilla force in the central province of San Vicente.

title: HUNTING FOR LESSONS IN JAPAN
description: The drive by American corporations to improve the quality of their products and increase the productivity of their factories at times resembles some odd religion.

title: THEATER: 'HANDLEBARS,' A VIEW OF PUBLIC ISSUES
description: Plastered on the front of Douglass Watson's desk is a painting of the historic Bread and Roses strike in Lawrence, Mass. That rebellion sets the scene for Leslie Weiner's ''Upside-Down on the Handlebars,'' a play about workers' rights, corporate greed and academic freedom. Mr. Watson is playing an overburdened associate professor of labor studies at a New Jersey college, and in the course of the play he is called upon to practice what he teaches.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: ROOKIE BLANKS YANKEES
description: Fortified with healthful food, the Yankees nevertheless had trouble last night with the pitches by a rookie left-hander who credited his effectiveness to a psychologist.

title: Around the Nation; Thornburgh Asks U.S. To Stall Reactor Startup
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh has asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to postpone restarting the undamaged nuclear reactor at Three Mile Island until he is satisfied that it is safe.

title: RATES UP
description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday a modest $400 million decline in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended May 25, but that did not still fears in the credit markets of a rapid money supply growth, and short-term and long-term interest rates rose slightly.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pen Pals in the Park

title: Wilson Foods Strike Voted
description: Union meatpackers for the Wilson Foods Corporation, the nation's largest processor of fresh pork, voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike beginning at 12:01 A.M. Saturday, the United Food and Commercial Workers Union said today.

title: Slowdown In Germany
description: The West German Government reported a drop in economic activity and a rise in unemployment today, dealing a setback to the nation's hopes for recovery.

title: IN THE IRONBOUND AREA, MANY ANGRY QUESTIONS
description: It's not just the discovery of dioxin contamination at the old Diamond Alkali Company property that bothers residents of the Ironbound section, this city's industrial area.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 4, 1983; The Economy
description: New-car sales by the Big Three auto makers rose 17.7 percent during the final selling days of May. This brought the industry's annual selling rate for the month to seven million vehicles, the highest in nearly two years. Analysts welcomed the increase as a ''breakthrough'' to a ''new plateau,'' indicating that full recovery might be under way. Chrysler's sales were up 38.9 percent in the period, while Ford's rose 22.2 percent and G.M.'s 12.5 percent. (Page 29.)

title: HIGH PRAISE FOR FLIGHT CREW IN JETLINER FIRE FATAL TO 23
description: When Air Canada Flight 797 came to a smoldering halt at the Cincinnati airport, Graham Wright clutched his thrice-folded jacket to his face, dropped to the floor and crawled on his knees through black smoke ''to a small spot of light.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think I always felt we were going to make it.

title: Around the World; Hanoi Leaving I.L.O.  For an Indefinite Time
description: Vietnam notified the International Labor Organization today that it was ''temporarily'' leaving the United Nations agency for an indefinite period.

title: Baseball
description: John Shelby, a pinch-hitter, drew a bases-loaded walk on a full-count pitch from Joey McLaughlin with one out in the ninth inning, forcing in the winning run as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-2, tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Camera Shy in Court House

title: Auto Layoffs Up Slightly
description: Additional layoffs at the Ford Motor Company and callbacks at the Chrysler Corporation left 208,150 American auto workers on indefinite furlough this week, up 300 from last week's level, the nation's auto makers reported on Thursday.

title: GAMBLING ON THE RUSSIAN RESPONSE TO MX MISSILE
description: A Senate committee was taking testimony recently on the MX missile, and James R. Schlesinger, the former Secretary of Defense, was at the witness table. The issue was whether the weapon was necessary to deter nuclear war.

title: VOLCKER LINKS STABILITY OF U.S. TO DEBT SOLUTION
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board warned yesterday that the financial stability of the United States - not only in 1983 but in years to come - could hinge on satisfactory handling of the crisis in international debts.

title: U.S. JOBLESS RATE DECLINES SLIGHTLY A 3D MONTH, TO 10%
description: The nation's unemployment rate fell slightly in May to 10 percent from 10.1 percent as employment increased and the size of the labor force was unchanged, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SaturdaySports
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 2 P.M., live, and 8 P.M., tape. Radio - WABC, 770; 2 P.M.) Mets vs.

title: Consumer Saturday; ADVICE ON HIRING CATERERS
description: BECAUSE summer is a traditional season for weddings, family r eunions and other celebrations, New York City's Department of C onsumer Affairs is reminding those who may be planning parties o utside their homes to be careful of services they hire.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Bars Milk Support Paid by the Farmers
description: A Federal district judge ordered the United States Department of Agriculture today to stop making dairy farmers help finance milk price supports and to return to them more than $21 million that had been collected.

title: DOROTHY FOX CROSSLEY
description: Dorothy Fox Crossley, co-founder of the Crossley public opinion poll in the 1930's, died May 28 in Princeton, N.J., where she had lived.

title: Princess Rooney Will Be Rested
description: Princess Rooney, the 3-year-old filly who suffered her first defeat in 11 career starts when she finished a distant second to Ski Goggle in the Acorn Stakes last Saturday, may have a suffered a hairline fracture in her left knee and will not race again until next winter.

title: PUBLIC TV'S TIN CUP
description: Public broadcasting is an educational service, teaching more Americans each day than the nation's public schools, private schools, colleges and universities combined. As such, public television and radio are as worthy of full financial support from taxation as are the public schools. Yet, public broadcasting has become a charity case - complete with on-air telethons, premiums, direct-mail solicitations, auctions, sweepstakes and extended sponsorship credits.

title: Books of The Times; Medieval Mystery
description: THE NAME OF THE ROSE. By Umberto Eco. 502 pages. A Helen and Kurt Wolfe Book. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: JACKIE SIMPSON
description: Jackie Simpson, who was a star as a linebacker at the University of Mississippi and played in the American Football League in the early 1960's, died here last night.

title: The Everest Excuse
description: As of now the best that can be said about the recent creation of an eight-cell human embryo from an unfertilized egg is that it gives new edge to that old saw, ''A woman without a man is like a fish without a bicycle.'' The British scientists responsible for this phenomenon, however, seem delighted.

title: Padres 8, Phillies 5
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Kurt Bevacqua's pinch-hit single with the bases loaded highlighted a a three-run eighth inning for San Diego. Steve Garvey and Terry Kennedy hit consecutive singles to lead off the eighth off Ed Farmer (0-3).

title: Scenic Gap Filled
description: To the Editor:

title: Game 12 Tabled
description: Southeastern Conference schools had been discussing the possibility of adding a 12th game to their football schedules, but yesterday the conference decided not to ask the National Collegiate Athletic Association for permission to do so. Instead, the league's executive committee decided to send the matter back to the coaches for further discussion.

title: ECLECTIC ISRAELIS
description: Habrira Hativ'it (''The Gathering''), an eclectic group from Israel that mixes Middle Eastern music with jazz, rock and folk traditions, will perform tonight at 8 at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenur (427-6000). Tickets are $10 and $12.

title:
PATENTS;
An Ozone Generator For Swimming Pools
description: An ozone generator for swimming pools was patented this week by Thomas D. McBride, an electrician in Westwood, N.J. He assigned patent 4,386,055 to Joan McBride, his wife.

title: METS TOP DODGERS, END 4-GAME SLIDE
description: With George Bamberger watching from the press box, and Frank Howard watching from the dugout in his first night as manager, the Mets ended a four-game losing streak tonight by defeating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2.

title: GRADUATIONS HELD AT THREE SCHOOLS
description: Long Island University's Brooklyn Center conferred degrees on 1,000 graduates yesterday, including the first in its new master of public administration program.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Clean and Sweet From Stem to Stern

title: Canada's Oil Reserves
description: Canada's crude-oil reserves have fallen for the 13th consecutive year and the country could face an oil shortage by the 1990's if exploration is not pressed, according to Ted Best, chairman of the Canadian Petroleum Association.

title: RUMANIA'S TARIFF STATUS WILL CONTINUE FOR A YEAR
description: President Reagan said today that he would extend most-favored-nation status to Rumania for another year because he had received assurances from President Nicolae Ceausescu promising to drop an ''educational tax'' on prospective Rumanian emigrants.

title: Baldwin Default Notice
description: One of the Baldwin-United Corporation's major creditor banks said yesterday that Baldwin was in default on the payment of part of $100 million worth of debentures.

title: Gun Law Post-Mortem
description: To the Editor:

title: 2D PLANT CALLED A POSSIBLE SITE OF JERSEY DIOXIN
description: New Jersey officials yesterday identified a second site that may be contaminated with dioxin and said nine chemical plants now in operation would also be investigated for the toxic compound.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ASIAN MUSIC

title: Soccer Officials In Perilous Role
description: Gus Constantine, who tests and licenses more than 500 soccer referees in New York State, was not surprised that Senio Figliozzi, a referee at a youth soccer tournament in New Rochelle, N.Y., was assaulted by two spectators last Sunday. Figliozzi, who reportedly was knocked unconscious, was released from New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center after he was treated for a scalp wound.

title: Transportation Aide to Quit
description: Arthur Teele Jr., one of the highestranking black officials in the Reagan Administration, intends to resign from his post as administrator of the Transportation Department's Urban Mass Transit Administration, his press aide said today.

title: 'VESTIBUL SCHOOLS' FOR THE DISRUPTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: TIME TO STRUT TO THE LATEST ALBUMS
description: My favorite summer dance is a rather balletic maneuver that involves reclining in a lounge chair while, with my right hand, raising a tall cool drink. Apparently I'm in a minority, because since summer brings parties, it also triggers the release of albums designed for more strenuous dancing, records that do their best to hit a groove and stay there. While some dance records barely last through a season, the latest rhythms are tested on the dance floor, and those that survive are likely to show up soon afterwards all over pop. A sampling of current dance albums suggests two paradoxical directions for the beat - one minimal, one exotic.

title: Shopper's World; BELGIAN LACE:, AN ENDURING FINERY
description: A thin shaft of sunlight comes through the living room window of a modest cottage in the Belgian village of Nieuwerkerken. By its light, an 80-year-old woman, toothless and with swollen ankles, applies herself to the painstaking and ancient task of lacemaking.

title: EGGPLANT: FROM KEBABS TO PASTA TO A GRILLING
description: THE eggplant, one of our most beautiful vegetables, is commercially available in several varieties. In addition to the familiar large, shiny, purple eggplants, suitable for slicing and frying or for stuffing and baking, there are their smaller cousins, not more than two inches wide at the thickest part, with skins that are almost black. In Korean and Chinese markets you can find long, thin pale mauve eggplants with a sweet flavor and thin tender skin. And soon we can expect to see white-skinned eggplants. These are as big as the common black-skinned variety, but have especially delicate taste and no bitterness.

title: 10 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 10 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named three that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and five that were closed for failing to do so.

title: MAN DEAD IN GUNFIGHT IDENTIFIED AS DAKOTA FUGITIVE
description: Gordon W. Kahl, the radical fugitive tax protester from North Dakota who was wanted for the murders of two United States marshals, vowed he would not be taken alive.

title: PROGRAM AIDS PROBLEM GAMBLERS
description: FOR George, a 26-year-old salesman from Middletown, it began innocently in high school with $1 and a slip of paper that furtively advertised, ''For Points Only.'' It ended on April 3, 1982 when he bet the New York Rangers to win, and lost.

title: Around the World; French Police Union Condemns Paris Protests
description: The union representing the majority of French police officers today condemned as ''undignified'' a series of demonstrations by thousands of officers protesting what they view as laxness in the judicial system.

title: Business Forum; AND A CRITIQUE FROM CARNEGIE-MELLON
description: EVERYONE recognizes that American manufacturers are in serious trouble because of i nternational competition. Many explanations are given -particularly t he role of government subsidies for foreign companies - but the u npleasant fact is that imports, especially in steel and automobiles,h ave been gaining a larger and larger share of the American market a nd we seem hard-pressed to stop the trend.

title: WHERE DID THE LILAC GO?
description: AS I toured our neighborhood recently as I am wont to do each year in spring, I thought wistfully of our Brooklyn backyard - a postagestamp plot on which my father managed to raise iris and roses, hydrangea, lilac and, of course, the borough flower, forsythia. Even tomatoes flourished there, allotted an infintesimal amount of space within which they respectfully grew, understanding, it seemed, that my father could afford nothing larger for them.

title: INDIANS WIN 10-YEAR BATTLE OVER SACRED SITE
description: Because she is in her 80's and cannot make her way up the steep mountain path, Lowana Brantner no longer visits the sacred area known to her tribe as ''the high country.'' But, according to her lawyer, she ''uses'' the area daily by calling upon its power in her prayers.

title: CAPPY P. GREENSPAN
description: Cappy Petrash Greenspan, an Emmy Award-winning television producer, died of cancer Friday at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 51 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CASINO UNION HELD UNLIKELY
description: THE swift collapse of the country's first strike of gambling-casino dealers means that it may be a long time before unions try again to organize this key segment of employees, casino and union spokesmen said last week.

title: PROMISE AND PROBLEMS GATHER AT THE FRONTIERS OF AUDIO
description: As the fountainhead of the laser techniques now changing the face of phonography, the Dutch province of Brabant is keeping up its long musical tradition. The setting seems incongruous for such futuristic developments, for the steeples rising above wooded plains still look the way Ruysdael painted them, and the musical links date back even farther to the days of Ockeghem and the other polyphonists of the Lowlands who, by adding extra voices to the austerities of plainchant, invented harmony in the Middle Ages. Later, Richard Wagner chose Brabant as the setting for Lohengrin, which fostered the mistaken idea that swans are the usual means of transportation in those parts.

title: What's New in Lobbying; THE CANADIAN CONNECTION
description: In the past year, as the recession lingered and as protectionist forces grew in Congress, a vigorous new lobbying effort has emerged from an unlikely source: Canada.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: HARING AT WADSWORTH

title: Dr. James Auran, Elizabeth Cascella Wed in New York
description: Elizabeth Anne Cascella, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Cascella of New York and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. James Drake Auran, son of Mrs. Richard W. Auran of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Minneapolis, and the late Mr. Auran. The Rev. Victor R. Yanitelli, Episcopal Vicar of East Manhattan, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where he is the pastor.

title: TRICENTENNIAL SHOW TO MAKE ITS DEBUT
description: ARNOLD GAMSON, the supervisor of performing arts for the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, is a bit nervous today: The Traveling Tricentennial Show, a musical revue with 12 songs he composed, makes its debut at the Tricentennial Festival at the County Airport.

title: JAZZ GROUP: PARED VERSION OF A BIG BAND
description: In these cost-cutting days, a nine-piece jazz ensemble can be a viable alternative to a 12- to 14-piece big band because it allows for the traditional big-band essentials - a brass section, a reed section and a rhythm section. Despite this, however, the current tendency is to go to extremes - to stay within a ''practical'' fouror five-piece limit or occasionally to take the plunge with a fullsized big band.

title: UTAH SCENE: FLOWERS BLOOM AMID SLUSH
description: From their small house on Main Street, James and Bonnie Hadlow watched the Wasatch Mountains try to cover the town with a cold gray ooze.

title: ON ICAHN
description: To the Business Editor:

title: STATE, CITING GAP IN LAW, SAYS IT WON'T REPAY REPEALED TAX
description: New York State has belatedly refunded part of $9 million in realestate taxes that it acknowledges it has no claim to, but state officials say that a gap in state law leaves them without authority to repay the rest of the money unless the taxpayers sue.

title: ATONING FOR AN ACT OF MERCY
description: KILLDEER MOUNTAIN, By Dee Brown. 279 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $14.95.

title: ILLEGAL DUMPING OF TOXINS LAID TO ORGANIZED CRIME
description: The following article is based on reporting by Ralph Blumenthal and Ben A. Franklin and was written by Mr. Blumenthal.

title: YOUTH ORCHESTRA A HIT ABROAD
description: THE New Jersey Youth Symphony has returned in triumph from its first European tour, during which it won first prize, cum laude, at the 31st European Music Festival for Youth in Neerpelt, Belgium.

title: CONCERN IS GROWING OVER USE OF LASIX
description: Can a drug so apparently straightforward that doctors routinely prescribe it for overweight people be affecting the outcome of thoroughbred horse races around the country? According to recent veterinary research, the drug - furosemide, better known as Lasix - prevents water-weight buildup in people but also seems to make horses run faster. Even more baffling, no one is sure just why that is.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: WHOSE LITTLE BOY ARE YOU? A Memoir of the Broun Family. By Heywood Hale Broun. Illustrated. 215 pp. New York: Marek/St. Martin's Press. $14.95.

title: Victoria A. Davis To Marry Nov. 19
description: Barbara E. Davis of Lake Luzerne, N.Y., and Rexford A. Davis of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria Allison Davis, to Donald Scott McCullough, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert McCullough of Riverside, Conn. A Nov. 19 wedding is planned.

title: An Opening on Afghanistan?
description: It could be wishful thinking, but Pakistan President Zia ul-Haq said last week that Moscow may be ready for a troop withdrawal settlement in Afghanistan. And a United Nations intermediary in Geneva has obtained agreement from Pakistan and Afghanistan on most provisions of a 20-page withdrawal agreement, according to an article in Foreign Policy magazine.

title: EXECUTIVE OF UTILITY TAKES A MOVIE ROLE
description: ''MICHAEL O'BRIEN, you have committed the crimes of an adult but the law protects you ...''

title: Jane B. Rosenthal Is Wed in Capital To Robert Cafritz
description: Jane Blair Rosenthal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Michael Rosenthal of Washington and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Conrad Cafritz, son of Mrs. Laughlin Phillips of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Conrad Cafritz of Washington.

title: PEKING IS PUZZLED BY MONGOLIA MOVE
description: There is puzzlement here over why Mongolia has apparently moved forcibly to relocate or expel hundreds of Chinese nationals who had lived amicably for years in Ulan Bator, the Mongolian capital.

title: State Aide Questions Bond-Rating Findings
description: In an Opinion Page article on May 15, Prof. Ken Harrison of Stockton State College claimed that his research had proved that bond ratings did not bear a systematic relationship to interest costs.

title: Ruminations: Fishing Options
description: HAVING been as improvident as a grasshopper - although somewhat more industrious - in failing to accumulate worldly goods, I was filled with regret by a letter from Land Vest Inc. of Boston informing me that Castle Hyde in Ireland's County Cork is for sale.

title: Robert Hardy Married To Diana Lucile Dodds
description: Diana Lucile Dodds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Wegner Dodds of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Robert Sayre Hardy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald S. Hardy of Chestnut Hill, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: No Headline
description: Frank Howard, in his first full day as the 10th manager of the Mets, conceded today that the Mets needed help because ''we can't go on the way we've been going.'' But neither he nor his bosses offered an immediate plan to rescue the new manager from the old problems he had inherited from George Bamberger.

title: IN DEFENSE OF AMERICA'S PUBLIC SCHOOLS
description: SOME weeks ago, the National Commission on Excellence in Education released a report that screamed out about the mediocrity and failure of American public education. Things are so bad, the report said, that our nation would have gone to war if our current educational malaise had been a consequence of an act of a foreign power.

title: Recovery Displays A Growing Vigor
description: Rosy statistics underscored an economy growing more vigorous. The index of leading economic indicators, designed to foretell economic activity, rose a substantial 1.1 percent in April - the 10th consecutive monthly increase. Economists hailed the rise.There was more good news. Unemployment for the nation's civilians edged down to 10.1 percent in May - the third consecutive monthly decline. According to the Government, some 99,000 people found jobs in an improving labor market. May's jobless rate was just one-tenth of a percentage point below the April level but was the best monthly showing since a 9.9 percent unemployment rate last August. By December, joblessness had reached 10.8 percent and more than 12 million people were out of work.

title: WORKSHOPS OFFERED FOR SUMMER STUDY
description: OPPORTUNITIES to develop technical and professional craft skills will be widely available in New Jersey this summer. In most places, short-term workshops and specialized approaches are being offered, along with regular courses in basic techniques.

title: Julia T. Schuster To Marry in Fall
description: Virginia Schuster of Reisterstown, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Julia Temple Schuster, to Andrew Davis Klingenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Klingenstein of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is to be in October.

title: Gaylord Edges Vidmar As All-Round Gymnast
description: Mitch Gaylord emerged from close competition with Peter Vidmar in the men's optional phase to win the all-round championship today in the McDonald's men's and women's gymnastics championships.

title: CHANTILLY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHOOSING A CAREER IN MOTHERHOOD
description: ''DID you find it hard to leave your baby?'' asked Christina Kantrowitz. ''Very hard,'' said Susan Wilkes, recalling a recent holiday to the island of Jamaica, where she thought about her 3-month-old son, Jesse, ''at least six times a day.''

title: DANCE: 'COLD STEAL,' A PARODY
description: ''A Dance Farce'' is what Barbara Allen subtitled ''Cold Steal,'' the work she presented Friday night in the Danspace of St. Mark's Church. Yet this choreographic narrative was not so much a farce as a deadpan parody of a detective story. With a jazz score by Stephan Wischerth and a text by Lizzie Olesker that was read in a laconic manner by Eric Bogosian, the action could have been taken from a novel by Raymond Chandler.

title: CHILDREN HAVE A VOICE IN PEGGY CHARREN
description: ''Why can't children's television be more like a good children's library, with lots of diversity, and less like the comic-book rack in the local drugstore?'' Peggy Charren asks the question with the confidence of a prosecuting attorney who knows she has a good case. Yet, it is a question she has been asking, without much satisfaction, since 1968 when she first posed it to a small group of concerned mothers who had gathered in the living room of her Newton Centre, Mass., home to form Action for Children's Television (ACT).

title: Herod's Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAGUE FACES THE QUESTION OF BALANCING ATHLETE RIGHTS
description: Chet Simmons, commissioner of the United States Football League, testified in hearings last month before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the Collegiate Student-Athlete Protection Act of 1983. The bill would allow professional sports leagues to adopt a ban on signing college underclassmen with no threat of a suit by a college player wanting to turn pro. The following article has been excerpted from Simmons's testimony.

title: STUDIO TOUR TO AID ART CENTER
description: CRAFTSMEN do not usually allow the public the run of their studios. It is distracting and detrimental to the creative processes. Next Sunday, though, one potter, two weavers and two jewelry designers, all residents of Fairfield County, will surrender their privacy and hold open houses from 11:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. The incentive is to raise funds for an institution with which they are all involved, the Silvermine Guild Center for the Arts in New Canaan.

title: Mitchell Wins in 400 For 3d Schoolboy Mark
description: Dennis Mitchell won the 400-meter run in 46.5 seconds today to give him his third record this weekend at the New Jersey high school track and field championships at Rutgers Stadium.

title: Ignorance of the Law
description: Sometimes, as a Dickens character put it, the law is indeed a ass.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 5, 1983
description: International

title: THE FORGOTTEN LAND IN SHOREHAM PLANS
description: BY road, they are more than 100 miles apart, but as the neutron flies, the coastline around New Haven is less than 20 miles from the new reactor that the Long Island Lighting Company is building at Shoreham, on the north shore of Long Island. Officials on both sides of Long Island Sound are now getting a quick refresher in geography over that point.

title: TAKING AS SUBJECT NOTHING MORE THAN SPACE AND LIGHT
description: In David Haxton's photographs, all the world's a stage. Or perhaps we should say that in his pictures the stage is all we see, since they refer not to the world of people and things, but to the theater of their own existence and the act of their making. By restricting himself to subject matter as mute, immaterial and elemental as space and light, Mr. Haxton fashions images of a splendid purity and isolation that sets them apart from most photography that has come to be called fabricated.

title: Margaret Prosser Is Married
description: Margaret Howland Prosser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. Woodward Prosser of Chatham, Mass., was married there yesterday to the Rev. David Bertles Stewart, associate pastor at Christ Church (Assemblies of God) in Washington. He is a son of Potter Stewart, former Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, and Mrs. Stewart of Washington and Sugar Hill, N.H. The Rev. Whitney H. Burr performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church.

title: Timothy John Leahy Wed To Nancy Anne Carpenter
description: Nancy Anne Carpenter, daughter of Mrs. Herman J. Schmidt of Greenwich, Conn., and B. Wayne Carpenter of Iowa City, was married yesterday to Timothy John Leahy, son of Marcella Leahy and John Leahy, both of Seattle.

title: Around the World; Turkey Tightens Curbs On Political Foes
description: Turkey's ruling generals today gave local martial law commanders the power to expel from their areas people they regard as a threat to national security or public order.

title: INDIAN POINT IS A BARGAIN BY SOME MEASURES AND A BUST BY OTHERS
description: EVEN if the Nuclear Regulatory Commission carried out its threat to close the two reactors at Indian Point this week because of flaws in emergency plans, the Westchester plants would go down as a bargain impossible to equal in an age of high interest rates and strict regulations. Not that many utilities seem likely to try. The nuclear industry is at a dead-end, at least in terms of new construction. No reactors have been ordered since 1978, and no work has been done on the two ordered that year. The 59 plants being built represent decisions made years ago, based on projections of construction costs and electric demand long since disproved.

title: A POP-SOCRATIC SURVEY OF DESPAIR
description: LOST IN THE COSMOS, The Last Self-Help Book. By Walker Percy. 262 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title:
STAMPS;
A TRIBUTE TO THE NATION'S TOP AWARD FOR VALOR
description: A commemorative for the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest military award for valor, is being issued this Tuesday in Washington, D.C. with a first-day ceremony at the Pentagon. The stamp is also a tribute to all those who have been awarded this medal.

title: CIRCUIT BREAKERS TRIPPED BEFORE FATAL JET FIRE
description: Electrical circuit breakers tripped in the rear lavatory area shortly before smoke and flames engulfed an Air Canada plane, killing 23 of the 46 people on board, an investigator said today.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ARTS JUBILEE
description: To kick off its annual June Arts Jubilee, the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts is starting at the beginning - with ''A Salute to Youth.'' From 1 to 5 P.M. today, the spacious lawns of the Roslyn Harbor estate will be alive with the sound of youngsters having fun as they romp through a series of multi-arts experiences. There will be a performance of the children's opera ''Little Red Riding Hood'' by Opera Options; a concert by the Western Concert Orchestra; interpretative nature hikes and slide shows, and ''art happenings'' that will invite participants to paint, draw, carve and design collages using materials supplied on the site. Everything is free, and the center is off Northern Boulevard.ART GOES OUTDOORS

title: Spain
description: To the Editor:

title: Tougher on Labor
description: It is one thing to be a Socialist and another to govern. That's what Mr. Papandreou seemed to be saying last week when he forced through Parliament a bill that would make strikes more difficult in state-controlled companies, which have been prone to stoppages.

title: Jane Huffman to Marry Hays Jones Jr.
description: Announcement has been made by Grace Ewing Huffman and Moore Peters Huffman, both of Woody Creek, Colo., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Ewing Huffman, to Hays Jones Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jones of Hamden, Conn.

title: A FRAGILE BALANCE BETWEEN TEACHERS AND THEIR PUPILS
description: IN MY decade of classroom work, I have met very few teachers who knew what the law required of them with respect to child abuse. In their graduate courses and at their endless faculty meetings, the issue is either ignored or dismissed as volatile. Either way, the vast majority of practicing teachers do not know what is expected of them.

title: OPEN REEL OFFERINGS EXPAND
description: Through all the hoopla that greeted the LP, then stereo, then highfidelity cassettes and, currently, the compact disk, one small but hardy band of music lovers and audiophiles has remained constant - the steadfast devotees of open-reel tape.

title: COMING OF AGE IN MAMARONECK
description: OPEN only three months, Mamaroneck's American Bistro, even in its nonage indicates that its coming of age is worth watching for. As the name suggests, the small, informal restaurant serves an Americanization of Continental cuisine. Much of its fresh food is cooked to order; in fact, everything except the bread is made here, and the enthusiastic chef, Mark Kaplan, expects to make that as soon as he and his co-owner, Nancy Gedney, who manages the dining room, settle in.

title: THE MORNING SHIFT AT BELMONT
description: THE bagels and cream cheese were not yet up from the commissary and the morning traffic was just starting to build on the Cross Island Parkway, but the morning shift was well under way at Belmont Park.

title: KEAN TOURS AREA NEAR DIOXIN SITE
description: Governor Kean toured the city's Ironbound section today and sought to assure residents that there was no evidence that dioxin contamination had spread beyond an abandoned chemical plant.

title: CAN WE CHANGE 'NEED' TO 'WANT' IN THE LYRICS?
description: A FEW years ago, a new song quickly shot to the top of the charts, earning a gold record for the artist who sang it. The tune could be hummed easily, even by those of us with tin ears, but it was the words that made a definite imprint on the minds of the listener. They preached a message that appealed to young and old alike and persisted in memory for years:

title: A MEDIEVAL TALE IS RELIVED ON FILM
description: ''In school, you learn silly things like, 'the Middle Ages means barbarism.' In my film, I tell a very modern story that happened to take place in the 16th century,'' said Daniel Vigne, director of ''The Return of Martin Guerre.'' Based on a famous love story and trial that inspired a play, two novels, an operetta, and a soon-tobe-published historical account, this award-winning French film opens Friday at the 68th Street Playhouse.

title: PATIO HOMES GAIN IN CLUSTER COMPLEXES
description: HOUSING, like fashion, has its fads and fancies. Several developers s ay the town house, which had been so popular for the last decade, isa bout to be surpassed by by the patio home, which combines the best f eatures of a single family house with the convenience of a town h ouse.

title: Exit Perturbed
description: Like many a veteran trouper, Zsa Zsa Gabor knows more than one way to stop a show.

title: IN SEARCH OF OLD-TIME COUNTRY MUSIC
description: The country music coming out of Nashville these days has strayed a long way from its cultural roots. Most of it goes better with brie than with barbecue. It has no place for the hillbilly twang, the haunting ballads of Appalachia or a 95-year-old banjo player from the Ozarks. Tuxedos and designer jeans have replaced the rhinestonestudded wardrobes of the stars, and orchestras increasingly are relegating the banjos, fiddles and mandolins to the bluegrass underground.

title: Jack Dempsey Buried On Long Island
description: The former heavyweight boxing champion Jack Dempsey was buried today, one mile from the beach he loved, following a private funeral service here.

title: RENTING IS A GOOD WAY TO TRY BEFORE YOU BUY
description: With camera prices as high as they are, dealers who also rent photographic equipment report a steady increase in the renting of high priced cameras and other equipment. Some customers rent because they are thinking of buying new equipment, but would like to try out that equipment before they spend a lot of money, while others rent when they need an expensive camera or other piece of equipment that is used only rarely.

title: The Great Hall Of the Nonpeople And Nonevents
description: New York City's Convention Center is expected to be the largest assembly hall in the Western Hemisphere - when it's finished. ''When,'' of course, is the problem, but one that the project's chief supervisor will no longer have to worry about. Robert M. Jacobs, the vice president in charge of construction for the state's Urban Development Corporation, went on a permanent vacation last week, relinquishing his $87,000-a-year post and joining nine other top officials of the U.D.C. who have resigned or been dismissed since the chairman, William J. Stern, took office in January. Arthur R. Bates, deputy executive director of the state's Dormitory Authority, was named to replace him.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TOTTENVILLE
description: TOTTENVILLE: It sounds as if it should have a trolley. The southernmost town in New York State does not, but it does have a train, the Staten Island Rapid Transit (known as the SIRT to l ocals), which covers the 14 miles from Tottenville to St. George in a bout 37 minutes and costs 75 cents to ride.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Quilts and Objects That Are Quilted

title: Arnoux Gets Pole In Detroit
description: Rene Arnoux, driving a Ferrari with a turbocharged V-6 engine, won the pole position for Sunday's Detroit Grand Prix, lapping the through-the-streets course at 83.869 miles per hour.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Princeton Justice
description: Gabrielle Napolitano, a 21-year-old senior at Princeton University, sued for her diploma last year after the school had found her guilty of plagiarism and ordered the diploma withheld for one year. She lost in two New Jersey courts, and she also lost a chance to go to law school.

title: Sylvia Ansourian Wed To a Financial Analyst
description: Sylvia Ansourian, daughter of Marie Ansourian of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Derek D. Kruizenga, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kruizenga of New York and Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arten Ashjian at St. Vartan's Armenian Cathedral in New York.

title: Night for Conigliaro
description: Tony Conigliaro Night at Fenway Park tomorrow is designed to raise money for the stricken former Red Sox slugger, but it could also provide inspiration to help speed his recovery from the series of ailments that have kept him hospitalized for 18 months. The night is shaping up as a reunion of Conigliaro's teammates on the 1967 Red Sox - the team that turned around from finishing 26 games back in 1966 to win the American League pennant on the final day of the season.

title: Dueling for Dollars Begins In the House
description: So far, the White House and Congress have been warring over the broad outlines of a spending and taxing plan for 1984. Last week, the House last week moved the battle onto a tougher field - the specifics.

title: SEAT BELT LAW FOR CHILDREN UP TO 10 PROPOSED
description: Children up to 10 years of age would be required to wear a seat belt every time they rode in a car under a bill working its way through the State Legislature.

title: OLDER SINGLES FOUND TO VALUE TRADITION
description: Suburban men and women who become single between the ages of 30 and 50 tend to remain conservative in their social and sexual habits, according to a just-completed survey of 1,100 singles in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. They do not, the survey found, suddenly lead a ''swinging'' permissive existence.

title: Scottish Nuclear Protesters Throw Eggs at Tory Minister
description: Demonstrators protesting the presence of nuclear weapons in Britain threw eggs and insults at Defense Minister Michael Heseltine today as he campaigned for Thursday's general election.

title: INTENTIONAL DISTORTION FOR UNUSUAL EFFECTS
description: Every photographer occasionally feels the urge to stray from the usual photographic approaches he or she has been following - to experiment and find new excitement when using a camera.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: HUMOR IN THE HOSPITAL
description: ALICE IN BED, By Cathleen Schine. 228 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: CITING HARDSHIP, RUDINS RELUCTANTLY TURN TO CO-OPS
description: UNTIL this spring, the Rudin family had never tried to sell to its t enants any of the 4,000 rental apartments it had bought or built in N ew York. Now, however, the Rudins are doing what owners of many o ther rental properties have done before them: They have presented a p reliminary plan to tenants at 2 Fifth Avenue, offering to convert t he building to cooperative ownership.

title: Borg Playing New Game
description: Bjorn Borg, who won the French Open six times, showed up today in an NBC blazer as a tennis commentator. He expressed no regrets about being on the sideline following his recent retirement.

title: CAPITOL HILL MAY BE A TOUGHER SUMMIT
description: Here are two incidents about President Reagan's performance at last weekend's economic summit. Story A: After landing in Williamsburg, Va., Friday afternoon, Mr. Reagan conferred with aides about the arrival of the summit leaders the next day. The aides left the President to dine alone and spend the evening with a stack of briefing material. The next morning, he was asked at breakfast if he had gotten through the material.

title: COUPLES AND SIMPSON IN A TIE
description: Fred Couples completed a three-underpar 69 with a birdie on the final hole today and tied Scott Simpson for the third-round lead of the $400,000 Kemper Open golf tournament.

title: SOVIET ORDERS A U.S. DIPLOMAT EXPELLED ON CHARGE OF SPYING
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had ordered an American diplomat expelled for spying. It said the diplomat, Louis C. Thomas, an attache at the United States Embassy, had been ''caught red-handed during a spy action in Moscow.''

title: French Bankers
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Padres 5, Phillies 4
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Kurt Bevacqua delivered a one-out pinch single in the seventh inning to drive in 2 runs and snap a 3-3 tie as Philadelphia lost its sixth straight.

title: Follow-Up on the News; A Better Rat Trap
description: The problem in Washington, for once, was not bureaucrats but bureaurats, and two solutions emerged in November 1982. The General Services Administration, which has charge of 150 federally owned and 314 leased buildings, was trying new ''blue boxes.''

title: AND NOW, THE 9A CORRIDOR
description: Westchester County has long been viewed as golden territory by the metropolitian area's corporate community - and much of the county's office-building devlopment has been concentrated in the southeastern section of the county.

title: JUST A QUIET SUNDAY
description: IAM glad our city has finally stopped testing its civil defense s irens. For a while, I could count on regularly hearing them on S aturday mornings, above the whine of my vacuum cleaner as I did a q uick Saturday cleanup.

title: MITTERRAND IS FACING CRISIS OF CONFIDENCE ON ECONOMIC ISSUES
description: Two years after coming to power, President Francois Mitterrand is facing a crisis of confidence in his management of the French economy.

title: FInal 'No' on Abscam Appeals
description: Four former members of Congress ran out of places to take their Abscam appeals last week. Without comment, the Supreme Court refused to consider the convictions of ex-Representatives Raymond F. Lederer and Michael J. Myers of Pennsylvania, John M. Murphy of New York, and Frank Thompson Jr. of New Jersey.

title: THE LOSS OF CHILDHOOD
description: Indeed, I did live and raise my children in suburbia, a place Marie Winn describes as ''a paradise of material comforts and almost pastoral safety.''

title: Brown Crew Beats Navy to Take Cup
description: Brown University, which had been the favorite, captured the Varsity Challenge Cup to become the 1983 Intercollegiate Rowing Association champion today on Lake Onondaga.

title: BEWARE OF SPEED TRAPS
description: To the Editor:

title: What Price a Zimmerman?
description: Isidore Zimmerman hasn't had much of a life. He grew up a delinquent, was convicted of killing a cop, barely escaped electrocution, waited 24 years in prison to have his conviction overturned and 20 more years for compensation. Yet it has been his fate to dramatize two of the great social issues of his time. For two decades, he's been a walking advertisement against the death penalty. And now, at age 66, he embodies an even more difficult issue: how much is a life worth?

title: SCHOLARS CALL LUTHER A MAN FOR ALL CHRISTIANS
description: Five hundred years after Martin Luther was born, his vast works are being examined by both Protestant and Roman Catholic scholars seeking fresh insights for an ecumenical age.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: GOING ABROAD AND HAVING A BAD TIME
description: SOLO, An American Dreamer in Europe: 1933-34. By Wright Morris. 196 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title: Carter Speaks Up On Environment
description: The charges were not new but they came from a new and, up to now, fairly quiet source. Last week, former President Jimmy Carter aimed his sharpest criticism of the Reagan Administration to date at one of its most sensitive targets: environmental policy. Mr.Carter accused the Administration of trying to ''change the environmental laws to circumvent them and, in some cases, is violating them directly.''

title: Hamburg Retains Title
description: The European soccer champion Hamburg retained its West German League title today by defeating Schalke, 2-1. Horst Hrubesch put Hamburg ahead in the 38th minute with a header. Schalke's Wuttke tied the score a minute before halftime.

title: PENN SOUTH MARKING 2 DECADES OF SUCCESS
description: PAUL LIEBERMAN'S family owned the Chelsea Pharmacy years ago, when it was across the street on the w est side of Eighth Avenue. He remembers the way the area used to be,b efore much of it was demolished through a slum-clearance program andr eplaced by the Penn Station South Cooperative in 1962.

title: THE BLUE RIBBON SEASON
description: Visitors to New England this summer and fall will have no trouble finding an authentic country fair -not modern reproductions but fairs that have operated continuously for well over a century.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
U.S. COINS FROM BRAND COLLECTION TO BE SOLD HERE
description: United States coins from the world-renowned collection of the late Virgil M. Brand will be sold at public auction beginning this fall in New York. The sale will take place in two segments, one this November and one next year, and will be conducted by Bowers and Merena Galleries Inc. of Wolfeboro, N.H.

title: NEW SOCIAL INSTITUTE AT STATE UNIVERSITY
description: IN an effort to develop closer links between the university, the corporate community and the public sector, the social sciences division of the State University of New York at Purchase last week announced the formation of the Institute for Social Research. The institute will study social institutions and processes in the Westchester and Fairfield County, Conn., region, drawing upon Purchase faculty members in the fields of sociology, anthropology, political science and economics.

title: Elizabeth Ann Holland Engaged to J.S. Lewis
description: Dr. and Mrs. Mellor R. Holland of Minnetonka, Minn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Holland, to John Stuart Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart A. Lewis of Washington. The wedding will take place July 9 in Washington.

title: ABATEMENT REPORTS GET THE SILENT TREATMENT
description: Throughout his mayoralty, Edward I. Koch has rarely seemed at a loss for words. Without being asked, the Mayor has enthusiastically held forth on issues ranging from nuclear weapons to his favorite foods. Once, when a reporter sought to fill an awkward silence in a news conference by jokingly asking the Mayor to name his favorite color, Mr. Koch launched into a lengthy explanation of how he was partially color-blind, but that he preferred blue. Against such a background, the Mayor's recent behavior on the subject of tax abatements has been highly out of character. He has had almost nothing to say. Indeed, he has refused to say anything, even when baited by reporters who were seeking, if not a policy statement, at least a quotable outburst.

title: PHOENIX HOUSE UPHELD IN FIRE CASE
description: A STATE Supreme Court Justice has ruled that Phoenix House, the Manhattan-based drug-treatment foundation, does not have to identify or provide other biographical information about one of its former residents to the Yorktown Police Department.

title: EDITOR IN WYOMING AND SENATOR DUEL
description: The editor of Wyoming's largest newspaper has challenged a popular conservative Senator on two issues with special relevance to the state: worker identity cards and the MX missile.

title: Linda Anne Marcus and Eric C. Hochstein Marry
description: Linda Anne Marcus, a Foreign Service officer, was married yesterday in Buffalo to Eric Cameron Hochstein, a student at the Georgetown University School of Business Administration. Rabbi Donald Heskins performed the ceremony at the Marine Midland Center.

title: Nicaraguans Reporting A New Rebel Invasion
description: Nicaraguan military sources said today that 1,500 rebels had crossed the border from bases in Honduras and that fighting was under way in the north.

title: South Africa
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Jyo Teshima Wed at Yale
description: Jyo Keakealani Teshima, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Teshima of Wailuka, Hawaii, was married yesterday in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School to Frank Storm Bridgewater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Bridgewater of White Hall, Ill.

title: Sarah Theurkauf, A Writer, Marries
description: Sarah Hope Theurkauf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Robert Theurkauf of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Eldridge Roger Boyle 3d, son of Sarah Patton Boyle of Arlington, Va., and Mr. Boyle Jr. of Charlottesville, Va. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: 5 YEARS AFTER PROPERTY TAX SLASH: POWER SHIFTS TO CALIFORNIA CAPITAL
description: Five years after Californians heeded calls for a taxpayers' revolt and passed Proposition 13, political leaders say the measure's most significant effect has not been the billions of dollars it has saved taxpayers but a fundamental shift of power in the most populous state.

title: Trial by (White) Jury
description: Must a judge sit by silent while a prosecutor does everything he can to keep blacks from serving on a jury? Yes, as the law now stands in most states. The Supreme Court ruled in 1965 that a prosecutor may use peremptory challenges to strike every prospective black juror from a case without being required to provide a nonracial reason.

title: Korea's Wave Of Protest
description: South Korean President Chun Doo Hwan brooks no opposition, but by clumsy handling of a fasting former political leader, he has given his critics a platform for international attention.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORHTY
description: THE INVISIBLE BANKERS. By Andrew Tobias. (Pocket Books, $3.95.) In his sprightly study of life insurance and property and casualty firms, Andrew Tobias notes that insurance companies, like banks, are financial intermediaries and asks, ''Why can one live off the interest on the balance in your checking account, while the other needs to take 35 cents - or more - of each dollar you deposit?'' Characterizing the book as an analytical report deftly camouflaged as a page turner, our reviewer, Peter Passell, said it ''offers some simple fixes for simple outrages'' and focuses attention on waste built into the insurance industry.

title: BANKS DROPPING FOOD STAMP PAYOUT
description: IT'S getting harder and harder to be poor and get food stamps in Suffolk County. The number of banks that distribute the stamps has dropped from 51 to 24 in the last several months, making it difficult for food program recipients to get the stamps.

title: 3 Oriole Homers Top Stieb, 6-4
description: Eddie Murray, Al Bumbry and John Lowenstein hit home runs off Dave Stieb, who had given up only three in 97 previous innings this season, to lead the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight.

title: BLOOD DONOR POLICY REVISED OVER AIDS
description: SINCE 1980, at least 1,420 cases of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome, an illness that ravages the body's natural defenses against disease, have been reported in the United States. Nearly half of these cases were in the New York City area, and the Westchester Board of Health has reported two cases in the county, with six more cases among the prison population of the Taconic and Ossining Correctional Facilities.

title: Women Playwrights
description: I am moved to compliment Mel Gussow's article ''Women Playwrights'' (May 1).

title: MUSIC TEACHING IS ALIVE AND CHANGING
description: As spring ends and music schools disband for the summer, professors go in one direction, pupils in another. For both parties -for the young musicians who hover between artistic childhood and professional life and for those who teach them - there is a chance to reflect again on how time and circumstances are constantly altering the delicate blend of imposed authority and individual creative juices which marks one-to-one music training.

title: Elise S. Heckman Is Wed to Charles S.Q. Hughes
description: The marriage of Elise Stifel Heckman to Charles Scott Quisenberry Hughes took place in St. Louis yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. William Guy Heckman, father and stepmother of the bride. The Rev. William A. Baker performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden.

title: A 'SOUTHERN CALIFORNIAN' ANGLO-IRISHMAN
description: YEATS, By Douglas Archibald. 280 pp. Syracuse, N.Y.: Syracuse University Press. $25.YEATS & AMERICAN POETRY The Tradition of the Self. By Terence Diggory. 262 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $27.50.

title: PROTEST RALLY HELD IN TEL AVIV
description: Tens of thousands of protesters held a demonstration here today to demand the withdrawal of Israeli soldiers from Lebanon.

title: AFTER 200 YEARS, BALLOONING GROWS UP
description: Two centuries ago almost to the day, workmen in the town of Annonay just south of Lyons, France, hoisted a large sackcloth bag into position on a wooden scaffold. The Montgolfier brothers, Joseph and Jacques Etienne, then slid a brazier of burning wool and straw under the open mouth of the bag. Hot air from the fire inflated the balloon to full, rounded form.

title: TINY PORTRAITS BY A FORGOTTEN ARTIST ARE REDISCOVERED
description: HIS professional career spanned half a century. During his lifetime other painters, such as Gilbert Stuart, lavishly praised his work. And after the death in 1807 of Edward Greene Malbone, America's foremost painter of miniatures, Anson Dickinson of Milton was considered by many to be this country's finest portrait miniaturist.

title: INTEREST GROWS IN ALL-DAY KINDERGARTEN
description: ALTHOUGH the reasons are not clear, there is a growing interest on the Island in all-day, or extended, kindergarten programs. Some people attribute the trend to concern about education; others say it is based on economics or a combination of the two.

title: NINE PROPOSALS TO IMPROVE OUR SCHOOLS
description: ''During the Middle Ages everbody was middle aged. ... Middle Evil society was made up of monks, lords and surfs. ... In the 1400 hundreds most Englishmen were perpendicular. ... Finally, Europe caught the Black Death. The bubonic plague is a social disease. ...

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My mother told me she was 100 percent with the jury, and when you are in disagreement with the jury and your mother, there is some reason to doubt you are right.'' - Federal Judge G. Thomas Eisele of Little Rock, Ark. (18:6.)

title: THE THATCHER MYSTERY
description: Her smile could shatter plate glass at 50 yards. She comes across on television as brittle, relentless, unforgiving. She treats her colleagues in public as if she were their headmistress. She has none of the charm that in Ronald Reagan disarms ideology.

title: EMPHASIZING LAUGHS OVER THRILLS
description: PEOPLE who read mystery novels for relaxation will appreciate the intricacies, the wicked twists and the clever turns in Ira Levin's play ''Deathtrap.'' In this thriller, now being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, the form is the substance as plot is layered on plot with a dash of comedy sprinkled over the terror for added flavor.

title: Greece During World War II
description: To the Editor:

title: What Goes Up
description: Without taking anything away from the Wright brothers, a little homage is in order for the Montgolfier brothers. On June 4, 1783, in the small French town of Annonay, they launched a 35-foot globe of sackcloth, the first balloon.

title: Business Forum; HARVARD'S SEARCH FOR A FOUNTAIN OF YOUTH
description: Following are excerpts from ''Industrial Renaissance: Producing a Competitive Future for America'' by William J. Abernathy, Kim B. Clark and Alan M. Kantrow. THE present difficulties of American industry are not in fact the r esult of an unstoppable Japan Inc., or the lack of an adaquate i ndustrial policy to usher sunset industries into the wings at as lowa social cost as possible.

title: Racing the Sun
description: When Michele Bush took off in the women's 1,500-meter final at the National Colleiate Athletic Association Outdoor Track and Field Championships in Houston Friday evening, she was racing more than the clock and her fellow competitors.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A New Old Poem by Thomas Wolfe

title: V.L. Teahan Married To Dr. Johanna Triegel
description: The marriage of Dr. Johanna Triegel to Vincent Laurence Teahan, a lawyer in Poughkeepsie and Rhinebeck, N.Y., took place yesterday at their home in Clinton, N.Y. Justice Joseph Jiudice of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony.

title: CITY SCHOOL SUPERVISORS ASSESS PROBLEMS
description: Supervisors from New York City's school system gathered for their annual convention yesterday, and were told that the public schools, the key to the city's future, were facing troubled times.

title: 'GAG' ISSUE IS RAISED ON DUMPING PROJECT
description: A DISPUTE between two property owners and the governing body of the Monmouth County community of Allentown over a lake-dredging project has taken on added significance in recent weeks, especially for anyone who has stood up at a local Council meeting to complain or who has appealed a decision by his or her elected officials.

title: A POP SINGER FINDS THE PERFECT GROOVE
description: The qualities that go into the making of a great pop singer are so changeable, so subject to the whims of fashion, that it is difficult to pin them down. Judged by the standards that made Al Jolson great, Frank Sinatra is terrible and vice versa. Even within the context of a given period and a given style, the great pop singers are a complex mixture of voice, personality, sensitivity and taste - to mention just a few of the ingredients.

title: Turner Returning to Newport
description: Despite the record number of challengers for the America's Cup this summer and the largest gathering of 12-Meter yachts ever gearing up for the start of the trials June 18, something has been missing in Newport, R.I. But not for long.

title: COPING WITH DUST IS A MUST WHEN REFINISHING FURNITURE
description: EVERY experienced painter and furniture refinisher knows that, after sanding the surface, the biggest single obstacle to achieving a really smooth finish when applying varnish or enamel on furniture, cabinets, doors and similar surfaces is dust.

title: KIMBERLY WELLER ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Howard Weller of Portland, Ore., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Ann Weller, to Douglas Hartley Gordon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Lloyd Gordon of Englewood, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Future Events; Spring Frolics
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Artistic Exchange June 8 - A gala evening of dance sponsored by the Danish-American Society will begin at 8 P.M. with a performance at Carnegie Hall in which the Martha Graham Dance Company shares billing with Peter Martins and soloists of the Royal Danish Ballet. After the curtain calls guests will be whisked by bus to the aircraft carrier Intrepid for a dinner-dance and grand finale of fireworks. Proceeds will be used by the society to establish an exchange scholarship program for American and Danish performing arts students. Tickhty garments from Pat Kerr's London showroom incorporating heirloom laces and antique textiles will be shown with Cartier diamonds while guests sip Moet Champagne. ''They are terribly interesting and amusing,'' said Shirley King, benefit chairman, of the fashions, which include cocktail suits, evening dresses and bridal gowns. Tickets, $100 and $125 from 586-8700, extension 555.

title: The Weather That Left the West Awash
description: Meteorologists have sophisticated explanations for the nation's near-record rainfall and snow, now causing catastrophic mudslides and floods, but last week Robert Clark, director of the National Weather Service's hydrology office, put it plainly: ''It's the worst weather I've seen in 40 years.''

title: RIGHTS PANEL CHOICES DEFENDED BY LEADER OF B'NAI B'RITH WING
description: Support of school busing and racial quotas is being used as a ''latter-day loyalty oath to determine one's fealty to civil rights,'' according to the national director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: WHERE CULTURE AND FARMING THRIVE JOINTLY
description: At any time of year, one is likely to find the strains of a string concerto wafting through the grassy courtyard of the gray stone manor house, and Shakespeare on stage in a converted barn. There also may be a concert of Japanese flute music, a performance by a Parisian dance troupe, a screening of Cuban films, and a reading by a Zen poet from California. During the interludes, the audience savors specialties of a prosperous farming community: an array of distinctive cheeses, arguably the best yogurt in Britain.

title: Playoff-Record $422,500 Is Divided Among 76ers
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, the champions of the National Basketball Association, have split record playoff winnings of $422,500 among current and former team members and other club personnel.

title: Margarita del Carmen Arias Married To Roger Washburn van Voorhees
description: Margarita del Carmen Arias, daughter of Mrs. Charles Wilson Lucom of Palm Beach, Fla., and New York and Gilberto Arias of Panama City, was married in New York yesterday to Roger Washburn van Voorhees, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Irving van Voorhees Jr. of New York and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. William D. Donovan performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CITY BUDGET DRAMATICS
description: Mayor Koch, an impatient expression on his face, stepped purposefully out to the City Hall front porch at 1:30 A.M. Thursday, heading home for some sleep.

title: A PRACTICAL WAY TO ARMS CONTROL
description: Arms control is neither sin nor salvation. It is a way -along with diplomacy and military decisions - of managing Soviet-American competition. Without such negotiated mutual restraint, the competition would be far less controllable and both sides could acquire capabilities that just might make nuclear war more thinkable. It is not a way of solving our security problem. It is a way of preserving the Soviet-American ''peace'' that, with great good luck, has survived the last 40 years of tension and waste. To ask much more of a bargaining process between two powerful countries so mistrustful of each other is to condemn it to failure.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS LEFT BY THE TAMING OF NATURE
description: A SOFT breeze rippled through the waist-high grasses creating miniature ocean-like waves of the nodding stems. The red-and-white cloverheads scattered among the grasses were literally buzzing with the activity of slender, golden honey bees and fat black-and-gold bumble bees searching for sweet nectar. While flitting from one tall clump of grass to another, meadowlarks, red wing blackbirds and a myriad of golden finches pausedbriefly to lift their melodious songs skyward. Off in the distance, a kildeer defended his territory by repeating over and over the characteristic song from which he acquired his name.

title: Randi Beth Small Is Married
description: Randi Beth Small, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee R. Small of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday in New York to Franklin John Wilkes Jr., son of Mr. Wilkes of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Jean Parsons Wilkes. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The bride is an assistant vice president with Johnson & Higgins, Newkers.

title: Family of Youth Killed in Jail Files $25 Million Suit in Idaho
description: The family of a youth who was tortured and beaten to death by cellmates in a county jail have filed suit seeking more than $25 million from the county and its sheriff.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The pianist Elisenda Fabregas was born in Spain, and began her studies at the age of 5. She came to the United States in 1978, where she studied at the Juilliard School with Joseff Raieff and Beveridge Webster.

A RAINY, dreary midweek night is not a cinema's best box office draw, but this Wednesday is different in Newtown. A half-hour before the 9 P.M. show, Main Street is lined with cars, from the landmark Flagpole to the outer stretches of Route 6. The people have come from Brookfield, Heritage Village and Ridgefield, to name a few, and are waiting to see one of Hollywood's most successful recent films, ''An Officer and a Gentleman.''

title: 'I AM FORCED TO DO FLOWERS - THIS CANNOT GO ON'
description: Henri Fantin-Latour (1838-1904) painted some terribly dumb pictures. When he was bored, off form or away in a musical dreamland he produced work that has long been consigned to a High Victorian limbo. But that same Henri Fantin-Latour had a sense of social justice, a sense of human worth and a sense of the new. He has a position all his own in the history of French 19th-century painting, and he has a large constituency both in this country and in England, where he began to be shown at the Royal Academy as long ago as 1862 and has been popular ever since.

title: Indian Point Shutdown And Ossining's Roads
description: Richard Wishnie, the Town Supervisor of Ossining was asked why the Town Board had not addressed itself to the obvious inadequacies of Westchester County roads, should an evacuation be necessary as a result of a serious accident at Indian Point. He replied that the board had recognized the seriousness of the road situation but had given priority to matters of communication between emergency workers, procuring emergency equipment and training emergency personnel.

title: CLASSES FOR GIFTED AT ISSUE
description: ''IT'S pretty special to be in the gifted program,'' said Jason Hecht, a student in Bellmore's third-grade class for gifted pupils. ''It's not just your physical capacities, but how you think and if you can stick to things that you start. I think it's a privilege to be in this class.''

title: Crime Update; 2 MEN SOUGHT IN THE SLAYING OF A MERCHANT
description: On May 12, two men entered a cigarette store on upper Broadway owned by 33-year-old Abdallah Saleh Abdallah, the father of six children. What happened next is not entirely clear, but Mr. Abdallah, who came to this country six years ago from his native Jordan, was fatally shot. The police believe he was killed in an attempted robbery.

title: IT Still Pays to Live in Alaska
description: A legislative deadline for scrapping Alaska's cash ''dividend'' program came and went last week, so the state's 450,000 residents are once again in line for a share of the black gold that's been pumped up from the North Slope oil fields.

title: PORTUGUESE COMMUNITY FLOURISHING
description: ''WHO wants to be an angel?'' -up goes the cry at the Portuguese American Citizens Club in Tarrytown. Quickly, two young volunteers with heavenly aspirations are outfitted in satiny robes and feathery white wings. When 100 candles are lighted, four men hoist the statute of Our Lady of Fatima on a flower-covered platform, and the procession begins its journey through the streets to the Church of St. Teresa of Avila, almost a mile away in North Tarrytown. On a recent rainy night, more than 100 PortugueseAmericans and two angels walked the route, singing, chanting and praying.

title: REPORT CARD ON THATCHERISM
description: I would dispute Steven Rattner's claim that the majority of British people agree that Mrs. Thatcher's dose of ''nasty medicine'' is necessary for a return to economic health in the longer term. Anger and outrage have now subsided - to be replaced by despair, apathy and fear, as the unemployment toll continues to mount, devastating the lives of those individuals and their families.

title: INNER CITY TROUPE WINDS UP; OTHER COMPANIES SET CONCERTS
