description: THE Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company of Paterson winds up its spring concert series tonight with a program of three diverse dance works, as well as the premiere of James T. McCartin's ''A Lil' Closer to the Sky,'' an original one-act play written for the troupe.

title: Trajectory From Williamsburg To Geneva
description: The Reagan Administration, braced by a large measure of allied backing at the Williamsburg summit, will send its delegates back to Geneva Wednesday to resume negotiation with the Soviet Union on reduction of their strategic arsenals. The watchword in Washington last week was ''flexibility,'' an attitude that critics have not associated with the Administration in the past but which President Reagan made a point of stressing when he met Edward L. Rowny, the chief of the American negotiating team.

title: Woman, 81, Dies and 3 Hurt In an L.I. Nursing Home Fire
description: An 81-year-old woman died of a heart attack and three other residents were injured today during a fire at a nursing home here, according to the chief of the Centereach Fire Department.

title: DEMYSTIFYING ECONOMICS
description: DANGEROUS CURRENTS, The State of Economics. By Lester C. Thurow. 247 pp. New York: Random House. $16.95.

title: Guerrilla Threat Provokes Peru to Suspend Rights
description: Fernando Belaunde Terry returned to the presidency of Peru in 1980 with a promise to defend democracy and restore national concord after 12 years of military rule. Last week, he declared a 60-day state of emergency that suspended civil rights and led to the roundup of hundreds of people, mainly in Lima and the provincial center of Ayacucho to the southeast.

title: THERE'S THIS TV COMIC NAMED RIGOLETTO...
description: Somewhere or other Thoreau remarks rather snappishly that if a man has found something worth doing, he will not need a new suit to do it in. This statement may have been true of the surveying business, which Thoreau followed in a rather lackadaisical way, but it is definitely not true of the opera business in 1983: snappy new suits and fashionable tailors are making most of the news.

title: DIFFERENT BUT SIMILAR LOOK
description: BACK in the 50's, a friend of mine had a pale blue 1932 Pontiac. It was a neat little car, a coupe, and a lot of people used to mistake it for a Model A Ford, which always surprised those of us who took our cars seriously. True, the Pontiac was angular and boxy. But a Ford? No way.

title: SONIC RICHES ABOUND IN NEW MUSIC
description: With rare exceptions, serious contemporary music is not a moneymaker. Record companies, being companies, are presumably in the business of making money. Thus it's a wonder any new-music records are made it all. But they are - lots of them.

title: 'THE SALAMANDER'
description: ''The Salamander,'' at the Sutton Theater, is a comatose melodrama about a neo-Fascist plot to take over the Government of Italy. Though it was made in Italy, it is so completely without character, national and individual, that it could have been produced on the Isle of Wight.

title: CALIFORNIA FUNDS BRING LOW RETURN
description: Two state-controlled pension funds that contain more than $30 billion are earning far less than they should because the money management group that runs them is understaffed and underpaid, the California State Senate-Assembly Pension Fund Investment Committee has been told in hearings in Sacramento.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS LEFT BY THE TAMING OF NATURE
description: A SOFT breeze rippled through the waist-high grasses creating miniature ocean-like waves of the nodding stems. The red-and-white cloverheads scattered among the grasses were literally buzzing with the activity of slender, golden honey bees and fat black-and-gold bumble bees searching for sweet nectar. While flitting from one tall clump of grass to another, meadowlarks, red wing blackbirds and a myriad of golden finches pausedbriefly to lift their melodious songs skyward. Off in the distance, a kildeer defended his territory by repeating over and over the characteristic song from which he acquired his name.

title: ENSHRINING GREEK FOLK ART
description: The comfortable, white neo-classical house, with its shady courtyard and cats dozing near the doorstep, seems an unlikely setting for what the International Council of Museums has officially described as ''something close to a miracle.'' Yet the unassuming building, in a quiet residential area of the Greek town of Nafplion, houses a remarkable collection of Greek costumes and folk art.

title: What's New in Lobbying; MAIL THAT SPEAKS LOUDER THAN WORDS
description: In the nation's early days, before the dome of the Capitol was even completed, lobbyists operated in the hallways of Congress and in the saloons of the capital. There were only a handful of them, shadowy figures mostly, and they wooed legislators with the traditional medium of political exchange, grub and grog.

title: MAKING FILMS THE WAY THEY WANT
description: WHILE some film makers are capitalizing on the public's huge appetite for extraterrestrial life forms and Bruce Lee clones, others are asking only that they be left alone to make the kind of films they believe in.

title: STAYING OUT OF COURT
description: JUSTICE WITHOUT LAW? By Jerold S. Auerbach. 182 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: UTOPIA ON THE PRAIRIE
description: Cornfields surround the little town of Bishop Hill, Ill., just as they did a century ago, when it was known as Utopia on the Prairie. Horses and cows still gaze a few blocks from the quiet main street. Motorists in a rush could be forgiven for thinking that they were driving through one more rural community like many others on this vast plain east of the Mississippi. Yet the size and distinction of the buildings and the discreet identifying signs; the gambrel-roofed church, shaped somewhat like a barn; the spacious, fenced-in park at the crossroads, all bear witness to the town's singular past. Bishop Hill, 157 miles west of Chicago, was once a thriving communal settlement founded by religious dissidents from Sweden, and its restoration is due in large part to the efforts of their descendents.

title: Cuisine
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ
description: One of the problems of hearing Gil Evans' Orchestra during its sporadic appearances around town in recent years has been that in the course of one or possibly two nights it was just beginning to achieve its peak when the engagement was over and the band was gone. Some of this lack of continuity was solved recently when, during April and early May, the band played every Monday night at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South.

title: Miss Stillger Engaged To Wed Jonathan Mills
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter Marcel Stillger of Muttontown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Christine Francoise-Louise Stillger, to Jonathan Scott Mills, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Mills of Los Alamos, N.M. A July 9 wedding is planned.

title: TOPICS
description: HOW sweet it was. The Islanders' retention of the Stanley Cup has proved to be the warmest and brightest moment of this cool and soggy spring. Sports are one of those rare commodities that a community as well as a team can share in - in victory as well as defeat. There are certain aspects of this fourth and perhaps most convincing championship season, however, that deserve some further observations.

title: SALES UP OF HARDCOVER BEST SELLERS, STUDY SHOWS
description: Despite a period of hard times for the book-publishing industry, the sales of best-selling hardcover books have risen by 1.3 million, or almost 14 percent, in the last five years, according to a detailed analysis by The New York Times.

title: Another Look At the Holocaust
description: I read with interest the ''Speaking Personally'' article by Michael Allergo (''After the Holocaust, a Need for Homage,'' Opinion Page, May 15). Mr. Allegro's opinion, after visiting the gathering of the Holocaust survivors in Washington, D.C., last April, is that an important fact was overlooked, namely, that others met the same fate as the Jews. He goes on to say that ''the Holocaust was universal'' and emphasizes that in the lectures he gives about his own experiences. He always starts with the above proclamation.

title: SCALING BACK PLANS FOR A NUCLEAR FUTURE
description: OVER breakfast recently, Peter T. Johnson, a businessman from Idaho who heads the Bonneville Power Administration, crunched cereal and noted wryly, ''I need all the iron I can get'' to handle a job that he ''wouldn't wish on the devil himself.''

title: COURSE ON AIRPORT CURFEW QUESTIONED
description: AS the county prepares to go to court July 6 to defend the airport curfew, which bans night flights at the Westchester County Airport, questions are being raised about the wisdom of this course.

title: AN INNOCENT IN REVOLUTIONARY CHINA
description: THE WARLORD, By Malcolm Bosse. 717 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: LONGTIME GARMENT UNION LEADER
description: Charles S. Zimmerman, a labor leader in the garment industry for nearly 40 years, died Friday at St. Luke's Hospital. Mr. Zimmerman was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Vanessa Guerrini-Maraldi Will Marry
description: Count and Countess Demetrio Guerrini-Maraldi of Rome, New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Vanessa Guerrini-Maraldi, to John Caven Wilcox, son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Wilcox of Katonah, N.Y. A September wedding is planned.

title: AN ART COLLECTOR SOWS LARGESSE AND CONTROVERSY
description: For a man who collects art on a cosmic scale and gives millions to art institutions, Dr. Arthur M. Sackler, a 69-year-old research psychiatrist from New York who's made a fortune in business ventures, has managed to maintain a very low profile. He's not a force on museum boards, he shies away from art world functions, and steers clear of interviews. Yet with recent big gifts to Harvard, the Smithsonian and the Metropolitan Museum, he is emerging as one of the country's leading art collectors and patrons.

title: WOMEN PLAYWRIGHTS
description: Marsha Norman, Pulitzer Prize winner, a married woman in her 30's, was described in the article as looking ''more like a graduate student than a serious playwright, wrestling with profound emotions.'' Mr. Gussow's choice of phrase reminds me of a story about Gloria Steinem.

title: KAYAK NOVICE
description: Once I rounded the river bend, I suspected that I would never make it. The frothing white water loomed ahead like Niagara Falls and the 13-foot fiberglass kayak seemed suddenly fragile. The current swung me broadside and, as my balance abandoned me, flipped me under the rushing water. I yanked the spray skirt sealing me in the cockpit and slid out and up to the surface of a river that now seemed embarrassingly benign.

title: The Loss of Childhood
description: Marie Winn's article ''The Loss of Childhood'' (May 8) may become one of the most important new themes in child raising since Dr. Benjamin Spock. As a psychotherapist who deals with ''prematurely independent children'' - victims of anorexia nervosa - I can only applaud Miss Winn's identification of one of the most sick-making trends in parenting today.

title: MRS. LLOYD CAPTURES FIFTH FRENCH TITLE
description: Chris Evert Lloyd won her fifth French Open and 15th Grand Slam title today with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia that took only 65 minutes.

title: Around the Nation;
description: A four-month civil rights trial ended Friday with a Federal district court jury awarding $1.5 million each to the families of Michael Guillory and Johnny Roman, both black, who were shot to death by Richmond police officers in separate incidents.

title: ISRAEL URGED TO CURB JEWISH VIGILANTES
description: The Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is facing public pressure to abandon the lenient treatment it has been giving Jewish settlers who commit crimes against Arabs in the occupied West Bank.

title: Julie Williamson Weds In San Antonio Church
description: Julie Elizabeth Williamson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John A. Williamson of San Antonio, was married there yesterday to Michael Keady Whitcomb, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Mary Margaret Mueller performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Chris Jones.

title: New Threats From Dioxin
description: Dioxin, which has quickly taken a seat next to radiation in the gallery of insidious threats, emerged again last week as a debating issue and as a backyard reality. Dow Chemical Company launched a $3 million campaign to assure the public there was nothing to fear, only to face a Congressman's revelation of scientific evidence to the contrary. Meanwhile, the city of Newark took steps to isolate an industrial site that was contaminated with dangerous levels of the substance. Other New Jersey sites were also being investigated.

title: Mailbox; Jackson's Day Of Humiliation
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Miss Uribe Is Married
description: Maria Adelaida Uribe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Luis Enrique Uribe of New York and Ibague, Colombia, was married yesterday to Edward Guerrant Read Bennett, sone of Mr. and Mrs. Craig Miller Bennett of Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Charles Dolan, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted by priest, performed the ceremony at St. Gertrude's Roman Catholic Church in Bayville, L.I.

title: SALVADORAN PLAN FOR LAND CHANGES SUFFERS SETBACKS
description: El Salvador's land redistribution program has suffered significant setbacks in the last few months, according to the country's largest farmers' union and a preliminary study made for the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: ISRAELI SCHOLARS PROPOSE JOINT RULE ON WEST BANK
description: Nine Israeli scholars, lawyers and politicians have proposed that the problem of the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip be solved neither by annexation, partition nor Israeli withdrawal, but by a system of shared rule by Jordan, Israel and the Palestinians.

title: C.F.A. OFFERS A TV PLAN
description: Some 70 games could be televised this fall under a contingency plan devised by the College Football Association for the 1983 season, with a maximum of four appearances per school the only restriction.

title: CRIME
description: In 1977 William McIlvanney wrote a Glasgow procedural called ''Laidlaw,'' and it turned out to be one of the best of the year. We have had to wait a long time for its sequel, but here it is - THE PAPERS OF TONY VEITCH (Pantheon, $12.95).

title: Youth on L.I. Held in Attacks On His Family With a Ball Bat
description: A 16-year-old boy beat his foster brother to death with a baseball bat early today, and then attacked his foster mother and three other family members, the police said. The police offered no motive for the youth's actions.

title: Prospects
description: Talk of Two Tax Bills

title: AS AN EXPLOITER OF TV, THE PRESIDENT IS MASTERFUL
description: While political experts wait for official word on whether Ronald Reagan will run again for the Presidency, ordinary television viewers could well be getting the distinct impression that he is already campaigning in earnest. The unofficial but unmistakable kickoff took place about two weeks ago when Mr. Reagan starred in the gala NBC celebration of Bob Hope's 80th birthday. Rarely, if ever, has an American President - indeed, any world leader - used popular entertainment so shrewdly and so disarmingly. Ronnie, as his showbusiness friends kept calling him throughout the taped, three-hour presentation, was in formidable form.

title: ELECTRONIC MUSIC ON DISKS REFLECTS A MATURING GENRE
description: Within the larger fabric of contemporary music-making, electronic music may seem to command less attention today than it did 15 years ago, in the heyday of multimedia ''happenings.'' Yet, if the publicity generated by electronic music concerts is less flamboyant and pervasive than it used to be, the art of electronic composition is nevertheless alive and well and maturing appreciably as sound shaping techniques are continually refined and extended.

title: ART ON MISSILES
description: Forty new drawings by Robert Osborn, dealing sequentially with mankind's march toward nuclear self-destruction, will be on view at the Katonah Gallery today through July 17. None of the works is for sale.

title: Man to Get $100,000 For a Lottery Misprint
description: A 60-year-old chicken hauler who thought he had won $100,000 in the Illinois state lottery, and then was told the ticket was a misprint, apparently is going to get his money after all.

title: GIBSON'S OFFICE TO HANDLE JAIL JOBS
description: THE office of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson will serve as a prime recruiter of candidates for the approximately 500 jobs at the 1,000-bed, medium-security state prison to be built here, according to correspondence between Mr. Gibson and state officials.

title: VIVIAN LEVINE IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert levine of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Vivian Ava Levine, to Lieut. William Julius Juhasz, U.S.A.F., son of Gisele Juhasz of Pleasantville, N.Y., and the late Dr. Francis Juhasz.

title: Laurie-Jo Zellweger Wed To Ross Donald Anthony
description: Laurie-Jo Zellweger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Richard John Zellweger of Saddle River, N.J., was married yesterday to Ross Donald Anthony, son of Dr. and Mrs. Russell Anthony of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey performed the Episcopal ceremony in St. Mary's-in-Tuxedo Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

title: SAYING FAREWELL TO THE MCKENNEY TROPHY
description: A famous contest faded into history last year when the American Contract Bridge League took the McKenney Trophy out of circulation. The first winner of the trophy, named for William McKenney who guided the fortunes of the American Contract Bridge League for more than a decade was Charles Goren. That was in 1937, and he won it on seven subsequent occasions, a record.

title: What's Doing in the Berkshires
description: Visitors have been summering in the region of western Massachusetts known as the Berkshires for generations, and the pleasures that brought them in the first place - the gentle green hills, the moderate climate offering relief from steamy cities - still prevail.

title: A TORPID VERSION OF 'CHERRY ORCHARD'
description: WHAT is wrong with Arvin Brown's staging of ''The Cherry Orchard'' at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven is simply that there is nothing especially right with it. In a clear and colloquial English version by Jean-Claude Van Itallie, Anton Chekhov's gently glowing comedy-drama (or dramatic comedy) ends the Long Wharf Theater season with a whimper.

title: WHen Uncle Sam Gets a Lemon
description: Critics have long maintained that too many purveyors of military gear are more concerned with megaprofits than with building weapons that work. Last week the Pentagon's No. 2 civilian told a conference of defense contractors that tighter quality controls could reduce the cost of producing ships, tanks and warplanes a whopping 10 percent to 30 percent.

title: YOUNGSTERS MAKE MUSIC WITH PEN
description: AS a child in Switzerland, Elide Solomon ''helped'' her grandfather conduct the military band he led, and she studied the piano diligently. But her family discouraged her efforts to improvise her own music. After moving to the United States, she spent many years playing and writing music, and became the founding director of the Purchase Music Ensemble, a group devoted to sharing the work of local composers.

title: Around the World; 41 Barrels of Dioxin Sent Back to Switzerland
description: Forty-one barrels of dioxin waste originating from a factory at Seveso, Italy, arrived by truck from France today and were stored at vaults of the Hoffmann La Roche Chemical Company here.

title: POISED FOR A STEEP LIFT-OFF AT PEOPLE EXPRESS
description: ''LOOK at that thing,'' said Donald C. Burr, the chairman and president of People Express Inc., sounding every bit like a proud father. The 41-year-old executive was pointing from his office window - at Newark International Airport - to a huge Boeing 747, which had just made an inaugural flight from Newark to London and back again.

title: Indians Take Reagan to Task
description: In January, fast on the heels of Interior Secretary James G. Watt's remark that American Indian reservations were worse examples of ''the failures of socialism'' than the Soviet Union, President Reagan promised to free tribes of Federal restrictions and allow them a larger role in managing their own affairs. Last week, the Indians said he hadn't, calling The Great Communicator ''the great fork-tongued liar and the great deceiver that sits in the White House.''

title: Miller Wins at Tucson By 12 Pins With a 237
description: Hugh Miller rolled a 237 today to beat Bob Handley by 12 pins and win the $100,000 Tucson Open on the Pro Bowlers Tour.

title: AT 300TH BIRTHDAY CELEBRATION, QUEENS FEELS IT'S ONE OF A KIND
description: As he strolled about the fair that marked the 300th birthday of Queens, Donald R. Manes, the Borough President, said he had become bored with competition among the city's boroughs. For as Mr. Manes put it, there was no competition.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS LEFT BY THE TAMING OF NATURE
description: A SOFT breeze rippled through the waist-high grasses creating miniature ocean-like waves of the nodding stems. The red-and-white cloverheads scattered among the grasses were literally buzzing with the activity of slender, golden honey bees and fat black-and-gold bumble bees searching for sweet nectar. While flitting from one tall clump of grass to another, meadowlarks, red wing blackbirds and a myriad of golden finches pausedbriefly to lift their melodious songs skyward. Off in the distance, a kildeer defended his territory by repeating over and over the characteristic song from which he acquired his name.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Pleasures of Hating

title: Miss Frank Plans Wedding In October to Lonny Unger
description: The engagement of Hilary Frank to Lonny F. Unger, son of Raquel Unger of Armonk, N.Y., and the late Nathan H. Unger, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Frank of New York, parents of the future bride. An October wedding is planned.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: On Wednesday night, the flutist Carl Adams and the guitarist Robert Clarke offered an ingratiating joint concert at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Adams began his training at the Cleveland Institute of Music and is currently an associate professor of music at the Indiana University of Pennsylvania. Mr. Clarke recently played in a master class for Andres Segovia, and is the chairman of the guitar department at Duquesne University.

title: No Headline
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has asserted that the Soviet Union has deployed nuclear warheads among its military forces in Eastern Europe.

title: BRITAIN IN THE SPRING
description: Britain in the spring is as constant and beautiful as always, except that this year there's an election, and everything seems topsy-turvy.

title: FARMERS AND UNIONS JOINING TO FIGHT ECONOMIC HARDSHIP
description: The crowd was already shouting when Tommy Williams arrived at the Randall Carson farm to auction off the family's possessions to cover debts. Moving with surprising organization, some 200 men in jeans, windbreakers and baseball caps used portable loudspeakers to shout down the auctioneer with thunderous chants of ''No sale! No sale!''

title: SUMMER THEATER COMING UP SHORT
description: UNLIKE star-filled summers past, when the Long Island theater season rose to its yearly peak of activity, the one coming up is relatively short of theater fare and long on change. Most of the boxoffice names are appearing in concert rather than roles.

title: ''Librettese''
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIAN STUDY URGES CHANGES IN THE NATION'S PRISON SYSTEM
description: A Government-appointed committee has recommended, after a three-year study, that India's prison system be revamped and that the 89-year-old legislation under which it is run be replaced.

title: Chicago's Activist Cardinal
description: As one who was present when Joseph Cardinal Bernardin addressed the Chicago Board of Rabbis and the Jewish Federation of Metropolitan Chicago, I was struck by two points (''Chicago's Activist Cardinal,'' by D.R.J. Bruckner, May 1). The first is that Cardinal Bernardin took the trouble to prepare a major, substantive address when all that was expected by members of his audience was a greeting and an expression of a desire to work together in the months and years ahead.

title: CONSERVATIVES SEE END TO TRUDEAU ERA
description: When Canada's Progressive Conservative Party meets this week to prepare its campaign against Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's faltering Liberals, many of the 3,000 delegates will be debating the importance of their candidate's fluency in French.

title: Carolyn Lazor and C.L. Abry 5th Marry
description: Carolyn Victoria Lazor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Alexander Lazor of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Leo Abry 5th of Washington, son of Mrs. Abry of Thompson, Conn., and the late Mr. Abry of Gr The Rev. Giles Hayes performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Abbey, Delbarton, in Morristown, N.J.

title: Report Card on Thatcherism
description: Steven Rattner's ''Report Card on Thatcherism' (May 1), was most perceptive, and provided, I believe, an accurate assessment of the state of the United Kingdom and, in particular, the mood of the populace. However, although Mr. Rattner glosses over the unemployment statistics, they are likely to play a major part in the coming election. Anything can happen. SIMON PALMER, London

title: FROM A CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK IN SICILY
description: It was supposed to be a nonworking vacation in Sicily. Forget opera, concert and symphony. Instead, concentrate on pasta and the local wines. Ruins and mosaics. Churches and monasteries. Driving here and there. Walking among the ruins left by the Greek and Norman and Spanish and Moorish settlers, who for millenia had made Sicily the crossroads of the Mediterranean. Perching on a fallen pillar in a Greek pantheon, preferably at sunset or under the full moon, and thinking the appropriate thoughts.

title: HARRY LIEBERMAN, 106, PAINTER
description: Harry Lieberman, a primitive-style painter who began his career as an artist in his 70's, died Friday in North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after suffering a cardiac arrest. Mr. Lieberman was 106 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: JAPANESE CHIDED AS 'EASYGOING' ABOUT QUAKES
description: The Japanese, to make a generalization with millions of exceptions, tend to worry a lot. In the last few days, some of them are worrying about how unworried others are.

title: VIDEOTAPED CONFESSIONS INCREASE THE CONVICTION RATE
description: The videotape camera focused on Jose Andujar, an accused killer, who sat slouched in a chair in the 43d Precinct station house in the Bronx, his black leather jacket loosely draped over a white T-shirt. A table separated him from the prosecutor.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Cashing in on Computers

title: Investing; UNCERTAIN TIMES FOR PHONE STOCKS
description: MCI COMMUNICATIONS, Ma Bell's chief competitor in the long-distance telephone market, has a problem. Despite a continued exceptional earnings performance so far this year, prices for MCI shares have underperformed the highly volatile but exceedingly popular telecommunications group.

title: DANCE
description: Merce Cunningham devised the ''Event'' so that he and his dancers could perform anywhere, from a hallway to a proscenium theater, while on tour. A fusion of excerpts from existing repertory into a new dance in itself, designed to be seen from almost any angle, his Events have been danced in some improbable places and usually before audiences limited by cramped seating arrangements.

title: WORDS FOR WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TRENTON HIGH, Class of '67, is the setting for the movie ''Baby It's You,'' which was made by a Trenton graduate, Amy Robinson. The Paramount film, which recently opened in theaters in Princeton and Paramus, is a love story about Jill, a middle class girl who wants to become a serious actress, and Albert, a working-class boy who wants to become an ersatz Frank Sinatra.

title: MANUAL INSTRUCTS SANDINISTS' FOES IN SABOTAGE
description: An anti-Government Nicaraguan guerrilla group has prepared a sabotage manual to guide its members on operations ranging from painting political graffiti on walls to disrupting the operations of factories.

title: METS DEFEATED, 2-1, ON HOMER OFF ALLEN
description: The Mets showed Frank Howard one of their high-risk traits tonight when Neil Allen threw a home-run pitch to Steve Yeager that sent the Mets to a 2-1 defeat to the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: On Language
description: Butterfly Words

title: Hussein in Iraq for Talks
description: King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today on a one-day visit for talks with Iraqi leaders, the official Iraqi press agency reported.

title: On Icahn
description: To the Business Editor:

title: FOCUS ON FOLK ART
description: Fred Wichmann began collecting Pennsylvania German folk art in the 1930's. And, for nearly a half-century until his death, he never stopped. A New York City schoolteacher, he was, at his retirement 20 years ago, chairman of the art department of Brooklyn's Erasmus Hall High School.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: ''WE EXPECT our successful New Jersey company to be noticed among the hundreds of publishers attending the American Booksellers Association convention,'' said John S. Reno Jr., president of the Fleming H. Revell Company of Old Tappan, as he prepared to leave for the association's 83d annual meeting, which opens in Dallas tomorrow.

title: Recent Sales
description: Clark $145,000 *2*1 Partridge Run, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*10-year-old colonial; heated porch, modern *2*kitchen, taxes $2,397. Hoboken $84,000 *2*645 Garden Street, 8-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*60-year-old town house; all-brick, fireplace; *2*taxes $1,600. New Brunswick $76,500 *2*252 Suydam Street, 50-year-old 3-family brick house, *2*1 bedroom, 1 bath each unit; onsite parking; *2*taxes $1,587. Ringwood $85,500 *2*45 Bellott Road, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old bilevel; freestanding fireplace, *2*carpeting; taxes $2,300. Short Hills $250,000 *2*27 Hillside Avenue, 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old colonial; central airconditioning; *2*taxes $5,028. Watchung $210,000 *2*58 Wildwood Terrace, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*21-year-old colonial ranch; 7-stall horse stable, *2*riding ring; taxes $2,855. OTHER AREAS Norwalk, Conn. $199,500 *2*Old Rock Court, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; *2*crushed-stone driveway, 2 ponds, 1 acre, *2*taxes $2,400. Mount Vernon, N.Y. $117,000 *2*54 Carwall Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*48-year-old stucco Mediterranean; living-room balcony, *2*playroom, den; taxes $2,384. Sayville, L.I. $65,000 *2*72 Lumur Drive, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 20-year-old *2*ranch; formal dining room, finished *2*basement; taxes $2,200.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 9.78 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 9.00 Maximum rate at savings institutions Money Market Funds 7.80 Donoghye's Money Fund 7-Day Average Bank Money Market Accounts 8.20 Bank Rate Monitor Index Home Mortgage 13.13 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year-maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 16.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 16.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 19.00

title: Geometry Lesson
description: To the Editor:

title: S.M.U. WINNER IN TRACK
description: Victories by Michael Carter in the shot-put and Keith Connor in the triple jump, plus a comeback fourth-place finish in the 1,600-meter relay gave Southern Methodist its first men's title in the National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships tonight.

title: A FARM FOR LEARNING
description: For those generations growing up and growing older out of earshot of a rooster's good morning, there is Macomber Farm, a blend of working farm, petting zoo and state-of-the-art educational facility. The two-year-old complex, set on 46 acres not far from the Massachusetts Turnpike in Framingham (22 miles west of Boston) was designed by the New York firm of Edwin Schlossberg for the Massachusetts Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

title: AROUND THE GARDENJOAN LEE FAUST
description: This Week:

title: 'MAN OF LA MANCHA,' PAST HIS PRIME, IN MILLBURN
description: ISN'T it time to declare a moratorium on ''Man of La Mancha''? In its third time around at the Paper Mill Playhouse, the 18-year-old musical sounds stale and seems far, far creakier than the theater's recent sprightly production of ''The New Moon,'' which pre-dates ''Man of La Mancha'' by 37 years.

title: NEW FOUNDATION WILL AID MEDICAL RESEARCH
description: For many years, Harold and Leila Young Mathers were known in the California community to which they retired as a devoted couple who gave money to help worthy causes in the Santa Barbara area.

title: ARCHDIOCESE ALTERS SCHEDULE OF MASSES
description: BEGINNING Sept. 1, Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of Hartford will find mass times changed in some parishes. ''The schedules of masses which were operative in the larger city par-ishes are probably the same schedules that had been there for years,'' said the Rev. James J. Noonan, M.S., dean of the archdiocese's metropolitan Hartford deanery, which consists of 16 parishes.

title: A NEW BEGINNING FOR AN OLD ESTATE
description: AFTER decades of uncertainty and two years of intense local debate, a 1,481-acre tract of land in Greenwich and the neighboring town of North Castle, N.Y., is being developed as a community of luxury homes.

title: Nets Move Focus Off Albeck
description: In a series of fast-moving developments yesterday, the Nets' search for a new coach appeared to be moving away from Stan Albeck to include other choices.

title: THE TRAJECTORY OF A BUMBLER
description: A CONSPIRACY SO IMMENSE, The World of Joe McCarthy. By David M. Oshinsky. Illustrated. 597 pp. New York: The Free Press/Macmillan. $19.95. WITHOUT PRECEDENT The Story of the Death of McCarthyism. By John G. Adams. Illustrated. 285 pp. New York: W.W. Norton. $17.50.

title: BOMBERS AND BALLETS
description: World War II bombers in full battle dress, modern jets and a glider that does an aerial ballet will fill the skies at the Morristown Airport Air Show next Saturday and Sunday.

title:
Business Forum;
WHY VOLCKER SHOULD BE LET GO
description: WHILE ''Will he or won't he be reappointed?'' (where ''he'' is Paul A . Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board) makes a nice p arlor guessing game, the more important question is, ''Will it or w on't it peter out?'' (where the ''it'' is the recovery of the e conomy).

title: A LOOK AT TRENDS IN CITY'S HOUSING
description: Everybody is interested in housing, at least his own, but some people also are interested in the philosophy, design, politics, economics and sociology of housing, and for them June offers some unusual events.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: FURTHERING TRIBALISM AT ITS WORST
description: To the Editor:

title: GIRL STIRS UP LEAGUE
description: ONE of the charms of the Norwalk Cranbury National Baseball League for 9- and 10-year-olds is that no batter can draw a walk until the pitcher has thrown two strikes.

title: ETHICS AND THE NEW MEDICINE
description: On a sweltering July day in 1979, I had just returned to my law office from Mount Sinai Hospital, where, along with fellow members of the hospital's institutional review board, I had spent the morning thrashing out the ethical problems posed by various proposals for medical research on human beings. As I tried to clear my head of medical issues and turn to a deskful of legal documents, the phone rang. The call was from the White House, asking if I would accept the chairmanship of the first Presidential commission on biomedical ethics.

title: THE IMAACT OF JACK DEMPSEY AND TWO SPECIAL PUNCHES
description: IF boxing in this century, like all Gaul, were divided into three parts they would be dominated, respectively, by Jack Dempsey in the first third, by Joe Louis in the period from 1935 through World War II and into the 1950's, and finally, of course, by Muhammad Ali.

title: PARKS DEPARTMENT TO RENT CABINS
description: BEGINNING next month, the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation will offer indoor accommodations for vacationers at Croton Point Park.

title: A POPULAR PLACE FOR THE FAMILY
description: ''IS the restaurant new?'' we asked our waitress at lunch. ''Sort of ...it opened a few months ago,'' she said. A few days later at dinner in the same place, we asked another waitress how old the restaurant was.

title: PREPARING FOR CONFLICT ON ORBITING BATTLEFIELDS
description: Sometime this summer an Air Force F-15 jet fighter is scheduled to launch a two-stage rocket in the first flight test of an American antisatellite weapon. For 15 years the Soviet Union has been testing -but with a failure rate of close to 50 percent - a less sophisticated and less capable satellite killer.

title: BOTANICAL GARDEN SEEKS TO RAISE $31.6 MILLION
description: The New York Botanical Garden has begun a $31.6 million fundraising campaign in connection with its 100th anniversary in 1991. The money is being raised by the 250-acre garden in the Bronx to meet basic operating needs. One of the first priorities is to raise $5 million to improve existing programs and restore staff positions that were substantially reduced in recent years because of cutbacks in government financing.

title: Bomb Blasts in Basque Area
description: Two bombs exploded here early today, one in an empty bar and the other outside a Government building, causing considerable damage but no casualties, the police said.

title: TEACHER'S LETTER TO SENIORS AND PARENTS
description: I HATE kids. Especially seniors. That's why I've been teaching for 36 years. This long martyrdom tells me I have the right to give two generations some advice.

title: N.J. Brakes on Auto Insurance
description: Auto insurance bills apparently have become more than even the New Jersey traffic will bear. Last week, State Insurance Commissioner Joseph Murphy postponed a scheduled increase of up to $33 and held out hope for a $50 rollback instead.

title: RAPE PROSECUTIONS CHANGING
description: ALTHOUGH changes in New Jersey's rape law and in public attitudes have made charges of sexual assault less liable to question, some of the state's 21 county Prosecutors say they still are skeptical of a significant number of cases.

title: GIVE-AND-TAKE KEYS APPEALS OF PROPERTY TAX
description: Nearly 30,000 owners of everything from the most modest singlefamily homes to the most prestigious office towers appeared before the New York City Tax Commission this year to argue that city assessors had put too high a value on their buildings.

title: Edna St. Vincent Millay
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO SETS RULES ON USE OF PLANES
description: Governor Cuomo has issued new rules on who can fly on state planes and who has to pay for the ride. Under the new rules, no state plane may be used by anyone unless the trip is related to official state business and ''the schedule of state business cannot be met by use of automobile or common carrier.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: THE new president of Stockton State College in Pomona, Dr. Vera King Farris, is known as a woman of many hats, which she designs herself to fit the occasion. Dr. Farris even created one to match the all-white outfit for her interview for the post, during which she told Stockton faculty members:

title: Cooperative Activities In Teaching Explored
description: In ''High Schools and Colleges Need to Bridge Abyss'' (Opinion Page, May 15), Joan Manheimer calls attention to the need for closer contacts between high school and college faculty.

title: Q and A
description: Question:This summer we plan to take our three children - ages 1, 3 and 5 - to Indonesia. What medical arrangements should we make? - K.G.H., Columbia, S.C.

title: HOUSE RETURNED TO WIDOW, 93
description: A 93-year-old widow evicted from her home of 75 years after she failed to pay $410 in taxes got the house back from the buyer who evicted her, her attorney says.

title: ON WEST 17TH STREET, A PANORAMA OF FAKE FLOWERS
description: Most people seem to be of two quite definite minds about fake flowers: Either they like them or they don't want to have anything to do with them. And Robert Currie, the interior and store-window designer, was no exception, until Benny Zucker came to him for help.

title: COSMOS HAVE AN EDGE IN CUP
description: For the first time in the four-year history of the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup, all four participants have a chance of capturing the trophy on the final day of the tournament, which will conclude with a doubleheader today at Giants Stadium.

title: EAST-WEST CLIMATE IS CHILLY BUT NOT FRIGID
description: For two weeks now the new United States embassy site in central Moscow has been largely deserted. Glimpses through the fence surrounding the project show the nine-story chancery building standing windowless and silent amid a wasteland of earth and bricks, abandoned by 300 Soviet workers who have been constructing it under the direction of American engineers. They were ordered off the job in protest at the ''health hazard'' posed by an American radioactive scanning device being used to spot electronic bugs in the walls and floors.

title: MRS. THATCHER'S ECONOMY ON TRIAL
description: BRITAIN'S blunt-spoken Employment Minister, Norman Tebbit, declared on a news program last week that ''the Government has always been committed to unemployment.'' Quickly catching himself, Mr. Tebbit added, ''I mean improving unemployment.''

title: MISS GRIFFIN WILL WED IN WATCH HILL ON JULY 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. William John Griffin of Greenwich, Conn., and Watch Hill, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kimberley Ellen Griffin, to Richard Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Reynolds of Delray Beach, Fla., and Brielle, N.J. The wedding is to be on July 9 in Watch Hill.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: ''SEE this photo - this is where I was shot down.'' ''Oh, so you bought it in Schweinfurt?'' ''Was it a Sunday, huh, was it? The big raids always seemed to be on Sundays.''

title: ONE OF THE INGREDIENTS IS FINESSE
description: ADD the new San Remo in Westbury to your list of small, attractive Italian restaurants that interpret the northern Italian repertory with a certain elegance. When the chef puts his mind to it, the food is light, perfectly cooked and seasoned with finesse. Lapses that occur do not seriously diminish the overall pleasure of dining here.

title: ONCE-BOOMING HOUSTON REAL ESTATE MARKET IS IN DEEP SLUMP
description: Devastated by the sharp slump in oil prices, the Mexican peso's devaluation and high unemployment, Houston's superheated market in rental real estate has suddenly plummeted to disastrous levels.

title: SPAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. ART MARKET: WHY GALLERIES COME AND GO
description: IN spite of the fact that a record number of small businesses in the country have gone bankrupt in the last two years, the commercial art gallery scene on Long Island appears to be lively and growing.

title: STAMFORD'S STATION HAS A LONG HISTORY
description: ANY time now, the wrecker's ball will take its first swing at Stamford's railroad station. Bulldozers will join the attack and the old depot will be reduced to rubble to make way for a sleek, new transportation center.

title: GRAND ILLUSIONS
description: Two grand illusions - about how easily and how soon the North Atlantic Treaty Organization can meet the threat of intermediaterange Soviet nuclear missiles in Europe - are opening the alliance to further political problems likely to weaken Western security. Still, there may be a way to avoid the headache - if we take a more imaginative approach to negotiations before it is too late.

title: Question of Excitement
description: Roy P. Benavidez got the Medal of Honor for heroism in Vietnam, but he can no longer get Social Security payments for the disabilities he incurred in earning the medal. Mr. Benavidez's checks were cut off recently under Social Security reforms that were accelerated by the Reagan Administration.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE LEGACY OF A PRINCESS FROM PORTUGAL
description: THREE hundred years ago, the dowry of a young Portuguese princess changed the English life style in a single generation. For collectors, it was the beginning of the modern age of antiques.

title: JUDGE FUCHSBERG RESIGNS
description: JUSTICE through law is something the people of the United States need to lobby hard for in order to improve and protect it, Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of Harrison said the other day on resigning from the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

title: ORWELL'S '1984'- NEARING?
description: In 1948, George Orwell wrote a novel satirizing the dehumanizing trends of the age. He first thought of calling it ''The Last Man in Europe'' but settled on a shorter title, transposing the last two digits of the date and giving the world a new synonym for tyranny: ''Nineteen Eighty-Four.''

title: Man Seized in Slaying Of Stage Designer, 22
description: A Manhattan truck driver has been arrested and charged with the stabbing death last month of a 22-year-old stage designer.

title: INVADERS STOP GENERALS, 34-21
description: The Oakland Invaders stopped Herschel Walker on the ground and shut down a little-used quarterback, Gene Bradley, through the air tonight to beat the New Jersey Generals, 34-21, before 32,908 fans at the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum.

title: Hoover As Translator
description: To the Editor:

title: Clement Wood 3d Wed in New York To Miss Sandberg
description: Sally Melissa Sandberg, daughter of Mrs. Carl Robert Kopp of Winnetka, Ill., and North Palm Beach, Fla., and the late John V. Sandberg of Kenilworth, Ill., was married yesterday in New York to Clement Biddle Wood 3d, son of Mrs. C. Daggett Harvey of Chicago and Mr. Wood Jr., of Water Mill, L.I., and Spetsai, Greece. The Rev. Anne Brewster Jones performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church.

title: 'DIVINE EMMA,' A CHAPTER IN DIVA'S LIFE
description: As film biographies go, Jiri Krejcik's ''Divine Emma'' is decorous and rather dull. It depicts the Czechoslovak diva Emma Destinn (or Emmy Destinn, as she is more commonly known) and her activities during World War I. ''She was a star in the world of opera and a true patriot of Czechoslovakia,'' the opening credits proclaim. The film establishes this in a plodding manner that isn't very likely to arouse new interest in Miss Destinn's life, nor liable to tell her admirers anything they don't already know.

title: A LEASH FOR THOSE NO-PET CLAUSES?
description: FOR Douglas Landrum and Ken Joffe, roommates in a garden apartment i n a West Side brownstone, the notice they received last September f rom their new landlord came as a blow.

title: BLACKS' SIDE OF THE HILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: May Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut's Way With Taxes
description: Connecticut residents have one of the highest average incomes in the nation and a Legislature that may be second to none in its determination not to tax it. For yet another year, the State Senate rejected ''comprehensive tax reform'' (as an income tax is euphemistically known in Hartford) and turned last week to a variety of new and increased levies to fill a $265 million gap in the $3.6 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning next month.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 12 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 9 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 3 4 6 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 4 3 9 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 5 7 4 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 6 5 10 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 7 6 7 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 8 8 10 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.)

title: 'SUMMER EVENINGS' SERIES BEGINS ITS 10TH SEASON
description: ''OUR goals haven't changed,'' says Kenneth Wentworth, director of the Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence series, which opens its 10thanniversary season a week from Saturday at 8 P.M. ''We still are aiming for programs of the highest musical value, presented by ensembles of the highest musical quality.''

title: THE DULUTH WE DESERVE?
description: DULUTH, By Gore Vidal. 214 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: PROJECT PROVIDING NEW LIFE FOR 'SONO'
description: MANY young executives on the way up feel it is important to have a good address. In Connecticut that has often meant straining their budgets to live in fashionable, expensive suburbs, or settling for the better neighborhoods of less prestigious towns.

title: Iroquois in Lacrosse Festival
description: The Iroquois nation, which had been playing lacrosse for generations before the game was discovered by a French missionary in 1636, has formed a team for international competition. This week the team will have its first major test.

title: 4 AWARDS WON BY THE TIMES
description: The Newspaper Guild of New York has announced the winners of its 48th annual Page One Awards for excellence in journalism. The 20 prizes were awarded to writers, reporters, photographers, artists and designers whose work appeared in newspapers and magazines in New York, New Jersey or Connecticut in 1982.

title: MARINERS' HOMERS BEAT YANKEES, 5-4
description: The compliment was left-handed, extended by the Yankees to their former pitcher, Jim Beattie. Manager Billy Martin put eight lefthanded batters into his lineup yesterday against the right-handed Beattie, but the Mariner pitcher kept them in check in Seattle's 5-4 victory at the Stadium.

title: ELIZABETH SEEKING WATERFRONT REVIVAL
description: FROM a marshy bank on the Arthur Kill, Philip Carteret began his journey to the Governor's house, George Washington boarded a ferry to his inaugural and the Navy launched its first submarine.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Abe Grossfield, head gymnastics coach at Southern Connecticut University, was named head coach of the 1984 United States Olympic gymnastics team. ... K.C. Jones, an assistant coach with the Boston Celtics for the last five seasons and a former player for the club, will be named the Celtics' new head coach, according to The Boston Globe. Bill Fitch recently resigned as coach of the Celtics and has been named coach of the Houston Rockets.

title: SUDDENLY, LITTLE-KNOWN REBELS FORCE GRIM CHOICES FOR PERU
description: The butt of political jokes here two years ago was a tiny band of leftists that drove around town crammed into a red Volkswagen, flipping dynamite sticks at embassies and private companies. The group, which called itself Shining Path, made more noise than damage.

title: BRITISH RUN FOR OFFICE WITH A SPECIAL GAIT
description: For starters, there is the matter of pace. A British general election campaign, like the one now under way, lasts about three weeks, compared with two years in the United States. There are no primaries to bother with, the selection of nominees being handled by local party committees. Less democratic, perhaps, but altogether less exhausting and perhaps more grown-up.

title: Liane Lunny to Wed C.W. Neuhauser
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Miller Lunny of Far Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Liane Lunny, to Charles William Neuhauser, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. William Neuhauser of Gloucester, Mass.

title: Another Aspect Of Baldwin Sportsnite
description: As a participant in Sportsweek 1983, I would like to comment on the letter to the editor by Marian Quient Guralnick on May 8. I was on gold (the second-place team), I am a freshman and, like Marian Guralnick, I was not on dance or gymnastics. She found her experiences as a participant in Sportsweek 20 years ago negative, because she lost study time, felt she was pressured to take part, felt she worked too hard and didn't get enough in return. This caused all the fun to be taken out of Sportsweek, then Girlsweek.

title: Polish Rivals Hold Their Fire
description: Hoping to arrange ''a calm and solemn atmosphere'' for next week's visit of Pope John Paul II, Poland's leaders last week sidestepped intraparty differences at a long-delayed meeting of the Communist Party Central Committee. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski postponed until after the papal visit an ideological debate that seemed likely to touch off challenges to the military regime by Soviet-supported hardliners.

title: Dorothy E. Weaver Marries
description: Dorothy Elise Weaver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Weaver of Wilmington, Del., was married in New York yesterday to Ethan Jeremiah Podell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Odif Podell of Plesantville, N.Y. Justice Leonard H. Sandler of the Appellate Division, State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club. The bride is a manager at Pepsico in Purchase, N.Y. Mr. Podell is a vice president of the Lexington Broadcast Services Company in New York.

title: Linda Lee Simon To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee K. Simon of Greensboro, N.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Lee Simon, to Joseph Albert Riggsbee 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Riggsbee Jr., also of Greensboro. The wedding is to be on Sept. 24 at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Greensboro.

title: Alma Mater
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Deal Seems Near On C.I.A. Files
description: The Central Intelligence Agency and the American Civil Liberties Union have been knocking heads for years over the Freedom of Information Act. Now a bill introduced by Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, has brought them close to compromise on what kind of information is free and what isn't.

title: 1,100 Employees Strike At Utility in Rockland
description: Employees of the Orange and Rockland Utilities Company went on strike today after rejecting the company's latest two-year contract offer on Friday.

title: Personal Finance; LETTING A COMPUTER HANDLE YOUR MONEY
description: YOU'VE probably heard the home computer touted as the silicon-age elixir, something that restores sanity to the family bank account, keeps household finances healthy and devises clever schemes to stretch a dollar.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Horse Power
description: With a flurry of publicity, a horseburger cart joined the licensed hot dog, souvlaki, tempura and Afghanistan spiced cofta carts in the streets of Manhattan last December. The horse flesh stand, operated by the M & R Packing Company of Hartford, offered ''high protein'' burgers for 75 cents and steak sandwiches for $1.40.

title: WHEN GARDENING BY THE SEA, FOLLOW NATURE
description: Seaside gardening is a challenge. Although the beach may be a good place to work on a tan, is is a difficult site for plants to grow. Sand is sterile, does not hold nutrients or water and is unstable when a plant hole must be dug. And, as if sand were not enough to cope with, there are the desiccating breezes and salt spray to compound the problems. What's a poor gardener to do?

title: TAP MAKES EVERYONE WANT TO DANCE
description: For a dance form that only recently was thought to be dead, tap is proving to be a lively, rackety ghost. These days, on Broadway, tap dancers are clattering in ''My One and Only'' and ''42nd St.'' The City Center engagement of Montreal's Les Grands Ballets Canadiens included ''Astaire,'' a ballet with tap sequences choreographed by Brydon Paige and John Stanzel. Over at the New York City Ballet, Jerome Robbins is preparing his own tribute to Fred Astaire and, although its technical vocabulary is classical, Mr. Robbins says it will contain references to the Astaire style.

title: Miss Owen Weds Investment Aide
description: Patricia Anne Owne, duaghter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Grissom Owen of Bronxiville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to George Lewis Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur George Taylor, also of Bronxville. The Rev. Alan Laird Chisholm performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: BOOKSELLER'S ART
description: ''To write books is easy, it requires only pen and ink and the ever-patient paper,'' Sir Stanley Unwin wrote. ''To print books is a little more difficult, because genius so often rejoices in illegible handwriting. To read books is more difficult still, because of the tendency to go to sleep. But the most difficult task of all that a mortal man can embark on is to sell a book.''

title: Foreign Bases Have a Price
description: A string of military bases around the world is one way the United States defends itself as well as its friends. But the friends do exact a price, as Washington was reminded last week when it signed a new base agreement with the Philippines and sweated out negotiations with Greece.

title: IS WEAVER THE ANSWER?
description: NORMALLY in baseball, as the Yankees prove every so often, the fronto ffice fires the manager. But when George Bamberger decided to resigna s the Mets' manager, he reversed the usual procedure. In a real s ense, George Bamberger fired the front office and the team from his l ife. Clearly, this is a man with a sense of values.

title: LIKE ALFRED THE GREAT AND PETER PAN
description: THE LAST LION, Winston Spencer Churchill. Visions of Glory: 1874-1932. By William Manchester. Illustrated. 973 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $25.

title: AT CHANTECLER, FEASTS FIT FOR A SUN KING
description: There are two things that set the great, white Hotel Negresco at Nice, built in 1913 and a favorite of three-star courtesans of another era, apart from every other palace hotel in France.

title: Reagan Assails Plan On Content of Autos
description: President Reagan said today that legislation intended to encourage foreign automobile makers to establish plants in this country was a ''cruel hoax'' that would increase car prices and cost Americans their jobs.

title: FARMING THE BEST ROOKIES
description: Brock arrived from that farm system's imposing Triple A team, the Albuquerque Dukes. When the 1983 season opened with Brock on first base for the first time, Mike Marshall, 23, a former first baseman, took over right field. A year ago, Marshall, too, was playing in Albuquerque. In midseason, Marshall was promoted to the Dodgers after hitting .388 with the Dukes. Officially, he is no longer a rookie, but he is one of the young players upon whom the Dodgers are planning their future.

title: NO CHARGES ON OSSINING HOSTAGES
description: A Westchester County grand jury investigating the January uprising at the Ossining Correctional Facility has decided against indicting any inmates for crimes against the corrections officers they held hostage.

title: NURTURING NEW THOUGHTS ON THE START OF SCHOOLING
description: In Lorraine Shapiro's kindergarten class in East Harlem, children talk about pollution, not playing house. Her all-day class is one example of how the nature of kindergarten has changed. With the growth of nursery schools, Head Start programs and preschool television such as ''Sesame

title: EXPEDITERS OF HISTORIC REGISTRY
description: SINCE the expansion two years ago of Federal tax benefits for the restoration and rehabilitation of h istoric structures, developers and property owners have been trying t o get their buildings listed on the National Register of Historic P laces.

title:
ART;
MODERN STILL LIFES AT THE WHITNEY
description: SINCE its beginning, the Whitney Museum has been astute in collecting realism, or more precisely, paintings containing nameable objects. (It is in the area of abstraction that the museum has had to play catchup.) Therefore, when Pamela Gruninger, who manages the Whitney's Stamford branch, mined the holdings for a modern still-life exhibition, she was able to get a show that embraces the subject in a very elastic way.

title: POP MUSIC
description: Ronald Shannon Jackson and the Decoding Society would be worth hearing for Mr. Jackson's jubilant drumming alone. He lays down a stomping backbeat, yet over and under and around that beat, he plays vigorous cross-rhythms and accents while trading fusillades with the rest of the band.

title: Michigan Triumphs Over Maine by 6-5
description: Chris Sabo, a junior, hit a three-run homer and Michigan stopped an eighth inning rally to earn a 6-5 victory over Maine tonight in a first-round game of the 37th annual College World Series.

title: Jones of Britain Wins Marathon in Stockholm
description: Hugh Jones of Britain, running his first race in a year, passed Paul Cummings of the United States with three miles to go today and held on to win the Stockholm Marathon.

title: MARGIOTTA STILL ACTIVE IN PARTY
description: THE efforts of Joseph M. Margiotta to stave off a jail term are being matched by his less visible efforts to remain a Nassau Republican power, according to Nassau Republican politicians.

title: LOG OF A VOYAGE INTO MURKY WATERS
description: What with one thing and another, unseen films accumulate so that, from time to time, it's necessary to spend a day catching up. It's not dangerous duty in any conventional sense. However, when the films aren't great, seeing three or four of them back-to-back becomes a test, a little like being on a submarine cruise under the polar ice cap. Sanity is risked. The following is the log of one such day, Friday, May 27.

title: SOMERSET PROGRAM SEEKS HEALTHIER WORK PLACES
description: MAKING the health of workers an issue is the principal goal of the Somerset County Occupational Health Program. The program, financed in part by the state's Department of Health as a pilot project, is run by the Somerset County Health Officers Association. It is largely the brainchild of the program chairman, Dr. Ronald Cohen, and of Dr. Kenneth Rosenman, director of occupational and environmental health services for the state.

title: CONCERT: SONNY ROLLINS MEETS WYNTON MARSALIS
description: The meeting of the saxophonist Sonny Rollins and the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis finally came to pass Friday night at the Beacon Theater, and it was worth the wait. The concert was originally scheduled last month at Town Hall, but that show got off to a false start when Mr. Rollins fainted early in the first set, shortly after he first locked horns with Mr. Marsalis. It was rescheduled, and ticket holders were offered a choice of refunds or new tickets for the Beacon Theater show.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Indian Stakes
description: A Maine law forbade Sunday gambling for profit and set a $1,000-aday ceiling on purses for legal gambling. But the Penobscot Indian tribe operated beano games - the Indian equivalent of bingo - on their reservation on Sundays, with purses up to $5,000.

title: Pentagon Is Opposed to Use Of Troops in Central America
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has affirmed the opposition of the Pentagon to the use of combat troops in Central America.

title: PHILHARMONIC: FESTIVAL OF NEW MUSIC
description: Without the constant reminders -publicity, posters and symposiums -that the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' new-music festival is about ''new Romanticism,'' its second concert would have sounded like a perfectly ordinary contemporary music concert of the sort we have been encountering for the past couple of decades.

title: Jordan Wins N.A.I.A. Title
description: Al Jordan of Southwest Baptist of Missouri defeated Martin Dyotte of Belhaven in Mississippi, 6-4, 6-4, for the men's title in the National Association for Intercollegiate Athletics tennis championships today.

title: ONCE AGAIN, REVOLUTION ROLLS THROUGH
description: THE aftermath of the Battle of White Plains, fought in October 1776, marked the begining of a somber period in the history of the fledgling county of Westchester. After George Washington's retreat from a difficult series of skirmishes around the city of White Plains with forces under the British commander, Sir William Howe, his armies headed north to the Hudson Highlands and West Point, where the Continental Army would remain well established for much of the rest of the Revolutionary War.

title: CASINOS STIRRING FEW RIPPLES
description: PILES of unused lumber sit in a clearing here, their plastic wrapping shredded and flapping in the wind. Off in the scrub-oak woods nearby, more clearings have been gouged out by bulldozers, but only the wind disturbs the stillness. The silence at what was supposed to be the next stage of development at The Pinnacle, a 1,375-unit housing project, is a testament to plans and visions that have gone awry in South Jersey.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend for many pallid-but-ready sun worshipers marks the unofficial beginning of summer. Well, that soggy holiday was last weekend, and the county's pools and beaches, apparently operated by prophets, remained closed, as they will until June 18.

title: Campus Security At Stony Brook
description: The Task Force on Campus Safety and Security appreciates the thorough coverage of the question of arming on our campus (''Firearms on Campus Debated,'' May 15). However, we feel that there are one or two points that need clarifying.

title: Laura Sipe Is Married In Virginia
description: Laura Ann Sipe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Sipe of Harrisonburg, Va., was married there yesterday to William Constable Breed 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Breed 3d of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Randolph Bragg performed the ceremony in Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: RIFT BESETS GUIDE DOG AGENCY
description: INFIGHTING has split the supervisory ranks of the Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind and threatens to destroy the Smithtown-based agency, the only provider of guide dogs in the metropolitan area.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: THE QUIET ALLURE OF ALAN GREENSPAN
description: JUST last weekend, Alan Greenspan attended Henry Kissinger's lavish 60th birthday party accompanied by Barbara Walters. When not attending such elegant affairs, he can be found on television or in Washington or in the most powerful of corporate board rooms offering his views on economic affairs, politics and the social issues of the day. At age 57, Mr. Greenspan is one of the most popular guests on New York's party circuit - and one of America's leading and most sought after economists.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Old Acquaintances

title: Waltrip Wins Pole Spot; Sets Mark at Riverside
description: Darrell Waltrip's track record was broken twice by other drivers during qualifying for Sunday's Budweiser 400-kilometer stock car race at Riverside International Raceway, but by the end of the trials, the defending Winston Cup Grand National champion set the mark and won the pole position.

title: 8 Promoted as Reagan Aides
description: President Reagan has promoted eight members of the National Security Council to special assistant to the President, the White House announced Friday. They were Norman A. Bailey, senior director of international economic affairs; Richard S. Beal, senior director of crisis management support and planning; Donald R. Fortier, senior director of political-military affiars; Geoffrey T.H. Kemp, senior director of Near East and South Asian affairs; Ronald F. Lehman, senior director of defense programs and arms control; Walter Raymond Jr., senior director of international communications and information; Gaston J. Sigur Jr., senior director of Asian affairs, and Robert B. Sims, senior director of public affairs.

title: A SATELLITE DESTROYER THAT MUST BE STOPPED
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Advisory; MINI-OKTOBERFEST AND ART WAY OUT WEST; Beer to Flow At Belgian and Munich Fetes
description: Despite differing settings - big city, little village - it's altogether likely that Bacchus, the Greek god whose jurisdiction encompassed not merely wine but also revelry, would smile upon the tours that follow.

title: Yellen Takes Title
description: Mike Yellen of Southfield, Mich., defeated Rubin Gonzales of New York City, 11-6, 11-10, 11-3, today to win the national racquetball championship and a $10,000 prize.

title: Home Design; ADDING A NEW CURVE
description: ONE might expect the apartments in today's so-called luxury highrise buildings to have open, loftlike floor plans as sleek as their modern facades. But a look inside shows that most of them offer little more than a set of poorly proportioned rooms with layouts as predictable as that of a 1930's building. The apartment shown here, in an East Side high-rise barely 10 years old, was no exception. Though there is the luxury of space - about 2,500 square feet - the rooms were surprisingly conventional. Too conventional, in fact, for the owners, Barbara and Jon Landau. ''We didn't want our lives compartmentalized into a series of preordained cubbyholes,'' said Barbara Landau, who is a freelance editor. ''Who says books have to be relegated to a library or glass to a cupboard?''

title: U.S. PLAN TO FOCUS ON THE COASTLINE
description: COUNTY officials are expressing optimism that a recent $3,500 investment will yield dividends by generating interest in more effective use of Westchester's 48 miles of waterfront.

title: REAGAN GETTING A SOVIET EXPERT AS NEW ADVISER
description: President Reagan has decided to name Jack F. Matlock, currently Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, as his senior specialist on Soviet affairs, White House officials have disclosed.

title: WHERE HAS SAM SHEPARD LED HIS AUDIENCE?
description: During the more than 20 years that Sam Shepard has been writing for the theater he has gradually acquired what is called a cult audience. What is a cult audience? It is a band of faithful playgoers whose tastes are identical or at least strongly similar to one another's and who respond well, as a group, to the rather private and deliberately enigmatic signals being sent from the stage. This is indeed an audience and it is capable of some enlargement as devotees pass the word along to friends of like mind. A prolific writer - and Sam Shepard is certainly that, turning out new work yearly - may find productions of his plays on the increase, especially in regional theaters. He may also find his playing-time being extended here and there, while one or another of his pieces may come up with a prize, sometimes a prestigious one. And I suspect that he may, in passing and not really by calculation, make a reasonably good living as a professional dramatist.

title: Around the Nation; Puerto Rican Policeman Convicted in Kidnapping
description: A high-ranking police detective and two other men were convicted today in a Federal District Court in the kidnapping of the son of a jewelry wholesaler.

title: F.B.I. Liability For Violence
description: Many civil rights workers were convinced during the 1960's that the Federal Bureau of Investigation often ignored and sometimes even encouraged violence against them.

title: Topics; Flights of Fancy; Celebrity Birds
description: Urban birdwatching, you might call it. The Greenland brothers, Drew of New York and Seth of Los Angeles, engaged in a four-month, bicoastal competition to determine who could randomly spot more celebrities.

title: MAKING THE BEST USE OF NEW OFFICE SPACE
description: THE empty floors loom. Some day they will be a company's new offices, but now they are an unfinished, uncharted wilderness. If the executive in charge of the company's move is wondering in which corner the president's office should be and where the potted palms should go, he is asking the wrong questions.

title: Flights of Fancy; No-Nonsense Nymphs
description: What better way to add a touch of romance to an urban garden than to introduce a few nymphs? A woman in Brooklyn is about to do so in the patch behind her brownstone. But her nymphs won't be the kind that dart from tree to tree trailing delicate veils.

title: SPANISH PREMIER ASSAILS U.S. OVER LATIN POLICIES
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain, who ends a five-nation tour of Latin America Sunday, has used the occasion to criticize United States policy in the region.

title: Food; CREATING EPIGRAMS OF LAMB
description: We have noted before that we dote on lamb in almost any form, whether it be a roast leg, as part of a true Mongolian hot pot, in soup or stew, or even raw as in the Italian carpaccio with a wellseasoned oil and vinegar dressing.

title: PLANTING THE SEEDS OF NEW FARM POLICY
description: Another search is under way in Washington and other parts of the country for new Government programs that will nurture American farmers in a changing world without bankrupting the Treasury in the process. This attempt, the latest of several in the last 35 years, starts two full years before the expiration of current farm legislation. It appears to have greater urgency than its predecessors.

title: Drawing a Line in Central America
description: We have sighted the enemy and it is Congress, Administration officials seemed to be saying last week. Led by William P. Clark Jr., the White House national security adviser, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, the Administration decided to dig in and fight Congressional efforts to curb United States military aid and covert operations in Central America. No more bargaining to reach bipartisan compromises; instead, the officials reportedly argued, Congress should be forced to accept or reject Administration proposals outright.

title: Girls' Title Won By Brooklyn Tech
description: Marcelle Kendall, Tonja Rice and Monica Jackson were double winners yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League girls' outdoor track and field championships at John F. Kennedy High School's field in the Bronx.

title: BOOKS BARRED BY PRAGUE FIND NEW LIFE IN TORONTO
description: A noted Czech emigre novelist and his wife, also a writer, have set out to sustain Czech literature and redeem it from the political arbiters of culture in Prague, who have banned more than 200 writers.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: COUNTIES and municipalities that apply to the state's Green Acres program for funds from now on will have to demonstrate better openspace planning and greater concern for the environment, according to Helen Fenske, Assistant Commissioner for Natural Resources in the Department of Environmental Protection.

title:
ART;
HIGH-TONED URBANITY IN THE COUNTRY
description: IT'S subtropical-sounding name is not the only unusual thing about Yellow Monkey Village in sylvan Cross River. The commercial businesses in this storybook complex are several notches above the usual, too.

title: THE COMPLETE BRAHMS IN ONE PACKAGE
description: While there has been some recording activity by various companies on the occasion of Brahms's sesquicentennial this year, by far the most ambitious project is that by Deutsche Grammophon, which has dutifully issued the first-ever integral recording of Brahms's complete works.

title: STEPFAMILIES: A BID TO COME TO TERMS
description: THERE are families that are referred to as blended, stepfamily, recombined or reconstituted. What are they? Besides being uncomfortable, they are different from other families. The relationship between parents and children predates the marriage. This structural difference has an everlasting impact that must be recognized if the family is to survive as a unit.

title: FRESH IDEAS PROPEL A BIG BAND
description: When Bob Moses was 12 years old, he kept his drums set up in the living room of his parents' Manhattan apartment, near the piano. That way, he could practice by playing with musically inclined guests, and there were plenty of those. One was Charles Mingus, who would quaff several ice cream sodas, then sit down at the piano. ''Mingus would be yelling at me from the piano bench,'' Mr. Moses recalled recently. ''He kept telling me I wasn't playing sloppy enough.''

title: NEW YORK HUNTERS KILLED 185,455 DEER IN '82
description: Hunters in New York State killed 185,455 deer, 7,313 wild turkeys and 694 black bears in the 1982 hunting season, according to reports issued by the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THREE individuals and three organizations have been named winners of the sixth annual arts awards to be presented on June 25 by the Connecticut Commission on the Arts. Recipients of the specially designed medallions for 1983 are Arvin Brown, artistic director of the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven for 16 years; James Merrill, of Stonington, Pulitzer Prize-winning poet in 1977 for ''Divine Comedies'' and author of the recently published ''Changing Light at Sandover;'' Jackie McLean, jazz saxophonist and chairman of the African/American Music Department at the Hartt School of Music in Hartford; the William Benton Museum of Art at the University of Connecticut in Storrs for its innovative exhibitions, and the Greater Hartford Arts Council, which raises more than $1 million a year for 50 arts groups in 23 towns.

title: Miss Miller Weds Matthew R. Korn
description: Cynthia Kathleen Miller, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Orlando J. Miller of Teaneck, N.J., was married yesterday to Matthew Richard Korn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Korn of Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Stephen S. Pearce performed the ceremony in the common room of Silliman College at Yale University.

title: ART
description: People sometimes think - and the auction houses do not always contradict them - that only in the auction rooms can you find certain kinds of great pictures for sale.

title: Data Bank  June 5, 1983
STATE OBTAINS DEVICE FOR TESTING THE TINT OF VEHICLE WINDOWS
description: The state finally has the proper equipment to start enforcing a law against windows in vehicles that have too much tint on them, according to officials of the Department of Motor Vehicles.

title: Wretched Refuse Suit Is Settled
description: The tide turned last week in a New Jersey community's four-year effort to stop New York City trash from washing up on its beaches. Federal Judge Herbert J.
