Stern ordered the city to reimburse Woodbridge ''dollar for dollar'' for cleanup costs; since it filed suit in 1979, the township has spent $90,000 but received only $74,000 from the city.

title: A VETERAN VISITOR, HOSTS AND FRESH AIR
description: JORGE CAMACHO visited his home in Glen Cove last week, and everything seemed just as he had left it a year ago. The porcelain collie he bought in a Penn Station gift shop was tucked between plants in the living room as its breathing canine counterpart lumbered about the house. The freezer was stocked with his favorite chocolate-chip ice cream, and the family garden was showing early signs of his least favorite vegetable, zucchini.

title: Susannah P. MacDonald Weds William D. Perkins
description: Susannah Patricia MacDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor R. MacDonald of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to William David Perkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sterling Perkins of Edina, Minn.

title: BEHIND ENEMY LINES
description: If winning material requires that you end up with a piece deep in enemy territory it stands to reason that you should have given some thought to how it might get home again. Otherwise your bird in hand might be canceled by the bird ensnared in the opponent's bush.

title: VIDEO CELEBRATION OF THE KILLER INSTINCT
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Nicholas Torriero Marries Helen C. Kaltner
description: Helen Claire Kaltner of Laconia, N.H., and New York was married yesterday to Robert Nicholas Torriero of Gloucester Point, Va., and New York in a garden ceremony at Tappan Hill Inn, Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Allen Wells, a Unitarian minister, and the Rev. Ronan Grimshaw, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony

title: 2 AGENCIES SEEK TO SHUT JEWISH MEMORIAL HOSPITAL
description: The Federal Health Care Financing Administration is acting to force the closing of Jewish Memorial Hospital in the Inwood section because of what the agency says are deficiencies that ''threaten the health and well-being'' of the patients there.

title: Bombs Defused in Jerusalem
description: Policemen safely dismantled two large bombs near Jerusalem's Old City today, averting a possibly heavy loss of life in an area frequented by tourists, a spokesman for the Jerusalem police said. The spokesman, Ziv Rotem, said one bomb was discovered by a passer-by who alerted the police. After dismantling the explosives, policemen found another bomb and defused it too, he said. Mr. Rotem said 12 or 13 suspects had been detained for questioning.

title:
DINING OUT;
A FLOWERY SETTING IN PLAINFIELD
description: THE shaped-glass front of Lily Greenleaves in Plainfield makes the place look more like a greenhouse full of hanging plants than a restaurant. However, a closer look reveals plastic plants and the sort of bric-a-brac (old wooden sleds, etc.) usually found in a second-hand store. Inside, however, the plants are real.

title: Cubs Activate Noles
description: The Chicago Cubs have activated the right-handed pitcher Dickie Noles, who had been undergoing alcohol rehabilitation treatment since April 12.

title: Miss Dudderar Weds W.P. Rockefeller
description: Lisenne Dudderar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Dudderar of Little Rock, Ark., was married yesterday to Winthrop Paul Rockefeller, son of Barbara (Bobo) Sears Rockefeller of New York and the late Winthrop Rockefeller, Governor of Arkansas from 1966 to 1970. Judge Richard S. Arnold of the Eighth United States Circuit Court of Appeals performed the ceremony on the grounds of the Rockefeller home on Petit Jean Mountain near Morrilton, Ark.

title: THE LOSS OF CHILDHOOD
description: I take issue with Marie Winn's view of lost childhood. It is the children who were raised in the Age of Protection who have rebelled against the institution of the family, and, in my opinion, often refused to accept adulthood and the responsibilities of adults toward children.

title:
ART;
CELEBRATING LAND AND SEA
description: SKY, water and land configurations are among the most broadly appealing themes in art. We like the reaffirmation of familiar experience, and we can be deeply moved by images that reflect infinity, vastness and nature's continuum.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE WRECK OF THE ZEPHYR, Written and illustrated by Chris Van Allsburg. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $14.95. (Ages 7 and Up)

title: DANCE: WORK BY MISS FISHER
description: At least this much was clear: On Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Margaret Fisher presented ''The True and False Occult -The False and True Occult.'' Miss Fisher, a dancer from San Francisco, contributed both the choreography and the elaborate decor, and her two-act piece was inspired, in part, by paintings by R.B. Kitaj. The recorded accompaniment included a score by Robert Hughes and traditional Japanese music. And the cast consisted of Janet Jaffe, Mia Borgatta and Miss Fisher.

title: Bomber Behind Bars
description: J.B. Stoner is caged at last. The white supremacist, who was convicted three years ago of bombing a black church in Birmingham, Ala., in 1968, surrendered to authorities in Montgomery last week to begin a 10-year prison sentence. Mr. Stoner said he had gone into hiding in January, when his sentence was to have begun, because he ''wanted to live a little longer'' and feared black inmates would kill him.

title: Beauty; LOOKING GOOD IN EYEGLASSES
description: Cosmetic considerations are important when selecting frames, which should complement an individual's facial features.

title: OF CIVIL RIGHTS AND GROUP PREFERENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER SUNRISE, THUNDER PUDDLES WIN
description: Super Sunrise, an English-bred colt, and Thunder Puddles, who was born and raised in New York, scored minor upsets to make off with separate divisions of the Red Smith Handicap yesterday on the grass at Belmont Park.

title: COMMUNITY SERVICE TAKES PLACE OF JAIL
description: GEORGE WHITE was caught running a betting game in Jersey City, and so he was doing time. But instead of spending it in the crowded Hudson County Jail, where he might have been sent several years ago, he was scrubbing wheelchairs and doing other maintenance work at Pollack Hospital in Jersey City, a few miles from his home.

title: RADIATION AID PROMISED TOWN
description: IT WILL take at least a year, but Frances Cielo will be able to sleep peacefully at night, knowing that low-level radiation no longer emanates from the land surrounding her bedroom.

title: THE ALGARVE: NOT JUST A SUNNY PLACE
description: There is more to the Algarve then meets the eye, particularly if the eye is shut against a blazing sun on a swath of amber beach. Aside from the hundred miles of mostly sandy Atlantic coastline and wine-carved cliffs that hem Portugla's southernmost province, the Algarve offers attractions that the single-minded sun worshipper might easily miss.

title: RX FOR HEALTH COSTS: STRESSING WELLNESS
description: ''I THINK the largest problem we have today is the ever increasing cost of health care,'' said Edwin R. Werner of Manhasset, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York. He said that 1982 ''is the first year we spent in excess of 10 percent of the gross national product for health.''

title: Miss Miller Is Engaged To Wed Craig C. Reilly
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee D. Miller of McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melanie Blair Miller, to Craig Crandall Reilly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald D. Reilly of Greenwich, Conn., and Vero Beach, Fla.

title: TRYING NEW TACTICS IN SEARCH OF SALVADORAN MILITARY GAINS
description: Indications that the Administration intends to follow a tougher military and political line against the guerrillas in El Salvador have raised the prospect of greater use of special counterinsurgency tactics. The Pentagon last week announced it would be sending 100 Green Berets from its Special Forces to train the Salvadoran military and that counterinsurgency would be emphasized.

title: CALCUTTA, SYMBOL OF URBAN MISERY, WON'T GIVE UP
description: For a city long pictured as the ultimate urban disaster area, a place of putrefying decay and absolute human misery, Calcutta rises awfully early, works awfully hard and radiates an astonishing amount of energy.

title: 2 P.L.O. FACTIONS CLASH IN LEBANON IN HEAVY FIGHTING
description: Heavy fighting broke out today for the first time between Palestinian guerrilla factions in eastern Lebanon. The violence grows out of a continuing rebellion by some Palestine Liberation Organization units whose members are opposed to Yasir Arafat's leadership. Mr. Arafat himself was out of the country at the time, having left for a visit to Rumania Friday after a daylong vister, he flew to Algeria for a two-hour meeting with President Chadli Benjedid, United Press International reported.)

title: Index; International
description: Shultz replaced two Latins aides as part of Reagan pact 3 Manual instructs Nicaraguan guerrillas on sabotage 4 Grenada's chief acknowledges jailing up to 40 without charge 6 Around the World 7 Quake stirs fears of a major dis- aster in Japan 8 Peking is puzzled by Mongolia's harassment of Chinese 9 Calcutta, symbol of urban mis- ery, won't give up 10 Israel pressed to crack down on Jewish vigilantes in West Bank 12 Antiwar rally staged in Israel 13 Weinberger says Soviet has atom warheads in East Europe 16 Emigre writer in Canada sets up Czech publishing business 21 Government/Politics Jeep's bigger little brother fail- ing Pentagon tests 22 Jewish leader defends Reagan's nominees for rights panel 24 Wyoming editor challenges Sena- tor on workers and MX 25 Five years after Proposition 13, a California power shift 26 California pension funds are termed seriously understaffed 28 Vidotaped confessions increasing convictions in city 30 Queens celebrating its 300th birthday as a county 30 Cuomo sets new rules for use of state planes 31 State receives the equipment to enforce law on car-window tint 31 Reporter's Notebook: The City Hall budget dramatics 34 City's tax panel handles 30,000 property-assessment appeals 35 General Around the Nation 18 In Utah, snow sets a scene for springtime in the Rockies 18 Tribes win 10-year battle over sa- cred site 19 Widow regains house that was sold at a tax auction 20 Police still seeking two men in slaying of store owner 29 Health/Science U.S. agency seeks closing of Jew- ish Memorial Hospital 36 New foundation will focus on medical research 43 Education/Welfare Supervisors told schools face troubled times 30 Arts/Entertainment Sales of best-selling hardcover books have risen 52 Sonny Rollins meets Wynton Marsalis in concert 52 Two pianists among debut recit- alists 53 ''The Salamander,'' an Italian film, stars Franco Nero 53 A work by Margaret Fisher, a dancer and choreographer 53 New York Philharmonic's new- music festival 54 Style On West 17th Street, a panorama of fake flowers 55 Survey finds that older singles value tradition 55 Obituaries Harry Lieberman, a primitive- style painter 32 Charles Zimmerman, vice presi- dent of the garment workers 32

title: Braves Defeat Cardinals
description: Terry Harper drove in four runs today with a three-run homer and a tiebreaking single in the sixth inning as the Atlanta Braves stretched their winning streak to five games with a 6-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Childproofing in Co-ops
description: Question: I have been a tenant in a co-op apartment for four years. During this time several families in the building, including my own, have had children. We have large windows without guards. Can you tell me whose responsibility it is to childproof the windows - the corporation's, or the shareholder's? ... H.F., Manhattan.

title: JAPAN'S NEW TEST IN CHIPS
description: BORDERED by majestic hills and mountains that are the work of volcanic rumblings of eons past, this verdant plain on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu seems a portrait of benign tranquillity. Yet it is from here that Japan developed and built what has become the symbol of its mighty semiconductor industry the 64K random access memory chip.

title: GRENADA'S LEADER CONCEDES JAILING UP TO 40 FOES
description: Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada, who has been accused by the Reagan Administration of human rights abuses, has acknowledged that his Government has jailed up to 40 people without charge or trial.

title: CONNECTICUT MOVES TO AID WORKERS AFFECTED BY PLANT CLOSINGS
description: Connecticut companies with more than 100 employees would have to pay health and medical benefits to workers for 90 days after a plant closing or relocation under legislation that received final approval in the General Assembly this week.

title: FEARS OF PARENTS ALLAYED BY FRESH AIR 'VETERANS'
description: Gloria Vouse wanted to get her three children away from the crowded streets and asphalt playgrounds in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn and let them see the countryside. She wanted them to meet children from different backgrounds and to broaden their understanding of the world outside of New York City.

title: ARMY'S REPLACEMENT FOR JEEP FAILING PENTAGON BATTLE TESTS
description: A new Army vehicle designed to play many key roles in combat has repeatedly failed tests under battle conditions and has a ''very low'' reliability, according to a Pentagon report made available today.

title: SHULTZ REPLACED LATIN AIDES AS PART OF A REAGAN PACT
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz agreed to replace his two chief advisers on El Salvador as part of an arrangement he worked out with President Reagan 10 days ago to regain control of day-to-day management of Central American policy, wellplaced Reagan Administration officials say.

title: ACROSS THE SOUND FROM SHOREHAM
description: BY road they are more than 100 miles apart, but as the neutron flies, the Long Island Lighting Company's new reactor at Shoreham is less than 20 miles from the coast of Connecticut around New Haven. Officials on both sides of Long Island Sound are getting a quick refresher in geography.

title: ROCKING CHAIRS AND CLIMBING ROCKS
description: They came, in those days, by stagecoach or the sleeping cars of the White Mountain Express, and they stayed in rambling, wooden hotels with porches that reached, or so it seemed, to the sky. They walked by the streams, they played a spot of badminton, they sat in the parlors and, with the resident orchestra playing softly in the background, they sipped champagne punch.

title: VAULTS FOR LEASING
description: Washington A. Roebling, the chief engineer of the Brooklyn Bridge, once remarked that the vaults underneath his structure were so safe that the Federal Treasury could be kept there.

title: BACK IN COLLEGE AT 34
description: THE first-period bell rang, and I sat staring at the blackboard, wondering what I was doing there. It was 8:45 A.M. on a cold January morning, and already I was limp from racing out of my house, finding a legal parking space and searching out Canisius 21. That was my classroom. Fortunately, when I found it, it was virtually empty, and I quickly took a front row seat across the room from the door. Unfortunately, in my rush to sit down and become as inconspicious as possible, I forgot that I hated sitting away from the door in a full classroom.

title: Headliners; Lost Years
description: Compensation of $42,000 a year may sound like a lot for doing nothing - unless you have to do it in prison. Certainly Isidore Zimmerman was none too happy with the sum when the New York State Court of Claims awarded him $1 million last week for spending 24 years in prison for a murder conviction shown to be based on evidence falsified by the prosecutor. Mr. Zimmerman, now 64 years old, said he ''should have gotten much more'' because he was denied an opportunity to have a career or children, among other things. He had asked for $10 million but said he would not appeal the smaller award because he needed the money immediately.

title: WHO STARTED THIS?
description: THE HEARTS OF MEN, American Dreams and the Flight From Commitment. By Barbara Ehrenreich. 206 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $13.95.

title: Chantilly
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Ericksen, Ana Castillo Wed
description: Ana Castillo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro A. Castillo of Darien, Conn., and formerly of Havana, was married yesterday to Michael Ericksen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Ericksen of Cincinnati. The Rev. Henry Albeke performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Noroton, Conn.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHAT'S worse than losing a pair of gloves? If you don't know the answer to that, you don't know what's worse than finding a worm in an apple. The answers are: 1. Losing one glove. 2. Finding half a worm.

title: U.S. INQUIRY SOUGHT ON BEEF-RAISING
description: MODERN methods of raising farm animals, and the potential dangers to humans who eat those animals, are the subjects of legislation proposed by Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of Spring Lake Heights.

title: O'ROURKE REJECTS DEVELOPER'S OFFER ON PARK PROPERTY
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke last week rejected a developer's proposal to swap some parkland for private property in White Plains -the builder's object being 600 units of new housing - and decided, instead, to spend $100,000 upgrading the park, Silver Lake.

title: LOVE IN AN OLD-AGE HOME
description: IN THE PALOMAR ARMS, By Hilma Wolitzer. 307 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $14.95.

title: Seal Pie
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Peruvian Security Forces Discover Guerrilla Center
description: Peruvian security forces said today that they had broken up a guerrilla training center in the Andean mountain province of Ayacucho.

title: Mary Ann Shea Weds A. T. Farley
description: Mary Ann Shea, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shea of Brookville, L.I., was married there yesterday at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church to Alexander Thomson Farley, son of Jane T. Farley of Mill Neck, L.I., and Edward I. Farley of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. William H. Weeks of the College of the Holy Cross performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Mario Costa, pastor of St. Paul's.

title: RATE-RISE REQUEST RALLIES SHOREHAM FOES
description: A WEEK after the Long Island Lighting Company requested the largest electric rate increase in state history, anti-Shoreham demonstrators ended their 100-day vigil outside the $3.2 billion reactor by preparing for yesterday's rally at the town beach and today's planned sit-in at the plant gates.

title: Miss Tagliaferro to Perform
description: Magda Tagliaferro, the 90-year-old French pianist, will make her first New York appearance in two seasons next Wednesday at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Thomas Wins Tennis
description: Second-seeded Keith Thomas of Pleasantville upset top-seeded John Schmitt of Jericho, L. I., 6-4, 6-4, today to win the New York State scholastic singles tennis championship. Westchester County won the team championship with 49 points, to 44 for the runner-up, Nassau.

title: Fashion; SEEKING WIDER MARKETS
description: In order to reach a new audience, many fashion designers are catering to women who could not afford their higher-priced collections.

title: CHANGES PLANNED FOR SUBWAYS TO ROCKAWAYS AND WEST SIDE
description: Changes in the JFK Express proposed last week are part of an effort to improve subway service in the Rockaways and along Central Park West and the Avenue of the Americas, according to the Transit Authority.

title: Coach Softens Stand
description: When the United States Football League signed Herschel Walker while he was still a junior at Georgia, Bill Yeoman, the Houston football coach, was one of those who expressed outrage and joined the clamor to ban U.S.F.L. recruiters from college campuses. Now Yeoman has softened his stand.

title: GLIDING IN MIDAIR ENTRANCES ITS FANS
description: ''PULL that red knob in front of you,'' said Mark Rovere, a soaring instructor, to the first-time pilot seated with him in the cockpit of the sleek yellow sailplane.

title: MAPPING THE SPACE AGE
description: ''What's the color got to do with it?'' asks Tom. ''It's got everything to do with it. Illinois is green, Indiana is pink. You show me any pink down here, if you can. No, sir; it's green.''

title: IN PURSUIT OF BRITTLE-BONE CLUES
description: THERE was no family history of skeletal defects, but the baby was born with many broken bones, slightly shortened extremities and thin blue sclera. After four days of seizures and respiratory distress, the infant died.

title: ON ICAHN
description: To the Business Editor:

title: HOUSE PANEL IN DISPUTE OVER AIDS RESEARCH DATA
description: A New York Congressman has charged that the Public Health Service rebuffed Congressional efforts to monitor its search for the cause of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, a mysterious disease that has killed more than 550 people in the last two years.

title: Hadrian's Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers in Florida House Vote to Restore Chain Gangs
description: Florida's House of Representatives has voted to bring back the chain gang for prison inmates who refuse to take part in voluntary work programs.

title: A BANK LIKE A PAGODA
description: When Golden Pacific Bank made plans to place its national headquarters building in lower Manhattan, it was determined that the design of the structure should reflect the architectural heritage of the Chinese-American community it would serve. So for the past 14 months, a pagoda-styled building has been rising on the corner of Canal and Centre Streets in Chinatown.

title: YEAR AFTER FLOOD, THE REBUILDING CONTINUES
description: A YEAR after the floods that devastated much of Connecticut last June, homes and businesses, dams, roads, bridges and other damaged property are still being mended. In Essex, George Washburn Jr. spends weekends rebuilding his 150-year-old house. In the village of Centerbrook, a group of residents is soliciting money to rebuild the privately owned Mill Pond Dam. In Milford the tax collector, Joel Baldwin, works in a makeshift office in the City Hall auditorium because the flood evicted him from his old basement office. In New Haven, road signs still prohibit traffic from traveling the length of Valley Street.

title: GIMME A J, GIMME AN E,GIMME AN R
description: IT ALL started with a Murphy bed, one of those fold-in-the-wall items that seemed to pop out regularly in the two-reel comedies of Hollywood's early days. The bed, installed to convert a retirement home guest room into an office, brought an echo of our native New Jersey when we learned that it was made in Lodi.

title: Life From Chemicals
description: Life may be considerably more durable than fragile humans have supposed, judging by the bacteria that inhabit volcanic vents on the ocean floor. According to two American biologists, the bacteria live and multiply at temperatures as high as 482 degrees Fahrenheit - more than twice as hot as conditions under which life was thought possible.

title: A House in the Georgian Mode
description: We certainly do not need to be reminded that money can buy anything and everything.

title: To Own or Rent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Judge in Soybean Case Has Second Thoughts
description: Federal Judge G. Thomas Eisele, who criticized the jury that acquitted a Missouri farmer for taking impounded soybeans from a bankrupt grain elevator, says he is having second thoughts after talking to his mother.

title: Last Suburban Schools Accept St. Louis Plan
description: The last holdout suburban school district has agreed to a desegregation pact that, if approved by a Federal district judge, would be the country's first comprehensive plan to exchange students voluntarily between a major American city and its suburbs.

title: DEATH IN A CLASSROOM
description: I WAS searching, head in hand, for yet another way to approach poetry and poetics, to get beyond the groans of ''Poetry again?'' ''Do we have to?'' ''Why do we have to know that?'' when I heard the radio report: a substitute teacher's aide, armed with khaki uniform, brogans and .22, had taken Room 201 of Brentwood East Junior High. He'd shot a boy - and the principal, too. He had a class of kids held hostage. Those poor kids, I thought.

title: 'SOCIAL ISSUES' REHEATED TO WARM UP THE G.O.P.
description: Twice recently a Senate subcommittee scheduled sessions to draft a constitutional amendment that would permit organized prayer in public schools. Both meetings were canceled when the White House and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who heads the panel, could not agree on a proposal.

title: Trainee Wed To Ann Clark
description: At the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday, Ann Warner Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield and Ocean Reef, Fla., was married to Jeffrey Philip Lupoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Irwin Lupoff of Sarasota, Fla. The Rev. Stanley Houston performed the ceremony.

title:
GARDENING;
PROBLEMS LEFT BY THE TAMING OF NATURE
description: A SOFT breeze rippled through the waist-high grasses creating miniature ocean-like waves of the nodding stems. The red-and-white cloverheads scattered among the grasses were literally buzzing with the activity of slender, golden honey bees and fat black-and-gold bumble bees searching for sweet nectar. While flitting from one tall clump of grass to another, meadowlarks, red wing blackbirds and a myriad of golden finches pausedbriefly to lift their melodious songs skyward. Off in the distance, a kildeer defended his territory by repeating over and over the characteristic song from which he acquired his name.

title: MURDER IN THE MONASTERY
description: THE NAME OF THE ROSE, By Umberto Eco. Translated by William Weaver. 502 pp. New York: A Helen & Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: Fare of the Country; YANKEE STAPLE: CLAM FRY
description: For several generations now, the smells of a New England summer have inevitably included the pungent sizzle of frying clams. But this was not always so. There was a time when New Englanders only ate these ineffable bivalves raw, on the half-shell; steamed, with butter, or diced, in milky chowders. But on July 3, 1916, a seminal event in gastronomical history took place.

title: European Socialism
description: To the Editor:

title: ATTACKS ON KEEPING 4 A.M. BAR CLOSINGS
description: ''THE battle may have been lost, but the war is by no means over,'' Martin S. Quigley was saying last week. Mr. Quigley, the Mayor of Larchmont, joined a chorus of criticism aimed at the county's Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, which had ruled that bars may continue to serve until 4 A.M.

title: FRAZIER DEFEATS BUGNER
description: Completing a successful afternoon for the Frazier boxing family, Marvis Frazier, the oldest son of the former world heavyweight champion Joe Frazier, outjabbed a surprisingly fit Joe Bugner today to win a unanimous 10-round decison.

title: About Men; MALE HUMOR
description: Most of us, if we are male, have gathered in groups that happened to be exclusively masculine. On those occasions, at least according to my experience, it is extremely common to have conversation turn to an exchange of off-color jokes.

title: DUDLEY MOORE PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: Dudley Moore, the well-known comic actor (''Arthur,'' ''10''), has become passionate about chamber music. So much so that he will appear at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening as a pianist, playing Beethoven's Triple Concerto with the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, Robert Mann, violinist, and Nathaniel Rosen, cellist, under the baton of Pinchas Zukerman. Mr. Moore has done a bit of classical concert work in Los Angeles, but this will his first in New York.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOR environmental reasons, the Town of Babylon may consider implementing a moratorium on construction along a seven-mile stretch of beach between Captree Island and Oak Beach. Because of erosion and piecemeal expansion in the area, the Town Board has set up a special panel to formulate a master development plan for the area over the next 20 years.

title: REPORTERS NOTEBOOK: CLOSING DAYS
description: WITH the General Assembly heading toward Wednesday's scheduled adjournment, some of the end-of-session frustrations surfaced last week in an unlikely form - a poem tucked between committee meeting notices in the legislature's daily bulletin. It said: Here at the Capitol under the dome Representatives grunt while Senators groan. What's going on, what do they do? While Senators snooze, the House is a zoo. The public is baffled, very perplexed This vision of lawmaking makes them quite vexed. So I say to all who admire the law Or hold the savor of sausage in awe, Stay home in bed, you should be afraid, Never watch sausage or laws being made. The poet was Representative David O. Thorp, a Cheshire Republican, who borrowed the idea from a quotation from the Prussian chancellor Bismarck.

title: Kate L. Stone Is Married to Michael J. Lombardi
description: Kate Lawson Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stone of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Joseph Lombardi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Lombardi of Rockville, Md. Judge John F. Holden Jr. of White Plains City Court performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE BROADWAY SEASON HAD ITS HIGHS - AND TOO MANY LOWS
description: It's only fitting that the Tony Awards ceremony, to be broadcast on network television from the Uris Theater tonight, is billed as a tribute to George and Ira Gershwin. If the Tony extravaganza actually tried to celebrate Broadway's present instead of push nostalgia, the show would probably run only 20 minutes. The just-concluded 1982-83 theater season - the ostensible subject of tonight's festivities - was a gloomy burial ground, now and then brightened by unexpected shafts of light. Though the theater at its best can often send audiences into passionate debate, this year the main question on everyone's lips seemed to be a plaintive, insistent, ''Did you see 'Moose Murders'?''

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: The pianist Bernard Rose studied at the Juilliard School and Columbia University and is currently a member of the Rose-Nagata-Kreger Trio. On Thursday night, Mr. Rose made his New York debut at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: What's New in Lobbying; LAWYERS NEED NOT APPLY
description: In the past, high-powered Washington law firms did a good deal of high-powered Washington lobbying. And the work was done e - not surprisingly - by lawyers. But now, with increasing frequency, some of the city's major firms are hiring professional lobbyists, who are not also professional lawyers.

title: Miss Creviston Weds Reginald C. Shiverick
description: Charlotte Lynn Creviston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Creviston of Urbana, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Reginald Coombe Shiverick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Asa Shiverick Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. David Fleming performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Urbana.

title: Practical Traveler; GUIDEPOSTS FOR A NEW ENGLAND VACATION
description: Perhaps more than any other part of the United States, New England abounds in travel literature this year. There is information and advice for almost every recreational interest and a wealth of guidebooks and directories to suggest places to dine and spend the night, from luxury resorts to budget motels to rustic country inns.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS: 'LIFERS' AND THE PARDONED
description: To the Editor:

title: RIDGEWAY OIL EXPLORATION & DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $31,988 for the latest year and $296,135 for the previous year.

title: Hingsen Regains Decathlon Record
description: Jurgen Hingsen of West Germany recaptured the world record in the decathlon today with a total of 8,777 points.

title: Advertising; Four Leave W.R.G. for Own Shop
description: WITHOUT doubt, there lies in the heart of many an advertising man or woman the ambition, coiled like a spring, to run his or her own agency. This week a spring will snap, and a new agency will be born with the name of Fredericks Kullberg Amato Pisacane Inc.

title: TREES MAY ALERT OTHER TREES TO DANGER, SCIENTISTS BELIEVE
description: Some scientists now suspect that trees can in effect warn one another of danger by releasing chemicals into the air. Researchers are preparing new experiments that they hope will confirm the tentative findings of their initial tests, the National Science Foundation announced yesterday. If they are successful, the science foundation said, they will probably be the first to show that plants emit signals that are received and responded to by other plants.

title: Stanford Gains in Baseball
description: Steve Cottrell and Kevin Kunkel combined for a four-hitter as No.2-ranked Stanford eliminated James Madison, 3-1, in the College World Series tonight.

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-Includes a charge of $143,000, or 6 cents a share, for a contract settlement on an unemployment agreement with a former company officer.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983
description: International Leaders of the O.A.U. will try again, for the third and possibly last time, to end rifts that threaten the role the Organization of African Unity has sought to play for two decades in Africa. There was uncertainly about whether the attempt would succeed as African leaders began arriving in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, for preliminary negotiations to determine whether the O.A.U. twice-postponed 19th summit meeting can take place. (Page A1, Column 3.) An attempt to stop further sabotage in South Africa by the underground African National Congress will be made by shutting the group's military wing out of neighboring black states, South Africa's highest-ranking military official said. Gen. Constand Viljoen, chief of the Defense Force, said this isolation could be accomplished through a combination of military and diplomatic pressure. (A1:3.)

title: Moths Plague South Jersey
description: Defoliation by gypsy moths is a problem this year in the southern half of New Jersey, but the leaf-munching insects are avoiding the northern parts of the state, according to the State Department of Agriculture.

title: CABARET: NINA SIMONE
description: MOST pop musicians are happy just to please an audience. But the obstreperous and brilliant Nina Simone, who returned to New York to sing at Swing Plaza this weekend after a five-year absence, demands more than polite appreciation. Rooted in extreme emotional ambivalence, her performances have the aura of sacramental rites, in which a priestess and her flock work to establish a mystical communion. Because of Miss Simone's fabled temperament, however, communion is not a foregone conclusion. Each performance becomes a group psychodrama that could as easily topple into disaster as soar into triumph. But at Swing Plaza on Friday, Miss Simone triumphed over an obvious case of nerves and physical discomfort to end up smiling.

title: Nuptials for Sylvia Harry
description: Sylvia Norman Duncan Harry and Dr. Frank W. Macdonald, both of New Orleans, were married yesterday at the St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York. Msgr.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Anniversary Award

title: SOVIET RABBI PROTESTS TO U.S. OVER ACTIVITIES OF A DIPLOMAT
description: The rabbi of Moscow's only synagogue recently sent a letter of protest to the United States Embassy about weekly visits by an American diplomat, and drew a stiff retort from Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman.

title: WEST GERMAN VENTURE CAPITAL
description: In 1976, Volker Dolch, an engineer, turned a backyard project into a flourishing company, making a product that tells whether a computer chip is working properly. When it came time to expand last August, though, the company found it hard to raise cash in West Germany.

title: Hardee's President; BUSINESS PEOPLE; Moves to Pepsico Unit
description: John E. Martin, who has worked for several major fast-food operations, has taken a job as president and chief executive of Pepsico Inc.'s Boulangerie bakery division.

title: DANCE: THREE DEBUTS IN BALLET THEATER 'BAYADERE'
description: SOMETHING interesting happens in the audience at the Metropolitan Opera House at every performance of American Ballet Theater's ''La Bayadere.'' When the curtain rises on a scenic and choreographic mixture of ancient India and academic ballet, some people titter. And when hunters carry in a stuffed tiger, the titters increase. But soon after that, all tittering stops, for the ballet has started to cast its spell. ''La Bayadere'' may be broad in its depictions of the emotions, but its emotional appeals are never false.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
FEDERAL CO reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
EXECUTIVES
description: * Advest Inc. has named Robert A. Fogliano vice president and director of the newly created futures department.

title: SCOT LAD FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Includes $4.8 million in costs and writedowns associated with the purchase of A. & P. stores and a tax credit of $70,000. c-After a tax benefit of $174,000. d-Net income The 1983 results include a gain of $126,000 and the year-ago results include a loss of $1,574,000 on facility closings.

title: Harold Ames, Banker And Automaker, Dies
description: Harold Ames, industrialist, banker and creator of two classic American automobiles, died at Eisenhower Medical Center Thursday after a lengthy illness. He was 89 years old.

title: CHERRY ELECTRICAL PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Caught in Court; Return to the Gulag
description: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has done more than expose the horrors of the Soviet penal system. He has used royalties from ''The Gulag Archipelago'' to help new victims of repression by creating a fund that for a decade has operated from Switzerland.

title: Newspapers and TV Expand Ad Revenues
description: Newspapers and television both showed advertising revenue increases in this year's first quarter.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Melting Pot

title: BRIEFING
description: Marching to the Right

title: AIRLINE TAKING STEPS TO COMBAT WIND SHEAR
description: Republic Airlines has taken the first steps in an ambitious project to install airborne devices to help cope with one of aviation's worst hazards, the phenomenon known as wind shear.

title: HADRON INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $129,000. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition by Hadron of Acumenics Research & Technology Inc. on March 23, 1983 on a pooling of interests basis.

title: STARS DEFEAT PANTHERS
description: Chuck Fusina completed 17 of 22 passes for 149 yards in the second half, including 3 for touchdowns, as the Philadelphia Stars rallied today from a 14-9 deficit to beat the Michigan Panthers, 29-20.

title: Essay; IGNORING SECTION 4
description: At 4:30 P.M. on March 30, 1981, the President was undergoing surgery to remove a bullet in his lung at George Washington Hospital; his three top staff aides were at the hospital; the Vice President was airborne. In the White House Situation Room, the counsel to the President, Fred Fielding, laid before Secretary of State Haig and the Vice President's chief of staff, Adm. Dan Murphy - for study and discussion - the documents needed to put into effect the never-before-used Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to the Constitution.

title: BESANA GALD TO GET ONE MORE CHANCE
description: In 1978, the quarterback Fred Besana was released by the Buffalo Bills five days before the team's first regular-season game. During training camp in 1979, Besana was released by the Giants.

title: ORTHODOX JEWISH WOMEN PUSH ROLE IN PRAYER
description: Rivka Landau's clear voice filled the room with the flowing tones of traditional Hebrew prayer. As she chanted, ''Baruch atah Adonai, Elohenu melech haolam'' (''Blessed be Thou, our Lord, King of the Universe''), more than 100 women, some of them wearing prayer shawls, stood to join in the response.

title: GRAVE OF STUDENT RALLIES THE POLES
description: The grave of a young man who died after being held by the police has become the latest symbol of resentment felt by many Poles for their Government.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the Business People column Friday gave an incorrect street number for the New York branch of Creditanstalt-Bankverein. It is at 717 Fifth Avenue.

title: 'CATS' AND 'TORCH SONG TRILOGY' WIN TOP TONYS
description: ''Cats,'' the British musical that was the most popular show of the Broadway season, led last night's Tony Awards with seven prizes, including the one for best musical.

title: DCNY CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 30.
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 15, 1983. DCNY Corp. is the parent company of Discount Corp. of New York.

title: CURRENCT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were always a lot of snide implications that we came to Princeton for social reasons.

title: MONDALE ASSAILS REAGAN POLICIES TOWARD SCHOOLS
description: Walter F. Mondale, the chief speaker at yesterday's commencement at the City College, denounced President Reagan's education policy, contending that the President is an ''enemy of excellence'' and does not understand the importance of public education.

title: Job for Needham Unit
description: The New York office of NH&S/ Issues & Images, a subsidiary of Needham, Harper & Steers Inc., has been retained by the Toronto-based Canadian Imperial Bank Group to handle its $2 million corporate advertising account in the United States. The account was formerly handled by McCann-Erickson/New York. Canadian Imperial, with assets of more than $55 billion, is the seventh-largest bank in North America.

title: New Business Weekly For Three-State Area
description: New York Business, a weekly publication devoted to business in the New Jersey-New York-Connecticut area, will be introduced in October by the Hagedorn Communications Corporation.

title: PLANS FOR NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music formally announced plans for its Next Wave Festival and touring program at a news conference Saturday at the Lincoln Center Library for the Performing Arts.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 6, 1983; The Economy
description: Any Democratic attempt to modify the 10 percent income tax cut scheduled for July 1 will be defeated, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, predicted. In a television interview, he also supported the reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve, a view that has been opposed privately by some Administration officials. (Page A1.)

title: Strong And Silent
description: SHORTLY after 7:35 P.M. tomorrow, a tall and muscular pitcher named Steve Carlton will raise his right leg high into the air with martial-arts grace and deliver a fastball with the sudden explosion of a karate expert breaking bricks with his bare hands.

title: SCHEIB, EARL, INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid April 15.

title: David Astrachan, Karen Kapel Wed
description: At the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y., yesterday, Karen Lynn Kapel, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Saul Kapel of Scarsdale, was married to David Isaac Astrachan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Boris Astrachan of Hamden, Conn. Rabbis Peter Weintraub and Robert E. Goldburg officiated.

title: COLLEGE CENTER FOR WORKERS GRADUATES 17 IN FIRST CLASS
description: Ana Brewster pinned a red carnation corsage to her graduation gown, and with the happiest of smiles said, ''I thought I was going to wake up this morning and somebody would say it was all a dream.''

title: RANK ORGANIZATION'S PROBLEMS
description: The past four years have been ones of sinking profits for Britain's Rank Organization, and the company's inability to find a new chief executive officer in the last 10 weeks has only worsened matters.

title: UNFAIR JUSTICE STARTS WITH PROSECUTOR
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HALF A LOAF

title: MTV Channel Rating
description: MTV: Music Television, the advertiser-supported video music channel of Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment, attained a 15 percent penetration of American television homes in April and thus was reported on for the first time by the Nielsen Home Video Index national ratings service. Nielsen's National Meter gave it a 1.2 household rating, the highest 24-hour rating ever for a basic cable service.

title: Mexico Decides to Try Morales for Homicide
description: Mexican prosecutors have announced that William Morales, an American terrorist sought by the United States on escape and other charges, will be tried for killing a Mexican police officer, possibly delaying extradition.

title: Yale's Oarsmen Topple Harvard
description: Yale defeated Harvard convincingly today in the 118th rowing of America's oldest intercollegiate sporting event. Tony Johnson, calling it ''the sweetest victory of all'' in his 14-year tenure as Yale's coach, joined his coxswain, John Sheffield, in the traditional victory dunking in the Thames River.

title: AFRICANS IN O.A.U. MAKE LAST EFFORT TO SAVE KEY TALKS
description: African leaders began last-ditch negotiations today in an effort to save the Organization of African Unity's twice-postponed 19th summit meeting, which is scheduled to open here Monday. The outcome was still uncertain tonight.

title: KELLY-JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $84,417, or 1 cent a share, from an accounting change.

title: WASTEWAY, GOVERNOR? NO WAY!
description: Governor Cuomo is a pragmatic politician as well as a respected one. He is risking his reputation on both counts by his curious reluctance to face reality in the Westway fiasco, which is rapidly turning into the Westway scandal.

title: History as Mush
description: To Henry Ford, it was bunk. To Gibbon, it was a register of the crimes and follies of mankind. Now New York State's Department of Education has offered trendier definitions: it calls history ''power,'' ''technology,'' ''change'' and ''environment.''

title: Bonn Official Supports Weinberger on Missiles
description: Defense Minister Manfred Worner, in an interview published today, backed recent assertions by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger that the Soviet Union had deployed nuclear weapon systems in countries of Eastern Europe.

title: JERSEY PRIMARIES TOMORROW BEAR ON LEGISLATIVE CONTROL
description: Candidates who hope to be on the ballot in November when control of the New Jersey Legislature will be at stake are winding up their campaigns for Democratic and Republican nominations for 40 State Senate and 80 Assembly seats that will be decided in Tuesday's primary elections.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-After a loss of $6.6 million from discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $178,000 from discontinued operations.

title: METS DOWN DODGERS, 4-2
description: The much-maligned ''kids'' of the Mets did some fancy work today before 48,214 fans in Dodger Stadium as they defeated the Dodgers, 4-2, and earned a split of the four-game series against the team with the best record in baseball.

title: Ban Is Lifted At Newark Market
description: Merchants in the Newark Farmers Market, shut down Thursday after dioxin was found at a nearby chemical plant, were permitted to reopen for business today under certain restrictions, state officials said.

title: CORPORATE PLANES TRANSPORT CANCER VICTIMS
description: Priscilla (Pat) Blum, a former cancer patient who flies her own private plane, was watching the corporate jets land at the Westchester County Airport here a few years ago and noticed that an average of only two persons got off every flight.

title: Washington Watch; Intense Debate On Trade Plan
description: WASHINGTON IN this corner: Malcolm Baldrige, Secretary of Commerce and principal backer of a proposal to reorganize Government trade functions. And in this corner: Barber B. Conable Jr. of upstate New York, ranking Republican on the House Ways and Means Committee and one of a growing number of opponents of the plan.

title: The Greatest Ever
description: When they hold the ''Ken Molloy Alumni Lacrosse Game'' at Manhasset (L.I.) High School next Saturday, Molloy, a 62-year-old lawyer who was a two-time all-American at Syracuse, will not be the main attraction.

title: THEATER: 'TERRITORIAL RITES,' BY CAROL K. MACK
description: ROBIN GROVES, who plays the central role in Carol K. Mack's ''Territorial Rites,'' is a fresh acting talent. With her large expressive eyes and tentative but unaffected manner, she beautifully projects that evanescent quality called vulnerability. That fact was first evident this season at the New Play Festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville, where she gave versatile performances in three plays.

title: U.A.W. Members Agree To Contract With Deere
description: United Auto Workers members at 11 Deere & Company locals in six states ratified a new contract today with the farm equipment manufacturer after a brief strike that idled 17,000 workers.

title: BAKER SAYS EFFORT TO MODIFY TAX CUT FACES SENATE LOSS
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the leader of the Republican majority in the Senate, predicted today that Reagan Administration forces there would defeat any Democratic attempt to modify the 10 percent income tax cut scheduled for July 1.

title: Northwestern Journal; HOW BUD CLARK GOT ANGRY AND SWITCHED DRAFT BEERS AT HIS GOOSE HOLLOW INN
description: The Goose Hollow Inn is the unlikely lair of a rabid activist, a man so committed to civic integrity that he would end two decades of business association over a little thing like misrepresentation in a political advertisement broadcast in another state.

title: Alboreto Captures Detroit Grand Prix
description: Taking advantage of the early leaders' problems, Michele Alboreto scored an unexpected victory in the Detroit Grand Prix auto race today by a margin of 7.702 seconds.

title: Eastern Wins Wage Deferrals
description: Eastern Airline said today that 16,000 nonunion workers had accepted a wage-deferral plan that will save the airline $200 million by the end of 1984.

title: BARBARA ANN FLAGG
description: Barbara Ann Flagg, a vice president in the municipal bonds section of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died of cancer Thursday at her mother's home in Jersey City.

title: NOAH CAPTURES FRENCH CROWN
description: In victory, Yannick Noah was his bouyant, irrepressible self. First he fell to his knees with his head thrown back and his arms stretched upward. Then he sprang to his feet and jumped into his father's outstretched arms. Finally he ran through the line of ball boys and onto the award platform with none of the shy decorum that usually accompanies such moments.

title: COUPLES TRIUMPHS IN A 5-MAN PLAYOFF
description: After soaring to a five-over-par 77 on the final round, Fred Couples sank a short birdie putt on the second hole of a five-way playoff today to win the Kemper Open golf tournament.

title: COMPUTER A PRESENCE AT BOOKSELLERS CONVENTION
description: Uncertainty about the future still hangs over many of the publishers and booksellers gathered in Dallas for the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association, but the principal emotional display on the floor of the Dallas Convention Center has been that of love and affection.

title: DEAF, BLIND WOMAN TO GET COLLEGE DEGREE
description: Geraldine Lawhorn, who is about to become the sixth deaf and blind person in the United States to receive a college degree, says she is no different from other college graduates, she just took a different road.

title: U.S. 1-0 Victor
description: The United States defeated the Ivory Coast, 1-0, today in the World Junior Soccer Cup, gaining a three-way tie for first in Group B with one game left.

title: LANDLORDS SEEK INCREASED RENTS OF 10% OR MORE
description: Landlords of rent-stabilized apartments in New York City yesterday proposed monthly rent increases of 10 percent for one-year leases beginning Oct. 1 on apartments renting for more than $400.

title: ALASKA'S OIL RICHES BRING COSTLY FIGHTS ON TAXES, TARIFFS
description: When oil pushed Alaska into the limelight in the 1970's, it did more than swell the state's treasury. With the money came a series of high-stakes legal confrontations with the big oil companies that pump the state's crude.

title:
A MONETARY DELEMMA PERSISTS IN WASHINGTON;
Economic Analysis
description: Controversy over whether the Reagan Administration made a formal commitment at the Willamsburg economic summit meeting to reduce interest rates in the United States threatens to undermine the cooperative spirit the conference was intended to foster.

title: DRAB SIDE OF A DIPLOMAT'S LIFE IN CITY OF SKYROCKETING COSTS
description: For ranking diplomats here, evenings are often elaborate dinners out on damask tablecloths, fine wines and brandy and comfortable rides home in chauffeur-driven limousines to spacious apartments or town houses on Fifth or Park Avenue.

title: ENEMIES OF HOPE FOR A PALESTINE STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: Roberta Bennett Marries
description: Roberta Gail Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bennett of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club to Peter Mark Gottlieb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton R. Gottlieb of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Peter Weintraub performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Joseph Boardman. The bride is with the circulation department of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company. Her husband is a staff accountant with Deloitte, Haskins & Sells.

title: COMMUNICATIONS GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $65,000 for the quarter and $197,000 for the year.

title: HOW TO SEE THE MOST GOLF AT WESTCHESTER CLASSIC
description: tournament spectator should always have - a comfortable pair of shoes and binoculars. An umbrella is a third necessity when conditions call for it.

title: Roberta Krueger, T. A. Bass Marry
description: Roberta Lyles Krueger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Krueger of Cincinnati, was married yesterday in New York to Thomas Alden Bass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan W. Bass of Cleveland. Judge Lorraine S. Miller of the Civil Court of the City of New York performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club.

title: BALLET: PENNSYLVANIANS ADD 'ORDINARY RHYTHMS'
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet has been absent from New York too long. But it is alive and flourishing at home, to judge by a program performed Friday at Philadelphia's Shubert Theater. Founded by Barbara Weisberger and now under the direction of Robert Weiss, the Pennsylvania Ballet remains that rarity - a strong, fluent ensemble company of dancers whose spirited distinctions never overwhelm the whole.

title: WELFARE RULING STIRS PENNSYLVANIA BUDGET FEARS
description: His eyes peered softly, obliquely, unfocused, down the street of boarded windows and scrawls of graffiti. His handshake was soft, his manner apologetic as he sat on the grimy steps of an abandoned rowhouse in North Philadelphia.

title: U.S. Aide Quits Israel As Dispute Foils Talks
description: A senior official of the United States Justice Department left Israel today without holding scheduled talks on the possibility of deporting suspected Nazis for trial here, because of a dispute over the status of East Jerusalem, an Israeli spokesman said.

title: Elissa Free and William Nooter Marry
description: Elissa Blake Free, a producer of public affairs programs for the Cable News Network in Washington, was married there yesterday to William Ward Nooter, an assistant corporation counsel for the District of Columbia. Judge William A. Ingram of the United States District Court for the Northern District of California, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the bride's home.

title: MALAWI EXILES SAY AIDES FLEE TERROR
description: Two Cabinet ministers have fled from Malawi to Zimbabwe and four people were killed trying to leave the country in a power struggle over who is to succeed the aging President for Life, Hastings Kamuzu Banda, exile sources said today.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A pitcher throws a ball that bounces in front of the plate and then hits the batter. Is the batter awarded first base?

title: COMBINED COMPANIES INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Whirlpool Union Votes To End 109-Day Strike
description: Union workers at the Whirlpool Corporation's Evansville Division ratified a four-year contract today, ending a 109-day strike that idled 4,200 hourly employees at the division's two plants.

title: Cuts by Bethlehem At Maryland Plant
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation will shut down the wire and nail manufacturing operations at its plant here before the end of the year, the company announced.

title: SPAIN'S CHIEF PUSHES LATIN PEACE PLAN
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain says he plans to urge the United States to support the Central American peace efforts of four regional nations when he holds talks with President Reagan in Washington this month.

title: Two Women Shot; Queens Man Held
description: Two women were in critical condition at a Long Island hospital yesterday after being shot by a male companion of one of the women, the police said.

title: Caught in Court; Cameras on Trial
description: Opponents of cameras in New York's courtrooms continue to predict that they will disrupt, sensationalize and distort the court proceedings, denying fair trials to the accused and scaring away witnesses. These arguments ignore the evidence.

title: NEW YORK BALKS AT U.S. BID TO END ALL CROSSING BETWEEN SUBWAY CARS
description: A Federal safety panel, alarmed at the growing number of people killed in New York City while riding between subway cars, has rebuked the Transit Authority for its ''permissive attitude'' toward this danger zone.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ron Guidry, who had a rocky start against the Mariners on opening day, is scheduled to pitch for the Yankees.

title: Express 17, Wranglers 13
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - Tom Ramsey threw a 26-yard touchdown pass to Jojo Townsell with 2:38 left for the victory.

title: AIDS RISK HELD SLIGHT FOR THOSE ON TRANSFUSIONS
description: The New York City Health Department's chief epidemiologist and the director of the Greater New York Blood Program say hospital patients requiring transfusions face little risk of contracting a disorder that destroys the body's immunological defenses.

title: TENANTS IN LIMBOEditor:
description: I agree with you (''The Off-Campus Housing Muddle,'' editorial May 16) that the New York State Legislature should amend the Emergency Tenant Protection Act to cover people in rent-stabilized or rentcontrolled apartments owned by nonprofit institutions, and I have urged the City Council to call for such action.

title: Cubs Win 5th In Row
description: Jay Johnstone's leadoff homer in the fifth inning today sparked a three-run rally that sent the Chicago Cubs to a 3-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. It was the fifth straight triumph for the Cubs.

title: A TROUBLED PERIOD FOR S.E.C. ENFORCER
description: John M. Fedders, head of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, is accustomed to remarks about his height and what a fine basketball center he must have been during his college days at Marquette University. After all, he is 6 feet 10 inches tall.

title: RECTISEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
How to Get There
description: FROM NEW YORK VIA NEW ENGLAND THRUWAY: Take Rye exit (No.20). At top of exit turn right; go one block and turn right onto Purdy Street; go three short blocks to traffic light and turn right onto Purchase Street (Route 120); follow Purchase Street and signs to Westchester Country Club.

title: PRINCETON REUNION HAILS '73 WOMEN
description: In a gala celebration of tradition and an affront to fashion, thousands of alumni clad in blazers and costumes of preposterous orange-and-black prints, tiger stripes and checks made their annual march this reunion weekend through the rhododendron-perfumed grove of oaks and elms that is Princeton.

title: DESPITE VIOLENCE, A SENSE OF CONTROL PREVAILS AT AUBURN PRISON
description: In recent weeks, the cement-and-stone fortress that is the maximum-security prison here has seen a rash of violent incidents, including stabbings and inmate attacks on guards.

title: DEMONSTRATORS AT ATOM PLANT ARRESTED ON L.I.
description: A total of 138 antinuclear demonstrators were arrested today at the Shoreham nuclear power station after they refused police orders to end a three-hour sit-in at the gates leading to the nearly completed $3.2 billion plant.

title: REUNIONS: WHO GOES AND WHY
description: IT usually happens sometime between 5 and 25 years after graduation.T he old grad falls prey to a curious affliction: Fear of Reunions. S ymptoms include vague feelings of inferiority, possibly accompanied b y an urge to lose 10 pounds, dye one's hair, invest in a new w ardrobe or win a Nobel Prize. In one extreme case, a Chicago woman s pent hours in a tanning parlor before returning to her alma mater inC alifornia.

title: G.M.'S 'LAST-WORD' AUTO PLANT
description: If the American auto industry has an answer to the quality and cost advantages enjoyed by Japanese producers, part of it is to be found here at the General Motors Corporation's newest assembly plant, which is due to start producing Cadillacs and Oldsmobiles later this year.

title: Marsala Shatters 2 Marks
description: Charlie Marsala posted meet records in the 1,600- and 3,200-meter runs and Roger Hunter won the 200-meter dash in a meet-record 21.2 seconds yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League outdoor track and field championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Monique Chalk, J.R.Hubshman Marry in Capital
description: Monique Chalk, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Chalk of New York and the late Mr. Chalk, was married in Washington yesterday to James Roy Hubshman, son of Mrs. Henry Hubshman Jr. of New York and the late Mr. Hubshman of New York and Santa Barbara, Calif. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. O. Roy Chalk, grandparents of the bridegroom.

title: A CITY READY TO WASTE AN IDEAL HIGH-TECH SITE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bandits 45, Stallions 17
description: Jimmy Jordan passed for 223 yards and four touchdowns, and Gary Anderson rushed for more than 100 yards for the first time as a professional running back to lead Tampa Bay.

title: SCOTT'S HOSPITALITY INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Includes a $14,765,000 net gain from disposal of assets and a writedown in carrying value of certain real estate.

title: EX-OFFICER AT BACHE JOINING MATTHEWS
description: William M. Marlin, a former vice chairman at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., has been named president and a director of Matthews & Wright Inc., a Wall Street firm specializing in municipal securities.

title: Bridge: Varnishing the Truth a Bit Seems to Improve a Story
description: Some bridge stories are nearly, but not quite, worth telling. So the player or journalist is tempted to add a smidgen of fiction to improve the fact. Consider, for example, the diagramed deal from the recent Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship in Honolulu.

title: Tax Refunds Lag Behind Administration Forecast
description: Taxpayers with the biggest refunds waited longest to file their income tax returns and got 9.55 percent more back from the Government than last year, the Internal Revenue Service says.

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
U.C.L.A. Gymnast Wins Three Titles
description: Mitch Gaylord of U.C.L.A. and Dianne Durham of Gary, Ind., won three individual championships apiece today at the United States gymnastics championships.

title: ZOE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on May 27 incorrectly reported a telephone number used in an advertis- ing campaign involving 800 Spirits, a New Jersey company. The number can be dialed as 1-800-BE-THERE.

title: MAJOR CHANGES IN THE ROAD TO BIG LEAGUES
description: NONE of them will create the commotion or command the money that John Elway did in football or that Ralph Sampson did in basketball this year. But 900 or so high school and college baseball players will be drafted today by the big league teams, and it does not take a mathematics major to calculate their career odds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Suddenly It's Summer

title: PLANE FIRE SURVIVORS ALL REPORTEDLY HELD WET CLOTHES ON FACES
description: A Federal investigator said today that the 23 survivors of the smoky fire that killed 23 people on an Air Canada plane all had held some kind of wet cloth or paper over their faces.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP ) reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $88,000.

title: COMPUTER INVESTORS GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $520,000 for the quarter and year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $3,218,000 for the quarter and year. d-Net income.

title: TWINS DEFEAT RED SOX, 10-4, ON 13 HITS
description: Gary Ward hit a two-run homer and a triple to lead a 13-hit attack today that gave the Minnesota Twins a 10-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Jumping at Devon To Dutch Crown
description: Harry DeLeyer of East Hampton, L.I., rode Dutch Crown to victory in the Paine Webber $7,500 open jumper stake in Saturday night's conclusion of the nine-day Devon Horse Show.

title: COSTAL BIDDING FOR TEXAS GAS
description: The Coastal Corporation announced last night a tender offer that would give it up to 52 percent of the common shares of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation, an operator of a natural gas pipeline. The transaction is valued at $450 million.

title: Accounts
description: * Nutritional Management Inc., Boston, to Barnum Communications Inc.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE RISE OF THE COMPUTER STATE. By David Burnham. 273 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: CPAC, INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
Commodities; Price Rises For Sugar Continue
description: WORLD SUGAR prices have doubled in recent months, with the contract for delivery in July moving from a February low of 6.40 cents a pound to a high of 13.47 cents on May 31. There have been some technical setbacks since then, and on Friday the July delivery closed at 11.66 cents a pound. But the question arises, how much further will prices go?

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC OF CALIFORNIA
description: CALIFORNIA'S new-music scene is burgeoning, both north and south, and by far the most interesting scores on Saturday's third concert of the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' contemporary-music festival at Avery Fisher Hall came from that state. The concert began with Morton Subotnick's ''Ascent Into Air.'' Mr. Subotnick first came to notice as a leader of the volatile San Francisco electronic-music scene of the 1960's, and later on with several colorfully titled Nonesuch disks. He teaches now at the California Institute of the Arts near Los Angeles.

title: BOND SCHEDULE FOR WEEK IS HEAVY
description: It is going to be a very busy week for underwriters of both corporate and municipal bond issues. More than $1 billion of corporate bonds are coming to market - the largest single week of offerings since the first week in May, when more than $2 billion in new debt rushed to market. Since then, those bonds have traded at discounts, and, unless the overall tone of the credit market improves, the issues this week face a similar trading pattern.

title: TORTURE IS KEY ISSUE IN ZIMBABWE TRIAL OF 6 AIRMEN
description: The issue of torture is likely to continue to loom large when testimony resumes here Monday in the trial of six white air force officers accused in the sabotage of 13 jet fighter planes - more than half of Zimbabwe's combat aircraft.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S STRATEGY: TO ISOLATE THE REBELS
description: South Africa's highest-ranking military official says he believes it will be possible to prevent the underground African National Congress from intensifying a sabotage campaign in South Africa by shutting the group's military wing out of neighboring black countries.

title: U.S. BARS 3D WORLD 'QUICK FIX'
description: An American delegate to a United Nations trade conference here said today that the United States will oppose any move to give developing countries ''quick fixes'' of aid.

title: Flares in an Andean Storm
description: Peru's troubles today are Peruvian, but by tomorrow they could also be Washington's. A fragile democratic regime in Lima is struggling with droughts and floods, a fiery insurgency, an $11 billion debt and an economic slump. But the Reagan Administration's hemisphere crisis chart has scant room for the Andean republics stretching south from the inflamed isthmus of Central America.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
FINAL SURGE IN BEARER BONDS
description: The last of the bearer bonds will be brought to market this week, signaling the end of anonymous trading in tax-exempt securities. The passage will be marked by the issuance of at least 168 new competitive bond offerings, totaling nearly $1 billion.

title: OPERA: 'POLIUTO' IS REVIVED
description: ''POLIUTO,'' Donizetti's late opera (1838), which received what may have been its New York premiere Saturday afternoon at Cami Hall, has had a checkered history. The story of religious persecution in third-century Armenia, ''Poliuto'' was never produced in Donizetti's naative Italy during his lifetime: the censors forbade the staged depiction of the martyrdom of a saint.

title: News Analysis
description: The British general election campaign has become a runaway for Margaret Thatcher and the Conservative Party, according to public opinion polls here. If they are correct, the last 72 hours of campaigning before the voting on Thursday will be enlivened only by the semblance of a contest for second place.

title: NAIVE VISION OF JEWISH LIFE ENDS IN SUICIDE IN ISRAEL
description: It has been more than a year now since Yefim Ladyzhensky, a 70-year-old painter from the Soviet Union, went as usual at dawn to his tiny studio on the outskirts of Jerusalem and, instead of beginning work, hanged himself in the stairwell.

title: BELMONT FORESEEN AS A 2-HORSE RACE
description: This has been a chaotic season so far for the 3-year-olds. Seven horses have won the eight Grade I stakes to date, and almost a dozen others have enjoyed a brief term as leader of the division. It might seem that the Belmont Stakes next Saturday would be just another spin of the wheel, a wide-open race.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Afghan Rebels Claim Success in Recent Battle
description: Guerrilla sources said today that rebels aided in their planning by Afghan army renegades had killed 90 Government soldiers and captured a military base in a province bordering the Soviet Union.

title: CONFLICT OF CALENDARS
description: Talk revives about a Soviet-American summit. It would be the first since President Jimmy Carter and First Secretary Leonid Brezhnev signed the SALT II Treaty in Vienna in 1979.

title: HOME COMPUTERS STEAL SHOW
description: The Consumer Electronics Show this year is almost all fun but not all games. Last year the show was almost all games but not as much fun.

title: Foes of Quotas for Police Charge Discrimination
description: An agreement to promote black officers in the city's Police Department one-for-one with whites would discriminate against other minority groups, opponents plan to tell a Federal appeals court Monday.

title: China Will Soon Get Long-Awaited President
description: Nearly 3,000 delegates will gather Monday to elect China's first President since the Cultural Revolution.

title: TV RATINGS WAR SPREADS TO NEW SUMMER SERIES
description: A diminutive elderly woman appears on the television commercial, looking off-camera. ''We asked people if they'd rather watch reruns of 'Tales of the Gold Monkey' or get a pie in the face,'' a narrator says. The woman considers for a second and says, ''Well, I guess I'd have to take a pie.'' She is pelted forthwith. The narrator says: ''This summer there is a better choice - 'Buffalo Bill.' ''

title: Nigeria Denies Oil-Price Cut
description: Nigeria has no intention of cutting oil prices but may have to trim its output this month to stay within its agreed production ceiling, according to an official source.

title: Denton Winner
description: Steve Denton, ranked 12th in the world, won the first singles title of his professional career today when he defeated 18-year-old Pat Cash of Australia, 7-6, 7-6, in the Kentish Times grass tournament today.

title: Saronni Is Victor
description: Giuseppe Saronni of Italy won the Italian bicycle tour today for the second time. With the completion of the 22d and last leg, Saronni was declared the overall winner with a time of 100 hours 45 minutes 30 seconds.

title: I.M.F. Consumer Prices
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that consumer prices in the industrialized countries rose 5.5 percent in the first quarter, down from 6.3 percent in the previous quarter and 8.5 percent in the first quarter of 1982.

title: TV: 'GOTTERDAMMERUNG' BEGINS CLOSING THE RING
description: THE television version of Richard Wagner's complete ''Ring'' cycle began last January. It ends, tonight and next Monday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13, with ''Die Gotterdammerung.'' The presentation length has nothing to do with the composer, although operagoers in the last couple of decades may understandably have developed the impression that the works were endless. The scheduling timidity of public television, which was certain that the great and presumably unenlightened American public wasn't ready for massive doses of Wagner, can be blamed for the stretching process, in this instance. The tetralogy, which also includes ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Dio e Walkure'' and ''Siegfried,'' was carefully excluded from fund-raising weeks, which are far more comfortable with old movies. As usual, the audiences have proven to be far more adventurous than the bureaucrats.

title: NW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Matter of Degrees

title: AMERICAN AMATEUR WINS IN PRO CYCLING
description: The United States Professional Cycling Championship was won today by an American amateur, Davis Phinney. The first-place prize of $25,000 did not go to him but to the United States Cycling Federation, the governing body of amateur cycling in the country.

title: INDIAN ENVOY ASSESSES GANDHI, MAN AND MOVIE
description: At speeches across the United States, at diplomatic receptions, at dinners in his official residence here, the Indian Ambassador to the United States hears one word repeatedly.

title: Getting There
description: There has been a lot of hype and hoopla surrounding the start of the United States Football League, but according to Dick Butkus, the former Chicago Bear linebacker who has been providing radio commentary on U.S.F.L. games, it doesn't extend to the broadcasting booth.

title: PUBLIC THREAT FEARED IN LOOPHOLES IN LAWS ON TOXIC WASTE DUMPING
description: The following article is based on reporting by Ben A. Franklin and Ralph Blumenthal and was written by Mr. Franklin. Public health and safety are in jeopardy because of the many loopholes in poorly enforced Federal and state laws that were designed to curb the indiscriminate dumping of hazardous industrial waste, according to environmental officials and members of Congress.

title: Happiness Is an Empty Office
description: IN its tranquil emptiness, George Steinbrenner's office at Yankee Stadium resembled one of those restored rooms in historic homes where a velvet rope keeps the tourists at a distance. At the shiny oval brown wooden table, one tall soft brown leather chair towered above five smaller rounded chairs. On the table was a white telephone with several extension buttons, a glass apple, a gold numeral 1 and a small sign in blue with white lettering.

title: G.O.P. STARTS TRAINING IN 'GENDER GAP' POLITICS
description: The Republican Party opened its 1984 Presidential campaign for the votes of women here this weekend. It was the party's first organized attack on the so-called gender gap, the evidence in polling data that women are increasingly tending to vote for Democrats. It took the form of the first Republican Women's Leadership Forum, where 100 participants were told that their party could sink under women's votes for the other side.

title: FOOD LION INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
JUDGE CLEARED OF CORRUPTION IS INVESTIGATED BY COLLEAGUES
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings, who was found not guilty of Federal charges of corruption earlier this year, is now the subject of a judicial investigation.

title: UMC Industries Picks G.E. Executive for Post
description: An executive of the General Electric Company had been tapped by UMC Industries to be its president and chief operating officer. Edwin F. Phelps, 49, general manager of the energy applications program at G.E., succeeds H. Ridgely Bullock in the UMC position, effective July 1. Mr. Bullock, 49, continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
AT WESLEYAN, A CASE FOR 'LAW AND MORALITY'
description: Judge Terry J. Hatter of Federal District Court in Los Angeles, who was once the only black student at Wesleyan University, told the college's graduates at the 151st commencement today that the fight for civil rights depended heavily on how judges and lawyers read the law.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Aviation Group, Raleigh, N.C., filed a shelf registration for a $25 million offering of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003, through a group including Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: Two Boys, 17, Die in Crash
description: Two Rockaway 17-year-olds - Thomas Engongoro and William Cilurso - were killed and a boy was injured today when the car they were in left the Garden State Parkway and hit a tree. Timothy Abline, 16, of Denville was admitted in fair condition to a hospital in Neptune after the accident in Wall Township.

title: Vallijeanne Hartrampf Weds W.G. Arader 3d
description: Vallijeanne Hartrampf, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Roerig Hartrampf Jr. of Atlanta, was married yesterday to Walter Graham Arader 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arader Jr. of Radnor, Pa. The Rev. Gary Bowman, minister of the Haverford (Pa.)

title: BUDGETARY POLITICS ENTERS NEW PHASE
