description: Congress begins its busiest period of the year this week, and what happens on Capitol Hill between now and the July 4 holiday could well determine the themes that dominate the rest of the Congressional session, and the election campaign next year.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $583,028 for the quarter and $703,379 for the year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $25,484 for the quarter and $119,049 for the year and a net charge of $434,949 for the year from cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting. The year-ago results for the quarter and year have been restated.

title: The Wrong Horse
description: As virtually every sports fan knows, next Saturday afternoon's Belmont Stakes represents the third leg of the Triple Crown of thoroughbred racing.

title: AT TIDEWATER, METS' TOP FARM, MANY FIND A PLACE TO GROW
description: Before each game, the Tidewater Tides and their Met Park fans are tantalized by a Frank Sinatra rendition of ''New York, New York.'' The team uniforms are blue and orange, the colors worn by the parent Mets. There is even a hint of Shea Stadium in the highway traffic flowing by beyond left field and in the low-flying jets passing overhead.

title: THE ROOT OF U.A.W. BARGAINING POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CALIFORNIA (AL) - Placed Bruce K ison, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. CLEVELAND (AL) - Released Joe C harboneau, outfielder, who was with Buf- f alo of the Eastern League.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After $37.1 million writeoff composed of reductions in the value of oil and gas properties for the quarter and 9 months and the latest quarter also includes $4.2 million gain on sale of two rigs. c-Net income

title: WIN CHALLENGE CUP
description: The Cosmos captured the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup for the second time today with a 4-1 victory over the Seattle Sounders before a crowd of 51,825. Fiorentina of Italy defeated Sao Paulo of Brazil, 5-3, in the opening game of the doubleheader at Giants Stadium.

title: MEETING I.M.F. NEEDS
description: The Senate is expected to vote this week on a bill authorizing an increase in the United States quota in the International Monetary Fund - part of a global effort to cope with the increasingly dangerous problem of the $700 billion debt of developing countries - but the question is whether the new money will be too little, too late.

title: The U.N. Today; June 6, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Committee on Science and Technology for Development - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: A Libyan Diplomat Is Wounded in Beirut
description: The Libyan charge d'affaires in Beirut was shot and wounded by an unknown gunman in a hotel here tonight and was taken to the American University hospital in serious condition, the state-run Beirut radio reported.

title: CSP INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
THATCHER M. BROWN JR.
description: Thatcher M. Brown Jr., an associate in the banking concern of Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York City, died Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: SUSPECT'S MENTAL STATE A KEY ISSUE AS TRIAL STARTS TODAY IN 13 DEATHS
description: 4In a courtroom in northeastern Pennsylvania today, an imported jury is to begin hearing murder charges against George Banks. And Wilkes-Barre and surrounding Luzerne County will begin reliving the rampage of rifle slayings that stunned the hard-coal region last September.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Mobs fighting in the streets marred elections in Kashmir state today, with 177 people injured despite the presence of 50,000 soldiers, the police said.

title: PURCHASING GROUP CITES OUTPUT RISE
description: Industrial production and the level of new orders rose in May, but the pace of the increases was slower than in April, corporate purchasing managers reported yesterday.

title: SUMMA MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $488,345 for the latest year and $277,556 for the previous year.

title: New Agency Keeping Data on Toxic Wastes
description: A new agency at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta has been established to prepare the first national registry of victims of hazardous waste seepage and to maintain a list of areas restricted because of contamination.

title: Nancy J. Schlesinger and Michael G. Izenson Wed
description: Nancy Jill Schlesinger, daughter of Renee C. Schlesinger of New York and Edward S. Schlesinger of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Gary Izenson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Izenson of Okemos, Mich. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of White Plains.

title: 39 Sailors Are Jailed Over Nile Boat Blaze
description: An Egyptian court today jailed 39 sailors for 30 days pending questioning on the fire that gutted their vessels and killed 317 people during a Nile River voyage from here last month.

title: CALL FOR COMPUTER CLASSES SWAMPING COLLEGES
description: At the University of Hartford this summer, 10 professors who have had only a passing acquaintance with computers are taking a crash course. By September they will be expected to teach beginning classes at Hartford's computer center.

title:
THE CALENDAR;
The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Ingmar Bergman: Summing Up a Life in Film
description: It is a chilly, desolate place, this island Faro. During the summer, tourists come here, bringing with them the laughter of children and the sun, but spring comes late to Faro, and even in May, reminders of winter remain. A Baltic wind that twists the evergreens into the shape of bonsai trees blows in from the sea, and in the early morning hours, a damp, insidious fog settles over the beaches, draining the landscape of color and turning everything gray.

title: Europe 3, U.S. Not Even Z-Zero
description: A team of 126 scientists at the CERN accelerator in Geneva reports proof of an important new subatomic particle, the Z-zero. The discovery carries two messages. The good news is that it confirms a major theory about the fundamental forces of nature. The bad news is that Europeans have taken the lead in the race to discover the ultimate building blocks of matter.

title: YANKS LOSE 4TH IN ROW
description: The Yankees, who traditionally have had a knack for good timing, chose Bat Day at Yankee Stadium to regain their hitting form. The Yankees forgot to bring their defense, though, and fell to Seattle, 8-7, for their fourth consecutive loss.

title: ARTIST REMEMERED AT HARBOR HE LOVED
description: On the shores of the Kill van Kull yesterday, a New York harbor boat captain remembered John Alexander Noble, who for 50 years painted and sketched scenes of maritime life in the harbor.

title: Market Place; Power of Analysts Seen As the Dow Dawdles
description: THE stock market last week demonstrated the positive power of analyst recommendations while the Dow Jones industrial average simply dawdled. The Dow slipped 3.10 points, closing at 1,213.04.

title: Long Island Takes Lacrosse Crown
description: The undefeated Long Island Lacrosse Club won the Northern Division title in the United States Club Association today with an 11-8 victory over North Hempstead at Hofstra Stadium. Vince Somborotto scored four goals and had two assists for the winners.

title: ELECTION VICTORIES STRENGTHEN SRI LANKA PRESIDENT'S POSITION
description: A convincing victory in recent local and parliamentary elections here has strengthened the hand of President Junius R. Jayewardene as he continues to liberalize economic policy and deal with a separatist movement among the country's Tamil minority.

title: Rudd First on Coast
description: Ricky Rudd, a 26-year-old driver who had competed in 160 Winston Cup stock-car races without a victory, led for the last 40 laps today in winning the Budweiser 400. In a Chevrolet, he gained a seven-second victory over Bill Elliott, with Harry Gant finishing third. Rudd averaged 88.063 miles per hour.

title: Congress; HOW MUCH SHOULD MEMBERS MAKE?
description: The other day, Senator David L. Boren gave some thought to budget issues. He took his mortgage payment for his two-bedroom home in Oklahoma, added his mortgage payment for the three-bedroom town house he owns in suburban Virginia, threw in his income tax and child-support payments and found that the total came to more than the $60,662 he makes each year in the Senate.

title: Matthew Gold Weds Linda Safran at Yale
description: Linda Safran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Safran of Alexandria, Va., was married at Davenport College of Yale University in New Haven yesterday to Matthew Jonathan Gold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack A. Gold of Caldwell, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi James Ponet, assisted by Joshua Gutoff, a rabbinical student.

title: Ingmar Bergman: Summing Up a Life in Film
description: It is a chilly, desolate place, this island Faro. During the summer, tourists come here, bringing with them the laughter of children and the sun, but spring comes late to Faro, and even in May, reminders of winter remain. A Baltic wind that twists the evergreens into the shape of bonsai trees blows in from the sea, and in the early morning hours, a damp, insidious fog settles over the beaches, draining the landscape of color and turning everything gray.

title: NICARAGUANS EXPEL 3 AMERICANS, CHARGING 'MACABRE PLOT' ON AIDE
description: The Nicaraguan Government expelled three American diplomats today, charging one with overseeing a ''macabre plot'' to kill or incapacitate the Foreign Minister.

title: U.S. PLANS TO EASE DISABILITY CRITERIA IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The Reagan Administration plans to liberalize the criteria for paying Social Security disability benefits to people with physical or mental handicaps, Administration officials said today.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 24.
description: b-Net loss

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 7, 1983; The Economy
description: The Supreme Court upheld the ''windfall profits'' tax on decontrolled oil, providing a substantial victory for the Treasury. The tax has yielded about $30 billion since 1980 and is expected to yield that much more over the next six years. (Page D1.) The Justices also ruled that Federal regulators need not weigh environmental consequences of waste disposal in licensing new nuclear plants. (B7.)

title: RUMOR SPARKS A FEW CHOICE WORDS
description: Sometimes even a rumor about a former colleague can touch off an outpouring of give-and-take in the House of Representatives.

title: Advertising; Supplying No-Frills Radio Ads
description: WE have learned to live with generic soapflakes, generic toilet paper, even generic cigarettes. But generic advertising? The proponent of this no-frills world is TM Companies, a Dallasbased company that sells libraries of generic advertising to radio stations. The libraries contain hundreds of generic themes and jingles that TM's stable of lyricists, songwriters and copywriters customize to match the needs of a local advertiser.

title: Ford Unit in Hertz Deal
description: The Ford Motor Company's tractor operations signed a $5 million contract to provide the Hertz Equipment Rental Corporation with farm and industrial tractors during the next two years, Ford Tractor announced today.

title: TV: THE TONY AWARDS WITH GERSHWIN TRIBUTE
description: FORCED to cope with a generally skimpy and lackluster Broadway season, Sunday night's live broadcast of ''The American Theater Wing's 1983 Tony Awards,'' Alexander H. Cohen, organizer of these television productions, decided to take a relatively classy route. The usual awards proceedings were intertwined with a tribute to the music of George and Ira Gershwin (as it happened, the Uris Theater, where the show was taking place, was being renamed the Gershwin Theater). The overall conception, written and produced by Hildy Parks, was promising. The results, however, were decidedly uneven.

title: FRIENDS OF THE MX
description: To the Editor: The coalition in the U.S. House of Representatives which approved $625 million on May 24 for en-gineering and flighttesting of the MX missile system has, I be-lieve, been incompletely portrayed in the press.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 20.
description: The share earnings reflect a 20 percent stock dividend declared March 21.

title: SOUTH AFRICA COMMUTES SENTENCE FOR 3 OF 6 BLACKS FACING GALLOWS
description: The Government said today that death sentences imposed on three of six condemned members of the outlawed African National Congress had been commuted to life imprisonment. The three others are now scheduled to be hanged early Thursday in Pretoria along with two convicted murderers, one black and the other white.

title: VISA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Year-ago figures were not available because the company began doing business in its current corporate structure April 1, 1982.

title: POCANO DUMP YIELDS JARS WITH SUSPECT SUBSTANCES
description: Federal, state and regional environmental officials have unearthed hundreds of bottles of unidentified substances at a hazardous waste site in a clearing in the woods in Pocono Summit, Pa.

title: Concern Over Money Supply
description: Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, has added his voice to others in the Administration who have expressed concern about the fast growth in the basic money supply.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. REBUFFS AID PLAN FROM THE THIRD WORLD
description: The leader of the American delegation to a major trade conference said today that industrial nations were unlikely to approve the requests put forth by the developing nations.

title: THE PRIVATE AGONY OF AN ADDICTED PHYSICIAN
description: A particularly poignant and troubling problem in the medical profession is that of the doctor whose easy access to drugs leads to his own addiction. What follows is the story of Dr. William J. Farley, one of the rare physicians who has been willing to reveal his experience.

title: VOLGA BOAT WRECK WITH 'LOSS OF LIFE' IS DISCLOSED
description: The Soviet Government and the Communist Party issued an unusual joint announcement today that a passenger ship was wrecked Sunday on the Volga River, raising speculation about a large death toll.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Bid for Tilling Studied
description: A spokesman for the Prudential Corporation P.L.C. said today that the group, which holds a 2.5 percent stake in Thomas Tilling P.L.C., remains undecided on the merits of BTR P.L.C.'s bid for Tilling. But she said that Prudential was predisposed to support the management of a target company if it was in ''good standing,'' as, she added, Tilling's management is.

title: O'Connell Back With Red Sox
description: Dick O'Connell, who molded the Boston Red Sox into one of the American League's strongest teams in the 1970's, was reappointed general manager today in an ownership shuffle installing Edward (Buddy) LeRuox as managing general partner.

title: Finance Chief Quits At A.& A. Services
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., a major insurance brokerage firm, said yesterday that William F. Farley, its chief financial officer had resigned ''to pursue other interests available to him.''

title: 5 Chevron Venture
description: The Standard Oil Company of California's Chevron U.S.A. subsidiary said it had decided to delay exploration of the Shelikoff Strait in Alaska. Thomas Cook, Chevron's exploration representative, said that because of the project's high risk and the unit's downturn in earnings, the company was re-examining plans for the remaining three years of its five-year lease.

title: Rare Tapir Dies at Coast Zoo
description: A 600-pound Central American Tapir, an endangered species, has died at the Los Angeles Zoo from an intestinal blockage caused by a rubber ball a visitor threw into his pen, zoo officials said. The Bairds Tapir, a hoofed animal with a foot-long snout, ate the ball Thursday, zoo veterinarians said.

title: MOUNTED OFFICER HELPS GET SUSPECT
description: Two bank employees and a mounted police officer captured a man at 8:40 A.M. yesterday after a $200 holdup at the Chemical Bank branch at 1350 Avenue of the Americas, at 55th Street, the police said.

title: Bonds Oversubscribed For San Diego Utility
description: A $100 million offering of industrial revenue bonds, issued by the City of San Diego on behalf of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, was oversubscribed by late yesterday.

title: PILLSBURY'S ICE CREAM CHAIN DEAL
description: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it would acquire Haagen-Dazs, a family-owned ice cream chain with an elite image, for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.

title: Texas Gas Is Silent On Coastal's Offer
description: The Texas Gas Resources Corporation declined comment yesterday on a $45-a-share tender offer made for its stock by the Coastal Corporation, but analysts predicted it would fight the bid.

title: SCOUTING
description: After the 1980 baseball season, when he hit .289 with 23 home runs and 87 runs batted in for the Cleveland Indians, Joe Charboneau was named the American League rookie of the year by the Sporting News and the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: When Trees Talk ...
description: Inevitably, whenever trees make news, a trail of bad jokes follows. Yesterday's trail was worse than usual, coming after the report about trees that send out warning signals when threatened by insects. Usually tasteful adults couldn't resist speculating about talking trees, whose bark is worse than their blight. Or wondering what the news means for the old conundrum about whether a tree, falling in a primeval forest, makes a noise. But beyond the drollery, there's a point about talking trees that's worth a moment's reflection.

title: GOVERNOR HOLDS A SLENDER HOPE FOR M.T.A. PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo said today that there was little chance that his program for taking control of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority could pass the Legislature over the objections of Mayor Koch.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. New York begins an important 26-game stretch against Eastern Division teams with Dave Righetti facing Rick Sutcliffe.

title: Reagan to Meet Mexican
description: President Reagan will visit President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico in a northern Mexican city in August, the White House announced today. Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said a site for the meeting had not been chosen. Mr. Reagan first met with Mr. de la Madrid Oct. 8 in San Diego.

title: An Agreement On Loughery
description: The Chicago Bulls today reached agreement on compensation to be given to the Atlanta Hawks for the rights to sign Kevin Loughery as their new coach.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CULTURE MILE

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in April.

title: Bridge: Kaplan Wins 2 Major Titles In Contests Over Weekend
description: Edgar Kaplan, one of the world's great players, achieved a rare double victory at the New York Hilton Hotel during the weekend by capturing the two most important New York team titles - the Reisinger Knockout on Saturday and the Grand National Teams on Sunday with different teammates. This extends a string of victories that has included two major national team titles in the past seven months.

title: UNDERFUNDED EFFORTS TO BETTER WOMEN'S STATUS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Is Not Tied to Profits
description: The Crude Oil Windfall Profit Tax Act, enacted in April 1980, was proposed during the Carter Administration as part of a program to deregulate oil prices.

title: ADAMS MEMORIAL DRAWS RESPONSES
description: The shrubbery that Henry Adams struggled to grow around the memorial to his wife now forms a towering bower around the shrouded bronze figure that is all that marks their graves.

title: Warren N. Gaffney Dies at 82; Former Jersey Banking Chief
description: Warren N. Gaffney, a former New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, died Sunday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J. He was 82 years old and lived in Red Bank.

title: L.I. MAN WITH UNLINCENSED LAWYER GRANTED RETRIAL
description: A Long Island man serving 25 years in prison for bank robbery has won a new trial because the man who defended him in Federal District Court in Brooklyn 12 years ago was not licensed to practice law.

title: RON KITTLE FIELDS A BUSY SCHEDULE
description: CHICAGO T he man in the suit and tie from the office of the Chicago White Sox stopped by Ron Kittle's locker in the clubhouse at Comiskey Park, and asked if he had an answer for the latest request from the office. Kittle, the rookie who is tied for the American League lead in home runs, turned and looked back into the clutter in his locker. He did not have an answer because he had not known there was another request.

title: Homer's Pharmacology
description: When in his wanderings Odysseus arrives at the island of Aeaea, according to Homer, the nymph Circe gives his crew a potion containing ''malignant drugs, so they might entirely forget their own fatherland.'' Modern scientists have speculated that the ''malignant'' ingredient of the potion might have been stramonium, which was apparently known to the ancient Greeks.

title: KENNEDY CUSTOMS SYSTEM REVISED TO SPEED LINES AND CUT SMUGGLING
description: At the start of the busy summer air-travel period, the United States Customs Service yesterday formally began a new procedure at Kennedy International Airport that it says moves travelers through customs 50 percent more quickly and is also more effective in catching drug smugglers.

title: CARBON MONOXIDE STUDY IS FLAWED, E.P.A. IS TOLD
description: The Environmental Protection Agency released a report today indicating that a proposed Clean Air Act standard on carbon monoxide was based in part on questionable, perhaps falsified, research.

title: LLOYD'S ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Business Day Friday about John M. Fedders and the Southland Corporation incorrectly reported the terms of a grand jury indictment of the company, one of its executives and a former New York City Council member. It charged conspiracy to bribe a New York State tax official.

title: WILSON RISES FROM SLUMP, SPECTACULARLY
description: M ookie Wilson remembers what it was like back in Bamberg, the sleepy town in South Carolina where he grew up: quiet. ''Not much to do,'' he said. ''Little town, nowhere to go. I learned to stay by myself, and I never changed much. Was I poor? That's an understatement.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Teen-Age Life, On and Off the Street

title: HARTFORD PASSES BILL TO INCREASE DRINKING AGE TO 20
description: With Lieut. Gov. Joseph J. Fauliso casting a tie-breaking vote, the State Senate gave final legislative approval tonight to a measure raising Connecticut's minimum drinking age from 19 to 20, effective Oct. 1.

title: ANDROPOV OFFERS ATOM-FREE BALTIC
description: Yuri V. Andropov, renewing a longstanding Soviet proposal for a nuclear-free zone in northern Europe, said today that the idea could be extended to the Baltic Sea.

title: Miss Allen Cites Insults
description: Leslie Allen was back home in New York yesterday, still angry over unpleasant experiences in Paris that caused her to give up plans to play in the Wimbledon tennis championships later this month.

title: News Analysis
description: Israel marked the anniversary of its invasion of Lebanon today by bringing to a climax an intensive weeklong reexamination of the war, in which most of the major decision-makers have been interviewed by Israeli newspapers, radio and television. The arguments have been familiar, the revelations tending to support the picture of a military machine hurtling forward beyond the control of the Cabinet.

title: U.S. BARS BERNADETTE DEVLIN
description: The State Department said today that a visa has been denied to Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the Irish nationalist, because of reports she intended to raise money in this country for a convicted member of the political wing of the Irish Nationalist Liberation Army. The group has taken responsibility for several terrorist bombings.

title: SOVIET SAYS THE JEWS WHO ASKED TO LEAVE HAVE LARGELY GONE
description: Leaders of an official Anti-Zionist Committee set up six weeks ago said today that they were satisfied that Jewish emigration had effectively stopped because most Soviet Jews who wanted to leave had gone.

title: GEOPHYSICAL SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRITAIN'S POOR GET POORER;RICH GET THATCHER
description: There are historic and deeply troubling changes under way in Britain, where the very fabric of life is tearing for many people. The general election Thursday may well these changes irreversible.

title: SECRECY IN A DISMISSAL BY STANFORD FUELS ACADEMIC FREEDOM DISPUTE
description: Stanford University's expulsion of a graduate student, on the basis of a secret report by faculty members who investigated his anthropological work in China, has touched off a dispute about academic freedom.

title: JUDGES HEAR ARGUMENTS IN KEY CASE ON REMEDIES FOR JOB DISCRIMINATION
description: The United States Justice Department today came before the court that desegregated the Deep South, to argue that the judges had gone too far.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Walter Goodman THE FATHER BROWN OMNIBUS. By G.K. Chesterton. 993 pages. Dodd, Mead & Co. $14.95.

title: Learning Songs Unheard
description: Ornithologists have long believed that most young birds learn to sing by listening to their parents' songs. But two North Carolina psychologists have recently conducted tests that indicate that other factors such as social actions, gestures and facial expressions by mature birds in contact with the infants may play an important role in song learning.

title: DEVILS SEEKING GOALIE
description: Billy MacMillan, the general manager and coach of the New Jersey Devils, will not say whom his club will select in tomorrow's annual National Hockey League draft. However, his dinner tab provides a hint.

title: Marschalk Assigned A Chun King Account
description: Marschalk Company has been assigned the nonfrozen Chun King Oriental food products from the Del Monte Specialty Grocery Products Group, a unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: All share earnings have been retroactively restated to give effect to a 50 percent stock split in the form of a dividend declared March 8.

title: WASTE UNFIT FOR THE 'MUNICIPAL DUMP'
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIRONMENTAL TECTONICS CORP reports earnings for yr to Feb. 28.
A BIG NIGHT FOR TONY C.
description: W hen the Boston Red Sox opened their 1964 season at Fenway Park, the club donated its net proceeds to the John F. Kennedy Memorial Library in honor of the President who was assassinated five months earlier. Ted Kennedy and the late Bobby Kennedy, as well as Joe Cronin and Stan Musial, members of the Hall of Fame, and the Governor of Massachusetts, Endicott (Chub) Peabody, were among the opening-day guests. On the first pitch in his first at-bat there as a 19-year-old Red Sox rookie outfielder, Tony Conigliaro hit a home run that soared over the net that sags above the left-field wall.

title: Utilities Seek Financial Aid
description: Executives of the Northwest's four largest private utilities met in closed session today with the Washington Public Power Supply System to propose a plan to find money, perhaps in world markets, to keep construction alive on a financially ailing nuclear unit 3 at Elma, Wash.

title: DRIVE-IN MOVIES: AN INNOVATION HITS 50 AND PASSES ITS PRIME
description: One night in 1933, Richard Hollingshead Jr. took a projector outside, flashed a movie on the side of a building and sat in his car to watch it. Friends and family were very worried about Mr. Hollingshead. He next patented a ramp system allowing the occupants of a car to see a screen over a car in front of them, and on June 6 of that year he opened the world's first drive-in movie theater, the R.H. Hollingshead Jr. Theater on Admiral Wilson Boulevard in Camden, N.J., showing ''Wife Beware.''

title: Reagan Reiterates His Desire To Eliminate Education Dept.
description: President Reagan today reaffirmed his desire to eliminate the Department of Education, using a visit with the young finalists in the National Spelling Bee to make his interest clear.

title: BUYOUT BID FOR NORTON SIMON INC.
description: The chairman and chief executive of Norton Simon Inc., David J. Mahoney, is heading an investor group seeking to buy the big consumer products concern for $1.65 billion and convert it into a private corporation, the company said yesterday.

title: Werblin Resting
description: David A. (Sonny) Werblin, the 73-year-old chairman of Madison Square Garden Corporation, was resting comfortably yesterday at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J., where he was taken Saturday after feeling nauseated. Tests for heart problems were negative, and he was expected to be released today or tomorrow.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
26 Soldiers Hurt in Texas As Weapon Explodes
description: An antitank weapon fired from the shoulder exploded today in a desert training session at Fort Bliss, spewing fragments and flames and injuring 26 soldiers, seven seriously, officials said.

title: Hearing Scheduled On Itel Settlement
description: The Itel Corporation of San Francisco, the capital equipment leasing company that has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since 1981, said that a hearing would be held in United States District Court in August on a proposed settlement of its securities class action litigation.

title: Bargain Desk Set
description: Irving Rudd, who works for Bob Arum, was showing Larry Holmes to the elevator last Wednesday after the heavyweight champion paid a visit to the promoter's 10th-story offices at 919 Third Avenue. Rudd wanted to introduce Holmes to Fran Goulston, who works for Arenson International on the same floor.

title: PHYSICISTS PONDERING NEW DIRECTIONS
description: THE long and elusive search for the ultimate truth about the forces and processes that control all matter has reached a turning point, and the world's physicists are trying to decide what to look for next.

title: HOUSE REPUBLICANS LOSE IN NICARAGUA DEBATE
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today rejected two Republican attempts to dilute a proposed ban on covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, and Democrats failed in efforts to negotiate a compromise with Administration officials.

title: VANDALISM REPORTED IN ROCKLAND UTILITY STRIKE
description: A strike by about 1,100 employees of Orange and Rockland Utilities continued for a third day today and the company said it had experienced ''several incidents'' of vandalism.

title: NEARING A PULLOUT FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: The United Nations mediation effort on Afghanistan has now reached a make-or-break stage. Although the emerging agreement is hardly ideal, it may well offer the best hope for getting Soviet forces out and advancing American interests in Southwest Asia.

title: Cook County Issue Cut by $44 Million
description: A Cook County bond issue that was rejected last week by the Continental Illinois National Bank was restructured and reduced to a $61.5 million issue, tentatively priced yesterday with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1984 to 9.90 percent in 1997.

title: COOPERVISION INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Volcano Linked to Acid Rain
description: Large concentrations of sulfur-bearing droplets from a Mexican volcanic eruption are floating in the stratosphere and may be slightly increasing rainfall acidity, Government scientists reported Monday.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday with a picture of an Orthodox church service misstated the nationality of Catholicos Karekin II. He heads an Armenian Orthodox group based in Lebanon.

title: Bamberger Discusses Outlook
description: George Bamberger said today that he believes his career as a baseball manager is over. Bamberger, who resigned as manager of the Mets Friday night, also said he doubted he would return to the Milwaukee Brewers in any capacity. He managed the Brewers from 1978 until a heart ailment and subsequent bypass surgery forced him to retire in September 1980.

title: STARTED UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
description: James E. Casey, a founder and former chief executive officer of United Parcel Service, died yesterday at a hospital-nursing home in Seattle. He was 95 years old and had lived in Seattle since boyhood.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Called up Alan R amirez, pitcher, from Rochester of the I nternational League. BOSTON (AL) - Announced that B uddy LeRoux, Jr., general partner, has a ssumed control of the club and named D ick O'Connell general manager. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Placed Bruce K ison, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. CHICAGO (NL) - Activated Dickie N oles, pitcher, and designated Paul Mos- k au, pitcher, for reassignment. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Kurt Still- w ell, shortstop, to a minor league contract a nd assigned him to Billings (Mont.) of the P ioneer League. Signed Robert Dibble, p itcher, Sent Brad Lesley, pitcher, to Indi- a napolis of the American Association. HOUSTON (NL) - Activated Nolan R yan, pitcher, and placed Mike Madden, p itcher, on the 21-day disabled list. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Traded Gorman T homas, outfielder; Jamie Easterly, re- l ief pitcher, and Ernie Camacho, minor- l eague pitcher, to Cleveland for Rick Man- n ing, center fielder, and Rick Waits, pitch- e r. Recalled Mark Brouhard, outfielder, f rom Vancouver of the Pacific Coast L eague. Optioned Bob Skube, outfielder, t o Vancouver. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Placed Jeff Lahti, p itcher, on the 21-day disabled list retroac- t ice to May 31. Recalled Kevin Hagen, p itcher, from Louisville of the American A ssociation. TORONTO (AL) - Placed Dave Col- l ins, outfielder, on the 15-day supplemen- t al disabled list because of a pulled right h amstring, and replaced him with Stan C larke, pitcher, from Knoxville of the S outhern League.

title: Texas Wins in 11
description: Jamie Doughty doubled to score Mike Trent in the bottom of the 11th tonight to give top-ranked Texas a 6-5 victory over third-ranked Oklahoma State in a College World Series game.

title: 6TH GRADERS PASS A TEACHERS' EXAM
description: Convinced that the mathematics and reading standards required of Florida teachers are ''very low,'' the principal of a private school here gave part of the state-mandated teacher-competency test to his sixth-grade class. The lowest score was 70 percent, the highest 100 percent.

title: Staying Eligible
description: A University of Florida football player, Roy Harris, remained eligible for the 1981 season when he received credit for a summer class he did not attend, The St. Petersburg Times said. The paper was told by Harris, a defensive tackle who will be a senior in the fall, that he took the course, ''Student Development in a University Setting,'' but in the summer of 1980. University records show that Harris passed the course twice, the second time in the summer of 1981, when he needed an hour's credit to remain eligible for football.

title: Braniff Chief To Resign
description: Howard D. Putnam said last night that he will resign tomorrow as chief executive of the Braniff International Corporation but remain as chairman to guide the company as it completes a reorganization under the bankruptcy code.

title: 102 Hurt on Trains in France
description: CLOUD, France, June 6 (UPI) -A suburban train ran into another at a station west of Paris today, injuring 102 people, two of them seriously, officials said.

title: Ewing Hitting Books
description: Patrick Ewing of Georgetown, one of college basketball's most dominant centers, will not play for the United States in this summer's Pan-American Games in Venezuela because of an academic commitment, the school said. The Pan-Am practice schedule conflicts with Ewing's enrollment in a Spanish class he needs to graduate on time. Ewing will be entering his junior year in September.

title: Moscow's Delegation Arrives For Arms Talks Without Chief
description: The Soviet delegation to the strategic nuclear arms talks with the United States arrived here today without its leader, Viktor P. Karpov.

title: Grumman-Israeli Deal
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that it had received a multimillion-dollar contract to build components for a new fighter for Israel Aircraft Industries.

title: Angelo J. Melillo Dies; Headed Health Agency
description: Angelo J. Melillo, executive director of the Mental Health Center of Northeast Nassau, in Glen Cove, L.I., died last Thursday at the Mercy Hospital Hospice in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: SHULTZ FINDS HE'S NO LONGER IMMUNE TO CRITICISM
description: As George P. Shultz approaches his first anniversary as Secretary of State, he is finding he has lost his immunity from criticism within the Administration and has had to respond to what one aide called ''sniping that sometimes resembles artillery shelling.''

title: AFRICANS TRY TO SOLVE DISPUTE THWARTING A SUMMIT MEETING
description: After a day of confusion, the Organization of African Unity was unable today to convene a formal summit conference, a meeting considered a critical test of the O.A.U.'s ability to survive.

title: Reagan Nominates Enders
description: President Reagan today nominated Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders to be Ambassador to Spain. Secretary of State George P. Shultz announced May 27 that Mr. Enders, 51 years old, would be replaced as head of the Latin America Bureau.

title: Deere Pact Is Approved
description: Workers returned to their jobs at 11 Deere & Company plants in Illinois and Iowa today after members of the United Automobile Workers union voted by nearly 86 percent to approve a new contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We were trying to figure out what was in Dan Rather's mind at the time of the broadcast, and most of us did not feel he had acted in reckless disregard for the truth.'' - David Campbell, foreman of the jury in a Los Angeles slander trial. (C11:2.)

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Chess: Tournament in Yugoslavia Results in a Four-Way Tie
description: The Vrnacka Banja International Tournament in Yugoslavia ended in a tie for first place among the Yugoslav grandmaster Slavoljub Marjanovic, and the international masters Nick de Firmian of the United States, Zenon Franco of Paraguay and Bosko @Abramovic of Yugoslavia. Each had a score of 10-5.

title: 169 Products Introduced
description: Thanks to a smorgasbord of new cheeses, snacks and health foods, 169 new products were introduced last month, a 19-year, 5-month record.

title: 15 BLACK REPUBLICANS AT WHITE HOUSE WARN OF POSSIBLE BLACKLASH IN 1984
description: The White House has been warned by black Republican politicians that the Reagan Administration's record toward blacks has been so negative that a sizable ''vengeance vote'' is likely to emerge next year in the Democrats' favor.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: Slater Hanft Martin Gets Muzak Business
description: The Muzak subsidiary of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, which likes to identify itself as the world's largest supplier of environmental music, has named Slater Hanft Martin Inc. as its new agency.

title: Ex-Oiler Fined, Gets Probation
description: Greg Stemrick, a former Houston Oilers' All-Pro defensive back who pleaded no contest to a charge of cocaine possession, was sentenced today to five years of probation and fined $3,000.

title: No Headline
description: George Bamberger said today that he believes his career as a baseball manager is over. Bamberger, who resigned as manager of the Mets Friday night, also said he doubted he would return to the Milwaukee Brewers in any capacity. He managed the Brewers from 1978 until a heart ailment and subsequent bypass surgery forced him to retire in September 1980.

title: THE WORM AND THE APPLE
description: The Worm and the Apple Rough Joints No Exit

title: PEKING TO CREATE NEW SECURITY UNIT
description: China will create a new Ministry of State Security to cope with espionage and persistent crime, Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang announced today.

title: ECLIPSE IS DUE IN PACIFIC
description: BEGINNING a few minutes after 10 P.M. Friday, Eastern daylight time, the shadow of the moon will fall on the Indian Ocean and race toward Indonesia in this year's only total eclipse of the sun. Its path will sweep across Java, Celebes and southern New Guinea before lifting off the earth at 3:15 A.M. Saturday among the Line Islands of the South Pacific.

title: FOUR SLASHED TO DEATH IN ISOLATED CALIFORNIA HOME
description: A couple, their 10-year-old daughter and a neighbor boy were slashed to death in an isolated home Sunday, and investigators were hoping today for clues to the killers from the only survivor of the attack, the couple's 8-year-old son, who was gravely injured.

title: 2D TEEN-AGE SUICIDE IN SUBURBAN TOWN
description: A 17-year-old high school student, writing that he was ''going to join Cathy,'' his girlfriend, hanged himself in the bathroom of his family's house Sunday evening, three weeks after the girl had hanged herself.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citizens Savings Financial Corp. filed a shelf registration for up to $50 million of debt securities.

title: CHIC SHOES AT GOOD PRICES
description: Just when it seemed that it was impossible to find well-made highfashion shoes for under $100, along comes Valentina Lima. The 21-year-old entrepreneur is designing, manufacturing, importing and retailing shoes for men and women that range in price from $42 to $65 but look at least twice the price.

title: FOR WATTERS, A 2D CHANCE
description: Sidney Watters may not seem too excited about training Slew o' Gold, a budding star who will probably be favored to win the Belmont Stakes on Saturday. That doesn't mean he doesn't like the colt's chances. It's just not Watters's style to get too high on a promising young horse. He knows how dangerous that can be.

title: ORIOLES DOWN JAYS AS RAIN CUTS GAME
description: A two-run homer by Cal Ripken Jr. and Leo Hernandez's three-run shot powered the Baltimore Orioles past the Toronto Blue Jays, 8-1, tonight in a game halted by rain in the sixth inning.

title: Guatemalan General Calls for Elections
description: The army's senior officer, in an open letter to President Efrain Rios Montt's military Government today, called for elections ''to satisfy the popular will'' and ''end Guatemala's international isolation.''

title: A CHANGE IN PERCEPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Curtis; Politics, but Not as Usual
description: FELIX G. ROHATYN is the investment banker who helped mastermind the painfully intricate negotiations solving New York's fiscal crisis. He did it by bringing government, labor and business leaders together. Somehow, he persuaded them to rein in their enlarged egos. Somehow, they put aside at least some of their partisan politics.

title: KEMP'S HOMER ENDS YANKS SLIDE
description: In a matter of minutes last night, Steve Kemp experienced the low of making a play that could have cost the Yankees the game and the high of making a play that won the game. At the same time, he learned about the fickle nature of Yankee fans.

title: O'NEILL PROPOSES TO LIMIT TAX CUT TO $700 A FAMILY
description: Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. drew the political battlelines with the Reagan Administration today by proposing to limit the benefits that upper-income taxpayers could receive under the tax cut scheduled to take effect July 1.

title: SURVIVAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
HIGH COURT EASES NUCLEAR LICENSING
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission need not consider the environmental consequences of nuclear waste disposal as a factor in licensing individual nuclear power plants.

title: A FUTURE ROLE FOR THE VIDEODISK
description: Chances are the personal computer will become an essential facet of future home life - but not necessarily in the way many computer buffs currently envision it. The computer could have powerful consequences for doing business or school work at home, of course. Financial programs like those involving the stock and commodity markets are apt to become even bigger hits than they are now, especially with serious investors, who can take advantage of the many time-saving benefits such software offers.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: BILL BLASS acted as the evening's chairman, which meant that if you c ouldn't drink Champagne, talk, laugh, dance and wear black and whitea ll at the same time then you had no business being there. F ortunately, those who attended the New York City Ballet's annual s pring gala Thursday, the last major event of the season, had no t rouble keeping up.

title: Poor Attendance
description: The Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League took out advertisements in area newspapers last week that advised readers to ''Turn off the set and go to the Vet.'' The message was prompted by the fact that the Stars, who have the best record in the league with 12 victories and two losses, have been running eighth in home attendance at Veterans Stadium with an average of 19,590 fans, about 6,000 below the figure for the entire league.

title: Bankers Trust Official Announces Resignation
description: Carlos M. Canal Jr., a member of the management committee at the Bankers Trust Company, has resigned, the company said yesterday. Mr. Canal, 52, was executive vice president in charge of the Administration Function, a term used by the bank when it centralized its administrative tasks in a reorganization announced last July.

title: Reliance Buyer Of Hall Shares
description: Ryder Systems Inc., the transportation and distribution company, has sold its 9.2 percent share in Frank B. Hall & Company, an insurance brokerage company, to a unit of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., a privately held concern, a spokesman for Reliance confirmed yesterday.

title: PANEL PICKS L.I.R.R. PAY OFFER
description: A Presidential emergency board has selected the Long Island Rail Road's final offer on wages and working conditions as the most reasonable basis for settlement with four shop craft unions, the last unions with which the line has no agreement.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why are there so few diamonds of any size, say as big as a grapefruit or bigger?

title: DOCTOR IN JERSEY CITED AILMENTS AT DIOXIN PLANT
description: A New Jersey dermatologist said yesterday that an associate had told public health officials as far back as 20 years ago that many workers at a former Newark chemical plant where dioxin contamination was recently discovered were suffering from skin disorders and other problems.

title: Driver, 41, Dies After a Crash
description: Mike Allen, a 41-year-old racing driver from LaVerne, Calif., died in a hospital this morning from injuries suffered in a crash Sunday in the opening event of the 1983 Can-Am season at Mosport Park.

title: Brewers Trade Thomas
description: Gorman Thomas, who has been one of the most popular players in Milwaukee baseball history, was traded to the Cleveland Indians today.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE CHARGES A COLLEAGUE TOOK PART IN KICKBACK PLOT
description: Cleveland's legal community is being rocked by public accusations against the Chief Federal District Judge by another Federal judge whose motives are being painted as the vengeful actions of a woman scorned in love.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tsongas Due to Back Glenn

title: BELL'S CONSUMER GROUP IN CORPORATE RESHUFFLE
description: Only five months after opening for business, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new subsidiary, American Bell, is shedding a major line of business.

title: Northern Feather Suit
description: Northern Feather International Inc., a manufacturer of down pillows and comforters, mislabeled the down and feather content of its products and should be assessed civil penalties, the Federal Trade Commission charged today.

title: Quarterback Review
description: It appears likely, said a National Collegiate Athletic Association official, that the eligibility of Mike Tomczak, Ohio State's starting quarterback, will be restored.

title: Owner of Blues Given Ultimatum
description: Ralston Purina, the owner of the St. Louis Blues, was told today by the National Hockey League that it must conduct the team's drafting or the club will lose all picks in Wednesday's draft.

title: People
description: * William M. Lane has been elected an executive vice president of J. Walter Thompson USA.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Crown Zellerbach announced that it had signed a preliminary agreement to sell certain assets of its Port Townsend, Wash., mill to the Haindl Paper Co. of West Germany.

title: Coach Cracks Down
description: The North Carolina State football team will have to live up to some stringent rules made by its new coach, Tom Reed.

title: Flat Wheel Derails IND F-Train
description: A Queensbound IND F-train derailed in the subway station at 53d Street and Fifth Avenue yesterday during the evening rush hour because of a ''flat wheel,'' the Transit Authority said. No injuries or fires were reported and service was expected to be restored before this morning's rush hour.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 7, 1983
description: International Nicaragua ousted three U.S. envoys, accusing them of working with the C.I.A. to build an organization of ''terrorist commando squads.'' One of the diplomats was charged with overseeing ''a macabre plot'' to kill or incapacitate the Foreign Minister. The American Embassy rejected the accusations ''in most emphatic terms.'' (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) Many Africans will starve to death because of the drought affecting 18 countries, according to American and international relief officials. They said the region faced the worst food shortages since the early 1970's, when at least 200,000 to 300,000 died from starvation. (A1:2-4.)

title: China Takes I.L.O. Seat Vacant Since 1971
description: China today took over the seat held open for it by the International Labor Organization since the United Nations agency expelled Taiwan in 1971.

title: Litton Contract
description: Litton Industries said it had been awarded a Navy contract to build three more Aegis missile ships for a total of $926.1 million. Litton has already built six of the ships. Production is scheduled to start in July 1984, with completion set for 1987.

title: FREDA CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
Bail Denied for Couple Accused in Fugitive Case
description: A judge denied bail today for a couple accused of conspiring with Gordon Kahl, a fugitive tax protester, to kill a sheriff who died after mortally wounding Mr. Kahl.

title: BRAIN CELL DISARRAY IN SCHIZOPHRENICS
description: ADRAMATIC disarray of certain brain cells in schizophrenics has been found by scientists at the University of California at Los Angeles in studies of a small sample of brain specimens taken at autopsies.

title: AMERICANS IN SPACE: WOMEN ARE READY
description: HOUSTON

title: Stocks Mixed; Dow Gains 1.20; Technology Issues Surge
description: Stock prices closed with minor changes yesterday as investors remained cautious over the direction of interest rates. The technology issues again made large gains.

title: Market Place; Phoenix Fund: How It's Doing
description: AS the nation's largest manager of mutual funds, Merrill Lynch announced plans last autumn for a speculative new fund intended to offer qualified investors a way to invest in high-risk - but potentially high-reward - securities. The aim of the fund, called the Merrill Lynch Phoenix Fund, was to seek long-term growth of capital by concentrating in securities of financially strained companies believed capable of recovery.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum RatesSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 1942 MILLER WORK BEING PUBLISHED
description: The fall catalogues that the hundreds of publishers have on display at the 83d annual convention of the American Booksellers Association here describe books to suit an endless variety of literary, commercial and nonfiction tastes.

title: SENATE CONSERVATIVES FIGHT I.M.F. FUND RISE
description: Senate conservatives today tried to block legislation authorizing greater resources for the International Monetary Fund.

title: No Headline
description: The Worm and the Apple Rough Joints Perils of Park Avenue

title: Strikeout Duet
description: Steve Carlton of the Phillies was scheduled to face the Cardinals tonight and was expected to become baseball's career strikeout leader. But the Houston Astros made his task tougher by activating the career leader, Nolan Ryan, and announcing that he would pitch tonight against the Giants. Ryan, out since May 2 with a thigh hamstring strain, has 5,321 strikeouts and Carlton 5,320.

title: Reports of Malawi Exiles Denied in Zimbabwe
description: Government sources today denied reports that former Cabinet ministers from Malawi fled into Zimbabwe last week to escape a political purge.

title: AFTER 5 YEARS IN JOB, MCGUIRE IS SEEN AS FLEXIBLE TACTICIAN
description: Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire took the call at his huge oak desk, the same desk from which his predecessors had been fighting crime since the days of Commissioner Theodore Roosevelt.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The chart of short-term interest rates in Business Day yesterday in- correctly reported the Federal funds rate. A corrected chart appears today on page D11.

title: AN AGRICULTURE 'WAR' WOULD BE DISASTROUS
description: The vague vow in the Williamsburg Declaration on Economic Recovery to dismantle trade barriers surprisingly said nothing about agriculture. Yet that issue has this year brought the United States and the European Economic Community to the brink of war - an agricultural trade war.

title: ONE MAN'S CANDIDATES FOR THE WONDERS OF THE WORLD
description: AFEW weeks ago I received a letter from a magazine editor inviting me to join six other people at dinner to make a list of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World, to replace the seven old, out-of-date Wonders. I replied that I couldn't manage it, not on short order anyway, but still the question keeps hanging around in the lobby of my mind. I had to look up the old, biodegradable Wonders, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon and all the rest, and then I had to look up that word ''wonder'' to make sure I understood what it meant. It then occurred to me that if the magazine could get any seven people to agree on a list of any such seven things you'd have the modern Seven Wonders right there at the dinner table.

title: NOMINATING REFORMS WARRANT UNREFORMING
description: It is a long time until the next Presidential election. Yet many people - notably Democratic candidates for President - believe that the 1984 election campaign already has begun. The political season has lengthened despite the last round of Democratic Party reforms, which explicitly tried to shorten it. Straw polls, state conventions, gridiron dinners and other such ''cattle auctions'' all have started to look like obstacles and opportunities to prospective candidates. Yet it is not until next year before anybody, anywhere, will be chosen a delegate to the 1984 Democratic National Convention.

title: Reagan Honors Hero Of Potomac Air Crash
description: President Reagan honored Arland D. Williams Jr. today, the man the Coast Guard says was the mystery hero who helped rescue fellow victims of an Air Florida crash last year, then disappeared into the icy Potomac River.

title: IN SUPPORT OF THE HUMANITIES, GROUP CHOOSES 99 TO GET GRANTS
description: When the National Commission on Excellence in Education delivered its highly critical report on the nation's schools, it was applauded by the Council for Basic Education.

title: Swift Independent In Armour Deal
description: The Greyhound Corporation's Armour Food Company unit said it had agreed to sell three pork-slaughtering plants in St. Joseph, Mo.; Worthington, Minn., and Huron, S.D., to the Swift Independent Packing Company.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: PAMELA, 5 years old, proudly handed over her original essay on ''writing time.'' It began: ''I Lik Riting time becrs I can get my feings out. you cant kep your hot felings in sid of you you mit get sec. ...''

title: CONCERT: HOUSING SYMPHONY
description: THE New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra, now it its second decade, presented its annual Alice Tully Hall concert on Sunday afternoon, under the direction of Tali Makell.

title: A HOTFOOT FOR TRANSIT
description: Every year or so, we have a noisy political dust-up about the subway ''mess'' and the ''sorry'' condition generally of transit in the region. And then the rhetoric clouds dissipate, and straphanging gets back to normal -which means sorry or messy or occasionally improving.

title: CAVENHAM, USA, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income

title: Bandits Get Dean
description: The Tampa Bay Bandits yesterday signed Fred Dean, a starting guard for the Washington Redskins in the last Super Bowl, after the sevenyear National Football League veteran had said that the United States Football League club ''offered me a deal I couldn't refuse.'' Dean, the first member of the Super Bowl champions to jump to the new league, turned down a one-year, $120,000 offer from the Redskins in favor of a three-year, $400,000 contract.

title: Reagan Has 'No Plans' to Go To New Hampshire for July 4
description: White House officials shelved plans today for a Presidential trip to New Hampshire for the Fourth of July. Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said President Reagan has ''no plans'' to attend a picnic in the state that holds the nation's first Presidential primary next year.

title: LEUCADIA MAKES OFFER FOR SOUTHERN INDUSTRIAL
description: The Leucadia National Corporation, a consumer finance and life insurance company based in New York City, has entered a bidding contest for an ailing industrial loan and thrift company that once was run by C.H. Butcher Jr., the east Tennessee banker-businessman.

title: Eastern Welcomes 'Giveback' Vote
description: Frank Borman, chairman of Eastern Air Lines Inc., said a vote by nonunion employees to divert 10 percent of their wages to company investment programs would have ''an enormous import for the future of Eastern Air Lines, not only from the standpoint of the money that will be involved but also from the standpoint of labor relations.''

title: FAMINE IN AFRICA IS CALLED WORST IN A DECADE
description: A drought affecting 18 countries in Africa is causing increasing concern among United States and international relief officials, who say that the region faces the worst food shortages since the early 1970's when at least 200,000 to 300,000 people starved to death.

title: Plea by South African
description: Rudolph Opperman, chairman of the South African Olympic Committee, urged the International Olympic Committee yesterday to lift its boycott against his country.

title: NEW FATAH LEADERS CALLED FOR BY REBELS
description: Al Fatah members opposed to Yasir Arafat were reported today to have asked for the election of new leaders of the group.

title: Banks to Get a Limit On Crediting Deposits
description: The state Banking Board must establish ''a reasonable period of time'' that a bank has before crediting a customer's account with a deposited check, under a bill signed into law today by Governor Cuomo.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: EASING UTILITY 'RATE SHOCK'
description: On opposite sides of Long Island Sound, two nuclear reactors are nearing completion with price tags so high that rates will rise 25 percent to 50 percent overnight if the traditional system of pricing is used and customers begin paying for the plants only when they are finished.

title: CONCERT: HARLEM BOYS CHOIR
description: THE highlight of the Boys Choir of Harlem's Sunday evening all-Mozart recital was a sinuous and propulsive presentation of the Requiem (K. 626) under the direction of Warren George Wilson. The choir sang with a winning enthusiasm, but it was Mr. Wilson's focused conception that carried the performance.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
SHORT TERM RATES ARE MIXED
description: Short-term rates were mixed and long-term rates fell in very quiet trading yesterday, reflecting a lack of direction in the credit market.

title: Stalking the Knotweed
description: ''The roots go out and strangle other plants,'' explained Rowena Murilla, brandishing a forbidding plant with a two-foot-long root. Rowena, a seventh grader at Lincoln Academy, was among 180 students from the Manhattan junior high trying yesterday to rescue Riverside Park from invasion by the dread Japanese knotweed.

title: METS SEEK TO SNAP CUBS STREAK
description: If the Mets expected any help from the Chicago Cubs in their struggle to revive, they got only bad news when they arrived today for a three-game series.

title: By United Press International
description: Following is a list of the winners of the Antoinette Perry (Tony) Awards, which were presented Sunday. Best Play: ''Torch Song Trilogy.''

title: SCOUTING
description: National Football League teams are allowed to hold one minicamp each spring for rookies and another for rookies and veterans. A team with a new head coach is permitted an additional minicamp so the players can become familiar with the new coach's system.

title: TWINS CHOOSE COLLEGE PITCHER AS NO. 1
description: Tim Belcher, a power pitcher with what was called a ''misleading'' 5-4 record, was the first player selected yesterday in the regular phase of major league baseball's free agent draft.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * ALS Metals Co., Pittsburgh, has named George B. Coulter vice president, sales.

title: TV: '1984 REVISITED'
description: IT has always been unclear whether George Orwell thought of ''1984'' as a warning, prophecy or satire, or even, as the writer Anthony Burgess says he did, as ''a kind of game, a horrible game.'' On the other hand, it may not matter. Orwell's novel resonates in the popular culture, anyway. The title is a synonym for the death of privacy, the end of freedom. Orwellian, as an adjective, means dehumanizing and bureaucratic. How close are we now to an Orwellian world? Walter Cronkite looks for an answer in ''1984 Revisited,'' on CBS-TV at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Talks on Greek Bases May Be Put on 'Hold'
description: If the United States and Greece fail to reach an agreement in principle on the future of American military bases in this country by the beginning of July, the negotiations will be suspended, according to authoritative Greek sources.

title: BOB JONES CASE: WHAT THE COURT DID NOT DECIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'WINDFALL' OIL TAX IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court handed the Federal Treasury a substantial victory today by ruling unanimously that the threeyear-old ''windfall profits'' tax on decontrolled crude oil is constitutional.

title: A Pension Line Worth Holding
description: ''Tier Three'' is shorthand for the pension plan that covers employees hired since 1976 by New York's state and local governments. Though it provides retirement benefits equal to aftertax pay in the final years of service, civil service unions call Tier Three unfair and are campaigning against its renewal this year.

title: NBC BIDS TO REVIVE APPEAL OF TENNIS
description: Despite its growth as a participant and spectator sport, tennis has lost some of its programming appeal with the major television networks.

title: BUILDING CAVE IN TRAPS MAN FOR HOURS
description: A construction worker was buried under bricks and beams for nearly three hours yesterday after a section of a building under renovation in lower Manhattan collapsed shortly before noon. Six other workers were injured.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Updating the Mystery Of Mohammed's Statue

title: Citicorp Merging Coast Loan Units
description: New York-based Citicorp is merging its recently acquired California savings and loan association with its other loan subsidiaries in the state, Susan Weeks, a company spokesman, said.

title: CONCERT: DUDLEY MOORE JOINS ST. PAUL ORCHESTRA
description: WHEN Alexander looked around and found there were no more worlds to conquer, all he could think to do was weep. There was no Carnegie Hall in his day, you see. Otherwise, he might have considered going on to make his debut there as a concert pianist, as Dudley Moore did last night. Mr. Moore, the British comedian, whose previous triumphs include such fiercely defended territories as the stage, television and the silver screen, appeared as the piano soloist in Beethoven's Triple Concerto and came away with considerable honor.

title: Tenneco Project
description: Tenneco Oil Exploration and Production, a subsidiary of Tenneco Inc., disclosed that it has a 44 percent share in a group that plans to build a $71 million synthetic fuel plant in Pittsburg, Calif. Tenneco said that the United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation would guarantee financing of up to $46.5 million, with the remaining $24.5 million to be financed by the project's partners. Other participants are the Alberta Oil Sands Technology and Research Authority of Edmonton, the California Synfuels Research Corporation, the Dynalectron Corporation and the Parsons Corporation.

title: As Britain Goes, So Goes Britain
description: Does Britain's election offer any clues to American politics? Though the systems and personalities are markedly different, there are some striking similarities between the two economies. Both suffer from serious ailments. Both are run by conservatives preaching shortterm sacrifice for long-term gain. One can be sure that President Reagan hopes Mrs. Thatcher wins big on Thursday, and not only because they are friends.

title: JUSTICES TO WEIGH BIAS CASE TIED TO JOB SENIORITY
description: The Supreme Court announced today that it would try again to resolve the recurring but elusive question of whether a Federal court can properly order a city government to protect the jobs of recently hired black employees at the expense of white workers who have more seniority.

title: CITY STORES CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $140,000. c-Net income which includes a gain of $5,580,000 on the sale of property. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: SLENDER DRESSES SPARKLE AT NIGHT
description: There is something quaintly nostalgic about taut bodices, tiny waistlines and big, bouffant skirts propped by hoops and petticoats. They carry a heavy baggage of memories, from costume movies to 19thcentury novels, and recall heroines as diverse as Marie Antoinette, Scarlett O'Hara and Jezebel as played by Bette Davis.

title: MARC L. PARRIS
description: Marc L. Parris, County Attorney of Rockland County, N.Y., died of a heart attack Sunday while being taken to Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 48 years old and lived in Pomona, N.Y.

title:
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Falcons Observed
description: ''Y ou know those two peregrine falcons nesting on the Throgs Neck Bridge? - well, now they have two pretty nice-sized babies,'' 13-year-old Brian Goldstein reported on the telephone, with a scientific observer's controlled excitement.

title: DAVID J. MAHONEY: ELAN AS SALESMAN FINANCIER
description: David J. Mahoney seems packaged as well as the consumer goods he has spent a lifetime selling. At age 60, he is tall and trim, with neat gray hair and blue eyes frequently described as piercing - the kind of Irish good looks that have put him in the celebrity magazines and have seemed appropriate for his role as television spokesman for Avis Inc.

title: Talking Business with Lundberg of Gasoline Survey; Calm Summer Is Forecast
description: At 70 years of age, Dan Lundberg, a network correspondent during World War II and an oil industry analyst for more than 30 years, is running the nation's broadest review of gasoline prices. The Lundberg Survey, published twice monthly from North Hollywood, Calif., reflects prices charged at 17,000 service stations.

title: The U.N. Today; June 7, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: DEVELOPED 'FLIPPER' AND OTHER TV SERIES
description: Ivan Tors, producer of animal movies and marine-oriented television series such as ''Flipper'' and ''Sea Hunt,'' died of a heart attack June 4 while engaged in pre-production work in Brazil. He was 66 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: STRIKE IN LEBANON MARKS INVASION
description: Most Moslem-dominated areas of Lebanon observed a general strike today on the first anniversary of the Israeli invasion to protest Israel's occupation of southern and central Lebanon.

title: LANDLORDS OF SMALL BUSINESSES LEAD PUSH TO GAIN RENT INCREASES
description: In the first of 10 public hearings this month on rent levels for stabilized apartments, landlords of small buildings turned out in unusually large numbers yesterday to plead for large rent increases.

title: BALDWIN EXPECTS DEFICIT OF OVER $100 MILLION
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said yesterday that it probably lost more than $100 million in the first quarter of 1983, pushing it closer toward financial insolvency.

title: Caterpillar Tractor
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company has put into effect a previously announced callback of 2,000 employees and the layoffs of 1,450 others nationwide. The company has 46,000 employees nationwide. James O'Connor, president of Local 974 of the United Automobile Workers, said the union had filed complaints with the National Labor Relations Board charging that Caterpillar is violating the seniority rights of employees.

title: World Chess Semifinal Scheduled for California
description: The world chess championship candidates' semifinal match between Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland will be played in Pasadena, Calif., starting July 29. The announcement was made by Florencio Campomanes, the president of the World Chess Federation, or FIDE, in Amsterdam.

title: 7 STATE PHONE UNIT GETS NAME: NYNEX
description: The New York Telephone Company and the New England Telephone Company yesterday jointly announced the name of the new regional company that will own them after the Bell System breaks up next January. They also disclosed some of their new corporate parent's operational details.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income The company is a wholly owned subsidiary of Cavenham (USA) Inc.

title: Volunteers Asked to Halt Salt Lake City Flooding
description: The authorities issued a plea today to the Mormon Church for 2,000 volunteers to pack more sandbags for a mile-long canal to save neighborhoods at the foot of the Wasatch Mountains from more heavy flooding expected this week.

title: JURY FINDS FOR CBS AND RATHER IN SLANDER CASE
description: A Los Angeles Superior Court jury today decided in favor of CBS, Dan Rather and Stephen Glauber, a CBS producer, in a slander suit that had been brought by a doctor who said a 1979 ''60 Minutes'' segment wrongly linked him to insurance fraud.

title: VMS to Buy Hotel
description: VMS Realty Inc., a Chicago-based real estate concern, said it had signed a contract to purchase the Boca Raton Hotel and Club for $100 million in cash from the Arvida Corporation, a subsidiary of the Penn Central Corporation. The agreement with Arvida came within hours after VMS received final approval of its $60 million purchase of the New York Sheraton Hotel.

title: AN ABUNDANCE OF SIMPLE MEDICAL PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The verdict delivered yesterday by a Los Angeles jury in favor of CBS News is a major victory for the network at a time when its journalistic practices have been under fire.

title: REAGAN REVIEWING 2 OPTIONS FOR STRATEGIC WEAPONS TALKS
description: President Reagan has before him two options for a new strategic arms proposal that would ease earlier proposed limits on the numbers of nuclear missiles but still press the Soviet Union to give up half of its biggest missiles, high-ranking Administration officials said today.

title: 11 Wilson Plants Open
description: Dave Thompson, a spokesman for the Wilson Foods Corporation, said today that there were picket lines at seven of the company's plants in Oklahoma City and other cities.

title: Schenley President Given Additional Posts
description: Howard S. Feldman, president of Schenley Industries, has been named to the additional posts of chairman and chief executive, the company said yesterday.

title: GANDALF TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Met Draft Pick Stars in Series
description: David Magadan, the Mets' second-round choice in Monday's draft, had three hits tonight as Alabama defeated Michigan, 6-5, to advance to the finals of the winner's bracket in the College World Series.

title: JERSEY SUSPECT IS ACCUSED OF 6TH MURDER
description: Richard F. Biegenwald, the man accused of murdering four teen-age girls and a 34-year-old man, was identified today as a suspect in another murder.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Their golden yellow caps and gowns glowed in the sun, and their eyes were bright, too, and their faces shone. The two in front carried a burgundy banner, and the ones behind followed with purpose down the path at the back of the quadrangle, to the center aisle leading to the stage.

title: RULING ON INDIAN POINT
description: When the Nuclear Regulatory Commission decides tomorrow whether to order the Indian Point nuclear plants, 35 miles north of midtown Manhattan, shut down, the issue before it will not be whether the communities surrounding Indian Point favor or oppose the nuclear facility, nor whether the plants are economical or uneconomical, nor even whether an accident is likely or unlikely. The issue will be whether or not the N.R.C. intends to uphold and enforce its own safety regulations.

title: OFFICER ACCUSED OF CORRUPTION TAKES STAND IN TRIAL
description: A New York City police officer accused of corruption took the stand yesterday and rejected earlier incriminating testimony by prosecution witnesses.

title: First Boston Bond Plan
description: The First Boston Company, which has traditionally served blue-chip companies, has announced that it has started to underwrite bonds for smaller, riskier businesses.

title: Hans Leip, Author and Artist; Wrote Lyrics of 'Lili Marlene'
description: Hans Leip, who wrote the lyrics to the World War II hit song ''Lili Marlene,'' died at his home in Fruthwilen on Monday, his wife, Kathrin, said today. He was 89 years old.

title: HOW MAGGIE DID IT
description: The British election has been the best play in London this season. It should be called ''Maggie,'' or how ''Upstairs'' tamed ''Downstairs'' and made them like it. Herewith the Fable:

title: REWARD OFFER IN L.I. KILLING OPENS DEBATE
description: As a gatherer of news, a newspaper or a television station is widely expected to be an impartial observer of its community. As a business operation, an employer and producer, it is also a member of that community. Sometimes the roles seem to intertwine and to create journalistic ambiguities.

title: British Cable TV
description: Several major United States companies and a British concern announced that they had reached an agreement to form a company to provide programming for cable television in Britain.

title: BREWSTER DRIVE-IN IS WEEKENDERS' OASIS
description: ON Friday nights they swarm into the Red Rooster, hordes of northbound Manhattanites in their theme T-shirts, weekend cowboy ginghams, unbuttoned button-downs and stretch jeans, bound for their weekends upstate, in Connecticut or the Massachusetts Berkshires. En route on Route 22, often with their children, often because of their children, they pause to wedge themselves up against the counter of the tiny red-and-white Putnam County drive-in they have made into a must-stop oasis seasoned with hamburgers, chili, fried chicken, hot dogs and ice cream.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: INSURGENCY IN PERU: THE UNARMED ARE DYING
description: About 4,000 Peruvian Army troops are waging a campaign against 2,000 insurgents on the high mountain plateaus above this small town, but according to reports from the battle area it is mostly unarmed peasants who are dying.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN WILL MODIFY PLAN ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: President Reagan indicated to top national security aides today that he would modify his proposal that the Soviet Union make deep cuts in long-range missiles, but continue to insist on a one-third reduction in missile warheads, according to Administration officials.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPACEMAN

title: Ex-Player Can Sue
description: The Michigan Court of Appeals has ruled that a former high school basketball player who charges that he suffered a mental breakdown because he was pushed into college even though he could not read and write may sue the University of Michigan. The suit was filed by a legal guardian on behalf of Curtis E. Jones Jr., a 34-year-old former Detroit high school star, who charges that Michigan athletic officials helped get him enrolled at North Idaho Junior College in 1968 in anticipation of having him transfer to Michigan two years later.

title: NUCLEAR UNIT GETS SABOTAGE WARNING
description: A study of sabotage at nuclear reactors has concluded that the biggest threat is not outsiders but disgruntled workers and that some actions taken to prevent sabotage, such as locking doors, may actually diminish safety.

title: U.S. Rebuts Soviet on Jews
description: The State Department today described as patently false an assertion made Monday by an officially sanctioned Soviet anti-Zionist committee that most Jews who wished to leave the Soviet Union had already done so.
