''The contention that the majority of Jews who desire to emigrate from the Soviet Union have already left is patently false,'' Alan D. Romberg, a State Department spokesman, said.

title: SALVAGING NICARAGUA
description: The writer, who uses the nom de guerre Commander Zero, was a principal figure in Nicaragua's revolution and Deputy Defense Minister in the Sandinist Government. He left the country in July 1981 and, in April 1982, publicly declared his opposition to the Sandinist directorate. A year later, he announced his intention to ''move from words to deeds'' in fighting Managua and is now reported to be directing military operations in southern Nicaragua.

title: Careers; Graduates Face Job Scarcity
description: EVERY college generation faces hurdles - and graduates in the 1980's are no exception. In the Depression years 1930-37, there was a bleak job outlook. During the war years of the 1940's many career paths were interrupted.

title: U.S. to Try Ex-General In Spy Fund Fraud
description: The Justice Department said today that it would take a retired Air Force general to trial on charges of embezzling $445,000, despite a judge's ruling that the general could disclose secret military information as part of his defense.

title: HIGHER BID FOR NORTON SIMON SEEN
description: The chairman and chief executive of Norton Simon Inc., David J. Mahoney, will have to increase the bid he and a group of investors are making for the large consumer products company, analysts predicted yesterday.

title: Savin Realigns Sales Structure
description: Richard T. Gralton, the Savin Corporation's new president and chief executive officer, yesterday announced a reorganization intended to broaden Savin's participation in the office products market.

title: HIGH SCHOOL YOUTHS SAMPLE, AND SAVOR, THE ARTS
description: Deanna Foote, who is 17 years old, had never seen a play until this spring. ''I was dying to see one,'' she said. ''I had never seen the ballet, either. I guess I thought different types of people went to that kind of thing. Middle-class, or upward. The types of people that go to my school don't attend artistic events like plays or ballets. They go to discos and movies instead. Once in a while maybe lower-income families like mine might go to the theater, but it's so expensive.''

title: THEATER: 'GOODNIGHT LADIES' AT PUBLIC
description: ''GOODNIGHT LADIES!'' is 60 minutes of atmosphere. In this Hesitate and Demonstrate company production at the Public Theater as part of the ''Britain Salutes New York'' series, enigmatic people meet in railroad cars, sidewalk cafes and hotel bedrooms. They exchange pregnant looks while passing counterfeit passports and stealing jewelry.

title: Roll-Call Vote On Covert Aid
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved a bill to forbid covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels and to provide $80 million in overt aid to friendly nations to help stop the flow of weapons to rebels in El Salvador and other nations: FOR THE BILL - 20 Democrats - 19 Barnes, Md. Berman, Calif.

title: Seattle Lapse Makes Kemp Instant Hero
description: ''I t was a mistake, a rookie mistake,'' Rene Lachemann, the understanding Seattle Mariners' manager, said by telephone from Seattle yesterday, explaining what his 24-year-old rookie outfielder, Ricky Nelson, did not want to talk about. ''He thought that was the end of the game. He thought it was the ninth inning. Then he heard the people yelling and he saw that the runners kept running, and he started after it.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs at Chicago. Mike Torrez, who has a 2-6 record for the Mets but has not won since May 18, when he beat San Diego, 2-1, will be opposed by Steve Trout (4-6), who pitched for Chicago's other team last year. (Television - Channel 9, 2 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 2:15 P.M.).

title: CALIFORNIA ASSESSING HEALTH THREAT AT WASTE SITE
description: After more than a decade of public concern, the state is conducting a limited study of the impact the Stringfellow Acid Pits, one of the nation's leading hazardous waste problem sites, has had on public health.

title: Michigan Rules Diploma Is Marital Property
description: A woman who was divorced after helping pay for her husband's schooling owned part of his law degree and is entitled to share his future earnings, the Michigan Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for qtr to May 15.
description: b-After a nonrecurring loss of $144,546. c-After a nonrecurring gain of $817,496.

title: FAMILY SUCCESS STORY AT HAAGEN-DAZS CHAIN
description: Reuben Mattus had a problem: too much success. Like many another family enterprise, his ''came to a point where the time and effort we had to put in was unbearable,'' Mr. Mattus said of his Haagen-Dazs ice cream chain. ''In other words, we needed some backing.''

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: RATE FEARS SEND DOW DOWN 19.33
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday, reflecting growing apprehension that the Federal Reserve might soon tighten its monetary policy, sending interest rates higher.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Bone in Meat Products

title: COOKE LETTER ON ARMS OFFERS ADVICE TO CATHOLICS IN SERVICE
description: In a letter to Roman Catholic military chaplains made public yesterday, Terence Cardinal Cooke sought to assure Catholics in the armed forces that the recent United States bishops' pastoral letter condemning the use of nuclear weapons did not conflict with their roles in the military.

title: LAWYERS FOR CARS
description: While Japan was producing automobiles the United States was producing lawyers. American lawyer production has more than doubled since 1960, with the result that there are now 612,000 on the market, or one lawyer for every 390 Americans.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Canada Investment Plan
description: Canada will streamline its review process for potential foreign investors, the country's International Trade Minister, Ed Lumley, announced today. Canada's Foreign Investment Review Agency has been criticized in the United States as an obstacle to trade between the two neighbors.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's weekly auction of $125 million of 91-day commercial paper resulted in an average rate of 9.281 percent, up from 8.948 percent last week. Bids ranged from 9.23 percent to 9.314 percent, with $1.04 billion in bids submitted.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE price of privacy in this city, as many New Yorkers will tell you, is a life behind half-drawn blinds. Nan and Arthur Wise, whose apartment was on the 15th floor of a building on East 45th Street, were not ones for drawn blinds, though. Nor were their neighbors in the building next door.

title: U.S. PROPOSES EASING SOME RULES ON COTTON DUST
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration today proposed retaining most of the basic requirements for protecting textile workers against byssinosis, or brown lung disease, while easing some protective standards in parts of the industry.

title: I.B.M. Cuts Prices Of Office Products
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would make ''significant'' reductions in the prices of some of its most popular office products, and would introduce a new data base management system for large I.B.M. computers.

title: 'GORE ALL OXEN' TO CUT THE U.S. DEFICIT
description: To the Editor:

title: THE RETURN OF ADIRONDACK GUIDE BOATS
description: TEN years ago the Adirondack guide boats, among America's lightest, fastest and roomiest rowboats, were almost forgotten. First built by woodsmen in 1840 and never mass-produced, the carefully made wooden rowboats were once the common carrier for sportsmen on the network of Adirondack lakes.

title: CHILDREN WHO SURVIVED MASSACRE SAY THEY SAW MAN KILL RELATIVES
description: BARRE, Pa., June 7 (AP) - Two 10-year-old stepbrothers testified today that George Banks, accused of killing 13 people including family members, broke into their trailer and shot their mother, sister and two nephews to death.

title: A Tennis Loss Off the Court
description: The off-again, on-again player-coach relationship between Martina Navratilova and Dr. Renee Richards appears to be off again. Yesterday, Dr. Richards said she had resigned as Miss Navratilova's coach ''for personal reasons'' and would not accompany the world's No.1 women's tennis player to Wimbledon, where Miss Navratilova will defend her singles title starting June 20.

title: Vauxhall Posts Loss
description: Vauxhall Motors Ltd., a unit of the General Motors Corporation, had a 1982 net loss equivalent to about $60.8 million, down $29.4 million from the previous year, a spokesman said today.

title: Lineman Faces Assault Charge
description: Bryan Millard, a tackle for the New Jersey Generals, pleaded not guilty today to two charges of sexual assault stemming from a complaint brought by a 26-year-old Belleville woman.

title: New Licenses: The Yea and the Nay
description: T here was clip-clopping along Broadway yesterday as 50 carriagehorse drivers - including Buster McGill with his long, black hearse - demonstrated outside City Hall.

title: A CREDITOR GROUP OFFERS BRANIFF PLAN
description: Leaders of the negotiating committee for many of Braniff International's secured creditors said yesterday that they had outlined to Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, terms of a proposal under which they would permit Hyatt to restart part of the airline.

title: East Germans Sentence SS Man to Life in Jail
description: An East German court sentenced Heinz Barth, an SS officer in World War II, to life imprisonment today, calling him a ''murderous rifleman'' who helped massacre 734 villagers in France and Czechoslovakia during the war.

title: YANKS LOSE IN 10TH AS GOSSAGE FALTERS
description: For the second time in six days, Dave Righetti was let down by the people who are paid to protect him. Rich Gossage, after 11 consecutive glittering relief performances, lost Righetti's lead last night, and the Yankees lost a 10-inning, 2-1 decision to the Cleveland Indians.

title: AKYROYD IN 'TRADING PLACES'
description: FROM the zany, slapdash comedy of ''National Lampoon's Animal House'' and ''The Blues Brothers,'' John Landis has graduated to the consummately slick entertainment that is ''Trading Places.''

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss including tax credits of $1,676,000 for the quarter and $3,873,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $53,000.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
TIGHTENING BY FED IS SEEN
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as dealers sold securities in the belief that the Federal Reserve's continued failure to add funds to the banking system was a signal that the Fed had tightened credit availabilty.

title: BATUS NAMES HEAD OF RETAIL DIVISION
description: Batus Inc. said yesterday that it had appointed a new chairman and chief executive officer for its retail division, which operates such stores as Saks Fifth Avenue, Gimbels and Marshall Field. The division's sales total $3 billion a year.

title: NEW JERSEY CAN'T REGULATE UNIONS AT GAMBLING CASINOS, COURT RULES
description: The Federal Court of Appeals here has ruled that New Jersey cannot regulate labor unions whose members work in the gambling casinos in Atlantic City.

title: Sive Associates Gets Chipmunks From Ideal
description: Sive Associates, a Young & Rubicam company, has been named the agency for the new line of The Chipmunks toys by Ideal, which was acquired by CBS Inc. last year.

title: COMMUNICATIONS & CABLE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
The U.N. Today; June 8, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: GARVEY SET TO QUIT PLAYER UNION POST
description: Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association since 1971, plans to resign this weekend and return to Wisconsin as an assistant state attorney general. His successor, at least temporarily, may be Gene Upshaw, the Los Angeles Raiders' offensive guard and for the last three years the president of the 1,500-member Players Association.

title: News Analysis
description: One of Governor Cuomo's early initiatives to restructure part of the government - to take control of the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority - was stymied even before his staff finished drafting the legislation.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BRIEFING
description: Strain at Williamsburg

title: P.L.O. IS REPORTEDLY PLANNING TO SEND NEW UNITS TO BEKAA
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has reportedly decided to transfer several combat units to eastern Lebanon from Arab countries to which they were dispersed last year from West Beirut.

title: TESTS AT NEWARK SHOW MORE DIOXIN
description: Three of 31 samples in preliminary tests taken in the area surrounding an abandonned herbicide plant here contain detectable levels of the toxic chemical dioxin, Governor Kean said tonight.

title:
DECISION FILE;
Shared Responsibility For a Murder
description: Partners in crime, even ''passive and compliant'' ones, are civilly liable for the dollar damages incurred by the principal culprit, according to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.

title: PROSTITUTES NOT ENTITLED TO JURY TRIALS, TOP STATE COURT RULES
description: New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that accused prostitutes are not entitled to a trial by jury because prostitution is not a ''serious'' offense.

title: TORY CAMPAIGN: SHREWD AND BRUTAL
description: If Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wins a second term on Thursday, as she seems almost certain to do, she will owe a major debt to a short, natty, jovial man who likes Havana cigars and $40-a-bottle champagne.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Money table in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the Federal funds rate. It reached a high yesterday of 8 7/8 percent and a low of 8 3/4, and closed at 8 7/8.

title: MORE THAN 100 DIED IN VOLGA BOAT CRASH, SOVIET OFFICIAL SAYS
description: A Soviet official said today that more than 100 people died when a Soviet passenger ship rammed a railway bridge across the Volga River on Sunday night, ripping off the vessel's top deck.

title: Fumes From a Blaze Rout 1,600 in Jersey
description: About 1,000 children were removed from their schools and 600 to 700 residents were told to leave their homes temporarily today after toxic fumes were released from burning fertilizers and pesticides at a farm market here, authorities said.

title: CENSUS FINDS AMERICANS HAVE EVEN MORE CARS
description: The American love affair with the auto continues. Statistics published by the Census Bureau show that by 1980 there was more than one car registered for every two people. Nationwide, the bureau reports, there were 544 autos registered for every 1,000 Americans, up from 438 a decade earlier.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Marshall, the veteran reliever who last pitched in the major leagues for the Mets in 1981, has been signed by the Edmonton Trappers, a pacfic Coast League farm team of the California Angels. The Angels have had pitching problems, but a club spokesman said the signing of the 40-year-old is ''for the purpose of evaluation only.''... Chuck Noll, the coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, was listed in good condition following back surgery. ... Bill Cofield, the 43-year-old former Wisconsin basketball coach who was the first black head coach in the Big Ten, is seriously ill with cancer of the pancreas, according to his wife. ... David Thompson, the free-agent Seattle SuperSonics guard, has completed his drug and alcohol rehabilitation program, his lawyer said. ... Bruce Curry will defend his World Boxing Council super lighweight title against Hidekazu Akai of Japan in Osaka, Japan, on July 7. ... Robert Reid, the 6-8 forward who left the Houston Rockets last season for religious reasons, has requested a meeting with General Manager Ray Patterson about a possible return, according to Patterson.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT'S pretty obvious that if a svelte pair of legs framed by a brief skirt made their way across a room, a good number of observers would be mesmerized. A particularly luxurious mustache, a billiard-ball head, a decolletage bordering on the dangerous or diamond-studded eyeglass frames would probably have the same effect. The eye is drawn not only by the pleasing and esthetic but also by the incongruous, the outrageous or by physical attributes deliberately overplayed and overemphasized.

title: 5 IN F.A.L.N. INQUIRY GET 3-YEAR TERM
description: Five advocates of Puerto Rican independence were each sentenced to three years in prison yesterday for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating bombings for which the F.A.L.N., the group seeking such independence, has taken responsibility.

title: Accounts
description: * Coca-Cola USA, Atlanta, to Castor Spanish International for Hispanic consumer advertising for all soft drink brands. * Nuvision Inc., Flint, Mich., to N.W. Ayer, Detroit.

title: Ottawa Critical Of Canadair
description: The state-owned aircraft manufacturer Canadair lost $1.1 billion (United States currency) last year and the Government today accused the company of bad management.

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $3.3 million, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of certain businesses. Share earnings reflect a 5-for-2 stock split paid May 2.

title: 36-Run Offense Brings Title
description: Marietta College scored 6 runs in the third inning, 12 in the fourth, and 9 in the fifth and went on to overwhelm Otterbein, 36-8, today in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. Division III World Series.

title: Celtics Name K.C. Jones
description: K.C. Jones, who earned a reputation as one of the best defensive guards in National Basketball Association history in nine seasons with the Boston Celtics, was named the team's head coach today.

title: SENATE DEFEATS CURBS ON I.M.F. FUNDS BILL
description: The Senate today turned back by large majorities last-ditch efforts by conservatives to block an $8.4 billion increase in the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund.

title: PREVIOUS VOTES ON COVERT AID
description: In action previous to today's vote by the House Foreign Affairs Committee to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels, Congressional committees took these steps:

title: CONNECTICUT GETS TOUGH IN DRUNKEN-DRIVING BILL
description: Legislation increasing most penalties for drunken driving received final approval today as Connecticut's General Assembly moved toward Wednesday's adjournment deadline.

title: BURDENED FEDERAL COURT DELAYING CIVIL CASES
description: A decade ago the judges of the Federal District Court here prided themselves on having the most efficient court in the nation in the handling and disposition of civil cases. Today such a claim is wishful thinking.

title: PGA TOUR REJECTS BID BY BALLESTEROS
description: An attempt by Severiano Ballesteros, the 26-year-old Spanish golf star, to join the American tour with certain waivers of regulations was ''regretfully'' turned down today by Commissioner Deane R. Beman of the PGA Tour.

title: 2 ON BILLBOARD ARE ON CLOUD 9 AS DUEL ENDS
description: Two men trying to outlast each other in a billboard sitting contest whose grand prize was a $18,000 mobile home both came to back the earth winners today after 261 days above.

title: German Embassy Aide Shot
description: The counselor of the West German Embassy was found shot to death in his suburban Washington home today, the Montgomery County Police Department said. Juergen A. Draeger, 40 years old, died of a gunshot wound to the chest, said Debbie Rodbell, a police spokesman. Investigators have not determined whether it was a homicide or a suicide.

title: FORMER E.P.A. HEAD CLEARED OF CONTEMPT IN HOUSE PANEL VOTE
description: A House subcommittee voted today to clear Anne McGill Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, of contempt of Congress, saying the agency was now cooperating with a Congressional investigation of wrongdoing in the agency.

title: Malone's Season Worth $2.96 Million
description: Moses Malone earned at least $2,965,000 in salary and bonuses during the first year of his lucrative six-year contract, while leading the Philadelphia 76ers to the National Basketball Association championship. In addition, the overpowering 6-foot-10-inch center received $27,258 as his share of the playoff money and a Pontiac Trans-Am yesterday as the most valuable player in the championship series.

title: Senator Warns of Risk Of a Wider Latin War
description: Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, says the similarities between the El Salvador conflict and the Vietnam War are increasingly evident, and there is a ''real risk'' that war could engulf other countries in Central America.

title: WINE TALK
description: CHRISTIE'S, the London auction house, has produced a curious little book about wine prices. The slim volume calls itself ''an indexed review of recent and significant salesroom prices,'' and it purports to offer a complete rundown of what wines cost at Christie's auctions in England, Geneva, Amsterdam and the United States from 1971 to 1982. But if you hope it's going to tip you off to the best deal on a nice California zinfandel, it won't.

title: Panel to Study Boxing Approved
description: The House Education and Labor Committee, by voice vote, approved legislation today to create a 10-member panel to study boxing and make recommendations to Congress aimed at reforming the sport.

title: Trafalgar Bid For P & O
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C. is prepared to spend up to $45 million to raise its stake in the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company to 15 percent, Trafalgar's chairman, Nigel Broackes, said today.

title: A Kaiser Closing
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it is closing the final two producing potlines at its 90 percent owned Valco smelter in Ghana because of continued low water. Valco's first two potlines were closed last November because of the below-normal water conditions and a third line was closed in February.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tribute to Educator

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of nature's great contributions at this time of year is the first red, ripe tomatoes of the season. Where I live, on the East End of Long Island, they begin appearing in the first days of June, when markets begin carrying locally grown hothouse tomatoes. Granted, their flavor is not quite as good as those that come later, but these early arrivals are still worth planning a menu around.

title: COMPUTERS POSE A PERIL FOR POOR, LAUTENBERG SAYS
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who built a personal fortune by founding the largest data-processing company in the nation, warned in his maiden speech in the Senate today that computers threatened to create a new class of poor people.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In an age that demands computer literacy, a school without a computer is like a school without a library.'' -Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey. (B1:6.)

title: WHEN THE GOVERNMENT TAKES BACK A DAM
description: To the Editor:

title: CARA OPERATIONS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DRESS BARN reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Louisiana Offering Draws Investors
description: A $99.85 million general obligation bond issue for the State of Louisiana was won yesterday in competitive bidding by Citibank and priced to yield 5.5 percent in 1984 and 9.25 percent in 2003. The issue was sold out on the first day, the underwriter reported.

title: Mubarak Leaves for Geneva
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt left for Geneva today at the start of a tour that will also take him to Yugoslavia and Rumania. Mr. Mubarak is to address the International Labor Organization conference in Geneva Wednesday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Algoma Steel Corp. said it would permanently close its 18-inch hot rolling mill in Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario, by the end of August. The company did not say how many of the mill's 100 employees would be affected.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have heard that it is possible to determine the ''sex'' of an eggplant or a tomato and that it is preferable to choose the ''female'' of the species. How can I tell the difference at the market?

title: Red Sox Feud Taken to Court
description: The feud among the Boston Red Sox owners spilled into court today when a lawyer for two partners asked a judge to block temporarily an internal ''reorganization.''

title: Playboy Raises
description: A ''very disappointing'' year has led Playboy Enterprises Inc. to put a cap on raises for some of its 1,700 employees during the next fiscal year, officials told employees in a memorandum.

title: CHINA CRITICIZES INVESTMENTS
description: China's efforts to readjust its economy in favor of the consumer are being seriously undercut by unbridled capital investment, a senior planning official said today.

title: Commodore
description: Commodore International Ltd. said it would cut the price of its software and hardware, and would introduce about 70 new programs for its home computers. At the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago, the company said that it was also introducing a new portable computer for business travelers, called the Executive 64, which will retail for about $1,000. Several other manufacturers have introduced similar portables in recent weeks.

title: DEFENSE SUPPLIERS THAT CAN'T AFFORD SHODDINESS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Officials Approve Buyout of Times Beach
description: Federal officials gave final approval today to a $33 million plan to buy all homes and businesses in Times Beach, a town 25 miles southwest of St. Louis that is contaminated by dioxins.

title: 6 Clios for Doyle Dane
description: Six of the 1983 Clio awards for United States print advertising have gone to Doyle Dane Bernbach, for ads for Volkswagen, Chivas Regal, Polaroid, Atari and Colombian Coffee. The National Campaign Clio went to Posey, Parry & Quest in Greenwich, Conn., for their work on behalf of The Reader's Digest. Other multiple print winners, with three each, were Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, Chiat/Day and Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos.

title: A STUDY OF PATTERNS IN FAMILY VIOLENCE
description: More than a quarter of the victims of family violence suffered repeated problems from the same person for months or even years after the original case, according to a two-year study by the Institute for Social Analysis, a private research organization in Reston, Va.

title: NORTHWEST UTILITIES IN WARNING
description: Four private utilities that have invested $700 million in a nuclear plant being built by the Washington Public Power Supply System told the system that they would take drastic steps - including legal action - to prevent the power system from halting construction on the plant.

title: DANIELE AMFITHEATROF
description: The American composer Daniele Amfitheatrof, who scored the music for the film ''Lassie Come Home,'' died today at his home, family members said.

title: City Budget Violins and Fiddles
description: While budget-making in Congress looks like a scrimmage, New York City's legislative action on the 1984 budget has turned out to be as decorous as a minuet at the court of Maria Theresa. The State Comptroller, Edward Regan, warns that the city's 1983 budget surpluses result far more from one-time grants by the state and Federal governments than from increased tax revenues. Yet the City Council and Board of Estimate cheerfully added $70 million in expenditures.

title: DEMOCRATS OFFER CAUTIOUS SUPPORT FOR TAX-CUT LIMIT
description: Some House Democrats expressed uneasiness today that the proposal by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. to limit the benefits of the July 1 tax cut could backfire politically.

title: RAPID AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income Rapid American Corporation is a private company with debentures listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: 2D HOUSE COMMITTEE VOTES TO BAN AID FOR NICARAGUAN REBELS
description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee today approved a Democratic plan to end covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels after a monthlong effort to achieve a compromise collapsed.

title: Malawi Aide Denies Plan To Hang Foe Tomorrow
description: The Malawi opposition leader Orton Chirwa and his wife will not be hanged on Thursday, a spokesman for the Malawi Embassy said here today.

title: Y.& R. Losing Four Accounts
description: ''Due to competitive conflict considerations, we have reluctantly concluded that it is in our best interest to assign these brands to our other agencies.''

title: First Chicago Bid
description: The First Chicago Corporation said it intends to submit a bid for the First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago, which has assets of more than $4.1 billion. The Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation held a bidder's conference for the thrift unit at the end of April, which was also attended by Sears, Roebuck & Company. The deadline for the submission of bids is Friday.

title: Man Sought in Shooting Of 2 Agents Gives Up
description: Clarence Eugene Robinson, who is suspected of wounding two Federal agents last week and who swore he would never be taken alive, walked into an office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation tonight and surrendered.

title: Ford Panel For Mediation
description: The Ford Motor Company said that dissatisfied customers would be able to take their complaints to a mediation board and the panel's decisions would be binding on the company and its dealers.

title: QADDAFI BODYGUARDS IN PATENT-LEATHER HIGH HEELS
description: Under the walls of Africa Hall, where the Organization of African Unity remains locked in possibly terminal dispute, there is a modest sideshow for those not privy to the deliberations within.

title: Vivian O'Gara Weyerhaeuser; Headed Met Opera Council
description: Vivian O'Gara Weyerhaeuser, president of the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera in the 1950's, died Monday at her home in St. Paul, Minn.

title: DANCE: A MERCE CUNNINGHAM EVENT
description: ALTHOUGH Merce Cunningham's Events are so constructed that they can be danced almost anywhere, over the years some sites for them have been more striking than others. On Monday night, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company offered the first in a series of six Events at a very spectacular site indeed, the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: Newspaper Revenue Up
description: Americans spent $6.7 billion on daily and Sunday newspapers last year, a 7.3 percent increase from 1981, according to the Newspaper Advertising Bureau. That represented 62.4 million daily newspapers each weekday and 56.2 million each Sunday. Readers and advertisers together spent $24.4 billion on newspapers last year.

title: Minnesota Power Bonds Shifted to Meet Demand
description: A $112 million bond issue for the Western Minnesota Municipal Power Agency that was tentatively priced on Monday by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb was restructured yesterday to offer yields ranging from 6 3/4 percent in 1985 to 9 3/4 percent in 2016.

title: McEnroe Gains
description: John McEnroe advanced to the second round of the $203,000 Stella Artois tennis tournament today by beating Jeff Borowiak, 6-3, 6-3. Ivan Lendl, playing on grass for the first time in two years, defeated Nick Saviano, 6-4, 6-4. This tournament is a tuneup for Wimbledon, which starts June 20.

title: Deadline Is Set On Brazil Debt
description: Brazil, with foreign debts close to $90 billion, has been given until the end of this month to repay an overdue $400 million loan from central banks, Fritz Leutwiler, president of the Bank for International Settlements, said today.

title: TSI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
No Headline
description: Letter: On Compensating Injustice Why Did Zimmerman Have to Wait? To the Editor: Your June 5 editorial ''What Price a Zimmerman?'' focuses public attention on the key issue that preoccupied us as attorneys for Mr. Zimmerman: ''How much is a life worth?''

title: DIPLOMAT SAYS AFGHAN REBELS KILLED 200 OF ARMY'S SOLDIERS
description: A Western diplomat said today that Moslem rebels in Afghanistan had struck a severe blow against Government forces by killing about 200 soldiers in a three-day battle. The rest of the Government unit involved deserted to the guerrillas, the diplomat added.

title: EDGAR S. ORLOFF
description: Edgar S. Orloff, a columnist and editor, died of Lou Gehrig's disease Saturday. Mr. Orlff, 59 years old, had continued until a month ago to supervise his nationally syndicated column, ''Medicine Today.'' He retired in January 1982 as assistant managing editor of The San Francisco Examiner. He also had taught journalism at the University of California-Berkeley and worked for 11 newspapers, including The Bergen Record.

title: BARBECUING WITH GAS
description: EVERY weekend at this time of year, little gray-blue cloud puffs can be seen hovering above the suburbs like Indian smoke signals. What they are announcing is that the season has arrived for barbecuing, the great American summer pastime.

title: Soviet Plans Gas Growth
description: Soviet natural gas production will increase to 630 billion cubic meters a year by 1985 from 500 billion last year, the head of the Soviet Gas Export Company said today.

title: ASTRAL BELLEVUE PATHE LTD reports earnings for year to Feb 26.
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A JOURNEY FOR OUR TIMES. A Mem- oir. By Harrison E. Salisbury. Harper & Row. 546 pages. $22.50.

title: South African Shares
description: A public offering of 9.5 million shares in the Prudential Assurance Company of South Africa Ltd. was 36.09 times oversubscribed, the Standard Merchant Bank said today.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Show On View Into September
description: ''The Great East River Bridge,'' an exhibition of drawings, paintings, prints, photographs and other material about the Brooklyn Bridge, will be on view through Sept. 5 at the Brooklyn Museum, Eastern Parkway and Washington Avenue.

title: PATRICK KENNEALLY
description: Patrick Kenneally, who worked as equipment and business manager in the Fordham University athletic department for 54 years until he retired in January 1982, died Monday.

title: Visiting P.S. 166 43 Years Later
description: L ewis Rudin, real-estate executive and chairman of the Association for a Better New York, returned to Public School 166, at 132 West 89th Street, yesterday - the first time since he graduated in 1940.

title: New Bicycle Inner Tube
description: A West German rubber company, Continental Gummiwerke A.G., announced today that it had developed a bicycle inner tube that eliminates the need to take off the wheel before fixing a flat tire. The inner tube has two sealed and overlapping ends, giving it the appearance of a piece of garden hose when straightened out. The tube can be pulled off the wheel rim sideways without removing the wheel or loosening the chain.

title: AS AT THE BEACH
description: IT rained, but bad weather didn't dampen the clambake steaming away on the terrace of Addison and Karen Kermath's Manhattan penthouse. There was no driftwood fire to rake, but the clams, lobsters, chicken, corn and potatoes steamed over rockweed were otherwise the same as at the beach. As one of the guests wryly observed, dining on clams and lobsters in a dry apartment had certain advantages over huddling on the beach poking at a fire in chilly, damp weather.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
A Tough Call
description: When the Texas Rangers drafted Jeff Kunkel, a Rider College shortstop, on Monday, it created a potential conflict of interest for Kunkel's father, Bill Kunkel, the American League umpire who just returned to work after a battle against cancer. ''If Jeff makes it to the majors, I'm going to have a tough decision to make,'' Bill Kunkel said.

title: CARLTON NEW STRIKEOUT LEADER
description: Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies passed Nolan Ryan as the career strikeout leader tonight, the second time this season a pitcher has eclipsed a record that had stood since 1927.

title: Sir Anthony Lewis, 68, Dies; Musicologist and Conductor
description: Sir Anthony Lewis, the British musicologist and conductor who successfully revived neglected works by Handel, Purcell and Rameau, has died, it was announced Monday. He was 68 years old.

title: YOUTH'S COLUMN MAKES HIM POPULAR WITH TOP MINDS IN VIDEO GAMES
description: From the neck up, Rawson Stovall looks like Dennis the Menace, his favorite cartoon character, blond with bright eyes and an impish smile. From the neck down, however, he looks every bit the professional that he is, dressed in a navy blazer, gray slacks, a tie and tassel loafers, with note pad and pen in hand.

title: OPEC Plans Review of Pact
description: A four-member OPEC market-monitoring committee will meet here Wednesday to review the state of the group's pricing and output pact, which was signed in London in March.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: 21 NICARAGUANS IN 6 CONSULATES EXPELLED BY U.S.
description: The United States today ordered the expulsion of 21 Nicaraguan consular officials and the closing of all six Nicaraguan consulates in this country in retaliation for the ejection on Monday of three American diplomats from Nicaragua.

title: House Authorizes Job Funds To Train Vietnam-Era Veterans
description: The House passed legislation today that would authorize $325 million for temporary emergency job training for unemployed Vietnam war era veterans.

title: VOLCKER IS SUPPORTED BY EXECUTIVES IN POLL
description: More than three-quarters of 702 institutional investment ''decision makers'' who were polled in May want to keep Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. His term ends in August.

title: President of the Ivory Coast Sees Reagan at White House
description: President Reagan met with President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast today to discuss economic prospects and the political situation in Africa.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. of Montreal, which is 53.4 percent owned by Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., announced that a subsidiary had reached an agreement to supply $70 million worth of equipment over a fiveyear period to Teleglobe Canada.

title: Fluor's Net Off 34.2% in Period
description: The Fluor Corporation, a worldwide leader in the engineering and construction fields, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of 1983 ended April 30 plunged 34.2 percent, to $27.7 million, or 35 cents a share, from $42.1 million, or 53 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues dropped 24 percent, to $1.46 billion, from $1.92 billion.

title: PARTICIPATION RISES IN LUNCH PROGRAM
description: Participation in the Government's school lunch program has begun to rise again after the budget cutbacks of 1981, which reduced the rolls by at least three million children, the Reagan Adinistration says.

title: Sanyo's German Project
description: The Sanyo Electric Company said today that it was negotiating with an unidentified West German steel company to buy an idle factory for the assembly of videotape recorders early next year.

title: AGREEMENT OPENS WAY FOR ALBECK TO BE NET COACH
description: The Nets and the San Antonio Spurs reached a settlement yesterday that should soon make Stan Albeck the new coach of the Nets. The Spurs will receive $300,000, the 22d selection in the second round of this year's collegiate draft and the rights to Fred Roberts, who was the 27th selection in the 1982 draft, but played that season in Europe. Roberts, an original draft selection of the Milwaukee Bucks, was subsequently obtained by the Nets with Mickey Johnson in a trade for Phil Ford last season. Richardson Leaves Hospital

title: THE TURMOIL AT AMERICAN BELL
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's new subsidiary, American Bell, is in a state of turmoil after only five months of operation. Developments today and Monday point to a scramble within American Bell to reduce costs and to eliminate troubling organizational problems that could retard its movement into new businesses.

title: TV: GIULINI CONCERTS COME TO A CLOSE
description: ''THE Giulini Concerts II'' series comes to a close this evening, on WNET/ 13 at 9 o'clock, with performances of Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 2 and Paul Hindemith's ''Concert Music for Strings and Brass.''

title: Cap Politics, Not Taxes
description: The Supreme Court did more to relieve the Federal deficit crisis this week than either the President or Congress. By upholding the ''windfall profits'' tax on oil, the Court spared the Treasury from having to pay out $26 billion in retroactive refunds and from losing billions more in future revenues. The only thing new from either of the other branches is the misguided plan from Speaker O'Neill to cap the tax cut that's supposed to start in 23 days.

title: Teamster Chief Tells Senators He Opposes Racketeering Bill
description: The president of the teamsters' union, Jackie Presser, said today that his union opposed a labor racketeering bill because it established a double standard for management and union officials.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $140,000.

title: Advertising; All Sci-Fi's Are Not All The Same
description: ANYONE old enough to be reading this column probably would find this summer's movies a confusing and largely indistinguishable crop of sci-fi, futuristic thrillers. But Hollywood's target is the teenagers and pre-teen-agers who make up the important summer audience, and the studios' markets are now unleashing the campaigns that, they hope, will make their films compulsory viewing.

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including net income of $70,000 for the quarter and a net loss of $467,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. SENDING A RETIRED JUDGE TO MONITOR A SALVADOR TRIAL
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to send a special representative to El Salvador to try to make sure that courts there conduct a thorough trial of Salvadoran soldiers accused of murdering four United States Roman Catholic churchwomen in December 1980.

title: VERTICAL MALLS: CITY SIDEWALKS MOVE INDOORS
description: It connects on one side to a department store, features an obligatory waterfall, a snack bar and mellow background music -like a lavish suburban shopping mall stood on end to soar six levels and capped with a skylight.

title: I.M.F. Terms To Venezuela
description: The International Monetary Fund will set stiffer economic conditions on Venezuela's request for a $1.1 billion compensatory financing credit than it has on previous loans, financial sources said today.

title: Crown Zellerbach
description: The Crown Zellerbach Corporation said that Haindl Papier, a West German paper company, had tentatively agreed to purchase and modernize its paper mill in Port Townsend. Crown Zellerbach plans to close the mill by Oct. 1, idling about 640 workers. Haindl plans to operate the mill ''to serve its own markets,'' according to a statement prepared by Crown Zellerbach.

title: SWEDLOW INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
ANDROPOV APPEARS WEAK AT CEREMONY
description: Doubts about the health of Yuri V. Andropov have been raised by what appeared to be weakness shown by the Soviet leader during the visit of the Finnish President.

title: Mellon Bank Withdrawals
description: Depositors at the Mellon Bank have rallied behind the United Steelworkers union and closed bank accounts worth thousands of dollars to protest the bank's freezing the assets of the bankrupt Mesta Machine Company.

title: Briton Lands His Jet On a Spanish Cargo Ship
description: A British navy warplane made a forced landing on a Spanish cargo ship in the Atlantic on Monday after losing radio contact with its aircraft carrier base, a British Embassy spokesman said today.

title: Marriott Plans Lower-Cost Inns
description: The Marriott Corporation plans to open five moderately priced hotels in Georgia this fall, in an experiment designed to compete with Howard Johnson's, Holiday Inns and other major hotel chains.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MY husband and I had just returned from our first summer weekend together. The shower felt wonderful after hours on the hot, dusty road, but no sooner did my husband turn off the water than he had what could only be called a ''skin fit.'' His body actually shook as an intensely itchy rash appeared over much of it, in particular those areas that had been exposed to the sun while we picked wild strawberries and lounged at the lakeside.

title: RUDOLPH FLUEGGE
description: Rudolph Fluegge, an investment executive, died Saturday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: BLACK LEADERS APPEAL FOR NEW U.S.-SUPPORTED SOCIAL POLICIES
description: A group of black scholars and civil rights leaders declared today that new government-supported social policies were urgently needed to bring equity to people excluded from society's mainstream, especially many blacks.

title: TELECOMMUNICATIONS A FACET OF OFFICE LEASING IN CITY
description: An important link is emerging between office building development and modern telecommunications. Tenants, whether they be banks, brokerage houses or law firms, are constantly trying to save money, and among the opportunities that technology is opening to them are ways to cut the cost of communications.

title: Yakov L. Fishman, 70, Moscow Rabbi, Is Dead
description: Yakov L. Fishman, chief rabbi of Moscow's Choral Synagogue, died Saturday of a heart attack, the press agency Tass reported Monday. He was 70 years old.

title: SCOUTING
description: Mark Slawson, the wide receiver for the New Jersey Generals, caught an 11-yard pass from Gene Bradley for a touchdown last Saturday night when the Generals lost to the Invaders, 34-21, in Oakland.

title: LIMITS SOUGHT ON BANKS' INSURANCE ROLE
description: Insurance industry representatives urged Congress today to quickly enact a moratorium to keep banks from moving into the general insurance business.

title: After the Nineties
description: ''The Sixties were a lot like the Twenties,'' somebody was saying the other day. ''That kind of vitality seems to run in 40-year cycles.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Investing column in the Busi- ness section last Sunday and an ac- companying table misstated the stock performance of the MCI Corporation. The stock closed at $19.44 a share on Aug. 11, 1982. Its performance has generally been in line with that of other telecommunications issues.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1983
description: International Shifts in American arms control plans were indicated by President Reagan to his top national security aides, according to Administration officials. They said that Mr. Reagan had indicated he would modify his proposal for the Soviet Union to make deep cuts in long-range missiles, but continue to insist on a one-third cut in missile warheads. (Page A1, Column 6.) 21 Nicaraguan consular officials were ordered expelled by Washington in retaliation for the expulsion Monday of three United States diplomats from Nicaragua. In addition, the Reagan Administration ordered the closing of all six Nicaraguan consulates in this country. (A1:5.) Covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels would be halted under a Democratic proposal adopted by the House Foreign Affairs Committee by a largely party-line vote of 20 to 14. (A1:3-4.)

title: State of the Tour
description: The PGA Tour has a dual role that is unusual in sports. Among other things, the organization of professional golfers establishes the conditions under which players may compete or not compete in tournaments, oversees a set of regulations and a code of conduct, and enforces discipline with fines and occasional suspensions.

title: TEXAS GOVERNOR FINDS OIL WEALTH HAS DRIED UP
description: Gov. Mark White has been in office 140 days, but already he takes the long and stoic view of things, particularly of the recalcitrant Texas Legislature.

title: Procter & Gamble Loses Plea on Toxic Shock Data
description: A Federal appeals court has rejected the Procter & Gamble Company's bid to obtain records on toxic shock syndrome from the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: Economic Scene; If the Japanese Shifted to Coal
description: TOKYO THE Japanese economy, while still the pacesetter among the major industrialized nations, is boxed in. The roads to future growth seem blocked. Restraints in various guises already curb the flow of more than half of its exports. Because the Government is worried about large budget deficits, fiscal austerity is the order of the day.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: All 1982 figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Martin & Stern Inc. last Feb. 3. The acquisition has been accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: Amoco Leases
description: The Amoco exploration and production subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) announced that the United States Minerals Management Service had accepted 53 of 68 high bids submitted by Amoco on May 25 in outer continental shelf lease sale No.72. The remaining 15 high bids by Amoco are being reviewed by Minerals Management. The 53 tracts awarded to Amoco so far represent a net outlay of $408.5 million for a total of about 214,000 acres.

title: REAGAN AIDE HAILS SHIFT ON DISABILITY
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today that new rules for the Social Security disability program were designed to end ''hardships and heartbreaks'' for innocent, worthy people who might otherwise lose their benefits.

title: Sun Deck on L.I. Falls; 40 People Are Injured
description: At least 40 people were slightly injured yesterday when a sun deck collapsed during an annual charity benefit at a resort development in Manorville, L.I., the Suffolk County police said.

title: Dee Engelbach, Producer, 73; Active in Radio and Television
description: Dee Engelbach, a radio and television producer-director, died after a short illness on Sunday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MASCAN CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss In the latest year preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: Hagler Wants 15
description: Jose Sulaiman, president of the World Boxing Council, said he would ask Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight champion, to accept the W.B.C.'s limit of 12-round title defenses or to abandon his title.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
CSX AND TEXAS GAS IN MERGER PACT
description: In a move that could touch off a bidding war, the CSX Corporation, the nation's biggest railroad company, announced yesterday that it had agreed to merge with the Texas Gas and Resources Corporation in a cash and stock deal approaching $984 million.

title: THE FLIP SIDE OF GREATNESS
description: G aylord Perry, the Seattle pitcher, recently moved into fourth place on the career list of major league losses - he now has 258. The man with the damp delivery is in highly select company.

title: DAF Trucks
description: The International Harvester Company intends to sell its 37.5 percent stake in DAF Trucks B.V. to a new Dutch consortium and a managing body, DAF said.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a net gain of $1,105,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of GTE Corp. common stock.

title: ACME GENERAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
BROKERAGE AND THE HARD SELL
description: The hard sell has come to the brokerage business. Brokerage products and prices are now being promoted with greater frequency and the kind of zeal previously reserved for cars, clothes and cigarettes.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has named Edward A. Weisman to the new post of vice chairman.

title: GOLFER STILL LIVING OFF ONE BIG VICTORY
description: Were it not for a hot putter during an extremely hot weekend in Houston 14 years ago this month, when he won the United States Open, Orville Moody might have quietly left the golf tour.

title: Head of Agent Orange Unit
description: John Svahn, Under Secretary of Health and Human Services, was named Monday to head the Government's working group on Agent Orange. The group, part of the Cabinet Council on Human Resources, coordinates Federal research on long-term health effects of exposure to herbicides, principally Agent Orange, used in the Vietnam War.

title: Iraqi Offers Iranians A Limited Cease-Fire
description: In an open letter to the Iranian people, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has proposed a limited cease-fire in the Iranian-Iraqi war, the official Iraqi press agency reported today.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 8, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices plunged as concern spread that the Federal Reserve may soon tighten monetary policy, pushing up interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 19.33 points, to 1,194.91. Over all, declines outnumbered advances by 1,044 to 588. The decline was the Dow's largest since May 2, when it fell 21.87 points. (Page D1.)

title: Convicted Killer Indicted In Coast Bombing Plot
description: A man awaiting sentencing for murder has been indicted by a Federal grand jury for conspiracy in at least 16 bombings in the San Francisco area from 1973 to 1978, prosecutors said today.

title: Unregistered Bank
description: Migrant workers picketed an unregistered bank here today, seeking return of more than $160,000 they had deposited at ''Fred's Place.''

title: ULTRASYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-to-3 stock split distributed Jan. 31.

title: RATES RISE ON FEDERAL MORTGAGES
description: For the first time in more than a year, the Government is raising the interest rate ceiling on federally insured single-family home loans, officials said today.

title: Bridge: Test of Marital Harmony Revised for Card Players
description: For several hundred years the village of Dunmow in England has awarded a flitch to the married couple who can best prove, after a light-hearted public inquisition, that they have lived in complete marital harmony for the previous 12 months.

title: UTILITY 'BONDHOLDERS' WITH NOTHING TO CLIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Player Protection
description: Twenty-four major league baseball teams, complete with stars and matinee idols, come to New York each season for games against the Mets and the Yankees. Naturally, the highly publicized athletes attract autograph seekers and some overenthusiastic fans at the teams' hotels.

title: AMUSING THE CHILDREN ON SUMMER DAYS
description: CHILDREN are bound to be around more once school lets out for the s ummer, which prompts thoughts of how to amuse and please them. Here a re a few suggestions: 1. Small Green Thumbs For budding gardeners there is a child's gardening kit from France that comes with navy blue apron, ticking-striped gloves, red plastic tools, plastic flowerpots and instructions in French and English. Called Les Petits Jardiniers and made by Manuwell, the kits are $30 in Barneys Chelsea Passage.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Optioned Don W elchel, right-handed pitcher, to Roches- t er of the International League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Acquired Bob T ufts, reliever, from Omaha of the Ameri- c an Association for Charlie Leibrandt, p itcher, of Indianapolis of the American A ssociation; called up Keefe Cato, pitch- e r, from Indianapolis.

title: Reagan to Make Appeal On Funds for Public TV
description: President Reagan will make an appeal for public television in a taped promotional message urging businesses to contribute more support, an official of the Public Broadcasting Service has announced.

title: FROST & SULLIVAN INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
HOLLINGS HACKS AWAY AT HIS RIVALS
description: To have a chance in the Democratic Presidential race, Senator Ernest F. Hollings figures he must beat out Senator John Glenn for the moderate vote. Therefore, Senator Hollings seldom misses a chance to denigrate Senator Glenn's political experience or his ideas, particularly, his plan to finance an acid rain cleanup with a consumer tax on electricity.

title: JERSEY DEMOCRATS REGAIN SENATE WORKING MAJORITY
description: Democrats regained a slim working majority in the New Jersey Senate last night when Assemblyman Raymond J. Lesniak of Elizabeth won a special election to fill a Senate vacancy in a district that includes parts of Union and Middlesex Counties.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday about a Pennsylvania welfare ruling incorrectly reported the state's usual welfare payment for a single person classified as ''chronically needy.'' It is $172 a month.

title: ANIXTER BROTHERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SEAVER HURT
description: After reasonably professional efforts in Los Angeles, the Mets suffered a relapse and a 6-1 loss today as the Chicago Cubs accepted all favors and ran their winning streak to six games.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BALLET: A WORK BY PETIPA
description: AMERICAN BALLET THEATER saved the best for last on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House in a program that culminated in a sparkling performance of ''Raymonda.''

title: F.D.A. PROPOSAL ON MEAT SAFETY DRAWS CRITICISM
description: A RECENT proposal by the Food and Drug Administration to relax safety standards for animal feed medicated with antibiotics and allow additional varieties of the feed on the market has brought protests from consumer groups, including the National Resources Defense Council, and from Representative John Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigation.

title: OFFICIAL TO URGE THAT STATE SELL CONVENTION SITE
description: The head of the state's Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that he would recommend to Governor Cuomo that New York City's Convention Center be sold to pay for overruns, estimated at as much as $75 million.

title: 'K2' Closing Saturday After 85 Performances
description: The Patrick Meyers drama ''K2,'' starring Jeffrey DeMunn and Jay Patterson, will close next Saturday night at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. The play, which concerns two climbers stranded below the peak of K2 in the Himalayas, will have played 85 performances and 10 previews.

title: REAGAN'S EFFORTS TO RAISE THE EAST-WEST CONFRONTATION LEVEL
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: 'ARTERY,' A TOUR THROUGH POP LANDSCAPE
description: WITH his walk-through style of theater, Chris Hardman may have created a new fun-house performance art form. ''Artery,'' a production of the Antenna Theater at the Performing Garage, a play written, directed and designed by Mr. Hardman, takes the audience on a guided tour of a labyrinth of adventure.

title: COSTS OF PROJECT IN SEAPORT AREA GO OVER BUDGET
description: Rehabilitation of a key section of the South Street Seaport is costing up to $700,000 more than the $9.6 million it was budgeted for, an official of the State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: Richmond Denied Parole
description: F ormer Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn, serving a prison term of a year and a day, has been denied a parole. Convicted of income-tax evasion, marijuana possession and making an illegal payment to a Federal employee, Mr. Richmond entered Allenwood Federal Prison Camp in Pennsylvania on Dec. 6.

title: RICHARD THOMPSON NOW OUT ON HIS OWN
description: ''IT'S funny how early stuff influences you,'' the guitarist Richard Thompson recently remarked. ''After the age of 3, it's all over in terms of taste. I grew up in London listening to my sister's Buddy Holly and Jerry Lee Lewis records. My dad's records of jazz and Scottish country-dance music filtered in, too, but basically, I'm an ordinary rock-and-roller.''

title: The Mirrors And an Unusual Reflection
description: A t Harvard, Maura Moynihan, the daughter of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, majored in comparative religion and English literature.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ONE COOK'S GUIDE: SAVORING THE HARVEST OF SUMMER BERRIES
description: THE surest sign that summer has made up its muddled mind and is actually coming is the start, in field and market, of the annual spate of berries. The calendar may so far have given us only mendacious months - and the weather, witness this year's cold and sodden spring, may have proved an unreconstructed cheat - but with the first strawberries of the year, we forgive nature her four unreliable seasons and dare to hope that for once she is about to keep her word.

title: Derby Cut Tabled
description: Churchill Downs's board of directors declined today to vote on a proposal to change the process for limiting the Kentucky Derby field to 20 horses. It voted to refer the change proposed by Howard Battle, the racing secretary, to its horsemen's committee.

title: Market Place; Negatives for Machine Tools
description: SEGMENTS of the machine tool industry are awash in red ink, yet three issues in this group traded last week at their highest prices in 52 weeks on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: AT NATURAL HISTORY, ADULTS FIND MORE TO DO
description: More adults are going to the American Museum of Natural History for their own pleasure and not primarily to show the museum to their children. That is is one of the major findings, announced yesterday, of a major survey of this leading West Side museum, which draws 2.5 million visitors a year. It is the second major survey ever taken of visitors to the museum.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
PRINCETON HEAD TELLS GRADUATES TO SERVE SOCIETY
description: In a commencement ceremony that combined laughter, solemn farewells and pageantry, Dr. William G. Bowen, the president of Princeton University, today urged the class of 1983 not to forsake public service for selfish goals.

title: BRITISH NONWHITES SEEK BIGGER VOICE
description: Mohinder Bhambra poured a cup of creamy sweet tea for the young man seated in his small living room and in a torrent of Punjabi explained why he planned to cast a ballot for the Liberal candidate in Thursday's general election.

title: Noah Is Suspended
description: Yannick Noah of France, who won the French Open last Sunday, has been suspended from competition for 49 days and fined $20,000 for refusing to participate in a match after his country was eliminated during the Nations' Cup tournament last month. The suspension, issued by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council, the governing body in the sport, is scheduled to go into effect July 11.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $196,000 for the latest quarter and $284,000 for the year-earlier period. Results for last year's first quarter included sales of $9,395,000 and net earnings of $33,000, or 1 cents a share, associated with the Holsum, Caribe Foods and Pueblo Communications operations that were sold during the fourth quarter of its last fiscal year.

title: FRANCE WARMS UP TO A ROLE IN NATO
description: At first the French Foreign Ministry explained the choice of Paris for this spring's Atlantic Council meeting as a routine one, a simple matter of rotation, as if France had received the job of managing a NATO ministerial session like a car-pool assignment.

title: N.H.L. WON'T RELENT ON BLUES FRANCHISE
description: The National Hockey League is telling parties interested in buying the St. Louis Blues to contact the Ralston Purina Company, which it says is still the owner of the troubled franchise. Ralston Purina is advising potential buyers to deal directly with the league, which it says is the owner of the franchise.

title: WASTE FROM ATOMIC RESEARCH FOUND CONTAMINATING STREAM IN JERSEY TOWN
description: Radioactive wastes produced in research on the atomic bomb after World War II have contaminated a half-mile stream and its banks here in a residential neighborhood near the Pompton River, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has found.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1983; The Economy
description: President Reagan's top aides told him the Federal Reserve should be headed by either Paul A. Volcker, whose term as chairman expires Aug.5, or the economist Alan Greenspan, according to Administration officials. They said Mr. Reagan had made no decision yet, and might name someone else. (Page A1.) Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan criticized Democratic attempts to cap the third year of the personal tax cut. (D10.)

title: Crippled Plane Down Safely After Burning Off Extra Fuel
description: A four-engine Reeves Aleutian Airline plane headed for Seattle with 15 people aboard made a safe emergency landing here tonight after circling to burn off fuel, officials said.

title: New Yorker Returns to TV
description: Having determined that younger media buyers are probably not media readers, The New Yorker has returned to television after a decade's absence in an attempt to reach advertisers and agencies.

title: JUDGE ORDERS NEW GAF PROXY VOTE
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered a new vote in the bitter GAF Corporation proxy contest, thus upsetting the victory claimed only a month ago by Samuel J. Heyman, a dissident GAF shareholder.

title: Safeway Bid Fails
description: Safeway Stores Ltd. said in a statement that it would not raise its bid for Fitch Lovell P.L.C.'s supermarket subsidiary, Key Markets Ltd., from the $69.9 million offered on May 26. A Fitch Lovell spokesman said plans are going ahead for the sale of Key Markets to Linfood Holdings P.L.C., which ultimately matched Safeway's offer.

title: MITTERRAND SEES UNITY AND ORDER DESPITE INFLATION AND ANGRY POLICE
description: President Francois Mitterrand, reacting to accusations that France has slipped into a crisis of authority, reasserted in a national television interview tonight that he is in firm control of the nation.

title: Gerald Ford on Board
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford was elected to the board of directors of the Peabody International Corporation today, replacing William D. Ruckelshaus, who resigned after being appointed administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Mr. Ford also serves on the boards of Amax Inc., the American Express Company, the Santa Fe International Corporation and the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation.

title: SBE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TOM STEEK, 32 YEARS IN CONGRESS
description: Former United States Representative Tom Steed, who once said that ''being a good errand boy'' for the people of his Oklahoma district earned him 32 years in Congress, died of cancer today at Shawnee Medical Center, family members said. He was 79 years old.

title: S.E.C. FILES SUIT AGAINST FOX & CO.
description: Fox & Company, one of the nation's leading accounting firms, was charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday with using careless and improper auditing methods.

title: Track Mark Set
description: Marlies Goehr of East Germany bettered her world record in the 100 meters today with a time of 10.81 seconds. The 25-year-old runner's previous mark was 10.88, set in July 1977 at Dresden, East Germany. Marita Koch, also of East Germany, was timed in 10.83 and finished second.

title: CLASSIC DIFFERS FROM THE OPEN
description: When Ray Floyd won the 15th Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic two years ago, the tournament was played a week before the United States Open. Floyd's victory at the Westchester Country Club, for which he earned $72,000, did not serve as a preparation for the Open, in which he tied for 37th place at the Merion Golf Club in suburban Philadelphia.

title: SPAIN WARM ON ENDERS, BUT WARILY
description: The nomination of Thomas O. Enders as United States Ambassador to Spain has met with a largely positive reaction here, mostly because of an assumption that his views on Latin America are closer to the Spanish Government's than to those of the Reagan Administration.

title: COMPUTERS AFFECT DECORATORS' PLANS
description: INTERIOR designers are working with more computers in the home, more childless families, more old buildings and less space, according to a survey conducted by the American Society of Interior Designers. The survey also found that business for designers has surged despite hard times for builders and architects.

title: CAVEAT IS LEARNING EARLY-SPEED LESSON
description: The brass nameplate on the colt's halter says Caveat. It isn't necessary to translate the name from the Latin - it's the third person singular subjunctive of the verb that means ''to be wary of'' - to know that the colt merits respect in the Belmont Stakes Saturday. That's obvious by who's training him and what he's saying: Woody Stephens is cracking down on Caveat, and it's a realiable caveat around the race track that when Stephens gets serious, it's time to beware.

title: SCIENTIFIC RADIO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Costa Rica Holds Soviet Ship
description: A Soviet ship bound for Nicaragua was being held today in Puerto Limon, Costa Rica, on suspicion of carrying arms, the authorities said. The vessel, the Nadezhda Krupskaya, docked there Tuesday to unload chemical and iron products. Costa Rican officials said the ship was carrying huge crates believed to be helicopters and weapons and was ordered held for a thorough check.

title: U.S.F.L. to Sign Bills' Top Choice
description: The United States Football League has become at least a minor irritant to the older National Football League by signing a handful of recent N.F.L. draft choices, including Gary Anderson, the wide receiver from Arkansas and a first-round selection of the San Diego Chargers.

title: LYPHOMED INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
YANKEES WIN ON RUN IN NINTH
description: Lou Piniella came off the bench as a pinch-hitter in the ninth inning last night and gave the Yankees the kind of relief they have not received from their relief corps the past week.

title: CONFEREES START TO DRAFT BUDGET
description: Senate and House conferees began trying to draft a compromise budget for the Federal Government today, and lawmakers from both parties stressed that if Congress failed to adopt a spending plan the economic recovery could be undermined.

title: The U.N. Today; June 9, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HYATT SUBMITS PLAN IN BRANIFF HEARING
description: The Hyatt Corporation submitted a final proposal on restarting part of Braniff Airways yesterday, meeting a deadline set earlier in the day by the Federal bankruptcy judge overseeing the case.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
HANDY WAYS FOR STORING WINE
description: THERE are several wine storage systems from which the homeowner can create a wine cave. Strong and easy to assemble, these units can be used singly or grouped in a closet or basement or exposed on a kitchen wall.

title: Union Synthetics
description: The Union Oil Company of California said it would begin production of 10,000 barrels of synthetic crude oil a day about Aug.1 at the Parachute Creek project in northwest Colorado.

title: TOPPS & TROWSERS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
3-Party Norwegian Coalition Affirms Policy Link to NATO
description: The new coalition Government of the Conservative, Christian People's and Center parties took office today and said there would be no change in foreign and security policies based on membership in the Atlantic alliance.

title: NETS SIGN ALBECK AS THE NEW COACH
description: In a move they hoped would end what was perhaps the most tumultuous episode in their history, the Nets made official today what had been rumored for weeks. They announced the signing of Stan Albeck as coach.

title: CONCERT: NEW ROMANTICISM AT THE PHILARMONIC
description: ''YES, I feel that the moment has come'' - says one of the singers in Luciano Berio's ''Sinfonia'' - ''for us to look back, if we can, and take our bearings.''

title: MRS. THATCHER CLOSES CAMPAIGN CONFIDENT OF VICTORY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ended her campaign for re-election today with a prediction that the Conservative Party would win a sweeping victory in Thursday's general election ''because of our steadfastness and our perseverance and our rightness.''

title: I.B.M. Settles Lin Data Suit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which charged that Yeong S. Lin and his company, the Lin Data Corporation, had used I.B.M. trade secrets, has reached an out-of-court settlement with the former I.B.M employee.

title: M.T.A. ASKS EXCEPTION FROM WHEELCHAIR LAW
description: Plans to modernize 88 New York City subway stations will be jeopardized unless the State Legislature acts soon to exempt the subway system from a state law that requires access for wheelchairs, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Wrong Schedule
description: Some football fans may remember the New Yorker magazine cartoon by Robert Day in which a radio announcer, seated before a microphone in a completely empty stadium, says, ''Well, folks, here it is starting time. One moment while we take a look at that little old schedule.''

title: SPRINGFIELD, MASS., TAKES NEW HEART
description: A few years ago, Main Street here was a decaying monument to the economic forces that have swept 20th century America: the exodus of Northern industry to the South and West and the flight of city people to the suburbs.

title: Advertising; Big Gains For Radio Networks
description: "FORTUNATELY, there is network radio.'' That is the message of an advertising campaign by the Radio Network Association, which says that the audience for network radio has soared in recent years, as half of the nation's 8,100 radio stations have affiliated with one or more of the 20 radio networks. Meanwhile, it notes, network television's share of viewers has declined.

title: Bonn Diplomat Dies in U.S.
description: Jurgen A. Drager, 40 years old, a counselor at the West German Embassy in Washington, apparently died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the chest, the authorities said today. His wife found the body Tuesday afternoon in bed at their Bethesda, Md., home.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Dirty Trick Reported

title: NEW CHAIRMAN NAMED AT CHANNEL 13
description: William M. Ellinghaus, president and chief operating officer of the American Telephone & Telegraph Company, was designated chairman of the board of trustees of Channel 13 yesterday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Robert Reid, the former Houston Rocket forward-guard who left the team at the beginning of last season to pursue religious work, told the club he would not be returning. ... George Brett, the Kansas City Royals' third baseman, will miss five games after having broken the little toe on his left foot when he bumped into a door jamb while doing laundry in his home. ... The nation's No.1 sports fan and its top professional basketball team met at the White House Rose Garden for some role reversal yesterday. The Philadelphia 76ers watched and President Reagan performed - bouncing an autographed gift basketball on the grass. ... Hector Camacho has asked the World Boxing Council to strip Bobby Chacon of his junior lightweight title on the ground that Chacon broke a contract to face Camacho in a title fight.

title: Chinaglia Deal Near
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, said yesterday that he was close to a deal to purchase the Lazio soccer club of Rome, for whom he spent seven seasons as a popular forward before joining the Cosmos in 1975. ''There are still some problems,'' Chinaglia said in a telephone interview from San Diego, where the Cosmos played last night.

title: Father, 15, Is Charged With Infant's Murder
description: A 3-month-old girl was fatally shot yesterday in a Bronx apartment by her 15-year-old father as he was showing a .22-caliber revolver to the infant's mother, the police said.

title: LEONIA NOW ADVERTISING FOR STUDENTS
description: In the marketplace of ideas, Leonia has decided it pays to advertise. The town is selling an education in its public schools through a direct-mail blitz of several neighboring communities.

title: BTR Obtains Tilling Control
description: BTR, a British conglomerate, said today that it had won control of Thomas Tilling, a widely diversified energy and engineering company. BTR's offer, totaling about $1.03 billion, was among the largest in Britain's corporate history.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Spahn vs. Appling
description: Who was the last batter to hit a home run off Warren Spahn? The 62-year-old pitcher who won 363 games, more than any other left-hander in major-league history, had no trouble answering that question yesterday.

title: Bank Money Market Rates Up a Bit
description: For the third straight week, interest rates offered by major banks on their money market deposit accounts rose nationwide, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK URGES CONGRESS TO SEEK ACCORD ON LATIN AMERICA
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick went to Capitol Hill today to urge a bipartisan consensus on policy toward Central America and to explain her remarks that some of her Congressional critics had Marxist sympathies.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE PRICE OF POWER. Kissinger in the Nixon White House. By Seymour M. Hersh. 698 pages. Summit. $19.95.

title: THOSE NEW BUILDINGS: PROMISE VS. THE REALITY
description: NOT the least interesting aspect about the flurry of new construction reaching completion in Midtown Manhattan is the extent to which many new buildings have turned out to be something other than what was expected by professional observers as well as lay building-watchers. In some cases the actual buildings have failed to live up to the promise that their designs held in drawing and model form; in other cases the real buildings have been better than anticipated. But in almost every case there seems reason to ask why so few people were able to predict reliably what the final result would be.
