title: Spending on Local TV 15.5% Higher in Quarter
description: Advertising spending on local television rose 15.5 percent in the first quarter, to $600.4 million, from $519.9 million a year earlier, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported.

title: Milwaukee Road
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court in Chicago approved a plan by the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad to pay accrued interest of about $28.4 million to certain bondholders. Under the plan, the Milwaukee Road, as it is generally called, will pay interest claims accrued through Dec.31, 1982, and certain litigation settlement amounts, with funds from the railroad escrow accounts. The payments for each $1,000 face amount, to be made by June 30, 1983, range from $220 for first mortgage bonds to $415.85 for series B general mortgage bonds.

title: PROVIDENCE MAYOR DENIES KIDNAPPING CHARGE
description: Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr., whose career has been buffeted by scandal and accusations of mismanagement, pleaded not guilty today to charges of kidnapping, assault and attempted extortion.

title: LABOR'S WELCOMING HAND TO NEW IMMIGRANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK PHOTO CORP LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a $629,358 gain on the sale of property.

title: EARLY CONTRACT TALKS AT CHRYSLER VIEWED AS LIKELY
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Chrysler Corporation are likely to begin early talks on a new labor contract this summer, both union and company officials say.

title: COUNCIL SUSPENDS VILAS FOR A YEAR
description: Guillermo Vilas, the world's fifth-ranked player, was suspended for one year and fined $20,000 by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council today for accepting guaranteed appearance money to play in a tournament in Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: SON'S JOB AN ISSUE IN MARGIOTTA APPEAL
description: On May 27, a lawyer for Joseph M. Margiotta sought to have the former Nassau Republican leader's two-year prison sentence postponed, and part of his argument was that Mr. Margiotta's 26-year-old son ''does not work'' and ''for all practical purposes he is a disabled person.''

title: Dr. Martin L. Stein, a Founder Of L.I.'s North Shore Hospital
description: Dr. Martin L. Stein, a pediatrician who was a founder of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., died of cancer Sunday at North Shore. Dr. Stein, a resident of Great Neck, L.I., was 77 years old.

title: Pima County Issue Is Mostly Sold
description: Only a little over $1 million in bonds remained unsold on the $44.9 million Pima County Industrial Development Authority of Arizona bond issue priced by Salomon Brothers Inc. to yield from 6 percent in 1984 to 10 3/8 percent in 2013.

title: New Children's Opera To Run Two Weekends
description: An opera for children called ''All in the Laundry,'' written by Fred Rogers, star of the daytime children's show ''Mr. Rogers Neighborhood,'' will run for two weekends beginning June 18 at the Opera Shop of the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street.

title: 2 DEAN WITTER BROKERS ACCUSED OF TRADE FRAUD
description: Two account executives, who were responsible for supervising the 24-hour trading desk that Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. opened in January, used a phony account to make at least $80 million of unauthorized trades yielding them more than $600,000 in profits, according to criminal charges filed yesterday with Federal District Judge Charles S. Haight.

title: Bridge: Virtue Brings Its Rewards Over Powerful Opposition
description: Some old-fashioned virtues are often called for at the bridge table. On the diagramed deal, played in a sectional tournament in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., East displayed both patience and charity and was duly rewarded.

title: A Nicaraguan Consul Applies for Asylum
description: Nicaragua's general consul in New Orleans, one of 21 Nicaraguan officials ordered expelled from the United States, applied for political asylum today.

title: SLOW PLAY A PROBLEM IN GOLF
description: Slow play, with rounds of five hours or more, is plaguing the men's golf tour again. ''We cannot live with the current situation,'' Commissioner Deane R. Beman said today as a field of 155 prepared for Thursday's start of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic at the Westchester Country Club.

title: MISSOURI RESEARCH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Joplin Home Purchased
description: The home of the ragtime composer and musician Scott Joplin here has been bought by the state and will be restored and operated as a museum, officials said. Mr. Joplin also lived in Sedalia, Mo. He frequently performed there at the Maple Leaf Club, which provided the title for his famous ''Maple Leaf Rag.''

title: New Wells Account
description: Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi, doing the advertising for the Conservative Party for today's election, is expected to triumph, but it does not win them all. It is losing the Max Factor account in Britain to Wells, Rich, Greene, which is the agency of record in the United States.

title: Coastal May Raise Its Texas Gas Bid
description: The Coastal Corporation, caught in a bidding war with the CSX Corporation to buy the Texas Gas Resources Corporation, may shortly increase a $45-a-share takeover bid it made for the company last Monday, Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

title: EDUCATION EMERGES AS MAJOR ISSUE IN 1984 PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGNING
description: Education is emerging as a major issue in the 1984 Presidential campaign, and so far the debate is being shaped by President Reagan and Walter F. Mondale, the Democrat who is expected to win the endorsement of the nation's largest teacher organization.

title: KARCHER, CARL, CO reports earnings for qtr to MaY 20.
TESTING FOR SUGAR IN DIABETIC CHILDREN
description: Diabetes in children can be better controlled by measuring glucose in the blood than in the urine, and by taking more than one insulin injection a day, doctors have reported.

title: OPEC SAYS ITS PRICE ACCORD IS HOLDING
description: Ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries said here today that the group's members had largely observed a pricing and production agreement drawn up in March.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Sense of History

title: NORTH-SOUTH ISSUE FLARES UP
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, speaking for the third world, warned the industrial nations today that economic recovery risked being snuffed out unless steps were taken immediately to help developing nations pay their debts and get their own economies growing again.

title: BIG 5 U.S. SECURITIES DEALERS
description: Wall Street is full of middlemen whose business is to bring buyers and sellers together and extract a profit along the way. In the Treasury market, the world's largest securities market, with more than five times the dollar volume of the New York Stock Exchange, middlemen have carved a special niche. Because there is no central trading floor for Treasury issues, a handful of little-known broker firms have evolved to execute trades between securities firms.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago results have been restated.

title: HERS
Atwater Named Dean Of Journalism School
description: James D. Atwater, a 54-year-old senior editor for Time magazine, has been appointed dean of the University of Missouri School of Journalism, the university announced yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS PICK '84 SENATE TARGETS
description: Russell B. Long, the Louisiana Democrat who is former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is not up for re-election next year. Even so, Mr. Long has a lot riding on the 1984 voting.

title: Nanny at the Gates
description: An officious Federal Government continues to tell Americans whom they may hear in person by selectively denying visas to foreigners with controversial beliefs. Cuban and Soviet scholars, Chilean dissidents, Japanese pacifists, Irish nationalists (and their hard-line Protestant enemies) have all been barred at the border because their presence would be ''contrary to the United States interest.''

title: Litton Paper Sale
description: Litton Industries said it had agreed in principle to sell the assets and business of its special paper, printing and forms group to Technographics Inc. of Fitchburg, Mass. The company said Technographics is a new privately held company formed to make the acquisition. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: LIFESAVING RUNS BLOCKED BY CITY DRIVERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS CHOOSE CENTER
description: The Islanders, fresh from their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup championship, wrapped their arms around another prize today.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1.8 million from the sale of real estate.

title: REYNOLDS'S ABSENCE AFFECTING ABC NEWS RATINGS
description: The prolonged absence of Frank Reynolds, the principal anchor of ABC's ''World News Tonight,'' has lowered the program's ratings and could affect planning decisions, according to top officials at the network.

title: OLD NEWFOUNDLAND IS BRACING FOR A ROYAL BIRTHDAY
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 6 -The castle-sized iceberg has for several weeks been bobbing in the narrow throat that leads from the Atlantic into St. John's harbor. Though not unheard of, such a presence in June is rare and some poetically inclined Newfoundlanders are describing the floating mass as a visual fanfare for the celebration June 24 of the 400th anniversary of the day when Sir Humphrey Gilbert, an Elizabethan adventurer, formally proclaimed this island a British possession, the first North American part of what was to become the British Empire.

title: Senate Panel Approves Radio Marti Proposal
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 13 to 4 today to authorize a proposal for United Statessponsored radio broadcasts to Cuba, to be known as Radio Marti.

title: Northwest, Sedco End Pogo Tender
description: Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc., which have been waging a battle for control of the Pogo Producing Company, announced that their tender offer to buy 6.25 million shares of Pogo had ended, and yielded only 2.2 million shares.

title: PARLIAMENT IN ISRAEL DEFEATS PLAN TO PULL BACK IN LEBANON
description: The Israeli Parliament today rejected a Labor Party proposal for an early withdrawal of forces from Lebanon.

title: Alaska Housing
description: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation yesterday announced a proposed public offering of $75 million state assisted mortgage bonds due June 1, 1993.

title: Market Place; Outlook Buoys Coachman Inc.
description: TEN years ago, when the stock market was in a sharp slump, shares of Coachman Industries sold for as low as $1. In the ensuing years, the stock moved in a seesaw fashion and, in early 1982, was trading at 6 3/8.

title: LOCHIEL EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
Garvey Still Active
description: Ed Garvey may be preparing to step down as executive director of the National Football League Players' Association, but his mind is still on union matters. With the players in the United States Football League due to vote next week on whether to affiliate with a union, Garvey charged that the league had hired a Michigan consulting firm to ''union bust.'' Gary Kaplan, a U.S.F.L. lawyer, confirmed that the league had engaged consultants ''to educate the players'' about unionization and management's view that a union could jeopardize the league's survival, but he took exception to Garvey's characterization of the move.

title: COMPANY WILL CLEAN UP NO. 1 TOXIC WASTE DUMP
description: The FMC Corporation plans to spend $6 million to clean up a site here that the Federal Environmental Protection Agency says is the nation's most dangerous hazardous waste dump.

title: THE THEATER: 'GREEK'
description: WHILE David Hare, Caryl Churchill and other playwrights are skillfully depicting the decline of the Empire, Stephen Berkoff, in his play, ''Greek,'' is flailing his native Britain as ''this septic isle.'' Take that word ''septic'' literally. The script is a cesspool of scatological imagery. One could regard ''Greek'' as a language expander, but then, of course, one could have the same attitude toward subway graffiti.

title: Houston Housing Issue Sold Out on Second Day
description: A $59.4 million Houston Housing Finance Corporation bond issue with yields ranging from 5.75 percent in 1984 to 10 percent in 2014 was sold out on the second day of the offering by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Debt Issues
description: * Citadel Holdings Corp. filed for an offering of $25 million principal amount of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003.

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
description: b-Net income after a loss of $341,694 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Life Savers Will Close Factory in Port Chester
description: Life Savers Inc., once this village's largest private employer, will close its six-story candy manufacturing plant here next spring and sell it for conversion into an office building.

title: DOLLAR GAINS STRONGLY, WORRYING EUROPEANS
description: America's buoyant dollar, lifted by expectations of rising United States interest rates, continued to climb against other major currencies in European trading today.

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a gain of $208,000, or 18 cents a share, from an adjustment of a previous charge for divestiture of two product lines. c-After a charge of $592,000 from divestuture of two product lines.

title: U.S. Bond Sales
description: The Treasury announced that sales of Savings Bonds rose to $418 million in May from $350 million in April and $242 million in May 1982, for the seventh straight increase in as many months. Since the market-based rate for series EE bonds was introduced last November, redemptions have also decreased.

title: CAREFREE (OR ALMOST) ON CAPE COD: A JOURNAL OF THE FIRST WEEK BACK
description: E.J. Kahn Jr., a writer for The New Yorker and a strictly urban type from way back, first went to Truro, a small town now mostly snuggled inside the Cape Cod National Seashore, as a summer renter in 1949. Now, for reasons unfathomable to nearly all save him, he -along with his wife, Eleanor, and their big black Belgian Shepherd, Rainbow - spend more and more of each year in a home they own there. They didn't vacate it in 1982, for instance, until shortly before Christmas, and then only when their pump froze. In May, they returned to Truro from Manhattan, where they theoretically reside; and the following is an excerpt from Mr. Kahn's first-week journal. By E.J. KAHN JR. Sunday

title: 'THE LAND OF BECOMING'
description: On a visit to Latin America in 1965, Robert Kennedy told a group of Peruvian students that the responsibility of our time was ''to lead a revolution - a revolution which will be peaceful if we are wise enough, human if we care enough, but a revolution which will come whether we will it or not.'' To lead it toward freedom and justice was a formidable task, he said, but not impossible for us in our hemisphere:

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Including tax credits of $30,000 for the quarter and $3,759,000 for the year. c-After a charge of $363,000 from the settlement of antitrust litigation. d-Net loss after an extraordinary charge of $9,550,000 from settlement of antitrust litigation.

title: PRESIDENT'S COMMENTS ON ARMS TALKS IN GENEVA
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's statement here on strategic arms negotiations, as provided by the White House:

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: Suspect Refuses to Talk About Coast Slaying of 4
description: A former convict identified by the sheriff as a ''fair suspect'' in the slayings of four people on a Southern California horse ranch refused today to discuss the killings with detectives.

title: Blore and Richman Win 7 Clio Awards
description: Chuck Blore and Don Richman of Hollywood dominated the 1983 Clio awards for radio commercials, winning seven of them, including one for their national campaign for A.T.& T. Long Distance. Their other commercials were for Michigan Travel, Roy Rogers Restaurants and K Mart Photo Processing.

title: President's remarks are on page A12.
description: President Reagan announced today that he was relaxing proposals that the Soviet Union scrap a substantial part of its long-range missile force, but he said he was maintaining his goal of obtaining large reductions in missile warheads in the strategic nuclear arms talks.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IT is astonishing how little has been documented about the history of housing in New York, for the story of housing is truly the story of the city. The city's physical growth, its social patterns, its ambitions, its cruelties and its kindnesses can all, in a sense, be traced through the kinds of buildings New Yorkers have lived in.

title: MAC O'GRADY'S GOLF STRUGGLE
description: HARRISON, N.Y. I n any sport, the gifted don't really understand the suffering of those who must struggle. Rod Carew has never been in a serious slump. Terry Bradshaw has never had to worry about being cut. Julius Erving has never been benched. Wayne Gretzky has never been a spot player. Chris Evert Lloyd has never been a tournament alternate.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Eubie!

title: WOMEN'S NEW ISSUE
description: Something interesting is happening to the gender gap: Today, for the first time, national security is becoming a woman's issue and adding significantly to the difference between men's and women's voting preferences.

title: HIGH COURT IN REBUFF TO I.R.S.
description: The Supreme Court handed a setback to the Internal Revenue Service today, ruling unanimously that the agency, like all creditors, can be required to return property seized from a company that later seeks reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy law.

title: Diasonics Lists Changes In Fischer Acquisition
description: Diasonics Inc., a growing maker of high-technology medical equipment, said yesterday that Albert S. Waxman, its co-founder, would become chairman and plans to give up the presidency.

title: Keep a Tie to Managua
description: Nicaragua's expulsion of three American diplomats raises two separate questions. The cloudier concerns the plausibility of Managua's charge that the Americans were plotting one of their officials' death, which is unlikely but not, alas, unthinkable.

title: Kings Are Sold
description: The Kansas City Kings, who have been struggling both on the court and at the gate, have been sold to a group from Sacramento, Calif., which promises to keep the National Basketball Association franchise in Kansas City, the team announced today. The purchase price was announced at $10.5 million. The new owners were introduced at a news conference as Joseph Benvenuti, Frank and Gregg Lukenbill, Robert A. Cook, Frank McCormack and Stephen H. Cippa, all of Sacramento.

title: Lever House Sues Over Its Lease
description: The owner of Lever House, the skyscraper at 390 Park Avenue that was recently designated a New York City landmark, said yesterday that it had gone to court to block ''an attempt to break the company's lease.''

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: The share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effected in April 1983.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ASHARP cutting tool is actually much safer to use than a dull one. The dull one requires the user to bear down harder, increasing the chances of slipping.

title: THE NEW SUMMER SLIPCOVERS: COOL LOOK, EASY FIT
description: THE interior designer Keith Irvine remembers the magical day that marked the advent of summer when he was a child in Scotland. ''The rugs were rolled up,'' Mr. Irvine said, ''and all the heavy brocade upholstered furniture was covered with beige linen slipcovers to protect it from the sun. The whole house looked and felt different. The brocade was scratchy to sit on; the summer slipcovers felt cool, soft and comfortable.''

title: Article 221576 -- No Title
description: The Senate tonight approved by a vote of 55 to 43 an increase of $8.4 billion in the United States' contribution to the International Monetary Fund.

title: Dodgers Win, 11-5
description: Fernando Valenzuela hit one of four Dodger home runs and drove in two other runs tonight in leading Los Angeles to an 11-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves. The Braves hit three homers.

title: 2 ISRAELIS KILLED IN LEBANON BLAST
description: Two Israeli soldiers were killed and five Lebanese civilians wounded today when a remote-controlled car bomb was detonated next to an Israeli Army patrol entering East Beirut.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS ARTS RISE
description: Federal spending on the arts and humanities would increase by 15 percent next year under a bill approved unanimously Tuesday by a House appropriations subcommittee that rejected President Reagan's request to slash the arts budget.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 9, 1983
description: International Flexibility in arms control talks was urged by President Reagan as the American-Soviet negotiations on strategic weapons resumed in Geneva. Mr. Reagan made the appeal in announcing he was relaxing proposals that Moscow scrap a substantial part of its missile force but at the same time was maintaining his goal of large reductions in the total number of missile warheads. (Page A1, Column 6.) Two Israeli soldiers were killed and five Lebanese civilians were wounded when a remote-controlled car bomb was detonated near an Israeli Army patrol entering East Beirut. (A7:1.)

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Q&A
description: Q. The stoop outside the front door of my house is covered with tiles that are embedded in cement. There is a sand base under them. Some of these tiles are falling out, so I tried cementing them back with a regular cement mix. However, this doesn't last; they keep falling out after a few months. Is there a stronger bonding mix I can use?

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: XCOR INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After income on the disposition of discontinued operations of $1,208,000. c-Net income after a loss of $805,000 on the sale of an investment, income of $10,534,000 from discontinued operations, a loss of $3,714,000 on the disposition of discontinued operations, a gain of $7,177,000 on the public offering of a subsidiary and a tax credit of $1,934,000.

title: REAGAN'S AIDES NARROW CHOICES FOR VOLCKER JOB
description: President Reagan's top advisers have told him that the choice for the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board should be between Paul A. Volcker, who currently holds the post, and the economist Alan Greenspan, Administration officials said today.

title: Rates Decline For New Homes
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported yesterday that conventional home mortgage interest rates offered on new commitments for the purchase of newly built homes continued to decline from early April to early May.

title: Technology; Automating Gas Stations
description: THE American gas station, after a decade of swift, disjointing changes that have made ''full service'' an increasingly scarce attribute, is about to undergo its own form of electronics revolution. Beginning next year, most analysts predict, a growing number of motorists will not only be pumping their own gasoline, but also paying for it on computer terminals.

title: G.I. Killed and 3 Injured In Army Shell Explosion
description: A shell exploded on a firing range here today as five soldiers were setting up a target for light antitank weapons, killing one soldier and injuring three others, the authorities said.

title: CALENDAR: ROSES AND MORE ROSES
description: Cranford Rose Garden, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, 212-622-4433, ext. 14.

title: PATCHING DAMAGED FURNITURE
description: AWIDE choice of patching materials is available to repair furniture surfaces. But sometimes these conventional fillers do not work - particularly if the damage is too minor or simply too horrendous.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. The Mets end their longest trip of the season with Ed Lynch pitching against Dick Ruthven.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Last Day of School

title: CONNECTICUT FAILS TO END BUDGET IMPASSE
description: Connecticut's General Assembly adjourned tonight after failing to adopt a state budget and new and higher taxes to pay for it. The State Constitution required an adjournment by midnight.

title: NO SOVIET CHANGE IS SEEN BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was intensifying its efforts ''to probe and test'' for any changes in Soviet attitudes that would warrant an early high-level Soviet-American meeting. So far, he said, ''I don't see any substantive result.''

title: SHARP DECLINE FOUND IN LEAD LEVELS IN BLOOD
description: The amount of lead in people's blood fell dramatically in the late 1970's, probably because of the declining use of leaded gasoline, a Federal study concluded today.

title: PRESSURE TO CUT OFF BENEFITS REPORTED BY DISABILITY JUDGES
description: Independent hearing officers employed by the Social Security Administration said today that the agency had put improper pressure on them to deny benefits to people with mental and physical handicaps.

title: GAF Finance Chief Is Going to Triangle
description: James T. Sherwin, executive vice president and chief financial officer at the embattled GAF Corporation, has resigned to join Triangle Industries Inc. in similar positions.

title: UNITED EDUCATION & SOFTWARE reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CHAMBER: PRESSLER'S PIANO
description: WATCHING Menahem Pressler play the piano in the Merkin Concert Hall Tuesday night was as much an education as his playing was a pleasure. In Mozart's Piano Concerto in E-flat (K. 271), accompanied by the New York Pro Arte Chamber Orchestra, every musical gesture could be read in his physical expressions - the playful cross-rhythms seen in the contrapuntal twists of his hands, the expectation of a melodic line in the lifting of his eyebrows, the tensions of the harmony in the controlled leaning of his body.

title: METS FALL TO CUBS IN 9TH, 2-1
description: For eight and a half innings today, the Mets played their best game in memory. But, needing only two outs to win it, 1-0, they suddenly lost it when the Chicago Cubs struck for two runs and their seventh consecutive victory.

title: JERSEY ABOLISHES COMMUTER TAX ON NEW YORKERS
description: New Jersey's highest court today struck down the state's special tax on New York residents who commute to jobs in New Jersey. The court said the tax interfered with the New Yorkers' ''constitutionally protected right to pursue an occupation outside their home state.''

title: MATHEMATICAL APPLICATIONS GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $163,000 for the quarter and $211,000 for the year.

title: Slew o' Gold In Fast Drill
description: Slew o' Gold clinched the role of the favorite for the Belmont Stakes Saturday with a sizzling workout of 58 1/5 seconds for five furlongs yesterday morning at Belmont Park.

title: COURT TURNS ASIDE KEY SEARCH ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court, with evident embarrassment and ''apologies to all,'' announced today that it would not, after all, use an Illinois narcotics case as the vehicle for deciding whether to modify the rule excluding illegally seized evidence in a criminal trial.

title: CLERICS URGE U.S. CURB ON GENE ENGINEERING
description: An unusually broad spectrum of religious leaders and several prominent scientists declared opposition yesterday to research that could alter the genes affecting inherited human traits.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange. The report of changes follows: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: THE KREMLIN IS SAID TO SEIZE MAIL FROM THE U.S. FOR JEWS
description: A Representative from New York says thousands of letters inviting Soviet Jews to the United States have been confiscated, returned or tampered with in a direct Soviet effort to prevent the Jews from leaving.

title: U.S. AGENCY FINDS PROGRESS IS MADE ON INDIAN PT. PLAN
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency said today that ''substantial progress'' had been made in resolving deficiencies in the evacuation plan for the Indian Point nuclear power plants in Westchester County.

title: City Opera Tour Unit Names Music Director
description: George Manahan has been appointed music director of the New York City Opera National Company, replacing Brian Salesky, whose contract has expired.

title: SILKNIT LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
description: The year-ago loss restated. The company said that it acquired the remaining 50 percent of the Lovable Brassiere Co. of Canada on Jan. 1. The latest period results include a loss of $78,918 from Lovable compared with a $56,310 loss a year ago which represented 50 percent of Lovable's loss.

title: HOME BEAT
description: shower curtains with the words of songs from 1950's rock-and-roll, Broadway musicals or country tunes.

title: Norton Simon Suit Filed by Holder
description: A class-action shareholder suit was filed against Norton Simon Inc. and David J. Mahoney, the company's chairman, attempting to block Mr. Mahoney's plan to buy the big consumer products company and convert it into a private concern.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CFS Continental, Chicago, has named Richard M. Seigel president of its Continental Foodservice Company subsidiary.

title: Static Over the Cubs
description: It has been several weeks since Lee Elia, the Chicago Cubs' manager, launched into a tirade against Cubs fans, but some Chicago radio listeners have been getting frequent reminders of the outburst. Jonathon Brandmeier, a disk jockey at WLUP-FM, has been playing a tape of the tirade over a recording of the Cubs' song, ''Hey, Hey, Holy Mackerel, No Doubt About It,'' and the Cubs, saying the routine is demeaning, have complained.

title: Two Directors Leave Oak Industries' Board
description: Oak Industries, an operator of pay television systems, said yesterday that two directors had resigned. The company has posted losses recently.

title: AFRICANS RESOLVE DEADLOCK IN O.A.U.
description: Leaders of countries in the Organization of African Unity opened a meeting here today after a guerrilla movement that had caused a boycott of the session agreed to stay away.

title: NEW YORK STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: Gun Fires Chickens at Planes
description: Officials at Langley Air Force Base said today that a cannon that hurls dead chickens at airplanes at 700 miles an hour is helping to reduce accidents caused by jets hitting birds. Maj. Dennis Funnemark said the device, called a chicken gun, was a converted 20-foot cannon that shoots 4-pound chickens into engines, windshields and landing gear to determine how much damage such collisions can cause.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report Monday with pictures of the Auburn Correctional Facility misidentified a deputy superintendent there. He was Abraham Taylor, deputy superintend- ent for administration.

title: Blacks and Women Win More Jobs in Little Rock
description: The Justice Department said today that Little Rock, Ark., had agreed to increase its hiring of blacks and women for the police force and as firefighters.

title: TENNIS BALLS GO FLYING IN NEW SCHOOL PROGRAM
description: There are new yellow court lines painted on the old asphalt of the schoolyard behind Junior High School 104 on East 21st Street. Tennis nets are stretched between bright green poles.

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes pre-tax loss of $224,000 and net loss of $121,000. The share earnings do not reflect the 3-for-2 stock split to be distributed June 15.

title: Report by M.A.C. Cites Fiscal Progress by City
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was formed to help New York City borrow money during the fiscal crisis, said yesterday that ''the worst is over'' in municipal budgeting.

title: G.E. To Close 10 Facilities
description: The General Electric Company today announced a three-year plant consolidation plan in which it will close 10 facilities in five states and reduce its work force by 1,400.

title: MEDGAR EVERS '83 CLASS TOLD TO EXTEND CIVIL-RIGHTS GAINS
description: The wife of Medgar Evers, the slain civil-rights leader, yesterday told graduates of the college in Brooklyn named in his honor that they must work to preserve and extend the gains made by those who went before them.

title: Don't Rush the Federal Cable Rules
description: The companies that wire homes and offices for cable television say Congress should free them from local regulation that limits their growth. But many cities, including New York, argue that the proposed relief would usurp local powers to bring a financial windfall to powerful cable interests.

title: ROLE OF MAN CITED IN ACID RAIN STUDY
description: A Reagan Administration team said today that it had concluded that man-made air pollution was probably the major cause of the acid rain it said was destroying fresh-water life in the Northeast.

title: GOODHEART-WILLCOX CO INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
FILM ON PIAF AND CERDAN STIRS FRANCE
description: Imagine this: a French movie whose female lead character represents to France what Judy Garland means to America and far more, and a male lead character who is the equivalent of Joe DiMaggio in a place that never had a Ted Williams. Naturally, they fall in love.

title: PROGRAMMING & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
PLANTING A CITY WINDOW BOX
description: DESPITE the rain, it is not too late to plant a city window box. These small gardens yield many of the rewards with none of the backbreaking work typical of more expansive plantings. And the visual pleasures are shared by those within as well as those passing by.

title: BAXTER ASKS END TO BANK BRANCHING BAN
description: One of the Reagan Administration's top antitrust officials today called on Congress to repeal laws that prohibit interstate branching by banks and bank holding companies.

title: Iranians Reject Offer by Iraq For a Cease-Fire in Gulf War
description: The Teheran radio said today that Iran had rejected an offer by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq for a limited cease-fire during the Moslem holy month of Ramadan.

title: Willard C. Drumm, 86, Dead; Assemblyman From Upstate
description: Willard C. Drumm, a former Republican Assemblyman from Columbia County, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack.

title: DOCTOR REGRETFUL ON BOGUS RESEARCH
description: A researcher accused of falsifying the results of medical experiments says he regrets ''inaccuracies and falsehoods'' and agrees that some of his studies should be retracted.

title: DALMYS (CANADA) LTD reports earnings for year to Feb 26.
A FEE PROPOSAL FIT TO STARVE PUBLIC-INTEREST LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Opposition Leader Ends a Hunger Strike
description: Kim Young Sam, a former opposition leader, said today that he had ended a hunger strike he began 23 days ago, but that he would press his struggle for democratic political changes.

title: ROCKEFELLER GRADUATES HAILED FOR THEIR SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH
description: Following tradition, there was no featured speaker at the Rockefeller University's 25th commencement yesterday. Instead, the faculty advisers of 20 graduating students gave short speeches lauding them before they received Ph.D. degrees for their scientific research.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for qtr to May 21.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: AN EXHIBIT OF CRAFTS ON DISPLAY AT Y.M.C.A.
description: ''Celebrating 50 Years of Creativity,'' an exhibition of works made between 1932 and 1958 by students of the Craft Students League, will begin tomorrow at the Y.W.C.A., 610 Lexington Avenue (53d Street).

title: RAINS ALTER TROUT PROSPECTS
description: I f you believe that you are an accomplished stream trout fisherman, this weekend could provide an excellent test of your expertise. In Connecticut and central and southern New York State, the last part of May and the first half of June usually include some of the best weeks of the season for both the fly fisherman and those who use lures, but this year's wet, cold spring has broken that pattern. Nonetheless, some persistent and talented anglers are doing well.

title: GENEVA TALKS: A BRIEF SMILE, THEN SILENCE
description: The American delegate emerged from the United States Mission here today to extend a warm greeting as the acting Soviet delegate arrived for the resumption of the strategic arms reduction talks after a 10-week recess.

title: TEAK GARDEN BENCHES IN VARIED STYLES
description: WEATHERED teak garden benches have long been a feature of English gardens and parks. More inviting than a cold stone bench, a wood seat beckons the garden stroller.

title: Mr. Cuomo's Pointless Transit Repair
description: It is easy to understand why a candidate for governor of New York would promise to abolish or revamp the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Its new cars are still far down the track, its old cars are a disgraceful mess, its schedules are unreliable, its stations are peeling, and its rehabilitation program, though carefully conceived and ingeniously financed, has barely begun. But it's hard to see why the now-successful candidate should believe that the remedy is for him to assume the power to outvote all other governmental interests on the agency's board of directors and make its chairman answerable only to the governor.

title: 6 Nuclear Plant Contractors Indicted
description: Six major electrical contractors were indicted today by a grand jury on Federal charges of conspiring to rig bids on four nuclear power plants being built by the Washington Public Power Supply System and one in Indiana.

title: CON ED COAL CONVERSION REMAINS 'UNACCEPTABLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: For both 1983 periods the average shares outstanding and share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split effective Dec. 3, 1982 2 PHOENIX C 1983 1982 Revenue 1,485,594 1,861,123 Netinc 217,899 377,352 Shareearns .08 14 L QtrtoMarch31 1983 198 2 Sales 11,249,532 9,594,438 Net inc 101,238 44,833 Share earns .02 .01

title: Train Fell on Volga Boat, Local Resident Says
description: A resident of the Volga River city of Ulyanovsk, at the scene of Sunday's boat disaster, said today that a freight train had toppled onto the boat after the vessel crashed into a railroad bridge.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SCULPTURE

title: A FEE PROPOSAL FIT TO STARVE PUBLIC-INTEREST LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Cosmos Win In Overtime
description: Roberto Cabanas scored from 20 yards out 5 minutes 56 seconds into overtime tonight to give the Cosmos a 1-0 victory over the San Diego Sockers in a North American Soccer League game.

title: TASK FORCE PROPOSES MERGING NEW YORK'S MAJOR TRIAL COURTS
description: A State Senate task force today proposed a new plan to merge the state's major trial courts, signaling for the first time that some form of court merger might be considered by New York voters in 1985.

title: 45 HONORED BY FIRE DEPT. WITH MEDALS FOR BRAVERY
description: Heat forced the firefighter to the floor as he tried to save the badly burned Brooklyn woman. That was when he saw her young daughter. As flames illuminated the room, he spied her son. Reaching the boy, he spotted another child in the distance.

title: Estelle Hamburger, 85; A Fashion Consultant
description: Estelle H. Hamburger, a fashion consultant and retailing executive, died of cancer Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EDWARD J. MITCHELL
description: Edward J. Mitchell, a lawyer and labor and management consultant, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: HENRY AND SY
description: I used to marvel at the way Seymour Hersh, the ace investigative reporter, used his telephone to break through the stonewalling of potential sources.

title: PRISON STATISTICS
description: To the Editor:

title: MISSPELLER IS A SPELLING BEE HERO
description: Eighty-five of 137 contestants were eliminated today at the opening of the National Spelling Bee, including a tearful child who told the judges that they had misunderstood him and that he had actually misspelled ''echolalia.''

title: FORMER E.P.A. AIDE PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Rita M. Lavelle, ousted as head of the Government's toxic waste cleanup program, pleaded not guilty today to charges of contempt of Congress, which contended she had ignored a subpoena to testify about the program.

title: EARHART COLLECTION GIVEN TO RADCLIFFE
description: ''Hope to take off tomorrow A.M. to San Juan, Puerto Rico. Here is three hundred bucks for Margot to put in household fund. - A.''

title: Regan Assails Move to Cap Tax Cut
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan yesterday called Democratic attempts in Congress to cap the third year of the personal tax cut ''good politics but poor economics.''

title: Soviet Probe Sent to Venus
description: The Soviet Union launched an unmanned space probe Tuesday to Venus, where it will go into orbit in October, the official press agency, Tass, reported.

title: Soviet Says Dissident Was Injured in Camp
description: The wife of Yuri F. Orlov, an imprisoned dissident, said today that she had been advised that her husband suffered unexplained ''injuries to the skull and brain.''

title: DEATH BY HANDGUN
description: To the Editor:

title: Ariz. State Wins
description: Arizona State and Michigan stayed alive in the College World Series with victories tonight.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
MOST INTEREST RATES MOVE UP
description: Disappointment over the Federal Reserve's failure to add reserves to the banking system prompted another round of markups in interest rates and cuts in prices yesterday.

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 7.
JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a loss of $2,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: PHILHARMONIC: NEW MUSIC IN A FESTIVAL REHEARSAL
description: THE New York Philharmonic's summer festival, devoted to the elusive New Romanticism, continued Tuesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall with an open rehearsal of two new works by young composers, as well as an excerpt from an incomplete composition by George Crumb.

title: DISTILLER IN OFFER FOR LENOX
description: The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation yesterday offered $87 a share in cash, or an indicated $392 million, to acquire Lenox Inc., a maker of china best known as the official supplier to the White House. Lenox's early reaction to the proposal was unfavorable.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Unionizing NOW Fund

title: KIM'S HUNGER STRIKE
description: The political unrest that has erupted in South Korea in recent weeks warrants a prudent decision by the United States Government. Kim Young Sam, former president of the now-banned New Democratic Party, has been on a hunger strike since May 17 to dramatize the popular desire for democracy in the country. He now is bordering on unconsciousness.

title: Guatemala Dismisses General Who Urged General Elections
description: The army's senior general was discharged today for having urged the military government to hold elections.

title: THE CITY;
description: Two former vice presidents of the Chase Manhattan Bank and three businessmen were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on charges of stealing $9.5 million from the bank through fraudulent loans in 1978 and 1979.

title: SAT ON U.S. COURT IN NEWARK
description: Judge Lawrence A. Whipple of Federal District Court in Newark died yesterday at Medicenter, a nursing home in Red Bank, N.J., of complications following open-heart surgery last September. He was 72 years old and lived in Sea Girt, N.J.

title: FOR HALSTON, CHALLENGE OF THE MASS MARKET
description: ROY HALSTON FROWICK is a man of no little experience and distinction in the world of fashion. He has, after all, designed and fitted hats for private customers, a job many would consider the most grueling in the fashion line, ranking it just before custom dresses, which he has also done. He has succeeded in pleasing such flamboyant clients as Liza Minnelli, Elizabeth Taylor and Martha Graham, along with corporate wives and corporate leaders such as Katharine Graham and Mary Wells Lawrence, all of whom require different modes of dress. So it is of some interest that, at the special showing of his first relatively inexpensive collection of clothes for the J.C. Penney Company, he said it was ''the most challenging and gratifying fashion job I have ever done.''

title: Hudson Bay Plans Restructuring
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said its public shareholders had approved a reorganization plan that will combine Hudson Bay and its 50 percent owned affiliate, the Inspiration Resources Corporation.

title: Dr. Henry Reiff Is Dead at 84; Ex-Professor at St. Lawrence
description: Dr. Henry Reiff, retired head of the department of history and government at St. Lawrence University in Canton, N.Y., died of cancer Friday at his home in Granville, Ohio. He was 84 years old.

title: STILL UNFULFILLED, KINGMAN AWAITS FATE
description: CHICAGO F rank Howard, the new manager of the Mets, can understand better than anyone in the organization the demands that have followed Dave Kingman everywhere he has gone. Howard hit 382 home runs in his 16-year major-league career, but each time he stepped into the batter's box, his current total was never enough. Kingman has hit 339, the seventh-highest total among active players, and still his name triggers thoughts of unfulfilled promise.

title: Dow Off 9.41 in Broad Decline
description: The stock market fell broadly yesterday for the second consecutive session as concern over the outlook for interest rates again weakened the list.

title: Injunction Issued In Red Sox Case
description: A judge called a temporary halt today to the struggle among owners of the Boston Red Sox, as he issued an injunction against a takeover bid by Buddy LeRoux and set trial for next month.

title: RESERVE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Adjusted to reflect an accounting change.

title: 200 NEW YORK LAWYERS ARE WORKING FREE TO AID HAITIAN REFUGEES
description: More than 200 lawyers in New York City, ranging from members of Wall Street firms to an assortment of legal activists, have joined a nationwide effort to work free for Haitian refugees who want political asylum in the United States.

title: DISPUTE ON DURANG PLAY IS EASED IN MISSOURI
description: An attempt in the Missouri State Senate to cut off funds to a St. Louis theater has ended in a compromise. A move had been made to reduce funds for the Missouri Arts Council and prevent any state financing of the Theater Project Company of St. Louis. The action was taken because the theater troupe had staged Christopher Durang's play ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You.''

title: WORLD BANKING GUIDELINES
description: New guidelines aimed at tightening supervision of international banking were released today by the West German Bundesbank.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The judges said I had a lot of integrity. I didn't want to feel like a slime.'' - Andrew Flosdorf, 13 years old, of Fonda, N.Y., who went to the National Spelling Bee judges at an afternoon break and told them that although they thought he spelled the word ''echolalia'' correctly he had mistakenly substituted an ''e'' for the first ''a.'' (A14:5.)

title: NICARAGUAN EMBASSY IS A STUDY IN TURMOIL
description: By the standards of diplomacy, Nicaragua's new Ambassador to the United States had barely unpacked his bags when he was summoned to the State Department on Tuesday and told that the Reagan Administration was ordering the expulsion of 21 Nicaraguan consular officials and the closing of all six Nicaraguan consulates in this country.

title: Boeing Jet Orders
description: USAir announced it had ordered three 737-200 aircraft from the Boeing Company for delivery in December as part of its fleet modernization program. Boeing also announced that it had sold one 737-200 jet to Thai Airways.

title: CHURCHES PRESS DISPUTE WITH CBS
description: The National Council of Churches asked CBS-TV yesterday to agree to hold an arbitration procedure to determine whether a January segment of ''60 Minutes'' violated the network's own standards of accuracy and fairness. CBS rejected the request.

title: Addenda
description: * Doyle Dane Bernbach International acquired Venema De Grott & Partners of the Netherlands for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: SEASIDE GARDENING IS CONFERENCE TOPIC
description: On June 26 at Southampton College, in the Shinnecock Hills of eastern Long Island, gardeners will meet for a six-day symposium entitled ''Gardening by the Sea.'' This is the second year that plant enthusiasts and landscape architects will gather for a lecture program on seaside gardening.

title: Export Record Set in Canada
description: Canada's exports in April rose by $730 million, to a record monthly level of $7.7 billion, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today.

title: MINI-COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Oct 31.
MARJORIE MAYROCK, 60, FORTUNOFF CHAIN'S HEAD
description: Marjorie Fortunoff Mayrock, president of M. Fortunoff of Westbury, L.I., the jewelry and home furnishings chain, died after a brief illness yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 60 years old and lived in Old Westbury.

title: THREE BLACK NATIONALIST GUERRILLAS HANGED AT DAWN IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African authorities carried out their scheduled executions at dawn today of three members of the outlawed African National Congress who had been convicted of high treason for their roles in a series of sabotage incidents and armed assaults.

title: LIGHTS THAT FOCUS BEAMS WITH PRISMS
description: THE Boston architectural designer Jerome Simon designed himself into a problem several years ago, when, in a Brookline house, he created a kitchen with a dramatic cathedral ceiling that left him no convenient way to light the work island below. ''I just could not get a wired source of light over the work counter,'' said the designer, ''without mounting unsightly wire on the wood ceiling I was trying to feature.''

title: Stitch in Time
description: Trades can be upsetting to athletes in any sport, but at least Gorman Thomas didn't have to worry about how he would look when he made his debut with the Cleveland Indians Tuesday night at Yankee Stadium.

title: Helping the Young
description: S unlight streamed into Tavern on the Green yesterday, adding to the warmth of the occasion - 250 foster grandparents celebrating the 10th birthday of the program, in which low-income elderly persons work with disabled children.

title: TALK OF MILITARY COUP PERSISTS IN LIMA
description: In this capital city of five million people, where politics is an obsession, there is much speculation these days that the military might stage a coup and end the three-year-old elected Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry.

title: Blood of Ancient Hunt Found by Archeologist
description: Preserved blood from animals killed thousands of years ago and from a human who may have cut himself by accident has been discovered on stone tools and weapons, a Canadian archeologist says.

title: JOBS FOR ITALIAN WOMEN: ROCKING THE POLITICAL BOAT
description: For Ludina Barzini, the elections that will decide Italy's new Parliament on June 26 and 27 are a case of ''the same old faces, the same old party politics.'' For Luciana Castellina they may be the most important in decades, not because they will produce a change, but because they may be the beginning of change.

title: Louisiana Land
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company said it planned to distribute one unit of beneficial interest in the L.L.& E. Royalty Trust for each two common shares held, payable June 28 to holders of record on June 22. The company will convey to the trust net overriding royalty interests in nine productive oil and gas properties and a 3 percent royalty interest in about 400,000 acres of the company's unleased and undeveloped south Louisiana fee lands, it said. Dissident shareholders, who recently lost a proxy fight, said the company's plans for the trust did not go far enough.

title: TV CAMERAS: NOT FOR COURTROOMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pillsbury Aide Joining Chili's
description: Norman E. Brinker resigned yesterday as executive vice president of the Pillsbury Company to become the chairman, chief executive officer and a major investor in Chili's Inc., a privately held restaurant chain based in Dallas, a Pillsbury spokesman said.

title: THEATER: GROWING OLD IN 'TAKING MY TURN'
description: ''TAKING MY TURN'' is a musical about aging that is irrepressibly young at heart. That it also deals sensitively with a serious subject is a tribute to the collaborative hands that are responsible for this joyful entertainment.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a tax loss carryforward of $4,000.

title: JAMES BOND MEETS 'OCTOPUSSY'
description: LET'S face it: the sensationally successful and long-lived James Bond films will not quit, and for good reason. They are ''Star Wars'' fantasies for the middle-aged of all ages. ''Octopussy,'' the 13th in the series that began with ''Dr. No'' in 1961, is actually better than most.

title: SOVIET SAID TO ADD TROOPS IN CUBA
description: Senior Government officials said today that the Soviet Union had increased the number of its troops in Cuba in recent weeks. The move has confused and worried the Reagan Administration.

title: Qaddafi and Arafat Pay Visits to Yemen
description: Both Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, visited Yemen today but apparently did not meet. Colonel Qaddafi, who flew here from the Organization of African Unity summit in Ethiopia, left later in the day for an undisclosed destination.

title: DROPOUT RATE OF 68%, HISPANIC UNIT SAYS
description: An agency that deals with the education of Hispanic people said yesterday that the dropout rate in New York City's high schools was 68 percent, not the 45 percent reported by the Board of Education.

title: Woolworth Pact
description: The F.W. Woolworth Company announced an agreement with the Pillsbury Company's Burger King Corporation unit to convert at least 50 Woolworth food units in its United States variety stores to Burger King restaurants. Woolworth said it would complete the conversions within the next five years. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Critics' Choices column in The Guide last Sunday referred incorrectly to a Cezanne portrait of Victor Choquet. Although it is cited in the Marlborough Gallery's catalogue as part of a show of 19th- and 20th-century master paintings, the portrait is out on approval and not on exhibit.

title: Accounts
description: * The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center to Healthmark Communications, a division of Bozell & Jacobs, for nursing recruitment.

title: MOSCOW SAYS SHIFT IN U.S. ARMS STAND IS NO BASIC CHANGE
description: A commentary by the Government press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's revised plan for strategic arms reduction was still aimed ''at gaining military superiority and pressing the Soviet Union into unilateral disarmament.''

title: STARS OF 'FOOL FOR LOVE' FIND SUCCESS CAN HURT
description: Ed Harris has scabs on his knuckles from slamming his fists against walls. Kathy Whitton Baker is suffering, her doctor says, from exhaustion.

title: OPERA: WORLD PREMIERE OF DELIUS IN ST. LOUIS
description: For collectors of musical rarities, the production of Frederick Delius's ''Margot la Rouge'' offered last night by Opera Theatre of St. Louis raised great expectations. It was the first staging anywhere of a 51-year-old opera, using the composer's original score, which disappeared shortly after his death but recently came to light in England. The unearthing came as the result of some detective work by Frank Peters, music critic of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch.

title: STATES EXPLORATION reports earnings for year to March 31.
Ex-A.T.& T. Aide Moves to Wall St.
description: Archie J. McGill made his plans known yesterday. He chose Wall Street. Mr. McGill, 52 years old, who resigned Tuesday as president of the advanced information systems division of American Bell, a division of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, joined Rothschild Inc. as president and chief executive of its venture capital group.

title: THE MANY SURPRISES OF OLD NEW ROCHELLE
description: NEW ROCHELLE is one of the oldest and most historic cities in the Northeast, the ''Queen City of the Sound'' immortalized by George M. Cohan's ''45 Minutes From Broadway.'' It is still that far from midtown and still a suburban home for many, but like any dowager, its age shows, especially downtown, which has become the focus of a major face lifting.

title: A Lesson On Hitting Successfully
description: I t was a case of the teacher showing the student how to do it. Lou Piniella, who is as popular with his teammates as a hitting coach as he is with the fans as a player, does not restrict his teaching to the do-as-I-say philosophy. Sometimes he puts his theories into practice so his students can do-as-I-do.

title: Canadian Lead Mine
description: Abitibi-Price Inc. said today that it and Asarco Inc. would reopen a lead-zinc mine at Buchans, Newfoundland, next week to salvage ore deep in the mine, closed since December 1981.

title: VILAS PENALTY A WARNING TO TOP PLAYERS
description: The decision by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council to suspend Guillermo Vilas of Argentina for one year represents a bold attempt to restore credibility to a $25 million prize-money circuit that seems to be heading out of control.

title: POLICEMAN GUILTY IN EXTORTION OF CLUBS
description: A New York City police officer was found guilty of extortion last night at the end of the first trial to grow out of a recent undercover investigation into suspected police corruption that centered on Manhattan's West Side.

title: SEAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $94,000 for the quarter and $135,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $21,000 for the quarter and $70,000 for the 6 months.

title: Squibb Files Suit
description: The Squibb Corporation has sued Diagnostic Medical Instruments Inc. and seven of its employees on charges of misappropriating trade secrets. All of the employees worked for Squibb's subsidiary, Instruments for Cardiac Research Inc., before joining Diagnostic Medical. The action, filed in United States District Court in Syracuse, seeks an injunction against shipping certain cardiac monitoring systems made by Diagnostic Research, and unspecified damages.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Senate, for the first time, has blown the whistle on outside earned income.

title: Venezuela In Debt Talks
description: The 13-bank advisory committee discussing the renegotiation of Venezuela's debt has agreed to continue talks, the Government announced today.

title: HOORAY FOR RAIN!
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Seizes Ex-Mountie
description: James Morrison, 67 years old, a former corporal of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, was charged today with passing secret information to Soviet diplomats in 1955-58. He was released on $42,000 bail.

title: WHITE HOUSE SOUNDINGS VIEWED AS SIGN VOLCKER MAY BE RETAINED
description: The White House has been taking political soundings on the likely reaction of Republican conservatives should President Reagan reappoint Paul A. Volcker to head the Federal Reserve Board, an aide to the Senate leadership said today.

title: As business lags, owners of theaters turn to producing.
description: NOT long ago, when Broadway was booming, the Jujamcyn theater chain expanded rapidly from two playhouses to five. Then, business went flat, and frustration set in. For much of the last season, until ''My One and Only,'' ''On Your Toes'' and ''The Flying Karamazov Brothers'' opened, Jujamcyn sat with all its theaters empty. As a result of this dismal experience, the Jujamcyn chain has decided to follow the lead of the Shubert Organization and the Nederlander Organization, the biggest theater owners on Broadway: Jujamcyn is now bullish about producing, with the aim of filling its theaters with its own shows.

title: GANE ENERGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SURPRISE STARTERS PAY A SMALL PRICE
description: The trainer John Nerud once cautioned handicappers to ''never knock a horse until he's been dead for six months.'' Even so, one has to wonder why a record field of 15 horses, some of them hopelessly outclassed, are running in the Belmont Stakes tomorrow.

title: SEDATE FORUM OF BELL HOLDERS
description: The 10,000 people in Madison Square Garden yesterday were considerably less boisterous than the Garden's usual run of sports or rock concert fans. But they were fans nevertheless - of a corporate variety.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 10, 1983; The Economy
description: The White House has been trying to find out how conservative Republicans would react if President Reagan reappointed Paul A. Volcker as head of the Federal Reserve, according to a Senate aide. The effort was seen as the strongest evidence so far that Mr. Reagan is inclined to retain Mr. Volcker. The White House said, however, that no decision will be made before next week. (Page A1.)

title: MET MUSEUM SALUTES CHARLES W. PEALE, RENAISSANCE YANKEE
description: ABRIGHT star in the glittering cast of 18th-century America was the polymath Charles Willson Peale (1741-1827). A saddlemaker in his youth, he went on to become a renowned portraitist, for whom George Washington sat no fewer than seven times. A naturalist, he led the first organized scientific expediton in American history. A museologist, he set up the earliest systematic museum of art and natural history in North America. An inventor and developer, he came up with porcelain false teeth and a farm cart based on the principles of the mariner's compass, which would transport milk without spilling it. A devoted husband and father, he survived three wives and sired 17 children, several of whom became artists themselves.

title: Economic Scene; Introspection In Europe
description: BONN LESS than two weeks after the Williamsburg Declaration, the fragile truce reached at the summit conference between President Reagan and his European allies seems to be unraveling rapidly.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Ball Corp., Muncie, Ind., has elected William L. Peterson senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Bridge: Recalling Bids May Solve A Tricky Suit Combination
description: Suit combinations tend to be easy when one partnership has four of the honors and the other has one. They tend to be much more difficult when one partnership has two and the other has three.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effected March 28, 1983.

title: JAZZ MARATHON TO BENEFIT WBGO
description: There will be a 12-hour jazz marathon starting Sunday at 2 P.M. at the Village Gate to benefit radio station WBGO, 88.3 on the FM dial, the only 24-hour jazz station in the metropolitan area.

title: Debt Issues
description: * The European Economic Community's Monetary Commission said it had approved a $1.5 billion issue of floating-rate notes as part of a $3.7 billion financing operation on behalf of the French Government; underwriters are led by Credit Suisse/First Boston.

title: Memorial for Donald Gramm
description: A memorial service for Donald Gramm, the American bass-baritone who died of a heart attack on June 2, will be held at 5 P.M. on June 20 in Alice Tully Hall and will be open to the public. Speakers will include Sarah Caldwell of the Opera Company of Boston, Beverly Sills of the New York City Opera, and Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: NEW SCHOOL GIVES PRAISE AND DEGREES
description: The New School for Social Research awarded 557 degrees yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in the school's 47th commencement.

title: 14 Held in Forcing 3 Women Into Jobs
description: Fourteen men, six of them members of a Chinatown gang, were arrested yesterday on charges they had forced three California women to work at a so-called massage parlor in Greenwich Village for about a month, the police said.

title: Aspen Quintet to Play
description: Bargemusic Ltd. will present the Aspen Wind Quintet with the Brazilian pianist Cipa Dichter as the group's guest tonight at the Barge at Brooklyn's Fulton Ferry Landing. The program includes music by Carter, Nielsen, Beethoven and Gershwin and begins at 8. Admission is $6.

title: SPECTATOR'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Major Earthquakes Strike Northern Japan
description: Two major earthquakes rumbled across northern Japan within minutes of each other tonight, spreading panic among residents recovering from a quake that killed nearly 100 people two weeks ago.

title: SHARP RISE IN CHILDBEARING FOUND AMONG U.S. WOMEN IN EARLY 30'S
description: The Census Bureau today reported a marked increase in the rate of childbearing among women in their early 30's. The fertility rate among women 30 to 34 years old rose 22.5 percent, from 60 births per 1,000 women in 1980 to 73.5 births in 1982, the bureau said.

title: PREAKNESS WINNER HITS THE ROAD
description: L ate this afternoon in the Maryland horse country, Bill Boniface Jr., will escort his Preakness winner, Deputed Testamony, into a van for the long haul to Long Island for the Belmont Stakes tomorrow afternoon.

title: SYM-TECK SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid May 23.

title: 'P-u-r-i-m' Spells Title For New Mexico Boy
description: Blake Giddens spelled a five-letter Jewish holiday and an eggplant stew today to win the National Spelling Bee and take home a trophy and $1,000 that twice eluded his older sister.

title: SENATORS, 51 TO 41, VOTE TO LIMIT THEIR LECTURE AND WRITING INCOME
description: Members of the Senate, in the wake of an outcry over the outside income they received last year, voted today to limit the amount of money they could earn from speeches and articles.

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a loss of $31,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DIOXIN CONTAMINATION FOUND AT A 2D BUSINESS IN NEWARK
description: New Jersey officials ordered a company in Newark today to fence in the property it uses and examine its 50 employees after potentially hazardous levels of dioxin contamination were found on the site.

title: Music of Turkish Jews To Be Heard on Sunday
description: ''The Sephardic Heritage in Music: From Ottoman Times to the Present,'' a survey of the secular and sacred music of Turkish Jews, will be presented Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue and 92d Street.

title: Oldrich Svestka, 61, Is Dead; Chief Editor of Prague Paper
description: Oldrich Svestka, a high Communist Party official and chief editor of the party newspaper Rude Pravo, died Wednesday, the press agency C.T.K.. announced today.

title: John V. Lintner Jr., 67, Dies; Harvard Business Professor
description: John V. Lintner Jr., the George Gund Professor of Economics and Business Administration at the Graduate School of Business Administration at Harvard University, died Wednesday morning, apparently of a heart attack, while driving his car to his office in Cambridge, Mass. He was a resident of Belmont, Mass., and was 67 years old.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Washington Square Art
description: This is the last weekend of the 103d Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit in Greenwich Village. More than 550 artists are showing their works on the sidewalks surrounding Washington Square Park in a tradition of spring and fall shows going back to 1931. Hours are noon to sundown tomorrow and Sunday, rain or shine.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: A WHILE back, an Australian movie called ''The Killing of Angel Street'' opened in New York and swiftly disappeared. Today, an Australian movie called ''Heatwave'' opens in New York at Cinema Studio 2; and the funny thing is that both ''Heatwave'' and ''The Killing of Angel Street'' are based on the same true story, of a woman who disappeared right under the noses of half the people in Sydney.

title: Florida Gives Credit
description: The University of Florida, said that Roy Harris, a senior defensive tackle, had received credit only once for a course he had taken twice. The St. Petersburg Times, citing university records, had reported Sunday that Harris had twice received credit for the course. A university statement, issued by the athletic director, Bill Carr, said Harris received credit toward his eligibility after he had met with instructors and written two papers during the summer before his sophomore year.

title: Late Advance Lifts Dow 3.50
description: A late advance enabled the stock market to end a two-day selloff and close slightly higher yesterday. Trading declined. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was off 2.51 points at 3 P.M., closed up 3.50 points, at 1,189.00. Analysts attributed the late rise mostly to bargain-hunting following the 28.74-point drop in the key indicator in the previous two sessions.

title: 'HEATWAVE,' DRAMA IN SYDNEY
description: AN air of portentousness pervades ''Heatwave,'' a compelling but murky Australian drama by the very talented director of ''Newsfront,'' Phillip Noyce. The city of Sydney is heading for a hot, muggy Christmas as the drama unfolds. The Eden Project, an elaborate housing development in which glass-walled apartments will rest on a treelike frame, is scheduled to replace some older buildings downtown. The tenants of those buildings protest vehemently against Eden, which is the work of a developer who ''came here with nothing but his nerve and made millions,'' according to one of his admiring associates. ''That's what this country's all about.''

title: EATON VANCE INVESTORS FUND INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
AFRICANS ARE ADVISED TO DEVELOP ATOM ARMS
description: A leader of the Organization of African Unity urged African countries today to develop nuclear arms and form a mutual defense pact against South Africa and other potential aggressors.

title: 'MARTIN GUERRE'
description: THIS is, as they say, a true story. In 1549 a young peasant named Martin Guerre disappeared from the small village of Artigat in the foothills of the Pyrenees in southwestern France. He left behind his wife of seven years, Bertrande de Rols, a young son, his parents and other members of a large, comparatively prosperous family.

title: Watt Backs City On Ft. Totten Deal
description: Interior Secretary James Watt has recommended that New York City be given 45 acres of underused Federal land in Fort Totten in Bayside, Queens. Mr. Watt said the city's proposal to use the tract for parks and recreation has ''considerable merit.''

title: COMPANY STOPS MAKING MORNING SICKNESS DRUG
description: Production of Bendectin, the only American-produced drug approved for the treatment of morning sickness, was halted by Merrell Dow Pharmaceuticals today.

title: DEFEATED LABOR PARTY ASSERTS IT IS ALIVE AND WELL
description: Officials and party workers at the Labor Party's headquarters here put on a brave face as news of the party's most crushing defeat since 1922 filled the early hours of the morning.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES TRADE CURBS
description: The Soviet Deputy Foreign Trade Minister, A.N. Manzhulo, today accused Western countries of ''aggressive protectionism in trade'' and of exerting economic and financial pressure on developing and Communist countries alike.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium. Frank Howard makes his home debut as the Mets' manager after taking over during a 4-9 road trip. Andre Dawson of the Expos is leading the league in hitting, and Gary Carter is leading the balloting for National League starting catcher in the All-Star Game. (Television -Channel 9, 8 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers at Milwaukee. The Yankees will play seven games in seven days on the road after an 8-5 home stand. This is their first game this season against last year's American League champions. (Television - Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8:30 P.M.) College World Series. Arizona State is in the first game and Michigan in the second as the N.C.A.A. Division I championship field narrows in Omaha. Television - ESPN, 6 and 9 P.M.).

title: New Transfer Agent Rules
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to adopt rules that provide for closer regulation of transfer agents who deal in the clearance and settlement of securities transactions.

title: GARISH INTRUDERS MUFFLING SPIRIT OF FRENCH QUARTER
description: As the yellow neon lights of a bar flickered ''Desire'' into Bourbon Street, a librarian attending a convention and a hot dog vendor fell to talking in the warm Louisiana twilight. Together they shared a long attachment to this city's French Quarter and the sad feeling that, like so much else in life these days, it has slid toward the abyss.

title: Tour Complaint Settled
description: The Tournament Policy Board of the PGA Tour, for the first time in the organization's 15 years, met tonight with 150 players to deal with questions about policies and activities. The board consists of three high-level businessmen representing the public interest, four player representatives and three officers of the Professional Golfers' Association of America.

title: VIETNAM AND THAILAND CONFER AND EASE STRAIN
description: Vietnam and Thailand said today, after a meeting of their foreign ministers, that they were committed to discussions despite differences over the military occupation of Cambodia by Vietnamese forces.

title: 2D U.S. TAKEOVER BID POSSIBLE, SOTHEBY SAYS
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet, the international art auction house, yesterday announced that it welcomed a possible takeover bid by A. Alfred Taubman of Michigan, one of the nation's largest real-estate developers.

title: BUDGET CONFEREES SEE 5% ARMS RISE
description: House and Senate members who are writing a budget for the 1984 fiscal year say their compromise spending plan will increase military expenditures by 5 percent after making up for the effects of inflation, about half what President Reagan has requested.

title: EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENTS BY N.R.C. MEMBERS ON INDIAN POINT
description: Following are excerpts from statements today on Indian Point by the five members of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission - Nunzio J. Palladino, chairman; John F. Ahearne, James K. Asselstine, Victor Gilinsky and Thomas M. Roberts: By Mr. Palladino

title: Thrift Unit Sale Stirs A Dispute
description: When the Federal Home Loan Bank Board receives bids Friday for the purchase of the $4.1 billion First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago, it will also be accepting a key role in resolving the growing dispute over interstate banking and deregulation of financial institutions.

title: MUSEUM HOPES 4 JADE PIECES MATCH THOSE STOLEN
description: Four of the 25 Mayan jade artifacts stolen last September from the American Museum of Natural History have apparently been recovered by an art dealer in Brussels, a museum official said yesterday.

title: HALLBERG LEADS IN WESTCHESTER CLASSIC
description: Gary Hallberg said that he was striking the golf ball so poorly in 1981 and 1982 that he didn't even want to go out to the course each day. He said that for those two years he would ''rather stay in bed than go out there and play golf.''

title: Gandhi Party Demands New Voting in Kashmir
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's party today demanded new voting in elections in the northern state of Kashmir, contending that there had been ''large-scale rigging'' of the balloting.

title: CHAPMAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AUCTIONS
description: A 3,000-year-old Egyptian statue from the reign of Ramses II, which was found in an abandoned trolley station in Chautauqua, N.Y., is expected to bring as much as $150,000 when it comes up for auction in a sale of antiquities today at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. The subtly modeled 1,100-pound, 3-foottall carved block of granite, depicts Merenptah, a royal charioteer and priest to Ramses II. He is shown seated, hugging his knees, the ''first life-size Egyptian sculpture to appear at auction in memory,'' according to Richard Keresey, Sotheby's antiquities specialist.

title: CONSERVATIVES WIN 140-SEAT MAJORITY IN BRITISH ELECTION
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Government scored a crushing victory in Britain's general election on Thursday, winning a majority of about 140 seats over the combined opposition in Parliament.

title: CHEMICAL LEADERS HEAR PUBLIC FEAR IS TOP PROBLEM
description: The outgoing head of the Chemical Manufacturers Association warned today that public fear of chemicals was now the industry's major problem and chemical companies themselves must ''clean up the dumps.''

title: GOULD DISMISSED FROM 'GUYS'
description: Elliott Gould was dismissed yesterday as the star of ''The Guys in the Truck'' by the play's director, David Black. Mr. Gould will be replaced by Harris Laskawy, who played Off Broadway in the original production of the Howard Reifsnyder comedy.

title: TURBO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: The latest year loss includes interest expense of $99 million, a $12 million writedown on real estate losses and an operating loss of $12.7 million.

title: ASSEMBLYMAN WILL RUN FOR EXECUTIVE IN SUFFOLK
description: Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, a Democrat from Lindenhurst, announced today that he would run for Suffolk County Executive against the incumbent, Peter F. Cohalan, a Republican.
