title: Carl J. Schmid, Former Chief Of Drug Maker, Is Dead at 85
description: Carl J. Schmid, former president of Schmid Laboratories Inc., a drug manufacturer, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and also had homes on Fishers Island, in Suffolk County, and in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Preparatory Draft
description: Cliff Fletcher, the general manager of the Calgary Flames, said he had been told by Soviet hockey officials that they were ''two years away'' from allowing players to join the National Hockey League. That explains why the Flames drafted one of the top players on the Soviet national team, Sergei Makarov. Also preparing for the future were the Montreal Canadiens, who drafted the Soviet goaltender, Vladislav Tretiak, and the New Jersey Devils, who drafted three Soviet players.

title: VILLAGE SUPER MARKET reports earnings for qtr to April 23.
E.P.A. to Study 14 Sites In 3 States for Dioxin
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has begun a preliminary investigation of 14 sites in Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia for dioxin contamination.

title: The U.N. Today; June 10, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Working Group on Protection of the Rights of Migrant Workers and Their Families - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mattel Loses $20.4 Million
description: Mattel Inc., hurt by depressed sales of its electronic games, today announced a deficit of $20.4 million for the fiscal first quarter, ended April 30.

title: LINCOLN CENTER TRYING TO ADD $5 MILLION TO ARTS ENDOWMENT
description: Citing ''serious cutbacks of Federal, state and city funds for the arts,'' Martin E. Segal, chairman of Lincoln Center, yesterday announced a fund-raising campaign to add $5 million to the center's $21.5 million endowment.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Edge Lower
description: Interest rates dipped in light trading yesterday amid indications that the Federal Reserve has not yet moved to tighten credit. Analysts also said the market was calmed by reports that President Reagan's top aides had narrowed their list of candidates for the Fed chairmanship to Paul A. Volcker, the current chairman whose term expires in August, and Alan Greenspan, a prominent economist.

title: Convertible Issue Planned by Wang
description: Wang Laboratories said it would sell $150 million of 7 3/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008 at an unspecified date. The debentures, which are being sold with Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group as the lead underwriter, are convertible into class B common stock at $52.1625.

title: OFFICERS IN FAMILY COURT PROTEST BAN ON FIREARMS
description: Court officers assigned to New York City's Family Court warned yesterday that unless they were given permission to carry firearms while on duty, starting Monday they would no longer search people entering the courthouses, many of whom they say are armed.

title: CHEMICAL BANK NAMES PRESIDENTS FOR 3 SECTORS
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, the sixth-largest banking company in the country, named three presidents yesterday, one for each of its major sectors.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for year to March 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: STAGE: LLOSA'S 'SENORITA'
description: ''THE SENORITA FROM TACNA'' by Mario Vargas Llosa is quite visibly a novelist's play more than a dramatist's. A story unfolds on stage slowly, its characters carefully delineated. One can almost hear the novelist's sentences building into anecdotal chapters more than into two dramatic acts.

title: Businesses Plan Less Spending
description: American businesses are planning to spend $305.5 billion on expansion and modernization projects this year, down 3.1 percent from last year's recession-depressed level after adjusting for inflation, the Government reported today.

title: Maggie At the Watershed
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's landslide reelection looks dazzling. This has to be written before the final count is in, but the statistics matter less than the sense already established that the vote is a watershed for Britain and in a way for Europe.

title: KASLER CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in February 1983.

title: METS BEAT CUBS IN 11 INNINGS, 6-4
description: The Mets ended an otherwise disastrous two-week trip today by beating the Chicago Cubs, 6-4, in 11 innings and breaking the Cubs' winning streak at 7 games.

title: U.S. AVOWS PRIORITY FOR ARMS CURBS
description: The Reagan Administration today issued a report on the history of its arms limitation efforts in an effort to persuade public opinion in Western Europe and in the United States that, in the booklet's words, a search for arms control ''will remain among the highest priorities of this and future administrations.''

title: U.S. ARMY CHIEF OPPOSES SENDING COMBAT FORCES TO AID EL SALVADOR
description: Gen. Edward C. Meyer, the Army's Chief of Staff, said today that he would oppose sending United States combat forces to El Salvador because Americans would not support them and Salvadorans were not fully committed to defeating leftist insurgents there.

title: O'NEILL LEADING PARTY OFFENSIVE AGAINST REAGAN
description: Fifteen minutes before the House goes into session each day, 50 reporters file into the Speaker's office to hear what has become an almost daily attack on President Reagan. It is a wide-ranging foray, whose underlying theme is that the Reagan Presidency is ''of the rich, by the rich and for the rich,'' the words used by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. on Monday to describe the Administration's tax program.

title: Miss Reinhardt Leads With a 67
description: Alexandra Reinhardt, a nonwinner in her nine years on the tour, shot a 67 for the first-round lead today in the Ladies' Professional Golf Association championship, the second of the annual four major tournaments for women.

title: MANITOU-BARVUE MINE LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LET I.R.S. NOW END JONESISM
description: Although the United States Supreme Court's landmark decision in the Bob Jones University case was a critical victory for civil rights and a stunning defeat for the Administration, the result is largely symbolic. Segregated private schools can still receive Federal tax benefits.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook Housewife Comma

title: Sayonara for 'Mikado'
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players will offer the final performances of ''The Mikado'' this weekend at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Show times are tomorrow at 3 and 8 P.M. and Sunday at 2 and 7 P.M. Tickets are $7 to $12; $6 to $10 for those younger than 13 and the elderly (Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted). Information: 864-5400.

title: The Supreme Court Apologizes
description: ''With apologies to all,'' the Supreme Court announces that after all, it will not now decide whether to relax the so-called exclusionary rule, which bars the use of illegally obtained evidence in criminal trials. The justices themselves raised the issue last fall in a case about how the police in the Chicago suburb of Bloomingdale handled a search for marijuana. The Court called for an extra round of briefs and oral argument over the alleged need for some kind of ''good-faith'' exception to the exclusionary rule.

title: Chrysler Offers New Rebate Plan
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced that it would offer rebates ranging up to $750 and the lowest car financing rate in the auto industry, 8.7 percent, starting this weekend.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Zico, the Brazilian soccer star, said he had rejected an offer to stay with Flamengo and would play next year for Udinese in Italy. ... Toni Fritsch, a placekicker with four N.F.L. teams before retiring last December, revealed he spent six weeks in a drug rehabilitaion center in Minnesota earlier this year for an alcohol-related problem.

title: BALLET THEATER: 2 DEBUTS
description: IT would be pleasant to report that Johan Renvall and Ronald Perry conquered a new world Wednesday night in their debuts in John McFall's ''Follow the Feet,'' presented by the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. That the two talented soloists did not is no comment on their considerable skills as dancers and actors.

title: Bank Capital Rules Seen
description: The Federal Reserve is expected to release rules early next week that would require the nation's 17 largest bank holding companies to keep their primary capital at least equivalent to 5 percent of their assets, banking sources said yesterday.

title: GRENADA PREMIER ESTABLISHES 'SOME SORT' OF U.S. RAPPORT
description: Prime Minister Maurice Bishop of Grenada said today that he had ''established some sort of a dialogue'' with the Reagan Administration but charged that the Central Intelligence Agency was plotting to overthrow his regime.

title: AUSTERITY MOVES SET BY BRAZIL
description: The Brazilian Government today announced a series of new austerity measures intended to gain agreement from the International Monetary Fund to proceed with its $4.9 billion program of assistance to Brazil.

title: Arms to South Africa Seized
description: A big shipment of weapons destined for South Africa has been impounded after being detected at the international airport here, the police reported today.

title: Moscow Says It Is Planning Maneuvers Starting June 29
description: Soviet army and naval forces will hold maneuvers for six days in the Baltic region beginning June 29, the Tass press agency said today.

title: PUERTO RICO OFFICER LINKED TO NEW YORKER'S DEATH
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that a high-ranking Puerto Rico police officer, convicted Saturday of participating in a kidnapping, organized the conspiracy that resulted in 1977 the murder here of Abraham Shafizdeh, a New York dealer in diamonds.

title: COAST POLICE CHARGE AN ESCAPED PATIENT WITH FOUR SLAYINGS
description: A man wanted for kidnapping and rape in Pennsylvania, who escaped from a mental hospital there and from a California prison, was charged today with the slayings of three members of a family and a young houseguest.

title: Pogo Extends Tender Offer
description: The Pogo Producing Company said it had extended its offer to purchase up to 6.25 million shares of its common stock until midnight June 13.

title: U.S. and Soviet Renew Talks
description: The United States and Soviet negotiating teams resumed the strategic arms reduction talks today. The acting Soviet delegation head said that no text of President Reagan's new proposals was submitted at the session.

title: Cleveland Issue
description: The City of Cleveland plans to come to market with a $27.58 million bond offering later this month, its first since defaulting on bonds in 1978. Salomon Brothers will be the lead underwriter. The city's Ba-1 rating by Moody's, a speculative grade, has not been changed, but Cleveland's finance director, Dan Mackel, said the issue was planned because ''the city needs the money.''

title: Top Posts Revamped At Beatrice Foods
description: The Beatrice Foods Company of Chicago, an enterprise that rings up worldwide sales of $9.2 billion annually, is in the throes of reorganization. Yesterday, it set forth a new top management structure ''designed to carry forward Beatrice's new corporate marketing strategy,'' as the company put it.

title: WORD'S OUT TO MUSICIANS: JIMMY ROWLES IS BACK
description: NEW YORK has not heard Jimmy Rowles for more than two years, since he went on the road as Ella Fitzgerald's accompanist. But now the jazz pianist, who is held in unusually high esteem by his fellow musicians, particularly by pianists, is back and has New York engagements that will keep him in town for at least two months.

title: Bench Plans Retirement
description: Johnny Bench has told Dick Wagner, the Cincinnati Reds' president, that he will not play next year, according to a club spokesman.

title: Power System Seeks Credit
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System executive board will vote Friday on a proposal to ask commercial bankers nationally for a three-year, $963 million line of credit so that construction can restart on a financially ailing nuclear unit.

title: SUBURBAN CONDOMINIUM BUILDERS VS. NEW STATE TAX
description: New York State's capital gains tax is endangering the financial stability of low-rise condominium developments and may prevent hundreds of buyers across the state from quickly moving into their homes, according to developers and spokesmen for the building industry.

title: CONCERT: EARLY ANDES MUSIC
description: Athousand years ago, the Aymara tribe inhabited the Altiplano, the highlands of the Andes in what is now Bolivia. They were conquered in the 15th century by the Incas, and then by Spain, but preserved their language, instruments and some ancient melodies.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Asset levels of money market mutual funds declined $412 million last week, to $169.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: Friday; QUILTS FROM THE INDIANA AMISH
description: The Museum of American Folk Art is presenting the first of three parts of a show on Amish quiltmaking through Aug. 31 at the Equitable Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 52d Street. Included are 18 cotton crib quilts from about 1900 to 1930. These are traditional Indiana Amish patterns, and unlike those of the Pennsylvania Amish, are brightly colored, many with contrasting black shapes. Open free, Monday through Friday, 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. The other sections of the exhibition open June 21 at the museum, 49 West 53d Street, and June 28 at the City Gallery, 2 Columbus Circle. JAZZ AT SYMPHONY SPACE

title: DR. JOHN A. MACKAY, EX-PRESIDENT OF PRINCETON THEOLOGICAL, IS DEAD
description: The Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay, president emeritus of the Princeton Theological Seminary and former moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., died yesterday at Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Heightstown, N.J. He was 94 years old.

title: Sears Raising Stake In Simpsons-Sears
description: The Hudson's Bay Company said today that it had agreed to sell 17,595,925 class B voting shares, or 20.2 percent, of Simpsons-Sears Ltd. to Sears, Roebuck & Company at $12 a share for a total price of $211.2 million (Canadian).

title: I.C.C. Relaxes Rules on Coal
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had agreed to exempt the transportation of coal for export from economic regulation.

title: A New Start for Start
description: By changing only a single number, President Reagan has changed the direction of his arms control proposals in a constructive way. He was forced to the change by public pressure, and Congress is now likely to reward him with more money to develop and test the MX missile. More such pressure will be needed, however, to alter America's nuclear strategy in ways that provide both maximum security and maximum opportunity for a Start treaty with the Soviet Union, which is already reacting skeptically.

title: WOMEN ARE THE STARS ON THEIR PODIUM
description: Blanche Ross and her cousin Dee Ann Mernit say they have one major mission in life: to put women on a podium, not a pedestal. The two women run a speaker's bureau, Ross Associates, at 515 Madison Avenue, that specializes in providing women to speak at conventions, workshops and seminars across the country. They call such bookings ''Programs by Women of Achievement.''

title: Required Reading; Buying American
description: Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia, in remarks to the House of Representatives, June 2, 1983: Mr. Speaker, a lot of us from areas hard hit by unemployment recognize the need to support products made in the United States. Major corporations sought tax breaks from Congress saying they would make themselves more competitive against foreign manufacturers. Today, I want to present the Buy American Award to United States Steel, which is presently negotiating the purchase of 3 1/2 million tons of British steel.

title: A theater choice and a river view.
description: ORSO, the newest addition to the rapidly changing scene on Restaurant Row, 46th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, offers a decent, pleasant and moderate-price option for light and heavy meals, before and after theater. Adjacent to Joe Allen's hamburger pub, and under the same management, the casual and attractive dining room, with its skylight and open kitchen, suggests a country courtyard, a style that is enhanced by colorfully decorated mix-match earthenware. Lighting at night is a bit gloomy, but the tone set by staff and customers is friendly, relaxed and convivial.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: COUNTERSUIT BY N.H.L. OVER BLUES
description: The National Hockey League filed a countersuit today against the Ralston Purina Company for its refusal to continue to operate the St. Louis Blues.

title: A RIO PARTY FOR 2,000 HONORS A SOCIAL CHRONICLER
description: ''Who invited you? I certainly didn't.'' Uttered by the Brazilian playboy Baby Pignatari in 1952, these turned out to be a lifetime's fighting words to the young man being turned away.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on pages A11, A15-18, A28, B7-11. Power Failure Strikes Austin, Tex., Area

title: WALESA, IN SMUGGLED SPEECH TEXT, TELLS HARVARD'S GARDUATES OF HOPE
description: In the text of a speech smuggled out of Poland, Lech Walesa, the Polish labor leader, told Harvard University graduates today that the trade union Solidarity had made it possible for Poles to begin communicating with one another.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: A Nuclear Anniversary
description: I n 1963, before the ''Dr. Strangelove'' scenario replaced contaminated milk as a public concern about nuclear weapons, the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain did something that seems remarkable by today's negotiating standards.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Space Shuttle Will Fly Over New York Today
description: The space shuttle Enterprise, built in 1976 as a prototype, is scheduled to make a 20-minute pass over New York City this afternoon atop a modified Boeing 747, Mayor Koch's office said.

title: CORPORATE TRIUMPH, THEN DEATH IN A FERRARI
description: The young president of a successful new computer company died Wednesday afternoon in a car crash in California's Silicon Valley, hours after his company had sold its stock to the public for the first time and he had become a multimillionaire.

title: BLACK NATIONALISTS VOW REVENGE
description: South Africa's white Government today hanged three black guerrillas who had been convicted of treason and murder, and the outlawed African National Congress to which they belonged vowed to avenge the deaths.

title: News Analysis
description: There is an air of selfcongratulation among African leaders here who, finally, and after much division, have been able to convene the Organization of African Unity's twice-postponed 19th summit meeting. It is as if a notion central to the continent's self-image - that a collective African resolve is capable of overcoming individual disputes - has been rescued.

title: Renault Deal in Mexico
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault said today that it had agreed with the Mexican Government to buy 52 percent of Renault de Mexico, increasing its stake to 92 percent. Renault and the American Motors Corporation (41 percent owned by Renault) will buy Mexico's 95 percent holding in Vehiculos Automotores Mexicanos. A.M.C. has the remaining 5 percent.

title: CAMPAIGN FINANCES OF 15 JUDGES UNDER INVESTIGATION IN BROOKLYN
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office and the State Commission on Judicial Conduct are investigating the campaign finances of 15 Brooklyn judges and their campaign committees in the 1979 Civil Court and 1982 State Supreme Court elections.

title: VISIT TO A CATSKILL WORLD OF YESTERYEAR
description: The public is invited to take a rare tour tomorrow of part of a rustic retreat in the northern Catskill Mountains that was home to a wealthy and artistic community of the 1890's. The tour, sponsored by the Greene County Historical Society, will traverse the rugged mountain area that was depicted in the mid-19th-century works of the Hudson River School of painters - and some of their prints and paintings will be exhibited at one tour stop.

title: CO-FOUNDED PROJECT TO HELP DRUG USERS
description: Dr. Daniel Casriel, a psychiatrist and co-founder of the Daytop Village narcotics addiction rehabilitation program, died Tuesday of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, known as Lou Gehrig's Disease, at his home in Manhattan. He was 59 years old.

title: Coming Home
description: The University of Notre Dame was a vital element when college basketball was introduced to Madison Square Garden on Dec. 29, 1934. The Irish played New York University in one half of a doubleheader that also included a game between St. John's and Westminster.

title: Salomon, Citibank Win Ohio Issue
description: A $50 million State of Ohio Water Development Authority note issue was jointly won by Salomon Brothers Inc. and Citibank.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in January 1983.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report on Monday with a picture of an Orthodox church service incorrectly identified the church and the title of its leader. It was the Armenian Apostolic Church, an autonomous body; its leader, Catholicos Karekin II, is Patriarch of the Holy See of Cilicia.

title: PROVIGO INC reports earnings for 12 wks to April 23.
O'Neill to Postpone MX Vote
description: At the request of liberals who want President Reagan to explain his new arms control proposals further, Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. agreed today to postpone a vote on the MX missile until after the Fourth of July recess.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 10, 1983
description: International Conservatives won a major victory in Britain's general election, seizing a majority of about 140 seats over the combined opposition in the House of Commons. The sweep for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Government was the most far-reaching since the Labor Party's landslide of 1945. Polling barely one vote in four, Labor suffered its worst debacle since 1922 and barely edged out the new Liberal-Social Democratic alliance in the popular vote. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington's new arms control plan was rebuffed in Moscow's initial response. A commentary by the Soviet press agency Tass said President Reagan's revised proposals for strategic weapons cuts were still aimed ''at gaining military superiority and pressing the Soviet Union into unilateral disarmament.'' (A1:4.)

title: Senate Rejects Ban on Trucks
description: The Senate today voted, 61-20, to delete from a supplemental appropriations bill a provision to exclude commercial traffic from U.S. Route 209 in Pennsylvania near the New Jersey border.

title: REFUGEES IN NEED OF A FAIR HEARING
description: To the Editor:

title: S.M.U. Faces A New Inquiry
description: Southern Methodist University has been removed from probation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association but now faces the possibility of another investigation into its football program.

title: REAGAN ACKNOWLEDGES COST OF SCHOOLS PROPOSALS
description: President Reagan acknowledged today that his proposal to have teachers paid and promoted on the basis of merit would cost more money, but he said that school systems should pay for the program by cutting other programs of ''much lower priority.''

title: PAUL MANN
description: Paul Mann, pianist and composer whose more than 50 musical compositions included Frank Sinatra's theme song, ''Put Your Dreams Away,'' died in Booth Memorial Hospital, in Queens, on May 27 of emphysema. He was 72 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens.

title: Children's Orchestra
description: The Harlem Children's Orchestra from the Harlem School of the Arts will make its debut in a free program tomorrow at 3 P.M. at the Belvedere Castle in Central Park. The program, to be conducted by Bonnie Black, will include music by Pachelbel and Beethoven as well as traditional, popular and jazz music.

title: Petrie Stores
description: The Petrie Stores Corporation said its board had approved the sale of 750,000 common shares of treasury stock to Milton Petrie, its chairman and chief executive officer, at $36.50 a share. The purchase increases Mr. Petrie's interest in the company from about 63 percent to 64 percent. Mr. Petrie said he planned to purchase up to 750,000 more shares from time to time in the open market. The company said the additional capital would be used for general corporate purposes, including possible acquisitions and maintaining the company's investment in Toys ''R'' Us Inc. Petrie now holds 20.7 percent of Toys ''R'' Us common stock.

title: Fratello Joins Hawks
description: Mike Fratello, a former Atlanta Hawks assistant coach who spent last season in that role with the Knicks, was named head coach of the Hawks yesterday. He replaced Kevin Loughery, who resigned Monday and signed a three-year contract to coach the Chicago Bulls yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ASIATICS. By Frederick Prokosch. 371 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Paperback, $8.25.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Business Day yesterday about Fox & Company incompletely identified an official of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He is Charles E. Padgett, regional counsel in New York.

title: Cook County Aide Indicted
description: Cook County's Treasurer, Edward J. Rosewell, was indicted Wednesday on charges of bank fraud involving misrepresentation of his net worth in applying for more than $160,000 in loans from five banks.

title: STERN DOCTOR, STERN REMEDY
description: April 3, 1982, was perhaps the darkest day in the political life of Margaret Thatcher. A national opinion poll published a week before reported that the British public thought she would go down as the worst Prime Minister in history. Her monetarist policies were being blamed for an unemployment rate that had almost doubled in the three years since she took office. Her constant declarations that she would halt the decline of Britain and get it back on the road to health and prosperity fell on many ears as the sound of someone trying to drown out criticism with strong but hollow words. Speculation About Departure

title: Pennant Factor
description: Since 1962 when the Mets were formed, New York's two major league baseball teams have won nine league pennants - seven by the Yankees and two by the Mets.

title: LAWRENCE SCHULMAN
description: Lawrence Schulman, president of the New York Export Company, an exporter of produce, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Crotonon-Hudson, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BRIDGE IS SOON TO LOSE A 'PEOPLE'S ROADWAY'
description: One bright summer day in 1978, a group of cyclists, in defiance of New York's traffic laws, rode their bicycles across an outer lane of the Queensboro Bridge and hung a banner that read, ''People's Roadway.''

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
ART: BARBARA ZUCKER AND HER SCULPTURES
description: BARBARA ZUCKER'S new exhibition at the Pam Adler Gallery, 37 West 57th Street, is a blessed relief from the macho semaphoring that so often passes for sculpture. The bigger pieces - and in particular, a family of five upright sculptures in the far room - take their idiom from the vernacular architecture of Vermont. But that is not to say that they look like bits of houses. On the contrary, the architectural element is lifted clear of its original function, even if the end result has sometimes the look of a thinking woman's steeple.

title: LASER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $564,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $871,000.

title: EXPEDITED BOND SALES BACKED
description: A temporary rule permitting corporations to sell stocks and bonds through so-called shelf registrations, due to expire at the end of the year, would be extended indefinitely under a proposal announced yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BELMONT DRAWS A RECORD FIELD OF 15
description: If the Belmont Stakes tomorrow lives up to its billing as a twohorse race between Slew o' Gold and Caveat, there is going to be quite a crowd running for third-place money. Fifteen horses were entered yesterday for the 115th Belmont, the largest field that has ever run in the third leg of the Triple Crown.

title: Sophie Mgcina Sings Of African Townships
description: Following in the footsteps of such singers and musicians from the black townships of South Africa as Miriam Makeba, Letta Mbulu, Dollar Brand and Hugh Masekela, Sophie Thoko Mgcina, who performed in the successful off-Broadway musical ''Poppie Nongena'' is making her American cabaret debut at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, with a program called ''Sound of the Township.''

title: CLINICAL DATA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: PROGRESS IN BRANIFF TALKS SEEN
description: Representatives for most of the creditors of Braniff International accepted an proposal late tonight between Braniff and the Hyatt Corporation to restart part of the airline.

title: 'A VERY EASY TOWN TO HAVE ACCESS'
description: Sir Oliver Wright, in his striped shirt, silk tie and golden cufflinks engraved with the coiled initials of Elizabetha Regina, settled back in a sofa the other morning at the British Embassy. Beyond the picture window, the red brick walls trimmed with white stone and capped by towering chimneys glistened in the sunlight.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: print dress and pearls, was ridinga n elephant sidesaddle along with Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr. Nearby, a gray-haired woman in a chiffon pseudo-sari was d elightedly saying ''Hello, you pretty things'' to a pair of playful s ea lions.

title: Nicaragua Says Army 'Contained' New Assault
description: Nicaragua said today that the army had ''contained'' a new invasion by 600 Honduran-based rebels and killed nearly one-fourth of them in heavy fighting in northern Nueva Segovia province.

title: 3-EX OFFICERS GET TERMS IN BEATINGS
description: A Federal judge today sentenced three former New Orleans police officers to five years in prison without parole ''for beating and torturing witnesses,'' most of whom were black, in investigating the slaying of a fellow officer.

title: Francis D. Rogers Dies; Architect for Hospitals
description: Francis Day Rogers, an architect whose firm designed many major hospital projects in New York City, died of diabetes Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: FIERY SEND-OFF FOR GRADUATES OF POLYTECHNIC
description: Smoke poured into Carnegie Hall yesterday as Mayor Koch prepared to speak at the Polytechnic Institute of New York graduation there. ''Fire! Fire!'' someone screamed in the top balcony. Some people crowded into the aisles. A few hurried for the doors. The Mayor's security guard, Edward Martinez, knelt in front of Mr. Koch on the stage, listening tensely to a walkie-talkie and pointing toward the rear exit. Mr. Koch shook his head and sat still.

title: Gato Barbieri Wields Saxophone at S.O.B.'s
description: Gato Barbieri, whose four-night engagement at S.O.B.'s was sold out before it began, makes some of the most raucous sounds ever to emerge from a tenor saxophone. His horn screams, grunts, honks, bleats, groans; even in ballads, he works up to a hefty, throbbing tone that sounds like it could burst at any moment.

title: CITY WITHDRAWS A RISE IN TUITION AT 7 CAMPUSES
description: The City University of New York plans to rescind a tuition increase for 18,600 part-time students at its two-year community colleges, university officials said yesterday.

title: TREES MAY TELL MAN: TURN OVER A NEW LEAF
description: Are trees more intelligent than humans? This question, which philosophers may have asked in the agora, takes on added bite in view of the National Science Foundation report that when trees are endangered they may emit signals that induce nearby trees to change their chemistry to protect themselves.

title: ANDERSON OFFERS PLAN ON SHARING MEDICAID COSTS
description: The Republican leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, has proposed a compromise plan to ease the burden on cities and counties of the growing cost of Medicaid.

title: TRAK AUTO CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Texas Sets Back Alabama in 10, 6-4
description: A double by Bill Bates in the 10th inning drove in the deciding run tonight as top-ranked Texas assured itself of a berth in the finals of the College World Series with a 6-4 victory over Alabama.

title: HONDURAS WANTS LARGE INCREASE IN U.S. ARMS
description: The commander of the Honduran armed forces said today that senior Defense Department officials had agreed to ask Congress for a large increase in American military assistance to his country over the next several years.

title: DATAMETRICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $165,613 for the quarter and $451,515 for the 6 months.

title: Harvester Unit Faces Default
description: The International Harvester Company said today that its French subsidiary was in ''critical condition'' and unless significant financial assistance was received, the unit would ''most likely'' default on its loan agreements.

title: Maryland Cup Merger Talks Off
description: The Maryland Cup Corporation said it had terminated the preliminary merger discussions announced May 27.

title: L.I. School Shut After Racial Clash
description: Officials today ordered Farmingdale High School closed until Monday to ease tensions after a student and a former student were arrested in a schoolyard racial melee. The Nassau County police said it took 30 officers to break up the fight.

title: LOSSES IN LEBANON
description: Disproportionate power and great distance breed extraordinary illusions. One year ago, Israel's enormously potent military machine invaded Lebanon with, it now seems obvious, tacit American acquiescence. One year later, the realization of Isreal's many, overlapping goals seems very dubious. What counts much more today is this war's awful detailed misery, the shattering dislocations and human bitterness left in its wake.

title: Market Place; A $14 Billion Stock Portfolio
description: $14 billion worth - in the country. In that case, what's your opinion?

title: Women's Organization Head Promises Defeat of Reagan
description: The president of the National Organization for Women vowed today to defeat President Reagan in 1984, should he run for re-election, but she cautioned that Democrats could not simply assume that voting by sex was ''an automatic windfall for them.''

title: SENATE'S ROLL-CALL ON INCOME LIMIT
description: Following is the roll call vote of 51 to 41 by which the Senate voted today to limit the income senators can collect for speeches to private groups.

title: PUBLISHING: A PULITZER AND FRIENDS MET AND UNMET
description: AFTER Galway Kinnell's ''Selected Poems'' won the 1983 Pulitzer Prize for poetry, just after it won the American Book Award, the Rhode Island legislature passed a measure saluting its native son. Mr. Kinnell has also been hearing from a great many friends and from what one letter writer referred to as his many ''unmet friends,'' people who have come to know him solely through his poems.

title: 4 Alaska Lawmakers Forced to Go to Session
description: What has been called the most chaotic session in the Alaska Legislature's history, marred by accusations and investigations of eavesdropping, took another twist Wednesday when Gov. Bill Sheffield had state troopers force four legislators to a joint session.

title: ISRAEL'S LEBANON GAINS
description: A year ago this week, Israel launched its action in Lebanon. Invoking the right under international law to pursue those who threaten the security of its citizens, Israel was soon embroiled in the most unpopular action of its 35-year history.

title: VICTORIA STATION INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: b-After a charge of $4.6 million for the quarter and year on the disposal of certain restaurants. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of $253,000 on the sale of a restaurant. d-Net income including a tax credit of $242,000 and a nonrecurring gain of $253,000 on the sale of a restaurant.

title: DeLorean Co-Defendant Set to Change His Plea
description: A man charged with John Z. DeLorean, the former automobile maker, with taking part in a $24 million cocaine deal will plead guilty next week to drug trafficking, the man's lawyer said today.

title: CUOMO STRESSES SOCIAL NEEDS IN COMMENCEMENT AT YESHIVA
description: Governor Cuomo told graduates of Yeshiva University yesterday to follow their Jewish heritage and American tradition to improve life for all and to reject the doctrine that government has no obligation to care for its people.

title: Margiotta Denied Shorter Sentence
description: A judge yesterday denied a motion to reduce the two-year prison sentence that Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader, is to begin serving next Wednesday for extortion and mail fraud.

title: DEMOCRATS UNITED ON THE ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: Reuschel Dropped
description: The Yankees, as expected, yesterday released Rick Reuschel. Reuschel underwent two shoulder operations last year and lost much of his ability to throw hard.

title: A FESTIVAL OF FESTIVALS, INDOORS AND OUT
description: THIS weekend, with warm weather at last more than a rumor, the metropolitan area heads determinedly into the festival season. Not that all festivals are outdoors; they just seem to germinate best in fine weather. So from clowns in Chelsea to dance on an East River pier, from a marathon of comedy to a marathon by women of jazz, from folk music in Middletown, N.J., to barbershop-quartet music in Armonk, N.Y., from Lincoln Center to Snug Harbor, there is a festival for almost every taste.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ORIOLES WIN DESPITE 6 ERRORS
description: The Baltimore Orioles scored seven runs in the first inning, three on a homer by Leo Hernandez, and earned a 10-7 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight - despite allowing five unearned runs on six infield errors.

title: Yugoslavia Freeing Prices
description: Yugoslavia said today that it would gradually remove price controls decreed last year, conceding they were ineffective.

title: Sayonara, Studies
description: Dan Schlesinger finished a surprising third in last year's New York Marathon after two years of steady training in South Korea. He was working there as an interpreter in a law office.

title: PITFALLS IN DETERMINATE SENTENCING
description: To the Editor:

title: BALDWIN PLANS SALE OF 'MAJOR' ASSETS
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation will present a restructuring plan to its creditors today that includes the sale of 10 to 15 ''major'' assets but not the MGIC Investment Corporation or its subsidiaries, Victor Palmieri, the president of Baldwin-United, said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Cable TV's Liberalized Guidelines
description: THE sky is blue, the house is white and the man who enters is very attractive; so is the woman who follows him into the house, seconds later. That it is a tryst, and probably an illicit one, is perfectly clear, but advertising has become more suggestive, after all, and - wait a minute! They're drinking wine! On television!

title: FILM: 'MARTIN GUERRE'
description: THIS is, as they say, a true story. In 1549 a young peasant named Martin Guerre disappeared from the small village of Artigat in the foothills of the Pyrenees in southwestern France. He left behind his wife of seven years, Bertrande de Rols, a young son, his parents and other members of a large, comparatively prosperous family.

title: Day in the Life Of a Champion
description: It has been 10 years since Secretariat ran one of the most memorable races in thoroughbred history. He won the Belmont Stakes by 31 lengths in 2 minutes 24 seconds, still the American record for a mile-and-a-half event.

title: What price varnish?
description: THE Cubist paintings of Picasso and Braque, together considered by art professionals one of the major achievements of 20th-century art, may have been seriously distorted because of the common practice of applying varnish to protect or polish the painting surface, according to John Richardson, an English art critic, who raised the question in ''Crimes Against the Cubists,'' an article in the June 16 issue of The New York Review of Books.

title: Kentucky Student Bond To Be Repriced Today
description: A $300 million insured revenue bond issued by the Kentucky Higher Education Student Loan Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company to yield between 5.5 percent in 1983 and 9 3/8 percent in 1993.

title: A Distant West Side
description: I t was a cozy Upper West Side gathering at Symphony Space the other night when Public School 84 received a $10,000 check from the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. And the Rockefellers came off like a bunch of neighborhood kids.

title: PROMOTED WORKS BY MODERNS
description: Robert Elkon, an internationally known dealer in classic modern and contemporary art, died of cancer yesterday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in New York.

title: Korf Planning Sale of 2 Units
description: Korf Industries, the American branch of Willy Korf's struggling West German steel empire, has arranged to sell one of its two steel mills and its engineering subsidiary.

title: PARITY IN INSURANCE FOR MEN AND WOMEN
description: The Senate Commerce Committee is scheduled to vote Friday on legislation that would make insurance rates and benefits equal for men and women. The bill and its companion in the House have recently emerged as one of the most hotly contested consumer and civil rights issues in years.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE AFRICAN NATIONAL CONGRESS
description: To the Editor: Mark A. Uhlig's May 31 Op-Ed article, ''South African Violence,'' is an example of the numerous misconceptions concerning the African National Congress and its terror activities.

title: A Decision for Mrs. Scull
description: I n the 60's and early 70's, Ethel and Robert Scull, the art collectors, were known as ''the mom and pop of Pop,'' she in her Halstons and Adolfos, he the man behind the fleet of Sculls' Angels taxis.

title: HIGH SUCCESS IS REPORTED IN TRANSPLANTING EMBRYOS BETWEEN MICE
description: Researchers in Philadelphia have reported achieving a success rate of more than 90 percent in transplanting nuclei from one mouse embryo to the embryo of another mouse of a different breed and color. The technique, they say, has resulted in the birth of 10 mice genetically unrelated to the mothers who delivered them but related to the mothers who produced the original eggs.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE alto saxophonist Jackie McLean doesn't get to New York too often these days, which makes his appearance at Swing Plaza this weekend a major event. Mr. McLean spends most of his time as a teacher and department chairman at the University of Hartford's Hartt School of Music, where he runs the African-American music department and its two-year-old jazz degree program. He's also involved with the Artists Collective, an arts school for children in the north end of Hartford of which he was co-founder (his wife, Dolly, is executive director).

title: HOW AIR TRAFFIC CONTROLLER GUIDED BURNING JETLINER TO SAFE LANDING
description: ''Where's the airport?'' came the radio call from the burning Air Canada jetliner as smoke churned into the cockpit and chances of emergency landing seemed increasingly fragile.

title: THE FAST PACE OF RETAIL SALES
description: Retail sales, which normally begin their summer dip now, are running at the fast pace that has already produced the strongest three-month period in at least two years.

title: U.S.F.L. Signs Kelly
description: Jim Kelly, the quarterback from Miami who was the first-round choice of the Buffalo Bills in the National Football League draft, signed with the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League. The Gamblers, who also signed Kelly's teammate at Miami, Mark Rush, a running back, will begin play next year.

title: I.L.G.W.U. Head Re-elected
description: Sol C. Chaikin has been re-elected president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Jay Mazur has been elected secretary-treasurer. Mr. Mazur succeeds Shelley Appleton, who has retired after 43 years with the union.

title: Pride in the Parks
description: A bout a year ago, Robert D. Santos, Parks Commissioner for the Bronx, got fed up with people's use of some of the borough's parks as dumps for stolen cars, construction wastes and just plain garbage.

title: NUCLEAR UNIT LETS INDIAN PT. PLANTS CONTINUE RUNNING
description: The Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to allow the Indian Point nuclear power plants to continue operating, despite continuing problems with the emergency plan for the surrounding area.

title: TO RESCUE A NORTHWEST POWER SUPPLY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ULSTER PETROLEUMS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HARRY H. HARPER Jr.
description: Harry H. Harper Jr., former executive editor of Reader's Digest, died Monday of Alzheimer's disease at his summer home in Baddeck, Nova Scotia.

title: KOHL BIDS MOSCOW STOP INTIMIDATION
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl warned the Soviet Union today against trying to intimidate West Germany in an effort to prevent the deployment of American medium-range missiles in December. Mr. Kohl also accused the Russians of blocking an agreement on limiting such missiles.

title: A PICK OF BRITAIN'S BEST RAIL JOURNEYS
description: IN case you haven't noticed, 'tis the season of reruns. The first time around may have been more than enough for most, but there are exceptions - the better programs that may have been missed or are even worth catching a second time. One such series, now being rebroadcast on Channel 13 on Friday nights at 9 o'clock is a BBC package titled ''Great Railway Journeys of the World.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Michael Jeffries, who has been in charge of investigating new business opportunities for Federated Department Stores, found a concept that he liked and decided to try it on his own.

title: BALLESTEROS, ZOELLER LEAD BY 1
description: Fuzzy Zoeller's relaxed attitude toward golf is the same on a good day as it is on a bad one despite back pain most of the time. Today was one of his good days as he shot his second straight 68 and shared the lead midway through the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic with Seve Ballesteros of Spain. Both were at 136, six shots under par and one shot ahead of the field.

title: The City; Body Is Found In Central Park
description: The body of a woman who had been stabbed in the chest was found at 11:20 Thursday night in Central Park, near Swan Lake and 60th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, the police said yesterday.

title: Federal Reserve; Wednesday, June 8, 1983
description: R Revised.* Seasonally adjusted.+ Over $100,000.** Excluding acceptances.n.a. Not available.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48. 1. What was the United States's response to the expulsion of three diplomats from Nicaragua? 2. An unusually broad spectrum of religious leaders has formed a coalition seeking to curb (abortion/nuclear warfare/genetic engineering research).

title: BIDDER WANTS SOTHEBY TO BE PRIVATE COMPANY
description: A. Alfred Taubman, who was identified Thursday as the man who plans a takeover bid for Sotheby Parke Bernet, said yesterday that he intended to make a cash offer and, if successful, to run the troubled art auction house as a private company.

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has often said that what the British economy needed to cure its chronic weakness was a second term of Conservative Party government under her leadership. It is about to get just that following the party's crushing victory in Britain's general election on Thursday.

title: U.S. WILL FIGHT PAY-TV MERGER BY FILM STUDIOS
description: The Department of Justice announced yesterday that it would file a civil antitrust suit to block a proposed merger of the second- and third-largest pay-television networks, Showtime and the Movie Channel.

title: DEAN OF U.S. DIPLOMATS BOWING OUT
description: W. Tapley Bennett Jr., the permanent American representative to NATO, has been going through the routine for the 14th and last time this week, shepherding a Secretary of State through the round-the-clock appointments associated with the twice-a-year meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization foreign ministers. In a few weeks, Mr. Bennett, who has the rank of Ambassador, will officially be retiring from the Foreign Service, the last of the prewar breed of diplomats.

title: Snead's Sight Failing
description: At the Masters tournament last April, Sam Snead said it would be his last appearance in the tournament.

title: GEORGE L. WASHINGTON
description: George Leward Washington, who helped establish an Air Force training program for black pilots at Tuskegee Institute in Alabama before World War II, died last Saturday.

title: Delay in San Diego
description: The United States Football League is having a tough time in San Diego, where the City Council is trying to decide if it wants another pro football team in addition to the Chargers of the N.F.L. City officials are concerned that the turf in Jack Murphy Stadium cannot stand up to additional pounding. The stadium is already home to professional baseball, football and soccer and one collegiate sports team. Bill Tatham Jr., whose father is the principal investor in the San Diego franchise, says that if the city continues to delay action, the Tathams will take their team to Tulsa.

title: SECURITIES GROUP DELISTS EAGLE COMPUTER'S STOCK
description: The stock of Eagle Computer Inc. will be deleted from the National Association of Securities Dealers over-the-counter listing following the company's decision to rescind its new offering, the Washingtonbased trade group said yesterday.

title: Texas Stays Unbeaten
description: Mike Brumley hit a grand slam, and Mike Capel pitched a four-hitter to lead top-ranked Texas to a 4-2 College World Series victory over Michigan tonight that eliminated the Wolverines.

title: U.D.C. CHIEF WITHHELD DATA ON CONVENTION SITE TO PANEL
description: The head of the New York State Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that, with his support, consultants to the agency formed to run the city's convention center were refused information that the agency believed would have helped it book conventions.

title: STATE SAYS LEVITT DIVERTED $5 MILLION FROM FAMILY FOUNDATION
description: William J. Levitt, the multimillionaire builder, was accused yesterday of having diverted $5 million from the Levitt Foundation for ''personal use and benefit.'' The foundation was set up by his family in 1949 as a tax-exempt philanthropy.

title: ORIOLES TAKE 5TH STRAIGHT, 3-0
description: Storm Davis pitched a three-hitter, and Gary Roenicke hit his seventh home run as the Baltimore Orioles won their fifth straight with a 3-0 victory tonight over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Your Money; Cutting Cost Of Child Care
description: FAMILIES with child-care or other dependent-care expenses have for years been claiming an income tax credit on their Federal tax returns to reduce this burden. Yet this credit often falls far short of actual costs, even at facilities subsidized by the Government, a non-profit institution or a corporation.

title: The Region; Man Pleads Guilty In Fire Fatal to 6
description: An 18-year-old man standing trial on charges of setting a 1981 tenement fire in which six people died has changed his plea to guilty after hearing his sister admit her role in the blaze.

title: THE MONSTER WE CREATED
description: At least with nuclear power plants you know where they are, so if you're worried about them you can focus your worries geographically. With toxic chemical wastes, which this country keeps generating in ever-larger amounts, no one has solid data on where it's all being generated or on where it's being dumped - and, more crucial, no one appears to know how to get a handle on this nationwide poison problem.

title: WALL OF SAND DEADLOCKS THE WAR IN WEST SAHARA
description: A great wall of sand stretches across the deserts of Western Sahara these days, a rampart 400 miles long encrusted with mine fields and artillery positions. The wall contains and protects the territory's ''useful triangle,'' where Morocco maintains its disputed dominance of its southern neighbor.

title: CHARMION VON WIEGAND, ARTIST
description: Charmion von Wiegand, an abstract artist and journalist who translated the writings of Mondrian and wrote about the Dutch artist, died Thursday in St. Vincent's Hospital. She was about 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title:
Patents;
Race Horse Shoe Adds To Traction and Speed
description: Jimmy L. Sparks of Norco, Calif., has patented a horseshoe for thoroughbreds. Mr. Sparks notes in patent 4,386,660, granted him this week, that typical race horse shoes are lightweight and have a single calk - the part of the shoe at the front end that projects downward to prevent slipping and provide additional traction.

title: The Thatcher Factor
description: Margaret Thatcher's impressive victory will surely be read as a rejection of radicalism and an augury for a Reaganite triumph in 1984. That pours a lot of water into a leaky jug. British voters had to choose between a forceful woman and a feeble opposition, and did so under a system that turns a plurality into a parliamentary landslide. That does not minimize her success, it only narrows its application to American politics.

title: Music of India
description: The sitarist Sharmistha Sen will perform music of North India at the Alternative Museum, 17 White Street, in TriBeCa, tonight at 8 o'clock. Dr. Sen, one of the few female instrumentalists in Indian classical music, is a visiting artist in the school of music at the University of Washington.

title: BONN'S BRIDGE TO SOVIET IS GOING HOME TO SWEDEN
description: The comings and goings of ambassadors are not usually of much moment in Bonn. But a few days ago Sven Backlund left the post he occupied at the Swedish Embassy for more than a decade, depriving West Germany's capital of one of its wittiest aphorists and one of its true insiders.

title: Letter: On Public Power; The U.S., Not Whoops, Needs Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Day by Day
description: White Tornado on 5th Ave.

title: Winter's Tale Wins at Belmont
description: Winter's Tale, the 7-year-old gelding who has frequently been sidelined with injuries, indicated he has recovered by posting a three-length victory in the Nassau County Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: I.B.M. AGREES TO BUY 15% OF ROLM
description: In an apparent move to enter the data communications field more forcefully, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 15 percent of the Rolm Corporation, a telecommunications company based in Santa Clara, Calif., for $228 million in cash.

title: Japan's Trade Chief Resigns
description: Sadanori Yamanaka, head of Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry, has resigned because of problems associated with his diabetes, his office said today.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Long-Distance Returns

title: DAVID M. DARRIN
description: David M. Darrin, senior vice president and treasurer of the Automatic Switch Company of Florham Park, N.J., died of cancer Monday at his home in Roseland, N.J. He was 65 years old.

title: AD FOR JOBS AT HOME CRITICIZED
description: AT first glance it can seem like a golden opportunity for s elf-employment or part-time work at home: ''Be your own boss. Work f rom home. No experience necessary. Over $500 per week possible. No s ales required.'' Such an advertisement ran frequently in some weeklyn ewspapers on Long Island, according to the State Consumer ProtectionB oard.

title: The City; 1,766 End Training And Join the Police
description: The ''class that almost wasn't'' graduated yesterday from the Police Academy, and the 1,510 new officers of the class will be at work Monday.

title:
Patents;
U-Turn Signal for Car Can Rise Above Hood
description: turn indicator light that may be raised above a car's hood and illuminated as a warning to oncoming motorists has been invented by Betty C. Reed of Rockville, Md., who was granted patent 4,387,361 this week.

title: BLACKOUT TIED TO SMALL ANIMAL
description: A small animal may have set off a chain of events that knocked out electrical power for half a million people in Austin and its suburbs, officials said today.

title: AID TO U.S. INQUIRY WINS CUT IN TERM
description: A Federal district judge today reduced the perjury sentence of a former city official who has admitted lying about his role in raising campaign funds for Mayor Kevin H. White.

title: Prison Action Questioned As Suspect Is Hunted
description: An escaped convict now charged with hacking four people to death had been placed in a minimum-security prison despite warnings that he fled a Pennsylvania mental hospital last year and was a high escape risk, the authorities say.

title: Books of the Times; Trying to Help the Self
description: LOST IN THE COSMOS. The Last Self- Help Book. By Walker Percy. 262 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $14.95.

title: News Analysis
description: The Labor Party emerged from Thursday's general election in no condition to offer itself as an alternative government. It must now struggle to remain the principal opposition force, struggle for its very survival.

title: NEWSROOM IS BACKDROP AS NEWSDAY TRIES CABLE
description: It is 7 P.M., and Bob Greene, with pancake makeup visible on the gray hair at the edges of his temples, is rehearsing the script he will deliver as anchorman for a nightly television news program. Behind him, the newsroom of Newsday is suddenly just a backdrop, and its reporters and editors pause for a beat or two as the lights flare up.

title: Action Sought
description: The concern about slow play among professional golfers has spread to the golfers themselves, and the problem touches a sensitive area: the wallet.

title: Furman's Faxon Leads
description: Furman's Brad Faxon took a threestroke lead today going into the final round of the 86th N.C.A.A. golf championships with a five-under-par 211.

title: ELSEWHERE, ANYWHERE, IS NOWHERE. THERE IS HERE.
description: I have a Yankee friend, who is always going somewhere beautiful. He is a collector of Great Places, of national parks and nifty seashores and lofty mountaintops.

title: University Revisions Approved in France
description: The French National Assembly today approved university revisions, proposed by the country's Socialist Government, that led last month to violent protests by students throughout the nation.

title: Coleco Denies Patent Claim
description: Coleco Industries, the Hartford-based company best known for its video game products, denied a claim by a California computer manufacter yesterday that the rights to the name of Coleco's new home computer, Adam, were already owned by another company.

title: CONFEREES SET UP CONTINGENCY FUND
description: House and Senate budget conferees today devised a new strategem of setting up a ''contingency fund'' of up to $10 billion for antirecession programs that have gained support in one chamber but have not yet been enacted.

title: PRESSURE BEING PUT ON BRANIFF HOLDOUTS
description: The creditors who accepted the Hyatt Corporation's offer to restart part of Braniff Airways today began pressuring the remaining holdouts, the secured bondholders, to support the agreement. But the bondholders vowed to fight the plan in court.

title: LITERARY AGENT HELPED JOYCE
description: Jenny Bradley, an internationally known literary agent who assisted the impoverished James Joyce with money and even a table to write on, died on June 3 in Cap d'Antibes in the south of France. She was 97 years old.

title: Harvester France
description: International Harvester France lost 415 million francs, or about $53.9 million, on a turnover of 2.08 billion francs, or about $270 million, in 1982, a company spokesman said.

title: U.S. ENVOY MEETS SANDINISTS AND OPPOSITION IN MANAGUA
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, arrived here this morning for a 24-hour visit and met with the head of the Government and his Foreign Minister.

title: 1 PHOTO, 2 JACKPOTS, 3 PAYOFFS
description: An unemployed Wildwood man who won $1.24 million won a $10,000 jackpot at the same slot machine today while posing for pictures - to the consternation of a woman who had been asked to move to another game.

title: GREYHOUND TO DISPOSE OF ARMOUR
description: The Greyhound Corporation, asserting that the wages it pays its union employees are too high for it to compete in the meatpacking industry, disclosed yesterday that it planned to close down or sell its Armour Food Company subsidiary.

title: Ise Frank Gropius, Archivist Of Bauhaus Founder's Work
description: Ise Frank Gropius, widow of the architect Walter Gropius and an archivist, interpreter and promoter of his work, died Tuesday at the Fairlawn Nursing Home in Lexington, Mass. She was 86 years old and lived in Lincoln, Mass., in a home designed by her husband.

title: DEMAND INCREASES FOR FIRE-SAFE CLOTHING
description: Clothing that can erupt into flames is coming under increasing scrutiny of consumer and fire safety organizations. They say Federal regulations governing the safety of fabrics used in clothing are too weak to protect the people who are most vulnerable: the elderly.

title: About New York; RIDING 2 ROPES TO THE DOUBLE-DUTCH TOP
description: Click-click, click-click, click-click, click-click. The ropes hit the asphalt, the feet go up and down. Two ropes, four girls. The Dynamos are jumping double dutch.

title: BELMONT MAY POINT TO A LEADING COLT
description: Is there a truly special and superior 3-year-old colt this year, or will the usual suspects continue beating one another for the rest of the year? The 115th Belmont Stakes today at Belmont Park figures to provide the answer.

title: Manhattan Bridge Tour
description: The history of the Manhattan Bridge, which dates to 1909, will be included in a tour of lower Manhattan June 26 at 1 P.M., sponsored by the 92d Street Y.

title: METS WIN ON CLOUT IN 17TH
description: Dave Kingman's homer with two out in the 17th inning gave the Mets a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium last night. Kingman, who earlier in the game drove in his first run since May 28, rapped Bryn Smith's 1-2 pitch over the left-field fence, some 375 feet away.

title: CUOMO SAID TO CHOOSE 2 AS MENTAL-HEALTH CHIEFS
description: Governor Cuomo has made his choices for Commissioners of the two state agencies responsible for care of the mentally ill and mentally retarded, aides in the Governor's office said yesterday.

title: BRITAIN'S PREMIER VOWS NOT TO SHIFT TO EXTREMIST LINE
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher promised today that her landslide victory in Thursday's general election, which gave her the largest majority of any British Government since 1945, would not prompt her to impose extreme right-wing policies.

title: Passing a Test In the U.S.F.L.
description: In his first professional game last Sunday, Jojo Townsell of the Los Angeles Express caught a 26-yard touchdown pass to boost his team to a 17-13 victory over the Arizona Wranglers.

title: BALDWIN SEEKS $500 MILLION IN ASSET SALE
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation's new president, Victor H. Palmieri, said yesterday that the company would try to raise $500 million by the end of the year through the sale of subsidiary companies and other assets.

title: Judge Allows GTE Deal
description: Setting aside the objections of a competitor, a Federal judge today authorized the GTE Corporation to consummate its purchase of the long-distance telephone and satellite subsidiaries of the Southern Pacific Company.

title: Genesis and Genetics
description: An important group of Catholic, Protestant and Jewish leaders has called for a ban on introducing inheritable traits into the human gene set. The clerics are right to raise the issue, even though the technology they fear is still far off. They are wrong to utter so far-reaching a proscription on the basis of little argument.

title: ALTERNATIVE POWER GETS A LIFT
description: The run-up in energy prices over the last decade gave a modest competitive lift to the ''soft-path'' energy sources, the group of alternative power devices so named for its gentle impact on the environment. But a Supreme Court decision last month could eventually widen the path into a full-fledged highway.

title: The Region; Court Allows Rise In Auto Insurance
description: A state appeals court ruled today that insurance firms could immediately collect surcharges of up to $33 on the car insurance of all drivers while the New Jersey Insurance Commissioner decides whether to impose the extra fee.

title: Amy Carson Negreann Is Wed to J.F. Stafford
description: Amy Carson Negreann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul S. Negreann of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of the All Souls in Manhattan to John Frederick Stafford, son of Mrs. Frederick M. Stafford of New York and New Orleans and the late Mr. Stafford. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: Australian Visits U.S. Today
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia arrives here Saturday for talks with President Reagan and members of his Administration.

title: Nuclear Weapon Tested
description: United States scientists detonated a nuclear weapon 1,050 feet underground Thursday at Yucca Flat on the Nevada Test Site. Residents in Las Vegas felt no earth motion from the test, 90 miles away.

title:
Patents;
Application Filed in '66 On Satellite Inspection
description: A system for inspecting a satellite in space and transmitting its optical picture by radio waves to a ground station was patented this week for the Navy. The invention was made by Klaus J. Hecker, an electronics engineer, while he was at the Naval Ordnance Laboratory in Corona, Calif.

title: LAWYER'S THEATER TRIP IS A REAL-WORLD LESSON
description: The prosecution's star witness, a Navy psychiatrist named Lundeen, had testified confidently that the commanding officer of the ship, Philip Francis Queeg, was perfectly healthy. Relieving him of command on the basis of any ''mental illness,'' he said, was ''completely unjustified.''

title: New York Day by Day
description: Harlem in Song

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Erica Lehrer Is the Bride Of R.A. Goldman, Lawyer
description: Erica Lehrer, daughter of Mrs. Jesse Shupack of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Sidney Lehrer, was married yesterday to Richard A. Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldman of Baldwin, L.I. Rabbi Richard Jacobs of the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: A RIGHT TO BARE ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATIC GROUP TO STUDY MERIT PAY FOR TEACHERS
description: Congressional Democrats, joining the political fray over education issues, announced today that they were forming a group to examine proposals for merit pay increases for teachers, an idea that is at the heart of President Reagan's new initiatives on education.

title: POLAND WATER SOLUTION
description: I wish President Reagan wouldn't get tough with Central America. I can understand why Central America makes him grind his teeth and feel like climbing the wall. When I had adolescent children they often made me feel the same way. Several times I decided the only solution was to get tough, and I got tough.

title:
Patents;
3 Control Mechanisms For Sikorsky Helicopter
description: Three inventions for the Sikorsky S-76, a commercial helicopter used in offshore drilling operations and as an executive aircraft, were patented this week. The inventors are staff members at the United Technologies Corporation's Sikorsky division in Stratford, Conn.

title: Reagan Guard Helicopter In Near Midair Collision
description: A Minnesota state helicopter patrolling near President Reagan's motorcade and a Western Airlines jet carrying 144 people came within about 300 feet of a collision as the airliner was landing at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport Thursday afternoon.

title: U.S. Missile Truck Crashes
description: A United States Army truck carrying three Hawk missiles flipped over in a crash on a West German highway today, seriously injuring two soldiers.

title: LATE SPRING IN COLORADO: SNOW AND RISING RIVERS
description: Along stretches of Trail Ridge Road, which crests the skyline of the Continental Divide just west of here, the snowdrifts on both sides of the highway form a steep white canyon more than 20 feet deep in some places.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. The United States ordered the expulsion of 21 Nicaraguan consular officials and the closing of all six Nicaraguan consulates in this country.

title: New York Telephone Seeks 2.7% Rate Rise
description: The New York Telephone Company asked the State Public Service Commission today for a special rate increase that would raise bills for residential customers by about 2.7 percent a month.

title: Bridge: Zonal Playoffs Being Held In Grand National Contest
description: Zonal playoffs in the Grand National Team Championship begin today in Cambridge, Mass., and continue tomorrow. New York will be represented by a strong team: Edgar Kaplan, Brian Glubok, John Lowenthal and Phillip Martin, all of New York; Tom Smith, Greenwich, Conn., and Steve Altman, Tenafly, N.J.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET OFFERS HELGI TOMASSON 'ISOLINE'
description: When Helgi Tomasson's ''Ballet d'Isoline'' was performed by the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet last month, it bore the marks of Mr. Tomasson's spirited classicism as a dancer. It was a ballet of parts, though flowing, yet a ballet with an easy, un-Balanchinian look that was remarkable, considering Mr. Tomasson's long years with the company and his relative newness to choreography. Would its move to the City Ballet repertory transform it, as happened with Peter Martins's ''Magic Flute''?

title: BALLET THEATER: TWO DEBUTS IN 'LA SYLPHIDE'
description: ''La Sylphide'' was charming and poignant once again when two talented young dancers made their debuts in its leading roles at the American Ballet Theater's performance Thursday night in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: ASYLUM'S COLD WAR REMNANT
description: Heherson Alvarez and his wife, Cecile, prominent critics of the Marcos regime in the Philippines, in February 1981 reapplied for political asylum in the United States. To date, the Administration has refused to rule on their application. The case is a striking example of the Government's continued refusal to apply fairly the laws governing political asylum.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Caterpillar Tractor Co.'s Towmotor Corp. unit signed a contract with Daewoo Heavy Industries Ltd., Seoul, to manufacture in South Korea lift trucks to be marketed internationally under the Caterpillar trademark.

title: Greek Leader Threatens To Remove U.S. Bases
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said today that he would give the United States 12 to 18 months to remove its military bases from Greece if there was no agreement by the end of next week in talks on the bases' future.

title: 'NO SMOKING' FLIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: An article Wednesday about a report on acid rain incorrectly reported a comment by Carl E. Bagge, president of the National Coal Association. He said the report pointed up the flaws in pending legislation that focused only on sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-fired plants in the Middle West.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LITHOGRAPHS

title: News Analysis
description: There is no comprehensive plan to protect residents of Rockland County from radiation in case of an accident at the Indian Point nuclear plants, across the Hudson in Buchanan, N.Y. But there is a plan to develop a plan, and that is enough, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided Thursday. In the next 30 days, New York State is to map evacuation routes, list the names and telephone numbers of those who would supervise in the event of an accident, identify facilities that would be available for emergency use -everything from airfields to radio links to telephone lines - and attend to dozens of other details. The following 30 days are to be used for training, and then a drill will be held.

title: Grappling With Dioxin
description: When residents of Newark met recently in the Lisbon at Night tavern to learn more about residues of dioxin discovered around an abandoned herbicide plant, the briefer behind the bar was the Governor of New Jersey. Mr. Kean's forthright manner sets the right style for handling such public health scares.

title: BIG CROP FORECAST DESPITE NEW PLAN
description: Even though farmers planted 19 percent less acreage in winter wheat this year in response to a new Federal program aimed at reducing the nation's crushing grain surpluses, record yields are producing another bumper crop.

title: No Loser Here
description: Joe McIlvaine, the director of scouting for the Mets, enjoyed the work of two players in a 6-4, 10-inning victory by Texas over Alabama on Thursday night in the College World Series in Omaha.

title: New York Day by Day
description: Frisbee With Fangs

title: 3 Israeli Soldiers Slain In Ambush in Lebanon
description: Palestinian guerrillas ambushed and killed three Israeli soldiers today in an attack seven miles northeast of the port of Tyre, the Israeli command announced. It was the second fatal strike against the Israeli Army in Lebanon in three days.

title: The Region; Cab Theft Suspect And Officer Shot
description: A Weehawken police officer and a Bronx man were wounded early today as they wrestled for the officer's revolver during an attempt by the man to steal a taxicab, authorities said.

title: 9 FINED FOR GARBAGE MONOPOLY
description: A Superior Court judge today imposed nearly $100,000 in fines on nine defendants who had pleaded guilty to conspiring to limit competition in the commercial wastehauling business.

title: William M. Tuck, 86; Ex-Virginia Governor
description: Former Gov. William M. Tuck of Virginia, the architect of the state's law prohibiting contracts that require employees to join a union after being hired, died Thursday after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: MEMORIES OF SECRETARIAT IN 1973
description: T en years after Secretariat's most awesome race, the Belmont barns look the same and the chickens cluck the same and the steam still rises from a pail of hot water set beside a perspiring horse.

title: The City; Schools Enter Pact On Handicapped
description: The New York City school system agreed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to hire 600 new psychologists, social workers or educational evaluators as part of an effort to provide physically and mentally handicapped students with special-education services.

title: WHY TAX INDEXING MUST NOT BE KILLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There will be some changes. I am not a good butcher, but I've had to learn to carve the joint.

title: Howe on Road Back
description: After undergoing two weeks of rehabilitation for cocaine abuse, Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodger reliever, is almost ready to resume pitching. According to his agent, Tony Attanasio, Howe, who was admitted to the Care Unit in Orange County, Calif., last month, is ''coming along well and so strong'' that he has asked doctors at the facility to modify his treatment so that he could return to the team by June 19. Before checking into the center, Howe had 7 saves and had not allowed an earned run in 22 innings this season.

title: U.S. to Aid Drought Victims
description: The United States will send $25 million in emergency food aid to drought-stricken countries in southern Africa, the State Department said today.

title: UNREPAIRED CAR DERAILED TRAIN AT IND STATION
description: The Queens-bound subway train that derailed in Manhattan Monday night had been pulled out of service the previous day because of a serious malfunction and then put back on the tracks with the problem uncorrected, the Transit Authority said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: In some editions of Business Day on Thursday, an article and a headline misstated the Senate vote to increase the United States' contribution to the International Monetary Fund. It was 55 to 34.

title: LIAO CHENGZHI, 75, A CHINESE LEADER
description: Liao Chengzhi, the Communist Party's specialist on Taiwan and the chief negotiator in talks with Britain on the future of Hong Kong, died of a heart attack today, a week before he was expected to be elected Vice President of China. He was 75 years old.

title: Pakistani Visits Soviet As Afghan Talks Near
description: Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today, Tass reported. United Nations-sponsored talks between Pakistan and Afghanistan are scheduled to resume next week.

title: TV: A U.S. DOCTOR TELLS OF EL SALVADOR
description: The best witness is a disinterested witness, testifying without embroidery or interpretation, addressing himself only to what he knows really happened. Dr. Charles Clements, an American physician who spent a year ministering to insurgents in El Salvador, appears to be this kind of witness. If he has a hidden agenda, it is not obvious. If he is speaking from hearsay, it is not apparent. He is interviewed on the ''David Susskind Show'' on Channel 5 tomorrow night at 11:30.

title: FOREIGN MINISTERS OF NATO REAFFIRM PLANS FOR MISSILES
description: Foreign ministers of the Atlantic alliance, meeting for the last time before NATO's planned deployment of new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe, asserted again today that they would start to deploy the weapons by the end of the year unless the Soviet Union and the United States agreed on an accord to limit medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: MAKING A DISH FIT THE SETTING
