description: The style and surroundings in which food is served are now getting much needed attention. The garnishing of dishes and the esthetic importance of the dining-room decor and tableware are seriously considered by chefs and home cooks alike. But one aspect that still seems neglected has to do with the scale of a particular dish in relation to its surroundings.

title: Louisiana Man Killed In Shootout With Police
description: An armed man who told fellow workers at a charity hospital that he killed two people earlier in the day was slain today in a gunfight with the police outside the hospital. Two bodies were later found.

title: SMALL RISE IN MONEY SUPPLY
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a smaller-than-expected increase of $100 million in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended June 1. This prompted a drop in interest rates in the credit markets.

title: MARTIN IS OPTIMISTIC ON VOLCKER
description: Preston Martin, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, ''has a very good chance of reappointment.''

title: The City; 3 Seized in Search For Stolen Cheese
description: The police yesterday arrested three men and seized 4,445 pounds of stolen Government-donated cheese that was supposed to have been given to the poor.

title: VIRGINIA, THEN BELGRADE
description: To take issue with the Williamsburg Declaration on Economic Recovery would be tantamount to taking issue with motherhood. There is clearly much in it to please everyone. The longest paragraph is devoted to the developing countries. No longer are their problems to be resolved simply through further belt-tightening. On the contrary, the summiteers acknowledged their own responsibility to take the fiscal and monetary steps necessary to provide a better climate for third-world economic growth.

title: Spurs Select McHone
description: For the last four years, Morris McHone worked as an assistant under Stan Albeck - one season with the Cleveland Cavaliers and the last three seasons with the San Antonio Spurs. Now Albeck has shifted to the New Jersey Nets, but instead of following him again, McHone is staying put and moving up, to be head coach of the Spurs. ''I'm confident we can go places,'' said the 39-year-old McHone.

title: LEADERSHIP CONFLICT JUST ONE PROBLEM FACING N.A.A.C.P. AT MEETING TODAY
description: When board members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People meet in Chicago today, they will be faced with the immediate problem of resolving a conflict between their chairman and executive director. But looming in the background are other longstanding, deep-seated difficulties that some members say have been exacerbated by the public clash of personalities and powers between the two top officials.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JUNE 11, 1983
description: International Extreme right-wing policies will not be imposed in the wake of the Conservatives' landslide victory in Britain's general election Thursday, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said. In a series of television interviews, she said her ''new look'' Cabinet, which is to be announced today, would ''reflect the whole spectrum of views in the party.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Two major meetings in Moscow scheduled by the Communist Party's Central Committee next week are expected to throw light on key questions: how much power has been amassed by Yuri V. Andropov in the seven months since he became Communist Party leader, and whether he can use it to shake up a sluggish economy. (1:3.)

title: Writers Honor Bloom
description: The American Society of Journalists and Authors, an organization representing freelance writers, has given its annual service award to Murray Teigh Bloom, one of its founding members and a former president. He was cited for his work as chairman of the editor-writer relations committee, which has arbitrated disputes between authors and agents, editors and publishers. The organization was originally known as the Society of Magazine Writers.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Scott Holman (1-3) will pitch for the Mets against Randy Lerch (0-0). (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050 7:35 P.M.) Yankees vs. Brewers, at Milwaukee. Ron Guidry (8-3), with two victories in his last two starts, will be seeking his fourth shutout of the season. (Channel 11, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8:30 P.M.) College World Series, at Omaha. Texas is assured a berth in what could be the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I championship game of the double-elimination event if the Longhorns win it. (Television - ESPN 8 P.M.) Golf Ladies P.G.A. Championships, at Jack Nicklaus Sports Center, Kings Island, Ohio, third round (Television - Channel 4, 5 P.M.).

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on June 3 about a Frisbee team at the Bronx High School of Science misquoted a student, Simon Yi, on the nature of the Frisbee's flight. He had explained correctly that because of the Frisbee's shape, air moves faster over the top than under the bottom. That creates lower pressure on the top, and the difference in air pressure keeps the Frisbee aloft.

title: WHAT BRYANT PARK CAN DO WITHOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: Not Very Frank

title: SHIPYARD IS SOLD BY BETHLEHEM STEEL
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation today announced the sale of its huge Key Highway shipyard to Swirnow Companies Joint Venture, a move that could reopen the yard and create hundreds of new jobs. The price of the transaction was not disclosed.

title: CLINTON HIGH TO ADMIT GIRLS IN BID TO SURVIVE
description: The rumor that the school would close began circulating last fall, after the enrollment at DeWitt Clinton High School dropped by 700 in a single year. Clinton's enrollment has dwindled along with its reputation, and what was the city's largest school a decade ago with 6,300 students now attracts only 2,300.

title: 2d Coke Plant in China
description: The Coca-Cola Company said today that China had opened its second Coca-Cola soft drink plant, in Canton.

title: 16 MAY GET A DONOR'S ORGANS
description: At least 16 people will receive transplants from a youth who was killed as he drove from a party celebrating his 18th birthday, doctors said today.

title: ANTIQUE LACE IN MODERN DRESS
description: ''It's an incredible collection,'' said Connie Cook, one of New York's top fashion models. ''I'm dying to have the see-through dress. And I'm usually the tailored type.''

title: Vietnam Hero Faces Death
description: Larry Webster, a Vietnam War hero who turned to alcohol and drugs, has been sentenced to die in the gas chamber for murder.

title: Beech Job Cuts
description: The Beech Aircraft Corporation, Wichita, Kan., said it would lay off 750 people within the next week and temporarily shut down 15 of its 225 departments between July 11 and the end of the year.

title: NORTH-SOUTH RIFT OF PRESBYTERIANS HEALED BY MERGER
description: A new church for the nation's more than three million Presbyterians was created here today, ending a North-South split that dated from the Civil War.

title: Nigerian Debt Plan
description: Twenty-four banks have accepted an offer to consolidate Nigeria's short-term debt into a three-year facility, a spokesman for Barclays Bank International said today.

title: 10% OF U.S. ELDERLY HAVE PROBLEM WITH ALCOHOL, CONGRESSMEN TOLD
description: Loneliness, idleness, poverty and neglect contribute to problem drinking among at least 10 percent of the elderly population of this country, a Congressional hearing on ''Alcoholism and the Elderly'' was told yesterday.

title: MANVILLE H. ABRAMSON
description: Manville H. Abramson, a lawyer who was co-founder of a Manhattan realty investment and management concern, died Wednesday at St. Mary's Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., after a long illness.

title: 2-Round Record Broken
description: Alexandra Reinhardt shot a 68 today for a two-round total of 135, the lowest 36-hole total in the 29 years of the tournament, and took a four-stroke lead in the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Championship.

title: CLUES TO TRUE POWER OF ANDROPOV ARE EXPECTED AT MOSCOW MEETINGS
description: Two meetings of the Soviet leadership here next week are expected to throw light on key questions that have arisen about the health of Yuri V. Andropov and his hold on power in the seven months since he became leader of the Communist Party.

title: PLAN FOR A 'SENTENCING SYSTEM THAT MAKES SENSE'
description: To the Editor:

title: New York Day by Day
description: Koch Names a Press Aide

title: Mets' Top Choice Helps Texas Win
description: Calvin Schiraldi, a junior right-hander who was selected by the Mets on the first round of the baseball draft Monday, pitched the final five and one-third innings Thursday night in leading Texas to a 6-4 victory over Alabama in 10 innings at the College World Series.

title: Bill to Outlaw Sex Bias In Insurance Is Delayed
description: Legislation that would prohibit setting insurance rates on the basis of sex was postponed for at least two months today by the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: NEW YORK'S OPPORTUNITY TO PIONEER CIGARETTE FIRE SAFETY
description: To the Editor:

title: BASKETBALL TO RESUME AT U.S.F. IN 1985
description: The University of San Francisco, which dropped its troubled men's basketball program last summer, will resume playing basketball in the 1985-86 season, the school's board of trustees said today.

title: Train Crash in Egypt Kills 22
description: A speeding train slammed into the rear of a stationary train 30 miles south of here today, killing 22 people and injuring 46, the police said. It was the second Egyptian railway disaster in less than two weeks. On May 30, 12 people were killed and 40 were injured when a train heading for Cairo derailed and was struck by another train.

title: CONVICT IS SENTENCED TO DEATH FOR MURDER OF A PRISON GUARD
description: A convict who has spent 25 of his 41 years in prison was sentenced today to die in the electric chair for the murder of a corrections officer.

title: A Long Journey
description: Mike Lashchev, the newest member of the New York Arrows, came from the Soviet Union to the United States through Vienna and Rome in 1979.

title: U.S. CHIDES SOVIET ON ARMS ISSUE
description: The White House criticized the Soviet Union today for replying publicly, through its press agency, to President Reagan's latest nuclear arms reduction proposal and said the Administration would not negotiate through the press.

title: Leading Civil Rights Official To Check Mississippi Cases
description: The Reagan Administration's chief civil rights official agreed today to go to Mississippi next week to look into complaints of voting rights violations made by the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson.

title: AT MISSISSIPPI HOMECOMING, B.B. KING UNITES NEIGHBORS
description: B.B. King, the blues singer and guitarist, came home to Indianola this weekend, and blacks and whites celebrated the occasion together.

title: Piper Jaffray Bid By Hartford Gains
description: The Hartford Fire Insurance Company announced that it has completed the first part of its plan to acquire a 25 percent share of Piper Jaffray Inc., a regional securities firm based in Minneapolis.

title: RETAIL SALES UP 2.1% IN MAY
description: The nation's retail sales rose 2.1 percent in May, led by strength in the auto industry and the biggest monthly gain in nearly six years for department stores and other general merchandise outlets, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT UPHOLDS AGREEMENT ON CAROLINA SCHOOLS
description: A sharply divided Federal appeals court today rejected an effort by civil rights lawyers to overturn the Reagan Administration's settlement of a dispute over desegregation of North Carolina colleges.

title: Montgomery Council Told to Redraw Districts
description: A Federal district judge today struck down the City Council's reapportionment plan. Judge Myron Thompson said the plan violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act by reducing the number of black voters in the district represented by a black Councilman, Joe Reed, the chief political rival of Mayor Emory Folmar, who is white.

title: Brokerage Net Rises Sharply
description: Heavy volume and a rising market led to large profits in the first quarter for the 393 member firms of the New York Stock Exchange that do business with the public.

title: Producer Prices Up 0.3%; Rise in May First for '83
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, which often indicates the direction of retail prices two or three months later, rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the first rise this year, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Dow Rises by 7.11; Volume Is Lighter
description: Stock prices ended moderately higher yesterday after plunging earlier this week because of concern over rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 7.11 points to 1,196.11. For the week, the key indicator, which is the average of the prices of 30 leading stocks, fell 16.93 points.

title: 4,500 SALVADORAN TROOPS PREPARE FOR MAJOR FIGHT
description: More than 4,500 Salvadoran troops have gathered in this rich agricultural province for the start of a major military and political offensive that one American adviser called ''El Salvador's last chance.''

title: Appeals Court Backs White Chicago Aldermen
description: An Illinois appeals court, voting 2 to 1, today upheld a lower court ruling that leaves control of the Chicago City Council in the hands of a bloc of white aldermen who wrested it from Mayor Harold Washington and his supporters shortly after the April mayoral election.

title: NO INJURIES IMMEDIATELY REPORTED
description: A strong earthquake rolled through Coalinga and the surrounding countryside just after dusk today, destroying an occupied house, knocking over trailers and splitting roadways, officials said.

title: J.T. TURNER ADOPTS NEW ROLE FOR A FILM
description: F or all the dozens of hours J.T. Turner has spent in darkened rooms, watching himself on a movie screen, he had never seen anything like this. Film study has been part of his job for six seasons with the Giants and the years before that as a player at Duke. For the last five years, Turner has been a starting offensive guard. He studies himself and listens to others evaluate his success and failure on each play, a process that will begin again when he reports to training camp next month.

title: North Sea Oilfield
description: Norsk Hydro has determined that the Oseberg oil and gas field in the North Sea is commercial and that production could begin in 1990, Torvild Aakvaag, the company's managing director, said today.

title: DANCE: GRAHAM COMPANY AND DANCE SHARE THE STAGE
description: The Martha Graham Dance Company and members of the Royal Danish Ballet made their only New York appearances of the season when they shared a performance Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall. The occasion was a benefit arranged by the Danish American Society for the establishment of an exchange scholarship program for Danish and American students of the performing arts.

title: STATE DEMOCRATS APPROVE A PLAN FOR '84 PRIMARY
description: The Democratic State Committee today approved a plan to select national convention delegates in a primary next May 22 that includes a statewide preferential vote for the candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Yonkers Trot Tonight
description: The first female trainer of a horse in the 29-year history of the Yonkers Trot, the first leg of the triple crown series, will be on hand tonight at

title: WHAT BRYANT PARK CAN DO WITHOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Todd Blackledge, the quarterback who led Penn State to No. 1 college football ranking last season, has signed a series of four one-year contracts with the Kansas City Chiefs. ... Terry Bradshaw, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback who is entering his 13th professional season, says he expects to play ''at least'' another five years. ''I don't even like hearing the word 'retirement.' '' he said. ... The World Boxing Council has warned that Larry Holmes must sign within a month to defend his heavyweight title against Greg Page or risk being stripped of his crown. The W.B.C. also reiterated its warning to the middleweight champion, Marvelous Marvin Hagler, who is balking over its new 12-round limit in title fights, and it threatened the title of the superfeatherweight champion, Bobby Chacon, unless he signs within a week to meet Hector Camacho. ... The Pittsburgh Pirates have reactivated Don Robinson, the right-handed pitcher who had been out since March 29 because of an inflamed shoulder. ... Chris Ford, a former guard with the team, has been named assistant coach by the Boston Celtics.

title: CZECHS QUIT WORLD PSYCHIATRIC ASSOCIATION
description: The Czechoslovak Psychiatric Society has joined its counterpart in the Soviet Union in withdrawing from the World Psychiatric Association.

title: Garvey Goes Home
description: Making his anticipated leap into public office, Ed Garvey, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, told a news conference in Madison, Wis., that his career had come full circle. The 43-year-old lawyer, a native of Burlington, Wis., who attended the University of Wisconsin for undergraduate studies and law school, will earn approximately $65,000 a year, roughly half what he was paid by the players association.

title:
Patents;
Portable Bar-Code Scanner
description: HELD instrument, regarded as important in the growing commercial practice of sorting consumer goods with bar-code laser scanners, was patented this week for its manufacturer, Symbol Technologies Inc. of Hauppauge, L.I. The device weighs only a pound and can be plugged into electronic cash registers.

title: LINK SEEN AMONG HEAVILY ARMED RIGHTIST GROUPS
description: The Federal authorities investigating the gun battles that led to the death of the tax protester Gordon W. Kahl say they are uncovering troubling links among small groups of heavily armed right-wing extremists. The ties cut across organizational lines from the Nazi Party and the Ku Klux Klan to radical elements of the farm protest movement.

title: Balinese Anniversary Dance
description: The Islene Pinder Balinese American Dance Theater, which draws from the traditions of Bali and modern dance, observes its fifth anniversary with the first of five performances tonight at 8 in its theater at 88 Franklin Street in TriBeCa.

title: RAWLEY AND YANKS DEFEAT BREWERS, 7-1
description: Billy Martin doesn't like to call it a new combination, but by any name it seems to be working for the Yankees. With Ken Griffey starring in center field and Andre Robertson at shortstop, the Yankees tonight routed the stumbling Brewers by 7-1. It marked the fourth straight game Griffey started in center after being moved from first base, and it marked the fourth straight game Robertson was at short. The Yankees have won three of those games.

title: S.E.C. PANEL URGES TAKEOVER CURBS
description: A special panel of the Securities and Exchange Commission that has been studying corporate takeover regulations today endorsed a package of revisions that includes possible curbs on surprise takeover bids.

title: ANDERSON OUTLINES PLAN FOR 3D PARTY
description: John B. Anderson, who won 5.7 million votes for President in 1980, said today that he would not run again as an independent candidate but was forming a new political party that would take ''risks for peace'' in East-West relations and strive for ''pay-as-you-go-government'' at home.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; 'Clean Up the Dumps'
description: The retiring president of the Chemical Manufacturers Association sounded a novel note from his section of the orchestra last week, saying public fear of chemicals was the industry's major problem and that companies themselves must ''clean up the dumps.'' At a man-made hazard near Minneapolis, which is No.1 on the Environmental Protection Agency's list of 418 most dangerous waste dumps, the owner has obtained Government approval to do just that.

title: PLANNERS CITE PRESERVATION EFFORTS
description: A SAUSAGE factory has been turned into an office building, a stormwindow factory has been turned into a waterfront restaurant, a vaudeville theater has been restored to its former glory and a rundown shopping area has been brightened and renovated.

title: Costly 'Break'
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. C. E. Walker from the American Council for Capital Formation lobby (''Letters,'' May 29) is all for reducing taxes for the wealthy, claiming this will provide capital to help finance the Federal deficit.

title: ITALIAN-AMERICANS: MAKING IT
description: Who should be considered as part of the Italian-American group? This issue goes to the heart of contentions about ethnic diversity in our own society, and it arises because the educational and occupational achievements, properly celebrated in Stephen Hall's article, have been accompanied, whether as cause, effect, or a mixture of both, by a flood tide of assimilation. This assimilation is most clearly reflected in the sharp rise in the rate of marriage between Italians and non-Italians.

title: U.S. SEEN CURBING HELP FOR HOMELESS
description: State officials say new rules established by the Reagan Administration severely restrict the use of money appropriated by Congress for providing food and shelter to homeless people.

title: A PAPAL VISIT SPELLS HOPE FOR ALL POLES
description: To the Editor:

title: AT THE BEACH IN BRITTANY EN FAMILLE
description: DAVID A. ANDELMAN is Paris correspondent for CBS News.

title: No Headline
description: Miller Barber shot a 70 today for a 6-under-par total of 210 and a 1-stroke lead over Gene Littler in the Senior Tournament Players Championship at the Canterbury Golf Club.

title: BOOK REVIVES A DEBATE ON PRESIDENTIAL POWER
description: Within hours after the attempt to assassinate President Reagan two years ago, his senior aides considered transferring Presidential authority to the Vice President without consulting the Cabinet.

title: PHILHARMONIC: FESTIVAL OF MODERNS
description: The trouble with ''theme'' concerts, indeed with ''theme'' series,'' is that we tend to become sidetracked by their basic premises. As most of us know by now, the premise of the New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' contemporary music festival is that a new Romanticism now fills our musical life. This seven-concert series is attempting to reflect it.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
U.S. MEDAL IS PLANNED FOR INTERNATIONAL SHOW
description: An unusual fine-art medal will be issued this year to recognize United States participation in the 19th worldwide congress of the Federation Internationale de la Medaille (FIDEM). The medal is intended to focus world attention on the healthy state of American medallic art, and to attract donations which can be used to help defray the expenses of the U.S. delegation.

title: APHRODITE'S DIVIDED ISLE
description: MARVINE HOWE is chief of the Athens bureau of The Times.

title: THE AGENDA FOR THE AMERICA'S CUP
description: The three United States yachts seeking to defend the America's Cup and the seven foreign yachts vying for the challenger's role will hold separate elimination races off Newport, R.I., throughout the summer. The defender and the challenger must be named by midnight Sept.8. They will meet in the America's Cup races, a four-of-seven series, starting Sept. 13.

title: Lisa Huber Weds W.B. Goodspeed, Michigan Lawyer
description: Lisa Marshall Huber, daughter of Mrs. Robert C. Stanley Jr. of Middletown, N.J., and Hans Anthony Huber of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to William Brooks Goodspeed, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillip W. Goodspeed of Grand Rapids, Mich. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title: Dr. Frances E. Jensen Marries in Connecticut
description: Dr. Frances Elizabeth Jensen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Bailey Jensen of Sharon, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dr. Stephen Barry Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Harrington Murphy of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church.

title: Ellen W. Seely, Physician, Wed
description: Dr. Ellen Wells Seely, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Seely of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan David Strongin, son of Thelma Strongin of St. Petersburg, Fla., formerly of Kingston, N.Y., and the late Jack H. Strongin. Rabbi David J. Seligson performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: FEDERALS 18, WRANGLERS 11
description: Craig James and Billy Taylor both scored touchdowns and Sandro Vitiello kicked a 48-yard field goal as the Washington Federals rallied for 18 second-half points to beat the Arizona Wranglers, 18-11, in a U.S.F.L. game tonight.

title: Jane Blum, G.A. Burdett Are Married
description: Jane Wilder Blum, daughter of John Robert Halsey Blum of New York and Lakeville, Conn., and the late Susanne Delatour Blum, was married yesterday in Lakeville to Gregg Alexander Burdett, son of Richard Alan Burdett of Milton, Mass., and the late Muriel Evelyn Burdett. The Rev. F. Gold-thwaite Sherrill performed the Episcopal ceremony in the chapel of the Hotchkiss School.

title: TAPPING THE SECURITY MARKET
description: GREENWICH THE chairman's name is Ransom. No one, John S. Ransom said, has ever remarked on the irony. That seems a bit surprising, since Mr. Ransom is in the business of storing people's riches. He is the chairman, chief executive officer and co-owner of the Vault, a security vault that opened here last week.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Coming Together Of Presbyterians
description: The two branches of the Presbyterian Church formally agreed last week that the issues separating them since 1861 need no longer keep them apart. In ceremonies in Atlanta, the denomination's Northern and Southern wings merged, becoming the nation's fourth largest Protestant church.

title: JUDGES' REASONING ON CASINO UNIONS
description: PHILADELPHIA SECTION 7 of the National Labor Relations Act guarantees employees the right to ''bargain collectively through representatives of their own choosing.''

title: 'HELPING' ALCOHOLICS CAN BE FATAL
description: agers, his room is an area not likely to be visited by other family members. Even if one could find an obstacle-free pathway to enter, the gymnasium-like aroma does not encourage one to linger.

title: OUTSIDER SHOWS FAITH IN NEWARK
description: LAST January, Sol Gillman, a New York developer, read in a newspapert hat the Griffith Building in Newark was for sale. The following day - a Saturday- he and his wife, Gloria, drove into Newark for the f irst time since before the 1967 riots and inspected the 17-story b uilding at 605-607 Broad Street in the heart of the central businessd istrict.

title: THE FIRST WASHINGTON: A CAPITAL PLACE
description: The District of Columbia's Washington considers itself the grandest Washington of them all, the 192-year-old epicenter of the United States and the custodian of its heritage and treasures.

title: Paris Armored Car Hijacked By Bandits in Police Uniforms
description: Three bandits dressed as policemen hijacked an armored car this morning and stole more than $80,000 in French currency, the police said.

title: Mailbox; 'Americanizing' Soccer Is Wrong
description: To the Sports Editor: Tim Schum is to be congratulated on his article ''The U.S. World Cup Bid Had Some Serious Failings'' (The New York Times, May 29). I would like to add a few thoughts.

title: KOCH SEEKS TO REVISE CONSTRUCTION BIDDING LAW TO CUT COSTS
description: New York City officials are negotiating with legislative leaders for changes in a construction bidding law that the city says could cut public building costs here $40 million to $70 million yearly.

title: HOW TO GET ALONG WITH A LADDER ON THOSE HIGH-UP JOBS
description: WORKING around the outside of the house at this time of year often involves a number of ''second-story'' jobs (painting, cleaning gutters, making minor roof repairs, etc.) that call for the use of a tall ladder - usually a two-piece extension ladder that will be leaning up against the house wall while you are working on it.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FUNGI THAT LOOM IN THE SPRING
description: THIS has been a strange spring. The first things to flower were exceptionally early, as a result of an unusually warm late winter. Later on, cool, cloudy, humid conditions delayed flowering of those plants next in line. Still later, the season seemed to telescope, with many plants that would not normally bloom together doing so.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ASIAN MUSIC As part of a Spring Festival of Indian Music, the Alternative Museum is hosting two concerts this week that will provide an opportunity to compare the different northern and southern Indian musical styles. The music of the north comes out of the Muslim tradition, and has mostly been associated with the courts.

title: CONNORS AND MCENROE ADVANCE TO FINAL
description: Jimmy Connors and John McEnroe will meet Sunday in the final of the $203,000 Queen's Plate Grand Prix tennis tournament, the last major grass-court tuneup before Wimbledon.

title: 2 NEW GUIDES OFFER ADVICE ON MEN'S WEAR
description: To judge from the number of fashion books published yearly that instruct men on everything from buying clothes to tying a shoelace, American men have never learned how to dress themselves. The truth, of course, is that many of them haven't, for the simple reason that they have been dressed for most of their lives by someone else, usually mothers and wives. Another truth is that many books on this subject are not worth the paper they're printed on, with pretty pictures and florid prose often taking the place of the hard, cold facts.

title: Air Controllers Strike At Ireland's Airports
description: A one-day strike by air traffic controllers shut Ireland's three main airports today and stranded thousands of travelers.

title: A DARING DEALMAKER PILES UP PROFITS
description: THERE'S a sign that hangs outside the trading room at Bear, Stearns & Company - a cavernous, darkened room populated by rumpled traders, jangling telephones and dozens of computerized screens that command the attention of all. The sign reads: ''Let's make nothing but money.''

title:
ART;
DRAWING AND SCULPTURE: A MIXED, BUT WORKABLE BAG
description: CLINTON DRAWING and sculpture are usually perceived as being at opposite ends of a spectrum. Elaborating on this truism, a drawing may be a first thought, while a sculpture is the culmination of a laboriously worked-out idea. A drawing can be casual in execution, while the materials that have traditionally gone into sculpture are too dear to be utilized with less than great care.

title: 10 Solidarity Activists Arrested, Poland Says
description: Security forces have arrested 10 underground activists of the banned Solidarity trade union in the southern city of Cracow, Polish television reported tonight.

title: BEING SERIOUSLY FUNNY
description: Ben Yagoda is articles editor of Philadelphia Magazine.

title: The Region in Summary; Small Step Is A Major Move
description: Another legislative plan to combine and streamline New York State's major courts? That is nothing new in Albany, where several such plans have been drawn - and quartered -in recent few years. Nevertheless, bar association officials and others advocating court reform were more optimistic than usual last week, because the latest proposal originated in the State Senate, where court merger talk has regularly been rebuffed.

title: Port Wine's English Accent
description: I read with interest Rob Roy Buckingham's article ''Port Wine's English Accent'' (May 15). Although Mr. Buckingham's account of the Port wine establishment in Oporto is written in terms that, if anything, enhance the prestige of an industry of which Portugal is justly proud, it overlooks its national quality. Mr. Buckingham seems to suggest that without the highly professional standards of the English Oporto families, whose names have been linked for centuries (but, by no means exclusively) with the production and marketing of Port wines, these wines would not have become what they are.

title: Cynthia Olney Is Wed to James Knight
description: Cynthia Forbes Olney, a research associate at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration, was married yesterday to James Atwood Knight, who is studying for his M.B.A. at Dartmouth. The ceremony was performed at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston by the Rev. Edward O. Miller Jr., assisted by the Rev. Leonard A. Schnider of New York.

title: CUOMO KEEPING HIS DISTANCE FROM LIBERAL PARTY'S TURMOIL
description: Five months after he took office with the support of the Liberal Party, Governor Cuomo has still not appointed any Liberals to major state posts or taken sides in the leadership struggle that has divided the party.

title: Moore And Jay In Final
description: Moore Catholic High School of Staten Island will face John Jay of Brooklyn for the city baseball title tomorrow at Yankee Stadium. The game, starting at 11 A.M., will match Moore's defense against Jay's speed and power. It will be followed by an all-star game at 2 P.M.

title: Marty Pansey Marries In Princeton Ceremony
description: Martha Joan Pansey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin W. Pansey of Pawtucket, R. I., and Brewster, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael Pratt, son of Mrs. Everett H. Pratt of Covington, Ga., and the late Mr. Pratt.

title: Matter of Protocol
description: To the Business Editor: ''A Baedeker to Banks and Boutiques in Europe'' (May 29) was very enjoyable but perhaps a little misleading with respect to the ''slighting'' of Mr. Volcker at the table of the King of Belgium during the International Monetary Conference luncheon. The King had expressed considerable interest in the I.M.C. several months in advance. In fact, he requested biographies of the various speakers and upon my arrival in Belgium more than a week in advance of the conference his aides requested a complete briefing script from me with respect to each session, the objectives and what each speaker might be expected to contribute to that session.

title: 19 Are Hurt as Airliner Catches Fire in Chicago
description: An engine of a United Airlines 727 caught fire today as the jet was taking off from O'Hare International Airport, forcing the evacuation of 148 people and slightly injuring 19, the police said.

title: A USTINOV COMEDY, PLUS A 20'S SPOOF; BY BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes frequently about the theater. LONDON They must both have seemed refreshingly good ideas to West End management worried by economic recession, fickle audiences and the current shortage of promising new products. A comedy by Peter Ustinov postulating the return of Beethoven to earth, with the author himself in the role of the curmudgeonly maestro. A stage version of the hit movie ''Bugsy Malone,'' with 50 real-life moppets embodying the speakeasy culture of 1929. Unluckily, however, the critical reception of each has been less than rapturous.

title: Stahr Takes 1,600 in Meet-Record Time
description: Mike Stahr closed out his New York State schoolboy career today in his usual style, by winning. The Carmel senior successfully defended his 1,600-meter title in a meetrecord time of 4 minutes 6.15 seconds at the State Interscholastic Outdoor Track and Field Championships in this suburb of Syracuse.

title: IN AUDUBON'S KENTUCKY
description: ROBERT MEYERS is a writer who lives in Alexandria, Va.

title: GRADUATES' NEXT CHALLENGES: STRIFE AMONG NATIONS, STRIFE AMONG PEOPLE
description: In this season of commencement addresses at colleges and universities around the nation the topics have ranged from the threat of nuclear war to the relationships between men and women. Here is a sampling from the current talks to graduating classes. Chaim Potok

title: Andrea Resnick Becomes The Bride of John Brandt
description: Andrea Lee Resnick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Resnick of Woodmere, L.I., was married in Manhattan last night to John Brandt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Brandt of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony at the Pierre.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: JOBS are Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan's department. Jobs are also the business of the Technical Training Project (T.T.P.), a 15-year-old private industry-sponsored technical school in Newark.

title: TESTIMONY DETAILS KANSAS CITY UNDERWORLD'S CONTROL OF A LAS VEGAS CASINO
description: A story of secret criminal control of a Las Vegas casino, providing new details about underworld involvement in Nevada gambling, is unfolding in Federal District Court here.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: A Visual Variety Pack A funny thing happened to cartoon books on the way to 1983. They were published in record-breaking numbers. According to the Cartoonists Guild, 143 of them appeared last year. That total represents a rise of 20 percent over 1981's output and nearly 300 percent over 1980's. The Guild also reports that 20 cartoon titles became best sellers in trade paperback during 1982, two made the hard-cover nonfiction list, and seven were book-club selections.

title: ECONOMIC RECOVERY ISN'T HELPING CITIES, MAYORS' CHIEF SAYS
description: Despite signs that the national economy is on the mend, the president of the United States Conference of Mayors said today that most American cities were in worse shape now than they were a year ago.

title:
INDUSTRIAL POLICY - A MISGUIDED DEBATE;
TOO LITTLE FOCUS ON THE BUSINESS CYCLE
description: ALTHOUGH some brave souls are rushing forward with rather o nedimensional solutions to our industrial problems, in fact, we haven ot yet sorted out the causes for the deterioriation.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FROM his vantage point at the bottom of South Highland Avenue in Ossining, 58-year-old George Shutt squinted through last Sunday's brilliant afternoon sun toward the starting gate at the top of the hill. He was on the finish line, grasping the large checkered flag in his two hands, waiting for his 15-year-old grandson, Timmy Byrnes of Peekskill, to join him in the ranks of Soap Box Derby champions. Forty-six years ago, Mr. Shutt had exploded down a hill in Peekskill and didn't stop till he reached the All-American finals in Akron, Ohio.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: STALLIONS TRIUMPH, 31-19
description: The Birmingham Stallions intercepted four passes and went on to beat the Boston Breakers, 31-19, tonight in a United States Football League game.

title: CAN CONGRESS KEEP SECRETS AND KEEP A REIN ON THE C.I.A.?
description: AT least some C.I.A. activities in Central America are an open secret and the subject of wide open debate. Last week, the House Foreign Affairs Committee, dividing 20 to 14 largely on party lines, approved a Democratic plan to end covert collaboration with anti-Sandinist guerrillas in Nicaragua. Instead, the measure would transfer $80 million to help friendly countries interdict Nicaraguan and Cuban weapons flowing to the Salvadoran rebels. ''This committee is about to sell the U.S.A. down the drain by aiding and abetting the spread of Communism.'' contended Gerald B.H. Solomon, Republican of New York. But Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, argued that covert aid ''has not prevented the flow of arms into El Salvador. It has enabled the Sandinistas to rally support.''

title: AN ARMS NONOFFER
description: President Reagan's revised proposals for strategic arms reductions have been generally well received in Washington for their new, more flexible tone. This apparent flexibility will certainly help to build an American consensus on a negotiating position. Unfortunately, it will do nothing to advance actual negotiations with the Soviet Union. Indeed, by creating expectations that Moscow might have responded favorably - misplaced expectations that will not be met - the revised proposals may in fact have seriously reduced prospects for a successful negotiation.

title: Miss Smith Is Married
description: Lucinda Ann Smith, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James W. Smith of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Richard James Hay, son of Mr. and Mrs. T. Douglas Hay of Toronto. The Rev. Dr. George A. Pera performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Greenwich.

title: House of Keynes
description: To the Business Editor: Paul Samuelson's ''The House That Keynes Built'' (May 29) buries the real genius of Keynes - that a 52-year-old person could, in effect, repudiate the system of economic ideas in which he had so heavily invested. The dichotomy between the two Keyneses is best illustrated by a comparison of Keynes's thinking after Versailles with the implications of the ''General Theory.''

title: A REUNION OF KOREAN, 81, AND ADOPTEES
description: PRESSING two children close to her, On Soon Whang bowed her head and began to cry. Then she gazed around the Dobbs Ferry living room filled with American parents and their adopted Korean children and said softly: ''I'm sorry for my tears, but this is a dream. I'm always thinking - how are the children? How are they doing, and how are they studying?''

title: Elizabeth Grover Wed in Vermont
description: Elizabeth Beach Grover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Grover of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Wright Clark Preston, son of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Preston Jr. of Burlington, Vt. The Rev. Thomas N.F. Shaw, an Episcopal priest who is headmaster of Shore Country Day School in Beverly, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Charlotte (Vt.)

title: EVOLUTION OF HOME-COMPUTER SCHOOL
description: THE white frame house in White Plains looks rather ordinary, but step inside on a Saturday and the conversation can be distinctly unusual. The talk might be about techniques for creating lowresolution graphics on a computer. It could be a lesson on concatenation: using a computer to link sets of letters and numbers. Or perhaps it is a detailed explanation of the procedures and structure of an advanced programming language.

title: Major News in Summary; Indian Point Gets a Break
description: A month after the Nuclear Regulatory Commission laid down the law at Indian Point, the agency seemed to turn that law on its ear, at least in the minds of some critics. Acknowledging that plans to evacuate nearly 300,000 persons living near the Westchester reactors were still flawed -the deficiency that prompted the May 5 threat to close the facility - the N.R.C. nevertheless decided last week to let the plants remain open because steps had been taken toward improvement.

title: CONFERENCE SPEAKERS EXPLORE THE HIDDEN WORLD OF MONSTERS
description: They came to talk about Yeti, Sasquatch, Nessie, Chessie and the Wildman. They warmly called them ''monsters,'' as a mother might call her children ''the kids.''

title: BY ALLAN KOZINN
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Imperiled Trees Apparently Don't Just Stand There
description: They don't exactly scream bloody murder, but trees possibly do something just as effective when attacked. According to preliminary research announced last week by the National Science Foundation, uninfested trees near others being gobbled by insects take defensive action, perhaps in response to a chemical signal sent by unfortunate neighbors.

title: MASS EFFORT FILMS A MASS RALLY
DESTINATIONS: AMONG MY SOUVENIRS
description: ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., now a reporter in the Washington bureau of the Times, has filed stories from 13 countries.

title: The Region in Summary; State Loses on Casino Unions
description: New Jersey is down, but not necessarily out, on one front of its battle to stop the infiltration of organized crime into the casino industry. A Federal Court of Appeals ruled last week that the state can't regulate labor unions whose members work in Atlantic City gambling casinos.

title: MATTERS OF CHANGING TASTE
description: NE of the great pleasures of pursuing a single subject in life is the depth of perception one gains along the way. This is particularly so in a pursuit such as ours, food and its preparation and enjoyment. Documenting American taste over the last two decades has been both adventurous and amusing, as we have observed the trends, the fly-bynight fantasies, the ins and outs.

title: TOWNS SEEK CHEAPER HEALTH INSURANCE
description: LIKE Hempstead and Smithtown before them, the five East End towns are shopping for better medical insurance for their employees than a statewide health program now offers. They expect to save 20 to 30 percent on their costs.

title: Robert M. Miller Will Wed Sara Lee Kessler on July 31
description: Dr. Edward Kessler and Eleanor S. Kessler, both of Youngstown, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Lee Kessler, to Robert M. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Miller of New York.

title: I. ARTHUR ROSENBERG
description: I. Arthur Rosenberg, a lawyer who practiced commercial law in New York City for more than 40 years, died of cancer Thursday at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: BEWARE THE OVERVALUED DOLLAR
description: THE Administration's resistance to taking up overvaluation of the United States dollar at last month's economic summit in Williamsburg not only threatened our economic recovery but also insured that demands for trade protectionism would grow.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: IN an apparent effort to compromise with artists and others who have been critical of last fall's decision to terminate the annual juried exhibition, the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton is reinstating the show on a biennial basis, alternating with an artists-of-the-region invitational. This year's offering will be open only to artists who maintain studios in Suffolk County, to be selected initially from slides of their work.

title: WHY DOES IT HURT?
description: During the past few months, two physicians at Massachusetts General Hospital who have been treating Leon Fleisher and Gary Graffman for their physical difficulties playing the piano, have been distributing questionnaires to other musicians about their pains and playing habits. The inquiry is expected to be part of a research project examining the disabilities of professional musicians. Questionnaires have been distributed to members of the Boston Symphony Orchestra; the doctors also plan to distribute the forms to students at the New England Conservatory, the Curtis Institute of Music and the Peabody Conservatory.

title: Bargain Air Power
description: An ultralight plane, sometimes called a motorized hang glider, emerged last September as an alternative for small police forces unable to afford a helicopter.

title: JET LAG
description: To the Editor: The jet-lag diet article reminded me of the story about the elderly man who was losing his hearing rather rapidly.

title: Biologist Is Wed To Ann Loughlin
description: Ann de Lourdes Loughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Loughlin of Southold, L.I., was married there yesterday to Pedro Miguel Berrios, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose Miguel Berrios of Santiago and Las Cruces, Chile. The Rev. Robert J. Barnwell performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Southold.

title: NEW PACIFIC MYSTERIES: RED BEACHES AND RETURN OF SARDINES
description: As if they had been colored by a giant brush, some of the most pleasant beaches in southern California have recently turned crimson overnight. The cause: millions of tiny red crabs mysteriously washed ashore from the Pacific.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE, AT PACE, RENEWS HIS CALL FOR REFORM OF PRISONS
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, terming American prisons ''human warehouses,'' renewed his call yesterday for reforms that would convert them into ''places of education and training and into factories and shops for the production of goods.''

title: U.S. JUDGE TO RULE ON CONNECTICUT TRUCK BAN
description: A Federal judge here is scheduled to decide Monday whether to order a temporary halt to Connecticut's enforcement of its state law banning double-trailer trucks.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TUXEDO
description: AT dusk, when a light fog unfurls across Tuxedo Lake and fishermen c ast from small boats dwarfed by the surrounding hills, Tuxedo Park i n Orange County resembles a quiet Scottish loch a century ago.

title:
ART;
FRAGILITY IN COLORED FORMS
description: ONE of the most appealing settings for an art gallery is a converted residence, where works hang in a domestic atmosphere like that of the potential buyer's own home. Such ambience is provided at the Peri-Renneth Gallery in Westhampton Beach, which has been at the same Main Street location for several years but is under new management this season.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Claudia J. Flynn Is Bride of Daniel N. Perlmutter
description: Claudia Jeanne Flynn, an associate with the New York law firm of Parker Auspitz Neesemann & Delehanty, was married yesterday to Daniel Norton Perlmutter, an assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Judge Jon O. Newman of the United States Court of Appeals, Second Circuit, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. W. Paul Flynn, in West Haven, Conn.

title: Future Events; Dancing Around Town
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. A Formal Occasion June 15 - The New York University Institute of Fine Arts, the former James B. Duke house at 1 East 78th Street, will provide a suitably opulent setting for a turn-of-the-century dinner-dance in the spirit of Diamond Jim Brady. Guests in prescribed white tie and tiara will be offered champagne and caviar to start off the festivities at 7:30 P.M. The dinner menu will include bluepoint oysters, gulf shrimp and cold fillet of beef with pasta melange and ratatouille of spring vegetables. Kimberly Farkas is chairman of the evening, which is to benefit the Irvington House Institute for Medical Research, which is affiliated with the New York University Medical Center. Patron tickets $250, sponsor tickets $175, from 541-9856.

title: Luther
description: To the Editor: The elegant travelogue by John M. Todd, ''In the Land of Martin Luther'' (Travel, May 15) made reference to a photograph of what was asserted to be the second complete translation of Luther's German Bible, found in the Luther Room of the Wartburg Castle. However, the book featured in the photograph that accompanied the article was not Luther's German Bible but his controversial ''Tischreden'' or ''Table Talk.''

title: ROSARY BEADS ON LENIN SHIPYARD FENCES
description: ''The idea of cooperation between Marxists and Christians to improve society,'' Poland's Communist Party newspaper Tribuna Ludu wrote last week, ''dates back to the Communist Manifesto.''

title: Chinese Establishes High-Jump Record
description: Zhu Jianhua, a Chinese high jumper, set a world record with a leap of 7 feet 9 1/4 inches today at a national track and field meet here.

title: DECISION OVERTURNING TAX CAUSES A DELAY ON BUDGET IN JERSEY
description: The Legislature's Joint Appropriations Committee delayed final deliberations Friday on Governor Kean's proposed fiscal 1984 budget because of problems created by a State Supreme Court ruling overturning the state commuter tax.

title: Paul Taylor to Receive Scripps Prize for Dance
description: Paul Taylor, founder of the Paul Taylor Dance Company, will receive the 1983 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award. Terry Sanford, president of Duke University and a former governor of North Carolina, will present the $25,000 award in a ceremony scheduled at Duke on Sunday.

title: C.T. Jensen Wed To Miss Doelger
description: Christine Ellin Doelger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., was married yesterday to Christopher Thomas Jensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jensen of Wantagh, L.I. The Rev. John A. O'Callaghan performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Chatham.

title: SALADS: SUITABLE FOR SUMMERTIME
description: THE calendar is about to announce summer. Assuming the weather pays any attention to this, the season for casual foods suitable for outdoor entertaining will be upon us. Although salads have become popular fare any time of year, they are particularly appropriate for summer because they can often be prepared in advance and served attractively with little fuss.

title: CORRECTION
description: Last Sunday's Investing column and an accompanying table misstated the MCI Corporation's stock performance. The stock closed at $19.44 a share on Aug. 11, 1982. Its performance has generally been in line with that of other telecommunications issues.

title: Sunny's Halo Heads Arlington Classic Field
description: Sunny's Halo, the Kentucky Derby winner, and eight other 3-year-olds are scheduled to run in Sunday's $109,000 Arlington Classic at Arlington Park.

title: FLOOD CANAL IN SALT LAKE CITY IS CONVERTED BACK TO A STREET
description: Salt Lake City's Venetian ambiance, created two weeks ago when flood waters were diverted into a major street in the central business district, yielded to front-end loaders and dump trucks today.

title: FOR A SUNNY AFTERNOON
description: THE intriguing antiques shops burgeoning along with the lush old trees in the town's center make Nyack a attractive place to spend a sunny afternoon. For nourishment, a number of places in the area serve anything from a French pastry snack to a complete elegant dinner, among these establishments the two-year-old Cottage Cafe, just a few minutes north on Route 303 in Lake Ridge Plaza. In the main, the cooking, long on seafood with a substantial offering of meat, reflects the straightforward style of most seafood-steak houses; in particular, some dishes exhibit the influence of Italian cuisine and quite a few more of Greek.

title: TEXAS CAPTURES TITLE
description: Kirk Killingsworth knocked in the go-ahead run with a triple off the left-field fence in the seventh inning as Texas captured its fourth baseball title with a 4-3 victory over Alabama in the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game tonight.
Lee Whitfield is editor of a herb magazine.

title: Carol Luce Wed To Scott Brodie
description: Carol Ann Luce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Gordon Luce Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Allen Brodie, son of Mrs. Benjamin Brodie of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Brodie. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents, by Judge Robert J. Ruben of the Rye City Court.

title: Data Bank; June 12, 1983
Nuptials for Miss Campbell
description: Natalie L. Campbell, daughter of Angela Mitchell Campbell and the late Dr. John B.S. Campbell of Cincinnati, was married yesterday to Russell T. Walden, son of Brevoort Walden and the late Margaret Howe Thoman Walden of Weston, Conn. The Rev. Francis Ralph of St. Gertrude's Roman Catholic Church in Cincinnati and the Rev. Scott McLennan of the Unitarian Church in Dorchester, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Chapel of the Sacred Heart in Milford, Ohio. The bride is an actress and singer. Mr. Walden is a pianist, arranger, composer and conductor.

title: The Region in Summary; Another Notch On Drinking Age
description: Connecticut teen-agers waiting to buy their first legal drink may have to wait a little longer. Last year, amid nationwide concern about the number of teen-agers killed in alcohol-related accidents, Connecticut's General Assembly raised the minimum drinking age from 18 to 19.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IDON'T ask much from a supermarket - enough carts that work and e nough checkout clerks. I am tickled pink if it is well ordered e nough to let me remember from one week to the next whether the rice i s east of the chicken broth or west of the lentils.

title: Topics; Flowery Projects; Slug Fest
description: The little girl next door calls violets ''the purples.'' Flowering in their youth, they are dainty, fragrant and sweet-faced, the focus of continuing affection.

title: OWNERS OF COMMERCIAL PROPERTIES CHARGE CITY TAX SYSTEM IS UNFAIR
description: An organization of owners of commercial property has charged that New York City's real-estate tax system puts an unfair burden on commercial properties and large apartment houses, and is scaring away potential investors.

title: A LOOK AT THE 10 SYNDICATES THAT WILL SAIL FOR THE CUP
description: FRANCE 3 Yacht Club de France, Paris

title: Alexandra Van Alen Is Wed
description: Alexandra Kent Van Alen, daughter of William L. Van Alen Jr. of Newtown Square, Pa., and Mrs. Henry Reid Blynn of St. Davids, Pa., was married yesterday to Richard Campion Walling Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walling of Gladwyne, Pa. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: Headliners; Her Honor, His Honor, etc.
description: If there are heights of judicial decorum there must also be depths, and it seems they are being plumbed in Cleveland. In a sworn affidavit to the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeals, Federal Judge Ann Aldrich recently accused the district's chief judge, Frank Battisti, of steering bankruptcy cases to the law firm where his 28-year-old nephew was a first-year associate.

title: CASINOS STIR FEARS FOR THE ENVIRONMENT
description: THE rich pie that developers, builders and speculators hoped to carve up among themselves when casino gambling came to Atlantic City five years ago has turned out to be more of a cupcake than a pie.

title: Beth C. Fisher Is the Bride Of Automotive Executive
description: Beth Carlyle Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram D. Fisher of Sands Point, L.I., was married there yesterday in the Community Synagogue to Marc Craig Cutler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Cutler of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg, assisted by Cantor Jacob Yaron, performed the ceremony.

title: NEXT THATCHER MOVES
description: For Britain, the question now is what Margaret Thatcher will do with her resounding triumph and whether she will move even more boldly than she has to revolutionize its industrial society.

title: Panel of House Issues Study on Child Support
description: Seventy-nine percent of divorced fathers do not support their children, a Congressional report says. The nationwide study, issued Thursday by the House Select Committee on Children, Youth and Families, also found that 25 percent of American children were living with only one parent.

title: ITALIAN-AMERICANS: MAKING IT
description: The quotation of my remark that ''I do not think of myself as Italian-American'' might be misinterpreted. In context, what I meant was that, having arrived from Italy as an already trained adult, I cannot consider myself as a typical product of the Italian-American community, from which the many leaders mentioned in the article have emerged. S.E. LURIA Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences Stanford, Calif. -------

title: Budget Trims Mr. Cub
description: Ernie Banks, once known as Mr. Cub, is now a former Cub.

title: Litigation Practices In Malpractice Cases
description: When Charles G. Loeb Jr. speaks of the doctor-patient relationship (''Patients, Doctors Need 'Partnership' on Malpractice,'' Opinion Page, May 22), he speaks ably; however, when he addresses the question of medical malpractice and its compensation, he misses the point of the issue. The question is not whether malpractice exists; the question is how to deal with it. The problem has been aggravated by the system of lawyers' contingency fees, which adds incentive for lawyers to press frivolous suits.

title: SIHANOUK OFFERS TO STEP DOWN AS PRESIDENT IN EXILE
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk has offered to resign the presidency of Cambodia's government in exile if his coalition partners do not like his talk of resolving the Cambodian conflict through political means, a representative of the Prince said today.

title: PAT LAFONTAINE: POISED ON AND OFF ICE
description: The Minnesota North Stars called the first name, Brian Lawton. Next, without much hesitation, the Hartford Whalers put their marker on Sylvain Turgeon.

title: Modern Examples of Nonseparatism
description: Regarding the cross on the firehouse in Mount Kisco (''Cross on Mount Kisco Fire Station Raises Public Debate,'' May 22): the struggle between church and state has been with us since the time of Charlemagne and has its origins in antiquity. However, it should be emphasized that one of the most important things that distinguishes America from Europe is the fact that in our country not only have we done away with kings and queens but church and state are officially separated.

title: THATCHER AND REAGAN
description: 4LONDON, June 11 - A Washington reporter in London for the British election can hardly avoid comparisons between Prime Minister Thatcher and President Reagan. They are both successful conservative politicians, but in styles of leadership, they are as different as Maggie and Jiggs.

title: THE FAVORITE BREW OF SINGAPORE
description: PATRICIA WELLS is the restaurant critic of The International Herald Tribune in Paris.

title: FALSE IMAGES AND POLITICAL BIAS
description: AGROWING number of economists and government officials today have e xpressed concern that America's industrial base is in serious d ecline, threatening economic recovery and a continuation of high u nemployment. They fear that the West will not survive if the United S tates forsakes the production of steel and becomes a nation of i nsurance companies and fast-food restaurants. An industrial policy f or the United States is being proposed to counteract this trend.

title: Southern Pastor Elected Head of Presbyterians
description: The new Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has named as its first leader a Charlotte, N.C., minister who helped forge the agreement to create the denomination from two that had been divided since the Civil War.

title: Rebels Raid Colombia Village
description: Leftist guerrillas of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia ransacked the village of Aguada some 130 miles northeast of here, killing a policeman and wounding two more, the police said. They said the rebels had destroyed the town hall, the police station and the post office in grenade attacks before looting stores and then rounded up villagers to give them a two-hour lecture on Communist doctrines.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Further Growth Revision?

title: Fire Found in Lavatory Of 2d Air Canada Plane
description: An Air Canada jet with 72 people aboard landed safely here today after crew members put out a fire in a lavatory towel bin, the second such incident involving the airline in 10 days.

title: A BUDGET MEETING ON UTILITY AGENCY
description: THE county's Public Utility Agency, which is supposed to obtain low-cost electricity for residents within the Consolidated Edison service area, is expected to get some money to work with tomorrow after its chairman, Brother John G. Driscoll, president of Iona College, explains the agency's monetary needs to county legislators.

title: SHOULD BARGAINING BE BROADENED?
description: ABILL recently passed by the Assembly, and now awaiting action in the Senate, would broaden the scope of negotiations for thousands of state employees.

title: ALICE A. MARTIN ENGAGED TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John McKenzie Martin of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alice Anne Martin of Washington, to J. Bruce Whelihan, also of Washington, son of Mrs. George D. Beck of Philadelphia and Fripp Island, S.C., and hte late John E. Whelihan Jr., of Philadephia and Carmel, Calif.

title: The Nation in Summary; ON Schools, Hard Knocks
description: The question of Federal responsiblity for declining standards in the nation's schools just might generate enough attention on the stump to bring gains in the classroom. But first the political side of the debate will have to be settled, and it began in earnest last week with all the vigor of a schoolyard free-for-all.

title: Rise of the Raider
description: To the Business Editor: In the past couple decades we have witnessed the rise of the professional corporate raider. Among the most publicized are men such as Carl Icahn, Irwin Jacobs and Victor Posner.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FUNGI THAT LOOM IN THE SPRING
description: THIS has been a strange spring. The first things to flower were exceptionally early, as a result of an unusually warm late winter. Later on, cool, cloudy, humid conditions delayed flowering of those plants next in line. Still later, the season seemed to telescope, with many plants that would not normally bloom together doing so.

title: A TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: By Carrie Donovan

title: EXCESS AND ALLURE AT THE ORGAN
description: There seems to be something about the combination of the pipe organ and Bach's music that encourages gifted, successful virtuosos to go to extremes and indulge in excesses that their counterparts in, say, the piano and violin worlds would never dream of. Take the late Virgil Fox, for example. Naturally musical and phenomenally talented, he could have dazzled the world with first-class interpretations of Bach, whose music he claimed to admire above all. What he did, instead, was to put his talents at the service of cheap theatricality, obscuring the diamond-hard quality of Bach's masterworks with rhinestone glitter.

title: OLD WARPLANES REVVED UP FOR A NEW TOUR
description: MUSTANGS. Wildcats. Corsairs. These are some of the planes that helped the Allies win World War II, but for most people the only way to get a glimpse of them now is to visit an air museum, where they hang dull, dusty and lifeless from the rafters of a long unused hangar.

title: SHULTZ COMPLAINS FRENCH AS ALLIES ARE 'AGGRAVATING'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz has expressed irritation with the French Government, saying ''it is aggravating'' to deal with France on allied matters because of ambiguity among the French about their role in the Atlantic alliance.

title: Inside and Out
description: Question: I signed a subscription agreement in January to buy a coop at the outsider's price. Now the sponsor is reoffering apartments at an insider's price to tenants who were in residence before I arrived. Am I entitled to the lower price? ... M.S., New Rochelle, N.Y. Answer: According to Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general, an offering is limited to its own specific terms, which, according to your letter, are limited to the insiders only. Read the amendment terms carefully. One important element for you is whether the amendment makes the offering to all tenants or only those who lived there after a certain date. In Westchester, Nassau and Rockland Counties, you are considered a tenant under the law if you move into the building before the plan is declared effective, even if you have signed an outsider's purchase agreement.

title: The World in Summary; Show Goes On Without Qaddafi
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi arrived in Addis Ababa with eclat and left shortly afterward in a huff, his 10 months of efforts to preside over the Organization of African Unity in ruins. After two postponements had put the very existence of the O.A.U. in danger, an accord allowed a summit meeting to convene last week in the Ethiopian capital.

title: Major News in Summary; Mrs. Thatcher's Battle of Britain Is No Contest
description: Thanks largely to the ineptness of the opposition and the peculiarities of the British electoral system, Margaret Thatcher's Conservative Party won so big in Britain last week that historical comparisons were in order: the greatest sweep since Labor's Clement Attlee ousted Winston Churchill in 1945, the worst Labor defeat since 1922, the first Prime Minister since Lord Salisbury in 1900 to win two straight elections with margins big enough to guarantee full five-year terms.

title: PHILANTHROPIST RECALLS THE JOY OF GIVING OVER 50 YEARS
description: After a half-century of philanthropic activity, Lucy Goldschmidt Moses says her greatest joys have come helping children, supporting the city's hospitals and watching the restoration of Central Park, which she likes to call ''my backyard.''

title: NEWARK FARMERS' MARKET: DIOXIN IMPERILS FUTURE
description: NEWARK THE STREETS were nearly deserted except for a handful of curious visitors, some of whom used to be regular customers. A small American flag, weathered and torn, flapped feebly in the humid breeze, adding to the ghost-town look of the 12-acre Newark Farmers' Market, an area normally filled with people and produce.

title: Coastal's Sire: Majestic Prince
description: To the Sports Editor: In the article about Slew o' Gold's victory in the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park, an error was made in the colt's breeding.

title: IN PARLIAMENT, CHINESE OFFER NO SURPRISES
description: The National People's Congress, which opened here last Monday, heard a Cantonese fisherman say the other day that he would support the policies of Deng Xiaoping, China's paramount leader. His statement came as no great surprise to the other delegates.

title: BRIBE TO DEMOCRATS IN WANAQUE IS DENIED BY GARBAGE CONTRACTOR
description: A garbage-disposal contractor who is accused of having ties to organized crime, testified here Wednesday that $1,000 he gave to Democratic officials of Wanaque was a campaign contribution and not a bribe.

title: 'L'ETOILE DU NORD,' WITH SIMONE SIGNORET
description: The chain of events that leads Pierre Granier-Deferre's ''Etoile du Nord'' from a bazaar in Alexandria to a boardinghouse in Brussels is not easily explained. It's not meant to be, because the film's early scenes have a deliberately disjointed and mysterious style. But it gradually emerges that Edouard (Philippe Noiret), a Frenchman who has been living in Egypt, has decided in 1934 to return to Europe, and that en route he has met a beautiful young gold digger named Sylvie (Fanny Cotten,con).

title: PARKING HOMES ON PARKING LOTS
description: George Greene is a Selden, L.I., developer who cut his homebuilding teeth on projects in the wide-open spaces of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. In central Queens, where Mr. Greene has been working for the last few years, vacant land is much harder to find, but that has not kept him from acquiring the property needed for his projects.

title: BUDGET OFFICE SAID TO HOLD UP AID FOR LATINS
description: The Agency for International Development has urged that $90 million in emergency aid be given to Bolivia, Ecuador and Peru, but has run into reluctance in the White House's budget office, Government officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article May 22 about a professor honored by the University of Vermont - which dismissed him in the 1950's after he declined to answer questions at a Senate hearing on Communist influence at colleges - included an erroneous subheading. The professor was questioned by a subcommittee headed by Senator Herman Welker, Republican of Idaho. Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was not involved.

title: 3 JUDGES AND LAWYER CHOSEN BY CUOMO FOR COURT OF CLAIMS
description: ALBANY June 11 (AP) - Governor Cuomo has nominated three judges and a Queens lawyer to fill vacancies on the State Court of Claims. The Governor put forward the names of Judges Lawrence J. Tonetti and Dennis Edwards Jr. of New York City Criminal Court, Judge Rena K. Uviller of New York City Civil Court and John Gallagher, the Queens lawyer.

title: Miss Hack to Wed Oivind Lotenzen 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hack of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Darrell Claire Hack, to Oivind Lorentzen 3d, son of Mr. Lorentzen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Evelyn Byrd La Prade Lorentzen.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Arts and Crafts In Candyland

title: MURDER INQUIRY UNCOVERING INTRIGUES
description: Last January, George M. Perry, a 64-year-old millionaire business executive who carried three passports and had worldwide business contacts, vanished from the Grand Hyatt Hotel in Manhattan. Three months later, he was found with weights on his legs in an upstate lake, shot in the head.

title: HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN CITY TAKING MORE DIFFICULT COURSES
description: The following article is based on reporting by Edward B. Fiske and Samuel Weiss and was written by Mr. Fiske.

title: Modell, Browns' Owner, Suffers a Heart Attack
description: Art Modell, the principal owner of the Cleveland Browns, suffered a heart attack today and was in stable condition at the Cleveland Clinic, a team spokesman said.

title: U.S. CONSULAR CITIES CONSULT NEW YORK
description: As the consular capital of the world, New York City is bound to have a lot to teach other cities about the concerns and benefits of playing host to a host of diplomats.

title: Bobbi Ann Horowitz Weds Bruce Alden Langer on L.I.
description: Bobbi Ann Horowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius M. Horowitz of Woodmere, L.I., was married yesterday to Bruce Alden Langer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel S. Langer of Merrick, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Klaperman performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I., assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich.

title: South Africa Bans Protests Over Hangings
description: A judge issued a 48-hour ban beginning today on protests over the hanging of three black nationalist guerrillas.

title: BAZELON GIVES DIFFERING VIEW ON COURT WOES
description: Federal Judge David L. Bazelon said today that the sharp increase in litigation was rooted in human problems made worse by twin revolutions in technology and social expectations and could not be solved by curbing access to the Federal courts.

title: San Diego 'Nite Cap'
description: Anthony Pellegrino, an 40-year-old engineer from San Diego, began experimenting with a Padres batting helmet after he almost fell asleep at the wheel one night. The result was what he calls ''Nite Cap,'' a batting helmet fitted with batteries, some mercury switches and a buzzer that goes off when the wearer's head droops. If the wearer's head flops forward, backward, or to the side, the mercury shifts and completes an electric circuit that sets off the buzzer, awakening he driver. Mr. Pellegrino said he was looking for someone to market the device, but did not indicate that it would be available for fans at dull Padre home games.

title: The Case Favoring Westbeth Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Court Bobbles A Cold Potato
description: The Supreme Court labored months over modifying the ''exclusionary rule,'' which bars illegally seized evidence from trial. Last week, it brought forth a mouse of a ruling that avoided the exclusion issue altogether, deciding an Illinois search warrant case strictly in terms of the warrant's validity.

title: PENSION FUNDS LOADING UP ON STOCKS
description: WITH government, corporate and union pension funds now controlling a lmost $1 trillion in retirement assets, the force of their c ollective attitude toward investments is formidable indeed, and it c an often provide the mainstay of support for a bull market once it g ets rolling.

title: Miss Scholberg Marries
description: Katherine Jean Scholberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Jay Scholberg of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Noble Weeks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Noble Weeks of Scituate, Mass. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony in the First Presbyterian Church in New Canaan.

title: ARE THERE BARGAINS IN TAPE?
description: Before heading for the hills or the beach, vacationers often dub their favorite disks onto cassettes to take along. The records themselves stay home, being too vulnerable for exposure to the rigors of travel. Besides, cassettes are so much more portable: They just slip into your pocket.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
WHEN DEATH BECOMES TRIVIALIZED
description: IRECENTLY spoke to a friend who was in a crisis and had just come back from a marathon weekend ''encounter'' of the sort that guarantees quick and complete answers to most existential questions, including, I gather, death.

title: FOREIGN SECRETARY IS FORCED TO QUIT BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher dismissed Foreign Secretary Francis Pym tonight as part of a reorganization of her Cabinet at the start of her second term. Sir Geoffrey Howe, who served as Chancellor of the Exchequer throughout Mrs. Thatcher's first four-year administration, was named as Mr. Pym's successor.

title: COURTHOUSE MOVED BECAUSE OF ASBESTOS
description: PATERSON FOR most of last week, employees at the Passaic County Courthouse here have been packing official and personal effects into cardboard boxes, getting ready to leave the building for quarters across the street.

title: Helen Clark and Timothy G. Atkeson, Lawyers, Are Married in Washington
description: Helen West Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Doran Clark of Chevy Chase, Md., was married in Washington yesterday to Timothy Granger Atkeson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Breed Atkeson of Washington. The Rev. Raymond C. O'Brien performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Navy Chapel.

title: BOMB MISSES ISRAELI PATROL, HURTS 6 LEBANESE
description: A remote-controlled bomb planted along a road exploded near an Israeli checkpoint here today, wounding six Lebanese and narrowly missing an Israeli military convoy.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: EVEN low levels of pollutants in New Jersey's coastal waters can be enough to gradually kill some kinds of marine life, according to tests being conducted by the Federal Government at Sandy Hook.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Jumping Jedi

title: HARTFORD'S 'MENAGERIE' A MIXED BLESSING
description: FOLLOWING the death of Tennessee Williams last February, a spate of revivals burst forth in commemoration of our premiere poetic playwright. These ranged from reinterpretations of his lesser works (an acclaimed staging of the 1977 ''Vieux Carre'' at Off Off Broadway's W.P.A. Theater) to the inevitable stock and amateur stagings of ''The Glass Menagerie'' (1945), his first success, and with ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' one of his undisputed great works.

title: TOWN BATTLES U.S. FOR NEW ONE-LANE BRIDGE
description: For the third year in succession the village council of this community of 600 people has tightened its belt and decreased its real estate tax rate.
