But, at the same time, the council is having a difficult time persuading Federal Highway Administration officials the village does not need a new $500,000 bridge.

title: Miss Gebelein, a Coach, Marries Jeremiah Jones
description: Louisa Allen Gebelein, daughter of Mrs. Bruce Crawford of Grafton, Mass., and the late George C. Gebelein Jr., was married yesterday to Jeremiah Walcott Jones, son of Mrs. Arthur M. Jones of Manchester, Mass., and the late Mr. Jones. Retired Bishop Brooke Mosley of the Episcopal Diocese of Delaware and the Rev. H. Eugene Goll performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Church in Southborough, Mass.

title: THE FAMILY DOCTOR IS MODERN MEDICINE'S LATEST SPECIALIST
description: Family doctors, recently regarded as an endangered species in medicine, are making a comeback. Medical students who once dreamed of becoming high-powered brain surgeons or high-priced ophthalmologists are now looking closer at Marcus Welby and liking what they see.

title: THE CHALLENGE TO OVERCOME OUR INDIFFERENCE
description: The late Allard K. Lowenstein, who served as United States Representative from Long Beach, addressed these remarks to the annual convention of the National Student Association in 1956. Mr. Lowenstein was slain by a onetime protege in March 1980.

title: AND NOW, THE NEW WAR IN SOFTWARE
description: CHICAGO The Consumer Electronics Show is the showcase for the best and brightest products of the industry all hawked in an atmosphere of hype and dizzying yellow glare. The cheapest computers, tiniest televisions, most deafening loudspeakers, cleverest video games and the flattest calculators. Even the shoeshine stand at the convention advertised itself as the ''World's greatest shoeshine.''

title: Airplane Crashes Onto Bridge In Trenton, Injuring 3 Aboard
description: A single-engine plane crashed onto a railroad bridge while trying to make an emergency landing on the Trenton Freeway Friday night, injuring the pilot and two passengers, authorities said.

title: PROTEST OVER TOKYO AIRPORT DRAGGING ON AFTER 17 YEARS
description: Two workers died the other day in a fire deliberately set on a construction site, becoming, in the process, the first unwitting bystanders to be killed in the seemingly endless protest over the airport in the town of Narita.

title: IN NEW HAVEN, A PUSHCART CAUSE CELEBRE
description: NEW HAVEN LOUIS WEISSER says he is just a ''little old man trying to make a living.'' But Mr. Weisser, who sells flowers from a pushcart, is also a lawbreaker under a New Haven city ordinance that will be the subject of a repeal attempt this week.

title: COMPOSERS WHO DON'T DO IT ALL
description: ''On Your Toes,'' with its cheerful, tuneful score by Richard Rodgers, has just won a Tony Award for the Broadway season's best revival. Part of what makes Rodgers's music so delightful is its sound. That statement might seem painfully self-evident. Except that in this case, as in nearly every Broadway show, the architect of that sound was somebody other than the composer.

title: SMALL SCHOOL, BIG MISSION
description: So in this song of sadness That would bring about some tears, Are words of hope and happiness For all my future years. FROM ''NEXT YEAR WILL BE BETTER,'' A POEM IN A COLLECTION BY STUDENTS AT DAMON HIGH SCHOOL. By JOSEPH MALINCONICO NEW BRUNSWICK AL IS 18 years old and the author of ''Next Year Will Be Better.'' When he was 7, he learned that he was adopted, and he did not take the news well. At 12, he was sent to a program in Connecticut for children who were not getting along at home.

title: CLOUDS WITH MORE THAN SILVER LININGS
description: HAVE you ever noticed that it sometimes happens that the most profound ideas come about from standing back and just taking notice of things?

title:
GARDENING;
THE FUNGI THAT LOOM IN THE SPRING
description: THIS has been a strange spring. The first things to flower were exceptionally early, as a result of an unusually warm late winter. Later on, cool, cloudy, humid conditions delayed flowering of those plants next in line. Still later, the season seemed to telescope, with many plants that would not normally bloom together doing so.

title: PIONEER OF DANCE CRITICISM
description: On June 2, John Martin, the first dance critic of The New York Times, turned 90. Therefore these words are a kind of birthday card for him. However, the occasion demands not only warm greetings, but also serious thinking, for Mr. Martin always regarded dance as a serious art.

title: DIFFERING VIEWS ON SEX EDUCATION
description: The following is a response to Charlotte Lichterman's letter regarding sex education in the schools. I applaud loudly for the few schools that have the courage to present Birthright as an alternative to the pro-abortion viewpoint.

title: WHY THE MILITARY HAS FOUR TACTICAL AIR FORCES: A CASE STUDY
description: Among the many reasons the nation's military budget is so high is the resistance of the four armed services to undertaking joint development and acquisition of guns or radar or aircraft.

title: SHOULD BARGAINING BE BROADENED?
description: SHOULD educational policy decisions on class size, teaching assignments, curriculum and the academic calendar be made in ''closed door'' labor-negotiation sessions out of public view?

title: PUBLISHERS WEAKLY: FORECASTS
description: Each week America's booksellers, publishers, agents, authors and librarians, among others, turn to the forecasts of books carried by Publishers Weekly, the book industry's major trade publication. From these short previews, one may learn what books are coming out in the near future, what they are about, PW's opinion of them and how extensively they are being promoted; with this information the experienced reader can assess a new book's chances of success. One loyal reader of PW's forecasts is Joseph Epstein, the editor of The American Scholar, who here offers his own forecasts of some imaginary titles in some only too real genres.

title: Miss Epstein Is Bride Of Christopher Leich
description: Judith Susan Epstein, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Epstein of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday to Christopher Martin Leich, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Leich of Ruston, La., and Cornwall Bridge, Conn. The ceremony was performed at the Faculty Club at the University of Virginia by Federal District Judge Harry Michaels Jr.

title: JOIE DE VIE, $9.80, WINS YONKERS TROT
description: A few pieces of cotton made the difference tonight as Joie de Vie, a California-bred colt whose owner paid $25,000 to supplement him for the Yonkers Trot, raced off with the first leg of trotting's triple crown.

title: DOCUMENTS ASSAIL 2 TIMBER CONCERNS
description: A House subcommittee today released confidential Government documents that its chairman said showed the Reagan Administration chose not to act on Agriculture Department recommendations to start proceedings against two timber companies. He said the documents contained allegations of fraudulent and monopolistic practices in a national forest in Alaska.

title: Atomic Plant Running Again
description: The Connecticut Yankee nuclear plant resumed operations today after having been shut down Friday because of a faulty water valve, Northeast Utilities said. Anthony Castagno, a company spokesman, said the plant was operating at about 25 percent of capacity by 6:30 A.M. today and was expected to be brought back to full capacity by Sunday afternoon. Northeast Utilities operates and is part owner of the plant.

title: STATES STRETCH AND SQUEEZE TO STRIKE A FISCAL BALANCE
description: ''Everbody wants to go his merry way,'' grumbled a Democratic leader in the Connecticut Legislature last week. ''There are 76 different ideas on how we ought to spend and tax.'' But for the first time in 12 years, none of them got through the General Assembly before it was forced to adjourn Wednesday as required by the State Constitution. As a result, lawmakers won't be going very far, at least not until they find a way to bridge a $265 million gap in the $3.6 billion budget for the coming fiscal year.

title: Kathy Slobogin Wed To Barry N. Spodak
description: Kathy Slobogin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Slobogin of Rockport, Me., was married yesterday to Barry N. Spodak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Spodak of Manhasset, L.I. The wedding was performed by State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff at the home of Margaret Roach, a friend of the couple, in Douglaston, Queens.

title: The World in Summary; The Penalty of 'Disobediance'
description: ''There have been strange and unpleasant happenings in Malawi,'' an editorial in The Times of London said last week. Few outside the landlocked African nation of six million people know exactly what is going on but it seems clear that President for Life Hastings K. Banda is doing what he can to prevent any unnatural shortening of his term of office.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL TO SPEED CLEARING OF CHECKS
description: Banks will soon be required to clear checks deposited by their customers within a ''reasonable period,'' under legislation signed this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: IN MADAGASCAR, MIG-21'S AND A MEAGER RICE CROP
description: The grounds of the presidential palace here are shared by trees and Soviet antiaircraft guns, and a presidential bunker is being built on the outskirts of this capital.

title: Cultural Unity
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL NEGOTIATING TRADE AND AID DEAL WITH SURINAME
description: Brazil, in a break with international efforts to isolate the leftist government of Suriname, is negotiating a trade and aid package with the former Dutch colony.

title: Jeanette Lee Weds Francis Flaherty in Kentucky
description: Jeanette Lee, a city planner for the New York City Public Development Corporation, was married yesterday in Covington, Ky., to Francis Flaherty, a staff reporter with The National Law Journal in New York. The Rev. Sante Reale performed the ceremony in the Mother of God Roman Catholic Church.

title: Revivals: Plans and Progress
description: To complement the new titles scheduled for summer, many wellregarded older books will be accessible at popular prices in the coming months. Re-releasing worthy work from the recent or distant past seems an increasingly popular practice nowadays. Publishing houses of every size in every area of the country are bringing individual titles, especially fiction, back into circulation. Two well-known firms - The University of Chicago Press and Arbor House - have just announced new imprints for reprints. And two others -Dell and E.P. Dutton - now have track records sturdy enough to warrant cautious optimism about the success of such efforts. Old Novels Made New.

title: THIS TIME, BELMONT RECEIVES TROPHY
description: Until yesterday it had been a dream although never an obsession. August Belmont 4th had not shared the interest in thoroughbred racing that his great-grandfather and grandfather had, despite all the times he had come to the track that bears the family name. Then, in 1976, when he was 68 years old, Belmont purchased his first interest in a race horse. Now, seven years later, he has reclaimed a piece of family silverware.

title: BIG EFFECTS AND HARD-WORKED PERCEPTIONS
description: BARTLEBY IN MANHATTAN AND OTHER ESSAYS By Elizabeth Hardwick. 292 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: Nuptials for Laura Curioli
description: Laura Marie Curioli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Curioli of the Bronx, was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to Peter Steven Nemeth, son of Marian Pantano of Bayside, Queens.

title: No Headline
description: Audubon Society Sets Record Straight I write to ask you to correct some errors printed in the ''Connecticut Journal'' of May 8. The Connecticut Audubon Society (C.A.S.), established in 1898, (42 years prior to the incorporation of the National Audubon Society), has 12 sanctuaries, 3 nature centers and 5,800 memberships statewide.

title: AIDES URGE SHULTZ TO VISIT MOSCOW TO TEST ITS MOOD
description: Some State Department officials have been urging Secretary of State George P. Shultz to consider undertaking a diplomatic mission to Moscow this summer, according to high-ranking Administration officials.

title:
CAMERA;
SOME POINTERS ON SHOOTING PICTURES AFTER DARK
description: After dark most photographers use flash for taking pictures, especially when shooting indoors in low-light situations - which is one reason why more and more automatic cameras come with built-in flash. These will insure reasonably good pictures in most situations, but they offer no challenge to creativity. However, those who prefer to shoot pictures at night, indoors or outdoors, can now get pleasing results without using flash, due to the introduction of faster films and to the use of simple techniques that not all photographers are familiar with.

title: Leigh Simon Weds Broker
description: Carol Leigh Simon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to John Randolph Porges, son of John Melville Porges of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Anne E. Porges. The Rev. John Corr performed the ceremony at the Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon.

title: CAMP SCHOLARSHIPS OFFERED IN YONKERS
description: SCHOLARSHIPS for the Yonkers school system's summer camp program, in which elementary school children can learn everything from computer programming to acting, are going begging.

title: Auto of Slain Family Is Found 40 Miles Away
description: A car believed stolen by the killer of four people in a Chino Hills home last week was found here today, 40 miles from the crime scene, the police said.

title: MRS. GANDHI'S PARTY FAILS IN KASHMIR VOTING
description: An attempt by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party to make major electoral gains in northern India's Kashmir Valley has failed, election returns from the region showed today.

title: THEATER SALUTES GALLERY HEAD
description: MILLBURN ''IT'S ABOUT time!'' exclaimed Betsy Palmer, who once lived in Englewood. The performer was alluding to what many of the state's artists and actors have expressed as ''a too-long overdue'' acknowledgement of Gene Carrington, who has been in charge of the art gallery at the Paper Mill Playhouse for more than 30 years.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Once upon a time ''modern French painting'' meant one thing and one only to most of the English-speaking world. Impressionism had not yet come to notice.

title: LOW STANDARDS AND OUR SCHOOLS: SHARING THE BLAME
description: IT was reported recently that students at the Harvard Law School were staging protests to demand that teachers account for the time spent out of the classroom and for their incomes. At the same time, the students were clamoring for release from any accountability of their own until the final exam; they demanded that they not be asked to discuss what they had learned, or to be tested on it during a class, if such accountability was to be reflected in their grades. Thus the students refused to accept responsibility for their performance during the semester even while demanding just that from the teachers.

title: The Region in Summary; Cuomo Salvages Something on His M.T.A. Plan
description: Last year, as a candidate, Mario Cuomo wanted to get rid of the Metropolitan Transit Authority. This year, as Governor, he has tried - but so far failed - to gain control of it.

title: FROM TEAROOM TO FRENCH RESTAURANT
description: EARLIER this spring, La Maison des Champs moved from the rear of a small shopping center in Water Mill to a more visible location on the highway in East Hampton. In the years since it first opened in Water Mill, it had gradually matured from a charming tearoom to a more serious French restaurant. This evolution has continued with the move to East Hampton.

title: A NEW SHOW AT WINDSOR
description: CELEBRATING the 350th anniversary of the arrival of Pilgrim settlers in 1633, a new outdoor show will be produced Saturday on the campus of the Loomis-Chaffee School in Windsor. Although none of the antiques to be shown is expected to match the age of this ancient township, probably more real items will be offered here than are seen at many other summer sales.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am interested in spending a week in Jamaica. Instead of spending all my time on the beaches I would like to explore some of the interior mountainous regions on foot or by bicycle. Is Jamaica set up for hikers or bikers as well as for sunbathers? - K.I., Irvington, N.Y. Answer:The Jamaica Camping and Hiking Association (Post Office Box 216, Kingston 7, Jamaica; 809-927-5409) will furnish information on hiking and bicycling in various parts of the island nation. To get information about self-guided tours and places of special interest, send a check for $10 along with your inquiry to the association at its Kingston headquarters. In your inquiry be as specific and detailed as possible about what sort of accommodations you would like, the ages and physical condition as well as the interests of the members of your party and the amount of money and time you have budgeted.

title: SPANISH CAUTIONS U.S. ON LATIN WAR
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez said this week that a war in Central America could have ''unforeseeable consequences'' and he called on the United States and the countries of the region to ''avoid at all costs the triggering of a general conflict.''

title: 'Tax-Free' Bonds?
description: To the Business Editor: I am retired and living on Social Security, stock dividends and interest from alleged ''tax-free municipal bonds.'' Your article, ''An Insidious Nose Under the Tent'' (May 22), was very timely and to the point.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Montreal Expos at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050 1:30 P.M.). Yankees vs. Brewers at Milwaukee. (Television -Channel 11, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2:30 P.M.) Braves vs. San Francisco Giants at Atlanta (Television - WTBS 2:10 P.M.).

title: 12 Journalists Are Selected For Nieman Class at Harvard
description: Twelve people will study next fall at Harvard University as members of the 46th Nieman Fellows class of journalists, the Nieman Foundation said Friday. The fellowships were established in 1938 through a bequest from Agnes Wahl Nieman.

title: SKIN CANCERS BELIEVED RISING
description: SKIN cancers induced by exposure to the sun are said to be increasing in New Jersey, with little public education and few prevention programs by government or private institutions. ''I'm seeing in the neighborhood of 10 to 15 new cases of basal cell epithelioma and squamous cell carcinoma a week in my private practice,'' said Dr. Ira H. Gouterman of Kearny, chief of the Division of Dermatology at St. Michael's Medical Center in Newark.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 THE RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 1 13 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 3 2 10 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 4 3 7 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 5 4 10 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 6 5 5 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 7 7 8 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 8 6 11 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.)

title: DILIETO TO SEEK A 3D TERM
description: NEW HAVEN MAYOR BIAGIO DiLIETO almost forgot to say something to several hundred of his supporters Wednesday morning. ''By the way,'' he said after he had finished a prepared speech at the Park Plaza Hotel and the crowd had begun applauding, ''in case you didn't know, I'm running for re-election.''

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
WHEN THE GOLFERS PLAY THE U.S. OPEN, IT'S PURE SPORT
description: THE week ahead brings a gold star event to the sports calendar. Golf takes center stage as Tom Watson defends the United States Open championship at Oakmont, in the green hills of western Pennsylvania near Pittsburgh.

title: THE WELFARE STATE WAS A BOON TO MRS. THATCHER
description: The real victor of last week's British general election, some wag commented, was Clement Attlee. For it was Attlee's Labor Government that, starting in 1945, put in place the safety net of welfare benefits without which, it is argued, no Conservative prime minister could have even dreamed of winning re-election with more than three million people unemployed.

title: GAMES THAT OUT-TEACH TEACHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKEES LOSE TO BREWERS,6-2
description: A high fly ball that Steve Kemp lost in the final glow of twilight helped continue a big inning for the Milwaukee Brewers tonight as they defeated the Yankees and again mastered Ron Guidry, 6-2.

title: 100 OF THE CITY'S BRIGHTEST PROMOTE ITS SCHOOLS
description: One hundred of the brightest students in New York City's public schools got together yesterday to receive praise and help promote a common interest -New York City's public schools.

title: CONCERT: FLORILEGIUM
description: The Florilegium Chamber Choir and Orchestra straddled musical eras at the Abraham Goodman House on Thursday night, but the range and variety of the musical personalities represented here went beyond simple dichotomies.

title: Statue a Student Found Brings $341,000 at Sale
description: An Egyptian statue nicknamed ''Ralph'' by the college student who happened upon it is expected to earn about $300,000 for the venerable Chautauqua Institution.

title: Watergate Burglar Acquitted
description: One of the Watergate burglars, Bernard A. Barker, who became a housing inspector after leaving prison, was acquitted Wednesday of perjury charges filed after an investigation of zoning payoffs. Circuit Judge Thomas E. Scott of Dade County said he had had no choice under existing law but to acquit Mr. Barker. Under state law, perjury suspects must get a chance to recant. Mr. Barker was not given that chance.

title: CLEVELAND PARLEY ASSESSES ECONOMY
description: Business, political and civic leaders have begun a dialogue here that they hope will lead to a detailed legislative and political agenda for the economically stricken Middle West and Northeast.

title: Reagan Education Plan Is Assailed by Weicker
description: President Reagan's education policy was criticized today by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut, who called for increased Federal financing of education.

title: COLUMBIA LAW REPRESENTING CHILDREN
description: The offices of Morningside Heights Legal Services are decorated with simple crayon drawings, and toys clutter the carpeted floor. The law agency's clients are children.

title: DETROIT'S SAD VOICES
description: When I left Michigan nearly 20 years ago, the Big Three - General Motors, Ford and Chrysler - pretty much ran Detroit. Though my father built houses rather than cars, it was understood that our family's fortunes rose and fell with the auto industry. We lived 10 miles west of Detroit in Dearborn, the solidly middle-class birthplace of Henry Ford and home of the Ford Motor Company. Our taxes were low, people said, because Ford's were high. Unlike most of my friends, who either went away to college or stayed in Dearborn and attended - where else? - Henry Ford Community College, I went downtown to Wayne State University. Unlike most of my classmates, I left Michigan within a year of graduation.

title: FINALLY, A GOOD BREAK ON WAGES
description: IT'S just a snapshot of the American economy, but what's happening to wages is remarkable. For the first time in the 15 years that the Government has been keeping such statistics, average union wage settlements in the first year of multi-year contracts are actually declining. What's more, many of the cost-of-living adjustments that seemed to lock in higher salaries year in and year out are now pulling them back down. And, even where wages are still rising, it is at a pace considerably slower than the 10 percent plus increases of the inflation-wracked years of the late 1970's.

title: WHAT WENT WRONG AT NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO?
description: WASHINGTON As best as anyone can now determine, the financial crisis that is threatening the future of National Public Radio had been brewing unseen for at least half a year. Last March, it had come as a shock to most people when a deficit of $2.8 million was discovered, but it came as an even bigger shock when it was revealed last month that the deficit, if left uncorrected, would reach $5.8 million.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Getting a Fix On Acid Rain
description: A Reagan Administration task force on acid rain perhaps went a long way last week toward countering the impression left by the President's 1980 campaign that trees are a major source of pollution. In its annual report, it concluded that emissions from power plants, factories and automobiles were the prime contributors to acidity damaging freshwater habitats in the Northeast.

title: FLOWERY PROJECTS; Facade and Face
description: There is disagreement, to put it mildly, over what the west facade of the national Capitol should look like. Changes are in order because some of the building's sandstone is crumbling.

title: Italian-Americans: Making It
description: Finally, a tribute to the accomplishments of all Italian-Americans (''Italian-Americans: Coming Into Their Own,'' by Stephen S. Hall, May 15). It has long been awaited and is very much appreciated! RACHEL BARCIA-MORSE, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: BREEDING CONDITIONS IDEAL FOR MOSQUITO
description: ''If you're a mosquito, things are looking good,'' said Joseph Sanzone. 'But if you're trying to control them, it looks bad. They've got us outnumbered.''

title: FROM 'TICO TICO' TO 'A GOOD YEAR'
description: ''MY father said to me that he did not want to aid and abet me on the road to hell,'' said Ervin Drake of Great Neck, ''and he insisted I come into his business.

title: FISHING AND HUNTING WITH WOMEN
description: The New York Times Magazine's new weekly column, About Men, will address a broad range of male-related topics of interest to both sexes. The column will include essays, reportage, service pieces and advice on personal appearance. Nelson Bryant writes the Outdoors column for The Times.

title: RED CROSS IN DRIVE FOR U.S., LOCAL AID
description: THE county's delegation to the American Red Cross convention has returned from Atlanta, where national officials announced the disasterrelief funds have run out, to face an equally dire local situation. While the ocunty chapter's own funds have been exhausted, it is being asked, along with other lcoal chapters, to help bail out the national emergencyrelief fund.

title: CATSKILLS RAILROADING REVIVED BY TOWNS IN DELAWARE COUNTY
description: The unfamiliar cry of ''All aboard'' rang through the Bushkill Valley here at 3:47 P.M. today at the Arkville Railroad Station. ''The Delaware and Ulster special train for Fleischmanns is now leaving,'' a voice from the loudspeaker said.

title: Tyler Baldwin Jr.  Weds Ellen Coker
description: Ellen Sasser Coker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Westfield Coker Jr. of Hartsville, S.C., was married yesterday to Tyler Baldwin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baldwin of Fairfield, Conn. The Rev. Richard G. Wilson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Hartsville.

title: Vilas to Appeal Ban
description: Guillermo Vilas will appeal the one-year suspension and $20,000 fine imposed on him last Wednesday by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council for allegedly accepting a tournament appearance guarantee, according to his attorney, Thomas F. Betz Jr. The appeal will be made to a review officer agreed upon by Vilas and the council.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ''HISTORICALLY in this state, education has been a priority in municipal budgets,'' said Donald W. Goodrich, vice president of the nonprofit goverment research organization called Connecticut Public Expenditure Council.

title: ORIOLES DEFEAT RED SOX FOR 6TH STRAIGHT
description: John Lowenstein drove in three runs with a pair of singles, and Ken Singleton lined a two-run double today as the Baltimore Orioles extended their winning streak to six games with a 10-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: REBS AND YANKS
description: The 12th Virginia Cavalry and the Pine Creek Railroad will re-enact the Great Locomotive Chase, a colorful Civil War episode, in Allaire State Park next Sunday.

title: ILLEGAL LOFT TENANTS GET 2D CHANCE
description: TENANTS and owners illegally occupying residential or artists' l iving-and-work loft space in several lower Manhattan neighborhoods h ave been given until June 21 to file a grandfathering application w ith the City Planning Department or lose their right to remain.

title: ABRAMS CRITICIZES UTILITY PRACTICES
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams has asked the Public Service Commission to bar what he called conflicts of interest between public utilities and outside directors.

title: O.A.U. ACTS TO END WEST SAHARA WAR
description: The Organization of African Unity, making its first major decision since it ended a long political deadlock, agreed today on a formula to end the 10-year-old conflict in the Moroccan-controlled territory of Western Sahara.

title: EAST END APPROACHES CHOICE ON BRIDGES
description: THE bridges built for East End farm wagons three generations ago are wearing out. Local residents would like to see them repaired and retained just as they were - small and picturesque. But if the residents want Federal and state dollars to do the work, they will have to accept new, larger two-lane structures - unlovely in the eyes of some, but more efficient.

title: NOSE SURGERY BECOMING MORE COMMON
description: ''I'VE always been self-conscious about my profile,'' said Jane Timmons, a 23-year-old nurse of Woodhaven, Queens. ''As a teen-ager, you look in the mirror and are very concerned. I dreamed it could be improved someday.''

title: CITY OFFICIALS FIND SURPRISE IN COMPUTER
description: On a little green screen in the City Hall basement, the names of state legislators who have voted on certain bills are cross-indexed with the groups that have contributed to their campaigns.

title: 5-2 CAVEAT WINS THE BELMONT STAKES BEFORE 60,397
description: The winner of the third leg of the Triple Crown was tipped off everywhere you looked yesterday: all over the program, on the infield flowerbeds, on the starting gate, on the sign at the front of the track and on the name of the race itself. In the Belmont Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, the winner was Caveat, a colt owned by August Belmont 4th, in whose family's honor the race and the track are named.

title: BEACH EROSION: NATURE VS. SHORTSIGHTED MAN
description: ALONG Westhampton Beach, at about 650 Dune Road, is a most remarkable man-made stone jetty, where people often stop to marvel at the extraordinary shortsightedness of man when he tries to control nature and does not go about it wisely.

title: RACING FOR BENEFITS
description: A race for love or money - love of Dad, that is, and money to benefit the Muscular Dystrophy Association -will be held at 8:45 A.M. Saturday at the New Bazaar in the Mount Kisco Mall on Route 117.

title: ENVOY IN GUATEMALA FOR TALKS
description: Richard B. Stone, President Reagan's special envoy, nearing the end of a 10-day Latin American tour, met today with Guatemalan officials after a day of talks in Nicaragua.

title: Mailbox; Steinbrenner Seen as Father
description: To the Sports Editor: Mathias Hagovsky and Michael Gerson provide a very interesting prism through which to view team sports, the way players react to the supportive or disruptive ''family'' created by owners and managers (''The Familial Relationship of the Pro Sports Team,'' The New York Times, May 22).

title: MUMBLES: CHILDHOOD'S SUMMER IDYLL
description: SARA EVANS is a writer based in New York.

title: ALBANY RACES DEADLINE ON RENT-STABILIZATION CHANGES
description: AT the end of this month, the two-year extension of the New York S tate's rent stabilization law expires, and once again legislators a re haggling over what to change and what to leave alone.

title: TURNER CAPTURES REGATTA ON 2 FIRSTS
description: Ted Turner, the cable television entrepreneur and former America's Cup skipper, today won the Moet Masters Regatta, 2-1, over Gary Jobson, his former tactician, in extremely close racing on Narragansett Bay.

title: Controversy Over Striped-Bass Limits
description: ABILL that would make it illegal to harvest striped bass under 24 i nches long in New York State's coastal waters has passed all its c rucial committee tests and is expected to go before the Assembly s hortly.

title: WASHINGTON GETTING RESORT 'BOARDWALK'
description: TRENTON STROLLERS around the landlocked Washington Monument and Lincoln Memorial may imagine they hear the pounding of surf this summer because an Atlantic City-style boardwalk will be laid out on the mall.

title: IT'S PICKING TIME ON THE FARM
description: FIRST there was the mild winter, which had the farmers cheering - too soon. A cold, wet spring hardly deserving of the name has stalled the growing season.

title: BOARD OF N.A.A.C.P. DECIDES TO STRIP CHAIRMAN OF POWERS
description: By an overwhelming majority, the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today reaffirmed its call for the resignation of its chairman, Margaret Bush Wilson, and stripped her of all her powers.

title: STATE STUDYING STEPS TO IMPROVE PUBLIC EDUCATION
description: IN A widely acclaimed report, the bipartisan National Commission on Excellence in Education recently warned that a ''rising tide of mediocrity'' was sweeping the country's schools and threatening the nation's security.

title: NEW BEGINNING FOR AND OLD ESTATE
description: AFTER decades of uncertainty and two years of intense local debate, a 1,481-acre tract of land in the town of North Castle and in neighboring Greenwich, Conn., appears about to be developed as a community of luxury houses.

title: STEVIE NICKS AND RICKIE LEE JONES CARRY ON THE TORCH
description: The newest albums by Stevie Nicks and Rickie Lee Jones both stand firmly against the prevailing pop trend toward aural mechanization and cool-headed irony.

title: THE PLANT BIOLOGISTS TURN OVER A NEW LEAF
description: Ten years ago, in a book called ''The Secret Life of Plants,'' the idea was advanced that plants were more than just roots, stems, trunks, branches, flowers and leaves. The authors cited the work of polygraph expert Cleve Backster, who contended that some members of the plant kingdom were sentient organisms with human-like emotions and could perceive and react to the injury or death of other organisms.

title: AUTO ORATORY
description: My friend Ralph bought one of the new talking cars. When he took possession, it had new-car smell and said things like, ''Buckle your seat belt,'' ''Lock your door'' and ''Turn on your headlights.''

title: CAESAREAN BIRTHS INCREASE
description: ABOUT one of every five babies born in the state last year was delivered by Caesarean section, major surgery that has increased in use over the past decade in Connecticut and across the country.

title: NEW LIFE FOR MOTEL
description: Perched on a hilltop above Suffern, N.Y., the Japanese-style buildings of the Motel on the Mountain have long been a landmark for motorists on the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.

title: The Nation in Summary; SEnators Limit Outside Earnings
description: It didn't sit well with voters when some United States Senators earned more last year from speeches for profit than from speeches for principle. Last week, after six months of uncapped outside income - and uncapped criticism, inside and out -the Senate voted to limit earnings from speeches and articles.

title: Carol L. Wallis and James F. Duffy, Lawyers, Wed
description: Carol Leigh Wallis, daughter of Lucille Fischer Wallis of Endicott, N.Y., and the late Vernon P. Wallis, was married yesterday to James F. Duffy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Duffy of Orange City, Fla. The Rev. John Sanborn performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Evangelical Lutheran Church in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Yugoslav Mine Toll Up to 21
description: The death toll from a coal mine explosion in southern Serbia on Tuesday rose to 21 today after six Yugoslavs and a West German engineer died of burns and other injuries.

title:
GARDENING;
THE FUNGI THAT LOOM IN THE SPRING
description: THIS has been a strange spring. The first things to flower were exceptionally early, as a result of an unusually warm late winter. Later on, cool, cloudy, humid conditions delayed flowering of those plants next in line. Still later, the season seemed to telescope, with many plants that would not normally bloom together doing so.

title: YOUTH OFFICIAL ASKS COMMUNITY EFFORTS
description: IN his first public appearance since being confirmed last month as Director of the state's Division for Youth, Leonard G. Dunston told a county audience that the efforts of his administration ''would be geared toward delinquency prevention, with community involvement as the key.''

title: GAYLE DYER VIEBRANZ WILL MARRY ON JULY 16
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Viebranz of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagemment of their daughter, Gayle Dyer Viebranz, to Robert D. Welch, son and Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Welch of Phoenix. AJuly 16 wedding is planned.

title: Italy Halts Signings
description: Italy's governing body for soccer has banned teams from signing any more foreign stars, although foreigners playing in Italy can continue to do so.

title: Emily Fuller and Newby Toms Marry
description: The marriage of Emily Fuller Kingston and Newby Toms took place yesterday in the garden of St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church in Greenwich Village. The Rev. Louise L. Kingston, sister-in-law of the bride and chaplain of the Medical Center in Princeton, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: RENTING YOURS FOR THE SEASON
description: FOR owners of properties in resort areas, the approach of summer is f requently the time when they wonder what they can earn by renting f or the season.

title: AID AND TRADE ARE IN THE AIR AT NORTH-SOUTH TALKS IN BELGRADE
description: like building on the banks of the polluted and anythingbut-blue Danube.

title: DEALING WITH POLITICS
description: The political problems that bedevil the World Bridge Federation have in recent years improved quantitatively but not qualitatively. The People's Republic of China now meets Taiwan in international events, although only on neutral ground. Israel is now a minor problem, since Arab countries other than Egypt rarely compete in world championships. But for the world body the South African headache has become a migraine.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN WEST ORANGE, ASK FOR SERGIO
description: THERE are some little restaurants so special that the cognoscenti go to great lengths to keep them from being discovered. However, this week's review is of a year-old trattoria called Ca Mea, which is just the opposite; in this case, the restaurant itself plays hard to get.

title: U.S. PREPARES SITES FOR NEW MISSILES
description: Officials at Atlantic alliance headquarters here report that preliminary work on deploying American-made mediumrange nuclear missiles in Europe is under way.

title: WASHINGTON
description: RECENT Supreme Court decisions give the impression that the Court has suddenly discovered nuclear power and doesn't know what to do about it. The decisions wander all around the topic, from the psychological legacy of Three Mile Island to last week's ruling on nuclear waste disposal, without converging on a theme.

title: Marilyn Katz Engaged to Steven Weiss
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Katz of Mount Lebanon, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marilyn Dianne Katz, to Steven Neil Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Weiss of New York.

title: HOUSING RE-EMERGES AS A CENTRAL ISSUE
description: Congress has had little taste or time for a battle over housing policy in recent years, largely because it was ensnarled in budget, immigration, Social Security and regulatory issues. Congress and the White House remain sharply divided over budget matters, but with the 1984 election looming, Washington last week moved deeper into a struggle over the first major housing legislation since 1980.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Have-Nots of The New Era
description: Twenty years ago, C.P. Snow foresaw a ''gulf of mutual incomprehension'' separating literary intellectuals and scientists. In his maiden speech in the Senate last week, Frank R. Lautenberg, Democrat of New Jersey, said a similar gulf now separates computer literates and illiterates - meaning, all too often, children in wealthy school districts and children in poor ones.

title: LEO AND THE LADIES OF TEMPERAMENT
description: IN SEARCH OF LOVE AND BEAUTY By Ruth Prawer Jhabvala. 251 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.95.

title: THE NEW ACTIVISTS: BIG INVESTORS
description: FOR Citibank, it was an awkward situation. The bank's $20 billion t rust department, which held one million shares of Superior Oil for i ts clients, wanted to vote them against Superior's management in a p roxy battle. The hitch was that the oil company was also a customer o f the bank, so a vote against management in effect would be a vote a gainst one of the bank's own customers.

title: EXPOS DEFEAT METS,5-2
description: Bobby Ramos spent six weeks in New York last summer, all of them in Yankee pinstripes. He now wears the red-white-and-blue uniform of the Montreal Expos, as the backup catcher to Gary Carter, a job that has added only 10 games of major league experience to his career record.

title: Fighting Back: Lewis W. Lehr; AT 3M, A TOUGH STANCE AGAINST A TOUGH ENVIRONMENTAL BILL
description: WHEN Lewis W. Lehr graduated from the University of Nebraska in 1 947 with a degree in chemical engineering, one of his professors c asually suggested that he apply for a job at the Minnesota Mining & M anufacturing Company -''that nice little company up in St. Paul,'' t he professor called it. The 26-year-old Mr. Lehr took the advice ands oon landed a position working in 3M's Tape Division testing a dhesives for $65 a week.

title: SHARING SPACE FOR THE SHORT TERM
description: ''T HIS is all temporary - just until we see how we're going to do,'' said Diane Lepold, glancing around the cramped eight-foot-square office she shares with her partner, Naomi Singer. ''In six months, we'll look at it again.''

title: Shell Game
description: The waterfront is notorious for bringing out thievery in the human spirit, as any boat owner will testify. Yet things are getting worse. Nothing that isn't nailed down and patrolled by three-headed dogs with slavering jaws has ever been safe from thievery on a docked boat. But there was once a certain honor among thieves on the open water.

title: Jean Bronson Is Bride
description: Jean Henderson Bronson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Richardson Bronson 2d of Southampton, L.I., was married there yesterday to Cameron Frederick Conway, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Conway of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Malcolm L. Foster performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church. The bride, a graduate of Drew University, is a trainee at the Selected Risk Insurance Company in Morristown, N.J. Her husband, a material handler at Pyrotronics, a Cedar Knolls, N.J., manufacturer of fire and smoke detectors, graduated from the American University in Washington.

title: REAGAN, ASSAILING CRITICS, DEFENDS HIS ENVIRONMENT POLICY AS 'SOUND'
description: President Reagan, asserting that it was ''time to clear the air'' on his environmental policies, charged today that critics had distorted his environmental record and that under his Administration the nation was growing ''more healthy and more beautiful each year.''

title: MISS HAYNIE LEADS LPGA BY 4 SHOTS
description: Sandra Haynie surged past the faltering Alexandra Reinhardt with a five-under-par 67 to take the third-round lead today in the Ladies Professional Golfers Association championship, the second of the four major women's events.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Someone in the press the other day said that if Jim discovered a cure for cancer, there are those who would attack him for being prolife.'' - President Reagan, speaking of Interior Secretary James G. Watt. (1:1.

title: Differing Views On Sex Education
description: I was extremely disturbed to learn from Charlotte Lichterman's letter to the Long Island editor on May 22 that Birthright enthusiasts are permitted to moralize in Long Island schools in the absence of presentations by the pro-choice majority.

title: ROSE-BREASTED GROSBEAK; Pheucticus ludovicianus
description: Size: Seven to eight and a half inches. Color: Male: head, throat and back, black; rosy triangular breast patch and underwing coverts; wings, black with white markings; tail, black tipped with white.

title: High U.S. Submarine Official To Be Head of Naval Academy
description: The United States Naval Academy has announced that Rear Adm. Charles R. Larson will become superintendent of the school in September.

title: X-RATED MOVIES AND OTHER MISCELLANY
description: Move over Walkman. Micro-Phonics Ltd. of Mesa, Ariz., hopes to sell its ''Earadio,'' an FM radio so small it clips on to one's ear like some hearing aids. Unlike the Walkman, though, it lacks a numbered dial and is not stereo. For a fuller sound, however, an earplug for the other ear can be plugged in using a wire that runs around the neck . . . . Toshiba now has a telephone-answering machine that uses electronic speech synthesis. Instead of beeping, it electronically says: ''Please leave your message'' . . . . With AM stereo radio unable to get off the ground, lacking a signal-transmission standard, Sansui and Sony have come out with radios that can pick up broadcasts using any of the four competing AM stereo systems . . . . Sony, which developed the Betamax video cassette recorder, is going to make tape for the competing VHS machines. While Sony said it would still support Beta, the VHS format has 70 percent of the market and making blank tapes for that market is necessary for the growth of its tape business.

title: SUFFOLK IN PHOTOS: THEN AND NOW
description: AT first glance, ''Mile-a-Minute'' Murphy, who in 1899 pedaled his bicycle behind a Long Island Rail Road train to prove he could ride a mile aminute, would seem to have little in common with the vacationers disco dancing the hours away at a Hamptons night club, circa 1982.

title: Atlanta
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT REINSTATES LAWSUIT BY NURSE ON DISMISSAL FROM A CITY HOSPITAL
description: A Federal appeals court has reinstated a suit by the former director of nursing at the Harlem Hospital Center who contended she was dismissed last year because of her efforts to expose what she said was evidence of fraud, waste and mismanagement at the municipal hospital.

title: P.C. Bowers Plans to Wed Miss Davies
description: The engagement of Wendy Anne Wilding Davies to Philip Caldwell Bowers has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Edward Alfred Davies of New York and Redding Ridge, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Philippa Stanwood Bowers of Washington and Alexander Stewart Bowers of New York and Earlysville, Va.

title: TARGET OF 'FLEXIBILITY' IS CONGRESS, NOT THE KREMLIN
description: WASHINGTON AMID much fanfare last week, President Reagan announced that he was altering his proposal to the Soviet Union in the strategic arms reductions talks and dangled promises of continuing flexibility. But when the noise died down, the situation looked like this: He had made the minimum necessary changes in his negotiating approach to capture a Congressional majority for the new MX missile, but not nearly enough to achieve a breakthrough in the talks that resumed in Geneva on Wednesday.

title: RECITAL: MISS LIPSON-GRUZEN
description: The pianist Berenice Lipson-Gruzen is at her best in the Impressionism of Debussy and Ravel. At Alice Tully Hall Thursday night, Miss Lipson-Gruzen presented an exhilarating performance of Ravel's ''Jeux d'eau,'' which captured the flash and sparkle of a long-ago fountain with the antiquated vividness of an aural daguerreotype.

title: BY GEORGE TALOUMIS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Taloumis is a garden photographer and freelance writer.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE LORE AND LURE OF PAPERWEIGHTS
description: HAMMONTON PAPERWEIGHTS have been made in New Jersey since the mid-1800's, a period when glassworks proliferated in the southern part of the state.

title: MORE BANKS WEIGH DISCOUNT BROKERAGE
description: FIVE Connecticut banks are offering, or soon will offer, discount brokerage services. Others are expected to follow suit in coming months, as a result of a Federal Reserve Bank ruling in November that dealing in stocks and bonds is an acceptable banking practice.

title: OUTLOOK DIM ON THE SUNRISE
description: EFFORTS to get the lights back on along two miles of Sunrise Highway through Valley Stream have met another roadblock. A report by the State Department of Transportation says there is no link between street lighting and a reduction in accidents on the roadway.

title: SVEN NYKVIST PAINTS WITH LIGHT
Ballesteros Takes One-Shot Lead on a 70
description: Seve Ballesteros, the Spanish golfer who has become a major attraction, lost a match with the PGA Tour commissioner, Deane Beman, early this week when Beman refused to allow him to make numerous appearances in European tournaments if Ballesteros became a regular member of the tour.

title: ARTWARE THAT GOES TO YOUR HEAD
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR AS a subject for adornment, the ear has intrigued metalsmiths in every corner of the world through every period of history. Rarely, however, is the earring celebrated as a genre in itself.

title: NEW YORK TELEPHONE SEEKING 2.7% RATE RISE
description: The New York Telephone Company has asked for a $160 million rate increase, which would raise the average cost of home telephone service about 2.7 percent throughout the state.

title: RUSSIAN ECONOMY GIVES ANDROPOV HUGE PROBLEMS
description: Yuri V. Andropov is seeking to rescue the Soviet economy from the stagnation into which it lapsed during the final years of the Brezhnev regime. But his effort faces enormous economic, political and ideological obstacles.

title: Australian Premier In Washington for Talks
description: Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia arrived today on an official visit that could be marred by disagreement over his Government's plan to resume aid to Vietnam.

title: Jet Lag
description: To the Editor: The concept of jet lag discussed in the article ''The Jet-Lag Diet'' (Travel, May 22) is baloney. Passengers are tired after a night on an airplane because the airline refuses to let them sleep.

title: SHOREHAM DISPUTE: FILM WITHOUT END
description: FOUR years ago, Michael Madigan and John Hall, Long Island film makers, set out to make a documentary about the nuclear plant at Shoreham. Today, with 400 minutes of 16-millimeter film in the can, hundreds of hours of sound track recorded, and thousands of still photographs on file -some 90 percent of what they estimate they will need for a one-hour film -they are still no closer to completing what has become a prolonged ''labor of love.'' For until the fate of the Lilco facility is decided, by either government or the courts, ''The Critical Balance of Nuclear Power'' has no end.

title: LIBRARIES LENDING COMPUTERS
description: BACK in the days B.C. (Before Computers), libraries stuffed their shelves with books and lured potential readers with literary lectures and story hours.

title: CANADA'S TORIES CHOOSE A CHALLENGER TO TRUDEAU
description: Brian Mulroney, a 44-year-old Quebec businessman who has never won any political office, tonight eked out a narrow come-from-behind victory to gain the leadership of a Conservative Party that is seeking to end l5 years of Liberal rule.

title: The World in Summary; General Sounds Cautionary Vote On El Salvador
description: A lot of people fear that the errors of Vietnam could be repeated in Central America. It may matter that one of them is Gen. Edward C. Meyer, the Army Chief of Staff.

title: A MAJORITY IN POLL APPROVE OF CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo is getting good marks from New Yorkers for his first five months in office, even among groups that voted heavily against his election last year, according to a statewide public opinion poll.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
HISTORY FESTIVAL
description: Although the work at the Brookhaven National Laboratory is very much geared to the present - and the future - the lab has a past, too. Until 1947 it was the site of Camp Upton, an active military post during both World Wars. Emphasizing this chapter of its past, the lab is staging a History Festival today to kick off its seventh season of free public tours and to mark Suffolk County's Tercentenary.

title: DOOMED SCENARIO FOR SOVIET WITHDRAWAL FROM AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: INQUIRY ON MT. VERNON CHEMICAL CONCERNS
description: MOUNT VERNON TWO companies operating a chemical resale business in this city have become the subject of investigations and enforcement actions by state and city agencies, which have accused them of improper storage practices, discharging industrial wastes into a storm drain and endangering residents by abandoning chemicals in a leased warehouse.

title: STATE NEAR DECISION ON OAK BRUSH AREA
description: THE State Office of General Services will soon make a recommendation to Governor Cuomo on whether to permit development of the largest remaining open space in western Long Island.

title: Laura Griffith Married To R.G. McDermott Jr.
description: Laura Ladd Griffith of Short Hills, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Community Congregational Church to Richard Gerard McDermott Jr. The Rev. Keyon J. Wildrick performed the ceremony.

title: CONCERT PIANIST AND TEACHER
description: Nadia Reisenberg, a pianist and teacher whose technique was praised by Sergei Rachmaninoff, died Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 78 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Fare of the Country article (Travel, May 15), the recipe for osso buco as prepared at La Pesa restaurant in Milan erroneously included cream as an ingredient.

title: REHABILITATION HOLDING BRONX BLIGHT AT BAY
description: FROM the breezy roof where he takes visitors for panoramic views of t he Bronx to the sparkling tile lobby that must be crossed for a g limpse of the new boiler in the basement, the handsome brick a partment house at 114 West 183d Street is clearly the apple of J oseph Bodak's eye.

title: The Region in Summary; Welcome Move On Medicaid
description: Medicaid, the health care program for the poor, strains the fiscal resources of cities and counties up and down New York State. Last week it cut across the political landscape, too, when Warren M. Anderson, leader of the Senate Republicans, changed his mind and proposed a partial state takeover of the program's mounting local costs.

title: NEW LOOK AT OX RIDGE SHOW
description: ALTHOUGH the Merrill Lynch-Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show in Darien is one of the area's oldest and most traditional equestrian fixtures, this year's edition, which opens on Thursday, will have a brand-new look.

title: Lizabeth Lefferts Wed To C.J. Arliss, Broker
description: Lizabeth M. Lefferts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jacob R.V.M. Lefferts 3d of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles J. Arliss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Arliss of Locust, N.J. The Rev. James Duffy performed the ceremony at the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Rumson.

title: THE BRITISH KNOW WHEN TO CALL IT QUITS
description: Television's situation comedy is a curiously fragile creature. Each year dozens of new sitcoms are splattered across the prime-time schedule with the fervent hope that at least a few will stick in there and last long enough to reap a fortune for the producing studios and networks. The vast majority, of course, fail, their inane plots and loud laugh tracks quickly and blessedly doomed to oblivion. But the basic form remains peculiarly compatible with television's urge to entertain, and the sitcom marches relentlessly on.

title: SUMMARY OF 1983 REGULAR SESSION
description: Following are some of the major issues dealt with by the 1983 regular session of the General Assembly, which adjourned Wednesday:

title: Integrated Music
description: MTV's Bob Pittman considerably distorts history when he ''cites the fact that black and white popular music have always been segregated'' (''TV Rocks With Music,'' by Ed Levine, May 8). This statement is so far from the truth that merely by refuting it, one must also call into question the assertion in the same article that ''there is no racial motivation behind this programming decision.''

title: POETRY AND MUSIC
description: Describing his recent piano composition, ''Night Fantasies,'' Elliott Carter referred to poems by Mallarme, William Carlos Williams and Robert Lowell. A previous composition, ''Syringa,'' was a collaboration with the poet John Ashbery. Most of Mr. Carter's recent works draw upon parallel poetic universes: ''A Symphony of Three Orchestras'' is a musical interpretation of Hart Crane's ''The Bridge''; ''A Mirror on Which to Dwell'' sets poems by Elizabeth Bishop. Throughout his career, Mr. Carter - one of the most important, imaginative and challenging of contemporary composers - has been drawn to the conceptual world of contemporary poetry, to its irony and intricate images.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (NL) - Optioned Paul Mos- k au, right-handed pitcher, to the Cubs' c lass AAA team in Des Moines. COLLEGE FLORIDA - Hired Scott Irving as a ssistant women's track and field coach. I rving has held a similar post at Oregon, FOOTBALL MICHIGAN (USFL) - Signed Bob G rupp, former punter with the Kansas C ity Chiefs, to a one-year contract.

title: A REINCARNATION
description: For 67 years, until 1977, National Guard soldiers met, drilled and stored equipment in the White Plains Armory on Boston Post Road and Mitchell Place. Then enrollment began to dwindle, maintenance costs rose sharply, and the National Guard stopped using the castle-like yellow brick building, which has been designated a landmark by both Federal and state governments.

title: NEW AND THE OLD IN MUSIC FESTIVALS
description: ''WHEN I play a Bach concerto with the East Overshoe Philharmonic,'' jokes the renowned harpsichordist, Igor Kipnis, ''the modern instruments and limited rehearsal time make it impossible to achieve what you really want. The music usually comes out heavy, sounding a bit like not well-cooked potato pancakes.''

title: Tess Keresey Has Nuptials
description: Mary Therese Keresey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Mill Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to Kevin Randall Hennessy, son of Mrs. John Edward Hennessy of Sacramento, Calif., and the late Mr. Hennessy. The Rev. Dr. Hays H. Rockwell performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: WOMEN GET JOB TRAINING AT Y
description: BARBARA BOYD, at the age of 32, believed she was in a rut. Recently separated from her husband, she was living in a dreary housing project in Bridgeport, trying to support herself and two children last year on welfare and income from a part-time job.

title: SPORTS FIGURES AID CHARITIES
description: NEXT Thursday, the Long Island chapter of the American Diabetes Association will be aided in its fund-raising efforts by the wives of several members of the New York Islanders.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JUNE 12, 1983
description: International The British Cabinet was reorganized by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher at the start of her second term. Foreign Secretary Francis Pym, a moderate with whom she had often quarreled, was dismissed and replaced by Sir Geoffrey Howe, who was Chancellor the Exchequer. Mrs. Thatcher also shifted William Whitelaw, who had been Deputy Prime Minister and Home Secretary, to the House of Lords. He will be given a hereditary peerage. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: AFOOT AND UNHURRIED IN LUCCA
description: A. ALVAREZ's most recent book is ''The Biggest Game in Town'' (Houghton-Mifflin).

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Two flutists and a cellist made their New York debuts last week and, as usual, each had an accompanying pianist. One way of evaluating the soloists is to consider their relationships with those pianists.

title: Government Thrift
description: With Federal and state aid to cities shriveling, Jersey City's Mayor said a year ago this month that he hoped to trim administrative costs by turning over 25 to 40 municipal services to United Way agencies and the Jersey City Medical Center.

title: HUNTERDON TUNES IN TO CHAMBER MUSIC
description: EIGHT years ago, Hunterdon County residents had to drive 50 miles to find classical music in the summertime. Ira and June Kapp remedied that by founding the Soclair Music Festival, a four-part chambermusic series sponsored by the Clinton Historical Museum Village and directed by the harpsichordist Edward Brewer.

title: DOES A 'PUBLIC FIGURE' HAVE A RIGHT TO PRIVACY?  WELL...
description: Early in Mayo Sisler's libel suit against The Courier-News, a newspaper in Bridgewater, N.J., the trial judge held that Mr. Sisler was not a public figure. It did not matter that the offending article concerned Mr. Sisler's loan from a bank he once headed, that he had run for public office and had long been active in civic affairs. For that trial, which ended two weeks ago in a $1 million verdict against the newspaper, he was a private figure.

title: No Headline
description: Oklahoma State won the team title in the 86th National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championship by seven strokes today, but Jim Carter of Arizona State won the individual championship on an extra hole.

title: Major News in Summary; Looks Like a Long Lebanon Summer
description: Blocked on the ground in his contest for control of demoralized Palestinian troops who have mutinied in Lebanon's Bekaa district, Yasir Arafat last week sought support and solace on a flying tour of Arab and third world capitals.

title: THE WHITNEY COLLECTION HELPS FILL OUT ART HISTORY
description: The main event of the summer at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., is the first-ever exhibition of the John Hay Whitney Collection in its entirety. Certain facts about the collection have long been well known. Since Mr. Whitney died last year, important groups of paintings have been given to the National Gallery of Art, the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Yale Art Gallery. But a great many others remain, and such is the private character of the collection that nothing comparable to the present show has been seen before.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN PORTLAND, ME.
description: It has been more than a century since Portland, Maine's largest city, served as the state capital and saw its windswept shores immortalized in the seascape of Winslow Homer. Those golden days might be gone, but after decades of economic and cultural stagnation, the city has recently managed to turn itself around. A building renaissance, spurred by civil outrage over a policy of urban renewal by demolition, got under way 10 years ago and has largely succeeded in rescuing Portland's rich architectural heritage.

title: A FEW STAY ON IN LONELY TIMES BEACH, MO.
description: Adam Johnson often sits on the redwood picnic table in his backyard and talks to his cat, Midnight, one of the boy's few remaining companions in a town destroyed by floods and dioxin.

title: JOYCE MARATHON
description: A marathon reading of the 783 pages of ''Ulysses'' by James Joyce will be undertaken from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. Thursday at Paperback Alley, 984 Sullivan Avenue, South Windsor. Visitors will be invited to read passages from the book that was banned in the United States as obscene from 1922 to 1934.

title: College Results; World Series; AT OMAHA, NEB.; FIRST ROUND; June 3
description: Oklahoma State 3, Stanford 1. Texas 12, James Madison 0. JUne 4 Alabama 6, Arizona State 5 (11 inn.)

title: THE CASE FAVORING WESTBETH CO-OPS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; LOosening Up Social Security's Disability Fund
description: Pruning of Social Security's $18 billion disability payment program was probably overdue - the General Accounting Office once estimated that 20 percent of the recipients weren't entitled. But the political cost of a crackdown that began soon after Inauguration Day had come to outweigh savings, some officials feared.

title: DEATH OF A PARTY
description: The British election is being treated widely in the United States as Margaret Thatcher's triumph, but it is that only up to a point. More significantly, it is a defeat for the Labor Party: defeat by self-destruction. And it is there that Democrats in this country should look for lessons.

title: Stephanie Hugus Married
description: Stephanie Hugus, daughter of Elizabeth Woods Hugus of Old Greenwich, Conn., and Wright Hugus Jr. of Aspen, Colo., was married yesterday in Dorset, Vt., to Michael B. Racz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen E. Racz of Milford, Conn. The Rev. Hal Miller performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ.

title: NEWFOUNDLAND SEALERS CALL HUNT VITAL TO ISLE
description: It truly bothers Jack Troake that, far away from this picturesque fishing village in northern Newfoundland, there are people who apparently think he is a barbarian, and who would like to prevent him from making his living in the way that thousands of others here have done for centuries - by including sealing among his other pursuits of fishing, chopping wood and hunting moose.

title: BOXING AND THE BRAIN
description: Ringside at the Felt Forum. It is a night of fights. Eager young men are climbing into the ring for the first official bouts of their lives. Some of them look frightened, some of them look confident and some of them look sleepy and confused, as if they had just waked from a strange dream. They are subnovices, amateurs fighting in the preliminary matches of the New York Golden Gloves tournament.

title: Article 228260 -- No Title
description: The crowd at Belmont Park saw one of the best cards in the track's history yesterday. Besides the Belmont Stakes, there were four other stakes races. They were run as the fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh races, directly preceding the Belmont.

title: Girl, 7, Awarded $8 Million
description: A 7-year-old girl whose parents were among 154 people killed in the crash of a Pan American World Airways jet in New Orleans in July will receive $8 million to $12 million under a court settlement announced by her attorneys. A Dade County Circuit Court judge approved the settlement Tuesday for Janice Zerwal, who is now living with an aunt and uncle in Texas.

title: 'RESKILLING' WORKERS
description: Springtime is always a period of great optimism. This year, even the economy is cooperating. Each week brings forth a new burst of glowing statistics, blossoming into financial euphoria like so many brilliant flowers. Yet this recovery is unlikely to provide what people want most -jobs - because this recovery is unusual.

title: Stars Are Excelling With Consistency
description: What is the key element of the Philadelphia Stars' success? Is it Kelvin Bryant? Is it the lack of turnovers or the other teams' turnovers? Is it the consistent play of the Doghouse Defense? Is it being able to field the same lineup week after week, a result of few injuries?

title: NO EDITORS NEEDED: BAD WRITING WINS PRIZES
description: Andrew Sterbenz, a straight-A high school student, will remember Wednesday night for a long time. It was the night of the banquet for all graduating seniors. And it was the night he was declared the worst juvenile author in the world.

title: HEARINGS ON DRUG AGENCY NOMINEE DELAYED AGAIN
description: Hearings on the long-delayed confirmation of Francis M. Mullen Jr. to be chief of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration have been postponed by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: ON ECONOMICS, REAGAN RELIES ON 'AUTOMATIC PILOT'
description: The Reagan Administration's leading economic policy advisers, known as the troika, still breakfast once a week in the Treasury Secretary's private dining room. There they discuss the issues of the day, the Federal budget, taxes, monetary policy and the international debt. But for all the trappings of collegiality, it seems clear that there is little agreement or direction among them.

title: WHEN MONEY TALKS, WHAT DOES IT SAY ABOUT ART
description: ''$1 million has a very neat sound, but it has nothing to do with painting.'' -Jasper Johns

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Gillian C. Yarbrough Married to David W. Baulieu
description: Gillian Chambers Yarbrough, daughter of Mrs. Victor Stirling Luke of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Kenneth Yarbrough of Miami, was married yesterday to David Warren Baulieu, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Baulieu of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Thiel performed the ceremony at the Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale.

title: Major News in Summary; The Heavy Odds Against a Budget
description: Optimists in Washington were nearly as rare as atheists in foxholes last week as Congressional conferees began work on a budget resolution for fiscal 1984.

title: Maine Town Combats Bugs With Dragonfly
description: The Wells Chamber of Commerce has imported more than 13,000 dragonflies this spring to feed on mosquitoes and help control the insect population in several southern coastal towns.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $98,000 *2*36 Idlebrook Lane, 5-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*19-year-old Cape Cod; 2 patios, large family *2*room; taxes $2,950. Guttenberg $85,000 *2*15 68th Street, 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 50-year-old *2*row house; extra apartment in basement; *2*taxes $1,280. Livingston $109,000 *2*22 Audubon Road, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old *2*split level; screened porch, new appliances; *2*taxes $2,344. Morristown $145,000 *2*11 Sycamore Lane, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath *2* 3-year-old colonial; house condominium; parquet *2*floors, wet bar, brick patio; *2*taxes $1,374. Mountainside $150,000 *2*1101 Sylvan Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*19-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, pool, *2*chair rail in dining room; taxes $2,215. Wayne $73,500 *2*41 Redwood Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*22-year-old ranch; hardwood floors, some *2*furniture included; taxes $1,346. OTHER AREAS White Plains, N.Y. $92,000 *2*62 Mount Morris Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*33-year-old frame ranch, basement playroom, *2*eat-in kitchen taxes $1,515. Avon, Conn. $120,000 *2*45 Applewood Lane, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*4-year-old town-house condominium on golf course; *2*monthly common charges $217; taxes $1,466. Westbury, L.I. $80,000 *2*968 Grand Boulevard, 4-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*32-year-old Cape Cod; formal dining room, *2*den with fireplace; taxes $1,800.

title: GUATEMALA ASKS REFUGEES TO RETURN
description: Guatemala has begun a campaign to persuade the tens of thousands of Guatemalan refugees in Mexico to return home, saying the violence that made them flee over the last two years has abated.

title: LEAD THE CHILDREN BACK TO CLASSICS
description: To the Editor:

title: COZY AND ETHNIC IN WESTPORT
description: MARIKA'S, yet another newcomer to the Westport scene, is one of those tiny, homey restaurants that is easy to like. What makes Marika's especially appealing is that it features ethnic specialties rare in this part of Connecticut: Polish, Hungarian and Russian. There are a few American and international dishes as well, and at lunchtime sandwiches, salads and omelets.

title: Body Found on Coast Studied For a Link to New York Man
description: A badly decomposed body has been found in clothes similar to those worn by Roy Alexander Radin, the New York theatrical producer, before his disappearance, the Los Angeles County Coroner's office said today.

title: BUYING TIME ON THOSE STUDENT LOANS
description: WITH most college graduation ceremonies now a matter of record, m any new graduates are turning their attention to more pressing m atters - such as determining how to repay their federally guaranteeds tudent loans. One option is a little-known government program, a ppropriately called Options, that allows borrowers to stretch out t heir repayments.

title: A.A. Gosnell Wed To Miss McGloon
description: Holly Susan McGloon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Howard McGloon of Nashua, N.H., formerly of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Arthur Andrews Gosnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hale Gosnell of Webster, N.Y. The Rev. Curtis G. Kemmerer performed the ceremony at the New Canaan (Conn.) Congregational Church.

title: HOUSTON VOTERS REJECT FUNDS FOR $2.35 BILLION TRANSIT PLAN
description: In a stunning setback to this Sunbelt boomtown's plans to build a modern urban rail system, voters today rejected by a wide margin a $2.35 billion bond issue that would have financed the first, 18.5-mile segment of the system.

title: Microcritic at Large
description: When 11-year-old Rawson Stovall traveled from his Abilene, Texas home to play video games at the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago last week, it wasn't just for the fun of it.

title: THE BAROQUE OF MINAS GERAIS
description: When the Portuguese colonizers arrived in Brazil, they didn't all tarry along the country's beaches, and there's no reason modern-day visitors should either. Many colonial settlers hiked over the mountain range that twists along the curving littoral, and on the high plains of what is today the state of Minas Gerais they found what they had gone looking for: gold.

title: THE PRIVATE LIFE OF HOMEMADE BREAD
description: IAPPROACHED the making of my first bread casually, knowing I would never want to get involved in serious weekly baking. I had known people who had become serious about bread making. They would guard a refrigerated jar of starter that dated from the time of Carlyle. They would hover over a bowl of dough and poke at it with two fingers. Flour would fall off their sleeves like drifting snow. They had schedules of watching and waiting, of shaping loaves, that seemed to consume an entire day. There was a zealousness and loftiness about these people that made me wary.

title: Acoustiguides
description: To the Editor:

title: ITALIAN AMERICANS: MAKING IT
description: In his article, Stephen Hall suggests to Mario Cuomo that he (Cuomo) has traveled a great distance in one generation. Mr. Cuomo's response, ''... as a family, as people of merit and excellence, I don't think I've yet improved upon my father,'' is a touching and insightful tribute, not only to a parent, but to understanding the wellspring of personhood.

title: The World in Summary; No Mail In, No Jews Out
description: One of the West's most aggrieved accusations against the Kremlin has been that it severely limits the emigration of disaffected Jews, in the past principally to Israel. Not at all, the Soviet Union said last week.

title: THE PLEASURES OF REREADING
description: Muriel Spark

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Cards Lose Smith
description: Lonnie Smith, eighth among National League hitters with a .311 average, will be lost to the St. Louis Cardinals for the next three weeks because of ''a drug problem,'' Manager Whitey Herzog said before yesterday's game against the Cubs in Chicago. ''Lonnie came up to me Thursday in Philadelphia and said he had a drug problem,'' Herzog explained.

title: CONSUMER RATES
JOINT EFFORT RENEWS A DUNE AT FAIRFIELD
description: THERE is a new sign at Rickard's Beach in Fairfield that reads: ''Dune Restored by the People of Fairfield - 1983.'' Carol A. Shively, a former Fairfield resident who conceived and executed the dune restoration project, says that it represents ''an exciting example of individuals, community groups, local government and private business working together for the welfare of the people and the conservation of natural resources.''

title: WHEN MORE IS LESS
description: t happens like this: A Paris waiter looks around, then whispers conspiratorially in your ear, ''Try this Burgundy; it's actually a declassified Gevrey-Chambertin from my brother-in-law's vineyard.'' The bottle is brought and opened. You sip, smile and exchange winks with the clever waiter. How wonderful to find a bargain in good Burgundy. Well, maybe. The declassification racket is under tighter control now than it was a few years ago, but it persists.

title: LEARNING TO LET GO MEANS LOVE
description: LAST week, I watched my daughter, Erika, pack her camp trunk. It was interesting to see what she would choose to pack into the unfilled corners. What she chose were things that would help link her to the family that she was leaving and would help her bring security to the new place to which she was going.

title: Third Volume
description: To the Editor:

title: ARAFAT SAYS 5 WERE EXECUTED FOR PLOT AGAINST AIDE
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said here today that five people were tried and executed three weeks ago after they attempted to kill a P.L.O. official.

title: VOLCKER'S SELECTION LOOKS MORE LIKELY
description: Paul A. Volcker appeared to gain an edge late last week for reappointment as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Administration officials had said early in the week that President Reagan had been advised by top aides either to reappoint Mr. Volcker, whose term as chairman expires Aug. 6, or to choose Alan Greenspan, the economist. Later, soundings by the White House indicated conservative Republican sentiment favoring a Volcker reappointment. Republican Senator Paul Laxalt of Nevada, a Reagan confidant, was said to have found ''a lot of support'' for Mr. Volcker, and Howard H. Baker, the Senate Majority leader, has been actively campaigning for reappointment.

title: BRAZIL'S PASSIONATE CINEMA NOVO DELIVERS A FINE MOVIE
description: ''They Don't Wear Black Tie'' isn't a great title. There's something show-offy and a little bit patronizing about it, as if Leon Hirszman, the director, felt he had to introduce the characters and to explain that, unlike the rest of us who dine regularly on caviar and champagne, his people are simple, working-class folk.

title: Elizabeth H. Siener Marries Peter Raho
description: Elizabeth Holden Siener, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. P. Robert Siener Jr. of Greene, R.I., was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Peter S. Raho, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas C. Raho of Rye, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Peter Sidler of the Portsmouth (R.I.) Abbey School performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
