description: THE STORY OF BASEBALL By Lawrence S. Ritter. 148 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $8.50. (Ages 10 and Up) By MICHAEL LICHTENSTEIN

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN DANIEL GILDESGAME, a young man with a doctorate in developmental psychology, was talking to a woman seated across from him. ''Why are you so depressed,'' he asked, fixing her with a long stare and the faintest suggestion of a smile.

title: DISABLED VISIT A FRESH AIR FUND CAMP
description: Brandishing a large twig, Glenn Specht poked the ground as if he were searching for gold. He uncovered his treasure - an earthworm, bait for an evening fishing expedition.

title: CENTRIFUGAL FORCE AT WORK IN INDIAN POLITICS
description: Behind snow-capped Himalayan barriers, the Valley of Kashmir, the geographic and cultural heart of India's northernmost state, has always been set apart. Visitors arriving on domestic flights at the state capital of Srinagar after a short hop over the mountains from New Delhi are asked to show their passports, and Kashmiris traveling in the other direction say that they are ''going to India.''

title: THE QUEEN'S INDIAN HAS TAKEN ON NEW VITALITY
description: The Queen's Indian Defense is alive and well everywhere from Vrnjacka Banja to New York. For years it held an undisturbed niche in the scheme of the openings as a quiet, correct way to defend when White avoided a confrontation with the Nimzo-Indian Defense by the supposedly colorless 3 N-KB3. Lately, however, two things have happened to expand and threaten its niche: Fewer Nimzo-Indians are allowed by White because variations such as 3 N-QB3, B-N5; 4 P-K3, P-B4; 5 B-Q3, N-B3; 6 N-B3, BxNch; 7 PxB, P-Q3 are producing a very favorable win-to-loss ratio for Black. And White has bent to the task of developing 3 N-KB3 into a weapon - and with considerable success.

title: Miss von Stade And Brett Lewis Exchange Vows
description: Kathryne Steele von Stade, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. von Stade of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Brett Noyes Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willmott Lewis Jr., of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Herbert Beardsley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury, L.I.

title: Pakistani Ends Soviet Visit
description: Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan of Pakistan left here today after talks about Afghanistan, the Tass press agency said. Mr. Yaqub Khan conferred with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko on Friday. Asian diplomats said the Pakistani had been looking for signs Moscow might be ready to moderate its conditions for withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan.

title: ROMANTIC IDEALISM, BARNYARD REALISM
description: DURING THE REIGN OF THE QUEEN OF PERSIA By Joan Chase. 215 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: VATICAN EXHIBIT A SELLOUT
description: The exhibition of 237 Vatican art treasures has attracted a full house to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with a total attendance of 855,939 people in the course of the exhibition, which opened to the public on Feb. 26 and closes today.

title: The Flora Of India
description: From the mountains of Zabarwan, ablaze with flowers and studded with cedar and cypress, the route leads to the Pleasure Gardens of Kashmir, to the Taj Mahal at Agra, the medieval temples of Khajraho and the modern cities of Bombay and New Delhi. Beyond all this lie the tea farms of Sri Lanka, the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kandy, with their 150 varieties of orchids, and the tropical low country flora at the Henarathgoda Botanical Gardens near Colombo.

title: WHEN COMIC DANCING IS SERIOUS BUSINESS
description: Fresh from triumphs in Yokohama and points Far East, Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, the all-male dance company known for its zany ballerina impersonations, is back in New York after an absence of four years. The Trocks, as they are familiarly known, will open an ambitious three-week season at City Center on Wednesday with two old favorites, ''Les Sylphides'' and ''The Dying Swan,'' the premieres of ''The Pharaoh's Daughter'' and ''I Wanted To Dance With You at the Cafe of Experience,'' and the Soviet-style fireworks of ''Spring Waters.'' Leading the troupe are such stars as Ludmila Beaulemova, Margaret Lowin-Octeyn, D.B.E., Jacques d'Aniels and the Legupski Brothers. It is sure to be a controversial three weeks.

title: FLOODS AND DROUGHT SWEEP ACROSS SOUTH AMERICA
description: Widespread floods and a major drought in South America have left hundreds of people dead and hundreds of thousands sick and homeless over the last eight months.

title: VANDALISM DAMAGE DECLINES AT CITY'S SCHOOLS
description: The cost of vandalism in New York City public schools fell in 1982 and dropped by one-quarter in the first four months of this year from the same period last year, according to a Board of Education report.

title: 'VENGEANCE VOTE' WORRIES WHITE HOUSE
description: One of the President's men raised the specter last week that the G.O.P. is in danger of becoming known for the next generation as ''the party of the men'' - a minority party in an era when female voters are in the ascendance and are showing a statistical preference for Democrats that has become more pronounced during President Reagan's incumbency. Unfortunately, perhaps, for purposes of the warning presented by Edward J. Rollins, the White House political director, the message was delivered to Republican women who already know there are difficulties in trying to sell parts of the Reagan record to their sisters.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOW TO PROTECT YOUR CHARTER TOUR PAYMENTS
description: A New Jersey couple paid $690 for a four-day package tour to the World's Fair in Knoxville, Tenn., last June. The price included round-trip air fare, ground transportation, hotel accommodations for three nights and tickets to the World's Fair. Everything went fine until the couple landed in Knoxville.

title: New Earthquakes Hit Coalinga, Calif., Area
description: An earthquake and aftershocks struck the Coalinga area today and Friday, destroying a house, shifting mobile homes and breaking up roads, sixweeks after a devastating quake.

title: FOUR DIE AS SMALL PLANE CRASHES MINUTES AFTER LEAVING DANBURY
description: Four people were killed when their single-engine private plane crashed near the New York-Connecticut line yesterday afternoon, just minutes after taking off from Danbury Municipal Airport, authorities said.

title: STARTING OVER: A STATE IN NEED OF A BUDGET
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly is back at the Capitol in special session, about where it was when it first convened its regular session last Jan. 5.

title: BOULEVARD OF BROKEN WORDS
description: Charlton Heston, the only actor who turns when somebody yells, ''Moses!'' or, ''El Cid!'' called me one morning recently. His stentorian voice over the telephone was indistinct - he was calling from a car, or from the top of Mount Sinai - but it was clear he had a language problem.

title: Miss McKinney Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Cunningham McKinney, daughter of Representative and Mrs. Stewart Brett McKinney of Greens Farms, Conn., was married yesterday to Ronald Barthold Gaeta, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Gaeta of Southern Pines, N.C. The Rev. Steven Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., assisted by the Rev. William Sangiovanni of the Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Encyclopaedia Africana
description: To the Editor:

title: Christina Irwin Weds Steven Astrove
description: Christina Susan Irwin, head kindergarten teacher at the Christ Church Day School in New York, was married in Norfolk, Conn., yesterday to Steven Roger Astrove, a member of the class of '85 at the Columbia University School of Law. The Rev. Carol Anderson of All Angels Episcopal Church in New York performed the ceremony at the home of Elizabeth Irwin, mother of the bride.

title: Theresa Grace Plans August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Peter Grace of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Theresa Mary Grace, to Richard Michael Sears, son Jacqueline M. Sears of Concord, Mass., and the late John J. Sears.

title: MODEL, 53, IS A RARE SUCCESS STORY
description: Kaylan Pickford is a fashion model who readily admits that she is 53 years old. She wears the lines on her face proudly, and has not attempted to cover the white-on-gray hair that has helped give her what is known in the modeling business as ''a look.''

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: ADMITTING one's own mortality is a difficult thing, say psychiatrists and legal experts, which could help explain why many people do not leave wills. According to the American Bar Association, perhaps 50 percent of the people who should have wills do not. Fees charged by lawyers usually range from $75 to $100, another reason that some people, especially those financially burdened, have not looked toward the future.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: The following list has been selected from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of December 1982. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography & Biography

title: Palmer Near a Start
description: Jim Palmer of the Baltimore Orioles threw for 17 minutes without any problems today, indicating that he was ready to come off the disabled list.

title: MT. VERNON MAYOR WARNS LANDLORDS
description: THE city of Mount Vernon, which began phasing out rent control two years ago, will try to restore it if some of the landlords there persist in raising rents by 100 to 200 percent, Mayor Thomas E. Sharpe said last week.

title: U.S. IS FACING A TOUGH AMERICA'S CUP SUMMER
description: NEWPORT, R.I. IF the America's Cup is lost to a foreign challenger, Robert McCullough, chairman of the New York Yacht Club's cup committee, suggested, the losing skipper's head will be placed on the pedestal vacated by the trophy. McCullough was joking, naturally, but there was a certain sting behind the jest.

title: SUCCESS HOLDS NO LAUGHTER FOR RICHARD PRYOR
description: At a Lincoln Center tribute last year, Billy Wilder joked about the studio executives' recipe for producing a successful movie: ''They approach it very scientifically - computer projections, marketing research, audience profiles - and they always come up with the same answer: Get Richard Pryor.''

title: OFFICES PLANNED AT LIFE SAVERS SITE
description: PORT CHESTER OPERATIONS at the historic Life Savers candy plant on Main Street will end next year, leaving only one of the huge models of the familiar candy rolls - a landmark outside the building - ''as a souvenir in one of our parks,'' said Mayor Peter Iasillo. But by 1985, in a refurbished version of the same structure,''we should have an office building with 800 employees and tax revenues of $400,000 to $600,000,'' the Mayor said last week, as plans for the building were disclosed. Life Savers, which once had a payroll of 600, was down to 145 employees and tax payments of $125,000 when the plant's closing was announced.

title: THE ERRORS OF MARTIN FELDSTEIN'S CLAIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST GERMANY'S ANTIMISSILE ACTIVISTS DISCOURAGED
description: As the likelihood grows that new American mediumrange missiles will be stationed in West Germany late this year, a loose coalition of church and political groups known as ''the peace movement'' is showing signs of disorientation and even resignation over its failure to halt the deployments.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Ultimate Genetics Story

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS;
YOUR MOVE, MONTY
description: Computers have already mastered chess and checkers. Now the Ritam Corporation of Fairfield, Iowa, has developed a computerized Scrabble game.

title: ABORTION BATTLE MOVING TO STATES
description: After a decade of working to abolish abortion through Federal action, the anti-abortion movement is winning passage of restrictive measures on the state and local levels, both sides agree.

title: HOME BOX OFFICE MOVES INTO HOLLYWOOD
description: Robert Lindsey is the Los Angeles bureau chief of The Times. By Robert Lindsey

title: THE NOUVELLE RAPPAHANNNOCK CUISINE
description: MARIAN BURROS reports on food for The New York Times.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
PORTRAITS OF PEOPLE HELD SPELLBOUND BY READING
description: The photographs in Andre Kertesz's ''On Reading'' are simple in a way that seems old-fashioned now, however modern it may once have been. They are black-and-white candid camera shots of a sort that several generations of newspaper and magazine illustration have made familiar to almost everyone. They feature real and reasonably normal human beings, not dolls or models or freaks, they are taken of subjects who seem to be quite unaware of the photographer's presence, and though they are quite ''photographic'' in the sense that they do not resemble paintings, they do not seem to make ''being photographic'' into an end in itself.

title: 'CAMELOT' REWORKED BY ITS STAR
description: MOST Broadway musicals are simply streamlined for travel, ranging from the ''tab shows'' (short for tabloid) that are the trademark of some resorts) to abridged versions in stock or dinner theaters where lines and songs are shorn for the sake of speeding things up.

title: A PAX POLITICO HOLDS IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY WHAT passes for peace these days has returned to the Hudson County political scene. Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City has survived a strong challenge to his leadership by former Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith, and Mr. Smith has returned to his daily chores as City Clerk in his office one floor below Mr. McCann's in City Hall.

title: A STRANGELY EXHILARATING MIX OF ANGER AND HOPE
description: You can't do it until you get there, of course, but I'd suggest that you make very special note of the final minute or two of Caryl Churchill's ''Fen,'' which has quite sensibly extended its run at the Public through July 3. ''Fen'' has been borrowed from London as part of the Salute to Britain festival, it is by the already admired author of ''Cloud 9'' and ''Top Girls,'' and its wistfully upbeat coda tells us something interesting about an excellent but highly unpredictable playwright.

title: ALL ABOARD EL FRONTIZERO
description: EDWARD C. BURKS is a reporter and editor in the Washington bureau of The Times.

title: 19 RESTAURANTS CITED BY CITY
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 19 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and six that were closed for having failed to do so.

title:
Volcker's Fed;
THE RIGHT MAN, 'THE RIGHT STUFF'
description: ''Y EAGER received just about every major decoration and trophy that was available to test pilots, but the Yeager legend grew not in the press, not in public, but within the fraternity. As of 1948, after Yeager's flight was made public, every hot pilot in the country knew that Muroc (Army Air Force Base) was what you aimed for if you wanted to reach the top.

title: IF ROMANCE BE FOOD OF LIFE, WRITE ON
description: SEVERAL years ago, Rosemary Guiley, a writer and editor who worked for newspapers, magazines and corporations, decided she wanted to write a romance novel.

title: GREENMARKET IS BURGEONING IN SUNSHINE
description: Just before the sky above his family's 100-acre farm in Goshen, N.Y., turned light yesterday morning, Tom Osczepinski loaded his truck with crates of spinach, radishes, rhubarb and lettuce and headed for Union Square in Manhattan.

title: ITALIAN-AMERICANS: MAKING IT
description: To illustrate further the insularity of various local Italian regions, Mario Cuomo's southern-Italian mother had a favorite proverb, ''Chi va pian piano, non arriva mai'' (''He who takes his time never arrives at all'').

title: Let the Middle East Simmer
description: Arabs and Israelis know how to start wars, not how to end them. Decades of battle have conditioned them to expect others, notably Americans, to arrange their cease-fires, disengagements and even one peace treaty. As Lebanon drags on to become their longest war, it is only natural that the combatants pine for Washington to do something to pull them apart, and that Americans, from sheer habit, rush to oblige them, against great odds.

title: AUDUBON PRINTS STIR
description: John James Audubon's hand-colored engravings in ''The Birds of America'' have always been admired as examples of some of the finest ornithological illustrations ever produced. The history of the project and its fewer than 200 completed sets, possibly the most valuable of all color-plate books, are very much on the minds of collectors these days with the upcoming auction of the 435 illustrations from a complete Audubon. The sale, which is not without its share of controversy, takes place Thursday and Friday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, and is expected to establish new records for many of the illustrations, all of which have escalated dramatically in price over the past six years.

title: Arnoux Wins Pole Spot For Canada Grand Prix
description: Rene Arnoux of France today won the pole position with his Ferrari for Sunday's Canadian Grand Prix race.

title: A SECOND COMING FOR TAPES
description: As a means of storing computer data, cassette tapes have been losing out to floppy disks. Tape systems are cheaper, but they are painfully slow and unreliable. But new types of tape machines have been developed that are swifter than cassettes and might lead to a resurgence in the use of tape as a storage medium.

title: No Headline
description: ONCE he was one of five athletes adored by a nation. In the decade known as the Roaring Twenties, he was always linked with Babe Ruth, Jack Dempsey, Bobby Jones and Bill Tilden, but now Red Grange is the last survivor. Tomorrow he will be 80 years old.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ What has become an annual rite of spring - the two-handed piano conjunction of Dick Hyman and Roger Kellaway at Michael's Pub - will begin this week, just in time to slide in under the wire before spring gives way to summer.

title: RECOMMENDED ROUTE
description: ERICA BROWN is a writer based in London.

title: HOSPITALS NEED DRESS CODES AGAIN
description: COMPETITIVE service businesses must pay a lot of attention to staff training and morale if they are to prosper. You would not patronize a hamburger stand at which you were served by surly individuals wearing sloppy clothes. When you have a choice, you will certainly not go to a hospital in which the nurses - male and female alike - stroll around in a variety of costumes that make them indistinguishable from the orderlies.

title: Smiting Smut
description: Even before the Times Square Bookstore opened in downtown Stoughton, Mass., word of its stock in trade - pornography - spread fast. Protesters in the town of 28,000 people organized a picket line at the store two days before the opening in August 1982 and vowed to put Stoughton's first ''adult'' shop out of business.

title: PATE PUTS SIGHTS ON U.S. OPEN
description: In his eight years as a professional golfer, Jerry Pate has been troubled and sidelined by many injuries, but none so severe as his most recent one. But he is looking forward to a good week in the United States Open, which begins next Thursday at the Oakmont Country Club near Pittsburgh.

title: The World in Summary; Poorer Nations Make Their Pitch
description: Third world leaders last week warned that the industrial nations' budding economic recovery could falter if developing countries were left behind. Not to worry, said Gordon Streeb, the American chief delegate at the 166-country United Nations Conference on Trade and Development in Belgrade.

title: A Teen-Ager Wins $2.5 Million In Suit Over Bronx Park Rape
description: A jury has awarded $2.5 million to a teen-ager who was raped when she was 9 years old by a park attendant in a Bronx playground.

title: KNITS FROM NORWAY
description: RUTH ROBINSON is a reporter in the Style section of The Times.

title: TIME TO INNOVATE?
description: From 1909 to 1938, ferry boats shuttling between lower Manhattan and South Brooklyn were berthed in the Battery Maritime Building at 11 South Street. Since ferry service was discontinued, the building, which has both city and national landmark status, has been used as the terminal for the Coast Guard's ferries to Governor's Island and as office space for the Department of Ports and Terminals.

title: MISSIVES FROM A MURDERER
description: DEAR MR.CAPOTE, By Gordon Lish. 258 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $15.95.

title: MENUDO TAKES HOLD OF HISPANIC HEARTS
description: Most Saturday mornings, 15-year-old Evelyn Morales spends two hours traveling from her home on Staten Island to the basement of St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church on East 104th Street in Manhattan. Evelyn takes a ferry and two buses to get there, but she says she feels the trip is worth it.

title: THEY'LL BE DANCING AT RADIO CITY
description: In their ongoing effort to keep Radio City Music Hall viable, officials there have been taking advantage of its theatrical possibilities, most recently with a widely applauded revival of ''Porgy and Bess.'' Looking for a new kind of stage show for its summer spectacular, the Music Hall's production office asked the choreographer Ron Field to concoct one. He was given carte blanche - and he agonized. ''This is the hardest thing I've ever had to come up with,'' he declared in a rehearsal room the other night, collapsing in a chair but looking pleased.

title: STUDENTS LEARN JOBS ARE HARD TO FIND
description: RICK BARBIERI and Jim Curtis, friends from Southington, went further than most college students to find summer jobs this year. They pooled their resources and flew to Seattle, where they hoped to find work aboard a fishing boat.

title: Briton Takes Marathon
description: Gerald Helme of England won the annual Grandma's Marathon along Lake Superior today in 2 hours 12 minutes 9 seconds. John Tuttle of Auburn, Ala., was 35 yards behind in second place. Dick Beardsley of Rush City, who won the two previous years, did not enter because of injuries.

title: CRANSTON BEATS MONDALE IN WISCONSIN DEMOCRATIC STRAW POLL
description: In a substantial upset, Senator Alan Cranston of California defeated former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in the Presidential straw poll at the state Democratic convention here today.

title: THE ERRORS OF MARTN FELDSTEIN'S CLAIMS
description: To the Editor:

title: C.H. Sands Wed To Miss DeGraff
description: In the First Church of Christ Congregational in West Hartford, Conn., Betsy Dodd DeGraff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur C. DeGraff Jr. of West Hartford, was married yesterday to Christopher Hyde Sands. The Rev. Sidney Lovett performed the ceremony.

title: Legal Tender
description: Her ex-husband's name may be on the law degree, but Ann M. Woodworth owns a piece of it, the Michigan Court of Appeals ruled last week. The court upheld a 1982 ruling that Michael G. Woodworth's law degree ''was the result of mutual sacrifice and effort'' by him and his wife, whose earnings helped pay for it, and therefore was marital property.

title: THE BOOK THAT I'M WRITING
description: Philip Roth

title: Plans Are Made for August Weddding Of Donna Rattigan and Michael Smith
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Rattigan of Westport, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Donna Ann Rattigan, to Michael Bryan Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Smith of McLean, Va.

title: HOW ENROLLMENT IN HIGH SCHOOL MATH AND ENGLISH HAS CHANGED IN 10 YEARS
description: Percentage of students in the classes of 1973, 1978 and 1982 in New York City public high schools who have completed three years or more of ''academic'' courses in English and two years or more in math by the end of their junior year. N.A.= Data incomplete or unavailable Asterisk denotes schools that have programs requiring special application for admission. CITYWIDE AVERAGE

title: A LOOKING GLASS ON THE WAY WE MIGHT LIVE
description: PEOPLE who live in glass houses should hasten to see ''Transparent Structures: Endless Summer,'' at the Thorpe Intermedia Gallery in Sparkill, Rockland County, through June 26. They will see the history and the projected future of the way they live. The rest of us can absorb that lore, too, and see a slew of glass sculpture.

title: 30 SITES ARE ADDED TO DIOXIN INQUIRY
description: Prompted by findings of dioxin contamination in Newark, officials have begun investigating at least 30 other long-known manufacturing sites in five Eastern states where Government records say the toxic impurity may have been produced.

title: A Ride Into the Record Book
description: WOODY STEPHENS is hardly the only member of the Laffit Pincay Jr. fan club, but he's willing to be a life member after yesterday's hard ride along the rail that put the two of them in the record books.

title: Consumer Group Questioning Safety of New Contraceptive
description: The Food and Drug Administration has failed to prove that a new contraceptive sponge will not cause cancer or toxic shock syndrome, a consumer group says.

title: POLL SAYS LABOR ENDORSEMENT MAY HAVE NEGATIVE INFLUENCE
description: The endorsement of organized labor is more likely to harm than help a Presidential candidate, according to a survey by the Gallup Poll made public yesterday.

title: Elizabeth Palomba a Bride in Stamford
description: Elizabeth Ann Palomba, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gary E. Palomba of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to William Whitney Sprague, son of Dr. and Mrs. John L. Sprague of Williamstown, Mass. Msgr. Martin McDermott performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Stamford, assisted by the Very Rev. Earl Whepley, an Episcopal priest.

title: AUTO DEALER RECALLS KIT DAYS
description: ENGLEWOOD NEAR the turn of the century, before Walter Stillman and Daniel Hoag began selling Buicks here, you could buy a kit of automobile parts and assemble the cars yourself.

title: ITAILAN-AMERICANS: MAKING IT
description: Stephen Hall's penetrating analysis of the success of the Italian-American community today is in sharp contrast to what we see on television and in films.

title: THE CHIC SPOT FOR ALL THE 'SWELLS'
description: THE town into which I sail my boat for docking and vacation is East Hampton. Now people say East Hampton has beaches of splendor, dunes piled high on long white strands; farms, stretches of green fields, harbingers of the prepubescent potato and casual cabbage; snobbery, the uppermost men of the uppermost crust hobbing and nobbing in Dean & DeLuca emporiums of overstated hedonism.

title: A Soldierly Warning on Salvador
description: In a salutary interview, Gen. Edward Meyer spelled out some home truths about military involvement in El Salvador. The Army's Chief of Staff opposes sending American forces because the home front is reluctant and because Salvadorans are not properly committed to defeating the leftist guerrillas.

title: Miss Ferguson Wed in Bethesda
description: The marriage of Katharine Bowen Ferguson, the White House correspondent for National Public Radio, to Glenn Eric Roberts, legislative director for Representative Norman Y. Manetta, Democrat of California, took place in Bethesda, Md., yesterday. The Rev. Dr. James D. Ford, chaplain of the United States House of Represenatives and a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Steven V. Roberts, brother and sister-in-law of the bridegroom.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUES HONOR A COMPOSER AND AN EDUCATOR
description: Scott Joplin, who contributed so much to native American music as the ''King of Ragtime,'' and Thomas Hopkins Gallaudet, who revolutionized education for Americans with impaired hearing, appear on two new United States issues.

title: CARNEGIE DEBUT FOR CLARINETIST
description: UNTIL now, Katherine Anne Crane of Andover has been content with a rather private life - riding horseback, romping with her two dogs and studying the clarinet. But on Saturday Miss Crane, 19 years old, will be before the spotlights of New York's Carnegie Hall, where she will give a solo recital.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER The vitality of the one-act play is demonstrated in the final two parts of the Ensemble Studio Theater's four-part ''Marathon 1983,'' an annual festival of short plays in the company's West Side home. Heading Series C, the first bill of four one-acts, is James G. Richardson's ''Eulogy,'' a moving play about an unmourned death in a wealthy Southern family, featuring an excellent double performance by John Randolph and Sarah Cunningham.

title: Millions Are Surprised By Start of Ramadan
description: Ramadan, the Moslem holy month of fasting from surise to sunset, arrived today one day earlier than expected and caught millions of Moslems off guard.

title: VIDEO-GAMES CURB IS PLANNED
description: THE sign on the glass door at Spanky's Arcade in Bridgeport reads: ''If you should be in school, then you should not be here.'' By the time the new school year begins in September, the sign at Spanky's Arcade may be there not as a statement of business policy, but as a reminder of a city regulation. Bridgeport officials are seeking to enact an ordinance that would ban grade school pupils from playing video games during school hours.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
'ONE OF THE MOST EXCITING CHALLENGES'
description: IF you like the sea and boats and you welcome adventure, and if you find your adrenaline flow increases when a challenge is before you, then the America's Cup is one of the most exciting challenges you can possibly attempt.

title: 'THESE PEOPLE DON'T MEAN TO BEAT THEIR CHILDREN'
description: CHILD abuse and its causes and complexities have been exposed to growing public awareness over the last decade. Yet only recently has a clear picture of family violence in the suburbs begun to emerge. Understanding the particular stresses of suburban life and the kinds of families most vulnerable to them has become a valuable key to the prevention and treatment of child and spouse abuse, according to psychiatrists on Long Island.

title: Conflict on Sunday
description: For the time being, Jonathan Schultheis will play the organ and teach Sunday School at the Pentecostal Church in Keansburg, N.J., where his father is the minister. The 21-year-old Schultheis, who was graduated from Princeton this month, has decided for religious reasons not to accept an offer to play for the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: Allison Triumphs
description: Bobby Allison won his third consecutive stock car race at Pocono International Raceway today, posting a nine-second victory over Darrell Waltrip in a $300,000 Nascar Grand National event.

title: JOHN JAY ROUTS MOORE CATHOLIC FOR TITLE
description: When the high school baseball season began in April, Coach Mike Rozzi of John Jay said that 1983 would be a rebuilding year. But the Indians surprised their coach, and practically everyone else in the city, and yesterday they defeated Moore Catholic of Staten Island, 10-0, to win the city championship at Yankee Stadium.

title: Cabdriver Fatally Shot In an Apparent Holdup
description: A taxicab driver was found slain at the wheel of his cab in Queens early yesterday, apparently the victim of a robbery, the police reported.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Modest Anniversary

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mummies on the Move

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Chemical New York Corp. and its principal subsidiary, Chemical Bank, promoted Alan H. Fishman to senior executive vice president.

title: Bid For Missouri Utility
description: The Missouri Public Service Company yesterday announced a tender offer to buy 2,894,000 common shares, or two-thirds of those outstanding, of the Gas Service Company for $14 apiece. Both utilities serve Kansas City, Mo.

title: Stars Set Back Generals, 23-9
description: The Philadelphia Stars, who have set a swift pace for the other teams, became the first one to qualify for the United States Football League's playoffs today when they defeated the New Jersey Generals, 23-9.

title: DEFENSE BY VOLCKER
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Paul A. Volcker, today defended the Federal Reserve's ''pragmatic'' approach to economic problems, and urged Dartmouth College's class of 1983 to ''retain a health skepticism about single dramatic answers.''

title: MISSES PUTT IS COSTLY FOR BEAN
description: When Andy Bean finds himself at a loss for words, he asks, rhetorically, ''What can you say?'' In the closing minutes of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic today, Bean was sitting outside the scoring tent, in a threeway tie for the lead at six under par, when Severiano Ballesteros scored an eagle 3 on the 72d hole to snatch the victory from Bean and Craig Stadler.

title: Sasson Jeans at J.W.T.
description: Sasson Jeans has named J. Walter Thompson in Los Angeles as its agency. The account, previously handled in-house, bills more than $5 million.

title: CABLE LEADERS TO BREAK MEETING TO GO LOBBYING
description: As the 32d annual convention of the National Cable Television Association gathers in Houston this week, the official proceedings will be competing with a debate on cable in the United States Senate, and with newly raised questions on the future of five of the industry's 40 cable program channels.

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's election triumph in Britain, after the conservative victory in West Germany's elections three months ago, could persuade the Kremlin to reassess its approach to the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles, Western diplomats here believe.

title: Call for a War Inquiry Withdrawn by Sharon
description: Ariel Sharon, former Defense Minister, asked the Cabinet today to set up an inquiry into its conduct of the Lebanon invasion but then backed down when Prime Minister Menachem Begin told him that the Cabinet took full responsibility for all Israel's war moves.

title: Amy Jane Sall Is Wed To Robert L. Chender
description: Amy Jane Sall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman L. Sall of Elkins Park, Pa., was married yesterday to Robert L. Chender, son of Mrs. Jules L. Chender of New York and the late Mr. Chender. Rabbi David H. Wice performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Shalom in Philadelphia.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Mike Torrez lasted eight and two-thirds innings but lost to the Cubs the last time he faced them on June 8.

title: SAVE HOSPICE CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Malawi Denies Rumors Of a Power Struggle
description: The Malawi Government has dismissed rumors of a ferocious power struggle and denied that President Hastings Kamuzu Banda intends to take a one-year leave.

title: Important Numbers
description: When he graduates from Lafayette High School in Brooklyn on June 24, Luis Lopez will be cited as a New York State Regents' Scholarship winner who maintained an 88 scholastic average and earned honors in physics and trigonometry.

title: BANK ASSET RULE EXPECTED FROM FED
description: The Federal Reserve Board is expected to propose today that the nation's biggest banks be required to maintain their primary capital at 5 percent or more of their total assets. The proposal would come against a backdrop of increasing concern within Congress about the stability of both the nation's and the international banking system.

title: Ship Disappears Off Alaska
description: The Athena, a Greek-registered freighter abandoned by its Japanese crew after it ran into trouble in the North Pacific, has apparently sunk, the Coast Guard said today. The vessel, carrying newsprint from Eureka, Calif., to Aikamaisi, Japan, appeared to have gone down in 600 fathoms of water about 650 miles south of Adak, Alaska. The 23 crew members, who abandoned the ship Friday, were taken aboard two merchant vessels.

title: Coghlan Wins
description: Ireland's Eamonn Coghlan beat America's top miler, Steve Scott, for the first time in four years today, by a hundredth of a second in 3:52.52 seconds at the Kinney Invitational meet.

title: Girl 4 Months Premature Is Taken Off Critical List
description: A 14-ounce baby girl born four and a half months premature was taken off the critical list today but remained on a respirator in the neonatal intensive care unit, a spokesman for Hermann Hospital said.

title: Goldome Adding Florida Thrift Unit
description: The Goldome Bank for Savings, one of the largest mutual savings banks in the country, has announced that it will acquire the Guaranty Savings and Loan Association of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: NEW CASUALTY CHIEF FOR HARTFORD GROUP
description: The Hartford Insurance Group has named Donald R. Frahm president and chief operating officer of its principal property-casualty companies -the Hartford Fire Insurance Company and the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company.

title: Suffern Schoolboy Sets Meet Record
description: Jeff Van Wie of Suffern, N.Y., erased a 14-year-old meet record when he won the 800-meter run Saturday night in 1 minute 48.56 seconds at the annual Golden West Invitational for senior schoolboys.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article Saturday on a possible takeover bid for Sotheby Parke Bernet, the number of shares in the art-auction house held by A. Alfred Taubman was incorrect. Mr. Taubman owns more than 5 percent of the total stock, which is 11 million shares.

title: Mayors' Group Urges Research for AIDS Cure
description: A special task force at the U.S. Conference of Mayors called on the Federal Government today to commit itself to finding a cure for acquired immune deficiency syndrome. The Mayors are scheduled to vote Wednesday on the task force's recommendation, one of 35 proposals made today.

title: Debra S. Perskie Becomes a Bride In Tenafly Rites
description: Debra Susan Perskie, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Berger Perskie of Tenafly, N.J., and Washington, N.H., was married yesterday to Michael Eric Leeds, son of Byron J. Leeds of Flanders, N.J., and Mrs. Martin A. Gettinger of Wayne, N.J., and New York. Rabbis Andre Ungar and Israel Dresner officiated at the Perskie home in Tenafly.

title: METS ROUT EXPOS, 9-1 YANKEES LOSE IN 12TH
description: The Yankees struggled evenly with Mike Caldwell for 11 innings today before he went reluctantly to the showers. But they still lost to the Milwaukee Brewers, 6-5, in the 12th as Jim Gantner singled home Cecil Cooper with the bases filled, two out and Rudy May pitching with the count at 3-2.

title: A WARNING ON 'FRIVOLOUS' APPEALS
description: A lively behind-the-scenes debate seems to be under way at the Supreme Court over what to do about people who, in the opinion of some Justices, abuse the judicial process by filing frivolous appeals.

title: 3,500 JAPANESE APPLAUD HOROWITZ FOR 14 MINUTES
description: It took Vladimir Horowitz 79 years to get to Japan, which by his reckoning was not all that long, no matter what some Japanese might think.

title: JOIE DE VIE CAN'T GO FOR CROWN
description: The United States Postal Service has been maligned for many reasons, but this may be the first time that it must take the blame because there will be no winner of the triple crown of trotting.

title: Cocaine Cache in Carnations
description: Federal Customs agents discovered 1,000 pounds of cocaine in a shipment of carnations from Colombia that arrived at Miami International airport Saturday, officials said.

title: PIANO RECITAL: HOWARD PLAYS LISZT WALTZES
description: A CONCERT of Beethoven and Liszt by Leslie Howard at the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night divided its considerable pianistic difficulties into two categories. Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata, on the one hand, seemed at war with both instrument and instrumentalist, fiercely awkward to play and straining constantly against the piano's limitations.

title: Market Place; Rescinding Stock Offers
description: LAST week's decision by Eagle Computer Inc. to rescind its initial stock offering following the death of its chief executive was a extreme, if necessary, response to unforeseen circumstances.

title: A 1946 ARMS PLAN TAILORED FOR SOVIET REJECTION
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: When Senator Alan Cranston's victory in the Wisconsin straw poll was announced Saturday, no one smiled more broadly than Tom Ochs, the lone Glenn staff member assigned to the state convention here.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983; International
description: The United States, Britain, West Germany and Japan should expand their economies more quickly to help avert an international debt crisis and foster world recovery, the Bank for International Settlements said in its annual report. By doing so, the bank said, the four nations would raise demand for the exports of developing countries, enabling them to repay their heavy debts. (Page D1.)

title: Million-Dollar Accounts Awarded
description: Million-dollar-plus accounts are going to Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, which was earlier named the agency for the New York Future Exchange's Stock Index Futures contract, to develop a campaign for the introductions of options on the exchange's composite index; and to Kornhauser & Calene, for Kayser-Roth's line of Oscar de la Renta men's wear. The previous agency for the Kayser-Roth account was Anesh, Viseltear, Gumbinner, now defunct.

title: COCOA PRICES ON THE RISE
description: COCOA futures trading during the month of May more than doubled on the New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, jumping to 83,275 contracts from 38,332 contracts a year earlier. The strong pace continues so far in June.

title: IRON AND CARDBOARD
description: Margaret Thatcher's electoral triumph has reverberated widely. All kinds of politicians are studying Britain's decision to read the tea leaves for themselves.

title: BROWN-FORMAN STRAYS AFIELD
description: Ever since 1870, when George Garvin Brown sealed the first bottle of Old Forester bourbon and affixed a handwritten label to it, the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation has not strayed from its basic spirits and wine business.

title: HORSES IN BELMONT PROMISING
description: The 115th Belmont Stakes may not have yielded a superhorse or even an obvious 3-year-old champion, contrary to what happened last year when Conquistador Cielo ran off with the race by 14 1/2 lengths in outstanding time. However, Sunday's race did suggest that this unspectacular bunch of 3-year-olds was finally coming to hand and might provide better contests later in the season.

title: BALLESTEROS WINS CLASSIC BY 2 WITH AN EAGLE AT 18TH
description: Severiano Ballesteros, the Spaniard whose flair for dramatics has been an exciting addition to golf in recent years, won another tournament in just that manner today as he eagled the final hole to break a three-way tie and capture the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: Robertson Is First
description: Andy Robertson of the Westchester Road Runners, winner of the Brooklyn Half-Marathon earlier in the year, scored a 700-yard victory over Pat Peterson in the Westchester Half-Marathon this morning.

title: BALDWIN WILL SELL EMPIRE SAVINGS
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation plans to sell its savings and loan subsidiary, the Empire Savings, Building and Loan Association, as part of a divestiture program aimed at raising $500 million by the end of the year, the company's president said yesterday.

title: FROM SAIGON, WITH LOVE, EIGHT YEARS LATER
description: For years, whenever Canh Tran saw a dress at a bargain price, he would buy it for his eldest daughter, Thuy, planning to give it to her on the day she arrived in America.

title: 'TRUE BELIEVERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: COSMOS BEATEN
description: The Cosmos' winning streak in the North American Soccer League was stopped at six games Saturday night when the Golden Bay Earthquakes beat the defending champions, 3-1, at San Jose, Calif.

title: KISSINGER ROLE IN '68 RACE STIRS CONFLICTING VIEWS
description: Two former national security advisers, each from the other side of the political fence, were having lunch one day last month in a Washington hotel dining room and reminiscing about their respective roles in the 1968 Presidential campaign.

title: Nuptials for Miss Gregory And Curtis Miles Slepian
description: The marriage of Nicole Gregory, associate book editor of Family Circle magazine, to Curtis Miles Slepian, associate editor of Games magazine, took place at the Murray Hill Townhouse in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Seagram's Net Up 1.3 Percent
description: The Seagram Company, the giant distiller, has announced that its net income in the latest quarter edged up 1.3 percent despite a 16.8 percent drop in earnings from operations.

title: ON MONOFILAMENT LINE
description: MANY otherwise accomplished anglers handicap themselves by failing to pay proper attention to their line and to the knots that are used to attach it to the leader, snap swivel or lure.

title: BIG BOND ISSUES DUE THIS WEEK
description: Hoping to take advantage of a slight drop in interest rates and a light schedule of Treasury borrowings, underwriters are planning several large municipal and corporate bond issues this week.

title: Gail Kursh Is Married to Zev Primor in Peekskill
description: Gail Kursh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kursh of Peekskill, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Zev Primor, son of Meir Przemyslawski of Malmo, Sweden, and Esther Sendrowicz of Amsterdam, N.Y. Rabbi Alan Yuter performed the ceremony at the Monteverde Restaurant, also known as the Oldstone Inn.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: COMING JUNE 23, A FESTIVAL OF JAZZ FROM J TO Z
description: This year's Kool Jazz Festival, which will begin Thursday, June 23, and continue for 11 days through Sunday, July 3, will celebrate the history of jazz through salutes to some of its late major figures - Duke Ellington, Charles Mingus, Kai Winding, Coleman Hawkins, Bill Evans - and to one who is still very much alive, the 70-year-old composer and arranger Gil Evans, whom George Wein, the festival's founder, calls ''the senior statesman of modern jazz.''

title: Southern Baptists Gather For Pittsburgh Meetings
description: The first of an expected total of 20,000 Southern Baptists began gathering here over the weekend for a seven-day convention.

title: FOR SCHOLAR AND PROTESTER, HARD ROAD TO THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Later this week, Ariela Gross is to meet President Reagan. The President will give her a medallion. In return, Miss Gross plans to give the President a petition urging that he support a proposed Congressional resolution calling for a nuclear freeze.

title: Jet Passengers Routed By Smoke at Kennedy
description: Passengers on a Pan American World Airways flight from Rome were evacuated from their plane at Kennedy International Airport yesterday afternoon after a service vehicle under the jet caught fire and smoke entered the cabin, a spokesman for the airline said.

title: Miss Sheehan First After Trailing by 7
description: Patty Sheehan, seven strokes off the pace at the start of the round, rallied with five consecutive birdies on the back nine today to overtake Sandra Haynie and win the $200,000 L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: BIPARTISAN CONSENSUS? A MIRAGE.
description: In recent weeks, several pundits, Congressmen and the President have hailed the birth of a bipartisan consensus on two of the most controversial foreign policy issues we face: Central America and arms control. In fact, there is no such consensus on either issue - and one can't help wondering, with some apprehension, why so many in Washington wish to pretend that there is.

title: NIKE PRESIDENT OUTLINES AIM: 'BUSINESS AS USUAL'
description: Nike Inc., the Oregon-based maker of athletic shoes and apparel, has named Robert L. Woodell president and chief operating officer. Mr. Woodell, 38, who trained as a long jumper and sprinter at the University of Oregon, succeeds Philip H. Knight, 45, a co-founder of the company. Mr. Knight remains chairman and chief executive officer, and he said he would spend more time on long-range planning.

title: BRIEFING
description: Convention Threat

title: REDEFINING THE ROLE OF FATHERS
description: ''T HE meaning of Father's Day has been pretty much limited to 'the day you give your father a tie,' '' said Dr. Joseph H. Pleck, a behavioral scientist. ''It has been primarily a day that could inspire New Yorker cartoons. We know how we're supposed to feel about Mother's Day and all the other days, but people feel awkward about Father's Day.''

title: CANADA'S NEW TORY LEADER: BILINGUAL AND STYLISH
description: Brian Mulroney, a 44-year-old lawyer and businessman who defeated former Prime Minister Joe Clark late Saturday in a contest for the leadership of the Conservative Party, has sought to project himself as a model Tory and a new kind of Canadian politician.

title: LIBEL SUIT LAWYER SAYS CBS DESTROYED A TAPE
description: The lawyer representing Gen. William C. Westmoreland in his libel suit against CBS News asserted today that the network had surreptitiously tape recorded an interview with former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara, later destroyed the tape and improperly concealed these facts in formal pretrial proceedings.

title: SANDINISTS SAY HONDURAS PLAYS MAJOR ROLE IN FIGHTING
description: Nicaraguan officials say that fighting between Government troops and Honduran-based insurgents has intensified sharply in the last two weeks and that the Honduran Army is playing a major new role in the conflict.

title: ARAFAT SAYS THE ARAB LEADERS HAVE AGREED TO A CONFERENCE
description: Yasir Arafat, head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that an Arab summit meeting would be convened to discuss Middle East problems. The date and site are under discussion, he said.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: Enthusiastic fans at a college football game rip down the goal posts at both ends of the field after a touchdown in the final seconds of the game. Assuming that a 1-point conversion will either tie or win the game, would the team that scored the touchdown be forced to try for 2 points, a more difficult conversion? What happens in professional football?

title: Ryan Ties Carlton
description: Nolan Ryan tied Steve Carlton for baseball's career strikeout lead tonight as he struck out 11 San Diego batters in throwing a five-hitter and pitching the Houston Astros to a 2-0 victory over the Padres.

title: Washington Watch; Technology Pact Favored
description: WASHINGTON SENTIMENT is increasing for the United States to renew a high technology procurement agreement with Japan, even though there has yet to be any great bonanza for American companies.

title: INTENSE BATTLE FOR ANTIBIOTICS
description: Since the appearance of penicillin during World War II as the first of the ''miracle drugs,'' antibiotics have helped tame many of the terrors of human health. They have helped to cure countless victims of tuberculosis, scarlet fever, pneumonia and other dreaded killers, and people have come to ask for them - and doctors to prescribe them - for almost any ailment.

title: Argentina Gains In Youth Tourney
description: Argentina and Brazil advanced today to the semifinals of the Second World Youth Soccer Championship.

title: COUNSELING STUDENTS FOR NEW LIFE AT COLLEGE
description: ''You are a scholar and your roommate is barely scraping by academically. You're Jewish and he's a born-again Christian. You're an only child and he's one of eight. How do you communicate?'' Kathleen Nottage puts that question to nine collegebound high school seniors who have come to her office to talk about leaving home.

title: Whitney at 42d St. Lists Reginald Marsh Show
description: Paintings, drawings and prints depicting New York City during the 1930's are among the works included in ''Reginald Marsh's New York,'' an exhibition that goes on view June 29 in the new Philip Morris branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street.

title: Panthers 42, Exress 17
description: LOS ANGELES (AP) - The rookie Bobby Hebert completed 16 of 25 passes for 247 yards and four touchdowns to lead the Panthers.

title: Sicilian Soccer Game Erupts in Gunfire
description: A stadium guard enraged by soccer fans' jeers fired a shotgun into the stands today, killing one person, the police said. Twenty-five others were reported injured by gunfire or by other spectators fleeing the gunman.

title: Palmer Returning
description: Jim Palmer, the Baltimore Oriole pitcher who has been on the disabled list since May 3, will be activated Tuesday, the club announced today.

title: JUSTICE BLACKMUN TELLS NEW LAWYERS 'TAKE RISKS'
description: Justice Harry A. Blackmun, who has emerged in recent years as one of the most outspoken members of the United States Supreme Court, urged the graduating class of New York Law School yesterday to ''take the proper risks, the calculated risks, that innovation and progress require.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I was still looking for a little girl. I said: 'No that is not her.

title: Citizens Group Hails City Budget
description: The Citizens Budget Commission, a private group that has often criticized city policies, yesterday commended Mayor Koch and other officials for what it called a ''sensible and prudent'' budget for fiscal 1984.

title: ROCK: SCANDAL PLAYS THE RITZ
description: WITH the age of video rock upon us, a young band's chances for commercial success depend as much on presenting a slick visual package as on musical merit. Scandal, an up-and-coming New York-based band heavily promoted by MTA, is an usually good-looking group, whose 25-year-old lead singer Patty Smyth looks like Linda Ronstadt's kid sister and has the vocal style of a punkier Pat Benatar.

title: STATE-OF-THE-ART PRIVACY-INVASION ROUTES
description: To the Editor:

title: Blitz Defeats Bandits
description: Tim Spencer scored three touchdowns today to help the Chicago Blitz rout the Tampa Bay Bandits, 31-8, and tie them for first place in the Central Division of the United States Football League.

title: Leslie Mintzer Is Bride
description: Leslie Alexandra Mintzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Mintzer, was married yesterday at the home of her parents in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Brian Jeffrey Lutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Jay Lutz of Denver. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony. The bride, who will keep her name, is an account executive at the Graphic Experience, a direct marketing advertising agency. Mr. Lutz is president of Berne Yarns Inc., importer of machine knitting yarns.

title: G.M. AND FORD FACE FINES ON MILEAGE
description: A resurgent demand for big cars has forced the nation's two biggest auto makers, General Motors and Ford, into violating Federal minimum mileage standards, confronting them with a potential liability of millions of dollars in fines.

title: AN AILING JAVITS SPEAKS AT A GRADUATION
description: Because he was impelled by parental pride and loyalty, and despite his failing health, former Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York delivered the commencement address today at his daughter Carla's graduation from the University of California.

title: SLAIN FAMILY'S NEIGHBORS LIVE IN NEW-FOUND FEAR
description: Residents here were stocking up on guns, attack dogs and locks as the authorities pressed their search today for an escaped mental patient charged with killing four people in a Chino Hills home.

title: FOR AN INCOMES POLICY
description: The debate in Congress about economic policy is Hamlet without the Prince. The critical missing element is an incomes policy - a business-labor-Government agreement to gear average wage increases to the average rate of increase in productivity. In fact, there is a virtual conspiracy of silence among working politicians in both parties on this matter.

title: Advertising; The Big Winners Of Clios
description: ALLY & GARGANO keeps doing it. After sweeping The One Show last month for the third consecutive year, the agency was the biggest Clio winner last Friday in the television category - also for the third year in a row.

title: TAX ERROR CAUSES PROBLEMS IN CALIFORNIA
description: California officials have discovered that nearly $1 billion in property taxes have been improperly distributed statewide, a finding that could put a large hole in this city's already straining budget.

title: CONNORS, IN TOP FORM DEFEATS MCENROE
description: Jimmy Connors turned on his best grass-court tennis today and defeated John McEnroe, 6-3, 6-3, in the final of the Stella Artois Grand Prix tournament at the Queen's Club, the last important event before Wimbledon.

title: COSTUME COURT GETS NEW SETTING
description: It has been five years since the massive iron and glass dome over the Costume Court at the Victoria and Albert Museum threatened to cave in, forcing its collection of fashions from 1540 to 1950 into storage while repairs were made.

title: JEROME A. JOHNSON
description: Jerome A. Johnson, former president of the Brass Rail Restaurants and senior vice president of its parent company, the Interstate United Corporation, died of lung cancer Friday at Desert Hospital in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: A Turk in Pope Case Is Reported on the Move
description: A Turk whose extradition from Bulgaria was reportedly requested by an Italian judge in connection with the attempted assassination of Pope John Paul II has left that country, according to the Italian news agency ANSA.

title: PUERTO RICANS CELEBRATE DAY IN THE SUN
description: As Candy and Hector Camacho put their two children, Jason and Vanessa, into the car yesterday, the streets of the Soundview section of the Bronx had already emptied. Earlier, in the morning sun, people had piled into cars and onto the downtown IRT No. 6 train for the trip to Manhattan to the 25th annual Puerto Rican Day parade.

title: Modell's Condition Reported Stable
description: Art Modell, the 57-year-old principal owner of the Cleveland Browns, was reported in serious but stable condition in the Cleveland Clinic today after suffering a heart attack Saturday morning.

title: EUROPE'S DIOXIN DRAMA: A SLAUGHTERHOUSE FINALE
description: It was a mystery in which the identity of the victim was not known until the end. The mystery is how 41 steel drums containing chemical wastes, including highly toxic dioxin, could vanish in the middle of Europe. Last month the search ended in a slaughterhouse owned by Andre Droy in Anguilcourt-le-Sart.

title: A CAUTIOUS GONZALEZ
description: Spain's Socialist Prime Minister, Felipe Gonzalez, who meets with President Reagan next week, while seeking to expand his country's influence in Latin America is laboring at home under severe economic restraints in formulating and trying to carry out new domestic policies.

title: LEADING KENTUCKIANS LINKED TO DRUG AND BETTING INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into allegations of illegal gambling and cocaine trafficking among some leading Kentucky horsemen, socialites and politicians, culminating a yearlong inquiry.

title: CHANGE IS SWIFT IN SEOUL AS POPULATION EXPLODES
description: This is the quick-change artist of cities: every time one looks, its appearance is different. Office towers have opened that did not exist a year ago, and every second or third corner has the skeleton of a new building that is being fleshed out more and more each day.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in Metropolitan Report June 1, with a picture of the memorial service for Mayor Erastus Corning 2d of Albany, misidentified the man shown preceding Governor Cuomo. He was Peter V. Ball.

title: No Headline
description: George Vecsey Woody's Drive to Glory

title: Gail S. Hodosh Marries R.L. Gibbs in Newport
description: Gail Susan Hodosh, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Hodosh of Providence, R.I., was married in Newport, R.I., yesterday to Randall Lee Gibbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Gibbs of Swampscott, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Wayne Franklin performed the ceremony at Rosecliff, a mansion owned by the Preservation Society of Newport County.

title: Don't Sell Conrail Short, or Yet
description: FOR SALE. Cheap. One very large, very used railroad. Will gladly divide. No offer too small to be considered. Write c/o Privatize Offer, The White House, Washington, D.C.

title: BANKS FIND SUCCESS IN NEW ACCOUNTS
description: Only six months after their introduction, money market deposit accounts at banks and savings and loan associations have become one of the most popular savings vehicles ever created.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.69 An index of yields for long-term

title: MOSES AND MAREE WIN IN ELLIOT TRACK
description: Edwin Moses and Sammy Koskei won their specialties today in the fastest times in the world this outdoor track season. Sydney Maree won his specialty in the fastest time in the United States this season, though the distinction lasted only a few minutes.

title: GROWTH URGED IN 4 NATIONS
description: The United States, Britain, West Germany and Japan, which together account for almost half of the world's output of goods and services, must expand their economies faster to avert an international debt crisis and make sure the world recovers from recession, the Bank for International Settlements says in its latest annual report, published today.

title: MIAMI HERALD TO BROADEN ITS ROLE IN FLORIDA AND LATIN AMERICA
description: When the presses at The Miami Herald complete their nightly runs in the wee hours of the morning, it often seems they have produced a product that matches any American newspaper's efforts to offer something for everyone.

title: Cox Names President For Broadcasting Unit
description: Walter Liss Jr. is joining Cox Communications as president of the broadcast division, effective July 5. Mr. Liss, who is currently vice president and general manager of WPLG, Post-Newsweek Stations Inc.'s television station in Miami, replaces William Schwartz, president of Cox.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PICKUP ART

title: Simmone Burbano Married
description: Simmone Ophelia Burbano, daughter of Gabriel Burbano and Penny Burbano, both of New Orleans, was married in New York yesterday to Steven Neil Salzman, son of Dr. Stanley Salzman of Miami and Mrs. George Michel of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room at the Pierre Hotel. The bride attends the University of New Orleans. Mr. Salzman, a geophysicist for the Mobil Oil Company in New Orleans, graduated from Lafayette College.

title: SPECIAL ENVOY PRAISES GUATEMALA
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, today praised ''positive changes'' in the Guatemalan military Government of President Efrain Rios Montt.

title: DURAN'S HEART AND STOMACH READY FOR FIGHT WITH MOORE
description: ROBERTO DURAN'S stomach is no longer in his way. Trimmed down and grown-up, the once-great Panamanian fighter who had eaten himself out of two world boxing titles has returned to New York hungry for a third.

title: BRITISH ELECTION DOES LITTLE FOR ULSTER'S PROSPECTS
description: ''Elections won't stop the violence here,'' said Patrick Grogan, a Roman Catholic resident of this rural town in County Tyrone. ''The violence stops when they get out.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Life's Tiny Successes

title: NEW POWER IN THE N.A.A.C.P.
description: In the more than 40 years of Kelly Alexander's involvement in the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, there have been some little-known moments of personal terror, mirroring the well-known events of the civil rights movement.

title: Mexico to Repay Debt
description: Mexico will complete repayment of a $1.85 billion bridging loan extended by central banks when it falls due in the second half of August, the director of Mexico's central bank, Miguel Mancera, said today.

title: BILL TO INCREASE STATE PENSIONS NEARING A VOTE
description: A major change in the state's pension system that would increase benefits for 300,000 employees of state and local governments has been drafted by Republicans in the State Senate, despite the opposition of Mayor Koch, school boards and business groups across the state.

title: LOSS SEEN BY TEXAS INSTRUMENTS
description: Texas Instruments Inc., citing a sudden and sharp drop in the sale of home computer software to retailers, has announced that it expects to report a ''major loss'' in the second quarter, possibly as much as $100 million.

title: Important Dates In Seoul's History
description: 1392 - Established as the capital of Korea by King Taejo, first of the Yi dynasty rulers. It had long been a trading village.

title: Simon and Garfunkel Tour
description: Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel will start their first tour in 13 years with an appearance at Akron's Rubber Bowl July 19. Belkin Productions said it expected all 40,000 seats to be sold at $16 a ticket. There will be at least 16 other cities in the tour.

title: TEXAS WINS N.C.A.A. TITLE
description: With a runner on third and two out in the seventh inning and the national collegiate title on the line, the Texas cleanup hitter, Jose Tolentino, stepped to the plate.

title: CRASH KILLS PILOT OF SMALL PLANE AT JERSEY SHOW
description: As 15,000 spectators watched, a pilot in an aerial acrobatic display was killed yesterday as his small, experimental plane crashed and burned at an air show in Morristown, N.J.

title: Arnoux Takes Grand Prix
description: Rene Arnoux had to restrain himself and his turbocharged Ferrari over the last 10 laps of today's Canadian Grand Prix, a difficult situation for the usually hard-charging Formula One racer.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 13, 1983
description: International Britain's Labor Party leader, Michael Foot, indicated that he planned to step down in October, after his party's defeat in last week's general election. Within minutes of his announcement, two prominent Labor figures said they would seek his job. They are Neil Kinnock, a Welsh left-winger who speaks for the party on education issues, and Peter Shore, an economics specialist who opposes Britain's membership in the Common Market. Later a third prominent party figure, Roy Hattersley, also announced his candidacy for the post. (Page A1, Column 6.) A construction boom in Seoul brings to notice that the capital of South Korea has become one of the world's biggest cities, the seventh-largest metropolitan area. Construction of office buildings, apartment houses and a subway system is being speeded to accommodate a population that has nearly quadrupled in the last two decades, to about nine million. (A1:2.)

title: More Growth For Cable TV
description: For all its woes, cable television continues to be a growth industry. Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, McCall Publishing, Hearst/ ABC and Post-Newsweek are collaborating on an advertising-supported cable program, ''Working Mother,'' named after McCall's monthly magazine.

title: Let a Raise Be a Raise
description: The Senate's Backdoor Pay Smells No Sweeter

title: Union Dispute Slows Delivery Of Early Sunday Times Edition
description: A dispute between The New York Times and its drivers delayed some deliveries of the early edition of Sunday's paper, a spokesman for The Times said yesterday.

title: Marguerite de V. de Wet And William Gould Wed
description: Marguerite de Villiers de Wet, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jacobus S. du Toit de Wet of Cape Town, was married yesterday to William H.M. Gould, son of Curtis E.L. Gould of Berwyn, Pa., and Mrs. John G. Stewart of Rumson, N.J. and New York.

title: Teheran Zoo Gets U.S. Meat
description: Animals at the Teheran zoo have received a seven-year supply of food -frozen meat from storerooms at the captured United States Embassy, the national press agency said today.

title: Pioneer 10 to Leave Solar System Today
description: Pioneer 10, after exploring 3.5 billion mostly uncharted miles of the solar system, will leave the last of the known planets behind Monday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Professional Politics

title: Disabled Man Defiant About Motor Tricycle
description: A disabled man said today he would continue to ride his small motorized tricycle on city streets despite threats of being jailed.

title: BUILDER OFFERS A DEAL TO SAVE 79TH ST. TEMPLE
description: A real estate developer has offered to buy the former home of the Mount Neboh Synagogue in Manhattan and convert it to a community center, if he is permitted to transfer its air rights to an apartment tower he is planning to build across the street.

title: Bridge: Westchester Team Ahead At Grand National Zonals
description: The first day of action in the Grand National Team zonal playoffs at the Hyatt Regency Hotel here Saturday proved to be a bitter struggle. Three teams were battling for the right to compete in the national quarterfinals in New Orleans next month, with international honors beckoning on the horizon.

title: VENEZUELA'S ORINOCO OIL PLAN
description: Less than a year ago, the Venezuelan Government was pushing ahead with a multibillion-dollar plan for developing the country's vast potential in heavy petroleum. Today, one major project lies on the scrap heap and spending on the development of heavy oil has been scaled back sharply.

title: White Sox Ready To Trade Pitchers
description: Eddie Einhorn, the president of the Chicago White Sox, said today that any of the club's five starting pitchers ''could be had for the right price'' in a deal with another American League team.

title: TV: RIDDLES OF THE GENES ON 'THE BODY HUMAN'
description: ''THE BODY HUMAN,'' a series of programs extolling medical science, examines ''The Living Code'' tonight at 8 on Channel 2. This time, the focus is on ''pioneer doctors deciphering the riddles of human genes.'' There is little or no dealing with the objections that some groups, notably a broad spectrum of religious organizations, have raised against the prospect of tampering with genes.

title: Households Hit by Crime Show a Decline for 1982
description: Twenty-nine percent of American households, or nearly 25 million homes, experienced a violent crime or a theft in 1982, a decline of one percentage point from 1981, the Justice Department said today.

title: 6 TOURISTS WHO WERE SEIZED IN ZIMBABWE SAID TO BE DEAD
description: The Zimbabwe Government has received evidence that six foreign tourists kidnapped in the western part of the country a year ago may have been killed, it was reported here today.

title: Blue Cross to Marsteller
description: Marsteller in Chicago has been named to handle national advertising for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association. The account, which billed $3 million last year, had been handled by N.W. Ayer in Chicago.

title: Addendum
description: * Tennis magazine increasing its circulation rate base 8.7 percent, to 500,000, from 460,000, effective immediately. Advertising rates will increase 8.7 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: Marschalk Promotions
description: James Johnson, 44-year old executive vice president of the Marschalk Company, has been appointed to the new position of chief executive officer of the Cleveland office. And Robert Gold, 49, general manager of the office becomes chief operating officer.

title: M.T.A. SAYS 5 OF 8 AREAS GET A BARGAIN IN TRANSIT
description: For every dollar that residents of New York City and Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Putnam Counties pay for mass transit services, they get more than a dollar's worth in return, according to a new analysis.

title: Dr. Sharon Yost Weds a Teacher
description: Dr. Sharon Lynn Yost, an attending physician at the Preventive Medicine Institute/Strang Clinic, was married yesterday to Joshua Israel Guttman, a teacher of physics at Queens College. Rabbi Solomon Slomowitz performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club.

title: WEST AND EAST ARE BETTER OFF WITHOUT CRUISE MISSILES
description: To the Editor:

title: AFRICAN UNITY ORGANIZATION ENDS ITS SUMMIT GATHERING IN DISUNITY
description: The Organization of African Unity ended its 19th summit conference here today with its affirmations of unity undermined by disputes over the appointment of a new Secretary General.

title: Peru's President Visits Area of Rebel Fighting
description: President Fernando Belaunde Terry made a surprise visit today to Ayacucho, the center of fighting by rebels waging a three-year campaign to try to topple his civilian Government.

title: Taming a Dragon
description: When representatives of the Hong Kong Tourist Association were looking for someone to put together a United States team for next Sunday's international dragon boat races in Hong Kong harbor, it seemed only natural that they would look to Jack Kelly.

title: LABOR PARTY CHIEF TO QUIT AFTER LOSS TO MRS. THATCHER
description: The leader of Britain's Labor Party, Michael Foot, indicated today that he planned to step down in October after his party's defeat in last week's general election.

title: Swiss Cyclist Dies
description: A Swiss motorcycle rider, Rolf Reuttiman, died today of injuries he received when he fell in a 125cc World Cup race near here earlier in the day.

title: Spike Picks Rosenfeld
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been named the agency for International Spike, a fertilizer marketer. The account, which billed $2.5 million last year, was previously handled by J. Walter Thompson, Chicago.

title: SCRAMBLING FEARLESSLY TO THE TOP
description: The Gallery around the eighth green at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic last Thursday followed the the flight of the golf ball, a black speck in the blue sky, and watched it descend at length. It landed with a startling crack against a rock-edged knoll beside the green, and bounced back and came to rest in a clump of grass. Had it rolled a little further it wold have landed in a nearby lake. in the distance, a hefty 1-iron shot away, a man could be seen beside a hill with a golf club over his left shoulder. Obviously he also followed the descent of that shot with particular interest..

title: CONCERT: AMERICAN COMPOSERS
description: GOLDEN FLEECE LTD. is a chamber theater organization now in its eighth year of providing a modest but workable forum for American composers. Its program Saturday afternoon at the Open Gate Theater on East 29th Street divided evenly into opera and choral singing.

title: The U.N. Today; June 13, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Petitions, Infor- mation and Assistance - 10:30 A.M.

title: PAUL TAYLOR RECEIVES SCRIPPS AWARD
description: The choreographer Paul Taylor, recipient of the Samuel H. Scripps-American Dance Festival award, says he'll use his $25,000 prize to help pay off his dance company's debts.

title: REAGAN'S RIGHTS CHIEF REACHES OUT TO BLACKS
description: The Reagan Administration's civil rights chief, in a conciliatory appearance with black leaders, said today that the President's civil rights policies had been ''terribly misunderstood.''

title: WHO SHOULD PICK JURORS, ATTORNEYS OR THE JUDGE?
description: In New York State's Supreme Courts, the selection of a jury to hear a felony case usually takes weeks. In New York's Federal courts, the selection of a jury to hear a felony case usually takes hours.

title: THE PSYCHOPRIMARIES
description: In the beginning, a few states had primaries. Then, with all the publicity and tourism that accrued to primary states, every state had to have a primary.

title: The Wonder 1st
description: The Wonder, with Bill Shoemaker up, came from last place today to win the 30th running of the $327,000 Californian Stakes at Hollywood Park.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
RATE RISE LAID TO INVESTOR PSYCHOLOGY
description: Interest rates rose last week, not because the Federal Reserve tightened credit availability but because market participants sold securities in the belief that such tightening had occurred, according to analysts. They reached this conclusion after reviewing Fed data released Friday.

title: Stephens Winner
description: Woody Stephens returned to the winner's circle yesterday as Claiborne Farm's Number romped home eight lengths ahead of Ogden Phipps's Dance Number in the $109,800 Hempstead Handicap at Belmont.

title: RED SOX END SLIDE BY STOPPING ORIOLES
description: Wade Boggs drew a two-out, bases-loaded walk off the reliever Tippy Martinez, forcing home Jerry Remy with the winning run in the ninth inning, as the Boston Red Sox snapped a seven-game losing streak today with a 7-6 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Susan Weinstein Weds Dr. Kenneth J. Dobuler
description: Susan Martha Weinstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Weinstein of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Kenneth Jay Dobuler, son of Mrs. Morton Young of Boca Raton, Fla., and Lake Mahopac, N.Y. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein performed the ceremony at the Weinstein home.

title: Yugoslav Furniture Problems
description: The forests that surround this Bosnian city in central Yugoslavia for years have supplied the country and some of its close neighbors with a steady supply of valuable timber.

title: Lauren B. Gash and Gregg Garmisa Wed in Jersey
description: Lauren Beth Gash, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ira A. Gash of Berkeley Heights, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregg A. Garmisa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict Israel Garmisa of Chicago. Rabbi Simon Glustrom performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

title: US-SOVIET TALKS HELD ON LEBANON
description: Morris Draper, the United States special Middle East envoy, said today that the Reagan Administration has had ''serious discussions'' with the Soviet Union about the situation in Lebanon, but he stressed that there was no plan to involve Moscow in diplomatic efforts to bring about a withdrawal of Syrian troops from Lebanon.

title: ROBERTET, FILLING A GAP, NAMES TOP U.S. OFFICER
description: Robertet Inc., a French developer of fragrances and flavors, has named Peter N. Lombardo president and chief operating officer of its American operations.

title: NO LIMITS FOR LEWIS
description: AT the Olympics every four years, track-and-field names leap out of huge headlines. In between, their names appear mostly in the small type of the meet results. Because of the Olympic boycott in 1980, many names have stayed in that small type. But beginning this week in the USA/Mobil Outdoor Championships at Indianapolis, one name in particular should gradually increase in size. The name is Carl Lewis, a sprinter and a long-jumper. By the end of the 1984 Summer Games at Los Angeles, that name might be as much a part of Olympic lore as Jesse Owens, Mark Spitz and Eric Heiden.

title: Susan Linowes Weds J.G. Allen in Scarsdale
description: Susan Joyce Linowes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David F. Linowes of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Champaign, Ill., was married yesterday to Jeffrey G. Allen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis D. Allen of Salem, Ore. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the ceremony at the Linowes home in Scarsdale.

title: Della Femina and Unit Win 2 New Accounts
