description: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners has been named the agency for Cointreau America, which has a budget of $4 million.

title: DO WE WANT TO KEEP INVESTOR-OWNED UTILITIES?
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about the American Telephone and Telegraph Company misstated the plan to be followed when the company divests itself of local telephone subsidiaries. For every 10 A.T.& T. shares held, shareholders will receive one share in each of seven regional holding companies.

title: CALIFORNIA BODY IDENTIFIED AS THAT OF MISSING PRODUCER
description: A body found Friday in a canyon north of Los Angeles was identified through dental X-rays yesterday as that of Roy A. Radin, the New York theatrical producer who disappeared a month ago on a business trip to Los Angeles. He had been shot to death.

title: Marathon to Tabb
description: Ron Tabb of Eugene, Ore., outpaced 2,400 athletes today to win the first Australian Marathon in 2 hours 10 minutes 53 seconds, one of the fastest times in the world this year.

title: ABUSES ARE FOUND IN MINORITY HIRING IN NEW YORK STATE
description: Some construction companies are creating spurious subcontracting concerns purportedly headed by minority-group members to qualify for multimillion-dollar New York State construction contracts, according to officials of the State Commission of Investigation.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On Chemical Warfare 'Yellow Rain' Is a Weapon To the Editor: We represent a diverse group of scientists, independent researchers, physicians, political scientists and members of other professions who have followed the issue of the use of chemical weapons in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan for several years.

title: Crowd Holds Rape Suspect
description: An angry mob of relatives and neighbors yelling ''Stop that guy!'' chased a man accused of raping a 6-year-old girl, struck him and pinned him down yesterday until the police arrived. Officials said Mozell Brooks, 40 years old, of Indianapolis had been visiting the child's parents and led her to an abandoned house where he assaulted her.

title: Scott Margol Weds Deborah Bookspan
description: Deborah Joy Bookspan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bookspan of Eastchester, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Howard Margol, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Margol of Miami. Rabbi Melvin Sirner and Cantor Lawrence Avery performed the ceremony at the Beth El Synagogue Center in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Consumer Reports Challenge To Shampoo to Be Presented
description: A consumer group is to make its case Monday to the Food and Drug Administration that the lice-killing shampoo Kwell causes cancer and should be banned.

title: EX-ADDICTS REVISIT BYRANT PARK FOR THEIR GRADUATION
description: Davene Hunt used to buy marijuana from the army of drug dealers that has plagued Bryant Park. Yesterday, Miss Hunt was back at the park, this time as the valedictorian at a commencement exercise honoring graduates of an education program for drug addicts.

title: PENTAGON CHIEF IS DOUBTFUL ON G.I.'S FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger appeared today to rule out the dispatch of American combat forces to Central America at any time, and then shortly afterward seemed to soften his position to leave open the possibility.

title: SUNNY'S HALO IS 4TH IN ARLINGTON CLASSIC
description: Play Fellow scored a three-length victory in the 52d running of the $109,000 Arlington Classic at Arlington Park today, as Sunny's Halo, the 1-5 favorite and the Kentucky Derby winner, finished fourth.

title: THE BATTLE OF THE OAK BEACH INN
description: There are those who would suggest that having a beer at the Oak Beach Inn has become some sort of political statement, what with the owner having distributed a million ''Save The Oak Beach Inn'' bumper stickers and now publishing his own newspaper ''to tell the story of years of harassment by police and public officials.''

title: SOCIAL DEMOCRATIC CHIEF IN BRITAIN QUITS
description: Roy Jenkins announced tonight that he was resigning as leader of the Social Democratic Party and urged that Dr. David Owen be chosen unanimously to succeed him.

title: Briton Gives Up Bid To Row Across Pacific
description: The British adventurer Peter Bird, his small boat battered by brutal seas, today gave up his bid to become the first man to row solo across the Pacific Ocean.

title: Even in South Africa, Respect for Law
description: Even as it dishonors humanity's basic codes, South Africa worships forms of law. The security police will torture a prisoner to death, then the Government stages an elaborate inquiry to clear itself. The Government ''bans'' dissenters, denying their most elementary rights and virtually their existence, but only under duly enacted statutes.

title: Morton Gould Winner Of Golden Baton Award
description: The composer and conductor Morton Gould has won the 35th Golden Baton Award of the American Symphony Orchestra League, a national organization whose members are drawn from 800 symphonies.

title: LAB ANIMALS' USE
description: While all of us have benefited from the ability of modern medicine to prevent and treat many devastating diseases, there are critics who fail to realize that the improvement of medical care depends upon research involving animals and who insist that the use of animals in research is inhumane and unnecessary. They are mistaken.

title: Westchester Man Sentenced in Fraud
description: A builder from Harrison, N.Y., was fined $50,000 and sentenced to five years probation today, after being convicted in March of grand larceny in a $2.5 million fraud.

title: The Best Defense
description: The owner of the Bostic Celtics, Harry Mangurian, says that not only does he plan to keep the Knicks from signing one of his players, Kevin McHale, as a free agent, but that the Celtics will try to sign all three of the Knicks' free agents. Mangurian said that the Knicks are ''going to have a battle'' if they try to sign McHale, a star forward in whom the Knicks have expressed interest.

title: Finance Institute Picks First Director
description: The Institute of International Finance, founded in January to give banks more information relating to major government borrowers, yesterday named Andre de Lattre as its first managing director at a meeting in Tokyo.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading Whose Fault?

title: Chess: Once in a While, the Victor Can Learn From the Loser
description: Usually the winner glows, the loser thinks. But every once in a while, a perspicacious winner finds something to admire in his defeated opponent's play, something to prompt a change in his own concept of the game.

title: Advertising; Changes At Isidore Lefkowitz
description: ANTHONY F. ISIDORE has left Isidore Lefkowitz Elgort, of which he was president, and opened the doors yesterday of Isidore & Paulson with Paul J. Paulson, former president of Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc., the New York office of DDB International.

title: DAYTON VOTES A SCHOOL TAX: PUBLICITY EFFORT HELD CRUCIAL
description: When voters narrowly approved the first Dayton public school tax in 12 years, they acted more from a concern for property values and jobs than from a desire for better education, according to the political consultant who organized support for the measure.

title: Perishable Pesticides
description: Several years ago corn farmers in the Middle West complained to the United States Department of Agriculture that certain chemically related insecticides and herbicides had become ineffective. The chemicals included insecticides used to control corn rootworm and herbicides used against nut sedge and certain grasses.

title: THE KISSINGER DEBATE
description: So swift and so virulent have been the attacks by friends and suitors of Henry Kissinger on a new book, ''The Price of Power,'' that one feels compelled to try to understand the significance of this controversy.

title: Senators Hear Mayors On Rising Pleas for Aid
description: Big-city mayors told a Senate Agriculture subcommittee today that requests for emergency food assistance had risen dramatically in cities nationwide as millions of unemployed people suffered what one called ''the fallout of a national economic disaster.''

title: Jersey Students Admit Extortion
description: Two college students admitted today that they had plotted to extort $50,000 from a Princeton, N.J., business executive by threatening the lives of his wife and children.

title: ETHIOPIAN, NEW HEAD OF O.A.U., DENOUNCES U.S. AS MILITARY PERIL
description: The Ethiopian leader, Mengistu Haile Mariam, new chairman of the Organization of African Unity, delivered a harsh attack on the United States today that seemed to foreshadow a more radical voice for the African continent in world affairs.

title: HELP FOR BUYERS OF 'LEMON' CARS VOTED IN ALBANY
description: A bill designed to protect new-car buyers in New York State from defective vehicles known as ''lemons'' overwhelmingly passed both houses of the Legislature today. Governor Cuomo is expected to sign it.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Pavarotti Note On Education

title: SOVIET REVEALS LOCATIONS OF NOT SO SECRET SITES
description: AFTER more than 20 years of secrecy, the Soviet Union has decided to reveal something the West has long known -the location of two of the three launching sites the Russians usse for their manned and unmanned space flights.

title: I.B.M.'S ROLM DEAL ENDS MITEL ACCORD
description: An agreement between the Mitel Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation to develop telecommunications products has been discontinued because I.B.M. plans to purchase a 15 percent stake in the Rolm Corporation, which competes with Mitel. The I.B.M.- Mitel agreement in principle was reached last July.

title: FOR GOLF, RATINGS AREN'T EVERYTHING
description: O ne of the theories among television sports executives is that ''golf is good business,'' even without significant ratings. Last Sunday's concluding round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic on CBS was another example of how this theory works.

title: Holmes Decision
description: Larry Holmes, incensed at what he called a World Boxing Council ''ultimatum'' to defend his heavyweight title against Greg Page, said yesterday he was ready to sign a $3.4 million contract to meet young Marvis Frazier.

title: HIGH COURT IMPOSES FIRST PENALTY UNDER RULE ON 'FRIVOLOUS' APPEALS
description: The Supreme Court today took a step it has been hinting at and ordered an appellant to pay damages to the other side, $500 in this case, as a penalty for bringing a ''frivolous'' appeal.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: CITY U. GRADUATE SCHOOL GAINS HIGH RANK
description: PERHAPS the least known part of the City University of New York has been its Graduate School. Now, however, many of its quietly developed doctoral programs are gaining national recognition, placing the university for the first time among the leading research institutions in certain fields.

title: Robert I. Brougham Is Dead; Former Chairman of Aramco
description: Robert I. Brougham, former chairman and chief executive officer of the Arabian American Oil Company, died June 8 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived in La Jolla.

title: Australian Declares U.S.  Can Rely on Close Ties
description: Australia's new Prime Minister, Robert Hawke, met with President Reagan today and said his Labor Party Government would be a close ally of the United States.

title: REACHING OUT TO THE SYSTEM
description: THE word ''system'' creeps continually into any discussion of computers, and although the concept is now a common one, it is also a relatively recent one in the history of technology. Philosophically, of course, man has been trying for millenniums to develop systems ideas - as opposed to physical systems - to clarify the basic principles of the world and its contents.

title: GAF Dissidents Claim 58.3% of Vote
description: A group of dissident shareholders of the GAF Corporation, led by Samuel J. Heyman, won 58.3 percent of last month's proxy vote, Mr. Heyman said yesterday.

title: Hunt for Manager Of Convention Hall
description: State officials talked yesterday to a second company interested in managing New York City's Convention Center, a spokesman for the state's Urban Development Corporation said.

title: Magnets Against Cancer
description: A new cancer treatment that combines conventional chemotherapy with the use of magnetic particles to separate healthy from diseased cells has been tested at a London hospital. Two patients underwent the treatment for the often-fatal cancer called neuroblastoma, which affects the bone marrow, and were reported to be in good postoperative condition.

title: EFFECT OF NEW SPORTS CABLE DEBATED
description: Top officials of two cable channels that carry substantial amounts of sports events said that a new premium sports network announced here by Group W Satellite Communications would pose little threat to their operations.

title: U.S. JUDGE BLOCKS CONNECTICUT'S BAN ON TANDEM TRUCKS
description: A Federal judge today ordered Connecticut to stop enforcing its law banning double-trailer trucks. The judge, Jose A. Cabranes of the United States District Court here, ruled that the state law violated the constitutional powers of Congress to regulate interstate commerce.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
RALLY CONTINUES IN U.S. ISSUES
description: Prices rose on Government securities yesterday and rates fell as investors continued a rally that started late Friday after the Federal Reserve announced a much lower-than-expected rise in the basic money supply.

title: NORMA SHEARER, FILM STAR TWO DECADES, IS DEAD
description: Norma Shearer, one of the famed Hollywood stars of the 20's and 30's, died of bronchial pneumonia Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif., a hospital spokesman said. She was about 80 years old and had lived at the hospital since 1980.

title: MARION CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting and 5 percent stock dividends paid in July 1982 and January 1983. Marion Corp. has been in Chapter 11 reorganization proceedings since March 1983.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL CRITICIZES REAGAN ON APPOINTMENTS
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today it was ''disappointed and concerned'' that President Reagan had not appointed more blacks, women and Hispanic Americans to full-time, high-level positions in the Federal Government.

title: THE REGION
description: The General Assembly returned to a special session today to try again to adopt a budget and new and higher taxes before Connecticut's new fiscal year begins July 1.

title: ALABAMA AT A CROSSROADS IN ITS DRIVE FOR PROSPERITY
description: Alabama's economy, built up over the last three decades largely with heavy industry, is suffering the same strains as many Northern industrial states, fueling a debate over prescriptions for its future.

title: BRIEFING
description: Watergate Revisited

title: WEST GERMANS REOPEN A TOUCHY ISSUE: ADVANCED ARMS FOR SAUDIS
description: The West German Government, confirming news reports that Chancellor Helmut Kohl met recently with Saudi Arabia's Defense Minister, said today that it was re-examining a Saudi request for advanced weapons systems. The request was turned down a few years ago.

title: PERUVIANS ASSAIL PRESIDENT'S TACTIC
description: The Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry has come under continued criticism for urging peasants to help fight leftist guerrillas.

title: VARO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $163,000 for the quarter and $3.7 million for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $357,000 for the quarter and $1,170,000 for the year.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY ANTI-SANDINISTS ARE GROWING STRONGER BY THE DAY
description: Administration officials say that the number of guerrillas fighting the Nicaraguan Government has increased by about one-third to 8,000 in the last two months and that the rebels have enough support inside the country now to continue fighting without United States backing.

title: STAGE: 'LIGHT OPERA' PRESENTED AT CAFE LAMAMA
description: DOES ritual have a place in the modern world? The composer Charlie Morrow thinks it does. In recent years, he has performed as a solo, shamanistic chanter and as the instigator of outdoor events involving large numbers of people, geometric patterns and instrumentalists playing anything from woodwinds and drums to ocarinas and conch shells.

title: REX-NORECO INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $426,632, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and $411,488, or 20 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: The U.N. Today; June 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Natural Resources - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ELLMAN'S INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
WOODWARD STORES LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: COUNCIL AT-LARGE POSTS NEARLY AT END
description: Some of them are bitter, some are good-humored. A few are scouting for work. All eight of them - the remaining at-large members of the New York City Council - are likely to lose their jobs in a little more than a week.

title: Court Officers Halt Searches
description: Officers in New York City's Family Courts refused to conduct searches of people or packages entering courthouses in all five boroughs yesterday, but their action had no impact on court proceedings.

title: LIGHTNING RODS: FRANKLIN HAD IT WRONG
description: BEN FRANKLIN and King George III rarely saw eye to eye on anything, including lightning rods. Franklin believed lightning rods should have sharp tips, the sharper the better. George, who often felt like telling Ben to go fly a kite, disagreed and had his palace equipped with blunt rods. And so the Americans and British went their separate ways not only politically but on the relative merits of lightning rod configuration.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $447 million bond issue for the M-S-R Public Power Agency of California was tentatively priced yesterday by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company with yields ranging from 6.93 percent in 1986 to 9.6 percent in 2022.

title: INDICTMENT IS LIKELY FOR FORMER PLAYER
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn is expected to indict Ernie Cobb, star guard on the Boston College basketball team in 1978-79, on charges stemming from a point-shaving conspiracy that season, sources familiar with the investigation said yesterday.

title: CONNORS, MISS NAVRATILOVA SEEDED NO. 1
description: Jimmy Connors, the defending men's champion, was named the top-seeded player today in the All-England Tennis Championships that start here next Monday.

title: SUITS AGAINST MILITARY AND U.S. SUPERIORS BARRED
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that enlisted military personnel may not bring damage suits against their superior officers for violating their constitutional rights.

title: KEY FIGURE IN RULING IN '54 ON SCHOOL BIAS
description: Federal District Judge Oren R. Lewis died Sunday at Arlington Hospital in Virginia after suffering a heart attack at his home in Arlington. He was 80 years old.

title: Steinberg Sells Stake in Broker
description: Saul Steinberg, the New York financier, yesterday sold his 1.06-million-share stake in Paine Webber Inc. for an estimated profit of nearly $8 million, Wall Street sources familiar with the sale said. The stake represented a 7.85 percent interest in the brokerage house.

title: Mankiewicz At Gray & Co.
description: Frank Mankiewicz, who resigned May 10 as the president of National Public Radio, has been named executive vice president of Gray & Company, a public relations company.

title: U.S. Permitted to Collect Fee From Dairy Farmers
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that the Agriculture Department can continue collecting production assessments from dairy farmers until a lawsuit is settled.

title: EX-C.I.A. HEAD NOW WORKS FOR A NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Eight years ago, while this city was undergoing its post-Watergate cleansing, William E. Colby did something unusual for a director of Central Intelligence.

title: Troubled Canadair Gets Interim Chief Executive
description: Canadair, the Canadian aircraft manufacturer that has been plagued by poor sales and high development costs for its executive jet, has named Gilbert Bennett as interim president and chief executive.

title: Ballesteros's Fateful Choice
description: Like other competitive golfers, Seve Ballesteros selects the 14 clubs he feels he most needs each day when he is playing a round in a tournament. He chooses them from a supply of 16 or more that he has with him regularly. On Sunday, for the final round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, he almost made the wrong choice.

title: BOHEMIA INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,070,000 for the quarter and a net gain of $1,207,000, or 30 cents a share, for the year from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting. c-Including a tax credit of $1,906,000. d-Net loss including a tax credit of $3,880,000.

title: Richard Kelly Picked To Head W.R.G./West
description: Richard Kelly, 36, who helped found Scali McCabe Sloves in Canada in 1977, has been named president, general manager and director of client services of Wells, Rich, Greene/West in Los Angeles, Kenneth S. Olshan, chairman of W.R.G./Worldwide, announced yesterday.

title: Opera in the Parks To Begin Tonight
description: The Metropolitan Opera will launch its 17th season of free outdoor performances with a concert presentation of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' on the Great Lawn of Central Park tonight at 8:30. ''The Met in the Parks'' is jointly sponsored by Chemical Bank and the city's Department of Cultural Affairs.

title: TRECO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.8 million for the quarter and $3,845,000 for the year and a gain of $2,420,689 for the year from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Including tax credits of $1.5 million for the quarter and $1,953,000 for the year and gains of $1.7 million for the quarter and $1,852,358 for the year from the exchange of assets with bank creditors.

title: KITTY CARLISLE HART READY FOR RETURN TO BROADWAY
description: For the last seven years as chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts, and for many years before that as a panelist on the long-running television game show ''To Tell the Truth,'' Kitty Carlisle Hart has consistently projected the public image of a woman of elegance, sophistication and unflappable self-confidence. But the other morning, Mrs. Hart freely conceded that she was about to become unglued.

title: Carmet Lundy Sings At Greene Street
description: In the five years since Carmet Lundy arrived in New York from Miami she has developed a vocal range, a presence and a sense of direction that have put her in the front rank of contemporary jazz singers.

title: AVONDALE MILLS reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
description: b-Net loss after a charge of $400,000 from the closing of a yarn plant.

title: RICHARDSON SAYS ADDICTION IS CURED
description: The sparkling, white Volkswagen Beetle was cruising south on Route 17 early this afternoon. Its top was down and its driver, Michael Ray Richardson, was smiling broadly as he basked in the sunshine.

title: N.H.L. Controls Blues Franchise
description: The National Hockey League's Board of Governors took over the St. Louis Blues franchise from the Ralston Purina Company today and assumed control of the club's assets, including player contracts.

title: People
description: * Larry Cugini has been named group senior vice president-general manager of the Campbell-Ewald Company, Warren, Mich.

title: Gunmen Kill Tourist in Kenya
description: Unidentified gunmen opened fire on three safari tour vans today, killing a British vacationer and wounding a driver in the Great Rift Valley, the British Embassy said.

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: NATIONAL MINE SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The adoption of the F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52 for foreign currency translation increased net income for the latest fourth quarter by $1.7 million, or 15 cents a share, and for the fiscal year by $3.9 million, or 36 cents a share.

title: NUTRI/SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split effective August 1982.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring net gain of $40.1 million, or $2.14 a share, for the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to conform to the current presentation.

title: CLEAN-WATER BILL OFFERED IN HOUSE
description: The chairman of the House Public Works Committee today introduced what he described as a ''strongly proenvironmental'' bill to reauthorize the Clean Water Act, setting the stage for a key test of the 98th Congress on major environmental legislation.

title: Not Fair Enough for the Disabled
description: After months of dissembling, the Department of Health and Human Services acknowledges the ''hardships and heartbreaks'' for innocent victims of its disastrous mismanagement of Social Security Disability. Yet the department's new Secretary, Margaret Heckler, remains unwilling to follow up candid talk with straightforward reform.

title: FIAT CHIEF SEES CHANCE FOR CHANGE IN ITALIAN POLITICS
description: Giovanni Agnelli, the chairman of the board of Fiat and one of Italy's most listened-to voices on everything from soccer to politics, says he knows no reason why parliamentary elections should be held on June 26-27, one year earlier than required.

title: James W. Drought, 52, Writer; Ran Own Publishing Comany
description: James W. Drought, a writer who lived in Westport, Conn., died on June 2, in Norwalk Hospital. Mr. Drought, 52 years old, died of a heart attack. He was the author of many novels published by Skylight Press of Norwalk, which he and his wife, Lorna, established in 1963 for the purpose of publishing his books.

title: TRE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, Andrew's Neil article Sunday, ''Next Thatcher Moves,'' said that Labor received 3 percent fewer votes in the British election than the Liberal-Social Democratic alliance. It got 3 percent more.

title: Role Takes Shape
description: When Robert DeNiro played the part of Jake LaMotta in the movie ''Raging Bull,'' he put on dozens of extra pounds to authentically portray LaMotta at different stages of his boxing career. Sylvester Stallone sharpened his muscles for the role of another fighter, Rocky Balboa, in the movie ''Rocky.''

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE orange juice wasn't working. Even though the younger members of New York's fashion establishmentw ere drinking great quantities of it to wake themselves up at the S chnoodle Studios last Thursday morning, the honest truth was that t he last thing any of them needed was another fashion show, and e veryone could have used five minutes in the sun.

title: CENTRAL BANKS ASK MORE PRIVATE LOANS FOR THE THIRD WORLD
description: Western central bankers, at their annual meeting here, today called on private commercial banks to expand their lending to heavily indebted third world countries ''over a period of years'' to prevent another round of international debt problems.

title: CONSUMER DEBT IS UP
description: In April, consumers took on $2.27 billion more of installment credit than they paid off, an increase that was less than the month before, the Federal Reserve Board said today. The growth in total debt is regarded as a sign of consumers' confidence in the economy.

title: New Law Lets Military Bar Turkish Candidates
description: Turkey's ruling generals have amended the new election bill so that they have a right to veto candidates put up by political parties in the general elections scheduled for November.

title: Florida Execution Is Stayed
description: The Florida Supreme Court today blocked the execution of James C. McCrae, who had been condemned to die in the electric chair June 21 for raping and beating to death a 67-year-old woman. The court ruled 6 to 1 to issue the stay pending a ruling on an appeal Mr. McCrae has filed.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day June 6about John Fedders of the Securities and Exchange Commission incorrectly reported Orin E. Atkins's tenure as chief executive officer of Ashland Oil Inc. He resigned in September 1981, two months before Bernard H. Barnett, a lawyer, reportedly complained to Mr. Fedders about an S.E.C. investigation of Ashland.

title: News Analysis
description: The Supreme Court's ruling last month that racially discriminatory private schools are not entitled to tax exemptions has apparently set the stage for more complicated disputes in the months and years ahead.

title: Herbicide Maker Sued Over Dioxin
description: Seven people and two companies sued a herbicide manufacturer today, charging that they had been injured either physically, emotionally or economically by the company's manufacture of a dioxin agent at a now-closed plant here.

title: MANHATTAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Business and the Law; Trying to Alter Gas Contracts
description: BACK in the 1970's, when energy supplies were tight, all kinds of companies were eager to sign long-term supply contracts, some of them for high-priced natural gas. Now that plenty of fuel is available, however, many gas pipeline companies are trying to get out of those contracts.

title: POLES SEEK '91 START ON PAYING DEBTS
description: Poland proposed today that it make no further payment of foreign debt to Western banks until 1991 and after that stretch out repayment over 14 years.

title: SOVIET PRISONERS' HEROIC NEW HELPER
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERHAUL URGED OF MANAGEMENT FOR NEW CENTER
description: A lack of coordination between the agencies building and running New York City's Convention Center has created the need for a sweeping management overhaul, according to a report by the State Senate's minority leader.

title: ISRAELI-SYRIAN CLASH REPORTED
description: The Lebanese state radio and television reported that Israeli and Syrian tanks exchanged fire in eastern Lebanon for an hour tonight. An Israeli military spokesman outside Beirut said he had no reports of any fighting in the area.

title: LARGE LOANS FOR SEAFIRST
description: The Seafirst Corporation, the Seattle bank holding company that has begun borrowing from the Federal Reserve System, said yesterday that the loans were large but it declined to specify their size.

title: CO-DEFENDANT OF DELOREAN AGREES TO AID PROSECUTION IN PLEA BARGAIN
description: William Morgan Hetrick, a co-defendant with John Z. DeLorean in a $24 million cocaine case, today changed his plea to guilty and agreed to testify against the automobile maker and another co-defendant. The step appeared to be a considerable gain for the Government in its prosecution of the DeLorean case.

title: INDIANS ROUT YANKEES, 9-0
description: He couldn't have helped them tonight, but Rich Gossage, the Yankees' most effective reliever, may be lost to the team for as long as 10 days with a strained right-shoulder muscle.

title: Six Concerns Bid For First Federal
description: Amalgamated Trust and Savings Bank of Chicago said it was one of six concerns that had submitted bids to the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation to acquire First Federal Savings and Loan Association of Chicago.

title: Sephardic Rabbi in Office
description: Mordechai Eliahu took office today as the Chief Rabbi for Israel's Sephardic Jews, those of Mediterranean and North African origin, the Israeli radio said. It said 600 people had jammed a synagogue in Jerusalem's Old City for the ceremony. Rabbi Eliahu was elected in March by a conclave of public figures to succeed Ovadiah Yosef.

title: FOR TOM WATSON, AN ENCORE
description: F or the last year, Tom Watson has been cherished by golf historians for having won the United States Open as spectacularly as anyone else ever has - with his chip-in at Pebble Beach for a birdie 2 at the 17th hole in the final round. Now that this year's Open is about to start Thursday at Oakmont in the hills above the Allegheny River outside Pittsburgh, the defending champion will be expected to do something for an encore. The trouble is, Tom Watson doesn't know what to expect.

title: Beam Falls on Car, Injuring Driver
description: A 42-year-old motorist was injured yesterday when a 40-foot steel beam held by a crane fell onto his station wagon as he waited at a red light on Broadway at Barclay Street, two blocks south of City Hall, authorities said.

title: Lawrence, Eydie Gorme Play Carnegie Hall
description: Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme, who this year are celebrating their 25th anniversary together, have always been an unusually well-matched vocal team. Mr. Lawrence's smooth mellow baritone and Miss Gorme's ripe, theatrical soprano with its extra-wide vibrato seem to blend together naturally. Their singing voices also match their marriedcouple patter, in which Mr. Lawrence plays the imperturbably cool and cocky husband to Miss Gorme's garrulous, emotionally dependent spouse.

title: Q&A
description: Q. On a recent trip to Bermuda I saw rainbows day after day. They appeared to be the same size every time. Were they?

title: Steyr-Logan Deal
description: Steyr Daimler-Puch A.G. of Austria has reached tentative agreement to purchase the Logan Manufacturing Company from John Z. DeLorean, the former auto executive, Automotive News, a trade paper, reported. It said the price would likely be $10 million and the deal could be closed before July 25.

title: Burger King Shifts to Pepsi
description: The Burger King Corporation said today that it would serve Pepsi-Cola products instead of Coca-Cola products in its 3,200 restaurants in the United States.

title: Switch for Upshaw
description: After a 16-year career that included 217 games, Gene Upshaw is leaving the Los Angeles Raiders to replace Ed Garvey as the executive director of the National Football League Players Association. The association's board of player representatives met yesterday in Chicago and approved the selection of Upshaw, who had served as union president during the 57-day players' strike in 1982.

title: WRONG AUTOPSY REPORT FOR THE ROMAN EMPIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH AMERICAN ROYALTIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Salvador Asks Rebels to Vote
description: The Government Peace Commission called today for the political wing of the leftist guerrilla movement to participate in presidential elections scheduled for the end of the year. The Peace Commission director, Francisco Quinones Avila, told the Diario de Hoy newspaper the Government stands by its position of limiting negotiations with the left to terms for fielding candidates in the elections. Before participating in any voting, guerrillas want to negotiate with the Government on ways to share power.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Tree Grows, Again, On East 63d Street

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in March 1982.

title: The Older Generation; The Video Kid
description: As the sun rises on this American summer, parents are pushing their children out of bed and onto their paper routes. Squeezing lemons so they can make a killing in lemonade.

title: POLES IN DETROIT: WELCOME BUT NO JOBS
description: Stanislaw Boguszewski sat in the tiny living room of his apartment in this suburb of Detroit, a small Solidarity flag perched in a water glass in the window.

title: 'CUBS FAMILY' MINUS BANKS
description: Ernie Banks smiled. It is perhaps the most famous smile in sports. Once he would greet someone with, ''It's a beautiful day today, let's play two.'' That was in a different life. Banks's hair is thinning now, and he wears steel-rimmed spectacles for reading some of his business papers. He had on a dark tie and a vest from a blue business suit as he sat in his office at the Equitable Life Insurance Company on Michigan Avenue.

title: Race-Car Driver Killed in Crash
description: One race-car driver was killed and a second was critically injured in a three-car pileup Sunday at Summit Point Raceway.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Today, Neptune; yesterday, Pluto, and tomorrow, on to the stars.'' -Jack Dyer, chief of spacecraft operations for Pioneer 10. (A1:1.)

title: U.S. Remains Leader In Advertising Spending
description: When it comes to advertising, the United States is indeed the land of plenty. While various countries shift in and out of second place in total advertising spending, advertising per capita and advertising spending as a percent of gross national product, No.1 in each is always the United States.

title: Dodgers 5, Reds 1
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - Fernando Valenzuela stopped Cincinnati on five hits for his fifth straight victory, and Steve Yeager and Mike Marshall hit consecutive home runs.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,042,000. c-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,213,000.

title: L.I. School Opens After Racial Strife
description: Farmingdale High School reopened today, four days after scuffles between black and white students caused the school to be shut down.

title: FED SETS CAPITAL RULES AFFECTING 5 LARGE BANKS
description: The Federal Reserve Board today adopted new minimium capital standards that will require five of the nation's largest banks to raise $800 million in new capital funds. Four of the banks are in New York, and the other is the BankAmerica Corporation, San Francisco.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: KANSAS CITY (AL) - Placed George B rett, third baseman, on the 15-day dis- a bled list retroactive to June 8. METS (NL) - Named Bill Monbou- q uette pitching coach.

title: Honduras Reports 100 G.I.'s Arrive Today in Training Role
description: About 100 soldiers of the United States Special Forces will arrive on Tuesday to staff a center that will be used to train Salvadoran military units, a Honduran Army spokesman announced today.

title: Caste Rioter Killed in India
description: Untouchables rioted and burned down a police station in southwestern India today.

title: Service for Mary Jane Jossel
description: A memorial service for Mary Jane Jossel, director of advertising and promotion of the Dell Publishing Company, will be held at 11:30 A.M. on Thursday at the Church Center for the United Nations, 44th Street and First Avenue. Mrs. Jossel died last Wednesday at the age of 64.

title: MISSISSIPPI LAWYER, BELIEVED DEAD, HELD IN MURDER
description: Edward L. Cates, a prominent Jackson lawyer who was a close adviser to Gov. Ross Barnett in the 1960's, is being held without bond on charges of murder, arson and embezzlement, a month after he was believed to have died in his burned-out automobile.

title: Bridge: Westchester Squad Takes Grand National Zonal Title
description: A strong team representing Westchester and the Hudson Valley captured the Grand National zonal title in the small hours of this morning, while an experienced New York squad disappointed its supporters.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Founder of Cycle Study Transfers to Columbia
description: Geoffrey H. Moore has seen many a business cycle, and he has made the business cycle and leading economic indicators the centerpiece of his research in a career that began in 1939 and is still going.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
NOTORIOUS DARSEE CASE SHAKES ASSUMPTIONS ABOUT SCIENCE
description: AYOUNG researcher fakes the bulk of his 100 publications, gets caught red-handed, and publicly apologizes after Federal and university investigators expose his deception. The case would appear to be closed. Yet the celebrated fakery of Dr. John Darsee, performed during the course of 14 years at two respected medical research centers, raises fundamental questions about the self-policing system of science. How could he get away with so much for so long?

title: Wheeling Steel Shares
description: The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation said yesterday that two investors had purchased a ''substantial'' number of its common shares. It identified them as Allen E. Paulson, chairman and president of the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, and Burt Sugarman, a private investor.

title: LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
FMI FINANCIAL reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $624,000 and a tax credit of $306,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $318,000 and a tax credit of $406,000. Revenue for the latest first quarter includes a recovery of $1,035,000 of an allowance for doubtful accounts in a prior period.

title: WRONG AUTOPSY REPORT FOR THE ROMAN EMPIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Southwest Financial Corp. filed an offering of up to $50 million of Government National Mortgage Association collateralized bonds, through the Merrill Lynch White Weld Markets Group.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 14, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices rose sharply as investors reacted to favorable economic news. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.44 points, to 1,220.55, the biggest one-day gain since Feb. 24, when it climbed 24.47 points. Analysts cited Friday's report that the basic money supply had risen less than expected. (Page D1.)

title: DRESSING UP IN MIDTOWN
description: Now that raincoats can be doffed and what the weathermen call a warming trend has set in, it is apparent that while casual country clothes are worn on the Upper West Side or SoHo, women who come to midtown to work or do serious shopping are making an effort to dress up.

title: TIER THREE PENSION: UNFAIR TO SANITATIONMEN
description: To the Editor:

title: EMIGRES IN ISRAEL DENY SOVIET CLAIM
description: A group of Jewish emigres whose parents, children and friends have been blocked from leaving the Soviet Union gathered today in Jerusalem to rebut a recent Soviet contention that almost all Jews who wished to emigrate had done so.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LIBERATOR

title: Addenda
description: * Doyle Dane Bernbach International has acquired RZA, a direct marketing agency in Zurich, which will be renamed RZA Rapp & Collins AG.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: High Tech, Low Profile

title: Olof Palme Renews Call For Nuclear-Free Zones
description: Prime Minister Olof Palme of Sweden called today for nuclear-free zones in Scandinavia and central Europe, in an address before the North Atlantic Assembly.

title: 1,500 ATTEND CENTRAL PARK MEMORIAL SERVICE FOR AIDS VICTIM
description: More than 1,500 people attended a candlelight vigil and memorial service in Central Park yesterday evening for a New York City hardware store manager who became a national symbol of the discrimination and pain suffered by victims of a condition that ravages the body's immune system.

title: SEAGRAM CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in March.

title: Pirates 4, Expos 3
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Richie Hebner drove in the tying run with a pinch-hit double, then scored the winning run on an error as the Pirates rallied for three runs in the seventh inning.

title: Fannie Mae Sets Marketing Shift
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association will begin marketing its mortgage-backed securities through a group of 17 investment bankers, rather than through an underwriting syndicate, the corporation announced yesterday.

title: CLEMENS HOLZMEISTER
description: Clemens Holzmeister, the Austrian architect who designed the Turkish Parliament Building in Ankara and the Salzburg Festival Playhouse, died last night in a hospital here.

title: Scientology Leader's Son Loses a Court Challenge
description: A Superior Court judge today dismissed a claim by the son of L. Ron Hubbard, the founder of the Church of Scientology, that his father was either dead or mentally incompetent.

title: INVENTORIES RISE 0.5% AS SALES CLIMB BY 0.7%
description: Business inventories rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest gain in a year, and sales climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said today.

title: CORSICAN SEIZED ON MITTERRAND ROUTE
description: The police said tonight that they had arrested a man carrying a loaded revolver as he waited for President Francois Mitterrand's motorcade to enter Ajaccio this morning.

title: Bush Will Coordinate New Effort to Bar Drugs
description: A new coordinated effort to block illegal drugs at the borders of the United States will be headed by Vice President George Bush, employing undercover operators of the Central Intelligence Agency as well as surveillance by military units, a spokesman for the Vice President said today.

title: MAURICE LAMONTAGNE
description: Senator Maurice Lamontagne, a Quebec economist who played influential roles in provincial and federal political affairs in the 1960's, died today after a long illness. He was 65 years old. Mr. Lamontagne was credited with having helped bring Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau into federal politics.

title: BALLET: 'DIVERTISSEMENT'
description: PETER MARTINS'S ''Delibes Divertissement,'' performed on Saturday afternoon by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, is exactly what its name promises - a pretty, diverting little romp through a bouncing Delibes score. Crafted for the company-affiliated School of American Ballet, it is also a celebration of youthful high spirits and ballet manners. And on Saturday it received a young a vibrant performance.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Curran Working For the State

title: EUROPE'S CLOUDY CAR OUTLOOK
description: On balance, Europe's powerful automobile industry could not complain last year. Car sales rose across the Continent, big markets such as Britain and France were jumping and there were indications that the Japanese, fresh from their successes in North America, were beginning to find the pickings less easy against costcutting European car makers.

title: SPACECRAFT LEAVES REALM OF PLANETS
description: Pioneer 10 crossed the orbit of Neptune yesterday to become the first spacecraft ever to depart the realm of the known planets and head out toward the stars.

title: BETTER TEACHERS SIMPLY AREN'T COMING ALONG
description: DEMANDS for better schools are being shouted from the housetops. Legislatures call for tougher competency tests. The College Board urges stiffer college admission reqirements. Commissions warn that, without curriculum reforms, the nation is in peril.

title: Schlichter Home
description: Art Schlichter, the Baltimore Colts quarterback who had been in a rehabilitation program at the South Oaks Hospital in Amityville, L.I., for treatment related to an addiction to gambling, has returned to his parents' home in Bloomington, Ohio, and will continue his treatment with a private doctor in the area.

title: Indian Music Festival At Alternative Museum
description: The Alternative Museum in TriBeCa is holding a festival of Indian music this month, and the two offerings last weekend provided an indication of how varieties of music from India can differ in both style and quality.

title: M.T.A. SAYS CITY SUBWAYS HAVE HALTED DROP IN RIDERS
description: After a steady, long-term decline that shrunk the number of riders on New York City's subways to less one billion last year for the first year since 1917, there has been a turn-around, officials said yesterday.

title: STATE AGENCY TO INVESTIGATE WESTWAY CASE
description: The State Commission of Investigation announced today that it would investigate accusations that state officials presented ''tainted environmental studies and testimony'' about the Westway project in Federal Court.

title: Renault Offers A Free Option
description: Buyers of Renault Fuego and Fuego Turbo models will receive free air-conditioning systems on vehicles purchased between now and the end of August, the American Motors Corporation said.

title: RATE HOPES PUSH DOW UP 24.44
description: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday as interest rates declined. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.44 points, to 1,220.55, its biggest one-day advance in more than three months. Other major market indicators also finished higher. The New York Stock Exchange's composite index of 1,500 common stocks rose 1.17, to 95.62, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 2.16, to 164.84.

title: The Older Generation; Doctored
description: It's the season for honorary degrees and commencement speeches, pleasant customs by which colleges (a) honor excellence and (b) induce celebrities to enliven often endless graduation ceremonies.

title: BUDGET WRITERS HEAR OUTLOOK IS BRIGHTER AND DEFICIT SHRINKS
description: Senate and House budget writers were told today that the economic outlook had brightened in recent months. As a result, the budget deficit projected for the fiscal year 1984, which begins Oct. 1, might be $10 billion to $15 billion less than was expected at the beginning of this year.

title: SMD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $66,940 for the quarter and $81,801 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $47,352 for the quarter and $152,580 for the year.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article June 2 about a reunion of the first team that climbed Mount Everest included an incorrect subheading. Only two members reached the summit.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Diseased Cows Killed in Jersey
description: More than 100 cows in southern New Jersey have been sent to slaughterhouses this spring because of an outbreak of brucellosis, an incurable bacterial disease in cattle that causes sterility and low milk production, State Agriculture Department officials said today.

title: MCNAMARA CRITICIZES CBS ON TAPING OF CALL
description: Robert S. McNamara, the former Secretary of Defense secretary, said today that it would have been ''entirely unethical'' if CBS News had made an audiotape, without his knowledge or consent, of what he said had been an ''off-the-record'' telephone conversation with a CBOS producer.

title: LEBANESE HASHISH IS INVADING ISRAEL
description: In the year since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, the heavy, loosely controlled traffic across the border has allowed so much Lebanese-grown hashish to come south that the police say it is more abundant here now than it has been in years.

title: ATLAN-TOL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BROADWAY LUMINARIES TURN OUT TO FETE LIZ SMITH
description: Broadway saluted Mary Elizabeth Smith of Fort Worth, Tex., last night with an all-star benefit production that began in a tentcovered Shubert Alley and continued onto the stage of the Shubert Theater itself.

title: Cards Surprised
description: Not even his teammates on the St. Louis Cardinals were aware that Lonnie Smith had a drug problem and would require treatment. ''The first we heard about it was in the clubhouse meeting right before the game on Sunday,'' said Darrell Porter, the catcher who several years ago was also hospitalized for a drug and alcohol problem.

title: Merrill to Acquire Securities Options
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to buy the Securities Options Corporation, a private concern that clears trades on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed.

title: Hospital Mortgage Bonds Sell Well
description: An $87.5 million bond issue for the New York State Medical Care Facility Finance Agency that was tentatively priced by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. with yields ranging from 8 percent to 9 7/8 percent was oversubscribed on the first day of the offering, a spokesman for the underwriter said.

title: CUOMO SAID TO PICK UPSTATE PROSECUTOR TO HEAD STATE POLICE
description: Governor Cuomo has chosen the District Attorney of Monroe County, Donald O. Chesworth Jr., superintendent of the state police, an aide to Mr. Cuomo said today.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM ROOTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO MAJOR BANKS PLAN MERGER IN NEW ENGLAND
description: The CBT Corporation and the Bank of New England Corporation yesterday announced a plan to merge their assets and operations. The merger would create a bank with more than $10 billion in assets that would rank as the second largest in New England.

title: Switzerland to Try A Russian for Espionage
description: Swiss authorities said today that they had arrested a Russian spy who used Switzerland as a base for an espionage ring operating in South Africa.

title: PERSEVERANCE PUTS TEEN-AGER ON TOP; GARY, Ind.
description: D ianne Durham will return tonight to the Emerson Middle School she attended until she moved to Houston in February 1982. She has been invited back as part of a triumphant return to her hometown, after having won three individual titles at the recent United States gymnastics championships in Chicago.

title: FOREIGN POLICY GROUP PICKS EDITOR
description: The Council on Foreign Relations has announced the appointment of William G. Hyland, a deputy national security adviser to President Ford, as editor of the quarterly Foreign Affairs.

title: PIERCE, S S, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income. c-Including a gain of $1,897,000, or $1.54 a share, from a fire insurance settlement.

title: 21 Hurt in 2-Car Crash On Verrazano Bridge
description: Twenty-one people were injured yesterday, one critically, when a driver on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge had a heart attack and the driver's car slammed into a passenger van that had stopped because of a flat tire, authorities said.

title: XONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss The latest year net includes a charge of $263,000 to settle a 1977 lawsuit. All 1982 figures are restated for acquisitions.

title: 'PRENATAL ADOPTION' IS THE OBJECTIVE OF NEW TECHNIQUE
description: THE art of laboratory fertilization of humans has progressed far in recent years, and now some medical scientists are trying to add yet another new dimension to the work through a technique that might broaden farther the range of infertility problems that can be overcome.

title: Music Noted In Brief; Bel Canto Opera Offers Moniuszko's 'Halka'
description: It is an irony of European history that beauty and violence seem so often to issue from the same collective human spirit. In the middle of the 19th century - at the moment that Pole, Russian, Prussian, Frenchman and Hungarian were busily killing one another in the name of patriotism - a nationalistic opera tradition of great beauty was beginning to form. There was Glinka in Russia, Erkel in Hungary and then the Polish composer Stanislaw Moniuszko, whose ''Halka'' the Bel Canto Opera has been performing at the Robert F. Wagner School Theater.

title: Books Of The Times
description: SISTER AGE. By M.F.K. Fisher. 243 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Leonard Marshall, a defensive tackle from Louisiana State who was the 37th pick in the draft, was among 10 players signed by the New York Giants yesterday. ... The Kansas City Royals placed George Brett on the 15-day disabled list. Brett, the third baseman who is hitting .369, suffered a broken little toe on his left foot June 8. ... Ben Lindsey, who was dismissed after his first season as basketball coach at Arizona, said he would refuse the university's offer to remain as an assistant director of intramural sports. He said the job would ''not restore the earning power and career opportunities'' he had before going to Arizona. ... The Montreal Canadiens signed a former coach, Claude Ruel, as director of player personnel.

title: Charlotte Curtis; Mrs. Carter Speaks Out
description: imposed Georgia exile. Yet she hasn't made much peace with the past.

title: High Court To Hear Bond Case
description: The Supreme Court today injected a late-hour note of uncertainty into the imminent change-over in the municipal bond market from bearer bonds to registered bonds. The Justices agreed to hear arguments in South Carolina's lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of the Federal law that requires all new municipal bonds to include a record of ownership.

title: The Older Generation; The Granny Flat
description: Except when the house or apartment in question is ''magnificent'' or ''important,'' American real estate ads conjure up a cozy world. The ''eat-in'' kitchen seems like a homey place.

title: GIANT SQUID FINALLY SEEN, ALIVE
description: ONE favorite scene in popular sea yarns is a battle to the death between a diver and a giant squid. Authors of such tales have had a free rein, since giant squid have never been seen in their habitat, and their existence has been known only from dead examples.

title: Turn On the Coal Faucet
description: Transport coal in a pipeline? The idea seems bizarre, but it has long been possible. The coal is pulverized, mixed with water or oil and pumped as a ''slurry'' hundreds of miles from mine to customer.

title: TEACHER PAY ON AGENDA FOR REAGAN IN KNOXVILLE
description: President Reagan will visit Tennessee Tuesday, apparently to embrace what has become Gov. Lamar Alexander's national campaign for an education program that centers on merit pay for teachers.

title: ACTS OF VIOLENCE AGAINST THERAPISTS POSE LURKING THREAT
description: ''I'VE come to shoot some squirrel,'' the patient told Dr. Howard A. Bernstein as the psychotherapist sat in his office at a mental health clinic in a rural area of Illinois. The teen-age girl was carrying a hunting bow and wearing a quiver of steel-pointed arrows designed for killing bear or deer.

title: MASONITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $696,000. c-After income from discontinued operations of $415,000. d-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $2,877,000. The income for the latest 9 months includes a gain of $3.6 million on the sale of the company's remaining domestic timberlands. The year-ago 9-month loss includes a loss of $3.1 million relating to Masonite Canada Inc. in which the company sold its 50 percent interest in January 1982.

title: Postal Service Postpones Rate Increase Until 1984
description: A United States Postal Service rate increase scheduled for November will be postponed at least until next year as the agency heads for its second straight surplus year, Postmaster General William F. Bolger said today.

title: Paradyne Sees Earnings Dip
description: The Paradyne Corporation, a data-processing equipment manufacturer in Largo, Fla., that has been accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of fraudulently obtaining a Government contract, said yesterday that it expected its 1983 earnings to decline to $1.10 to $1.20 a share on revenues of between $235 million and $245 million.

title: TICKET SALE STARTS FOR 1984 OLYMPICS
description: A total of 5.6 million tickets for the 1984 Summer Olympic Games will go on sale Tuesday through a nationwide mail-order system, the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee announced today.

title: STRAINS IN SEABROOK PROJECT
description: The managers of New Hampshire's largest electric utility are wagering the company on what many analysts call a long shot that grows longer every day: the Seabrook Station nuclear power project.

title: Withholding Plan by Dole
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said yesterday that he would try to salvage a law that would withhold taxes from interest and dividend income.

title: U.S. CURBS LIBYA ON JERSEY MANSION
description: The State Department, in an official letter that Libyan officials received yesterday, said the chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations can use a mansion in Englewood, N.J., only for his immediate family's recreation.

title: SOTHEBY TAKEOVER OFFER RAISED BY FIRST BIDDERS
description: The takeover bidding for Sotheby Parke Bernet, the international art auction house, heated up yesterday between the two American contenders.

title: CUBS SEND TORREZ TO EIGHTH DEFEAT
description: The Mets matched the Cubs hit for hit last night, but their problem was that they could not make the same claim in runs. Jay Johnstone and Keith Moreland each drove in a pair of runs, leading Chicago's 12-hit attack against 4 New York pitchers in a 7-3 victory over the Mets before a crowd of 9,792 at Shea Stadium.

title: SHUTTLE FLIGHT FOR MILITARY IS DELAYED
description: The 10th flight of the space shuttle, originally set for November, has been delayed indefinitely at the request of the Air Force, the space agency said today.

title: GUATEMALA ELECTION PROMISED
description: President Efrain Rios Montt has promised a national election in the second half of next year. Last month the President said Guatemala was not ready to return to democratric rule, bringing protests from labor, the church, political parties and the military, the former general's power base.

title: THEATER: NEW YORK CLOWN FESTIVAL
description: THE fine art of tomfoolery is center stage at the First New York Festival of Clown-Theater, a five-week celebration of physical comedy in all its forms. The festival, running daily at Theater Guinevere on West 28th Street through July 10, features some of the funniest people in performance, in lecture demonstrations and, in several classic cases, on film and on tape. The producers plan to make it an annual affair, and, for the sake of laughter, one hopes that they succeed.

title: BOMAC BATTEN reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a special gain of $817,000. c-Net income.

title: Chinaglia Moonlighting
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the scoring star of the Cosmos of the North American Soccer League, got a rousing welcome from flag-waving fans as he arrived in Rome to take over as part-owner and president of the Lazio soccer club.

title: Cuzco Blacked Out in Attack By Guerrillas of Shining Path
description: Guerrillas attacked the city of Cuzco, hurling sticks of dynamite at an American-Peruvian cultural center and a hotel and blowing up three electrical towers, the police said today.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 14, 1983
description: International Pioneer 10 crossed Neptune's orbit and became the first spacecraft ever to leave the realm of the universe's known planets and head out toward the stars. After a voyage of more than 11 years, the hardy, 570-pound robot craft was 2.81 billion miles from the Sun and traveling 30,558 miles an hour. (Page A1, Column 1.) Nicaraguan rebels have increased in number by about one-third to 8,000 in the last two months and now have enough support inside the country to continue fighting Government forces without United States backing, according to officials of the Reagan Administration. (A1:2-3.)

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Dick Ruthven faces Ed Lynch for the second time in less than a week. Last Thursday, Ruthven yielded only one hit through seven innings, but was knocked out in the eighth and the Mets won, 6-4, in 11. (Television - Sports@Channel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland, 7:30 P.M. Rudy May was to have started for the Yankees for the first time since last August, but he is needed in the bullpen and Bob Shirley will start instead. (Television -Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Dodgers, at Los Angeles. Atlanta's ace rookie, Craig McMurty, seeks his eighth victory as the Braves try to loosen the Dodgers' hold on first place. (Television - WTBS, 10:35 P.M.) Boxing Jerome Clouden vs. Larry Lane, light-heavyweights, 12 rounds, at the Marriott Hotel, New Orleans. Clouden has lost only once in 16 bouts; Lane is 16-3. (Television - ESPN, 8:30 P.M.) Maurice Blocker vs. Danny Paul, welterweights, 10 rounds, at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City; first preliminary at 7:45 P.M. Blocker is unbeaten in 12 fights and has 8 knockouts; Paul is 18-5, with 6 knockouts.

title: CONVICT-POET, IDOL OF FRANCE'S LEFT, IS FALLEN
description: A 36-year-old convict turned writer who became a hero of the French left and was pardoned by President Francois Mitterrand has been charged with armed robbery and impersonating a police officer.

title: Safeway Stores
description: The Justice Department said it had tentatively agreed to end a 25-year-old antitrust consent decree against Safeway Stores Inc. that grew out of a suit charging the grocery chain with attempting to monopolize the market in Texas and New Mexico.

title: Martin Plays The Peacemaker
description: Rudy May was frustrated. He sat by himself in the rear of the Yankees' chartered airplane taking the team to Cleveland Sunday night after he was the losing pitcher in the 12th inning at Milwaukee.

title: FLOCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $7,700. c-Net loss.

title: ISRAELI ENVOY SAYS HE'S NO DIPLOMAT
description: Meir Rosenne, a dapper, silver-haired lawyer and diplomat, laughed when asked how he found out he was coming to Washington to serve in the most powerful and delicate post in the Israeli Foreign Service, Ambassador to the United States.

title: BREZHNEVED BY THE U.S.
description: Under the so-called Brezhnev Doctrine, Moscow claims the right to intervene in its sphere of influence, Eastern Europe, whenever ''internal and external forces hostile to socialism'' try ''to turn the development'' of a socialist country ''toward the restoration of a capitalist regime.'' In what is historically considered our sphere, we pursue a reverse Brezhnev Doctrine, intervening in Latin America whenever we find a capitalist country is threatened with a socialist regime. We do not do it very well.

title: TRANSMATION INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Market Place; Glamour Stock Shock Waves
description: THE disclosure that Texas Instruments Inc. expects an after-tax loss that might reach $100 million for its June quarter because of sudden reversals in the fiercely competitive home computer business sent shock waves through Wall Street yesterday. While traders and investors sought to respond to the announcement affecting one of the market's glamour stocks, security analysts slashed their 1983 earnings estimates for the company.

title: DEMOCRATIC ERRORS
description: To the Editor:

title: MOST COMPUTER STOCKS SHOW DROPS
description: Texas Instruments stock fell sharply yesterday, depressing share prices of other computer companies. The company's shares declined $39.50, to $118.25, in response to a weekend announcement that the company expected second-quarter losses as high as $100 million because of a sudden slowdown in sales of home computer products.

title: SACRABUDGETATION
description: Concern about preserving the ''budget process'' has become a pillar in the temple of conventional wisdom on economic policy. The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr., for example, argues ''the Congressional budget process lies at the heart of modern and coherent democracy.'' Peering behind the rhetoric, we see a record that does not measure up.

title: TWO PLAGUES THAT WILL NOT GO AWAY
description: With 90-degree temperatures signaling the onset of outdoor activity for thousands of New Yorkers, two of the city's most visible problems -festering piles of curb-side garbage and large numbers of illegal street peddlers - are back again like the shimmering heat waves of summer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Capital Research Co., Los Angeles, has elected Henry G. Grundstedt a senior vice president.

title: BANKENO MINES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-The company did not provide year-ago results saying they were not comparable due to significant acquisitions made in 1982 through the issue of equity. Revenue includes results of Merland Explorations from March 17 through Dec. 31. Turbo Resources Ltd. holds a controlling interest in Bankeno Mines.

title: Gonorrhea Cases Decline As Fear of AIDS Spreads
description: Fear of contracting sexually transmitted diseases such as the incurable AIDS and herpes helped reduce the gonorrhea rate in Los Angeles County in 1982, health officials say.

title: ROEBLING'S OHIO FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Inside Information On Miss Liberty ANational Parks Service spokesman offered some inside information a bout the Statue of Liberty recently when Michael Reagan, son of the P resident, announced his July 4 Miami-to-New York boat race to raise r estoration money for the statue and Ellis Island.

title: Boat With 76 Haitians Stopped and Returned
description: Seventy-six Haitians bound for the United States on an overcrowded wooden sailboat were stopped by a Coast Guard cutter off the coast of Haiti and returned to Port-Au-Prince today.

title: CONFEREES STRUGGLE OVER BUDGET AND COUNT VOTES
description: In a daylong series of private sessions, Congressional negotiators struggled today to draft a compromise Government budget for the fiscal year 1984 that could command a majority in both the Democratic-controlled House and the Republicandominated Senate.

title: TV: 'WORLD OF JAMES JOYCE' MARKING BLOOMSDAY
description: TOMORROW is Bloomsday, one of the most famous days in all literature, and tonight at 8 o'clock on Channel 13, public television is acknowledging the occasion with ''The World of James Joyce.'' Joyce's ''Ulysses,'' his master novel, takes place in Dublin on a single day - June 16, 1904 - tracing the meanderings and thoughts of Leopold Bloom; his wife, Molly, and Stephen Dedalus, a young writer bearing some resemblance to the author himself.

title: LEBANON PARLIAMENT, 65 TO 2, BACKS PULLOUT PACT
description: Despite Syrian objections, the Lebanese Parliament today overwhelmingly approved the agreement with Israel that provides for withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon.

title: CAROLINA LIEUTENANT GOVERNOR CITED IN SUSPECTED BRIBE PLOT
description: A Wake County grand jury has named Lieut. Gov. James C. Green as a participant in a suspected conspiracy to take bribes of $10,000 a month from an undercover Federal agent.

title: What's the Merit in Merit Pay?
description: ''If we want to achieve excellence, we must reward it,'' President Reagan said yesterday in Knoxville. ''It's the American way.'' Once again, the President was insisting that the way to restore excellence to public education is to provide merit pay for teachers. Too easy.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: A $29.7 million bond issue for Florida's Palm Beach County, won by Citibank in competitive bidding yesterday, was priced at yields ranging from 5.5 percent to 8.25 percent.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Gifts that are chosen to fit someone's particular interests are always the best kind. Here are some ideas for Father's Day that are geared to specific tastes, hobbies or pleasures. 1.A Challenge for Dad If he enjoys puzzles, ciphers and codes, then he should get many hours of pleasure - or frustration, as the case may be - from a new brain-teaser called Decipher. He may also get a chance to win $100,000. The game consists of a jigsaw puzzle whose pieces are contained in a drawstring flannel bag. To make the puzzle difficult, all the pieces are a gold color with numbers printed on both sides - and of course there is no picture. When the puzzle is completed, the numbers form a cipher that must then be solved by breaking the code to determine the letters the numbers stand for. The first person to send in the correct solution wins the prize. Bloomingdale's has Decipher in its stationery department, where it sells for $12.

title: PRISON ISN'T THE ONLY SOLUTION
description: In rural Maryland one evening, a 19-year-old boy, high on marijuana and beer, killed 10 of his friends while driving. Instead of being sentenced to prison, he was ordered to a program of drug and alcohol counseling, psychotherapy and three years of volunteer work in a hospital emergency unit.

title: S.Y. Katz Is Married To Nancy A. Spielberg
description: Nancy A. Spielberg, daughter of Mrs. Bernard Adler of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Arnold Spielberg of Laguna Beach, Calif., was married in West Orange, N.J., yesterday to Shimon Y. Katz, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Leon Katz of Clifton, N.J. Rabbi Katz, spiritual leader of Congregation Adas Israel in Passaic, N.J., performed the ceremony at the Town and Campus.

title: O'ROURKE SEEKING TO REMAIN WESTCHESTER'S CHIEF
description: County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke traveled throughout Westchester County today formally announcing what had been apparent for some time - that he would seek election to the $81,500 post this fall.

title: OROSCO SAYS THANK YOU
description: J esse Orosco is sorry the meeting was so brief: a few kind words, a handshake, a promise of ''see you soon.'' There was so much more he wanted to say when George Bamberger resigned as manager of the Mets 12 days ago. But he understood that Bamberger had to make the rounds of the clubhouse, shake each hand, and get on home to Florida.

title: JERSEY NO-FAULT LAW'S PRIME BENEFICIARIES
description: To the Editor:

title: PERILOUS ARGENTINE REARMING
description: Considerable arms purchases by the Argentine military raise the possibility of another conflict at the southern tip of the continent. Developed countries that support this buildup with sales and unconditional financial credits should reconsider their careless policies before it is too late.

title: Texas Gas-CSX Merger Opposed
description: The Coastal Corporation has filed suit seeking to block the proposed $1 billion merger of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation and the CSX Corporation.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Nutrition for Children

title: Sacramento Issue Is 6.5% to 10.18%
description: A $30 million issue of single-family mortgage revenue bonds from the City of Sacramento in California was tentatively priced yesterday by Blyth Eastman, Paine Webber with yields that range from 6.5 percent to 10.18 percent.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: RACHELLE KESS was 21 years old when she first noticed that her eyelids looked droopy. Then she began experiencing periods of extreme weakness, when doors were too heavy to open, stairs too difficult to climb, food too hard to chew. Between times, she felt absolutely fine, full of her usual energy and able to pursue the normal life of a bright, beautiful, ambitious young woman.

title: LAST LIBYAN PLANE DETAINED BY BRAZIL DEPARTS
description: The last of four Libyan planes carrying arms destined for Central America left Brazil for Tripoli today, nearly two months after being detained for false declaration of its cargo.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Move Ahead
description: Bond prices fell to their Friday levels as a lack of continued buying by investors at a time of additional Treasury borrowing helped to raise rates.

title: U.N. Palestinian Parley Is Scheduled in Geneva
description: Ignoring objections from Switzerland, organizers of a United Nations conference on Palestinian rights agreed today to hold a meeting in August in Geneva.

title: Baptists Re-elect Draper
description: The Rev. James T. Draper Jr. was reelected head of the Southern Baptist Convention today after urging the nation's largest Protestant denomination to stand united to ''our commitment to the Bible as the final authority.'' Mr. Draper, a 47-year-old Texan, was unopposed for a second one-year term as president of the 14-million-member convention, which opened its annual meeting today. Four years ago Mr. Draper helped gain control of the convention for a wing of the church that believes in strict interpretation of the Bible.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AM International, Chicago, has named Dieter E.A. Tannenberg a senior vice president.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every day I go out in the field. And I say, 'What am I doing here? I've got all these debts and I'm up against all these big companies.'

title: British Liberal Chief Talks of Stepping Down
description: David Steel, head of Britain's Liberal Party, said today that he was considering stepping down from the post.

title: Moynihan Seeking Park at Ft. Totten
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, introduced a bill today that would transfer portions of Fort Totten, in the northeast corner of Queens, to Federal departments for use as a public park and recreation area and for a halfway house for victims of paralysis.

title: HOUSES OF WORSHIP TAKE LANDMARK FIGHT TO ALBANY
description: Religious groups and preservationists, who have clashed for years over giving landmark status to houses of worship in Manhattan, have taken their battle to Albany for the first time.

title: IN BARBADOS, A PICTUREESQUE FISH MARKET CONTROLLED BY WOMEN
description: OISTINS, Barbados THE fish sellers in this town on the south coast of Barbados have by tradition been women, dressed in brilliantly colored print dresses, half aprons and straw hats with upturned brims. They helped the fishermen haul in their dinghies with the day's catch, and then they sold it at the market.

title: DEMOCRATS FIGHT LIMIT ON TAX CUT
description: Key House Democrats, including some liberals on the Ways and Means Committee, said today that they were opposed to a proposal by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. to limit personal income tax reductions this year to $700.

title: ISLAM, AFTER PERSECUTIONS, REBOUNDS IN CHINA
description: From a slender minaret of the Id Kah Mosque, a loudspeaker summoned the faithful to evening prayer. A street vendor removed his cloth shoes, knelt on a piece of cardboard under a poplar tree and pressed his forehead to the ground in the southwestward direction of Mecca. Inside the rambling mosque in this heavily Moslem city in western China, a row of other worshipers facing the whitewashed wall took up the affirmation of God's greatness - ''Allah akhbar!''

title: ON BIG PICTURE, ALLIES AREN'T IN STEP
description: An issue that complicates meetings of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was present as usual when foreign ministers of member countries met last Thursday and Friday in Paris.
