In the words of one American official, it is the ''refusal'' by a majority of members to understand that crises outside the area of the alliance could erode its military position in Europe.

title: WINE TALK
description: FLORENCE A revolution is taking place in the Italian wine world, and at the moment it's hard to say how it will turn out. Exciting things are happening from the Piedmont in the north to Palermo, Sicily, in the south. New wines appear regularly, traditional wines are improved. Wineries all over the country are moving into the 20th century and wine makers are, for the first time, welcoming viticulturists and enologists into their vineyards and cellars.

title: SIX NEW UNITS TO BOLSTER FIGHT ON DRUG SMUGGLING
description: The Reagan Administration plans to accelerate its campaign against drug smuggling across the nation's borders by marshaling the existing resources of nine Federal agencies in six cities, including New York, Administration officials said today.

title: Dow Up 6.71 as Volume Rises
description: Favorable economic news enabled the stock market to post a moderate gain yesterday following its sharp advance on Monday. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was up slightly more than 3 points at 3 P.M., finished ahead 6.71 points, to 1,227.26. On Monday, the 30 issues that make up the key average soared 24.44 points as interest rates fell.

title: Edward Rhatigan, 71; Federal Court Official
description: Edward P. Rhatigan, the supervisor of naturalization for the United States District Court in Brooklyn, died Monday after suffering an apparent heart attack in his office at the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old and lived in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: PRINCETON AND 3 MEN'S CLUBS FIGHT SUIT ON SEX BIAS
description: Women are now admitted to the Triangle Club, where men once held down all the female roles in the club's shows. The Daily Princetonian named its first female chairman four years ago, and 10 of Princeton's 13 student eating clubs, including Colonial, Cap & Gown and Tower, have women.

title: GLENN SEEKING TO TURN A HERO'S IMAGE INTO VOTES
description: For a tiny moment, perhaps half a beat of that legendarily slow astronaut's pulse, Senator John Glenn seemed taken aback by the question. Then his normally squinty eyes narrowed even further with amusement.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF GOING PRIVATE
description: Going public is almost always a bonanza for the owners of young, growing companies. The founders sell some of their shares to the public and put cash in the bank. But financial strategy is coming full circle. Now, taking companies private is becoming lucrative and popular as well.

title: 2 EX-ARBITRAGERS ACCUSED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged two former managers of the arbitrage department at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. with artificially inflating the prices of stocks and options in the brokerage firm's portfolio in order to get higher year-end bonuses.

title: Faithful Fans
description: Cesars, a 45-room motel and bar in a Milwaukee suburb, received national publicity last fall while the Brewers were defeating the California Angels in the American League championship playoffs and then losing in the World Series to the St. Louis Cardinals. Fans of the Brewers filled Cesars - five minutes away from Milwaukee's County Stadium - before, during and after every game.

title: SENATOR BAKER UNCOVERS BIG NEWS IN A SMALL ITEM
description: Browsing through The New York Times of June 9, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee was fascinated when he happened on a two-sentence article with the headline ''Gun Fires Chickens at Planes.''

title: APPRAISING VOLCKER'S RECORD
description: Growth of the economy was beginning to stall. The dollar was plunging, and interest rates were soaring. The price of an ounce of gold, the recourse of frightened investors, was climbing above $800. Opinion polls were showing that what people feared most in the economy was no longer unemployment but ever-rising prices.

title: TRUMP OFFERS DIRECT WORK AT CONVENTION CENTER
description: Donald J. Trump, one of the most active developers in midtown Manhattan, has offered to take charge, without pay, of the state's efforts to finish building New York City's Convention Center.

title: MILTON L. BRAUN
description: Milton L. Braun, president of Milton L. Braun Inc., a jewelry wholesaler in Manhattan, died Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Monarch Machine Tool Loses Chief Executive
description: The Monarch Machine Tool Company is having difficulty finding a successor to Kermit T. Kuck, its longtime leader. Mr. Kuck, 70, has returned as chief executive of the Sidney, Ohio, concern, replacing Howard W. Geyer. The announcement of Mr. Geyer's leaving was made on Monday.

title: LITIGATION: NEGOTIATORS VS. FIGHTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW PLAN OUTLINED ON BETHLEHEM UNIT
description: Kenneth Lipke, an industrialist, said today that he would drop his efforts to buy the entire Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Lackawanna Works, which Bethlehem is phasing out of production this year.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BANKING-CONSUMER BILLS ENACTED IN A TRADE-OFF
description: Governor Cuomo held a bill-signing ceremony today that marked the culmination of a deal in which consumer groups and legislators traded their support of banking bills for passage of a series of consumer-protection measures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Going Fishing in the Big City

title: CHN AND DAYTIME ANOUNCE MERGER
description: As has been anticipated, two companies involved in cable television programming announced today an agreement to merge their two financially ailing channels into one 24-hour ''life style'' channel of talk shows and magazine-style programs covering topics ranging from fashion and cooking to fitness and family counseling.

title: A MATCH OF SOCCER CHAMPIONS
description: The first confrontation between the champions of the United States and Europe has nothing more at stake than pride, but the game between the Cosmos and Hamburg of West Germany Wednesday night is viewed as important in international soccer.

title: New Effort Fails to End Philadelphia Rail Strike
description: Negotiations to bring the last union holdout into the fold and end a three-month commuter rail strike broke off today with no progress reported.

title: JOHN A. MURRAY JR.
description: John A. Murray Jr., who practiced law in Flushing, Queens, for 40 years, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Hampton Bays, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: Mrs. Fenwick Gets U.N. Post in Rome
description: Former Representative Millicent H. Fenwick has been appointed the United States representative to the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization in Rome.

title: Economic Scene; Hard-to-Repair Soviet System
description: ONE returns from a journey to the Soviet Union like a space voyager who has for the first time seen the dark side of the Earth. Not that everything is dark in that Communist land: the dancers of the Kirov Ballet are as sparkling and delightful as any in America; the acrobats and clowns and trained bears at the Moscow Circus match anything that Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey has to offer. And some individuals, whether sitting in research institutes or on the back of reindeer in Yakutia, Siberia, are as sensitive and good-hearted as any you can find in Washington, Cambridge or Big Delta, Alaska.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt DANGEROUS CURRENTS. The State of Economics. By Lester C. Thurow. 247 pages. Illustrated with Tables and Dia- grams. Random House. $16.95.

title: Good News For Reagan
description: If anybody in Washington can take pleasure in the British election results it should be President Reagan and his political managers.

title: The Hissing Of Hersh
description: Among the well-tailored group headed for Seymour Hersh's house, I recognized Endicott. ''Come join us,'' he cried. ''We're all going to stand outside Seymour Hersh's house and hiss.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Who's in Charge?

title: Japan Air to Buy Jets
description: Japan Air Lines said today that it planned to double the number of Boeing 747 freighters in its fleet to 10 by 1985 to replace four DC-8 freighters.

title: Lisle Blackbourn Dies at 84; Coached Green Bay Packers
description: Lisle (Liz) Blackbourn, head coach of the Green Bay Packers football team from 1954 to 1957, died early Tuesday in a nursing home here after a lengthy illness.

title: 'FLIGHTS OF FANCY'
description: IT may be time for a historian with a passion for mini-projects to do an in-depth piece on the relentless rise of the Soviet Cinema of the Bourgeoisie, exemplified by the 1982 Oscar winner, ''Moscow Does Not Believe in Tears,'' and now by Roman Balayan's ''Flights of Fancy,'' which opens today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema.

title: FARMERS
description: ''Five years ago,'' said Charles Hannan, a lawyer, ''we were busy doing estate planning for farmers. Right now, I'm handling 50 farm bankruptcy cases. That's how things have changed.''

title: A Boxing Breakthrough
description: Ever since the New York State Athletic Commission started the first computerized data bank of boxers' ring and medical records four years ago, Jack Prenderville, the commission's chairman, has been trying to talk other states into establishing a nationwide network of such data bases.

title: COMBATING ACID RAIN
description: REAGAN Ad ministration report confirmed last week what the National Academy of Sciences concluded two years ago: There is a direct link between airborne industrial pollutants, acid rain and the destruction of fresh-water life in the Northeast. With the findings of the Interagency Task Force on Acid Precipitation in hand, the question for Congress and the Administration is no longer whether to reduce emissions but by how much?

title: Pension Denial Upheld In Reparations Case
description: Reparations paid to a Los Angeles woman by West Germany because of persecution by the Nazis must be counted as income in determining eligibility for Supplemental Social Security benefits, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: CAPE TOWN BLACKS' 'NEW HOME': SEGREGATED IN SAND
description: The site, an expanse of sand dunes that is suddenly being clawed at, pounded and scraped by a task force of Caterpillar earth-moving machines, has been officially named Khayalitsha. In the Xhosa language, which is spoken by more than 90 percent of Cape Town's blacks, that means ''new home.''

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Optioned Allan R amirez, pitcher, to Rochester of the In- t ernational League and reactivated Jim P almer, pitcher, from the disabled list. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Recalled Cliff P astornicky, third baseman, from O maha of the American Association. MINNESOTA (AL) - Called up Jim L ewis, pitcher, from Toledo of the Interna- t ional League. Sent Greg Gagne, short- s top, to Toledo. NEW YORK METS (NL) - Traded Marvell W ynne, outfielder, and Steve Senteney, p itcher, from minor-league system to Pitts- b urgh for Junior Ortiz, catcher, and Art R ay, a minor league pitcher. Signed Ken- n eth Reed and Jeffrey Ciszkowski, pitch- e rs, and Everton Johnson, outfielder, and a ssigned them to Sarasota of the Gulf C oast League. SEATTLE (AL) - Signed 19 players f rom 1983 free agent draft: the outfielders D ave Hengel, John Wallace, Oriol Perez, T homas Steinbach and Brad Colton; the p itchers Bob Hinson, Scott Nielsen, Rob- e rt Gunnarsson, Mickey Meister, Edward S alazar, James Bryant and Doug Swerin- g en, and the infielders Frank Tunnel, Rob- e rt Bruzik, Jeff Lawson, Paul Smith, G eorge Priftis, Gary Balmer and Ben A maya.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Standing Tall on Flag Day

title: DIOXIN TRACES FOUND AT EDISON PLANT SITE
description: TRENTON June 14 - Governor Kean announced today that small traces of dioxin had been found at the site of a defunct herbicide mixing plant in Edison. However, he said that the levels were lower than expected and that they were not believed to pose a threat to residents or businesses.

title: POP: TRACY NELSON, VOCALIST
description: HAVING been a respected cult figure for nearly two decades, the pop-blues singer Tracy Nelson remains a compelling but unjustly overlooked pop talent. Miss Nelson, appearing with Dr. John's band at the Lone Star Cafe, has refined a plain declarative style of interpretation by inflecting the deep blues styles of Ma Rainey and Bessie Smith with varying shades of country, folk and gospel.

title: New Offer Made To Buy the Blues
description: An attorney who specializes in representing sports teams flew to New York today with an offer from a Beverly Hills, Calif., businessman to buy the St. Louis Blues.

title: 1,000 French Farmer- s Smash Eggs in Protest
description: BRIEUC, France, June 14 (AP) - About 1,000 French poultry farmers, angry over low prices, smashed an estimated 5.5 million eggs at a public dump outside this Brittany town today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: NEW YORKERS are bearcats for forming associations. Wherever two or three like-minded New Yorkers are gathered together, there you will find an association. In the case of vampirologists, the name of the association is the Vampire Research Center. It was founded in 1972 by Dr. Stephen Kaplan and it has its headquarters not in Transylvania but in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Northeast Utilities Seeks Rise in Rates
description: Northeast Utilities announced today that it would seek increases of 12.2 percent in its electricity rates and 3 percent in its gas rates.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pride in Menudo

title: TOWELS AND POTHOLDERS
description: FOR all the discussion about the importance of quality knives, pots and pans in cooking, there is one other item that, for me, is right up there on the priority list: the kitchen towel. When I am cooking I always have one secured to my belt or apron string and I use it constantly: for drying my hands, cleaning knives, wiping counters, picking up hot pans and patting my perpetually wet brow.

title: Doing Business With Racists
description: Uniquely among modern governments, South Africa's white regime employs all the instruments of state to subjugate a racial majority. Having chosen to be a nation apart, it invites special contempt. Americans, as well as most other peoples, want nothing to do with South Africa.

title: Hearst-ABC, Viacom in Pact
description: Hearst-ABC Video Services and Viacom International Inc. said that they had agreed in principle to merge Hearst-ABC's Daytime cable television service with Viacom's Cable Health Network.

title: 'The 700 Club' Chooses Compton Advertising
description: ''The 700 Club,'' a syndicated, religious television talk show, has selected Compton Advertising to be its first advertising agency largely, it said, because of the agency's Religion in American Life public service advertising campaign.

title: DAVEY MOORE ON EDGE IN HOMETOWN
description: Davey Moore, the world traveler, has returned, a stranger in his hometown to fight Roberto Duran tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden. The big crowd there will overwhlemingly favor the Panamanian over the former high school honor student from the Bronx.

title: FOES OF PINOCHET IN MASS PROTESTS IN CHILEAN CITIES
description: Hundreds of thousands of Chileans joined in a national day of protest today against the 10-year-old rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet.

title: Pilot of Fuel-Drained Jet Dismissed by Airline
description: Republic Airlines has dismissed the pilot of a twin-engine jetliner that came within 30 seconds of running out of fuel last month on a flight from Fresno, Calif., to Phoenix, the airline said today.

title: A Passer Displays Old Touch
description: A lthough it was thrown in a losing cause, Craig Penrose's first touchdown pass in three years was a personal achievement. The Denver Gold, in third place in the Pacific Division with a 6-9 record, lost, 16-10, to the Los Angeles Express Monday night. But Penrose, completing 22 of 35 passes for 258 yards and a touchdown in only his second appearance with the United States Football League team after a three-season layoff, played brilliantly.

title: Expos 7, Pirates 3
description: PITTSBURGH (AP) - Tim Wallach, Tim Raines and Andre Dawson hit homers for Montreal, helping Steve Rogers gain his eighth victory. Rogers (8-3) worked 6 1/3 innings, leaving after giving up 2 runs in the seventh.

title: 4 LEADING CANCER SPECIALISTS WIN GENERAL MOTORS AWARDS
description: Three awards of $130,000 and a gold medal each for important advances in research on the causes and treatment of cancers were announced in New York City yesterday by the General Motors Cancer Research Foundation.

title: Nigerian Refinancing
description: Twenty-four Western banks have agreed on a formula to refinance $1.6 billion of Nigeria's short-term foreign debts, a spokesman for Barclays Bank International in London said yesterday. The agreement was confirmed by the Bankers Trust Company in New York.

title: BUSINESS TRAVEL: AMENITIES CURBED
description: The chairman of the Xerox Corporation now flies coach class on domestic business trips. The Digital Equipment Corporation will not pick up the tab for drinks employees order with a meal while on the road. And the General Motors Corporation has started to monitor by computer all corporate travel.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about new directors for two state mental health agencies misidentified Martin S. Begun. He is dean of New York University Medical Center and chairman of New York City's Mental Health Board.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Friday about the Indian Point nuclear plants included an incorrect word in a quotation from John F. Ahearne, a member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. In explaining why he voted to keep the plants open, he actually said: ''Until receiving the state plan and reviewing it, I had intended to vote to shut the plants down, and in fact had begun drafting an order of views in that direction. I was impressed by the work the state had done.''

title: Dean Witter Group Gets New President
description: Jay H. Perry, a man who made his Wall Street reputation as a trader of large stock blocks, was named president and chief executive yesterday of Dean Witter Reynolds Capital Markets Group, the brokerage firm's investment banking arm.

title: Summer Series Opens June 28 at 92d Street Y
description: A performance of Stravinsky's ''Histoire du soldat,'' featuring Fritz Weaver and the Bil Baird Marionettes, will open the third Summermusic festival June 28 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: MAYOR ATTACKS BILL TO IMPROVE STATE PENSIONS
description: Mayor Koch today denounced a proposal to improve pension benefits for state and city workers hired since 1976, even as Governor Cuomo was saying he supported the basic outline of the plan.

title: B.B. KING HOMETOWN PROVES MUSIC DISSOLVES ALL BARRIERS
description: TWENTY years ago, the Mississippi Delta's well-to-do whites and upwardly mobile blacks agreed on one important point; they despised the blues.

title: Making Matches At the U.S. Open
description: The United States Golf Association traditionally pairs the reigning United States Open, British Open and United States Amateur champions in one of the threesomes for the first two days of each United States Open championship. Then comes the cut and players tee off according to their standing on the scoreboard in each of the last two rounds.

title: BEELINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge:
description: 4-Year-Old Cheating Case May Be Coming to an End By ALAN TRUSCOTT

title: Sardines and Sentiment
description: So far this year El Nino, a warm Pacific Ocean current, has brought floods to Latin America and drought to the Andes, mudslides to Utah and baseball-sized hailstones to Texas. For a few days, Cologne, West Germany, looked a lot like Venice and in the Sierras the snow is still as high as an elephant's eye.

title: British Banks Cut Rate
description: Britain's major banks, responding to concerns of the new Government, cut their base interest rate by half a percentage point today, to 9 1/2 percent.

title: AUTHORS OFFER PLAN TO EXTEND SALES LIFE OF BOOKS
description: A plan aimed at extending the commercial lives of books, most of which can no longer be found in bookstores just months after publication, is being proposed in a mailing this week to the 6,000 members of the Authors Guild.

title: Market Place; Maryland Cup: Merger Bait
description: EVERY time someone buys a Coke in a disposable cup at McDonald's, the cash register rings in the Owings Mills, Md., headquarters of the Maryland Cup Corporation.

title: CONRAIL WORKERS OFFER TO BUY LINE FROM GOVERNMENT
description: Conrail's 40,000 employees, in an effort to preserve their jobs, offered today to buy the huge freight-carrying railroad from the Government in a deal they valued at $2 billion.

title: NICARAGUA REPORTS REBEL DEFEAT
description: Insurgents who attacked a border village in northern Nicaragua for eight days retreated to Honduras after 140 of them were killed, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: SHOULDERS FIND A PLACE IN THE SUN ON CITY STREETS
description: EVERY summer, without fail, a sort of do-it-yourself fashion that bares a part of the anatomy turns up on New York streets as if by spontaneous combustion. Last year it was T-shirts razored into multihole patterns, revealing little patches of tanned skin.

title: FOUR CHARGED IN SLAYING OF CABBY
description: Four people were charged yesterday with second-degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting early Sunday morning of cabdriver in Queens. A fifth person was charged with supplying a revolver used in the shooting, and the police are looking for a sixth suspect.

title: STAGE: MODERNIZED 'MIKADO'
description: THE new production of ''The Mikado,'' presented by the New York Gilbert & Sullivan Players at Symphony Space, could hardly be described as ''avant-garde'' in the style of Peter Sellars, who unveiled his reinterpretation of the G. & S. work in Chicago recently. But there were more than enough allusions to contemporary life.

title: World Food Output Falling
description: World food production will fall this year after bumper grain crops last year, according to the director general of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, Edouard Saouma of Lebanon.

title: Woman Is Injured In Fall at Overpass
description: A woman was severely injured today when she fell from a Garden State Parkway overpass, the police said. The woman, Anna Gross, 35 years old, of Chatham, narrowly missed being hit by a car, according to Patrolman Robert Thomas. Miss Gross, who fell onto a shoulder of Route 528 here, was admitted to Point Pleasant Hospital in critical condition with a broken pelvis, fractured skull and back injuries, the officials said.

title: NINE BANKS END LOANS TO SEAFIRST
description: All but five of the fourteen leading banks that agreed last January to participate in a $1.5 billion safety net for the Seattle-First National Bank have dropped out of the agreement, banking sources in California said yesterday.

title: 2 BOOKS ON ENTERTAINING AND 2 ON DIETING
description: ENTERTAINING in summer always poses a problem. As enjoyable as it might be to spend evenings, afternoons or entire weekends surrounded by friends, the work involved in keeping guests fed and quenched often seems a high price to pay. A solicitous host or hostess is often robbed of the enjoyment so graciously lavished on the others.

title: MACK PUTTING UP 2 MORE OFFICE BUILDINGS IN PARAMUS
description: By its own count, The Mack Organization, a 90-year-old, family-held real estate concern, has developed about 130 office and industrial buildings in 14 New Jersey and New York counties. The buildings add up to 14 million square feet of commercial space.

title: DELEGATES TO CHURCH CONVENTIONS GET A COURSE IN POLITICS OF RELIGION
description: For most of the last week Rosemary Koch toted 20 pounds of documents to meeting rooms at the World Congress Center here. Flipping through thousands of pages, she followed discussions on such topics as pensions for church workers, communion services for children and United States policies in Central America.

title: RIGHTS UNIT FAULTS REAGAN ONCE MORE
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that the Reagan Administration had made numerous ''efforts to reduce Federal civil rights enforcement in education,'' and it urged the President to halt such efforts.

title: Careers; Women As College Officials
description: LAST year, there were 251 women serving as college presidents in the country, or 9 percent of the total, not an impressive figure, according to some women's rights enthusiasts at an all-day seminar sponsored by the American Council on Education. They would like to see a 50-50 distribution.

title: Tenneco Names Head Of New Minerals Unit
description: Tenneco Inc. announced yesterday that it planned to consolidate its mineral operations and form a new division for products such as soda ash, gold and uranium.

title: Preparations Completed For Shuttle Launching
description: Ground crews today completed final preparations for the second launching of Challenger, which is scheduled to carry America's first woman into space.

title: BIG 3 AUTO SALES JUMP BY 19.7%
description: Aided by sales incentives, the Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today a 19.7 percent increase in sales for the first 10 days of June.

title: MEMORIES OF WAR
description: THE ironies to be found in ''Irreconcilable Memories'' might have been overpowering, but they have been delicately presented by the three directors of this West German documentary. The 98-minute film, which was directed by Klaus Volkenborn, Karl Siebig and Johann Feindt, consists almost entirely of interviews with two men whose wartime experiences, were greatly at odds.

title: DERAILMENT TRACED TO DRINKING
description: A train loaded with chemicals derailed in Livingston, La., last year because a worn hose set off emergency brakes and a clerk running the train while its crew was drinking took the wrong action, a Federal safety board ruled today.

title: Hit Wins In 10th
description: The Mets had three things working for them last night - the long ball, the pinch hit and the front office.

title: BALLET DANCER HURT
description: Danilo Radojevic, a principal dancer of American Ballet Theater, injured his back during a rehearsal and will be unable to dance the title role in 'Don Quixote' tonight.

title: WEINBERGER SAYS PACT WITH ISRAEL CAN BE RESTORED
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger signaled a willingness today to revive an American-Israeli understanding to cooperate against Soviet military threats to the Middle East.

title: Seton Hall Names Petillo Chancellor
description: Msgr. John J. Petillo, administrative head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Newark, has been named to the newly created post of chancellor for Seton Hall University and Immaculate Conception Seminary.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PERFORMERS

title: 'LUCIA' OPENS OPERA SEASON IN PARKS
description: THIS is an era when a piece of penny candy rarely costs less than a nickel, so perhaps it is not surprising that a pair of tickets to the Metropolitan Opera can set the buyer back $100 or more. However, last night a crowd estimated at 75,000 people took advantage of one of New York's perennial bargains and came to the Great Lawn of Central Park to sit under reluctant stars, share picnic dinners and, not so incidentally, to hear mad, trilling Lucia di Lammermoor weep melodiously for her lost Edgardo.

title: 5 ARE KILLED AND 33 INJURED IN HOTEL FIRE AT FORT WORTH
description: A fire that started early today in a roll of carpeting raced through a wing of a two-story Ramada Inn as most of the guests slept, killing five people and injuring 34. The authorities said the fire alarm had failed to sound because of corroded batteries, and the area that burned had no smoke alarms.

title: PASTRY CHEFS WHO BREACH A MALE BASTION
description: LORI LECKMAN remembers vividly the sights and scents in the Los Angeles bakery where she worked one summer vacation while in high school. ''I served customers up front and later helped out in the back,'' she recalls. ''But the chef never let me touch the ovens. He told me that women could never be bakers - too tough for them.''

title: 22 STATES ARE REPORTED HIGH ON THE JOBLESS LIST
description: Twenty-two states and the District of Columbia reported unemployment of 10 percent or more in April, the Labor Department said today.

title: A ROLE FOR THE TREASURY IN CURBING THE DOLLAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Send Duguay, Mio and Johnstone to Detroit
description: The Rangers traded experience and fan appeal for youth and size yesterday in a six-player deal with the Detroit Red Wings. They sent three of their most popular players - the goalie Eddie Mio and the forwards Ron Duguay and Eddie Johnstone - to Detroit for Willie Huber, a defenseman who is the biggest player in the National Hockey League, and two wings, Mike Blaisdell and Mark Osborne.

title: David B. Sherwood, Executive Of the Colgate-Palmolive Co.
description: David B. Sherwood, vice president in charge of operations and business development in Europe of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, died of complications from malaria Sunday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: AFGHAN VILLAGES REPORTED SHELLED
description: Soviet and Afghan Government forces have reportedly subjected villages north and south of Afghanistan's capital to heavy bombardment in retaliation for a series of fierce attacks by insurgents on convoys and other targets.

title: Schlichter 'Better'
description: Art Schlichter, the Baltimore Colt quarterback who has been suspended indefinitely, says his gambling that left him with losses of more than $700,000 was ''a disease that takes over.'' In an interview on WBNS-TV in Columbus, Ohio, Schlichter, a former Ohio State star, said he had ''no regrets'' about going to the F.B.I. with the story of his involvement with four Baltimore-area gamblers.

title: REPORTER DISMISSED AFTER ELECTION TO SCHOOL BOARD
description: A Knoxville, Tenn., newspaper has dismissed a reporter because she ran for and won a seat on the school board in her hometown of Alcoa, Tenn.

title: Hearing Record Altered, 2 Say
description: The published record of a Congressional hearing on the Environmental Protection Agency was materially changed, altering the positions taken by Congressmen and possibly by witnesses, two Republican legislators said today.

title: Marietta to Buy Stock Allied Holds
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it would pay about $280 million for the remaining 20 percent of its stock held by the Allied Corporation, the peacemaker in Marietta's merger battle last year with the Bendix Corporation.

title: DOLLAR REACHES A HIGH AGAINST SPANISH PESETA
description: By The Associated Press

title: OAKMONT CHALLENGES U.S. OPEN FIELD
description: Jack Nicklaus stood on the back of the treacherous second green at the Oakmont Country Club and dropped a golf ball from waist high to the putting surface. The ball rolled more than 80 feet right off the front of the green.

title: Advertising; New Unit To Report On Ads
description: THE Publishers Information Bureau, which gathers information on advertising for its members, has decided to hire a replacement for Leading National Advertisers, which has been publishing the bureau's statistics for the past 38 years. Starting in January, the statistics will be compiled and published by Publishers Advertisers Reports, a recently formed subsidiary of Interactive Marketing Systems.

title: INCREASING NUMBER OF MEDICAL SCHOOLS STRESS NUTRITION IN THEIR CIRRICULUMS
description: CONCERNED about patients' complaints that some physicians know little about nutrition, an increasing number of medical schools are offering instruction that ranges from how to tell whether an alcoholic is malnourished to the role of intravenous feeding and the care of patients who have had surgery.

title: 2 California Bonds Repriced Upward
description: The prices of two term bonds, part of the $447 million bond issue for the M-S-R Public Power Agency of California, were increased yesterday by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company because of heavy demand.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1983; Companies
description: Conrail's 40,000 employees, in a bid to save their jobs, offered to buy the railroad from the Government in a transaction they valued at $2 billion. The plan, if approved by the Administration and Congress, would be the biggest denationalization of federally owned assets ever. As part of the bid, the employees agreed to wage concessions that they said they would deny any other buyer. (Page A1.)

title: MERCHANT BANK BIDS FOR NORTON
description: A leading New York merchant banking house submitted a rival bid yesterday for Norton Simon Inc., whose chairman, David J. Mahoney, is trying to buy the company.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This is her world, the world of the classroom and the school, the world of noisy corridors, dull brown linoleum flecked with green and pink, ''Danny-N-Steph'' on the walls in pencil, loose-leaf paper fluttering on the floors, bells, beat-up books, peeling paint and adolescents everywhere. For 24 years, this has been Eleanor Friedman's world from September through June.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Tom Cousineau, the Cleveland Browns' linebacker, was found not guilty of drunken driving charges yesterday by a Municipal Court jury in Rocky River, Ohio. An earlier trial ended in a hung jury. ... Gerry Cooney's heavyweight bout against his sparring partner, Philip Brown, has been postponed once again, this time until Sept. 9, because Cooney still hasn't recovered from a bruised knuckle. ... The principal owners of the Cincinnati Reds, the brothers William and James Williams, remained silent yesterday about a report that they were thinking of selling the team after two years of financial losses. ... Ed Badger, former head basketball coach at the University of Cincinnati and before that of the Chicago Bulls, has been signed as an assistant coach by the Cleveland Cavaliers. ... Nate Branch, a Harlem Globetrotter, was fined $1,000 and placed on probation for two years after pleading no contest to a misdemeanor charge of possession of marijuana. ... Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns owner who is recovering at a Cleveland hospital from a mild heart attack he suffered Saturday, will undergo coronary bypass surgery ''sometime in the future,'' according to a hospital spokesman. ... Mike Stahr, the Carmel (N.Y.) High School track star who won the scholastic mile at the Millrose Games last winter, has been selected by a panel of sportswriters to receive the Hertz 1 Award for excellence in high school athletics in the state.

title: SALVADORANS TAKE REBEL BASE
description: The Salvadoran military met little resistence from guerrilla forces as it moved to occupy Chinchontepec Volcano in the central province of San Vicente and to secure the towns at the base of the volcano, according to military officers.

title: RUCKELSHAUS ENDORSES CLEAN AIR PROPOSALS
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, in his first appearance before a Congressional committee as Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, today largely endorsed proposals made by his predecessor, Anne McGill Burford, for revising and extending the Clean Water Act.

title: ARGENTINES PRESS FALKLAND CLAIM
description: President Reynaldo Bignone said today that Argentina was continuing to fight for its claims to the Falkland Islands despite its defeat by Britain a year ago.

title: MARTIN IS ENRAGED
description: Billy Martin took the Yankees' latest loss quite badly tonight. In fact he broke something. He clubbed the urinal behind the dugout into pieces with a bat while watching his team fall to the Indians by 9-6, New York's fourth straight defeat.

title: HELLER'S PECULIAR CASE AGAINST TAX INDEXING
description: To the Editor:

title: MRS. HECKLER LISTS ADDED AIDS FUNDS
description: The Secretary of Health and Human Services today defended the Reagan Administration's efforts to find the cause and cure of the deadly acquired immune deficiency syndrome disease, or AIDS, describing it as the nation's No. 1 health priority.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA IS AT PEAK IN A GRASS ROUT
description: Martina Navratilova swept aside Sue Barker, 6-1, 6-0, today in the second round of the $150,000 BMW grass-court tennis tournament, the last tuneup for Wimbledon.

title: Postcard to Posterity
description: Controllers on Earth send out a message every morning to the little Pioneer 10 spacecraft. Even at the speed of light, it's not until evening that they receive Pioneer's faint answer. Within a few years, even that small voice will fall silent, as its radioisotope power ebbs. But Pioneer will become - has already become - a message in itself.

title: Article 233423 -- No Title
description: Gulf and Western Industries sold 6,020,000 shares of the General Tire and Rubber Company yesterday in the largest single block of stock in dollar value ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A CHEF WHO TEACHES HIS ART TO THE POOR
description: ''IT is my repayment to this country,'' said Dusan Bernic. ''I was permitted to come here and given an opportunity to succeed. So I am happy to help out. It gives me pleasure.''

title: CONCERT: THE MCLEANS
description: IN a spirit of friendly but genuine competition, the alto saxophonist Jackie McLean and his son, Rene, who plays saxophone and flute, together led a sextet last weekend at Swing Plaza. The group's original tunes were written by Rene McLean, and they offered harmonic and rhythmic challenges that galvanized father and son.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Police Horse That's Gentle and Retiring

title: Endurance Test
description: A field of more than 20 seemingly tireless runners will assemble at Pennsauken, N.J., on June 25 for the start of the fourth annual Edward Payson Weston race, an ultramarathon event that continues for six days while the runners circle a quarter-mile cinder track in Cooper River Stadium.

title: KOCH TELLS LEGAL AID TO SHIFT RIGHTS UNIT TO APPEALS WORK
description: Mayor Koch has notified the Legal Aid Society that, starting in January, the city will no longer finance an 11-lawyer unit of the society that specializes in protecting the rights of prisoners.

title: FRANK O'CONNOR
description: Frank O'Connor, a television producer credited with ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'' starring Orson Welles, has died after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 65 years old. Mr. O'Connor also produced such television specials as ''The Snow Goose,'' starring Richard Harris, and ''Hamlet,'' starring Richard Chamberlain.

title: The U.N. Today; June 15, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Petitions - 3 P.M.

title: Drug Indictment
description: John Williams, a former all-pro lineman who retired in 1980 after 12 years in the National Football League and became a dentist in Minneapolis, has been indicted by a Federal grand jury in Minneapolis on charges of distributing cocaine. Williams, a one-time all-American at the University of Minnesota, said he had been caught after he sold cocaine to a former college teammate who turned out to be a Federal informant.

title: GROUP FOR THOSE WHO CAN'T FIGHT FOOD
description: EIGHT years ago, Dr. K., a successful Washington psychologist, had not solved her own most evident problem. At 5 feet 1 inches, she weighed 250 pounds. In the past, she had gone on diets, participated in a supervised weight-reduction program and even formed a therapy group with other failed dieters to combat her problem. But while she had lost weight several times, she always gained it back, and then some. Clinically, she was mystified. Emotionally, she was at a dead end.

title: DWG-Rexham
description: The DWG Corporation, which is headed by Victor Posner, the financier, reported to the Securities and Exchange Commision that it had acquired 230,650 shares, of the Rexham Corporation.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium. 7:35 P.M. Craig Swan, who pitched 7 solid innings last Friday in the 17-inning victory over Montreal, will oppose Ferguson Jenkins, who shut out the St. Louis Cardinals earlier that day. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. Trade talk surrounds the Yankees, who have until 8 o'clock tonight to make a deal in the American League. After that deadline, the only transactions that can be made are waiver deals, the kind that have been permitted on an interleague basis since April 1. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.).

title: Executive Assails Commercials on Radio
description: Radio apparently suffers from the same handicap as magazines - the very best agency creative people only want to make television ads. Or in the words of Philip B. Dusenberry, vice chairman and executive creative director of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, ''The answer is simple: A great many creative people just don't give a bloody damn about radio.''

title: Q & A
description: Q. There is a plant that grows in my neighborhood that I am told is skunk cabbage. Can you tell me how to prepare this for salads?

title: Australian Sees Peace Role
description: Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia said today that his country stood ready to act as a mediator in Southeast Asia. After a meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, Mr. Hawke said the Secretary had expressed the hope that Australia would be able to take a leading role in efforts to persuade Vietnam to withdraw its forces from Cambodia. ''I indicated that the major concern of Australia is to achieve the position where Vietnam will be able to resume her place within the broader community of nations,'' Mr. Hawke said.

title: OLDEST STREETS ARE PROTECTED AS LANDMARK
description: New Amsterdam's road plan, which has survived almost intact for more than 300 years as the crooked and narrow network of lower Manhattan's modern streets, was granted landmark status yesterday.

title: Escape Material Found in U.S. Jail
description: Federal marshals and the office of the United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York office are investigating the discovery of ''escape paraphernalia'' - a hacksaw blade, blowtorch equipment and a substantial length of rope - at the Metropolitan Correctional Center at 150 Park Row, a spokesman for the center said yesterday.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Aviation Group's $25 million of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003 were priced at par, through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 15, 1983
description: International A new American-Israeli accord to cooperate against Soviet military threats to the Middle East is sought by the Reagan Administration. Washington's willingness to revive a memorandum of understanding for strategic cooperation with Israel was signaled by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. (Page A1, Column 6.) A Soviet ideological offensive to counter President Reagan's ''crusade'' against Communism was urged by a senior Kremlin official, Konstantin U. Chernenko. (A3:4-6.)

title: Hoechst-Kuwait Talks
description: Hoechst A.G. has set up three groups to discuss joint ventures with Kuwait, now the company's largest shareholder, Hoechst's chairman, Rolf Sammet, told the annual meeting today. Talks have progressed most on fertilizers but Hoechst said it was also discussing cooperation in petrochemicals, plastics and biotechnology. In the past year Kuwait has bought a major stake in Hoechst, which company officials put at just below 25 percent.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IHAVE long been fascinated by the different tastes of nations when it comes to the use of herbs and spices. In Italy, for example, tarragon was until recently not commonly used in home kitchens. I have even met an Italian friend or two who was not certain of the Italian word for it. It is dragoncello.

title: Quality Inns Plans Top Rooms at $40
description: Quality Inns International said it plans to offer ''luxury'' hotel rooms at $40 a night in new hotels that eliminate such traditional amenities as restaurants, lounges, meeting rooms and a large staff.

title: INNOCENT VICTIMS OF U.S. POLICY TOWARD CUBA
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Riots in Kashmir Bring 24-Hour Curfew
description: The authorities imposed a 24-hour curfew on parts of Srinagar, the Kashmir capital, today. The curfew came after renewed political violence over the weekend in which 600 people were hurt, 75 of them seriously, the Press Trust of India news agency reported.

title: STAGE: MUSICAL 'TALLULAH'
description: ''TALLULAH,'' which is described as ''a musical cartwheel,'' is, of course, about Tallulah Bankhead. Who else? In this case, it is also about Helen Gallagher, the actress. In fact, ''Tallulah'' is Helen Gallagher.

title: FINK IS CRITICAL OF A CITY CARTER OF TOXIC WASTE
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink charged today that a Newark company that handles hazardous waste violated Federal and state environmental regulations in disposing of 2,800 gallons of highly toxic PCB fluids for New York City.

title: U.S. ENVOY BACKS LATINS' PEACE BID
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America ended a fact-finding trip to the area today with a strong statement of support for the four Latin American nations trying to negotiate solutions to regional problems.

title: Bulgaria Asserts Turk Has Not Left Country
description: A Turk wanted in connection with the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II is in Bulgaria under police surveillance and has not left the country as was reported in Italy, the Bulgarian press agency said today.

title: ARE U.S. COVERT ACTIVITIES BEST POLICY ON NICARAGUA?
description: The Reagan Administration and Congress are struggling over covert operations in Central America. At stake in the short term is the future of aid to rebels in Nicaragua; over the longer term, the debate will help define when and how covert action should be an instrument of foreign policy.

title: U.A.W. Chrysler Leaders Back Reopening of Pact
description: Leaders of the United Automobile Workers at Chrysler Corporation plants voted narrowly today to authorize an early reopening of contract talks with the resurgent No. 3 automaker.

title: NETS TRYING TO GET MICKEY JOHNSON BACK
description: The Nets admit they made a mistake with Mickey Johnson. Now, they are trying to correct it. Negotiations are now under way in an attempt to bring the veteran forward, who appeared in 42 games with the Nets last season, back to the team.

title: GIBSON OF TIGERS HITS HUGE HOMER
description: Jim Rice and Dwight Evans each hit two-run homers to back the combined four-hit pitching of Mike Brown and Bob Stanley as the Boston Red Sox beat the Detroit Tigers by 6-2 tonight. One of the hits off Brown was a fourth-inning homer by Kirk Gibson, who became only the eighth player to hit a ball over the right-field stand in Tiger Stadium. The ball landed on the roof of a lumber company across the street, and it was estimated to have traveled almost 600 feet from home plate.

title: Inquiries Into Donovan End on Election Report
description: The official investigations of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan are finally over.

title: U.S. RULES ON CABLE TV ARE PASSED BY SENATE
description: The Senate approved legislation today that would establish national guidelines for regulation of the growing cable television industry.

title: WEINBERGER CITES MILITARY'S SAVINGS
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the Pentagon had cut military spending $39 billion through better management but had not been given credit for those savings.

title: Murphy at the Bat
description: Dale Murphy, the Atlanta Braves outfielder, may not be William Bendix, but he has apparently borrowed a page from the Babe Ruth legend. The way they're telling it in Atlanta, Murphy paid a call at a local hospital a while back to help cheer up Elizabeth Smith, a 6-year-old girl who had lost her arms and legs in a power-line accident.

title: 200 Leave Homes After Benzene Spill
description: A tanker truck overturned on the Southern Tier Expressway and leaked highly flammable benzene early today, forcing 200 residents to leave their homes.

title: Medical College Unit Sues Over Copyright on Tests
description: United States marshals raided a company that prepares students for medical school entrance examinations after the Association of American Medical Colleges, which gives the tests, filed a $1.5 million copyright infringement suit.

title: U.S.F.L. Riches
description: Over the next five years, the quarterback Jim Kelly will have about $3.5 million to spend. That's the estimated value of the contract he signed last week with the Houston Gamblers of the United States Football League.

title: MUSIC: CAPPELLA NOVA
description: FOR the last eight years, Cappella Nova has been singing liturgical music of the Renaissance and the late Middle Ages for New York audiences. Sunday evening at St. Joseph's church in Greenwich Village the 19-member group and its director, Richard Taruskin, gave their last concert for a while. Cappella Nova is taking a year off and is scheduled to reassemble in the fall of 1984.

title: City Freed of Liability In '73 Hotel Collapse
description: The state's highest court ruled today that New York City should not be held liable for damages in the 1973 collapse of a Manhattan hotel, in which four people died and many others were injured.

title: FIGHT REAGAN 'CRUSADE,' SOVIET AIDE SAYS
description: A senior Soviet official called today for a broad ideological offensive to counter President Reagan's ''crusade'' against Communism and to rid Soviet life of corrupting influences that he said were undermining the economy and the attitude of young people.

title: REAGAN VISITS TENNESSEE IN ANOTHER SWING TO PRESS EDUCATION ISSUE
description: President Reagan today urged reducing the Federal Government's powers over education to reflect what he described as its relatively minor financial role. The plan would leave state and local officials with dominant authority.

title: Blue Jays 13, A's 7
description: TORONTO (AP) - Jesse Barfield drove in five runs with a pair of homers, and Buck Martinez and Barry Bonnell also hit home runs for Toronto. Martinez went 4 for 4 with 3 r.b.i. to lead the 18-hit Toronto attack.

title: Air Quality Watched In Metropolitan Area
description: The Interstate Sanitation Commission, which monitors pollution in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, issued an ''air-pollution stagnation advisory'' yesterday for the metropolitan area and began to watch the situation round-the-clock.

title: LEVINE SAID TO SEEK ARTISTIC CONTROL OF MET
description: The task of the committee at the Metropolitan Opera that is seeking a successor to Anthony Bliss, who retires as general manager on July 31, 1985, may be complicated by contract negotiations involving James Levine, the Metropolitan's music director and principal conductor. If Mr. Levine gets what he wants, the Metropolitan Opera will most likely end up with an administrator as general manager rather than with an impresario of the old-fashioned kind, one who involves himself directly with each production of an opera.

title: David Owen to Head The Social Democrats
description: Dr. David Owen was chosen today to be the leader of the Social Democratic Party to succeed Roy Jenkins. Dr. Owen was nominated by Mr. Jenkins and the four other Social Democrats returned to Parliament in last week's general election, which the Conservative Party won in a landslide. Mr. Jenkins, 62 years old, announced Monday he was stepping down.

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT'S OPINION AND DISSENT ON ABORTION CASE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's principal abortion decision today, declaring unconstitutional an ordinance in Akron, Ohio, that limited access to abortion. Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. wrote the opinion and Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote the dissent. From the Opinion By Justice Powell

title: Davenport Plans Return
description: He has been a member of five Olympic teams and he set an Olympic record in winning the 110-meter high hurdles in Mexico City in 1968. Now, at the age of 40, 6 years after he retired from competitive hurdling and almost 20 years after he made his first Olympic team, Willie Davenport has his eye on a new challenge - the 1984 Olympics.

title: 100 ARRESTED IN KASHMIR CAPITAL AFTER POLITICAL VIOLENCE IN THE STREETS
description: More than 100 people were reported to be under arrest today in Srinagar, capital of the state of Kashmir, and policemen were patrolling the streets with orders to shoot curfew violators on sight.

title: HOMOSEXUALS CONFRONTING A TIME OF CHANGE
description: In neighborhoods throughout the city and across a broad spectrum of New York life, the influence of homosexual men and women is being seen and felt more than ever before.

title: Tax Cut Limit Vote Due
description: The House Ways and Means Committee will meet Thursday to approve a $700 cap on the 10 percent individual tax cut that takes effect July 1, committee staff members said today. At a Democratic caucus, many members expressed their reluctance to support the proposal but said they would vote for it because it is the idea of House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: Transactions; AUTO RACING
description: Fined Roger Penske $1,000 for i mproper conduct during postrace techni- c al inspections during the Rex Mays 150 at M ilwaukee last Sunday. RIVERSIDE INTERNATIONAL R ACEWAY - Announced Les Richter re- s igned as president but will continue as di- r ector of racing. BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Sold Ken Smith, first b aseman-outfielder, to Richmond of the I nternational League. NEW YORK (NL) - Obtained Keith H ernandez, first baseman, from the St. L ouis Cardinals in a trade for Neil Allen a nd Rick Ownbey, relief pitchers. Sent M ike Jorgensen, first baseman-outfielder, t o the Atlanta Braves for cash or a player t o be named. Sent Ronn Reynolds, catch- e r, to Tidewater of the International L eague. NEW YORK (AL) - Acquired Matt K eough, pitcher, from the Oakland A's for B en Callahan, pitcher, and Marshall B rant, first baseman-designated hitter. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed freee- a gent draftees Anthony Blasucci, John S miley, Aaron Carlie, Kevin Litwin and J eff Satzinger, pitchers, Bryan Burrows, i nfielder, and Chuck Carr, first baseman. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Sent Ownbey to L ouisville of the American Association a nd called up Andy Van Slyke, outfielder, f rom Louisville. Placed Mike Ramsey, in- f ielder, on the 15-day disabled list. SEATTLE (AL) - Traded Julio Cruz, s econd baseman, to the Chicago White Sox f or Tony Bernazard, second baseman. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Jeff Hear- r on, catcher, and Alan McKay, pitcher, a nd assigned them to Florence of the S outh Atlantic League.

title: MARTIN IS CALLED FOR TALK TODAY
description: With Manager Billy Martin unfazed by having been summoned to a meeting here Thursday with the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees ended a four-game losing streak tonight, and acquired a right-handed starter.

title: Aileen's Chairman Quits
description: Meyer Osofsky, one of the founders of Aileen Inc., a New York apparel company, has resigned as chairman and a director for personal reasons, the company said yesterday. Abe Oberlin, president and chief executive officer, was named to the additional post of chairman.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Ford Funds Awards 11 High Schools $20,000 Each

title: A.P. Agrees to Settling Suit Filed by Minorities
description: The Associated Press agreed yesterday to spend up to $2 million to employ more women, blacks and Hispanic people, to advance more of them into managerial jobs and to compensate minority employees who had been denied raises and promotions.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 16, 1983
description: International Balance in East-West relations was stressed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. In Congressional testimony, Mr. Shultz said Washington remained concerned about Moscow's military buildup, its ''unconstructive involvement'' in unstable areas of the world and its ''unrelenting effort'' to impose its philosophy on its allies. But he said the Administration sought ''to engage the Soviet leaders in a constructive dialogue.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) The Pope's return to Poland today is viewed by the military rulers as potentially risky but also as a chance to gain legitimacy, with the goal of an easing of Western economic sanctions imposed after martial law was declared Dec. 13, 1981. As Warsaw's welcoming banners were hung, plainclothes policemen were posted around the home in Gdansk of Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity union, and he was told he would not be allowed to leave. (A1:5.)

title: Required Reading
description: Think About It

title: PORT AGENCY OFFERS BRONX HERB 'FARM' SOME ROOM FOR GROWTH
description: The Port Authority, the operator of airports and bus terminals, wants to help build a $1.2 million greenhouse for an herb nursery in the South Bronx.

title: BUSES GET OWN 5TH AVE. LANE IN A NEW BID TO EASE TIE-UPS
description: Fifth Avenue will get a ''red zone'' bus lane today that officials hope will help unsnarl traffic congestion there. The effect the lane will have on the avenue's commerce, however, remained an open question.

title: TECHNOLOGY AND TRADITION MARK CHICAGO SHOW
description: If there was doubt in anybody's mind that the computer would be an intrinsic part of American working lives, then this year's National Exposition of Interior Contract Furnishings will convince the most severe sceptics. Every major office furniture concern in the show coped with the computer.

title: SENATORS CALL FOR BIPARTISAN LATIN PANEL
description: Two Senators who have frequently disagreed on foreign policy joined today in proposing the creation of a bipartisan commission on United States policy in Central America.

title: CON ED AND 2 UNIONS PRESS TALKS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company and two unions representing 16,577 employees intensified bargaining talks yesterday in an effort to reach new agreements before contracts expire at midnight tomorrow.

title: U.S. Open Notebook; Backache Forces Trevino to Withdraw
description: A recurrence of his back ailment forced Lee Trevino, twice the winner of the tournament, to withdraw today from the United States Open golf championship, which begins Thursday. Because he had not qualified, Trevino was here by special invitation of the United States Golf Association, as were two other former champions, Arnold Palmer and Gary Player.

title: 3 TEXANS END BID FOR BUTCHER UNIT
description: Three Texas investors have withdrawn their offer to buy C.H. Butcher Jr.'s troubled Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, their lawyer said today. Jack Bailey, a Nashville attorney representing the Texans, said the offer was withdrawn because it had not been accepted by a Monday deadline they had set.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Indians, at Cleveland. Ron Guidry goes after his ninth victory for the struggling Yanks. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 7:30 P.M.) Boxing Davey Moore, champion, vs.

title: ORTIZ EAGER TO SHOW METS HIS WORTH
description: The joke began last week, when Junior Ortiz and Steve Nicosia heard the trade talk. One of them was leaving the Pirates, for sure, and the best way to cope was with humor.

title: BRIEFING
description: No Autographs, Please

title: IN NEW IRONWORK, HINTS OF A RENAISSANCE
description: LAST week, as the American Craft Museum's exhibition ''Towards a New Iron Age'' was being set up for tomorrow's opening, it was clear that the rugged, substantial pieces of iron - from Europe, America and Japan - were essentially decorative, and not the practical, everyday tools ironsmiths once made.

title: Technology; A Robot to Aid The Disabled
description: AROBOT to serve as a companion is being developed by Stanford U niversity's Robotic Aid Project. It listens, talks and performs s imple chores. In an improved version, to be introduced in the next f ew months, it also walks. It even ''feels,'' with a primitive but s erviceable sense of touch.

title: Reputed Mobster Gets 8-Year Term
description: An eight-year sentence for extortion was imposed yesterday on Mario Gigante of Yonkers, described by a Federal prosecutor as ''a rich and feared captain in the Genovese family of la Cosa Nostra.''

title: Drugs Called Bribe Lure
description: The heavy use of cocaine among some college and professional athletes has increased the chances that players may shave points or fix games for illegal bookmakers, a top Federal agent said today.

title: RICE CONTRACTS ORDERED LIQUIDATED
description: The New Orleans Commodity Exchange, which suspended trading Tuesday, today ordered the liquidation of all futures contracts in rice, the main item traded on the exchange.

title: Clue Sought in Plague Death
description: Health officials today looked for fleas and rodents near the home of a 9-year-old boy who died last week of bubonic plague. A spokesman for the State Health Division said plague could be contracted from flea bites or from rodents infected by fleas. The boy, whom officials have not identified, was the 11th person in Oregon to contract the plague and the fourth to die from the disease since 1934, according to Dr. Paul Williams of the State Health Division's epidemiology department.

title: CUOMO'S NAMING OF HADDAD BLOCKED
description: The Republicans who control the State Senate have blocked Governor Cuomo's nomination of his campaign coordinator, William Haddad, to be chairman of the State of New York Mortgage Agency, Republican legislators said today.

title: Zimbabwe Insurgents Kill a White Farmer
description: Anti-Government rebels shot and killed a white farmer in southwest Zimbabwe, officials said today. Ian Brebner, 39 years old, was shot in the chest Tuesday after being approached by about eight gunmen at the Lushabi Outspan Farm, 40 miles west of Bulawayo in Matabeleland Province, a Government statement said.

title: Chrysler Makes Big Repayment
description: The resurgent Chrysler Corporation today paid off one-third of the $1.2 billion in federally guaranteed loans that helped save the No.3 United States auto maker from bankruptcy in 1980 and 1981.

title: Reagan Names Special Aide
description: President Reagan announced today that he would appoint Catalina Villalpando, who recently worked for the Texas Republican Party, as a special assistant to the President with responsibility for Hispanic relations. Miss Villalpando, 43 years old, comes from San Marcos, Tex., and once operated her own consulting business.

title: Sirhan Says No One Helped to Kill Kennedy
description: Sirhan B. Sirhan said today that he and ''no other person'' was responsible for the death of Senator Robert F. Kennedy in 1968. He also told the California parole board he was under the influence of alcohol when he did it.

title: MAYORS CRITICIZE REAGAN'S ECONOMIC POLICIES
description: The United States Conference of Mayors, declaring that there was a national hunger crisis, adopted by a narrow vote a resolution today urging President Reagan to solve it by delaying his tax-cutting program and by spending less for the military and more for the poor.

title: Sunny's Halo Out
description: Sunny's Halo, the Kentucky Derby winner, has a sore right foreleg and will not run in the Queen's Plate at Woodbine on June 26, a race the colt had been expected to dominate.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
IN HOT-WATER HEATERS, SMALL IS ECONOMICAL
description: SMALL hot-water heaters, long popular in Europe becausethey are economical to use, are gradually finding their way into the home market here. Typically, American homes have a large tank that heats and stores 30 to 40 gallons of water. The advantage of this system is that many tasks - running the dishwasher and clothes washer and taking a bath - can all be done at the same time. It is also an expensive system because when no hot water is being used it is still being kept hot for future use.

title: HERS
description: WHEN Mary McCarthy, the writer, appeared on a Dick Cavett show a few years ago, he noted that it was her second appearance and asked her in what way she felt different from her previous time on the show. ''I'm more irritable,'' she said. That comment went ping in my head. And it started a long sequence of painful thoughts.

title: CALENDAR: BROWNSTONE ADVICE
description: Creative Methods of Ownership, 579 West 181st Street (between St. Nicholas and Amsterdam Ave- nues), 212-561-2154.

title: 'Star Wars' Creator Getting a Divorce
description: George Lucas, whose ''Star Wars'' extravaganzas have made him one of the most successful film makers in movie history, is getting divorced from his wife of 15 years, an official at Lucasfilms, his company, confirmed today.

title: Cleveland Issue Brings Yields of Up to 11.5%
description: A $27.5 million City of Cleveland general obligation bond was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers yesterday with yields ranging from 7 percent to 11.50 percent.

title: Losses of U.S. Japanese In War Put in Millions
description: The 120,000 people of Japanese descent who were interned by the Federal Government in World War II suffered income and property losses of $149 million to $370 million, according to a study made public today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: GREAT improvements have been made in the development of exterior paints in the last 20 years and, according to some advertisements, many newer paints are foolproof to apply and can be used on almost any surface.

title: Excerpts from Akron case, page B10.
description: The Supreme Court today forcefully reaffirmed the constitutional right to obtain an abortion and struck down an array of local legislative restrictions on access to abortions.

title: Two Tests of Mr. Cuomo's Courage
description: Since Mario Cuomo was elected Governor with strong labor support, an expression of gratitude in tangible form was to be expected. Yet the apparent agreement between the Governor and legislative leaders to alter the pension system for New York State and local government employees puts the interests of labor way ahead of the general public interest.

title: Denver Club on Block
description: His team is lagging, he has been hounded by the local news media, his family has been begging him to get out of the spotlight and now Roy Blanding, the owner of the Denver Gold, has decided he has had enough. He has put the United States Football League team up for sale with an asking price of $12 million.

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT A LINK BETWEEN COMMON VIRUS AND AIDS CASES
description: A team of New York scientists say they have found a link between a moderately common virus, called adenovirus, and acquired immune disorder syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Lloyd's to Pay Millions In Kidnapping of Horse
description: Lloyd's of London said today that it had agreed to pay millions in the theft insurance claim for Shergar, the $15 million champion racehorse kidnapped in February from the Aga Khan's stud farm in Ireland.

title: CBS PRODUCER SUSPENDED FOR SECRET TAPING
description: CBS News today suspended George Crile, the producer of a January 1982 documentary about the Vietnam War that is the subject of a major libel suit, for tape-recording telephone interviews with former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara and others in 1981 without their authorization.

title: COSMOS TROUNCE EUROPE CHAMPIONS
description: In a soccer match that had nothing at stake but pride, the Cosmos routed Hamburg of West Germany, the European champion, by 7-2 tonight in Giants Stadium.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT CONTRACTS VOIDED, RAISING CONCERN IN BOND MARKETS
description: The Washington State Supreme Court yesterday declared invalid contracts that bound local utility companies to pay off $2.25 billion in bonds to build two nuclear power plants that were never finished.

title: The U.N. Today; June 16, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Subcommittee on Small Territories - 3 P.M.

title: Fine Is Given In Hitachi Case
description: The only American businessman charged in an espionage case involving trade secrets of the International Business Machines Corporation sold to Hitachi Ltd. of Japan was given a suspended sentence today and fined $7,500.

title: FALLING IN LOVE AGAIN; BY William Safire
description: After two frustrating years of unrequited ardor for the Arabs, the Reagan Administration has suddenly fallen passionately in love with Israel.

title: RATES AT BANKS RISE
description: Interest rates on banks' money market deposit accounts increased for the fourth week in a row, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: AN INDIAN LEGACY OF DISCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND DEBT TALKS END
description: Western bank representatives and Polish officials ended two days of talks on how and when Poland will pay $25 billion it owes the banks and other governments.

title: Evans of Giants Clouts 3
description: Darrell Evans hit three home runs and drove in six runs today to lead the San Francisco Giants to a 7-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SHULTZ STATEMENT ON SOVIET TO SENATE COMMITTEE
description: Following are excerpts from a statement today by Secretary of State George P. Shultz before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on United States-Soviet relations, as made available by the State Department:

title: IF ARAFAT LOSES HIS LATEST BATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Jazz and Jobs

title: PRESBYTERIANS SUPPORT PRELATES' ARMS LETTER
description: The highest policy-making body of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has voted to send each of its 13,000 congregations a copy of the United States Roman Catholic bishops' pastoral letter on nuclear war.

title: Carroll O'Connor Plans Broadway Show in Fall
description: Carroll O'Connor, who is best known as Archie Bunker in the television series ''All in the Family,'' will appear on Broadway next fall as the star and director of ''Brothers,'' a play by George Sibbald.

title: GTE Completes Telephone Deal
description: The GTE Corporation said it had completed the acquisition of the long-distance telephone and satellite units of Southern Pacific Company for $727.4 million.

title: POLISH EXILES: HOMESICKNESS AND A REBIRTH
description: A few days ago Andrzej Skowron, a six-year-old Polish refugee, tugged at his mother's arm and pointed to a pair of American F-4 Phantom jets high above this wooded spa east of Frankfurt.

title: MAYOR ATTACKS EDUCATION CHIEF ON WAGNER VETO
description: Mayor Koch, breaking a long silence on the subject, charged yesterday that the State Education Commissioner had been politically motivated when he refused to allow Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. to become the city's Schools Chancellor.

title: MOTHER'S HELPERS: A SUMMER GUIDE
description: THIS summer Rebecca Lipman of Manhattan will take on her fifth consecutive job as a mother's helper, living with a family on vacation and caring for their small children. Thus far she has summered in Cape Cod, East Hampton, the Berkshires and Southampton. This July through Labor Day she will be staying in Atlantic Beach, L.I., looking after a 5-year-old boy and a 9-month-old girl.

title: CABLE-TV INDUSTRY TO PRESS DECONTROL MEASURE IN HOUSE
description: Top officials of the cable television industry expressed the hope today that the House of Representatives would soon approve a bill removing many city and municipal regulations from the cable television industry.

title: KEEPER OF ENVIRONMENT
description: When Robert E. Hughey showed up for work last year on his first day as New Jersey's Environmental Protection Commissioner, he parked his Jeep, strode in unannounced and sat behind his desk.

title: BLOCK PROPOSES AN EXTENSION OF WHEAT PAYMENT PROGRAM
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, hoping to make further reductions next year in the price-depressing wheat surplus, today disclosed the outlines of a plan to extend the payment-in-kind program to the 1984 wheat crop.

title: ACCORD IS SET ON HALFWAY HOUSES TO EASE CROWDING IN STATE PRISONS
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders said today that they had reached agreement on a plan they hoped would reduce prison overcrowding by setting up alternatives to imprisonment.

title: FORMER FIGHTER KEEPS A HAND IN
description: T he hand flicked through the van's open window and slapped Davey Moore, who had just defended his title by knocking out Charlie Weir, the white hero of Johannesburg.

title: AN UNSURE POLAND AWAITS JOHN PAUL
description: Banners in patriotic and religious colors were hung along the major streets tonight as this usually drab capital prepared for the long-awaited, politically charged return home of Pope John Paul II on Thursday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I still go home almost every weekend for a hurried gazing pass at the people of my state, masquerading in the guise of a man trying to find out what is going on. Who in the world can find out what is going on in the people's minds on a Saturday or Sunday when people would rather not be talking to politicians to begin with?'' -Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate Majority Leader. (A18:2.)

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in late editions Saturday, with a picture of Yuri V. Andropov leaving the Kremlin, dated the scene incorrectly. It occurred June 8.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Brad Davis, the Dallas Mavericks' free-agent guard, was told he could get a better deal elsewhere, but he did not want to leave Dallas and has agreed to a four-year contract worth $200,000 a year, according to his agent, Tom Collins. ... Michael Spinks, who united the light-heavyweight title, will defend it July 15 against Eddie Mustafa Muhammad in Washington.

title: French Retail Prices Up
description: French retail prices rose provisionally six-tenths of 1 percent to seven-tenths of 1 percent in May after a 1.3 percent gain in April, the National Statistic Institute said today. The figures show that from year to year retail price inflation eased to between 8.9 percent and 9 percent in May, from 9.1 percent the previous month.

title: CORRECTION
description: A recipe in The Living Section yesterday listed an incorrect quantity of chocolate chips for brownie pie and failed to give a baking temperature. Three and a half cups of chips should be used; the temperature should be 325 degrees.

title: COFFEE'S DRINKERS SAID TO RUN RISKS
description: Heavy coffee drinking may raise the risk of heart disease by raising levels of cholesterol in the blood, according to a study conducted in Norway.

title: Football at 100o
description: Playing football in hot weather can be debilitating and dangerous, but the New Jersey Generals have not suffered any serious problems so far.

title: NATURAL HISTORY AND INDIAN MUSEUMS TO JOIN
description: The Museum of the American Indian, long troubled by the drawbacks of its upper Manhattan location and frustrated in its attempts to find a new home without leaving New York City, has reached an agreement in principle to merge with the American Museum of Natural History.

title: I.B.M. Predicts A Strong Year
description: The International Business Machines Corporation expects a strong financial performance in 1983 compared with the results of a year ago, the chairman, John R. Opel, told analysts today.

title: Course Choices
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I am writing in reference to the ''Susannah'' who decided to drop physics and calculus, discussed in the ''Hers'' column of June 2. Sex role stereotyping may indeed have been the trigger for that particular decision. Yet after 33 years of college and university teaching, where cases like ''Susannah'' are legion, I would like to note that the tendency to avoid ''hard'' subjects is not the domain of one or the other sex.

title: Greece Says Dispute Arises Over U.S. Bases
description: The Greek Government said tonight that ''substantial differences of opinion'' had arisen in talks on American military bases here.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THERE were over 700 entries in the Formica Corporation's ''Surface & Ornament'' design competition.

title: JOHNSTONE HIT TOPS METS IN 10
description: The Mets' pitching staff was depleted last night even before their game started at Shea Stadium when Allen and Rick Ownbey were traded to the St. Louis Cardinals. Then the Mets spent the next three and one-half hours opening and closing the bullpen door, using five relief pitchers.

title: SYRIANS CALL FOR GUERRILLA WAR AGAINST GEMAYEL IN LEBANON
description: A Syrian Government newspaper said today that guerrillas in Lebanon should now wage war against the Government of President Amin Gemayel because the Lebanese Parliament endorsed the troop withdrawal agreement with Israel on Tuesday.

title: Occidental Unit Gets Chairman
description: Thomas D. Jenkins, 55 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Occidental Gas and Oil Corporation, a subsidiary of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation responsible for overseas exploration. David R. Martin, 52, succeeds him as president and chief operating of officer of the subsidiary, which is based in Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Pogo Sees Decline
description: The Pogo Producing Company said it expects a substantial decline in second-quarter earnings below the $13.7 million, or 55 cents a share, it earned in last year's period.

title: Born-Again Supply-Siders
description: The supply-siders are coming back to life. Determined to prove that theirs is the only true path to economic growth, they argue that the big deficits produced in part by their big tax cuts can't be blamed for high interest rates. Given their record so far, you'd expect a little more modesty.

title: MILLER AT OAKMONT WITH SURGERY NEXT
description: Johnny Miller was 26 years old, a winner of only two events in his first four years on the PGA Tour and as surprised as everyone else when he took the giant step to fame in the final round of the 1973 United States Open here at Oakmont Country Club.

title: MUSIC' SCHULLER LEADS 'HORIZONS '83'
description: THE New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' series, a two-week experiment in packaging contemporary music under the name of ''A New Romanticism,'' came to an end last night with a program that on the whole did not uphold its shaky premises. ''Romanticism'' is one of those all-purpose words that has come to mean so many different things to so many people that it makes little or no sense in a modern context.
