The series ought to have been able to stand on its own firm ground, without recourse to any such specious theme.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Sidewalk Obstructions; Sand Traps
description: If New York resembled Frank Lloyd Wright's vision of a spread city, construction of new buildings would be far less disruptive. There would be plenty of room on building lots for the contractors' field offices and to park the bricks, concrete blocks and sand for foundations and walls.

title: Market Place; Cautious View Of the Market
description: BY the standards of most Wall Street money managers, the San Mateo, Calif., firm of Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser Inc., which provides financial planning and investment advisory services mainly to wealthy individuals, is taking a rather cautious view of the stock market.

title: NO THINGS OF BEAUTY
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO ROADS LEADING TO A HEAD-ON CLASH IN ATLANTA
description: Beside the flowering magnolias and towering oaks of Atlanta's well-to-do neighborhoods dwell some of the most tenacious road foes in America. The streets they battle are parkways that would cut past or through Atlanta's treasured expanses of trees, homes and land.

title: A New Start
description: Matt Robinson, who in the late 1970's competed for three years with Richard Todd for the starting quarterback job with the New York Jets, will be starting over again - this time with the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Tuesday about loans to the third world misstated the participation of the Union Bank of Switzerland in current lending to Brazil. The bank has fully met its lending quota under the terms of a bankers' agreement to reschedule Brazil's short-term debt.

title: New Generals' Kicker
description: The Generals changed place-kickers again yesterday, making John Roveto their third of the season.

title: TV AUDIENCE OFF SHARPLY FOR TONYS
description: The audience ratings for the June 5 live telecast of ''The American Theater Wing's 1983 Tony Awards'' on CBS-TV were the lowest in five years, network officials said.

title: RENTING GREENERY FOR SPECIAL EVENTS
description: CAN you rent a yucca? You can. You can also rent a ficus benjamina, a ponytail palm or a small tropical forest with bird of paradise palm trees. Photographers, interior designers and caterers are the traditional clients for short-term rentals of greenery. Many companies prefer to rent rather than buy plants for their offices. Apartment dwellers are discovering they can do the same at home.

title: DEMOCRATIC HOPEFULS URGE FUNDS FOR SCHOOLS
description: The political debate over how best to upgrade the nation's schools intensified today as two Democratic Presidential hopefuls pushed for programs of their own that would nearly double the Federal investment in education.

title: Chief Increases Duties At Anthony Industries
description: Bernard I. Forester, chairman and chief executive of a miniconglomerate called Anthony Industries, has temporarily taken on additional responsibilities as president of the company's Shakespeare subsidiary, which makes fishing tackle.

title: Index; International
description: Mitterrand in Corsica: Socialist sermons in the sun A2 Senators call for bipartisan com- mission on Central America A3 Chile arrests leader of protests A3 100 arrested in Kashmir after political violence in streets A4 Pakistani negotiator says Afghan settlement is not imminent A6 Bonn questioning Moscow's motives on missiles A7 Syria urges guerrillas to fight Lebanese Government A8 For Polish exiles, homesickness and dreams of rebirth in U.S. A13 Soviet makes minor changes in leadership group A16 Government/Politics U.S. mayors ask Federal help to combat hunger A17 Secretary Block suggests extend- ing wheat payment program A20 Reagan presses attack on merit raises for teachers A24 Republicans block nomination of key Cuomo aide B4 Accord reached in Albany on plan to reduce prison overcrowding B5 Joseph M. Margiotta has begun serving his Federal sentence B5 Rulings on abortion hailed as women's rights victory B11 Washington Talk Briefing B12 Working Profile: Margaret Hayes, aide on Latin America B12 Presidential appointments and the trouble they bring B12 Health/Science Astronauts arrive at space center on countdown eve A9 Data bank on toxic products of fires is urged A23 Scientists find virus link to AIDS B9 Religion Presbyterians support Catholic bishops' arms letter A11 The Home Section Home Technology and tradition mark Chicago show C1

title: SOUTH AFRICANS DROP CASINO PLANS
description: A South African company that had attempted to help build and operate a $300 million casino in Atlantic City dropped out of the venture today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Calling Dad on His Day

title: People
description: * Tamara K. Homer, founder and president of Homer & Durham Advertising, named president of Advertising Women of New York.

title: SMALL WORLD OF ASTRONOMY AT CONFERENCE
description: On the same day mankind sent a spacecraft beyond the planets, it sent Giusa Cayrel's luggage to Schenectady, N.Y. The bags, unfortunately, were meant to follow Mrs. Cayrel here, to a convention of astronomers. Such are the earthly intrusions into the realm of the stargazer.

title: IT'S NOT TOO LATE TO PLANT VEGETABLES
description: THERE is still plenty of time to plant vegetable seeds. Hopefully, gardeners saved their spring seed catalogues because these informative pages tell how many days a vegetable needs to mature after the seed is planted.

title: WARRANTS ISSUED FOR SLAYERS OF EAGLES OVER EIGHT STATES
description: The Federal and state authorities, cracking down on what they described as the ''massive'' slaughter of bald and golden eagles, issued arrest warrants, search warrants or criminal subpoenas today for about 50 people charged with killing or trafficking in eagle feathers and other parts of protected birds for profit.

title: Advertising; Bates Adds Feeling to Hard Sell
description: WHEN you are running an agency known for creating advertising that sells hard, and suddenly discover that the public is turned off by such an approach, what do you do?

title: IS THERE NO MERCY
description: Anatoly Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet Jew, is suffering from what appears to be a grave heart condition. The authorities have not hospitalized him. But he has been given various medicines in prison, and now he has had a severe allergic reaction to those.

title: U.S. Carrier in Mediterranean
description: The aircraft carrier Coral Sea was due to enter the Mediterranean today, temporarily at least increasing United States naval air power within reach of the Middle East.

title: FRENCH OUST CHIEF OF ELF AQUITAINE
description: Albin Chalandon, president and chief executive officer of Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the state-controlled oil and natural resources company, was dismissed by the Government today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beverly Enterprises said it had agreed in principle to acquire all of the stock of Beacon Hill America Inc., which operates 62 nursing homes and intermediate care facilities in 11 states; terms were not disclosed.

title: 1,000 ROSEBUSHES BLOOM AT THE U.N.
description: The White House Rose Garden may be for occupants only, but that's not so at the United Nations, where scores of imported rosebushes line the East River and a ring of Japanese cherry trees await any who pass.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION HAILS RULING AS WOMEN'S RIGHTS VICTORY
description: Lawyers at the American Civil Liberties Union who specialize in cases involving free choice on abortion yesterday hailed the Supreme Court ruling on the Akron, Ohio, law and said they expected it to lead to nullification of laws limiting women's choice in many other states.

title: MITTERRAND IN CORSICA: A POLITICAL RITUAL IN THE SUN
description: In the harbor the Mediterranean was millions of little wavelets, billions of sun flashes. A breeze swiped at the miniature French flags strung over the speaker's rostrum, an arbor of blues, whites and reds. Three old men, dressed as Napoleonic drummer boys, whacked out a presidential paradiddle.

title: DAY CAMPS AND CLASSES FOR CITY CHILDREN
description: INSTRUCTION in computers, vegetable gardening, basketball and music and dance are among the activities available for children at day camps and workshops around the city this summer. Many programs still have openings and are now taking registrations. Here is just a sampling:

title: Michigan Hires New Yorker
description: M. Peter Lanahan Jr., first deputy commissioner of New York State's Environmental Conservation Department, today was appointed director of the Michigan Department of Natural Resources.

title: HOUSE DENIES FUNDS FOR NEW CHEMICAL WEAPONS
description: The House voted today to prohibit the Reagan Administration from starting production of a new form of chemical weapon.

title: A Runner's View Of Long Journey
description: Stu Mittleman teaches the psychology of sports at Queens College, but he also uses it in his athletic career as a long-distance runner. Mittleman, who is 32 years old, has won the New York Road Runners 100-mile invitation race for the last three years and is hoping to score a fourth victory this weekend at Shea Stadium in the race for The Athletic Congress's national championship.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 16, 1983; Companies
description: The Washington State Supreme Court declared invalid the contracts obliging local utilities to pay off $2.25 billion in bonds for the construction of two canceled nuclear plants. While a review is certain, concern spread in the bond markets that a default might be imminent. Few of the bonds could be traded, although some speculators were offering to buy them at 15 cents on the dollar. (Page A1.)

title: DANCE: LES BALLETS TROCKADERO AT CITY CENTER
description: THE Trocks are back. And, fame thrust upon them by divine mischance, they had what can only be described as un triomphe fou last night at City Center, where they'll be assaulting a wide repertory of new ballets and familiar classics through July 3.

title: Wimbledon Loses Arias
description: Jimmy Arias, the 18-year-old from upstate New York who won the Italian Open, has withdrawn from the Wimbledon tennis championships because of a strained stomach muscle. Arias, who has been nursing the injury for some time, had been seeded 10th for Wimbledon, which begins June 20. The injury had earlier forced him out of a Grand Prix tournament in Venice, and according to a spokesman for the tour, ''it is still no better.''

title: CIVIL RIGHTS CHIEF ASSURES MISSISSIPPI BLACKS ON FAIR VOTING DISTRICTS
description: Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds assured Mississippi blacks here today that the Department of Justice would not approve new voting districts in Mississippi that ''dilute minority voting strength.''

title: KEITH HERNANDEZ SENT TO METS FOR ALLEN, OWNBEY
description: The Mets, looking to add punch to their lineup, acquired Keith Hernandez, a former National League batting champion who was hitting .284 through Tuesday night's game, from the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday for two relief pitchers, Neil Allen and Rick Ownbey.

title: Lawyer Will Head Dome Mines Group
description: The Dome Mines Group, North America's largest gold producer, yesterday named Fraser Fell, a 54-year-old lawyer, as chairman and chief executive.

title: Books Of The Times
description: A Difference of Design. By W.M. Spack- man. 116 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Article 235444 -- No Title
description: Six million new shares of the Sperry Corporation were offered yesterday by an underwriting group led by Salomon Brothers at a price of $37.50 a share.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUPTUT UP 1.1% IN MAY
description: Industrial output in May rose 1.1 percent from April, the Government reported today. The rise was the sixth in a row.

title: WATT'S PARK LAND FAILURES
description: In his weekly radio address last Saturday, President Reagan defended the preservation record of Interior Secretary James Watt by pointing to the 2.7 million acres he has proposed for designation as wilderness areas. But this action is insignificant when compared with the record of the Carter Administration - which set aside 64.9 million acres - and obscures a more important issue: It is not what Mr. Watt has done to carry out his preservation mandate, but what he has failed to do.

title: Bridge:; Seattle Is Picked as the Site Of the '84 Team Olympiad
description: The World Bridge Federation, at a meeting of its executive committee in Geneva last week, endorsed a decision by the American Contract Bridge League that seems destined to be quite unpopular around the world.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alaska Housing Finance Corp.'s $75 million issue of 11 1/2 percent bonds due in 1993 was priced at 99 3/8, to yield 11.611 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: SHUTTLE'S CREW FLIES TO BASE ON EVE OF COUNTDOWN
description: The five astronauts who are to fly the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger arrived at the Kennedy Space Center here today as technicians prepared to begin the countdown leading to a launching of the four men and the first American spacewoman on Saturday.

title: DR. ELLIOT D. WEITZMAN, EXPERT ON SLEEP, DIES
description: Dr. Elliot D. Weitzman, founder and director of the Institute of Chronobiology in White Plains and a leader in studying sleep, died of lymphoma Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 54 years old and lived in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: CITY BOILS, BEACHES BUZZ, AMBULANCES KEEP BUSY
description: A sharp rise in ambulance calls, problems with water pressure and crowds at the beaches were reported yesterday as New York City steamed through its fourth straight day of temperatures in the low 90's.

title: THEATER: THREE SHORT PLAYS BY SAMUEL BECKETT
description: FROM first to last, Samuel Beckett celebrates life while waiting fearfully for the arrival of death cloaked in the ''old terror of night.'' His three new short plays, opening last night at the Harold Clurman Theater in a production directed by Alan Schneider, are epilogues to a ''Catastrophe,'' to borrow the title of the evening's centerpiece. Each of the plays is an end game. Together, including two intermissions, they last only 70 minutes. In that brief time, they tantalize the mind as well as the eye.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I recently purchased and installed a free-form fiberglass garden pool that is about 7 feet long, 3 feet wide and 14 inches deep. I placed some rocks in the bottom, then filled it with water and installed a small recirculating water pump to create an artificial waterfall at one end. This works well and looks fine, but now I am concerned about what maintenance is required. Do I need to keep this pool filled with water at all times (someone told me it would pop out of the ground if I didn't) and if it ever cracks, can it be repaired?

title: MOVES LOOMING IN N.B.A.
description: For the first time, a nationwide television audience was able to view the National Basketball Association's awards luncheon yesterday. But the most interesting show was behind the scenes, where the first wave of possible free-agent moves was already in evidence.

title: COMPENSATION SUITABLE FOR A MEMBER OF CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT UPHOLDS LABOR BOARD STEPS TO AID UNION RIGHTS
description: The Supreme Court, in a significant victory for organized labor, today upheld the National Labor Relations Board's approach to protecting workers against retaliation for prounion activities.

title: DATA BANK URGED FOR TOXIC SMOKE
description: A study sponsored by New York State, delivered to Governor Cuomo and the Legislature today, recommends that manufacturers of building and furnishing materials be required to identify the poisonous gases their products create when burning.

title: RISING INFLUENCE OF A KEY AIDE ON LATIN AMERICA
description: It is 7:30 A.M., and Margaret Daly Hayes has stepped out of her 1974 chocolate brown Audi Fox at a Senate parking lot beside Union Station to walk the five long blocks to her office at the Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Row Houses
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Since the row houses at 84th and Madison are of such importance to the architectural history of New York City, certain inaccuracies in your article concerning the one at 1130 Madison (''Living Over the Store,'' June 2) deserve correction.

title: HARRIS CONCERN AND TWO AIDES INDICTED UPSTATE
description: The Harris Corporation, one of the country's largest computer and satellite-communications companies, and two of its executives were indicted today on charges of illegally dumping up to 200,000 gallons of toxic waste in upstate New York.

title: PRIVATE LIVES' TO CLOSE EARLY
description: Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton have cut short their run in Noel Coward's ''Private Lives'' at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The play, which was originally scheduled to close on Aug. 14, will close instead on July 17.

title: Canal-Randolph Names President Its Chairman
description: Raymond French, president and chief executive of the Canal-Randolph Corporation, a real estate company, was named yesterday to the additional post of chairman. Mr. French, 63, succeeds Sir Walter H. Salomon, 77, a London investment banker who is stepping down after 24 years on the board.

title: 9 Investigations Into Ad Claims
description: The National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus concluded nine investigations into advertising claims last month, and found that six of the advertisers could substantiate the claims.

title: CHILE SEIZES LEADER OF MASS PROTESTS
description: A confrontation between labor unions and the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet hardened tonight as Rodolfo Seguel, the copper workers' leader who led nationwide protests Tuesday demanding democracy, was jailed for violating ''national security.''

title: The Worm and the Apple; Sidewalk Obstructions; Fast Cards
description: The three-card monte dealer deftly shuffles two black playing cards and a red one, face down. The player's object is to pick the red card and win $20 or $40.

title: WORLD WAR II: THE DAY HIROHITO OVERRULED JAPAN'S CABINET
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 KILLED IN BATTLES WITH POLICE
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot and his assailant killed in a gun battle on a Manhattan street early yesterday, the police said. Less than four hours later about a mile away, two officers killed a man after, they said, he struck one of them and then drew a gun.

title: Officer Is Crushed Between Cars of El
description: A 24-year-old officer on his way to work was crushed to death yesterday when he fell beneath an elevated subway train at the Ditmars Boulevard Station in Astoria, Queens.

title: TERM STARTED BY MARGIOTTA IN FRAUD CASE
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader, reported to the Federal prison in Allenwood, Pa., shortly after midnight yesterday to begin serving a two-year sentence for mail fraud and extortion. He was accompanied by members of his family.

title: DANCE: PETIPA 'DON QUIXOTE' PRESENTED BY BALLLET THEATER
description: ''DON QUIXOTE'' returned in all its giddy glory to the American Ballet Theater's repertory Tuesday night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Once again, Mikhail Baryshnikov's staging of a comic ballet originally choreographed by Marius Petipa in 1869 had little to do with Cervantes's ''Don Quixote'' or with any Spain that ever existed outside of operettas. Yet, though it was dramaturgically preposterous and often choreographically negligible, it was jolly nonetheless, for it was filled with some unusually ebullient dancing. This ''Don Quixote'' was choreographic sangria for a hot summer's night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Central Park Recovering

title: 2 Creditor Groups Back Braniff Plan
description: The full committees representing two major groups of creditors of Braniff Airways have voted to accept a $70 million offer made by the Hyatt Corporation to restart part of the airline.

title: L. Richard Marshall, 65, Dies; Served 16 Years in Assembly
description: L. Richard Marshall, a Republican Assemblyman who represented Chemung and Tioga Counties in upstate New York from 1963 to 1978, died Sunday at the Arnot Ogden Memorial Hospital in Elmira, N.Y. He was 65 years old and lived in Elmira.

title: Eagle Offering Sold Out
description: The reissue of the Eagle Computer Company's initial public offering of 2.75 million shares was quickly oversubscribed yesterday on the over-the-counter market. The issue price was $12 a share.

title: PAKISTANI AIDE DOUBTS AFGHAN SOLUTION IS IN SIGHT
description: No political settlement of the Afghan impasse appears imminent, according to a Pakistani official involved in the talks on the matter.

title: Robbie Seeks Twins
description: Since Calvin Griffith let it be known that he might sell the Minnesota Twins after the season, his phone has been ringing with calls from prospective buyers.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atlas Copco North America Inc., Wayne, N.J., the U.S. arm of the Atlas Copco Group, Stockholm, has named C. Frank DeMeo president.

title: Track Sale Discussed
description: The New Jersey Meadowlands sports complex, which has been trying to lure the Jets from Shea Stadium, has held ''preliminary discussions'' about a possible purchase of Monmouth Park race track, according to a Meadowlands official. Monmouth's major stockholder is Leon Hess, the principal owner of the Jets. George Wirt, the director of public affairs for the Meadowlands complex, said the negotiations to buy Monmouth Park began several months ago but had no bearing on the effort to get the Jets to play their home games at Giants Stadium, a Meadowlands facility.

title: 2d Killing Charged To Biegenwald
description: Richard Biegenwald of Asbury Park, who has been indicted in one murder and linked to four others, was indicted today on charges of slaying a former business associate.

Retail investors returned as buyers of government securities yesterday, apparently attracted by a rise in yields in recent weeks. The demand helped raise prices and lower yields, particularly for longer-dated issues.

title: COMPUTER MAKER'S FAST START
description: In many respects the Compaq Computer Corporation, an 18-month-old company based in Houston, is a symbol of the personal computer industry of the 1980's.

title: WHEN CLEAN-AIR RULES NEED RESTUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Celtics Seek Knicks' Webster; Sly Williams Gets Offer
description: The much-expected tug-of-war for players between the Knicks and the Celtics began yesterday when Boston announced that it had signed Marvin Webster and Sly Williams, two of New York's three key free agents, to offer sheets.

title: POLES, ON PONTIFF'S VISIT
description: Followi ng are excerpts from a survey of Polish opinion on the visit of Pope John Paul II to his native country, which begins today, compiled by Tygodnik Powszechny, a Cracow Roman Catholic weekly newspaper. The authorities forbade publication of responses to the question, ''What do you expect from the Pope's visit?'' Here are some of the answers.

title: 3 ACQUIRED IN TRADE GLAD TO BE RANGERS
description: In Regina, Saskatchewan, Tuesday morning, Denise Blaisdell took the call from the Detroit Red Wings and was the first to hear that her son Mike had been traded to the Rangers. Mrs. Blaisdell immediately called Mike, at his Detroit apartment. ''He was absolutely ecstatic,'' she said.

title: ISABELLE T. G. FOGLER
description: Isabelle T.G. Fogler, president in 1945 of Women's American ORT, the Organization for Rehabilitation through Training, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home in Miami Beach. She was 81 years old and a former New Yorker.

title: BLACK BASS SEASON TO OPEN SATURDAY
description: L ures neatly arranged in tackle boxes and old lines replaced, eager devotees of the black basses will be on the water Saturday, the opening of the regular season for the species in New York State.

title: LENINGRADER GETS HIGH SOVIET PARTY POST
description: A two-day-meeting of the Communist Party's Central Committee that had been seen as a potential test of Yuri V. Andropov's authority ended today by making minor changes in the leadership as it stood under Leonid I. Brezhnev, Mr. Andropov's predecessor as party chief.

title: CONGRESS OUT OF TOUCH WITH U.S., BAKER CONTENDS
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, warned today that members of Congress had become ''elected bureaucrats'' who had lost contact with the world beyond Washington.

title: Security Pacific
description: The Security Pacific National Bank said it had received approval from the Comptroller of the Currency to acquire two New York City bond brokerage companies. The bank, a subsidiary of the Security Pacific Corporation, said that it had purchased Clifford Drake & Company., a municipal bond broker, and Chapdelaine & Company Corporate Securities Inc.

title: KOCH CRITICIZES AMERICAN JEWS WHO YIELD TO 'ANTI-ISRAEL SENTIMENT'
description: Some American Jews have ''knuckled under to the pressures of the State Department and the anti-Israel sentiment that has grown in our land,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday.

title: Record Magazine Plans A Change in Format
description: Thomas F. Braun, the new publisher of Record magazine, a sister publication of Rolling Stone in the Straight Arrow Publishers stable, said yesterday that the monthly would change its format to a standard-sized, glossy magazine from a tabloid printed on newsprint. When the change takes place, with the October issue, the cover price will rise to $1.25, from $1.

title: 3 MEN HELD IN PLANE SALE PLOT
description: A plan to sell seven surplus Australian C-130 military transport planes to Libya without a license was thwarted with the arrest of three men, Federal agents said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BRONX TIDINGS

title: TRADING DEADLINE IS A FRAGILE TIME
description: T he condolence calls were made late Tuesday night, after the trade had been announced. The Mets and the Pittsburgh Pirates had made a deal that had been discussed for months. Bob Bailor had been hearing about a trade since spring training, and at last one had been made, and now the callers were stopping by his locker near a corner of the Met clubhouse at Shea Stadium and observing a ritual that takes place each year in the middle of June.

title: Albany Influence
description: The 10-man team that will represent the United States in the World Junior Greco-Roman wrestling championships in Norway from June 30 to July 2 will include 9 athletes who live within 20 miles of Albany, N.Y.

title: MARSHALL FIELD HUNT SEEN NARROWED
description: An intensive search for a new chairman and chief executive officer of the Chicago division of Marshall Field & Company, one of the nation's most prestigious department store jobs, has been narrowed to four candidates, industry executives reported yesterday.

title: SHULTZ TESTIFIES RIFTS WITH SOVIET AREN'T INEVITABLE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Reagan Administration was seeking ''to engage the Soviet leaders in a constructive dialogue.'' The United States, he said, ''need not accept as inevitable the prospect of endless, dangerous confrontation with the Soviet Union.''

title: Chock Full Shareholders
description: J. Patrick Lannan, a 77-year-old former top executive of the ITT Corporation, was named yesterday as a member of a new Chock Full o'Nuts shareholders' committee that said it represents 875,100 shares, or 17.5 percent of the company's stock. A previous committee was headed by Jerry Finkelstein, 67, a New York businessman.

title: Jamaica Hospital Fined by State
description: The State Health Department has fined Jamaica Hospital in Queens $4,000 for violations of state hospital regulations.

title: Strong Month For Casinos
description: The nine casino-hotels here won $146 million from gamblers during May, their third-highest month ever, casino officials said today.

title: BROWN BID SPURNED BY LENOX
description: Lenox Inc., the maker of fine china, yesterday rejected the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation's cash offer of $413 million for the company and retaliated with a novel tactic aimed at threatening the Brown family's control of the big distiller.

title: AUDIT SHOWS NPR HAS A DEFICIT OF $6.5 MILLION
description: An audit of National Public Radio's books revealed today that the organization's deficit had reached at least $6.5 million, that it has not paid $651,000 in Federal and state employee taxes and that its management controls were ineffective. But the network's board chairman vowed that it would continue in operation.

title: Insecticide Cloud Forces 1,500 to Flee in Texas
description: A cloud of insecticide leaked from a greenhouse at Stephen F. Austin State University tonight, forcing the evacuation of more than 1,500 people, the authorities said. At least 82 people, including the city's Mayor, were brought to the city's two hospitals for treatment, but the extent of their injuries was unknown, said Nancy Martin, a spokesman for Medical Center Hospital.

title: IS 'NEW ROMANTICISM' MUSIC OF THE FUTURE?
description: THE New York Philharmonic's ''Horizons '83'' contemporary-music festival ended last night, and to judge from the first three concerts and a couple of the symposiums, and from the reactions of others to the rest, it seems to have been a healthy success. Lots of new music got played, most of it reasonably well, and lots of people crowded into Avery Fisher Hall at refreshingly inexpensive rates.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Population Put at 233 Million
description: There are nearly 234 million Americans, the Census Bureau reported today. The bureau's latest official estimate of the population, as of April 1, is 233,736,000.

title: A New Prison for Newark
description: When he learned of plans for a new 1,000-bed medium-security state prison in his ward in Newark, Henry Martinez, a Councilman, said, ''The pilots flying into Newark airport point out our scenic garbage recycling plant, toxic chemical storage tanks - and now a prison complex?''

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES SCHOOL MERIT PAY
description: President Reagan cautioned against making a political football of the education issue today as he stepped up his attack on the National Education Association, the country's largest group of organized teachers, for opposing merit pay programs.

title: Cardinals 7, Phillies 6
description: ST. LOUIS (AP) - Steve Carlton (7-7) regained the career strikeout mark but was the losing pitcher after David Green hit a two-out runscoring single in the eighth inning to cap a four-run rally.

title: METAL PLATING GOES BEYOND BABY SHOES
description: Baby shoes aren't the only things people are bronzing today. ''We get a lot of requests for bronzed sneakers or track shoes,'' said Deanna Rothman, vice president of Perma Plating Company Inc., a Brooklyn-based specialty plating company.

title: House Unit Subpoenas Watt, Assailing 'Incredible' Delays
description: A House subcommittee, charging ''an incredible obstacle course'' of delays, subpoenaed documents today that it said the Interior Department was attempting to withhold.

title: MORGAN MAY GET STRAVINSKY PAPERS
description: An anonymous donor has pledged $3.75 million to acquire the Igor Stravinsky archive and manuscript collection with the aim of depositing the papers in the Pierpont Morgan Library in Manhattan, Francis S. Mason Jr., assistant director of the Morgan, said yesterday.

title: Newport Race To Running Tide
description: Running Tide, a 61-foot sloop sailed by Al Van Metre of Alexandria, Va., today won the 473-mile Annapolis-to-Newport Race on elapsed time.

title: JAPANESE SEEK A COMPUTER STANDARD
description: Fourteen of Japan's leading electronics companies, working with two American companies, have agreed on standard specifications for lowpriced home computers, according to the American concerns involved. The agreement, announced yesterday in New York and Japan, is expected to accelerate the movement of Japanese home computers into the United States market.

title: FINANCE NEW ISSUES;
description: The First Boston Corporation has tentatively priced a $45 million Indiana Housing Authority finance issue with yields ranging from 9.62 percent to 10.12 percent.

title: Metro-North Cars Go Off Track
description: Four empty passenger cars of a Metro-North commuter train derailed near the station here today, halting service between New Canaan and Stamford during the morning rush.

title: LEADERS OF RIGHTS COALITION CALL FOR REJECTION OF 3 REAGAN NOMINEES
description: The executive committee of the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights called on the Senate today to reject President Reagan's three nominees to the United States Civil Rights Commission.

title: THE TRIALS OF A TOP-LEVEL APPOINTEE
description: First comes the good news. The White House is on the phone. The President wants you to come to Washington as an assistant secretary of a Cabinet department. Power, prestige and public service beckon.

title: IN TENNESSEE, THE U.S. AND JAPAN MESH
description: When Marvin T. Runyon climbs into the cab of a Nissan pickup truck and drives it off the assembly line here tomorow, it will represent the first results of an expensive attempt to transplant a formidably efficient production system from the tightly structured islands of Japan to the reddish clay soil of central Tennessee.

title: Canada's Tory Chief to Run
description: The newly installed leader of the Canadian Conservative Party, Brian Mulroney, who has never stood for political office in his life, announced today that he would contest a House of Commons seat in Nova Scotia. No date has been set for the special election. Mr. Mulroney, a 44-year-old lawyer from Montreal, won leadership of the main opposition party last weekend.

title: BONN QUESTIONING SOVIET MOTIVES ON MISSILES
description: West Germany's Defense Minister told Parliament today that the Soviet Union started stationing short-range nuclear weapons in Eastern Europe before or just after the Western alliance reached a decision in 1979 to modernize its own medium-range missile force.

title: Dow Hits A Record 1,237.28
description: A late rally enabled the stock market to post its fifth consecutive advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing to a record 1,237.28, up 10.02 points.

title: Elf Aquitaine President
description: Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, the Government-controlled oil and natural resources company, today named Michel Pecqueur president to replace Albin Chalandon, who was dismissed Wednesday. Mr. Pecqueur is head of the French Atomic Energy Commission. Mr. Chalandon was dismissed by the Government in a dispute over Elf's role in the Government's plan to restructure France's ailing petrochemical industry.

title: News Analysis
description: The last three days have seen the largest flurry of political activity since Leonid I. Brezhnev's death in November, but two high-level meetings have ended with little sign that the Kremlin is any closer to bold initiatives that could shake up a sagging economy or ease tensions with the United States.

title: Excerpts from speech, page A8.
description: Yuri V. Andropov today added the largely titular position of head of state to his job as general secretary of the Communist Party, thereby assuming the third of the major positions left vacant in November by the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: The U.N. Today; June 17, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Decolonization Subcommittee on Petitions - 10:30 A.M.

title: ALEXANDER'S INC reports earnings for qtr to May 7.
description: b-Net loss

title: Executive Service Corps Campaign Introduced
description: The International Executive Service Corps, which for almost 20 years has been sending volunteer retired people to help businesses in the third world, is about to benefit from an Advertising Council print advertising campaign aimed at recruiting more executives and raising funds to help the effort.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA GAINS
description: Martina Navratilova continued her domination of the $150,000 BMW women's grass-court championships today by defeating Jo Durie, the new hope of British women's tennis, 6-2, 6-1.

title: Sirhan Denied Parole; 2-Year Wait Lies Ahead
description: A California parole board today denied parole for Sirhan B. Sirhan 15 years after he shot Senator Robert F. Kennedy dead in Los Angeles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Together with all my compatriots, especially with those who are most acutely tasting the bitterness of disappointment, humiliation, suffering, of being deprived of their freedom, of being wronged, of having their dignity trampled upon, I stand beneath the cross of Christ.'' - Pope John Paul II, in Poland. (A1:6.)

title: Accounts
description: * Proprietary Brands to Wolff Whitehill & Thomas Inc.

title: 'LIGHT OPERA' COMPOSER IS ALSO WRITER OF JINGLES
description: The trademark for Charles Morrow Associates Inc. includes the slogan ''Music and Sound for Anything.'' Mr. Morrow, a 41-year-old New York-based composer, has taken these words to heart. Over the last two decades, he has written and performed dozens of commercial jingles; served as a musical consultant for Simon and Garfunkel, among others; commissioned and played many compositions for trumpet and piano; created a ''sound portrait'' of Marilyn Monroe that uses recordings of her voice and a string trio, and scored a group of works for up to 100 conch shells.

title: FIRST CITY PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1.6 million for the latest first quarter and $917,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: EXEMPT GROUPS VOICE OBJECTIONS TO KOCH TAX PLAN
description: Representatives of more than 100 art, cultural and educational institutions told Mayor Koch yesterday they opposed his plan to collect property taxes from many institutions that traditionally have enjoyed exemptions.

title: In Trading Mood
description: Perenially one of the most successful teams in the Western Conference of the National Basketball Association, the Seattle SuperSonics have fallen recently into a spiral that can be altered only by mass changes, according to General Manager Les Habegger.

title: MORE SOVIET ENIGMAS
description: The news from Moscow is more opaque than ever. Yuri Andropov has been made President of the Supreme Soviet, after a curious delay. It seems to consolidate his power, but there are many other signs that his control is not complete.

title: Drugs to Remain A Lively Issue
description: When the USA/Mobil national outdoor track and field championships are held today, tomorrow and Sunday in Indianapolis, there will be no testing of athletes for banned drugs. But Ollan Cassell insists that violators will soon be discovered.

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
More Wings' Changes
description: General Manager Jim Devellano's Detroit Red Wings may continue to lose next season, but it won't be with many of the same players.

title: U.S. FIGHTS QUEBEC CURB ON FILM DISTRIBUTION
description: The United States Embassy here has condemned proposed legislation in Quebec that could severely curb the major American film studios from distributing movies in the largely French-speaking province.

title: CANADIAN NATURAL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $442,990.

title: DURAN STOPS MOORE IN 8TH, CAPTURING W.B.A. CROWN
description: After the first sellout boxing crowd in more than nine years at Madison Square Garden chanted ''Ali, Ali, Ali,'' in celebration of cherished memories, Roberto Duran reached back and recaptured his youth last night. He battered Davey Moore into submission after 2:02 of the eighth round and won the World Boxing Association junior middleweight championship.

title: Their credits include a mad computer.
description: PSYCHOPATHIC killers made of silicon chips are replacing felons of flesh and blood in the movies. There's the machine in ''WarGames'' that's out to nuke the world, and now ''Superman III'' (at the Criterion Center, Manhattan 1 and 2, Murray Hill and other theaters; a review appears on page C4), brings us what its director, Richard Lester, calls ''a criminally insane computer.''

title: Summer's hottest ticket? How about Sondheim musical?
description: WHAT is going to be the hottest ticket in town this summer? The obvious answer is ''Cats.'' But not during the three-week period from July 9 to 30. That is when ''Sunday in the Park With George,'' the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical, will make a fleeting appearance at Playwrights Horizons. The musical, which has a cast led by Bernadette Peters and Mandy Patinkin, will be staged as a workshop and is supposed to be open to Playwrights Horizons subscribers only. But inevitably there will be outstanding displays of creativity as others devise ingenious schemes to get in.

title: HUMANA INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Two Arrested in Murder Of Black Alabama Youth
description: Two Ku Klux Klansmen were charged today in the 1981 death by beating of a black teen-ager. Moss Stack, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, identified the two as James Knowles, 19 years old, and Henry Hays, 28, both from Mobile County. Mr. Knowles pleaded guilty to a civil rights violation before Federal District Judge W.@B. Hand.

title: SCHLUMBERGER VENTURE
description: The Nippon Steel Corporation and Schlumberger Ltd. a leading United States oil service company, have tentatively agreed to a joint venture that would include serving the Chinese market with petroleum drilling and exploration, a Nippon Steel official said today.He said the companies had also talked about cooperating on research and development of seamless piping and drilling equipment and exchanges of technical experts.

title: Switching Sports
description: Frank Conner, who scored a one-over-par 72 yesterday in the first round of the United States Open at the Oakmont Country Club in Pennsylvania, is one of those versatile athletes who have left their original sports to play golf for a living. Conner competed in amateur tennis for 9 years, reaching the rounds of 32 in the national championship of 1967 and the Open championship in 1968.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 17, 1983
description: International The Pope went home and allied himself at once with the victims of the martial law restrictions imposed in Poland 18 months ago. John Paul II confronted the nation's political troubles with unusually tough, direct references, both in his arrival at Warsaw's airport and a homily in St. John's Cathedral, which rang with applause. (Page A1, Column 6.) The Pope's return to Poland is considered the most personal of his 18 foreign journeys. Polish priests at the Vatican said John Paul II had an acute sense of personal responsibility for the joyous and tragic events that have swept Poland since his first visit there as Pope in 1979. (A9:1-4.)

title: A Relief Mission
description: Neal Heaton, a left-handed pitcher, attracted major league scouting attention through his fine performances at Sachem High School in Lake Ronkonkama, L.I., and at the University of Miami. After two seasons of minor league training, he made the roster of the Cleveland Indians this season at the age of 23.

title: Savings Unit Contraction
description: The number of banks and savings and loans could be halved within the next decade as competition grows among financial service companies, a study indicated.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boles & Co., San Francisco, announced that it had concluded arrangements for the acquisition of Tozer Kemsley & Millbourne of London's Spicers International Ltd. trading company unit for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: ANGRY FRENCH PRISON GUARDS STOP PERFORMING SOME TASKS
description: Thousands of French prison guards began work stoppages today, refusing to bring prisoners to or from courts, or to allow them to see their lawyers. The Government accused the strikers of ''hindering the functioning of justice'' in France.

title: Prisoner, 19, Shot In Station House
description: A 19-year-old man was shot in the face when he snatched a police officer's service revolver and menaced policemen and civilians in a Bronx station house where he was being detained, the police said.

title: Cargill Corn Mill
description: Spurred by increased demand from the soft-drink industry, Cargill Inc. said it planned to spend $100 million converting an old power plant into a corn milling operation to produce corn sweeteners.

title: SFN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago quarter and year results include gain from a change in accounting methods of $1,736,000.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday about Norton Simon Inc. incorrectly identified the owner of the Congoleum Corporation. The company is owned by its management, creditors, the First Boston Corporation and Century Capital Associates.

title: News Analysis
description: Reagan Administration officials are saying that the outlook for Soviet-American relations is a little bit brighter than it has been in the last few years, although they are quick to add that neither side has changed its substantive position and they are hard put to show exactly where improvements will occur.

title: U.S. WILL REGISTER MISSISSIPPI VOTERS
description: The chief of the Justice Department's civil rights division announced today that, on the basis of complaints he heard on a trip to Mississippi this week, he had decided to send Federal observers to facilitate voter registration for blacks in five counties there.

title: Lenox Officers Get 'Golden Parachutes'
description: Lenox Inc., which is fighting an unsolicited tender offer from the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, has given eight of its executives ''golden parachute'' contracts that would protect them if the company is taken over, according to documents filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Alumni Celebrate Early
description: T he High School of Music and Art and the School of Performing Arts won't merge under one roof until September. Nevertheless, their alumni and friends joined forces Tuesday night to hand out the first annual awards of La Guardia High School of Music and the Arts, as the new school in the Lincoln Center area is known.

title: Mass Transit Includes the Mass
description: After years of dirt and decay, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority finally has the money and the management to start remodeling New York City's subway stations - but can't. There's a wheelchair on the tracks.

title: COURT DISMISSES A CHALLENGE TO WATT'S OFFSHORE LEASING PLAN
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, in a major victory for Interior Secretary James G. Watt, has dismissed a challenge to Mr. Watt's program to offer virtually the entire United States coastline for oil and gas drilling.

title: MUSIC: REBO AOKI PLAYS FLUTE
description: IN a culture that tends to equate high art with high spending, it is sobering to hear someone like Rebo Aoki play the Japanese flute known as shakuhachi. Little more a thick tube of bamboo drilled with four holes on the top and one on the bottom, the shakuhachi can produce an astonishing variety of sounds and effects.

title: JERSEY OFFER SAID TO BENEFIT JETS
description: The Jets have been offered ''basically the same deal as the Giants'' to move to the Meadowlands in New Jersey, according to people familiar with the negotiations. That deal, the sources say, is financially better than the Jets get in Shea Stadium.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
Grand Jury Charges 3 In Movie Copter Deaths
description: John Landis, the director, and two other men who worked on ''Twilight Zone: The Movie'' have been indicted by a grand jury on criminal charges in the deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children, lawyers said today. The actor and children were killed when a damaged helicopter crashed on them while the film was being made.

title: U.D.C. Computer Course
description: T he state's Urban Development Corporation will run a six-session computer seminar this summer for 12 minority-group students in junior high school.

title: FAREWELL CALL TO NATION ON ARMED FORCES POLICY
description: After fighting in two wars and then leading the United States Army out of the valley of disorder and turmoil into which it stumbled after Vietnam, Gen. Edward C. Meyer is on the verge of stepping down as Chief of Staff.

title: CUBA IS OPEN TO TALKS ON TIES WITH U.S.
description: Cuba is willing to open ''serious negotiations'' on re-establishing normal relations with the United States, but the Reagan Administration will have to take the first step, a Cuban Vice President, Dr. Carlos Rafael Rodriguez, says.

title: Upshaw's Tough Stance
description: The National Football League owners may be relieved that the militant Ed Garvey has resigned as executive director of the National Football League Players Association, but by the sound of his successor, Gene Upshaw, the former Raider lineman, is not planning to be a pushover.

title: No Headline
description: Steven Crist on Horse Racing TRAINER MAKES ART OF CLAIMING HORSES

title: PRIESTS SAY POPE WILL WARN POLES OF HATE'S HIGH PRICE
description: Pope John Paul II came home to Poland today on a journey that many in the Vatican consider more personal than any of his 17 other foreign trips.

title: Timex Complaint
description: The Timex Corporation has filed a complaint with the United States International Trade Commission contending that imported watches from several watch companies are infringing the company's patent and trademark for its ''Command Bar'' digital watches, which feature a front-push bar that replaces side buttons. Last year, watches with the Command-Bar accounted for more than half of Timex's digital watch sales.

title: TRIP IN AFRICA ON THE ZAMBESI EXPRESS
description: THIS week's installment on the BBC series ''Great Railway Journeys of the World,'' being shown tonight at 9 on Channel 13, takes an unusual turn. Michael Wood, the writer and narrator, follows the route of the Zambesi Express, starting in South Africa's Capetown and ending, some 1,000 miles to the north, at Victoria Falls in Pretoria. The time is late 1979, when blacks and whites were still battling for Rhodesia, which would later become Zimbabwe. Whatever happens, Mr. Wood observes at the outset, ''the journey will be unrepeatable.''

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE sixth annual New York Women's Jazz Festival, which began last Sunday at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center and has continued through the week at the Jazz Gallery, 55 West 19th Street, will close this Sunday evening with a concert at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, by the Janice Robinson Orchestra and the Abbey Lincoln Quintet.

title: 'African Textiles'
description: ''African Textiles,'' a survey of Africa's traditional fabrics and cultures, is on view at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, through Dec. 4.

title: Grumman Stock Split
description: The Grumman Corporation said today that its board had authorized a 2-for-1 stock split and that the company would hold a shareholders' meeting July 21 to vote on a proposed increase in authorized shares to 80 million from 30 million.

title: New Bid for Sotheby's Referred to Merger Unit
description: A bid for the embattled auction house Sotheby Parke Bernet by the Michigan real-estate developer A. Alfred Taubman been referred to Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission for approval, a Department of Trade official said today.

title: BALLESTEROS SHARES LEAD ON 69
description: Seve Ballesteros gave further indications today that this may be the year he dominates golf. With a 69, 2 under par on the 6,972-yard Oakmont Country Club Course, the 26-year-old Spaniard earned a share of the lead with John Mahaffey and Bob Murphy in the opening round of the 83d United States Open.

title: Man and Nature Producing Ever-Changing Canvass
description: T he Friday-getaway motorcade, backed up at the Holland Tunnel, will find an 80-by-90-foot expanse of red paint today on the Broome Street wall of the parking garage at Varick Street.

title: Addendum
description: * Natural History magazine is increasing its circulation rate base 1.1 percent, to 465,000, from 460,000, effective with the October issue. The ad rate for a four-color page will increase 3.5 percent, and a black-and-white, 4.9 percent.

title: LABATT, JOHN, LTD reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-After special charges of $3.5 million for the latest year and $3.5 million for a year ago. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Cosmos Face Team America; Two Teams Meet for First Time
description: As the Cosmos and Team America prepared for their first meeting ever Friday night, the talk on both teams focused on whether those players from last year's Cosmos who joined Team America - and those who didn't -made the right decisions.

title: FAMILIES PRACTICE TOGETHERNESS IN RENTED HOT TUBS
description: To Crawford Brown, who works in municipal financing and soaks on Friday evenings, ''It's the perfect transition into the weekend.'' Arlene and Robert Gilbert, who prefer Sunday evenings after a weekend atop horses, bicycles or skis, consider them ''the ideal place to relax, catch up on reading periodicals and practice yoga between soaks.''

title: Will Tuesday Be Super?
description: I t seemed good political strategy at the time. In 1980, Carter-Mondale campaign strategists, wanting to give President Carter a chance to make a quick rebound should he lose the New Hampshire primary to his Democratic challenger, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, arranged to move up the dates of three Southern state primaries to one week behind the New Hampshire contest. Thus ''Super Tuesday'' was created in the South, with voters in Georgia, Alabama and Florida expressing their Presidential preference the same day.

title: Indiana's High Court Rejects Case of Dead Retarded Infant
description: The Indiana Supreme Court refused to decide whether a severely handicapped baby should have been denied food and medical care, saying the issue was moot because the child had died.

title: Idaho Bond Issue Is Priced at Par
description: A $35 million Idaho Housing Finance Agency issue was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers & Company with yields ranging from 5.56 percent to 9.875 percent.

title: Japan Pagers Held Dumped
description: Certain telephone pagers made in Japan are being sold in the United States at less than half the price that the manufacturers charge at home, the Commerce Department says.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SIBERIA plays the role in Soviet economic thinking today that the Great Frontier played in American thinking during the 19th century. The vastness of Siberian space seems limitless. A flight from Moscow to Yakutsk crosses six time zones, and there are still more than a thousand miles to go before reaching the Kamchatka Peninsula and the Pacific Ocean.

title: Burns Soars To a 10 on Crucial Hole
description: OAKMONT, Pa. E ven in his amateur days, George Burns was no admirer of the United States Golf Association. And as recently as the 1981 United States Open at Merion, in which Burns tied for second, he thought he overheard a U.S.G.A. official saying something derogatory about one of his shots; he reacted angrily with an insult that could be heard several yards away.

title: IF IT'S SUMMER, IT'S TIME TO CATCH A FILM FESTIVAL
description: ONE of the joys of summer is slinking into a cool, dark movie house and being transported away from eye-blinding sun, hot sidewalks and soggy clothes into a world where only the flickering screen images suffer. Which may be why film festivals particularly thrive at this time of year.

title: SENATORS REJECT A WITHHOLDING OF INTEREST TAX
description: The Senate voted tonight to repeal a 1982 tax law that would require financial institutions to withhold 10 percent of the interest and dividends paid to most of their customers beginning July 1.

title: PLAN FOR BUDGET COMPROMISE DISAPPROVED BY WHITE HOUSE
description: The White House threw cold water today on a Federal budget being drafted on Capitol Hill, but House and Senate negotiators continued their efforts to reach a compromise that both chambers would accept.

title: 11.02 GAIN SENDS DOW TO 1,248.30
description: New data indicating that the economic recovery is a strong one sent stock prices sharply higher yesterday in the heaviest trading in more than a month, with the widely followed Dow Jones industrial average closing at its second consecutive record high.

title: ETHNIC DIFFERENCES FOUND TO AFFECT NURSING HOMES
description: A problem has arisen in nursing homes in New York City because most patients are non-Hispanic whites and most attendants are black or Hispanic, conferees at a meeting on care for the elderly agreed yesterday.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKED ABOUT STORY OF THEFT FROM CARTER IN 1980
description: A House subcommittee chairman, declaring that ''there may be possible violations of criminal law'' at stake, called on three senior Reagan Administration officials today to disclose any role they might have had in a reported theft of a briefing book from the White House under Jimmy Carter in 1980.

title: HARTFORD HOUSE PASSES MEASURE TO RAISE TAXES
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives, overcoming computer and political breakdowns, tonight approved $241 million in new and higher taxes.

title: CLIFFORD T. WEIHMAN
description: Clifford Tobias Weihman, a founder of the Smith-Weihman Company, vegetable-oil importers in New York City, died Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: NEW WINDS BLOWING ON ECOLOGICAL FRONT
description: Although it is still less than a month since he took over the Environmental Protection Agency, William D. Ruckelshaus already appears to have charted his own course for the battered agency.

title:
ISSUE IN POLISH DEBT: HOW TO BORROW AGAIN;
Economic Analysis
description: The opening moves were made this week in the latest match between the Polish Government and international banks. Both sides met Monday and Tuesday in Vienna to talk about rescheduling about $2.5 billion in bank debt due this year that the Poles say they cannot pay.

title: WORTHINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The 1982 share earnings have been adjusted for a 4-for-3 stock split paid March 31.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Net income represents net investment income.

title: Brazilian Loan Needs
description: Carlos Langoni, president of Brazil's central bank, said yesterday that Brazil would need more bank loans than the $4.4 billion already promised for this year, and that short-term financing needs for 1984 are now under discussion.

title: Shell Plans to Drill 3 to 5 Wells at Sea
description: The Shell Oil Company said it would proceed with a plan to drill exploratory wells at extreme depths in the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of New Jersey, despite a continuing decline in offshore oil exploration. The company said it would drill from three to five wells beginning next month in 6,800 feet of water 125 miles southeast of Atlantic City.

title: FRIDAY, JUNE 17, 1983; The Economy
description: The Senate voted, 86 to 4, to repeal tax withholding on income from interest and dividends. The bill now goes to conference, where three provisions meant to deter a threatened Reagan veto must be reconciled with a differing House version. The withholding, adopted just nine months ago as part of a move to cut budget deficits, was to take effect July 1. But if Congress fails to complete action by then, the start of withholding will be delayed a month. (Page A1.)

title: REPAIRING CHINA TIES
description: After a decade of steady progress, there has been a sharp deterioration in relations between China and the United States. Unless this decline is reversed, it could have adverse consequences not only for the peace and prosperity of Asia but the world. Therefore, it is important to understand what has gone wrong and what needs to be done about it.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
STRICTER MATH STANDARDS ARE BACKED BY REGENTS
description: New York State's Board of Regents today unanimously recommended toughening mathematics requirements for all high school students. Under the plan at least two years of math would be required in high school.

title: LAWYERS FOR THE POOR
description: America is the most attorney-crammed nation on earth. There are 600,000 lawyers -one for every 400 people - and the law schools churn out 35,000 new lawyers a year. But most of this talent is and will be placed at the disposal of rich people and wealthy institutions. For the poor, there is relatively little.

title: GCI INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SUPREME COURT JUSTICE IN QUEENS IS REBUKED FOR JAILING PROSECUTOR
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens was admonished yesterday by a judicial review agency for ''gross abuse of power.'' The justice, W. Eugene Sharpe, improperly cited a prosecutor, Seymour Roth, for contempt of court and ordered him jailed in a detention pen until a prosecution witness, a police officer, arrived in court, according to the findings of the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: Reagan Sees Nicaraguan
description: Jose Antonio Jarquin Lopez, Nicaragua's new Ambassador, was among five foreign envoys who presented their credentials to President Reagan at the White House today. The new ambassador's visit, which was short and in accord with traditional diplomatic practice, was without incident. The other envoys were from Spain, Benin, Lebanon and Finland.

title: Riot Police and Youths Clash in Soweto
description: Riot policemen and stone-throwing youths clashed in Soweto today, and cars were set on fire as blacks commemorated the anniversary of the 1976 riots here.

title: PRESIDENT AND A STUDENT INDIRECTLY DEBATE ARMS
description: President Reagan and a 17-year-old student engaged in an oblique debate over the arms race today. The President emphasized the lessons of the past while the student was concerned with the fragility of the future.

title: Braniff Meeting
description: Representatives of Braniff Interntional, its creditor groups and the Hyatt Corporation are to meet Sunday in Washington, D.C. to nail down the details of Hyatt's latest plan to revive the bankrupt airline. Committees representing most of Braniff's secured and unsecured creditors are expected to recommend approval of the $70 million Hyatt plan, which would revive Braniff as a smaller airline, using 30 planes and about 2,000 of the airline's laid-off workers. The plans still faces opposition from Anthony Walsh, spokesman for the committee representing Braniff's secured bond holders, who are owed $100 million.

title: IN MEXICO: ILL ECONOMY, ILL WEATHER, NOW ILL HEALTH
description: The effects of an unexpected drought, coupled with shortages of imported medicines and cutbacks in Government spending on health, are making health care in Mexico more precarious than ever, according to doctors and health officials here.

title: NEW DEAL BANK ACTS TURN 50
description: In the last year, more American banks - 42 - have failed than in any other 12-month period since World War II. But the nation's depositors go about their business with hardly a worry, let alone resorting to the runs on banks that plagued the financial system half a century ago.

title: BLOOMSDAY MARATHON ON WEST SIDE
description: Some came because they had read ''Ulysses'' so often it was as familiar and as complex as a beloved friend, and some came because they had never managed to get beyond the first chapter, but were still hoping for inspiration. Some happened in by accident, and some had been planning it for months. Most came because it was Bloomsday.

title: PAYMENTS DEFICIT NARROWS
description: A big drop in oil imports helped narrow the deficit in the United States balance of payments to $3.05 billion in the first quarter, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Nature Walk Sunday
description: Dragonflies, turtles, swans and bass are only a few of the creatures that may be seen Sunday during a nature walk around Van Cortland Lake in Van Cortland Park in the Bronx.

title: DISORDER HAS STRUCK 1,552
description: According to authorities at the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, as of June 7 the collection of cancers and infections associated with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, had struck 1,552 people around the country, killing 597. They say that no one with AIDS has been cured. Almost half the cases have occurred in New York City, and a fifth have been diagnosed in San Francisco and Los Angeles combined.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. The Yankees open a home stand that will last only for the weekend. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. Keith Hernandez makes his Met debut, and he'll have to settle for No.17 on his uniform. No.37, which he wore at St. Louis, was long ago retired by the Mets in honor of Casey Stengel. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Football Generals vs. Los Angeles Express, at Giants Stadium, 9 P.M. Here's a chance to see Jojo Townsell, the wide receiver who was drafted on the third round by the Jets but who decided instead on the United States Football League. In his second game with the Express, last weekend, he made 11 receptions for 174 yards. (Radio - WOR, 710; 9 P.M.) Stallions vs. Chicago Blitz, at Birmingham, Ala. (Television - Channel 7, 9 P.M.) Golf United States Open, second round, at Oakmont, Pa. (Television -ESPN, 2:30 P.M., live, and Channel 7, at halftime of U.S.F.L. game, taped highlights.)

title: HOUSING: IGNORED MIDDLE-INCOME EARNINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: STRAWBERRY IS IN, LATE BUT LUSCIOUS
description: Delayed a week by the early-spring rains, the strawberry crop is now ready for harvesting by pick-it-yourselfers on farms around the metropolitan area.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Banker on L.I. Kills Wife And Himself
description: A Chase Manhattan Bank vice president asked his estranged wife to meet him to talk about arrangements for divorce, then stabbed her to death with a steak knife and killed himself the same way, the police said today.

title: Panel Votes Funds For Jersey Cleanup
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved $4 million in Federal funds for the cleanup of radioactive wastes buried in Wayne and Maywood, N.J.

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for qtr to May 21.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $300,000.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL AMERICAN LEAGUE - Lee Mac- P hail, president, announced that the own- e rs, in a mail vote, unanimously approved t he transfer of 49 percent of the ownership o f the Kansas City Royals to Avron Fogle- m an. CINCINNATI (NL) - Placed Dan D riessen, first baseman, on the 15-day dis- a bled list, retroactive to June 11.

title: ATLANTIC METROPOLITAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After charges of $3.1 million for the quarter and $3.2 million for the 9 months for allowances for losses from litigation and a credit of $1 million for the 9 months from the recapture of loss reserve for real estate. c-Net income including gains of $799,000 for the quarter and $2.4 million for the 9 months from the recapture of loss reserve for real estate. Year-ago results have been restated for adjustments to loss reserve.

title: Germany's G.N.P. Up
description: West Germany's gross national product grew five-tenths of 1 percent in this year's first quarter from the final quarter of 1982, but recovery is not yet assured, Karl Heinrich Oppenlaender, president of the Institute for Economic Research, said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CARUSO. By Howard Greenfeld. Illustrat- ed. 275 pages. G.P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

title: Overseer Opposed For New Center
description: Two figures in the construction of New York City's Convention Center said yesterday that they opposed a developer's offer to oversee completion of the project for free.

title: Lehman Band Concert
description: The Lehman College Community Band will give the first of five free outdoor concerts Sunday at 6 P.M. in the garden at the college, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue in the Bronx.

title: Celtics Seek Sparrow
description: The Celtics' drive to sign free agents away from the Knicks continued yesterday when Boston tendered an offer sheet to Rory Sparrow, the speedy guard who bolstered New York's defense and playmaking ability last season.

title: PILOTS USE DEVICE TO AVOID ACCIDENT
description: Experimental equipment designed to avert midair collisions gave a real-world demonstration of its potential recently when pilots using it unexpectedly received guidance to avoid a dangerously close airplane.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
The Court Draws the Line
description: In forthright terms, the Supreme Court has now turned back a sneak attack on Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that declared a woman's right to decide whether to give birth to an unwanted child. Rather than challenge that basic right directly, anti-abortion forces asked only that the Court approve a few rules, like:

title: Money Fund Assets Down
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined by $794 million, to $168.6 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. It was the 28th consecutive decline for the funds.

title: Cut Hunger, Not Food Spending
description: This week mayors from all over the country, speaking at the U.S. Conference of Mayors in Denver, told of hunger in their cities - and of how their cities were helping the hungry.

title: Bill Sackter, a Retarded Man Portrayed in TV Movie, Dies
description: Bill Sackter, a mildly retarded man whose life was portrayed by Mickey Rooney in the television movie ''Bill,'' was found dead today at his apartment. He was 70 years old.

title: Pittston Refinery
description: The Pittston Company of Greenwich, Conn., said it had discontinued efforts to develop a 250,000-barrel-a-day oil refinery here to process foreign oil. The company said that the increase in estimated costs from $350 million to $1 billion and changes in world oil market conditions since the project was proposed 10 years ago ''have made it uneconomic'' to build the refinery. Pittston, a coal-producing conglomerate, had planned to link the refinery with a supertanker terminal in the deep-water port here.

title: WHEN FREE-TRADER REAGAN WINKS AT CONGRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: National news is on A10-20, A28, B6 and D16-17. Southern Baptists Reject Nuclear Freeze Move

title: A Jazz Night For Jo Jones
description: There will be a benefit for Jo Jones, the drummer with the original Count Basie orchestra, who has influenced two generations of drummers, beginning tomorrow night at 8 and running until 4 A.M. or so at Swing Plaza, Irving Place at 15th Street. Mr. Jones has been ill for some time, and the proceeds will help pay his medical expenses.

title: JIM WALTER CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,250,000 for the quarter and $13,865,000 for the 9 months.

title: First Nissan Truck Produced
description: The first Nissan truck made in America was driven off the assembly line today to mark the start of production at the Japanese automobile maker's $660 million plant here. The truck, which broke a banner bearing the date, was driven by Marvin T. Runyon, president of Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation, U.S.A., to the cheers of 1,300 Nissan workers.

title: Indian Denounces Watt On Eagle Indictments
description: The indictments of dozens of people suspected of killing or selling bald eagles and other endangered birds for profit were staged for political purposes, one of those charged says.

title: Black College Drive Begins
description: President Reagan, in a brief ceremony marking the beginning of the United Negro College Fund drive, today passed along a $1 million check from the R.J. Reynolds tobacco company.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
New Vote Sought
description: The owners of a United States Football League expansion franchise for San Diego may get another chance to use Jack Murphy Stadium for the team's home games. On Tuesday, the San Diego City Council voted, 5-3, to prevent the team from using the stadium, but Deputy Mayor Bill Cleator, a member of the council who supported the U.S.F.L. team's use of the stadium, said he would press for a rehearing on the matter within 10 days.

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The results in U.S. dollars were translated yesterday at the foreign exchange rate in Tokyo of 242 yen to the dollar. The share earnings reflect American Depositary Shares.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS COMPLETES DEAL TO MOVE TO BATTERY PARK
description: The American Express Company yesterday sold its office building in downtown Manhattan to a Canadian development company, which will build a new American Express headquarters in Battery Park City.

title: SAFECARD SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SENATE IN JERSEY BACKS EXECUTION USING INJECTIONS
description: The New Jersey Senate approved a bill today that would make lethal injection the state's official method of capital punishment.

title: Logical Challenges Coleco's 'Adam'
description: A maker of computer systems that can be programmed in nontechnical English has filed a trademark infringement suit seeking to bar Coleco Industries from calling its new home computer system ''Adam.''

title: Sinkhole Swallows 2-Story Building
description: An underground water main ruptured today and created an enormous sinkhole that swallowed a two-story tavern-apartment building, authorities said.

title: KOCH OPENS BUS LANE ON 5TH AND HAILS CITY TRAFFIC EFFORTS
description: Mayor Koch called the city's recent efforts to reduce severe traffic congestion in midtown Manhattan an ''enormous success'' as he opened a special ''red zone'' bus lane down Fifth Avenue yesterday.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $2.5 million. The income from discontinued operations in year-ago period includes earnings from resources distributed to Newhall Investment Properties and Newhall Resources in March 1983.

title: MARTIN IS CONFIDENT AS YANKEES WIN
description: Billy Martin, the Yankees' manager, and George Steinbrenner, the principal owner, held their first meeting of the season early this morning. According to Martin, they emerged from it still optimistic about the future of the Yankees, who had split their first 60 games.

title: Panel Approves a Cut In Milk Price Supports
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today approved legislation lowering milk price supports, thus clearing the way for Congressional action later this month on the first reduction in these supports since the early 1960's.

title: 7 Hurt After Fight At L.I. Carnival
description: A young man fought with carnival employees early today, got into his car and ran down four of them, the police said. Seven people were reported injured.

title: SERVICE FOR LESS BUT NOT FOR NOTHING
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; Century 21 Switches to McCann
description: Erickson in the same city.

title: KEAN'S TOWN MEETING: LOCAL ISSUES STAND OUT
description: In Saudi Arabia, it is known as the majlis, the day when any petitioner may enter the court of the King for an audience. Here they called it a town meeting, and it took place in a pleasant, if altogether unimperial, elementary school. Yet the object remained constant: the Governor meeting the governed, with the layers of ministers and secretaries stripped away.

title: Down the Ladder
description: Joe Charboneau, who has been working his way down the baseball ladder since being named the American League's rookie of the year in 1980, has found a new rung after being released last week by the Buffalo Bisons of the Class AA Eastern League. Charboneau, who batted .289 and hit 23 home runs for the Indians in 1980, has joined the Buffalo Voyageurs, one of eight amateur teams in the city's MUNY League.

title: Israeli Consults in U.S.  On Lebanon Pullback
description: David Kimche, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, began consultations here today on plans for redeployment and partial withdrawal of Israeli forces in Lebanon.

title: SENATORS VOTE TO INCREASE PAY AND DEFER LECTURE FEE LIMIT
description: The Senate voted today to raise its members' salaries 15 percent and to permit them to continue to earn unlimited income from speeches and articles through the end of the year.

title: POP: RAY CONTRERAS'S LATINIZED ROCK
description: Ray Contreras, the 22-year-old singer and songwriter who played Chino in the 1979 Broadway revival of ''West Side Story,'' has put together a band and developed an act designed to appeal to a mainstream pop-music audience. On Wednesday, Mr. Contreras, leading a quintet that featured a Latin percussionist, opened a two-night engagement at the Other End.

title: OF DIFFICULTIES FOR HOUSTON'S MAYOR
description: Ten days ago, when Houston's sanitation workers threw up an illegal picket line in a wildcat protest of work rules, Mayor Kathy Whitmire did what a lot of mayors would do under the circumstances. She called the police.

title: Art Classes in Parks
description: Tomorrow is the last day for those 4 to 13 years old to register for free ''Summer in the Parks'' art classes sponsored by the Children's Art Carnival School at 62 Hamilton Terrace. The program lets youngsters design kites, banners, puppets and silk-screen designs and to participate in other arts projects in city parks.

title: THE REGION
description: Jack R. Clarcq will never question the principle that every vote counts.

title: ALBANY REPORTED READY TO INCREASE WORKERS' BENEFITS
description: Negotiators for Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have reached an agreement to increase unemployment insurance, disability and workers compensation benefits, people familiar with the talks said today.

title: MARIO CARDINAL CASARIEGO, 74, OF GUATEMALA, DIES
