description: Mario Cardinal Casariego, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Guatemala, and the first clergyman elevated to Cardinal in Central America, died of a heart attack Wednesday, a spokesman here said. He was 74 years old.

title: PLANE CRASHES IN MILITARY EXERCISE IN HAWAII, KILLING ALL 14 ABOARD
description: A plane participating in a military exercise crashed on a remote, treacherous section of Kauai Island early today, killing all 14 people aboard, the Navy said.

title: Koch Knows His Audience
description: M ayor Koch surveyed the city's fiscal situation for the Citizens Budget Commission at their Waldorf-Astoria dinner Wednesday. ''Some people,'' he said, deadpan, ''months ago warned that it might be too optimistic to assume that the city will even be able to balance its fiscal 1983 budget, let alone have a surplus.''

title: GAF Hearing Set
description: A court hearing on an appeal of a ruling on a GAF Corporation proxy vote has been rescheduled to Aug.8 from July 11. Samuel J. Heyman, who said he had received 58.3 percent of the GAF shareholder votes at the April 28 annual meeting, is appealing a ruling in the United States District Court requiring a resolicitation of proxies. The court ruled that Mr. Heyman had failed to include relevant information in his proxy material.

title: Bell Unit in West
description: The parent corporation for the five Middle Western Bell subsidiaries will be called Ameritech, William Weiss, chairman-designate of the new unit, said. Ameritech, which stands for the American Information Technologies Corporation, will become the parent company of Illinois Bell, Indiana Bell, Michigan Bell, Ohio Bell and Wisconsin Telephone after Jan.1, when the operating subsidiaries are separated from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Ameritech is also creating a new subsidiary to offer expanded mobile telephone service.

title: Power Unit May Default
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System is considering defaulting on the $2.25 billion bond for two nuclear power plants and perhaps declaring bankruptcy.

title: LIVING UP TO DIAMOND JIM
description: There are still men around who buy diamond bracelets for women who are not their wives, but alas, the really generous days have long disappeared. Early in the century, Diamond Jim Brady would casually toss a bunch of baubles in the center of a table, so that each of the women at his parties would have a little memento. These days, the only things that are tossed casually are play money and little pendants of fake brilliants, even at a party celebrating the spirit of Diamond Jim.

title: German Insolvencies
description: Corporate insolvencies in West Germany rose 13.4 percent, to 4,301, in the first four months of 1983 from a year earlier, the Government said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday about the Legal Aid Society omitted an aspect of New York City's response to a request for help in handling criminal appeals cases. Mayor Koch authorized the society to hire 15 more lawyers.

title: DODGERS AND PENA TOP BRAVES
description: Alejando Pena, who missed his last two scheduled starts for Los Angeles because of migraine headaches, hurled a seven-hitter for eight and two-thirds innings tonight, and Steve Yeager drove in two runs as the Dodgers defeated the Atlanta Braves, 6-1.

title: TRADE SHIFT ON CHINA SEEN NEAR
description: A decision to put China into an export category that would allow it to receive more sophisticated equipment and technology is likely to be announced within days by the White House, Administration officials said today.

title: THE BARD AND POLITICS
description: It's been front and center stage for Shakespeare and education much of this week as politicians have made their rounds of campaign summer stock.

title: Gunmen Said to Kill 15 In Lebanese Port City
description: At least 15 people were killed and 20 wounded in the northern port of Tripoli today when gunmen opened fire on pedestrians with machine guns, according to the state-run Beirut radio. The reason for the shootings, which were apparently random, and the identity of the assailants were not clear.

title: OPERA: THE MET'S 'BOHEME' IN BRONX BOTANICAL GARDEN
description: AT the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx on Wednesday night, it hardly seemed like a cold Chistmas Eve in Paris's Latin Quarter. And in the humid weather, it hardly seemed necessary for a Bohemian poet to keep himself warm by burning the pages of his roommate's book. But such were the ironies of the setting for the Metropolitan Opera's first concert performance of Puccini's ''Boheme'' in the parks this summer, and the Met's first presentation in the Botanical Garden since 1972.

title: MERIT PAY FOR TEACHERS VS. SINGLE SALARY SCHEDULE
description: Hardly anyone would have thought it possible just a few months ago that a matter seemingly so mundane as the salary schedule of schoolteachers would become a matter of debate among those contending to be elected President of the United States in 1984, but it has happened.

title: Music of Puerto Rico
description: Pepe Castillo and his group, Estampa Criolla, will offer folkloristic music of Puerto Rico at the Alternative Museum in TriBeCa tomorrow night at 8.

title: POPE, IN WARSAW, MAKES A FIRM PLEA FOR THE 'WRONGED'
description: Pope John Paul II returned to Poland today to chants of ''Solidarity, Solidarity!'' and almost immediately identified himself with his homeland's political troubles.

title: Canadian National
description: Canadian National Railways will merge the administration of its money-losing trucking and express divisions and move from Quebec to Toronto, the state-owned transportation company said. Eventually, there will be a full integration of the two divisions, company officials said.

title: People
description: * Robert E. Drinkwater named a partner and general manager of Brainreserve.

title: Dr. Minter to Take Post At Lehman College
description: D r. Thomas K. Minter, who was a leading candidate to replace Frank J. Macchiarola as Schools Chancellor, will return to the borough of his birth as a full professor and dean of professional studies at Lehman College in the Bronx.

title: Shergar's Owners to Get $10.6 Million in Insurance
description: A spokesman for Lloyd's said today that a total of $10.6 million in insurance would be paid to some of the owners of the stolen race horse Shergar.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1983 and a 3-for-2 stock split in October 1982.

title: Officer Is Dismissed in Arrest Of Man Who Died in Custody
description: One police officer was dismissed and four others were suspended today for their roles in the arrest of Ernest Lacy, who died in their custody in 1981.

title: 27 in Messenger
description: Twenty-seven 3-year-olds have been entered at Roosevelt Raceway for tomorrow's Messenger Stakes, the first leg of the pacing triple crown. The race has been divided into three heats, with the top three pacers in each qualifying for the final. Salute Hanover is favored in the first heat, Hamilton R H in the second and Ralph Hanover in the third.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO SPEECH REVIEWING SOVIET UNION'S FOREIGN POLICY
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko before the Supreme Soviet yesterday, as distributed in translation by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

title: NU-TECH INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
STIEGLITZ SHOW AT THE MET, THE ESSENCE OF GREATNESS
description: FOR all his influence on 20th-century art and photography, Alfred Stieglitz has remained something of a shadowy figure. This is partly because of the diversity of his accomplishments, partly because of his complex personality and partly because of the frequency with which the photographs he made over 50 years have been exhibited. No doubt his achievements will continue to seem diverse and his personality complex, but with ''Alfred Stieglitz,'' the exhibition that opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, we can begin to comprehend the greatness of his photography unhampered by legend.

title: Assailants in Istanbul Kill 2 And Wound 27 Near Bazaar
description: Terrorists detonated five bombs in front of the ancient Grand Bazaar today and fired into a crowd, killing at least two pedestrians and wounding 27 people, the police reported. One of the attackers was killed.

title: REAGAN URGES CONGRESS TO NULLIFY SUPREME COURT'S ABORTION RULINGS
description: President Reagan, in an unusual comment on a Supreme Court decision, expressed ''profound disappointment'' today at the Court's reaffirmation of the constitutional right to abortion.

title: Indonesian Ferry Sinks
description: More than 80 Indonesians were feared dead after an inter-island ferry carrying schoolchildren sank in the Banda Sea southeast of Sulawesi, the official press agency Antara said today.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET OFFERS DEBUTS IN 'OTHER DANCES'
description: THERE are times when a change of cast seems to transform a ballet. One of those performances occurred on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, when the New York City Ballet presented Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances'' with role debuts by Kyra Nichols and Sean Lavery. It should come as no surprise to anyone who follows the company that the two danced superbly. But this was one of those electric performances when all but stage time seemed to have stopped.

title: PRO AT THE WALLPAPER STORE
description: year-old younger brother of Lanny Wadkins was permitted to play a practice round by himself.

title: PUBLISHING: LITERARY AGENT AS EDITOR-PACKAGER
description: MOST new publishing programs are greeted with an industry 21-gun salute, but the reaction to the announcement by Pocket Books this week that it was starting a science fiction and fantasy line called Starscope sounded more like a shot across the bow.

title: A Leading Banker In Texas to Retire
description: Paul Mason, a well-known Texas banker, announced yesterday that he planned to retire at the end of the year. Mr. Mason, 62 years old, is chairman, president and chief executive of the First United Bancorporation, a holding company that operates the First National Bank of Fort Worth.

title: More Than Academic
description: When he lost his academic eligibility two years ago after college officials accused him of getting a friend to take an English competency test for him, Rick Rebozzi, a Boise State quarterback, was upset that the school had revealed details of his academic problems. Contending that the disclosures violated his civil rights, Rebozzi, whose stand-in had reportedly failed the test, filed a $35,000 damage suit against Boise State. Last week the suit was dismissed from a Federal court in Idaho, but, according to his lawyer, Rebozzi plans to pursue the litigation by filing an amended complaint.

title: East Side trattoria and TriBeCa cafe.
description: FROM the same energetic Lattanzi family that gave us the Trastevere restaurants on 83d and 84th Streets, comes Erminia, on 83d Street, between Second and Third Avenues. Opened at the end of April, this trattoria is named for and is said to belong to the mother of Paul (the chef), Maurizio (dining-room manager) and Joseph (accounts and finances). Although the dishes differ from specialties at the two Trasteveres, the same lusty and original style prevails. The biggest difference is in main courses, broiled Tuscan style over a wood fire at Erminia.

title: COUNTDOWN STARTS FOR 2D LAUNCHING OF SHUTTLE CHALLENGER TOMORROW
description: Launching crews began the countdown today for the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger, which will carry two communications satellites, a score of scientific experiments, a colony of carpenter ants and the first American woman to go into space.

title: INDIA CANCELS PUNJAB RAIL SERVICE FOR TODAY TO THWART SIKH PROTEST
description: With Sikhs threatening to disrupt rail traffic Friday in the northern state of Punjab, the Indian Government today canceled all rail service there for the day.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday on summer day camps and classes for children misstated the schedule for Creative Playtime at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. Classes will be held three times a week.

title: Sidney Jacobi Is Dead at 77; A Former S.I. Assemblyman
description: Sidney Jacobi, a former Republican Assemblyman from Staten Island and a former member of the New York City Tax Commission, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home on Staten Island.

title: Benefit Aboard Barge
description: Judith Jamison, Maurice Hines and other Broadway stars will perform at a benefit Sunday from 7 to 11 P.M., on board the Purple Barge, anchored at Pier 40, Houston Street and the Hudson River.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THE waiters were having a pretty hard time balancing the trays of C hampagne as the Circle Line boat took off for the Statue of Liberty T uesday night, but they didn't have to worry long. The Champagne ran o ut, and the only thing left to amuse the 400 thirsty passengers b efore they disembarked was the fireboat chugging along, shooting up r ed, white and blue spray in honor of Flag Day.

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $3.1 million, or 22 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, from the sale of property.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS BILL LIMITING JULY TAX CUT
description: The Democratic-controlled House Ways and Means Committee today approved, by an 18-to-15 vote, a bill that would limit the July 1 income tax cut. The bill was proposed by Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.

title: AUSTRALIA ASKS U.S. FOR MORE TRADE COOPERATION
description: Prime Minister Robert J. Hawke of Australia, visiting New York, called on the United States yesterday to work more closely with his country and other Pacific nations to preserve the world trading system.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aloha Airlines, Honolulu, has named Randy M. Rogers vice president of finance and treasurer, and Ramiro L. Montes controller.

title: Bridge: Reality Sometimes Upsets Theoretical Generalization
description: If a partnership locates a six-three major-suit fit and then retreats into a five-three minor-suit combination, something has obviously gone wrong. But theoretical generalizations like this have a way of being dislocated by the ironies of practical play. As evidence, consider the diagramed deal, from the final of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship early this month.

title: Woman, 32, Seized In Banker's Killing
description: A woman was arrested in Puerto Rico yesterday in the killing of a Buffalo bank official in Manhattan, the police said.

title: CONNER HOMES CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
FACTORY USE UP TO 72%
description: Factories in the United States operated at 72 percent of capacity last month, the highest level since February 1982, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: WHITNEY MUSEUM OFFERS A 2D LOOK AT GRANT WOOD
description: THE name Grant Wood is still good for a snicker in respectable art circles. Though this regionalist painter (1891-1942) won fame in the 1930's for his corn-fed but well-turned and sometimes funny scenes from heartland America, received opinion today ranks him along with Maxfield Parrish and Norman Rockwell as superficial cutesifiers of American life. Even at the height of his reputation, Wood had plenty of detractors. In 1935, his landscapes were assailed by the critic Lewis Mumford as ''unmitigatedly bad,'' and the regionalist, American Scene approach he represented - along with John Steuart Curry, Thomas Hart Benton and others - was described by the modernist painter Stuart Davis as ''reactionary'' and ''sentimental.''

title: BROWN-FORMAN DISTILLERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.

description: Prices of Government securities surged yesterday for the second consecutive day and yields declined. Institutional investors apparently concluded that the Federal Reserve would not reduce the availability of credit despite expectations of a new surge in the money supply.

title: THE MULTIPLE FACETS OF SENTENCE DISPARITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ATCO LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
TO START CORRECTING $1 BILLION WORTH OF FOOD STAMP ERRORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Generals Try Another Kicker; Roveto Joins Team
description: When the New Jersey Generals play the Los Angeles Express Friday night at Giants Stadium, their kicker will be a newcomer named John Roveto, who had to be persuaded to leave an automobile tire store in Atlanta to return to pro football.

title: Market Place; Elliott Wave Is Superbullish
description: WHERE is the Dow Jones industrial average heading? ''It will reach or exceed 1,400 before any correction of 10 percent or more occurs,'' Robert R. Prechter predicted yesterday. ''The stock market is only beginning a huge advance that will carry the Dow to 3,600 or higher between 1987 and 1990.''

title: CUOMO SAYS THE STATES SHOULD HAVE VETO POWER OVER REACTORS
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed that states be given the power to block nuclear power plants by refusing to develop offsite emergency plans, according to a letter to key Washington legislators made public today.

title: Article 239007 -- No Title
description: A Federal study commission recommended today that the Government pay $20,000 to each of the 60,000 surviving Japanese-Americans who were forced out of their homes on the West Coast and held in detention camps in World War II.

title: Kuwait Petroleum In Oil-Lease Suit
description: The Santa Fe International Corporation and its parent company, the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation, have filed a suit in United States District Court in Wilmington, Del., against the Interior Department for attempting to prevent them from owning Federal onshore oil and gas leases, Santa Fe said.

title: Mako Triumphs In Open Jumping
description: Mako, ridden by Allen Smith, won the open jumper class today as the Merrill Lynch Ox Ridge horse show opened a four-day stand at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: INGMAR BERGMAN'S 'FANNY AND ALEXANDER'
description: EVEN as you watch Ingmar Bergman's new film, ''Fanny and Alexander,'' it has that quality of enchantment that usually attaches only to the best movies in retrospect, long after you've seen them, when they've been absorbed into the memory to seem sweeter, wiser, more magical than anything ever does in its own time. This immediate resonance is the distinguishing feature of this superb film, which is both quintessential Bergman and unlike anything else he has ever done before.

title: COPPER MINES IN CHILE DEFY REGIME
description: Workers at a copper mine challenged Chile's military rule today by beginning an illegal strike, and they were immediately dismissed by the Government's copper monopoly.

title: REEVE JOINED BY PRYOR
description: SUPERMAN or ''Supe,'' as Richard Pryor has taken to calling him by the end of ''Superman III,'' which opens today at the Criterion Center and other theaters - has become a familiar figure on the screen. It's easy to take him for granted. After all, for audiences accustomed to intergalactic travel and endless technological wizardry, someone who can merely fly through the air to stop a falling elevator may not be much of a novelty anymore. Or so the makers of this sequel, which is by no means as lumbering as ''Superman,'' but not quite so sprightly as ''Superman II,'' would seem to believe.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON PAY PACKAGE
description: Here is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today to raise its pay to $69,800 and delay new limits on outside income. Senators not listed did not vote.

title: Profit Margins Up at Factories
description: Manufacturers' after-tax profits rose to an average of 3.2 cents per dollar of sales in this year's first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 26.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings have not been adjusted for a 50 percent stock distribution declared June 13.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Digicon Inc. filed for an offering of 25,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of senior subordinated notes due in 1993 and warrants to purchase 27 shares of common, through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: SIMCO STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
EUGENE L. BELISLE
description: Eugene L. Belisle, an advertising and public-relations consultant who directed the Hartford Development Commission from 1965 to 1975, died last Friday at his home in Hartford following recent surgery for a brain tumor. He was 73 years old.

title: A MAN'S PLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Agencies Win 4 Andys Each
description: Three companies tied for the title ''most honored ad agency'' last night at 19th Annual Andy Awards Presentation of the Advertising Club of New York. Each won 4 of the 43 Awards of Excellence.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
Dollar Bond Yields Are Up
description: Yields on fixed-interest dollar bonds rose between 1/4-point and 3/8-point in very quiet trading here today, dealers said.

title: Municipal Bond Prices Recover After Court Jolt
description: Prices in the municipal bond market stabilized yesterday and then rose slightly after a court decision Wednesday raised the possibility that bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System might not be repaid in full.

title: Subway art by Alex Katz.
description: THE painter Alex Katz, whose public works include a large Government-commissioned mural on permanent display at the Federal Courthouse Annex on Foley Square, has just completed a 50-foot-long standing mural for the Chicago subways. It will be installed in the Harlem Avenue station on the new O'Hare extension line outside the city when the station, which is now in operation, is finished late this summer or early in the fall.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $13,850.

title: LAOS HILL PEOPLE TRY YET AGAIN IN CALIFORNIA VALLEY
description: On the low-rent side of Highway 99 in a two-story apartment complex filled with Asian refugee families, Say Pao Moua spoke of a life in northern Laos, where he had three acres of rice paddy and several head of cattle.

title: LIMITS IN AIDING SALVADOR
description: ''Give me one regiment of my old First Division and I can clean up all Central America.'' Those were the words of a United States Army adviser in El Salvador 35 years ago - in 1948, after he had spent some months on duty as director of the Salvadoran military academy.

title: Michigan Post Is Declined
description: The New York State official chosen to head Michigan's troubled Department of Natural Resources today turned down the job. M. Peter Lanahan Jr., first deputy commissioner of New York's Department of Environmental Conservation, said he had declined the ''tremendous offer'' for personal reasons.

title: HAPPY RETURN OF DANCER WHO CHOSE TO WALK OFF
description: For Clark Tippet, a star at American Ballet Theater at 21, a dropout at 22 and now making an extraordinary comeback with the company as a principal dancer at 28, it has been a hard trip back. The discovery that made his return possible was that to dance successfully you must enjoy it.

title: Seuffert Band Opener
description: The 150th anniversary of the birth of Brahms will be celebrated by the Seuffert Band on Sunday at 3 P.M. in Forest Park, at Woodhaven Boulevard and Myrtle Avenue in Queens.

title: Carnegie-Mellon Dean To Offer New Program
description: The new dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Administration at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh plans to begin a new program, offering a two-year master's degree in conjunction with the School of Engineering.

title: Eastern Air Pilots Accept Wage Deal
description: Eastern Airlines pilots have voted overwhelmingly to forgo wage increases in exchange for the chance to acquire stock in the company, the airline said.

title: STAGE: SANDY DUNCAN WITH THE ROCKETTES
description: SANDY DUNCAN warms Radio City Music Hall with her cheerful personality. As a dancer, singer and talker, she has a natural ease and informality, facts that can be attributed to her appearances on television as well as her experience in the theater. The new Music Hall musical, ''Five-Six-Seven-Eight ... Dance!,'' directed and choreographed by Ron Field, gives Miss Duncan center stage - an enormous stage - and also carries her aloft in a reprise of ''I'm Flying'' from her Broadway success, ''Peter Pan.''

title: An Empire Builder
description: His Spectator organization in Philadelphia already operates the Spectrum arena and owns the Prism cable television service, the SpectaGuard security service and the Showcase chain of retail stores, not to mention the Flyers of the National Hockey League. But for Ed Snider, that is apparently not enough.

title: PAN AM'S FLIGHTS TO TAIWAN BRING PEKING PROTEST
description: China protested today against the resumption of flights to Taiwan by Pan American World Airways and demanded that the United States Government designate another airline to fly Pan Am's route into China.

title: MAY STARTS IN HOUSING ROSE 19.1%
description: New housing starts across the United States rose 19.1 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.79 million units, the highest level since September 1979, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Economists considered the rise convincing evidence that the economic recovery is a strong one.

title: Major sale of Judaica.
description: AN 18th-century illuminated Haggadah, a rare 13th-century manuscript by the German-Jewish scholar Mordecai Ben Hillel and a 12th-century letter written for Rabbi Moses Maimonides by one of the Spanish philosopher's students are highlights of what Sotheby Parke Bernet describes as one the most important auctions of Judaica ever held. The sale, next Thursday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. in the artauction house's York Avenue and 72d Street galleries, is expected to bring more than $2.5 million.

title: CENTRAL PARK, SUBCONTINENT FOR A DAY
description: INDIAN music, dances, foods, aromas, costumes and colors are a feast for the senses. And tomorrow, New Yorkers who are interested in or curious about things Indian will be able to feast their senses in Central Park, on the Mall near 72d Street.

title: Lawyers Will Appeal Man's Death Sentence
description: Attorneys for the first person to be sentenced to death in New Jersey in 12 years said today that they would argue that the sentence should be overturned because juries that indicted and convicted their client were unconstitutional.

title: Hernandez Trade a First Step
description: Rebuilding Mets' Goal By KEVIN DUPONT

title: AIDS SPREADS PAIN AND FEAR AMONG ILL AND HEALTHY ALIKE
description: As public awareness of the disease known as AIDS has grown in the last few months, a picture has begun to emerge of the emotional and physical agony of those afflicted and of the fear, among homosexuals and about homosexuals, that has spread around the country at a rate much faster than the disease itself.

title: Soviet Helicopter Crashes
description: A large Soviet helicopter exploded and crashed just inside the East German border today. West German border police in nearby Kassel said at least two men were aboard the MI-24 attack helicopter when it went down 200 yards from the West German border.

title: Sony Income Plunges 57%
description: The Sony Corporation, the big Japanese consumer electronics concern, today reported a 57 percent drop in earnings for its second fiscal quarter ended April 30.

title: BEHIND THE LIONS, LITERARY TRAVELERS HERE AND ABROAD
description: ''Married people should never travel together,'' George Bernard Shaw insisted in a letter. ''They blame one another for everything that goes wrong.''

title: ARO CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Friday; OFFBEAT MUSIC AT ST. JOHN
description: David Hykes and his Harmonic Choir, known for their eerie sounds, started out using Mongolian and Tibetan techniques in which a person sings more than one note at a time: each of the singers can produce soaring melodies using the harmonics above a sustained fundamental tone. Now they've found a way to do other vocal wonders too involved to explain here. But the results should be interesting among the echoes of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street, where the choir will perform tonight through Sunday at 8. The group is also adding instruments, including hammered dulcimer, guitar, clavichord, zither and Laotian mouth organ. The music, although rooted in early music of both East and West, is 20th century, most of it composed by Mr. Hykes. Tickets: $7 ($6 for students and over-65's). 'MIMEDANCE' ON BOWERY

title: WHO'S WHERE AT JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: This weekend's schedule for the sixth New York Women's Jazz Festival follows: Today: Tina Fabrik with the Ralph Dorsey Ensemble, Bryant Park, Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street, noon, free; Piano Workshop with Harold Mabern, Jazz Gallery, 55 West 19th Street, 2 P.M., $3; Noreen Gray Trio, Carmen Lundy and Trio, Jazz Gallery, 8 P.M., $5.

title: A DEBATE OVER EXTENDING RENT CONTROLS TO SMALL APARTMENT UNITS
description: Of New York City's 1.9 million rental apartments, about 23 percent are in small buildings with fewer than six units, according to city housing officials. And state officials said that of New York's total of 3.2 million rental units, 66 percent are in buildings of fewer than six units.

title: Tax Changes Seen by Regan
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that broad changes in the tax system ''will probably be necessary'' for the United States to be more competitive in world markets.

title: JAPANESE LOAN SHARKS BIGGER THAN THE BANKS
description: She was 46 but she easily looked 10 years older. Her face was drawn, and the nervousness that had caused her to lose 16 pounds began to show as she told of how she had run up what for her were enormous debts to loan sharks.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. He sponsored a bill in the New York State Assembly to protect buyers of new cars from defective vehicles, or ''lemons.'' The measure was passed by both chambers of the Legislature.

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SANTA CLAUS IN JUNE; by Sydney H. Schanberg
description: For those who labor under the naive notion that Christmas occurs only in December, I suggest a visit to the next meeting of the state's Job Incentive Board in Albany. The board is scheduled to go out of business at midnight on June 30, and it wants to give away all the gifts it can before that funeral knell sounds.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
INTERNATIONAL LEASE FINANCE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
City U. Taken Off A List of Censured
description: The American Association of University Professors removed the City University of New York from a list of schools censured for violating principles of academic freedom and tenure.

title: ADVANCE CIRCUITS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: APPETIZERS WIN OVER DESSERTS
description: It is just possible that the world of eaters is divided into those who love appetizers and those who have more affection for desserts. Rarely have I met anyone who shows equal enthusiasm for both courses, or who could not make a clear-cut choice when necessary.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Supermarkets Inc. is offering to repurchase two million of its common shares, or 17 percent, at $3.33 each; the offer expires July 29 unless extended.

title: by Thomas A. Reppetto
description: In 1978, a commission that studied sentencing in New York State presented 41 judges with actual cases and asked them to impose a ''sentence.'' The results varied greatly. For example, one defendant convicted of holding up an old man at knife point received sentences ranging from the then statutory minimum of 0-3 years to the maximum of 8 and one-third to 25. Maximum terms clustered at 5, 7, 10, 15 and 18 years. (The actual sentence was 0-5 years). Last year, a New York City Criminal Court judge offered to determine the length of a defendant's sentence by having a coin tossed in court.

title: Lewis Gains In 3 Events
description: Carl Lewis, who won the 100-meter dash and long jump in the meet in 1981 and 1982, advanced in three events tonight as the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships began.

title: SENATORS ASSERT 15% PAY RAISE IS NOT ADEQUATE
description: Despite a 15 percent pay increase, most Senators from the metropolitan region say that because of the responsibility of the job and the financial burden of running two homes, the new salary is inadequate.

title: CITIBANK IS WINNER IN CUBAN DEBT CASE
description: Citibank won a Supreme Court victory today in a dispute growing out of Cuba's expropriation of 11 Citibank branches during the Cuban revolution 23 years ago.

title: Teamsters' Defendants Denied a New Trial
description: A Federal district judge today denied a request by Roy L. Williams, the former president of the teamsters' union, three others for a new trial on bribery-conspiracy charges, saying a witness's admissions of misconduct were insufficient to overturn the convictions.

title: Sports People; Anile Becomes Scout
description: Dom Anile, the former C.W. Post football coach who has been offensive coordinator at Columbia since 1980, has become a scout for the Cleveland Browns.

title: REVISIONS ADOPTED IN INFORMATION ACT
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee has unanimously approved, with minor changes, the same revisions in the Freedom of Information Act adopted last year and intended to limit public access to documents dealing with law enforcement, national security and personal privacy.

title: No Credit to the F.T.C.
description: After eight years of research, public comment and deliberation about consumer credit, the Federal Trade Commission appears to have brought forth a mouse. It has rejected seven of nine staff recommendations to protect consumers in credit transactions. Of the two regulations accepted, one is already law in 49 states. The other is the least important of the bunch.

title: GUNS AND THE NEW YORK CITY FAMILY COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH AIR, T.W.A. IN FARE STANDOFF
description: British Airways yesterday slightly undercut Trans World Airlines' lower fares to London for next fall and winter, a move that was quickly matched by T.W.A. Both carriers also dropped requirements for advance purchases of tickets.

title: Zimbabwe Says Rebels Destroyed a Village
description: Heavily armed rebels have destroyed a village in Zimbabwe's Matabeleland Province, leaving 156 people homeless or injured, The Herald newspaper reported today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Youthful Perspective

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid January 1983 3 SYSTEM ASS QtrtoApril30 1983 1982 Revenue 3,190,000 2,746,000 Netinc 6,000 237,000 Shareearns ate.TECHNOLOe s aidthattheyear-earliers 1983 198 2 Revenue 1,575,000 2,082,000 Net loss 153,000 b132,000 Share earns .05 b-Net income after a tax credit of $62,000.

title: BRENNER COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: OAKRIDGE ENERGY reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
TAX ABATEMENT PANEL LABORS ON AMID ITS CRITICS AND SOME CHAOS
description: A tax abatement panel, meeting for the first time since it was criticized recently by the Department of Investigation, denied an incentive to a Bronx funeral parlor yesterday and put off consideration of much larger incentives for several Manhattan office towers.

title: IDEAS FOR THE SUBWAYS WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:$

title:
PATENTS;
System for Keeping Liquids in Proportion
description: An electrical engineer and a biomedical scientist, who received a patent this week on a system for keeping liquids in proper proportion, intend to use it in producing equipment for home hemodialysis, cleansing the blood through an artificial kidney.

title: CHILEAN MAKES CONCESSIONS TO PROTESTERS
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, under pressure after a week of political protest and strikes, said in a nationally televised speech tonight that he would not step down ahead of schedule but would make a number of concessions to the protesters.

title: Sports People; Setback for Ashe
description: Arthur Ashe, the former tennis champion who underwent a quadruple heart bypass after being stricken with a heart attack four years ago, said yesterday that he suffered ''a major setback'' several weeks ago and might have to undergo further bypass surgery. ''My doctors tell me I'm in no danger of keeling over tomorrow,'' the 39-year-old Ashe said, ''but I'm still being watched very closely and I'm not supposed to travel too far from home right now.''

title: New Claims by Jobless Drop
description: First-time applications for unemployment benefits in the first week of June were at their lowest point since mid-September 1981, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
MX MISSILE SAILS OVER PACIFIC IN A SUCCESSFUL MAIDEN FLIGHT
description: The MX missile, the foundation of President Reagan's program to strengthen American strategic nuclear forces, popped out of a towering white canister and arced more than 4,000 miles over the Pacific today on what officials called a successful first flight.

title: SCRAMBLING TO MUFFLE REAGAN'S RADIO ADDRESSES
description: Last Saturday Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democrats' choice to reply to President Reagan's weekly radio address to the nation, arrived in the recording studio with four aides, three typewriters, paste and a hunch.

title: REMARKS BY JOHN PAUL AND THE POLISH LEADER
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Pope John Paul II at his meeting here today with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader; from General Jaruzelski's response, and from the Pope's homily at a mass. The Pope's remarks and homily were translated by the Vatican, and General Jaruzelski's remarks were translated by the official Polish press agency. The Pope's Remarks

title: DANCE: TROCKADERO SPOOFING
description: On Thursday night at the City Center, the men of the all-male Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo donned their wigs, tutus and toe shoes - and their outlandish stage names, as well - and pirouetted through another evening of parody. As instructive as it was amusing, the program demonstrated that balletic spoofing is at its best when it is directed toward specific works or specific attributes of a choreographer's style.

title: SATELLITE TESTS TO HIGHLIGHT SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger reviewed plans today for a flight on which they are to deploy two commercial satellites and, for the first time, release and retrieve a satellite using the shuttle's 50-foot mechanical arm.

title: HARDING CARPETS LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
3 INDICTED IN FAILURE OF BANK
description: A Federal grand jury in Nashville has indicted three businessmen - John H. Candler Jr., an heir of the founder of the Coca-Cola Company; Jerry B. Yokley, the former president of the Hohenwald Bank and Trust Company, and Jack B. Ramsey, former head of an investment firm, on charges growing out of their purported role in the Tennessee bank's failure last summer.

title: VICTOR COMPANY OF JAPAN LTD Year to March 20 1983 reports earnings for Sales.
description: The results in U.S. dollars are based on yesterday's foreign exchange rate in Tokyo of 240 Japanese yen to the dollar.

title: INDIA SAID TO SHUT DOWN REACTOR
description: One of the two Indian reactors at Tarapur, a city north of Bombay, has been shut down because of the lack of needed parts such as monitors and coolant pumps, according to a State Department nuclear expert and Congressional staff members.

title: Bodies of 14 Navy Men Recovered From Plane
description: The bodies of 14 men killed when a fourengine Navy patrol plane crashed on a remote mountain ridge were recovered today, a Navy spokesman said.

title: Dublin Car Theft Casts Doubt On Visit by the Queen Mother
description: Thieves stole a car containing a secret itinerary for a trip to Northern Ireland by Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother, throwing the planned visit into doubt, the police said today.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
G.M. Steel Pact
description: The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest steel buyer, announced that it would buy steel for its 1984 car models from the same 12 suppliers that it used for its 1983 models. The company declined, however, to provide any further details about its steel contracts, and did not say whether the proportions purchased from each supplier would change. Last year, in an effort to improve quality and reduce inventories, G.M. announced that it would institute for the first time a bidding system, under which the steel suppliers would be required to bid for the company's future business.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Purer the Bloodlines, The Higher the Price

title: News Analysis
description: The Senate has approved an $8.4 billion increase in the United States contribution to the International Monetary Fund, and the House of Representatives is expected to do the same soon. But opponents of the increase are still wondering if it is any more than an effort to rescue the Western world's commercial banks.

title: Penn Square Repayment
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation announced today that depositors with balances in the defunct Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma that exceeded the $100,000 guaranteed insurance limit may recover about 65 percent of their uninsured deposits.

title: CHILDBEARING CENTERS ARE INCREASING IN POPULARITY
description: The increasing number of pregnant women seeking an alternative to traditional hospital delivery, which they say is too costly, too impersonal and an unnecessary infection risk, is causing a rapid growth of independent childbearing centers.

title: HELPING THE AGING IN A CRISIS; Fred Feretti
description: ALTHOUGH it has been open less than four months, Respite House has a lready served 30 men and women in need of temporary homes. Respite House, which has 12 beds, was set up to help elderly v ictims of crimes, residence fires or family crises. It is the most r ecent program of the Educational Alliance, the Lower East Side s ettlement house that was established in 1890 to help ease the a ssimilation into American society of Eastern European Jews.

title: S.I. Youths Injure 6 Visitors to Park
description: Six Brooklyn youngsters were slightly injured when a group of local youths broke up their graduation picnic at a sports and recreation complex in New Dorp, S.I., yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SPARTEK INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of 8,000 for the quarter and $1,254,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $533,000 for the quarter and $712,000 for the 6 months. The company recently changed its name from the Spartan Manufacturing Corporation.

title: STATE OFFICIALS AND ENVIRONMENTALISTS ASSES THE PROBLEMS OF TOXIC WASTE
description: The recent discovery of dioxin in the Ironbound district of Newark has refocused public attention on the problem of disposing of hazardous waste.

title: LEISURE GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $60,000 for the quarter and $90,000 for the 6 months. c-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $30,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: 16,000 WORKERS AT CON EDISON GO OUT ON STRIKE
description: Sixteen thousand employees of the Consolidated Edison Company went on strike against the utility at 12:01 A.M. this morning and set up picket lines outside the company's offices and its nuclear and conventional power plants, according to those involved in negotiations.

title: STOCKMAN ASSAILS HEALTH AID BILL
description: David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, said today that he would recommend that President Reagan veto any legislation setting up an unlimited program of health insurance for the unemployed.

title: ALASKANS ASSERT GOVERNOR CALLED OUT TROOPERS TO WARD OFF POLITICAL ATTACK
description: Using state troopers to force attendance at a joint session of the Legislature was a tactic Gov. Bill Sheffield chose to thwart a plan to attack him over his choice for Attorney General, state officials say.

title: by Zick Rubin
description: The institutions and images of our society don't do enough to encourage sons to honor their fathers, especially once the sons have passed through the childhood years. In other times and places, sons learned a trade at their fathers' knee and were expected to follow in their fathers' footsteps. In our society, sons are expected to do their own thing and become their own men. The prevailing image is of fathers and sons who have different occupations, live in different cities and have little to say to each other. On Father's Day, the son's wife reminds him to send the old man a card - or, more often, sends one for him.

title: Honecker Warns on Missiles
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, warned today that deployment of new United States missiles in Western Europe would be nuclear suicide, A.D.N., the East German press agency, said today. Speaking to the Council of State, he said the two Germanys had a duty to make sure no war broke out on German territory. ''Let no one forget: these devilish creations will be installed for a nuclear war, for nuclear suicide,'' he said.

title: Teledyne Seeks More of Kidde
description: Teledyne Inc., an industrial conglomerate based in Los Angeles, announced that it had notified Federal antitrust authorities on June 6 of its intent to acquire an undetermined number of shares of Kidde Inc., a broad-based industrial and commercial products concern with headquarters in Clifton, N.J.

title: Fair on Third Ave.
description: The East 50's Association is holding a fair on Third Avenue between 43d and 54th Streets tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. There will be food, arts, crafts, collectibles and antiques, but no entertainment.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 18, 1983; Markets
description: The Federal Reserve reported a large - but widely expected - increase in the basic money supply for the week ended June 8. The $5.6 billion increase, to $514.1 billion, put M-1, a key money supply measure, well beyond the Fed's targets. But analysts remained divided as to whether the central bank was acting to brake the rapid money growth by raising short-term interest rates. In late trading, the rates on Government securities rose slightly. (Page 29.)

title: IDEAS FOR THE SUBWAYS WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Ways to Help
description: To most people, $25,000 sounds like an extravagant price to pay for tickets to the 1984 Olympics. But the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee has developed an unusual plan under which a set of two tickets per day to various Olympic events will cost just that.

title: Friendly Frost Stock Slides 46%
description: The common stock of Friendly Frost, which trades on the Americcan Stock Exchange, plunged 46 percent on a volume of 158,500 shares. The 4 5/8-point decline in the price of the common stock of Friendly Frost Inc. yesterday, from 10 1/8 to 5 1/2, apparently stemmed from an announcement late Wednesday that the Swanton Corporation would defer indefinitely its previously announced plan to acquire all the remaining outstanding shares of Friendly Frost, a spokesman for the company indicated.

title: ANGRY CHANTS AND 'V' SIGNS FILL WARSAW
description: More than a million Poles gathered at a soccer stadium to hear Pope John Paul II celebrate mass this evening, and when he was done the crowd saluted him with a forest of upraised arms, hands in the V-for-victory sign, and a thundering chant of the name of the founder of the outlawed Solidarity union, Lech Walesa.

title: YANKS TOP BREWERS' CALDWELL
description: Despite the turmoil behind the scenes, the Yankees scored a coup on the field last night in Yankee Stadium when they defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 7-2, for their third straight victory. And in the process, they scored a rare knockout over Mike Caldwell, the most persistent Yankee-beater in baseball.

title: BASTIAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After a loss of $854,000 for the quarter and income of $455,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operatiions. c-Including income of $74,000 for the quarter and a loss of $37,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations.

title: STEINBRENNER REMOVES FOWLER, PITCHING COACH
description: The strain between George Steinbrenner and Billy Martin deepened yesterday when Steinbrenner removed Art Fowler as Yankees pitching coach, and thereby split Martin from his closest friend and confidant.

title: TOXIC WASTE WEAPON: 'BUGS'
description: Scientists have begun to use the tools of biotechnology to create microorganisms that decompose toxic wastes. It is a young field, long on speculation and anticipated growth, short on achievement. Eventually, advocates say, a new industry could emerge that would supply industrial generators of hazardous waste with the means to render their byproducts harmless.

title: EUROPEAN SPACE AGENCY PUTS COMMERCIAL SATELLITES IN ORBIT
description: A European Ariane rocket lauched here Thursday placed two satellites in orbit. It was the first successful satellite deployment for the European Space Agency's commercial satellite launching program.

title: Excerpts from remarks, page 5.
description: Pope John Paul II urged Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today to allow Poland the ''renewal'' worked out in August 1980. The Polish leader responded by defending the imposition of martial law, which ended the country's brief experiment.

title: Girl Found Bound Is Dead on L.I.
description: A 5-year-old girl found Tuesday tied to a bedpost with a plastic bag over her head has died in Stony Brook University Hospital, police said today.

title: Kilauea Lava Flow Stalls
description: A flow of lava from Kilauea Volcano stalled today and began forming a pool about a mile from a subdivision of homes.

title: IDLE WILD FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
Sports People; Conner Picks Liberty
description: Dennis Conner, the America's Cup skipper of Freedom in 1980, made a choice yesterday that many yachtsmen in Newport, R.I., expected. Conner decided on Liberty, not Freedom, to sail in the trials to select the American defender.

title:
Patents;
Solar-Run Chiming Sundial
description: WASHINGTON ACHIMING sundial, which is solar-powered and celebrates the passage of each hour with a musical note, was patented this week by Edwin F. Shelley, who is director of the Center for Energy Policy and Research at the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, L.I. He received patent 4,387,999 for the electronic apparatus.

title: ANOTHER STEP UP FOR SISK
description: Doug Sisk's journey to the major leagues did not teach him one lesson necessary for the proper outlook in the Met clubhouse: Be prepared for anything.

title: The Talk of Odessa
description: You can spot an old Odessan by the sharp tongue. At the Privoz farmers' market, as vast and teeming as any Eastern bazaar, their jabs rise above the din of haggling and hawking: ''How much for your influenza?''

title: Execution Is Set For Jersey Slayer
description: A Superior Court judge in Essex County today set the week of July 31 for the first execution of a convicted murderer in New Jersey in almost 20 years.

title: Sikhs Drop Protest Plan As India Cancels Trains
description: Militant Sikhs abandoned plans to block train traffic in the Punjab today after the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi canceled all train travel in the northern state for 12 hours and local officials temporarily closed the state's public bus system.

title: M.T.A. TO HIRE OUTSIDE EXPERTS ON DERAILMENTS
description: Two private consultants will be hired next week to determine the causes of a recent rash of subway derailments in New York, a special committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday.

title: CENTRAL CORPORATE REPORTS SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DORIS EMRICK LEE
description: Doris Emrick Lee, a painter and book illustrator known for her simplified, sympathetic renderings of country people working or celebrating American holidays, died on Thursday in Clearwater, Fla. She was 78 years old.

title: Baryshnikov Is Injured
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov pinched a nerve during his appearance in ''Don Quixote'' Thursday evening and will be unable to perform in the matinee program with the American Ballet Theater today. ''Apollo,'' the ballet in which he was scheduled to appear, will be replaced by ''Great Galloping Gottschalk.''

title:
PATENTS;
Abandoned Mine's Coal Is Burned for Energy
description: A method of burning out the coal in abandoned mines and recovering the energy for electric power was patented this week for the Department of the Interior. Robert F. Chaiken, a supervisory research chemist in the Pittsburgh research center of the Bureau of Mines, was granted patent 4,387,655.

title: BEATRICE CAN KEEP TROPICANA
description: The Federal Trade Commission ruled unanimously today that the Beatrice Foods Company does not have to divest itelf of Tropicana Products Inc., the largest producer of ready-to-serve orange juice.

title: Residents of a Michigan City Must Boil Water for 7th Day
description: Grand Rapids residents were ordered today to boil all drinking water for the seventh day, and officials said the order might be extended through the weekend.

title: THE CITY;
description: A Federal jury awarded $40 million in damages yesterday to the author Jackie Collins in an invasion-of-privacy suit involving a magazine. Miss Collins said the magazine, Adelina, had incorrectly identified her as the subject of nude photographs published three years ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BERGMAN REPRISE

title: STAGE: 'A KISS IS JUST A KISS,' BOGEY BUFF VIA WALTER MITTY
description: The Humphrey Bogart film buff has become as much a part of our society as the birdwatcher. Woody Allen wrote ''Play It Again, Sam'' about him, and now we have one about her. It is ''A Kiss Is Just a Kiss,'' a play by Paul Foster, at the Manhattan Punch Line, and it is downright funny.

title: Armour Deadline On Plant Closings
description: The Greyhound Corporation said that its Armour Food Company unit will close 13 plants on Dec. 17 because union wages put the plants at a competitive disadvantage.

title: GUNS AND THE NEW YORK CITY FAMILY COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: Lutheran Unit Elects Its First Black Bishop
description: The American Lutheran Church, a 2.3-million member denomination formed largely of Scandinavian immigrants, elected its first black bishop yesterday.

title: Tompkins Square Fair
description: Artists and artisans, mimes, poetry readings and music on a stage, including the 4th Wall Repertory Theater, can all be found this weekend at the Tompkins Square Arts Festival, on East 10th Street, between Avenues A and B. Hours, today and tomorrow, are noon to 6 P.M. The event is sponsored by the Arts Festival Committee and the Friends of Thompkins Square Library. If it rains, the festival takes place next weekend. Information: 475-5737.

title: THE GAP'S PROGRESS; by Russell Baker
description: As a student of gapology, I was both thrilled and puzzled by the sudden appearance of the gender gap. The thrill was in the news of a new gap yawning before us, for it suggested that undiscovered gaps still remain to be explored and that gapology, therefore, was not a closed science, as I had feared.

title: Knicks Keep Sparrow
description: Less than 24 hours after the Boston Celtics signed Rory Sparrow to an offer sheet, the Knicks retained the speedy free-agent guard yesterday by matching the offer: $500,000 a year for four years, all guaranteed.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY AGREE ON MEASURE TO SHIELD TENANTS
description: An agreement on a bill that would permit two tenants who are not related to share rental housing was announced yesterday by members of both houses of the New York State Legislature, the State Attorney General and the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: COURT UPHOLDS RANDOM SHIP SEARCHES BY CUSTOMS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Federal customs officials may make random inspections of ships on inland waterways that provide access to the open sea.

title: JURY ACQUITS FIVE OF RAPE CHARGES
description: Five men who were once fined $5 a week in exchange for pleading guilty to rape were acquitted of rape today after four days of deliberations by a jury in Norfolk County Superior Court in Dedham, Mass.

title: San Juan Fiesta in Park
description: The Central Park Bandshell, near 72d Street, will be the setting tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. for a San Juan Fiesta, with music, food and a pinata, filled with party favors for youngsters. There will be a procession for the mass of St. John the Baptist at 1:30 P.M. There is no rain date.

title: CBS-Sony Deal
description: CBS Inc. and the Sony Corporation announced the formation of the Digital Audio Disc Corporation, a new subsidiary of CBS-Sony, a record company equally owned by CBS and Sony. Digital Audio, which will be based in Terre Haute, Ind. and which will be started up at a cost of about $21 million, is expected to begin producing compact disks - the first commercially produced digital audiodisks -in late 1984 and will function as a custom pressing plant to manufacture compact disks for CBS and other record companies.

title: COMPUTERS ENTER HOLLYWOOD PICTURE
description: Over the last several thousand years, the act of writing has moved through clay tablets and papyrus and parchment and through goose quills and ball point pens and electric typewriters. For a small group of novelists and screenwriters here, the act of writing now involves renting space on a computer in a small store in West Hollywood.

title: G.M.-Toyota Decision
description: The Federal Trade Commission indicated yesterday that it would not reach a decision on the antitrust aspects of the proposed venture of the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation before September.

title: PLAN FOR NEW HAMPSHIRE PRIMARY HELD TO VIOLATE DEMOCRATIC RULES
description: Democratic Party officials told New Hampshire today that the state risked losing its status of holding the first primary in the nation if it defied the party timetable for Presidential primaries and caucuses.

title: BACKERS SEE OBSTACLES TO COMPENSATION OF JAPANESE-AMERICANS
description: It might take up to six years for Congress to act on a Federal study commission's recommendation that Japanese-Americans who were interned in World War II be compensated, Representative Norman Y. Mineta, Democrat of California, said today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: It is truly amazing how many things grow in New York City, in window boxes, on terraces, in tiny backyards, from the ailanthus trees that seize and hold the stony soil in vacant lots to the geraniums that bloom in pots on apartment windowsills. It is as though there are plants that refuse to cede the city to the concrete, as though there is a part of many New Yorkers that refuses, finally, to be citified, and yearns for a little piece of soil.

title: FRENCH SAY NEW RAPID REACTION FORCE IS TO STOP THRUST INTO EUROPE
description: The French Defense Minister revealed details of the country's new rapid reaction force today. The decision to create this 47,000-man mobile intervention force was announced in April when the Government unveiled a five-year military spending program. In a long interview with Le Monde, Defense Minister Charles Hernu said the force's principal mission would be to stop, in cooperation with other allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, ''an armored thrust'' into Western Europe outside France's own frontiers.

title: LOCAL OPPOSITION IS STALLING DEVELOPMENT OF WASTE SITES
description: At a hearing on a plan to build a landfill for hazardous wastes near Last Chance, Colo., 350 farmers from miles around kept the meeting going for more than 19 hours, demanding to know just what the dangers could be to their livestock, their property values and their families' health.

title: HITACHI LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: Share earnings are per American Depositary Shares each of which represents 10 underlying shares.

title: by Louis Auchincloss
description: The brief visitor to Peking today may find it difficult to relate himself to what he sees. A society of which the national bird is the builders' crane, that seems to be breaking its neck to convert its urban centers into so many Newarks, where millions of bicyclists, clad in Government-issued blue jackets, pedal patiently to work and back over broad highways almost bare of vehicular traffic, where lines of silent young men and women wait respectfully in the big square for their turn to file past Mao's embalmed remains, where the streets at night are as dark and silent as in a puritan village and everyone seems abed, is depressing to a Western sense.

title: Federal Reserve; Wednesday, June 15, 1983
description: R Revised.* Seasonally adjusted.+ Over $100,000.** Excluding acceptances.n.a. Not available.

title: DEBATE ON ORDAINING WOMEN AVOIDED BY SOUTHERN BAPTISTS
description: The Southern Baptist Convention has carefully avoided debate on the ordination of women and has voted instead to support the roles of women as homemakers and women who work for the church.

title: Bridge: Familiar Bidding Problem Comes to Fore in Far East
description: There is one commonplace start to the auction that is a continual source of misunderstandings and disasters. If the opening bid is one diamond and the response is two clubs, there are several different schools of thought about how the opener should proceed. What sort of hand should bid two hearts? Or two spades? Or two no-trump?

title: FRANCOISE DE LA RENTE, 62, A LEADER IN FASHION
description: Fran,coise de la Renta, well known in the international fashion and social world for more than three decades and the wife of Oscar de la Renta, the designer, died of cancer early yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 62 years old.

title: Sports People; New Post for MacPhail
description: Lee MacPhail said yesterday that he planned to step down as president of the American League at the end of the year but that he had agreed to remain in baseball as the president of the Major League Player Relations Committee. The 65-year-old MacPhail, who is completing his second five-year term, said he would assume his new duties immediately but would concentrate on league matters until the end of the season.

title: Fair in Forest Hills
description: A Forest Hills ''Tricentennial Plus 30 Days'' street fair will take place today and tomorrow from noon to 6 P.M. on Continental Avenue and 71st Road, between Queens Boulevard and Austin Street.

title: KLM ROYAL DUTCH AIRLINES reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: Results were translated at the rate as of March 31, 2.73 Dutch guilders equal $1.

title: ZONIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Rebels in P.L.O. Report Striking Israelis Often
description: Palestinian guerrillas opposed to Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that they and Lebanese ''resistance forces'' fighting under a joint command had carried out most of the recent attacks on Israeli soldiers in Lebanon.

title: Rev. Dr. Norman Victor Hope; Taught at Princeton Seminary
description: The Rev. Dr. Norman Victor Hope, a professor of church history at Princeton Theological Seminary in New Jersey from 1946 to 1978, died Thursday at Mercer Medical Center in Princeton. He was 75 years old and lived in Ewingville, N.J.

title: MARGARET E. CONRAD
description: Margaret E. Conrad, a former associate dean and professor of nursing at Columbia University and director of nursing at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, died Tuesday at Guilford, Conn., where she lived. She was 88 years old.

title: Krishna Group Loses Brainwashing Lawsuit
description: A jury today ordered the International Society of Krishna Consciousness to pay more than $32 million in damages to a young woman and her mother, who claimed the girl was kidnapped and brainwashed by the religious sect.

title: Ox Ridge Event To Dutch Crown
description: Dutch Crown, ridden by Harry deLeyer, won the open jumper class today at the Merrill Lynch Ox Ridge horse show. Other winners on the second day of the four-day event were Aspenglow, ridden by Diana Owen, in the amateur owner division; Touch and Go, ridden by Richard Rinehart, in the junior jumper event; Apollo, ridden by Leslie Burr, in the intermediate jumper class, and Charleton's Boy, with Buddy Brown up, in the preliminary jumper class.

title: Sports People; Move to Attract Fans
description: Stung by a 25 percent decline in fan support, Lee Stern, the owner of the Chicago Sting, said he was exploring the possibility of playing one of the North American Soccer League club's home games in Milwaukee this August.

title: COSMOS BEATEN, 2-1, BY TEAM AMERICA
description: Team America survived game-long pressure from the Cosmos tonight to defeat the defending North American Soccer League champions, 2-1, in a shootout at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: METRO STRIKE CHOKES STREETS OF PARIS
description: A 24-hour strike on the Paris subway system today snarled traffic, created long lines for taxis and buses and caused many businesses to close early or not open at all.

title: DELOREAN ACCUSES THE BRITISH
description: Lawyers for John Z. DeLorean said today that the British Government, for political reasons, had instigated the Federal investigation that led to his arrest on drug charges.

title: A BOOKSELLER, AND MORE
description: By Anatole Broyard SYLVIA BEACH AND THE LOST GEN- ERATION. A History of Literary Paris in the Twenties and Thirties. By Noel Riley Fitch. Illustrated. 447 pages. W.W. Norton. $25.

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Loud Lame Ducks of Civil Rights
description: Ronald Reagan may be the best thing that's ever happened to the United States Commission on Civil Rights. With no enforcement power, the commission's only source of influence is its ability to command publicity, and until recently it didn't command much.

title: CONSUMER MEASURES ENACTED
description: After years of lobbying, the State Legislature has passed a bill designed to limit the time banks take to clear checks. The bill, one of a series of measures dealing with consumer issues, was signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: BASE TEN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U.S. OPEN TO SPACE WEAPON TALK WITH SOVIET
description: The White House said today that it was interested in the possibility of talking with Soviet representatives about ''implications of the new defensive technologies'' that might provide a protective shield in space against nuclear ballistic missiles.

title: Help From Drew
description: It took a confrontation with his coach, Frank Layden of the Utah Jazz, to make John Drew admit that he was addicted to cocaine. On Thursday, five months after he completed a drug rehabilitation program, Drew confronted the coaches.

title: ELIZABETH ARNOLD
description: Elizabeth Arnold, an activist in family planning for half a century, died in her sleep Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 77 years old.

title: Boy, 8, Dies in Fire; 11 People Injured
description: An 8-year-old boy was killed and 11 people, including two who jumped from windows, were injured in a fire that destroyed a home here today, authorities said.

title: AN EX-KOCH AIDE URGES TAXING EXEMPT GROUPS
description: Art, education and cultural institutions should not be exempted from New York City real-estate taxes, former Corporation Counsel Allen G. Schwartz testified yesterday, interrupting a chorus to the contrary.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 18, 1983
description: International The Pope urged Poland's leadership to allow a resumption of the ''renewal'' that was worked out with Solidarity's leaders in mid-1980. Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski replied by defending the imposition of martial law, which ended the brief experiment. After John Paul II and the general made formal speeches, they spoke privately for more than two hours, and the Government agreed to let the Pope meet with Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity union, which is now outlawed. (Page 1, Column 6.) More than a million Poles gathered at a Warsaw soccer stadium to hear Pope John Paul II celebrate an evening mass. Then the throng saluted him with a forest of hands upraised with the V-for-victory sign and a thundering chant of ''Lech Walesa.'' The stadium was filled with banners of the banned union. Displaying them is illegal. (1:5.)

title: by Linda Amster
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 21.

title: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 12 wks to May 14.
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Protecting the West Side

title: News Analysis
description: With the defeat of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in the straw poll at the Wisconsin Democratic convention, Presidential politics moved into a period of turmoil and realignment this week.

title: Summer League, Eastern-Style
description: The Knicks, the Nets, the Washington Bullets and the National Basketball Association champions, the Philadelphia 76ers, have decided to set up their own East Coast substitute for the Southern California Summer Pro Basketball League.

title: PETER MENNIN, JULLIARD PRESIDENT AND PROLIFIC COMPOSER, DIES AT 60
description: Peter Mennin, the American composer and president of the Juilliard School of Music since 1963, died yesterday morning at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 60 years old.

title: RAGAN, BRAD, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
THEATER: 'GREAT DAYS,' BY DONALD BARTHELME
description: Donald Barthelme's ''Great Days,'' adapted by the author from his book of the same name, is a fanciful collage of quirks, quiddities and eccentricities. In published form, the dialogues are spontaneous streams of conversation. The individual speakers are unidentified, and the dialogues lead to no dramatic conclusion.

title: The Editorial Notebook; 'It's Only a Movie'
description: ''If you'll come with me,'' a friend said many years ago, ''maybe I could watch that scene this time.'' The scene was in a movie called ''Psycho,'' and everyone was talking about it that faraway June of 1960. Talking about it, but revealing nothing. ''Just wait,'' they all said, ''you'll see.'' Then they giggled.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PARADOX IN TRIALS FOR TREASON
description: To the Editor:

title: SAFETY: THE U.S. AND THE PUBLIC
description: In the commercial a 10-year-old boy leans against a twisted country fence. His voice is wistful. The backdrop is a silent farm on a windless day.

title: ALTAMIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.6 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a large, but widely expected, increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week to June 8.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I do not lose hope that this difficult moment may become a path to social renewal, the beginning of which is established by the social agreements stipulated by the representatives of state authority made with the representatives of the world of labor.''

title: Martin Marietta Shares Purchased
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation announced that Goldman, Sachs & Company and Salomon Brothers Inc., as underwriters, had purchased 4.65 million shares of Martin Marietta common stock at a price of 57 5/8 a share. Martin Marietta, as previously announced, will use the net proceeds of the sale to acquire the remainder of its shares held by the Allied Corporation.

title: 'BIG TREE' IS LEAVING FORDHAM PRESIDENCY
description: In 1960, when he received his Ph.D. in political science from Duke University, the Rev. James C. Finlay looked forward to the life of a college professor. He relished the intellectual exchanges with college students and believed then, as now, that there ''is nothing like having your own captive audience.''

title: ITALIAN POLICE SEIZE 425 IN A MAJOR DRIVE AGAINST ORGANIZED CRIME
description: In a major sweep against organized crime in Italy, more than 10,000 paramilitary policemen and special agents staged coordinated raids during the night here and in 25 other cities. The police said 425 people were arrested, among them a Roman Catholic priest, a nun, a television quiz show host and several local politicians.

title: State Funds Approved For Theater Purchase
description: Funds were approved today for the state to purchase the financially troubled American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., and turn the property into a state park.

title: Sports People; Tempest in Tennis
description: The director of the Women's Tennis Association said he would seek sanctions against the operators of the Wimbledon tennis tournament for deviating from the computer ranking in the seeding procedure for the women's division. ''They do not have the right to change computer rankings,'' declared the official, Jerry Diamond, who complained that one American player, Zina Garrison, ranked 15th in the computer standing, had been omitted from the tournament's 16 seeded players, while the popular British player, Jo Durie, who is ranked 17th, was seeded 13th for the tournament.

title: Dow Declines 6.11 Amid Profit Taking
description: After gaining sharply most of the week, stock prices declined moderately yesterday as investors awaited the latest report on the nation's money supply for a clue to the direction of interest rates next week.

title: STATES ARE CHANGING THE ABORTION RULES VOIDED BY TOP COURT
description: The State Health Departments of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut reported yesterday they were preparing to revise their regulations to comply with the United States Supreme Court's decision allowing abortions after the first three months of pregnancy to be performed in clinics.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Undertakers Unit Warns of AIDS
description: The New York State Funeral Directors Association, the state's largest such group, urged its members yesterday not to embalm victims of AIDS until the government issues guidelines for safe handling of such cases.

title: CITY BALLET: A PREMIERE BY ROBBINS
description: In ''You Were Never Lovelier,'' a 1942 Columbia Pictures film, Fred Astaire and Rita Hayworth danced a ballroom duet to Jerome Kern's ''I'm Old Fashioned.'' The song's lyrics, actually heard before Mr. Astaire and Miss Hayworth began their dancing in this number, were by Johnny Mercer.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Correction, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: THE DEFECTS IN AN EAST HARLEM HEALTH-CARE PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CABLE MEETING
description: ''The world expects us to do something spectacular,'' said Allen Gilliland, president of Gill Cable in San Jose, Calif. ''But I don't think we should expect anything spectacular. We will continue to push this evolution on.''

title: Bid For Lenox Inc.
description: A Federal judge postponed until Monday a decision on whether Lenox Inc. can take further steps blocking a proposed takeover by the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation.

title: A CHINESE OFFICIAL'S WARNING MISATTRIBUTED
description: To the Editor:

title: Gold Concern Meeting Held
description: More than 250 angry creditors gathered for a meeting at the National Guard armory here today but found little hope they would ever recover their investments in the now-bankrupt International Gold Bullion Exchange.

title: ROOKIE SHARES LEAD IN OPEN
description: John Mahaffey, who won the PGA Championship at this Oakmont Country Club in 1978, and Joey Rassett, a rookie on the PGA Tour, shared a one-stroke lead today after the second day of the 83d United States Open golf championship.

title: BIG ROLE FOR JUICE AT BEATRICE
description: Two years ago, the Beatrice Food Company decided to rely heavily on its Tropicana Products Inc. orange juice subsidiary to provide big earnings, even if it would someday have to sell Tropicana under a Government order.

title: Federal District Judge Appears to Defy Law
description: Federal District Court Judge Alcee Hastings, who was acquitted on a bribery charge early this year, today published details of a recommendation that he be impeached, apparently defying a Federal law.

title: SIMPLICITY PATTERN BUYS A 9.9% STAKE IN AMSTAR
description: The Simplicity Pattern Company disclosed yesterday that it and another company had acquired 9.9 percent of the common stock of the Amstar Corporation, the nation's largest refiner of cane sugar.

title: Law on Draft Status Ruled Unconstitutional
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that a law requiring male students to disclose their draft registration status when applying for financial aid is an unconstitutional requirement of self-incrimination.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY MEDICAL ADVISER IS TERMED IN CONFLICT OF INTEREST
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, has charged that the regional medical adviser to the Social Security Administration in Chicago had a financial conflict of interest involving his Government work and a private medical consultation company he had established.

title: Fair on West Fourth
description: The Village Independent Democrats are holding their annual street fair, today from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. on West Fourth Street, between Seventh and Perry Streets.

title: Iran and Iraq Report Outbreak of Fighting
description: Iran and Iraq each reported that the other's forces launched a major attack in the Missan sector of their battlefront today, and each said the other's attack was repulsed with heavy losses.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tenants of City Balk At 2,000% Rent Increases

title: Your Money; Estimated Tax Modifications
