description: SOME of the procedures for making estimated Federal income tax payments have been changed this year as a result of provisions in the 1982 tax law and new regulations of the Internal Revenue Service.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a real estate deal involving Battery Park City misidentified the company that realized a $90 million profit in the sale of an American Express building. It was American Express.

title: DELTA SPREADS OUT AT LA GUARDIA
description: Delta Air Lines, long cramped in its facilities at La Guardia Airport, will open a new terminal there tomorrow that should not only ease congestion but also permit the carrier to eventually build a hub at the airport.

title: Duran Savors His Triumph
description: Roberto Duran's eyes were red and dull yesterday, a condition that, the new junior-middleweight champion of the World Boxing Association sheepishly explained, was caused by the celebration of both his 32d birthday Thursday and his rebirth as a fighter.

title: BRIEFINGThe Anderson Mystery
description: J ohn B. Anderson, the former Republican Congressman from Illinois who ran for President in 1980 as an independent, is a sore point with some Democrats who view him as the spoiler who damaged Jimmy Carter's re-election campaign by siphoning off liberal money and energy that might have made a difference in some close contests.

title: 'I'm One of Those People'
description: This morning, at 7:33 Eastern daylight time, an astronaut named Ride is to fly the next mission of the space shuttle Challenger. The astronaut, who has a Ph.D. in physics, will act as flight engineer and will also launch two communications satellites. Astronaut Ride calls the flight ''the experience of a lifetime.''

title: CUOMO DELAYS MEETING ON BUSINESS TAX AID
description: Governor Cuomo today postponed a Monday meeting of the Job Incentive Board following a warning that the state was about to rush through nearly $100 million in tax credits to businesses without adequate review.

title: FAMILY CLASH ON MACANDREWS
description: Faith G. Perelman, the estranged wife of Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., asserted yesterday that she owns a 33.9 percent controlling block of the candy flavoring company's stock that her husband has long claimed.

title: TREES TRIUMPHANT
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio -WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 7:30 P.M.) Blue Jays vs. California Angels, at Toronto, and Dodgers vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 4, first game at 1:15 P.M.) Golf United States Open, third round, at Oakmont, Pa. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M.) Harness Racing Roosevelt Raceway, 8 P.M. Twenty-seven 3-year-olds are entered in the three heats of the Messenger Stakes, the first leg of the pacing triple crown. (Television - Channel 9, 11:30 P.M., tape.)

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CNRP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
THREE D DEPARTMENTS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BUDGET CONFEREES BREAK OFF TALKS
description: Attempts to reach a compromise on the 1984 Congressional budget resolution unraveled somewhat today as House and Senate negotiators encountered White House protests over proposals President Reagan deemed too heavy on taxes and too light on Pentagon spending.

title: Inmates Win Right To Sue the State
description: A group of prisoners who were in Westchester County Jail at the time of a riot there two years ago has been given the right to sue state prison officials for damages for themselves and other prisoners.

title: Safety First
description: They have an unusual rule at the annual Molson N.H.L. Slo-Pitch Softball Classic, which takes place in Niagara Falls, Ontario, this weekend: No sliding into any base, including home plate.

title: GENERALS WIN 5TH, BEAT EXPRESS, 20-13
description: The New Jersey Generals defeated the Los Angeles Express, 20-13, tonight, partly on merit and with the help of mistakes from the opponent before a crowd of 31,807 at Giants Stadium.

title: A NEW NAME ON THE LEADERBOARD
description: The 24 year-old rookie touring pro was walking down the 10th fairway yesterday when he noticed that his name had gone up on the United States Open leaderboard near the 11th green. That meant his name also was up on the other leaderboards all over the Oakmont course. At the time, a black number one was next to Joey Rassett's name, meaning he was one over par for the tournament. After he came off the 18th green with a 2-under-par 69, a red number one, matching the color of his slacks, was next to his name. At that moment, Joey Rassett was leading the Open through 36 holes at 141, 1 under par.

title: Film Starring Redford To Be Shot in Buffalo
description: Most of the scenes for ''The Natural,'' a baseball film starring Robert Redford, will be filmed in Buffalo. Mark Johnson, producer of the movie for Tri-Star Pictures, said at a news conference Wednesday that two-thirds of the scenes would be filmed here starting late next month, with much of the shooting to be done at the 45,00-seat War Memorial Stadium, home of the Buffalo Bisons baseball team of the Eastern League.

title: HERNANDEZ GETS 2 HITS, BUT METS LOSE, 7-2
description: Keith Hernandez got a taste tonight of what life might be like for a player who went from the World Series champions to the team with the worst record in baseball. Hernandez had two singles in his first four times at bat as a member of the New York Mets, but his new team was beaten, 7-2, by the Montreal Expos.

title: 100-Mile Race Attracts 90
description: Stu Mittleman and Marcy Schwam were the favorites to win the USA/The Athletics Congress 100-mile championship race today at Shea Stadium in a field of 90 that began running yesterday.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: MOUNT VERNON ROGER supplied many of the students in his exclusive private school with cocaine. Bob first got high with a friend who had stolen the marijuana from his own father. Stacey says, ''I used to eat 20 Valiums a day.''

title: The Law's Delay
description: MARTIN P. LEVIN always wanted to be a lawyer but did not have enough money for law school after graduting from Temple University in 1950. Yet he has not done badly. Since 1966 he has been president of the Times Mirror Company's book publishing division, which includes the New American Library and Harry N. Abrams in New York, C.V. Mosby (textbooks and reference works) in St. Louis and Year Book Medical Publishers in Chicago. He is also a former chairman of the Association of American Publishers.

title: Miss Semler Weds on L.I.
description: Tatiana Boldyreff Semler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Semler of Rome and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Laurence Pouschine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Pouschine Jr. of Sea Cliff, L.I. The Rev. John Turkevich performed the Russian Orthodox ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: ULTRA-ATHLETES TAKE IT TO THE LIMIT
description: HER story reads like a page from Greek mythology and might have beene ntitled, ''Julie's Odyssey.'' Julie Moss, after all, was swift, as w as the goddess Atalanta, who was so fleet and proud that she vowed n ever to marry any man unless he was capable of defeating her in a f ootrace.

title: TORY FOES DENOUNCE ELECTION RESULTS
description: In a British equivalent of the traditional Brooklynese ''We was robbed,'' a leader of the fledgling Liberal-Social Democratic alliance denounced the results of the June 9 parliamentary elections.

title: VIRTUOSO SET PIECES
description: SEAVIEW, By Toby Olson. 250 pp. New York: New Directions. $15.95. LIKE the Hollywood Nathanael West pictured in ''The Day of the Locust,'' Toby Olson's ''Seaview,'' an imaginary Cape Cod golf course and beach area, is a place in which disparate American characters come together to live, play and die. Here the apocalyptic confrontation takes the form not of a riot of movie fans, but rather of a small-scale war engaged in by golfers, golf course workers, Indians who lay claim to the links, a motorcycle gang, armed handglider enthusiasts, troops from a nearby Air Force station and a group of nude sunbathers. Even a remarkable dreamer of nightmares like West might have been hard-pressed to top the book's finale - a scene in which two former friends meet in a Western-style showdown, one armed with a gun, the other with a golf club and balls. What makes these various absurdist encounters doubly odd is that the story they conclude begins and develops so quietly and meditatively that it seems, in retrospect, to belong to a different sort of book entirely.

title: Senate Steps In On Cable TV
description: The Senate spared cable television the regulatory rod last week by voting to replace thousands of local rules governing cable operations with a uniform Federal law. The Cable Telecommunications Act passed overwhelmingly, 87 to 9, with the support of all six Senators from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: GENERAL SEES MX TEST AS PRODDING CONGRESS
description: The director of the Air Force's MX missile program said that he expects its successful first flight Friday night to help persuade Congress to move the longdisputed weapon into full production.

title: PETER GREENAWAY'S MOVIES: VERY ENGLISH, VERY ECCENTRIC
Reagan Writes Andropov
description: President Reagan has sent a letter to Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet party chairman, congratulating him on his election as chief of state Thursday and pledging American cooperation in efforts to reduce nuclear arms and tension between the superpowers. The letter, dated Friday, was made public today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Coach Jim Valvano of North Carolina State has donated $25,000 to the school in gratitude for the faith the university officials placed in him during a season when the Wolfpack had a 9-7 record at one point before going on to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball title. The donation was made in the form of a life membership in the Wolfpack Club, where an endowment fund is set up and the accrued interest is used for athletic scholarships.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
It's Only Gasoline
description: Americans love big cars again. Detroit loves to sell big cars. So Federal mileage standards go by the wayside, and General Motors and Ford face fines of more than half a billion dollars this year for violating the 1975 Energy Policy and Conservation Act.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
THE RIGHT FIT
description: Alan Flusser, the men's-wear designer, is the author of ''Making the Man.''

title: IN PRAISE OF EARLY MUSIC
description: One of the reasons that 20th-century works have such a small audience is precisely because we think in terms of ''old'' versus ''contemporary.'' Compositions can receive their premieres only once.

title: GORON WASLEY WED TO FRANCIS AUSTIN JR.
description: Gordon Hall Wasley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. W. Wasley of East Lyme, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to Francis Reed Austin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin of Dover and South Darmouth, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Erik Larsen at the Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn.

title: THE CANADIAN DIFFERENCE
description: When Michael Kaufman invoked Thoreau (''In Canada, you are reminded of the Government every day''), it brought to mind a remark I heard at a recent conference studying comparisons between Canada and the United States: ''In the United States, the people hate the Government, while in Canada, the Government hates the people.'' MICHAEL H. EBNER Lake Forest, Ill.

title: SUSIE'S WEDDING
description: To the Editor:

title: COOL, VERSATILE ASTRONAUT: SALLY KRISTEN RIDE; W
description: The celebration over sending the first American woman into orbit has tended to overshadow the fact that Dr. Sally K. Ride is to be the first person to perform one of the most significant tasks of the space age. Reaching into the void with a 50-foot robotic arm, she plans to capture a satellite as it hurtles about the earth and, using mechanical might conferred by gears and motors, bring it safely to rest in the cargo bay of the space shuttle.

title: SHADOW OF DOUBT WIPES OUT BENDECTIN
description: Can medical researchers prove that a drug is safe during pregnancy? Assuming they can, does an official green light mean all pregnant women can use the drug freely?

title: UNDERSTANDING MONDALE
description: THE PLACE IS JACKSON, Miss., and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale is here to deliver a speech from the front steps of the Mississippi Governor's mansion. His performance is not unlike those he has given in 100 cities in 26 states between January and June of this year. A sprinkling of national press has come along to watch, and Mondale exhibits guarded ease. He is 55 years old and has no illusions about the process he must go through to win the Presidency. The reporters have come to examine his soft spots, and neither he nor they need to be told that the last two decades of Democratic Party history have been littered with the mistake-plagued wreckage of early front-runners.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
NATURE AT TWILIGHT
description: As the sun sets this evening, a fleet of canoes will embark from the Center for Environmental Studies in Roseland for a twilight nature cruise on the Passaic River.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: For vacationers who have to watch their budgets, one unexpected benefit of the recession of the last few years has been the rapid increase in the number of motels charging low rates. ''The industry has been experiencing phenomenal growth,'' said Joan Ganje, a budget-motel executive. ''We credit the bad economy entirely. We hate to say it, but we're taking advantage of a bad situation.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SAN FRANCISCO
description: You will enjoy this delightful place where life bubbles like champagne, the scenery is memorable, and laughter echoes in the night air. Be prepared to gain weight, to lose sleep, to arrive home tired and vaguely dissatisfied.

title: NEW YORK REASSERTS ITSELF AS A POP TREND-SETTER
DANGLING MAN
description: Richard Nixon recently came to Washington to speak to a U.S.-China trade group and provided grammarians with a wrong way and a right way to use participial phrases.

title: STATE SEEKS U.S. SYSTEM TO CHECK AIR
description: WHEN wind drifts in from the southwest on a summer's day, Connecticut residents, especially those in New Haven and Fairfield Counties, often experience stinging in their eyes, burning in their throats and some have trouble breathing, say state environmental officials.

title: Mulroney Takes No Chances
description: Brian Mulroney, the new leader of Canada's Conservative Party, took another step last week in his campaign to become the next Prime Minister and end 20 years of almost continuous Liberal rule. Facing the need to get elected to the House of Commons and assume effective leadership of the principal opposition, he chose to run for a safe Tory seat in Nova Scotia rather than risk defeat in his native Quebec.

title: GARDENS IN HISTORIC SETTINGS CAN GUIDE AMATEUR RESTORERS
description: A garden gate swinging back to the past opens to a balance of color and form stemming from our Colonial heritage. According to Ronald P. Boucher, a Massachusetts landscape architect who has specialized in historic restorations for more than 25 years, reclamation of vintage properties is a growing trend.

title: WITNESS SAYS HE AIDED 2 BRINK'S ROBBERY SUSPECTS
description: A key witness has testified that he gave medical treatment to a wounded suspect and helped another suspect escape after the 1981 Brink's robbery and shootout in Rockland County.

title: Red Sox Set Back Orioles on 5-Hitter
description: John Tudor tossed a five-hitter and Tony Armas's bases-loaded sacrifice fly capped Boston's two-run rally in the eighth inning as the Red Sox defeated Baltimore, 3-2, tonight. It was the Orioles third straight loss.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE Clean Air Act amendments introduced last week by Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of Spring Lake Heights, would counteract proposals made by the Reagan Administration to weaken the law.

title: PEAK PERFORMANCE EXPANDING
description: WHAT are the limits of physical endurance? How far can a person go? Even the most dedicated coast-to-coast runner has to eat, sleep and pause for the other necessities of daily life. Yet once these are out of the way, sports physiologists say there appears to be an endless frontier. The limits will slowly be pushed back. Records, they say, will continue to be broken.

title: KEYNES REVISITED
description: To the Business Editor: As I think about the contents of economics courses today and what I got half a century ago, I can raise questions, not answer some of them.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
AT LAST, HOPE FOR COHERENT POLICY
description: TRADE means jobs. Five million jobs depend on exports and about 40 p ercent of our farmland is planted for exports. Reduced exports c aused somewhat short of half the rise in unemployment since 1980.

title: THE FUJIYA
description: To the Editor: Both my husband and I read with considerable interest the article ''Japanese Victorian'' about the Fujiya Hotel. The Fujiya certainly does represent a part of Japan and Japanese history that most Westerners no longer have an opportunity to see.

title: MESSENGER STAKES TO RALPH HANOVER
description: Ralph Hanover, unbeaten in five starts this year, won the 28th Messenger Stakes in record time tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. The Canadian-owned colt, driven by Ron Waples, was clocked in 1 minute 57 seconds for his two-length victory over Raffi in the final of this event, the first in the triple crown for 3-yearold pacers.

title: ZANUCKS' WILLS: 'MORE DRAMA THAN SOAP OPERAS'
description: The image of an elderly, terminally ill millionaire looking into a television camera and telling her son why she intended to disinherit him is expected to be part of the evidence in a legal battle unfolding here over an estate valued at more than $10 million.

title: An August Bridal In Newport Is Set By Miss Garrahan
description: Dr. and Mrs. William F. Garrahan of East Greenwich, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pawler Ann Garrahan of New York, to Douglas A. McIntyre, also of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce H. McIntyre of Pontiac, Mich.

title: No Headline
description: In Praise of Early Music I was most interested to read Bernard Holland's article ''In Praise of Early Music'' (May 22). However, I take exception to his implication that the renaissance of early music is due to the public's dissatisfaction with the music of its own time.

title: Kristy Weinschreider Plans to Become The Bride of Anthony Rudel in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Weinschreider Jr. of Hinsdale, Ill., and Rockport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristy Weinschreider, to Anthony Jason Rudel, son of Julius Rudel and Dr. Rita G. Rudel of New York.

title: Thomas Aquinas Connor Weds Mary Jane Barbieri
description: Mary Jane Barbieri, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Barbieri of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Aquinas Connor, son of Mrs. Frank P. Connor of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Connor. The Rev. William O'Leary performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity.

title: Martha R. Hinckley is Wed
description: Martha R. Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Robinson of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel J. Bliss of Spring Grove, Pa. The Rev. Walter Carlson, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. The bride has been previously married and divorced as has the bridegroom, who is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Bliss of Oceanport, N.J.

title: HARVARD 8 WINS ROWING TITLE
description: Harvard's varsity heavyweight crew won the second annual Cincinnati Regatta, the collegiate rowing championship of the United States, on Harsha Lake today.

title: JANE T. LAVATY WILL WED DONALD R. COOKE IN 1984
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Anton Lavaty of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Terese Lavaty, to Donald Robert Cooke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Ralph Cooke of Millbrook, N.Y. The wedding will take place next year.

title: IT'S ALL TOO EASY TO BE A CRITIC; LESTER C. THUROW
description: LITTLE is more disconcerting to the average citizen than the seemingi nability of economists to agree on anything. Something troubling h appens to the economy, two economists appear on television, and in 3 0 seconds they seem to give diametrically opposing views. If e conomists disagree that sharply, how can they possibly know a nything?

title: SALVADOR'S LEADER REBUFFS CONGRESS
description: The Provisional President of El Salvador said today that he would not comply with United States Congressional stipulations that his Government begin unconditional discussions with insurgents.

title: AN INQUIRY INTO THE VANISHING ENDING
description: Please don't take this as criticism. It is meant to be speculation. An all too familiar sensation swept over me as I was sitting in a playhouse the other evening. Actually, it has only recently become all that familiar, say in the last few seasons or so. It was this. As I watched, I wondered if there was any possibility that the play would ever end.

title: SEATTLE
description: To the Editor: Eastern cities may have a ''Skid Row,'' but the original, mentioned in the article ''What's Doing in Seattle'' is Seattle's Skid Road, not Skid Row.

title: Civil Rights Panel; Turns Up the Heat; On White House
description: Who's in at the United States Commission on Civil Rights still isn't clear, but in the panel's opinion, at least, there isn't much doubt about who's out in the Reagan Administration - blacks, women and Hispanic Americans. In a report it unanimously sent to the White House last week, the commission said it was ''disappointed and concerned'' that President Reagan had not appointed more of them to important posts in the Federal Government.

title: LITCHFIELD FEATURING AMERICAN SCONCES
description: MORE than 175 exhibitors from throughout the Northeast are expected in Litchfield Saturday for the Litchfield Antiques Flea Market, held each summer on the grounds of the White Memorial. The show, from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., is a benefit for the Little Guild of St. Francis for the Welfare of Animals.

title: BUILDING BRIDGES, FOSTERING PH.D'S
description: IN the late 1940's, a structural engineer named Edward Cohen presented himself for an interview at the firm of Ammann & Whitney, which had summoned him on the basis of a favorable recommendation. The economy was in a recession, and Mr. Cohen, a product of the Depression, remembers posing a question to the interviewer: ''I said, 'Is this a permanent job?'

title: WHAT'S TO BE FOUND IN THE OPERATIC ATTIC?
description: We live in a time of penance, operatically speaking, but let's try to see the bright side. Although the age of masterpieces may be past, like the age of miracles, the scarcity, at the moment, of stirring new works has provided us with breathing space, with more than enough time to go sifting through the detritus of the past for buried wonders. Generally, of course, such digging leaves the musical archeologist with little more than dust in his hands. Every excavator into dark and dusty regions of the repertory comes to understand that most neglected works have been neglected for good reasons, not always because our ancestors had tin ears or armor-plated souls.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS INFLICT HEAVY DAMAGE AT BORDER
description: Anti-Government insurgents have inflicted extensive damage on Nicaraguan farms and agricultural storehouses near the Honduran border.

title: SMALL BUILDING, BIG GESTURES; PRINCETON, N.J.
description: Gordon Wu Hall at Princeton University is not a large building, and like much of the work of its architect, Robert Venturi of the firm of Venturi, Rauch & Scott Brown, it seems at first glance not a little awkward. But its awkwardness fades into pleasure with even the slightest degree of familiarity, and as for its small size - well, let it just be said that Wu Hall is large enough to bring to Princeton, for years something of an architectural backwater, a sense of commitment to serious architectural intent that has not been seen on that campus in more than a generation.

title: VIOLIN CONCERT: MARY FINDLEY
description: Mary Findley subtitled her Thursday evening violin concert in Carnegie Recital Hall ''American Beauty: Music for Violin and Piano.'' It was an apt description, for Miss Findley's program, with Marjorie Lee at the piano, caused the listener to reflect on the diversity and appeal of our homegrown musical material.

title: LONDON AUCTION OF AFRICAN TRIBAL ART ADDS SPARKS TO CONTINUING; CONTROVERSY
description: Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan began collecting African art and artifacts in the early 1960's when he traveled frequently for the United Nations to the developing countries of Africa. The Frenchborn, Harvard-educated Iranian served first as Deputy and later as High Commissioner for Refugees, a post he held through 1977.

title: TV'S MR. ROGERS-A BUSY SURROGATE DAD
description: In the eyes of many children Fred Rogers, the man who has been entering the nation's living rooms for two decades on ''Mister Rogers's Neighborhood,'' is America's nurturing, surrogate dad. And, of late, an increasingly busy dad. This Father's Day weekend marks the debut of Mr. Rogers's comic opera for children ''All in the Laundry'' at the Opera Shop of the Vineyard Theater in Manhattan. His first book for grownups, ''Mister Rogers Talks With Parents,'' has been in bookstores since the beginning of the month, and this week he'll be taping his next prime-time television special for parents, about day care, which will be broadcast in the fall. And last week he began work on a new batch of episodes for his half-hour series, which will help children to deal with conflict and aggression.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE This is the last week to catch the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater before the company goes off to its summer home in Saratoga and then on European tour. The dancers have looked superb this season, and the week offers a host of new and old favorites.

title: ON GREENSPAN
description: To the Business Editor: If, as Alan Greenspan says, he has always valued men and women equally, how come he pays his female economists less? What kind of equality is that? MARY ELLEN REILLY

title:
HOTEL HEAVEN?  MAKE MINE MODERN;
BERNARD SLOAN lives in Larchmont, N.Y., and is working on his second book, ''Confessions of a Young Stockbroker.''
description: ''I only go to countries where there's a Hilton,'' a man once announced to me over a roulette table in San Juan, a confidence that necessitated some quick coughing to conceal my smirk. How cloddish, how middle American, thought I. How dull compared to our adventuresome friends who would commit hara-kiri before setting foot in the lobby of anything suggesting American or touristy. One did not experience local culture in New and Modern, only in Old and Charming.

title: ORGANIZED LABOR IN THE STATE IS FACING DIFFICULT TIMES
description: ORGANIZED labor in New Jersey is facing its toughest time since the Depression of the 1930's. Membership rolls have been eroded by five years of inflationary recession and by plant closings and the loss of jobs, and employers are increasingly seeking contract concessions under a threat of further closings.

title: SLOPE-SIDE HOUSES
description: For years, skiers and recreation seekers have flocked to the area around Great Gorge in the heart of New Jersey's Vernon Valley for day trips. Now, with expectations that visitors will want to spend more than a day, two condominium projects are being developed in the area.

title: SPOLETO BETWEEN THE ACTS
description: To have gathered into a small Umbrian hill town the cavalcade of musicians, actors, dancers and practitioners of all imaginable art forms that Gian Carlo Menotti has drawn to Spoleto every summer since 1958 is no doubt in itself a work of high art.

title: A GUIDE TO A JUNGLE OF JARGON
description: ''Can a DAMP be ULURPed?'' That did it. He knew the answer but he deplored the jargon, even though he understood it. So he started keeping definitions on 3-by-5 cards and now, if you study the results of his labors in a dictionary of planning soon to be published by New York City, you will be able to learn, among other things:

title: ON AVOIDING GAMBITS
description: The easy life, sought after by those who sidestep or decline dangerous gambits, is not what it's touted to be. In avoiding the sharpest opening lines, it becomes all the harder to play for a victory later in the game.

title: MANHATTAN DRAWING THE BRITISH INVESTOR
description: IN London, a real-estate investment and development company called G reycoat City Offices is building 250,000 square feet of g lassenclosed office space above the tracks of Victoria Station. It i s a joint venture with Sir Robert McAlpine & Sons Ltd.

title: Jill Habermann Marries Jerald Howe Jr. in Capital
description: Jill Liane Habermann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley John Habermann of Paris and New York, was married yesterday to Jerald Shropshire Howe Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howe of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Campbell Gillan performed the ceremony at the Georgetown Presbyterian Church in Washington.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL METS (NL) - Signed Calvin Schiraldi, p itcher from University of Texas, and said h e would be assigned to a farm team Mon- d ay. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Sent Mike Cou- c hee, relief pitcher who has been sidelined s ince May 28 with a broken rib, to Las V egas farm club for 20-day rehabilitation p rogram.

title: 2,6000 COMPETITORS ENTER SPORTS FESTIVAL
description: The National Sports Festival, America's largest amateur athletic extravaganza, returns to its birthplace this week, having grown so rapidly that even its creator has a hard time recognizing it.

title: HARTFORD GIRDS FOR A NEW RISE IN PROPERTY TAX
description: A SERIOUS problem glares from behind the gleam of Hartford's new skyscrapers. Residential property taxes, already the highest in the state, are scheduled to increase by 15 to 22 percent this year, and to double over the next five.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR THE AUTHOR WHO PORTRAYED LIFE IN CHINA
description: Pearl Buck, who won both the Noble Prize and the Pulitzer Prize for literature, is taking her place in the current Great American Series with a new 5-cent regular issue coming out this Saturday. It will be put out at Hillsboro, West Va., the author's birthplace.

title: Troublesome Tapes
description: Former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said he was talking ''off the record'' when George Crile, a producer for CBS News, interviewed him in 1981. Unknowingly, however, he was talking on the recorder. Mr. Crile, who secretly tape-recorded that interview and others for a 1982 documentary on the Vietnam War, was among those named in a $120 million libel suit by Gen. William C. Westmoreland, whose lawyers demanded that CBS produce the McNamara tape. Mr. Crile, who had said the tapes were lost or erased, said he found them last week. CBS, saying secret taping violated company policy, suspended him.

title: Left Out of the Plan
description: Question: I have lived in my apartment in a rent-stabilized building for four years. The building is now undergoing a noneviction conversion to cooperative ownership. The plan revealed that my apartment is not covered under the building's certificate of occupancy. The sponsor says that he is trying to get the certificate amended and that if he does, we will become part of the co-op plan; if not, he says, we would be subject to eviction. What can I do? ... M.O., Manhattan Answer: Lawyers who represent both landlords and owners say that the sponsor is obligated to try to legalize your apartment and that if he cannot, he will be forced to evict you. They also believe, however, that you have a strong argument for damages or another apartment, or both; you should consult a lawyer.

title: A LINK TO LIFE
description: WO PLASTIC BEER COOLERS SIT SIDE by side in the rear of a chartered airplane's dimly lit cabin. One contains a human liver, doublesealed within two plastic bags of a preserving solution and packed in ice. An hour ago, it had been taken from the body of a 9-year-old boy in New York who had just died of a stroke. It is being rushed to a 17-year-old patient in Pittsburgh whose own diseased liver is being removed at that moment in an operation closely timed to the flight in progress. The other cooler holds a recently cracked six-pack of Molson beer, a reward for the three men stretched out across the seats. Their part in the night's work is finished.

title: Margaret Lee Cooper Marries Stephen W. Fuller
description: Margaret Lee Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll M. Cooper of Newport News, Va., was married there yesterday to Stephen Washington Fuller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen D. Fuller of Oyster Bay, L.I. The Rev. Douglas Burgoyne performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: No Headline
description: The Canadian Difference Michael T. Kaufman had best watch his step as an American in Canada (''Canada: An American Discovers Its Difference,'' May 15). He has described Canada well.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Not all artists come to New York. There are some who, believe it or not, prefer to stay in their native haunts, where their work may - or may not - be as mainstream as that of their Manhattan counterparts.

title: THE METROPOLITAN UNVEILS ITS FULL EGYPTIAN TREASURES
description: ''These are not wonderful, dusty halls, gloomy, redolent of the Valley of the Kings,'' said Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. ''But I don't think you can make an installation today by trying to recreate that British Museum habitat. This is the new world. This is America.''

title: A SCIENTIST WITHIN LIMITS
description: BOSS KETTERING By Stuart W. Leslie. Illustrated. 382 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $19.95.

title: Man Charged in 6th Slaying
description: A sixth murder charge has been filed against a man already accused of five stranglings of homosexuals. Randy Kraft, 39 years old, a computer programmer from Long Beach, Calif., was charged Friday with murder, robbery and mayhem in the slaying of 22-year-old Mark Hall, whose nude body was found seven years ago in San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

title: SKETCHES OF THE FOUR MEN OF THE CHALLENGER'S CREW
description: Robert Crippen

title: YOUTH GOLF OPEN SET
description: The second yearly William M. Jennings Jr. Golf Open for boys and girls begins at 7:30 A.M. Thursday at the Saxon Woods Golf Course on Old Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale.

title: THE LEGACY OF THIS HARPSICHORD PIONEER LIVES ON
SHUTTLE ROCKETS TO ORBIT WITH 5 ABOARD
description: Four men and a woman, the first American woman to go into space, rocketed into orbit today aboard the space shuttle Challenger and then launched the first of two satellites in the successful beginning of a busy six-day mission.

title: RECALLING 'THE BRAIN'
description: Half a century ago a young army lieutenant was leading a busy life. Each night he was in New York City directing a headline-making bridge event. Each morning at 7:30 he was teaching mathematics to a West Point class. Most of his sleeping was done in his car, with his wife assigned to do the driving.

title: A Fitness Program
description: George Allen, the chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, announced the establishment of a National Fitness Academy to train athletic instructors and administrators and to serve as an information and research center for physical fitness, exercise, nutrition and health. The academy, to be based in Indianapolis, is being sponsored by the National Fitness Foundation, a newly organized nonprofit organization that plans a fund-raising campaign for the center, which is not expected to be in full operation until next year.

title: Celia Smith Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Howard Haldeman Steel of Villanova, Pa., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Steel's daughter, Celia Ellan Smith, to Brian Winstanley Carroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Patrick Carroll Jr. of New York. Miss Smith is a daughter also of Dr. Edward Cary Smith of Spokane, Wash.

title: SKIRMISHES IN THE BATTLE OF THE NEW CENTURY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CLOWNS SEND IN A FESTIVAL
description: FROM ancient times (Horace, 25 B.C.: ''Who is not a fool?'') to the Elizabethan Age (Shakespeare: ''It is meat and drink to me to see a clown'') to modern musicals (Stephen Sondheim: ''There ought to be clowns''), the clown has been proclaimed as a convention of circuses and a necessary diversion in life.

title: Q AND A
description: Question: We are planning a three-month stay in Sicily. Where can we obtain information on accommodations in the Palermo and Messina area? - V.L., Massapequa, N.Y. Answer: The Italian Government Travel Office (630 Fifth Avenue, New York N.Y. 10111; 212-245-4822) can supply a pamphlet containing a list of hotels nad pensions; the list includes hotels but no pension in Palermo and Messina. (The pamphlet is a partial listing; it gives a few pensions for each of the eight principal tourist cities: Bologna, Florence, Genoa, Milan, Naples, Rome, Turin and Venice.)

title: METS TOP EXPOS BY 6 to 1
description: Rusty Staub, who is remembered fondly by Canadians as ''Le Grand Orange'' for the season he played in Montreal, tonight helped spoil the Expos' bid to move into first place in the National League East. He got an important pinch-hit in a five-run seventh-inning that enabled the Mets to crush the Expos, 6-1.

title: POLAND'S ENDURING FAITH
description: It's not difficult to understand why the Polish Government was worried about inviting the Pope of Rome to come back to his native land. He may be more dangerous to the Communist philosophy than all the missiles of the West. For centuries, the Roman Catholic Church has been Poland's refuge from alien aggressions, and this particular Pope is a symbol of Poland's national identity and faith.

title: GREATEST AFTER DANTE
description: THE MORAL ESSAYS Operette Morali. By Giacomo Leopardi. Translated by Patrick Creagh. 265 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $25.

title: OPPOSITION GROWS TO SAFETY PROJECT ALONG SAW MILL
description: ABOUT 900 trees along the Saw Mill River Parkway are to be cut down as part of a $3 million Roadside Safety Improvement Project of the state's Department of Transportation. The project is part of a $140 million 10-year plan to improve the parkway system. The plan is scheduled for completion by 1989.

title: Jumping at Ox Ridge Captured by Pachelbel
description: Pachelbel, ridden by Dina Santangelo, won the Insilco amateur owner jumper stakes at the Merrill Lynch Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show. The winning time was 36.893 seconds.

title: STUDY SAYS AFFIRMATIVE RULE EXPANDS HIRING OF MINORITIES
description: A new study by the Labor Department has concluded that affirmative action of the type criticized by President Reagan has been highly effective in promoting the employment of blacks, women and Hispanic people.

title: SCANNELL CAPTURES 100-MILE TITLE RUN
description: In a race marked by surprises, Ray Scannell and Donna Hudson ran their personal bests and emerged yesterday as the winners in the twoday USA/The Athletics Congress 100-mile championship race at Shea Stadium.

title: Fallen Horse: A Lament
description: To the Sports Editor: It is a shame that greed had to rear its ugly head in this year's Belmont, resulting in the tragic breakdown of the thoroughbred El Cubanaso.

title: DOCTOR, DISCOVER YOUR HUMANITY
description: WHENEVER people gather, if the subject of illness comes up, a kind of mass shudder of sympathy usually runs through the group. First of all, we know what the ill person is going through and, secondly, we fear that some unseen problem may put us in the same boat.

title: ROAR OF THE CROWD
description: The crowd is obsolete. It impedes traffic and is hard to feed. It is a nuisance to everyone in its vicinity. It is costly to police budgets and, because it creates great quantities of trash and garbage, costly to sanitation budgets.

title: COMMUTERS SEEK ALTERNATIVES
description: MOST Connecticut commuters resumed taking the train to New York City after the 42-day rail strike earlier this year. But an increasing number are turning to alternative transportation to get to work.

title: RHINEBECK: ONWARD AND UPWARD
description: THE FAIR at Rhinebeck, N.Y. - the ''grand-daddy of all the craft fairs'' - opens to the public next Friday at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds.

title: HOW DO HONEYBEES NAVIGATE SO WELL? FINDINGS SUGGEST A 'COMPASS'
description: DR. BENJAMIN WALCOTT is one of about 400 beekeepers whose hives dot backyards and farms across Long Island. The honey he gets, though, is just a pleasant byproduct of research that may shed light on the navigation ability of bees and other animals.

title: Patricia Weigel Is Married
description: At Christ Episcopal Church in Pelham, N.Y., yesterday Patricia Weigel, daughter of Frances P. Weigel of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Lighthouse Point, Fla., and William F. Weigel of New York, was married to Timothy Charles Blank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus J. Blank of Pelham Manor. The Rev. David S. Hoag performed the ceremony.

title: BEYOND WALDEN
description: SAY ''PASSIVE SOLAR ON A WOODED LOT'' AND the house that leaps to mind has vertical rough-sawed siding, all the better to blend unobtrusively with the trees. And in an era that champions contextual architecture - buildings that defer to the existing character of a neighborhood - such humility seems perfectly apt at first blush. But when one considers that the neighbors on a large wooded lot tend to be the four-legged sort who are unlikely to take umbrage at architectural impudence, the modesty of the typical passive solar house begins to seem misplaced.

title: Second Thoughts In the Senate
description: As the Senate demonstrated last week, embarrassment will sometimes propel a legislative body only so far. Members of the Senate voted to raise their pay - from $60,662 to $69,800, the same amount now earned by Representatives - but delayed until Jan. 1 a limit on income they may receive from outside speeches and articles.

title: Firefight in Guatemala
description: Government soldiers killed 10 guerrillas in a firefight Thursday in northern Quiche Province and rescued 32 peasants held by the guerrillas, the army announced today.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID PLANTS REFLECT MARKET DEMAND
description: LIKE nuclear power facilities and garbage dumps, new hybrid plants sometimes draw unfavorable comment. With some justification, there are those who lament the loss of unique flavors, forms or fragrances. There is also concern with the trend toward monoculture or sameness in all plants being grown.

title: Patricia D. Smith Marries
description: Patricia Diane Smith, daughter of Bernice V. Smith of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Robert H. Smith, was married yesterday to Staff Sgt. E. Edward Hooper, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Moses Hooper of Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Robert M. Davidson performed the ceremony at the West-Park Presbyterian Church in New York. The bride, until recently an executive secretary and departmental supervisor with National Utility Service Inc. in New York, graduated from Columbia University. The bridegroom is stationed at Shaw Air Force Base in Sumter, S.C.

title: EFFECTS OF TRAILER RULING AWAITED
description: HARTFORD THE shiny new signs had only been posted for a few days beside the Interstate highways entering Connecticut. ''Tandem Trailers Prohibited in Connecticut,'' they read. Last Monday afternoon, crews from the State Department of Transportation made the rounds and covered each sign with a sheet of plastic.

title: Lauren Ingersoll Plans to Be Wed To T.A. Murray
description: The engagement of Lauren Reeve Ingersoll to Thomas Anthony Murray has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps Ingersoll Jr. of Manhasset, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Brady Murray of Earlysville, Va.

title: HOW L.I. WILL PAY FOR SHOREHAM
description: THE Shoreham nuclear power plant, now scheduled for completion at a sum of $3.2 billion, is so expensive that Long Island would suffer serious economic consequences if its cost were passed along to consumers under the conventional rate-making method, according to consumer advocates and the Public Service Commission. Even the Long Island Lighting Company, the project's builder, acknowledges that special steps will have to be taken to phase in its cost, which will raise rates by about 50 percent.

title: 2 BANKS ANNOUNCE MERGER AGREEMENT
description: ONLY five days after a law permitting interstate banking was signed in Connecticut, a Hartford-based bank announced a merger that would create the second largest bank in New England.

title: Syria Extends Its Campaign Of Disruption
description: Syria last week did its best to prove that nobody wins in the Middle East. Seasoned losers themselves, the Syrians tried to undermine the Lebanese Government as punishment for its acceptance of the Israeli withdrawal accord that Damascus has rejected. The Lebanese Parliament voted, 65 to 2, last week to ratify the agreement, whereupon Damascus newspapers urged the terrorists who have been killing Israelis to launch assaults against the Government of President Amin Gemayel as well.

title: Miss Kean Is Married
description: Elizabeth Stuyvesant Kean, daughter of Hamilton Fish Kean and Ellen Shaw Kean, both of New York, was married yesterday to Philip LeBreton Douglas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Douglas, also of New York. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Leslie M. Chanler Becomes a Bride
description: Leslie Murray Chanler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bronson Winthrop Chanler of Rhinebeck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Allen Brooks, son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Brooks of Dedham, Mass. The Rev. Frederick Shafer, chaplain of Bard College, performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Barrytown, N.Y.

title: AIR FORCE SEEKING JOINT SPACE UNIT
description: The Air Force has recommended that its Space Command in Colorado become a unified, four-service command to control the nation's rapidly expanding military activities in space, according to senior officers in that service.

title: Maine Ships
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Terence Smith's article on the Maine Maritime Museum in Bath, entitled ''Rediscoverying the Era of Wooden Boats'' (Travel, May 1). I would like to bring your readers up to date, however, on one aspect of the museum that has changed since Mr. Smith wrote his piece.

title: VOLCKER'S RECORD
description: To the Business Editor: Lester Thurow's arguments for letting Paul Volcker go may or may not have merit. But he discredits himself with the statement: ''Inflation is to be repressed with permanent high unemployment.

title: The Fallout From The British Vote
description: Margaret Thatcher did more than win an election 10 days ago. Her landslide victory provoked a hecatomb last week in the leadership of the British opposition parties, and may even have given Moscow pause.

title: Article 241836 -- No Title
description: A Dade County Circuit Court has awarded $3 million to the parents of an 8-year-old boy who was buried alive in a sand pile next-door to his home and died four hours later. The court agreed with James Kaylor, a flight engineer, and his wife, Diana Kaylor, that the contractor who ordered the sand pile and the owner of the property it was on were guilty of negligence.

title: WHY BLACKS ARE USING A WIDER LENS
description: To the Editor:

title: GRIEVING FOR A CLOSED SCHOOL
description: EVERY school is special to its students, staff and alumni, and when a school board decides to close that school it comes as a traumatic shock to all concerned. Each group - parents, faculty, support staff and students - has its own reaction, but when the anger has subsided and all the hearings have ended the truth sets in: ''This beloved school will close next June.''

title: COURAGEOUS UPSETS LIBERTY IN OPENER
description: On a fog-shrouded Rhode Island Sound, Courageous pulled off a stunning upset victory over Liberty today in the opening of the United States trials to select an America's Cup defender.

title: IN JAPAN, PROBLEMS OF WORKING WOMEN
description: For Eiri Bessho, a recent graduate of Tokyo's prestigious Waseda University, job hunting was a nightmare. While men from her class were wooed with promises of lifetime employment and steady promotions by Japan's top corporations, the same companies made Miss Bessho very different offers.

title: SUPPORT
description: President Reagan reappointed Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board because of Mr. Volcker's aura of success and because, in the end, there was no alternative candidate who could challenge him, Administration officials said today.

title: OF SUMPS, PUMPS, AND INSURANCE
description: WITH the incessant rains of the past few months has come a f irsttime experience for thousands of suburban homeowners in the New Y ork metropolitan area - basement flooding.

T he small building along State Route 52, not far from Lexington in northern Kentucky, says much about the family business inside, the people who work there and the product they make. Constructed of weathered logs, its tin roof faded and streaked, the rambling shack could be just another rickety barn in a part of the country where such sights are common.

title: Miss Adams Wed To H.H. Miller 3d
description: Caroline Rule Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rule Adams Jr. of Bethesda, Md., and Hoyle Haywood Miller 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller Jr. of Annapolis, Md., were married yesterday. The Rev. P. Roger Bowen performed the ceremony in the Great Choir of the Episcopal Cathedral of Saint Peter and Saint Paul (National Cathedral).

title: THE CANADIAN DIFFERENCE
description: Mr. Kaufman speaks of trade-offs, but the major trade-off I've noticed is not mentioned in the article: the Government is accessible. For instance, in 11 months of lobbying, Canadian women won a guarantee of equality between the sexes in the new Constitution - at about the same time the E.R.A. fell to its deadline in the United States. PENNEY KOME Woman's Place Editor Homemaker's Magazine Toronto ------

title: RIPARIAN PLAN: HEARING IS SET
description: TRENTON ANEW proposal to solve a problem that has vexed thousands of coastal homeowners since the state claimed their land more than a year ago will be the subject of a hearing to be held this month.

title: Cranston Bests Hollings In Alabama Straw Poll
description: Senator Alan Cranston of California, in his second major boost in a week, today overwhelmingly defeated Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina in the Alabama Young Democrats' Presidential straw poll.

title: Arrest in Food Stamp Fraud
description: Dorothy Parrish, a 35-year-old fugitive identified as an organizer of a $250,000 food stamp fraud in Florida, has been arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Lieut. Gen. Winfield Scott Jr.  Is Air Force Academy Chief
description: Lieut. Gen. Winfield W. Scott Jr. has become the Air Force Academy's 10th superintendent.

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 19, 1983
description: International The Pope visited Czestochowa in Poland and addressing more than a million people, hailed the Polish people for their acts of ''solidarity'' with those who were interned or dismissed from work under martial law. His remark drew a tumultuous ovation, with many people raising their arms in a V-for-victory sign of resistance. (Page 1, Column 1.)

title: FRIVOLOUS ACTIVITIES; Newspaper Nuns
description: There's probably not a day in the life of American newspapers when one of them isn't featuring a photograph of a lost child licking an ice cream cone and wearing a police officer's cap.

title: Death Penalty The Jersey Way
description: For years, the New Jersey Legislature debated whether to reimpose the death penalty. It took less than a minute last week to decide how.

title: What a Way to Buy a Railroad
description: Once upon a time, owning a railroad was a ticket to plutocracy. But with robber barons few and far between these days, 40,000 Conrail employees last week offered to buy the largely Government-owned line themselves.

title: CHARACTER DANCE RETURNS WITH PANACHE
POPE HAILS THE 'SOLIDARITY' OF POLES AND GETS A TUMULTUOUS OVATION
description: Pope John Paul II, addressing a crowd estimated at more than a million people here, hailed the Polish people today for their acts of ''solidarity'' with those who were interned or dismissed from work under martial law. His remark drew a tumultuous ovation.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Hazardous Duty In April, 1982, after completing a scheduled six months of filming king penguins on South Georgia - a dependency of the Falkland Islands - two British filmmakers, Cindy Buxton and Annie Price, found that they were stranded by the Falklands' war. ''I suppose the first two or three days were the worst, the actual day we were invaded,'' Miss Buxton said. ''And then when the Argentines sent a radio message to us and said they were going to pick us up and take us back to Port Stanley, obviously, Annie and I were a little bit concerned. We just hoped that they would treat us as nicely as possible. But there wasn't very much we could do about it; there was just nowhere we could go, there was no alternative but to stay where we were.'' Their camp was reachable only by sea or air, but Royal Marines shut off those routes.

title: A NEW PRESIDENT IS NAMED BY CHINA
description: Li Xiannian, an old revolutionary warrior who went on to manage the national economy, was named China's President today, filling a post that has been vacant for 15 years.

title: COLLEGES JUGGLE PERFORMING-ART SCHEDULE
description: ALTHOUGH financial problems and shifts in academic emphasis have put a crimp in summer music and theater activities at Southampton College, Adelphi University and the State University at Stony Brook, the hot-weather performing arts are alive and seemingly well at the C.W. Post Center in Brookville. And with the Bach Aria Group returning to the State University's Fine Arts Center for its third annual Bach Aria Festival and Institute at Stony Brook, at least two Long Island campuses will be open to local music, dance and theater audiences this summer.

title: A PLEA FOR SHARING CHILD-REARING DUTY
description: THE occasions of Mother's Day and Father's Day seem reason enough to reflect on the way the roles of men and women in our society are changing -or are they?

title: LITERARY INVECTIVE
description: I called Lillian Hellman's lawyer the other day to ask what had become of the $2.25 million libel suit that she initiated against Mary McCarthy more than three years ago. He promised that it would finally come to trial this year. If this suit, which has elicited reservations even among those who hold a higher opinion of Miss Hellman's career than Miss McCarthy does, should actually reach the courtroom, no matter what the jury decides it is bound to diminish Miss McCarthy's purse, Miss Hellman's reputation as a friend of free expression and the vigor of literary dispute in America, none of which is in particularly robust shape.

title: The Art Of the Sauna
description: About 2,000 years ago the idea was the same as it is today, but the execution was primitive: a hole in the ground, some heated stones and water to pour on the stones to raise steam. Since then, the sauna has come a long way and its popularity has spread to many corners of the world.

title: LYME STUDENTS TO GET OBSERVATORY
description: STUDYING astronomy in Lyme-Old Lyme Regional School District 18 used to mean rigorous study, a look or two through a small telescope and perhaps a trip to a planetarium.

title: U.N. STUDY SEES SLOWER GROWTH IN POPULATION
description: A worldwide effort to limit population growth is beginning to achieve results, according to a United Nations study.

title: EVEN THE UPRIGHT FED CAN SOMETIMES NOD TO POLITICS
description: It was late in 1965, and defense spending was rising after years of quiescence, and with it inflation was bubbling up again. Concerned, the governors of the Federal Reserve Board jacked up the discount rate, the interest that it charges banks for loans from the Fed. It was only half a percentage point but an action, nevertheless, that many believed would cool a hyperactive economy by forcing up interest rates everywhere.

title: Playing Favorites
description: To the Sports Editor: Jim Brown of Syracuse may be, as Ken Molloy states, the ''greatest lacrosse player who ever lived'' (Sports World Specials, The New York Times, June 6).

title: South Korean Dissidents End Hunger Strike
description: Five leading South Korean dissidents ended a 19-day hunger strike today but pledged to continue their fight for the restoration of democracy.

title: Sally Goldfarb to Wed Joseph N. Straus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goldfarb of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Fay Goldfarb, to Joseph Nathan Straus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Straus 3d of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: IN THE SWISS VALAIS, RACLETTE IS A RITUAL; PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a correspondent for The New York Times, lives in Rome.
description: As far back as people can remember, the mountaineers of the upper Rhone Valley, the Valais, have had their own way of preparing a quick and easy meal that sticks to the ribs. The cheese dish, known as raclette, has won growing favor with city people from Geneva and Zurich and with other visitors who flock to the Alpine region around the year.

title: PECONIC NOW PROTECTED AS A 'SCENIC RIVER'
description: THE Peconic River has white perch and catfish, carp and eels, largemouth bass and chain pickerel. The woods and fields, the old cranberry bogs and marshes through which it flows are home to Canada geese, coots, mallards, grebes, web-tailed hawks, distinguished, often ferocious mute swans, and sky blue herons. Deer hide in the bushes, turtles bask on the rocks, and near the headwaters there are mink, raccoon, red fox, woodcock and ruffled grouse.

title: In Office, Out of a Job
description: Would the Knoxville News-Sentinel be or appear to be any less objective if one of its reporters sat on the school board of a small town 25 miles away? Jacqueline B. McClary didn't think so when she ran for the Alcoa, Tenn., seat, but her boss did when she won it, so he fired her. Mrs. McClary, who is contesting the dismissal, said last week she thought she had a ''constitutional right to hold office'' while working as a reporter since her job did not involve covering events in Alcoa. A rival newspaper, The Knoxville Journal, also criticized the action, noting that the editor who fired Mrs. McClary continued to sit on the city parking authority.

title: A FATHER'S ROLE
description: WHEN we were growing up, we were always within reach of the sound of my father's voice. He worked as an announcer for a radio station in the city, and it was a simple matter to turn the knob on the little box to hear him speak. It was his livelihood, and we took it for granted.

title: WHY ALL THESE MYSTERIES?
description: In recent weeks, several mysterious new dances have been presented in New York. One was a choreographic ''whodunit,'' while others were almost metaphysically mysterious. In every case, however, a choreographer appeared to be declaring, ''I love a mystery!''

title: COUNTY PLANS NEW STEPS ON EVACUATION
description: TELEPHONES may soon start ringing in homes of off-duty county employees who would be involved in future nuclear-accident drills ''just to see if on a weekend we could actually get in touch,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week.

title: WOMEN'S LEADERS HAIL SALLY RIDE
description: Women who blazed trails in their own professions hailed the space mission of the astronaut Sally K. Ride yesterday as a giant leap for American women.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: HERNANDEZ IS UPBEAT ON THE METS
description: After the third game of the World Series last year, Keith Hernandez, in a batting slump and guilty of a fielding error against Milwaukee, taped forks to each of his hands.

title: BILL BACKED BY HELMS VETOED
description: President Reagan vetoed legislation today that Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, had argued was vital to the North Carolina School of the Arts in Winston-Salem.

title: New Jersey to Join 7th Fleet
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. NEW JERSEY (AP) - The battleship New Jersey has arrived in Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on the way to join the Seventh Fleet in the western Pacific on her first mission in 14 years. In December the refitted 887-foot battleship was recommissioned by President Reagan.

title: POPE HONORS THE SAINT OF AUSCHWITZ
description: Pope John Paul II, on the third day of his visit to Poland, paid homage today to the victims of the Nazi occupation.

title: Nancy Ellen Rogers Weds Richard William Ohaus
description: Nancy Ellen Rogers of New Canaan, Conn., daughter of Mrs. Charles F. Rogers of Rumford, R.I., and the late Mr. Rogers, was married yesterday to Richard William Ohaus, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Ohaus of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. William J. O'Halloran, assisted by the Rev. Normand Demers, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Providence, R.I.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
SEEKING SIGHTINGS
description: For those who must go down to the sea in ships these days, but prefer a few extra added attractions, the South Fork-Shelter Island chapter of the Nature Conservancy and the Okeanos Ocean Research Foundation have scheduled a whale-birdwatching trip today. Humpback, sei and blue whales, dolphins, porpoises, gannets, shearwaters, fulmars, petrels and phalaropes are in the waters off Montauk, waiting to be spotted by eager binoculars. The boat leaves the Sportsmen Dock on West Lake Drive in Montauk at 10 A.M., and a few reservations, at $30 a person to benefit both organizations, may still be available by calling 267-3748.FAMILY ARTS DAY

title: Good Tidings Ahead
description: Next week, there will be some of the best news so far about the recovery. Almost daily, economists have been lifting their forecasts for economic growth in the second quarter. Robert Ortner, chief economist of the Commerce Department, is now musing about an 8 percent surge in the gross national product after adjustment for inflation. Just a few days ago, he was predicting ''at least 6 percent.'' And a month ago, the estimate was in the 3 percent range.The first official measure of growth for the quarter will come with the G.N.P. flash figure due out Tuesday.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: SATAN: His Psychotherapy and Cure by the Unfortunate Dr. Kassler, J.S.P.S. By Jeremy Leven. (Ballantine, $3.95.) The devil undergoes psychoanalysis in this ''boisterous, wonderfully disturbing'' novel that our critic, Peter Andrews, said ''mixes religion, sex, science fiction and black comedy with considerable skill.'' ''Satan,'' he declared, contains a complex theological colloquy, a savage indictment of modern mental health procedures, a mad-scientist horror story and, every so often, ''the kind of great, rolling belly laughs S.J. Perelman used to get.''

title: Able Money Is Winner in Mother Goose
description: Able Money, a tough little filly with an excellent record but few supporters, finally won some respect yesterday with a gritty frontrunning victory in the $140,250 Mother Goose Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Belmont Park.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
UNSETTLING A DELICATE BALANCE
description: THE Reagan Administration is correct in placing greater emphasis on t rade, but mistaken in urging creation of a new trade department to f urther its objectives.

title: A Soprano Is Honored
description: Nadja Witkowska, a soprano, is the recipient of the 1983 Woman of the Year award of the Orchard Lake Schools Alumni Association Ladies Auxiliary in Orchard Lake, Mich., a suburb of Detroit. Miss Witkowska was born in Detroit, where she and her family have been active in Polish-American affairs. Now a soloist with the St. Patrick's Cathedral Choir, Miss Witkowska has sung with the Metropolitan Opera, the New York City Opera and numerous opera companies and symphonies throughout the country.

title: FLUORIDE RINSE IN SCHOOLS QUESTIONED
description: FLUORIDE mouth rinse programs for Long Island schoolchildren - including one considered a national model program - have recently become snagged in the kind of controversy that fluoride seems unable to shake. Some parents have voiced opposition to the rinse programs, known as ''Swish and Spit,'' which give students in grades K-6 a fluoride rinse once a week to help reduce tooth decay.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a review last week of an art exhibition in Westhampton Beach, the first name of one of the artists was given incorrectly. The artist is Charles Schucker.

title: THE REAL PROBLEM
description: Tick-tick-tick-tick-tick-tick-tick. ...

title: Miss Ferro Is Married To David Blair Barrett
description: At St. Gabriel's Roman Catholic Church in Saddle River, N.J., yesterday, Kathleen Elizabeth Ferro and David Blair Barrett, 1981 graduates of Alfred University, were married by the Rev. Edward F. Kavin.

title: CHILD'S PLAY FOR VISITORS IN BRITAIN By Sara C Evans; SARA C. EVANS is a New York-based writer.
description: T his is my London dream day: Up at the crack of, breakfast-on-thehoof while antiquing at the Caledonian Market in the gray, Bermondsey dawn, ever on the lookout for the perfect piece of black Wedgwood, the definitive 18th-century watchfob, a perfect gypsy ring; by cab to the Haymarket, to check out Burberrys, some serious shopping at Harvey Nichols, quick nap and shower back at the Savoy before meeting friends for tea at the Connaught; then the evening performance at the Royal Court, followed by an elegant supper at Inigo Jones. This is my London nightmare: Doing all the foregoing with my 7-year-old son in tow.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Frivolous Activities Reflect and Repent

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GARRETT'S FOREIGN AND ANCIENT COINS TO BE SOLD
description: The foreign and ancient portions of the famed Garrett Collection will be sold at a series of three public auctions that are tentatively scheduled to start next spring. The sale will be conducted jointly by Numismatic Fine Arts Inc. of Beverly Hills, Calif., and Bank Leu Limited of Zurich, Switzerland.

title: Carole Fox Weds At Groton School
description: Carole Denise Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Keith Fox of Groton, Mass., and Lancaster, N.H., was married yesterday to Ens. Peter Hedden Congleton, U.S.N., son of Richard Jerome Congleton of Groton, Mass., and Oxford, Me., and Sandra Orr Congleton of Somerville, Mass.

title: ON CONDOMINIUMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wales
description: To the Editor: In all the panegyrics itemized in ''Capturing the Essence of Wales'' (Travel, May 22), I looked in vain for a mention of my own favorite spots. Should the Lleyn Peninsula (the ''Land's End'' of Wales) have changed so much within the last 20 years when I last saw it that it deserves not even a marking on the map? I had heard rumors that the tongue-twisting little town of Pwllheli had been practically turned over to one of Butlin's Holiday Camps but has that affected the small settlements on the south and north coasts? o word to spare for Abersoch and Llanbedrog, for the beautiful bay of Hell's Mouth (Porth Neigwl), for Aberdaron at the southernmost tip and the two Nefyns on the north shore? Nobody who has made it as far as Criccieth should turn round or cut back but continue along the coast.

title: LANSING
description: GOV. JAMES J. BLANCHARD likes to compare his situation when he took office to that of Lee A. Iacocca at the Chrysler Corporation in 1979. Both chief executives, he says, faced imminent financial disaster and had to take immediate, distasteful steps to avoid insolvency. Mr. Iacocca has become something of an industrial hero for rescuing Chrysler by means of massive layoffs, concessions from workers and $1.2 billion in Federal loan guarantees. Mr. Blanchard is not quite a hero to some.

title: HIGH COURT CLEARS UP ANY DOUBTS ON ABORTION
description: A key part of the antiabortion movement's strategy during the past few years has been to ''send the Supreme Court a message.'' According to this scenario, continual efforts to amend the Constitution and to strip the Court of its jurisdiction to decide abortion cases would keep the pressure on Justices who have grown increasingly weary and conservative, eventually persuading them to reconsider their 1973 decision that established a constitutional right to abortion.

title: BILLY CUNNINGHAM: THE 76ERS 2 TITLES
description: IPLAYED on the Philadelphia 76ers' 1966-67 team that won the National Basketball Association championship. I am the coach of the7 6ers' team that won the title this season. Which team was better? I realize comparisons of this type are a major topic among sports f ans, but it's a question that I find impossible to answer. There are a lot of similarilties between both teams, but 16 years i s a long time in the fast-moving game of pro basketball. Player s tyles have changed and coaching has become more sophisticated.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: DISTANT OBLIGATIONS Modern American Writers and Foreign Causes. By David C. Duke. 326 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50 By TOM CHAFFIN

title: James Bedell Wed To Lisa Schrader
description: Elizabeth Bear Schrader, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cutler Schrader of Hingham, Mass., formerly of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to James Michael Bedell, son of Mary C. Miller of Tempe, Ariz., and James L. Bedell of Flagstaff, Ariz.

title: Indian Museum Needs a Shelter
description: ''I could advertise the Second Coming and nobody would come up here for it,'' said Roland W. Force, the director of the Museum of the American Indian-Heye Foundation, possibly the world's finest collection of Indian artifacts from North, Central and South America.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: TURN RIGHT AT THE RHODODENDRON
description: I'M writing a new song to be called ''Gardening Is a Sometime Thing.'' Now, the only problem is getting words to rhyme with dig, mulch and earwig. When we moved to Long Island, our orientation was strictly city. Our former landmarks were buildings, stores or, at times, restaurants. We soon found out that things were quite a bit different here on the Island.

title: IN ALBERTA, HELP ISN'T JUST AROUND THE CORNER
description: When Bill Yarrow decided to move to Alberta from Montreal in 1975, his wife was not sure where the province was located. ''It's north of Montana,'' he told her. Several years later, such ignorance would have been most unlikely.

title: A FATHER'S GIFT
description: A SECRET hiding place -what delicious childhood images that phrase conjures up to me. It means love notes from my 13-year-old passion of the moment, top secret gossip and bits of trivia from my girlfriends, my diary containing my innermost thoughts.

title: Miss Staniford Marries Francis Joseph Reid Jr.
description: Virginia Bulkeley Staniford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rockwell Simpson Staniford of Fenwick, Conn., was married yesterday to Francis Joseph Reid Jr., son of Mrs. Reid and the late Mr. Reid of Old Lyme, Conn. The Rev. Joshua L. Crowell, minister of the First Congregational Church in Essex, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Staniford home.

title: PEACE PROPONENT IS FONDLY RECALLED
description: NEW HAVEN A LOT of people who never met John Marsalka will remember him anyway - as the person who sometimes would not shut up on radio callin shows.

title: IN HARTFORD, THE MAJORITY DOESN'T ALWAYS RULE
description: There was no air conditioning in the General Assembly last week, but that wasn't the only reason the state's Democrats were sweating. Despite solid majorities in both houses and a Democratic Governor elected by a wide margin in the fall, party leaders worked overtime to accomplish what they had failed to do for five months: pass a budget and the tax increases to balance it.

title: Canadian Rockies
description: To the Editor: I was gratified to see a mention of Canada's littleknown Yoho National Park in British Columbia in the ''Visitor's Guide to the Rockies'' (Travel, May 15). spent some time in Yoho in the ''Land of the Lordly Moose,'' as it was called in 1939.

title: UPSTATE ARBORETUM GIVES UP ON SOLAR HEATING
description: After five years of solar heating, the Cary Arboretum here is dismantling its system and replacing it with propane gas.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Briermere Farm in Riverhead was omitted from a recent listing of Long Island farms offering ''pick-your-own'' fruits and vegetables. Briermere, at 79 Sound Avenue (telephone 722-3931), is open to the public for strawberry picking on weekends from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. For the raspberry season in July, prospective pickers are asked to call in advance to determine whether the berries are available. Other picking seasons at the farm generally run as follows: peaches, end of August through September; pears, end of August through September; apples, last week of September through October.

title: A TRUMPETER AT HOME WITH JAZZ AND THE CLASSICS
description: The 21-year-old trumpeter Wynton Marsalis is running out of worlds to conquer. While still in his teens, he came to national attention playing with Art Blakey and the Jazz Messengers. He soon became one of a handful of mainstream jazz musicians with a major-label (CBS) recording contract, and last year his debut LP as a leader sold 100,000 copies, an extraordinary figure for an album that used no electric instruments. He also won the annual Down Beat jazz poll as Artist of the Year.

title: T.S. Jewett Wed To Miss McCune
description: Elizabeth Rebecca McCune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Foster McCune of Bethesda, Md., and Thomas Sanford Jewett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeborn Garrettson Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va., were married yesterday in the Great Choir of the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul (National Cathedral) in Washington by Bishop John Thomas Walker.

title: AN ARTIST LOOKS ANEW AT COLOR
description: Since he began photographing more than 40 years ago, Harry Callahan has been taking color pictures, more or less as an adjunct to the black-and-white images for which he is best known. For the past six years, however, he has devoted himself exclusively to color. His decision to abandon black and white may be due in part to a desire to avoid, at age 70, the drudgery of the darkroom, but it also is a sign of the increased importance that color has attained in the past decade within the arena of art photography.

title: No Headline

title: REASSESSING THE FAIRNESS DOCTORINE
description: Irving R. Kaufman is a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, where he was Chief Judge from 1973 to 1980.

title: Correction
description: Incorrect credits were given May 8 for the photographs on the Home Design pages. The photographer was Edgar De Evia and the flowers were by Madderlake.

title: G.J. Miller Wed To Bijou Clinger
description: Eleanore Whitla Clinger, daughter of Representative William F. Clinger Jr., Republican of Pennsylvania, and Mrs. Clinger of Warren, Pa., and Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Gregory John Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew W. Miller of Steubenville, Ohio. The Rev. Eleanore Whitla Drury, the bride's aunt, performed a Protestant ceremony in the Hall of Philosophy, at the Chautauqua (N.Y.) Institution, a cultural and educational center.

title: JOURNEYING BACK IN TIME AT, YES, THE WHITNEY
description: The news of the week from the Whitney Museum of American Art is that it has taken aboard some prehistoric pots. This is the more remarkable in that not only prehistory but history in general has hitherto played at most a subordinate role in the Whitney's affairs. The museum has mounted some very good shows of Colonial and early post-Colonial art in the past 10 years, but by and large it was intended to be, and has always been, a place in which the living American artist would feel at home. As for the far past of this continent, it had to be sought out above all in the Museum of the American Indian, or in the American Museum of Natural History, rather than in the Whitney.

title: Donald P. Blakeslee Jr.  Wed to Miss Sulimirski
description: Elizabeth M. Sulimirski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Witold S. Sulimirski of Bronxville, N.Y., and Donald Powell Blakeslee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blakeslee, also of Bronxville, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Bedingfield performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church in Bronxville, assisted by Msgr.

title: A SUMMERY SALAD OF THEATER FARE
description: THE normal diet of summer theater is usually light and lively, topped by standard musicals. There are the ever-popular ''plays-inthe-park,'' not to mention a plethora of musicals and perhaps a Neil Simon comedy here and there.

title: OLD SOLDIER'S TRAIL LEADS TO BROADWAY
description: Until Bill Turner started searching the country for the personal belongings of a general who died 134 years ago, the most unusual thing he had ever done was use his cabin cruiser as a customers' waiting room at his fence company here.

title: Majority Enterprise
description: To traditional building materials -mortar, brick, glass, steel - contractors seeking New York projects have evidently added another: whole cloth. The State Commission of Investigation disclosed last week that some construction firms had created fictitious subcontracting companies, purportedly headed by minority group members, to qualify for construction contracts with the state and local governments.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
THE RIGHT FIT
description: Alan Flusser, the men's-wear designer, is the author of ''Making the Man.''

title: MIDDLETOWN REACHES OUT IN 2D PHASE OF ITS RENEWAL
description: FOR years, Middletown was the image of the deteriorating small city; its fine old brick downtown had been plastered with 1940's and 50's facades that, in turn, had begun to rust and decay.

title: COLUMBUS
