description: ON the eve of his first 100 days as Ohio's new Democratic Governor, Richard F. Celeste went to the Cleveland Indians' opening game and got booed by his hometown crowd. The reception made it clear that no honeymoon was in store. With the state's unemployment rate dogging the mid-teens for the last few years and a budget deficit estimated at $500 million, Mr. Celeste and his staff had decided that some unpopular but essential steps had to be taken.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: DELAYED eight months, the paving of the pathway that leads strollers, bicyclists and joggers along the Bronx River in Tuckahoe and Eastchester is expected to be completed next month.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYAlfred Stieglitz is a central figure in the history of American art photography both as a photographer and as an impresario of photography, and the collection of prints owned by the National Gallery in Washington is the one he himself designated as the most representative of his work. Some 150 photographs from this group are now on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art through Aug. 14, giving New Yorkers a chance to judge for themselves the nature of Stieglitz's achievement as a photographer.

title: INDIAN CHIEFTAINS PROTEST EAGLE INDICTMENTS
description: Alvin Zephier remembers being told as a child how the buffalo and eagle once roamed the land and the skies, free of the white man's bureaucratic rules.

title: THE CANDIAN DIFFERENCE
description: As a Canadian and a journalist, working in the United States, I agreed with many of Michael Kaufman's observations. However, he has exaggerated the differences between our two peoples - at the Canadians' expense.

title: Nuclear Power, Bonding Power
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System, which bet heavily on the future of nuclear power, may be headed for the largest meltdown in the history of the tax-exempt bond market. A Washington State Supreme Court ruling last week left the power authority without the means to pay off $2.25 billion in construction bonds issued for two nuclear power plants that were not finished.

title: CON ED MANAGERS REPLACE STRIKERS
description: Consolidated Edison Company workers went on strike at 12:01 A.M. yesterday in four boroughs of New York City and in Westchester County, but the company said that supervisory personnel had taken over vital jobs to avoid an interruption in service.

title: SCHOOL CLOSINGS SPELL END OF AN ERA
description: SOME more of Stamford's residential nature died last week. Rippowam High School, which opened in 1961 when Stamford was mostly a city of homes and families and residents who traveled to New York to work, was closed because of declining enrollment.

title: YEARS LATER, VACATIONS SPONSORED BY FRESH AIR FUND ARE RECALLED FONDLY
description: Arnold Keith remembers vividly the first time he saw a bull. He and a friend picked up some stones and hurled them between the slats of a picket fence, teasing the animal. Suddenly the bull came toward them.

title: NELSON PURSUES LEADERS
description: By Larry Nelson's count, he tried ''498'' kinds of strokes to break his putting slump before finding one that worked. With the help of the 499th, Nelson reversed today what has been a dismal season.

title: SOME DISCORD IS SEEN IN PLANNING FOR 350-YEAR JUBILEE
description: SOME discord has arisen over how the observance of the 350th anniversary of the founding of Connecticut's three oldest towns should conclude three years from now.

title: RECRUITING A DOCTOR
description: THE screening committee of the South Fork Community Health Initiative selected a doctor last week to participate in setting up a practice to provide medical care to residents including Medicaid and low-income patients. The recommendation is subject to approval by the group's governing board, which will meet on Tuesday.

title: SUSIE'S WEDDING
description: To the Editor:

title: AUSTRALIAN ASSURES U.S. ON USE OF JOINT BASES
description: Prime Minister Robert Hawke of Australia, ending a visit to the United States, has reaffirmed his country's determination to maintain joint military installations with the United States on Australian territory, even though this entails risk.

title: MUSIC: STEVEN RICHMAN AND HARMONIE ENSEMBLE
description: The Harmonie Ensemble, a skilled group of wind players directed by Steven Richman, had some unusual music for its audience at St. Peter's Church in the Citicorp Center Friday night. Darius Milhaud's Symphony No. 5 for 10 wind instruments is not that often played.

title: by Kendall J. Wills
description: Caught off guard over a year ago by Sony's announcement that it would begin marketing a totally electronic photography system, several camera companies quickly attempted to develop their own systems. They saw the promise of a booming new business and booming new profits.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: OFFICER Thomas Morrissey of the New Haven police has been trying to emphasize the importance of academics to the inner-city high school students he coaches on the basketball team sponsored by the Police Department. So, he enlisted the help of Michael McKay, who spent the last semester starting to catch up on the 21 credits he had not completed while playing four years of basketball for the University of Connecticut.

title: DISABLED ENTERING WORLD OF COMPUTERS
description: LAST May 16 marked a big day for Peter Milkey. After having spent six months as a trainee, the 25-year-old Mount Kisco resident was promoted to associate computer programmer at the Reader's Digest. ''I was really thrilled,'' Mr. Milkey said. ''If I can do it, anyone can do it.'' Then he paused and added, ''Especially with my disability.''

title: Geoffrey W. Parnass Weds Miss Tscherny
description: Nadia Tscherny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Tscherny of New York, was married yesterday to Geoffrey Wagner Parnass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wagner Parnass of Saranac Lake, N.Y. Judge Harold Silverman of New York City Civil Court performed the ceremony at the Tscherny home in Manhattan.

title: DEBATE GROWS OVER ADOPTION OF NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: The ills of the American economy are obvious - high interest rates, high unemployment, low productivity, uncompetitive plants.

title: CULTIVATING CULTURE IN PARIS
description: Justine De Lacy reports that the French considered a nickname for Paris, a la New York's Big Apple, but decided against it. But I'm sure our foremost Francophile, Miss Piggy, would have two suggestions: Le Grand Pond or, in tribute to the fleur-de-lis, Le Grand Pad de Lily. ERIC HYMAN Somerset, N.J.

title: Dian Larkin and John S. Diaconis, Lawyers, Marry
description: Dian M. Larkin, daughter of Mrs. Ronald Veyo of Indiana, Pa., and William Barnum Larkin of Kansas City, Mo., was married yesterday to John S. Diaconis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel J. Diaconis of Oceanside, L.I. The ceremony was performed at Mrs. Veyo's home by Judge Earl L. Handler of the Court of Common Pleas of the 40th Judicial District in Pennsylvania.

title: PEWTER: GOOD FOR MORE THAN ALE
description: ALL that glitters in the metals market isn't gold, or even silver. However, when it comes to antiques, pewter more than holds its own. Which brings one to Habbakuk O. Westman, an English public-school teacher. Writing about pewter spoons in 1845, Westman digressed a bit to observe:

title: THE MET PLANS ITS CENTENARY
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present five ''Live from the Met'' telecasts next season over the Public Broadcasting Service network. Following what has become common Met practice, only one of these will actually be live. The other four will have been videotaped - at live performances, to be sure - some only a few days, others nearly two years prior to the telecasts.

title:
FROM POINT REYES TO THE TOP OF THE STATE;
DONALD E. WESTLAKE is a novelist who lives in New York. His latest book is ''Why Me'' (Viking).
description: In many trips to California I'd always understood that Los Angeles was ''southern'' while San Francisco was ''northern,'' with nothing beyond it upstate but a few vineyards. The truth is that San Francisco is central California, being (as flown by our old friend the crow) about 550 miles north of Mexico and 400 south of Oregon. That unknown coast of northern California, I was recently told, is among the most beautiful in the world. Oh, really? Finding ourselves in San Francisco with a rented car and a few days off, we decided to drive north and see what happened.

title: A PLACE 67 BUFFALOES CALL HOME
description: THOSE who would look for a home where the buffalo roam need search no farther than Homestead Farms in Stormville. There, near the Putnam-Dutchess border, just 20 miles or so from Westchester, Charles S. Tucker Jr. keeps a herd of 67 buffalo. He also has beef cattle, sheep, lambs and a few pigs, but it is the buffalo, raised for meat, that bring a soft, amused look to his eye and an affectionate tone to his voice.

title: Victoria von Gontard to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Adalbert von Gontard Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria von Gontard, to Spyros Solon Skouras Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Skouras of Greenwich, Conn., and New York.

title: STATE WILL TEST HOME CARE FOR AGED
description: BEFORE Vera B., a 61-year-old stroke victim with a bad heart, died in a Jersey City nursing home two weeks ago, nurses said that she was still asking to be at home with her husband.

title: 25 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 25 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it department named 13 that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and 5 that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: SUSIE'S WEDDING
description: To the Editor:

title: CONSIDERING THE BENEFITS OF SPECIAL SCREENING
description: WHEN window screens and door screens are installed, homeowners normally expect them to do only one job - keep out flying and crawling insects. However, a specialized type of insect screening introduced several years ago also does a second job.

title: BLACK FESTIVAL SET
description: NEWARK THE ninth annual Newark Black Film Festival will begin and end with two native sons - Amiri Baraka of Newark, the political activist and writer, and Richard Wesley of Montclair, screenwriter and playwright.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE FAVERSHAMS Written and illustrated by Roy Gerrard. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 6 to 9) By JANICE PRINDLE

title: Israeli Digs
description: To the Editor: The selection of 14 archeological excavations in Israel that accept volunteers, as published in ''The ABC's of Joining an Archeological Dig'' (Travel, April 24), was not a complete listing. The booklet ''Archeological Excavations, 1983,'' published by the Department of Antiquities and Museums in Jerusalem (P.O. Box 586), enumerates 26 projects accepting volunteers this spring and summer.

title: Volcker's Record
description: To the Business Editor: After reading Professor Thurow's article (''Why Volcker Should Be Let Go,'' June 5) it's difficult to determine if he considers himself an optimist or a pessimist, given current monetary policy. But one thing is indeed certain: Fed Chairman Volcker is a realist.

title: GARMENT INDUSTRY IN CHINATOWN SEEKING AID
description: A call to protect Chinatown's garment industry from residential and commercial encroachment and to establish a private development agency to marshal resources for the industry has been made in a two-year union and industry study.

title: RENOVATIONS BEGIN ON 1ST BRANCH HERE OF FEDERAL COURT
description: LAST Monday, contractors began work on a project that will create a branch of the Federal District Court in the center of this city, bringing to fruition an effort started 12 years ago.

title: PLAYING IT SERIOUSLY IN SUMMER STOCK
description: To the industrious, summer means vacation. To the ambitious and the slow, it's the season of extra credit and remedial classes. In the theater, summer is a little of both, a chance to play in a more bucolic and preferably less grueling environment as well as an opportunity to stretch a talent that's been cooped up all year in a television series or to try something new that might end up on Broadway.

title: BOND RATINGS-THE PLAIN AND ARCANE; by Michael E. Quint
description: IN the municipal bond market, where more than 40,000 different governments, agencies and authorities have bonds o utstanding, individual investors have little alternative than to r ely on the ratings of Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & P oor's Corporation. Without a rating, how can the investor decide b etween bonds of Pennsylvania and Alabama? Without ratings, investorsw ould be completely baffled by the thousands of small issues that m ay be unfamiliar even to the securities firms that sell them.

title: VIDEO ARTISTS STILL SEEK A SHOWCASE FOR THEIR WORKS
description: For at least a decade now, especially since the portable videotape camera arrived on the electronics scene and people began tinkering with techniques known as feedback and computerized images, there has been a very special product called ''video art.'' The label is almost irritatingly loose, covering everything from independent documentaries to 90-second spurts of music, from chamber works designed for the delectation of a chosen few to pieces included in museum exhibitions for the curiosity of a vast public. The most common denominator, perhaps, is that the content is tightly controlled by the artist or artists producing the work. A guiding vision can be sensed. These are not assembly-line artifacts coming out of a factory, in Hollywood or New York, for easy mass consumption.

title: AIR FARE BARGAINS OVER THE ATLANTIC
description: T he vacation travel days of summer are upon us, that time of year welcomed by the airlines as their ''peak load'' season when trans-Atlantic jets are often filled and when the airlines offer all sorts of bargain fares to insure that they remain filled until September.

title: ESTIMATES OF ALIENS BAFFLE U.S.
description: At least two million aliens are in the United States illegally, but the Census Bureau says it cannot figure out how many more there might be.

title: E.P.A. Sticks To Its Course On Water Policy
description: If the Reagan Administration baked a new pudding of environmental policies after the shakeup at the Environmental Protection Agency, it has yet to provide the proof. Last week, Congress held hearings to reauthorize the Clean Water Act, one of a cluster of landmark environmental statutes now expiring.

title: LEWIS ANDREAS
description: Lewis Andreas, the former Syracuse University athletic director and the school's top-winning basketball coach, died here Thursday. He was 88 years old. Mr. Andreas coached Syracuse basketball teams for 26 years, compiling a record of 355-134, a winning percentage of 73 percent. He was head coach of Syracuse football from 1927 to 1929, compiling a record of 15 victories, 10 losses and 3 ties.

title: Policemen in West Berlin Clash With Protesters
description: Policemen in West Berlin and in Celle, West Germany, using tear gas, water cannon and clubs, battled thousands of protesters today during two demonstrations, one involving leftists and the other neo-Nazis.

title: Alexander Donat Dies at 78; Published Holocaust Books
description: Alexander Donat, a survivor of Nazi concentration camps and founder of Holocaust Library Publications in New York, died of a pulmonary illness Thursday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was a resident of Manhattan and was 78 years old.

title: HERPES: BURROUGHS WELLCOME SEES ITS TREATMENT AS A WAY TO CURE PROFIT ILLS
description: RESEARCH TRIANGLE PARK, N.C. ON 5,800 acres, just west of Raleigh, N.C., laboratories dot the heavily wooded terrain that forms one of the nation's largest research centers. Here, scientists in white lab coats come and go, absorbed in tasks for such corporate giants as I.B.M., General Electric and Data General.

title: A SCHOOL PRIORITY BEYOND THE COMPUTER
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA'S COMMITMENT
description: THE University of California Press, whose books have received a great deal of critical attention in recent years, is by far the largest among state university presses. In fact, measured by the number of new hard-cover titles published, it is the largest academic press in the country, with 3,000 books in print and about 150 new titles and 75 paperback reprints issued every year. Its editorial director, William McClung, points out that it also has the most eclectic publishing program. Its current list includes works in Asian studies, art, film, English and American literature, world literature, classics, history, the social sciences and the physical and life sciences.

title: LIFE OF A CANTOR
description: Cantor Solomon Mendelsohn of Congregation Beth Shalom on Long Island will conduct a three-day seminar this week at the University of Hartford on ''The Cantorate as a Career.'' Tuition for three days, Monday through Wednesday, is $100, and 1.5 academic credits may be earned.

title: IBERIA WAITS AT EUROPE'S THRESHOLD
description: For Spain and Portugal, Western Europe means the Common Market. Their long effort to join it will be six years old next month and after so many vows of good intentions and so many postponements, they are beginning to feel like brides left at the altar.

title: On Condominiums
description: To the Editor:

title: Unplugging Ears
description: A ban on the wearing of headphones - one of the first in the nation - went into effect in the streets of Woodbridge Township, N.J., last Oct. 7, and before the day was out a protester had received the first summons. The ban, which carried a maximum penalty of a $50 fine and 15 days in jail, was intended to protect portable stereo addicts from traffic accidents.

title: CABARET: LEATA GALLOWAY
description: Leata Galloway's career as a singer has hit an unusual mixture of peaks. She went from two and a half years on Broadway in ''Hair'' and in the subsequent screen version, to stardom in West Germany in the late 1970's as a rock singer and jazz singer on records, to films and concert halls and most recently to acclaim for her appearance in the Los Angeles version of the Duke Ellington musical, ''Sophisticated Ladies.''

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH GATHERS MOMENTUM; by Nathaniel C. Nash
description: Upbeat economic news abounded last week, leaving little doubt that the recovery will be stronger than previously expected. Economists on Wall Street and in Washington joined the celebration, raising their predictions almost daily for the economy's growth. Housing starts led the way, jumping 19.1 percent in May to their highest levels in three and a half years, while industrial output rose 1.1 percent last month and car sales climbed 21.1 percent in early June. More important, the big liquidation of inventories by retailers, wholesalers and manufacturers that accompanied the recession came to an end in April. For the first time in more than a year business stocks actually rose.

title: WATSON TIED WITH BALLESTEROS
description: Tom Watson, the defending champion, and Seve Ballesteros, the spectacular Spanish golfer, were tied for the lead after three rounds of the 83d United States Open today. These two long hitters were at one-under-par 212 for 54 holes at the difficult Oakmont Country Club course.

title: STRIKING PAY DIRT IN THE GOLD COUNTRY
description: You rock the pan slowly with your palms, rotating it back and forth. The icy water from the stream sluices over the side, your head fills with the aroma of nearby pine trees, and you scan the bottom of the pan, looking for the elusive sparkle in the sand that locals call ''color.''

title: Mozambique to Send Jobless to Countryside
description: The Mozambican Government today gave unemployed city dwellers two weeks to register for transfer to the countryside in a move aimed at clearing them from cities and setting them to work on the land.

title:
DINING OUT;
A NEW FEATHER IN WESTFIELD'S CAP
description: FOR THE last three and a half years, Westfield has been the home of Chez Catherine, a French restaurant that we consider to be one of the best in the state. Now this Union County town also has a good Italian restaurant.

title: ALFRED J. YARDLEY
description: Alfred J. Yardley, board chairman of Jenkins Brothers of Norwalk, Conn., and Jenkins Canada of Lachine, Quebec, died of cardiac failure Friday at Norwalk Hospital. Mr. Yardley, a resident of Darien, Conn., and Lyford Cay, the Bahamas, was 71 years old.

title: Pair Dumped Into Garbage
description: A rubbish truck driver picked up more than he expected on his early morning rounds: a boy and his mother who had been sleeping in a garbage bin near a discount store. Buried in the garbage being compressed in Matthew Frederick's big truck Friday were Dennis Gwaltney, 11 years old, and his mother, Frankie Gwaltney, 31, both of Catawba, N. C.

title: Arizona Governor Cites A Flooding Emergency
description: Gov. Bruce Babbitt declared a state of emergency today in three counties because of flooding of the Colorado River.

title: TWO NATIONS' SHARED ELECTORAL DEFICIENCIES
description: To the Editor:

title: TINY RECORDERS TRAVEL FAR
description: At the beginning of summer, time itself stretches out like a great meadow - an open expanse to be filled with one's pleasures and likings. For many, this means yielding to the urges of wanderlust - following the lure of exotic places and of days measured by the sun, not by the clock.

title: On Greenspan
description: To the Business Editor: Alan Greenspan is quoted as saying (''The Quiet Allure of Alan Greenspan,'' June 5): ''I always valued men and women equally, and I found that because others did not, good women economists were cheaper than men. Hiring women does two things: It gives us better quality work for less money, and it raises the market value of women.''

title: Reagan Decides On Volcker
description: President Reagan at times seems to delight in making the usually reliable sources on his staff look foolish. But last week's flood of well-informed speculation that Paul A. Volcker would soon be renominated for a second term at the Fed was right on the money.

title: WALES
description: To the Editor: In the article on Wales, reference is made in the information obtainable from the British Tourist Authority, that the National Eisteddfod is held in Llangollen, Wales. It is the International Musical Eisteddfod which is held in Llangollen and not the National Eisteddfod.

title: Laws That Work When Cars Don't
description: The New York Legislature last week approved an alternative to ulcers for new-car buyers who happen to get lemons. If, as expected, Governor Cuomo signs the bill, New York will be the second state in the region to say no dice to a sales policy of no refunds and no exchanges.

title: LINCOLN
description: THE last four years have been hard on governors, whether liberal or conservative, Democrat or Republican. With rare exceptions their work has been circumscribed by rising deficits and decreasing services and by an electorate that is snappish about any suggestion of new taxes. Voters in economically depressed farm and industrial states of the Middle West have been throwing out incumbents and trying something new.

title: THE VICIOUS CIRCLE OF EDUCATIONAL MEDIOCRITY
description: IF IT is true, as Aristotle said, that the fate of empires depends on the education of youth, then the United States is in trouble. Teacher discontent is high. Good college students avoid the profession, and many of the better people already in teaching are leaving it. Strikes are frequent, and school administrators regard teachers as adversaries rather than as valued professional colleagues.

title: ART FOR THE FEW AND THE MANY
description: ART historians are like most other historians in that, other things being equal, they would love to be published by a university press. To appear under the imprint of Oxford or Cambridge, Yale, Princeton or Cornell, is in their view a consummation devoutly to be wished.

title: Miss Howe Leading By 2 Shots on 68-134
description: Lauren Howe shot a four-under-par 68 today to take a two-stroke lead into the final round of the $200,000 Lady Keystone Open.

title: MARTIN'S FUTURE AS MANAGER IS IN DOUBT
description: Billy Martin said last night that his job as manager of the Yankees was not in danger despite the latest in a series of controversies. But he was disputed by George Steinbrenner, the chief owner of the team, who said:

title: Tracy Purcell Is Married
description: Tracy Lucille Purcell, daughter of Mrs. David W.C. Webber of Old Greenwich, Conn., New York and London and Robert Purcell of St. Louis, was married yesterday to F. Keith O'Brien, son of Mr.and Mrs. Francis X. O'Brien of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Amato performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena in Riverside, Conn.

title: FOR MRS. FENWICK, A NEW CAREER AT 73
description: BERNARDSVILLE SMELLING faintly of rose water, and wearing a simple summer dress and sensible shoes, Millicent Fenwick sat in the setting she has been in all her life - old portraits and period furniture - and spoke of the new career she is about to begin at age 73.

title: FRIVOLOUS ACTIVITIES; Supreme Waste of Time
description: The Supreme Court, which complains it's so overworked that it needs a new court to lighten the load, has decided to give itself still more work. The justices will now vote on which pleadings are frivolous and award damages to the other side.

title: CHINESE CHIEF OF STATE AN ASTUTE OLD WARRIOR
description: Li Xiannian's knack for survival has served him well over many years. His appointment as China's new President, its first in 15 years, caps the career of a crusty old revolutionary who still commands the nation's respect.

title: Bluefish Receive Close Attention
description: AT long last, proper attention is being paid the bluefish, the Northeast's hard-fighting, rapacious summer visitor. A multibilliondollar marine-recreational fishing industry heavily depends on the bluefish's continuing fecundity.

title: 2 More Indicted in Crash That Killed Actors
description: A helicopter pilot and the effects specialist in the ''Twilight Zone'' film crew have been indicted by a grand jury investigating the helicopter's fatal crash on a movie set last July, their attorneys said.

title: Miss Ferrari Wed To R.H. Furman
description: Theresa Marie Ferrari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick N. Ferrari of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Ronald H. Furman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Furman of Garden City, L.I. Msgr. John J. Wiest performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: A RULING ON RESIDENCY AGITATES SOUTH AFRICA
description: A banner headline embellished with an exclamation point raised the alarm across the front page of a leading Afrikaans newspaper two Sundays ago. ''DIE SWART STROOM!'' it cried, arousing readers to the looming threat of ''the black flood.'' The imperative the headline didn't need to spell out for its readers was a reflexive stop it, block it, dam it.

title: J.R. Richard Comeback
description: J.R. Richard, the Houston Astro pitcher who suffered a near-fatal stroke three years ago, has recovered from surgery and has started another comeback. The right-hander, now 33 years old, had leg surgery March 10 to relieve a circulatory problem that had driven him from spring training.

title: The Death Penalty's Hardest Case
description: Of the 1,200 prisoners under sentence of death in the United States, New York has only one. But that condemned man, Lemuel Smith, has caused more destruction than most, and he promises nothing but anguish even for those who would spare him the electric chair. His brutal crimes make him Exhibit A for capital punishment and a great burden for its opponents.

title: JUDGE ORDERS REVIEW OF DISABILITY CUTS IN 9 STATES
description: Accusing the Social Security Administration of operating ''outside the law,'' a Federal district judge has ordered the agency to stop cutting off benefits to disabled recipients in nine Western states unless it could be shown that they have improved medically.

title: World Dog Award To Spanish Mastiff
description: On the grounds on which Philip II proclaimed this city the capital of the kingdom four centuries ago, a Spanish mastiff was proclaimed the world champion of dogdom last Sunday.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: AMAN who has been ''father'' to hundreds of boys is celebrating his special day today. He is Msgr. Robert P. Egan, the ''father'' of New Jersey Boys Town in Kearny, and today marks the 40th anniversary of his ordination.

title: Medicine for Profit
description: To the Business Editor: The incisive and timely article ''Operating for Profit at Hospital Corp.'' (May 29) presents an issue which may be the most critical one to emerge in the American health care system in two generations. This issue involves the relatively recent potential of providing most medical care services as a profitable enterprise. The reasons for this potential are partially delineated in the article, but the emergence of marketplace considerations in the health care system is relatively new and highly disruptive of public expectations and traditional health professional rhetoric.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Reagan's appointment of Paul A. Volcker for a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board appears likely to mean a stronger recovery this year and continuing into 1984.

title: HOW COLLEGE STUDENTS ESTABLISH CREDIT
description: WHEN Stephen G. Kaplan was a junior at Rice University in Houston, he wanted a department store credit c ard, but did not apply for one. ''I didn't think I'd be able to get c redit because I had no credit record,'' he said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It sure is fun.'' - Sally K. Ride. (20:2.)

title: Davis Alters Style and Stops Rival in 8th
description: Howard Davis Jr., bigger and better than ever, stopped Greg Coverson, a leading lightweight contender, in the eighth round today and then said he would feel more comfortable as a junior welterweight.

title: No Headline
description: Cultivating Culture In Paris Justine De Lacy enlightened us with her insights into the aliveand-well estheticism traditionally characteristic of the French (''Cultivating Culture in Paris,'' May 22). Clearly, the blows pelting their economy have not diminished the French craving for the cultural artistry that has always been synonymous with their spirit. What other country, pummeled by a 12 percent inflation rate, an 8.6 percent unemployment rate, a $12 billion balance-of-payments burden, a crestfallen franc, would have the desire to appropriate zealous men (Minister of Culture Jack Lang and Mayor of Paris Jacques Chirac, for example) and sorely needed funds (''close to $1 billion for 1983'') to launch such a ''program of urban and cultural change to humanize Paris and make it creative again''? HENRY SEIDEMAN Westport, Conn. ------

title: Speaking of DeLorean
description: John Z. DeLorean's ship may or may not be sinking, but an evacuation of sorts seems to have begun.

title: PRESIDENTIAL 'NEWS FLASH'
description: The reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as Federal Reserve Board chairman was announced by President Reagan as he began his weekly radio address.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday incorrectly characterized the stance of 15 states on the use of Medicaid funds for abortions. The states, Alaska, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Hawaii, Massachusetts, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Washington and West Virginia, provide state Medicaid money for that purpose.

title: CONSULTANT REPORT ON SALEM I IS DUE
description: LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK TWP. AFINAL REPORT is due this week from a California consulting company that looked into the structure, management and staffing at the Salem I nuclear-power plant here after it was shut down by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: Paris Tailors
description: To the Editor: In John Vinocur's article on ''English Tailoring: Tres Chic'' (Travel, May 22) several names of men's clothing stores in Paris cited as ''English-sounding'' were mentioned, two of which were Scott & Bruce and Auld Reekie.

title: LEWIS WINS U.S. 100 FOR 3D YEAR IN ROW
description: Give Carl Lewis credit. He is not one to rest on his laurels. In 1981 and 1982, he won the 100-meter dash and the long jump in the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships, the first to achieve that double in these national championships since Jesse Owens in 1936. Now Lewis is trying to become the first since Malcolm Ford in 1885 and 1886 to win the 100- and 200-meter dashes and the long jump in the same year.

title: NEWARK: MANIPULATING SPACE
description: NEWARK SOMETIMES, the title of a group art show and its explanations seem like any old port in a storm, an expedient for bringing diverse artists together.

title: SUSAN MCCALL AND J. MATTHEW MACKOWSKI TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond G. McCall of Wooster, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Sloan McCall, to J. Matthew Mackowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mackowski of Darien, Conn.

title: Use of Lasix In Humans
description: To the Sports Editor: It is at best misleading to state that ''doctors routinely prescribe (Lasix) for overweight people'' as it was stated in the article on the drug in The New York Times on June 5. Lasix, or furosemide, is a potent diuretic used in treatment of those states characterized by generalized edema, or swelling.

title: Ellen Brown Becomes Bride
description: Ellen Claire Brown, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Brown of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday in SS.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SONG OF PENTECOST By W.J. Corbett. Illustrated by Martin Ursell. 216 pp. New York: E.P.Dutton. $10.95. (Ages 10 and Up) By CAROL VAN STRUM

title: CITY ORDERED TO GIVE ABATEMENT ON TAXES TO THE TRUMP TOWER
description: A State Supreme Court justice has directed that New York City grant ''without further delay'' a multimillion-dollar tax abatement to Donald J. Trump for the Trump Tower, the 59-story luxury office and condominium building that was constructed on the site of the old Bonwit Teller store in midtown Manhattan.

title: MAJOR SHIFTS NEAR IN POLICE COMMAND
description: One of the New York City Police Department's five so-called super chiefs has retired and another reportedly has said he plans to, setting the stage for major changes in the department's high command.

title: Rudolph G. Schlobohm Weds Victoria J. Noyes
description: Victoria Jane Noyes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Noyes of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Rudolph Grant Schlobohm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Schlobohm Jr. of Montclair, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Michael Neils performed the ceremony at the First Evangelical Lutheran Church in Montclair.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID PLANTS REFLECT MARKET DEMAND
description: LIKE nuclear power facilities and garbage dumps, new hybrid plants sometimes draw unfavorable comment. With some justification, there are those who lament the loss of unique flavors, forms or fragrances. There is also concern with the trend toward monoculture or sameness in all plants being grown.

title: Who's In Charge Here?
description: The inflation of modern job titles has advanced so far that ''vice president'' is beyond rescue. But if vigilant citizens will bestir themselves, it may not be too late to protect ''president.''

title: IN AN ERA OF CHANGE, LEAGUE OF WOMEN VOTERS FACES BIG BATTLE
description: FOUNDED almost as soon as women won the franchise, the League of Women Voters observed its 50th anniversary in 1974, with ceremony appropriate to a half-century of public esteem and influence. Less than a decade later, however, there are hints that the league's 50th may have been akin to a couple's golden wedding celebration - a fanfare for a cherished association whose time is running out.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: West New York waterfront. What he came up with is sure to do that - and a lot more.

title: BEECHER CLAN TO CATCH UP ON 124 YEARS
description: THE Stowes and the Beechers, the Hookers and the Perkinses, more than 300 strong, have not had an old-fashioned family reunion since 1859, when Lyman Beecher got his 11 children together, including his famous daughter, the author Harriet Beecher Stowe. On that occasion Mathew B. Brady, the noted photographer of Abraham Lincoln and the Civil War, took a photo of the whole family.

title: TULIPS AND MORTALITY SPRING ETERNAL
description: WHEN my wife and I were looking at our tulips the other night, our next-door neighbor told us he had had to put his two cats to sleep. He said it as we were admiring the row of yellow tulips that bordered the front of his house. His tulips had been open for a few days, while ours were only just beginning to flower.

title: Melinda Murray Is Married
description: Melinda Gray Murray, a partner in the Washington law firm of Schultz, Dunn & Murray, was married at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Weston, Conn., yesterday to Robert D. MacDougall Jr., a program analyst for the waste management division of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in Washington. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. C. Michael Thornburg of Emmanuel, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Brunkow of the Dumbarton United Methodist Church in Washington.

title: COHALAN AND HALPIN TESTING THE ISSUES
description: IN their formal announcements of their candidacies, Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and his Democratic opponent, Assemblyman Patrick G. Halpin, barely mentioned the Long Island Lighting Company's nuclear plant at Shoreham and the Southwest Sewer District.

title: by Kendall J. Wills
description: A Japanese newsletter recently described the photography business as a ''sunset industry'' and predicted troubled times ahead, a period in which the survival of some companies was very much in question.

title: USE OF WATERFRONT STUDIED
description: SUMMER finds Port Jefferson's harbor dotted with pleasure craft, its streets crowded with day-trippers on their way to shops or clam bars and restaurants near the jammed shore parking lots.

title: THE DANCE: A NEW CAST IN 'QUIXOTE'
description: Some breathtaking dance prevailed at the Metropolitan Opera House Thursday, when the American Ballet Theater presented a new cast in ''Don Quixote.''

title: Laurie Hawkes Wed to Paul Grand Pre
description: Laurie Anne Hawkes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lawrence Hawkes of Waterville, Me., was married yesterday to Paul David Grand Pre, son of Mr. and Mrs. John David Grand Pre of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Carl F.G. Kohn of Zion's Hill Methodist Church in Wilton performed the ceremony in the First Parish Church in Brunswick, Me., assisted by the Rev. John H. Wild, a United Church of Christ minister who is pastor of the First Parish Church.

title: More on Jet Lag
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed reading ''The Jet Lag Diet'' (Travel, May 22) and would like to offer another formula for minimizing jet lag. My formula is forged from the experience in frequent flying for periods up to 30 hours and crossing 15 time zones at one clip.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AFTER 35 years as one of Long Island's pioneering cultural organizations, the North Shore Community Arts Center is going out of business. Faced with the prospect of running up a deficit next year and hampered by the absence of volunteers to raise funds and help in programming, the Great Neck-based center will close its doors on Aug. 31. With its remaining funds, however, the center will establish an endowment to assist students and artists with scholarships and grants.

title: JAZZ: HERITAGE HALL BAND
description: Although the name of the Heritage Hall Jazz Band from New Orleans, which is playing at the Blue Note through tonight, might suggest a similarity to the better-known Preservation Hall Jazz Band, the two are actually quite different.

title: PILOTS SAY SPEED LED TO CRASH
description: HANOVER TWP. AFATAL crash just before an air show at Morristown Airport here last Sunday was probably a result of the pilot's overtaxing his craft's design limitations, not a flaw in its construction, say aviation experts and local fliers.

title: The Fujiya
description: To the Editor: William Hamilton's article ''Japanese Victorian'' (Travel, April 17) about the Fujiya Hotel rekindled memories of our pleasurable stay there in 1960 and 1963.

title: The Meaning Of Wisconsin
description: The Democrats' Wisconsin straw poll last weekend was not binding, it gauged Presidential candidates' strength within a small circle of state party activists, and came many months before next year's true tests, the caucuses and primaries. All in all, a terrific opportunity for candidates and political analysts to begin the handwringing and handicapping that make American Presidential politics nearly a full-time affair.

title: CONVERSATIONS ON A TRAIN HEADING FOR THE FUTURE
description: THEY were fragments of conversations. Why should I look for any significance in them? The people were not chosen by any careful sampling process, after all. All the conversations took place on trains, somewhere between Great Neck and Penn Station on the Port Washington line of the Long Island Rail Road.

title: 2 BENEFITS ON ROAD TO FALL
description: HOW can you bid farewell to spring and look ahead to fall at the same time? Attend the lawn party, miniconcert and dinner benefiting the popular Music for a Sunday Afternoon series today at 5:30 in Tarrytown's Christ Church.

title: 35-STORY MIDBLOCK TOWER
description: Like many midtown blocks, East 55th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues is lined with low buildings. Among them are a redbrick Georgian structure that would look at home in Colonial Williamsburg; some gracious brownstone and limestone townhouses that could be time-warped with ease back to the 1890's; the modern, marble-facaded community house of the Central Synagogue, and, at the Lexington Avenue corner, the synagogue itself, a neo-Moorish structure, circa 1872, that has been designated a landmark by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Miss Berry and J.C. Esten Are Wed at Pocantico Hills
description: Margaret M. Berry, daughter of Cecilia Berry of Babylon, L.I., and the late William Berry, was married yesterday to Jonathan C. Esten, son of Nathaniel S. Esten of South Natick, Mass., and Barbara C. Esten of Denver. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer performed the Protestant ceremony in the Union Church at Pocantico Hills, North Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: 2 SUITS AGAINST TRANSIT UNIONS OVER '80 STRIKE ARE DISMISSED
description: The New York State Court of Appeals has dismissed two lawsuits seeking more than half a million dollars in damages from two transit unions for their 11-day strike in 1980.

title: VOLUNTEERS GIVE FREE MEDICAL CARE
description: AGROUP of health professionals in Southampton have banded together to provide modern medical services to uninsured South Fork residents and Medicaid recipients.

title: PELHAM EXHIBIT SPANS A CENTURY OF DREAMS AND ENGINEERING
description: IN 100 years of providing perhaps the most impressive passage across the East River - and in the 14 years it took to build it -the Brooklyn Bridge has cast its shadow and its influence over millions of people. And on the way to becoming one of the great engineering feats of all time, the bridge has evoked tribute from many devotees in various mediums: books, poems, films and artistic images.

title: TOWING SERVICE STARTED FOR BOATERS
description: AS the boating season comes into its own on Long Island Sound and engines and batteries fail on board, the Coast Guard will not be the only rescuer of stranded boaters.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 2 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 2 14 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 3 3 11 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 4 4 8 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 5 5 11 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 6 6 6 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 7 7 9 ANCIENT EVENINGS, by Norman Mailer. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) Ten centuries of rites and orgies in long-ago Egypt. 8 10 3 ASCENT INTO HELL, by Andrew M. Greeley.

title: Krents Is Appointed WQXR Vice President
description: Lawrence B. Krents has been appointed vice president for program and syndication sales at WQXR, Warren G. Bodow, president and general manager of the radio stations of The New York Times, has announced.

title: CHAMBER CONCERTS BEGIN AT NORFOLK
description: FOR the last 43 summers, the Yale School of Music has shifted its headquarters from the slightly seedy-looking building it regularly occupies in New Haven to the breathtakingly beautiful Ellen Battell Stoeckel estate in Norfolk. There, a carefully selected group of exceptionally promising young professionals gathers for seven weeks of intensive exploration of the chamber music repertory: training, coaching and performing under the close supervision of a distinguished Yale and visiting artists faculty.

title: MISGUIDED CRITICISM OF DEMOCRATIC REFORMS: A MYTH IN POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: VEAL SHANKS; FLAVORFUL SIMPLICITY ITSELF
description: Americans seem to shun one of the most admirable cuts of meat - shank of veal - that is widely appreciated throughout Europe. When it is brought into the American kitchen, it is generally for one purpose only: to be turned into an Italian dish known as osso buco, that savory blend of shanks braised in broth with herbs and vegetables. The fact is that veal shanks can be put to infinite good uses, for it is an enormously versatile cut with a host of uncommon virtues. In the first place, when properly cooked, it yields some of the most succulent, fork-tender meat imaginable. The shank is abundantly endowed with a natural gelatin and the center bone is filled with a morsel of marrow that is absolutely irresistible.

title: No Headline
description: Trials of a Mississippi Lawyer As a member of Oberlin College's class of 1984, I am moved by Wilbur Colom's story of his efforts as a black lawyer in the South, and glad that Oberlin students took a role in helping him to reach his goal (''The Trials of a Mississippi Lawyer,'' by Wilbur O. Colom, May 15). If Mr. Colom ever needs help again, we are still here. KEITH SABIN Milltown, N.J. ------

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: TOWN GIRL By Ellen Cooney. 184 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $9.95 (Ages 11 to 15) By MARILYN KAYE

title: Lima Rocked by Explosions
description: At least 10 explosions rocked Lima Friday night and two homemade bombs were defused close to the presidential palace, the police said.

title: WHAT HOPES FOR THE CONTADORA PROCESS?
description: President Reagan's special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, knew what his hosts wanted to hear. After visiting 10 countries in 11 days, he announced last week that the Administration was ready to support the efforts of Mexico, Colombia, Panama and Venezuela to negotiate a firebreak against the military conflagration threatening the region. Many Latins see the mediating attempts of the four countries, named the Contadora group after the Panamanian island where they first met in January, as the best hope for averting disaster.

title: CONSUMER RATES
17 Strawberry Pickers Injured As a Bus Overturns in Jersey
description: A bus filled with farm workers on their way home from picking strawberries broke its drive shaft and overturned here today, and 17 of the laborers had to be treated at a local hospital.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FIVE The Dilemma of Old Age in America's Past. By Carole Haber. 181 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $19.95.

title: STATE STUDIES CURRICULUM CHANGES
description: IF THE National Commission on Excellence in Education had its way, all high school students would be required to complete four years of English, three years of mathematics, three years of science, three years of social studies and a half-year of computer science.

title: OSHA ASSAILED ON 'GAS' BLAST
description: NEWARK REPRESENTATIVE Frank J. Guarini says that, although he does not expect Federal regulations to result from hearings on the explosion of three Texaco gasoline-storage tanks here last winter, he hopes they will put pressure on the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration.

title: PICKING A CENTRAL AIR-CONDITIONING SYSTEM
description: THE easiest, cheapest way to cool a house is to put room a irconditioners through the windows. But such units block the view, i mpair the look of the house outside and often leave some areas i nside unbearably hot and others unpleasantly chilly. For the most c omfortable and least intrusive cooling, a whole-house central systemd oes the best job.

title: 'TRADING PLACES' BRINGS 30'S COMEDY INTO THE 80'S
description: In addition to being the funniest American movie comedy of the year to date, John Landis's ''Trading Places'' has several other things going for it. It establishes Eddie Murphy, who made his big-screen debut late last year in Walter Hill's ''48 Hrs.,'' as the brightest young comic actor to hit Hollywood in a decade. The screenplay, by Timothy Harris and Herschel Weingrod, rediscovers and brings up to date a kind of social awareness that was so important to such comedies of the 30's and 40's as ''My Man Godfrey'' and ''Sullivan's Travels.'' And it demonstrates that Mr. Landis (''The National Lampoon's Animal House,'' ''The Blues Brothers'') is capable of directing a comedy of precise style as well as those that are accumulations of gargantuan, often messy effects.

title: 5 HELD AT A SHIPYARD AS 500 DEMONSTRATE AGAINST NEW TRIDENT
description: Five people, including a woman who climbed aboard and shouted antinuclear slogans, were arrested today as the U.S.S. Florida became the third Trident submarine to join the nation's fleet.

title: Fresh Option on Central America
description: The Reagan Administration has frequently called for bipartisan support for its Central American policies. Last week two influential Senators proposed a separate bipartisan path to higher ground.

title: Helen Cooke, Russell Pyne Are Married
description: Helen Darlington Cooke, daughter of Thornton Cooke 2d of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Joan Davis Cooke, was married yesterday to Russell Bradhurst Pyne, son of John Insley Blair Pyne of West Trenton, N.J., and Elizabeth Stuyvesant Pyne of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Frederick T. Vanderpoel performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Kansas City.

title: Ecumenical Giving
description: The fire broke out mysteriously after midnight on Oct. 8, 1982, and by the time it was put out, the chapel of the Narkiss Street Baptist Congregation in Jerusalem was a charred shell. The police suspected arson.

title: STATE POLICE ADDING COLOR TO UNIFORMS
description: COMMISSIONER Lester J. Forst of the State Police is adding a splash of color to the uniforms his department has worn for more than 40 years.

title: Jocelyne Albert Is Wed to R.M. Hecht
description: Jocelyne May Albert, daughter of May Albert of Frenchville, Me., and the late Valere Albert, was married yesterday to Robert Michael Hecht, son of Amalie M. Kass of Lincoln, Mass., and the late Malcolm Hecht Jr. The Rev. Joseph Lebroc'h peformed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Eglise St.-Severin in Paris.

title: THE LONGEST DEAL
description: His colleagues at Edward S. Gordon, the real-estate brokerage and management concern, like to say that Henry Baker is not a retiring man. And recently the 93-year-old broker, who started his career in 1911 after graduating from Columbia, showed he has not lost his skill as a deal-maker.

title: STIMPMETER DOES THE JOB
description: Oakmont, Pa.

title: SOME EASILY PREPARED DISHES FOR THE LAST MINUTE
description: RAIN or no rain, this is the time of year for weekend guests. Dishes that can be prepared in advance are, of course, essential if the host or hostess is not to spend the entire time in the kitchen. But there are also dishes that can be prepared easily at the last minute. A souffle made from goat's cheese, for example, can be prepared, cooked and placed on the table within little more than an hour. Served with salad and followed by fruit, it makes a fine dish for lunch or dinner. Use a soft, strong-flavored cheese such as Montrachet or Bucheron.

title: Horses' Rights
description: Mindful that a half-dozen horses had died in the streets of New York last summer, the city's Health Department proposed in April a bill of rights for rental animals. Fines of up to $500 were suggested for violations.

title: Jean S. Padjen Wed in Bay State
description: Jean Seward Padjen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Padjen of Salem and Topsfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Oliver Wolcott 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott Jr. of Hamilton, Mass. The Rev. Lowell L. Erickson, executive director of the Boston Society of Architects, performed the Congregational ceremony in the garden of the Padjen home in Salem.

title: Bear Hunting in the Yard
description: A man who says he shot and killed a year-old, 102-pound black bear in his backyard to protect his home has been charged with hunting out of season. Ervin E. Mann, 38 years old, who says he has not been hunting in 20 years, plans to plead not guilty to the misdemeanor charge when his case comes up in Superior Court. He said neighbors in his residential subdivision near Dalton had called the authorities twice to report the bear was roaming around the neighborhood.

title: Lani Lippincott Weds An Insurance Broker
description: Charlotte Lippincott, daughter of Virginia Hampson Rickard of Darien, Conn., and Dr. Richard C. Lippincott of Hanover, N.H., was married yesterday to Thomas Edward McHugh, son of Mrs. Walter P. McHugh of Katonah, N.Y., and the late Mr. McHugh. The Rev. Stanley B. Rousseau performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the United Congregational Church in Rowayton, Conn.

title: New York Times Magazine June 19, 1983
description: William Safire 8 On Language Dangling Man Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Roar of the Crowd Irving R. Kaufman 16 Reassessing the Fairness Doctrine Should the First Amendment apply equally to the print and broadcast media? Sally Kalson 20 A Link to Life Coordinators of organ-procurement programs are transplantation's ''unsung heroes.'' David Harris 26 Understanding Mondale The front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Walter Mondale is reticent in public about a personal side that others might translate into charisma. Alan Flusser 42 About Men The Right Fit 44 Fashion Summer Comfort Marilyn Bethany 48 Home Design Beyond Walden Craig Claiborne 50 Food with Pierre Franey Veal Shanks: Flavorful Simplicity Itself 64 Puzzles Answers, Page 60 74 Letters Cover: Photograph by Alex Webb/Magnum.

title: VOLCKER RENAMED BY REAGAN TO RUN FEDERAL RESERVE
description: Ending months of speculation that has roiled the financial markets, President Reagan announced today that he would reappoint Paul A. Volcker to another four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Track Bans Webster
description: Ben Webster, the harness driver who had been accused of participating in a race-fixing scheme at the Meadowlands, has been banned from competing at the track from tomorrow through the first 48 days of the 1984 campaign. Track officials said that Webster had agreed to the suspensions after a series of meetings last week.

title: Susie's Wedding
description: To the Editor:

title: MILITARY BUFFS GET FIREHOUSE FOR BASE
description: WHEN Dennis A. Ambruso of Bridgeport and his friends recreate a scenario from World War II, every detail is authentic, from the vehicles and uniforms to the packs of Lucky Strikes their ''soldiers'' carry. The audience, he believes, has to feel it is Europe, 1944.

title: ALL THE WORLD'S THE STAGE
description: NESTLED at the Hudson River's edge with long, dumbfunding views of the great river and the highlands of Storm King and Crows Nest Mountains, Cold Spring has a unique charm, one due not only to its natural beauty. Although settled about 100 years before, the stageset village bustled by 1818, when the opening of the West Point Foundry - then the country's largest - brought 2,000 colonizers to the area. Since then concerned residents and busy historicalpreservation societies have successfully resisted newfangledness and have encouraged clean-as-a-whistle restorations allowing minimal adaptions to the needs of present-day living. And so the pretty old brick and wood houses market their past as antique shops, restaurants, old clothing stores and such.

title: Mortgage Scare
description: As interest rates soared in the nation, the Adirondack Trust Company in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., began in July 1982 to recall hundreds of 10-year-old, low-interest mortgages. Homeowners were shocked.

title: NUCLEAR DEBATE SHATTERS CATHOLIC PANEL
description: HARTFORD FOR the Roman Catholics of America, from the cardinals and bishops to the faithful in the parishes, these are days of great ferment and debate about peace, war and nuclear weapons.

title: PROBLEM FOR AGED: GETTING A RIDE
description: ALTHOUGH public transportation on Long Island has become more accessible to the elderly, with many north-south feeder lines added to east-west bus routes in the last several years, some - particularly the frail and disabled and those who live in the eastern section of Suffolk - remain isolated. Both public and private agencies have made efforts to meet the needs of these residents, but success has been limited.

title: Mirror Images East and West
description: Washington and Moscow talked at each other last week, but to no apparent effect. Secretary of State George P. Shultz offered ''constructive dialogue'' and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko ''smoother relations'' but neither side thought the other was doing anything to attain these goals.

title: SULLIVAN STARS FOR GENERALS
description: Dwight Sullivan, who describes himself as ''a loner type of person,'' spent most of yesterday in his apartment in East Orange, N.J., nursing a sprained ankle and musing about what had happened the night before.

title: CHEMICAL CONCERNS HELD STILL VIOLATING
description: MOUNT VERNON THE head of Mount Vernon's Bureau of Fire Prevention told a judge last week that he thought two chemical companies had made little progress in correcting fire-code violations.

title: WHAT THERE IS TO BE SAID FOR IT
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF DEATH Edited by D.J. Enright. 353 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Lake Champlain
description: To the Editor: As owner-master of the new schooner Homer W. Dixon, I was pleased to see mention of the vessel in the Advisory item, ''Champlain Fete in Burlington'' (Travel, May 8).

title: CITY SETS DEADLINE FOR PICKING INCINERATOR SITES
description: After being told that Staten Island was threatened by a buildup of 500-foot mounds of garbage, the Board of Estimate agreed last Thursday to set a deadline to pick sites for incinerators.

title: LORI ELLEN ROSS ENGAGED TO JAMES MICHAEL WEISS
description: Mrs. Philip B. Kimmel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Donald M. Ross of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Ellen Ross, to James Michael Weiss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis of Bedford, N.Y.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICE
description: ETHNIC MUSIC It's possible to travel the world - musically speaking - without ever leaving the boundaries of Manhattan. This week, there are several programs of ethnic music that should be worth hearing.

title: No Headline
description: Headliners Not Forgotten, or Gone Either

title: STYLISH SETTING, AMBITIOUS KITCHEN
description: AFTER a few months of operation, Le Petit Pourvoyeur, a stylish little bandbox of a restaurant in Bellmore, finally seems to be headed in the right direction. Three partners in the small place are recent graduates of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, one of the leading professional culinary schools in the country. The high quality of their training is evident, but so is their lack of experience.

title:
CAMERA;
THE NEW BREED OF COMPACT VIDEO CAMERAS
CHILE ISN'T POLAND BUT LABOR IS RESTLESS
description: After 10 years of limping aimlessly under the rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet Ugarte, Chile's trade unions last week made a sputtering start toward challenging the general. The National Workers Command, a union coalition, spearheaded a nationwide protest against 20 percent unemployment, 30 percent inflation and steeply dropping real income that produced an impressive display of public opposition to the Pinochet regime.

title: BOROUGH LOSES BID TO SILENCE PROJECT'S CRITICS
description: AN ATTEMPT by the Allentown Borough Council to silence two local critics of a lake-dredging project is over. Judge Marshall Selikoff, sitting in Superior Court in Freehold, has ruled that the borough's suit against the critics, had it been allowed to succeed, would have ''a chilling effect and abridge the freedom of speech.''

title: W.F. SCHNITZLER, LABOR CHIEF, DIES
description: William F. Schnitzler, who served for 14 years as secretarytreasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died on June 17 at the Beebe Hospital in Lewes, Del., where he lived. Mr. Schnitzler was 79 years old.

title: Miss Kearns Wed To J.C. Fields Jr.
description: Anne C. Kearns, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Kearns of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Jack C. Fields Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fields of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Frank Strasburger performed the ceremony at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title:
PAPERBACK TALK;
Who Knows How to Be a Parent?
description: Publishers call them parenting books, and new ones are born every month, as Vicki Lansky is in a position to know. Mrs. Lansky, the author of ''The Taming of the C.A.N.D.Y. Monster,'' a best seller in 1978, has been producing the Practical Parenting newsletter since 1979 and gets well over 100 titles a year for review. ''When people become parents, they often feel a need for some particular book and, if they can't find it, they write it,'' she says.

title: LIVING WITH A SLIVER
description: When developers of a 55- by 34-foot lot on the corner of 81st Street and Lexington Avenue first made known their plans for a highrise residential project on the site, several organizations in the community vigorously opposed the design because the structure would have been taller than many of the block's town houses. Under the zoning code that existed at the time - before the ''sliver'' law was enacted - the structure could have risen to 26 stories if the apropriate building bulk and lot size ratio was maintained.

title: STAGE: JEWISH REP MUSICAL ABOUT SEPHARDIC POET
description: Judah Halevy, the great poet of the golden age of Sephardic Jewry in 12th-century Spain, is the hero of ''My Heart Is in the East,'' a new musical at the Jewish Repertory Theater on East 14th Street. Its title is taken from his poem that expressed his passion for Zion, his yearning to visit Jerusalem.

title: FOR 5 COUNTY NATIVES, SYMBOLIC VICTORY
description: ELEPHANTS and donkeys gearing up for November's elections, eat your hearts out. Westchester voters have already spoken and the whitetailed deer reigns supreme.

title: A STRONG RIGHTS UNIT
description: In the wake of President Reagan's attempt to fire three of its commissioners, the United States Commission on Civil Rights released reports critical of Federal civil rights enforcement in education and minority appointments. The reports provide clear and encouraging evidence that members of the commission intend to maintain an independent voice, despite the President's efforts to undermine their autonomy.

title: UTILITY IS SEEKING A 'BETTER MOUSETRAP'
description: NEWARK ''WE'RE looking for a betert I. Smith, chairman of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, said in summing up what the utility was doing to prevent breakdowns in the safety equipment at its nuclear-power plants.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BRIGHTON BEACH
description: THIS is the season when year-round residents of Martha's Vineyard a nd East Hampton complain that the ''summer people'' have arrived. T hat lament also is sounded by year-round residents of Brighton B each.

title: Former Indian Leader Sues Over U.S. Book
description: Former Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai said today that he had filed a $5 million lawsuit in the United States over allegations in the book ''The Price of Power'' that he worked for the Central Intelligence Agency, the Press Trust of India reported.

title: PAYING THE PRICE FOR THE MIGHTY DOLLAR
description: ON Memorial Day, when President Reagan read the Williamsburg Declaration from a stage on the basketball court at the College of William and Mary with the leaders from other industrial nations by his side, they seemed a united group. But in the weeks since then, that veneer of solidarity has been cracking - and the predominant reason has been the surging value of the American dollar.

title: ON THE 'LEMON LAW' AND ARBITRATION
description: AUTOMOTIVE horror stories are legion. Automatic transmissions that break again and again. Engines that seem never to be fixed. Constant, niggling problems that have a car in the shop more than it is on the street. They are a consumer's nightmare and they are the genesis of ''lemon laws'' such as the one passed by both houses in Albany last week.

title: OPPONENTS REACT TO FEINER 'GUARANTEE'
description: ''IT sounds like a campaign gimmick to me,'' said Mayor Reginald F. Marra of Irvington. ''Why is that getting so much attention?'' asked Councilman Thomas J. Abinanti of Greenburgh, syllables clipped, voice heavy with incredulity.

title: WHITE KNIGHT WITH A PICASSO
description: EVERY morning, A. Alfred Taubman rises at 6 A.M. and goes down to t he basement of his suburban home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich. There, i n his well-appointed gym, the 58-year old businessman spends 45 m inutes sparring with a professional prize-fighter in a hobby that heh as pursued in recent years with as much zeal as he gives to his b eloved golf game.

title: Fleck and Brewer Share Title
description: Jack Fleck, who fired a fourunder-par 67 in a strong wind, and Gay Brewer finished in a tie for the title Friday in the $100,000 Stanford P.G.A. Seniors Tournament.

title: SHOW ENHANCED BY A NEW SETTING
description: THE Smithtown Township Arts Council's headquarters in the historic Mills Pond House in St. James suffers from the familiar restrictions of too many windows, doors and other architectural features that make such buildings difficult to adapt as showcases for contemporary art. Large varied exhibitions like the annual juried show are especially hard to mount there.

title: IN THE SHADOW OF CHINA'S REVOLUTION
description: ONE DAY IN CHINA: MAY 21, 1936 Translated, edited and introduced by Sherman Cochran and Andrew C.K. Hsieh with Janis Cochran. Illustrated. 290 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: CONCERT: S.E.M. PERFORMS NEW MUSIC
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris began a series of free concerts with a Wednesday evening performance by the S.E.M. Ensemble, under the direction of Petr Kotik. Mr. Kotik has put together a disciplined and eclectic group; it plays with a palpable commitment to the challenging new music it performs.

title: ELIZABETH SEIFERT
description: Elizabeth Seifert, who wrote more than 80 novels about doctors after quitting medical school after a year and a half because she was told women did not belong in medicine, was found dead at her home here Friday.

title: John Paul Cheers Poland and Poles Cheer Him
description: ''Here I am. I have come home.'' For millions of Poles, it was not a moment too soon. They needed solace and Pope John Paul II brought it, and more, to them last week. It was his second visit to his native land since he became spiritual leader of the world's Roman Catholics, and thus of the vast majority of Poles, in 1978.

title: Japan to Explain Trade Aims
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan said today that he would send a public relations mission to the United States and Western Europe soon to promote imports and, at the same time, combat bitterness over Japan's large trade surplus. The Finance Ministry estimates that the surplus in the year ending next March will be more than $14 billion, compared with just over $9 billion in the last fiscal year.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Bears and Lions
description: To the Editor: The article by Barbara Gelb ''Please Don't Feed the Grizzlies'' (Travel, May 15) reminded me of an amusing incident.

title: DETERMINED ON DISTICTION
description: THE LETTERS OF MARGARET FULLER Edited by Robert N. Hudspeth. Illustrated. Volume I, 1817-38, 374 pp. Volume II, 1839-41, 264 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $25. each.

title: HIGH-CALIBER HUNAN IN GREENWICH
description: QUESTION: Can Fairfield County absorb yet another Hunan Chinese restaurant? Answer: Yes, if it is of the caliber of Hunan Gourmet, a six-month-old newcomer to the Post Road in Greenwich. In spite of the dozens of Hunan-style restaurants that have sprung up in the area over the past two years, Hunan Gourmet offers some attractive variations on a familiar theme. Perhaps this is because this is the first and only restaurant of the owner-manager, Tommy Chu, and he brings considerable experience from years as maitre d'hotel at Uncle Tai's and David Keh's in New York.

title: A YOUNG SON MAKES A FATHER'S DAY
description: IT was late, I was out the door and racing to make the 7:29 to Grand Central, when my boy called from the front step: ''Daddy, do I look like you?''

title: Kathryn Sheeran Is Wed
description: Kathryn Lynn Sheeran, daughter of James Jennings Sheeran of New York and Remsenburg, L.I., and Kathryn Leuver Sheeran of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Edward O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lawrence O'Brien of Marshfield Hills, Mass. The Rev. Thomas J. McCoy performed the ceremony at the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton, L.I.

title: SPAIN OFFERS COMPROMISE AT EAST-WEST TALKS
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez has presented a compromise to try to break the deadlock between the Soviet and Western bloc nations at the two-and-a-half-year-old Conference on European Security and Cooperation.

title: Yacht Rules Changed
description: Officials of the two major national grand prix yacht-racing events, the Bermuda Race and the Southern Ocean Racing Conference, have announced significant changes in the rules.

title: Yanks Win, 5-4, on 3-Run 9th
description: In the middle of the latest controversy involving their manager, Billy Martin, the Yankees rallied for three runs in the ninth inning last night to beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-4, at Yankee Stadium. It was their fourth consecutive victory.

title: Tandem Trailers Get Right of Way In Connecticut
description: Connecticut's rules of the road yielded to the law of the land in Federal Court in Hartford last week. Judge Jose A. Cabranes struck down the state's ban on double-trailer trucks as a violation of the constitutional powers of Congress to regulate interstate commerce.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID PLANTS REFLECT MARKET DEMAND
description: LIKE nuclear power facilities and garbage dumps, new hybrid plants sometimes draw unfavorable comment. With some justification, there are those who lament the loss of unique flavors, forms or fragrances. There is also concern with the trend toward monoculture or sameness in all plants being grown.

title: Testing Weapons On Education
description: For an issue that President Reagan insisted should not be a ''political football,'' education was booted about considerably last week. While Mr. Reagan attacked the National Education Association and called for tougher course requirements, three Democratic contenders for his job offered their own remedies.

title: Marijuana 'Breakfast': 22 Ill
description: A breakfast party at the Dade County courthouse resulted in 22 people going to the hospital. They ate brownies laced with marijuana, the authorities said. ''The old demon weed was in the brownies,'' said the Fire Department's operations officer, Joe Dalman.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE AMERICAN NOVEL AND THE WAY WE LIVE NOW By John W. Aldridge. 166 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95. By RICHARD J. MARGOLIS

title: HOSPITAL'S COLLECTION COMFORTS PATIENTS
description: WHEN the Yale-New Haven Hospital's new building opened last year, the hospital quarterly advertised it as ''the newest art gallery in town.'' This is no idle blurb. Over 500 works of art have been placed in 312,000 square feet of the building -and there is ample room for more.

title: HELPING PREGNANT TEEN-AGERS
description: Pregnant teen-agers and young single mothers experienced marked improvement in education and employment during a project designed to make them more self-sufficient, according to a report on the project.

title: CHARACTERS ON A COURSE
description: BLUE PASTORAL By Gilbert Sorrentino. 315 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: North Point Press. $18.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: WHAT I remember most about my cousin Linda's house was its revolving-door atmosphere. People were always visiting. Surprise guests showed up armed with bagels. It was always Sunday morning there.

title: WHO - OR WHAT - CAN CONTAIN THE MISSISSIPPI?
description: The rain-swollen Mississippi River recently crested 17.2 feet above sea level but safely behind levees, thanks to gargantuan earthworks and the Army Corps of Engineers. The normal level for late spring is eight or nine feet above sea level. Though the dangers of flooding have abated, eyes are on the future.

title: Julie Ann Farrell Is Wed
description: Julie Ann Farrell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Farrell of Millburn, N.J., was married yesterday to Douglas Paul Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas P. Jackson of Laurence Harbor, N.J. Msgr. Harrold A. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Art in France
description: To the Editor: John Russell's delightful article ''For Art Vagabonds in France'' (Travel, April 3) brought back memories of my many years of ''chasing'' some 50 French museums in nearly 40 cities and towns, a quest only recently completed.

title: Patricia Kearton Is Married
description: Patricia Lynn Kearton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kearton of New Canaan, Conn., was married at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Fairfield, Conn., yesterday to Laurence George Payson 2d, son of Mrs. Charles H. Sanford of Southport, Conn., and William S. Payson of Stamford, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Mrs. Sanford's cousin, Bishop John S. Spong of Newark, assisted by the Rev. Edward S. Prevost.

title: THE COMING CRISIS IN HOME COMPUTERS
description: BASKING in the newfound success of its home computer business last January, Texas Instruments Inc. hosted a lavish party at the ConsumerElectronics Show in Las Vegas. Comedian Bill Cosby, who does the company's commercials, posed for pictures with other guests and made a few remarks. Referring to the $100 rebate that had helped make the T.I. home computer popular, Mr. Cosby joked about how easy it was to get people to buy computers if you paid them $100 to do it.

title: CUBAN COMMANDER IN NICARAGUA POST
description: Cuba's top military combat commander has been working in Nicaragua for about a month and has been ''secretly assigned to duty'' there, according to an intelligence report disclosed by a Reagan Administration official.

title: TENNIS AND DIPLOMACY
description: SUDDEN DEATH By Rita Mae Brown. 241 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $13.95.A WOMAN OF CONSEQUENCE By Sondra Gotlieb. 286 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: COSMOS ARE WEARY
description: The Cosmos will play the Toronto Blizzard at Giants Stadium Sunday afternoon in the North American Soccer League champions' third game in 90 hours.

title: Recent Sales
description: Lebanon $129,500 *2*Hollowbrook Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*new contemporary; 5 acres, solar heating, wood stove; *2*taxes to be assessed. Morris Township $210,000 *2*12 Ironwood Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*3-year-old colonial; pool, burglar alarm, bay *2*window; taxes $3,474. South Brunswick $87,000 *2*Fresh Ponds Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*15-year-old bilevel; wood stove, well water, *2*1.5 acres; taxes, $1,751. Springfield $96,360 *2*8 Layng Terrace, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*35-year-old split level; fireplace in living *2*room, new dishwasher; taxes $1,760. West New York $69,000 *2*38 62d Street, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old brick town house; parquet floors, *2*garage; taxes $1,784. Wyckoff $172,500 *2*715 Highview Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*30-year-old colonial; family room, new kitchen; *2*taxes $2,402. OTHER AREAS Farmington, Conn. $355,000 *2*187 Talcott Notch Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*28-year-old colonial; spectacular views, *2*4.7 acres; taxes $2,499. Bedford Hills, N.Y. $137,500 *2*3 Burbank Avenue, 6-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*77-year-old Victorian; glassed-in porches, portico, *2*third-floor playroom; taxes $2,835. Smithtown, L.I. 104,000 *2*4 Rotondi Court, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*14-year-old colonial; formal dining room, fireplace, *2*den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,900.

title: TO DAD FOR HIS LEGACY: THANK YOU, DEAR FRIEND
description: ONLY in recent years, with the onset of maturity, have I realized how very much I loved my father. He was afflicted with Parkinson's disease at the age of 32, and I was born when he was 36. However sick of body he may have been, he was anything but sick of mind.

title: TRIALS OF A MISSISSIPPI LAWYER
description: If Wilbur Colom can handle a court with the skill that his story indicates, I urge him to use that skill in the real fight for black independence.

title: by Kendall J. Wills
description: If the size of a product's success is proportional to how quickly competitors market imitations, Eastman Kodak's disc-model cameras have scored well indeed.

title: SAM-5'S IN SYRIA: WHAT IS MOSCOW REALLY UP TO?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Lawns Are Ready at Wimbledon
description: Bright sunny skies baked the All England Lawn Tennis Club with unaccustomed afternoon warmth today less than 48 hours before the start of the Wimbledon tennis championships Monday.

title: CHILE ARMY TAKES OVER MINES
