description: Chile placed two copper mines under military control today in an effort to clamp down on anti-Government political activity by unions. Miners had been on strike at one mine and were to decide Monday whether to walk out at the other.

title: TOWARD ARMS CONTROL
description: Is there any doubt that there are simply too many nuclear weapons and warheads in the hands of the superpowers? There are about 9,500 strategic weapons on our side and at least 8,500 on the Soviet side. Will we just keep modernizing our weapons while the nuclear stockpiles continue to mount? Or should we just stop building weapons now, or freeze them at current deployment?

title: FOR HOMESICK MISSISSIPPIANS, A DAY FULL OF GRITS AND GRINS
description: The fourth annual ''Way Up North in Mississippi'' picnic was well under way in Central Park yesterday when Eloise Wexler, a transplanted Mississippian who works as a public-relations executive in Manhattan, decided to show her stuff in the watermelon seedspitting contest.

title: THE CANADIAN DIFFERENCE
description: Only an American would describe cleanliness and order as ''antiseptic'' and ''exotic.''

title: Keynes Revisited
description: To the Business Editor: Professor Samuelson's ''The House That Keynes Built'' (May 29) dodges, with considerable skill, the underlying problem with this remarkable though terribly flawed theory of economic capitalism.

title: TOXIC WASTE LAW YIELDS NO RESULTS
description: Several indictments under the state's 1981 hazardous-waste law for the illegal dumping of materials were dismissed by three State Supreme Court justices last year because the Department of Environmental Protection apparently failed to file with the Department of State a list of toxic chemicals and substances covered by the law.

title: Cuomo's Newest Nuclear Strategy
description: Alternating currents emanated from Albany last week as Governor Cuomo continued his effort to articulate a policy on nuclear energy. The Governor proposed in a letter to members of Congress that states be given the power to block nuclear plants by refusing to devise emergency plans for the surrounding area.

title:
GARDENING;
HYBRID PLANTS REFLECT MARKET DEMAND
description: LIKE nuclear power facilities and garbage dumps, new hybrid plants sometimes draw unfavorable comment. With some justification, there are those who lament the loss of unique flavors, forms or fragrances. There is also concern with the trend toward monoculture or sameness in all plants being grown.

title: ON THE RIDGE, HACKENSACK'S LUXURY ROW
description: HACKENSACK does not come readily to mind when discussing luxury h ousing in Bergen County. But along one six-block strip of Prospect A venue in that city are more than a dozen condominium, cooperative a nd rental apartment high-rises usually associated with the long s tring of luxury towers atop the Palisades in Fort Lee.

title: Medium As Mirror
description: Richard Wirthlin, public opinion analyst for candidate Reagan and now for the President, was driving home on the Los Angeles Freeway one day during the 1980 primary season. Twirling his radio dial, he came upon an interview with a campaign adviser to George Bush. He listened.

title: THE KREMLIN ADDS SOME NEW TEA LEAVES TO A FAMILIAR BREW
description: MOSCOW ''What good can a meeting do,'' Yuri V. Andropov asked his comrades on the Communist Party's Central Committee last week, ''if, as so often happens, it is held according to a prepared script, if there is no interested, frank discussion, if statements are edited beforehand while initiative and especially criticism are smoothed over and muffled?''

title: DIOXIN IS ONLY NEW JERSEY'S LATEST ENVIRONMENTAL HEADACHE
description: TO the litany of Newark's many urban ills was recently added an environmental one: dioxin contamination. The byproduct of the manufacture of herbicides, dioxin is one of the deadliest chemicals known to man. Readings of one part per billion are considered hazardous to health. On the three-acre grounds of a Newark factory that produced the defoliant Agent Orange during the Vietnam War, dioxin ranging up to 1,200 parts per billion was found earlier this month. A chemical waste treatment plant next door had levels between 3.7 parts per billion and 15 parts per billion. In a check of homes in the surrounding Ironbound neighborhood, however, a level of 0.2 parts per billion - considered too low to be alarming - was recorded in dust in a vacuum cleaner bag. Traces of dioxin were also discovered in a defunct Edison herbicide plant and yesterday, Governor Kean reported that more of the chemical had been found at a Clifton fragrance plant employing 300 people and located near a grammar school in a residential neighborhood. The Governor said the Diamond Shamrock Company, successor to the company which operated the Newark factory, would pay for tarpaulins to be spread across the site to prevent further exposure to the chemical. Still, seven people, including two former employees, and two food distributors forced to curtail operations in the area have filed what might be the first of many lawsuits over the chemical. And of course, dioxin is just one of a series of vexing environmental problems that have cropped up in the nation's most densely populated state in recent years.

title: PRESIDENT OF IVORY COAST SEES MORE MODERATION BY AFRICANS
description: Felix Houphouet-Boigny, the President of the Ivory Coast and one of Africa's most durable leaders, says he senses a trend toward greater political moderation among the nations of Africa and suggests that the United States could encourage this trend by promoting peace and development in the region.

title: COMPUTER 'DOG TAGS' BEING WORKED OUT FOR ELECTRONIC ARMY
description: The metal dog tags worn around the neck by soldiers for decades in war and peace may soon be another casualty of the computer age.

title: 2 IMPRESSIONISTS WITH L.I. TIES
description: WHEN Impressionism reigned as the dominant style in American painting, at the turn of the century, its methods were adopted by many artists then in their formative years, including Ernest Meyer (1863-1952) and Peter Bela Mayer (1887-), the subjects of the ''Two American Impressionists'' exhibition currently at the Moseley Galleries in Greenvale.

title: AN EGYPTIAN FOREIGN MINISTER'S MEMOIRS
description: NEGOTIATING FOR PEACE IN THE MIDDLE EAST ByIsmail Fahmy.Illustrated. 331 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $25.

title: Abdul-Jabbar May Go
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the free-agent Los Angeles Laker, may be headed to the Chicago Bulls or another team, according to the 36-year-old star's agent. The agent, Tom Collins, said he would begin ''actively pursuing,'' other teams after the Lakers apparently failed to match the $2 million-a-year salary Collins said the Bulls had offered.

title: KEAN ORDERS 3D DIOXIN SITE SHUT
description: Governor Kean said today that preliminary tests had discovered dangerous levels of dioxin in the soil at a chemical plant near an elementary school in a mostly residential area here.

title: NEWSPAPER NOVELS
description: BYLINES By Bernard Weinraub. 590 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95. I SHOULDN'T BE TELLING YOU THIS By Mary Breasted. 361 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $15.95. By CATHLEEN SCHINE

title: WHY GRASS-COURT TENNIS MUST SURVIVE
description: WIMBLEDON is once again upon us, and for the next fortnight the ''lawn'' goes back into lawn tennis. The most coveted of all tennis titles is up for grabs, and only one man and one woman will be able to say, ''I'm number one,'' come July 3.

title: SKIRMISHES IN THE BATTLE OF THE NEW CENTURY
description: To the Editor:

title: 4,000 CUBANS ARE WORKING IN MANY JOBS IN NICARAGUA
description: Several thousand Cuban advisers have been in Nicaragua since immediately after the Sandinist takeover in July 1979, working in areas ranging from education and health care to military and security affairs.

title: SACRIFICE A WAY OF LIFE FOR RESERVE CHAIRMAN
description: The world's most powerful banker lives mainly in a tiny garret-like apartment with a 10-inch black-and-white television, endures long separations from his ailing wife, smokes 25-cent cigars, yearns to do more fly-fishing and, for security reasons, is denied the chance to walk to work. Dinner often consists of spaghetti he prepares himself.

title: YONKERS WEIGHS EFFORT TO REVIVE PUTNAM RAIL LINE
description: YONKERS EXCEPT for one mile of track in the Bronx, nothing moves any more over the old Putnam Division, a rail line more than a century old that Conrail would like to abandon.

title: RECORD SET IN HURDLES
description: Tony Valentine of Plainfield (N. J.) High School posted a meet record as he won the 300-meter intermediate hurdles today in 35.98 seconds at the Keebler International Prep Invitation track and field meet.

title: COST SHARING FOR WATER PROJECTS IN WEST IS STUDIED
description: Under a new policy being developed by the Interior Department, Western states and private water users would be required to share the cost of building new Federal water projects only according to their ability to pay.

title: TECHNICARE'S CAT SCANNER WOES
description: CUSTOMERS had become so bitter and their complaints so heated, said D avid J. Morgan, that he was ready to quit. ''It was hard to keep a pologizing because our machines wouldn't run,'' said the former i nstaller for the Technicare Corporation, a leading maker of X-ray m achines and other diagnostic devices.

title: AUSTIN
description: WHEN Mark White reoccupied the Governor's Mansion for the Democrats after the only Republican interregnum in more than a century, he did it with a display of street theater remarkable even in Texas, where the play is very much the thing in politics.

title: Seattle
description: To the Editor: In the article ''What's Doing in Seattle'' (Travel, May 8) Moira Farrow, the author, overlooked one of the city's most exciting attractions at the Seattle Center, site of the 1962 World's Fair - the Science Center. A two-story structure left over from the Fair, the Center houses one of the most intriguing collections of modern scientific information in easy-to-understand format.

title: Plane Crash Ignites Brush
description: A small plane crashed near the San Joaquin Valley community today, killing the pilot and igniting a 500-acre brush fire, fire officials said. A force of 150 to 200 firefighters, most from the California Department of Forestry, battled the flames in 95-degree heat,

title: NEW FIGHTING SAID TO FLARE BETWEEN P.L.O. UNITS
description: New fighting was reported to have broken out today between Palestinian military units in eastern Lebanon as a rebellion against Yasir Arafat continued to spread. Reports here said more military units had joined the mutiny against Mr. Arafat's leadership, (The Associated Press, quoting the Voice of Lebanon, a Christian radio station, said at least two people had been killed and an undetermined number wounded.)

title: Sampson in Pro Debut
description: The National Basketball Association draft won't be held for 11 more days, but Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch University of Virginia center, has already signed his first professional contract - to take part in an exhibition game in Norfolk Tuesday night. ''I'm here to play a little bit of basketball and to let the people in this area see me play,'' Sampson said in Norfolk after signing the contract with the promoter, Bill M. Douthat.

title: COMMON MARKET MOVES TOWARD ACCORD
description: The leaders of the 10 Common Market countries inched toward a consensus on how to solve the organziation's financial problems today, agreeing to grant Britain a substantial cut in its 1983 budget contribution.

title: Timothy D. Nolan Marries Patricia Flood in Plainfield
description: Patricia Anne Flood, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Flood Jr. of Plainfield, N.J., was married there yesterday to Timothy Desmond Nolan, son of Dr. Timothy F. Nolan Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mary Dolores Nolan. The Revs.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: THE SUBJECT IS LOVE IN MUSICAL REVIEW
description: WITH durable new musicals in short supply, the cabaret revue is increasing in theatrical credibility. In fact, in Manhattan, there is an organized movement afoot to have cabaret shows acknowledged as an art form and reviewed - and respected - accordingly.

title: WHAT'S THE SHAPE OF CITY'S HOUSING?
description: IS the housing market in New York City on the verge of a boom d ecade or in a state of near-chaos? A score of experts representing b uilders, architects, urban planners, financial institutions, p hilanthropic groups and various levels of government grappled with t he city's massive housing difficulties at a symposium in midtown M anhattan last week, but there were no clear winners.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Milwaukee Brewers at Yankee Stadium, 2:05 P.M. Matt Keough, acquired from Oakland last week, is scheduled to start for the Yankees. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos at Montreal. The Expos' Steve Rogers, looking for his ninth victory of the season, is scheduled to oppose Ed Lynch, who is 4-2. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050 1:30 P.M.).

title: CRACKS IN A SHOPPING CENTER'S IMAGE
description: WHEN does a shopping center become a nuisance? To some Stony Brook residents and merchants, the situation had got out of hand recently at the shopping center called Brooktown Plaza, at Nesconset Highway and Hallock Road. They complained of littering by teen-agers and others and a lack of security.

title: Future Events; Town and Country
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Going, Going, Gone June 22 - In the market for a Nevelson sculpture or a Milton Avery pastel? Interested in Roman and Persian antiquities? Come bid on the paintings, drawings, sculpture, primitive art and antiquities offered at the 30th annual art auction to benefit the women's campaign for the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies. The 120 donated artworks are scheduled to go on the block at Sotheby Parke Bernet, 1334 York Avenue at 72d Street, at 7:30 P.M. Information from 212-9890-1000, extension 520. Admission is free.

title: LEGISLATORS PROMOTE RESTITUTION FOR CRIME VICTIMS
description: Judges would be encouraged to consider ordering a criminal to make monetary restitution to his victim as an alternative to a prison sentence under terms of a bill passed this week by both houses of the State Legislature.

title: Betsy Linzer Is a Bride
description: Betsy Anne Linzer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton A. Linzer of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Garrett Lord Silveira, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Silveira of Stamford, Conn. Acting State Supreme Court Justice Walter M. Schackman, cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y. The couple graduated from Skidmore College. The bride is a manager of the Art Works Gallery in Cleveland, and Mr. Silveira is a third-year student at the Case Western Reserve University Law School.

title: LACEY FOSBURGH, a former reporter for The New York Times, is the author of ''Closing Time: The True Story of the Goodbar Murder.'' Her first novel, ''Old Money,'' about a woman's investigation of her father's past, will be published this fall by Doubleday. She lives in San Francisco.
description: T he lamb is fattened to order on home-grown grains. The lettuce - all 20 varieties - comes from the owner's back yard. And Chez Panisse, the nationally known restaurant that may have started the new ''food movement,'' as Northern Californians like to call it, has spawned a network of other restaurants, related businesses and customers galore.

title: The Plot Begins
description: When Roger Kahn, the author of ''The Boys of Summer,'' decided to take over a minor league team and write a book about the experience, preferably ending with a dramatic victory in the league championship, he didn't know how many plot twists he would go through just to get to opening day.

title: CON ED'S SUPERVISORS FILL THE BREACH
description: In his regular job at the Consolidated Edison Company, Martin Scott sits behind a desk in an air-conditioned Manhattan office, preparing documents for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission about the Indian Point 2 power plant.

title: The U.N. Today; June 20, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 3 P.M.

title: NO-NONSENSE CODE OF CONDUCT STRESSED
description: Sometime around 11 A.M. Monday, 200 umpires and linesmen will be summoned to a meeting at the All England Lawn Tennis Club and told that controlling player behavior is a priority for this year's Wimbledon championships.

title: Working Off the Railroad
description: Conrail's union workers are offering to buy the giant rail system from its Federal overseers. That's welcome confirmation that the once-bankrupt company has become profitable again. But what the union proposes amounts to taking the railroad off Washington's hands for nothing. It's difficult to take seriously. Almost any option - including hanging on for a few years - is preferable to dumping Conrail on the first eligible suitor.

title: Books Of The Times
description: PILGERMANN. By Russell Hoban. 240 pages. Summit Books. $13.95.

title: COMMUNISTS TRY MITTERRAND PATIENCE
description: There are signs that the French Communist Party is becoming a more difficult, more uncomfortable element for President Francois Mitterrand to control within the framework of his Socialist-led Government.

title: COMING: SPACE WAR?
description: A little noticed passage in the generally tough speech by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko last week contains what may be a crucial new arms control offer.

title: Leaders From 2 Nations To Discuss Acid Rain
description: New England governors and premiers of eastern Canadian provinces met today to discuss cultural exchanges, the sharing of interests in energy, acid rain and other issues.

title: CONTROLS ON GUNS SUPPORTED IN POLL
description: A majority of Americans favor stricter controls on pistol sales but stop short of calling for an outright ban, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Caroline K. Rennolds Becomes a Bride
description: Caroline Kent Rennolds, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Kerr Branch Rennolds of Richmond, was married yesterday to Jeremiah Milbank 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milbank Jr. of New York. The Rev. David H.C. Read of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church performed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Edmund Addison Rennolds, the bride's grandmother, in Quaker Hill, Pawling, N.Y.

title: Balloons Explode, Burn 5 at Game
description: Four Mexican cheerleaders and a man were burned at the World Youth soccer championship today when hundreds of balloons, ignited by sparks from fireworks, exploded in Aztec Stadium at the end of the final game.

title: Elisabeth A. Weiss Weds Leonard Horowitz on S.I.
description: Elisabeth Anne Weiss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Weiss of Grymes Hill, S.I., was married yesterday to Leonard Marc Horowitz, son of Mrs. Nathan Horowitz of Lake Worth, Fla., and West New Brighton, S.I., and the late Mr. Horowitz. Rabbi Marcus Kramer, assisted by Cantor Jan Meyel, performed the ceremony at the Weiss home.

title: TANTALIZING WINS IN BOWLING GREEN
description: The colt's name is Tantalizing and that is what training him has been like for Angel Penna. The colt flashed spectacular promise as a youngster, but every time Penna got him close to a race, something went wrong. There was a knee injury, then sore shins, then an injured shoulder. Tantalizing did not get to the post until three months ago, a 4-year-old making a very belated debut.

title: Cubs Defeat Cards on 2-Hitter
description: Gary Woods and Ryne Sandberg drove in two runs each in a four-run second inning, and Dick Ruthven pitched a two-hitter to pace the Chicago Cubs over the St. Louis Cardinals today, 4-1.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Cessna Aircraft Co. filed for a public offering of $75 million of convertible subordinated debentures due in 2008, through Kidder Peabody.

title: Chase Unit at Rosenfeld
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has been asked by the Chase United States Consumer Services business, a loan company, to do its advertising. The client, a subsidiary of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, is currently operating in 13 cities in Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Texas and Utah. The previous agency was Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, which had to relinquish the assignment upon winning the Beneficial Management Corporation account.

title: FOR STUDENTS, 4 MONTHS ON THE JOB REPLACES SCHOOL
description: A 10-year-old executive internship program open to New York City high school students may soon become a model for similar projects across the country, according to the head of the program.

title: JAZZ: HYMAN AND FRIEND
description: DICK HYMAN and Roger Kellaway are having their third engagement as a two-piano and vocal duo at Michael's Pub, and their ability to think responsively while improvising is becoming more and more fascinating. At the same time, their source material is becoming wider ranging and their use of it more adventurous.

title: Economic Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision to reappoint Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board means a continuation of an eclectic and moderately expansive monetary policy, a policy that has been aimed at strengthening the economic recovery without reviving inflation.

title: WARSAW CAUTIONS CHURCH TO AVOID A POLITICAL ROLE
description: The Government warned the Roman Catholic Church today that continued opposition demonstrations during the visit of Pope John Paul II would harm the relations between church and state and delay the lifting of martial law.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Peace Shows' and Poland

title: Kriek Tops Gullikson
description: Johan Kriek defeated Tom Gullikson of the United States, 7-6, 7-5, today to win the $117,000 Volvo Grand Prix tournament.

title: TESTS FOR DIOXIN AT 8 JERSEY SITES TO TAKE 1 MONTH
description: New Jersey hopes to complete within a month soil tests at eight remaining sites it suspects may be contaminated by the toxic chemical dioxin, the state's Environmental Commissioner said yesterday.

title: 39 More People Are Arrested In Italy's Crackdown on Crime
description: The police said today that they rounded up 39 people overnight as part of a nationwide crackdown on organized crime that has netted 454 people so far.

title: 'Evita' to Close for Summer
description: ''Evita,'' a musical that won seven Tony Awards, will close after Saturday evening's performance to go ''on vacation'' for the summer, according to Robert Stigwood, the show's producer. Mr. Stigwood said ''Evita'' would reopen at a new theater when ''a star with charisma and talent'' was found to play Evita Peron. After Saturday night, ''Evita'' will have been performed 1,568 times at the Broadway Theater since its opening Sept. 25, 1979.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
WORRY OVER TREASURY ISSUES
description: The reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve cleared up one of the major concerns hanging over the credit markets, but the Treasury's huge borrowing demands are creating another.

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER IN TUDOR'S 'PILLAR OF FIRE'
description: ANTONY TUDOR'S ''Pillar of Fire'' cast a dim light when American Ballet Theater offered it for the first time this season Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Choreographed in 1942 to music of Schoenberg, ''Pillar,'' as the ballet has always been known for short, was one of the company's early triumphs, and it remains a fine example of the psychological dance-dramas that were favored in the 40's.

title: No Headline
description: Question BoxS. Lee Kanner QUESTION: How wide and how long is the runway for the javelin throw? How is the distance of the throw measured?

title: MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983; Reappointment at the Fed
description: Confirmation of Paul A. Volcker to direct the Fed seems sure, but many legislators will use the hearings to raise questions of policy. They acknowledge that Mr. Volcker has curbed inflation but worry about the costs in terms of economic stagnation. (Page A1.)

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.38 An index of yields for long-term

title: Hawks May Bid For Abdul-Jabbar
description: Ted Turner, the owner of the Atlanta Hawks, has told his team's president, Michael Gearon, to enter the bidding for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers, a newspaper reported today.

title: TEACHER, 72, SUING TO REMAIN IN HIS CONNECTICUT CLASSROOM
description: For the 26th time, Armand Zimmermann has watched a school year end at Branford High School. The students wore T-shirts or light, willowy skirts, the message board told of locker cleanup and final examinations. And last Friday, the class of 1983 graduated, scores of them having passed through Room 220, Mr. Zimmermann's room.

title: U.S. Engineers Faulted Over Munitions Plant
description: In a hurry to build a Mississippi ammunition plant, military construction officials failed to measure the equipment that went inside carefully enough, a lapse that, according to a Pentagon audit, cost nearly $2 million.

title: TENSION HIGH IN GUATEMALA AS CHIEF IS PRESSED ON VOTE
description: Guatemala's President, Brig. Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, appears to be facing his most serious political challenge since coming to power in a coup 15 months ago.

title: Chile's Copper Workers Said to Urge Wider Strike
description: Chile's striking copper workers reportedly tried today to persuade other unions to agree on a general strike this week against the military Government of President Augusto Pinochet.

title: A TIGHTROPE ACT ON AID TO NICARAGUA
description: Representative Dante B. Fascell, a veteran, mainstream Democrat from Florida, was recently talking outside the House chamber to a group of junior high school students from his district when one politely drew him aside.

title: MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL PLANS 17TH LINCOLN CENTER SUMMER
description: Armed with a much-needed contribution of $125,000 from the Fan Fox and Leslie R. Samuels Foundation and hoping for a more focused artistic direction under its music adviser, Gerard Schwarz, the Mostly Mozart Festival will begin its 17th season of summer concerts at Lincoln Center on July 11.

title: G.M. ELECTRONICS BACK IN U.S.
description: It seems as if most things here are very small and very busy. There are little vacuum probes that dart up and down, selecting good integrated circuits from bad among hundreds on a silicon disk. A nearby machine whirs and clicks as it stitches each tiny chip to a larger circuit with 40 pieces of gold wire, one-third the diameter of a human hair, in 14 seconds. Soon to come is an assembly machine that will place 256 electronic components on a circuit board in 2.4 seconds.

title: BLACKS CRITICIZE HANDLING OF ALABAMA KLAN CASE
description: Since Federal agents arrested two Ku Klux Klansmen in the 1981 slaying of a black man, several black leaders have criticized local law-enforcement officials for not pursuing the case.

title: News Analysis
description: Pope John Paul II's eight-day visit to Poland, painstakingly arranged by the Communist authorities in hopes of bolstering their virtually nonexistent popularity and ending their international isolation, has turned instead into a vast public outpouring of support for the outlawed Solidarity union.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CLOWNING AROUND

title: Vicki E. Taussig Becomes a Bride
description: Vicki Ellen Taussig, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Taussig of Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Marc George Gershwin, son of Judy Gershwin of New York and the late Arthur Gershwin. Rabbi David Seligson performed the ceremony at Windows on the World.

title: Bridge: Mascots Apparently Help, Or So These 2 Players Feel
description: Two card players from opposite ends of the earth have never met but have two things in common: they are both brilliant players, and they both rely on toy-animal mascots.

title: WATSON AND NELSON TIED AS OPEN IS HALTED BY RAIN
description: Tom Watson and Larry Nelson were tied for the lead and three shots in front of their nearest rival today when play was suspended until 10 A.M. Monday in the final round of the 83d United States Open because of a heavy rainstorm.

title: COURAGEOUS WINS AGAIN IN CUP TRIALS
description: The two-time America's Cup defender Courageous, driven by John Kolius, soundly defeated Defender, driven by Tom Blackaller, to win the second race in the preliminary trials to select a cup defender. The margin of victory was a commanding 1 minute 56 seconds.

title: A TOUGHER MRS. LLOYD IS FOCUS OF WIMBLEDON
description: LONDON THE red brick house looked tastefully elegant in the hilly suburban surroundings of Kingston-Upon-Thames. Flowers filled the spacious, well-manicured front, and a quaint brown sign wrapped around a large willow tree, in old English lettering, read ''Willow Cottage.''

title: Neil Simon Is Ending Marriage to Miss Mason
description: The playwright Neil Simon filed a petition for divorce from his second wife, the actress Marsha Mason, on Friday in Los Angeles Superior Court. The 55-year-old Mr. Simon cited irreconcilable differences, all that is needed under California law, as his reason for seeking a divorce. He said he and Miss Mason married on Oct. 25, 1973, and separated last April.

title: DIOXIN UNSETTLES QUIET NEIGHBORHOOD
description: Thomas T. Nieglos, whose home abuts the Givaudan Corporation plant here, spent this morning reading the newspaper articles over and over. He wanted to know as much as he could about the dangerously high levels of dioxin that were found in the soil of the 55-acre industrial complex.

title: ROBERT A. LEWIS, 65, CO-PILOT ON MISSION OVER HIROSHIMA
description: Robert A. Lewis, the co-pilot of the Enola Gay, the B-29 that dropped the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, died of a heart attack Saturday in Riverside Hospital in Newport News, Va. He was 65 years old and had lived in Smithfield, Va., for two years.

title: POISONING AMERICA'S 'NOOKS AND CRANNIES'
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * John A. Kinley has been named president and chief operating officer of Dix & Eaton Inc., Cleveland.

title: Cosmos Triumph Over Blizzard, 5-1
description: The Cosmos, with Franz Beckenbauer playing effectively on defense as well as offense, beat the Toronto Blizzard today, 5-1, and took over first place in the Eastern Division of the North American Soccer League.

title: Lauren Dana Wagner Marries Mitchell E. Cantor
description: Lauren Dana Wagner and Mitchell E. Cantor, who received M.B.A. degrees this year from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married at the Hotel Pierre in New York yesterday by Rabbi Schlomo Balter.

title: Woodward Paces Breakers' Victory
description: Doug Woodward, who played quarterback at Pace University in New York, made his first start of the season today in the United States Football League and threw two touchdown passes to lead the Boston Breakers to a 24-17 victory over the Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: 'YELLOW RAIN': VERY REAL VICTIMS AT BAN VINAI
description: To the Editor:

title: BID FOR CAROLINA REFINERY STIRS ECONOMY-ENVIRONMENT FIGHT
description: Bald eagles wheel in tight circles above the unbroken tree line of Winyah Bay, one of South Carolina's last and largest unspoiled stretches of coastal wetlands.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: An Expanding Perspective

title: McGraw-Hill's Changes For 'Market Segments'
description: A major restructuring involving seven executives was announced last week by John G. Wrede, president of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company. Although James R. Pierce of Business Week really was not involved, he did get promoted to senior vice president publisher, a title that also went to four of the seven men.

title: DANCE: PEARL LANG PRESENTS 'TEHILLIM' AND 'INTERLUDE'
description: LIFE is to be affirmed even in the midst of pain, or so Pearl Lang seemed to be saying in a program of new and old dances performed Friday at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Newman Theater.

title: LITTLE JOY AFTER COMMON MARKET SESSION
description: A three-day meeting of Western European leaders ended today without a resolution to the European Economic Community's grave financial problems and with a victory for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on reducing Britain's contribution to the group's budget.

title: Miss Neubert Sets Hectathlon Record
description: Ramona Neubert of East Germany bettered her world record in the hec-tathlon by scoring 6,836 points today in a meet against the Soviet Union team, Tass, the official Soviet press agency said.

title: 'OLD OLD' GROW IN NUMBERS AND IMPACT
description: When Myrtle E. Morris retired as a New York City office worker 30 years ago, she had her husband, her health, a home and a car. Now, at the age of 83, she is widowed and nearly blind, and she lives in a retirement home. Her driving days are only a memory.

title: FOR MANY A WEEKENDER, TRAFFIC JAM BEGINS AT CAR RENTAL OFFICE
description: For many New Yorkers, it is as much of an annoyance this time of year as sunburn and humidity. ''I really, really hate standing in line a long time to get a rental car,'' said Anne Flandreau, who had just finished an hourlong wait Friday night at the Avis office at 76th Street and Broadway.

title: SHARKS IN ABUNDANCE
description: ANGLING for sharks continues to grow in popularity along the Atlantic Seaboard, and one of the reasons for this is that the region's populations of these big game fish - some weigh 1,000 pounds and more - have not been commercially exploited.

title: Visa Renewed
description: Ali Kazemaini, the Cleveland State soccer player who was accused of spending the last four years in the United States illegally, has renewed his student visa with the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service for legal status, his attorney, Christopher A. Kalis, said Saturday.

title: BRIEFING
description: How About 200 Candles?

title: Begin Is Reported Planning To Meet With Reagan July 27
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin told his Cabinet today that he had been invited to a meeting with President Reagan on July 27, the Israeli radio quoted Cabinet sources as saying.

title: A FUELS PLAN FAR REMOVED FROM 'WELFARE'
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: BERNSTEIN'S 'QUIET PLACE' OPENS IN HOUSTON
description: Thirty-one years ago Leonard Bernstein wrote a one-act opera called ''Trouble in Tahiti,'' which dealt with a young suburban couple's arid existence and failed marriage. Last night, the Houston Grand Opera presented that work in tandem with the world premiere of Mr. Bernstein's 1983 sequel to that story, ''A Quiet Place.'' To call the result a pretentious failure is putting it kindly.

title: ISSUES IN WALKOUT AT CON EDISON
description: The major issues in the strike by 16,000 workers against the Consolidated Edison Company were reported by the participants to be these:

title: U.S. HELPS BLACKS REGISTER TO VOTE
description: More than 100 blacks filed into the tiny 68-year-old post office here this afternoon to sign up with two voting registrars sent here by the Justice Department.

title: MONDALE PREDICTS SENDING OF TROOPS INTO LATIN REGION
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said today that he believed ''it is inevitable that American troops will be sent into Central America'' because the Reagan policy was ''failing.''

title: FOX'S FORMER CHIEF A VENTURE CAPITALIST
description: Dennis C. Stanfill, former chairman and chief executive officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, has begun a new role as a venture capitalist in the entertainment industry.

title: ECONOMISTS, IN SHIFT, SEE STRONG SECOND QUARTER
description: A flurry of promising economic news in the last 10 days has prompted economists across the United States to revise upward their second-quarter forecasts for economic growth. Experts, who earlier this year said the recovery would be weak from April to June, now acknowledge that it will be powerful and widespread.

title:
THE CALENDAR;
The Calendar
description: Monday

title: EDIBLE OIL IMPORTATION CRITICIZED
description: On June 10, a Japanese freighter, the Satu Maru, left the southern Brazilian port of Paranagua with a cargo of vegetable and other edible oils. Ordinarily, such news would cause hardly a ripple in the vast sea of commerce in commodities.

title: WALL ST. AUTO ANALYST TO BE MONEY MANAGER
description: Maryann Keller, one of Wall Street's top automotive analysts, is leaving Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins to become a money manager at the firm of Vilas-Fischer.

title: RENAMING OF VOLCKER WELCOMED
description: Wall Street officials yesterday endorsed the reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. They cited his efforts to temper inflation and his role in meeting the complex problems of international debt.

title: Iran Reportedly Executes 16 Bahais in Secret
description: Sixteen members of the Bahai faith condemned to death in Iran on espionage charges have been executed in secret, a Bahai official said here today.

title: TV: A COMPENDIUM OF TWYLA THARP DANCES
description: FOR all of her adventurous experimentalism in dance, Twyla Tharp is a remarkably practical woman. Just as she does not waste movements, she also does not overlook opportunities for repackaging. Tonight at 10, for instance, Channel 13 is broadcasting ''Twyla Tharp Scrapbook: 1965-82,'' a compilation of excerpts from just about all of Miss Tharp's dances in those years.

title: ANTINUCLEAR PAPERWORK WEAPONS DEFUSED
description: To the Editor:

title: CANADIANS DEBATING OIL PRICE DECONTROL
description: On the face of things, this should be an ideal time for Canada to decontrol oil prices, a step President Carter took in the United States in 1980.

title: DR. SIDNEY M. GREENBERG
description: Dr. Sidney M. Greenberg, a physician at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills, Queens, and longtime member of its executive medical committee, died of a stroke Saturday at his home in Old Westbury, L.I. He was 77 years old.

title: SIMCHA EHRLICH, DEPUTY ISRAELI PREMIER, DIES AT 67
description: Deputy Prime Minister Simcha Ehrlich, the leader of the Liberal Party, died today after a stroke. He was 67 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: One morning last week, negotiators were meeting privately in some Capitol Hill office, trying to hammer out a Federal budget for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. Representative Delbert L. Latta, Republican of Ohio and co-author of the last two budgets, was quietly reading a newspaper just off the House floor. He had no direct role in the talks. That vignette sums up some of the major changes that have taken place in the budget-writing process this year. So far, the negotiators have failed to agree on a budget in part because they are still trying to adjust to the new political environment created by last November's elections, and to calculate the potential effect of any budget compromise that environment is likely to produce.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Legal Opinion on Love

title: TENTATIVE PACT GIVES CONTROL OF RENT STABILIZATION TO STATE
description: A tentative agreement to have New York State assume administration of the rent stabilization system has been reached by key legislators, according to participants in the negotiations.

title: MARTIN INQUIRY OPENED
description: The American League opened an inquiry yesterday into the latest conflict involving Billy Martin. But Martin's job apparently was safe for now, and he received some tentative support from George Steinbrenner, the chief owner of the Yankees.

title: Palmer Starts And Wins
description: Jim Palmer pitched effectively in his first start since April 26, and Eddie Murray hit two one-run homers today as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Boston Red Sox, 6-3.

title: FOR A LABOR CRUSADER, THE PLAY'S THE THING
description: Over the last three years, Jehane Dyllan has traveled from Appalachia to Alaska with her one-woman dramatization of the Karen Silkwood story, re-creating in union halls, churches and universities the life of the labor organizer who died in a mysterious automobile wreck.

title: WHAT SURROGATES KNOW OF A PERSON'S ESTATE
description: To the Editor:

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: THERE is a good-natured, eager-to-help altruist born every day -and y ou may be one of them. Remember that bus ride home when the fellow b alancing books, briefcase and umbrella made his way through the s tanding-room-only throng and stood limply before you? You were so t ired you could have cried, but you let him have your seat with a c asual, ''My stop's coming up,'' and a mumbled, ''in 35 blocks or s o.''

title: DESPITE RESERVATIONS IN CONGRESS, APPROVAL OF VOLCKER IS EXPECTED
description: President Reagan's nomination of Paul A. Volcker to a second four-year term as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board stirred criticism of the Administration's economic policies on Capitol Hill today. But confirmation of his reappointment appeared assured.

title: TRUSTEES GO OUTSIDE CITY U. TO FIND NEW ADMINISTRATORS
description: A University of Massachusetts dean and a Columbia University professor have been chosen for top administrative posts at the City University of New York, according to university trustees.

title: May Stores Sees Record Earnings
description: David C. Farrell, president of the May Department Stores Company, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting in St. Louis that May expected to register its ninth consecutive year of record earnings in 1983. ''In May we were up 1 percent and June sales look even better,'' he said.

title: Jan Stephenson Wins by 1
description: Jan Stephenson sank a 12-foot putt for a par on the 18th hole today to win the $200,000 Lady Keystone Open for the second straight year.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook Growing Out of Crime, Into Jobs

title: DeLorean Bid By Sinclair
description: Sir Clive Sinclair, founder of Sinclair Electronics, may buy the closed DeLorean sports-car plant in Belfast to manufacture an electric car, a spokesman for Sir Clive said today.

title: Britain's Inflation Down
description: Britain's annual rate of inflation dropped to a 15-year low of 3.7 percent in May, down from 4 percent the previous month, the Government announced Friday. The rate was the lowest since March 1968, when it was 3.4 percent.

title: Blue Jays Climb To Second Place
description: The Toronto Blue Jays continued their home-field mastery of the California Angels and moved into second place, ahead of Detroit in the American League East yesterday with a 6-1 victory over the Angels.

title: Audrey Sandler Is Married
description: The marriage of Audrey Lauren Sandler to Gary Colin Bernhardt took place yesterday at the Tavern on the Green.

title: Sam Rosmarin Marries Miss Gresser in Jersey
description: Susan Gresser, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Newton H. Gresser of Hackensack, N.J., was married yesterday to Sam Rosmarin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Rosmarin of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Joseph Berger and Louis Siegel at the home of the bride's parents.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. St. Louis Cardinals, at Shea Stadium, doubleheader, 5:30 P.M. Keith Hernandez makes his Shea Stadium debut as a Met and faces his former teammates for the first time since being traded last week. (Radio - WHN, 1050; 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs.

title: SEASONED STARS ARE AGLOW ON TWO LONDON STAGES
description: Michael Hordern doesn't wait for his first line to get his first laugh in the National Theater's new revival of Richard Brinsley Sheridan's ''Rivals.'' He sets the audience to giggling the moment he enters in the period costume and wig of Sir Anthony Absolute. And the giggle builds into a roar when the frazzled, gouty Mr. Hordern swivels on his cane to get a better view of the backside of the young maid who's just escorted him into Mrs. Malaprop's drawing room: the actor lets loose with a long, low, rumbling growl of unbridled lechery that is as close to poetry as an aural leer can be. Then the leer becomes a mournful sigh: this fellow is all too keenly aware that sex is behind him in his declining years.

title: Texas Gas Bid Raised By Coastal
description: The Coastal Corporation, in a bidding war with the CSX Corporation for control of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation, yesterday raised its offer to $55 a share.

title: French Production Up
description: French industrial production in April rose a seasonally adjusted eight-tenths of 1 percent from March, the Government said Friday. In March, production had fallen at the same rate.

title: SOVIET SHELLS ON DRIFTING SHIP
description: A cargo ship that was found abandoned in the Atlantic northwest of the Caribbean island of Barbados was carrying 5,000 crates of Soviet-made artillery shells, according to the Venezuelan Navy.

title: EARLY MUSIC: AN HOMAGE TO WOMEN
description: IN medieval poetry and music, the figure of the woman became nearly mythological. She was Eve, the mother of all; Venus, the goddess of beauty; Mary, the mother of Jesus; Guinevere, Isolde and Blanchefleur, the centers of romance, as well as the fickle goddess Fortuna.

title: YANKEES WIN, 8-3, FOR FIFTH STRAIGHT
description: The Yankees rolled to their fifth straight victory yesterday before a crowd of 40,630 persons in Yankee Stadium when they overpowered the Milwaukee Brewers, 8-3, with 39-year-old Lou Piniella driving in five runs.

title: No Headline
description: Dave Anderson One Putted, One Didn't

title: A KEY ARAFAT AIDE WOUNDED IN SYRIA
description: A senior aide to Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chief, was shot and wounded today in Syria, and a Palestinian official in Damascus accused guerrilla mutineers in the attack.

title: FIELD IN BOSTON MAYOR'S RACE MAY BE 11
description: Would Kevin H. White run? For months that question dominated the mayoral campaign here. When Mayor White, who has been in office for 16 years, announced last month that he would not seek a fifth term this fall, the 10 other candidates were ecstatic. They believed they could finally concentrate on one another and the issues.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blackman & Garlock, San Francisco, is changings its name to Blackman, Garlock, Flynn & Co. because Thomas J. Flynn has joined the merchant banking firm as a partner.

title: AGGRESSION: STILL A STRONGER TRAIT FOR MALES
description: While psychologists and psychiatrists often disagree sharply when they discuss whether behavioral differences between the sexes exist, many agree on one difference - that boys and men are still the more aggressive and violent. Nevertheless, the subject of aggression continues to produce heated conversation.

title: PHILLIP BURTON'S WIDOW SEEN AS LIKELY SUCCESSOR IN HOUSE
description: Sala Galant Burton is considered the leading candidate in a special election to be held Tuesday to fill the Fifth Congressional District seat left empty by the death of her husband, Phillip.

title: HOUSE PANEL DESCRIBES 'QUESTIONABLE' PRACTICES BY NUCLEAR AGENCY
description: A House subcommittee staff report charged today that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission had a record of ''questionable investigative practices.'' These include providing inspection reports to companies under scrutiny and failure to take disciplinary action against agency officials known to have violated agency rules.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report last Monday on graduation exercises at New York Law School incorrectly described Constance Baker Motley, who received an honorary Doctor of Laws degree. She is chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.

title: Judith Berkowitz, Teacher, Is Bride of Jeffrey J. Tretin
description: Judith Michele Berkowitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra Berkowitz of White Plains, was married yesterday at the Washington Hotel in Belle Harbor, Queens, to Jeffrey Jay Tretin, son of Laura Tretin of New York and the late Louis Tretin. Rabbi Israel Schorr performed the ceremony.

title: HIGH WATER LEVEL DEPRIVES GREAT SALT LAKE OF BUOYANCY
description: Water climbing toward record levels has so diluted the Great Salt Lake that bathers no longer are able to ''float like a cork,'' a state official reports.

title: Ghana's Leader Reports Crushing of Revolt
description: Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, the Ghanaian leader, said on the Accra radio today that troops loyal to his military Government had crushed an attempted coup by disgruntled soldiers.

title: LEWIS WINS JUMP IN 28-10 1/4
description: Carl Lewis does everything in style. Tonight, he became the first athlete in 97 years to win three titles in a national outdoor track and field championships. Along the way, he made history's second-longest long jump (28 feet 10 1/4 inches) and ran history's second-fastest 200 meters (19.75 seconds).

title: Feathers Are Out
description: After 500 years, you'd think they'd have perfected the golf ball, but according to Bob Molitor, who has spent much of his professional life trying to do just that, there is still room for improvement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am a son of this nation and that is why I deeply feel all its yearnings, its wish to live in truth, in freedom, in justice and social solidarity.'' - Pope John Paul II. (A1:6.)

title: EDUCATION IS IN DIRE NEED OF NEW FEDERAL EFFORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: 'DISABLED,' BUDGET-CUT CASUALTIES
description: ''DISABLED,'' a ''Frontline'' public-television documentary, looks at some of the people who have been dropped from the Social Security disability rolls. More important, it looks at the bureaucracy that has dropped them. In point of view it is sympathetic to the people and skeptical about the bureaucracy - it is unlikely anyone will make a documentary in praise of bureaucracy - but in a measured, thoughtful way. ''Disabled'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 tonight.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CUT FARM EXPORT LOSS
description: Farm exports by the United States continue to decline, and so once again American trade and agriculture officials will hold talks with their European Economic Community counterparts this week to ask them to stop subsidizing grain and meat sales.

title: TENANTS FIGHT ORDER TO PAY LANDLORD'S LEGAL COST
description: A Civil Court judge in Manhattan has ordered eight tenants to pay their landlord's legal costs of $74,300 after the tenants lost a court battle to block rent increases of up to 70 percent.

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Pattern Key to Action
description: THE stock market looked past a chilling price plunge in Texas Instruments last week and, instead, took its cue from Wall Street's favorite glamour issue, International Business Machines. As a result, both I.B.M. and the Dow Jones industrial average swept on to new highs.

title: JERSEY 'TOWN MEETINGS' FOCUS ON LATIN AMERICA
description: On this muggy weekend morning, when beaches and backyards beckoned, 50 curious citizens came to the paneled municipal chambers here to meet their Congressman. They were interested not so much in budget deficits, Social Security or even the state's toxic waste problems, but rather in Central America.

title: MANAGEMENT DISPUTE HURTING RED SOX
description: BOSTON TO most Americans, the cavernous, decaying Suffolk County Courthouse here is the setting for Paul Newman's triumph in ''The Verdict.''

title: HEAVY U.S. BORROWING THIS WEEK
description: The Treasury's weekly auction today of three- and six-month bills, totaling $12.4 billion, inaugurates a heavy week of Government borrowing. However, the tax-exempt market is expected to be very light because of recent weak demand and a flurry of municipal issues two weeks ago.

title: FRENCH BACCALAUREAT: A MIGHTY TICKET TO MATURITY
description: This is the week in which hundreds of thousands of French students earn their certificate of adulthood. For most, it's a miserable time.

title: 14 Poisoned by Prison Brew
description: Fourteen minimum-security prisoners at San Quentin were poisoned by liquor made and sold by inmates and all but three had to be hospitalized, a prison spokesman said today.

title: TWO WOMEN
description: Washington - What is it with Our Side in Central America, that we cannot come up with articulate, dedicated, stunning spokeswomen for the anti-Communist point of view - as the Other Side is so effectively doing?

title: PLAYING FOR LAUGHS AND SCOUTS
description: handed batter's feet.

title: 19TH-CENTURY U.S. ART WINNING NEW ESTEEM
description: Nineteenth-century American art -once so disdained that a 50-year span of it, from 1815 to 1865, was ignored by some art historians in their survey books - has emerged in the last two decades as an artistic and economic force.

title: High Tech's Promise to NATO
description: High tech, the industrial world's answer to everything, is held out also as a way to rid the West of the burden of threatening ''first use'' of nuclear weapons in Europe. Super-smart missiles and other nonnuclear weapons, it is said, could help reduce NATO's defense costs, conserve manpower and, by supplanting the nuclear strategy, disarm the continent's peace movement.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 20, 1983: MONDAY Esterline Corp PHH Group Inc Horizon Bancorp Rochester Tel Corp NBD Bancorp SCM Corp Outlet Co TUESDAY Amer Bldg Maint Ind Hexel Corp Brunswick Corp Genl Tire & Rubber CPC Intl Joy Mfg Firestone Tire & Rub Upjohn Co WEDNESDAY Brooklyn Union Gas cean Drill & Explor Federal Company Raytheon Co Flight Safety Intl SFN Companies Heller (Walt E) Intl Scientific-Atlanta Knight-Ridder Newsp Trico Indus THURSDAY Boston Edison Keller Indus Campbell Soup Pfizer Inc Commwlth Energy Sys Tektronix Inc Handy & Harman FRIDAY Centl Hudson G&E Rexham Corp FMC Corp Snap-On Tools Manor Care Sterchi Bros Strs Omark Indus Vulcan Materials

title: Civil Liberties Leader Assails Administration
description: Violating the Bill of Rights appears to be ''the primary goal'' of the Reagan Administration, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, Ira Glasser, said today.

title: SPELL AMERICAN
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Sailor Is Found In Car at La Guardia
description: The body of a Navy radio operator was found yesterday wrapped in a blanket in the back seat of a car parked in a lot at La Guardia Airport, the police said.

title: Miss Athos Weds Michael A. Adler
description: Jeanne Pamela Athos, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William J. Athos of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Allan Adler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Richard R. Adler of Missoula, Mont. The Rev. Socrates Tsamutalis performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian, of which he is the dean.

title: Schering Expects Flat 2d Quarter
description: Robert P. Luciano, president and chief executive officer of the Schering-Plough Corporation, said the pharmaceutical company expected relatively flat results in the second quarter, but he predicted ''robust'' growth in the third quarter. He also forecast a modest gain for the final quarter of 1983.

title: Livius Is Winner At Ox Ridge Show
description: Livius, ridden by Anne Kursinski, won the $25,000 Almaden Vineyards Grand Prix today at the Merrill Lynch Ox Ridge charity horse show.

title: ESKIMOS USE OIL TAXES TO MODERNIZE
description: This low rise of land on the Arctic Ocean shore has become a stage for the dramatic attempt of young Eskimo leaders to bring their village out of the late 19th century and into the late 20th in a decade.

title: Pershing 2 Test Marred
description: An unspecified problem developed on re-entry today in the 13th test-launching of a Pershing 2 missile, an Army spokesman said.

title: ANOTHER SATELLITE SENT FROM SHUTTLE
description: The five astronauts aboard the space shuttle Challenger dispatched a second communications satellite toward a high orbit today and checked out systems for the first test involving deploying and retrieving a satellite.

title: Washington Watch; Auto Content, Trade Abuses
description: WASHINGTON THE House Energy and Commerce Committee is expected to approve on Tuesday a bill that would have the effect of sharply limiting imports of Japanese cars, but chances of the measure ever becoming law are not rated high. The committee's chairman, John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, managed to keep the so-called Domestic Content Bill intact last week after a series of attacks by committee opponents.

title: River Currents Claim 4 Cousins in Texas
description: Four young cousins picnicking on a sandbar were swept away while swimming today and were presumed drowned where a river empties into the Gulf of Mexico, the authorities said.

title: Chew Wins Race
description: Tom Chew of Allentown, Pa., won the 11th annual Harlem Championships 35-Mile Criterium bicycle race in 36 minutes 4 seconds yesterday at Marcus Garvey Park in Manhattan.

title: SUCCESSFUL MIDEAST DIPLOMACY
description: If there is any area of foreign policy endeavor that can properly be called Sisyphean, it is the Middle East. You would think that, having put forward an initiative on the Palestinian issue nine months ago that was widely judged to be balanced, and having labored successfully in the interim to bring about an agreement on Lebanon, Washington deserved to get some breaks in this tormented part of the world.

title: HAYWOOD TRIO WINS LE MANS
description: Hurley Haywood of the United States, with his American partner Al Holbert and Vern Schuppan of Australia, scored his second triumph in the Le Mans 24-Hour race today, winning the 51st edition of the endurance auto race.

title: Staub Extends Streak, but Mets Lose, 4-3
description: A towering ninth-inning home run brought the fans to their feet in Olympic Stadium today. That was unusual because the homer was hit by a Met.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Cambridge Bioscience Corp. has entered into a licensing agreement with Harvard College that grants the company exclusive rights to a patent application and any resulting patents covering a method and products for the detection of human t-cell leukemia virus.

title: Advertising; Optimism On Direct Marketing
description: based direct-marketing specialty agency that is a subsidiary of Tatham-Laird & Kudner in Chicago is in a position, he believes, to go in the directions in which he is confident the business is headed.

title: SALES AT CITY'S STORES UP 9.9% IN MAY
description: Sales at New York City's big department stores rose a strong 9.9 percent in May from a year earlier, according to a spot-check made last week.

title: Lynn Henry, an Artist, Marries Thomas James
description: Lynn Susan Henry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Henry Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Thomas N. James, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guido James of Milford, Conn. Rabbi Stephen Klein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Explosion Is Said to Kill Afghan Defense Official
description: A land mine planted by guerrillas in eastern Paktia province of Afghanistan killed a top Defense Ministry official and nine other people traveling in an air force van, rebel sources said today.

title: Cunningham Pact Is Reported
description: Billy Cunningham has agreed to sign a multiyear contract at more than $300,000 a year with the Philadelphia 76ers, apparently making him the highest-paid coach in the country, according to a report in The Philadelphia Inquirer.

title: D.D.B. International Wins Michelin Account
description: The New York office of Doyle Dane Bernbach International has won the Michelin Tire Corporation account. It will take over the passenger car tire assignment on Aug.1 and the truck, off-the-road and motorcycle tire business Jan.1.

title: CONGRESS GONE ASTRAY
description: I wonder sometimes how we lost our way in defining Congress's role, for I am sure that our Founding Fathers never intended us to be what we are - an aggregation of Senators elected by popular vote, committed full time to the legislative undertaking in the Federal city, returning to our homes for periodic visits on weekends and the occasional breaks from the legislative schedule afforded by Christmas, Memorial Day, July 4 and the like. We have become elected bureaucrats.

title: Long Financial Times Strike
description: Tens of thousands of British business executives are wishing there was a bit more color in their lives these days - pink, to be exact. A three-week strike that shows no sign of ending has taken the strikingly colored Financial Times out of their lives.

title: CITY BALLET: 2 BALANCHINE FAVORITES
description: THE New York City Ballet, which has one more week at the State Theater this season, offered some old and more recent favorites Saturday afternoon.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Aid for the Sightless

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have agreed that there should be an improvement in pensions for some 300,000 state and local government employees this year, but they are still haggling over the price.

title: AN UPHEAVAL IN MEATPACKING
description: Bankruptcy, strikes, employee buyouts and distress sales are spreading like prairie fires through yet another old-line Middle Western business, the meatpacking industry.

title: Yarborough Wins
description: Cale Yarborough held off a belated challenge by Tim Richmond to win his second straight Michigan 400 today at the Michigan International Speedway.

title: Gaining Respect
description: The sad-sack reputation that United States teams have had in international soccer circles for many years appears to be changing finally -particularly at the youth level.

title: BRITISH STEEL MAKING CHANGES AT HIGH LEVEL
description: The British Government has appointed Robert Haslam, chairman of Tate & Lyle, the big sugar and commodity company, to be part-time chairman of the British Steel Corporation, effective Sept. 1. Robert Scholey, the present deputy chairman, ''is expected to play a key role in the future management of the corporation,'' the Department of Trade and Industry said.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 20, 1983
description: International The Polish Government warned the Roman Catholic Church that continued opposition demonstrations during the visit of Pope John Paul II would harm its relations with the church and delay the lifting of martial law. The Pope, meanwhile, celebrated an outdoor mass in Czestochowa, the site of a religious shrine, attended by about one million people, including cheering supporters of the outlawed Solidarity union movement. (Page A1, Col. 6.) United States troops will be sent to Central America, Walter F. Mondale said in an attack on the Reagan Administration's Central American policy. He said it was ''inevitable'' that troops would be sent there because the Reagan policy was ''failing.'' In a television interview, the former Vice President, who is now a Democratic Presidential candidate, accused the Administration of ''widening,'' ''Americanizing'' and ''militarizing'' the war in El Salvador. (A1:4.)

title: Figure in Tylenol Case Held on a Murder Charge
description: A man once questioned in the seven Tylenol-cyanide deaths was ordered held without bail today, charged with killing a man whom he may have mistakenly blamed for implicating him in the poisoning case, the police say.

title: NOMURA SECURITIES' EXPANSION
description: When he discusses the global ambitions of the Nomura Securities Company, Masanori Ito emphasizes ''the broader context.''

title: Talking Business with Mackworth-Young of Grenfell; World Debt: Progress Seen
description: Gerard W. Mackworth-Young, the 56-year-old chairman of Morgan Grenfell & Company, one of Britain's leading merchant banks, is also a director of Lloyds Bank P.L.C. and among the most prominent voices in the City of London on international debt problems. He is among a small group of bankers that has proposed a reorganization of the world banking system in response to those problems.

title: A 'HOMECOMING' FOR NEIL ALLEN
description: He appeared in the visiting team's dugout at Shea Stadium, wearing the light-blue uniform with the two Cardinals perched on the baseball bat on his chest, and the red name and numeral on his back. ''Is there anybody above the dugout?'' Neil Allen asked. ''Anybody with grenades?''

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD 'CANINE SNIFF' OF LUGGAGE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police may expose a traveler's luggage to a narcotics-detecting dog without violating the Constitution, but the luggage may be held for only a brief period.

title: Advertising; Team Has Grim Story To Tell
description: FREQUENTLY at ad agencies, people in the creative departments volunteer to work on public service assignments for the opportunity of working on something a little more dramatic than selling soap.

title: NEW TEST OF WRITING IN 5TH GRADE
description: THE State of New York has begun an effort to emphasize the teaching of writing in elementary schools by administering a test to every fifth grader and requiring remedial attention in the sixth grade for students who score below a minimum level.

title: Spanish Harpist Plays In Carnegie Recital Hall
description: Maria Rosa Calvo-Manzano is a professor of harp at the Conservatorio Superior de Musica in Madrid. Friday night, under the auspices of the Consulate General of Spain, Miss Calvo-Manzano presented an ambitious program in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Liberty Suffers 3d Loss
description: Defender, skippered by Tom Blackaller, rolled past Liberty, driven by Dennis Conner, to win both races sailed today on a hazy Rhode Island Sound by more than 30 seconds each.

title: DANCE: ZSEDENYI BALLET
description: THE Zsedenyi Ballet Company presented an ambitious but unsatisfactory program on Saturday night at the New York University Theater. The evening was bothersome because the group's three choreographers attempted dramatic works, yet were seldom able to make passing time convey a sense of historical or stylistic period; nor were they able to make stage space suggest a place in the world.

title: NELSON WINS OPEN BY 1 ON 62-FOOT BIRDIE PUTT
description: Larry Nelson waited patiently for 16 1/2 hours overnight after putting out on the 15th hole late Sunday afternoon and then sank a 62-foot birdie putt on the 16th green this morning to win the 83d United States Open championship by one shot over Tom Watson, last year's champion.

title: MCCALL ASSAILS AS RACIALLY DIVISIVE KOCH'S ATTACK ON EDUCATION CHIEF
description: The state's Commissioner of Human Rights said yesterday that Mayor Koch has contributed to racial polarization in the city by criticizing the State Education Commissioner's actions during the battle over who would be New York City's Schools Chancellor.

title: MCCARVER PUTS LIFE INTO METS GAMES
description: The Mets' telecasts have been much more entertaining this season, and any baseball fan knows it isn't the ball club that makes them so. The credit belongs to the new announcing team, and primarily to Tim McCarver.

title: I.R.S. Ruling Aids Bid by Internorth
description: The Internal Revenue Service has given a ''favorable tax ruling'' that will allow Internorth Inc. to go ahead with its acquisition of Belco Petroleum Corporation, the two companies announced.

title: Ashe Getting Heart Surgery
description: Arthur Ashe, the former Wimbledon champion, will undergo heart bypass surgery today at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: LEVI JUMPS
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, reported yesterday that net income for its second fiscal quarter ended May 31 fell 25.8 percent, to $22.2 million, or 92 cents a share, from $29.9 million, or $1.24 a share, for the same period last year. Secondquarter sales slid 6.9 percent, to $545.3 million, from $585.6 million a year earlier.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports News Briefs column yesterday incorrectly identified the event in which Ramona Neubert set a world record. It was the heptathlon.

title: I.C.C. Backs 2 Rail Plans
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission said today that it had approved two separate proposals by the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company and the Soo Line Railroad to purchase 720 miles of the bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island & Pacific Railroad Company.

title: Boston Jury Acquits 4 In Beating of Policeman
description: A Suffolk County jury acquitted four men today of charges arising from the beating of an Everett, Mass., police officer, John McLeod, at the King Arthur Lounge and Motel last July.

title: Scientific-Atlanta Shift
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc. said yesterday that Jack R. Kelly Jr. had resigned as executive vice president and chief operating officer, effective July 31. Mr. Kelly plans to become a general partner in Noro-Mosley Partners, a venture capital fund in Atlanta. No successor was announced.

title: THE 17TH HOLE GETS EVEN
description: For a year to the day, Tom Watson had glowed with the memory of having won the United States Open with that 16 foot chip from scruffy rough for a birdie 2 at Pebble Beach's 209-yard 17th hole. But as Larry Nelson won the Open yesterday by one stroke, completing a final round of 67 that included a 62-foot birdie putt, the treacherous 322-yard 17th hole at Oakmont got even for its California cousin.

title: DOW FALLS BY 3.01, TO 1,239.18
description: Stock prices responded yesterday with much less enthusiasm than many financial experts had expected to the weekend reappointment of Paul A. Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Registration Held For Kindergarten
description: Registration for the all-day kindergarten classes that are scheduled to begin in September is continuing at New York City public schools through Friday.

title: ART MUSEUM TO BID THE HILL ADIEU
description: The Museum of African Art, currently housed in nine adjacent town houses on Capitol Hill, one of them the historic home of the abolitionist Frederick Douglass, will shortly be moving to Washington's museum mile, that complex of Smithsonian museums on the greensward known as the Mall.

title: AT THE CONTROLS OF A CESSNA 182, MORE OR LESS
description: WE were about 15 minutes out of Fort Lauderdale in a friend's Aero Commander with its 750-horsepower engines purring along. The boatfilled Atlantic was looking unusually clear to my New England eyes when suddenly one of my daughters yelled from the passenger compartment, ''Daddy, are you flying this plane?'' Our rather sporadic course made the answer obvious. But familial flak aside, Wayne Stayton, the pilot, let me continue practicing my rather dubious aeronautical talents for the first time.

title: 53.4% STAKE SOUGHT IN CAPITOL AIR
description: A group of New York investors has agreed tentatively to buy a controlling interest in Capitol Air Inc., the company announced yesterday.

title: CITY BALLET: VARIETY OF FORM
description: TO go in one day from ''Scotch'' Symphony, George Balanchine's meditation upon 19th-century Romantic ballet, to his ''Symphony in Three Movements,'' which surges forward into a not-so-brave new world of the 21st century, is a fairly common experience at the New York City Ballet.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;
description: Thieves wearing masks held up a jewelry store this morning and escaped with up to $9 million in uncut diamonds and jewelry, Scotland Yard said.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 21, 1983
description: International

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: THE heat settled on the city like a very large person on a very small chair. Completely, so that it seemed that no air could get through. New Yorkers took it in stride. They put on their summer clothes and cut their hair. Indeed, there are probably more crew cuts in New York today than in all the Cub Scout packs of America put together, which means that it's time to let your hair grow.

title: JACOB DESCHIN, CAMERA EDITOR
description: Jacob Deschin, a leading writer on photography, died of cancer Sunday at a nursing home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 83 years old and lived in Great Neck.

title: INCOME INCREASED 1.2% IN MAY
description: The personal income of Americans rose 1.2 percent in May, the biggest month-to-month increase in nearly two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Chess: Five Finish Tied for First At Los Angeles; Tourney
description: The fourth annual Memorial Day Classic in Los Angeles ended in a tie among the grandmasters James Tarjan of the United States, Miguel Quinteros of Argentina and Larry Christiansen of the United States, the international master Kamran Shirazi of the United States and Dan Durham of the United States.

title: REAGAN SAYS HIS OPPONENTS RISK CENTRAL AMERICA INFLUX
description: President Reagan warned today that rejection of his Central American policy could result in ''a tidal wave of refugees - and this time they'll be 'feet people' and not 'boat people' - swarming into our country.''

title: U.N. CHIEF OPPOSES PRESS CURBS
description: Attempts by Unesco members to limit press freedoms are ''misguided,'' the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, told a group of United States journalists yesterday.

title: Wanted: A Bridge Deal
description: Already a gateway, an artery and one of New York's most enduring symbols, the Brooklyn Bridge might also become - a shopping mall. Standing in a cavernous vault under the bridge, Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city was searching for a private concern to convert the 29 enclosed arches of the Manhattan approach into shops and restaurants.

title: IRVING MANSFIELD, PRODUCER, MARRIES BEVERLY ROBINSON
description: Beverly Robinson of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., widow of David Robinson, was married in New York yesterday to Irving Mansfield of New York, a television and film producer.

title: CONCERT: HARMONIC CHOIR
description: THE Harmonic Choir celebrated the summer solstice at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Sunday with some new additions to its customary musical resources. This group of five singers has been known the last few years for its Mongolian- and Tibetan-inspired overtone chanting, and now it has added musical instruments to its concerts.

title: MARK A. LOTHROP
description: Mark A. Lothrop, a partner in the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, died of a heart attack Saturday at his summer home in Orient Point, L.I. He was 39 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: NELSON MEASURES IT JUST RIGHT
description: The history of the United States Open is rich with marvelous shots that led to victories, including the 16 foot chip that Tom Watson holed from the rough behind the 17th green in the final round of the 1982 championship at Pebble Beach. That birdie 2 crushed Jack Nicklaus's hopes for a victory or at least a tie.

title: DOCTOR FINDS ULCER REMEDY WHILE IN IRAN PRISON
description: UNDER the grim conditions of captivity in Evin prison in Teheran, Iran, a physician found what he believes to be a new and remarkable treatment for the pain of peptic ulcers.

title: New Eagles' Group
description: After months-long negotiations aimed at the sale of part of the debt-ridden Philadelphia Eagles, an agreement was announced yesterday in which a ''significant interest'' in the team was purchased by a group of investors who include Susan Fletcher, daughter of Leonard Tose, the principal owner. Mrs. Fletcher, who has been running the nonfootball operations of the club for almost a year, was joined in the purchase by Julius Newman, a Philadelphia surgeon; Newman's wife, Sandra Schultz Newman, an attorney; Lou Guida, a Wall Street investor and syndicator of Niatross, the standout harness horse, and Ira F. Lampert, the managing partner of an accounting firm. Under the agreement, Mrs. Fletcher will remain managing general partner and will be responsible for day-to-day operations. ... Art Modell, the owner of the Cleveland Browns, underwent heart surgery Sunday for the second time in three days but was reported in satisfactory condition in the cardiac intensive-care unit of Cleveland Clinic Hospital.

title: GROUP OF BLACK LEADERS SUPPORTS IDEA OF BID BY BLACK FOR PRESIDENCY
description: A group of black civil rights and political leaders voted today to approve the concept of a black candidate's seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Kodak Picks Atex Chief
description: Joseph Quickel today was named president of the Atex Corporation, an Eastman Kodak Company unit that makes word processing and typesetting equipment. Mr. Quickel, 61, who was promoted from senior vice president and general manager, joined Atex in 1982 from Kodak's Apparatus Manufacturing division. He succeeds Robert W. Camp, who will be assistant manager of Kodak's Rochester Paper Manufacturing Organization.

title: 3 SYRIANS KILLED IN AMBUSH IN LEBANON
description: Two Syrian Army officers and a Syrian enlisted man were killed today when their jeep was ambushed near the northern Lebanese port city of Tripoli.

title: Police Program To Focus on Guns
description: The Police Department announced yesterday that it would begin an educational program about the dangers of handgun ownership. Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire said that statistics showed that ''when people carry guns, they're very much more at risk than the victim of a crime who does not possess a gun and does not attempt to use it.'' Mr. McGuire said that in 1981, 62.7 percent of the murders in New York were committed by people who were friends or acquaintances of the victims.

title: Top Officer Named At Marshall Field
description: Philip B. Miller, the 45-year-old president of Neiman-Marcus in Dallas, has been selected as the new chairman and chief executive officer of Marshall Field & Company, it was announced yesterday by Batus Inc., the parent company of Marshall Field.

title: SCHOOLMASTER'S METHODS STIR FUROR IN JAPAN AFTER BOY DIES
description: When Hiroshi Totsuka opened his school for emotionally troubled youngsters in 1976 he promised stern discipline, and that is what he gave.

title: Bridge: Mill Basin Club Should Get More Than Passing Notice
description: In North America, unlike the rest of the world, bridge clubs have no significance outside their own doors. There are virtually no interclub contests, and if members of a particular club do well in tournament play, nobody pays any attention. Perhaps we should.

title: ISRAELI DOCTORS EXPAND HUNGER STRIKE FOR PAY
description: More doctors joined a hunger strike today to protest the Government's refusal to give them a substantial raise. The fast, begun a week ago by doctors at Soroka Hospital in Beersheba, spread to hospitals throughout the country, threatening to close surgical and other departments as doctors became weak and unable to work. Some were reported to have collapsed and to have been given fluids intravenously by colleagues. Conditions in the hospitals worsened but emergency services were being maintained in most areas.

title: Trading Quiet In Eurobonds
