description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds declined throughout the day to show losses of about 3/8 point in very quiet trading, dealers said.

title: Bout Too Costly
description: The return of big-time boxing to Madison Square Garden last week with the Davey Moore-Roberto Duran fight, which drew 20,061 people, could augur well for the sport in its erstwhile mecca. But the next main event that could have taken place there got short-circuited by electricity costs.

title: An Omen in Song
description: Even Sheila Loughery did not know what her husband, Kevin, was going to do: stay as coach of the Atlanta Hawks or go to the Chicago Bulls.

title: STAKE IN VOLKSWAGEN IS ACQUIRED BY KUWAIT
description: The Government of Kuwait has widened its interest in Western European industry by acquiring nearly 10 percent of Volkswagenwerk A.G., the auto manufacturer, industry sources said today.

title: A POLITICAL INSIDER'S NEW VIEWS FROM THE OUTSIDE
description: It's four months since Richard S. Schweiker quietly left the Cabinet to become chief lobbyist for the life insurance industry, ending a public career as House member, Senator and Secretary of Health and Human Services that was highlighted by his surprise selection as Ronald Reagan's Vice Presidential running mate in 1976.

title: China Names Head Of New Security Ministry
description: China announced today that Ling Yun, a Deputy Minister of Public Security since 1964, would head a new Ministry of State Security.

title: The Importance of Being Wrong
description: Dissent, President Reagan seems to think, should speak in a pale and patriotic voice. Addressing a group of students outside the White House last week, he said, ''You have a responsibility and right to speak out about your concerns. ... We have that right because we're Americans.

title: Coco Leaves Comedy
description: James Coco has withdrawn from the cast of ''You Can't Take It With You'' because of a leg injury. Ellis Rabb, who directed the revival of the George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart comedy, will enact tonight the role that Mr. Coco played, that of a Russian ballet instructor. Mr. Rabb plans to remain in the play several weeks while he searches for a permanent replacement.

title: Senate Officer Shuns Bid To Be Mayor of Boston
description: William M. Bulger, the President of the Massachusetts State Senate, said today that he would not run for mayor, ending speculation that has overshadowed the campaigns of the 10 announced candidates for several weeks.

title: Czech Chief Shuffles Cabinet, Replacing Technical Minister
description: President Gustav Husak made major changes in the Czechoslovak Cabinet today in a move believed to signal a new emphasis on technical development.

title: Required Reading; Forgotten Employees
description: J. Lynn Helms, head of the Federal Aviation Administration, in a June 17 letter to a House subcommittee challenging the General Accounting Office report entitled ''F.A.A. Can Better Manage the Aircraft It Uses to Keep Pilots Current and Provide Transportation'':

title: To the Victor ...
description: Billy Cunningham, the coach of the champion 76ers, will be back.

title: Imasco Tire Bid Faces Opposition
description: Imasco Ltd., the Montreal-based tobacco, retailing and fast-food group, is considering whether to go ahead with a proposed $1.08 billion (Canadian) cash and stock offer for the Toronto-based Canadian Tire Corporation, in the face of opposition of two Canadian Tire family shareholders controlling 30 percent of the voting common.

title: SCOTS, RESISTING THATCHER TIDE, HEARTEN HOME-RULE BACKERS
description: Proponents of home rule for Scotland have drawn encouragement from the Scottish vote last week that rejected Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative Government.

title: ON FABLED SILK ROAD, FREE TRADE THRIVES IN CHINA
description: The other Sunday, Turgan Tokhti went down to the bazaar and found a new donkey to pull the wooden cart that provides the family transportation. It was a good sturdy donkey, only 2 years old, and he bought it for $90.

title: Contested Atlanta Road Approved by Governor
description: Gov. Joe Frank Harris of Georgia has given his approval for the construction of the North Atlanta Parkway, a six-lane highway designed to relieve traffic congestion by cutting through some of Atlanta's most desirable residential neighborhoods.

title: BELO TV PURCHASE PUT AT $606 MILLION
description: The A.H. Belo Corporation said it had agreed to pay $606 million to the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation for its Corinthian Broadcasting Group of six television stations.

title: METS GAIN SPLIT WITH CARDS
description: The bumper sticker above Rusty Staub's locker simply states, ''Older Is Better.'' And a growing list of pitchers throughout the National League could verify the statement.

title: Tax Bills Backed In Connecticut
description: The Democratic majority in the Connecticut Senate agreed today to support most parts of a $241 million package of tax increases approved Thursday by the House of Representatives.

title: Court to Re-examine Disputed Antitrust Doctrine
description: The Supreme Court announced today that it would re-examine a long-held and increasingly disputed tenet of antitrust law: the doctrine under which affiliated companies can be found to have conspired with each other in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How are permanent magnets made?

title: S.I. Survival Alone Viewed as Possible
description: The staff of a State Senate committee has found that if Staten Island became an independent city it could provide all the basic services it gets now and have $17 million left over.

title: DeLorean Car Discounts
description: About 700 or 800 of the stainless steel, gull-wing DeLorean sports cars are left for sale, the president of the company that bought the autos said today.

title: PREGNANCY RULING EXTENDS BENEFITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that company medical plans must cover the pregnancies of employees' wives to the same extent that they cover all other dependents' medical expenses.

title: Saab to Construct Connecticut Plant
description: Saab-Scania, the Swedish automotive and aerospace group, said it would invest $7 million in a plant that could build 250 buses each year in Orange, Conn.

title: No Train Service At Williamsbridge
description: There was no service yesterday at the Williamsbridge station on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's Harlem line, because of a water main break in the Bronx.

title: Juilliard Seeks President
description: The Juilliard School of Music has formed a search committee for a new president. The post had been held by Peter Mennin, who died Friday. Peter S. Paine, chairman of the board of trustees, also announced yesterday that Gideon Waldrop, the school's dean since 1963, will serve as acting president in the interim. Dr. Waldrop will retain the job of dean as well.

title: Union Leader Held in Peru
description: The head of Peru's largest labor coalition, Baldomero Valenzuela, has been arrested on charges of creating ''public disorder'' by staging nationwide strikes in 1981 and in March of this year and planning a third in defiance of a state of emergency, the police said today. Mr. Valenzuela, leader of the leftist Popular Democratic Union, was also arrested on charges of training guerrillas.

title: HASIDIC RABBI'S BEARD IS CUT IN AN ABDUCTION IN BROOKLYN
description: A 36-year-old Lubavitcher rabbi on his way to a synagogue yesterday morning in Brooklyn was attacked by several men who forced him into a van and cut off his beard, the police said.

title: Title Bout in Capital
description: Michael Spinks will defend the world light-heavyweight championship against Eddie Mustafa Muhammad on July 15 at the D.C. Armory in Washington. It will be the first title fight in the capital since Joe Louis beat Buddy Baer there 42 years ago.

title: FINANCE/ NEW ISSUES;
description: A $100.7 million bond issue for the Health and Educational Facilities Authority of the State of Missouri was tentatively priced yesterday by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group with yields ranging from 6 1/4 percent to 10 1/8 percent.

title: GRAND JURY INDICTS LIEUT. GOV. GREEN OF NORTH CAROLINA
description: Lieut. Gov. Jimmy Green was indicted by a Wake County grand jury today on charges of conspiring to receive bribes from an undercover agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: TENNESSEE'S BANKING TURMOIL
description: The collapse of the Butcher brothers' banking empire, which has thrown the Tennessee financial world into turmoil, promises to tie up the courts and state regulators for months, if not years.

title: Letter: On the Middle East; No Time for U.S. Neutrality
description: To the Editor:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THROUGH THE NIGHT

title: GROWTH OF INTEREST IN FARMING IS SEEN AMONG YOUNG PEOPLE
description: The farm on which Rick Plumb stands, worrying about the corn yet unplanted, once belonged to his greatgrandfather. Mr. Plumb's grandfather received it as a wedding present, and from there it came down through the generations.

title: Guatemala Reports Clashes With Rebels
description: The Guatemalan Army said today that its soldiers killed 15 leftist guerrillas in the northwest province of Quiche in renewed fighting over the weekend.

title: BEIRUT ISSUES REPORT ON MASSACRE
description: A report by Lebanon's military prosecutor said today that the political and militia leadership of the Christian Phalangist Party was not responsible for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians in two refugee camps last September.

title: AN ECONOMIST AND PROFESSOR
description: Sidney Weintraub, a professor of economics at the University of Pennsylvania who proposed using the Federal income tax to discourage wage and price inflation, died at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania of a heart-related disease Sunday. He was 69 years old and a resident of Philadelphia.

title: Poland Regains Its Voice
description: The bold words of Pope John Paul II have obviously discomfited Poland's rulers. They must worry even more about the response of his huge Polish audiences. In a few days, the Pope will go home. But he will leave behind a population that after 18 months of General Jaruzelski's martial law still denies his regime's legitimacy.

title: HEART ATTACKS: TURMOIL BENEATH THE CALM
description: THE Omaha business executive, president of a major division of a multimillion-dollar conglomerate, seemed to take in stride the demands of his work and of an active family life. He was always so calm that everyone who knew him, including his wife, was shocked when he suffered a heart attack.

title: A Creditor Plan Filed by Lionel
description: The Lionel Corporation, operating under Chapter 11, said it had filed a reorganization plan that would give its unsecured creditors an initial payment of $70 million in cash.

title: THE NEW STRATEGIES FOR PAYING TEACHERS MORE
description: AREVOLUTION in the way school teachers are paid is imminent. Fundamental changes, long opposed by teachers' unions, are likely to be introduced in many states, hastened by political debate in advance of the 1984 elections.

title: TWO TIGER PITCHERS STOP BREWERS, 4 TO 1
description: Dave Rozema combined with Aurelio Lopez on a three-hitter for Detroit tonight as the Tigers defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-1.

title: GROUP ACCUSES CHANNEL 13 OF PRO-SANDINIST BIAS
description: In the last three years, as the conflict between the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua and American-backed guerrillas has heated up, WNET-TV, Channel 13, in New York, has broadcast three documentaries on that Central American country. Now, a decision not to offer a fourth documentary film has led to charges that the public-television station is presenting a one-sided, pro-Sandinist point of view.

title: PENSION CHANGE IS TERMED DEAD IN ALBANY FIGHT
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, said today that the effort to improve pensions for some 300,000 public employees was dead for this legislative session unless the Democrats accepted the plan the Senate passed last week.

title: Job Is Abolished
description: Phil Woosnam's job as the commissioner of the North American Soccer League, a post he had held since 1971, has been abolished in what the financially troubled N.A.S.L. is describing as a cost-cutting move. Most of Woosnam's responsibilities will be assumed by Howard Samuels, who, with his appointment as president last summer, had already superseded Woosnam as the league's chief executive.

title: SHAVING AREA OF OPERATION NOW SEEMS DANGEROUS
description: FOR as long as anyone can remember, surgeons have shaved the skin around an impending operation, both for better access to the operative area and to help prevent infections. But now some doctors have raised a critical question: Does the shaving actually do the patient any good?

title: U.S. GAINS IN SMALL TRUCKS
description: In the long struggle with Japanese companies for the American car market, there is one area where Detroit seems to be winning, at least for now: small, sporty pickup trucks.

title: OPERA: A RARE BERLIOZ
description: Although it is in only its eighth season, Opera Theater of St. Louis already must be counted among the few indispensable companies. Its productions consistently show the kind of ingenuity, daring and refinement that force the opera world to take notice. Under the direction of Richard Gaddes, it has already developed an individual style and character, much in the tradition of such older operatic meccas as Glyndebourne and Santa Fe.

title: Team at the Top
description: When Marian L. Schwarz was promoted to Coordinator of Youth Services yesterday, the city got a husband-and-wife team in highlevel municipal jobs.

title: CHILE COALITION CALLS A NATIONWIDE STRIKE BEGINING THURSDAY
description: A coalition of unions, students and some professional associations tonight called for an indefinite nationwide strike beginning Thursday to protest Government economic policy and the jailing of seven leaders of the Copper Workers Confederation.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. SECURITIES CLIMB IN YIELD
description: Prices of Government securities fell and yields rose yesterday amid some nervousness over large bill auctions this week. Dealers expressed concern that yesterday's quiet trading session, where retail interest was minimal, signaled higher rates and lower investor participation during the auctions.

title: ALMOST 1,000 ARRESTED IN NUCLEAR WEAPONS PROTEST
description: More than 950 people were arrested today while trying to blockade entrances to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, where most American nuclear weapons are developed, in the largest of several demonstrations, coast to coast, for disarmament.

title: Sun Will Sell Flagship Units
description: Sun Banks Inc. of Orlano announced agreements today to sell 11 units belonging to Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami for $132 million, an essential step in a $334 million merger of the two institutions.

title: VETERAN PLEADS CASE TO CONGRESSMEN
description: A Vietnam War veteran honored for valor by President Reagan denounced the Administration today for cutting off his Social Security disability benefits and said his plight typified the experience of many Americans.

title: TENTATIVE ACCORD REACHED BY STATE IN OIL TAX DISPUTE
description: Governor Cuomo announced tonight a tentative outof-court settlement with major oil companies over a tax, in dispute since 1980, that the companies had refused to pay.

title: FRAUD CASE SPLITS SOUTH AFRICA CHURCH GROUP
description: At a time when they are under sustained pressure from the Government, the South African Council of Churches and its general secretary, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, have become caught in a sharp conflict of emotions and recriminations over their response to the conviction on fraud and embezzlement charges of a leading Christian layman.

title: SURPRISING SUCCESS FOR COURAGEOUS
description: As Liberty and Defender competed today in the preliminary trials to select an America's Cup defender, the crew of Courageous had a day off from racing. And it was a day to bask in the joys of success. By winning the opening two races over the weekend, Courageous had turned these trials upside down.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alpine Geophysical Corp., Wallingford, Conn., has elected Terrence Swain president and chief operating officer and Steven S. Elbaum vice chairman.

title: Weinberger Off to London
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger left today for a two-day visit to London that will include talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe and Defense Minister Michael Heseltine. Mr. Weinberger planned to return Thursday, the Pentagon said.

title: NEW LOOK AT NORTHERN LIGHTS
description: A television camera mounted on a satellite is expected to give scientists their first look at the ultraviolet sections of the Northern Lights, according to the project's directors at the Applied Physics Laboratory of Johns Hopkins University.

title: A WORLD ILL-SUITED FOR SCIENTIFIC RIVALRY
description: To the Editor:

title: NUCLEAR ARMS CHARTS DON'T TELL ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN EXPLORING SALVADORAN TALKS
description: President Reagan today authorized his special envoy to Central America, Richard B. Stone, to explore the possibility of meeting with Salvadoran guerrilla leaders if the Government of El Salvador endorses the idea, senior Administration officials said.

title: The Gases of Titan
description: Recent observations of Titan, Saturn's largest moon, have provided new evidence that its atmosphere is much like the one scientists have postulated for the primitive earth, feeding speculation that though Titan's low temperature precludes liquid water, substances that figured in the evolution of life may be forming there.

title: U.S. GENERALS ARE LEERY OF LATIN INTERVENTION
description: With unusual unanimity, senior generals of the United States Army say they oppose any American military intervention in Central America without the clear, unequivocal support of Congress and the people.

title: NELL KIRBY
description: Nell Kirby, who opened the Kirby Allen tearoom on Madison Avenue at 67th Street in 1923 and ran it for half a century, died on June 11 in Sidney, Ohio.

title: A FAMILY BATTLES TO HAVE GIRL TREATED AT HOME
description: Four-year-old Julia Mikol of Manhattan, who was born without an immune system, has been hospitalized frequently and for extended periods during her short life.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON U.S. BUDGET FOR FISCAL 1984
description: Working against a midnight deadline, House and Senate negotiators agreed tonight on an $860 billion Federal budget for the next fiscal year.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Site for a Tete-a-Tete

title: SOVIET OIL REVENUE ROSE IN '82
description: The Soviet Union, contrary to expectations of some Western analysts, managed to overcome a decline in world oil prices and to increase its crucial hard-currency revenue from oil exports in 1982.

title: CHALLENGER, PASSING ITS TESTS, PREPARES TO CATCH A SATELLITE
description: Scientific experiments on a West German satellite were switched on and tested today as the Challenger astronauts prepared for the next major event of the space shuttle mission - the first deployment and retrieval of an orbiting satellite.

title: ODIZOR OF NIGERIA TOPS VILAS IN 5 SETS
description: Guillermo Vilas and Jose-Luis Clerc, missing from last year's Wimbledon tennis championships because of Argentina's war with Britain over the Falkland Islands, were eliminated on the tournament's opening day today.

title: 'FEN,' UNUSUAL ON-THE-SPOT CREATION
description: In September 1982, six actors from the Joint Stock Theater Group began work on a new play. In the tradition of this highly regarded English experimental troupe, such work does not always begin in an empty theater or rehearsal hall. This time the work began in the swampy fields of an area called the Fens, 100 miles north of London.

title: A WORLD ILL-SUITED FOR SCIENTIFIC RIVALRY
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about banking in Delaware erroneously quoted the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company concerning bank income tax rates in New York and Delaware. The tax rate on bank net income in New York is 25.8 percent. In Delaware, it is 8.7 percent on the first $20 million of net income, 6.7 percent on the next $5 million, 4.7 percent on the next $5 million and 2.7 percent on net income exceeding $30 million.

title: STAY HOME, RISING STAR
description: It appears that I may soon be the only columnist in North America who hasn't endorsed Mario Cuomo for national office, so I decided I'd better get into print in a hurry to explain my holdout status.

title: Chicago Mayor Granted Control of 900 City Jobs
description: A Federal judge today approved an agreement that allows Mayor Harold Washington to replace 900 employees in key policy positions.

title: Home Loan Banks In Bond Offering
description: A $500 million bond offering was announced yesterday by the Federal Home Loan Banks.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AGS Computers Inc., Mountainside, N.J., announced that it had completed the acquisition of Disc Inc., a Baltimore-based software products company, for $6.9 million in cash and notes.

title: NO DIOXIN IS FOUND OUTSIDE EDISON SITE, KEAN TELLS RESIDENTS
description: Five samples taken from businesses and residences near a dixoin-contaminated industrial site here show no traces of the toxic chemical, Gov. Thomas H. Kean announced tonight.

title: MONEY-FUND PAY PLAN FOR MERRILL'S BROKERS
description: Merrill Lynch & Company plans for the first time to pay its stockbrokers a commission on the cash that investors have in some of the firm's money-market funds, including two of the most popular - Merrill Lynch Ready Assets and the CMA Money Fund.

title: CSX INCREASES OFFER FOR TEXAS GAS
description: The battle to take over the Texas Gas Resources Corporation intensified yesterday, with the nation's largest railroad, the CSX Corporation, increasing the value of its bid for the oil and gas company to nearly $1.1 billion, or $52 a share in cash for its 20.6 million shares.

title: A BILL FOR HARSHER, NO FAIRER, SENTENCES
description: To the Editor:

title: Music Noted in Brief Naumburg Symphony Plays in Damrosch Park
description: When the music is out-of-doors, weather becomes a major part of the program. For the Naumburg Symphony Orchestra's concert in Damrosch Park on Saturday night, there was a cooling breeze and clear skies to go with Stravinsky, Ravel and Beethoven.

title: Arafat Opens Mutiny Talks
description: Yasir Arafat opened a long-deferred official debate today on the six-week-old mutiny against his leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The group reportedly discussed an eight-point program incorporating many of the rebels' demands for a bigger role in the making of policy.

title: Lonnie Liston Smith With Funk and Fusion
description: The jazz keyboardist Lonnie Liston Smith has built a sizable following by making sophisticated mood music that combines equal measures of jazz fusion and funk. And Friday and Saturday nights, Mr. Smith, leading a quintet that featured his brother Donald on flute and lead vocals, brought his polished brand of funk-fusion to the Bottom Line.

title: 2 HASIDIC GROUPS IN BROOKLYN INVOLVED IN COMPLEX CONFLICT
description: Since World War II, the remnants of many Hasidic groups have planted new roots in Brooklyn and created some of the most active communities in American Judaism. The Satmar and Lubavitcher Hasidim have become the largest and best known.

title: News Analysis
description: When the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People stripped its chairman of her powers recently in response to a conflict between her and the executive director, Benjamin L. Hooks, Mr.

title: LARGE TREASURY OPTIONS BEGIN TRADING AT AMEX
description: The rapidly expanding markets in securities-based options took a new turn yesterday when the American Stock Exchange began trading larger versions of its Treasury note and bill options. At the same time, the Amex announced that it would allow its current smaller note and bill options to run out without listing new contracts.

title: London Stock Index Up
description: The Financial Times 30-share index ended 13.7 points higher today at a record 727.8, dealers said. The close of the index of 30 London Stock Exchange issues topped the previous high of 726.4 on June 14. Dealers said that electrical stocks showed particular strength.

title: '84 Outlays Could Top $1 Billion at 2 Concerns
description: Both Procter & Gamble, the multi-brand packaged goods giant, and General Motors, the multiproduct automobile maker, each could exceed $1 billion in advertising spending in 1984, according Schonfeld & Associates, the Evanston, Ill., computer company whose annual Ads Forecasts does a pretty good job of being in the budget ballpark.

title: Goodyear Closing
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it would close its Jackson tire plant by the end of this year, cutting 600 jobs. Goodyear said the plant, which produces biasply tires for the North American market, was being closed because of excessive production costs.

title: First for Miss Hu
description: Hu Na, the Chinese tennis star who received political asylum in this country in April, will compete in the First National Bank-Michelob Light women's tennis tournament in Erie, Pa., June 27 to July 2. ''Hu Na is coming to Erie to play tennis,'' said her coach, Bob Huang.

title: The U.N. Today; June 21, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: YANKS DROP MURCER, ENDING HIS CAREER
description: Bobby Murcer, the last active link with the Mickey Mantle-Whitey Ford years, has been asked to end his playing career at the age of 37.

title: POPE'S WORDS LEAVE POLES 'ALL AMAZED'
description: ''He has fulfilled his task completely,'' said a portly man in a group from Gdansk, basking here today in the presence of Pope John Paul II. ''He came here and did good.''

title: ABC NAMES RADIO AND TV PRESIDENT
description: Anthony D. Thomopoulos, the president of ABC Entertainment for the last five years, will move to a newly created position of president of the ABC Broadcast Group, the company announced yesterday.

title: New Group Seeks Holmes Title Bout
description: A new promotional group has entered the bidding for a Larry Holmes-Marvis Frazier heavyweight title fight and, while it has signed the champion for the bout in late September or early October, it has not reached agreement with Frazier.

title: Private Group to Send Aid to Afghan Refugees
description: A private relief group announced plans today to send between $2 million and $4 million worth of medical supplies to Afghan refugees in Pakistan.

title: Ruling Appealed On Casino Union
description: New Jersey gaming authorities today asked a full Federal appeals court to review a three-judge panel's ruling that the state had no authority to regulate a casino workers union.

title: Hot Spot Hypothesis
description: Volcanically active ridges in all the world's oceans define cracks where plates of the earth's surface are being pulled apart. But there are other, quiescent ridges, clearly of different origin.

title: New Du Pont Unit
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would form a new industrial department and realign two other departments so it can enter the health, agricultural and electronic fields. The new biomedical department and the newly named agricultural chemicals and photosystems and electronic products departments will be formed from a reorganization of businesses currently managed in Du Pont's biochemicals and photo products departments. The realignment will be effective on Sept. 1.

title: 'Guys in Truck' Closes; Two Other Shows End
description: A new play on Broadway and two productions Off Broadway closed last weekend. The Broadway play was ''The Guys in the Truck'' by Howard Reifsnyder.

title: DIOXIN LEVEL HIGH AT A MISSOURI SITE
description: The highest levels of dioxin found so far in Missouri have been detected along a rural road not far from the farm of Russell Bliss, the waste hauler who sprayed oil containing the substance on roads when he was in the dust control business, Federal officials said today.

title: Pope's Assailant Appeals
description: The Rev. Juan Maria Fernandez Krohn, the Spanish priest convicted of trying to kill Pope John Paul II on May 12, 1982, appealed his six-and-half-year prison term today, saying the court unfairly delayed sentencing him. He was sentenced May 2, six months after an eight-hour trial on Oct. 20, 1982.

title: Westphal Waived by Knicks
description: Faced with the choice of either picking up the two one-year options on Paul Westphal's contract by July 1 or placing him on waivers, the Knicks yesterday did what had been expected. They waived him.

title: Salary Restoration At Allis-Chalmers
description: The Allis-Chalmers Corporation will restore about 6,500 employees' salaries to the level that existed before a 10 percent cut was introduced in September 1982, a company official said.

title: E.E.C. to Act On I.B.M.
description: The commission of the European Economic Community said today that it intended to proceed with its antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation and hoped to reach a decision by late this year.

title: Son of Bic's Founder To Add Chief's Position
description: Bruno Bich, son of the founder of the Bic pen business, has completed his move to the top at the Bic Corporation. Mr. Bich (pronounced beek) has been president and chief operating officer of the Bic Corporation, which is based in Milford, Conn., and is controlled by Societe Bic of France. Yesterday, the company announced that Mr. Bich would become chief executive July 1 in addition to his other duties.

title: Books Of The Times
description: HOW HE SAVED HER. By Ellen Schwamm. 273 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: DISEASE VICTIM DIES AT GATHERING
description: A 9-year-old Chilean boy afflicted with progeria, a condition characterized by premature aging, died today during an international gathering of 14 children who suffer from the disease.

title: MURJANI SEEKING A STABLE OF DESIGNERS
description: In 1975, when jeans were designed exclusively for men, Mohan B. Murjani turned work clothes into high fashion by cutting them to fit women and using Gloria Vanderbilt's name to sell them in television advertising. The success of the Murjani-Vanderbilt team established a sure-fire formula for the selling of ''designer'' jeans and set in motion a new trend in apparel marketing and advertising.

title: Court Rebuffs Brown-Forman
description: A request by the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation for a temporary restraining order that would have prohibited Lenox Inc. from taking actions to thwart a tender offer was denied in Federal District Court in Newark.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Eller to Be Chairman Of Circle K Corporation
description: Karl Eller, who made his mark in the broadcasting and newspaper industries, is going to try his hand at running a big chain of convenience stores.

title: Reynolds to Raise Cigarette Prices
description: The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company said it would raise the price of its cigarettes $1.50 per 1,000 for all domestic brands, except the new Century brand. Reynolds's announcement was closely followed by one by American Brands, which said it would match Reynolds's increase.

title: Market Place; Mutual Fund Resurgence
description: ''NOWADAYS, when you go to a cocktail party, you often hear people bragging about the performance of their equity mutual funds,'' said Donald W. Spiro, president of the Oppenheimer Management Corporation and its 12 mutual funds with $8 billion in assets. ''That's quite a change from a few years ago.''

title: WARREN E. WINSCHE, BROOKHAVEN OFFICIAL AND ENERGY EXPERT
description: Dr. Warren E. Winsche, deputy director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory and a prominent figure in energy research, died of cancer Sunday at the laboratory's hospital. He was 66 years old and lived in Bellport, L.I.

title: Husband Charged In Sailor's Death
description: A 22-year-old resident of Norfolk, Va., was arrested last night and charged with the murder of his wife, a Navy radio operator whose body was found under a blanket in the rear of her car at La Guardia Airport on Sunday, the police said.

title: A New Monthly on Movies
description: At a time when many publications are merging or closing, Joe Armstrong, former publisher of New York magazine and Rolling Stone, has begun a new monthly, The Movies.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: KOCH'S CHUTZPAH
description: If Ed Koch had merely been shooting from the hip, as usual, it wouldn't be necessary to pay any attention to him, least of all to respond. But when Edward I. Koch, Mayor of New York, falls into the gutter of a latter-day McCarthyism, then it's time to take notice.

title: STARTING OUT: THE HURDLES YOUNG DESIGNERS FACE
description: The seats marked for Vogue and Women's Wear Daily often go empty. Others reserved for Saks Fifth Avenue and Bloomingdale's are seldom filled. Still, the show begins, and the applause, when it comes, sounds like two sticks being rubbed together in a wintry, unfriendly place.

title: A Timely Assist For Soccer Player
description: His experience as a medic in the Angolan civil war finally paid dividends in the best possible way for Seninho, the Portuguese forward.

title: WEATHER BRIGHTENS TRADE IN SUMMER RENTALS
description: For the tourist industry, the summer season, which got off to a soggy slow start, has had a sudden new burst of energy in the last few weekends.

title: SCIENTISTS TAKE SIDES AS BATTLE INTENSIFIES
description: THE scientific debate over whether lethal chemical weapons have been used by the Soviet Union or its allies in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan is escalating in intensity and moving into new scientific forums.

title: Saudi Trade Surplus Off
description: Saudi Arabia's trade surplus fell by more than half, to $38.2 billion, in 1982 because of a drop in oil exports, a Saudi newspaper said today.

title: 3 Officers in Jersey Hurt in Car Chase
description: Three Elizabeth police officers were slightly injured and five police vehicles were badly damaged in a chase that ended when a car containing a Newark man and a companion from New York slammed into a police roadblock at the Bayway Circle here early today, said Thomas Haedrich, a spokesman for Union County.

title: SHULTZ MEETS LEBANESE ON A PULLBACK
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz met today with a senior Lebanese representative, Wadi Haddad, to discuss a notification by Israel that it was seriously considering a redeployment and partial reduction of its forces in Lebanon - a move viewed with misgivings by Washington and Beirut.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS STRUGGLE WITH COACH SHORTAGE
description: Red Bank Regional High School is losing its athletic coaches and doesn't know where to find them. As school lets out, administrators here and at schools elsewhere in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are beginning what has become an annual summer scramble to fill a surfeit of coaching vacancies.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 21, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Ex-Tylenol Suspect Indicted
description: Roger Arnold, once questioned in the seven Tylenol-related cyanide deaths, was indicted today in the murder of John Stanisha, whom the police say he may have mistaken for the informer who sought to implicate him in the deaths. He was also indicted by the Cook County grand jury on charges of armed violence.

title: Net Is an All-Star
description: The National Basketball Association's all-star squad, determined by a vote of sportswriters and broadcasters, includes the Net forward Buck Williams, on the second team. He is the only Knick or Net selected. The first team is made up of Moses Malone, Larry Bird, Julius Erving, Magic Johnson and Sidney Moncrief.

title: Generals' Bargain
description: Lance Olander not only does the punting for the Generals but also has performed on the punt-return and kickoff-return units this season and is a reserve running back.

title: Transit Transition
description: For 21 years Luis Angel Acevedo has run the newsstand at Astor Place in the Lexington Avenue IRT uptown stop. He has two daughters in college and a house he is still paying for.

title: DENVER TO ELECT NEW MAYOR IN RUNOFF TODAY
description: Denver will get its first new Mayor in 14 years Tuesday as voters choose between Dale Tooley, the city's former district attorney, and Federico Pena, a former state legislator.

title: 4 Journalists Receive Awards for Reporting
description: Reporters for The New York Times, Esquire magazine and WTSP-TV in St. Petersburg, Fla., the winners of the 1983 Livingston Awards for Young Journalists, were honored yesterday in ceremonies at the New York Public Library.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Administration that put this medal around my neck is curtailing my benefits.'' - Roy P. Benavidez, a Medal of Honor winner. (A14:1.)

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: KEY HORMONE IS DISCOVERED
description: SCIENTISTS in Ohio have discovered a natural hormone that regulates the body's production of granulocytes, an important class of white blood cells.

title: ELIZABETH SEIFERT
description: Elizabeth Seifert, an author who wrote more than 80 novels about doctors and their problems, was found dead Friday at her home.

title: FRIEND OF TAX INDEXING
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Volcker, Continued
description: President Reagan made the right choice in deciding to keep Paul Volcker as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: 98 Held in Jersey For Cockfighting
description: The state police said today that they had arrested 98 men for cockfighting in a raid in this rural area of southern New Jersey.

title: Rizzo Backs Democrat For Philadelphia Mayor
description: W. Wilson Goode, who defeated former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo in the Democratic mayoral primary in May, was endorsed by Mr. Rizzo today.

title: Japan's Itoh to Use Century 21 Name
description: The Century 21 Real Estate Corporation of Irvine, Calif., said it had signed an agreement to be represented in Japan by C. Itoh & Company, a Tokyo-based trading concern.

title: UNSKILLED AMERICANS MUST HAVE JOBS, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 CABLE COMPANIES THREATEN TO DROP PLANS TO SERVE CITY
description: Two cable television companies said yesterday that they were canceling plans to wire parts of Brooklyn and Queens, charging that actions by the city had changed the basis of negotiations.

title: LIBEL SUIT HELP WITH NO 'IDEOLOGICAL AX TO GRIND'
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 KEY ISSUES SNAG CONSTITUTION FOR EL SALVADOR
description: A special commission said today that it had finished its work on a new constitution for El Salvador but had failed to reach a consensus on two key issues.

title: E.E.C. Jobless Rate Off
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community slipped to 10.4 percent in May from 10.7 percent in April, largely because of seasonal factors, Eurostat, the community's statistics agency, said today.

title: ECONOMIC THEORIES FACE TEST
description: Scholars from 15 countries, contending that today's economic practices are not functioning for either capitalist or Communist countries, are preparing a sweeping and intensive inquiry into the theories undergirding those practices.

title: Charlotte Curtis; Wanted: Graduates Who Think
description: DR. MATINA HORNER, president of Radcliffe College, approached the studies suggesting that girls weren't as competent in science and mathematics as their boy counterparts with her usual skepticism. She saw nothing in the 1980 report indicating anything more than that girls had not demonstrated competence. She didn't believe they couldn't excel if they wanted to.

title: KEAN APPROVES A 'LEMON LAW' FOR AUTO BUYERS
description: Governor Kean today signed a ''lemon law'' to protect buyers of defective new automobiles. Under the law, consumers will be able to have the vehicle replaced or the purchase price refunded if the car cannot be repaired by the dealer under the warranty.

title: A BASIC CURRICULUM
description: Those of us in education are pleased that general dissatisfaction is finally being expressed about the standards in high schools. At the same time, everyone is being extremely cautious in proposing remedies. It is as if we would like to improve the situation but are not ready to come right out and make the tough choices about what to teach and what not to teach.

title: WHAT SAUDI KEY?
description: It is often argued by American policy makers and journalists that Saudi Arabia holds the key to the success or failure of the Israeli-Lebanese agreement. Such an assertion reflects a widespread but mistaken - and indeed dangerous - perception of Saudi Arabia as a power capable of shaping the course of events in the Middle East.

title: Agca Is Questioned in Rome By Magistrates From Turkey
description: Two Turkish magistrates today ended a weeklong interrogation of Mehmet Ali Agca about the killing of an Istanbul newspaper editor, judicial sources said.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND SEVERE LOSS OF COASTLINE
description: AS summer vacationers flock to their favorite seashore haunts along the Atlantic Coast they will find many of the beaches changed, some almost beyond recognition. From Cape Cod to Florida, last winter's storms have ravaged beaches, toppled homes into the sea and changed the contours of long stretches of sandy shoreline.

title: MERGER OF 2 TEXAS BANKS RUMORED
description: Southwest Bancshares and the Mercantile Texas Corporation asked the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to halt trading in their shares, amid rumors of a merger between the two Texas banks.

title: Miss Donahue, Soprano, Presents a Recital
description: Marilou Donahue, a dramatic soprano, sang music by Donaudy, Wagner, Beethoven, Strauss and Argento at the Abraham Goodman House Sunday afternoon.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article on care of the aging gave an incorrect location. The scene was a center in Boynton Beach, Fla., not a retirement home in Lake Worth.

title: FLORIDA COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $476,000 for the latest first quarter and $195,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Don Reese Paroled
description: Don Reese, the former Miami Dolphin lineman, was paroled yesterday, five months after being jailed for having used cocaine while on probation from a previous conviction for drug trafficking. Reese, wearing a tan suit and a white shirt and looking quite trim, had ''no comment'' to assembled reporters as he left the Lawtey (Fla.) Correctional Institution.

title: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After a loss of $3 million from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a pretax charge of $57.6 million for plant closures. Year-ago results have been adjusted for a 2 percent stock dividend paid April 27.

title: FILES DESTROYED BY A COMPANY TIED TO DIOXIN
description: A company that operated a former Newark chemical plant recently found to be contaminated with dioxin ordered its employees around the country last month to destroy unneeded company files and records, according to court arguments today.

title: News Analysis
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson now confronts a new and and more difficult set of political hurdles, precisely because a group of black civil rights and political leaders granted his wish and endorsed the concept of a black Presidential candidacy in 1984.

title: Slaying a Dragon
description: Learning to paddle a Chinese dragon boat was an unnerving experience for Jack Kelly and his team of Philadelphia oarsmen, but their practice runs on the Schuylkill have paid off in Hong Kong harbor. The Kelly crew, the first Americans to compete in the International Dragon Boat Races at Hong Kong, came in second in the race final Sunday, crossing the finish line just 2.8 seconds behind the winning crew, which was from China.

title: SMUCKER, J M, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Includes gain of $698,000, or 19 cents a share,from the sale of the company's pickle business

title: Ghana Tells of Coup Attempt
description: Ghana said today that an attempted coup on Sunday was the work of former servicemen exiled in neighboring Togo. A report on the Ghanaian radio, citing information from interrogation of the rebels, said they released about 50 soldiers from jail before the attempt in Accra.

title: The Quarterback Who Got Away
description: Doug Woodward, last weekend's hero at quarterback for the Boston Breakers, was once right under the Giants' noses. In his senior season, 1979, as the best passer in the history of Pace University, Woodward practiced on the same field in Pleasantville, N.Y., that the Giants use for their summer camp. Tom Marino, then a Giant scout, argued that the team should at least take a look at the 6-foot-2-inch quarterback ''because if this guy makes it with St. Louis or Washington, we're going to look like fools when we had him in our own backyard.''

title: Commuter Strike Talks Reopen in Philadelphia
description: Negotiations resumed today in the 99-day commuter train strike in the Philadelphia area. Mayor William Green attended the session as an observer.

title: LINK THE DOLLAR TO... TO... TO...
description: It has been suggested of late in certain quarters of the financial world that the floating dollar, approved by Richard Nixon with an assist from then Secretary of the Treasury John Connally, has not done much for world trade and economic stability, and that a dollar stabilized in a vague relationship to gold or some suitable commodity might do better.

title: DATAPOWER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: NATIONAL SECURITY DECISIONS TO BE FOCUS OF BROAD INQUIRY
description: John Tower, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, announced a sweeping inquiry today into the way the Pentagon, White House, other executive agencies and Congress make decisions affecting national security.

title: Stokely Receives $169 Million Offer
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc. said yesterday that it had received a $169 million acquisition offer from an American industrial company. Stokely, describing the offer as unsolicited, did not identify the suitor.

title: GRENADA'S 'CURIOUS KIND OF DEMOCRACY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Nadia Tueni, Lebanese Poet And Wife of a Publisher, Dies
description: Nadia H. Tueni, a poet and writer and the wife of Ghassan Tueni, the Lebanese Government's coordinator of talks on withdrawal of foreign troops and its former chief delegate to the United Nations, died on Monday. She was 47 years old.

title: YANKEE STREAK ENDS AT 5
description: The Yankees, in their first game against the Orioles this season, were beaten for the 10th straight time at Memorial Stadium. The 5-2 defeat tonight ended a Yankee winning streak at five games.

title: CHARVOZ-CARSEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Alaskan Housing Issue Will Yield 5.5% to 9.5%
description: A $75 million Alaska Housing Finance Corporation bond issue was won by Salomon Brothers yesterday and priced with yields ranging from 5.5 percent to 9.5 percent.

title: EDWARDS, A G, & SONS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in February.

title: CUOMO AND KEAN AGREE ON RAISING TOLLS ON BRIDGES
description: Governor Cuomo of New York and Governor Kean of New Jersey announced an agreement today to raise PATH fares and the tolls on the Port Authority's bridges and tunnels and then to channel the surplus revenues into regional development.

title: DATARAM CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,443,000 from the sale of stock.

title: AT BECTON DICKINSON, PRESIDENT RETIRES AT 55
description: Marvin A. Asnes, president and chief operating officer of Becton Dickinson & Company, has announced that he is retiring at age 55 after a 30-year career.

title: REACTOR PARTS FOR INDIA SUPPORTED
description: The State Department has recommended to President Reagan that the United States export nuclear reactor components to India, senior Administration officials said today.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''SOONER or later we're bound to fail,'' the Talking Heads singer, lyricist and front man, David Byrne, said the other day. ''It's just inevitable that we'll put out a disappointing album sooner or later, isn't it?''

title: REAGAN ASSAILS BUDGET PLAN AND ITS PASSAGE IS IN DOUBT
description: The battle between President Reagan and Congress over spending and tax policy intensified today, and passage of the budget compromise adopted by House and Senate negotiators Monday night remained in doubt.

title: Israeli Doctors Say The Fast Will Continue
description: Leaders of Israel's striking doctors said today that they were disappointed with a new Government pay offer intended to end a four-month-old dispute and that doctors would continue fasting to back their demands for higher wages.

title: MEXICO ACTING TO STEM INFLUX OF CENTRAL AMERICANS
description: The Mexican Government has taken steps to stem the flow of Central American refugees, arguing that they have taken jobs away from Mexicans and added to social pressures here.

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for year to May 31.
2 TEXAS BANKS PLAN TO MERGE
description: Two major bank holding companies, the Mercantile Texas Corporation of Dallas and Southwest Bancshares Inc. of Houston, yesterday announced an agreement in principle to merge in an exchange of stock valued at more than $515 million.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Per Class A common stock. c-Per Class B common stock.

title: Piedmont Aviation
description: Piedmont Aviation Inc. said it would buy a Maryland-based commuter airline to feed a new hub at Baltimore-Washington International Airport.

title: CHILE LETS 128 POLITICAL EXILES RETURN
description: The Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet announced today that 128 leading political exiles could return immediately without conditions.

title: WD-40 CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: The share earnings for the year-ago periods were adjusted for 3-for-1 stock split paid April 11.

title: SPANISH SUCCESS STORY
description: To the Editor:

title: 50-Hour Rodgers Broadcast
description: A 50-hour broadcast of music by Richard Rodgers and recorded interviews with the composer and others in the music industry will begin Sunday at 9 P.M. on WKCR-FM (89.9). The broadcast is a celebration of the 81st anniversary of Mr. Rodgers's birth, next Tuesday. Included in the programming will be recorded performances by Ella Fitzgerald, John Coltrane and Oscar Peterson as well as previously unreleased material from Mr. Rodgers's personal archives.

title: MARGIOTTA'S CHOICE PREFERS 'MY OWN WAY'
description: Joseph N. Mondello, the new Nassau County and Hempstead Republican chairman, has started trying to demonstrate that he is not merely a surrogate or seat warmer for Joseph M. Margiotta, his close friend and political mentor who began serving a two-year prison sentence a week ago for mail fraud and extortion.

title: Osborne Choice
description: Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago, has become the agency for the Osborne Computer Company of Hayward, Calif., a major manufacturer of portable computers. The assignment, which involves $8 million in ads, had been with Carlick & Associates, Menlo Park, Calif., since Osborne was founded in the beginning of 1981. Six agencies were in the running, according to the advertiser, but no New York shops.

title: World Steel Output in May
description: Crude steel production in the European Economic Community spurted in May, while Japan recorded only modest gains and output in the United States fell, the International Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

title: Sampson Gets 20 In Pro Debut
description: Ralph Sampson, making his professional debut, scored 20 points tonight in an exhibition game involving National Basketball Association players.

title: Honduras Approves A U.S. Training Camp
description: The Honduran Congress today authorized the establishment of a United States training camp that will be used to teach Salvadoran soldiers to fight leftist rebels in El Salvador.

title: Freestyle Record Broken
description: Michael Gross of West Germany set a world record in the 200-meter freestyle today at the national swimming championships.

title: Spill From Truck Closes Highway
description: The state police removed about 50 people from their homes this morning after a truck carrying a highly toxic and flammable chemical spilled a liquid on Interstate 84. The highway was closed in both directions for three hours and one state trooper was overcome by fumes.

title: DURABLES ORDERS UP 0.2% IN MAY
description: Orders placed with factories for durable goods rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AMEX SETS MARK
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE PASSES $241 MILLION TAX RISE
description: The State Senate, moving to break an impasse that has delayed adoption of a new budget for Connecticut, today approved $241 million in new and higher taxes.

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $3 million which represented proceeds from a life insurance policy. c-Net loss

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Electronic Gift Insert
description: Both House Beautiful and Science Digest magazines in the Hearst Magazines stable will be carrying a 16-page advertising insert in their December issues on electronic gifts. For the total circulation of 1.3 million, the ad rate for a single four-color page is $29,045. A black-and-white ad goes for $20,640.

title: SENATORS ENDORSE FARM SUBSIDY BILL
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee today sent to the floor a bill sought by the Administration that would freeze the levels of subsidy payments on grain and cotton crops for the next two years.

title: INFORMATION INTERATIONAL INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $218,790 and a charge of $990,678 from reserve for discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $132,227 from discontinued operations.

title: Montana Bond's Top Yield at 8 1/4%
description: A $64 million highway revenue bond issue for the State of Montana Department of Highways was tentatively priced by the First Boston Corporation at yields ranging from 6.75 percent to 8.25 percent.

title: WALL & REDEKOP CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U.N. REPORT ON IRAN-IRAQ WAR CALLED POSSIBLE KEY TO PEACE
description: A United Nations inquiry into civilian damage in the Persian Gulf war has reported more extensively on the suffering of Iran than Iraq.

title: Economic Scene; Recovery's Strength
description: THE Commerce Department's ''flash'' report of a 6.6 percent increase in real gross national product during the April-June quarter was a bit higher than most economists were expecting a few weeks ago, but not quite the ''barn burner'' some are now calling it.

title: LAWHON, JOHN F, FURNITURE reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income including a gain of $503,878 on the sales of leasehold interest.

title: PORTABLE BUTANE STOVE
description: AT this time of year it doesn't take much to persuade me to cook outdoors. Barbecuing is one of my favorite summer pastimes. It always seems, though, that some part of the meal requires me to run into the kitchen.

title: PUBLIC RADIO CHAIRMAN RESIGNS IN FISCAL CRISIS
description: Myron Jones, the chairman of National Public Radio, was forced to resign today in the aftermath of the financial crisis facing the organization.

title: 'NO DISAGREEMENT' IN GONZALEZ-REAGAN TALKS
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain discussed the situation in Central America at length today and were reported in agreement on broad goals of peace, democracy and justice for the region.

title: Auto Content Bill Advances
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved, 25 to 17, a bill aimed at forcing foreign auto makers to establish factories in this country.

title: Convertible Eurobonds Up
description: Japanese Eurobonds convertible to equity rose sharply in active trading today. Prices rose on average around 2 or 3 points with some issues showing gains of up to 10 points.

title: ALLEN STANDS OUT IN STOPPING METS
description: Six days after they traded him, Neil Allen returned to Shea Stadium in the uniform of the St. Louis Cardinals last night and not only haunted the Mets but overpowered them.

title: TAMBELLINI IS TRADED BY DEVILS
description: The Devils traded speed and youth for strength and experience today when they sent Steve Tambellini and Joel Quenneville to the Calgary Flames for Mel Bridgman and Phil Russell.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
BROOKLYN: NEW PLAN OF GROWTH
description: After decades in Manhattan's shadow, downtown Brooklyn has the potential to emerge within a decade as New York City's third major business district after midtown and the financial district, according to a Regional Plan Association study.

title: INDUSTRIAL AMERICA CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
EX-GUARD FOUND GUILTY IN RIFLE SLAYINGS OF 13
description: George E. Banks, a former prison guard, was convicted of first-degree murder today in the slayings of 12 people, including his five children and their four mothers, in a wild rampage of rifle fire last Sept. 25.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $645,000.

title: MEN'S WEAR FASHION AWARDS
description: Before a crowd of several hundred that included fashion designers, fashion journalists and retailers, the Cutty Sark Men's Fashion Awards were presented tonight at the Bellevue Stratford Hotel in Philadelphia during a week of showings and seminars sponsored by the Men's Fashion Association. There were cocktails, dinner and almost no surprises.

title: Ayer Unit Gains
description: Ayerdirect, the direct marketing subsidiary of N.W. Ayer, has added to its assignment from Time-Life Books.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: THERE'S a little devil in all of us that sometimes makes us feel good when others don't. Some people's devils are bigger than others, but human nature being what it is, there is little doubt that even good and quite decent people get a feeling of gratification over the misfortunes of others. Nothing major, mind you. Very few would be nasty enough to wish serious trouble or calamity on anyone, but a small tribulation is quite another thing. Indeed, some minor misfortunes are just meant for others to enjoy.

title: SIKES CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
BRIEFS
description: * American Telnet Corp. said it had joined a $60 million joint venture with New Century Productions Ltd. of Los Angeles and Cine Artist G.m.B.H. of West Berlin to produce 6 to 12 feature films during the next four years.

title: SURVEY PRESSED ON ILLNESS OF ATOMIC VETERANS
description: When Orville E. Kelly died of cancer in 1980, he left a wife, two children and a group that represents some of the ''atomic veterans,'' the servicemen exposed to radiation in American tests of nuclear weapons.

title: He's All Business
description: Little Ray Leonard, the 9-year-old son of the former welterweight champion, became almost as famous as his father in their 7-Up television commercials.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Can you tell me the French name for a food processor? I would also like to know the French name for a convection oven.

title: ZENJA SAFT CARY
description: Zenja Saft Cary, head of Cary Kitchens, which prepares food to be photographed for magazines and television advertising and for movies, died of cancer Sunday at New York Hospital.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MUSIC AL FRESCO

title: 60,042 Fans See Vancouver Win
description: A total of 60,042 fans, the largest Canadian crowd in the history of the North American Soccer League, saw Peter Beardsley score two goals Monday night to lift the Vancouver Whitecaps to a 2-1 victory over the Seattle Sounders.

title: Bid for Datatab
description: Data Probe Inc. said a unit had begun a tender offer of $1.25 a share for Datatab Inc. The offer, which expires at midnight July 19, requires that Datatab's shareholders reject a proposed merger between Datatab and the CRC Acquisition Corporation. Data Probe said its offer was not conditioned on a minimum number of shares being tendered. Datatab has about 704,000 shares outstanding.

title: Dr. Emanuel Mandel, 73, Dies; Medical Director in Brooklyn
description: Dr. Emanuel E. Mandel, former director of medicine and medical education at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Monday after open-heart surgery at New York University Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Oceanside, L.I.

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a net income reduction of $75,000 in the amortization of an asset acquired in the merger with Lafayette Radio Electronics Corp. ck Exchange and (O. E RGYCORP(O)terand6months 1983 198 2 Revenue 3,027,000 7,632,000 Net inc 2,124,000 b187,000 Share earns .57 b-Net loss.

title: N.J. Transit Seeks 8% Fare Increases
description: N.J. Transit today proposed to increase bus and rail fares by an average of 8 percent in early September, to raise enough to balance its budget for the first time since the statewide transit agency was created in 1979.

title: MEASUREX CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
OBSERVER/By Russell Baker; SHE AIN'T NO MA TO ME
description: We went to the country. It was 165 degrees in the sun and the poison ivy was growing by leaps and gallops up the trunks of the locust trees in front of the house. I went outside to strip it off so the trees could breathe free.

title: STATUS MOVE: SECURITY AIDE SHUFFLES STAFF
description: Why was it that, three weeks ago and with little public notice or comment, William P. Clark, the President's national security adviser, announced the elevation of nine members of his National Security Council staff to the rank of ''special assistant to the President''?

title: Real Work for Real Money in Prison
description: Chief Justice Warren Burger has been insisting lately that the nation's prisons put more of their inmates to work in productive jobs. It's a sound idea that raises a question: How come real work isn't already common in prison?

title: CSX Financing
description: The CSX Corporation said it had raised $1.1 billion in its effort to buy the Texas Gas Resources Corporation. CSX has offered $52 a share in a tender offer for the 20.6 million Texas Gas shares.

title: The U.N. Today; June 22, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: U.S. Easing China Trade
description: The Government is easing restrictions on exports of computers and other high-technology equipment to China, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: Dome Mines Ltd.
description: Dome Mines Ltd. said it had sold its entire stake of 1.14 million shares of Noranda Mines Ltd. for $26.50 (Canadian) a share, or a total of $30.3 million. The company said the proceeds would be used to reduce bank debt.

title: Afghan Rebels Mount A New Round of Attacks
description: Afghan rebels have opened their most intensive attacks in two years against the Soviet-backed regime in Kabul, Western diplomatic sources said today.

title: BELL AND A HOUSE PANEL CLASH OVER REAGAN'S SCHOOLS POLICY
description: Secretary of Education T.H. Bell found himself hard pressed today as he sought to defend President Reagan's campaign in behalf of better schools.

title: Jury Selection Begins In First Hyatt Trial
description: Jury selection began Monday in the first trial resulting from the 1981 collapse of elevated walkways at the Hyatt Regency hotel.

title: MARTIN, JEFFREY, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
U & I INC reports earnings for year to Feb 26.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $4,064,000 and a gain of $474,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Including a tax credit of $2,644,000 and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $1,586,000.

title: P.L.O. REBELS SEIZE 8 ARAFAT POSITIONS
description: Palestinian guerrillas opposed to the leadership of Yasir Arafat overran eight positions belonging to Arafat loyalists in eastern Lebanon today with the support of Syrian troops and tanks, Palestinian officials said.

title: RECIPES THAT TAKE FIBER BEYOND BRAN
description: Apple Walnut Salad With Coriander 2 heads Bibb or Boston lettuce 2 small apples 2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar 2 tablespoons walnut oil or vegetable oil 1/2 teaspoon ground coriander 4 tablespoons chopped walnuts Fresh ground black pepper to taste.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Denies Saatchi Rumor
description: Reports reaching these shores from Britain have it that the talk throughout the advertising community is that Saatchi & Saatchi, ad agency of the victorious Margaret Thatcher, is very close to acquiring our own McCaffrey & McCall, just as it has acquired our Compton Advertising.

title: Advertising; Grey Chief Salary Criticized
description: IN an incident rare in the annals of publicly held ad agencies, a shareholder at the Grey Advertising annual meeting yesterday not only took to his feet but also criticized the company's executive compensation.

title: Careers; Women's Prospects In Science
description: WHEN Dr. Sally K. Ride became the first American woman to enter space, many career hopes went with her. She has a doctorate in astrophysics from Stanford University, demonstrating how far a woman can go today in the more exciting areas of science.

title: SHAPED BY THE WAR IN VIETNAM
description: The Vietnam era still pulls the nation's strings. It was both catalyst and fuel for much of the social, political and economic upheaval of the last 20 years and it could have even more effect in the next 20 years. If we understand how the Vietnam era shaped us, we will have a better chance of influencing how it will continue to shape us.

title: Up at Bat, LaMotta and Seaver
description: Monte Irvin didn't play it in Orange, N.J., and Tom Seaver and Ralph Kiner didn't play it in California, they all said yesterday. It was the New York game, but George Plimpton didn't play it on East 98th Street, either.

title: Rumania Debt Pact
description: Rumania has signed an agreement with foreign bankers deferring repayment of part of its commercial debt falling due this year, banking sources in Bucharest said today. The sources said that under the agreement 30 percent of the overall $860 million of commercial debt principal due in 1983 would be repaid this year. Ten percent of the remainder would be paid in two installments in 1984 and the rest over six and a half years.

title: BRIEFING
description: Seeking Answers on AIDS

title: B.& M. Railroad
description: A Federal judge has approved the sale of the bankrupt Boston & Maine Railroad to Guilford Transportation Industries, a venture of the Timothy Mellon family of Pittsburgh, for $24.25 million.

title: Legislators Agree On Tax Incentives
description: Legislators who have wrangled for months over extending New York City's principal tax-incentive program for developers announced tonight that they had reached an agreement.

title: EXOTIC OLD FOREIGN BONDS FOCUS OF COLLECTION SUITS
description: Some people keep them in safe-deposit boxes. Some frame them and hang them on their walls. Some have even used them for wallpaper. The world of New York-area residents who own bonds from czarist Russia and similar exotic securities is diverse though small. And now it is being shaken a bit by litigation.

title: Brown-Forman Is Sued by Lenox
description: Lenox Inc. said is had filed a countersuit in Federal court in Newark against the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation, charging a violation of Federal securities laws.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Cheer at Vandalized School
description: Vandals broke into Public School 377 in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn on Memorial Day weekend and stole $100,000 worth of equipment. ''The robbery had a devastating effect on the children,'' Gilberto Vazquez , the principal, recalled yesterday.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA ADVANCES
description: On the second day of Wimbledon, one player won a match in long white trousers, another player's wife gave birth only hours before he was to take the court, the fourth-seeded Tracy Austin withdrew, and signs of a Martina Navratilova-Chris Evert Lloyd singles final began to strengthen.

title: TORONTO SUN reports earnings for year to April 30.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $135,900.

title: Lehrman Will Set Up Conservative Project
description: President Reagan has asked Lewis E. Lehrman, last year's Republican nominee for Governor of New York, to found and head a new national conservative lobbying organization, a spokesman for Mr. Lehrman said today.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
1,000 Are Stranded In IND Derailment
description: Two cars of a Brooklyn-bound IND train derailed south of the West Fourth Street station at the height of the evening rush, interrupting service on the D line for an hour and causing service on the B line to be rerouted.

title: Cairo Expels 20 Palestinians
description: Security authorities have ordered 20 Palestinian students expelled from Egypt, an Interior Ministry statement said today. The university students are said to be members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a hard-line group within the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: 4-YEAR NOTES SOLD AT 10.62%
description: The Treasury yesterday auctioned $5.75 billion in four-year notes at an average yield of 10.62 percent, the highest since September 1982, when the rate was 12.30 percent.

title: TO WHOM REAGAN LISTENS ON CIVIL RIGHTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want a budget resolution. Even though it's not good, it ain't bad.''

title: Raymond's Board Approves Buyout
description: The board of Raymond International Inc., a construction and engineering company, approved a leveraged buyout plan that gives control of the company to management and employees.

title: Western Flood Threat Brings Some Evacuations
description: Worried residents protecting their homes from the flooding Colorado River used the last of 70,000 sandbags today, less than 24 hours before the authorities plan to increase the flow of water from three reservoirs on the river that were near to overflowing. About a dozen families were evacuated from the popular tourist area, but most stayed behind to protect their property.

title: ELF-TOTAL ACCORD ALLOWS FRENCH CHEMICAL SHIFTS
description: France's two big state-controlled oil companies, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine and Compagnie Fran,caise des Petroles, tonight announced details of an agreement that will finally permit the Socialist Government to reorganize the country's money-losing chemical industry.

title: L.I. LANDFILL REGULATIONS TIGHTENED BY STATE LAW
description: Governor Cuomo today signed legislation that would eventually ban the dumping of raw garbage in landfills in more than half of Long Island.

title: Time for Egg Creams
description: On the first day of summer, patrons of the Brighton Beach Baths gathered to egg on their favorites in an egg cream drinking contest.

title: Youth Is Sentenced In Rail Crash Case
description: A 17-year-old Fair Lawn youth was sentenced last week to one year on probation for his role in a fatal commuter-train crash last summer, Bergen County authorities disclosed today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: TO some cooks leftovers are merely roadblocks in the refrigerator that have to be maneuvered around until they are dumped in the garbage. To others, and I include myself, leftovers are an inspiration. It might be a salad with leftover steak, a casserole of leftover chicken or duck with pasta, or a small stew of leftover seafood.

title: DISABILITY REVIEWS: TO MEET A MANDATE FAIRLY AND HUMANELY
description: To the Editor:

title: BLANTON VERDICT WEIGHED BY PANEL
description: Ten judges on the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit heard arguments Monday on the mail fraud and conspiracy case against former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee and two associates. Their convictions were overturned in February by a three-judge panel of the circuit.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Highway, Street and Sidewalk The Asphalt Jail
description: People who drive to work in New York City, like people in prison, find they have a lot of time to think. The reason is they're stalled in traffic.

title: Bison Attacks Park Visitors
description: A 2,000-pound bull bison attacked two visitors to Yellowstone National Park in two days, park officials said today.

title: Bridge: Slams Spur Deep Thought In Head-to-Head Matches
description: All top-ranked players have notable powers of concentration, and are able to play hour after hour without permitting their minds to wander. But most of them would admit that they concentrate just a little bit more, and put their brains into top gear, if they have occasion to bid and play a slam contract in a head-to-head match. The decision to be made on such deals will often will win or lose a match.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
THE RUSSIAN'S JOY AND ANGUISH OF CAR OWNERSHIP
description: Family motorists hitting the road are a certain sign that the Russian summer has arrived. After winter hibernation in storage parks, swarms of small cars emerge from covers of plastic, canvas or cardboard to undergo preparations for the open road.

title: CAROLINA OFFICIAL SURRENDERS IN PAYOFF INQUIRY
description: Lieut. Gov. Jimmy Green surrendered to the Wake County authorities today on charges of accepting a $2,000 bribe and conspiring to take bribes of up to $10,000 a month.

title: Comings and Goings
description: James Green fractured a rib during sparring practice Monday and had to withdraw from a title fight July 3 against the World Boxing Council's superwelterweight champion, Thomas Hearns. A substitute challenger is to be named later. ... Doyle Alexander, the 32-yearold right-hander released by the Yankees June 1 with an 0-2 record, was signed by the Toronto Blue Jays to a contract with their Class A affiliate, Kinston of the Carolina League.

title: Realty Credit Ads Challenged
description: Home builders and real estate agents in 16 metropolitan areas have increased their ''deplorably low'' 13 percent compliance rate with credit advertising laws to more than 84 percent under a Federal Trade Commission project that is being expanded nationwide, James C. Miller 3d, the agency's chairman, said today.

title: ART: AT LAST, ALL EGYPT ON VIEW AT MET MUSEUM
description: THIS is a remarkable day for the Metropolitan Museum of Art, for New York City in general and for everyone who has felt, in no matter how small a degree, the Egyptological addiction.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Highway, Street and Sidewalk; Super Scooper
description: New Yorkers have always had to watch their step on city streets because their steps have been dogged by dogs. Things have been looking up since 1978 because of the pooper scooper law.

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
The Promise of Clean Water
description: The Clean Water Act now being reauthorized by Congress has been a mixed success. It has enabled fish to return to the Hudson, but the fish are too contaminated to eat. It has kept the nation's lakes and rivers from getting any filthier, despite substantial growth in industrial activity, but water quality has not greatly improved in the last seven years.

title: News Analysis
description: Underneath the oratory, another turning point occurred this week in President Reagan's relationship with Congress. Today, in fact, marked the abandonment by Mr. Reagan of the Congressional budget process that served him so well the last two years.

title: CURATOR WITH A DREAM
description: For the last 11 years, Christine Lilyquist has been supervising the reinstallation of the entire collection of ancient Egyptian art and artifacts of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the job has taken over her life.

title: C.I.A. Seeks Protection Against Opening Files
description: The Central Intelligence Agency recommended today that its files on intelligence agents be placed completely off limits to people using the Freedom of Information Act in efforts to declassify Government secrets.

title: U.S.-Detroit Talks on Fuel
description: The Government's regulatory relief task force has held meetings with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, examining ways to relax car fuel economy standards for 1984 and 1985, a weekly trade publication, Ward's Automotive Reports, said today.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Highway, Street and Sidewalk Lost Grit
description: The recent Northeast monsoon made clearer than ever that too many of New York City's midtown sidewalks are a disaster when it rains. These sunshine sidewalks, usually of two-tone terrazzo, permit good pedestrian footing only in fair weather.

title: A PARTY BOXED INTO A POLITICAL CORNER
description: President Reagan and the politics of 1984 have managed to put the Congressional Democrats on the defensive on many major issues of the day.

title: CONFIDENCE GROWS AT BATTERY PARK CITY
description: It was no surprise to insiders last week that the American Express Company finally completed its deal to move its headquarters and extensive operations to Olympia & York's World Financial Center at Battery Park City late next year.

title: RISING LABOR COSTS THREATEN NEW YORK PORT
description: Stacked on Wards Island in the East River are 169 wooden crates of chain. How they got there helps explain why high costs and new pricing formulas may transform New York from the nation's dominant general cargo port into a backwater of ocean commerce.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Approval Postponed

title: I.B.M. Systems For 20 Schools
