description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would give $40 million in computer systems to 20 universities. The computer systems are designed for use in computer-aided design and computeraided manufacturing.

title: GROMYKO SAYS SUMMIT MEETING DEPENDS ON ATTITUDE OF U.S.
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today that a Soviet-American summit meeting would become feasible only when Washington adopted a ''serious and constructive'' approach to relations with Moscow.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
F.H.L.B. Bond
description: The Federal Home Loan Banks set a 10.80 percent interest rate on its $500 million bond offering today. Secondary trading in the issue, which matures June 27, 1988, will begin at 10 A.M. today. Minimum initial purchases must be in units of $10,000, with additional purchases in $5,000 units.

title: HIGH-FIBER DIET: TASTE IS HIDDEN ATTRACTION
description: THE high-fiber fashion, well into its second decade, has lost its faddishness and has become part of mainstream nutrition. With good reason: The more scientists examine fiber, the component of food not broken down by the digestive tract, the more they learn about its beneficial properties. And the more humans eat foods high in fiber, the more they discover how much they like them. This may be one of the first instances in modern culinary history where what's good for us to eat tastes good. An increased interest in ethnic foods - tostados with refried beans, chili, stir-fried Chinese vegetables and tabbouleh, to name a few - has proven that Americans will eat highfiber foods even though they don't think of them as healthful.

title: JAPAN OUSTS SOVIET AIDE ON COMPUTER DATA CHARGE
description: The Japanese Government ordered a Soviet Embassy official to leave the country over the weekend for supposedly having tried to steal confidential information from a major computer company, the Foreign Ministry announced today.

title: Daughter-in-Law Of Mrs. Gandhi Arrested
description: The police arrested Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's estranged daughter-in-law and more than 100 of her supporters today for staging illegal marches in New Delhi and in the northwestern state of Punjab.

title: 'Showboat' to Close
description: ''Showboat'' will close Sunday at the Gershwin Theater. The revival of the Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical, starring Donald O'Connor, will have given 73 performances. ''Showboat'' was directed by Michael Kahn and was produced by James M. Nederlander, the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and the Denver Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Market Place; Kodak Stock: Dow Laggard
description: IN the midst of the most dynamic bull market of the postwar era, Eastman Kodak has won top honors - as the consistently worst performing stock among the 30 issues in the Dow Jones industrial average. The action of Kodak's shares has reflected lower company profits, as well as reduced earnings forecasts by Wall Street analysts.

title: GESUNDHEIT! SNEEZING GETS A BIG REACTION
description: AS a child with various minor allergies, I used to sneeze quite often. Each time she heard me sneeze, my grandmother would quickly bless me with ''zum leben un gesund'' (to life and health) and pull up on my right ear. Upon the inevitable second sneeze, my left ear would be pulled, accompanied by another blessing, ''zum wachsen un kwelln'' (to grow and thrive).

title: Offer by Trafalgar
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C. said its offer for the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, which was due to expire Thursday, had been extended until July 14. Trafalgar said it had decided to extend its offer, consisting of five Trafalgar ordinary shares for every four P & O deferred shares, because the British Government has not yet said whether the bid would be referred to the Monopolies Commission.

title: Accounts
description: * BYTE and Popular Computing magazines to Rafferty Communicators.

title: MEMBER RESIGNING AT S.E.C.
description: Barbara S. Thomas, a 36-year-old New Yorker who is the youngest person to serve on the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that she would be resigning for personal reasons ''sometime before the end of this year.''

title: A POLISH OFFICIAL REPLIES TO POPE'S CRITICISMS
description: In what appeared to be a response to Pope John Paul II's criticisms of the Polish authorities, a Deputy Prime Minister warned today against feeding Polish youths ''myths, legends and half-truths.''

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
BUDGET CUTS MAY FORCE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA TO REDUCE ITS SIZE AND SCOPE
description: The University of California is on the verge of a period of retrenchment arising from an unaccustomed shortage of money and the prospect of major demographic changes.

title: Gray Loses Appeals Suit
description: A Federal appeals court today threw out a lawsuit that L. Patrick Gray 3d, Acting Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the Nixon Administration, filed in retaliation for the Government's 1978 indictment of him. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit agreed with a lower court that Mr. Gray could not sue former Justice Department officials, including former Attorney General Griffen Bell, because they were immune from lawsuits for actions taken while in office.

title: WHY DOES IRAN KILL BAHAIS?
description: News of the barbarous execution on Thursday and Friday of 16 Bahais in the southern Iranian city of Shiraz has shattered the small remaining hope of many well-wishers of the Iranian revolution who kept saying, as I did: ''Wait, give it time.''

title: Panama Hails Duran
description: Thousands of cheering fans gave Roberto Duran, who won the World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title from Davey Moore last week, a hero's homecoming in a tropical downpour yesterday in Panama City. President Ricardo de la Espriella sent his executive jet to bring Duran from Miami.

title: PRESIDENT OF OLIN JOINS OCCIDENTAL
description: Ray R. Irani, president and chief operating officer of the Olin Corporation, has resigned to join the Occidental Petroleum Corporation as head of its chemical operations and coordinator of its Middle East oil activities.

title: AYALA IS SENTENCED TO 35 YEARS IN JAIL
description: Tony Ayala, the World Boxing Association's top-ranked junior-middleweight contender, saw his career come to an end today when he was sentenced to 35 years in prison and was ordered by the judge to serve at least 15 years before becoming eligible for parole.

title: ATTACK ON RABBI BRINGS ANGUISH TO BOROUGH PARK
description: Borough Park is a neighborhood of 100,000 people and 200 synagogues. These days its bustling streets are also filled with many questions.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: TOKYO STOCK INDEX AT RECORD HIGH
description: With foreign investors buying aggressively, prices on the Tokyo stock market today jumped to a record high of 8,798.62 points on the Dow Nikkei Index, up 86.89 for the day.

title: Vatican Chides Press On Coverage of Trip
description: The Vatican press office complained today that some Western news reports of Pope John Paul II's visit to Poland had focused too much on political topics.

title: IN NORWALK, A 'DISNEYLAND' DAIRY STORE
description: ''MY dream ever since I was a little boy was to be a milkman,'' Stew Leonard recalls, leaning back in a chair in his office here. ''My family was in the dairy business that's what I knew best and it's all I wanted.'' To say that Mr. Leonard has realized his dream is somewhat like saying the astronaut Neil Armstrong made good on a boyhood fantasy of flying an airplane.

title: CASH POTATO CONTRACTS CLEARED TO TRADE TODAY
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday approved a cash potato futures contract that signals another fundamental change in how commodities are traded.

title: No Comment
description: Marty Blake, who runs the National Basketball Association's scouting service, usually offers in his report at least 100 words of comment on each player who will be available in the draft, such as ''did not show much senior year until postseason play,'' ''good anticipation on rebounds'' and so forth.

title: AFGHANS WILL FIGHT ON
description: While another round of indirect talks on Afghanistan is drawing to a close in Geneva, prospects for a peaceful settlement of the conflict remain as dim as ever.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WE do not need a calendar nor a thermometer to know when summer has come to the city. We rely instead on the silliness quotient of the stories that find their way to Metropolitan Diary. Since this week's mail contained two items that lead us to believe that brains are beginning to fry, we will now declare the season of unreason officially open.

title: FOR FALL, ADOLFO EXPANDS HIS REPERTORY
description: BY noon, the Ladies, as they are known, all sat in the front row at the showing of Adolfo's fall and winter collection at the St. Regis-Sheraton waiting for the show to begin. And at least 11 of them wore the same silk leaf-print dress with matching cardigan. They didn't care.

title: BILL COFIELD
description: Bill Cofield, a former head basketball coach at the University of Wisconsin, died of cancer in a hospital here Monday night. He was 43 years old. Mr. Cofield became the first black head coach of a major sport in the Big Ten Conference when he was hired by Wisconsin in 1976. In 6 seasons his teams won 61 games and lost 103, and he resigned under pressure in March 1982.

title: AGENCY ASSAILS LOVE CANAL ASSURANCES
description: A Congressional agency said today that the Federal Government had no scientific basis for declaring last year that the neighborhood surrounding the Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., was safe enough to live in.

title: Rosalie Swedlin Marries
description: Rosalie Swedlin, a literary agent for Creative Artists in Los Angeles, was married yesterday in New York to Robert William Cort, a senior vice president of 20th Century-Fox in Beverly Hills, Calif. Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg performed the ceremony at the Hemsley Palace Hotel. The bride is a daughter of Cecile Swedlin Berman of New York and the late L.John Swedlin. Mr. Cort is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Mack Cort, also of New York.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MAGNETIC FIELD(S). By Ron Loewinsohn. 181 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: 20 Top Players Support Vilas
description: Twenty of the world's leading professional tennis players, including John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl and Vitas Gerulaitis, issued a signed statement of support and ''concern'' today over the one-year suspension recently issued to Guillermo Vilas.

title: U.S. PRESSES SOVIET FOR BIG REDUCTION IN ITS ICBM FORCE
description: The Reagan Administration plans to deploy 100 MX missiles unless the Soviet Union agrees to give up most of its 818 medium and heavy land-based strategic missiles, Kenneth L. Adelman, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said in a letter made public today.

title: Citibank Service
description: Citibank has introduced a new discount brokerage service at its metropolitan branches.

title: JOHN PAUL SAYS FUTURE OF POLAND DEPENDS ON RESTORATION OF TRUST
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the future of Poland depended on restoration of mutual trust in all fields, including politics.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 22, 1983
description: The Economy

title: 5 Chicagoans Admit Tampering With Ballots
description: Five people have pleaded guilty to Federal charges of illegally casting 203 straight Democratic tickets in the November general election.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
RETRIEVAL TESTING DUE IN ORBIT TODAY
description: The Challenger astronauts are preparing the way for space shuttle operations of a new dimension, in which crews could be going forth regularly to grab satellites in orbit for refueling, repairs or a return to earth.

title: LATEST MET TRADE
description: When the New York Mets joined the National League in 1962, they quickly established their identity as the Statue of Liberty of baseball. The hungry, the tired, the poor, the lame of arm and the slow of foot, all the huddled masses found a home at the Polo Grounds.

title: Not at the Race Track
description: Bill Fox owns, trains and races thoroughbreds in Louisiana, and his wife, Patricia Sabino Fox, owns, trains and races thoroughbreds in Louisiana. But when the Foxes both tried to enter horses in the same race at the Fair Grounds in New Orleans in February 1982, stewards for the Louisiana Racing Commission said no.

title: N.B.A. PLAYOFFS A ROUND OF 16
description: The National Basketball Association's board of governors, closing its two-day meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria, agreed yesterday to expand the playoffs from 12 to 16 teams starting next season. It also acted to help prevent a club from trading or selling away top draft choices and established talent.

title: SNEAKY BEARS STAGE SNACK ATTACKS
description: The crowd of cars on the roadside ahead meant someone had seen a bear. It was poking along at the edge of the forest a quarter mile away, its nose a muddy red from foraging among roots and tree stumps.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 22, 1983
description: International

title: Earthquake Hits Japan
description: A strong earthquake rocked northern Japan today in the same region where 102 people were killed last month in a major quake that sent 10-foot waves crashing ashore. There were no reports of casualties or significant damage, the police said. In Hong Kong the Royal Observatory estimated the quake's intensity at 6.9 on the open-ended Richter scale and said its epicenter was in the Sea of Japan.

title: RETAILERS DEBATE 'OFF-PRICE' THREAT
description: Some department stores and brand-name producers served notice yesterday that they would not stand idly by while a new wave of apparel discounters made fortunes at their expense.

title: Dow Closes at 1,247.40, Up 8.22
description: Stock prices rose on late buying yesterday after moving in a narrow range most of the day. The Dow Jones industrial average, down about 2 points at noon, gained steam in the last half-hour of trading to finish with a gain of 8.22 points, at 1,247.40, just 0.90 below the record set on June 16, 1983.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes charges of $453,038, or 28 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,035,508, or 63 cents a share, for the 6 months from tender offer expenses. c-After capital gains of $114,395 for the latest period and $544,958 for the year-earlier period.

title: Liberty in First Victory
description: Liberty, sailed by Dennis Conner, won her first race today in the preliminary trials to select an America's Cup defender, beating Courageous, driven by John Kolius, by 19 seconds.

title: Marathon Wins Trial Over Sale
description: A Federal jury today upheld last year's acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company by the United States Steel Company.

title: A New Car for the Mayor
description: Mayor Koch, who said three weeks ago he deserved a raise, said yesterday he had ordered a bigger car. Complaining of being scrunched into his four-door sedan, the 6 foot, 1 inch Mayor said he had ordered a limousine with more legroom. The city will lease a Lincoln Continental for $3,000 a year, the same price it pays for the smaller car.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net income

title: Girard T. Kohman, 85; Electronics Researcher
description: Dr. Girard T. Kohman, former head of the physical chemistry research and development department of Bell Telephone Laboratories in Murray Hill, N.J., died last Wednesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 85 years old and a resident of Summit.

title: Dairy Plan for China
description: The House Agriculture Committee unanimously approved a proposal today by Tony Coelho, Democrat of California, urging President Reagan to declare China eligible to buy surplus dairy products acquired under a Government farm price support program. Mr. Coelho said he understood Peking was interested in buying surplus milk products but that the State Department planned to oppose such a request.

title: INTERMOUNTAIN LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
OCELOT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CABLE TV COMPANIES REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD WITH CITY
description: City officials and cable-company executives said last night that they had reached a tentative agreement on contracts to bring cable television to the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: 'SURVIVORS'
description: WITHIN the first 15 minutes of Michael Ritchie's ''Survivors,'' a comedy that is less black than severely mottled, a lot of peculiar things happen, some of them quite funny.

title: Philips Video Pact
description: Philips N.V. said it and Thomson-Brandt S.A. had agreed to cooperate to produce video game consoles and cassettes. The accord mainly involves the exchange of research and development results, a considerable expansion of new games and a strengthening of the position of the standardized European model, Philips said.

title: A CHAMPION AND HIS MILD MANNERS
description: Larry Nelson has a very calm outward appearance when playing golf, never displaying the excitement or self-condemnation that players such as Seve Ballesteros and Craig Stadler show at times of good shots or bad. The 35-year-old Nelson shows even less emotion than Tom Watson, for whom emotion is usually a big smile.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Hempstead Gets A Landmark Law
description: The Hempstead Town Board adopted a landmarks preservation ordinance today to protect historic sites in the 300-year-old town.

title: INSURANCE BROKER STILL SUFFERING FROM SCANDAL
description: Among the nation's largest insurance brokers, Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. has long stood out as the most aggressive. For years, its competitors have marveled at the pace with which Alexander forged into new markets and acquired other companies. In 1981 alone, Alexander, the nation's second-largest insurance broker, purchased 21 companies.

title: Weicker's Son Signed
description: Gray Weicker, the 22-year-old son of Senator Lowell Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, and an all-American goaltender from St. Lawrence University, has been signed by the Hartford Whalers.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: 1. Jewels From the Sea

title: Ashe Is 'Stable' After Surgery
description: The former tennis champion Arthur Ashe was listed in ''satisfactory and stable'' condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center last night after undergoing double-bypass surgery, his second heart operation in four years.

title: BURLINGTON COAT FACTORY reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
TV: PENGUINS, AN INVASION AND STRANDED PHOTOGRAPHERS
description: THERE is some hokum in ''King Penguin: Stranded Beyond the Falklands,'' even in the title. For one thing, the king penguins aren't stranded; two wildlife photographers are stranded, and even if Orson Welles, the narrator, persists in telling us how threatening everything is it does seem that the photographers are having quite a nice time.

title: MAJOR FIGURE IN BLACK DRAMA
description: Owen Dodson, a poet, novelist, playwright and teacher whose 20 years as a professor of drama at Howard University influenced the course of African-American drama, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 68 years old and lived on Manhattan's West Side.

title: HISPANIC EX-LEGISLATOR IS ELECTED MAYOR OF DENVER IN CLOSE VOTING
description: Federico Pena, a 36-year-old former state legislator, was elected the new Mayor of Denver today, defeating his opponent, Dale Tooley, in a close runoff election.

title: Canadian G.N.P. Up
description: Canada's first-quarter real gross national product rose at an annual rate of 7.2 percent, seasonally adjusted, after an adjusted fourth-quarter fall of seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. In the first quarter a year ago real G.N.P. fell 2.2 percent.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
AL HIRSCHFELD IS IN THE SPOTLIGHT AT 80
description: Al Hirschfeld, whose incisive caricatures have constituted a continuing hall of fame for more than half a century for theater folk who have come and gone before the footlights, stood in a spotlight of his own yesterday. Mr. Hirschfeld observed his 80th birthday, an event that evoked celebratory comment from Broadway, from City Hall and from his colleagues in the newspaper business.

title: First-Hand View
description: When the National Football League Players Association and the league's owners signed a new collective bargaining agreement last winter, they established a policy by which any player who needed treatment for problems related to drug or alcohol abuse could seek help at the Hazelden Foundation in Center City, Minn., at no cost to the athlete.

title: DAVID JAMISON CARLYLE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $110,497 for the quarter and $124,256 for the 6 months.

title: PADRES, ON 2-HITTER, DOWN DODGERS, 2-0
description: Tim Lollar permitted only two singles, by Dusty Baker in the seventh inning and by Bill Russell in the ninth, and drove in a run with a sacrifice fly to lead the San Diego Padres to a 2-0 victory tonight over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Payment Lag By 3 in OPEC
description: Iraq, Nigeria and Libya are finding it increasingly difficult to pay for construction work, a West German building company said today.

title: Decision File; No Easy Money
description: In the last couple of years, many enterprising people paid $24,000 each to a Nevada company that promised to set them up in business making ''Open,'' ''Closed'' and ''Beware of the dog'' plastic signs in their homes.

title: DON'T BLOCK FRESH STARTS FOR DEBTORS IN TROUBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Wayne B. Colburn, 76, Dies; Top Marshal at Wounded Knee
description: Wayne B. Colburn, a retired United States Marshal who commanded the 71-day standoff against 300 militant Indians at Wounded Knee, S.D., in 1973, died at his home Sunday. He was 76 years old.

title: IN HOUSING POLICY, IT SEEMS TORIES HAD A WINNER
description: In the last year, a maintenance supervisor for a drugstore chain here made two key decisions. He added a fourth bedroom to his house and switched his allegiance from the Labor Party to the Conservatives.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE square towers of the Castello di San Polo in Rosso, a few miles south of here, have watched over the Tuscan hills for a thousand years. They are so old they predate the cannonball, which the round tower of the Middle Ages was invented to deflect.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Broadcasting Companies has named Michael P. Mallardi executive vice president and chief financial officer, Everett H. Erlick executive vice president and general counsel and Mark Cohen senior vice president.

title: NEW HEAD OF COINTREAU IN U.S. MAPS SALES PUSH
description: Robert A. Schu has been promoted to the presidency of Cointreau America Inc., which is planning a campaign to get a bigger share of the United States liqueur market.

title: '85 Recovery Seen in Japan
description: The Japanese and other major industrialized economies are likely to begin a solid recovery only in 1985, although there are some signs of an upturn at present, Sumitomo Bank said today in a report.

title: Outlook After Bell Spinoff
description: Four telephone companies of the Bell System told stockholders today that divestiture by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company would offer more opportunities than pitfalls.

title: Universal Cigar
description: The Universal Cigar Corporation said its board had proposed a transaction in which a newly formed corporation would offer $13 a share to take Universal private. Based on about 1.4 million Universal shares outstanding, the deal would be valued at $18.2 million. The new corporation would be formed by Edward Gropper, Universal's chairman and president, and his family and family trusts. Mr. Gropper and his family own about 84 percent of Universal's shares outstanding, the company said.

title: TWO AMERICAN JOURNALISTS KILLED AT BORDER, HONDURAN ARMY SAYS
description: Two American journalists were killed today in Honduras near the Nicaraguan border when their car was hit by a rocket-propelled grenade, according to the Honduran Army.

title: Presley Executors Settle With Manager and RCA
description: Executors of the Elvis Presley estate ended a legal battle with the RCA Corporation and Mr. Presley's former manager, Col. Tom Parker, in an out-of-court settlement worth more than $3 million.

title: LOUISE BROOKS
description: THE Film Forum's new program, which opens a three-week engagement today, is for dedicated film students, amateur as well as professional: the New York theatrical premiere of ''Prix de Beaute,'' a not-great but historically important film made by the now-legendary Louise Brooks in Paris in 1930, plus ''A Conversation with Louise Brooks,'' a 23-minute interview with Miss Brooks conducted by Richard Leacock at her Rochester apartment in 1974.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $112,000 for the latest year and $68,000 for the previous year.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 29.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $228,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $190,000 for the quarter and $238,000 for the year. Results for the latest year include a gain on the sale of a facility in Norwalk, Conn., increases in reserves against the carrying value of certain assets and moving expenses and increases in inventory reserves for discontinued and slow-moving products, the net effect of which was to increase net income by $58,000 for fiscal 1983.

title: DO IT YOURSELF AND SAVE ON CHICKEN PARTS
description: A MEDAL should be awarded to the chicken for its distinguished service in the otherwise losing battle against food inflation. Ten years ago whole broiler-fryers went for 49 cents a pound on sale. Today they still do. Other sources of protein may have taken their pricing guidelines from the Federal budget, but chickens have in effect gone down in cost.

title: AIRLINE COMPUTER SYSTEM 'BIAS' CITED
description: The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board told a Congressional subcommittee today that the agency has found that while there is ''bias'' in the computer reservations systems sponsored by United Airlines and American Airlines, they are not in violation of antitrust laws.

title: Welcome Mat in Queens
description: Perhaps taking his cue from the other boroughs, Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens introduced the first of nine ''Welcome to Queens'' signs yesterday, on the Long Island Expressway near the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. ''I felt the celebration of our tricentennial would be an appropriate time for Queens to wave its own flag,'' he said.

title: STRONG RECOVERY IN THIS QUARTER FORECAST BY U.S.
description: The economic recovery has turned unexpectedly vigorous and this spring has been moving as briskly as recoveries normally do, the Government reported today.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Nuclear Monitors Wary Of 3-Mile Island Proposal
description: Several members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission expressed doubts today about a plan by the commission staff to endorse management integrity at Three Mile Island in order to speed a decision on reopening the undamaged reactor at the Pennsylvania site.

title: FILM: 'THE DRAUGHTSMAN'S CONTRACT'
description: ''The Draughtsman's Contract'' was shown as part of the 20th New York Film Festival at Alice Tully Hall. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby that appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2, 1982. The film opens today at the Cinema 2, Third Avenue and 60th Street.

title: Miller's Condition Serious
description: William E. Miller, Barry Goldwater's Vice-Presidential running mate on the Republican ticket in 1964, was listed in serious condition today at a hospital here with an undisclosed illness. Mr. Miller, 69 years old, was admitted to Millard Fillmore Hospital earlier this month to undergo medical tests. A hospital spokesman declined to disclose the nature of the tests. The Goldwater-Miller ticket was soundly defeated by the Democratic ticket headed by Lyndon B. Johnson and Hubert H. Humphrey.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Olympic Sites Are Completed
description: Selection of a site for the 1984 Olympics shooting events was finally made Tuesday: the Prado Recreational Area, 40 miles east of Los Angeles in San Bernardino County near the town of Chino.

title: Socal Earnings
description: The Standard Oil Company of California expects to report higher earnings for the second quarter from those of a year earlier, with profits for the full year showing a ''modest improvement'' over 1982, George M. Keller, chairman, said. In last year's second quarter, Socal earned $263 million, or 77 cents a share, on sales of $9.18 billion. For all of 1982, Socal had earnings of $1.38 billion, or $4.03 a share, on sales of $35.2 billion.

title: Old Master of a Quick and Subtle Art
description: On the fencing strip stood Deborah Tavares, who, at 25, is quick and agile but who just now was suffering from a decided lack of conviction.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for qtr to May 7.
description: b-Including a capital gain of $60,000.

title: COSMOS ARE BEATEN AND A STREAK ENDS
description: The Cosmos were defeated by the Chicago Sting, 3-2, tonight for their first North American Soccer League loss in the month of June since they moved into Giants Stadium in 1977.

title: A STAR WHO SHINES BRIGHTLY IN REAGAN'S SHADOW
description: Vice President Bush embarks Thursday on a 15-day, eight-nation European trip to follow up on an earlier swing to rally support for the Reagan Administration's arms control policies. When he returns to Washington on July 7, Mr. Bush will have added 11,000 miles to the 340,000 he already has logged in Air Force Two, as his jetliner is called.

title: This Way, Please
description: Curtsies and bows are as much a part of the tradition at Wimbledon as white balls, predominantly white apparel, and strawberries and cream. To alert players that royalty is seated in the Royal Box, a red light is stationed over the door outside the players' waiting room to the center court.

title: Cheers for the Higher Tolls and Gas Tax
description: A Proper Way for Cars to Help Mass Transit

title: Ford to Undergo Surgery
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford entered Eisenhower Medical Center today for elective urological surgery and was expected to be hospitalized four to five days. Penny Circle, assistant to the 69-year-old Mr. Ford, described the operation as ''purely routine.''

title: FARM PROTESTERS' FOCUS: PRICES AND FORECLOSURES
description: The farm protest movement set off across the Middle West by the continuing agricultural recession is focusing on the passage of state laws that would give farmers and related workers some financial relief.

title: EMPLOYERS OFFERING SEMINARS TO HELP THE WORKING PARENT
description: ''IT'S not easy to raise children and work at the same time,'' Stephen Segal told the 19 Bankers Trust employees assembled in a conference room in the company's Park Avenue skyscraper.

title: MAKING HOUSES FROM THE PAST FIT THE PRESENT
description: If I were asked to define the difference between house restoration and renovation,'' Dr. Theodore Lindauer says, ''I would say $100,000.'' Dr. Lindauer, a Los Angeles psychiatrist, knows the distinction well. He recently completed six years of work restoring the Edwards House, an International style classic in the Los Angeles hills designed by the California architect Gregory Ain.

title: Anti-Israeli Resolution Is Rejected by the I.L.O.
description: The 150-nation International Labor Organization rejected an Arab-sponsored resolution today that would have had the group condemn Israel's policy of ''settlements, expansion and racism.''

title: COUNTRYWIDE CREDIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
SAKHAROV SPEAKS
description: From his exile in Gorky, Andrei Sakharov has reached the West with an important document of the nuclear age. It is a powerful new statement on the danger of thermonuclear war. It has special fascination because the great Soviet scientist, isolated and tormented by his government, addresses both the urgency and the difficulty of dealing with the Soviet Union on arms control.

title: Nuclear Spill in France
description: About 80 gallons of slightly radioactive water spilled Monday at the Fessenheim nuclear power plant on the Rhine River, the plant's surveillance committee announced today. Some of the water spread on the ground and the rest ran down storm drains.

title: SEAVER AND TORREZ SWEEP CARDS
description: The Mets managed something of a baseball rarity last night in Shea Stadium: They became the first team in nearly three years to sweep a doubleheader from the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: MONOGRAM OIL & GAS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After tax credits of $59,000 for the quarter and $20,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: REAGAN'S 'TRUTH' ON BLACKS
description: President Reagan says he would ''have perfect confidence with black voters ... if we could get the truth to them.'' He faces a monumental task because his Administration's ''truth'' is that blacks are not discriminated against. Whatever vestiges of discrimination may remain, in his view, are aimed at individuals - singly, alone, presumably at random. Thus, he reiterated his conviction that wherever ''any individual's constitutional rights are being unjustly denied'' the Government must restore them ''at point of bayonet if necessary.''

title: 'GODLESS' POLISH CITY GETS 6TH CHURCH
description: When Poland's Communist rulers began to build this steel-mill town in 1950, they envisioned it as a workers' paradise in the new Communist order.

title: I.M.F. View On Economy
description: The International Monetary Fund has issued its most optimistic economic forecast in recent years, but said that huge budget deficits in the United States threatened recovery in that country and elsewhere.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WINDOW shades, long popular for insuring privacy as well as blocking unwanted light and glare, can also be useful as energy savers: In summer they keep out much of the sun's heat, helping to lower air-conditioning costs, and in winter they conserve heat.

title: TV: ABC OFFERS 'THE AMERICAN INQUISITION'
description: ''THE AMERICAN INQUISITION'' looks at the anti-Communist fervor of the 1950's, reconstructing what happened then to one person caught in its excesses and examining the life of another 30 years later. It is a powerful, moving look, suggesting the intensity of the frenzy that once was let loose in this country and showing some of its legacy now. The documentary will be seen on ABC at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ex-Guard Who Killed 13 Is Given Death Sentence
description: George E. Banks, a former prison guard who was convicted of killing 13 people, including five of his own children, was sentenced to death today.

title: BROKERS VS. BANKS: CANADIAN TEST CASE
description: If the Toronto Dominion has its way, Canada could be on the verge of a fundamental change in the way its financial institutions compete.

title: NEIL ALLEN SURPRISES WITH 2-STRIKE BUNT
description: Neil Allen's wife, Linda, rounded up all the newspapers in town yesterday morning and spread them over the kitchen table. They told the story of Allen's return to Shea Stadium in the uniform of the St. Louis Cardinals, almost a week after he had been traded by the Mets. The story made great reading for the Allen family: 8 innings of 4-hit pitching, 6 strikeouts and a 6-0 victory for Allen.

title: SOVIET INCREASED 1981 ARMS OUTLAY
description: The Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency have told Congress that Soviet military spending continued to rise in 1981 at a steady rate despite a stagnant economy and a decline in Soviet citizens' standard of living.

title: OPERA: 'L'ORMINDO
description: THE first impression of Francesco Cavalli's 1644 opera ''L'Ormindo,'' as performed by the Chamber Opera Theater of New York, is of Beni Montresor's sets and costumes. The floor and walls are copper-colored mirrors, the costumes luxurious metallic cloths of gold, silver and gauze that often gather in swirls around the mirrored floor. The lighting and atmosphere are at once Venetian and North African in tone; abstract, reflecting drop pieces create an ocean, a castle, a prison.

title: DOCTORS APPEAL FOR ARMS CURB
description: An international physicians' group, calling nuclear deterrence and civil defense planning ''immoral'' and ''illusory,'' appealed to President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, to halt the arms race.

title: 50 GRAND PIECES OF 50'S FURNITURE
description: WHEN Mark McDonald, Mark Isaacson and Ralph Cutler joined forces, they did it in a big way. The three 1950's dealers have moved into a grand 4,500-square-foot space and are celebrating their new shop with a 50-piece show, ''The Sum of the Parts: Ray & Charles Eames,'' on view until Sept. 10.

title: A GAPTOOTHED BILL ON TWO-WAY CABLE PRIVACY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILEAN UNION CHIEF FREED AS GENERAL STRIKE NEARS
description: A magistrate has ordered the release on bail of the leader of Chile's truck owners, whose union is one of those that has called a general strike against the military Government for Thursday.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: The 1983 and 1982 year periods include net gains from property dispositions of $1.9 million, or 20 cents a share, and $2.2 million, or 30 cents a share, respectively. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 21 to shareholders of record, Dec. 31, 1982.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD IMPOSITION OF DEATH PENALTY IN GEORGIA CASE
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the imposition of the death penalty in a Georgia murder case. The Court ruled, 7 to 2, that the jury's reliance in part on a sentencing factor later found to be unconstitutional did not invalidate the sentence of death.

title: A Soviet Military Attache Is Expelled by Norway
description: Norway expelled the assistant military attache at the Soviet Embassy in Oslo today on charges of military espionage.

title: 100 YOUNG CZECHS CALLING FOR FREEDOM ARE ROUTED BY POLICE
description: At least 100 young Czechs chanting ''We want freedom'' and other slogans were dispersed by policemen Tuesday night, a spokesman for a Government-sponsored peace conference said today.

title: President Budget Buster
description: Who says they're for reducing the Federal budget deficit? Everyone. President Reagan, all 535 members of Congress, the man in the street, the chairman of Citibank, economists left and right, even foreigners. But how? President Reagan says his is the only way. In fact it's Congress, by effectively combining procedure and politics, that's using the budget better as a way to govern.

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After tax credit of $1.7 million. c-After gains of $2.3 million and $4.5 million for the latest year and earlier year, respectively.

title: DOCTORS BACK TAX ON HEALTH PLANS
description: Spokesmen for the nation's doctors and hospitals joined the Reagan Administration today in urging Congress to start taxing workers for their employers' contributions to the cost of the workers' health insurance.

title: NOVAN ENERGY, INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-After a tax credit of $66,000.

title: Nearly 2,000 Doctors Are Fasting in Israel
description: Nearly 2,000 of Israel's 4,500 public health doctors were reported fasting for higher pay today, and there was speculation that the army would put them on reserve duty to keep hospitals from closing.

title: STOPPARD'S 'REAL THING' IN LONDON
description: In a weak West End theater season, there is only one new play that almost everyone agrees comes close to the real thing - namely, Tom Stoppard's flawed but adventurous ''Real Thing.''

title: STATE OIL PACT FACING FIGHT IN THE SENATE
description: Senate Republicans objected tonight to a key element of an out-of-court settlement reached between Governor Cuomo and major oil companies over hundreds of millions in back state taxes.

title: Threat to Close Ford Plant Denied
description: The Ford Motor Company denied a report that it had threatened to close its Rouge Steel plant if the United Automobile Workers union did not agree to wage concessions from 4,200 workers at the plant.

title: Bridge: Japanese Have Indicated They Can Play With Best
description: Many countries with no bridge-playing tradition have developed strong teams within the past decade. One of these is Japan, which finished a respectable fifth in the 1982 Far East Championships and pinned the only heavy defeat on the formidable Indonesian team, which won the title.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
EXTRAS FOR HOSES
description: STRUGGLING with a recalcitrant garden hose on a hot summer day can seem to demand the skills of a snake charmer. This year there are many new products available to make hoses easier to use and more versatile.

title: Dr. Jenne Britell, A Banker, Weds
description: The marriage of Dr. Jenne Katz Britell, a vice president with Citibank's North American Banking Group in New York, to Daniel Jacobson, a partner in the New York accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi James Rudin of the American Jewish Committee performed the ceremony at the couple's apartment.

title: Doing Justice to Landmakers And to Theater Interiors
description: To answer the objections of Broadway theater owners, 34 prominent scenic and lighting designers have volunteered to work with the Landmarks Preservation Commission on guidelines on making theater interiors landmarks.

title: HEALTH CARE: A MISSING AMERICAN RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Surrender in Murder Case
description: Two Philadelphia men wanted in the robbery and slaying of a Bucks County pharmacist last week have surrendered to a newspaper columnist.

title: Dancer and Dorland Holding Talks
description: Dancer Fitzgerald Sample of New York is holding talks with Dorland Advertising of London, which could lead to renewed ties, Peter F. McSpadden, president of DFS Holdings, reluctantly disclosed yesterday.

title: SENATORS ENDORSE TOUGHER CIGARETTE WARNING
description: The Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today endorsed legislation to strengthen the health warning on cigarette packages.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss c-After loss from discontinued operations of $94,000, loss of $1,595,000 from termination of Canadian operations and tax credit of $1,692,000. d-After loss from discontinued operations of $1,009,000.

title: STAGE CONFERENCE ASKS WHAT IS A DRAMATURGE?
description: Samuel Beckett was recently visited in Paris by Alan Schneider, who directed the three short Beckett plays that opened last week in New York. Mr. Schneider mentioned that he was returning home to a conference on dramaturges. According to Mr. Schneider, Mr. Beckett replied, ''What's a dramaturge?''

title: Veterans' Agency Opposing Measures on Toxic Chemical
description: The Veterans Administration today opposed efforts by Vietnam veterans to win compensation for diseases they believe were caused by Agent Orange, contending that no link to the herbicide had been proved.

title: Carroll B. Larrabee, 86; Ex-Magazine Publisher
description: Carroll B. Larrabee, a retired director of Applied Journals of the American Chemical Society and former president and publisher of Printers' Ink publishing company, died June 15 at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va., after a stroke. He was a resident of Annadale, Va., and was 86 years old.

title: Interest in a Bengal
description: Cris Collinsworth, the star wide receiver for the Cincinnati Bengals of the National Football League, and John Bassett, the owner of the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League, are old friends. And it is common knowledge that Bassett has been trying to get Collinsworth to jump leagues when his Cincinnati contract expires after the 1984 season.

title: Abscam Convicts Told To Go to Prison on July 7
description: Two former Congressmen from Philadelphia and a former City Council member have been ordered to report to Allenwood Federal prison July 7 to begin serving three-year terms in their Abscam bribery convictions.

title: U.S.-Soviet Grain Talks
description: Negotiators from the United States and the Soviet Union concluded three days of talks today without reaching a new agreement on the sale of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Ex-Player Admits He Sold Cocaine
description: John Williams, a 37-year-old Minneapolis dentist who was once a star offensive lineman for the Baltimore Colts and the Los Angeles Rams, pleaded guilty here Tuesday to a Federal charge of having sold cocaine.

title: VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $192,000 for the latest year and $25,500 for the earlier year.

title: SEPARATISTS LOSE IN 3 QUEBEC VOTES
description: The candidates of Quebec's governing party, the separatist Parti Quebecois, were defeated in three by-elections for the provincial legislature Monday, bringing to 16 the number of such elections it has lost in a row.

title: SNORKELING REVEALS UNDERWATER BEAUTY
description: Just as even a cursory knowledge of plants, trees and wildlife can enhance the enjoyment of a summer hike, so can snorkeling bring new pleasure and insights to a seacoast or lakeside visit.

title: STARS IN JAPAN'S POLITICS HAVE LOST THE LIMELIGHT
description: They have been famous actors and singers, newscasters and novelists, performers such as a comedian who goes by the stage name of Columbia Top and personalities like Akiko Santo, who was sort of the Betty Furness of Japan, selling Hitachi appliances on television.

title: UMET PROPERTIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After gains on sale of real estate of $23,000 and $35,000 and tax credits of $405,000 and $565,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-After gain on the sale of real estate of $670,000 for the quarter and 6 months, and tax credits of $1,211,000 for the quarter and $1,361,000 for the 6 months.

title: MINDREADING JACKSON
description: ''The Rev. Jesse Jackson for President'' -oh, it has all the brothers in a tizzy. Most of them are saying, ''Remember Shirley Chisholm in 1972.'' I remember, all right: Shirley ran in the North Carolina Democratic primary, pulled the black vote away from Terry Sanford, the liberal, and George Wallace won. So the conventional wisdom is that a black candidate for President only hurts the black community by helping the candidate we like least. Well, I wonder.

title: Bendix Plans Sale Of Some Units
description: The Bendix Corporation, a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation, said it would sell its cutting tools division operations in Massachusetts, California, Ohio and Illinois, and close a turning-machine division in Cleveland and a Burbank, Calif., manufacturing site. The moves are part of a further consolidation of Bendix's automation group.

title: Failures in France Rise
description: The number of corporate bankruptcies, liquidations and legal settlements in France jumped by 30 percent in May from April, the national statistics agency said today. It said that 2,080 failures were recorded, seasonally adjusted, compared with 1,601 in April and 1,686 in March.

title: MGM GRAND HOTELS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes gain of about $2.1 million, or 7 cents a share, from sale of land.

title: Swedish Prices Up
description: Swedish consumer prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May from April and were up 8.7 percent from May 1982, Statistics Sweden said today.

title: Required Reading; Reagan's Education
description: Representative Frederick C. Boucher, Democrat of Virginia, in remarks to the House, June 15: Mr. Speaker, it is appropriate that President Reagan's new-found interest in education comes at the end of the school term. Let us look at his report card.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Adams-Russell Co. said that it had sold its television station WYTV in Youngstown, Ohio, to the Youngstown Broadcasting Co. for $8.8 million.

title: 'STRENGTH AND DIPLOMACY' STRESSED BY SHULTZ
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that although the United States was seeking to negotiate ''in a spirit of give and take'' with the Soviet Union on a wide number of issues, no significant progress had been achieved yet in any of them.

title: Farm Talks With E.E.C.
description: The United States and the European Economic Community opened a new round of talks today aimed at resolving longstanding disputes over agricultural trade.

title: Man Held in Stranglings Of Two Teen-Age Boys
description: A 30-year-old man was charged today with stalking and strangling two teen-age boys, the LaPorte County authorities said.

title: G R I CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 14.
description: Results for the latest quarter and 6 months include operations of American Heritage Industries, acquired earlier this year.

title: STRIPPED FURNITURE ENHANCED BY WAX
description: Stripped and waxed pine furniture became popular in the 1960's as kitchen pieces fresh from British stripping shops were given a wax treatment and shipped here in goodly numbers.

title: YANKS' LAST LINK TO BYGONE DAYS
description: Bobby Murcer, who as of last Monday no longer plays for the Yankees, was recently talking about his singing career. ''A guy I know came to me one day last winter when I was home in Oklahoma City and asked if I could sing,'' said Murcer. ''I said: 'Why, you must be crazy. Of course I can sing.' But I was kidding. I had never sung before, except in the shower. No, once I did it to a pack of dogs. They seemed to like it. It was my only true test in front of a crowd.

title: Market Place; Penn Central Buyback Plan
description: ON Monday, the Penn Central Corporation extended an offer to an estimated 55,000 of its 65,000 shareholders. The company wants to purchase the common stock of those owning fewer than 100 shares.

title: MUSEUM'S MISTAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: Year-ago results have been reclassified.

title: FOCUS ON FEDERAL FUNDS RATE
description: The credit markets have been on edge recently because of fears that the Federal Reserve might have decided to tighten credit and thereby cause interest rates to rise. The most closely watched interest rate of all is the rate for overnight loans between banks, known as the Federal funds rate.

title: TEXAS GAS ACCEPTS CSX OFFER
description: Directors of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation approved an offer by the CSX Corporation to buy the oil and gas company's 20.6 million shares for $52 apiece, or a total of $1.1 billion, Dennis Hendrix, chairman of Texas Gas, said yesterday.

title: GUIDRY DEFEATS ORIOLES
description: The eighth inning of tonight's game between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles, Rick Cerone said, was what ''people pay to see.'' The eighth inning, Ron Guidry said, ''might be the best inning I've had all year as far as a clutch situation goes.''

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 27.
Downtown New Orleans, Blacked Out By Accident
description: A construction crane at the site of the 1984 World's Fair struck a power line today, knocking out traffic lights at the morning rush-hour and blacking out 15,500 businesses and homes.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Don Reese Gets a Job
description: It was an article he wrote for Sports Illustrated that led to his latest incarceration, and now that he is out of prison, Don Reese, the former pro defensive lineman, has found a job through the magazine. A day after Reese returned to his home in Marietta, Ga., following his parole from a Florida prison, Sports Illustrated officials said that he would be taking a job at the Atlanta regional distribution center for Time Inc., the magazine's publisher.

title: New Developer Using Familiar Plans
description: For his Manhattan real-estate debut, Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the Boston-based multimillionaire and owner of The Atlantic Monthly, plans an office tower on Lexington Avenue across from from Citicorp Center.

title: S I HANDLING SYSTEMS, INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
description: b-Net income.

title: PHILHARMONIC PARKS CONCERTS
description: The 19th season of the New York Philharmonic's free Parks Concerts will begin Aug. 8 at 8 P.M. on the Great Lawn in Central Park. For the first time, there will also be a concert at Battery Park in lower Manhattan, Aug. 23 at 12:30 P.M. The orchestra will also present concerts in Queens, the Bronx, Staten Island, Brooklyn and Long Island.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
LOCAL CONTENT: GLOBAL PRACTICE
description: Data General, the big computer manufacturer, had exported its products to Mexico for years. In 1980 the company had a 5 percent share of a $400 million market that was expanding by roughly 30 percent a year. The country's financial difficulties cut into the growth of the computer market, but Data General continued to ship its products.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: DEMOCRATIC LEADERS IN HOUSE SAY BUDGET PASSAGE IS LIKELY
description: Democratic leaders predicted today that the compromise Federal budget for the next fiscal year would be approved by the House of Representatives when it goes to the floor Thursday.

title: 36 Miners in Hungary Killed in Explosion
description: An underground explosion killed 36 miners in a northwestern coal mine today and injured 10, the Hungarian state television reported.

title: Greece Accuses Turkey
description: Greece has protested to Turkey, saying a Turkish ship doing underwater sonic research violated its continental shelf, the official press agency said today.

title: FAULTY TESTS LEAD TO CANADIAN CHEMICAL BAN
description: The Canadian Government has banned or restricted six pesticides that were approved for use on the basis of studies by Industrial Bio-Test Laboratories, whose research procedures have caused widespread concern in the chemical industry.

title: REBELS DEMAND P.L.O. END COMPROMISE AND CORRUPTION
description: Col. Saed Musa, the leader of the rebellion against Yasir Arafat, said today that his men would not give up their revolt until Mr. Arafat agreed to root out corruption in the Palestine Liberation Organization, reject all compromise peace plans and consent to share power with the dissident officers.

title: GUNMEN WOUND THREE STUDENTS NEAR YESHIVA U.
description: Gunmen firing automatic weapons from a passing car wounded two Yeshiva University rabbinical students and a 14-year-old Yeshiva High School student yesterday in a restaurant across from the university's campus in Washington Heights. None were seriously hurt.

title: SCINTREX LTD reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net income

title: INDIAN PT. 3 SHUT FOR 5 MONTHS
description: The Indian Point 3 nuclear reactor, which reopened June 8 after a 14-month shutdown for repairs and refueling, will be closed for at least five months because of generator problems, the plant's owner, the New York Power Authority, said yesterday.

title: Kaufman & Broad Has Profit; Sales Up
description: Kaufman & Broad Inc., citing a strong upturn in the housing market, reported yesterday that it had net income of $5.1 million, or 30 cents a share, in the fiscal second quarter, which ended May 31; it had a loss of $7.2 million in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Iraq Asks U.N. to Study P.O.W. Camps in Iran
description: Iraq has asked Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to inquire into the conditions under which Iraqi prisoners are being held in Iran.

title: Rebel Attack in Chad Is Reported Imminent
description: Dissidents armed and trained by Libya and supported by its air force are poised to attack a city in northern Chad, the State Department said today. The attack, it said, could come ''almost at any moment.''

title: KNICKS PLAN OFFER FOR NETS' ELMORE
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' executive vice president, has been saying for weeks that ''we have a game plan'' to build a solid team for next season. Yesterday the plan, at least temporarily, went in a direction different from what had been expected.

title: U.N. PRESS REPORT APPROVED
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has apparently helped win acceptance of findings regarding Western journalism that he had previously described as ''unfortunate and ill-considered.''

title: Mrs. Abzug Comes Out For Nuetrality
description: Bella S. Abzug was subdued meeting with reporters in Albany after her election as Democratic national committeewoman.

title: Officials Release a Flood On Residents Downriver
description: Torrents of water released from reservoirs into the Colorado River poured over sandbag dikes today, flooding homes and resorts, for the start of what is expected to be the worst flooding along the California-Arizona border in 50 years.

title: WIDOW OF REP. BURTON IS ELECTED IN CALIFORNIA CONGRESSIONAL RACE
description: In what she described as ''a bittersweet victory,'' Sala Burton easily won election here Tuesday to the Congressional seat left vacant by the death of her husband, Phillip.

title: MEDICAL EYE PROBLEMS REQUIRE MEDICAL DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: South African Loans
description: The Finance Ministry said today that South Africa would prepay some of its $860 million of International Monetary Fund loans if financial reserves and gold prices remained satisfactory. The amount of the payment has not yet been determined.

title: HIGH COURT VOIDS JERSEY DISTRICTING FOR SEATS IN HOUSE
description: The Supreme Court ruled, 5 to 4, today that New Jersey's Congressional district lines violated the constitutional principle of one man, one vote. The lines for all 14 districts, reapportioned by the Democratic-controlled Legislature after the 1980 Census, will have to be redrawn in time for next year's election.

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company said that the 1983 year revenue includes sale of tax benefits of $365,000 which increased net income $178,000, or 11 cents a share.

title: Agency to Review Trafalgar's Bid
description: A bid by Trafalgar House, Britain's shipping and construction conglomerate, for the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company has been referred to Britain's Monopolies and Mergers Commission, which has the power to recommend that the bid be blocked.

title: Loehmann's Executive Promoted to President
description: Allan R. Bogner, who started at Loehmann's Inc. 20 years ago as an executive trainee, has been named president of the discount women's clothing store chain.

title: HOW THE 'INFORMATION POOR' GET POORER
description: To the Editor:

title: NASH GIVEN 100-YEAR MINIMUM TERM
description: Donald Nash, who was convicted of murdering a Federal witness and three CBS employees who tried to rescue her, was sentenced yesterday to four consecutive terms of life imprisonment.

title: IMASCO MAKES BID FOR CANADIAN TIRE
description: Imasco Ltd., the Montreal-based tobacco, retailing and fast-food group, yesterday made a formal cash and stock offer valued at $1.11 billion (Canadian) for the Canadian Tire Corporation, the Toronto-based hardware retail chain.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Q&A
description: Q. My son set a paper plate containing hot food on the top of a leather-topped coffee table. This left a large white solid circle that I cannot seem to remove, even though I have tried various cleaning methods. None of the local furniture stores have been able to help. Can you?

title: MAY CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 0.5%, LED BY GASOLINE AND NATURAL GAS
description: The Government reported today that consumer prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month and climbed at a rate of only 3 percent during the first five months of 1983.

title: Fate of Blues Still Undecided
description: The National Hockey League Board of Governors ended their first day of meetings today with the fate of the St. Louis Blues franchise still undecided. But the board banned the wearing of long pants in games next season.

title: NEW YORK AREA COSTS UP BY 0.7%
description: Higher prices for energy, apparel, and fruits and vegetables pushed up the Consumer Price Index for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area by a seasonally adjusted seven-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: 4 PREDECESSORS ASSAIL ADELMAN ON MISSILE IDEA
description: Four former directors of the arms control agency today strongly criticized a statement by the present director that the United States would abandon the MX missile if the Soviet Union gave up most of its medium and heavy land-based strategic missiles.

title: ECHLIN INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Some People Who Care Spruce Up the City
description: A vanload of women toured the South Bronx, Harlem and Washington Heights the other day as Mollie Parnis demonstrated that you don't have to live in a neighborhood to care about it.

title: AMERICAN SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
AMERICAN MEDICAL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Feb. 2.

title: DENVER ELECTION WIDENS CIRCLE OF HISPANIC LEADERS
description: Federico Pena's election Tuesday as Mayor of Denver added to a small but growing circle of powerful and highly visible Hispanic political leaders in the West and Southwest.

title: Article 251294 -- No Title
description: The Connecticut House of Representatives gave final approval tonight to a $3.6 billion state budget after voting $241 million in new and higher taxes to pay for it.

title: COASTLAND CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: CORNUCOPIA OF CRAFTS AT RHINEBECK
description: THERE'S nothing like a mammoth crafts fair to focus on the inventiveness, creativity and range of expression of contemporary American crafts people. And the Craft Fair at Rhinebeck, N.Y., which opens tomorrow on the Dutchess County Fairgrounds, is one of the nation's most prestigious showcases for the rich cornucopia of these handmade wares.

title: SENATE G.O.P. PLAYS CABLE TV CIRCUIT
description: A pop version of one of the Brandenburg Concertos plays in the background as the camera pans to portraits of John C. Calhoun, Henry Clay and Abraham Lincoln and moves to shots of the Capitol. ''This,'' the announcer says in a grave voice, ''is Conference Roundtable.''

title: Raymond H. Rieder, Founder Of Carling Yacht Racing Cup
description: Raymond Harrison Rieder, founder of yachting's Carling Cup and a retired executive of the Carling Brewing Company, died last Friday at Southern Ocean County Hospital in Stafford Township after a long battle against cancer.

title: MACKENZIE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GUARANTEED WAGE IS CRUX OF PIER ECONOMICS
description: Charles Garbelotto gets up at 5:15 each weekday morning, leaves his wife and son in their home in West Nyack, N.Y., and drives 40 miles to the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Trade Disturbs Mio
description: Commenting publicly for the first time since the Rangers sent him to Detroit last week, the goalie Ed Mio said yesterday that General Manager Craig Patrick told him in May that the Rangers did not intend to trade him. ''I'm bitter because I'm a very loyal person and teamoriented, and I wanted to stay with the Rangers,'' said Mio.

title: CBS IN STRUGGLE OVER NEWS BUDGET
description: A struggle is under way at CBS between corporate management and officials at CBS News over a proposed budget cut in the operations of the news division, according to sources at CBS News.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes after-tax gain of $343,000, or 6 cents a share, on sale of stock. c-Includes an after-tax gain of $81,000, or 1 cent a share, for settlement of litigation.

title: CONCEPT INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
CENTRAL SOYA CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting change.

title: NOTHING 'UNILATERAL' IN A MUTUAL FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: Holding of Unruh Upheld in Jersey
description: An appeals court ruled today that Howard B. Unruh, the killer of 13 people in Camden, should remain at the maximum-security hospital where he has been held since the slayings in 1949. He had sought a transfer to a less restrictive facility.

title: HYDRO OPTICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss after an approximate charge of $165,000 for start-up costs for a new contract.

title: Ex-Microsoft President To No. 2 Job at Metheus
description: James C. Towne, who resigned Monday as president and chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation, begins work today as president of the Metheus Corporation, a two-year-old computer-aided design and graphics company based in Hillsboro, Ore.

title: HERS
description: AGNES ROGERS ALLEN, that splendid lady whose prescient book ''Women Are Here to Stay'' appeared in 1949, once remarked: ''Sex is more fun to do than talk about.'' Agreed. But 50 years have elapsed and a lot more is now said and written. Consider geriatric sex, for one, a subject just beginning the slow creep from mind to paper. Since my credentials to brave the subject are limited to a husband and a Senior Citizen card that permits me to ride on subways at half fare, I did some research.

title: OIL-DATA PROGRAM TO RESUME
description: The Department of Energy, settling a suit filed earlier this month, has agreed to resume a program of reporting financial data from the nation's largest energy companies.

title: Fannie Mae Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association will offer $400 million in 12 percent securities on Monday.

title: ALL 8 ON PLANE DIE IN ALABAMA CRASH
description: A plane carrying six students who had been hired for summer jobs selling soap crashed in the night, killing all eight people aboard, the authorities said today.

title: TESTING OF ARMS HELD INADEQUATE
description: Major weapon systems costing billions of dollars are being deployed by the Defense Department without adequate testing, according to a report to be released Thursday by the General Accounting Office.

title: New Panty Hose Line
description: Hanes Hosiery has developed a new line of panty hose specifically for black women and has assigned the advertising to Mingo-Jones Advertising, specialists in that market. Plans call for a multimedia campaign in both broadcast and print that will break in early autumn in three major markets. Haynes estimated that black women buy $200 million worth of hosiery annually.

title: HARTMARX CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,765,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of real estate. Hartmarx Corp. was formerly Hart Schaffner & Marx. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect the exchange of three Hartmarx shares for each two shares of Hart Schaffner & Marx in April.

title: E.P.A. CHIEF URGES UNIFORM POLLUTION ASSESSMENT
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, the new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that ''many communities are gripped by something approaching panic'' over pollution problems. He called for a uniform Federal policy to assess and deal with risks to public health, safety and the environment.

title: SAMPSON SHOWS PRO TOUCH
description: With more than an hour remaining before Tuesday night's game against a National Basketball Association allstar team, the Atlantic Coast Conference all-stars enjoyed a cordial locker-room reunion.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFING
description: Of Watt and Truman

title: PACT REACHED IN LEGISLATURE ON TAX ABATEMENTS BY CITY
description: An agreement to extend and alter New York City's principal tax-incentive program for the rehabilitation of rundown housing was announced today by key legislators in both houses.

title: ON STRATEGIC PARITY
description: The following is adapted from an open letter to an American scientist, Sidney Drell, published in full in the current issue of Foreign Affairs.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article June 12 on states' abortion regulations failed to take account of various court injunctions.

title: COFFEE EXCHANGE SEEKS FUTURES ON A PRICE INDEX
description: The Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange requested permission yesterday from the Commodities Futures Trading Commission to trade futures contracts based on the CPI-W, a Government index that is used to set cost-of-living increases in industrial wages and Federal benefits payments.

title: Nissan Motor Plan
description: The Nissan Motor Company, which has been considering building a plant in Britain since January 1981, said it hopes to make a decision by the end of this year. The original plan called for Nissan to build 200,000 Datsuns a year by 1986.

title: Sharon Sues Time Magazine Over Article on Palestinians
description: Ariel Sharon, a member of the Israeli Cabinet, filed a $50 million libel suit against Time Magazine yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $91,260 from tax credit. c-Net loss

title: A.M.A. PLANS DRIVE TO COUNTER REPORTS OF DIOXIN AS HAZARD
description: The American Medical Association, charging that some news reports of the dangers of the toxic chemical dioxin have been overblown, voted yesterday to conduct a publicity campaign to alleviate public fears concerning the chemical compound.

title: MODERN HILARIONS CHANGE 'GISELLE'
description: NOT long ago at the Metropolitan Opera House, I saw American Ballet Theater in a performance of ''Giselle'' in which Hilarion was played by a young dancer who turned his character into a likable, goodlooking, bearded country lad. The portrayal was sincere, and the dancer had been well-coached in it. Yet it was wrong. These days, almost all portrayals of Hilarion are wrong, for dancers are being encouraged to sentimentalize the character.

title: SENATE KILLS FUNDS FOR BREEDER REACTOR IN PASSING ENERGY-WATER BILL
description: The Clinch River nuclear power plant, which has been at the center of an energy and environmental controversy for a decade, suffered a major setback today when the Senate passed an appropriation bill that specifically set aside no money for it.

title: Transit Authority Warned on Costs
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, reviewing the City Transit Authority's financial plan for the next four years, said the authority should take immediate steps to increase productivity and reduce operating costs to close a growing deficit.

title: Court Affirms Council Power Of Dissident Chicago Faction
description: The Illinois Supreme Court denied Mayor Harold Washington's request for an appeal today, letting stand a ruling that gave control of the Chicago city council to a majority of Democratic aldermen who oppose him.

title: GLASS EXHIBITION OF STUDENT WORKS
description: The first exhibition of glass sculpture in New York City by eight students in Kent State University's glass program can be seen at the Glassmasters Guild, 621 Avenue of the Americas (19th Street), through July 19.

title: Advertising; British Air Ads Create Quite a Stir
description: IF getting talked about was what British Airways had in mind when it spun a sparkling Manhattan into space, it certainly accomplished that.

title: Topics; True Romances, More or Less; Love and Law
description: In childhood, the words ''I love you'' are interchangeable with, ''How would you like a nice peanut butter and jelly sandwich?'' and, ''Get into bed and I'll read you a story.'' But as one becomes an adolescent, the words take on weight.

title: RUSSELL PAGE, THE MASTER OF THE SUPERLATIVE GARDEN
description: IT is beyond dispute that Russell Page, an Englishman now in his 77th year, has designed more gardens for more people in more parts of the world than anyone else in history. He has been doing it since 1928, and a short list of the countries in question would include Britain, France, Belgium, Germany, Italy, Spain, Portugal, Switzerland, Egypt and the United States, plus the West Indies. One of his smaller gardens is in the courtyard of the Frick Collection, on East 70th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues; you can see it from the street, and it is at its very best.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REBIRTH

title: NEW LAW GIVES S.I. DRIVERS A 25 DISCOUNT ON VERRAZANO
description: Governor Cuomo today signed legislation giving Staten Islanders a special 25-cent discount on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll. But across the Narrows in Brooklyn the measure got a resounding Bronx cheer.

title: OPEC Outlook On Oil Demand
description: An expected revival in the world economy later this year will not be strong enough to increase demand for OPEC oil, the organization's research director, Ahmed Said, forecast.

title: Timely Advice On Pinch-Hitting
description: Dave Philley, the man whom Rusty Staub is chasing for the major leagues' consecutive pinch-hit record, is rooting for the Met supersub. After all, two decades ago Philley taught Staub a few things about hitting.

title: SUBWAY DERAILMENTS LEAD TO CHECKING OF GUARDRAILS
description: Faulty or missing guardrails were responsible for at least 5 of the 10 New York City subway derailments so far this year, the Transit Authority said yesterday. It said trains would be slowed throughout the system to allow the guardrails and other parts of the track to be inspected.

Prices for government securities were depressed when the average yield on the seven-year Government notes auctioned yesterday reached 10.80 percent, much higher than expected. This caused yields on other issues to rise.

title: JARUZELSKI HOLDS SURPRISE MEETING WITH THE PONTIFF
description: Pope John Paul II held a surprise meeting here Wednesday night with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. The Government said it had been requested by officials of the Roman Catholic Church.

title: CABLESHARE INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Anderson Wins
description: Mark Anderson finished with 8,152 points to win The Athletics Congress national decathlon at U.C.L.A. today, and Jane Frederick scored 6,493 points to take the heptathlon.

title: PLANTINGS FOR STREET TREE PITS
description: A STREET tree's life is not ideal, especially if its home is a sidewalk in New York. The problems include compacted soil, lack of water, damage from trucks and vandals, inadequate root room and visits from inconsiderate dog walkers.

title: CHALLENGER CREW SNARES SATELLITE
description: The space shuttle Challenger engaged in a stately minuet with a satellite today, going round and round the world in a sequence of careful new celestial maneuvers.

title: New Times Beach Deadline
description: Federal officials today extended the deadline for applications from Times Beach residents seeking temporary housing to escape the dioxin contamination in their city.

title: 2 SLAIN U.S. JOURNALISTS FLOWN TO HONDURAN CAPITAL
description: The bodies of the two American journalists who were killed on Tuesday on a road near the Nicaraguan border were flown here today en route to the United States.

title: Scientific-Atlanta Shifts
description: Scientific-Atlanta Inc., a maker of telecommunications and microwave equipment, said yesterday that John Levergood had been named president and chief operating officer. Mr. Levergood has been senior vice president. As president, he succeeds Sidney Topol, who continues as chairman and chief executive. As chief operating officer, he succeeds Jack R. Kelly Jr., who resigned to join a venture capital firm in Atlanta.

title: Courageous Wins Twice
description: Courageous, the two-time America's Cup winner, today continued to dominate the preliminary trials to select a United States defender for the cup. Courageous convincingly won two of three races sailed today against Defender on Rhode Island Sound.

title: CHRIS-CRAFT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,961,000 for the quarter and $2,816,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income after a loss of $1,276,000 from discontinued operations. d-Including income of $444,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Topics; True Romances, More or Less; Fiddlehead and Firefly
description: Ferns respond to shade the way sunflowers respond to sun. While the helianthus tracks the Helios across the summer sky, ferns wait for a thick leaf canopy to spread before reappearing each year.

title: JUDGE IS URGED TO DISMISS WESTWAY BID FOR A LANDFILL PERMIT
description: Environmental and civic groups urged a Federal judge yesterday to dismiss the Westway project's application for a permit to create a landfill in the Hudson River.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $393,000. c-After a loss of $2.3 million on divestiture.

title: PRETORIA UPHOLDS RULING ON BLACKS
description: After several weeks of anxiety and indecision, the Government announced today that it would not seek legislation to overcome a ruling by South Africa's highest court that opens the possibility for black migrant workers to gain permanent rights as urban residents.

title: Dow Declines 1.71; Two Indexes Rise
description: Stock prices were little changed yesterday in accelerated trading. The best performers were auto and technology issues. The Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 prominent stocks, slipped 1.71 points, to 1,245.69. In the general market, though, advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored those that fell, 890 to 748.

title: Panel on Charter Urges End to At-Large Seats
