description: The Charter Revision Commission recommended yesterday that the atlarge City Council seats be eliminated, that a mayoral panel be created to redraw Council district lines and that community districts be allowed to fall under a population of 100,000.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE HEMINGWAY WOMEN. Those Who Loved Him, the Wives and Others. By Bernice Kert. 555 pages. Illustrated. Norton. $20.

title: COONEY IS MENDING AND STARTING OVER
description: Gerry Cooney was down for the count on Tuesday afternoon, and this time he did not seem to mind. In fact, he was doing his own counting. The rules and regulations of the New York University Medical Center do not provide for a standing eight count, and anyway, Cooney was not standing. He was lying and waiting for the anesthetic to do its work so that the middle finger on his left hand, and the hopes for becoming a heavyweight champion, could be repaired.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: LANDMARKS SERIES
description: Architectural Landmarks in the Metropolitan Area, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6868.

title: Ashe Is Improving
description: The condition of the former tennis star Arthur Ashe was upgraded to good yesterday, one day after he had undergone his second heartbypass operation in four years. Bernie Wisneski, a spokesman for St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, said that the 39-year-old Ashe might be able to leave the hospital in a week to 10 days. ... Willis Reed is scheduled to be released from an Omaha hospital today, but the former Knick, who coaches at Creighton University in Omaha and has been suffering from an intestinal inflammation, plans to keep a nurse in his life: He will marry Gale Kennedy, a nurse from Roslyn, L.I., in August.

title: Bank Money Accounts Up
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts have risen for the fifth consecutive week, The Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The Monitor's average, based on a weekly survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, rose to 8.28 percent in the latest reporting week, from 8.23 percent the week before and 8.22 percent two weeks earlier.

title: Doyle Dane Loses Hyatt Legal Services
description: Come Oct.31, the relationship between Doyle Dane Bernbach-New York and Hyatt Legal Services, Kansas City, Mo., that began in February 1981, will end, D.D.B. said, ''due to an irreconcilable difference of opinion with regard to agency profitability in servicing the account.''

title: A STRIKE IS AUTHORIZED
description: Negotiations for a new contract between the New York City Opera and its musicians have broken off with only five days left before orchestra rehearsals are to begin for the company's new season.

title: New Mexico Bond Issue Priced to Yield 6% to 8%
description: A $58.1 million revenue bond issue for the State of New Mexico was won in competitive bidding yesterday by the First Boston Corporation and priced to yield from 6 percent to 8 percent.

title: Group Guarantees $180 Million Loan
description: A $180 million construction loan note for Chicago's Presidential Towers housing project was guaranteed yesterday by the Municipal Bond Insurance Association, making it the largest note financing ever to be so insured.

title: CHIEF NEGOTIATORS FOR LABOR AND MANAGEMENT IN CONSOLIDATED EDISON STRIKE
description: Donald L. Miller, the chief negotiator for the Consolidated Edison Company during the strike, is a 51-year-old labor-relations expert who left his Harlem home at 16 to join the Army and later forged a career as a government official and business executive.

title: 8,000 More Cambodians Reach Refugee Camp
description: About 8,000 Cambodians, many suffering from malaria and other diseases, have arrived at a refugee camp on the Thai-Cambodian border in the last month, Thai military officials said today.

title: Military Analysis
description: Gen. Edward C. Meyer, who retires at the end of June after four years as Army Chief of Staff, is credited by his peers and his subordinates with instituting some of the most far-reaching changes in recent Army history.

title: Socal and Dravo Agree on Project
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said that the Dravo Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based engineering and construction compnay, had agreed to build the nation's first commercial-sized geothermal power plant.

title: JESSICA TANDY IN TALKS FOR 'MENAGERIE'
description: Jessica Tandy, who won the Tony Award as best actress last season for her performance in ''Foxfire,'' is in negotiations to star in a revival of Tennessee Williams's ''Glass Menagerie'' on Broadway next fall.

title: REAGAN AND O'NEILL SPAR ON TAX BILL
description: On the eve of consideration by the House of Representatives of a Democratic bill to limit the July 1 reduction in income taxes, President Reagan and Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. traded angry accusations today over whose policies were hurting the middle class.

title: Reggie Jackson Out
description: The bruised ribs that Reggie Jackson suffered when he ran into a fence while chasing a fly ball Tuesday night will keep him out of the California lineup for five or six games, the Angels said. ... Rick Reuschel, the veteran pitcher cut by the Yankees earlier this season, is trying out with the Chicago Cubs, the team with which he had spent most of his career.

title: CHIEF RESIGNS POST AT APPLIED DIGITAL
description: Robert A. Degan, president and chief executive of Applied Digital Data Systems, was named yesterday to become president of another high-technology company, the Data Switch Corporation, of Wilton, Conn. Applied Digital Data based, in Hauppauge, L.I., has been a subsidiary of the NCR Corporation since 1980.

title: DURALITH CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Mayor Is Replaced In Passaic Election
description: A former City Council President, Joseph Lipari, replaced Robert C. Hare as Mayor of Passaic today after winning a recall election on Tuesday.

title: Technology; A Pay Phone Of Your Own
description: WITH all the deregulation in the telephone business, the pay telephone has remained one of the last monopolies of the local telephone company. Now, however, time is running out on that monopoly, too.

title: 16 WIN U.S. HERITAGE AWARDS
description: Sixteen folk artisans and performers today were named winners of the 1983 National Heritage Fellowship awards of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Chemical Seeks to Lift Order on Supply System
description: Chemical Bank of New York filed a motion today to lift a restraining order that has prevented default by the Washington Public Power Supply System on $2.25 billion in bonds floated to finance construction of two nuclear power plants.

title: Texas Instruments
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating possible insider trading of Texas Instruments shares that took place earlier this month shortly before the company announced that it expected a big second-quarter loss, according to sources.

title: THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1983
description: The Economy

title: The U.N. Today; June 23, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Blair's Choice
description: It would have been a challenge. A talented young team. A bright young coach. And a free-wheeling owner with an open checkbook, Ted Turner.

title: Congress Votes Radiation Cleanup
description: The Senate voted today, 91 to 6, to provide $4 million to clean up radioactive wastes in Maywood and Wayne, N.J. The House has passed an identical measure, and Republicans on the Senate's Appropriations Committee said they did not expect a veto.

title: CUOMO SAYS STATE WILL STEP UP AIDS RESEARCH AND ASSIST VICTIMS
description: Governor Cuomo today announced a program to help find a cure for AIDS and to protect the rights of victims and their families.

title: Meeting Men, And Avoiding Them
description: Addressing a perennial complaint by New York women, William Novak has written ''The Great American Man Shortage and Other Roadblocks to Romance.'' But the other evening he offered this wisdom to matchmakers: ''Never introduce two people unless you're sure you're doing both of them a favor.''

title: QUANTECH ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Quotations of the Day
description: ''They are the only people in the City of New York who have to pay to go home.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 23, 1983
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: INTERFERON FOUND A TRANSPLANT AID
description: The natural antiviral agent interferon can prevent flareups of a common virus that sometimes causes severe complications in kidney transplant patients, according to a study reported in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: McDonnell Planes
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said China had agreed to buy two Super 80 jetliners, the first purchase by China of the company's aircraft. McDonnell Douglas did not release the purchase price, but the regular selling price of the jet is $22 million. The Super 80's will fly from Shanghai to Hong Kong and will also be used on routes in China.

title: FED BACKS ACQUISITION OF SEAFIRST
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday approved a proposal by the BankAmerica Corporation to acquire the ailing Seafirst Corporation for $400 million. The purchase would be the largest bank acquisition ever across state lines.

title: Fight Over, 24-1, Wins the Juvenile
description: Fight Over, a well-bred maiden who went off at odds of 24 to 1, scored a decisive upset yesterday in winning the $55,400 Juvenile Stakes for 2-year-olds at Belmont Park.

title: ANDERSON REFUSES TO ACT ON PORT AUTHORITY BILLS
description: The State Senate will not act this legislative session on bills to enact Governor Cuomo's agreement with Governor Kean of New Jersey to channel surplus funds of the Port Authority into regional development, Senator Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader, said today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Broadcasting Companies has promoted Lewis H. Erlicht to president of ABC Entertainment, succeeding Anthony D. Thomopoulos, who was recently named president of the ABC Broadcast Group.

title: CHIEF NEGOTIATORS FOR LABOR AND MANAGEMENT IN CONSOLIDATED EDISON STRKE
description: In 1960, in what would have been his last year at St. John's University Law School, Patrick J. Gallagher dropped out and entered the Democratic primary for a State Assembly seat from Queens.

title: BILLIE JEAN KING WINS IN 3 SETS
description: At 5-6 in the final set, Billie Jean King said she knew she was at the ''point of no return,'' perhaps never to play another singles match on the center court at Wimbledon.

title: Indonesian Projects
description: Major industrial construction projects recently shelved by Indonesia after the drop in world oil prices may be resumed when resources permit, the Development Planning Minister, Johannes Sumarlin, told an international energy conference today. Last month the Government announced it was ''rephasing'' four projects with a total cost of more than $5 billion.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 7 VIRGINIA COAL MINERS, INCLUDING A WOMAN, DIE IN SHAFT BLAST
description: The bodies of seven coal miners, including a woman and a foreman three days from retirement, were pulled from a 460-foot mine shaft today after an explosion that was considered Virginia's worst mine accident in 25 years.

title: INTRODUCTION TO VATICAN UNIT'S REPORT
description: Following is the introduction to ''Essential Elements in the Church's Teaching on Religious Life,'' a report by the Vatican's Sacred Congregation for Religious and Secular Institutes: (1.)

title: UDS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-After income from a minority interest of $3,000. c-After losses from minority interests of $3,000 and $5,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a loss on discontinued operations of $149,000 for the quarter and 6 months. d-After a loss from a minority interest of $1,000.

title: JURY SELECTION: ONE STATE'S RACIAL BIAS REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Watanabe Wins On Split Decision
description: Jiro Watanabe of Japan retained the World Boxing Association's junior-bantamweight championship tonight with a majority decision over Roberto Ramirez of Mexico.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-After tax credits of $1,224,000 for the quarter and $1,366,000 for the 9 months.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS ON U.S. POLICY IN AFRICA
description: Following are excerpts from the text of a speech tonight in San Francisco by Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, before the National Conference of Editorial Writers:

title: Cluett Plans Sale
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company, a New York-based apparel concern, said it would sell Boyd's, the last of its specialty store group, and said it had begun discussions with a group of investors interested in the eight Boyd's stores. Cluett said it would provide a reserve of six cents a share in the second quarter to cover combined costs of the disposal, the recent withdrawal from its Young Quinlan store in Minneapolis and the discontinuance of its Retail Stores division. The company said the operations did not project a near-term potential for reaching target levels of return on investment.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JUNE 24, 1983
description: International

title: Bush Begins a Trip to Europe To Explain U. S. Latin Policy
description: Vice President Bush left today for a two-week tour of Europe, where he will try to convince Governments there that the Reagan Administration is trying to promote democracy in Central America, ''imperfect as some of the systems are.''

title: Dollar Bonds Fall in London
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds fell by up to 3/8 of a point in quiet trading today, reflecting the trend in United States credit markets, dealers said.

title: Brazilian Debt Arrears Mount
description: Brazil is about $1.2 billion behind in payments to its private creditors, New York bankers said yesterday. The head of Brazil's central bank, Carlos Langoni, said last week that Brazil was $900 million in arrears.

title: U.S. STEEL MEETS ON IMPORT PLAN
description: David M. Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, met privately yesterday in New York with Ian MacGregor, chairman of the British Steel Corporation, to discuss U.S. Steel's controversial plan to import unfinished British steel.

title: Economic Scene; The Legacy Of Keynes
description: IN his ''Essays in Persuasion,'' John Maynard Keynes called himself ''a Cassandra who could never influence the course of events in time.'' Yet here we are at the 100th anniversary of his birth, and he has turned out to be the century's most influential economist - whether for good or evil or both.

title: Mrs. Hart Reappointed Arts Council Chairman
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday reappointed Kitty Carlisle Hart chairman of the New York State Council on the Arts. Mrs. Hart has served as chairman since 1976.

title: DAVID A. LEINBACH
description: David A. Leinbach, an international financial consultant and president of David A. Leinbach & Company of New York City, died of cancer Wednesday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He lived in Rye, N.Y., and was 48 years old.

title: A MIDEAST CROSSROADS
description: The fighting in Lebanon these days is essentially a battle between Yasir Arafat and Syria for control of the Palestinian armed forces.

title: Reagan Says Medicaid Rule Will Be Eased for Girl, 4
description: The parents of 4-year-old Julia Mikol, who have been battling to have Medicaid cover her care at home, were assured by President Reagan yesterday that the usual Medicaid rules will be waived.

title: STATE WILL BUILD A MAJOR PRISON IN SOUTH BRONX
description: New York State has selected an isolated site on the Harlem River in the Bronx for a new 1,000-cell maximum-security state prison, senior aides to Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch said tonight.

title: OFFICIAL URGES DISMISSAL OF 3 AT THREE MILE ISLAND
description: A member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, chastising his own agency for inept handling of the Three Mile Island case, said today that the three senior executives of the nuclear plant should be dismissed before an undamaged unit of the reactor was allowed to operate.

title: SOME SALVADOR PRISONERS, FRESH FROM JAIL, SEEKING EXIT VISAS
description: With her eyes starting to fill with tears, the 17-year-old pulled her hair down over her face. Her face was covered with sores, and she looked down at the floor as she told of spending nearly a year in a women's prison.

title: Elmore Accepts Knicks' Offer
description: The Knicks yesterday signed the Nets' free-agent center, Len Elmore, to an offer sheet, a move that almost certainly means Marvin Webster's five-year career with New York has come to an end.

title: POWERFUL COMMUNITY WITH DIPLOMATIC LICENSE
description: For the European Community, there has always been a recognition problem in the United States, even though it has had representation in Washington for almost 30 years.

title: Cadwell Davis Hires Bartley as President
description: Eugene F. Bartley, 37, is being brought over to Cadwell Davis Partners from Compton Communications as president. At Compton, he was a supervisor on the Procter & Gamble business.

title: Ex-Boxer Indicted
description: Bobby Halpern, a onetime heavyweight boxer from New York with a long criminal history, has been indicted in Westchester County on a charge of conspiring to murder a man suspected of raping the wife of one of Halpern's associates in Pelham Manor. The indictment, handed up Wednesday, names Halpern and four other men, including the woman's husband and a Pelham Manor police detective, Carmine Denisco.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
5-MINUTE OVERTIME IS VOTED BY N.H.L.
description: The National Hockey League's board of governors approved a five-minute sudden-death overtime period to settle tie games during the 1983-84 regular season, the league president, John Ziegler, announced today.

title: 'Berserk' Marine Is Shot After Wounding Another
description: A marine who went ''berserk'' began shooting wildly during target practice at a rifle range today, wounding one marine in the leg as others dove for cover, a spokesman for this base said.

title: PUBLISHING: WHERE BOOK BUYERS ARE
description: SOME statistics have come to light that provide insight into America's book-buying habits. The first of these, compiled by the Bureau of Industrial Economics of the Department of Commerce, shows that the New York metropolitan area is still the nation's major book market, with sales in 1981 estimated at $232 million. The runners-up are Los Angeles-Long Beach, with $148 million; Chicago, with $111 million, and San Francisco-Oakland, with $95 million. The next five most important markets are Philadelphia, Boston, Detroit, Long Island and Minneapolis-St. Paul.

title: Mavericks Keep Davis
description: Brad Davis, a point guard, ended speculation that he might enter the free agent market by signing a contract with the Dallas Mavericks. Davis will receive about $200,000 for next season.

title: Coming next fall, a song-and-dance Mike Doonesbury
description: GARRY TRUDEAU broke hearts across the country in January when he began a sabbatical from his ''Doonesbury'' comic strip, which ran in 723 newspapers and had 65 million daily readers. But his fans will be cheered by the news that ''Doonesbury'' is coming back - in the form of a Broadway musical. The singing-and-dancing ''Doonesbury,'' with book and lyrics by Mr. Trudeau and music by Elizabeth Swados, will go into rehearsal on Sept. 6 and will try out in Boston in October before its opening in New York, set for Nov. 10 at the Biltmore Theater. The production will be directed by Jacques Levy, who staged the Off Broadway productions ''America Hurrah'' and ''Scuba Duba.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: '' In purely practical terms, it is obviously easier for action to be taken by one House without submission to the President; but it is crystal clear from the records of the Convention, contemporaneous writings and debates, that the Framers ranked other values higher than efficiency.'' - Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, in the Supreme Court's decision declaring the so-called legislative veto unconstitutional. (B5:6.)

title: No Shortcuts
description: From the time he purchased his first racquet, for $2.99 when he was 13 years old, Jose Rodriguez figured that tennis could be the way out of his East New York, Brooklyn, neighborhood and into college. But the 17-year-old graduating senior from Bushwick High School knows that tennis is no shortcut, not when he has to walk an hour and a half each day to practice at the Starrett City Tennis Academy.

title: LIMIT STUDENT LOANS
description: I just mailed a check for $60 to a bank in California. By October 1992, I will have repaid -with interest - federally guaranteed student loans totaling $5,000 that helped my family finance my bachelor's degree from one of the most expensive private universities in the country.

title: DELOREAN GRANTED DELAY IN HIS TRIAL
description: John Z. DeLorean today was granted a two-month postponement of his trial on Federal charges that he promoted a scheme to smuggle $24 million in cocaine.

title: MERIT PAY AT THE TOP
description: To the Editor:

title: STABILIZED RENTS IN CITY TO GO UP BY 4, 7 AND 10%
description: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board, in a raucous five-hour meeting that was twice stopped by shouting and sign-waving demonstrators, yesterday approved basic increases of 4, 7 and 10 percent for the 300,000 rent-stabilized apartments whose leases expire in the 12 months starting Oct. 1.

title: Brazilian tradition in modern setting
description: LONG a favorite of the Brazilian community in New York, the Brazilian Pavilion has been attracting an even larger following since it moved into its new and handsome modern quarters on 52d Street, just east of Second Avenue, two years ago. The dining rooms are festive and stylish, with brick, natural wood and white walls, leafy plants and green-and-white-glass lampshades. Perhaps the setting has reinspired the kitchen, for it is much improved since it was given a one-star rating in 1979. Two stars are in order now, especially for the restaurant's lusty and savory renditions of traditional Brazilian fare.

title: Manville Gets Another Delay
description: The Manville Corporation, which went to a Federal bankruptcy court last August to seek protection from thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits, was given 30 more days to come up with a reorganization plan.

title: A Lesser Eclipse
description: It's nothing to get out of bed for, the Amateur Observers Society seems to be saying, but if you're still on your way home - or getting ready to go fishing - you could see an eclipse of one-third of the moon tomorrow beginning at 3:14 and peaking at 4:22 A.M.

title: EMERGENCY PLAN FOR ATOM PLANT FOUND DEFICIENT
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency said yesterday that it had found major flaws in the emergency evacation plan submitted by the Long Island Lighting Company for its nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: UNVEILING OF KENNEDY TAPES ADDS NO REVELATIONS
description: Tapes and transcripts of some of President Kennedy's White House meetings and telephone conversations made public today add a footnote to history but contain no important revelations.

title: AN ILL-CONCEIVED 'CAP' ON CARE FOR THE DYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Lynch Names Banking Division Head
description: Another signpost in the changing world of financial services: Merrill Lynch & Company has formed a banking division within its Merrill Lynch Capital Markets organization. J. Arthur Urciuoli, who has been at Merrill Lynch for 15 years, was named chairman.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ITALIAN FOLK MUSIC REVIVED

title: MARTINS TO RETIRE FROM DANCING
description: Peter Martins, who was named balletmaster in chief of the New York City Ballet jointly with Jerome Robbins in March, announced yesterday that he would retire as a dancer this fall.

title: SHUTTLE FLIGHT TERMED 'NEARLY PERFECT MISSION'
description: Mission officials Thursday hailed the flight of the space shuttle Challenger as an unqualified success, with the astronauts accomplishing all their major objectives, the launching of two communications satellites and the smooth satelliteretrieval exercise, with ease and alacrity.

title: DANCE: BALLETS ABOUT PASSION
description: RECENT programs by American Ballet Theater and the New York City Ballet have featured ballets about passion. For instance, Ballet Theater's ''Don Quixote'' was decidedly hot-blooded on Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House when Martine van Hamel and Patrick Bissell took over the roles of Kitri and Basil and gave performances that were broad in scale and grand in manner.

title: MAJOR LAWS WITH VETO PROVISIONS
description: War Powers Resolution of 1973. Under this landmark legislation, Congress could force a President to remove American forces engaged in hostilities in other countries.

title: UNLIKELY SOVIET DESIRE TO QUIT AFGHANISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: The Howe Case
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodgers relief pitcher, will be released from a drug recovery center today but will not be allowed to rejoin his team immediately. Dodger officials will meet with representatives of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn next Monday to discuss possible disciplinary action against Howe.

title: VOLUME ALSO OFF
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in slower trading. Brokers attributed the weakness to renewed concern over the possibility of an increase in interest rates.

title: Police Stop 800 In Subway Sweep
description: The Transit Authority police stopped more than 800 people in their sweep of Manhattan subway trains and stations last night, a Transit Authority police spokesman said.

title: A.T.& T. Billing
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved a limited experiment by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company involving new billing options for interstate long-distance telephone calls.

title: REAGAN URGES END TO POLISH TENSION
description: President Reagan urged the Polish Government today to ''translate the restraint'' shown during Pope John Paul II's visit into a policy of ''reconciliation rather than confrontation with the Polish people.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM SUPREME COURT DECISION ON LEGISLATIVE VETOES
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today that the legislative veto is unconstitutional. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger wrote the majority opinion. From Majority Opinion By Chief Justice Burger

title: TRUCKERS IN CHILE BEGIN A WALKOUT
description: Thousands of truckers went on strike today in a protest against the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, but most other Chileans appeared to have ignored opposition calls for a national strike.

title: Imasco's Offer
description: Imasco Ltd.'s latest offer for the Canadian Tire Corporation will have to be increased to have a chance of success, analysts say.

title: Music of Bolivia
description: The Alternative Museum, at 17 White Street in TriBeCa, will present music of Bolivia performed by Grupo Aymara tonight and tomorrow night at 8.

title: Israeli Doctors' Strike Closes More Wards
description: The strike by Israel's doctors resulted in the closing of more hospital wards today, increasing pressure on Government negotiators trying to end a four-month-old wage dispute.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After gains on sales of investments of $198,000 for the quarter and $289,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Nuclear Plant Contract Case
description: Five of the nation's largest electrical contracting companies, and six executives of those companies, pleaded not guilty in Federal court today to charges of bid rigging in connection with electrical contracts for nuclear power plants in the state of Washington and Indiana.

title: ASIAN TROUPE MOVES 'YELLOW FEVER' UPTOWN
description: He wears a trenchcoat, of course, and a felt hat whose brim casts his face in shadow. He says things like ''I'd seen her kind before'' and ''The pieces were beginning to fall into place.'' He is a private eye, and making deductions is his game; play-by-play announcements like ''It was obvious MacKenzie was up to no good,'' are part of his modus operandi.

title: Beatrice Foods Net Up
description: The Beatrice Foods Company said yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter ended May 31 increased 5.6 percent, to $75.7 million, or 72 cents a share, from the year-earlier period.

title: Bridge: Odd Hands Can Test Skill Of Defenders on Discards
description: Highly freakish hands, of the type regularly encountered by commuter players who deal goulash-style, tend to be exciting to bid but a little dull to play. However, there are exceptions, and an example is the diagramed deal, played in a recent team practice event in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: ARAFAT SAYS SYRIA BLOCKS SUPPLIES TO ALL HIS GUERRILLAS IN LEBANON
description: Yasir Arafat said today that Syrian troops were choking off all supplies to his guerrilla supporters in Lebanon and that Syria's assertions to the contrary were ''big, big lies.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Albany Savings Bank, Albany, has elected Gilbert O. Robert chairman and chief executive officer.

title: JAPAN'S NONEDUCATION
description: In casting about for solutions to the problems raised by the National Commission on Excellence in Education, Americans will have to forego one of their favorite pastimes: looking to the Japanese. Although Japanese students demonstrate superiority in certain elementary and secondary school tests, their advantage slips drastically at the university level. It's something of a secret in the West, but a wide-open truth here that Japanese universities are a disgrace.

title: SATURN MOON MAY HOLD CLUES ON LIFE'S CHEMICAL EVOLUTION
description: Scientists are beginning to suspect that clues to the evolution of the chemistry of life will be found in the soil of Saturn's giant moon, Titan.

title: NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss The company said that the latest fourth quarter results included a $2.8 million after-tax gain resulting from the settlement of an insurance claim originating in 1978 and results of operations of Data Terminal Systems since the March 8 acquisition date.

title: Con Ed Employees Charge Lockout
description: Members of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers said yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company locked them out of their jobs on Staten Island yesterday in a new contract dispute. Management employees of the company took over operations of its Staten Island facilities.

title: LA PASIONARIA AT 87: JUST EMBERS OF PASSION REMAIN
description: In some ways, perhaps, it is best not to interrogate a legend too closely. The answers are apt to be more mundane than mythic. They kill colorful snatches of detail in the biographies.

title: Tribute to Rodgers
description: FM, the Columbia University radio station, at 89.9 on the dial, will begin a 50-hour tribute Sunday at 9 P.M. to the music of Richard Rodgers, in honor of the composer's 81st birthday.

title: BEL CANTO OPERA TURNS TO A FANTASY PLAY ON CHINA
description: The Bel Canto Opera, which specializes in reviving offbeat operatic fare, and which is accustomed to critical praise for it, is about to present a work that is not an opera at all. It is ''Tao Yuan,'' a fantasy play in English by Sung Fu Yuan combining music and dance. It takes off from an ancient Chinese legend that resembles the tale of Shangri-La in James Hilton's ''Lost Horizon.''

title: Reward Offered In Yeshiva Attack
description: Mayor Koch went to Yeshiva University yesterday and offered a $10,000 reward for the capture and conviction of the gunmen who wounded three students in an attack on a restaurant at the edge of the Washington Heights campus.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Article 253836 -- No Title
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today signed a $3.6 billion state budget and a $241 million package of new and higher taxes, which received final approval by the General Assembly Wednesday night.

title: REP. DINGELL CITES DATA DAMAGING TO CITICORP
description: Representative John D. Dingell said today that Citicorp documents recently obtained by his staff had lent ''substantial additional weight'' to accusations that the bank and its lawyers failed to adequately disclose information about the legality of some currency transactions in the 1970's.

title: MORE U.S.-EUROPE FARM TALKS PLANNED
description: Trade representatives of the United States and the European Common Market agreed today to another round of talks on the divisive problem of subsidizing agricultural exports.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Different Memorial

title: Exxon Suing Gas Pipeline
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest producer of natural gas, has gone to court to try to make the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation fulfill 80 contracts for the purchase of natural gas.

title: POPE ORDERS STUDY OF DROP IN RELIGIOUS ORDERS IN U.S.
description: Pope John Paul II named three American prelates yesterday to direct a sweeping review of Roman Catholic religious orders in the United States that will focus on studying the reasons behind a sharp drop in the number of men and women in the orders.

title: WHO'S PLAYING WHAT, WHEN AND WHERE
description: Today

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
41 Are Slightly Injured In Boston Subway Crash
description: Two crowded rapid transit trolleys collided underground in rush hour today, slightly injuring 41 passengers and stopping some service for two and a half hours.

title: MX DEPLOYMENT LINKED TO SOVIET STANCE
description: Acting Secretary of State Kenneth W. Dam indicated today that the Administration might deploy the MX missile even if Moscow agreed to drastic reductions in its strategic nuclear arms. But he added that deployment depended on ''what the Soviets want to negotiate about.''

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics

title: AIDS FOUNDATION IS SET UP IN CITY TO FIND OUT MORE ABOUT AILMENT
description: A private medical foundation has been established in New York City to undertake independent research into the fatal disorder called acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: Public Service Award
description: The public service advertising campaign judged the best of this year by an independent panel will get $10,000 in prizes donated by the Interpublic Group of Companies, Philip H. Geier Jr., its chairman, said yesterday. The award, which will help mark World Communications Year 83, will be divided equally between the creative person or people and the organization that is its subject.

title: COMPUTERS NOW LIST BRIDAL GIFTS
description: One of the cliches of weddings has long been the bride who gets seven blenders as gifts and has to chase all over town returning six. That nuisance may soon be licked. The solution, like the answer to so many of today's problems, lies in the computer. These days, computers are turning up in a new location: the office of a department store's bridal registry.

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for year to March 31.
Kimball Eliminated in Diving
description: The opening ceremonies will not be held until Friday, but there was preliminary competition Wednesday in the National Sports Festival, and it went mostly according to form.

title: U.S. TRACK TEAM FACES TEST
description: In a meet within a meet, the United States track and field team will face East Germany in a dual showdown Saturday and Sunday at Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: WESTERN STEER-MON 'N' POPS reports earnings for qtr to May 20.
ACCORD ON MEDICAID COSTS REACHED IN ALBANY
description: Governor Cuomo and the legislative leaders agreed today on a plan to help New York City and the 57 counties outside the city deal with the rapidly rising costs of Medicaid.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Merger Talks Again For Maryland Cup
description: The Maryland Cup Corporation said yesterday that once again it was discussing its acquisition by a major corporation. Unlike several times in the past, however, the Owings Mills, Md., company did not describe the talks as ''preliminary.''

title: JURY SELECTION: ONE STATE'S RACIAL BIAS REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Boxing Squabbles
description: The intramural squabbling and resulting confusion in the world of boxing continue as usual. The World Boxing Council has notified Larry Holmes that he must sign to fight the organization's mandatory challenger, Greg Page, or surrender his heavyweight title.

title: A COOL DRESS CHECKS IN
description: Fashionable women on New York City's streets have been endorsing checks as well as coat dresses during the first days of summer.

title: GODFREY CO reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the New York Philharmonic's free Parks Concerts gave an incorrect date for the one in Battery Park. It is Aug. 25, at 12:30 P.M.

title: Deschin Services Scheduled
description: Memorial services for Jacob Deschin, who died Sunday, will be held on Thursday at 6 P.M. in the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, between 94th and 95th Streets. Mr. Deschin was a leading writer on photography and a former camera editor of The New York Times. He was 83 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: E.P.A. WILL EASE SANCTIONS ON CLEAN AIR ACT VIOLATORS
description: William D. Ruckelshaus, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, announced today that his agency would not impose economic sanctions on communities that failed to meet the air quality standards of the Clean Air Act.

title: A Fair Blow at Foul Districting
description: If any Congressional redistricting plan deserved the back of the Supreme Court's hand, it was the New Jersey Legislature's. This shameless Democratic gerrymander brought new elegance to the dubious art of partisan line drawing. It gave Democrats a lopsided 9-to-5 advantage in a state that is narrowly divided politically. Its only claim to virtue lay in an arithmetic deviation of less than 1 percent from the one-person, one-vote ideal.

title: INVEST IN SOUTH AFRICA...
description: The question of what to do about South Africa's race policies is still with us. A host of organizations have had to decide whether to disinvest, stop new investments or stop trading with a country that is so well known for apartheid, jailings, beatings, murder and other racially derived practices. What few of these organizations recognize is that South Africa's blacks and the people of mixed race known as coloreds are better off, and so are Americans, if American businesses remain in that country than if they pull out.

title: I.B.M. System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it is introducing the Series/One videotex system, which links computers to low-cost displays using standard telephone lines. It said text and graphic information, including travel schedules, messages, and sales and merchandising information can be transmitted to videotex terminals. First shipments of the system, which costs $12,500, will begin in next year's second quarter.

title: Elston Howard's Ring Recovered
description: A 1977 World Series ring that was stolen two years ago from the Teaneck, N.J., home of Elston Howard, the late Yankee catcher and coach, was discovered on the finger of a man arrested early yesterday on car-theft charges, the police said.

title: Message About Missiles Takes A Novel Form
description: Pull toys and politics seem an unlikely pairing, but Red Grooms saw fit to join them in his sculpture, ''Nuclear Nuts.'' And on Wednesday night the brightly painted wooden work fetched $3,500 at the annual United Jewish Appeal auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: Books of The Times
description: MEN AT ARMS. By John Crosby. 221 pages. Stein & Day. $14.95 MURDER IN THE SMITHSONIAN. By Margaret Truman. 298 pages. Arbor House. $14.95

title: THE BIAS AGAINST SPRINTING
description: Thoroughbreds are called to the post about 70,000 times a year in North America. In more than 45,000 of these races, they are asked to sprint - to run less than a mile. But when it comes time for the tony races, rich purses and championship titles, sprinters are not taken seriously.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Maize Products Co., Stamford, Conn., said it had purchased the remaining 50 percent interest in a high-fructose joint venture operation in Decatur, Ala., from Amalgamated Sugar Co. for an undisclosed amount.

title: Required Reading; Helping Education
description: Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island, in an address to an education conference sponsored by George Mason University, June 22:

title: Comsat's Plans
description: The chairman of the Communications Satellite Corporation, Joseph Charyk, said Comsat was continuing talks with a number of companies about possible ventures involving its proposed direct-broadcast satellite television business. But he told the National Press Club that no decisions had been reached. Mr. Charyk made the statement in response to a question on recent reports that Comsat had been talking with United Satellite Communications Inc., which was begun by the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the General Instrument Corporation and others.

title: MOREHOUSE INDUS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
WESTCHESTER FIRE-BUFFS FAIR
description: The fire bells will be sounding tomorrow at Croton Point Park in Westchester. Fire fighters will be springing into action, responding with more than 150 pieces of apparatus. But it will not be to put something out so much as to put something on - the 14th Fairchester Antique Fire Apparatus Show and Muster.

title: Trying to Track A Record in Flux
description: For 56 years, Walter Johnson held the major league career strikeout record. Then Nolan Ryan broke it. Then Steve Carlton broke Ryan's record.

title: INTERSTATE UNIFORM SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
LILLY INDUSTRIAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
OLYMPICS HARBINGER AND SPECIALS FOR A FUND DRIVE
description: ABC SPORTS will be covering the National Sports Festival this weekend and next from Colorado Springs. The event attracts attention as a proving ground for about 2,700 athletes who hope to participate in next year's Olympics. The competitors are grouped in regional categories - East, Middle West, South and West - and 33 official Olympics sports are represented. The United States men's ice hockey and women's field hockey teams are determined at this festival.

title: SPOTLIGHT FOLLOWS YANKEES' COACHES
description: In nine years as a major league manager in San Diego, Boston and Texas, Don Zimmer learned the kind of rough treatment a manager can receive. Now, in his first year as a coach with the Yankees, he is with a club whose coaches can live dangerously, too.

title: Lebanon Aide Disputes Beirut Massacre Report
description: A senior Lebanese official has said a document issued this week on the Beirut massacre last September was an ''unauthorized first draft,'' one that did not represent the final results of the Government's inquiry into the slayings.

title: Cam Fella In Dead Heat
description: Cam Fella, the 1-9 favorite, and Walt Hanover, an 80-1 shot, finished in a dead heat tonight in the third leg of the Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll Pacing Series at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: CONGRESS ADOPTS 1984 BUDGET PLAN
description: Over the strenuous objections of President Reagan, both houses of Congress today approved a compromise 1984 Federal budget that mandates higher taxes, lower military spending and more domestic spending than the Administration requested.

title: SWISS TO PAY $5,250,000 FOR STRAVINSKY ARCHIVE
description: A private Swiss foundation has agreed to pay $5.25 million for the Igor Stravinsky archive of manuscripts and letters. The bid topped previous offers that would have kept the archive either at the New York Public Library or the Pierpont Morgan Library. Now the Russian-American composer's collection is destined to leave the United States within two months for Switzerland.

title: ART: ARCHITECTURE, REAL AND IMAGINED, IN PRINTS
description: ONE way or another, architecture is always getting into art. It serves either as a backdrop or accent for another subject, such as the delightfully Michael Gravesish palazzos and loggias in the religious scenes of Fra Angelico; or as a subject in itself - for example, the stern barns and factories painted by Charles Sheeler. The fact is that the built environment is as compelling a subject for artists as the human figure or landscape, and never more so than now, when realism is staging such a smash return engagement. By way of evidence, the Pratt Graphics Center, 160 Lexington Avenue, at 30th Street, is presenting ''Architecture in Contemporary Prints,'' a show of work done since 1970 by some 75 printmakers, including Christo, Roy Lichtenstein, Claes Oldenburg, Philip Pearlstein and Robert Rauschenberg .

title: PLAYERS' RESENTMENT DEEPENS
description: Player resentment against John McEnroe's behavior on the court surfaced more strongly today during the Wimbledon championships.

title: Amid Racket of the Present, An Echo of the Past
description: Daily, the pounding of pile drivers punctuates public hearings and other business at City Hall. It reverberates from the south tip of City Hall Park, where the M.T.A. is building a power substation.

title: Money Fund Assets Slump
description: After weeks of modest declines, assets of money market mutual funds fell a sharp $1.7 billion last week, to $166.9 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: PONTIFF MEETS WITH WALESA, THEN FLIES BACK TO VATICAN
description: Pope John Paul II met privately at a remote mountain retreat today with Lech Walesa, the founder of the Solidarity independent union, and then returned to Rome with a prayer for the triumph of good over evil in his native Poland.

title: Twin Phyfes, twin owners
description: TWIN Duncan Phyfe card tables from twin owners are expected to establish a record auction price for Federal furniture - possibly for American furniture of any period - when they come up for bidding in a sale to be held next Thursday and Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: AFTER A WEEK, MIXED REVIEW FOR BUS LANE ON 5TH
description: The special new bus lane on Fifth Avenue has been a success, or a failure, or a good idea that needs more time, depending on whether you talk to bus drivers, merchants, police officers or city traffic officials.

title: DANCE: ROD RODGERS UNIT
description: ROD RODGERS has been creating dances for 19 years now. The opening and closing pieces on a program by his company Saturday at the Symphony Space suggest why he has survived so long in the difficult business of dance.

title: U.S. Deficit Wider in May
description: The Federal budget deficit widened to a record $29.29 billion in May, the Treasury Department said today in its monthly budget statement.

title: Electronic Mail Completes Issue
description: The Electronic Mail Corporation of America said it had completed a $15 million zero-coupon Eurobond financing and the simultaneous repurchase of 400,000 shares of its common stock.

title: Jailed Protesters on Coast In Standoff With Judge
description: More than 900 antinuclear protesters, opposed to the terms for their release, challenged a judge today to come to them if he wants to arraign them.

title: Celeron Purchase
description: The Celeron Corporation unit of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it had acquired the All American Pipeline Company, taking over that company's plans to build a 1,200-mile oil pipeline.

title: Hospital Bond Priced To Yield 5.5% to 10%
description: A $26 million refunding revenue bond for the Jane Phillips Memorial Hospital in Bartlesville, Okla., was tentatively priced by Stifel, Nicolaus & Company yesterday to yield between 5.5 percent and 10 percent.

title: Guv'ner, Can You Spare a Dime?
description: If Governor Cuomo is going to pay his political debts to Staten Island with token handouts, let New Yorkers understand the source of his generosity. Giving a discount on Verrazano Bridge tolls is to levy a nuisance tax on every other toll and transit fare. It's a political payoff without redeeming social or economic value.

title: SENATE ROLL-CALL ON BUDGET VOTE
description: Following is the roll-call by which the Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a compromise budget plan. Those not listed did not vote.

title: Casino Unions Are Different
description: New Jersey's power to police its gambling casinos was dealt a serious blow recently by a 2 to 1 decision of the Third Circuit Court. The judges held that the Casino Control Commission had no authority over labor unions because their regulation is the exclusive province of the Federal Government.

title: NEW FEDERAL RENT RULES WILL HAVE A WIDE IMPACT
description: Robert C. Rosenberg, president of the Grenadier Realty Corporation, tells of a letter he received last fall from a bitter tenant in a federally subsidized building that Grenadier manages in Brooklyn.

title: METS WIN THIRD STRAIGHT
description: The Mets, who recently had trouble beating anybody, beat the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday for the third straight time and for the fourth time in an unusual six-game series at Shea Stadium.

title: Alfonso J. Cervantes; Ex-Mayor of St. Louis
description: Alfonso J. Cervantes, the flamboyant and often controversial Mayor of St. Louis from 1965 to 1973, died today. He was 62 years old.

title: ROLL-CALL OF HOUSE VOTE ON A LIMIT FOR INCOME TAX REDUCTION
description: Here is the roll-call vote of 229 to 191 by which the House of Representatives today voted approval of a $720 ceiling on the income tax cut scheduled for July 1. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the ceiling. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 229 Democrats and 0 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 29 Democrats and 162 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, yes; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, no.

title: SHARP SHIFTS IN CONGRESS PRACTICES AND LEGISLATIVE CONFLICT PREDICTED
description: Congressional supporters and opponents of the legislative veto agreed today that the Supreme Court decision would create conflict on Capitol Hill and significantly alter the way Congress conducts its business.

title: On Sick Leave
description: Jimmy White, a fight manager now in his 70's who was a regular around Madison Square Garden and St. Nicholas Arena a couple of decades ago, lives down yonder in New Orleans, where he has come up with a fair junior welterweight named Billy Parks. A few weeks ago White returned to New York to arrange a fight for Parks at the Garden, and the old manager was successful.

title: BAKER AND STOCKMAN REPORT RECEIVING '80 CARTER MATERIAL
description: Two senior Reagan Administration officials, responding to a Congressional inquiry, confirmed today that they received and used one of President Carter's political briefing books in the 1980 Presidential campaign.

title: WEDDINGS MARCH TO NEW TUNES
description: When Laurie Frassinelli gets married tomorrow evening in Princeton, N.J., she will walk down the aisle to the sound of Baroque music with ornate trills and stately rhythms. After she and Gary Solon have exchanged their wedding vows, they will march out to an elegant theme by George Frederick Handel.

title: PUBLIC RADIO TO GET AID
description: The federally financed Corporation for Public Broadcasting said today it would provide the financial support necessary to maintain ''essential programs'' of the ailing National Public Radio.

title: PANEL EXPECTED TO DENY TAX CREDIT TO BUSINESSES
description: The State Job Incentive Board plans to reject scores of applications for tax credits for businesses that say they are creating jobs, according to an agenda for a board meeting.

title: A GARDEN WALK IN THE CITY WITH FLOWERS AT THEIR BEST
description: ROSES are everywhere right now. Some have extravagant fragrances that fill the air, while others have barely a scent. Their petals come in every imaginable hue of red, pink, white and yellow. And flowering along with them right now are many of summer's finest blooms: marigolds, daisies, sweet alyssums, geraniums, impatiens, daylilies, astilbes and lilies.

title: 'ANGELS,' FROM FASSBINDER PLAY
description: ANYONE interested in the kind of theater in which the late Rainer Werner Fassbinder worked might want to make an effort to see ''Shadow of Angels'' (''Schatten der Engel''), which opens today at the Bleecker Street Cinema. The 1976 German film, directed by Daniel Schmid, is based on a Fassbinder play, adapted by Mr. Schmid and Mr. Fassbinder, who also plays a small role in it.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: THE music of four of the most celebrated figures in the history of jazz - two of the past and two of the present - will be heard in this opening weekend of the Kool Jazz Festival.

title: In and Out of Office Without Being Elected
description: Never having won actual election to the City Council, Edward C. Wallace gave up his Council seat at 12:01 A.M. yesterday. At a party on Central Park West, he displayed some old but unused campaign posters, telling friends he still hoped to run for some office, someday.

title: ...NO, INSTEAD DIVEST
description: Why should American universities divest from companies that do business in South Africa? The most powerful reason is the character of the South African regime: No government since Nazi Germany has been so infected with an official ideology of racial supremacy.

title: Juggling Generals
description: Though their season is nearing its end, the Generals continue to make changes in their player roster. The placing of Eric Johnson, a safety, on waivers this week was their 80th roster change of the year.

title: New C.B.O.E Index Options
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange will begin trading next Friday in options on the Standard & Poor's 500 market index that will be settled on a cash basis, rather than by the delivery and receipt of futures contracts, the exchange announced yesterday.

title: FULLER, H. B., CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $897,000 from the sale of undeveloped land.

title: Blind Woman Dies In Fall on the IND
description: A 56-year-old blind woman from Brooklyn was fatally injured shortly after 9 A.M. yesterday when she fell between two subway cars as she was attempting to board an IND train at West Fourth Street in Manhattan, the Transit Authority police said.

title: 65 by Beck Leads by 1
description: Chip Beck one-putted 10 times, shot a 7-under-par 65 and took a 1-stroke lead over Larry Nelson in today's first round of the $400,000 Danny Thomas Memphis Classic.

title: Director talks about his 'Survivors'
description: MICHAEL RITCHIE, who directed ''The Survivors'' (playing at Loews State, Tower East and other theaters), is what my grandmother used to refer to as ''a long drink of water,'' but even in the days when his legs and his pants were a whole lot shorter, he was a movie buff.

title: MCENROE ADVANCES AS TEMPERS FLARE
description: The mood turned sour and sassy at Wimbledon today, and once again John McEnroe was in the middle of a storm.

title: Smith Barney Fills Key Brokerage Post
description: George A. Vonder Linden was elected yesterday as president and chief operating officer of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the investment banking and brokerage subsidiary of Smith Barney Inc.

title: Fedders Hearing Set
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, chairman of a Congressional subcommittee that oversees the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced today that he would hold hearings next Tuesday on the involvement of John M. Fedders with the Southland Corporation. Mr. Fedders, head of the S.E.C.'s enforcement division, is the subject of a Federal grand jury investigation into his role in an purported bribery scheme involving Southland and a top company executive. Before joining the commission, Mr. Fedders served as an outside counsel to Southland.

title: WARY TRADERS LET RATES RISE
description: Prices of Government securities declined slightly and yields rose in moderate trading yesterday as lingering uncertainty about Federal Reserve policy continued to make investors reluctant to buy.

title: CHAD SAYS REBELS ARE RAIDING CITY IN NORTH WITH LIBYAN AID
description: Chad said today that 3,500 or more Libyanbacked rebel troops had attacked its northern city of Faya-Largeau but that its garrison was still in control despite Libyan air support for the attacking force.

title: MOVIE SYSTEMS (CO) reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Volcker Plan to Curb Bank Mergers
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, citing ''dangers to the financial system,'' has sent to Congress a proposal for legislation to slow the blending of banks and other types of businesses.

title: Liberty Wins 2 of 3 In Trials
description: Liberty sprang to life in the first moderate air of the preliminary trials for the selection of the defender for the America's Cup, beating Defender in two out of three races today on Rhode Island Sound.

title: HIGH TIME FOR SPAIN TO RECOGNIZE ISRAEL
description: To the Editor:

title: Pillsbury's Net Advances 36%
description: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that net income rose 36 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, ended May 31, to a record $53.5 million, or $2.46 a share.

title: ART: SUMMERTIME DISCOVERIES AT THE GALLERIES
description: THE summer hang - so often spoken of in the art world at this season - is not, as might be supposed, an archaic form of capital punishment. It is a device by which dealers' galleries give a limited exposure to this artist or that and wait to see what comes of it.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SUMMERTIME and the partying is easy. If, of course, the weather is appropriately balmy and the festivities are held out of doors. At least two annual events this week took advantage of the year's longest days to gather groups of people in the early evening light.

title: Vivitar-Omega
description: The Vivitar Corporation said its board had approved the acquisition of Omega Northwest Inc., a microcomputer concern based in Bellevue, Wash.

title: JERSEY'S ASSEMBLY APPROVES DEATH-BY-INJECTION MEASURE
description: After more than an hour of emotional debate, the New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative approval today to lethal injections as the method of carrying out the death penalty.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HOT WEEKEND IN CLUBS AWAITS DROVES OF FANS
description: THE Kool Festival comes but once a year, and every year it does a bang-up job of focusing attention on jazz. At its best, it provides a summary of the preceding year's jazz life - its accomplishments, its important trends, its explorations of the past, its popular and critical successes. Without this day-in, day-out jazz life, the Kool Festival probably wouldn't exist, and in New York City, the jazz life is lived primarily in nightclubs - during the festival as well as the rest of the time.

title: HOOVER WAS FIRST TO LET CONGRESS VETO PRESIDENT
description: When President Hoover sought authority to reorganize the Federal Government in June 1932, he worked out a deal with a balky Congress. The lawmakers gave him the reorganization authority, with the proviso that either the House or the Senate could veto the resulting plan.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 12.
description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split effected in May.

title: JURY SELECTION: ONE STATE'S RACIAL BIAS REMEDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Turks Impose a Ban On 21 Founders of Party
description: Turkey's military Government today banned 21 founders of a newly formed party from taking part in politics.

title: PIANO: VAN ZANDT ELLIS PLAYS LISZT
description: VAN ZANDT ELLIS played piano music by Liszt at the Circle Repertory Company Monday night. The one unusual event of the evening was Liszt's ''Feste Polonaise,'' the manuscript of which turned up in New York not long ago.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Corrected from Wednesday's editions.

title: 'YELLOWBEARD,' A 17TH-CENTURY TREASURE HUNT
description: IF pitching, as Connie Mack once said, is 75 percent of baseball, what value might be assigned to a script destined to serve an extensive assortment of comic actors?

title: Shultz's Trip Stalls in Alaska
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's two-week Asian tour stalled today in Alaska, where mechanical problems with his plane forced a delay of at least 15 hours and threatened to disrupt his schedule. A spokesman said the plane had been in no danger.

title: Advertising; Changes Ahead for New Wave
description: THE young man was hunched over a microphone in the cramped studio of radio station WBBI in Emory, Va., a beginner disk jockey on an all-night show. The turntable was playing a favorite record when the door swung open and the station manager made his presence known.

title: COASTAL BID FOR TEXAS GAS ENDED
description: The Coastal Corporation, bowing to a takeover defense that it had earlier threatened to challenge, yesterday ended its attempt to acquire the Texas Gas Resources Corporation.

title: HIGH WATER CAUSING SOME PROBLEMS FOR TOURIST BUSINESSES ON COLORADO
description: The record spring runoff from melting snow in the Rocky Mountains is causing some disruption at recreation areas along the Colorado River.

title: SYSTONETICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After tax credit of $115,628. c-Net loss

title: CUOMO, IN SHIFT, ACCEPTS ANDERSON'S PENSION PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo today accepted a plan by the Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, to improve the pensions for 300,000 state and local employees.

title: U.S. SEES REBOUND BUT NOT IN ALL AREAS
description: In an otherwise encouraging forecast for the economy this year, Commerce Department specialists today drew a somber picture of growth and jobs in several of the nation's most important industries.

title: Citicorp Note Rate
description: Citicorp announced that the interest rate on its floating-rate notes due in 2010 had been set at 9.15 percent a year for the 31-day period ending July 31. Interest on these notes is adjusted monthly and is paid on May 1 and Nov. 1 of each year. The interest rate for June was 8.35 percent.

title: FOR HOTELS, AN ERA OF CHANGE
description: Howard Johnson's orange-roofed hotels, Gregory Lenox concedes, seem plagued by their own Americana stereotype as uninspired roadside rest stops. Now, he says, ''If we have a negative image, we'd like to create a new one.''

title: 'TWILIGHT ZONE' IS ADAPTED TO THE BIG SCREEN
description: ROD SERLING'S phenomenally successful television series, ''The Twilight Zone,'' which had a five-year network run beginning in 1959 and which seems to have been in reruns ever since, has now passed through its own twilight zone and become a flabby, mini-minded behemoth called ''Twilight Zone - the Movie.''

title: GRADUATE TELLS OF A CAPITOL SCHOOL
description: For 16 months, Tom Highlands ranked high in the hierarchy of Capitol pages. He was Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.'s personal page.

title: Crime 'Quite a Problem,' Peking Official Says
description: China's new public security chief said in an interview published today that despite a three-year anticrime campaign, the nation has ''quite a problem'' with lawlessness in some areas of the country.

title: Norstar Merger
description: The Security New York State Corporation and Norstar Bancorp signed a previously announced agreement to merge in a $105 million transaction.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Cobb
description: The former Boston College basketball star Ernie Cobb has been indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of having participated in a scheme to shave points during the Eagles' 1978-79 season.

title: Ricky Bell Improved
description: His future in professional football remains in doubt, but Ricky Bell, the San Diego Charger running back who is suffering from a rare muscle ailment, says his health has improved ''about 50 percent'' since the start of the year. Bell learned last winter that his aching muscles, loss of weight and peeling skin were a result of polymyositis, and he was put on a daily dosage of 10 milligrams of cortisone. He went to the Chargers' minicamp in May but did not play, and his status for the opening of training camp next month is unclear.

title: NIELSEN, A.C., CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $1,644,000 from the sale of a building.

title: Pacific Telephone
description: The Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company said it had reached an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service that relieves the company of ''the largest portion'' of back tax liability for the years 1964 through 1980.

title: RICH SCHOOLS GETTING RICHER IN COMPUTERS
description: Luis Pereira once read a guidance brochure at East Side High here that said computers were the way to get ahead in America, and since ahead is precisely where 18-year-old Luis wants to be, he signed up for the school's computer programming course.

title: HOUSE VOTES $720 CEILING ON JULY 1 INCOME TAX CUT
description: The House of Representatives, heeding the wishes of Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., today approved a $720 ceiling on the amount each taxpayer can save as a result of the July 1 income tax cut.

title: PANEL BACKS TAX PLAN TO SAVE RAILROAD RETIREMENT SYSTEM
description: The House Ways and Means Committee today approved a series of increases in taxes paid by railroads and their employees in an effort to shore up the Railroad Retirement System.

title: Tambimuttu, 67, Dies; Indian Poet and Editor
description: Thurairajah Tambimuttu, a poet and editor widely known by only his last name, died Wednesday in London, apparently from injuries caused by a fall in his office. He was 67 years old.

title: THE COMPUTER AS BIG BROTHER'S NEMESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: ROLL-CALL OF HOUSE VOTE ON BUDGET RESOLUTION FOR FISCAL 1984
description: Following is the vote by which the House today adopted a budget resolution for the fiscal year 1984. A ''yes'' vote was a vote for the plan. A ''no'' vote was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 229 Democrats and 10 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 33 Democrats and 153 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, no; Shelby, no. Republicans - Dickinson, no; Edwards, no.

title: SUPREME COURT, 7-2, RESTRICTS CONGRESS'S RIGHT TO OVERRULE ACTIONS BY EXECUTIVE BRANCH
description: The Supreme Court today swept aside a 50-year-old practice used by Congress to delegate authority to the President and then block his action under the law when it disagreed.

title: Rick Springfield Tour
description: The rock star Rick Springfield will perform Sunday night at 7:30 at the Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J. This is a stop on his world tour of 85 cities.

title: TRAVEL UNIT PRESIDENT FOR AMERICAN EXPRESS
description: William M. McCormick has been named president of the American Express Travel Related Services Company, American Express announced yesterday.

title: Gas Service Co.  Rejects an Offer
description: The Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo., said its board had rejected as ''inadequate'' a $14-a-share offer by the Missouri Public Service Company for about 67 percent of Gas Service's shares outstanding. Gas Service, a natural gas distributor, said it would urge its shareholders to reject the offer, which is valued at $40.5 million.

title: Market Place; Bright Outlook For Apparel
description: WHEN the Value Line Investment Survey recently examined prospects for the apparel industry, it decided that ''the fall season looks like a real winner.'' As a result, the advisory service expects that approximately half of the 27 apparel stocks it monitors will outperform the overall market between now and mid-1984.

title: DANCE: A CONTACT FESTIVAL
description: CONTACT IMPROVISATION, a form of dance created in 1972, is a highly developed style of physical improvisation that epitomizes the ''natural movement'' that choreographers sought in the new dance explorations of the early 1960's in New York. In Contact Improvisation, two or more dancers come together for free-wheeling, purely physical improvisation in which bodies balance, roll, swing off and tumble against one another in movement that involves physical risk, occasional combativeness and sheer play.

title: DRAVECKY'S 11TH CAPS SWEEP OF DODGERS
description: Dave Dravecky became the first 11-game winner in the major leagues as the San Diego Padres defeated the Dodgers, 7-5, today to complete a four-game sweep of Los Angeles.

title: CHECKING FOR SAFETY IN THE GLOOM OF IRT CAVERNS
description: In a dark tunnel beneath Park Avenue where the only breezes were gushes of hot air from passing subway trains, Nathan Streeter led an inspection crew along the tracks looking for the problem that officials believe has led to numerous subway derailments this year.

title: The U.N. Today; June 24, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
U.S. TELLS OF SECRET AIR OPERATIONS IN EGYPT
description: Ever since it began preparations late in 1979 for the hostage rescue mission into Iran, the United States Air Force has secretly operated flights from a former British fighter base in the desert of southern Egypt, according to Defense Department and Congressional officials.

title: The Pitcher and the Lawyer
description: Suzanne Israel Tufts was filling out the application for the California bar exam when her husband, Bob, was traded from San Francisco to Kansas City in March 1982.

title: The Refugees Are Coming!
description: For weeks, officials in Washington have been muttering darkly about a potential tidal wave. Unless the public supports more military spending to combat troublemaking Communists in Central America, then watch out: hordes of poor refugees will start pouring in. Now, the muttering is no longer low-level or anonymous. It's coming straight from the President.

title: TAUGHT SCULPTURE
description: Jason Seley, a sculptor and dean of the Cornell University College of Architecture, Art and Planning, died yesterday at Tompkins Community Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Ithaca.

title: Curb on Boxing Voted by A.M.A.
description: The American Medical Association adopted a resolution today proposing the curtailment of amateur and professional boxing. The resolution, to develop model legislation aimed at reducing ''the utilization of boxing as a public spectacle to the extent feasible,'' was approved by a voice vote of the A.M.A.'s 351-member House of Delegates at the close of their annual meeting.

title: Fire Union Post Lost by Mancuso
description: The two-term president of the New York City firefighters union was defeated for re-election yesterday. Nicholas Mancuso, who had headed the Uniformed Fire Fighters Association since 1979, lost to James J. Boyle, who had been the union's financial recording secretary, by a vote of 3,700 to 3,316.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
UNDECLARED CAMPAIGN ON CLASSROOM HUSTINGS
description: White House officials now have to acknowledge the obvious, that a de facto re-election campaign is under way as President Reagan selectively barnstorms the nation, reading a bit of Shakespeare in public and, aides say, a lot of Wirthlin - Richard Wirthlin, his political poll-taker - in private.

title: Warsaw Pact Proposes Accord on Troop Cuts
description: The Soviet bloc proposed a draft agreement today that it said could break a 10-year East-West deadlock on how to reduce opposing troops in Europe.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES SOAR 73%
description: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported yesterday that sales of new cars in the June 11-20 period rose a substantial 73 percent from a year earlier.

title: Excerpts from speech, page A7.
description: The Reagan Administration said today that South Africa's policy of racial separation would inevitably be scrapped and that it was crucial for the United States to help make sure the change was peaceful rather than violent.

title: REAGAN ASKS DOCTORS TO SUPPORT FREEZE IN THEIR MEDICARE RETURNS
description: President Reagan, warning that continuing inflation in medical costs might jeopardize the quality of health care, urged the nation's physicians today to ''share the burden'' and accept a one-year freeze in Medicare reimbursements.

title: Czech Dissidents Sign Pact With Westerners
description: Western European activists held a public meeting with members of Czechoslovakia's Charter 77 human rights movement today and signed a manifesto proclaiming that ''peace and human rights belong together.''

title: STAGE: 'ACCOUNTS,' ON SCOTS BORDER FARM
description: WITH its usual innovative spirit, the Hudson Guild Theater in Chelsea is putting on a play by Michael Wilcox that takes place in a farmhouse on the border region of Scotland. It's a measure of theatrical tolerance to suppose that an urban audience will be drawn into a story that includes a fair amount of jokes about sheep and bestiality delivered with a Scottish burr.

title: COURT'S CURB ON CONGRESS ASSESSED
description: Administration officials, members of Congress and scholars of government today began exploring the restructuring of relations between Congress and the executive branch in the wake of the elimination of the legislative veto.

title: CHRYSLER AND VW HOLD TALKS
description: The Chrysler Corporation and Volkswagen said yesterday that they were holding talks on a wide range of subjects, but Chrysler denied published reports that it was negotiating the purchase of Volkswagen's American operations.

title: The Talk of Addis Ababa
description: Three Ethiopian men were walking the other day past the complex of buildings that houses some of this country's revolutionary institutions and whose security precautions include a metal fence severing what used to be the main approach to a cathedral.

title: Bridge: Blackwood, a Contributor Of Much to the Game, Is 80
description: Virtually every bridge player in the world has heard of Blackwood. But for the millions who know about Blackwood, the convention, there are only a few thousand who know about Blackwood, the man.

title: Parks Outpoints Braswell in 10
description: Billy Parks, a 140-pound junior welterweight from New Orleans, won by decision from Allen Braswell of Brooklyn in a 10-rounder last night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SAVOY MEMORIES

title: OSVALDO DORTICOS, AN EX-PRESIDENT AND AIDE TO CASTRO, KILLS HIMSELF
description: Osvaldo Dorticos Torrado, a former President of Cuba, shot and killed himself on Thursday, the official Cuban press agency reported in a dispatch from Havana. He was 64 years old.

title: Dodson Memorial July 11
description: A memorial service for Owen Dodson will be held on July 11 at Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, at 6 P.M. Mr. Dodson, a playwright, poet, novelist and teacher of drama, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at the age of 68.

title: A NORTON SIMON BID BY ESMARK
description: Esmark Inc. and Norton Simon Inc. announced yesterday that Esmark had offered to acquire Norton Simon - an event that prompted Norton Simon's chairman, David J. Mahoney, to drop his bid to take Norton Simon private in what would have been the nation's largest leveraged buyout.

title: JUSTICES DISALLOW LIMIT ON CONTRACEPTIVE ADS
description: The Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional a Federal law that makes it a crime to send unsolicited advertisements for contraceptives through the mail.

title: ARAFAT EXPELLED AFTER SAYING SYRIA AIDS P.L.O. REVOLT
description: Syria expelled Yasir Arafat today, one day after the guerrilla leader accused President Hafez al-Assad of orchestrating the anti-Arafat rebellion among Palestine Liberation Organization troops in Lebanon.

title: PIONEERING INFINITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAELI-EGYPTIAN TIES ARE WITHERING
description: Relations between Egypt and Israel continue to erode, with each country blaming the other. Tensions created here by Israel's invasion of Lebanon more than a year ago have not abated with the signing of the Israeli-Lebanese troop withdrawal agreement nearly six weeks ago.

title: LEGAL ADVOCATE FOR THE POOR
description: Edward V. Sparer, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania Law School who helped define and expand the legal rights of welfare recipients, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his summer home in Woodstock, N.Y. He lived in Philadelphia and was 55 years old.

title: POWER SYSTEM ASKS AGENCY'S HELP
description: Directors of the Washington Public Power Supply System passed a resolution today asking the Bonneville Power Administration to raise $963 million to complete construction of one of the supply system's remaining nuclear power plants.

title: A Soviet Device Was Found Near Base, Weinberger Says
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that a ''Soviet listening device'' was recently discovered near a West Coast base from which new United States Trident missilefiring submarines operate.

title: THE PLUSES OF CON ED COAL CONVERSION
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: KURALT AND MOYERS EACH IN A NEW SERIES ON CBS
description: In general, a problem in television is that reporters say too much, telling us things they do not really know to be true, but that they only think may be true. Consider, for example, a correspondent doing a stand-up on the White House lawn: he may be speaking with high purpose and utter certainty, even though the source of his meditation is the routine briefing of a deputy press secretary. The correspondent will not be lying; he will not even be fibbing. It may be, however, that he will be talking through his hat.

title: N.B.A. Votes Fines To Enforce Caps; Knicks Alone in Dissenting as 22 Agree
description: In an effort to enforce the National Basketball Association's new team-by-team player-payroll caps, the board of governors has authorized what Russ Granik, the league's general counsel, calls ''the biggest fines in N.B.A. history.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Full Court Press on Tax Cut

title: Rebels Said to Capture Town in Northern Chad
