description: The town of Faya-Largeau in northern Chad has fallen to the Libyan-supported forces of former President Goukouni Oueddei, the Chadian Embassy in Paris said early today.

title: Virtue Finally Triumphs in the Senate
description: By voting to increase their own salaries to $69,800, members of the Senate appear finally to have resolved the pay dispute in Congress, at least for this year. The raise makes the salary of a senator equal to a representative's, as it should be.

title: Michelle Marie Witteman Marries Craig M. Taylor
description: The marriage of Michelle Marie Witteman to Craig Monroe Taylor took place yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York. The Rev. Vincent O'Connor performed the ceremony.

title: Your Money; Seeking Help For a Portfolio
description: WHEN a securities portfolio reaches a certain size, it may be advisable to consider using the professional services of an investment adviser. Two questions immediately come to mind, however: What should that level be and how should the adviser be selected?

title: Military Analysis
description: The challenge to Yasir Arafat's leadership of the Palestine Liberation Organization has stirred serious concern in intelligence circles of the United States, other North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and Israel, too.

title: GETTING IN THE SWIM STYLISHLY
description: There was a time, and not so long ago, when it was next to impossible to buy a bathing suit in the summer. By June the few suits left in stores would be much the worse for trying on, and no new supplies were in sight. The next deliveries would be for the resort season.

title: New Claims by Jobless Drop by 3,000 in Week
description: New applications for unemployment compensation benefits totaled 424,000 in the week ended June 11, 3,000 fewer than in the previous week, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: News Analysis
description: For Poland's Communist rulers, establishing any kind of link between the Government and Pope John Paul II may be hard -at least as far as the Polish people are concerned.

title: CARLTON STOPS METS AS SWANIS ROUTED
description: Maybe the Philadelphia Phillies are old, baseball's Golden Ponders of '83, with a 42-year-old first baseman (Pete Rose) and a 39-yearold second baseman (Joe Morgan). But the Phils are not so frail that they cannot hold a six-run lead.

title: F.B.I. to Examine Yeshiva Shooting
description: The Justice Department yesterday asked the F.B.I. to conduct a preliminary inquiry into the shooting Wednesday of three students in a restaurant across the street from Yeshiva University in Washington Heights. A Federal Bureau of Investigation spokesman in New York City said the inquiry would be undertaken at once.

title: 837 Antinuclear Protesters Face Weekend in 4 Jail Tents
description: A jail fashioned from four circus tents was to hold 837 antinuclear protesters this weekend after arraignments stopped for the day.

title: GRAND OLD CITY I. BOATYARD BACK ON COURSE
description: It was in this huge barn of a building that they used to board up the plate-glass windows, shut the floor-to-ceiling door and lovingly build the sleek 12-meter yachts that went on to win every America's Cup race for the last 19 years.

title: FILM STUDIOS WONDER IF NEW HITS WILL LAST
description: ''Return of the Jedi'' has already earned $123 million. ''Superman III'' sold more than $13 million worth of tickets its opening weekend. In fact, America's top eight box-office movies - ''Superman III,'' ''Jedi,'' ''Trading Places,'' ''Octopussy,'' ''WarGames,'' ''Psycho II,'' ''Flashdance'' and ''Blue Thunder'' - earned $50.7 million last weekend, some $3 million more than all movies earned during the entire second week of June two years ago.

title: LOFT SUBTENANTS ON THE WRONG SIDE OF THE BATTLE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRANIFF SAYS HYATT PLAN HELPS SECURED CREDITORS
description: Braniff International told some of its secured creditors in New York yesterday that they stand to gain an additional 2 cents to 8 cents on every dollar they are owed by accepting a Hyatt Corporation plan to restart the airline, which is in bankruptcy proceedings.

title: PRESIDENT MAKING LIGHT OF STOLEN DEBATE DATA
description: President Reagan today dismissed as ''much ado about nothing'' the controversy over the strategy material for a 1980 Presidential debate that was obtained by his advisers from the rival camp of President Carter.

title: IN WASHINGTON, A GARDEN OF JERSEY DELIGHTS
description: Finally, a chance to get even. Ridiculed and rarely praised, New Jersey put itself on display here this week. In a bit of unabashed hyperbole, Governor Kean bragged that the state had the ''best tomatoes in the world.'' State officials spent $60,000 re-creating the Atlantic City Boardwalk. And squads of eager agricultural students tended hundreds of potted fruits and vegetables - all in the name of the Garden State.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Con Ed in Talks
description: Representatives of the Consolidated Edison Company and of 16,000 striking workers met for 90 minutes yesterday to try to end a sixday-old walkout, a Federal mediator said.

title: Jan P. Ryan, Lawyer, Is Married to David Fisher
description: Jan Patricia Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Ryan of Pittsbugh, was married yesterday to David Baldwin Fisher, son of Mrs. William Dale Fisher of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mr. Fisher. The Rev. William D. Persell, an Episcopal priest of Brooklyn Heights, performed the ceremony in the Rose Garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: WARNING ON PROPER DRUG USE
description: Social Security beneficiaries may be surprised to find a message from the Food and Drug Administration with their July checks. ''Prescription drugs can do much to cure illnesses,'' the F.D.A. insert says, ''but they must be taken properly to do their job. Yet studies show that as many as half of the people taking medicines aren't taking them properly.''

title: Back to Basics
description: The meeting had been called by Bob Arum, the promoter, to come up with a slogan for the Davey Moore-Roberto Duran fight at Madison Square Garden last week. Boxing promoters think they need slogans, such as Thrilla in Manila or The Crown Affair, to sell fights.

title: Eelco Nicholaas van Kleffens; An Ex-Dutch Foreign Minister
description: Dr. Eelco Nicholaas van Kleffens, a diplomat who was Foreign Minister of the Netherlands during World War II, died June 17 at his home in Almo,cageme, Portugal.

title: Police Check Man's Tale Of Killing 100 Women
description: Officials investigating a drifter's contention that he killed 100 women say they suspect the man, Henry Lee Lucas, may be responsible for some of what are referred to here as the ''I-35 murders'' of young women.

title: AFGHAN TALKS END WITHOUT PROGRESS
description: Seven days of United Nations-sponsored talks on withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan ended this afternoon with no sign of major progress on any of the significant issues.

title:
PATENTS;
Shadow Masks For Picture Tubes
description: The RCA Corporation, which has been developing high-resolution color picture tubes for the display of data from computers, received encouragement this week from its laboratory in Lancaster, Pa.

title: SECRETARY DOLE SAYS SHE IS EAGER FOR REVIEW OF AUTO CRASH SAFETY
description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole said today that she welcomed the Supreme Court's request that she review a standard calling for automatic crash protection equipment in automobiles.

title: 3 BANKS SEEK BUTCHER BANKRUPTCY
description: Three Tennessee banks and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation petitioned a Federal Bankruptcy Court today to force C.H. Butcher Jr. into involuntary bankruptcy. They said he owed them $13.4 million.

title: LEARNING A LESSON FOR THE MARATHON
description: A long time ago, before Julie Brown became willing to call herself a marathon runner, she had been led to believe that races begin when guns are fired, and spectators begin to cheer, and legs begin to pump, and clocks begin to count. She has since learned differently.

title: TIGERS TROUNCE ORIOLES BY 9-0
description: Chet Lemon and Enos Cabell hit home runs and Larry Herndon collected four hits to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 9-0 victory tonight over the Baltimore Orioles behind the five-hit pitching of Dan Petry (7-5).

title: No Comparison
description: The Generals will try at Giants Stadium tonight to win a second consecutive game for the first time this season, and Herschel Walker will try to get within range of O.J. Simpson's single-season pro football record of 2,003 yards rushing. Their opponents might make it all possible: The Arizona Wranglers have lost eight games in a row, and, when they met New Jersey back on April 3, they provided the Generals their first victory, 35-21.

title: Detroit Papers Avert a Strike
description: Negotiators for six unions and this city's two major newspapers reached tentative agreement on a one-year contract today, averting a strike that had been set for the afternoon, bargainers said.

title:
PATENTS;
An Exercising Device That Produces Power
description: A rotary exercising device invented by Lawrence W. Hall of Hermosa Beach, Calif., is to produce electric power. As explained in patent 4,389,047, granted this week, the user runs or jogs within a cylindrical mill wheel.

title: Would-Be Insider Offers Her Views
description: It was, Tracy Austin said by telephone from London, ''a great opportunity.'' ''Hopefully,'' she added, ''I won't be able to do it again.''

title: West German in Moscow
description: Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff flew to Moscow today for talks with Soviet trade officials to prepare for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's visit, which is to start July 4.

title: Donors' Fears Result In Blood Ban Decline
description: Blood supplies in New York and New Jersey have slipped below their normal summer levels, blood bank officials said.

title: WHITE HOUSE SAYS PUBLIC SUPPORT IS SLIPPING ON CENTRAL AMERICA AID
description: The White House said today that a ''reversal in the trend of public opinion'' was impeding President Reagan's proposal for more military and economic aid to Central America.

title: Superior Oil Unit To Study All Bids
description: The Superior Oil Company said that, though there are no offers for the company at present, its board had adopted a resolution calling for the creation of a special committee of outside directors to review any possible offer for 45 percent or more of the company's stock.

title: DOWNFALL OF AN ENTREPENEUR RAISES QUESTIONS ON HIS RISE
description: The following article is based on reporting by Raymond Bonner and George Volsky and was written by Mr. Bonner.

title: The Fear of AIDS
description: The new disease known as AIDS, or acquired immune deficiency syndrome, has set loose a deadly epidemic. Morticians, prison guards and policemen have expressed an understandable but probably excessive fear of AIDS. The Reagan Administration, on the other hand, yawned through the first two years of the crisis and has now awakened to declare that no special efforts are needed. It could usefully imbibe a little of the public's panic.

title: Filmmakers Deny Guilt In 'Twilight Zone' Deaths
description: John Landis, a movie director, and four assistants pleaded not guilty today to charges of involuntary manslaughter in the deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children in the filming of the movie ''Twilight Zone.''

title: Mazzilli Benched Again
description: Lee Mazzilli, whose baseball future seemed bright when he came out of Lincoln High School in Brooklyn not so many years ago, says he is baffled. Mazzilli would be the first to admit that his defensive play for the Pittsburgh Pirates left something to be desired, just as it had when he was with the Mets, the Yankees and the Texas Rangers.

title: THE CARTE BLANCHE EXPRESS
description: Abolishing an institution doesn't necessarily mean that it expires quietly or with grace. Such is the case with the state's Job Incentive Program, which comes under the Commerce Department and which -though it has been legislated out of existence as of midnight next Thursday, for throwing away the taxpayers' money - is still trying to donate tens of millions of state dollars, in its final moments, to healthy companies that don't need them.

title: MUSIC: HOLLANDERS IN CONCERT
description: The cellist Norman Hollander and the pianist David Hollander are father and son, so it is perhaps not surprising that their Tuesday night joint concert at Symphony Space was imbued with a sense of unity and direct warmth. The elder Mr. Hollander served as an assistant principal cellist of the Cleveland Orchestra and later as principal cellist of the Kansas City Philharmonic; his son is a solo pianist.

title: WESTERN GOVERNORS TO MEET CANADIAN CHIEFS
description: When the Governors of more than a dozen Western states gather for their annual meeting this weekend in Montana, they will be joined by some of their counterparts from north of the border.

title: Venezia Loses Appeal
description: Michael Venezia, one of three jockeys ordered suspended by the State Racing and Wagering Board last summer for their involvement in fixed thoroughbred races in New York in the mid-1970's, lost his appeal Thursday in the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. He and his attorney, Peter Fleming, are considering whether to go to the Court of Appeals, New York's highest judicial body.

title: News Analysis
description: Dioxin has rapidly become the most feared of all toxic chemicals in this country, but now there is an emerging argument over whether the fear has outstripped the hazard.

title: VANDALISM BY COMPUTER ALLEGED BY HIGH SCHOOL
description: An 18-year-old computer expert here faces a possible jail sentence for what he says was an accident that destroyed part of his high school's computer records. School officials say it was an act of vindictive vandalism by the young man, whom they describe as brilliant but arrogant.

title: DELOREAN FACING DRUG TRIAL ALONE
description: The remaining co-defendant of John Z. DeLorean in a $24 million cocaine smuggling case, Stephen Lee Arrington, changed his plea to guilty today, leaving Mr. DeLorean to face trial alone.

title: Seafirst Gains In Bank Takeover
description: A Delaware Chancery Court in Wilmington denied the request of two Seafirst Corporation shareholders who sought to block the Seattle bank's acquisition by the BankAmerica Corporation. The suit contended that the acquisition would nullify the shareholders' claims against Seafirst and some former officers.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Peggy Rajski, a Producer, Is Wed to Joshua Mostel
description: Peggy Rajski, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pat Rajski of Stevens Point, Wis., was married in Manhattan last evening to Joshua Mostel, son of Kathryn Harkin Mostel of New York and the late Zero Mostel, the actor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Challenger, we have good news: The beer is very, very cold. The bad news is that it's 3,000 miles away.'' -Bryan D. O'Connor, of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. (16:4.)

title: ST. LOUIS SELLING PARKING METER SPACE FOR ADS
description: Advertising messages have begun to appear on some of the 10,000 parking meters here. St. Louis is the first American city to use its meters as ''billboards,'' Such European cities as London and Amsterdam have done so. City officials estimate that the meter messages could generate as much as $260,000 a year, sparing some jobs at a time when the city is contemplating large-scale layoffs because of budget cuts.

title: A WILSON FOODS PACT IS REACHED
description: The Wilson Foods Corporation, which took the unusual step of filing for bankruptcy to reduce labor costs, said yesterday it had reached a tentative wage agreement with striking meatpackers. The agreement would end a 20-day walkout against the nation's largest processor of fresh pork.

title: ALASKAN NATIVES SEEKING MORE VILLAGE AUTONOMY
description: Some Indian, Aleut and Eskimo leaders have organized a movement aimed at establishing rule by Alaska native village councils that would be semi-independent and exempt from most state and Federal laws.

title: COUNCIL MEMBERS TELL PANEL THEY CAN'T LIVE ON $35,000 SALARY
description: City Council members, including one who brought along his 7-year-old daughter as proof of his financial need, asked a citizens' study group yesterday to recommend increases in their $35,000-a-year salaries.

title: Elizabeth Taylor to Miss Several Performances
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who has bronchitis and laryngitis, was unable to appear in last night's performance of Noel Coward's ''Private Lives'' and will miss the three performances scheduled today and tomorrow at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.

title: Father Pleads Guilty In Burning of Son, 7
description: A father pleaded guilty today to setting fire to a motel bed where his son lay, burning the boy over 90 percent of his body, because he feared his former wife would not allow him any more custody visits.

title: Honda to Offer A New Model
description: The Honda Motor Company said that on July 1 it would introduce a new sports car in which nearly half of the body is made with a lightweight plastic,

title: Beck Leads by 2 at Memphis
description: Chip Beck birdied four of his first five holes, shot a 68 for 133 and expanded his lead to two strokes today in the second round of the $400,000 Danny Thomas Memphis Golf Classic.

title:
PATENTS;
Handbook for Inventors To Be Published Soon
description: Calvin D. MacCracken, who holds 80 patents and manufactures some of the things they protect, will share his experience in ''A Handbook for Inventors,'' to be published next week by Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: WHY STATE UTILITY REGULATION NEEDS REVAMPING
description: To the Editor:

title: POLICE IN SUFFOLK ACCUSED BY U.S. OF BIAS IN HIRING
description: The Justice Department today sued the Suffolk County Police Department, the 10th largest in the nation, charging it discriminated against blacks, women and Hispanic people.

title: LANDING SWITCH COULD DELAY FUTURE MISSIONS
description: Failure of the space shuttle Challenger to land here at the Kennedy Space Center will almost certainly delay the launching of the next mission, possibly the one after that, and put off until at least next February a chance to evaluate the shuttle's ability to return to its launching base, project officials said today.

title: Ray Colcord 3d Is Wed To Madeleine E. Ennis
description: Madeleine Elizabeth Ennis, daughter of Thomas A. Ennis of New Canaan, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Alfreda W. Ennis of New York, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Ray Colcord 3d, son of Wanda Pearson Colcord of Shelbyville, Tenn., and the late Mr. Colcord Jr. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig, vicar of St. Thomas Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony at the Colony Club.

title: GOLDWATER'S 1964 RUNNING MATE
description: William E. Miller, a former member of the House of Representatives who experienced brief national fame as Barry Goldwater's Republican running mate in the 1964 Presidential race, died yesterday at Millard Fillmore Hospital in Buffalo. He was 69 years old.

title: CITIES, BE STREET-SMART: LEAVE PEDDLERS BE
description: Mayor Koch's campaign to ban all street vending downtown reflects a historical hostility toward peddlers. Mr. Koch and mayors throughout the country have sought to justify harsh regulation of vending on grounds of health, safety and ease of circulation. However, the actual intent of such regulation is more often related to the protection of local businesses, the physical appearance of the vendors and racial or ethnic bias. In fact, the experience in several cities, including Boston, Chicago and San Francisco, indicates that vinding, innovatively controlled, can actually provide a wide range of benefits for merchants, shoppers and the city itself. A primary benefit of peddling is that it draws shoppers and tourists as well as downtown employees into the downtown shopping area. The personality of the vendor, the uniqueness of the cart and wares all help to create a distinctive character and vitality appealing to shoppers. Vendors also provide services not usually offered in stores. An office worker on a short break can pick up a quick lunch and still have time to do shopping. Others find fresh produce and flowers to take home in the evening or a low priced gift for a fellow employee. Equally important is the fact that peddlers are a security presence on the street. New Orleans merchants describe how vendors are ''eyes on the street.'' In New York City and Newark, N.J., there have been numerous instances in which vendors have apprehended pickpockets or purse-snatchers and held them until the police arrived.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS AIRBAGS MANDATE
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the Reagan Administration had improperly revoked a Federal requirement that new cars be equipped with airbags or automatic seat belts.

title: Dodgers 7, Astros 2
description: Pedro Guerrero's two-run homer in the fifth inning snapped a 1-1 tie as the Dodgers ended a four-game losing streak.

title: F.D.I.C. Suit In Bank Loss
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation filed a suit today against the National Association of Securities Dealers Inc., charging that the group's failure to monitor the financial dealings of Gary Lewellyn, a stockbroker, led to the 1982 collapse of an Iowa bank.

title: MONEY SUPPLY FALLS BY $3.2BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply dropped $3.2 billion in the week that ended June 15, a far steeper decline than had been expected.

title: REUNION ECHOES BYGONE YEARS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: They were all there. All the unfamiliar faces who over the years have kept the food coming, the floors polished, the linens starched, the gardens in bloom, and the plumbing intact at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Gonzalez of Spain Beats Coe in 1,500
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain was defeated in a major 1,500-meter race today for the first time in seven years, beaten down the final straight by Jose-Luis Gonzalez of Spain. Gonzalez was timed in 3 minutes 34.84 seconds, the second-fastest time in the world this year.

title: 'PORKY'S II,' MORE HIGH SCHOOL HIJINKS
description: Just in time to rescue the summer in the name of unpretentious, un-self-conscious, foul-mouthed fun, the gang from Angel Beach High turned up yesterday at the Criterion Center and a host of other theaters in ''Porky's II: The Next Day.''

title: Eastern Air Fares
description: Eastern Air Lines said it would raise fares by 5 percent across the board on July 15 in a move to prop up sagging yields on domestic routes. The fare increase would bring Eastern's midweek fare from Miami to New York's La Guardia Airport to $146, from $139. The oneway weekend fare would rise $8, to $167.

title: UNSEEDED KATHY JORDAN UPSETS MRS. LLOYD, 6-1, 7-6
description: Chris Evert Lloyd, who had reached at least the semifinals of all 34 Grand Slam tournaments she had played since 1971, was beaten today in the third round of Wimbledon, 6-1, 7-6, by Kathy Jordan.

title: Books of the Times
description: Mystery Petpourri THE POETICS OF MURDER: Detective Fiction and Literary Theory. Edited by Glenn W. Most and William W. Stowe. 383 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $22.95 hardcover; $9.95 paperback.

title: Two Fires Delay L.I.R.R. Riders
description: Thousands of area commuters were stranded in the city and many others were delayed hours in reaching Pennsylvania Station by two separate fires and a derailment last night and early this morning, train officials said.

title: Taxation Fighter's Son Given Life in Murders
description: A Federal district judge today sentenced two men, including the son of Gordon Kahl, a tax protester who was killed in a gun battle, to life in prison for the murders of two United States marshals in February at a roadblock near Medina, N.D.

title: JUANTORENA, AT 32, MAKING COMEBACK
description: Seven years after his heroics for Cuba in the Montreal Olympics, Alberto Juantorena is in many ways as good as ever.

title: STUDENTS UNFAIRLY BARRED FROM TUITION AID
description: To the Editor:

title: Hartford to Audit New Nuclear Plant
description: The State Department of Public Utility Control has decided to hire a consultant to audit the construction of the $3.54 billion Millstone III nuclear power plant in Waterford.

title: CHARLES D. MARSHALL
description: Charles DeLaskie Marshall, former general manager of the Maritime Commission and retired chairman of the Associated Latin American Freight Conferences, died Thursday in Chesterfield Convalescent Hospital in Chester, Conn., after suffering a stroke. He was 72 years old and lived in Essex, Conn.

title: ALIEN'S DEPORTATION FIGHT LED TO LANDMARK DECISION
description: Jagdish Rai Chadha came to the United States to study, but after challenging Congress and winning a landmark Supreme Court decision, he has become part of the nation's history.

title: SOVIET SAID TO REJECT NEW OFFER ON NATO MISSILES
description: A senior official of the Reagan Administration said today that the Soviet Union had rejected what he portrayed as new and flexible interim proposals by the United States at the Geneva talks to limit medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: The Talk of Detroit
description: The onset of hot weather marks the fourth anniversary of Detroit's economic slump, a kind of economic solstice observed this week in the opening of a second Capuchin Brothers soup kitchen to feed the hungry and the beginning of an emergency summer job program for young people.

title: Giants Sign Carson
description: Harry Carson, whose love of daytime soap operas led him to make an appearance on ''One Life to Live,'' has ended his threat of a cliffhanger with the Giants. The big linebacker, who attended the team's minicamp last month after holding out the possibility that he might stay away because he had no contract, signed yesterday to play four more years. ... A Bergen County grand jury has cleared Bryan Millard, a New Jersey Generals offensive tackle, of charges of sexually assaulting a woman from Belleville, N.J., last month. Millard, a rookie from the University of Texas, is on the injured reserve roster.

title: CHURCH IN CHILE DEFENDS DISSENT AND URGES TALKS WITH OPPOSITION
description: The Roman Catholic Church spoke out today in defense of political dissent against President Augusto Pinochet's regime and called for talks between the Government and its opposition.

title: Computers to China
description: The United States has told Japan it would not block exports by Hitachi Ltd. of five computer-controlled telephone switchboards to China, Japanese Government sources said today. The United States, fearing the systems could be used for military purposes, earlier blocked the sale under an embargo of exports of sensitive high-technology equipment agreed on by a 15-nation committee.

title: Iran Toyota Truck Sale
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it had won a $42 million order for 4,700 trucks from Iran's state-run vehicle importer, the Irtoya Company. The sale was arranged by the C. Itoh Company.

title: NATIONAL FESTIVAL OPENS BEFORE 40,000
description: Following Olympic custom, the National Sports Festival was officially opened here this evening with the lighting of a perpetual flame, ignited by a torch carried by one female athlete and one male athlete.

title: APRICOTS FOR SUMMER: THE BEST ARE SMALL AND RIPE
description: Of all the luxurious fruits summer is about to bestow on us, my favorite by far is the apricot. A native of Persia, this small sungold fruit will be in markets from now through most of August, but there are really only about three weeks when apricots are worth eating. Rain in various parts of the country may have delayed the crops somewhat, but apricots should be at their best from now through the second week of July.

title: SALARY AND LETTUCE
description: Compared with baseball players, movie performers, rock singers, TV anchormen and business executives, members of Congress are wretchedly underpaid, with salaries in the $70,000-a-year range. Compared with schoolteachers, they are outrageously overpaid, so whenever the matter of a Congressional pay raise comes up, schoolteachers, an articulate bunch, flood newspaper editors with complaints about the injustice of it all.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: CHARLES P. TAFT, FORMER MAYOR OF CINCINNATI
description: Charles P. Taft, a former Mayor of Cincinnati, a founder of the World Council of Churches and a son of President William Howard Taft, died at a residence for the elderly in Cincinnati Friday morning. He was 85 years old.

title: NO TRASH BURIALS AT SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Absolves Mrs. Burford
description: The House Public Works Committee has voted to absolve Anne McGill Burford, former Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, of contempt of Congress.

title: KEAN SAYS TESTS SHOW NO DIOXIN PERIL FOR NEIGHBORS OF CLIFTON PLANT
description: Governor Kean announced today that tests had shown that dioxin outside a large chemical plant in Clifton had not contaminated a residential area around the plant.

title: 'NOT MUCH OF A WORLD TO LOOK FORWARD TO'
description: The writer, executive producer of CBS News's ''60 Minutes,'' delivered the following address, adapted here, to the graduating class at New Rochelle, N.Y., High School.

title: VATICAN NEWSPAPER SAYS WALESA 'HAS LOST HIS BATTLE' WITH REGIME
description: The Vatican newspaper said today that Lech Walesa had ''lost his battle'' and indicated that he was no longer in a position to play a public role as head of Poland's outlawed Solidarity union.

title: Liberty Wins 3 Straight
description: Liberty made a strong comback today, winning three straight races from Courageous on Rhode Island Sound in the United States preliminary trials to select the America's Cup defender. However, Courgeous, sailed by John Kolius, was flying a protest flag at the end of the last two races.

title: Sadik Hakim, 64, Jazz Pianist; Recorded With Charlie Parker
description: Sadik Hakim, a jazz pianist who influenced be-bop, and who recorded with Charlie Parker, died in New York on Monday. He was 64 years old. Mr. Hakim, who was born in Duluth, Minn., studied the piano with his grandfather, a professor of music.

title: At Park Clinics, It's Walk, Don't Run
description: Joggers might dispute that their ranks are thinning, but the four-year-old New York Walkers Club maintains that many runners, along with people who had never exercised at all, are turning to aerobic walking.

title: NICARAGUAN REBEL HOLDS FIRE, CHARGING U.S. BLOCKED ARMS
description: A leading anti-Sandinista rebel said today that he had suspended his two-month-old military offensive against the Nicaraguan Government because the United States had blocked donations of money and arms from countries in the region.

title: News Analysis
description: The telephone and the tape recorder help reporters gather information quickly and accurately. Using the two technologies together, however, is raising philosophical questions that neither journalists nor lawmakers have resolved.

title: Entomological Warfare: Fighting Bugs With Bugs
description: Yesterday, Joe Butera and Joe Rubino each had two gallons of ladybugs in their family refrigerators in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Joie de Vie Takes $376,000 Dexter
description: Joie de Vie, who set a track record of 1:59 2/5 for a mile in the first elimination series, came back to win the $376,000 Dexter Cup tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: ALBANY AGREES ON PRIVACY SAFEGUARDS FOR RECORDS
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders have agreed on a measure that they say will help restrict the release of the millions of pieces of information that the state keeps on its citizens.

title: Council Acts to Free Slayer
description: By a vote of 6 to 1, the Massachusetts Executive Council acted Wednesday to commute the life prison sentence of a Boston man convicted of first-degree murder in the slaying of a Saugus police officer in 1969.

title: Hot Dogs and Jazz On Gracie Mansion's Lawn
description: The Mayor's annual jam session to kick off the Kool Jazz Festival was held yesterday in the backyard of Gracie Mansion on the lawn under the trees.

title: CUOMO MOVES TO REPLACE 2 ON CONTROL BOARD
description: Governor Cuomo moved today to replace two of the three private members of New York City Financial Control Board. Mr. Cuomo nominated Penny Kaniclides, a retired computer executive and longtime political supporter, and Edward J. Babb, a lawyer who is a former corporate secretary to the New York City Transit Authority, as the new board members.

title: Canadian Tire
description: The estate of one of the founders of the Canadian Tire Corporation said it would make a tender offer to the public for the sale of its 30.4 percent interest in the retailer of automotive parts and hardware. The shares, which were put in trust by John W. Billes, one of the two founders of the company, have been ordered sold by a court in Ontario.

title: SHUTTLE RETURNS, DIVERTED TO LAND ON THE WEST COAST
description: The space shuttle Challenger returned to earth today after a triumphant six-day mission spoiled only by light rain and low clouds in Florida that forced a landing here in the Mojave Desert rather than at Cape Canaveral.

title: Letter: On State Employee Costs; Cuomo's Pension and Wage Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Declines 0.10 As Volume Eases
description: Stock prices closed mixed in slower trading yesterday, but drug, airline and technology issues registered big gains. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.10 point, to 1,241.69. For the week, the key average of 30 major industrial stocks fell 0.50 point as growing concern over the possibility of an increase in interest rates curtailed the recent buying enthusiasm.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday listed a jazz seminar - ''Jazz Writing: Survival in the 80's'' - for which the location has been changed. It will take place from 2 to 6 P.M. today at Top of the Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets.

title: U.S AGENCY CALLS FILM IT AIDED 'PROPAGANDA'
description: The chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities said today that a film on Palestinian women that had been made with funds from a $126,000 grant from the endowment was ''propaganda'' that should not have received Federal money because it was not really a subject that came within the humanities.

title:
Patents;
Helping Children To Read
description: AN educational device patented this week by Morton Phillips, a psychoanalyst who practices in Manhasset, L.I., and Forest Hills, Queens, is intended to teach young children to read.

title: Barney Suffers Stroke
description: Rex Barney, the 58-year-old former Dodger pitcher who once threw a no-hitter against the Giants, suffered a mild stroke in Baltimore, where he is a public-address announcer for the Orioles. A hospital spokesman said Barney was resting comfortably.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 25, 1983
description: Companies

title: Carol Lewis Sidelined
description: Carol Lewis, the American champion in the women's long jump, will miss the United States-East German track meet today and tomorrow in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum.

title: SATURDAY, JUNE 25, 1983
description: International

title: Wyoming Bank Closed
description: The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency announced today that it had declared insolvent and closed the Western National Bank of Lovell, Wyo., and appointed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation as receiver.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 15.

title: VITA LOOKS TO HERRING MAVEN
description: After a 14-year absence, the herring maven is about to make an advertising comeback, and Vita Foods is hoping the new campaign will revitalize its fortunes.

title: Of Skyscrapers and Sherpas - And Bills to Stuntmen
description: Skyscraper climbing costs the city money, Mayor Koch says, and he for one intends to stop it. The last time someone did it, at the World Trade Center on Memorial Day, it cost $4,235 in police salaries and equipment, the Mayor said.

title: U.S. Agency Told To Pay Legal Fees
description: A Federal judge ordered the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission yesterday to pay the legal fees of a Westchester County company that the agency had unsuccessfully sued in a discrimination case.

title: WHEN SALARY'S MORE THAN MONEY
description: Proper Pay for the Chairman of the Fed

title: SAATCHI AGREES TO BUY MCCAFFREY & MCCALL
description: Saatchi & Saatchi, a British advertising agency that is the world's ninth largest, has agreed to acquire McCaffrey & McCall of New York for more than $10 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Peru Said to Prevent Bombing of U.S. Envoy
description: The police have arrested a man whom they accused of trying to dynamite the American Ambassador's residence here, police sources said today.

title: ALBANY DRAWING BROAD CHANGES IN LAWS ON RENT
description: An agreement on broad changes in the laws that affect 950,000 rent-stabilized apartments in New York City was announced today by key state legislators.

title: Gas Service Co.
description: The Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit to block a tender offer by the Missouri Public Service Company on the ground that the offer violates Federal securities and antitrust laws. On Thursday Gas Service rejected Missouri Public Service's tender offer of $14 a share for about twothirds, or 2.9 million, of Gas Service's shares outstanding. Missouri Public Service said that it believed the courts would find the suit ''without merit.''

title: Rehearing Denied On N.C.A.A. TV
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit refused Thursday to hold a rehearing on its ruling that the National Collegiate Athletic Association's control of football telecasts violates the Sherman Antitrust Act. The association's president, John Toner, who is the athletic director at the University of Connecticut, said the N.C.A.A. would now appeal to the Supreme Court.

title: U.N. Chief Criticizes Article in The Times
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has criticized as ''totally deformed and truncated'' an article in The New York Times reporting on his closed-door meeting Monday with journalists from the United States.

title: Jonathan Latimer Dies at 76; Writer of 'Perry Mason' Show
description: Jonathan (Jack) Latimer, a writer for the ''Perry Mason'' television series and a best-selling mystery writer, died of lung cancer on Thursday here.

title: A TALE BLENDING MYTH AND REALITY
description: Peter Berczeller, a Manhattan physician and ardent recreational tennis player, recently took note of Bjorn Borg, a fellow recreational tennis player.

title: ORGANIZED CONCERTS ON BLACK COMPOSERS
description: Dr. Leon Thompson, a conductor, director of music at the Abyssinian Baptist Church and former director of educational activities for the New York Philharmonic, died after a heart attack Thursday in Massanetta Springs, Va., where he was guest conductor at the All-State Music Festival. He was 55 years old and lived in Englewood, N.J.

title: 3 TEACHERS ARE ROBBED IN SCHOOL
description: Two men entered a junior high school in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn yesterday morning and robbed three teachers at gunpoint before pupils arrived.

title: Executive Was Drunk in Crash
description: The president of Eagle Computer Inc. was legally drunk June 8 when his Ferrari crashed through a guard rail and plummeted down a ravine, killing him and injuring another man, coroner's deputies said.

title: RED SOX DEFEAT YANKEES BY 5-4
description: Just when the first game of the season between the Yankees and the Boston Red Sox was taking on the excitement that often adorns this rivalry, Bob Stanley appeared and spoiled the fun.

title: WESTERN ELECTRIC TO CLOSE A PLANT
description: The Western Electric Company announced yesterday that it was closing its oldest manufacturing plant, the Hawthorne Works near Chicago, eliminating 4,200 jobs.

title: BUSH, IN LONDON, GIVES LATIN VIEWS
description: Vice President Bush said today that the United States had failed to explain its policy in Central America to the people of Europe and he hoped ''to get the message across'' on his eight-nation trip that the United States role is ''honorable.''

title: HERBERT J. HERRLICH
description: Herbert J. Herrlich, former president of Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel Inc., died Tuesday at Yale-New Haven Hospital.

title: STOP FORCED REMOVAL OF RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL TENANTS
description: The question presents itself again and again - how extensive are the rights of owners of rental property in this period of urban redevelopment and gentrification? Are they limited by corresponding rights of tenants?

title:
PATENTS;
Method to Monitor Spent Nuclear Fuel
description: Spent nuclear fuel can be monitored to prevent its theft and possible conversion into nuclear weapons under a new method of checking radiation in storage ponds.

title: MEDICARE ANALYSIS PREDICTS INSOLVENCY OF THE FUND BY 1990
description: The Reagan Administration reported today that the financial outlook for the Social Security trust fund had ''dramatically improved'' in the last 12 months but that the Medicare trust fund was in a precarious position, facing insolvency around 1990.

title: U.S. and Soviet Discuss Spread of Nuclear Arms
description: The potential of such countries as China, Brazil, Argentina and South Africa to become new suppliers of nuclear fuel is becoming a factor in efforts to curb the spread of nuclear weapons, a United States official said today.

title: HIGH SCHOOL ATHLETES TOLD OF COLLEGE PITFALLS
description: For those who excel at athletics, high school is a time of life without limits. They grew strong and supple sooner than their classmates and dominated their games almost as adults among children. And when it came time to select a college, coaches pursued them as if they were beauty queens.

title: Wife Killer's 2-Year Term Spurs Protest in Denver
description: Colorado's first lady told 150 people at a protest rally today that a two-year work-release sentence given a butcher for the slaying of his wife reinforces the idea that women ''are property in our state.''

title: STATE TO BUILD 5 NEW PRISONS, INCLUDING ONE IN THE BRONX
description: A maximum-security prison to be built in the South Bronx was one of five new prison projects announced today by Governor Cuomo.

title: Dara V. Coulson Becomes a Bride
description: In the Old First Presbyterian Church of Huntington, L.I., yesterday, Dara Vernette Coulson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Coulson of Huntington Bay, L.I., became the bride of Steven Lawrence Jones, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Jones of Seaford, L.I., and Becket, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Lombard, pastor of the Boothbay (Me.)

title: WIRING EUROPE FOR CABLE TV
description: The rush to wire Western Europe for cable television is on. Virtually every government on the Continent, interested in creating new industry and combating unemployment, is speeding plans to establish cable television networks.

title: Bomb Found in Dusseldorf
description: The police said today that a bomb was found in a rented car outside the offices of Litton Business Systems. The police said it was supposed to go off during the night, but the detonator had been defective. The police said the bomb had apparently been set in connection with Vice President Bush's eight-hour visit to the Dusseldorf area on Saturday.

title: A WALL STREET PARTNER TRIES TO MAKE MARK IN ITALIAN POLITICS
description: In a Renaissance villa here, campaign posters clash with patrician surroundings, young Wall Street men plot their candidate's schedule and Mario d'Urso talks expansively about his plan to represent the Christian Democratic Party in Parliament.

title: PARTISAN DISPUTE DELAYS BILL TO MITIGATE SHOREHAM'S COST
description: A bill to provide relief for Long Island electric customers who must pay for the Shoreham nuclear plant was delayed today when Senate Republicans charged that Assembly Democrats were trying to give credit for the plan to the Democratic candidate for Suffolk County Executive.

title: RYE'S 3 R'S: READING, 'RITING, RENOVATIN'
description: THE week before school closed at the Rye High School, the scene was similar to that in other high schools countywide: students gathered in hallways and classrooms signing yearbooks and talking about their summer plans. What was different at Rye, however, was that this routine school activity -among others throughout the last year - was conducted in the middle of a major school renovation and construction project. While the sound of drilling and hammering has not always been conducive to learning, it has elicited a considerable degree of cooperation, stoicism and humor on the part of all concerned.

title: Programs for Gifted: Another View
description: One of the biggest farces perpetrated on the taxpayer can be programs for the gifted (''Classes for Gifted at Issue,'' June 5). I have seen the advanced placement and honors program at Lawrence High School watered down in the last decade to a euphemism.

title: TRACING THE THREADS OF L.I. HISTORY
description: IN the museum business, a little curiosity can go a long way - sometimes right into a major exhibition. Take the case of Martha V. Pike, assistant director for curatorial affairs at the Museums at Stony Brook.

title: Joie de Vie Captures $376,000 Dexter Cup
description: Joie de Vie, who set a track record of 1:59 2/5 for a mile in the first elimination series, came back to win the $376,000 Dexter Cup Friday night at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Foiled Astronaut
description: She learned to fly a biplane when she was 12 years old, and by 18 she was an accomplished licensed pilot. In early 1960, at 29, she became the first woman to pass all the grueling physical and psychological tests that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration gave to aspiring astronauts.

title: CITY AND TOWN APPROACH MERGER AMID CONTROVERSY
description: ON the night of Dec. 15, after residents of Windham and Willimantic voted to merge their two governments, bottles of champagne were uncorked as the forces that had worked for consolidation celebrated the end of a long battle.

title: AT DATA GENERAL, A SUBDUED 'SOUL'
description: brash management, brash salesmen, brash advertising, brash pricing, brash commissions.

title: Gray Blount and Jerome Fadden Marry
description: Katherine Graham Blount, daughter of Mrs. John Clarence Daughtridge of Charleston, S. C., and Judson Hasse Blount Jr. of Greenville, N.C., was married yesterday in New York to Jerome Tonra Fadden, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Fadden of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Beatrice Blair performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: BOAT INDUSTRY WORKING ITS WAY OUT OF A SLUMP
description: WHENEVER William Swartzbaugh, the director of the Connecticut Marine Trades Association in Essex, answered his telephone a year ago, he feared that it was another marine official reporting that the state's boating industry was sinking fast. Interest rates were climbing, boats were not being bought and marine businesses were folding.

title: Miss Peck and David Krist Wed at 5th Avenue Church
description: Stephanie Peck, daughter of Barbara Peck of Garden City, L.I., and Arthur Peck of Old Westbury and Islip, L.I., was married yesterday to David Peter Krist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Krist of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Prebyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: CONGRESSIONAL REPORT CRITICIZES DRILLING PLAN
description: A Congressional staff report has charged that Interior Secretary James G. Watt's program for offshore oil and gas development could result in huge losses to the United States Treasury.

title: THE TRIAL AND REWARD OF BEING ON JURY DUTY
description: THE jury assembly room on the seventh floor of the Fairfield County Courthouse in Bridgeport looks like a high school auditorium. This is where I reported recently after a computer in Hartford selected my name for jury duty from the lists of voters or motor vehicle operators. It is my first time.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Impact of Competition Most television producers are leary of describing their programs as informational or educational, and Tom G. Robertson is no exception. He is executive producer of ''Winners,'' one of NBC's ''Young People's Specials'' monthly broadcasts. Mr. Robertson said ''Winners'' is ''not a program about facts, it is about human beings.''

title: TOOLING AROUND TOWN; Limousine Logic
description: Small wonder that Mayor Koch sounds sensitive about his new limousine. It is, among other things, a vehicle for instant sniping.

title: VICTORIAN SAVVY
description: Victorian morality has come to serve as a foil for any kind of social ''liberation.'' We think of Victorian society as an unfettered patriarchy in which women were molded into passive and obedient servants, and everyone's sexual appetite was suppressed to the point of neurosis.

title: AFFORDABLE HOMES SNAPPED UP IN MORRIS
description: THEY began waiting on line before the temporary sales office opened a t 9 A.M. By midafternoon, the queue snaked through the parking lot o f the shopping center and people were waiting two hours or more for t he chance to put down a $250 nonbinding deposit to buy a town-house c ondominium in a new complex in Lincoln Park, a small Morris County c ommunity.

title: YANKS TOP RED SOX
description: Jay Howell could not bear to watch. When Rich Gossage relieved him in the eighth inning today, he went directly into the clubhouse and took a shower even though his first victory of the season was on the line.

title: RUTGERS SETS GOALS FOR ITS FRESHMEN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK RUTGERS, the State University, has gone on record with specific skills that a freshman must have to succeed at higher education, and has offered to help the state's public schools teach those competencies.

title: The Father's Role After a Divorce
description: As noted in the recent article ''Men Seek Aid on Family Problems,'' someone stated, ''It's wrong to take a father and reduce him to an unwelcome visitor.''

title:
'BIG BROTHER' AND BUSINESS;
THE U.N.'S BID TO PLAY CONSUMER COP
description: WHILE its peacekeeping activities are experiencing hard times, the U nited Nations is in a growth phase in its regulation of business. Asa case in point, let us focus on the U.N.'s draft Guidelines for C onsumer Protection. These are scheduled to be taken up by the E conomic and Social Council next month.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Chatham Township $112,500 *2*26 Britten Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*20-year-old Cape Cod; Florida room, full basement; *2*taxes $1,881. Fanwood $92,000 *2*256 Paterson Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*62-year-old colonial; built-in bookcases in *2*living room, new kitchen; taxes $2,019. Haledon $85,000 *2*24 Aberdeen Court, 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old *2*2-family; 1 bedroom, 1 bath in 2d *2*apartment; taxes $1,545. South Orange $75,000 *2*332 Meadowbrook Lane, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*60-year-old colonial; new kitchen, bath *2*and lavatory; taxes $2,250. Towaco $163,000 *2*140 Waughaw Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath *2*4-year-old contemporary; pool, 2 fireplaces, central *2*air-conditioning and vacuum; taxes $2,650. Union $83,000 *2*336 Washington Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*39-year-old colonial; track lights in den, *2*basement workbench; taxes $1,586. OTHER AREAS Long Beach, L.I. $67,000 *2*15 Armour Street, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*27-year-old ranch; fireplace, close to water; *2*taxes $1,700.Q Canton, Conn. $91,000 *2*331 Cherrybrook Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*1-year-old contemporary; dramatic setting on *2*pond; 1 acre; taxes $1,660. Mamaroneck, N.Y. $115,000 *2*1032 The Parkway, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 33-year-old *2*frame ranch; beach and boating privileges; *2*taxes $2,337.

title: Uphill Runner Wins in Denver
description: Federico Pena's chances seemed bleak last year when he said that he wanted to be Mayor of Denver. At the time, he was a little-known state legislator and Hispanic citizens, presumed to be his power base, amounted to no more than 18 percent of the population.

title: Florence Brown, A Physician, Wed To F. M. Taylor 3d
description: Dr. Florence M. Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold G. Brown of Evanston, Ill., was married at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn., yesterday to Frederick Morgan Taylor 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor Jr. of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Lake Forest, Ill. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Seymour St. John, former headmaster of the Choate School, of which the bridegroom is a graduate.

title: Catherine M. Richman Marries Thomas R. Wallace
description: Catherine Marshall Richman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Richman of Wilmette, Ill., was married yesterday in New York to Thomas Robert Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Wallace Jr. of Clifton, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: A Banking Officer And Miss Forster Are Wed Upstate
description: Pamela Murray Forster, daughter of Clare Chanler Forster of Boulder, Colo., and Bayard Stuyvesant Forster of New York, was married in Linlithgo, N.Y., yesterday to Henry H. Livingston 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Livingston of New York and Linlithgo. The Rev. Earl Van Leeuwen performed the ceremony at the Livingston Memorial Church (Dutch Reformed), where the couple's common ancestor, Robert Livingston, who emigrated to the New World in 1673, is buried.

title: CONVEYOR SYSTEMS FOR CLOSETS
description: There always seems to be yet another ultimate luxury item. Now it's revolving racks for closets, just like the ones dry-cleaners use. What makes them especially luxurious is that they can't be fitted into any old closet. They require a space that's at least 5 by 8 feet. How many people have closets that big? Or dressing rooms that size to turn into closets? And how many people will invest a minimum of $1,500 for a closet?

title: Hebrew Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: Lieut. Laura Klann Marries E.M. Heid
description: The marriage of Second Lieut. Laura Holly Klann, U.S.A.F., to Edwin Michael Heid took place yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Peter and St. Paul (National Cathedral) in Washington.

title: THE VIEW FROM THE BACK SEAT
description: There was Joseph Cotten in the movie ''The Third Man,'' having just climbed into the back seat of a car in post-World War II Vienna. Suddenly the driver took off like a drag racer, turning corners at speeds that defied the laws of both man and nature. Joseph Cotten knew his time had come.

title: SHULTZ, IN MANILA, AFFIRMS SUPPORT OF U.S. FOR MARCOS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived in the Philippines on the first stop of a four-nation Asian trip today and reaffirmed United States support for President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title:
DINING OUT;
IN THE SHADOW OF THE PAPER MILL
description: THE dearth of good restaurants near Millburn's rejuvenated Paper Mill Playhouse led us to Joe D's in Maplewood, less than a 10-minute drive from the theater. What a golden opportunity for an interesting restaurant to serve a custom-made clientele of arts patrons. Sad to say, Joe D's, which moved from adjacent Springfield to its present site 15 months ago, does not yet fill the playbill.

title: JAPAN'S VOTE TODAY SEEN AS TEST FOR NAKASONE
description: Japanese voters will elect a new upper house of Parliament Sunday and the results are likely to be widely interpreted as a referendum on Yasuhiro Nakasone's first seven months as Prime Minister.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant omissions or lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: JUVENILE CODE: WHO PAYS?
description: IN ONE of his last acts as Governor, Brendan T. Byrne vetoed a proposed Code of Juvenile Justice. The veto was surprising to both supporters and critics of the code, for it had been passed unanimously by the State Senate and Assembly and the Governor's office had expressed no opposition to it during its journey through the Legislature.

title: PARIS
description: To the Editor: The walking tour of French markets was delightful, and I thoroughly enjoyed the article. But how could Patricia Wells leave out almost the biggest and best of all?

title: Roberts Captures Race; Uncini Injured in Crash
description: Americans, led by Kenny Roberts, who won the event, took four of the first five places today in the Dutch Grand Prix motorcycle race.

title: Suzanne Alexandra Matthews Weds Patrick Foye
description: Suzanne Alexandra Matthews, daughter of John W. Matthews Jr. of Jackson Heights, Queens, and the late Dorismarie H. Matthews, was married yesterday to Patrick J. Foye, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luke A. Foye, also of Jackson Heights. The Rev. Eugene F. Donnelly performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of Fatima in Jackson Heights.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in last Sunday's Westchester Weekly section incorrectly identified the chairman of a committee that will establish rules and regulationns concering the new Federal District Court branch of White Plains. The chairman is Judge Lee P. Gagliardi.

title: THE PARTY NEXT DOOR: NOT AN INVITING THOUGHT
description: THE most melancholy sound of summer is that of ice tinkling in glasses at your neighbor's outdoor party. You know, of course, that you wouldn't have gone to it even if you had been invited, which, of course, you weren't. Further, it would have been odd if you were asked, since you didn't think to have them over to your last gala.

title: THE ALLURE OF FLY-FISHING AND A WOMAN'S QUEST TO MASTER IT
description: IHAVE failed to catch fish in some of the finest fishing spots in t he world. I couldn't catch marlin in the aqua waters off Tortola or t rout at Gaston's fishing resort on the White River in Arkansas. I e ven spent a fishless week on the fabled Lough Erne in Northern I reland, where I'd felt destined to catch a fish since few anglers, n o matter how foolhardy, dare to venture to Northern Ireland these d ays.

title: BRIDGING CONSTITUENCIES ON A TIGHTROPE
description: As a former local official, Alfonse M. D'Amato knows that one way to please the politicians back home is to bring them to Washington. So last week the Senator led a delegation of New York State Republican county chairmen around town for a day of briefings on the Hill and at the White House.

title: RIVER FESTIVAL
description: Hartford's third annual July 4 River Festival will be held from 9 A.M. to 10 P.M. next Sunday, July 3, at three locations: the Old Statehouse, Founder's Plaza and Charter Oak Bridge.

title: WHEN FORM DICTATES CONTENT, WHAT HAPPENS TO THE NEWS?
description: In its infancy, one respectable theory says, television news was so eager to separate itself from radio that it tried to ignore the spoken word and do it all with pictures. What the viewer could see was what he would get, and if he could not see it he would not get it. Form dictated content; form even became content. This is still a plausible theory about much of television news.

title: Dr. Louis Warren Dies at 98; Ex-Head of Lincoln Museum
description: Dr. Louis A. Warren, a Lincoln scholar and former director of the Louis A. Warren Lincoln Library Museum in Fort Wayne, Ind., died Tuesday at his home in Fort Wayne. He was 98 years old.

title:
INSURANCE BY GENDER;
BEWARE THE INDUSTRY'S LOGIC
description: WOULD it help women if insurance companies were required to offer t he same rates and benefit packages to men and women? Organizations d evoted to the equality of women and men believe so, and are backing a bill, H.R.100, that requires just that. The insurance industry, on t he other hand, is waging an expensive fight to defeat the bill. The i ndustry is claiming - in full-page advertisements and in a blizzard o f industry-concocted ''personal'' letters to Congress - that s exneutral insurance would hurt women by increasing their overall i nsurance costs.

title: IT'S OPERA TIME AGAIN IN SANTA FE
description: The Santa Fe Opera will resurrect two especially interesting operas for its 1983 season. Offenbach's ''Orpheus in the Underworld'' opens Santa Fe's season in New Mexico on Friday, with John Crosby, general director of the company, conducting, Bliss Hebert directing, and with sets and costumes by Nancy Thun and Steven Feldman, respectively. Neil Rosenshein, tenor, will sing the title role, with two sopranos, Karen Hunt and Sheri Greenawald, alternating in the role of Eurydice.

title: MARINERS DROP THEIR MANAGER
description: The Seattle Mariners, with the worst record in baseball, dismissed Manager Rene Lachemann today and named Del Crandall to replace him.

title: Stuart Bryan Married To Laura Jean Sheetz
description: Laura Jean Sheetz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Sheetz of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married there yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church to Stuart MacArthur Bryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Bryan of Mendon, Mass.

title: ABORTION RULE TO BE CHANGED
description: ARECENT Supreme Court decision that struck down a number of state restrictions on access to abortion made Connecticut's regulation calling for hospitalization for all abortions to be performed after the first three months of pregnancy ''immediately unconstitutional and unenforceable,'' according to Elliot F. Gerson, Deputy State Attorney General.

title: In a Nutshell, Hard to Crack
description: ''Our democratic technological society must dissolve the dissonance between science and the creation of public policy,'' William D. Ruckelshaus told the National Academy of Sciences last week. These were fine words from the new Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, which has caused its share of dissonance lately. Just how to do it, however, remained beyond the scope of his speech.

title: HIGH COST OF ARMS LINKED TO WASTE
description: A senior Defense Department official says that shoddy work by military contractors is adding even more to the cost of military equipment and weapons than an estimate of excesses cited earlier this month.

title: Elizabeth Foote Marries H.E. Jackson
description: Elizabeth Vaughn Foote, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Foote Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Howell Edmunds Jackson, son of Mrs. Kenneth B. Keating of Princeton, N.J., and the late William H. Jackson, were married yesterday at the Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Larry Hill, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: BY BANNON McHENRY
description: BANNON McHENRY is an art historian who lives in New York.

title: Rangers 8, A's 3
description: Bill Stein drove in four runs and Frank Tanana (3-1) combined with John Butcher on a six-hitter to give Texas its fifth straight victory.

title: SONGS: ALBERTA HUNTER RETURNS TO THE COOKERY
description: The redoubtable and resilient Alberta Hunter returned to the Cookery on Wednesday evening to sing for the first time since she collapsed after a performance there last December and was rushed to a hospital, where she underwent surgery and remained for two months. The 88-year-old Miss Hunter, who broke her hip three years ago but who was back in action within three months, walks a little more deliberately than she once did but in no other sense has she slowed down.

title: A Polite Default
description: Larry Scott of Merrick, L.I., was within a point of gaining today's men's final in the Arthur Ashe Classic yesterday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows. Then he walked off the court and defaulted his match to Robert Crames of Great Neck, L.I. No umpire's call had upset him.

title: Teams in N.H.L. Join In Suing Ralston Purina
description: Following the lead of the league, 17 National Hockey League teams have filed a multimillion-dollar counterclaim against Ralston Purina Company as part of the legal battle over the company's efforts to rid itself of the St. Louis Blues.

title: HOMOSEXUALS FIND SUBURBAN LIFE GOOD
description: ASK David Shutz how he likes New York City, and he will tell you that the Big Apple has a worm in it and that he would rather stay in the Bergen County community of Wyckoff and work on his four-bedroom house. Mr. Shutz seems like a typical, if somewhat more-devoted, suburbanite - except that he is a homosexual. And he is not alone. Scattered across the state in towns like Wyckoff, hundreds of homosexual men and women are finding a degree of security, as well as a measure of acceptance from neighbors.

title: OFFICE WORKERS HAIL A VICTORY
description: ON May 18, hundreds of clerical and technical workers at Yale University celebrated a union victory, ending a 2 1/2-year organizing drive. As an anthropologist studying the increased movement toward the unionization of female clerical workers, I have been in a unique position to witness the events of the union drive as they unfolded at this major New England university.

title: Susan Bryce Moore Becomes the Bride Of R.P. Morgenthau in West Virginia
description: Susan Bryce Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Evan Moore 2d of Charleston, W.Va., was married there yesterday to Robert Pattridge Morgenthau, son of Robert M. Morgenthau of New York and the late Martha Pattridge Morgenthau. Federal Judge Pierre N. Leval of New York and Judge Margaret Workman of the 13th District Circuit Court in Charleston performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. John B. Merrill.

title: CHELSEA MEN AND WOMEN
description: Among the Chelsea's inhabitants, past and present: the writer Jakov Lind, above; Mr. and Mrs. Sellis, a blind couple who were kept awake nights by Janis Joplin rehearsing next door, top right; the composer Virgil Thomson, who has made the hotel his home for 40 years, bottom right.

title: GOVERNMENT POWER POISED FOR A GRAND REALIGNMENT
description: WASHINGTON IF the landmark Supreme Court decision overturning the so-called legislative veto had come 15 years ago, the reaction probably would have been mild and predictable. Liberals would have applauded the Court for safeguarding the powers of the Presidency and conservatives would have regretfully observed a little more erosion of the authority of Congress.

title: CONCERT: GUGGENHEIM BAND
description: An annual New York summer tradition of many years' standing was continued Wednesday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell in Lincoln Center, when the Guggenheim Concert Band - formerly the Goldman Band - opened its 66th season of free concerts.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE WOMEN OF BREWSTER PLACE. By Gloria Naylor. (Penguin, $4.95.) Gloria Naylor's first novel, which won an American Book Award this year, is a ''fierce, loving group portrait'' of seven black women who live in the same housing development and fight together, with love and humor, against a hostile world. ''Miss Naylor bravely risks sentimentality and melodrama to write her compassion and outrage large, and she pulls it off triumphantly,'' our critic, Annie Gottlieb, said.

title: TAKE THE QUIZ ON WHAT IS TRIVIAL IN THE SUBURBS
description: RECENTLY I had the opportunity to be the host of a three-hour trivia show to benefit Ossining High School's own radio station, WOSS-FM. The show was a free-form, phone-in affair. An army of arcane county residents bombarded me and the listening audience with questions on such diverse categories as baseball and Broadway, the military and movies, radio and racing. Somewhere late in Hour Three of the show it dawned on me that there was one category that oh so justly deserves to be trivialized and that, to the best of my knowledge, has never been trivialized: Suburbia.

title: EXONERATED OFFICERS RETURN
description: HACKENSACK TWO Bergen County Police Department officers were returned to duty last week after a county grand jury found that they shared no responsibility in the death April 3 of a Middletown, N.Y., motorist in Fort Lee.

title: Chile Gripped by Fear and Doubt
description: Chile's military leaders alternated between concession and repression last week, seemingly uncertain of how to cope with mounting challenges to their rule.

title: Robert E. DeWitt Weds Miss Betts
description: Alison Whitney Betts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan W. Betts of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Manchester, Vt., formerly of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday in Manchester to Robert Evans DeWitt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. DeWitt of Granger, Ind. The Rev. Robert Leslie Clayton performed the ceremony in St. John's Chapel of the Zion Episcopal Church.

title: 1983 U.S. Cars Found To Cost 23.8 a Mile
description: A 1983 American-made car driven 15,000 miles a year for four years will cost an average of 23.8 cents a mile to operate, according to the American Automobile Association.

title: RAILROADS' HEYDAY IN STATE PORTRAYED IN EXHIBIT
description: THE golden age of railroads lives again at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford, in an exhibit titled ''On Time: Track and Trains in Connecticut.''

title: BIKING'S TOUR DE FORCE
description: THERE IS A SAYING HERE,'' RED SMITH, THE sportswriter, wrote from France in 1960, ''that an army from Mars could invade France, the Government could fall and even the recipe for sauce Bearnaise be lost, but if it happened during the Tour de France, nobody would notice.'' In the years since this observation, Governments - but not the Martians -have come and gone and the tarragon-flavored sauce has become available in any grocery store frozen, bottled and canned. The Tour de France itself, the world's premier bicycle endurance race, which sets off for the 70th time this Friday, however, is now escaping some Frenchmen's notice.

title: FORMER OFFICIALS VENT ANGER AT LARGE
description: ''I thought, like Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer, that I'd be coming to watch my own funeral,'' said one at-large member of the New York City Council last week. Reports of his political demise, and that of the at-large system, were not exaggerated. Under a Federal court ruling, the eight boroughwide members - two others have already resigned - lost their jobs when the Charter Revision Commission recommended that the seats be abolished. The commission was appointed by Mayor Koch after the election of two at-large members from each borough regardless of population differences was ruled a violatation of the Constitution's one man, one vote principle. The recommendation will be put before the voters in November. If they don't concur - an event considered improbable - the Mayor said the courts would be likely to eliminate the positions anyway. The seats were created in 1963 to provide minority parties with a greater Council role - no borough could elect two at-large members from the same party - and to give some representatives a broader constituency than a single district. But they came to be viewed by minority groups as a means of diluting their voting strength, a contention backed up by the panel, which noted that only one of the 50 at-large members elected during the past 20 years was a Hispanic politician and none were black. The panel considered various methods to preserve some sort of at-large system, but judged none satisfactory. ''Under the circumstances,'' said Michael I. Sovern, the commission chairman, ''to place a proposal for at-large representation on the ballot would be both unwise and provocative.''

title: EUROPEAN TALES AND DANTE'S CITY
description: Florencewalks By Anne Holler. Photographs by Daniel Bloch. 192 pages. New Republic/Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $9.95 paperback.

title: AUDIO SPLITS ALONG CLASS LINES
description: For four hectic days each June, the city of Chicago transforms itself into a giant sounding board for the latest offerings of the audio industry. Trend spotters and prognosticators have a field day among the clangorous acres of sonic gadgetry spreading across McCormick Place - Chicago's vast exhibition hall - and spilling over into the hotels along Michigan Avenue. My own impression, based on what was seen and heard at Chicago, is that the whole audio field is about to crack open in a huge split.

title: BASE PLAN RAISES HONDURAN TENSION
description: The scheduled arrival next week of 1,000 Salvadoran soldiers for training by United States Army advisers on Honduran soil has created political strains here, according to Hondurans of varied political views and foreign diplomats.

title: TEACHERS UNIONS ARE COURTED AND CASTIGATED
description: In past years, the country's two large teacher groups, the National Education Association and the American Federation of Teachers, could brush off criticism of the schools with some confidence that there would be no disturbing changes. Lately, however, education has become a topic of political debate at the highest levels and teachers may no longer be able to escape the calls for reform.

title: EXPLORATION FOR KNOWLEDGE IS BECOMING A SEARCH FOR PROFIT
description: In the early days of the space age, it was achievement enough just to get something up and in orbit, anything to prove it could be done. The goals were essentially political, with the United States and the Soviet Union striving to match each other shot for shot.

title: It Isn't How, It's How Many
description: The convoluted redistricting map devised by New Jersey Democrats didn't need a Hermann Rorschach to figure out its meaning. One Congressional district nipped corners of seven densely populated northern counties. Another cut a thin sliver through four counties, almost circling back on itself. A third, dubbed the ''flying duck,'' looped in a meandering arc of more than 100 miles. All to the advantage of the Democrats.

title: 175 Killed in Indian Floods
description: At least 175 people have died in flash floods that hit parts of India's western state of Gujarat this week, and another 275 people are missing, the Press Trust of India reported today. The press agency quoted state authorities as saying the floods, caused by three days of monsoon rains, had affected some 170,000 people in 225 villages in Gujarat.

title: ANDERSON GETS THE CREDIT BUT CUOMO GETS HIS BILLS
description: This is Warren M. Anderson's time of year. The leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate is always a key figure in the marble halls of the Statehouse. But during the last few days, it sometimes seemed that he was the key figure, outshining luminaries such as the Governor and the Assembly Speaker.

title: Ashley P. Riegel Becomes a Bride
description: Ashley Pierson Riegel and Edward Allen Harrington, who are teachers, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony.

title: Tapp Wins First Event In Seattle Open Bowling
description: After six years on the Pro Bowlers Tour, Charlie Tapp won his first career event today with a 229-208 victory over Wayne Webb in the Seattle Open.

title: Holly Burks, P.A. Becker Are Married
description: Elizabeth Hollister Burks, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Parnelle Burks of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Paul Avery Becker, son of Roland George Becker and the Rev. Jane Barnes Becker of Westborough, Mass. The Rev. John Crocker Jr. performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: PHILS BEAT METS, 4-2
description: The Mets kept the opposition on the run yesterday, much to the liking of the Philadelphia Phillies. The Phillies backed the pitching debut of Kevin Gross with only six hits but they also had six stolen bases, matching the National League high this season, and ran up a 4-2 victory over the Mets before 24,551 fans at Shea Stadium.

title: POPE'S TRIP STIRS VATICAN DEBATE ON POLITICAL ROLE
description: Pope John Paul II's eight-day visit to Poland has added fuel to a muted but persistent debate in the Vatican over his involvement in political events in his homeland.

title: The Algarve
description: To the Editor: The article by Ralph Blumenthal ''The Algarve: Not Just a Sunny Place (Travel, June 5) has a sin of commission and a sin of omission. e does not seem to realize that a kilo (a universal weight in Europe) contains 2.2 pounds. If a kilo of oranges or melons costs $1.20, the cost per pound would be 55 cents.

title: CALCULATING THE POWER OF THE DOLLAR
description: E. J. DIONNE Jr. is a correspondent in the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: The Science of Animal Behavior
description: Regarding the article on Long Islanders on May 29 (''Talking to Animals Is His Career''): When an animal behaviorist is called upon, it is for the very obvious reason that a pet is posing some kind of problem in the home.

title: GENERALS DEFEAT ARIZONA
description: The New Jersey Generals defeated the Arizona Wranglers tonight, 21-14, with Herschel Walker out of action for most of the game because of an eye problem.

title: Brewers 7, Indians 2
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Milwaukee, held to one hit by Cleveland's Juan Eichelberger through seven innings, erupted for seven runs in the eighth to break the game open. Jim Slaton (7-2) earned the victory.

title: FEAR AND FRUSTRATION BESET MIDWEST MIRED IN RECESSION
description: An angry collection of 30 unemployed men and women stood up and seized the microphone just as a Congressional field hearing into industrial problems was starting in Cleveland two weeks ago. They said they wanted to talk about jobs and high utility bills, but underlying everything they said were fear of the future, frustration with the present and a sense of powerlessness and rage.

title: Familiar Fears About Qaddafi
description: Twenty months ago, when the Libyan leader Muammar el-Qaddafi thought he would be presiding over the Organization of African Unity, he abruptly halted attempts to merge Libya with its southern neighbor, Chad. Last week, less than a month after the O.A.U. squelched Colonel Qaddafi's upward striving, his forces were again reported in Chad.

title: CUOMO ROLE IS ANOTHER SHOREHAM ISSUE
description: ALBANY GOVERNOR CUOMO'S policy on nuclear power plants has, by all accounts, gone through several phases during his first six months in office. The nuclear plant issue has arisen on several fronts, but nowhere is the development of Mr. Cuomo's policy laid out more clearly than in his public statements on the Long Island Lighting Company's nearly finished nuclear power generating plant at Shoreham.

title: AN OUTPOST OF ARTISTIC FREEDOM IS IN TROUBLE
description: AHUMAN rights/artistic freedom dream is about to die in Jersey City. The C.A.S.E.
