(Committee for the Absorption of Soviet Emigres) Museum of Russian Contemporary Art in Exile, a museum that began with a whirl of publicity, a promising collection and the participation and encouragement of Congressmen, art critics and artists of great reputation in the Soviet Union and elsewhere, may have to close.

title: Anne de Ravel d'Esclapon Is Married to Bryan Miller
description: Anne de Ravel d'Esclapon, daughter of Francois de Ravel d'Esclapon of Montady, France, and the late Marie Therese Crusiaux, was married yesterday to Bryan Miller, son of Mrs. Benjamin Butkus of Andover, N.J., and the late Albert J. Miller of New York. The ceremony was performed at the couple's home in Westport, Conn., by Justice of the Peace Wendell Scott Stephenson of West Hartford, Conn.

title: HER MARK IS ON THE COINAGE
description: At noon Tuesday a ceremony is to be held in the park behind Independence Hall here to celebrate the new Olympic silver dollar. The coin features a discus thrower in motion, and under his right foot, in a monogram, are the initials ''E.J.''

title: Bargaining Legislation Is Called Inimical
description: While I agree with the language of the State Supreme Court in its 1978 Ridgefield Park decision, which was quoted by Bernard Kirshtein on the June 12 Opinion Page,

title: BY PAUL HOFMANN
description: PAUL HOFMANN, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Europe.

title: THE WILL TO POWER
description: MODERN TIMES The World From the Twenties to the Eighties. By Paul Johnson. 817 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $27.95.

title: Megan Neyer Gains Pan Am Team Spot
description: Megan Neyer is the current world champion in 3-meter springboard diving, but today she was down to her last chance to make the United States Pan American Games team - and she had to take that chance on the 10-meter platform.

title: FEDERAL FRUIT REPOSITORY PLANNED FOR UPSTATE
description: A repository of apple trees and grapevines is being established here as part of a Federal system to preserve the genetic base of American fruits.

title: Cubs 2, Expos 1
description: MONTREAL (AP) - Consecutive doubles by Ryne Sandberg and Bill Buckner broke a 12th-inning tie and enabled the Cubs to snap a sixgame losing streak.

title: RENT RISES SHOCK CITY-PROPERTY TENANTS
description: IN 1980, Mayor Koch issued an executive order requiring market-valuer ents on properties the city had condemned in urban-renewal areas. Toa ccomplish this, private appraisers were hired to evaluate more than 2 00 properties rented by small businesses and nonprofit groups t hroughout the city.

title: SERVICE INSTEAD OF JAIL GAINING PROPONENTS
description: NEARLY every night, Arthur B. Powers, the former State Transportation Commissioner, leaves his insurance job in Berlin and goes to the Morgan Street Courthouse in Hartford, where he cleans and scrubs walls, washes windows, shellacs furniture and does any other maintenance work that might be needed.

title: SWISS PONDER FUTURE STATUS OF 8 RUSSIANS
description: Eight Soviet soldiers captured by Afghan guerrillas are serving two years of internment in the relatively pleasant surroundings of a minimum-security detention center in the foothills of the Alps.

title: GIMMICKS ALONE CAN'T MAKE A SEQUEL FLY
description: Are there new ideas for movies any more? This summer, there hardly seem to be. Audiences that once enjoyed the luxury of deciding what they cared to see can now choose chiefly what to see more of. What's worse, few of the current sequels, remakes and rehashes appear to have arisen out of any genuine need for their characters to be resurrected, or their stories to be retold. There's simply money to be made by providing more of the same: The motives for making a sequel are, in most cases, quite transparent - capitalize on the success of the familiar hit, instead of risking something uncertain and new. So the goose that lays golden eggs has been persuaded to work overtime.

title: FIREHOUSE BECOMES HIS OWN 'MUSEUM'
description: IT is not unusual for an artist in the Hamptons to adapt a barn, church or other roomy structure for use as a studio; this practice has been going on there for at least 40 years. The latest such conversion in Bridgehampton is unique, however, in that while it includes some studio space, it is principally devoted to the display of one artist's work, exactly as that artist wishes it to be seen. In effect, it is a made-to-order minimuseum of a type to be found nowhere else on the Island.

title: By Sports of Times; The New Math
description: THE humorist Myron Cohen tells a story about the old man who was watching a basketball game on television when his friend stopped by. ''What's the score?'' his friend asked. ''87-85,'' the old man replied, not looking up. ''Yes, but who's winning?'' ''87,'' the old man said. In the National Basketball Association, life once was that simple. But no longer. In the new math of the recent collective-bargaining agreement with the Players Association, five free-spending teams, including the Knicks and the Nets, are limited to fixed amounts on their player payrolls next season. Not that the workers will be dunking for a pittance. The 12 members of the Knicks must survive on a total of $4.6 million: the Nets must struggle on a total of $3.75 million.

title: BY MARK STEINBRINK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark Steinbrink writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: GAS BLAST BRINGS STRICTER RULES AT DUMPS
description: A NATURAL byproduct of the day-to-day buildup of garbage, always a hazard on Long Island, has now turned into a greater threat. Methane gas caused by decomposing garbage is being emitted from all of the Island's 22 landfills, according to the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, and in high concentrations it has proved to be lethal, as was the case recently at the Babylon town dump.

title: BALDWIN
description: JAMES MONTALBANO had always made it look so easy to play the big Bluther grand for the sippers and suppers that when he asked me to sit in for him for just one hour on a certain midweek night in Rockville Centre's Lincoln Inn, I said sure, I said fine, I said why not? I'd done it elsewhere many times.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''Yellow Fever,'' a droll comedy caper by R. A. Shiomi, has reopened with its original cast for an unlimited Off Broadway run at the 47th Street Theater, 304 West 47th Street. If you missed it last winter, put it on your theatrical calendar.

title: Wendy Jane Burd Weds Michael Jude Harrington
description: Wendy Jane Burd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Burd of Bernardsville, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Jude Harrington, son of Catherine A. Harrington of Doylestown, Pa., and Michael S. Harrington of Aurora, Colo. The Rev. Dr. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Basking Ridge, N.J., assisted by the Rev. William Warren.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:Where can we find information on home exchanges? -G.L.T., Colorado Springs, Colo. Answer:Among organizations offering home exchange information or services are the following:

title: Robin Richall Is Married
description: The marriage of Robin Claudette Richall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Richall of Stamford, Conn., and Greenwich, N.Y, to John H. Hobbs 3d took place in Bedford Village, N.Y., yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Hobbs, president of ''21'' Brands in New York, and Mrs. Hobbs, also of Stamford. Msgr. Martin J. McDermott performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Obstacles to Progress Racial discrimination exists, says the economist Dr. Walter Williams, but it cannot completely explain the unfortunate economic situation some black Americans find themselves in. Two main obstacles to black economic progress, Dr. Williams believes, are the $3.35-an-hour minimum wage and the government's regulations of economic activity, such as licensing.

title: MUSIC: ALLIANCE FOR SONG AND 60 AMERICAN YEARS
description: Because vocal music, apart from opera, needs all the performance encouragement it can get nowadays, the persevering Alliance for American Song deserves heaps of praise. Directed by Peter Perrin, the alliance has been ferreting out and performing American songs and other works for voice for six years now, covering an enormous range of period and compositional styles along the way.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS IT happens in bars, airplanes and beauty parlors, in doctors' waiting rooms, and lines that snake around movie theaters. One person begins talking to another, casually at first, then starts to outline a problem in his life. The listener, who may or may not be used to the outpouring of small and large sufferings, must in some way react.

title: IRAN AND IRAQ REPORT GULF ATTACKS
description: Both Iran and Iraq reported they had bombed targets in the Persian Gulf today, and Iran said it killed 200 Iraqi soldiers and wounded 250 in the northern sector of their battlefront.

title: Miss Kirby Is Married To Mark T. Walsh Jr.
description: Elizabeth A. Kirby, daughter of Josephine Kirby Lustgarten of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., and the late Frank J. Kirby, was married yesterday to Mark T. Walsh Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh of Carmel, N.Y. The Rev. John J. Keaveney performed the ceremony at St. James the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Carmel.

title: JERSEY SEEKS LAW TO REGULATE CASINO UNIONS
description: Legislation has been introduced in the House of Representatives that would allow New Jersey to regulate the unions that represent employees at casinos and casino hotels.

title: Boxing Bill Gains in Albany
description: An agreement on a bill that would involve a major reworking of New York's boxing laws was announced tonight by key members of the State Legislature.

title: THE MALAISE IN LAW SCHOOLS
description: David Margolick's concern for what is happening in America's law schools is shared by many. I would like to suggest, however, that this concern should focus on the law-school admission process.

title: FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE FOR OFFICIALS IN CITY IS UPHELD
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that New York City can require police and fire officials to disclose details of their personal finances.

title: WHEN IDEAS GO BEGGING
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox 8, Twins 3
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Carlton Fisk homered and added three singles as LaMarr Hoyt (9-7) picked up his seventh victory in his last eight decisions.

title: INSECTICIDE IS FOUND IN 2 BOTTLES OF SAUCE FROM STORES IN JERSEY
description: The New Jersey Health Department found insecticide today in two bottles of Gravy Master Seasoning and Browning Sauce taken from stores in two northern New Jersey communities, officials said.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: TURN the corner from George Street, go left onto Albany Street toward the Raritan River and, suddenly, you think you are walking into an 18th-century garden and arcade in the middle of New Brunswick.

title: OFFICIAL'S INDICTMENT MAY RESHAPE CAROLINA RACES
description: The indictment of Lieut. Gov. James C. Green for bribery has come like lightning before a thunderstorm. Mr. Green, who is a contender for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, has insisted that he will press his campaign. His case may affect several races next year, when a large number of statewide offices will be on the ballot, including the the seat held by Senator Jesse Helms.

title: For Newsmen, Death on a Honduran Road
description: Official and public interest in Central America is reflected in the presence there of a large press contingent, sometimes with tragic results. Last week two American newsmen, Dial Torgerson, a Los Angeles Times correspondent, and Richard Cross, a photographer working for U.S. News & World Report, were killed by a rocket-propelled grenade while driving along a road in Honduras just over the border from Nicaragua. Since 1979, four American journalists - among more than 50 local and foreign news people - have died in Central America.

title: Stavisky-Stavisky Bill Is a First in Legislature
description: State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky, a Queens Democrat, entered the annals of legislative footnotes today by becoming the first person to be the sponsor of the same bill in both houses here.

title: IN BRONX, 'DESPERADOES' BATTLE CRIME
description: When burglars broke into George and Hydee Matos's hardware store in the central Bronx last month for the third time in three years, they made off with electrical equipment valued at $4,000. A few blocks away, within the last few weeks, thieves broke into a dress factory owned by Victor and Rose Davi, taking 13 sewing machines.

title: A Bow to Staten Island
description: Staten Islanders pay a high price for the privilege of being New Yorkers, a legislative report concluded last week. It it seceded, the ''forgotten borough'' could cut sales and property taxes, hire 500 more policemen or firemen and, if not cease to be a repository for thousands of tons of garbage from other parts of the city at least profit from it, the Senate Finance Committee study found.

title: Palestinian Rights Parley
description: The Committee on Conferences gave final approval Friday to plans to hold a conference on Palestinian rights Aug. 29 to Sept. 7 in Geneva.

title: OILS SHOW BATHES IN SUCCESS
description: ''SIX PAINTERS'' at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers through July 17 is, as the catalogue laconically states, a show about paint and about looking. But it is also very much about New York art: It flows with the mainstream, but also stands apart from that stream as a kind of sober-sided commentary on current enthusiasms.

title: THE SUBJECT IS DANCE
description: Dance, a major focus at the State University of New York at Purchase, is the subject of an unusual exhibition opening today in the Neuberger Museum on campus.

title: RECITAL: EVE WEISS, GUITARIST
description: Eve Weiss, a guitarist who has studied with Oscar Ghiglia and Manuel Barrueco and who now teaches in New York, made her local debut at Cami Hall on Wednesday night. Her program included works by Sor, Ponce, Brouwer and Richard Rodney Bennett and the performer's own transcription of Bach's Cello Suite No. 1.

title: THE BENEFITS OF MEDIATING RATHER THAN LITIGATING A DIVORCE
description: To the Editor:

title: AFFORDABLE HOMES, WITH AMENITIES
description: When Steven A. Klar, a Long Island builder, was looking for a place to put a development of moderately priced homes, he could find no land left in his home territory at a reasonable price. He went far afield to Chester, in Rockland County, where he found 77 acres, enough space to build 690 attached condominium homes.

title:
STAMPS;
TRIBUTE TO BASEBALL'S IMMORTAL 'SULTAN OF SWAT'
description: Babe Ruth, widely regarded as the greatest baseball player who ever lived, is appearing on a new commemorative that depicts him in a characteristic moment - hitting a home run. The new 20-cent issue, the third in the ongoing American Sports Series, is being put out on July 6 in Chicago, Ill., in conjunction with the 1983 All-Star Game in Comiskey Park. This year marks the 50th anniversary of the first All-Star Game in 1933, a game in which Ruth hit a home run, scoring two runs and winning the game.

title: City Farm Woes
description: The problem New York City faced last January was how to keep the horses on the farm while disposing of the farm as an economy measure. The 175-acre property in Otisville, N.Y., was both a retirement home for city police horses and a laboratory that provided animal blood for medical tests.

title: COPING WITH CRIME IN OFFICE BUILDINGS
description: CRIME, and the fear of crime, have become priority concerns to the p eople who own, manage and work in New York City's office and c ommercial buildings. Some recent crimes, like these, have attracted p ublic attention:

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: DANCE: 'CALCIUM LIGHT' PERFORMED BY CITY BALLET'
description: Peter Martins's ''Calcium Light Night'' is a perfect ''Balanchine ballet'' in the way it makes the music almost visible on stage. The ballet, presented by the New York City Ballet on Friday at the New York State Theater, takes eight small orchestral pieces by Charles Ives and recreates them with two dancers' bodies and the space around those bodies.

title: USING THE RUY LOPEZ
description: The elephantine gait of the modern Ruy Lopez discourages an impatient player, but it does not put off a winner. Its development is ponderous; even its preparations have to be prepared. None of the other double-KP openings requires or makes provision for such a diversity of moves to limit what the opponent can do.

title: NEW GALLERY OPENS WITH NUN'S WORKS
description: JERSEY CITY AMONG the artists moving from Manhattan into apartments and lofts here is a diminutive nun who is making a name for herself with feminist paintings and satirical Pop art.

title: Nuptials for Susan Pincus
description: The marriage of Susan Terri Pincus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving M. Pincus of White Plains, to Dr. Douglas T. Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Miller of New Rochelle, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Harrison Jewish Center.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
ANOTHER MAJOR COIN COLLECTION IS PUT UP FOR SALE
description: The parade of major coin sales involving famed collections will continue late this summer when Stack's of New York offers Greek and Roman coins identified with J. Pierpont Morgan. The 101 coins - 86 in gold, the remainder in silver - will be sold at public auction Sept. 14 in New York.

title: 1970'S DIOXIN SPRAYER APOLOGIZES AT HEARING
description: Russell Bliss, a waste hauler, has apologized to his neighbors for spraying a local road with oil tainted with dioxin but has said he did not know the oil contained the chemical.

title: 2 Men Killed in Newark Fire; 8 Escape From Apartments
description: Two men were killed early today and eight people were left homeless when a fire swept through a brick apartment building, officials said.

title: 36 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 36 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named 10 that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for having failed to do so.

title:
INSURANCE BY GENDER;
PRICING BY RISK: FAIR TO BOTH SEXES
description: AS a person with a dedication to objectivity and to fair play, I am d isappointed when a practice is condemned despite being backed by l ogic, sound reasoning and demonstrable validity. The practice in q uestion is that of considering the sex of an insured person in s etting premium rates for life and health insurance, pension plans a nd auto insurance.

title: POP-JAZZ: A BRAZILIAN TRIO
description: Azymuth, the Brazilian pop-jazz trio that appeared at the Bottom Line Thursday, skillfully extends the languid pulse of 1960's bossa nova into the realms of jazz-fusion and funk. Where Brazilian samba lends itself to the sort of patterned electric mood music that has given jazz-fusion a dubious reputation, Azymuth is an improvisational trio in which the electric keyboards, played by Jose Roberto Bertrami, and Alex Malherios's electric bass interact like two lead instruments.

title: CBS News Division Receives Word on Cuts
description: Following a meeting on Friday between senior executives of CBS News and Gene Jankowski, president of the CBS Broadcast Group, the network news division announced that it had been ''assured of the necessary financial and personnel resources'' to continue operating in a competitive manner.

title: Brussels
description: To the Editor: The excellent article on Brussels did not mention the Museum of the Congo, one of the world's great collections of African art. It is located on the Louvain Road, only a 20-minute ride from Brussels by tram or car. MARCIA WAGNER Winnetka, Ill.

title: ASSAD BANISHES ARAFAT, AND PERHAPS SOME P.L.O. HOPES
description: Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasir Arafat was preparing to board his flight out of Damascus Friday, having just been told by the Syrians that he was no longer welcome in their country, when a lowly Syrian lieutenant colonel reportedly walked up to him, looked him in the eye and sputtered: ''Mr. Arafat, you are persona non grata.''

title: FOR THE NEW ETHIOPIA, OLD TROUBLES GRIND ON
description: Nine years after the overthrow of Emperor Haile Selassie, political signboards here still proclaim, ''Revolutionary Motherland or Death.''

title: CAUGHT RED-HANDED
description: Tass, the Soviet news agency, is fast on accusations and slow on double meanings in English. When Moscow expelled an American diplomat recently, Tass announced that the embassy attache had been ''caught red-handed during a spy action in Moscow.''

title: Victoria Seixas Is Married To Paolo Pelosini, Artist
description: Victoria Seixas, daughter of Norma Seixas of Englewood, N.J., and Donald Seixas of New York, was married yesterday to Paolo Pelosini of New York.

title: F.D.R.'S COALITION AWAITS A SPARK
description: Old New Dealers never die; they just fade away trying to answer the question, ''What ever became of the Roosevelt coalition of the 1930's and 1940's?''

title: AT THE TAPPAN ZEE, AN ARMY (AND NAVY) OF WORKERS
description: GUS TSAKOUNIS walks across three lanes of traffic on his way to work. Like most of the men on the maintenance crew of the Tappan Zee Bridge, he dodges the onslaught of traffic with a bullfighter's bravura. Only the bulls in this case are 18-wheel tractor trailers, 33-foot Winnebagos and cars manned by drivers that the bridgepainting supervisor definitely distrusts. ''The roadway is the most dangerous place to work,'' is the way Mr. Tsakounis describes it.

title: Sabin, $5.80, Wins Belmont Turf Race
description: Eddie Maple and a 3-year-old filly named Sabin played catch-me-ifyou-can with 11 older fillies yesterday at Belmont Park and their dare just lasted. Sabin stretched her early speed over 10 furlongs on the Widener Turf Course to win the $88,350 New York Handicap by a head.

title: Rekindling Warmth
description: To the Editor:

title: Beyond the Budget Votes
description: The House and Senate last week agreed on targets for Federal spending and taxes in 1984, and duly congratulated themselves on grappling with some unpleasant decisions. But many tough long-range issues remain to be tackled. Among them:

title: TIGERS DEFEAT ORIOLES'PALMER
description: Chet Lemon drove in five runs with two homers and the relief pitcher Doug Bair earned a victory in his first appearance with Detroit to lead the Tigers to a 9-3 triumph over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

title: BRIDGEPORT POLICE ASSAILED
description: THE operation of the Bridgeport Police Department is the target of some scathing criticism made in a report issued by a Washington-based consulting concern.

title: Tuning Up the Smoking Hazards
description: The warning on cigarette packages and advertisements that ''Smoking Is Dangerous to Your Health'' was presumably a factor in reducing the ranks of adult smokers from 41.7 percent of the population in 1965 to 32.6 percent in 1980. That's not good enough for Congress, where both houses are moving to require warnings that present smoking's dangers in gruesome detail.

title: THE MATURING OF A BULL MARKET
description: LAST Aug. 12 - a day when the news was dominated by the Israeli bombing of Beirut and the death of Henry Fonda - something important happened on Wall Street: The bull came out of the chute. Few noticed it then, but the strongest stock market since the end of World War II had just begun. Today, nearly a year later, spiraling stock prices have created $775 billion in new wealth and have lifted the Dow Jones industrial average 60 percent, to a record high of 1,248.30 just 10 days ago.

title: McHale Talks Recessed
description: Dave DeBusschere, the Knicks' executive vice president, was at his summer home on Long Island. John Sandquist, Kevin McHale's agent, was at his home in Mercer Island, Wash., and McHale, the Boston Celtics' free-agent power forward, was in Minnesota.

title: DANCE: 'LES NOCES' BY BALLET THEATER
description: Jerome Robbins's version of ''Les Noces,'' Stravinsky's dancecantata about a Russian peasant wedding, is one of the most impressive spectacles in American Ballet Theater's repertory, and it was impressive once again when it was revived on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Kathryn Shands, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Kathryn Nugent Shands, daughter of Mrs. Harley C. Shands of New York and Chilmark, Mass., and the late Dr. Shands, was married yesterday to Dr. Joseph Mulinare, son of Mrs. Anthony Mulinare of Harrison, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mulinare. The Rev. Elden H. Mills performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

title: Kerry Crandall Weds Timothy Hewitt Fast
description: Kerry Crandall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Crandall of Afton, Iowa, was married yesterday in South Britain, Conn., to Timothy Hewitt Fast, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Fast of New York and Southbury, Conn. The Rev. Richard Merrick performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: REPAIRING HOUSE SIDING CORRECTLY
description: ALTHOUGH wood clapboard and similar types of wood siding will normally last for the life of the house if reasonably well maintained by proper painting or staining at periodic intervals, siding boards do sometimes crack and split - or get damaged by accidents of various kinds (for example, when struck by a hard-hit baseball or by a thrown rock).

title: New Mexico on Alert For Spread of the Plague
description: The persistence of plague in New Mexico, with a record 10 cases reported this month, has led health officials to set up a system to quickly block the spread of the contagious form of the disease.

title: UPGRADING EDUCATION: MERIT PAY IS NOT THE WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; Tooling Around Town; Bizarre Bazaars
description: ''Almost everyone goes to the bazaar,'' the man said. ''I go myself and it's wonderful.'' The bazaar is in Kashgar, China, a stop on the legendary Silk Road, and among its wares are horse bridles and camel bells, window frames for mud-brick houses and rugs to brighten up a yurt.

title: FAST GROWTH LEADS TO FEAR OF INFLATION
description: The Return of Inflation? Now that Paul Volcker need not fret about his reappointment as Fed chairman, economists say he should be worrying that the fast pace of recovery will rekindle inflation. Two key indicators show they may be right. The Commerce Department's flash forecast for second-quarter growth showed a strong 6.6 percent annual rate of increase, which would be the strongest quarter in more than two years. At the same time, consumer prices popped one-half a percentage point in May. Mr. Volcker seems to have one of two alternatives - either let the money supply, and thus the economy, grow unhindered and risk losing credibility in his fight against inflation, or clamp down again on money supply growth, which would send interest rates soaring and dampen the recovery.

title: Campanella Resting
description: Roy Campanella, the former Brooklyn Dodgers catcher, was listed in ''good'' condition Friday after undergoing surgery for removal of an external ulcer at Northridge General Hospital in Los Angeles. Campenella, 61, was the Dodgers' starting catcher from 1949 through 1957. His career ended in January 1958 when an automobile accident left him partly paralyzed.

title: Abigail Homans Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Hampton Barnes of Edgemont, Pa., and Dark Harbor, Me., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Barnes's daughter, Abigail Homans, to Henry L.B. Wilder of San Francisco, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Fessenden Wilder of Essex, Conn., and MacMahan Island, Me. An Aug. 27 wedding is planned.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Three springs have come, and the sun is still shining. The grass is still green.

title: FIREMAN-SCHOLAR WORKS TO ALLEVIATE STRESS OF JOB
description: As a fireman at Ladder Company 26 in Harlem, Lieut. Robert Quilty says, he shared the tension, fear and depression the men around him frequently experienced working out of Manhattan's busiest firehouse.

title: ILLEGAL SOUND OF FIREWORKS HERALDS JULY 4
description: On the streets of Manhattan's Upper West Side these days, the exploding sounds of illegal Fourth of July fireworks fill the night. Blockbusters, pineapples, firecrackers and M-80's are the loudest and most popular. As Independence Day approaches, explosions can be heard in every borough of the city and in the suburbs.

title: PEOPLE TO WHOM THINGS HAPPEN
description: THE TIMES ARE NEVER SO BAD A Novella and Eight Short Stories. By Andre Dubus. 180 pp. Boston: David R. Godine. $13.95.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE director of the Environmental Sciences Laboratory at the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Medicine in New York says there is no telling how people who live near dioxin dumps react to low-level exposures to the chemical over long periods.

title: PAINTING ON CLAY: NEW, BUT OLD
description: WITH clay, taking liberties often means taking control. This can be seen these days as increasing numbers of artists assert their autonomy over the kiln by applying paint to fired surfaces. Within the context of recent ceramic history, this seems to be a startling new development.

title: A RICH LEGACY OF HISTORY LIES HIDDEN ALONG THE SHORE
description: WHEN luggage-laden, shore-bound cars begin lining up at toll booths along the Garden State Parkway next Friday - the start of the long holiday weekend - many of their occupants will be following a seasonal migratory path at least 200 years old.

title: John Regan 3d Is Wed To Tracy Ann Villani
description: Tracy Ann Villani, daughter of Mrs. Peter P. Villani of Plymouth, Mass., and the late Mr. Villani, was married yesterday to John MacVeigh Regan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Regan Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I. The Rev. Daniel Lynch performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Plymouth.

title: DISCOVERING AMERICAN INDIAN ART
description: American Indian art and artifacts have been enthusiastically collected and studied here and abroad for decades. Most of the craft techniques employed by American Indians seem familiar, especially in the everyday objects they made - the carved-wood bowls, woven blankets, quill-embellished moccasins, bead-decorated bags and willow baskets. What is surprising and frustrating, therefore, is how little we know about these objects and the artisans who created them.

title: CELEBRATING PENNSYLVANIA'S GERMAN ROOTS
description: BARBARA CROSSETTE, an assistant foreign editor of The New York Times, is the editor of ''America's Wonderful Little Hotels and Inns'' (Congdon & Weed).

title: Proust's Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: LONG ISLAND EXPRESSWAY and Northern State Parkway veterans have some new scenery these days - 74 steel structures spanning the highways that look like fledgling bridges but are actually the superstructure for computerized traffic signs that will go into action in a year or so.

title: Nuclear Agency In the Wringer
description: Just before his subcommittee began hearings last week on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's conduct, Representative Edward J. Markey of Massachusetts put the issue plainly: Has the commission compromised its independence as regulator of the nuclear industry? A subcommittee staff report had already answered ''yes.'' The report said that N.R.C. inspectors regularly contravened agency rules by showing their notes to companies under scrutiny and that they were not disciplined for making such disclosures.

title:
ABOUT MEN;
BUYING A BASEBALL GLOVE
description: The New York Times Magazine's new weekly column, About Men, will address a broad range of male-related topics of interest to both sexes. The column will include essays, reportage, service pieces and advice on personal appearance.Edward Tivnan is a freelance writer based in New York.

title: Nature Book Is Fine Reading
description: WHEN you visit the Eastern seaboard in the company of George Reiger, via his ''Wanderer on My Native Shore'' (Simon & Schuster), you will be with a superb observer and a first-rate writer. The book is a brilliant blend of a naturalist's diary, human encounters, sociology, geology, economics and wise, compassionate and sometimes acerbic comment on man's astonishingly ambivalent relationship with the planet that sustains him.

title: CHAD SAYS REBELS HOLD A THIRD OF THE COUNTRY
description: The Government said today that Libyan-backed rebels now controlled about a third of the country. On Friday Chad reported that the insurgents captured the strategic northern town of Largeau, also known as Faya, which was attacked Thursday.

title: New Evidence in A Blood Mystery
description: A shortage of white blood cells leaves the human body open to disease; a great excess of them is a disease. The means to control these conditions has eluded scientists, but now researchers at Ohio's Wright State University medical school say they've found the regulatory mechanism - a hormone called granulopoietin - for one type of white blood cell.

title: DECLINE IN CHURCH MEMBERSHIP NEARLY STOPPED, COUNCIL SAYS
description: Church membership in the United States increased slightly in the past two years, and there are signs the membership decline in some Protestant denominations has nearly abated, according to the National Council of Churches.

title: Dorothy Wehman Is Married
description: Dorothy Ann Wehman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wehman of Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to Robert John Camposa, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Camposa of Syosset, L.I. The Rev. John Sullivan performed the ceremony at SS. Philip and James Roman Catholic Church in St. James, L.I. The bride is a ticket sales agent with Trans World Airlines. Mr. Camposa is a buyer with Alexander's department stores.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: If you are a flexible traveler who has not yet made summertime plans, you could find yourself jetting to Europe at the last minute at a much lower fare than if you had made detailed arrangements months in advance.

title: GIVING GAS PIPELINES ANOTHER LOOK
description: THE word was making its rounds on Wall Street all week: Natural gas p ipeline companies, long in disfavor among investors, have rapidly b ecome more attractive, speculative investments.

title: THIS 'SYLPHIDE' SURPASSES ITS PREDECESSORS
description: One of the most interesting new productions that American Ballet Theater has offered during its season at the Metropolitan Opera House is not a piece of new choreography, but a fresh staging of a beloved old ballet, August Bournonville's ''La Sylphide.'' Ballet Theater has previously presented two other versions of the great Danish classic, which received its world premiere in Copenhagen on Nov. 28, 1836. But, though one can object to certain of its details, this one by Erik Bruhn clearly surpasses its predecessors.

title: MORE SCENTS FOR THE DOLLAR
description: MARYLIN BENDER is the author of ''Nouveau Is Better Than No Riche at All,'' a book about fashion and society to be published by Putnam in October.

title:
MUSIC;
NEW MUSIC FESTIVAL BECKONS JERSEYANS
description: NEWTOWN PA. THE pastoral landscape of Bucks County, Pa., with its outdoor art shows and cafes, antiques shops, country inns and quaint villages, has long been an oasis of serenity for New Jerseyans in the summer.

title: Patricia Anne Joyce and Bairj Donabedian Marry
description: Patricia Anne Joyce, daughter of Michael J. Joyce of Huntington, L.I., and the late Mrs. Joyce, was married yesterday in New York to Bairj Donabedian, son of Dr. and Mrs. Avedis Donabedian of Ann Arbor, Mich. The Rev. Stanert L. Dransfield of Marble Collegiate Church performed the ceremony at the home of Myron Beldock, a friend of the couple.

title: PLAYING SURFACES, PLAYER STYLES
description: To the Sports Editor: As one who has been watching, playing, and writing about racquet sports for 30 years, I was of course pleased to read Vic Seixas's opinions on today's tennis. I admire him enormously - I watched him win Wimbledon, he easily beat me in a veterans' squash tournament, and luckily I never met him on any tennis court, Har-Tru or other.

title: Shelley Myerson Is Wed
description: Shelley Myerson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Myerson of Tenafly, N.J., was married there yesterday to William David Curtis, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Leonard Curtis of Valdosta, Ga. Mayor Richard Van Nostrand of Tenafly performed the ceremony at the Myerson home. The bride graduated from Emory University, as did Mr. Curtis, who attends the Medical College of Georgia in Augusta.

title: Harmon Lawrence Remmel, a Lawyer, Married to Helen L. L. Victor, an Artist
description: Helen Louise Lash Victor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Victor of Lattingtown, L.I., was married yesterday to Harmon Lawrence Remmel, son of Harmon Liveright Remmel of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Jaquelin Towson Remmel. The Rev. E. Nils Blatz, rector of Trinity Episcopal Church in Roslyn, L.I., performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church.

title: PUBLISH-AND-PERISH CATCH IN DEFENSE RESEARCH
description: Emanuel Donchin is a scientist at the University of Illinois Cognitive Psychophysiology Lab. He has been working with Department of Defense support since 1973, a relationship he describes as being for the most part ''very enlightened.'' But this year he protested about pre-publication review clauses in an Air Force contract, and now finds himself minus a potential two-year project.

title: Motherhood as a Career
description: I applaud those women who have made the decision to stay home with their babies rather than work (''Choosing a Career in Motherhood,'' June 5). Let me first emphasize that ''freedom to choose'' are the key words.

title: CONCERT: CHORAL GROUP PERFORMS
description: Fifteen years ago, it probably would have been difficult to create a choral group composed entirely of homosexual men, let alone to advertise it publicly as the New York City Gay Men's Chorus. But attitudes have changed during the last decade, and in August 1980 a choral group by that name was indeed founded. Its musical seriousness has won it praise.

title: Thanks for 'Living'
description: To the Editor:

title: ZOELLER'S 203 LEADS AT MEMPHIS BY A SHOT
description: Fuzzy Zoeller lipped the cup on a chip shot for an eagle, then tapped in for a birdie on the final hole, finishing a five-under-par 67 that provided him with a one-stroke lead today after the third round of the $400,000 Danny Thomas-Memphis Classic.

title: IN ALBANY, THE PLOYS OF SUMMER
description: As surely as death and taxes, there comes a time in this city when 211 grown men and women stay up all night to get done the things they did not do all year.

title: The 'Contra' Revolution Won't Work
description: If the Reagan Administration has a dream about Nicaragua, it is this: With modest American support, the foreign-based insurgencies may catch fire inside the country and topple its leftist regime. ... If not, the junta may be forced to broaden its base, become less Marxist, more nonaligned. ... If not that, maybe it will be drained by diversionary battles and kept from spreading revolution in Central America during President Reagan's watch.

title: HUGHES PRESSES FOR NEW ROUTE
description: ACAMPAIGN to build the most ambitious toll superhighway in the state, other than the New Jersey Turnpike and Garden State Parkway, has been started by Representative William J. Hughes, Democrat of Ocean City.

title: Ghana Moves to Create 'People's Judicial System'
description: Workers Defense Councils, grassroots groups supporting the Government of Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, have taken over the nation's judiciary in order to set up a ''people's judicial system,'' the Accra radio reported today.

title: BOSS KETTERING AND INVENTIONS
description: Boss Kettering, by Stuart W. Leslie. Columbia University Press, New York. 382 pages, $19.95.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: CONSERVATIVES DISAPPOINTED WITH 'SHIFT' BY REAGAN
description: Ideological conservatives, who provided the core of Ronald Reagan's support in 1980, have been deeply disappointed with his performance as President, especially what they regard as his growing moderation in advance of the 1984 campaign.

title: FIRE-RETARDANT PLASTICS CAN ALSO MAKE DEADLIER FUMES
description: ''Five ounces of burning polyvinyl chloride in an average-size bedroom will kill the occupants in 10 minutes,'' says Dr. Yves C. Alarie, a professor of environmental sciences at the University of Pittsburgh. Most rooms contain many pounds of the plastic - nicknamed PVC or vinyl - in wallpaper, floors, window frames, furniture, electric wire insulation. ''On average, smoke from synthetic polymers is five to six times more toxic than wood smoke,'' according to Dr. Alarie.

title: 'Art and Dance' to Open At Purchase Museum
description: ''Art and Dance: Images from the Modern Dialogue, 1890-1980'' will open at the Neuberger Museum, State University of New York at Purchase, today.

title: FOLK: STEVE GOODMAN
description: Steve Goodman, the Chicago-based singer and songwriter who has been recording since the early l970's, belongs to a select breed of folkoriented musician-raconteurs whose high comic sensibility coincides with an impeccable musicianship. On Thursday, at the Lone Star Cafe, where he played a one-man acoustic set, Mr. Goodman delved into his career, reprising his well-known cover versions of Arlo Guthrie's ''City of New Orleans'' and Mike Smith's ''The Dutchman,'' among other old favorites.

title: Parks Wins in Decision Over Braswell at Forum
description: Billy Parks, a 140-pound junior welterweight from New Orleans, won by decision from Allen Braswell of Brooklyn in a 10-rounder Friday night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: THREE WITH MUCH IN COMMON RUN FOR A QUEENS SENATE SEAT
description: The three candidates for the State Senate in a special election on Tuesday in Queens have much in common. Two are Democrats. Two are teachers. Two are labor leaders. Two are Italian-Americans. Two are seeking public office for the first time, and two have some campaign experience running for party office and a local school board.

title: Condolences to Mrs. Miller
description: President Reagan has sent a personal message of condolence to the widow of former Representative William E. Miller, a White House spokesman said today. Mr. Miller, the 1964 Republican Vice-Presidential running mate of Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, died Friday in Buffalo. The former New York Congressman was 69 years old.

title: Miss Rockefeller Weds Douglas Currier
description: Elizabeth Gray Rockefeller, daughter of Mrs. John P. Fisher of Edmundston, New Brunswick, and Andrew C. Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Douglas Parker Currier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Currier Jr. of Aurora, Ohio.

title: Chilean Strikers Soften Their Demands
description: Truckers and other workers who joined a protest strike against President Augusto Pinochet's military Government softened their demands today, calling for more democracy but not necessarily the ouster of Mr. Pinochet.

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 3 RETURN OF THE JEDI, adapted by Joan D. Vinge. (Random House, $6.95.) Profusely illustrated storybook based on the latest ''Star Wars'' film. 2 2 15 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 3 3 12 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills is at large among a Pennsylvania town's high school set. 4 4 9 HEARTBURN, by Nora Ephron. (Knopf, $11.95.) A roman a clef about a marriage breaking up. 5 5 12 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 6 6 7 THE SUMMER OF KATYA, by Trevanian. (Crown, $12.95.) A love story with dark family secrets, set in France before World War I. 7 8 4 ASCENT INTO HELL, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Bernard Geis/Warner, $16.50.) The ordeal of a man who leaves the priesthood to enjoy the pleasures of secular life. 8 9 13 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.)

title: MODELS WHO SHOW AND TELL; June Weir
description: short dark hair, smoky eyes, pale skin, bright red lips, much like the Van Dongen painting that hung in the foyer of his showroom. It was an era of a modeling caste system that usually separated those fashion models who posed for magazine and newspaper photographers from those who paraded before live audiences at fashion shows.

title: BY STANTON PEELE
description: THE NATURAL HISTORY OF ALCOHOLISM By George E. Vaillant. 359 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ While the Kool Jazz Festival is occupying the city's concert halls this week, a more personal jazz celebration will be held at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South. From Tuesday through next Sunday (July 3), Benny Carter, the saxophonist, composer and arranger, an unusually hale, hearty and vigorous member of the fast-fading group of great jazz stars who came out of the 1920's (his peers were Louis Armstrong, Earl Hines, Duke Ellington, Coleman Hawkins, all gone, and the still active Count Basie) will be celebrating his 75th year by leading a quartet made up of Norman Simmons, piano, Lisle Atkinson, bass, and Ronnie Bedford, drums.

title: Salvadoran Troops Press Offensive Against Rebels
description: About 2,000 Government troops pressed an offensive today against leftist guerrillas who dynamited a bridge northeast of the capital and isolated two hydroelectric dams that supply half of El Salvador's electricity.

title: BY MICHAEL BILLINGTON
description: Michael Billington frequently reports on the cultural scene in England. LONDON Albert Finney and Tom Courtenay are two sides of the same coin. Both exemplify the kind of regional, working-class actor who seemed to dominate British theater and cinema in the 1960's. Both come from the North of England. Both played Billy Liar on the London stage. Yet, for the first time, they are now appearing together, in roles which call for a virtual symbiosis. The vehicle is a $6 million film version - directed by Peter Yates - of Ronald Harwood's stage hit, ''The Dresser,'' being shot at London's Pinewood Studios.

title: AIDS AND CIVIL LIBERTIES
description: THE control of contagious disease is a prerequisite for the full exercise of individual freedom. Constitutional and legislative guarantees of civil liberties are invariably suspended when a government decides that it must act to protect the society from the rapid spread of illness. These official actions are usually sanctioned by law and based on the best scientific information available.

title: A NEW FOCUS FOR U.S. JEWS: ISRAEL'S SLUMS
description: For years, many American Jews who cared deeply about Israel rarely visited the country except on group tours that took the well-worn paths to holy places, archeological sites and model kibbutzim. The official itineraries did not include the slums, and the visitors often left with the same idealized visions of Israel they brought with them.

title: CRIME AND THE COURT
description: MIRANDA Crime, Law and Politics. By Liva Baker. 463 pp. New York: Atheneum. $22.95. CRIMINAL JUSTICE REFORM A Blueprint. Edited by Patrick B. McGuigan and Randall R.Rader with Claudia A. Keiper. 273 pp. Chicago: Free Congress Research and Education Foundation/ Regnery/Gateway. Cloth, $21.95. Paper, $14.

title: A Veto Vetoed
description: Like other great Supreme Court decisions, the one handed down last week undoing the legislative veto is supremely simple. Chief Justice Warren Burger, writing like a patient schoolmaster, explained it in familiar, basic terms. Remember what we all learned in social studies about how laws are made? Well, he says, that's just how it should still work.

title: M.B.A., PH.D., O.K.?
description: THERE is a new badge of status in America. Gone are the success symbols of the 70's - two cars in every garage, a tennis court and swimming pool, and designer everything. In the 80's, everyone who is anyone is going back to school.

title: Invaders 17, Breakers 16
description: Louis Jackson, a reserve halfback, caught a touchdown pass and gained more than 100 yards in total offense to help Oakland clinch the U.S.F.L. Pacific Division title.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: A Changing Profile Four years ago, Amiri Baraka, the poet and playwright, was jailed for 90 days after he was convicted for resisting arrest and assaulting police officers who said they intervened between him and his wife during a domestic argument on a Greenwich Village street. St. Clair Bourne, the filmmaker, said he used this incident as the focal point for an award-winning videotaped profile of the political activist. ''In Motion: Amiri Baraka'' will be broadcast on Channel 13 Tuesday from 10 to 11 P.M.

title: Mary Beth Hennessy Wed To T. J. Flenniken in Texas
description: Mary Beth Hennessy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hennessy of Harrington Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Terrill J. Flenniken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. Flenniken of Shreveport, La. District Court Judge Myron Love performed the ceremony in the chapel of the University of St. Thomas in Houston.

title: THE MALAISE IN LAW SCHOOL
description: David Margolick's discussion of the Socratic method mentions that it ''..shakes the self-confidence of the most intelligent students.'' Should it not? Is not the purpose of education to make you stretch, exercise and question? Socratic teaching introduces the student to two of the most important tools of the lawyer: preparation and the ability to perform under pres- sure. JONATHAN S. BARNETT New York City

title: Court Demands a Good Explanation On Air Bags
description: Wanting deregulation doesn't in itself justify getting it, the Supreme Court reminded the Reagan Administration last week in a unanimous opinion. The immediate issue was the Federal requirement that new cars have air bags or automatic seat belts to protect riders in a crash.

title: INGMAR BERGMAN: SUMMING UP A LIFE IN FILM
description: Michiko Kakutani, a member of The New York Times' staff, writes on cultural subjects.

title: Index; International
description: Arafat, ousted by Syria, goes to Prague to seek help 3 Some American Jews turn their attention to Israeli slums 4 Around the World 5 Japanese vote seen as test of Nakasone's popularity 7 Warsaw criticizes Reagan for ''interference'' in Poland 8 Chad says rebels control a third of the country 11 In the new Ethiopia, the old trou- bles grind on 12 Government/Politics U.S. preparing rule for fire-block- ing material on airline seats 19 Most states unaffected by Jersey redistricting ruling 21 Official's indictment may re- shape Carolina races 22 Conservatives, upset with Rea- gan, may withhold support 22 Reporter's Notebook: Closing days in Albany 30 General Replacing an unsafe dam in Wyo- ming churns up debate 15 Around the Nation 16 Trial raises key issues for sports and municipal law 17 As July Fourth approaches, fire- works sellers are out in force 27 Fireman-scholar studies ways of reducing stress in his work 28 Battery Park City Esplanade at- tracted hundreds of sunbathers 29 Health/Science Scuffed-up space shuttle is pre- pared for Florida trip 16 Fossil skulls of man's ancestors to be assembled in New York 18 Groups seeking AIDS finding pri- vate blood donors 26 Religion Christian churches report gains in membership 18 (20:1.) Arts/Entertainment Alfano's ''Resurrection'' per- formed by Cincinnati Opera 44 Alberta Hunter returns to the Cookery 44 American Ballet Theater per- forms ''Les Noces'' 44 Style Her mark is on the coinage 47 Conveyor systems for closets 47

title: Saving Manatees
description: The manatees of Florida - aquatic creatures that resemble elephants, minus the trunk - were in trouble last year. Their numbers already low enough to make the Federal Endangered Species List, the vegetarian mammals were being further decimated by the poisonous red tide and other natural causes.

title: MATERNITY WARDS WELCOME YOUNG SIBLINGS
description: NOT long ago, the arrival of a baby was a cause for celebration for everyone in the family except, perhaps, the new arrival's older siblings. Now, thanks to innovative programs at many of the state's hospitals, these older brothers and sisters have become welcome visitors to the maternity ward, and share with parents and grandparents the excitement of the new arrival.

title: Miss Chesebro Becomes a Bride
description: Genevieve Alanna Chesebro, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Marsh Chesebro of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Peter Betts Rathbone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry T. Rathbone of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

title: Angels 9, Royals 2
description: Bobby Grich hit a pair of home runs, and Brian Downing hit a two-run homer as California collected 17 hits. Mike Witt (4-5) surrendered six hits over seven innings, allowing a pair of unearned runs in the third. Rod Carew, who went 3-for-6 to raise his league-leading average to .413, opened the game with an infield hit and, two outs later, Downing hit his fourth home run of the year off Keith Creel (0-3).

title: Lucy Lee Talbot Weds John Myers
description: Lucy Lee Talbot, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Timothy R. Talbot Jr. of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to John William Myers, son of Mrs. Myron Cohn of Albany and the late James Carroll Myers. The Rev. Dr. David B. Watermulder performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr (Pa.)

title: ABROAD IN TULSA
description: DAVID PLANTE, an American writer, has lived in London for 20 years. His most recent book is ''Difficult Women'' (Atheneum).

title: Pirates Take 7th In a Row
description: Dale Berra drove in three runs with a homer and single today to lead the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 10-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. The victory was the seventh in a row for the Pirates.

title: Speaking Up On South Africa
description: For an Administration that has made a policy of not openly criticizing South Africa, a public statement last week was strong and surprising stuff. Under Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger called apartheid morally wrong and said that ''by one means or another, South Africa's domestic racial system will be changed.''

title: COSTS OF JOBLESS YOUTH CITED
description: New York City cannot afford to continue to allow 150,000 youths to remain unemployed, according to a study by Interface, a nonprofit public-policy research organization.

title: Lesley Ann Schultz Is Wed
description: Lesley Ann Schultz, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Carl Fearing Schultz of Glastonbury, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stephen Norman Faber, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Norman Faber of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father at the First Congregational Church of Christ, where he is senior minister, The Rev. Craig M. Whitcher assisted.

title: DISABILITY INSURANCE FOR YOUNG WORKERS
description: THE last thing young and healthy wage earners may want to think a bout is buying more insurance. Premiums for car, home, or health i nsurance are large enough, they are likely to say. If they have no d ependents they are quick to add that it is senseless for them to buyl ife insurance.

title: Horsing Around
description: Speaking to reporters at an impromptu news conference at Vernon Downs race track in Vernon, N.Y., the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner, said that sometimes he'd rather be around his horses than his players. ''They can't say bad things about me to guys like you,'' said Steinbrenner, who was at the track to watch some of his standardbred horses race.

title: A GALLERY SCENE THAT PIONEERS IN NEW TERRITORIES
description: Maybe you thought that Gracie Mansion meant Mayor Koch's official residence? In the gentrifying East Village, it signifies something else - a tiny but up-and-coming art gallery that shows the work of new young talents. Gracie Mansion, and a handful of other spaces - some ''alternative,'' or not for profit - are part of a growing East Village gallery scene that threatens to erupt into Manhattan's third art district, after Uptown and SoHo. Its principals are apt to be young and mainly artists themselves, the neighborhoods they're in are still hairy enough for the word ''dealer'' to have a double meaning, and the art they show - which includes some very prettied-up grafitti - tends to be flashier, more ''political'' and quicker in its appeal to a broader public than frequents Manhattan's more rarefied art zones. As it does elsewhere, a wild and funky figuration prevails, but while the work of some very good artists can be seen in these galleries, the range is very uneven, including a good deal that can at best be labeled kitsch.

title: PAPERS SHOW F.B.I. HAD LITTLE EVIDENCE AGAINST U.S JUDGE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation never expected to trace an alleged bribe payment to Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings and thought that the case against him was weak, according to newly unsealed court documents.

title: Horse Born in Colorado From a Frozen Embryo
description: Scientists at Colorado State University have reported the first birth in the United States of a horse produced from a frozen embryo.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: John Jeb Seder Marries Miss Plough, a Teacher
description: Frances Plough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Plough of Wrightstown, Pa., was married yesterday to John Jeb Seder, son of Elizabeth M. Seder of St. George, Staten Island, and John W. Seder of Washington. The Rev. William W. Wood 3d performed the ceremony at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Solebury, Pa.

title: OUR MINISTRY OF INFORMATION
description: THE MEDIA MONOPOLY By Ben H. Bagdikian. 282 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $14.95.

title: Data Update
description: * Five counties of New York City plus Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Putnam, Bergen, Essex, Morris, Union, Hudson, Middlesex, Somerset and Passaic. **Comparable data unavailable because method of computing homeownership costs has changed.

title: No Requirement to Rent
description: Question: There are four empty apartments in my building. They have been repaired, plastered and painted yet they have been vacant for more than a year. Is there a law in New York City requiring landlords to rent vacant apartments? ... E.K., Manhattan Answer: A spokesman for the New York State Attorney General says there is no law requiring landlords to rent their apartments. Vacant apartments usually are a sign that the landlord intends to convert the building to cooperative or condominium ownership or sell it to an investor. Under the law covering conversions, an owner is allowed to keep only 10 percent of his apartments vacant. If the Attorney General finds that apartments have been ''warehoused'' in violation of this requirement, he will not accept the owner's offering plan for filing.

title: LONG ISLANDER SET FOR TEST OF SKILLS IN MOTOCROSS EVENT
description: TENS of thousands of spectators will congregate later today alongside a hilly stretch of rugged terrain near Carlsbad, Calif. As the fans look on, dozens of motorcyclists will be preparing for their 30-minute rides over jarring bumps and ruts, through dangerously alluring sand pits and up and down nearly vertical slopes.

title: SPOT AT A BUSY CROSSROADS
description: ONE of the questions about restaurant reviewing that readers often ask is how we decide which establishments to review. More often than not, they are surprised to learn that we visit almost twice as many restaurants as we write up; quite a few prove unworthy of further consideration after an exploratory visit.

title: THE POLES ARE BUOYED, BUT WHAT'S NEXT?
description: WARSAW ACROSS the length and breadth of Poland last week, pictures of Pope John Paul II and the Virgin Mary, usually in the image of the Black Madonna of Czestochowa, a symbol of church and nation, were taped to the front window of almost every house and apartment block in the land. The scene was most striking in the countryside at night, when every village of stone houses was ablaze with tiny decorative lights that had been placed around the portraits.

title: Not So Sweet Home
description: It was a bittersweet homecoming for the Cleveland Indian slugger Gorman Thomas. Making his first appearance in Milwaukee since being traded to the Indians earlier this month, Thomas, one of Milwaukee's most popular sports figure during his nine-year career there, was cheered before Friday's game for every move.

title: MOTHERHOOD AS A CAREER
description: I was much interested in the article about young mothers who decided to stay home. Many years ago, I graduated from college into the Depression.

title: Bergland to Lead Co-Ops
description: Former Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland has been selected as the chief executive officer of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association, the Washington-based group announced Friday.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IN a move that comes as a surprise to many area residents, John L. Frisbee, acting senior vice president for preservation programs for the National Trust, will replace Richard Slavin as director of Lyndhurst, the National Trust property in Tarrytown, on Sept. 1.

title: Lee Freeman Fox Marries a Lawyer
description: Lee Freeman Fox, daughter of Joseph C. Fox and the late Louise Lee Fox, was married yesterday to Peter Markley White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert O. White of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Bruce F. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church of Christ in Norfolk, Conn.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
THE REPORT CARD OF A RETIRING TEACHER
description: IT WAS the last day of school, and the students had run out as soon as they heard the bell. The air was hot and still, and the walls were bare, with unfaded spots where supposedly interesting posters and pictures had hung. All the books had been collected, accounted for and stacked in neat piles for redistribution in September. Two wastebaskets overflowed with paper and the remains of lunches.

title: IN PERPETUAL POLITICAL STANDOFF, ITALY ELECTS A 44TH GOVERNMENT
description: Italians go to the polls today and tomorrow in the latest act of a democracy whose paradoxes baffle political scientists and commentators, as well as much of Italy.

title: FOR NEW ASIAN ARRIVALS, CALIFORNIA IS SOMEPLACE LIKE HOME
description: Newcomers to this dusty agricultural city in the heart of California's San Joaquin Valley are sometimes startled by the sight of Hmong tribesmen from Laos walking along a sidewalk in their native dress.

title: SCUFFED-UP SHUTTLE PREPARED FOR FLORIDA TRIP
description: The space shuttle Challenger was a little scorched and dented, looking more used after its second flight, but engineers reported today that the spaceship should be ready to return here Thursday to be prepared for its next mission in August.

title: BALLET, PINCHED, PLANS A BRIEF SEASON
description: DESPITE the cancellation of its spring season, administrative disarray, inadequate fund-raising, a poor reception on Long Island for its production of ''The Nutcracker'' and a nagging deficit, the Eglevsky Ballet is getting ready to open an abbreviated summer season with two performances, beginning July 9.

title: AFTER SAMPSON AND STIPANOVICH, THE DRAFT IS A GUESSING GAME
description: BEFORE the start of the college draft on Tuesday, Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association will notify the teams that they have a maximum of five minutes to make their firstround selections. But it should take only seconds for the Houston Rockets and the Indiana Pacers, who will pick first and second, respectively, to make official what is already known.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: ANEW list from the United States Census Bureau reveals that Connecticut residents own more cars per capita than residents of any other state except Montana. The list, released this month and based on the 1980 census, shows that 662 automobiles are owned for every thousand residents of Connecticut. In comparison, New York ranked 49th of the 50 states, with 409 registered cars per 1,000 residents. New Hampshire ranked 11th, with 588, and Massachusetts 15th, with 579.

title: ADULTS-ONLY HOUSING CAUSING HARDSHIPS FOR SOME
description: When Kathy Siek became pregnant, she hid from her neighbors in a luxury mobile home park by staying indoors and entering and leaving through her carport.

title:
GARDENING;
POTTED PLANTS ARE PRETTY OUTDOORS, TOO
description: ONE of the most appreciated pleasures of summer is the opportunity it provides to spend time outdoors. The backyard becomes the center of family activities from barbecues and games to basking in the sun. It is time when the enjoyment of these activities can be enhanced by the presence of colorful plants grown in containers.

title: Le Mans Winner Ends Losing Streak
description: In Europe the winners of the Le Mans 24-hour race are given the same sort of recognition that the Indianapolis 500 victor is afforded in the United States. So Hurley Haywood was a little disappointed when he returned to his New York apartment after winning the French sports car classic for the second time and found his achievement had rated little more than a brief mention in most newspapers and on television.

title: AS A LIFE IS ERASED
description: CHRONICLE OF MY MOTHER By Yasushi Inoue. Translated by Jean Oda Moy. 164 pp. New York : Kodansha International. $14.95.

title: 20 YEARS OF TEAMWORK
description: One of the world's greatest partnerships has recently emerged, like the national economy, from a recession. Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay have played together for almost 20 years, and in the late 1960's they had a series of national triumphs that brought them close to world titles on two occasions. In the 70's they battled hard but were regularly defeated, often by small margins, by younger, hungrier, experts - most of them from Texas and California.

title: AMERICANS LEAD EAST GERMANS IN TRACK
description: For most of the 15,829 spectators in the 92,000-seat Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum today, a strong performance by the American women overshadowed a world record of 72 feet 10 3/4 inches in the men's shot-put by Udo Beyer of East Germany.

title: DANGEROUS DAM CHURNS UP DEBATE
description: The United States Bureau of Reclamation is studying ways to repair an unsafe dam on Jackson Lake, which lies at the foot of the spectacular Teton mountain range in Grand Teton National Park.

title: European Rightists Bid Soviet Negotiate Seriously on Arms
description: European conservative leaders called on the Soviet Union today to negotiate seriously on curbing nuclear weapons and to respond positively to Western disarmament proposals.

title: DANBURY GOLFER BATTLES OBSCURITY
description: WHEN Ken Green of Danbury teed off in the first round of the United States Open 10 days ago at the Oakmont Country Club in Oakmont, Pa., a harsh sun had already helped infuse the early morning with a midday mugginess.

title: MACHINES THAT MASQUERADE AS THE PIANO
description: Despite all temptations, I continue to open my mail. All of it. Even when I find myself relegated to the mimeographed status of Occupant or Resident, I am at least driven to glance, hoping against all the odds for some bit of wonderful news, some hint that there is life in outer space. How else but from a press release could I have learned, for instance, about a symphony orchestra's world-premiere performance of the balcony scene from Prokofiev's ballet ''Romeo and Juliet,'' starring the Olympic skaters Dorothy Hamill and Brian Pockar? ''Among the scenes,'' says the Utah Symphony's advisory, ''is one in which Miss Hamill and Mr. Pockar make several trips up and down a curved staircase on skates.''

title: Creeping Toward An Income Tax?
description: Just before the final vote on proposed increases in state spending and taxes in Connecticut last week, a Republican in the House of Representatives warned his colleagues that they were about to put the state ''on the wrong road.'' But Democrats, who dominate the Legislature, were convinced they were finally heading in the right direction - home.

title: Ellen M. Maxwell Wed in Newport
description: Ellen Mary Maxwell, daughter of Mrs. James A. Maxwell of Worcester, Mass., and the late Professor Maxwell, was married yesterday to Hakan Nicolaus Lonaeus of Washington, son of Gunnar Lonaeus, Swedish Ambassador to Japan, and Mrs. Lonaeus of Skarkind, Sweden, and Tokyo. Canon D. Lorne Coyle performed the ceremony in Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

title: THAT DELICATE VOICE: A SINGER'S NEMESIS
description: Evelyn Lear remembers 1968, the year she couldn't sing. Her throat, she said, simply closed up. Miss Lear now blames repertories too heavy for her voice. She blames menopause. She blames not having mastered a good vocal technique. Most of all, she blames the paralyzing panic sprung by the first tremors in her voice.

title: UNDERSTANDING THE REALITIES
description: LIVING WITH NUCLEAR WEAPONS By the Harvard Nuclear Study Group: Albert Carnesale, Paul Doty, Stanley Hoffmann, Samuel P. Huntington, Joseph S. Nye Jr., Scott D. Sagan. With a foreword by Derek Bok. 268 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $12.95. New York: Bantam Books. Paper, $3.95.

title: Ellen F. Hartwell And W.L.Blais Exchange Vows
description: Ellen French Hartwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Hartwell of New York and Williamstown, Mass., was married yesterday to William Lee Blais, son of Mrs. Eugene McCarron of Barrington, R.I., and the late Bertram Blais of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Robert Buckwalter of the Congregational Church in Williamstown performed the ceremony at the Hartwell home there.

title: TANNER DEFEATS WILANDER IN 4 SETS
description: Last fall, Roscoe Tanner considered quitting tennis. He was tired of travel and tournaments and worried about protecting what he had already achieved. Today, playing as if his opponent were Bjorn Borg, the 31-year-old left-hander served 19 aces and powered past Sweden's latest two-handed hero, fifth-seeded Mats Wilander, 6-7, 7-5, 6-3, 6-4, for a spot in the last 16 of men's singles at Wimbledon.

title: Andalusia
description: To the Editor: We have just read R. W. Apple's article ''The 1,001 Delights of Andalusia'' (Travel, May 29) in which he gives a very unfavorable report on the Parador de San Francisco on the grounds of the Alhambra in Granada. Based on our perfectly delightful stay there during Holy Week this year, we must disagree totally.

title: Hitler's Jobless
description: To the Business Editor: It was with interest that I read the letter of Prof. Lynn Turgeon (June 12). The learned professor stated that ''Hitler reduced the unemployment rate to 1 percent by 1936 without significant increases in rearmament.''

title: SIX YEARS FOR THE PRESIDENT
description: The idea was debated in the Constitutional Conventiion. Andrew Jackson revived it 40 years later. Most 19th-century Presidents favored it, and in 1913 Woodrow Wilson had to intervene personally to stop Congress from approving it. The idea of electing the President of the United States for only one term of six years won't die. Now an impressive new National Committee for a Single Six-Year Presidential Term has brought it out again and is pushing the necessary constitutional amendment with what may be better-than-usual prospects for success.

title: PLANNERS ASSESS HOMES FOR RETARDED
description: DESPITE neighorhood opposition in almost every case, the county now has 64 group homes for the retarded, while in 1974 it had only four, according to a survey completed recently by the Department of Planning.

title:
CAMERA;
POINTERS ON PHOTOGRAPHING FIREWORKS DISPLAYS
Mailbox; Playing Surfaces, Player Styles
description: To the Sports Editor: By stressing the conduciveness of grass courts to the serve-andvolley style of play (of which he was certainly a shining example), Vic Seixas fails to make as strong a case as he might (''Why Grass Court Tennis Must Survive,'' The New York Times, June 19).

title: No Headline
description: Transactions BASEBALL PHILADELPHIA (AL) - Placed Garry M addox, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled l ist; called up Kevin Gross, pitcher, from P ortland of the Pacific Coast League. SEATTLE (AL) - Dismissed Manager R ene Lachemann and hired Del Crandall, a former manager of the Milwaukee B rewers, to replace him; released Gay- l ord Perry, pitcher, and Todd Cruz, short- s top.

title: Carolyn Patterson Walser Married to Earl Johnson 3d
description: Carolyn Patterson Walser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gaither Stokes Walser of Lexington, N.C., was married yesterday to Earl Johnson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Johnson Jr. of Raleigh, N.C. The Rev. James Grant performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Lexington, N.C.

title: JUST WHAT IS AN IMPORTANT ACTOR?
description: Ialways supposed that I knew what an important part in a play was. It was a nice fat bundle of sides (lines of dialogue with cues indicated) that brought the actor who'd been cast in the role onto the stage early in the evening and kept him there, preferably up center in a bright light, until the last curtain came down. Something rich and roaring and thereafter unforgettable. I also supposed I knew what an important actor was. An important actor was an actor who got that kind of part, and was thereafter extensively interviewed about it. Right on both counts? Not necessarily. Lately I've been peering a bit more closely at performers and the parts they appear in because the word ''important'' - in my mind, at this moment - no longer means exactly what it used to mean.

title: SAVORING SAVORIES
description: The savories of the British Isles, a curious and fascinating category of food, have always intrigued us, particularly because of their original placement on a menu.

title: A HAPPY YANKEE CAREER THAT SPANNED GENERATIONS
description: IFIRST came up to the Yankees in September of 1965, from Greensboro (N.C.) in Class A ball. I was 19y ears old, a shortstop then, and this was my first full summer out ofh igh school. I had signed with the Yankees shortly after graduating f rom Southeast High in Oklahoma City. I broke into the lineup in Y ankee Stadium and was so excited that when I was at the plate my f eet weren't even touching the ground.

title: Donald Blake Jr., Anne Fuchs Wed
description: Anne Elizabeth Fuchs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Clement Fuchs of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Donald Michael Blake Jr., son of Mr. Blake and the late Aileen Blake of Upper Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Louis Mazza performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L.I.

title: TABLE GRAPES TAKING ROOT ON EAST END
description: WINE grape production, now one of the most rapidly growing industries on Long Island, has stimulated interest in another aspect of viniculture - table or dessert grapes. Until recently, fresh grapes for table use have been grown primarily in home gardens and on scattered patches in a few of Suffolk County's orchards. Now, several grape growers on the East End are raising table grapes for distribution to local markets.

title: RECALLING COLLEGE AND FACING REALITY
description: EVERY September, when the weather cools and the days grow short, I am filled with a sense of nostalgia, a wistful longing for the time when this change of season signaled the opening of another school year. Invariably each fall, I yearn to pull out my sweaters, pack my trunk, and return to those hallowed halls for just one more year.

title: SUNDAY, JUNE 26, 1983
description: International Support for the Philippines President, Ferdinand E. Marcos was reaffirmed by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on his arrival in the Philippines, the first stop of a four-nation Asian trip. Mr. Shultz in a luncheon toast called the relationship between the United States and the Philippines ''very special.'' At the same time, senior American officials traveling with Mr. Shultz said the Reagan Administration was seeking to establish contacts with Filipino opposition groups that might someday share power after Mr. Marcos's eventual departure. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Sports of The Times; Smoke and Fire In Pro Tennis
description: NO matter who wins at Wimbledon in the next week, the most important tennis action of the year has already taken place with the suspension of Guillermo Vilas for taking acceptance money.

title: Trains
description: To the Editor: Quentin Crisp writes charmingly in ''Riding With a Stiff Upper Lip'' (Travel, May 8), but as one who has traveled by rail not only up and down Britain, but many times, on several routes, across our continent, I can assure him that the latter experience is not, as he has been told, ''absolute hell.'' Except for the occasional hassle I find it the opposite absolute.

title: JAZZ FESTIVAL: RALPH SUTTON ON SOLO PIANO
description: The first official concert of this year's Kool Jazz Festival was, as it traditionally is, a late-afternoon piano solo performance at Carnegie Recital Hall, inaugurating the piano solo series that will continue there throughout the festival. Friday's curtain-raiser was a particularly auspicious beginning because the pianist was Ralph Sutton whose colorfully strong-fingered playing, frequently involving the stride style that is closely associated with Fats Waller and James P. Johnson, got the festival off to an invigorating and colorful start.

title: Data Bank; June 26, 1983

GARDENING;
POTTED PLANTS ARE PRETTY OUTDOORS, TOO
description: ONE of the most appreciated pleasures of summer is the opportunity it provides to spend time outdoors. The backyard becomes the center of family activities from barbecues and games to basking in the sun. It is time when the enjoyment of these activities can be enhanced by the presence of colorful plants grown in containers.

title: ON 7TH AVENUE, IT'S ALL IN THE FAMILY
description: IT was back in 1921 when 15-year-old Freddie Hazan left his small village in the countryside of Greece to come to the United States. He tells of finding work that year on Manhattan's Lower East Side making garments for a few cents an hour. By the time he was 24, he founded the Lloyd's Sportswear Company, just off Seventh Avenue, naming it after a textile manufacturer who had lent him money.

title: Firebombings in Ulster
description: Firebombs destroyed or damaged 25 post office vans today in the town of Armagh, the police said.

title: CONCERT: N.Y.U. OFFERS NEW MUSIC
