description: New York University has been offering a series of new-music concerts at the Loeb Center, and Thursday's installment centered mostly on composers from New Jersey.

title: HARVEY FIERSTEIN'S LONG JOURNEY TO THE TONY AND BEYOND
description: He began his theatrical career as a 270-pound teenaged transvestite specializing in impersonations of Ethel Merman at a Lower East Side club. He was a nice Jewish boy from Brooklyn - his father a handkerchief manufacturer, his mother a housewife, his brother a lawyer - but he had a voice that sounded as if he gargled with drain cleaner and a tendency to write such works as a musical about seven drag queen prostitutes living in a subway men's room. He couldn't even manage a conventional chorus line, his chorus of singing cockroaches in an early work being an example that lingers in the mind. Harvey Fierstein seemed, at first, an unlikely prospect for widespread success and commercial acceptance, either onstage or behind it.

title: Israel Acts in Doctor Strike
description: The Israeli Cabinet has decided to vote Sunday whether to try arbitration to resolve the doctors' strike that began three and a half months ago, the Cabinet spokesman, Dan Meridor, said Friday. The announcement called on the hundreds of doctors taking part in a hunger strike, which has spread rapidly, to stop their fast and return to work.

title: BY BARRY LAINE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine is a regular contributor to Arts and Leisure.

title: RONALD REAGAN'S PERFORMANCE
description: GAMBLING WITH HISTORY Ronald Reagan in the White House. By Laurence I. Barrett. 511 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $19.95. MAKE-BELIEVE The Story of Nancy & Ronald Reagan. By Laurence Leamer. Illustrated. 395 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $14.95.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
MILL TOWN
description: The early settlers on eastern Long Island were a practical lot - especially those who in 1644 staked out the territory between Southampton and Bridgehampton for their very own. Rather than fool around with any fancy names for their settlement, once they built a water mill to grind their grain they merely took that economic fact of life and turned it into a geographical reality: the village of Water Mill was born. To honor those founding families, the Water Mill Museum has been taping interviews with their descendants, and today ''The Mill That Named the Town,'' an exhibition based on this project, opens at the museum. Featuring historical photographs, documents, artifacts and quotes from the interviews, as well as the original tapes, the display can be seen from 1 to 4 P.M. Sundays and from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Mondays and Wednesdays through Saturdays. The museum is on - you guessed it -Old Mill Road.

title: BUSH'S CAR STONED IN GERMANY
description: Demonstrators threw rocks and bottles at a motorcade carrying Vice President Bush today, delaying his departure from a ceremony here that marked the first emigration of Germans to America, 300 years ago.

title: TURNING OLD INTO NEW
description: THE recent conversion of the Chase Brass and Copper Company's former manufacturing complex in Waterbury into prime industrial space is offering renewed hope to other aging mill towns in the Naugatuck Valley seeking to refurbish old buildings for modern use.

title: THE CRIMINAL COURT: A SYSTEM IN COLLAPSE
description: New York City's Criminal Court is in chaos, according to judges, prosecutors, defense lawyers, police officials, witnesses, crime victims and defendants.

title: Letters; Hidden 'Subsidies'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT ACCOUNTANTS NEED TO KNOW
description: AS he moves into the third and final stage of his leadership of the 26,000-member State Society of Certified Public Accountants, Robert L. Israeloff of Hewlett Bay Park is preoccupied with the question of education. Are certified public accountants keeping up with complex changes in their profession? Should schooling for those intent on such careers be extended?

title: No Headline
description: The Malaise in Law Schools It is evident from David Margolick's article ''The Trouble With America's Law Schools'' (May 22) that little has changed since my graduation five years ago from another national law school. At that time, I was disheartened to find that the law-school placement office ruled the last two years of law school absolutely.

title: Abigail Murphy to Marry John Kean Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ray Bradford Murphy of Little Silver, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Abigail Margaret Murphy, to John Kean Jr., son of Joan Jessup Kean of New York and Hobe Sound, Fla., and Mr. Kean of Bedminster, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
POTTED PLANTS ARE PRETTY OUTDOORS, TOO
description: ONE of the most appreciated pleasures of summer is the opportunity it provides to spend time outdoors. The backyard becomes the center of family activities from barbecues and games to basking in the sun. It is time when the enjoyment of these activities can be enhanced by the presence of colorful plants grown in containers.

title: PROBLEM FOR MISS NAVRATILOVA
description: Martina Navratilova's most difficult moments at Wimbledon today were denying reports about a split with her close friend, Nancy Lieberman, and worrying whether her skirt would fall off during her third-round match against Mima Jausovec.

title: Carolyn Gibbons Married to Samuel F. Abernethy
description: Carolyn Gibbons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Gibbons Jr. of Rye, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Samuel Fawkner Abernethy, son of Jane Dunn Abernethy of Tryon, N.C., and the late Samuel Abernethy of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Whitney Burr of Chatham, Mass., performed the Episcopal ceremony at the American Yacht Club in Rye.

title: DANCE: THE TROCKADERO DRAWS SOME DANCERS
description: Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo is drawing a good many dancers to City Center, where the all-male ballet company plays through July 3. One night last week there was a contingent from the old Ballet Russe, another night brought dancers from the New York City Ballet and Alvin Ailey companies. And there is a good deal of dance interest in the Trocks' informed, affectionate parodies of classics by everyone from Martha Graham to Jerome Robbins, and in the skillful way they dance those parodies.

title: Carol Merten, Chemist, Wed to Arthur Upshur
description: Carol Ann Merten, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Merten of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday at the Reformed Church of Locust Valley to Arthur Littleton Upshur, son of Capt. Giles C. Upshur Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Upshur of Machipongo, Va. The Rev. Dr. Randall B. Bosch performed the ceremony.

title: MUSHROOMS? PICK AN EXPERT PICKER
description: THE mushroom-gathering season is upon Long Island and will continue until first frost. While edible specimens of the fungi are plentiful, a handful of poisonous varieties make the picking best left to those accomplished in the exacting act of mushroom identification.

title: Cynthia J. Dunlop Wed To Anthony S. Lapolla
description: Cynthia Jean Dunlop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Dunlop of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Anthony Stephen Lapolla, son of Mrs. Dominick J. Lapolla of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Lapolla. The Rev. Thomas P. Thorne performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: U.S. MAY REQUIRE ANTIFIRE MATERIAL IN AIRLINE SEATS
description: The Federal Government will soon propose a requirement that a layer of fire-blocking material be installed on airliner seats, according to Government and industry sources.

title: FOOD MARKET IN GALICIA
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: COOPERMAN HAS HIGH HOPES FOR NEW HIGH SCHOOL TESTS
description: ''THE skills and competencies tested will be those a student needs in order to become a productive citizen in our society.'' A new, tougher New Jersey high school graduation test with this seemingly reasonable goal is the centerpiece of the effort of Saul Cooperman, Commissioner of the state's Department of Education, to upgrade educational standards in the state. Dr. Cooperman hopes that the examination will have a ripple effect throughout the entire system, forcing elementary and secondary schools to revise their expectations and reducing the need for remedial help in college or the marketplace.

title: THE POLICE FUSE AVANT-GARDE AND THE COMMERCIAL
description: The Police, who gave their first New York performance at CBGB on the Bowery in the late 1970's and last performed here a year ago as headliners at Madison Square Garden, will be back again on Aug. 18 - at Shea Stadium. This British trio has been nothing if not upwardly mobile, and its rise to the top has been rapid, especially for a time when rock economics have been closer to bust than to boom.

title: BLUEGRASS FOR BERGEN
description: A bluegrass program Tuesday evening will open the Palisades Interstate Park Commission's 10-week concert series marking Bergen County's 300th anniversary.

title: DRUNKEN-DRIVING PUSH URGED
description: THE Governor's Task Force on Drunken Driving called for a wideranging attack on the problem in its preliminary report, released last week.

title: YES, TALK WITH SALVADOR GUERRILLAS
description: It is hard to know what to make of Secretary of State George P. Schultz's hint this week that the Administration may be prepared to consider dialogue with the Salvadoran guerrillas. The Administration continues to portray them as Soviet proxies bent on absolute power. In reality, the guerrillas are Marxist-Leninists, but most are not pro-Soviet. And, despite steady military advances, they have been more willing to compromise than their adversaries in El Salvador and Washington.

title: COSMOS OVERTIME WINNERS
description: Angelo DiBernardo scored his first goal of the season 2 minutes 31 seconds into overtime today to give the Cosmos a 2-1 victory over the Montreal Manic.

title: 4 FRESH AIR FUND CAMPS BEGIN SEASON THIS WEEK
description: Amid the 2,500 acres of the Sharpe Reservation here, deer graze quietly. Squirrels scamper about. Dragonflies skip across the surface of Deer Lake looking for shelter, and a gaggle of Canada geese converse contentedly.

title: Adelman Gets A Lesson in Letter Writing
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, got some on-the-job training last week in what not to say to the Russians - and Congress. Mr. Adelman advised the Senate Foreign Relations Committee by letter that the Administration intended to deploy MX missiles unless the Russians were prepared ''to forgo their heavy and medium ICBM's.'' Senate arms-control advocates and four of his predecessors at the agency were quick with their blue pencils. ''I think this is a terrible way to negotiate with the Soviet Union - to have public letters clarify our position,'' said Eugene V. Rostow, who was dismissed by President Reagan in January. Gerard C. Smith, an agency director in the Nixon Administration, found the policy ''totally impractical.'' Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, said it would be ''very difficult to require the Soviets to completely change their force structure.'' Senator William S. Cohen, Republican of Maine, predicted a swift rejection.

title: Miss Flynn, Bank Officer Are Married
description: Francesca Rowe Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Joseph Flynn of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to John Richard Madden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Blaine Madden of Ross, Calif. The Rev. Gregory Floyd, headmaster of the Portsmouth (R.I.) Abbey School, performed the ceremony at the Salve Regina Chapel at Ochre Point.

title: Yount Signs Contract
description: Robin Yount, the American League's most valuable player last season, has signed a multiyear contract with the Milwaukee Brewers, the club announced today.

title: BLOCK GROUP, BORN IN CRISIS, FLOWERS
description: Communities often band together in times of emergency, but when the crises pass the organizations they spawn tend to founder. Not so on 142d Street in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Shoreham Plan Is Not Exactly a Hit
description: Federal officials threw a yellow flag last week at the Long Island Lighting Company's plan to have meter readers and gas repairmen help supervise an evacuation of nearby residents in case of an accident at its Shoreham nuclear plant.

title: SPENDING IN GILDED STYLE
description: ANTHONY V. MILONE got an expensive new suit when he became vice p resident of a new medical products company in Tuckahoe, N.Y., last y ear. He also got an American Express Gold Card.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Walloping Sale Before a Closing

title: PUBLIC-SECTOR UNIONS SEEN FACING A DECLINE IN GROWTH
description: SINCE 1968, when public-employee unions were first allowed to represent workers in New Jersey, they have become some of the largest and most powerful labor organizations in the state. But their own success in organizing now leaves them facing diminished growth opportunities. ''Public-sector union growth has leveled off in the last few years since reaching its peak in 1977-1978,'' said James P. Begin, director of the Institute of Management-Labor Relations at Rutgers University. ''I don't see many possibilities for organizing in this state because most of the eligible groups - municipal, state and county employees, teachers and other school personnel and university and support staffs - have already been organized.''

title:
GARDENING;
POTTED PLANTS ARE PRETTY OUTDOORS, TOO
description: ONE of the most appreciated pleasures of summer is the opportunity it provides to spend time outdoors. The backyard becomes the center of family activities from barbecues and games to basking in the sun. It is time when the enjoyment of these activities can be enhanced by the presence of colorful plants grown in containers.

title: Suspect in Coast Killings Is Indicted in Michigan
description: A California computer salesman charged with six West Coast killings faces murder charges in the deaths of two Michigan men.

title: MCGORTY RALLIES TO WIN THE DECATHLON
description: Kevin McGorty confirmed today that he is a rising star in the decathlon. The high school senior from Westfield, N.J., came from behind in the final three events to win with 7,133 points in the United States National Junior Track and Field Championships at Penn State.

title: Lisabeth A. Rehm Marries John Hopper, an Executive
description: Lisabeth Alisan Rehm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Daniel Rehm of Des Moines and Fenwick, Conn., was married yesterday to John Anthony Hopper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Frederick Hopper of Greenwich, Conn., and Danby, Vt. The Rev. Robert Aufieri performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Sharon Holmgren Is Wed
description: Sharon McManus Holmgren, daughter of Mrs. Paula McManus of Ronkonkoma, L.I., and John McManus of Orlando, Fla., was married yesterday to Christopher Ralph Alfenito, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph F. Alfenito of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. T. Carlton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce. Mr. Alfenito is an engineer technician with Miteq Inc., a maker of microwave communications instruments in Hauppauge, L.I.

title: Brussels
description: To the Editor: If Jane Gross thinks that Flemish taxi drivers and waiters can be surly if addressed in French as she notes in ''What's Doing in Brussels'' (Travel, May 15), she should try addressing a Walloon taxi driver or waiter in Dutch. The results would likely make ''surly'' seem downright friendly in comparison. t should also, perhaps, be pointed out that native Dutch speakers are much more likely than native French speakers to be able to handle English. DAVID G. LAWRENCE Fordham University

title: Miss Martin Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Barbara Read Martin and Sandon Mark Herzlich, both graduates of Wesleyan University, took place yesterday in Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Donald W. Emig performed the ceremony at the United Church of Rowayton, Congregational.

title: WATT SAYS HE'LL SHIFT TOWARD CONSERVATION
description: James G. Watt and his legion of critics are in agreement on one thing at least: In two years he has accomplished the most sweeping changes in the way the Federal Government manages public land and resources of any Secretary of the Interior in memory.

title: Suffolk Police Accused of Bias
description: The Suffolk County Police Department is known as a tough law-andorder outfit. In some ways too tough, the United States Justice Department contended last week.

title: ALONG THE BATTERY ESPLANADE, SALT AIR, GREENERY AND PEACE
description: The official opening of the Battery Park City Esplanade is not until Wednesday. But that did not deter a few hundred people who turned out yesterday to stroll, sunbathe, sleep or simply admire the city's newest park.

title: TRANSPORTATION BOND ISSUE DEBATE BLOCKING ADJOURNMENT IN ALBANY
description: Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders negotiated into this morning on the final details of a $1.25 billion bond issue to rebuild the state's network of roads, bridges and waterways and its mass-transit systems.

title: Killer's Fate Decided
description: Under the weight of ''41 years of racial abuse heaped upon me in this country,'' something snapped in George E. Banks last Sept. 25.

title: TOWN HALL SITE IS AT ISSUE
description: BROOKHAVEN'S Town Supervisor, Henrietta Acampora, says she has received petitions from ''everybody under the sun'' on the question of relocating the Town Hall.

title: WORST-CASE PLANS FOR CENTRAL AMERICA
description: What will the Reagan Administration do if the Salvadoran guerrillas seize permanent control of a major provincial city? What if Soviet jet fighters are sent to Nicaragua? How will the United States respond if Nicaraguan forces, lashing out against American-supported insurgents, attack neighboring Honduras?

title:
PAPERBACK TALK;
At the Annual Booksellers' Bash
description: Simultaneously a carnival, a social gathering, a rights fair, a marketplace, a trend-spotting session and a trade association meeting, the 83d American Booksellers Association convention and its partner, the 36th A.B.A. trade exhibit, attracted nearly 16,000 people to Dallas earlier this month.

title: LEGGETT, HARRIS TRIAL JUDGE, STEPS DOWN
description: WHEN Russell R. Leggett goes to work in White Plains tomorrow, it will not be as a judge in the County Courthouse, as he has been for the last seven years, but as a lawyer specializing in litigation at the law firm of DeVito and Pilkington - and now Leggett - on nearby Mamaroneck Avenue.

title: TAXES HOLD PRIMARY-RESIDENCE KEY
description: ANEW regulation requiring tenants to pay New Y ork City income taxes or face eviction from rent-stabilized or r ent-controlled apartments does not basically alter the city's 1 2-year-old policy, according to a legal spokesman for the Departmento f Housing and Preservation Development.

title: TRAINS
description: To the Editor: A railway journey through Great Britain was not always as described in ''All Aboard: Three Great Trains'' (Travel, May 8). I remember, on a G.I. pass in '45 a most enjoyable London-to-Edinburgh trip on the then Great Western Railroad.

title: DRUG ABUSE BY POLICE CALLED FORCE'S MAJOR INTERNAL WORRY
description: New York City's police commanders are concerned about drug abuse by young officers and the potential for police corruption posed by an increasing number of illegal after-hours clubs, according to a Police Department report.

title: OPERA: 'RESURRECTION' PERFORMED IN CINCINNATI
description: If there were an award for the most quixotic operatic enterprise of the year, the Cincinnati Opera's production of Franco Alfano's ''Resurrection'' would surely be a leading candidate. Presented last night as the first production of the company's 63d Summer Festival, the 79-year-old work made a powerful bid to defy opera history and arise from the dead. It was a daring idea, and it almost worked.

title: OPENING DOORS FOR WOMEN ISN'T ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: LAWYER DISCUSSES NEW JUVENILE LAW
description: THE state's new Juvenile Delinquency Procedure Act becomes part of Family Court law next Friday. The sweeping statute, containing more than 100 sections, represents the first major revision in 20 years in the legal treatment of juvenile delinquents and is being awaited with some anticipation by members of the legal community.

title: BUS GARAGE DISPUTE RAISES HEALTH ISSUE
description: THE Nassau County Planning Commission will decide this week whether to approve construction of a $27 million suburban bus garage and office facility in an area known to contain cancer-causing and other hazardous chemicals.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Going, Going, Gone to Basel
description: The New York Public Library and the Pierpont Morgan Library may have their share of rich patrons, but none were willing to match checkbooks with Paul Sacher last week. Mr. Sacher, a Swiss conductor and noted collector of musical manuscripts, won a two-month bidding war for the Igor Stravinsky archive with an offer of $5.25 million for the collected manuscripts and letters of the Russian-born composer. That was $1 million more than the next highest bid,Morgan's. The collection, acquired for Mr. Sacher's Foundation, will be shipped to Basel for permanent display.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: BLACK dresses, bouquets and barbs marked the third annual Godmothers' Baste 'n' Broil at the Princess Restaurant in Lodi on June 17. The Godmothers, two dozen politically active Bergen County women, formed their alliance because of exclusion from the doings of a male political group called The Boatjumpers. The women's choice of name and garb is a play on the male power structure epitomized in the movie ''The Godfather.''

title: TRAINS
description: To the Editor: As an addendum to the article, ''Six Days on the Peking-Moscow Express'' (Travel, May 8), I should like to contrast it with my experience. This past summer, I traveled on the Trans-Siberian Railroad from Khabarovsk to Irkutsk.

title: No Headline
description: Feeling Expansive Speaking of dilated uses of words with seemingly established meanings, a business correspondent of mine recently advised me that: ''Further review of the agreement indicated that the majority of provisions were impertinent'' (''Feeling Expansive,'' by William Safire, On Language, May 29).

title: SEEING MANET WITHIN HIS OWN WORLD
description: PARIS One would have to be crazy - so people said - to go to Paris to see the Manet centenary exhibition. It is, of course, one of the great exhibitions of the age. As to that, there is no dispute. It has very nearly all the major paintings that are available for loan. It has a fresh and lively choice of watercolors and drawings, and a particularly well documented set of prints. Manet is seen entire, as he always wanted to be, and in a way that is unlikely ever to be repeated. The catalogue weighs five-and-a-half pounds, reproduces everything in color and would take a week to read through with due care.

title: DISORDERLY MASTERPIECE
description: ''Three hours of leisure, unannoyed by any alien anxiety, and looked forward to with delight as a change and recreation, will suffice to realize in literature a larger product of what is truly genial, than weeks of compulsion,'' Samuel Taylor Coleridge said about writing in ''Biographia Literaria.'' And the leisure hours of 30 years spent reading at random in that book will put one in touch with more of the product of genius than can be found in any other book of criticism. The literary historian George Saintsbury thought Coleridge's only equals were Aristotle and Longinus, the author of the Greek treatise, ''On the Sublime.''

title: Rematch Tune-Ups
description: Aaron Pryor, the World Boxing Association junior-welterweight champion and the former three-time champion Alexis Arguello are scheduled to fight in separate bouts in July at Caesars Palace.

title: THE MALAISE IN LAW SCHOOLS
description: The problem is not the law schools' emphasis on appellate cases. The problem is that, according to a common conceit, the law professor's real job is not to teach these materials and their significance as living law.

title: Doing 'Better' in Hostage Situation
description: I'm afraid that there was one exceptionally large failure on the part of the hostage team that ''passed the test.''

title: No Headline
description: Asking for Donations: A Volunteer Replies Well, it seems like poor local storeowners can't win in the asking-for-money-gracefully game (Letters to the Editor). According to Rena Garter Kunis, they are either subject to the dread ''withholding of custom'' if they refuse requests, or to be put on a ''suckers' list'' if they donate.

title: INVADERS: SOME ARE WELCOME, AND SOME NOT
description: THE county is populated with flowers, trees, insects, and birds unknown here before aliens of the species Homo sapiens called the land New Netherlands. Nature's aliens have given us a truly aweinspiring diversity of colors, sounds, and shapes. Some have given us only trouble. And if they have yet to teach us any general truths about manipulating nature, at least they are a fascinating subject for examination and speculation.

title: UPGRADING EDUCATION: MERIT PAY IS NOT THE WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: A LONG MENU EMPHASIZING HUNAN
description: ACCORDING to the menu, the kirin, namesake of the Chinese restaurant in Manhasset called Kirin Palace, is a gentle mythical beast and a harbinger of happy times. If you are at all superstititous, it should make the restaurant more appealing.

title: A CALL FOR REGULATING USE OF BICYCLES ON OUR ROADS
description: YOU are driving your car along the main street of your home town. Your destination is the shopping center just outside the city limits. As a law-abiding citizen you keep within the speed limit. At every red traffic light you stop. You pride yourself upon two facts. First that you are a very careful driver. And, second, that you are a courteous driver. There are cars parked along the street. In this day and age it is rare to find an empty parking spot vacant for more than five minutes along Main Street.

title: 'CHAPTER TWO' COMES UP DULL
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR JUST about everyone knows that Neil Simon's ''Chapter Two'' is more or less (mostly more) about the time the playwright met and married the actress Marsha Mason soon after his first wife died and before he was able to deal with that loss.

title: South Korea Jails Former Legislator
description: A South Korean court today jailed a former opposition member of Parliament for 10 days for distributing anti-Government leaflets about the recent hunger strike by Kim Young Sam, the former opposition leader, Mr. Kim's aides said.

title: Laura H. Waldron Is Wed to Richard D. O'Brien
description: Laura Hunt Waldron, daughter of Mrs. Martin O. Waldron of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Waldron, and Richard Douglas O'Brien, son of Mrs. Richard E. Norberg of St. Louis, and the late Francis X. O'Brien, were married yesterday in Princeton. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston performed the ceremony at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: Toll and Fare Increase to Spread Wealth
description: Governor Cuomo and Governor Kean proposed sweeping changes last week in the way the Port Authority spends its money in New York and New Jersey. The most immediate change, however, will be in the way motorists and mass-transit riders spend their money: Tolls on the authority's bridges and tunnels and fares on PATH trains are going up.

title: FLAWLESS CASTING MARKS 'PICNIC'
description: THE playwright William Inge has been well treated on Long Island this summer. First there was the stellar production of ''Bus Stop'' by the Nassau Repertory Theater, and now there's an equally fine ''Picnic'' being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale.

title: THE MALAISE IN LAW SCHOOLS
description: As a young law student, Felix Frankfurter heard Louis D. Brandeis (by 1905 already renowned as a ''people's lawyer'') chastise his own profession during an address at the Harvard Ethical Union:

title: Cynthia Lea Hostage Weds
description: Cynthia Lea Hostage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Michael Hostage of Wellesley, Mass., was married in Rye, N.Y., yesterday to Karl Richard Morningstar, son of Eleanor Klarman Morningstar of Rye and the late Thomas Wood Morningstar. The Rev. Gerard Rafferty performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection. The bride's father, formerly president of the I.T.T. Continental Baking Company in Rye, is president and chairman of the Howard Johnson Company in Braintree, Mass.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: The Rise of 'The Rose'

title: SOFTENING SOME IMAGES, IF NOT POLICIES
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, probably could not change the Reagan Administration's stance on issues of concern to her department even if she wanted to. But to some extent she has changed the tone of the department, and that is no mean feat.

title: MAKING IT
description: When I go back to my hometown with my world-weary New York eyes and my expensive New York teeth the folks always look at me in that sly superior country way. That's partly because they're country people and my hometown - Morrisonville, Va. - is a country town, nestled as it is three miles south of metropolitan Lovettsville and two miles north of Wheatland, which is not a town at all but just a sign on the side of the road.

title: CABLE CATALYST: JANE DEKNATEL THE IN-HOUSE MOVIE MAKER AT HBO
description: JANE DEKNATEL is under siege, Hollywood-style. Her modest Century City office in central Los A ngeles is bombarded by scripts and movie ideas from producers and w ould-be producers. She ''takes'' endless meetings, interrupting themf or telephone calls from the other coast, Europe and Australia.

title: Louisiana Drops Racial Fractions
description: Louisiana is a state of many distinctions. It stripped itself of one of its more dubious last week - its so-called black blood law - in repealing 1970 legislation that designates anyone with one thirtysecond ''Negro blood'' as black.

title:
HOME DESIGN;
RETOUCHING A MASTER'S WORK
description: Veronica McNiff often writes about interior design.While the exterior of this Frank Lloyd Wright house (above) is characteristically timeless, the interiors began to seem out of date. Thus, the designer Linda Holtzschue replaced the aggressive color and pattern in the living room (right) with subtle textures and hues, and stripped the black-lacquered dining furniture (left).Left: The family room offers a panoramic view of Wright's masterly indoor-outdoor scheme. Below: Once a bedroom, the game room now retains much of the original built-in furniture.

title: Mystery Writer?
description: Louis L'Amour, a best-selling author whose many books have included some with surprise endings, was taken aback recently by a couple with surprise beginnings.

title: THE MUSICAL AVANT-GARDE: AN IDEA WHOSE TIME MAY HAVE GONE
description: When Pierre Boulez proclaimed, in 1952, using capital letters, ''SCHOENBERG IS DEAD,'' he was not referring to the composer's actual physical demise the year before. His was an esthetic proclamation, a call to arms against what Mr. Boulez felt were the conservative forces that Arnold Schoenberg represented. It is time, Mr. Boulez argued, to be more radical with serialism and atonality than its first practitioner ever was. ''It is time to neutralize the setback,'' he wrote. The future needed still more progressive composition, less retrospection, more innovation. The avant-garde was ready to enter the new post-war era.

title: GHANAIANS IN CITY JOIN TO AID AILING COUNTRYMEN IN AFRICA
description: Beginning several years ago, the letters Kwaku Kwarteng received at his home here from relatives in Ghana referred with increasing frequency to a single subject: the serious lack of basic medical equipment and drugs in the African country.

title: UPGRADING EDUCATION: MERIT PAY IS NOT THE WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: The Librarian And the Camera An item in the June 5 Long Island Journal leaves me with decided misgivings. ''More than 20,000 Sun cameras ... will be donated by Polaroid to libraries nationwide,'' we're informed.

title: James J. Brady 3d Wed To Janice Eileen Major
description: Janice Eileen Major, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Major of Weston, Conn., and Kennebunkport, Me., was married yesterday to James J. Brady 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. James J. Brady Jr. of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. Robert C. Franklin and the Rev. Randall Blackall performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church in Weston.

title: ELEGANT PASTRIES AND GOOD SERVICE
description: THOUGH its name - Versailles - evokes visions of monumental, formal grandeur, the small, L-shaped, palm-festooned restaurant in the Harbor Plaza complex on Shippan Point in Stamford has the spirit of an informal, light-hearted cafe or bistro.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Graduate Work ''Loving,'' television's newest soap opera or daytime serial, will make its debut on Monday from 11:30 A.M. to 12 noon. ''For the first time,'' says Agnes Nixon, who created it, ''we have a college campus as a story's focal point. This is new for a serial. You need, for the sake of the story, something like a market place. That's why a lot of folks have a hospital. We're going to have a college campus because we think it is a microcosm of life today. You have - from the oldest tenured professor to the youngest freshman - all the range of emotions and the social and economic strata. It also appealed to us because college students are such fans of the soaps and we want to have them feel that they are being represented.''

title: Colorado River's Flow Called Highest Since '64
description: The snow-swollen Colorado rushed from dam to dam through Arizona like an untamed river today, raising floodwaters for hundreds of miles.

title: Kate Welch Is the Bride Of George L. Hopkins Jr.
description: Kathleen Stuart Donnelly Welch, daughter of Mrs. Peter C. Welch of Boston and Osterville, Mass., and the late John Donnelly, was married yesterday to George Lawrence Hopkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hopkins of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Msgr. Francis J. Lally of the United Catholic Conference performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Osterville.

title: CLINIC HELPS DIABETICS COPE WITH FEARS
description: HARTFORD FOR many patients, being diagnosed as a diabetic in the past meant being hospitalized for a week while learning to live with the disease.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics National Sports Festival, at Colorado Springs. The telecast will concentrate on boxing, men's platform diving and swimming. (Television - Channel 7, 4:45 P.M.). Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium, 1:05 P.M., doubleheader. Tom Seaver (5-6) and Tom Gorman (0-1), who was 6-1 at Tidewater before he came up to the Mets, will start New York's 9th and 10th games in the last 7 days. (Television - SportsChannel 1 P.M. and 8 P.M. tape Radio - WHN 1050 1 P.M.).

title: STUDY SEES NEED FOR MORE AID TO ISRAEL
description: A Government report has concluded that the United States is likely to come under increasing pressure to provide more economic grants or other concessions to Israel because of Israel's growing debt.

title: VETO BATTLES SET THE STAGE FOR '84
description: As the House of Representatives was about to pass a Federal budget last week, Budget Committee chairman James R. Jones had the floor. ''These conference agreements are only the first step,'' the Oklahoma Democrat said. ''Now we have to enforce them.''

title: More in Poll Expecting Candidacy by Reagan
description: Seventy-nine percent of the prospective voters surveyed now expect President Reagan to seek re-election, according to the Gallup Poll's report of the responses of people questioned May 20-23.

title: Christine Lou Braen Wed In Morristown Ceremony
description: Christine Lou Braen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Peter Braen of Morristown, N.J., was married at the Morristown Unitarian Church yesterday to Dr. Carl A. Futia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo R. Futia of Greenwich, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul Ratzlaff, assisted by Msgr.

title: THE STATURE OF AN ECCENTRIC
description: DJUNA The Life and Times of Djuna Barnes. By Andrew Field. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $16.95.

title: Kari Unksova, Dissident Poet, Said to Die in Soviet Mishap
description: Kari Unksova, a dissident feminist poet who was about to emigrate from the Soviet Union, was hit and killed by a car in Leningrad early this month, friends of the woman disclosed today.

title: 4 Arrests Are Made As Klan Holds a Rally in New Britain
description: Riot-equipped police officers arrested four people before and after a Ku Klux Klan rally that drew a crowd of 75 - supporters, hecklers and sunbathing spectators - to a football stadium here today.

title: POLISHING SURFACES OF WOOD
description: IF six collectors of fine old furniture were together in a room and were asked the best way to protect antique wood surfaces, the result could be a half-dozen different recipes. The main variations would be in the proportion of bees' wax to turpentine, linseed or other oils. The same arguments prevailed in the 18th and 19th centuries. Few today, however, would add the coloring agents, such as red ochre, that were suggested 200 years ago on what was then new furniture.

title: LaPorte Holds Title On a Split Decision
description: Juan LaPorte, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion who had predicted an easy victory, won a hard-fought split decision from Johnny de la Rosa today.

title: BY THEODORE JAMES JR.
Miss Moonan, Editor, Marries D.N. Darrow
description: Wendy Lyon Moonan, architecture and design editor of Town & Country magazine, was married yesterday at the Wainscott (L.I.) Chapel to Duncan Noble Darrow, a New York lawyer. The Rev. Daniel Burke of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I., performed the ceremony.

title: Cuomo, Friends Iron It All Out
description: When Governor Cuomo and legislative leaders put their heads together to pass a budget with a punctuality unrivaled in recent years, skeptics wondered just how long they would remain cheek-tocheek. The answer seemed clear last week: long enough.

title: NEW YORK WILL GET A CONVENTION OF FOSSIL SKULLS OF MAN'S ANCESTORS
description: Fossil skulls of human progenitors, some more than four million years old, are to be assembled in New York City next year from repositories in Africa, Asia, Europe and North America.

title: FUND FOR INMATES CELEBRATED
description: With the last few dollars remaining from a $127,000 fund awarded to inmates at the Bedford Hills Correctional Institution two years ago in an unprecedented court decision, the women at the prison gave themselves a picnic last weekend - with support from the facility's administration.

title: Foes Demagogic, Reagan Says
description: President Reagan, citing the ''noisy debate'' that followed the report of his National Commission on Excellence in Education, advised Americans today to ''ignore the noise makers and set sail'' on the course charted by the panel.

title: No Headline
description: Cards and Flowers From Nursery School Gerald Eskenazi has written articles about his friend Adele Rubins, all of them humorous, heartwarming and definitely true. Nevertheless, there is another side to Adele that few people know about.

title: Why Not a Black Candidate for The Presidency?
description: In a decision that had to be disturbing to any white liberal Democrat who wants to live in the White House one day, a group of black civil rights and political figures last week formally endorsed the notion of a black's seeking the Democratic Party Presidential nomination.

title: THE NOVELIST AS MEMOIRIST
description: THE STRANGERS ALL ARE GONE The Memoirs of Anthony Powell. Volume Four. Illustrated. 208 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $18.50.

title: PUBLIC RADIO'S WOES ARE NOT WNYC'S
description: To the Editor:$

title: Bompago Heads Field Of 14 for Queen's Plate
description: Bompago, a 3-year-old gelding owned by a group that includes the trainer John Cardella, heads a field of 14 3-year-olds that will compete for a record purse of $252,310 in the 114th running of the Queen's Plate at Woodbine Sunday.

title: GROUPS SETTING UP OWN BLOOD BANKS
description: When some members of the Roslyn Country Club Civic Association expressed the concern that they might contract AIDS if they received blood from a blood bank, the association set up its own list of potential blood donors.

title: A Glorious Fourth in Deerfield, Mass.
description: In Historic Deerfield in Massachusetts, where 12 restored houses celebrate the history and culture of early America, the observance of Independence Day is something more than a perfunctory rite.

title: PARIS
description: To the Editor: Pleasant memories and embarrassing moments were vividly recalled by Patricia Wells' article "A Paris Ritual to Savor" (Travel, May 29). t's true there is much market etiquette to be learned.

title: Maryann Lyons Is Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. John and St. Mary in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday Maryann Lyons and George Charles Civita, 1982 graduates of the University of Maryland, were married by Msgr. Robert J. Skelly. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Frederick T. Lyons of Chappaqua and Mr. and Mrs. George Civita of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Eastham, Mass.

title: WALKER ENDING LONGEST SEASON
description: IN one more week, the longest season will end and Herschel Walker w ill be able to put aside the playbook and uniform and helmet that heh as worn since fall football practice began at the University of G eorgia last August. Since then, Walker has left the insulated and f riendly environment of a college campus to enter the pro football b usiness world. He also has become a millionaire, which has prompted s ome people to portray him as Saturday's hero turned fortune hunter.

title: CHARLES KURALT CONTINUES TO WONDER WHAT'S AROUND THE BEND
description: Studio 44 in the CBS Broadcast Center on West 57th Street clears out fast when ''CBS News Sunday Morning'' is over, especially on a warm, sunny day when some members of the crew are talking anxiously of getting out to Connecticut and the Hamptons. ''I've never been to the Hamptons,'' remarked Charles Kuralt, bound for Sheboygan, Wisc., -and seemingly pleased about it.

title: ARAFAT VISITS PRAGUE FOR HELP ON P.L.O.
description: Yasir Arafat flew to Czechoslovakia today to seek international support for his struggle against mutineers in the Fatah guerrilla movement.

title: BEGIN, TOO, SEEMS AMONG THE WAR WEARY
description: During his six years in office, Prime Minister Menachem Begin has gone through occasional periods of depression and withdrawal, provoking speculation in the Israeli press about his ability to function as the head of government. Such retreats have always been followed by bouts of frenetic activity, most dramatically in 1981, when months of withdrawal were broken by the start of his vigorous campaign for re-election.

title: THE MALAISE IN LAW SCHOOLS
description: In the article on legal education, the title of Dean John Ely's prize-winning book was wrong.

title: MONDELLO HAS A MANDATE, BUT HIS PARTY IS DIVIDED
description: DESPITE the unanimous selection of Joseph N. Mondello as Nassau Republican chairman, the powerful Republican county organization begins a new era without Joseph M. Margiotta as its leader in a far from unified state.

title: 'Rosy' Statistics?
description: To the Business Editor: To refer to ''rosy statistics'' and ''more good news'' in the ''Week In Business'' column (June 5) directs attention away from a trend that should disturb all thoughtful Americans.

title: THE CHERRY NOW IS THE LOVELIEST OF FRUITS
description: ''THE cherry now,'' is the ''loveliest of trees,'' as A.E. Housman observed, and also the loveliest of fruits. And now is the time for cherries.

title: FARMERS MARKETS FLOURISHING
description: HARVESTS and stores may come and go, but at least two farmers markets in southern Westchester and one in White Plains are showing quite a bit of staying appeal.

title: SPEEDING MORTGAGE APPROVAL
description: BE home buyers are discovering to their alarm that mortgage c ommitments from lenders are taking longer to process this summer, s ometimes as much as two months.

title: WARSAW ACCUSES REAGAN OF INTERFERENCE IN POLAND
description: The Government said today that President Reagan's call for the restoration of banned labor unions in Poland constituted ''another glaring example of interference in the internal affairs of our state.''

title: OAKLAND PRESSING EFFORT FOR TEAM
description: A legal dispute with potentially broad implications for professional sports, as well as for municipal law, is nearing a conclusion here after more than a month of contentious testimony.

title: WHERE IRON AND BAMBOO CURTAINS MEET
description: Two decades of official animosity between China and the Soviet Union have created some strange situations for the minority peoples divided by the border between the two countries in Central Asia. Two frontier points will reopen next month for resumption of local Chinese-Soviet trading. But there are no prospects for reviving normal cross-border traffic, sealed off since the 1960's.

title: OVERZEALOUS LEGISLATORS KEEPING GOVERNOR BUSY
description: TRENTON HUNDREDS of bills make it through the State Legislature each year, not all of them perfect, and Governor Kean has been taking on a Horatio-at-the-bridge role recently to block some from enactment.

title:
ANTIQUES;
MAIN STREET, CHESTER: A THRIVING RELIC OF THE MID-1800'S
description: CHESTER THE main street in this Morris County community is appropriately named Main Street, and it does not seem to have changed much since the mid-1800's. That is when Chester was a prosperous iron-ore mining village.

title: THE KISSINGER LESSON
description: History will credit Henry Kissinger with great achievements in his years of power. The Nixon opening to the People's Republic of China could not have happened without his skill. Whatever hope there is for peace in the Middle East goes back to the disengagement agreements that he negotiated between Israel and Egypt, Israel and Syria. There were gains for U.S. interests and those of international order.

title: Mary D. Spalding Becomes a Bride
description: Mary Dodd Spalding, daughter of Mary Miller Spalding of New Canaan, Conn., and East Hampton, L.I., and Francis Odiorne Spalding of the Sea Ranch, near Gualala, Calif., was married yesterday to Richard Clement Hasner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rolf Kaare Hasner of Greenwich, Conn., and Oslo.

title: JUBILEE CELEBRATION MIT SCHLAG
description: R.W.APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times.

title: INDUSTRIAL POLICY AND A FREE MARKET DO MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: Pope's Assailant Says 'Some' In Vatican Want to Kill Him
description: Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk who shot and wounded Pope John Paul II in 1981, has repeated his assertion that ''some people'' in the Vatican want to kill him, the Italian news agency A.S.C.A. reported today.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CHINESE MUSIC Sunday afternoon at 2:30 and again on Wednesday and Thursday at 8 P.M., the Bel Canto Opera will take a stylistic and a geographical leap from its accustomed repertory. ''Tao Yuan,'' which plays at the Wagner School Theater on East 76th Street Sunday afternoon and twice at Symphony Space later in the week, is really more a play than an opera.

title: Industrial Policy
description: To the Business Editor: In their discussion of industrial policy (June 12), Jerry J. Jasinowski (''Too Little Focus on the Business Cycle'') and Bruce Bartlett (''False Images and Political Bias'') make many good arguments on peripheral aspects of the economy but they miss the central point. That is, that precisely because now we are dealing with a global market our country needs a dual economic policy.

title: COUNTY CENTER REHABILITATION IS WEIGHED
description: WHITE PLAINS VAN CLIBURN has played the piano in its auditorium. The Harlem Globetrotters once wreaked hilarious havoc on other basketball teams there. Metropolitan Opera stars have sung from its wide stage and so has Nelson Eddy. In 1932, two years after it opened, the state Republican convention was held there.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART They're in every walk of English life, driving taxis, writing plays, publishing books, making book, getting married, going to weddings, hunting foxes, celebrating bar mitzvahs and marching in Memorial Day parades. There are nearly a half-million of them, at every level of British life, and save for their religion, they're pretty much like other British citizens.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: KATONAH
description: AT the turn of the century, when Katonah quite literally picked i tself up and started over, great care was taken to insure that the s mall hamlet would get off, again, on the right foot. Breweries and d istilleries were prohibited, as were slaughterhouses and soap f actories, and anyone planning to build a new house had to agree to s pend at least $2,500.

title: No Headline
description: The New Romance With Tonality That David Del Tredici should be in the vanguard of contemporary neo-Romanticism, and that he should be receiving the well-deserved appreciation of concertgoers across the nation, suprises no one who knew him in his student days (''The New Romance with Tonality,'' by Tim Paige, May 29).

title: RAILROAD PROPOSAL DRAWS HEAVIER FIRE
description: HADDONFIELD APLAN to resume railroad service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, announced June 1 by John P. Sheridan Jr., Commissioner of the state's Department of Transportation, is running into mounting opposition, especially in Camden County.

title: AUSTRALIA II LOOMS AS THREAT
description: As the opening round in the trials to select the challenger and the defender for the America's Cup drew to a close this weekend, Australia II loomed as perhaps the strongest threat for Americans who have been successfully defending the cup for 132 years.

title: Still Proving Himself
description: Saying that he wanted a chance to ''show 'em I've got something left,'' Rick Reuschel, the last 20-game winner for the Chicago Cubs, has accepted a contract with the Cubs to play for their Quad Cities team in the Midwest League. ''I'm going to have to pitch somewhere, if this is where I have to start,'' said Reuschel, who pitched for the Cubs from 1972 to 1981 before being traded to the Yankees, where he spent most of the 1982 season on the disabled list.

title: New York Times Magazine June 26, 1983
description: William Safire 8 On Language Caught Red-Handed Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Making It Tom Wicker 16 Six Years for the President? Proponents of a single, six-year term say that not having to run again would eliminate some of the political pressures on a President. Opponents worry that six years would shorten the tenure of a good President and lengthen that of a poor one.

title: POPULAR MUSIC TAKES A SERIOUS TURN
description: In the innocent old days, there was cultivated music and there was vernacular music. Cultivated music professed a direct connection to the tradition of Western art-music. It was (and is, for that matter) created by ''composers'' who expressed themselves ''artistically.''

title: A JOURNEY FROM 60'S DREAMS TO 80'S REALITIES
description: A FRIEND of mine who is 33 recently bought his first house. Soon after he and his wife moved in, he developed mysterious chest pains that began waking him up in the middle of the night.

title: STARTING IN GERMANTOWN
description: T he appropriate starting point for a tour of German-American history is, of course, Germantown. Once a rural village separated from Philadelphia by six miles of William Penn's woods, the area is now part of the city and the victim of some urban decline. But a collection of fine houses and public buildings has been restored and maintained by a host of historical groups, among them the Germantown Mennonite Church Corporation, the Germantown Historical Society and the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Germantown Avenue, once an Indian trail along which a number of buildings were erected, is a National Historic Landmark.

title: SPECIAL SCHOOL FOR 'FAILURES' GRADUATES FIRST PUPILS
description: A program created by the Community School Board on the Lower East Side and the Grand Street Settlement to work with problem students graduated its first class last week.

title: Brzezinski Questions Source of Carter Book
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, said today that the 1980 Reagan campaign may have been involved in a ''form of Watergate'' by obtaining Mr. Carter's debate briefing book.

title: THE LONG PATH TO TAX ACCORD
description: HARTFORD AS the General Assembly was finally nearing approval last week of legislation increasing taxes by $241 million, an aide of Governor O'Neill was jokingly offering a definition of short-term and longterm planning.

title: SUMMER FESTIVALS OPENING
description: SATURDAY at 8:30 is opening night for two of Westchester's oldest, most ambitious, most beautiful summer festivals, so take your pick between the aristocratic ambience of Caramoor, with its fantastic gardens and the Old World elegance of the Venetian Theater, and Lyndhurst, where informality is king and most of the audience sit on folding chairs or blankets on the huge lawn that sweeps down to the concert tent.

title: NORWALK TO DECIDE ON SITE OF CITY HALL
description: NORWALK lawmakers this week will be asked to decide between providing new offices for city workers or helping to establish a new institute to educate the area's young adults.

title: JUDGE INCREASES PROTECTION FOR HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: Homeless families with children must be given habitable living quarters in emergency housing or a hearing if the city denies or terminates them from shelter, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan has ordered.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Complacency on Deficits?

title: NORA BETWEEN NED AND THE DEVIL
description: HOW HE SAVED HER By Ellen Schwamm. 274 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: LEFRAK CO-OPS EXTENDING MARKET RANGE
description: ONE by one, the rental buildings of the L efrak Organization have been converted to cooperative ownership o ver the last few years as part of a long-term sales program by one o f the city's largest owners of conventionally financed housing.

title: Statistics Unit 99 Years Old
description: The Government's Bureau of Labor Statistics will mark its 99th anniversary Monday. The bureau, part of the Labor Department, publishes economic statistics on prices, wages, employment and unemployment, productivity, economic growth and occupational safety and health.

title: THE RITES OF VINTAGE ASSEMBLY
description: On a chill, rainy day in early spring, seven men gathered in the refectory of Chateau Prieure-Lichine in the tiny village of Cantenac, 20 miles north of Bordeaux. They had come here at the invitation of the owner, Alexis Lichine, to help him make a wine.

title: No Headline
description: When There's Wildlife In the House Thank you for ''Cute Little Things, but Not in the House'' (Opinion Page).

title: Joan Dineen Has Nuptials
description: At the Friends Meeting House in Chappaqua, N.Y., yesterday,Joan Dineen, a designer with the New York architectural firm of Gillis Associates, and Christopher Weld Gould, president and owner of Broadway Play Publishing in New York, were married in a Quaker ceremony.

title: RECOVERY ARRIVES, STAYING POWER UNCERTAIN
description: Sometime around Labor Day 1986, the chill could come again. It would start with word from Sears of ebbing sales, then from Florida of condominiums going begging, then from Detroit of unemployed autoworkers. Ever since the end of World War II, the economy's recessions have lasted 11 months on average and recoveries, 46, which means that the current recovery has 40 months to go.

title: A SHORE GUIDE
description: SEASIDE PARK FOR many people, a weekend or a two- or three-week vacation at the Jersey Shore conjures up images of sand and surf by day and amusement rides, arcades and perhaps a restaurant or lounge at night.

title: MUSICAL PLAY: 'TAO YUAN' BY THE BEL CANTO OPERA
description: ''Tao Yuan,'' a musical play with dance being given by the Bel Canto Opera this week, was written in English by a Chinese composer now living in America, Sung Fu Yuan. Its style draws both on Chinese tradition and Mr. Sung's political and social idealism. There is extensive dancing choreographed by Allan Tung, and projections of paintings by Choi Chor Foo create the major visual effects.

title: Governor of Kentucky Has Open-Heart Surgery
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. underwent open-heart surgery tonight at the University of Kentucky medical center.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
ALFRED STIEGLITZ WAS A DETERMINED PUBLICIST TOO
description: It has been said of Andy Warhol that he belongs more to the history of publicity than to the history of art. The same thing has not yet been said of Alfred Stieglitz, but there is no doubt that he belongs to both, the only question being one of proportions.

title: Newark Residents Seek More Testing for Dioxin
description: About 50 residents of Newark's Ironbound section marched today to protest the state's handling of the dioxin contamination problem at a defunct herbicide plant in their neighborhood.

title: A Lawyer Is Wed To Rebecca Benet
description: At the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco yesterday, Rebecca Benet was married to William Kent Sawyer by the Rev. Richard Fowler.

title: THE WAY TO MAKE CONGRESS'S LIFE EASIER
description: In a recent Senate speech, Howard H. Baker Jr. compellingly expressed his concern that members of Congress have become ''elected bureaucrats'' spending most of the year in the capital, returning home at most for hurried weekends and occasional holidays. Nowhere in the Constitution, nor in the early documents of the Republic, he noted, does it say ''Congress was supposed to compete with the bureaucracy in the detailed daily nitty-gritty of governing.''

title: Jacqueline Crane Is Married
description: The marriage of Jacqueline Crane, a member of the class of '84 at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, to Dr. Glen Stuart Moscowitz, who graduated earlier this month from the New York University College of Dentistry, took place at Temple Beth Sholom in Fair Lawn, N.J., yesterday. Rabbi Robert Aronowitz performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Henry K. Crane of Ridgewood, N.J., and Mr. and Mrs. Carl Moscowitz of Tappan, N.Y.

title: A CORPORATE IDENTITY
description: Since it was organized in 1970, United Jersey Banks has been a tenant, first in Hackensack and currently in Princeton's Forrestal Center. Now the holding company, with seven member banks throughout New Jersey, 118 offices and $3.3 billion in assets, is looking forward to moving into its own home in Princeton.

title: CITIES SEEKING TO SAVE U.S. AID
description: FEARING the loss of $50 million a year if Congress abolishes the Federal General Revenue Sharing Program, Connecticut's towns and cities are lobbying to save it.

title: ELLA FITZGERALD AT CARNEGIE
description: NO one can make a Kool Jazz Festival performance seem more like a gathering of family and friends than Ella Fitzgerald. She has been appearing at the festival with great regularity for 27 years, starting when it was known as the Newport Jazz Festival, and the Fitzgerald faithful are always out in numbers great enough to require two concerts in an evening.

title: THE MAN WHO BOXED HEMINGWAY KEEPS WRITING
description: Morley Callaghan, who has been a serious writer for 57 of his 80 years, sat in his living room with his wife, Loretto, and his shaved poodle and talked about his new novel and about what it was like to have outlived his contemporaries and his own commercial popularity.

title: UMBRELLAS: THE CHEAPER THE BETTER
description: WASHINGTON June 26 - ''What this country needs is a good $5 umbrella,'' said a man as he raced through the rain holding the skeletal remains of a Taiwanese import. More than two feet of water havefallen on Washington this year and it is beginning to tell on the city's umbrellas.

title: Bridge: Father-Son Teams Attain The Heights Only Rarely
description: There have been very few cases of father and son both reaching the highest levels of the game. Oswald and Jim Jacoby of Dallas have both been world champions, a parlay that may soon be matched by two New York experts: B. Jay Becker is already a world champion, and his son, Michael, has a good chance of becoming one in Stockholm in October.

title: Brown Stable After Surgery
description: Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. was in stable condition today after triple bypass heart surgery to replace blocked arteries.

title: Mrs. Morehouse, A Banker, Weds
description: The marriage of Kathleen Stapleton Morehouse, a vice president with Chemical Bank's World Banking Group in New York, to Dale F. Maycen, vice president and treasurer of American Standard Inc. in New York, took place in Madison, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Hayward L. Levy performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: ISLAND WHIRL WINS
description: Island Whirl led from the start today to win the $500,000 Gold Cup at Hollywood Park. The favored entry of Erins Isle and Exploded finished fifth and fourth in the field of six.

title: A CHANCE TO UNDO THE CHILEAN REGIME
description: Chile, silent as the grave for 10 years, is alive again with the sounds of marching feet, angry chants and the cacophony of clanging pots and pans. The Reagan Administration must decide whether to bolster an old friend or dissociate itself from a murderous and economically ruinous regime.

title: Litton Microwave
description: Litton Microwave in Minneapolis is moving its advertising account in-house and has assigned all of its media buying activity to SFM Media Corporation. It will be leaving the Bozell & Jacobs office in Minneapolis. The agency has told its people that the reason for the client's move was economic and that it would be spending less for media advertising, but Lyle Cavanagh, director of marketing and advertising for the company, , said this would not be the case and that the $6 million budget would be maintained.

title: Cleveland Reassesses $510 Million House
description: Cleveland school officials have discovered that, because of a keypunch error in the county auditor's office, they do not have $4 million they thought they did.

title: David Simon, Lawyer, Marries Mrs. Wasser
description: The marriage of Suzanne Cohn Wasser, a practicing hypnotherapist, to David Simon, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Barrett Smith Schapiro Simon & Armstrong, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony at the Harvard Club.

title: BAD POPULATION NEWS
description: To the Editor:

title: 408 Bodies Recovered In West India Floods
description: Rescue workers have recovered 408 bodies in the flood-swept Saurashtra region of western India, where nearly 130,000 residents are still marooned, the authorities said today.

title: Libyan-Backed Rebels Moving South in Chad
description: Libyan-backed guerrillas moved south from the rebel-held city of Largeau in northern Chad today, and several thousand people demonstrated here in the capital to protest what they called Libyan intervention.

title: COMMODITY STOCKPILE FUND
description: King Hammurabi of ancient Babylon first tried to regulate commodity markets, declaring a ''just price'' for grain throughout his realm. Later Joseph showed the Egyptian Pharaohs how to run a commodity buffer stock, setting aside surpluses from the fat years to provide food during the lean.

title: John James Wins Ashe Tennis Final
description: John James of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and Kathy Farrell of Dunkirk, N.Y., won the open singles finals of the $10,000 Arthur Ashe Tennis Classic yesterday at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: GOLD BEAUTY WINS AT BELMONT
description: ''Sooner or later,'' Bill Curtis, Gold Beauty's trainer, was saying at Belmont Park yesterday, ''if they keep putting weight on her, she's going to get beat. It's inevitable.''

title: NEWARK STUDIED BY 3 PROSECUTORS IN NEW INQUIRIES
description: Federal, state and county prosecutors have begun separate investigations into possible corruption in the operations of Newark's city government and Housing Authority.

title: LEGISLATURE APPROVES INCREASE IN OIL TAX
description: A measure that would increase taxes on oil companies that do business in New York State was approved by the Legislature tonight.

title: Cardinal Says a Mass For Divorced People
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin today became the highest-ranking Roman Catholic prelate to celebrate a mass for divorced and separated church members.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I will not quit like a rat, I will not run away.'' - Lech Walesa. (A8:3.)

title: MIZE WINS BY 1 ON BIRDIE AT 18
description: Larry Mize, a PGA Tour second-year man who never before had been in title competition, dropped a tie-breaking, 20-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today and won the Danny Thomas-Memphis Classic by one stroke.

title: NOT-ALL-THAT-INDEPENDENT M.T.A.
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; June 27, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHRYSLER WORKERS SEEK TO CATCH UP ON WAGES
description: Slightly more than two years ago the Chrysler Corporation was the automobile industry's 97-pound weakling and so pitifully close to bankruptcy that even its workers voted twice to give up some of their wages to keep the company, and their jobs, alive.

title: NEW BOND RULE LIGHTENS SCHEDULE
description: Friday will see the virtual end of bearer bonds in the municipal market. Instead, state and local governments must offer all new issues in registered form, signaling what some say is the beginning of a computerized bond record-keeping system.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In college basketball, what is a double dribble, a discontinued dribble and an illegal dribble?

title: Washington Watch; The Search For Revenues
description: WASHINGTON THE Senate Finance Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee begin drawing up their wish lists this week in search of $73 billion in tax increases over the next three years. The new revenues - $12 billion in the fiscal year 1984, $15 billion in 1985 and $46 billion in 1986 - are mandated in the budget resolution that was approved last week.

title: FOUNDATIONS SEEK TAX LAW CHANGES
description: The country's private foundations, facing their first full scrutiny by Congress in 14 years, are seeking changes in Federal laws that they contend have impeded philanthropy.

title: Advertising; A Serious Shearson Campaign
description: THE FIRST of the television commercials done by McCann-Erickson for Shearson/American Express appeared Saturday during NBC-TV's coverage of the Wimbledon tennis tournament - and they were a complete departure from the last campaign, which was introduced through Grey Advertising during the Super Bowl in 1982.

title: Kurdish Rebels Report They Killed 70 Iraqis
description: Kurdish rebels in northern Iraq fought off a large-scale assault on their base area at Shene on Friday, killing 70 Iraqi soldiers and shooting down a helicopter gunship, a spokesman for the rebels said in London tonight.

title: PIRATES BEAT CARDS FOR 8TH STRAIGHT
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates extended their winning streak to eight games yesterday, beating the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-0. The Cardinals have now lost 6 straight games and 9 of their last 11.

title: DAMASCUS STEPS UP ATTACK ON ARAFAT
description: Syria stepped up its personal attacks on Yasir Arafat today, describing the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman as a ''defeatist'' who had ''chosen the path of the wilderness.''

title: ...Well-Fed Viewers
description: Al Michaels is hardly the only fan who watches Atlanta's ''super station'' for its telecasts of Braves games, but his fervor for the satellite signal is rivaled by the obsessive interest in the Braves' telecasts of those who need neither cable nor dish.

title: BRIEFING
description: Every Penny Counts

title: SHULTZ CRITICIZES SOVIET REJECTION OF ARMS PROPOSAL
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz criticized the Soviet Union today for its rejection of interim proposals made last month by the United States at the Geneva talks on limiting medium-range missiles.

title: BUTCH MORRIS IN NEW JAZZ
description: BUTCH MORRIS opened the 1983 Kool Jazz Festival's ''New Music at Soundscape'' series Friday night, leading a group that included two violins, electric guitar, vibraphone, piano and drums, in addition to his own cornet. Some jazz composers are more concerned with melodic and rhythmic ideas than with instrumental color, but the feelings Mr. Morris was expressing Friday seemed to demand the richly allusive instrumental combinations he employed.

title: ISRAELIS ACT TO END DOCTOR STRIKE
description: Faced with a virtual shutdown of public hospitals, the Cabinet agreed today to accept arbitration of the pay dispute that has led to a 13-day hunger strike by doctors.

title: Habib in Israel for Talks
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, arrived in Israel today for talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin on the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: 'NEW' BAND IN DEBUT AT CARNEGIE
description: THE Toshiko Akiyoshi-Lew Tabackin Big Band has played at the Kool Jazz Festival before, but the band the two musicians presented at a festival program Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Hall was a debut -the first appearance anywhere of their ''New'' New York Band, formed in the last year, since they gave up the well-established band they had maintained in California for a decade, and settled in New York.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LEGION. By William Peter Blatty. 269 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: CONCERT: A PERFORMANCE ON HOMEMADE INSTRUMENTS
description: MUSIC FOR HOMEMADE INSTRUMENTS, which calls itself ''the group that invents, builds, composes for and performs on musical instruments built from trash,'' presented a concert Saturday night at 262 Bowery. Skip La Plante, between performances of his compositions, gave detailed information on the origins of his instruments.

title: Noah Resigns From the A.T.P.
description: Yannick Noah, winner of the French Open this month, has resigned from the Association of Tennis Professionals, the player union's executive director, Mike Davies, confirmed tonight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SILVER ANNIVERSARY

title: U.S. DEFEATED BY EAST GERMANY IN TRACK
description: The high hopes of the United States team dissipated today, and East Germany won the two-day combined competition, 197 to 181, between two of the world's track and field powers.

title: FIERY JESSE JACKSON ATTRACTING POLITICIANS' PRAISE AND CRITICISM
description: It was a rather dingy auditorium in Memphis and pretty early in the morning at that, but after 45 minutes of nonstop preaching, the Rev. Jesse Jackson had 4,000 black Baptist ministers crying out the word that every potential Presidential candidate loves to hear.

title: Bush Says NATO Must Show It Is Serious in Arms Stance
description: Vice President Bush said today that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must show the Soviet Union ''we are serious'' in disarmament talks and ''the Soviets must put something constructive on the table.''

title: WOMEN PLAN ARMS PROTEST UPSTATE
description: Beside a small farm on Route 96 here in the Finger Lakes Region, a sign says: ''Women's Encampment for a Future of Peace & Justice.'' The sign, leaning in the shade of a tall tree, is strikingly neat and glossy, in contrast with a nearby house where the shutters droop on their hinges, the porch railing is broken and only a hint of paint remains.

title: SPEAKER'S COUNSEL: A MAN IN DEMAND
description: It's trading time in Albany. These are the days when legislators and lobbyists watch bills they have nursed for months live to become law or die, as beneficiaries of special pleading or victims of the last-minute flurry of swaps.

title: Iraqi President Warns Of Intervention in War
description: President Saddam Hussein called today for new moves to end Iraq's war with Iran, saying there was a risk of foreign intervention in the conflict.

title: Hu Na Is Ready For U.S. Debut
description: Hu Na, the 20-year-old tennis player whose defection last summer stirred tension between the United States and China, will face Claudia Hernandez of Mexico here Monday night in her first tournament since being granted political asylum in April.

title: Janine Grewcock Wed to Dr. Peter G.S. Gunther
description: Janine Maud Grewcock, daughter of the late Mrs. John T. Cahill of New York and Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Derek Grewcock of New York, was marrried in Vergennes, Vt., yesterday to Dr. Peter Guy Stapleton Gunther, son of Mrs. Paul M. Traub of Newburgh, N.Y., and the late George Anthony Gunther of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Robert Senghas, minister of the Burlington (Vt.)

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics National Sports Festival, at Colorado Springs, Rowing, field hockey, archery, judo, canoe-kayak, baseball, cycling, volleyball, roller skating, softball and basketball events, some for men, women or both continue. Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. This rivalry was supposed to be the ABC national game of the week last Monday, but a rainstorm in Baltimore wiped it out. George Steinbrenner lifted the blackout so tonight's game could be shown locally as well as nationally. (Television - Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.). Mets vs. Tides, at Tidewater, Va., 7:30 P.M. After a marathon week of 10 games in seven days, the Mets face their farm club in the Class AAA International League before going to St. Louis for a twilight-night doubleheader tomorrow. Reds vs. Atlanta Braves at Cincinnati. (Television -WTBS, 8:35 P.M.).

title: DANCE: BALLET THEATER OFFERS ROBBINS'S 'OTHER DANCES'
description: IN an especially long season for any ballet company, American Ballet Theater continues to introduce a changing repertory and new faces in different roles.

title: LEADER OF TEXTRON UNIT NAMED WATERBURY CHIEF
description: An expert in the field of industrial fasteners has been named president and chief executive of the Waterbury Companies, a leading manufacturer of buttons based in Waterbury, Conn.

title: Susan Herman, a Teacher, Wed to Donald E. Mesibov
description: The marriage of Susan Herman, a teacher of emotionally handicapped children, to Donald Eric Mesibov, a union representative for the New York State United Teachers Organization in the northern tier of New York State, took place in Long Beach, L.I., yesterday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Village 'Volcano'

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.38 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.25 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: Commodities; New Wave Of Futures Contracts
description: ARE the nation's commodity exchanges opening new markets faster than the new products can be absorbed by the brokerage industry, commercial hedgers and the general trading public?

title: Regan Fights Bank Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said Friday that he opposes moves in Congress to temporarily ban nonbanking companies from establishing or buying banks and thrift institutions. Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has asked Congress to slow the blending of banking and other types of businesses.

title: ORDERS UP 14% IN MAY FOR TOOLS
description: Orders for machine tools, a barometer of industrial health, grew 14 percent from April to May, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration is engaged in not one but two sets of negotiations on arms control: one with the Soviet Union and the other with Congress. The differing demands of each has now kindled new controversy over the MX missile and foreshadowed more troubles for the project in coming months.

title: Baseball Hunger...
description: Al Michaels, the broadcaster who provides the play-by-play account for ABC's Monday night baseball telecasts, works just one game a week, but when he comes home to Menlo Park, Calif., he doesn't put his work behind him.

title: Conference Backs Return of U.S.F.
description: The executive committee of the West Coast Athletic Conference endorsed today the University of San Francisco's decision to resume basketball with the conference in the 1985-86 season.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1983
description: International A shift in favor of democracy in Chile has led to the first serious challenge that the country's ruler, Gen. Augusto Pinochet, has faced since he sized power nearly 10 years ago, according to his supporters and opponenets. But the general has said that there will be no elections until at least 1989. (Page A1, Column 1.) Moscow was sharply criticized by Secretary of state George P. Shultz f its rejection of interim proposals made last month by the United States at the Geneva talks on limiting medium-range missiles. He said the offer was "resonable." He made his Manila before leaving for Bangkok, the second stop of a four-nation trip to Asia. (A1:2.) 15 members of a Pentacostal family will be allowed to emigrate from the Soviet UNion to Israel, Soviet authorities announced. The 15 includes 7 who pressed their case by taking refuge for nearly five years in the United States Embassy in Moscow. The Soviet move appeared to an effort troward resolving a human-rights case troubling Soviet-American relations. (A1:3.)

title: COSMOS MISSING CHINAGLIA 'S EFFORTS
description: Giorgio Chinaglia will not retire until the season ends, but Coach Julio Mazzei believes now is the time to find a replacement for the leading career scorer in the North American Soccer League.

title: Strikers Vote to Accept Meat Packer's Offer
description: Striking union workers voted today in favor of a new contract with the Wilson Foods Corporation, the nation's largest pork processor, and a company spokesman said employees could be back on the job Monday afternoon.

title: Shawna McCarthy, Editor, Marries Wayne D. Barlowe
description: Shawna Lee McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McCarthy of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Wayne Douglas Barlowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sy Barlowe of Massapequa, L.I.
