Rabbi Charles D. Lippman performed the garden ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Rogers.

title: LIQUIDATOR FOR RETAILERS TO EXPAND INTO BARTER
description: Sam Nassi, the well-known liquidator of failed retail companies, has announced his intent to move into the barter business in a big way.

title: Benihana at Romann
description: Benihana of Tokyo, the restaurant chain where the chefs are the show, will be getting into the frozen food business in October, when it introduces into the New York market Benihana Restaurant Classics, with a $1 million ad budget. It has just named Romann & Tannenholz Advertising for that assignment. Hume Smith Mickelberry Advertising is the agency for the restaurant chain.

title: Reagan Aides Discuss Inquiry Into Campaign
description: Key aides to President Reagan met Saturday to discuss the handling of continuing questions about how his 1980 campaign staff obtained briefing materials prepared for President Carter, White House officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: The Editorial Notebook The View From Managua

title: YARRAWONGA REPRESENTED
description: league Australian Rules Football player. He has come all the way from Yarrawonga - twice.

title: STAUB TIES MARK
description: Rusty Staub tied a pinch-hitting record. Darryl Strawberry got three hits in a game for the first time as a major leaguer, and Mike Torrez pitched a three-hitter.

title: RECREATION VEHICLE INDUSTRY GAINING AS DEMAND REVIVES
description: Charles and Kaye Anders had been looking at motor homes for years, but kept putting off a purchase. In March, though, the New Jersey couple took the plunge: Encouraged by the brightening economic outlook, some creative financing wrinkles and the vehicles' improved energy-efficiency, the Anderses paid $25,000 for a 23-foot Coachmen motor home.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Monitoring Systems Inc., Broomfield, Conn., has elected A.B. Nelson chairman, following the resignation of Gale D. Burnett.

title: WALESA, COMMENTING ON FUTURE, DECLARES 'I WON'T QUIT LIKE A RAT'
description: Lech Walesa said today that he would not let up in his efforts to restore Solidarity, the independent trade union that was banned after martial law was imposed in 1981.

title: NEW CIVIL SERVICE CHIEF
description: Two months ago, Governor Cuomo ran into Karen S. Burstein at a luncheon in New York City. ''Are you loving what you're doing?'' the Governor asked Miss Burstein, who was then executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board.

title: INVESTOR-OWNED UTILITIES LED ASTRAY BY THE REGULATORY PROCESS
description: To the Editor: As both Mr. Jacobson and the editorial he responded to emphasized, rising costs of fuel, taxes and other essential elements of service do not lend themselves to cosmetic fixes. evertheless, there is room to hold down these costs, particularly by gearing rates to long-range advantage to consumers rather than keeping them so low as to impair credit and increase the cost of service.

title: Lauren Wachtler Is Married
description: Lauren Jane Wachtler and Paul Douglas Montclare, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Judge Sol Wachtler of the State Court of Appeals and Mrs. Wachtler of Manhasset, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony. Mrs. Montclare is an associate with the law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Montclare of Scarsdale, N.Y., is senior partner in the law firm of Montclare & Guay.

title: A TURIN OFFICIAL IS SLAIN AS ITALIANS VOTE
description: The chief public prosecutor of Turin was killed tonight in a street ambush in the northern industrial city. The slaying occurred on the first day of voting in the two-day national parliamentiary elections.

title: THE TRIALS OF OWNING JUST ONE MOVIE THEATER
description: It looks like a rich summer at the Sono Cinema: Italian art films, oldies but goodies and ''Wrestling Women vs. the Aztec Mummy'' - the piece de resistance of an annual ''turkey film festival.''

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY AGREE TO INSTITUTE OVERSEER OF M.T.A.
description: Governor Cuomo and key lawmakers agreed Sunday to set up an inspector general's office to oversee the operation of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a safety board to investigate mass transit accidents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Colorful Interlude

title: UNREST IN CHILE BRINGS PINOCHET FIRST TOUGH TEST
description: For the first time since he seized power nearly 10 years ago, Gen. Augusto Pinochet is being seriously challenged, according to supporters as well as opponents.

title: 15 PENTECOSTALS TO LEAVE SOVIET: 5 SPENT 5 YEARS IN U.S. EMBASSY
description: Soviet authorities announced today that 15 members of a Pentecostal family would be allowed to leave for Israel, including 5 who pressed their case by taking refuge for nearly five years in the United States Embassy.

title: MANGIONE AND SOLOISTS
description: CHUCK MANGIONE'S concert Friday night managed to make amplified music sound perfectly balanced in Avery Fisher Hall - no small feat. Equally improbable was the fact that Mr. Mangione, a flugelhornist, was performing as part of the Kool Jazz Festival, since his widely popular music touches only marginally on jazz.

title: D'RIVERA HEADLINES LATIN BILL
description: AT Soundscape on Saturday, two bands showed just how open-ended ''Latin jazz'' can be. Paquito d'Rivera's Havana/New York is a geographically limited rubric for a group that played not only tunes based on the Cuban merengue and bolero, but a samba and straightahead hard bop as well. Mr. d'Rivera, an alto saxophonist, and the drummer Ignacio Berroa are native Cubans who live in New York.

title: HINSON'S A FAVORITE IN DRAFT
description: Everybody loves shot-blockers. Basketball fans cheer them and coaches often talk of their importance. With 146 blocked shots in 31 games at Rutgers University last season, the 6-foot-9-inch Roy Hinson was one of the premier shotblockers in college basketball. Tomorrow, in the National Basketball Association's annual player draft at the Felt Forum, he will learn what the pros think of his ability. Several pro scouts project him as a first-round selection.

title: Texans Plan Team For Merged Banks
description: As promised in an era of deregulation, the number of bank merger announcements around the country is increasing; the latest is the proposed combination of the Mercantile Texas Corporation of Dallas and Southwest Bancshares of Houston in an exchange of stock valued at $515 million.

title: NUDE SUNBATHING AT RIIS PARK IS BANNED BY NEW STATE LAW
description: Two little girls pressed their faces against the chain-link fence that divides Beach 149th Street in Neponsit, Queens, from Jacob Riis Park, in the Federal Gateway National Recreation Area.

title: DELAWARE MUSEUM SEEKS FUNDS TO SUPPORT A DU PONT LEGACY
description: Behind the wealth of blooms and exotic plants in a landscaped park, surrounded by riches of silverware, art and antiques, the directors of the Henry Francis du Pont Winterthur Museum are confronting the harsh reality of running a cultural institution in the 1980's.

title: MONDAY, JUNE 27, 1983; The Economy
description: Machine tool orders, a key industrial barometer, rose 14 percent in May from April and 28 percent from the 1982 level. However, the tool industry needs much larger gains to show a profit. (Page D1.)

title: Robert Fields, Actor, Marries Miss Robbins
description: The marriage of Betty-Jane Robbins, marketing director for trade books at Harcourt Brace Jovanovich in San Diego, to Robert Samuel Fields, an actor, took place at the Fairview Country Club in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday.

title: IN GANDHI'S FOOTSTEPS, POLITICIAN TREKS 2,700 MILES
description: Under a blistering summer sun, an opposition party leader trekked into the capital this weekend, ending a 2,700-mile walk across India that he called both an act of ''self-education and an effort to reach people at their level instead of preaching from New Delhi.''

title: NAKASONE PARTY TAKES BIG VOTE LEAD
description: The governing Liberal Democratic Party took a commanding lead in national elections Sunday, tightening its already considerable hold on Japan's upper house of Parliament.

title: Miss Okamoto Wins
description: Ayako Okamoto, who led the Rochester International from the start, dropped a 10-foot birdie putt on the third playoff hole today to capture the $30,000 first prize.

title: LEADING ARGENTINE COMPOSER
description: Alberto Ginastera, the Argentine composer, died Saturday in Geneva, Switzerland. He was 67 years old and, according to his wife who announced his death yesterday, had been in Geneva's Cantonal Hospital since May 4.

title: THE LATENT PERIL OF OLD PCB INSULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MIRIJUANA STORES DEFY ENFORCEMENT EFFORTS
description: From the front, it looks like any other food store on the East Side. But one day last week dozens of people stopped at the Belsam Grocery to buy something other than the food and kitchen goods that line its shelves.

title: Stars 31, Stallions 10
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - The Stars scored on four of their first five possessions for a 24-0 lead and limited the Stallions (8-9) to 2 yards and one first down in the first period. The Stars (15-2) will be host to an as-yet-undetermined opponent July 9 in the first round of the playoffs.

title: COCKERELL CAPTURES SKATING
description: Mark Cockerell used a spectacular long routine to win the men's figure skating championship at the National Sports Festival today.

title: Ship Blast Hurts 16 in Brazil
description: An engine-room explosion aboard a Brazilian oil tanker at sea injured 16 of 27 crew members and crippled the ship, port authorities said today.

title: WITH THE 'MOLE' JOKES, RISING ANXIETY
description: President Reagan's counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, tried humor the other day as he flew on Air Force One and faced questions about the advance debating information that Reagan partisans somehow obtained in 1980 from the camp of President Carter.

title: Ashe Searches Past
description: Get-well cards are nice, and flowers are even nicer, but if you really want to cheer up Arthur Ashe during his recuperation from last week's heart-bypass surgery, you might want to rummage through the attic to see if you have any old scrapbooks or letters telling of the exploits of obscure black athletes.

title: New Bioethics for a New Biology
description: Doctors have faced ethical problems since the time of Hippocrates, but biomedical research is raising fresh dilemmas at a fast clip. Recently a group of church leaders sought to anticipate one issue by demanding a ban on inheritable changes to the human gene set. How can problems of this genre best be addressed?

title: Missile Truths
description: To follow the arms control debate, just forget about the brawl over the testimony of Kenneth Adelman, the new head of the disarmament agency. His dutiful report that the MX missile would be bargained away only in the unlikely event that Moscow dismantled all its heavy missiles was neither news nor an Adelman opinion. As others have now made clear, he was conveying an agreed policy statement that combined two earlier declarations.

title: New Ads on Planes
description: Beginning July 11, some American Airlines planes that are equipped with television sets will offer the CBS ''Early Morning News'' on each flight all day long. The advertising that had run when the halfhour show was on the network will be erased and replaced by messages from advertisers who will pay $200,000 to run their minute's worth of advertising throughout the day for six months, with a promised audience of 670,000 a month. The airline will get a piece of the ad action.

title: Common Stock
description: * Aircal Inc. filed for an initial public offering of four million shares, through Blyth Eastman Paine Webber.

title: Kansan Urges Reagan Not to Rule Out Troops
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (Reuters) Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum urged President Reagan today to keep all his options open for preventing Communist takeovers in Central America, including sending American troops to the region.

title: MERCER ELLINGTON LEADS HIS FATHER'S '43 SUITE
description: WHEN Duke Ellington introduced his first major extended work, ''Black, Brown and Beige: A Tone Parallel to the History of the American Negro,'' at Carnegie Hall in January 1943, the critical response was less than enthusiastic. After two more performances in Boston in the same month, Mr. Ellington never performed the work in its entirety again, although several of its themes became a familiar part of his band's repertory.

title: JAZZ: 2 GUITARISTS, PETE COSEY AND JOHN SCOFIELD, AT PUBLIC
description: THE concert by Pete Cosey and John Scofield at the Public Theater on Saturday was not officially connected to the Kool Jazz Festival. But Mr. Cosey was the electric-guitar soloist in Miles Davis's band during the mid-1970's, and Mr. Scofield plays electric guitar with Mr. Davis's current band, which performed at the Kool Festival on Sunday.

title: Brewers 4, Indians 3
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Robin Yount's double brought home the tie-breaking run in the eighth inning, and Cecil Cooper hit two homers for Milwaukee.

title: RACKETEERING LAW'S FALLOUT
description: First the Godfather, and now Morgan Stanley. Morgan Stanley may not have been the target that Congress had in mind in 1970 when it passed a tough anti-racketeering law. But more and more private suits under the Racketeering Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act are directed at such blue-chip financial institutions as Arthur Andersen & Company, Shearson/American Express and Morgan Stanley Inc.

title: Wendy A. McKinley Is Married to Stephen Bander
description: At the Unitarian Meeting House in Hartford yesterday, Wendy Ann Mc-Kinley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Justus McKinley of Simsbury, Conn., and Reading, Vt., was married to Stephen Bander, son of Anna Minna Bander of Floral Park, Queens, and the late Arthur Bander. The Rev. Richard Miller performed the ceremony.

title: WALKER'S BACKUP PROVES ABLE
description: The cornea of Herschel Walker's right eyeball was superficially scratched while he was being tackled in the seventh minute of Saturday night's game between the Generals and the Arizona Wranglers, a contest won by New Jersey, 21-14.

title: LOUGANIS TRIUMPHS IN PLATFORM DIVING
description: The nation's best male diver made a distinct contrast to the nation's two best male swimmers this weekend, when the three athletes voiced their reactions to the pressure of being top contenders for Olympic medals next summer in Los Angeles.

title: BELL SYSTEM AND 3 UNIONS SEEK NEW ACCORDS
description: A complicated search for new labor contracts between the Bell System and three unions representing 650,000 telecommunication workers is going on here as the two sides move through another round of exploratory talks.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Circle for a Jazz Great

title: TV: 'GREAT PERFORMANCES' PRESENTS SPOLETO U.S.A.
description: EVEN public television's ''Great Performances,'' one of the more dependable series for outstanding drama and music performances, isn't immune to the infectious ennui of summer. The offering tonight at 9 o'clock is something called ''Festival!'' which turns out to be an hourlong glossy commercial for Gian Carlo Menotti and his Spoleto U.S.A.

title: TV: VIEW OF RULES ON WAGES
description: The political consensus today upholds the notion that the minimumwage law is social legislation as much as it is economic. Wipe out the minimum wage, the argument goes, and the poor will grow poorer; a divided society will become more divided. The notion, however, is being challenged by some economists, who insist that the minimum-wage law discriminates against the poor, particularly poor blacks.

title: Ann Marcus and a Teacher Are Married on Fire Island
description: Ann Nash Marcus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence N. Marcus of Brooklyn Heights and Saltaire, Fire Island, was married in Saltaire yesterday to Philip Saul Golub, son of Albert Golub of Orlando, Fla., formerly of Brooklyn, and the late Florence Golub.

title: Stabler Signs
description: Kenny Stabler has signed a new contract as quarterback with the New Orleans Saints, Greg Suit, a team spokesman said today.

title: POP: ROBERT PALMER SINGS
description: THE British singer Robert Palmer has finally found a balance between his tastes and his talents. For years, Mr. Palmer's songs have delved into American and Caribbean dance music while he has come across as a suave crooner, an unconvincing mixture of hot rhythms and cool delivery.

title: Jean Grumet Wed To Fellow Lawyer
description: Jean Grumet, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Samuel C. Grumet of the Bronx, was married in New York yesterday to Seth Kupferberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kupferberg of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Melanie Aron performed the ceremony at the Spanish Institute.

title: EMOTIONAL EFFECTS OF NATURAL DISASTERS
description: Natural disasters strike suddenly and leave behind lives shattered by physical injury or the loss of home and job. At the time that flood waters rise over riverbanks, as they have done recently in several Western states, or when an earthquake shatters a community, as one did last month in Coalinga, Calif., there is little time at first to pay attention to the survivors' feelings. Emotional pain is usually hidden at the outset, but it often lingers, to emerge long after the debris has been cleared away.

title: THE PRIMARY SPECIES: CALL THEM DARWINNERS
description: Lord Mancroft once remarked that the British, not being a religious people, invented cricket to give themselves a sense of eternity. We Americans created the Presidential primary for the same purpose.

title: Kathleen Ash Is Married
description: Kathleen Louise Ash, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Merriam Ash 3d of Allamuchy, N.J., was married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church in Hackettstown, N.J., to John Richard Lange, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Lange of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. George H. Brant performed the ceremony.

title: Man-Killing Grizzly Trapped, Put to Death
description: A large male bear was put to death today Officials had identified it as the grizzly that killed a camper after dragging the man screaming from a tent.

title: Plainer Talk About Cigarettes
description: The proposed new health warning on cigarette packages, as endorsed by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, is commendably accurate and blunt. ''Warning:'' it reads, ''Cigarette Smoking Causes Cancer, Emphysema and Heart Diseases; May Complicate Pregnancy And is Addictive.''

title: AUSTRALIAN CARDINAL WAS VATICAN ENVOY
description: James Robert Cardinal Knox, a senior Vatican administrator and diplomat, died today in a hospital here. He was 69 years old and suffered a stroke last month.

title: Dolphin Linebacker Dies
description: Larry Gordon, a starting linebacker for the Miami Dolphins, died while jogging in the desert near here Saturday night. He was suffering from a heart disease known as ideopathic cardial myopathy, according to the Maricopa County medical examiner's office.

title: NEC Information Moving to Ingalls
description: NEC Information Systems, a Massachusetts-based subsidiary of the Japanese computer company, Nippon Electric, has assigned its advertising to Ingalls Associates in Boston, promising a budget in the ''mid-seven figures.'' The previous agency was the Strayton Corporation in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Free-Piston Engine Debated
description: A West German inventor has developed an internal combustion engine with one moving part that, he says, consumes about 30 percent less gasoline than conventional motors and can be made for a fraction of the cost.

title: RALLIES BY RED SOX SINK YANKEES, 12-5
description: In case the Yankees thought they were ready to make their move, let them study today's 12-5 loss to the Boston Red Sox. The Yankees, who had won seven of their previous nine games leading to the week before the All-Star break, embarrassed themselves.

title: Fisher-Price Cuts Video Game Role
description: Fisher-Price Toys has cut short its expansion into video games, R. Bruce Sampsell, its president, said. In the last four months, the division of the Quaker Oats Company has liquidated the U.S. Games Corporation, a video cartridge maker it acquired last year, and sold its interest in a Mexican toy company, he said.

title: DAVIS BID FOR NO-HITTER FOILED
description: It didn't surprise Storm Davis of the Baltimore Orioles that Rick Leach of the Detroit Tigers spoiled his no-hitter with a leadoff pinch homer in the ninth inning.

title: CANADIAN JUDGE WEIGHS KEY DIOXIN CASE
description: A lawyer for the plaintiffs, in his final argument, called the trial a World Series of scientific dispute, saying he felt he was in the batter's box in the ninth inning of the seventh game with the bases loaded. ''No matter what happens as a result of this hearing, the record will stand for all time,'' Richard Murtha declared.

title: Michele Solomon, Teacher, Marries a Realty Executive
description: Michele B. Solomon, daughter of Shirley Korostoff of Brooklyn and the late Sol Korostoff, was married yesterday to Paul Portnof, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Portnof of Lawrence, L.I. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony at the Lawrence Country Club.

title: NORTHWEST'S POWER TANGLE
description: A default later this year by the nation's biggest borrower in the tax-exempt bond sector became more likely when the Washington State Supreme Court ruled this month that the state's utilities were not obligated to repay the $2.25 billion raised by the Washington Public Power Supply System to construct two now-abandoned nuclear power plants.

title: Egypt Raises Its Oil Prices
description: Egypt has raised the price of its Gulf of Suez crude oil by 50 cents a barrel, to $28.25, with 60 days' credit, effective July 1, according to oil trade sources.

title: Crayola to Needham
description: Needham, Harper & Steers/New York has become the agency for all of the Crayola products produced by Binney & Smith. Now that may not be as big a story as the acquisition of McCaffrey & McCall by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi for $10 million, as reported on Saturday, but it's not too bad for a sunny summer weekend. The Crayola account, with an ad budget in excess of $3 million, was previously at Creamer Inc., which acquired it when it acquired James Neal Harvey Inc., whose Crayola relationship went back to 1976.

title: HOMOSEXUALS' PARADE DEDICATED TO AIDS VICTIMS
description: With band music and banners, homosexuals and their supporters marched yesterday from Central Park West to Washington Square in Greenwich Village. The Lesbian and Gay Pride March, the 14th annual such parade, was dedicated to the victims of AIDS.

title: OUTDOORS: CANOEING MADE EASIER
description: COLD SPRING, N.Y. ARRANGED about the lawn of the Dockside Inn with the majestic Hudson just beyond, dozens of sleek canoes, nearly all built of materials developed since World War II, glistened in the sun.

title: Challenge 12 Wins in Trials
description: The Australian 12-Meter yacht Challenge 12 today defeated Australia II, ending her winning streak of 10 races in the opening round of trials to select the America's Cup challenger.

title: INVESTOR-OWNED UTILITIES LED ASTRAY BY THE REGULATORY PROCESS
description: To the Editor:

title: TO HELP THE ECONOMY, INVEST IN PUBLIC WORKS
description: Almost everyone believes that substantial new investment in industry is the only sure road to economic recovery, both at home and abroad. But this assessment overlooks the fact that private industry -operating in a world economy that is glutted with industrial capacity -lacks good markets in which to invest. Our economy is characterized by overinvestment in unneeded and duplicative industrial projects, and underinvestment in public works - bridges, roads, transportation, environmental and water systems, which constitute the infrastructure.

title: Davis Excels In 200
description: Clinton Davis ran the second fastest 200 meters by a schoolboy when he won the event today in a meet record 20.29 seconds at the United States National Junior track and field championships at Penn State.

title: SOME RICH TOWNS BEING WALLED OFF
description: After several years of debate, the City Council here approved a plan two weeks ago that would eventually turn this tiny suburb of Palm Springs into California's fourth walled city.

title: UNDERWRITINGS SURGE IN NUMBER AND IN SIZE
description: Corporate underwritings for the first five months of 1983 reached $49.6 billion, more than double the amount in the period a year before, according to Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm. The number of underwriting deals more than tripled, to 798, between January and May; a year ago, there were 263 deals, which raised $20.9 billion.

title: 8 SEIZED IN BRONX GOLD ROBBERY
description: Eight men were arrested by F.B.I. agents Saturday night and charged with the interstate transportation of $1.5 million in gold that the eight took from a Bronx jewelry manufacturer earlier in the day while bureau agents watched, according to the F.B.I.

title: Shoshana Rosenfeld Marries Classicist
description: Shoshana Shira Rosenfeld, daughter of Dr. Hadassah T. Brooks and Norman Rosenfeld, both of New York, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Simon David Goldhill, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Goldhill of London. Rabbi Pinchas M. Teitz, grandfather of the bride, and Rabbi Nisson Shulman officiated at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

title: ALVARADO TO CLOSE A CITY HIGH SCHOOL
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, plans to close one high school and turn three others into centers for specialized training, according to officials at the Board of Education.

title: Ferment In France
description: This year's key election campaigns are completed now, in Germany, Britain, Italy and Japan, leaving the West a breathing space of political stability until the U.S. vote in 1984.

title: FIRE IN PATERSON RUINS FACTORIES IN HISTORIC AREA
description: The nation's first historic industrial district, a collection of brick and stone mills and factories along the Passaic River's Great Falls dating back a century and a half, was largely destroyed by fire this weekend.

title: PETE ROSE TALKING .300
description: IN the dugout at Shea Stadium yesterday, Pete Rose was informed that Gaylord Perry had been released by the Seattle Mariners. ''How many wins did he have?'' Pete Rose asked.

title: TENNIS STRUGGLES WITH AN UNCOURTLY IMAGE
description: WIMBLEDON, England TENNIS'S struggle to enforce its code of conduct on the court is causing bitterness and division between the players and the establishment, and even among the players themselves.

title: People
description: * F. Kent Mitchel of General Foods is the new chairman of the Advertising Council.

title: Conference in Czechoslovakia Denounces U.S. Missile Plan
description: A Communist-backed antinuclear conference ended today with a statement that said the world was on the ''abyss of nuclear war'' and denounced a United States plan to deploy new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: TWO JEWEL BOX HITS OF LONDON'S FRINGE THEATER'S
description: As the New York theater often depends on Off Broadway for its new ideas and even for its commercial hits, so the London theater increasingly relies on the scattered playhouses that make up the fringe. And just as an English visitor to New York might be startled to discover that last season's notable Off Broadway plays included Britain's ''Plenty,'' ''Top Girls,'' ''Fen'' and ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' so an American in London is bemused to find that the current fringe favorites include our own ''Crimes of the Heart'' and ''The Dining Room.''

title: IN PEAPACK, MOROCCAN FANTASY BENEFITS CHANNEL 13
description: Fox hunting is out of season here. The baying of the hounds will not be heard for another month. But the narrow lanes, split-rail fences and easy rolling hills have not been deserted.

title: STEADYING OF GASOLINE PRICES SEEN
description: Retail gasoline prices edged up less than half a cent a gallon in the last two weeks, indicating that the peak summer price may have been reached, The Lundberg Letter said today.

title: THE DANCE: 'SWAN LAC' OFFERED BY ANDREW DE GROAT
description: IT was a great pity that Andrew deGroat happened through New York on such short notice and at such a busy time in dance. Mr. deGroat is now working in Europe, where he has just created a well-received piece for the Paris Opera Ballet. He is one of the most interesting modern-dance choreographers of his generation. His performers tend to be exceptional. And his ''Swan Lac,'' performed Saturday at St. Mark's Church, was a brilliant and very funny new look at an old classic, and certainly one of the most memorable new dances of the New York season.

title: Rangers 4, A's 1
description: Danny Darwin (6-6) pitched a three-hitter and Billy Sample drove in two runs with a checked-swing single as Texas won its sixth straight and completed a four-game sweep of Oakland.

title: Market Place; Some Groups Show Strength
description: THE Wall Street adage, ''It's not a stock market but a market of stocks,'' was borne out last week. While the Dow Jones industrial average remained virtually unchanged at 1,241.69, off 0.50 point, some stocks were kicking up their heels.

title: SALES OF MOVIE CASSETTES FOR HOME USE RISING
description: Nowadays a night at the movies can be had cut-rate at home on tape, and more and more people are choosing to spend their evenings that way. As a result, the distribution and revenue patterns of movies throughout the world have begun to change.

title: Musyoki Retains Cascade Title
description: Michael Musyoki of Kenya defended his Cascade Run Off title today in world record time for the 15-kilometer road race.

title: Michele Kaplan Is a Bride
description: Michele Amy Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Solte Kaplan of New York, was married yesterday to Ira Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris L. Green of New York. Rabbi Jacob J. Schachter and Rabbi Emeritus Leo Jung of the Jewish Center in New York performed the ceremony at the Congregation Ahavath Torah in Englewood, N.J. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Kaplan & Pellegrini. Mr. Green's father is a partner in the New York law firm of Green, Sigall & Zich.

title: FINDING A NAME THAT SUITS
description: ''And what,'' he said in his most courtly manner, ''would you like us to call you?'' ''I would like you to treat me as my own children do,'' Gussie Gold replied with graciousness equal to his own. ''I would like to think of you all as my very own children. Please call me Mother.''

title: The Pope In Retreat
description: Washington, June 25 - Pope John Paul II has surprised and disappointed Lech Walesa, arrogated to himself the spirit of Polish nationalism, and apparently cut a deal with General Jaruzelski to guarantee the Vatican's opposition to any uprising in return for an end to martial law.

title: FOCUS REMAINS ON FED POLICY
description: The credit market continues to focus on trying to judge the Federal Reserve's policies. Some analysts contend that the recent rise in the Federal funds rate -the cost of overnight loans among banks - is an indication that the Fed has tightened the availability of credit. They point to an increase in this rate over the past week, from 8.84 percent to 9.14 percent, as a sign that the Fed wants higher short-term interest rates over all.

title: POLICE TERM DRUNKEN-DRIVER CRACKDOWN A SUCCESS
description: Police Officer Joseph Reitano has arrested six people since he was assigned in May to the Police Department's new program to combat drunken driving. None was more intoxicated, he said, than a driver he stopped at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll plaza in Staten Island.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Singular Letter

title: TO LET THE HANDICAPPED GET TO THE SUBWAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine Bonds Tentatively Priced
description: A Maine State Housing Authority bond issue totaling $20.6 million was tentatively priced by Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group to yield between 5 1/4 percent and 9 7/8 percent.

title: Press Group Protests Law Planned in Turkey
description: The International Press Institute, representing nearly 2,000 editors and publishers around the world, has protested a press law being prepared by the military Government of Turkey, saying the matter should be left to the government formed after the election promised for November.

title: POPE IS SAID TO HINT END TO MARTIAL LAW IF SOLIDARITY YIELDS
description: Sources close to Lech Walesa, the former Solidarity leader, said today that Pope John Paul II told him in their private meeting Thursday that martial law could be lifted in September if the banned union stopped protesting in the streets.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JUNE 28, 1983
description: International Italy's Christian Democrats suffered a sharp setback in general elections but apparently remained the nation's largest party. The Communists remained in second place, but were much closer to the Christian Democrats than before. The Christian Democrats have dominated all 43 Italian Cabinets since the end of World War II. (Page A1, Column 3.) A major increase in Iraq's firepower was reported by State Department officials. They said France had agreed to lend Baghdad five of its Super Etenard fighter-bombers capable of firing Exocet missiles. Super Etendards armed with Exocets enabled Argentine forces to sink two British ships in the Falklands war last year. (A1:1-2.)

title: FRENCH AGREE TO LEND IRAQ PLANES TO USE IN FIRING ITS EXOCET MISSILES
description: France has agreed to lend Iraq five of its Super Etendard fighter-bombers capable of firing Exocet missiles, State Department officials said today.

title: STAGE: 'THAT'S IT, FOLKS!'
description: IT'S the cheery message of the writer Mark O'Donnell that if the world comes to an end, it's not necessarily the end of the world. Mr. O'Donnell's play at Playwrights Horizons' upstairs Studio Theater, ''That's It, Folks!'' is a Looney Tunes vision of the apocalypse. Set on ''the last day on earth'' (Scene 1) and ''the same, later that evening'' (Scene 2), this brief farce makes good on its promise: a meteor shower and a plague of locusts, among other catastrophes, reduce the Earth to rubble.

title: SUPREME COURT TO TRY AGAIN AT RESOLVING EVIDENCE ISSUE
description: The Supreme Court, less than a month after its apology for failing to decide whether to modify the rule against admitting illegally seized evidence at trials, announced today that it would try again next year.

title: Common Stock
description: * American Express Co. said that First Data Resources Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary, expects to make a public offering of about 25 percent of its common stock.

title: 2 Scientists in Soviet Report Hunger Strike Over Exit Visa
description: Two Soviet scientists barred from leaving their country to attend an international physics conference that opened today in Greece said they would go on a hunger strike along with two of their colleagues in the Soviet Union, conference officials said.

title: Ford Cuts Rates
description: The Ford Motor Company lowered the interest rate on its financing for purchasers of EXP and LN7 models to 8.6 percent, from 8.8 percent, to undercut the Chrysler Corporation's 8.7 percent incentive program, a company spokesman said.

title: Change of View
description: One of the excercises Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini does to stay in shape while he recuperates from a broken collarbone is to pedal a stationary bicycle.

title: SWIMMING AS ONE TOWARD OLYMPICS
description: Mix one package unflavored gelatin with water. Spread evenly on hair, making sure to coat every strand. ''It's really kind of gross, but it does the job,'' said Tracie Ruiz. Apply blusher to cheeks, add two swabs of eye shadow and mascara. ''Definitely more makeup than your mother would approve of,'' said Candy Costie. Pin hair ornament in place, pull up swimsuit, secure noseclips and practice smile. ''And on top of doing all this, we've got to be in shape to compete,'' said Miss Costie. Compete? Or perform? ''That, too,'' said Miss Ruiz. Candy Costie and Tracie Ruiz are the number one duet on the United States Synchronized Swimming team, which ended its Senior National Championships here tonight. The sport has been compared to gymastics and figure skating and evokes countless comments about Esther Williams backstroking in the old M-G-M movies.

title: HOT PEPPER AND PAIN
description: FOR centuries, extracts of hot peppers have been known as potent folk remedies for toothache and some other types of pain even though there seemed to be little logic and less science to explain why. Now, as it has in other cases in the past, science has come to the defense of folk medicine.

title: INQUEST JURY UNDECIDED ON CALVI
description: A jury today returned an open verdict at the second inquest into the death last year of Roberto Calvi, the 61-year-old president of the bankrupt Banco Ambrosiano, once Italy's largest privately owned banking group.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HOMAGE TO A BRIDGE

title: The U.N. Today; June 28, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: TURBO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a $5.7 million writedown of the company's U.S. oil & gas properties which are not part of the Bankeno Group and interest expense of $24 lion.

title: Article 260978 -- No Title
description: National Public Radio, which last week projected a $9.1 million deficit for the current fiscal year, would receive a loan in that amount from the federally financed Corporation for Public Broadcating under terms of a plan worked out over the weekend and announced here today.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: A $110 million single-family mortgage revenue bond issue from the Ohio Housing Finance Agency was tentatively priced yesterday by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb to yield between 6 percent and 10 percent.

title: A Saudi Princess Gets a New Kidney
description: Princess Sultana of Saudi Arabia was reported doing ''very well'' today after undergoing a kidney transplant over the weekend, a spokesman for the royal family said.

title: Kostoff, Miss Richardson Win 3d Events
description: Jeff Kostoff, considered to be the chief American threat to challenge Vladimir Salnikov, the star from the Soviet Union, at the Los Angeles Olympics next year, joined Michelle Richardson tonight as the only triple winners of individual swimming events at the fifth National Sports Festival.

title: Imasco Ends Offer For Canadian Tire
description: Imasco Ltd., the Montreal-based tobacco, retailing and fast food group, decided to withdraw its proposed $1.11 billion (Canadian) cash and paper tender offer for the Torontobased hardware retailer, the Canadian Tire Company.

title: FORMER E.P.A. AIDES RECEIVE $240 A DAY AS U.S. CONSULTANTS
description: As a result of the controversy over the Environmental Protection Agency, seven of 21 political appointees left their jobs. But they did not leave the agency.

title: ANDERSON MAKES BID FOR NORTON
description: The bidding for Norton Simon Inc. heated up yesterday when Anderson, Clayton & Company, a Houston-based producer of foods, made an offer for the consumer products company.

title: MYSTERIOUS LOON DEATHS
description: THE mysterious death of more than 2,000 common loons along Florida's Gulf Coast last spring is puzzling wildlife scientists who have been trying to determine the cause of the fatalities.

title: ARE TWO DISK DRIVES ALWAYS PREFERABLE?
description: THE two-car family is nearly established as a standard in our culture, as are the two-bathroom and the two-television-set homes. The new cooking ranges have two ovens, and most sinks are double. This twofer consumerism may well be a minor indication of temporary market saturation. After all, the necessity of such duality is, in most cases, doubtful. They are convenient, yet, but how often are they really necessary?

title: International Borrowing
description: Total international borrowing in 1983 is likely to fall to between $145 billion and $155 billion, down from $170.5 billion in 1982, as a result of unsettled market conditions, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development said today.

title: New Inquiry on Killings Ordered in Puerto Rico
description: Secretary of Justice Hector Reichard said today he had ordered a new inquiry into the 1978 police killings of two independence activists.

title: India Police Kill 2 in Punjab
description: The police opened fire today on clashing Sikhs and Hindus in Punjab state, killing 2 people and wounding 6. Officials said street fighting between the groups erupted when Hindus gathered for a march through Jullundur and shut their shops in a statewide strike demanding an end to Sikh protests. Sikhs, are demanding autonomy for the northwestern state.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Two friends of mine were swept away by a ''seiche'' on Lake Michigan while standing on a wharf one evening. Their bodies were never recovered. I had never heard of a seiche before. What is it?

title: BEIRUT HOLDS 8 IN U.S. ENVOYS' KILLING
description: Eight people - all Lebanese leftists and Palestinians - have been arrested and charged with the abduction and murder in 1976 of the United States Ambassador, Francis E. Meloy, his economic counselor, Robert O. Waring, and their Lebanese driver, sources at the military prosecutor's office reported today.

title: HAITIAN PAUSED TO GIVE AID AND LOST ON A POINT OF LAW
description: A young Haitian refugee who stayed on a United States beach to help fellow victims of a shipwreck instead of fleeing may now be deported for doing what he thought was right, his lawyer says.

title: Turnstile Justice: The Breakdown of Criminal Court Second of four articles.
description: To a judge, New York City's Criminal Court is an endless crush of cases that rarely allows time for compassion or careful consideration of complex human issues. To a defense lawyer from the Legal Aid Society who has been on the job nine months and has yet to try a case, the court is a daily exercise in frustration.

title: STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Rain Interrupts U.S.F.L. Game
description: A rainstorm, accompanied by gusting winds, thunder and lightning, caused the United States Football League game between the Denver Gold and Tampa Bay Bandits tonight to be held up for 50 minutes in the fourth quarter.

title: WEAVER REMAINS AN OLD ORIOLE
description: F or the first time since 1968, the Baltimore Orioles were in Yankee Stadium last night without Earl Weaver strutting around as their manager. He wasn't even strutting around the Monday night TV booth. Since he remains under contract to the Orioles as a special scout and consultant, the ABC network considers it a conflict of interest for him to sit in judgment on Oriole games.

title: CHEFS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to May 1.
DIXICO INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $112,000. c-Net loss including income of $196,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Mountain-Climbing Fossils
description: Dr. Peter N. Webb of Ohio State University examining specimens collected 18 years ago at elevations above 7,000 feet in the mountains of Antarctica, has discovered that many of them are the remains of creatures that lived in the sea as recently as 2 million to 70 million years ago.

title: THE MUFTI CALLS FOR ASSAD'S DEATH
description: The top Moslem leader in Jerusalem, Sheik Saad el-Din el-Alami, has issued a religious dispensation for any Moslem who assassinates President Hafez al-Assad of Syria.

title: HUNTERS NEED NO EXTRA 12 MILLION ALASKAN ACRES
description: To the Editor:

title: MILES DAVIS AT AVERY FISHER HALL
description: MILES DAVIS seemed to be having a good time at the second of his two jazz festival shows Sunday night. He repeatedly smiled and blew kisses to the enthusiastic audience at Avery Fisher Hall, and he walked out to the front of the stage to deliver his trumpet improvisations. But when he wasn't soloing, the music failed to justify his high spirits.

title: ALVARADO, IN TESTIMONY, WARNS OF ELITIST SCHOOLS
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor said yesterday that in its sudden focus on educational excellence, the country runs the risk of developing ''a system that becomes elitist'' and hurts some of the very students that educators are supposed to help.

title: REAGAN ASKS INQUIRY INTO PAPERS REPORTEDLY PURLOINED FROM CARTER
description: President Reagan, indicating increased concern about the debate material that his aides secretly obtained from the 1980 campaign of President Carter, asked the Justice Department today to conduct a ''vigorous monitoring'' of the incident for evidence of illegality.

title: Race Car Driver Held in Shooting
description: The race car driver John Paul Sr. surrendered to the police today to face charges of attempted first-degree murder, St. Johns County sheriff's officials said.

title: JAPAN'S RULING PARTY WINS BUT WITHOUT LANDSLIDE
description: Although Japan's long-governing conservatives strengthened their parliamentary majority in Sunday's upper-house election, final totals tonight showed them falling short of the landslide victory that many had forecast.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: A $400 million mortgage-backed security offer by the Federal National Mortgage Association was priced yesterday to yield 12.45 percent.

title: Chacon Loses Title
description: Bobby Chacon has been stripped of his superfeatherweight title by the World Boxing Council, Jose Sulaiman, the council's president, said yesterday in Los Angeles. Sulaiman said that Chacon had violated ''at least nine'' W.B.C. rules, most of them relating to timely defense of his title.

title: BRIEFING
description: Welcoming Wayne Newton

title: BURNETT & HALLAMSHIRE (BRIT CO) reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: Revenue figures represent billings.

title: THE PEOPLE'S RIGHT IN PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: The year-earlier results were restated.

title: Grey Advertising Unit
description: Grey Advertising has set up a new subsidiary, Grey Strategic Marketing, which is prepared to consult agency clients worldwide. Its president is Shirley Young, who has been executive vice president for market planning for the agency.

title: HAITIANS, SEEKING FREEDOM AND JOBS, FIND HEARTACHES INSTEAD IN AMERICA
description: Romer St. Gilles and his wife Lillian looked puzzled and weary Just above a mumble, the two Haitian refugees were describing how their search for freedom and work in America became a hell of sorts.

title: BACHE PROPOSES BANK ALLIANCE
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., one of the nation's largest securities firms, proposed yesterday that it form an alliance with its bitterest rivals, the nation's commercial banks.

title: 56 Suffer Food Poisoning
description: Fifty-six cases of suspected food poisoning were treated at the Naval Education and Training Center over the last four days, the Navy said today. A public information officer, Frank Pritchard, said contaminated dairy products were the suspected cause of diarrhea, vomiting and dehydration. He said none of the cases were serious.

title: U.S. FEARS ONE BOMB COULD CRIPPLE THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON TECHNICAL experts in and out of government are concerned that the highly computerized economy of the United States could be brought to a crippling halt by the electrical effects of the explosion of a single nuclear weapon a few hundred miles over the center of the nation.

title: TV Networks to Cover Reagan News Session
description: President Reagan's news conference will be televised at 8 P.M., Eastern daylight time, on the CBS, NBC and ABC News networks; on CNN, the Cable News Network, and on SNC, the Satellite News Channel.

title: COURT LETS STATES TAX COMPANIES ON PORTION OF WORLDWIDE INCOME
description: The Supreme Court today handed a major victory to state tax authorities, ruling 5 to 3 that states may include the worldwide income of American-based multinational corporations in calculating state tax liability.

title: BILL LETS LIFE INSURERS USE FUTURES TO HEDGE
description: A little-noticed bill that Governor Cuomo is expected to sign soon would allow life insurance companies for the first time to hedge their investments and loans in the futures markets.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Brooklyn Sesquicentennial

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: ON the first day of summer Kenneth J. Lane, the jewelry designer, g ave a lunch at his Park Avenue apartment. Among those sitting at ther ound table in his red dining room were Fred Hayman, the owner of G iorgio's on Rodeo Drive; Hiro, the photographer; D.D. Ryan, one of H alston's right arms who wears black night and day; Fred Hughes, p resident of Interview magazine, and Nan Kempner.

title: SENATE TRADITION, MONDAY ABSENTEES
description: It was, Senator Orrin G. Hatch was saying this afternoon, one of the most important moments of this session of Congress, the first time that the merits of a Constitutional amendment on abortion had been debated in the Senate.

title: Rise Forecast In Car Output
description: United States car production during this model year is likely to be 9.5 percent above the level of a year ago, the first gain since the 1979 model year, according to an auto trade journal.

title: Chess:; Two Finish Tied for First In the Cuba Championship
description: The grandmaster Guillermo Garcia and the international master Reynaldo Vera tied for first place in the Cuban Championship in Sagua de Tanamo. Each scored 7 1/2-3 1/2 in the 12-player round-robin tournament.

title: Nation's Air Conditioning Bill Is One-Third Lower This Year
description: As a result of cool weather over much of the country this year, Americans have spent nearly one-third less than normal to cool their homes so far this year, Government weather experts said today.

title: Two Magazines Sold
description: Morgan-Grampian, the publishing company, has sold Industrial Distribution and Contractor magazines to the Technical Publishing Company, part of Dun & Bradstreet.

title: BEFORE WE START TALKING OF TALKING TREES
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAD POISONING: AN INSIDIOUS FOE IN ROMAN TIMES AND TODAY
description: To the Editor:

title: TO SEARCH FOR A BOSON
description: To the Editor:

title: CHANGING WOMEN'S NAMES
description: A New York City woman who is divorced and who earns more than $30,000 a year was recently rejected by a department store when she applied for credit under her maiden name. The store said it was sorry but it could not issue a credit card because it had no indication whether she paid her bills.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Dynastic Merger

title: CUBA OFFERS TALKS ON RETURN OF 'UNDESIRABLES'
description: Cuba has informed the United States that it is willing to discuss the return of some of the Cubans who came to this country illegally in 1980, but only as part of overall negotiations on ''normalization of migration'' between the two countries, Administration officials said today.

title: TENNECO ORDERED TO BUY GAS IN 'HIGH-COST' PACT
description: The Superior Oil Company has won a preliminary injunction that requires the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Company to abide by the terms of contracts it signed to purchase high-priced gas when supplies were tight.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid May 31.

title: Bridge: An Important Rule Helps In Making Right Discard
description: Discarding is one of the most difficult areas of the game, but there is one golden rule: With a significant holding in a suit held by the declaring side, try to keep matching length.

title: 104th Test of Cruise Missile
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile fired from a submarine hit a target ship nearly 100 miles down the Pacific Missile Test Range today, the Air Force said.

title: A Signature Away
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, undisputed world middleweight champion, has agreed to defend his title against Roberto Duran the first week in November, the promoter Bob Arum said last night. ''Everything has been agreed,'' Arum said.

title: SPYRO GYRA AND STEPS AHEAD
description: BECAUSE its members are young and its music is aggressive and tuneful, Spyro Gyra, the popular jazz-rock septet, attracts a largely rock audience, which responds to any kind of musical exhibitionism with appreciative wolf whistles. And at the first of two Avery Fisher Hall concerts in the jazz festival on Saturday, the group performed a splashy, eclectic set, which blended elements of swing, Latin music, synthesizer pop and jazz fusion.

title: MRS. KING IN A FAMILIAR SPOT
description: Billie Jean King says she is not thinking about a final match with Martina Navratilova on Saturday. But she admits that she thought about being in the final round of Wimbledon while she was enduring the hard weeks of training several months ago.

title: NATALIE SWAN RAHV
description: Natalie Swan Rahv, an architect who practiced in New York City and Boston, died Saturday at Massachusetts Rehabilitation Hospital in Boston. She was 70 years old and lived in Danvers, Mass.

title: AFFIRMING AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: EXTREMISTS AND bigots must be gloating over the wedge increasingly separating traditional allies in the civil rights community. First, there was the acrimonious debate over affirmative action; now, there are the quarrelsome differences arising from President Reagan's assault on the Civil Rights Commission's independence.

title: CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for qtr to June 19.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $4.9 million from the exchange of debt for equity.

title: Seafirst Dissidents Limit Vote Goal
description: Opponents of the merger between the Seafirst Corporation and the BankAmerica Corporation say they probably do not have the shareholder votes to stop it outright at a meeting scheduled for Tuesday, but they may have enough support to force BankAmerica to take another look at the proposal.

title: Hughes Satellite
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company's subsidiary, Hughes Communications Galaxy Inc., said is planning to launch its first commercial communications satellite, Galaxy One, to transmit cable programming by Home Box Office Inc., Group W Broadcasting and Cable, Times Mirror Satellite Programming, Viacom International, the Turner Broadcasting System and others. The company declined to discuss the cost of the project, but trade publications have put it at $100 million.

title: People
description: * Diane Hall and James R. Hill have named partners at Tatham-Laird & Kudner Advertising, Chicago.

title: JAILED BURGLAR SEIZED IN MURDER OF OWNER OF A CIGARETTE STORE
description: A 34-year-old man in jail on a burglary conviction was charged yesterday with the murder of a cigarette store owner on the Upper West Side last month.

title: A SLEEPY CAIRO WAKENS TO A SUDDEN RAMADAN
description: Ola Leheta awakened early three Saturdays ago and, as is her custom, brewed a pot of strong tea. Savoring its aroma, she was about to take the first sip when the telephone rang.

title: 15 IN SOVIET DISSIDENT FAMILY, CLUTCHING BIBLES, FLY TO VIENNA
description: A family of 15 Pentecostalists arrived today from the Soviet Union on the first stop of a journey that took them 23 years to arrange. Their arrival, on the way to Israel, came five years after five members of the family rushed into the American Embassy in Moscow to seek asylum, slipping by Soviet policemen on the sidewalk.

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES SHOREHAM RATE BILL
description: Despite a threatened veto by Governor Cuomo, the State Assembly today passed legislation designed to spread the cost of the $3.2 billion Shoreham nuclear plant over a 10-year period in the electricity bills of Long Island residents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Staying the Course

title: Ocean Spray Reassigns Some of its Business
description: Ocean Spray Cranberries, the cooperative based in Plymouth, Mass., has reassigned a number of its advertising chores, dropping one agency and adding two.

title: Official Leaves F.D.I.C.  To Head Goldome Unit
description: Goldome, the big Buffalo-based savings bank, has chosen, from the ranks of Washington bank regulators, a new president for a recently acquired Florida subsidiary.

title: ITALIAN ELECTIONS DEAL BIG SETBACK TO LEADING PARTY
description: The Christian Democrats, who have dominated Italian political life since the end of World War II, suffered a sharp setback in general elections Sunday and today but apparently remained the nation's largest party.

title: NEW YORK CONCEDES IN SUBWAY 'TOKEN WAR'
description: Connecticut officials say they never altered the 10 million highway tokens that work on New York subways - six months after promising to do so.

title: PANEL OF SCIENTISTS BIDS U.S. ACT NOW TO CURB ACID RAIN
description: A report from a panel of scientists prepared for the White House Science Office concludes that action should be taken immediately to curb acid rain, despite continuing uncertainty.

title: LIBYAN ENVOY SAYS HE WILL IGNORE RESTRICTION ON USE OF JERSEY HOME
description: The chief Libyan delegate to the United Nations said yesterday that he would ignore restrictions imposed by the State Department on the use of his summer residence in Englewood, N.J. State Department officials responded by saying they would consider expelling him from the United States if he did.

title: Image and Reality
description: Joe Antenora, the commissioner of the Professional Bowlers Association, said that his organization's rules on beards, mustaches and hair length ''sound archaic to someone on the outside.'' It must sound that way closer to home, also.

title: Mrs. Reagan Visits Mother
description: Nancy Reagan traveled to Phoenix, Ariz., today to visit her mother, the First Lady's press office announced. Mrs. Reagan's recently widowed mother, Edith Luckett Davis, lives in an apartment in Phoenix and is confined to a wheelchair.

title: ACCORD IN ALBANY TO PUT BOND PLAN ON BALLOT IN STATE
description: Governor Cuomo reached an agreement with legislative leaders late Monday night to offer the voters a $1.25 billion bond issue for repairs of highways, waterways and mass transit.

title: SENATE OPENS DEBATE ON ABORTION
description: The Senate opened a highly unusual floor debate today over whether to amend the Constitution so that Congress and the states could ban abortions. While the sponsor of the measure involved, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, conceded he did not have the votes to win, he insisted, ''This is not an exercise in futility.''

title: SOVIET CRAFT LAUNCHED IN NEW LINKUP ATTEMPT
description: A Soyuz spacecraft commanded by an astronaut who once held the record for the longest space flight was lifted into orbit today to make the second attempt in two months to link up with the Salyut 7 space station.

title: ARA to Buy Solon For $100 Million
description: Solon Automated Services Inc. and ARA Services Inc. announced an agreement for ARA to acquire Solon for $100 million in cash and notes.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Part-Time Congress?
description: Reasonable, thoughtful, sound: in his 16 years in Washington, Howard Baker, the Senate majority leader, has earned all those descriptions. But none of them apply to his proposal to cut Congressional pay in half, to remove all limits on outside income and to allow members of Congress to earn most of their income outside politics.

title: CLARK,J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Caterpillar Sues T.A.P. Equipment
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it had filed a $10 million suit against a California company that, it said, counterfeited parts and packaging materials and illegally used Caterpillar's trademark.

title: U.S. to Consider Paroling Afghans
description: Federal immigration officials said yesterday that they would consider releasing on parole or bond 19 of 46 Afghans who have been confined in a Brooklyn detention center for up to 17 months.

title: STERCHI BROS STORES, INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
A ROOKIE PITCHER WAITS FOR CHANCE
description: Y esterday was the first day of the rest of Kurt Lundgren's life. He planned to go to the offices of Popular Mechanics magazine to learn the duties of his part-time job, his first employment since he was graduated from Columbia. Lundgren was grateful for the opportunity to gain some experience, but this was not what he had in mind.

title: House Sales Up 5% in May
description: Resales of single-family houses rose 5 percent in May, edging closer to the pre-recession level of nearly 2 1/2 years ago, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: TUESDAY, JUNE 28, 1983; The Economy
description: The Supreme Court ruled that states may include the worldwide income of American-based multinational corporations in calculating state tax liability. The decision, a major victory for state officials, upheld a method of calculation in which a multinational's state tax bill is generally - though not always - higher. The method, which has been used in 11 states, is likely now to be adopted by others. The ruling was attacked by many of the corporations. (Page A1.)

title: BASSETT FURNITURE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed June 10.

title: Bear's Killing of Camper Puzzles Wildlife Officials
description: Although a large grizzly that killed a Wisconsin man has been put to death, officials still hope to learn why the bear attacked the camper and dragged him from his tent, still in a sleeping bag.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. TO GIVE $183.7 MILLION TO MARSHALL ISLANDS
description: The United States will pay the Marshall Islands $183.7 million over the next 15 years for injuries and damages resulting from nuclear testing in the islands 30 years ago, officials said today.

title: 'Super' Chips Arrive in U.S.
description: Japanese electronics companies have started shipping samples of a new ''super'' computer memory chip to the United States, raising fears of an all-out battle for the semiconductor market with their American rivals, industry sources said today.

title: TV: DOCUMENTARY FILM EXAMINES AMIRI BARAKA
description: ''IN MOTION: AMIRI BARAKA'' is a brilliantly executed, supremely sentimental documentary about the writer and political activist who once was known as LeRoi Jones. It is also a paean to a family man. How do you like your revolutionaries? In this film you get Mr. Baraka as benign. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: Failed Wyoming Bank
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that it had been unable to arrange for another bank to take over the failed Western National Bank, of Lovell, Wyo., and that it would soon begin paying off depositors.

title: LYME DISEASE BROADENS ITS RANGE
description: WITH the arrival of warm weather, Lyme disease is back, and public health officials fear that the mildness of last winter could mean a dramatic increase in this tick-borne ailment in the Northeast this summer and fall.

title: Man Hit by Glass From Tower Dies
description: A 62-year-old Pelham, N.Y., man who was struck last month by glass falling from the Trump Tower in Manhattan has died of a fractured skull and lacerations of the brain, the Westchester County Medical Examiner's office reported yesterday.

title: A TRIBUTE TO CHARLES MINGUS
description: CHARLES MINGUS was a big man, and he was so full of ferocious energy that he used to seem even bigger. On Sunday, the Kool jazz festival presented a program billed as ''A Night of Genius - Artists Celebrate Mingus,'' and although it employed a combo of Mingus alumni, an orchestra conducted by Gunther Schuller, dancers, a trio of guitarists and an ensemble of bassists, it wasn't big the way Mr. Mingus was - big in spirit.

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $352,000 for the quarter and $680,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $49,000.

title: Trade Publication Sold
description: The SFN Companies, Glenview, Ill., which is largely in textbook publishing, will acquire Broadcast Advertisers Reports on July 1 for $24 million, SFN announced yesterday. BAR, which is 29 years old, is well-known in the advertising business as the source of estimates of advertiser spending on the television networks and stations.

title: ALLEGHENY & WESTERN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
CASES OF AIDS IN CITY INCREASE AT SLOWER RATE THAN WAS PREDICTED
description: The New York City Health Commissioner said yesterday that the number of cases of AIDS has continued to increase in the city but at a rate slower than had been predicted.

title: Well Done - and Undone - in Albany
description: Chilled in winter, broiled in July, Albany never seems like home to New York's Legislature. Its members inevitably leave more than they can handle for the last few days of the session. Thanks largely to Governor Cuomo's seduction and persuasion, they managed to finish most of their business. It was a marathon rush, leaving too little time for detailed evaluation. A quick appraisal provides both encouragement and doubt.

title:
CREDIT MARKETS;
BOND PRICES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices plunged and yields rose sharply yesterday as securities dealers slashed prices in an attempt to lure investors back to the credit market. But institutional buyers remained on the sidelines and the market turned bearish.

title: REPORT ON MINORITY PROGRESS: STILL 'DISTRESSING'
description: At a recent gathering of black Foreign Service employees, Terence A. Todman, a veteran diplomat and, most recently, Ambassador to Spain, recalled the ''deep sadness'' he felt as he left Washington in 1978 for his Madrid assignment.

title: A PREVIEW FOR WINTER HOLIDAYS
description: In the inexorable flow of fashion, designers are usually months, sometimes a full season, ahead of the calendar. It takes time to produce clothes, but it takes even longer for the fabrics to arrive.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Educational Linkage

title: CHICAGO POWER STRUGGLE IN NEW STAGE
description: The bitter struggle for control of Chicago's City Council is moving back to the council chambers, following Mayor Harold Washington's third setback in the courts.

title: Hip Injury Ends General's Streak
description: Wayne Harris, the right guard from Mississippi State, played in 1,097 consecutive offensive plays for the New Jersey Generals this season without accident. But pain and injury came with the 1,098th.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In our demand for excellence, we must be careful that we do not wind up with a system that becomes elitist, that increases standards for a significant upper percentage of those who can, and refuses to deal with those who will not.

title: DEBATERS SHINE IN THE BRONX
description: BRONX HIGH SCHOOL OF SCIENCE, celebrated for its outstanding students and the awards they garner year after year in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, has built an equally impressive - though far less widely known - record in a different arena: high school debating.

title: 'Twilight Zone' Studio and 3 Others Pay Fines
description: Warner Bros. and three people indicted in the deaths of the actor Vic Morrow and two children in the filming of ''Twilight Zone'' have dropped their appeals of civil charges and paid $20,000 in fines to the State Labor Commissioner, officials said today.

title: MUSIC: POP EXPERIMENTATION
description: based composer, presented an evening of music for two keyboards and tape at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation Thursday evening. Although the program - which consisted of one lengthy, untitled suite -was generally unsuccessful, Miss Holcomb is an original artist.

title: On the Road
description: Travel can be a valuable learning experience, as nine members of the C.W. Post basketball team found during a recent 19-day tour of Hungary. The Pioneers, a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division II team from Greenvale, L.I., played nine games in seven cities from mid-May to early June.

title: LOAN COMMITMENTS TO THIRD WORLD
description: The World Bank and 20 regional institutions that make long-term loans to finance projects in developing countries plan to commit $31 billion annually over the next four years, which could make it easier for some of these countries to pay their debts, according to a survey published today.

title: Smoke of Battle
description: An argument has resulted from a cigarette-advertising symbol on the Wimbledon tennis outfit of Martina Navratilova. Britain's antismoking campaign, Action on Smoking and Health, complained to authorities of Wimbledon, whose women's championship is sponsored by Virginia Slims, another cigarette brand. ''It's upsetting that top athletes in the best position to appreciate the value of fitness can take money for advertising a product that kills one in four customers,'' said David Simpson, the director of the antismoking campaign.

title: Pitcher Awaits Ruling
description: Steve Howe, the relief pitcher for the Dodgers, who was released from a drug-recovery center last Friday after five weeks of therapy, will have his immediate baseball future decided by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, who met with Dodger officials in New York to discuss possible disciplinary action against Howe. A statement from the commissioner's office is not expected until sometime this week.

title: BENIHANA NATIONAL reports earnings for year to March 27.
Mets Lose, 6-5, To Tidewater
description: The Tidewater Tides of the International League, the Mets' top farm club, scored five runs in the sixth inning tonight to defeat New York, 6-5, before a capacity crowd of 6,182 at Metropolitan Stadium.

title: Chile's President Bars Any More Protests
description: President Augusto Pinochet, speaking today after the collapse of a largely ineffectual general strike, said he would not allow any more protests against his military Government.

title: SALVADOR PARTY CALLS CHARTER THREAT TO NEW LAND EFFORTS
description: El Salvador's Christian Democrats said today that two articles in a draft constitution would ''close the door'' on future land redistribution efforts and vowed to seek a revision.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics National Sports Festival, at Colorado Springs. A heavy schedule includes finals in boxing, tennis (men's and women's singles and doubles), table tennis, archery and judo. Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Joe Altobelli, former Yankee coach and now manager of the Orioles, sends Mike Boddicker to the mound in the tight race for the lead in the Eastern Division. Ron Guidry will apparently miss a turn because of a backache. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis, doubleheader. The Mets took four of six games from the Cardinals at Shea Stadium last week. Rusty Staub may get a chance to set a record of nine consecutive pinch hits in one season. (Television - Channel 9, 6:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 6:30 P.M.) Braves vs. Houston Astros, at Atlanta. (Television -WTBS, 7:30 P.M.).

title: CARME INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Net loss

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC, CO reports earnings for qtr to June 5.
Exxon Refunding
description: The Exxon Corporation announced the sale of $45.3 million in three tax-exempt floating-rate monthly demand revenue bond issues with an initial interest rate of 5.05 percent. The bonds were issued in connection with the refunding of $50.5 million face amount of taxexempt pollution control bonds. They were issued by the Parish of East Baton Rouge, La.; the Gulf Coast (Tex.) Waste Disposal Authority and the Industrial Pollution Control Financing Authority of Union County, N.J.

title: Celtics Obtain Dennis Johnson
description: For much of last season, the Boston Celtics talked of the need for a big defensive guard. Yesterday, Red Auerbach, the club's president and general manager, came up with one of the best, Dennis Johnson.

title: Saudi Company To Offer Stock
description: The state-owned Saudi Basic Industries Corporation plans to offer 15 percent to 20 percent of its shares to the public in November or December, its managaing director, Abdul Aziz al-Zamil, said today.

title: 3,000 ISRAELI DOCTORS END HUNGER STRIKE
description: More than 3,000 public hospital doctors halted their two-week-old hunger strike for higher pay today after the Government agreed to arbitration.

title: Tandy Executive Made President of Microsoft
description: Jon Shirley, credited with propelling the Tandy Corporation and its 7,000 Radio Shack stores into its position as the world's largest merchandiser of microcomputers and software, will assume the presidency of the Microsoft Corporation of Bellevue, Wash., on Aug.1.

title: FREE COURSES OFFER JOBLESS A 2D CHANCE
description: On a hot summer's day, children in this city performed airborne somersaults on a mattress in a rubble-strewn lot and frolicked in the spray from a fire hydrant. Able-bodied men grouped on street corners, drinking from things concealed in brown paper bags and fanning themselves with the sports pages of newspapers. A man on the radio talked of the ''discomfort index.'' The temperature edged above 90 degrees, the unemployment rate, an estimated 15 percent.

title: PANDICK PRESS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed Jan. 17. The share earnings for the latest periods also reflect the sale of 645,000 shares of common stock on Jan. 27.

title: Monmouth Is Not For Sale
description: The board of directors of the Monmouth Park Jockey Club announced today that the thoroughbred race track in this Monmouth County community is not for sale.

title: Kennedy Tours Field Of PCB's Near Boston
description: Hundreds of worried residents signed up for blood tests Monday and Senator Edward M. Kennedy toured a 25-acre field that authorities say contains some of the highest levels of PCB's ever found in the United States.

title: DISPUTE ON FOOTBALL UNSETTLED
description: T he appeals process continues, and now the National Collegiate Athletic Association will ask the Supreme Court to overrule a lowercourt decision stating that the N.C.A.A. was in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act when it acted as the sole bargaining agent for its member schools in negotiations for television football contracts. For the college football fan, however, this probably will not change the television picture for the coming season, which will be well under way before the Court decides whether to hear the case.

title: S. Ralph Cohen, 65; A Cultural Promoter
description: S. Ralph Cohen, a former assistant to the president of Scandinavian Airline Systems and a promoter of Scandinavian cultural programs in the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LOS ANGELES WEIGHS MERITS OF BONUS PAY FOR THE BEST TEACHERS
description: It was a simple gesture on the part of Quentin Merriman as he taught fractions to 25 Los Angeles fifth graders, but in several young faces, it ignited the gleam teachers strive for, the elusive gleam of recognition.

title: SHOULD LIFE ALWAYS BE PROLONGED?
description: SEVERAL months ago, the body of an unconscious woman was kept biologically alive for more than two months although her brain had suffered damage too grave to support life.

title: CELEBRATING THE GENIUS OF COLEMAN HAWKINS
description: Among the jazz giants who appeared in the 1920's when jazz was establishing its fundamentals, two creative geniuses stood apart from their peers. Most of them, including Louis Armstrong, built on the work of musicians who had preceded them on their instruments. But Earl Hines and Coleman Hawkins did more than that: they invented the jazz use of their instruments.

title: VOGART CRAFTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
SOUTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
HU NA BEATEN IN HER DEBUT
description: Cameramen and reporters hovered by the side of the tennis court as a young Chinese woman rushed the net and slashed at the ball with her oversized metal racquet.

title: I-95 Bridge Collapse Sends Cars Into River
description: At least two tractor-trailer trucks and two passenger cars went into the Mianus River early this morning when a Connecticut Turnpike bridge over it collapsed, the Connecticut state police said.

title: OLIVETTI ASKS PARIS TO CUT ROLE
description: Carlo de Benedetti, the president and controlling shareholder of Olivetti, the big Italian office machinery maker, is seeking a substantial reduction in the French Government's 30 percent interest in his company, French business executives said today.

title: Eddie Murphy Signs Five-Film Contract
description: Eddie Murphy, a 22-year-old television comedian who has become a film star much in demand, has signed an five-film contract with the Paramount Pictures division of Gulf and Western, Frank G. Mancuso, the division's president, announced yesterday.

title: ENZO BIOCHEM, CO reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
description: b-Including extraorldinary credits of $155,000 for the quarter and $569,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: CELLS AND SOULS
description: While genetic engineering in humans seems close enough to justify public concern, we must not be swept away by fear of exaggerated dangers.

title: United Church of Christ Elects Woman as Officer
description: The Rev. Carol Joyce Brun of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been elected secretary of the United Church of Christ, becoming the first woman to be a national officer in the 1.75-million-member denomination.

title: ADMINISTRATION TRIES AGAIN ON CARE LAW FOR IMPAIRED INFANTS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they would try again to require 6,400 hospitals around the country to provide food and medical care to severely handicapped infants, even though a Federal district judge struck down a similar requirement last April.

title: CYPRUS SEEKS UNIT OF A.M.C.
description: A company headed by Willard F. Rockwell Jr., former chairman of the Rockwell International Corporation, announced yesterday that it would offer between $150 million and $200 million for the American Motors Corporation's AM General subsidiary.

title: ACCOUNTANTS' PASSION
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKEES DEFEAT ORIOLES IN 11
