description: Butch Wynegar nearly missed the Yankees' game with the Baltimore Orioles last night. If he had, the Yankees would have missed him. Wynegar, after failing to hit four times and grounding into double plays twice, lashed a run-scoring single in the 11th inning to give the Yankees a 4-3 victory in the opening game of a four-game series. The loss dropped the Orioles into second place in the American League East, half a game behind the Toronto Blue Jays, who did not play. The Yankees are three games behind the Blue Jays. Gossage Gets Victory

title: Gulf Oil Layoffs
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it is laying off 725 workers nationwide, including 220 at its operating headquarters in Houston and 95 at its corporate headquarters in Pittsburgh. The company said an additional 1,600 jobs have been eliminated through voluntary early retirements. Gulf said this reduction, coupled with earlier attrition, voluntary retirements, sales of operations and other layoffs during the past 18 months, will reduce its total domestic work force from about 36,000 in January 1982 to about 29,700 by the end of July.

title: STAUB A MASTER IN PINCH
description: R on Reed, the Philadelphia Phillies' right-handed reliever, had worked four innings before Rusty Staub came to bat Sunday afternoon for the Mets in the first game of a doubleheader.

title: SENATE PANEL SAID TO TRIM MONEY FOR B-1 BOMBERS AND MX MISSILES
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has tentatively decided to reduce production and research funds for the MX nuclear missiles and production funds for the B-1 bomber, according to Congressional officials.

title: Business and the Law; British View Of Mergers
description: LONDON NOBODY was surprised when Trafalgar House's bid to take over the Peninsular & Oriental Steamship Navigation Company was referred to Britain's Monopolies Commission last week for further study. The referral had been recommended to Cecil Parkinson, Secretary of State for Trade and Industry in Margaret Thatcher's re-elected administration, by the Office of Fair Trading. And Nigel Broackes, Trafalgar's chairman, had remarked that referral was a ''distinct possibility.''

title: The Editorial Notebook; Sticks, Stones and Somocistas
description: ''Somocista'' is a recent and fiery addition to the vernacular of abuse. The leftist Sandinistas in Managua spit out the term to discredit anyone suspected of serving the Somoza family, Nicaragua's corrupt and brutal rulers for 43 years.

title: Article 260960 -- No Title
description: The New Jersey Assembly gave final legislative passage today to a $6.8 billion budget for the 1983-84 fiscal year that increases spending by $501 million over the current budget and requires no new taxes. The vote was 75 to 2.

title: Pirates' Streak at 9; Candelaria Ejected
description: Cecilio Guante took over for John Candelaria at the start of the third inning tonight and blanked St. Louis the rest of the way as the Pittsburgh Pirates won their ninth straight game, a rain-delayed, 6-1 triumph over the Cardinals.

title: Charlotte Curtis; Frank Stella and Art
description: FRANK STELLA, that master of contemporary art, is one of very few painters whose ability to communicate is thought to include public speaking. And with this and his mighty accomplishments in mind, the Whitney Museum, ever on the prowl for ways to delight and educate its devotees, invited him to speak.

title: Market Place; Semiconductor Industry's Rise
description: LAST week, shares of the Intel Corporation jumped 10 1/2 points, to close at 74 1/2 in the over-the-counter market. The increase underscored the latest recovery of semiconductor stocks, a group that often rides the roller coaster on Wall Street.

title: IS SCIENCE STYMIED BY TODAY'S COMPLEXITY?
description: IT is easy to lose patience with science today. The questions are pressing: How dangerous is dioxin? What about low-level radiation? When will that monstrous earthquake strike California? And why can't we predict the weather better?

title: BEYOND CONTEMPT
description: One of these decades we may get to the bottom of the Westway scandal. In the meantime we'll have to settle for the unseemly spectacle of scared public officials changing lawyers and trying to rewrite history in a Federal courtroom in downtown Manhattan.

title: TWO LEADING U.S. BALLOONISTS DIE IN CRASH IN BAVARIA WHILE IN RACE
description: The American balloonists Maxie Anderson, who made a trans-Atlantic balloon flight in 1978, and Don Ida were killed today when their balloon crashed into a forest in Bavaria, the police said. Mr. Anderson was 48 years old, and Mr. Ida was 49.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Barrister Information Systems Corp., Buffalo, has named Leslie G. Foschio, former New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, as general counsel.

title: SPECIALIZED IN REPAIR OF NERVES AND SPINE
description: Dr. James B. Campbell, a neuro-surgeon who pioneered in nerve and spinal cord repair, died Friday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: PRUDENTIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for year to May 31.
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $750,000.

title: Reagan Will Visit Far East in November
description: President Reagan will visit Japan, South Korea and Indonesia in November ''to reaffirm the importance we attach to the region,'' a Presidential spokesman, Larry Speakes, announced today.

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOBACCO CO reports earnings for year to March 31.
BEEFSTEAK CHARLIE'S INC reports earnings for 16 wks to May 14.
description: b-Including tax credits of $830,000 for the 16 weeks and $1.2 million for the 28 weeks.

title: JAPAN TRAINING GLOBAL EXPERTS
description: This rural town, more than 100 miles northwest of cosmopolitan Tokyo, seems an unlikely place for corporate Japan to teach worldly executives how to function in an international arena that has become increasingly hostile to Japan's economic advance. But that is why the International University of Japan opened here in April.

title: GAP BETWEEN REFORM AND REALITY
description: ''THEIR rhetoric notwithstanding, public leaders are not interested in the schools,'' says Theodore R. Sizer. ''Regulation and coercion, which don't cost much, get great play today.'' Nevertheless, he says, despite all the talk about reforms and remedies, ''none seems to stick.''

title: A MONDRIAN SURPASSES $2 MILLION
description: A painting by the Dutch modernist Piet Mondrian was purchased tonight at Christie's by a private Japanese collector for $2,156,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for a work of abstract art.

title: Ford Recovering on Coast
description: Former President Gerald Ford is recovering successfully from elective urologic surgery at Eisenhower Medical Center, an aide said today. ''He is doing very well,'' Penny Circle said. ''He should be released from the hospital in a couple of days.''

title: Advertising; F.C.B. Unit Gets New President
description: FOOTE, CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS, after a lengthy and thorough search for a new president for its New York office, has gone over to the advertiser side for Jack M. Young, who has been president of the foods division of the Quaker Oats Company.

title: FIELD HOCKEY GLORY LURES VETERINARIAN
description: The boycott of the 1980 Olympics by the United States rearranged the lives of thousands of American athletes. It meant the end of any Olympic hope for some; for others, it meant four more years of the grueling regimen necessary to remain competitive until 1984.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Airlines is holding talks with McDonnell Douglas Corp. about possible additional purchases of DC-9 Super 80 jetliners, a spokesman said.

title: Cook United Names A New Chairman
description: Russell A. Hansen, a former executive at the K Mart Corporation, has been named chairman, president and chief executive of Cook United Inc., a financially troubled discount chain in the Midwest.

title: CHARTING INDUSTRY'S CAPACITY
description: More of the nation's production capacity is being put back into use as the economy recovers from years of recession. But a big question in charting the course of the recovery is how many of the plants idled during the past few years will be - or can be - started up again.

title: NU-WEST GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
U.S. PLANS RULES ON FIRE RETARDANTS IN PLANE SEATS
description: J. Lynn Helms, the head of the Federal Aviation Administration, said today that he expected to start a long rule-making process next month to require fire-blocking material on airliner seats, but he added that it would be three or four years before the improved seats would be in use.

title: France to Airlift Military Supplies to Chad
description: France agreed to airlift 35 tons of military supplies, including antitank weapons and rockets, to help Chad fight a Libyan-backed invasion, French radio said today

title: Prayer Amendment Endorsed
description: The Reagan Administration today formally endorsed a constitutional amendment restoring voluntary prayer to the classroom.

title: The Wilderness for Mr. Arafat
description: Why has Syria ''expelled'' Yasir Arafat and encouraged a further split in the decimated ranks of the Palestine Liberation Organization? Since Syria's President al-Assad has no obvious interest in completing the job begun by General Sharon a year ago, the reason must be devious - and important enough to override any incidental benefits to Israel.

title: ARID WEST TRYING DRIP IRRIGATION
description: GILA BEND, Ariz. ON this dusty stretch of desert in southwestern Arizona, where summer temperatures commonly reach 115 degrees, farmers at Paloma Ranch are installing what is believed to be the largest drip irrigation system for row crops in the world. At first glance, it appears unlikely that anything could grow in the sandy soil here, but farmers hope to turn the area into an example of technology destined to save agriculture in the arid West.

title: CONNORS UPSET BY CURREN AT WIMBLEDON IN FOUR SETS
description: Jimmy Connors, who has the best service return in tennis, succumbed to 33 aces by Kevin Curren of South Africa today and lost in four sets during the fourth round at Wimbledon.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD INJURED SUSPECT'S RIGHT TO TREATMENT
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution requires municipalities to provide medical treatment for criminal suspects who are injured while being captured by the police. But the Court said the Constitution does not specify who should pay the medical bills.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARCEL PROUST. Selected Letters 1880- 1903. Edited by Philip Kolb. Translated by Ralph Manheim. Introductions by J.M. Cocking. Illustrated. 376 pages. Doubleday & Co. $19.95.

title: Analysts Expecting Maryland Cup Bid
description: The Maryland Cup Corporation and the Fort Howard Paper Company requested a suspension in the trading of their stock on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, leading some analysts to conclude that Ford Howard intended to acquire Maryland.

title: Browner Testifies He Bought Drugs
description: Ross Browner, the Cincinnati Bengals defensive end, testified in a Federal drug trial today that he purchased cocaine on at least a dozen occasions from a Cincinnati man.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange because of investor concern that interest rates will rise. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 12.22 points, to 1,229.47.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to June 18.
Dress Barn Picks Par
description: The Dress Barn, a chain of discount women's clothing stores that went public last month, is moving its advertising out of its in-house operation and into Par Communications in New York. The agency says the budget will be $1.5 million and will cover the television advertising planned for this market. The advertiser is based in Stamford, Conn., has 70 shops and plans to open 25 more before the end of the year.

title: THE DANCE: CITY BALLET CLOSES SEASON
description: THE New York City Ballet's closing night ended on an unmistakably emotional note at the State Theater Sunday. The last ballet on the program was George Balanchine's ''Serenade,'' and the ovation that followed was not simply a tribute to the windswept performance by the dancers. It was very obviously a tribute to Mr. Balanchine, who died on April 30, just as the City Ballet's spring season began.

title: SUPREME COURT RULING CASTS DOUBT ON SALVADOR AID
description: A carefully wrought compromise on military aid to El Salvador, accepted by the White House and 36 of the 37 members of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, may come apart because of last week's Supreme Court ruling on legislative vetoes.

title: MGM/UA HOME ENTERTAINMENT GROUP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was a division of MGM/UA Entertainment Co. until shortly before its initial public offering on Dec. 22, 1982.

title: City U. Rolls Back Tuition Increase
description: The Board of Trustees of the City University of New York unanimously voted yesterday to rescind a tuition increase for 18,000 part-time students at the school's seven community colleges.

title: Florida Beckons
description: Cris Collinsworth, the Cincinnati Bengals' wide receiver who has two years remaining on his National Football League contract, said yesterday that he would join the Tampa Bay Bandits of the United States Football League when his pact with the Bengals expires in 1985.

title: NICARAGUA, CHOOSE A NEW PATH
description: Nicaragua's revolution is, in my judgment, in danger of dying in its infancy. Yet, like many Nicaraguans, I continue to pray that the Sandinistas - who are courageous in war and show real concern for the destitute -may see the wisdom of admitting their errors and may have the will to redress them in order to save the revolution for the sake of Nicaragua.

title: HEAD QUITS AT TIGER'S AIR CARGO
description: Tiger International Inc., a diversified transportation company that has been straining under heavy losses for more than a year, said today that the president and head of its faltering air cargo operations had resigned.

title: Ballet West Appoints New Choreographer
description: Helen Douglas has been named resident choreographer of Ballet West of Salt Lake City, one of the oldest of American regional dance companies.

title: Required Reading; MX and Jellybeans
description: Horace W. Busby, a former aide to President Johnson and now a political consultant, writing in his June 17 issue of The Busby Papers, a newsletter:

title: SAMPSON SEEKING A 'LOW KEY' STYLE
description: When Ralph Sampson entered the University of Virginia four years ago, he was the most celebrated high school basketball player in the country. The vast news media interest created by his presence soon forced the school to expand its offices in the athletic department. At 7-foot-4, Ralph Sampson needed space.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED CONGRESSIONAL APPROACH TO COMBATING ACID RAIN
description: To the Editor:

title: PICKING THE RIGHT KNIFE
description: THERE are so many brands of kitchen knives on the market today - each one boasting some technological advantage over the next - that consumers are understandably perplexed. A set of quality knives is one of the most important investments a cook can make, and one of the most expensive, so it pays to shop around.

title: THE U.S. AND SOVIET MUDDLE THROUGH
description: The constructive dialogue that Secretary of State George P. Shultz says the Reagan Administration seeks with the Soviet Union is nowhere in sight. Fortunately, the superpower competition is not at an explosive point, and Moscow and Washington alike seem determined to keep their rivalry under control. But the future is bleak indeed for negotiating a major arms control agreement.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $1.7 million for the quarter and $2.6 million for the 6 months. c-After income from discontinued operations of $798,000 for the quarter and $1.3 million for the 6 months.

title: Central Park Wine?
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In his wine column (June 1) Frank Prial discussed the relative importance of soil versus climate in the production of wine. This writer believes that both soil and climate are important but that the wine maker is the deciding factor.

title: ...KEY LEGISLATION STUCK IN THE SENATE
description: To the Editor:

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
CITY'S TRANSIT AGENCY IMPROVES CONCESSION REVENUE
description: The New York City Transit Authority is not among the largest owners of commercial real estate in the city, but its 458 subway stations offer a source of substantial revenue from concessions.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Out of High School And Right Into College

title: WIDE G.O.P. ACCESS TO CARTER PAPERS IN '80 IS INDICATED
description: The White House released sheafs of information today from President Reagan's 1980 campaign files indicating that Reagan advisers had repeated, secret access to strategy material prepared for President Carter, including debating tactics and other campaign plans.

title: Bengal Back Testifies That He Bought Drugs
description: Pete Johnson, the Cincinnati Bengal fullback, testified in Federal court today that he had purchased cocaine from an accused drug dealer ''about 15 times'' in 1980 and 1981.

title: THE DAY MONMOUTH IS THE ONLY GAME
description: Harold Springer and his track buddies were at the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan about a half hour earlier than usual this morning, because this was Tuesday - ''my day for taking in the sea breezes,'' as Harold puts it.

title: SENATE COMMITTEE RESTORES $888 MILLION FOR B-1 PLANE
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee, in an unexpected and controversial change of course, restored $888.7 million in funds for the B-1 bomber today after Reagan Administration officials testified that a lower inflation rate had freed extra money for arms programs.

title: CITY TO PROCEED IN REFURBISHING OF HARLEM UNITS
description: A New York State agency has dropped its requirement that a group of landmark Harlem brownstones be renovated to restore and preserve their interiors. The agency said there was nothing left to preserve.

title: Bryn Mawr-Dixon
description: The Bryn Mawr Corporation will acquire the Joseph Dixon Crucible Company and form a new concern, the Dixon Ticonderoga Company, the two companies said. Bryn Mawr is a real estate development and recreational-vehicle concern; Dixon makes consumer and industrial products. Upon completion of the merger, holders of Dixon common stock will receive for each of the 614,181 Dixon shares outstanding $29 in cash and one Bryn Mawr $15 principal amount sinking fund debenture due 1993.

title: Susan Perl, Artist, Dies at 60; Illustrations Widely Published
description: Susan Perl, a New York illustrator, died of kidney failure Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Fluor Division Is Put Up for Sale
description: The Fluor Corporation said it had put its money-losing Distribution Services division up for sale. The division accounted for about 8 percent of Fluor's $7.33 billion in revenues during its latest fiscal year.

title: HOUSE AIDE SUGGESTS BROADER IMPACT OF COURT'S VETO RULING
description: The Supreme Court's invalidating of Congress's legislative veto has jeopardized entire laws, including the War Powers Resolution and the budget process, not just their veto provisions, Stanley M. Brand, counsel to the House of Representatives, said today in an interview.

title: Tory Challenges U.S.  Over Irish Guerrilla
description: The case of an I.R.A. guerrilla arrested at a bar in midtown Manhattan over the weekend will be a ''touchstone'' of American willingness to fight terrorism in Northern Ireland, Michael Brown, a British lawmaker, said today.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
WINE TALK
description: plantings of geraniums - underlining hollow squares of black formed by windows opening into cool, dark interiors. Heat and silence.

title: STAGE: EUGENE O'NEILL'S 'AH, WILDERNESS!' REVIVED
description: ''AH, WILDERNESS!'' which the Roundabout has revived at the Haft Theater, will never make anyone's list of Eugene O'Neill's masterworks. Yet this turn-of-the-century frolic, its author's only major comedy, continues to charm and fascinate - perhaps even more so now than it did in its Broadway premiere in 1933.

title: STUDY FINDS NO TV LINK TO VIOLENCE
description: The National Broadcasting Company yesterday publicly discussed the findings of a 505-page study on whether television is a factor in violent behavior. The study, underwritten by the network, concluded that ''television was not causally implicated in the development of aggressive behavior among children and adolescents.''

title: Farm Credit Bond Is Priced
description: A two-part $2 billion bond issue for the Federal Farm Credit Bank system was priced today with yields of 9.60 and 9.65 percent.

title: UTILITIES SAY MOVE TO CONTROL ACID RAIN WILL PUSH UP RATES
description: Legislation now before the Senate to control acid rain would sharply increase electricity rates in some parts of the country, according to a survey of 24 utility companies that was released today by the Edison Electric Institute.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading 'That's Not It'

title: AN ARGENTINE BOMB
description: Shrewd policy may enable Argentina to acquire a nuclear arsenal without breaking its international agreements. It now enjoys the best of both worlds, obtaining extensive foreign support for its civil nuclear program without compromising its military options. Once outsiders are not needed, they will have lost valuable leverage for deterring production of the bomb.

title: HOUSE EXTENDS BAN ON OIL LEASES
description: The House voted today to block oil lease sales on the outer continental shelf off Massachusetts, California and the eastern Gulf of Mexico.

title: Jerusalem Bomb Wounds 2
description: A small bomb went off in a western Jerusalem supermarket today, slightly wounding two girls. A police spokesman said 10 suspects had been arrested in connection with the explosion.

title: THE LEGIBLE WOMAN
description: She was an eyeful with poison written all over her and she didn't think much of my $25 off-the-rack double-breasted with the pinstripes and padded shoulders. ''With a decent tailor you could lose 15 pounds in lapels alone,'' she said.

title: Newspaper Guild Backs Merger With Printers
description: Delegates to the Newspaper Guild's 50th anniversary convention today overwhelmingly approved a proposed merger with the printers' union to create the largest organization of newspaper employees in North America.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THE story begins on July 4, 1905, in a tenement on the Lower East Side. A young immigrant girl, newly arrived from a small village in Russia, awakes to the sound of martial music and runs to the window. The street below is a sea of flags and marching bands. Turning to an older sister, already schooled in the ways of the new country, she says, ''What is happening?''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about the shooting of three students near Yeshiva University misidentified a Jewish organization and its role in offering a reward. It is the American Jewish Committee, which has pledged to raise $10,000 in reward money.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for qtr to June 10.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split effective Nov. 15 and a 4-for-3 stock split effective May 31.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Market Place; CASINO DEALS: ODD TIMING
description: LAST Wednesday and Thursday, the investment firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. sponsored a seminar on gambling stocks in Atlantic City. The 60 clients who attended, including representatives of major banks and mutual fund groups, heard talks by executives of several companies that operate casinos.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Saturday about New York City's Financial Control Board misidentified Thomas P. Puccio. He is no longer a member of the law firm of Booth, Lipton & Lipton.

title: SOVIET CREW LINKS 2 CRAFT WHILE IN ORBIT
description: Two Soviet astronauts linked their Soyuz 9 capsule with a 40-ton orbiting space station today and began experiments on ''controlling large manned complexes'' in space, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.

title: CHURCH EASING HOMOSEXUALITY STAND
description: The United Church of Christ has accepted a report affirming that the homosexuality of a candidate for ordination should not be a ground for refusing to admit that person into the church's ministry.

title: No Headline
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a Federal energy regulation and ruled that natural gas pipeline companies are entitled to charge the maximum decontrolled price for gas they produce from their own wells and transmit through their own pipelines.

title: CARE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
AN EFFORT TO REVIVE NEW YORK BEER (IN UTICA, FOR NOW)
description: BACK in 1976 New York City went dry, figuratively speaking, as far as local brews were concerned. That's when the F & M Schaefer Brewing Company capped its last keg of beer in New York and joined such late and lamented local breweries as Ebling, Koster & Bial, Trommer's, Ringler, Henry Elias, Jetter and John Eichler.

title: CONCERN ON ACID RAIN EXTENDING TO PUBLIC HEALTH
description: Two fundamental changes seem to be lending urgency to the North American debate about acid rain. One is that falling acids and the toxic metals associated with them are increasingly seen by scientists and public officials as a threat to people, not just to fish and forests.

title: Ruling Reversed
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association reversed its stand on Mike Tomczak and ruled that the Ohio State quarterback would be allowed to play next season.

title: Indiana Standard Names a Chairman
description: Richard M. Morrow was named yesterday to succeed John E.Swearingen as chairman and chief executive of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), the nation's seventh-largest industrial company.

title: SWIMMER SETS OLYMPIC GOAL
description: Jeff Kostoff, the world's most promising young distance swimmer, says he knows what will happen the next time he swims against Vladimir Salnikov, the world and Olympic champion and world-record holder. Salnikov will beat him easily.

title: Hagler to Fight Duran
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the world middleweight champion, and Roberto Duran signed yesterday for a Nov. 4 title fight that, according to the promotor Bob Arum, could earn each fighter between $7.5 million and $10 million. The fight will be staged in either Madison Square Garden; Miami's Orange Bowl; Atlantic City; Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., or Manila. The fight with Duran, the World Boxing Association junior middleweight champion, will be the first of a two-fight contract for Hagler with Top Rank Inc.

title: FIVE-PARTY COALITION IS FORESEEN FOR ITALY
description: The secretary of the Christian Democratic Party, still Italy's dominant political organization, said today after its crushing setback in the general elections of Sunday and Monday that the only way to govern now ''is a coalition of five.''

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A slipped disk has become one of the most common of the debilitating and costly injuries to afflict people in societies like ours, where millions who are out of shape occasionally ask more of their backs than these architectural marvels are able to deliver.

title: U.S. TELLS OF EMBASSY ATTACK
description: The April 18 explosion that damaged the United States Embassy in Beirut was set off when a pickup truck carrying more than a ton of TNT raced into an exit driveway and crashed into the building, Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, said today.

title: Eliot Stark, Former Reporter, Became Public Relations Man
description: Eliot M. Stark, a public-relations man who represented Senator Robert F. Wagner Sr., Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., Arthur Godfrey and Jayne Mansfield, among others, died of cancer yesterday at the home of a friend in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. He was 72 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor.

title: BALLET: A MESSAC GISELLE
description: century classics until she joined the American Ballet Theater three years ago, has worked highly successfully to adapt to the arduous ballerina roles in these ballets.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to June 3.
description: The 1983 results include Keds Corp. which was consolidated as of Dec. 1, 1982, and before that it was an unconsolidated subsidiary.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE PHILOSOPHER'S PUPIL. By Iris Murdoch. 576 pages. Viking. $17.75.

title: Elizabeth Taylor May Rejoin Cast Thursday
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who missed four performances in ''Private Lives'' over the weekend because of laryngitis and bronchitis, was unable to return to the production last night.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $874,000 and income from reduced tax reserves of $962,000.

title: RICHARD III'S REPUTATION IS OFFERED A WHITE ROSE
description: The Rev. John Clermont, who was scheduled to say the 11 A.M. mass at Our Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral, walked over to the register yesterday morning to see for whom the mass was being offered. The schedule said: Richard Plantagenet.

title: BLUE JAYS FALL INTO 3-WAY TIE
description: Ken Schrom defeated his former teammates for the second time in a week, and Houston Jiminez slammed a two-run double to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays tonight.

title: Sudan Rebels Reported Ready to Kill Churchmen
description: South Sudanese rebels are threatening to shoot two Americans, a Canadian and two Europeans unless they are given shirts, pants and shoes for 150 men, nearly $100,000 in cash and an international radio audience for a statement.

title: Nepal Premier Won't Resign
description: Prime Minister Surya Bahadur Thapa rejected opposition demands today that he resign or face the first no-confidence vote since a new system of government was introduced in Nepal 23 years ago. Demands in Parliament for Mr. Thapa's resignation came after recent opposition rallies in which the Government was charged with corruption, inefficiency and failure to handle last year's drought.

title: Johannesburg Offices Wrecked by 2 Bombs
description: Two bombs wrecked South African Government offices near Johannesburg today and the country's defense chief warned citizens to be prepared for further violence.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Blacks in Aviation: Space Age and Before

title: MARKET VALUE INDEX OF AMEX TO BE HALVED
description: The American Stock Exchange will split its market value index in half on July 5 and adjust its records accordingly back to Sept. 4, 1973, when the index was started with a base of 100. It closed that first day at 100.62.

title: A Hypnotist for Hitters
description: The Chicago White Sox have hired a hypnotist who hopes to raise batting averages enough to win at least five more games.

title: Foreign Investing in U.S. Off
description: Foreign investors spent $8.6 billion last year to acquire or establish businesses in the United States, a 63 percent drop from the record set the previous year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Military Cargo Plane Crashes
description: An Air Force C-130 cargo plane with six people aboard crashed and burned this afternoon in a remote section of the huge Nellis Air Force Base test range while on a training mission, the authorities said. The Air Force refused to say if there were any survivors.

title: New Tiger Debt Accord
description: Tiger International Inc. said today that an agreement had been approved by representatives of its bank and institutional lenders that would enable the company to resume payments on about $900 million of its $1.8 billion in debt. The payments had been suspended Feb. 14.

title: Delay on Revenue Bill
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the Finance Committee, said tonight that Senate action on a major tax bill required by the new budget resolution would probably be delayed until September.

title: Preventive Medicine
description: A list of medicines, including many over-the-counter preparations, is being prepared by the United States Olympic Committee to forestall the possible disqualification of any American athletes through accidental violations of the international rules on drug usage at the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles. Ordinary cold medicines, cough syrups and asthma preparations are expected to be included on the list along with narcotics, anabolic steroids and amphetamines. During the 1972 Olympics, Rick Demont was stripped of the gold medal he won for the United States swimming team because urine tests showed that he had taken an asthma medicine before the race.

title: NO HANDOUTS FOR BLACKS
description: The Administration has been critized for its opposition to affirmative-action programs and compensatory treatment of minority groups. I regard this criticism as mistaken.

title: METS, CARDINALS IN SPLIT
description: The Mets banged out 19 hits on the way to a 10-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in the first game of a doubleheader tonight and then saw their offense weaken in an 8-1 defeat in the second game.

title: 10 ARRESTED AT KENNEDY IN A TAXI BRIBE SCHEME
description: Six taxi dispatchers and four security guards at the busy taxi stands at Kennedy International Airport were arrested yesterday on charges of taking bribes from cabdrivers in return for preferential treatment.

title: American Can Realigns Some Management
description: The American Can Company, which has been moving out of some basic industries into financial services, announced yesterday that it had formed an office of the chairman intended to strengthen management.

title: FORT HOWARD TO BUY MARYLAND CUP
description: The Fort Howard Paper Company, a leading maker of paper products, will acquire the Maryland Cup Corporation, a leading maker of plastic products for the food and beverage industry, the companies announced today.

title: SHORTAGES GROWING IN SEMICONDUCTORS
description: After two years of depressed sales, the semiconductor industry has suddenly entered into a period of product shortages that could last into 1984, according to industry officials.

title: BRIEFING
description: One Survey, Two Views

title: DISTILLER WINS BID FOR LENOX
description: Lenox Inc., after weeks of opposition, yesterday agreed to a takeover by the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation after the distiller raised its bid by $3 a share.

title: LOEB CITATION FOR TIMES
description: Judges for the Gerald Loeb Awards for Distinguished Business and Financial Journalism have given The New York Times a special citation.

title: Bridge: Aunt Agatha Joins a Group Of Distingished Eccentrics
description: In the most readable segment of bridge literature - the collection of deals built around a cast of characters - England has had a virtual monopoly for the past 45 years.

title: U.S. COLONEL IN SALVADOR WARNS CONGRESS ON AID
description: The departing commander of the United States Military Group in El Salvador said today that if Congress cuts off aid to El Salvador American troops will be needed to win this country's three-year-old civil war.

title: TURNER CATLEDGE OF TIMES IS HONORED AT A MEMORIAL
description: More than 200 friends and associates of Turner Catledge, former executive editor of The New York Times, attended a service in his memory yesterday in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Amateur Athletics National Sports Festival, at Colorado Springs. Competition continues in field hockey, rowing, canoeing and kayaking, table tennis, water polo, basketball, soccer and team handball. Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Dave Righetti, seeking his ninth victory, will oppose Mike Boddicker (4-2), whose start was pushed up one day because of last night's rainout. (Television -SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis. The last time that Craig Swan (1-4) and Kevin Hagen (2-1) met, each lasted 7 innings, with Hagen emerging as a 3-1 winner. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 8:30 P.M.).

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1983
description: International Some U.S. sanctions would be lifted if Polish authorities permitted a revival of free trade unions, President Reagan said. Earlier, Administration officials said Poland had been informed that once the authorities took ''meaningful steps'' to liberalize conditions the United States would begin lifting the sanctions imposed when martial law took effect in Poland in December 1981. (Page A1, Column 5.) Palestinian rebel forces opposed to Yasir Arafat attacked his loyalists in what appeared to be the start of an attempt to take control of all Palestinian forces in Lebanon. The Palestinian press service, which is loyal to Mr. Arafat, said the rebels had killed 15 loyalists and wounded 20. (A1:4-6.)

title: NEW LANDMARKS CHIEF
description: ''I don't know much about political maneuvering,'' said Gene A. Norman yesterday morning just after he was named chairman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: HONORED MEMBER OF CENTRE COURT
description: The Queen was not present, the crowds did not sing ''For She's a Jolly Good Fellow,'' and it was not 1977. The tennis tournament known as Wimbledon is 106 years old, not 100, and that makes Virginia Wade 12 days shy of 38. She has the self-confidence to flaunt her handsome shock of graying hair, rather than play cosmetic games with it, but her forehand has gone gray, too, and it did her in yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Accord On Mead Data
description: The Mead Corporation said it had reached an agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation that will enable users of the I.B.M. personal computer, the Displaywriter and the 3101 terminal to gain acess to Mead's databases of periodicals and legal decisions.

title:
SCOUTING;
DeBartolo Family Is Standing Firm
description: Over the objections of National Football League owners, the DeBartolo family of Youngstown, Ohio, has no intention of divesting itself of its interests in football teams in competing leagues.

title: DANCE COLLABORATIONS IN HARLEM
description: THE jazz festival ventured uptown Sunday to Small's Paradise in Harlem for an afternoon program of jazz-and-dance collaborations. ''Flashback'' was a half-hour of simultaneous, largely improvised solos by the pianist Anthony Davis and the dancer Dianne McIntyre. Mr. Davis drew on the lush harmonies of Rachmaninoff, Ellington and Debussy and on the percussive atonality of Stockhausen and Cecil Taylor.

title: TOXIC WASTE: INACTION IN ALBANY...
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED WESTBURNE INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
Marschalk Campaign On Running Red Lights
description: ''People who run red lights must be stopped'' is the theme of a new public service advertising campaign being started at a time when the number of drivers in New York who go through red lights has almost doubled in just over two years.

title: Rangers 3, Angels 1
description: Charlie Hough allowed three hits pver seven adn two-thirds innings, and Buddy Bell's bases-empty homer started a three-run outburst in the fourth inning for Texas.

title: FIRST EDITION SINCE '73
description: Some years ago a newspaper publisher fired off a memo to his staff saying, ''If I see the word 'upcoming' once more, I'm going to be downcoming and the person responsible will be outgoing.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Help Wanted

title: Dodgers 9, Padres 5
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Pedro Guerrero hit the first grand slam of his career to highlight an eight-run fourth inning for Los Angeles. Bob Welch (6-7) went six innings for the victory.

title: Two Booklets for Artists Published by Lawyers
description: Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts has published two booklets of use to the arts community. ''Cable Production: What Every Arts Organization Needs to Know'' deals with the legal and business aspects of cable production.

title: TV: 'LOVING,' NEW ABC SOAP OPERA
description: THERE is a new soap opera in television town. It's called ''Loving'' and can be seen weekdays at 11:30 on ABC, representing the first new ''daytime drama'' that the network has commissioned in eight years. One of the architects of the plot is Agnes Nixon, the so-called soap queen whose successes include ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live.'' Credit is also given to Douglas Marland, who, as head writer on the project, is clearly in charge of ongoing developments.

title: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 29, 1983; Markets
description: The stock market experienced its biggest decline in nearly two months as concern over rising interest rates continued to spread among investors. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.24 points, to 1,209.23. The decline was broadly based, with declines outnumbering advances by more than 4 to 1. (Page D1.)

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Farm-Fresh Produce

title: THE VARIED CULINARY RICHES OF WILD MUSHROOMS
description: A FEW years ago it would have taken a mycologist to positively identify the wild mushrooms that now confront shoppers in virtually every specialty food store and vegetable market. In truth, of course, a few years ago only a mycologist would have cared. That was before wild mushrooms had been ''discovered'' by many American cooks, who have now had ample opportunity to sample the culinary riches of morels, enokitake (or enoki) mushrooms, chanterelles, porcini, cepes, pleurotes, Black Forest mushrooms and, predominantly, shiitake mushrooms.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
BAR MITZVAH WITH A VIETNAMESE FLAVOR
description: THE chopsticks were the first clue that this was not to be the customary bar mitzvah feast. Placed prominently above the dinner plates - which were bracketed by the usual assortment of flatware - the sticks seemed, on first sight, to be aliens on the blue-clothed tables of the Kahn Auditorium banquet hall at Central Synagogue in Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: REAGAN ANNOUNCES A HIGHER FORECAST FOR THE ECONOMY
description: President Reagan, declaring that the American economy was ''beginning to sparkle,'' announced tonight at a news conference that his Administration was ''revising upward our projection of this year's economic growth from 4.7 to 5.5 percent.''

title: Book Assails Reagan Adviser
description: When William P. Clark, the White House national security adviser, was a Justice on California's Supreme Court, he discussed pending cases with the staff of Gov. Ronald Reagan, the man who appointed him to the bench, according to a new book. Mr. Clark denies any impropriety, though the author contends that he violated the court's confidentiality.

title: HEARINGS ON POLICE BRUTALITY WOULD DO HARM, KOCH SAYS
description: A Congressional subcommittee plans to hold hearings here on allegations of police brutality against black and Hispanic New Yorkers, and Mayor Koch said yesterday that the hearings could intensify racial animosities and embolden criminals.

title: 700 Filipinos Protest Ruling Upholding Power of Marcos
description: About 700 people chanting anti-Government slogans and waving banners blocked traffic in central Manila for three hours today in a demonstration against a court ruling backing President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Advest in Merger
description: The Advest Group Inc. said it had agreed in principle to merge with Cecil, Waller and Sterling Inc., a Philadelphia-based brokerage firm.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CITICORP OFFICIALS DEFEND 70'S CURRENCY TRADING
description: Citicorp officials, testifying publicly for the first time about investigations by the Securities and Exchange Commission and others into the bank's currency trading practices during the 1970's, told a Congressional subcommittee today that accusations of wrongdoing were unfounded and had unfairly maligned the bank.

title:
SCOUTING;
Switch Pays Off
description: Ten years ago, when Ayako Okamoto was 22 years old, she had already pitched her softball team to the women's championship of Japan and was considered one of the best softball players in the country.

title: WHAT POPE TOLD WALESA: A DEBATE DEVELOPS
description: A Polish source in the Vatican took issue today with speculation that Pope John Paul II asked Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity movement, to withdraw from public life.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 29.
RESHAPING THE JOINT CHIEFS BY WAY OF PERSUASION
description: In the year he has been Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr. has brought about a quiet revolution to expand the influence of the chiefs in making and executing the nation's military policy.

title: MRS. CUOMO AND SON SETTLING IN AT ALBANY
description: Matilda Cuomo moved from Queens to Albany this weekend, but nobody was home. Her husband and his staff were camping out over at the State Capitol, negotiating the final bills of the legislative session. At one point over the weekend, Mrs. Cuomo called her husband and suggested they go out to dinner, but he had to decline. Finally, Governor Cuomo said, she called him on Sunday night - after the Legislature had been in almost continuous session for three days - and said to him: ''This is great. I come to Albany and my husband doesn't show up.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * American Electric Power Inc.'s Indiana & Michigan Electric Co. subsidiary announced that it would sell, from time to time, up to $70 million of first mortgage bonds and up to $25 million of $25 par value preferred stock at competitive bidding on or about July 27.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $567,394. In fiscal 1982 the income from discontinued operations includes a $478,532 gain from the sale of discontinued operations.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Seattle Seahawks, in an effort to strengthen their offensive line, have acquired one of pro football's most durable players, Reggie McKenzie, from the Buffalo Bills, for a draft choice. McKenzie will join a former coach of the Bills, Chuck Knox, who now heads the Seahawks.

title: THE RUSH TO V-J DAY
description: To the Editor:

title: May Sells Stake
description: The May Department Stores Company said it had sold its stock in the Consumers Distributing Company, a Canadian catalog showroom concern, for $24 million. May said its earnings from the sale totaled about $8 million. May had owned a 22 percent share of Consumers since 1978, when the Canadian company bought May's catalog showroom division with stock.

title: Advertising; Ketchum Gets Y.&R.  Executive
description: ELEVEN years in the creative department of Young & Rubicam have obviously made Peter H. Cornish a valuable resource. He has just left it as a senior vice president, associate creative director and has resurfaced almost immediately at Ketchum Advertising/New York as executive vice president, creative director.

title: Deadly Consistency on Guns
description: New York City Police Commissioner Robert McGuire recently announced that his department will conduct a media blitz next fall on the dangers of handguns. He should have started sooner, and focused on Albany, where the Legislature quietly passed a bill to limit his power over guns in the city. Governor Cuomo belatedly indicates an intention to veto the bill. Well he should.

title: JUSTICES, 5-4, VOID LIFE TERM AS TOO LONG FOR MINOR CRIME
description: The Supreme Court for the first time invalidated a prison sentence today on the ground that it was so long in relation to the crime that it violated the Constitution's prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment.

title: P.O.W.'S IN VIETNAM AREN'T RULED OUT
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that the United States had information that kept it from ruling out the possibility that some Americans captured during the Vietnam War are still alive.

title: More Backing For I.M.F. Plan
description: Six former Secretaries of the Treasury met with President Reagan today to encourage his continued support of adding $8.4 billion to this country's contribution to the International Monetary Fund. The measure, approved by the Senate, is awaiting action in the House.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said it had signed a four-year contract to supply the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with DMS-100 digital switching systems.

title: On Airbags: The Court Cries 'Shame'
description: ''Today was a very bad day for deregulators,'' one lawyer insisted after the Supreme Court rejected the Reagan Administration's attempt to dump a ''passive'' safety restraint rule for autos. It would be more accurate to say it was a bad day for regulators who ignore the will of Congress. The Court's stunning, unanimous ruling should signal a fresh start in the long-delayed effort to reduce traffic deaths with modern ''airbag'' technology.

title: MICHEL PETRUCCIANI, PIANIST FROM FRANCE
description: year-old French jazz pianist who was discovered by Charles Lloyd, made his local concert debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday as part of the jazz festival, having earned critical comparisons with Art Tatum, Bill Evans and Keith Jarrett in his recent West Coast concerts. Like his more famous forerunners, Mr. Petrucciani is an unabashed romantic who works in a predominantly chromatic style.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
GAINS IN AIR QUALITY ARE CITED
description: The Reagan Administration, in making public its second annual environmental assessment, said today that the nation's air was becoming much cleaner. Less progress, however, was calculated in water quality.

title: Jet Loses Tires Upon Landing After Kennedy-Florida Flight
description: A Delta Air Lines L-1011 blew its left-gear tires upon landing at Fort Lauderdale-Hollywood International Airport Monday night, but the jet was safely evacuated, officials said.

title: Siberian Deliverance
description: The Soviet Union says that 15 Pentecostals are emigrating from Siberia to Israel in accord ''with the established procedures for departure.'' But five of them spent nearly five years in the United States Embassy in Moscow precisely because they had so little faith in those procedures.

title: The U.N. Today; June 29, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Lesotho at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TRADE GAP A RECORD
description: The nation's foreign trade deficit surged to a single-month record of $6.9 billion in May, the Commerce Department said today. One department economist said the deficit for all of 1983 would probably top expectations.

title: KILLING 3
description: A 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge collapsed here early this morning, hurling four vehicles into the Mianus River, killing three people and critically injuring three others.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Help for Fellow Artists

title: Robintech Default
description: Robintech Inc. said it was experiencing ''serious cash shortages'' and would default on certain lender agreements on Friday.

title: FOES OF ABORTION BEATEN IN SENATE ON AMENDMENT BID
description: The Senate today rejected a constitutional amendment that would have set the stage for laws to curb abortions. The vote on the 10-word amendment, stating simply, ''A right to abortion is not secured by this Constitution,'' was 50 to 49, 18 short of the two-thirds majority required. Both houses of Congress must approve a constitutional amendment before it can be submitted to the states. For it to be added to the Constitution, three-quarters of the states must also approve it.

title: Effect of Lead
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Jeremiah Horrigan (''Kosher Flour Sales Keep Old Mill Alive,'' June l) mentions that one of the gristmill owner George Smith's customers, a rabbi supervising the grinding of kosher flour, noticed solder on the millstone and ''threatened to withdraw his business on the ground that the lead compromised the purity of the flour.''

title: AT THE O.A.U., A SENSE OF BELONGING
description: To the Editor:

Bond prices edged higher, erasing about half the losses incurred Monday, on renewed optimism that the Federal Reserve would not have to tighten credit availability in response to the growth in the economy. Also, a slight drop in the Federal funds rate encouraged buying.

title: BLOCK, H & R, INC reports earnings for year to April 30.
DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to June 4.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $4.8 million.

title: STATE AIDE ENDORSES CITY'S BUDGET
description: Approval of New York City's budget was recommended yesterday by the executive director of the State Financial Control Board, the city's fiscal monitor.

title: MITCH RYDER, FROM DETROIT TO FAME
description: MITCH RYDER recorded ''Devil With a Blue Dress On'' and ''Jenny Take a Ride'' back in the mid-1960's, and those hits, along with several others, made him king of the rock-and-roll screamers. Bruce Springsteen, Bob Seger, John Cougar and several other contemporary rock stars owe much of their style and stance to Mr. Ryder; they still remember the thrill they got the first time they heard those records. Mitch Ryder, who is 38 years old now, remembers some moments of his own.

title: WITH FLOWERS AND 'V'S,' A POLISH ANNIVERSARY PASSES QUIETLY
description: An official wreath-laying ceremony was held here today at the stark monument where supporters of the outlawed Solidarity union used to gather on this special day.

title: N.Y. Mortgage Agency Begins a New Offering
description: A $170 million bond issue for the New York State Mortgage Agency was tentatively priced yesterday by Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group with yields ranging from 5 3/4 to 9.95 percent. The sale will be held Thursday.

title: Greschner Signed
description: If Ron Greschner continues to remain sound, Ranger fans will see a lot more of him next season than they did in 1982-83.

title: TAUBMAN TO BUY OUT SOUTHEBY RIVALS
description: Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen C. Swid effectively agreed yesterday to end their takeover bid for Sotheby Parke Bernet and to sell their 29.9 percent interest in the financially troubled international auction house to A. Alfred Taubman, the ''white knight'' that Sotheby's hoped would win in the takeover battle.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Kitchen Tip From Koch It was the pre-Gracie Mansion gourmet cook reacting when a caller reached Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: CUOMO EXPECTS NEW BOND ISSUE TO REBUILD STATE
description: Governor Cuomo today vowed to campaign through the fall to ''rebuild New York'' through a $1.25 billion bond issue for highways, bridges, mass transit and waterways.

title: CLOSING FORCES THOUSANDS TO TAKE ALTERNATIVE ROADS
description: Today's bridge collapse here on the Connecticut Turnpike, one of the nation's busiest roads, forced tens of thousands of commuters, long-distance automobile travelers and truck drivers to seek alternative, sometimes unfamiliar, routes.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS BILL TO PROTECT COTTON FARMERS
description: A House Agriculture subcommittee today approved legislation that would require the Reagan Administration to spend about $100 million more than it planned to fulfill its obligation to cotton farmers under a program to reduce crop surpluses.

title: Chicago Dock
description: Shareholders of the Chicago Dock and Canal Trust approved a joint venture with the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States to develop a residential and commercial complex in Chicago projected to cost between $2 billion and $3 billion. The action completes a transaction announced last October.

title: Title Won By Favors
description: The world amateur bantamweight champion, Floyd Favors, easily fought off the challenge of Jesse Benavides in their National Sports Festival title bout tonight, but Steve McCrory, the world champ in the flyweight division, suffered yet another loss to Todd Hickman.

title: Downpours Snarl Traffic in City
description: Heavy downpours at various times yesterday caused some flooding and major traffic tie-ups throughout the city and metropolitan area.

title: Correction
description: Bernard D. Davis's article on genetic engineering yesterday contained a reference to ''our inner nature - our cells or souls.'' It should have read ''our selves or souls.''

title: FEDDERS DENIES KNOWLEDGE OF PURPORTED BRIBERY
description: John M. Fedders, enforcement chief for the Securities and Exchange Commission, denied today that he had any knowledge of a purported bribery scheme involving the Southland Corporation and one of its top executives. It was his first public statement on the case.

title: TIME TO VOTE: THE SOUND AND THE FURY
description: Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a liberal Democrat from Queens, astounded his colleagues recently when he voted in favor of funds for the MX missile.

title: Books of The Times
description: <TD WIDTH=2

title: Colorado River Closed To Tourist Boat Travel
description: Officials at Grand Canyon National Park, citing heavy water discharges from Glen Canyon Dam upstream, closed the Colorado River to boats today.

title: RICH-POOR SPLIT AT U.N. TALKS DEEPER
description: The rich and poor nations attending a United Nations conference on their economic differences appeared tonight to be preparing to issue separate declarations that underscored their differences.

title: Yankees Are Rained Out
description: For the second time in nine days, rain last night washed out a game between the Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles, this one at Yankee Stadium. The teams also were rained out in Baltimore June 20.

title: DOG RACES: WIN, PLACE AND SHOW OFF
description: There is something very endearing about a dog that is one foot high, approaches life like a rhinoceros on amphetamines and hates rats. The Jack Russell terriers obviously do not realize they are merely dogs. How else could they take themselves so seriously?

title: By POLES' HISTORIC PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Careers; New Focus On Factory Engineers
description: MANUFACTURING engineering offers an important career path to many kinds of engineers these days, regardless of whether their fields may be electrical, computer, mechanical, robotic or chemical engineering.

title: FINANCE NEW ISSUES
description: Consolidated Edison Company of New York Inc. said yesterday that its board of directors had approved a plan under which it could begin to repurchase up to $250 million of its outstanding common stock in the open market beginning in 1985, if necessary.

title: A SHOWCASE FOR FANCY FOODS
description: ''It's all hand made in real small batches,'' shouted a salesman from one of the 1,300 booths at the 29th annual International Fancy Food and Confection Show being held in this city for the first time. The event, which takes place every second year in New York and changes location in the other years, is sponsored by the National Association for the Specialty Food Trade.

title: IN PAKISTAN, AN AFGHAN PEEPHOLE
description: For centuries, travelers on their way to India from Afghanistan, Persia and points beyond have stopped in this rough-cut frontier outpost lying astride ancient routes of trade and conquest that snake through the Khyber Pass, 25 miles west of here on the Afghan border. And for centuries they have gravitated to the street of the storytellers in the Old City's main bazaar to swap tales, both true and fanciful, about faraway places and events.

title: Koch Cites Crisis In Mental Health
description: Mayor Koch, saying that New York City has a ''real and growing crisis'' in mental health care, yesterday urged Governor Cuomo to overhaul the way the state and city deal with the mentally disabled.

title: Sting Withdraws
description: The Chicago Sting announced today it had terminated membership in the Major Indoor Soccer League and would participate in the North American Soccer League indoor and outdoor schedule.

title: LATIN NOMINEE CLEARS A HURDLE
description: Langhorne A. Motley, counseling United States patience in Central America, won unanimous approval from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as the senior official dealing with Latin American affairs in the State Department.

title: ACTORS EQUITY AND PRODUCERS REACH TENTATIVE AGREEMENT
description: Negotiators for Actors Equity and the League of New York Theaters and Producers have reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract for actors on Broadway and in touring shows.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOW STOPPERS

title: AMERICAN FURNITURE CO reports earnings for qtr to June 4.

SCOUTING;
Off-Ice Demands
description: For the last 10 summers, those members of the Islanders who make permanent homes on Long Island have generously attempted to transfer their skills on ice to softball diamonds, playing many of the games for the benefit of charitable causes.

title: OSCAR PETERSON PLAYS HIS MAINSTREAM PIANO
description: IN Oscar Peterson's two-and-a-half-hour Carnegie Hall concert Monday, part of the Kool Jazz Festival, the giant of mainstream jazz piano performed in three different contexts - as a soloist, in duets with the vibes player Milt Jackson, and finally, with his trio.

title: Baldwin Cites Move on Assets
description: Holders of $100 million in debentures issued by the Baldwin-Unitd Corporation have tried to assert claims to Baldwin assets that could be used as collateral for their unsecured debt, Baldwin officials said yesterday.

title: FEW SURPRISES IN N.B.A. DRAFT
description: Last season, the Houston Rockets lost the most gifted player in the franchise's history, Moses Malone, and won only 14 games, the fewest in the National Basketball Association. Yesterday, their futility helped bring them the most coveted player in the 1983 college draft - Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch center from the University of Virginia.

title: A BAG, SWEATERS, CAT AT THE DOOR; 1. Bags in Creel Shape
description: A fisherman's creel was the inspiration for casual summer bags from Italy. With webbing shoulder straps and outside pockets of natural canvas, the sturdy basket bags come in green, pink, yellow, orange or natural. In two sizes - $62 and $75 - at Maraolo, 782 Lexington Avenue (62d Street).

title: Q&A
description: Q. It seems to be quite fashionable these days to refer to small eating places as butteries. Where does the name derive?

title: NEW CLUES REPORTED ON POLLUTANT-ACID RAIN RATIO
description: New clues to the quantifiable nature of acid rain have been revealed at an International Colloquium on Acid Precipitation in Lindau, West Germany.

title: On Creme Anglaise
description: TO THE LIVINGSECTION: In ''One Cook's Guide: Savoring the Harvest of Summer Berries'' (June 8) Robert Farrar Capon writes of ''berries folded into a mixture of half creme Anglaise and half whipped cream, which may be either why the British Empire isn't what it used to be, or why it still survives''

title: Arkansas Guard Knicks' Top Choice
description: The Knicks used only two of their allotted five minutes yesterday to choose the guard that they had hoped for, but did not expect would still be available in the National Basketball Association college draft.

title: Seafirst Merger Backed
description: Shareholders of the Seafirst Corporation today approved a merger of the troubled bank holding company with the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS SAID TO PLAN 5,000-MAN OFFENSIVE
description: The anti-Sandinista rebel force based in Honduras is planning to send 5,000 men on a major offensive into Nicaragua, according to one of its leaders.

title: SOVIET BLOC SESSION DOES NOT ISSUE EXPECTEDD THREAT ON NEW MISSILES
description: Leaders of the Soviet bloc ended a meeting in Moscow today without issuing a threat, which had been expected, to retaliate for the deployment of new American nuclear missiles in Western Europe.

title: F.A.A. UNVEILS TECHNIQUES TO TAME AIRLINER FIRES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration staged a technological magic show today to rebut criticism that it has been laggard in developing better ways to protect airliners' cabins against fire hazards.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN it comes to naming foods and dishes, French cooks have always allowed themselves a playful imagination. There is a group of dishes, for example, called macedoines, consisting of chopped assorted fruits or vegetables combined and served together. The name derives from Macedonia, whose population comprises a mixture of peoples.

title: Royal Plans to Sell Its Banks in Florida
description: Royal Trustco Ltd. of Canada said today that it would sell its Florida banking operations to Florida National Banks of Jacksonville for $80 million.

title: P.L.O. INSURGENTS STEPPING UP THEIR ATTACKS
description: Palestinian rebels opposed to Yasir Arafat attacked troops loyal to him today in what appeared to be the start of a step-by-step campaign to take control of all Palestinian forces in Lebanon.

title: Economic Scene; Heavy Burden Of Big Deficits
description: THE biggest worry hanging over the securities markets is the surging Federal budget. The deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30, is now estimated by the Reagan Administration at $210.2 billion, with off-budget outlays lifting the total deficit to $227 billion, or 6.5 percent of gross national product. Unless drastic action is taken, deficits in the over-$200-billion class are looming through the next four fiscal years, even if the recovery continues.

title: Great Serves Carry Lendl To Victory
description: Everyone knew about Rosoe Tanner's grass court game and his monstrous southpaw serve. He reached the 1979 Wimbledon singles final before losing to Bjorn Borg and had served his way past Mats Wilander in the third round of this year's tournament. But it was Ivan Lendl's serve during a marathon 20-point game in the opening set that settled their quarterfinal round match today.

title: Teachers' Unit Asks Rise in Pay
description: Salaries are so low in American schools that all 2.1 million teachers need raises and more than half deserve merit pay as well, a leader of the National Education Association said today.

title: Midtown Gift Store Is Closed by City
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has temporarily closed a midtown gift and electronics store for violations of consumer protection laws, the department said yesterday.

title: NEXT DOME CHIEF: A FINANCIER
description: Today's annual meeting of Dome Petroleum Ltd. here marked the end of an era for the company that John P. Gallagher built into one of Canada's top oil and gas producers.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
PAINFUL SURPLUS FOR MEXICANS
description: Mexico's international finances have strengthened this year, but much of the improvement comes from the continuing decay of its economy and a dramatic plunge in the standard of living of its workers, according to analysts here.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I heard a loud noise, and I thought it was a clap of thunder.

title: PRESIDENT TERMS FREE UNIONS KEY TO AID TO POLES
description: President Reagan said tonight that if Polish authorities allowed a revival of free trade unions in Poland the United States would ''turn back'' some of the sanctions imposed when martial law was declared in 1981.

title: ONORATO, DEMOCRAT, TAKESSENATE RACE IN A QUEENS DISTRICT
description: George Onorato, a 54-year-old Democratic district leader and trade union official, won a seat in the State Senate yesterday in a special election in Queens.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
description: b-Net loss

title: Warm Welcome in Israel For 15 Pentecostals
description: A family of 15 Siberian Pentecostal Christians, who spent five years in the American Embassy basement in Moscow as part of a two-decade struggle to leave for the

title: MARION MONROE, AUTHOR, DIES AT 85
description: Marion Monroe, a child psychologist who was a co-author of the ''Dick, Jane and Sally'' school books that introduced millions of Americans to reading, died Saturday, a spokesman said today. She was 85 years old.

title: 20.24 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,209.23
description: The New York Stock Exchange suffered its worst decline in almost two months yesterday as fears continued to mount of a resurgence in interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 20.24 points, to 1,209.23, the biggest drop since May 2.

title: Soviet Chess Group Protests Choice of Sites for Semifinals
description: The Soviet Chess Federation lodged a formal protest today with the International Chess Federation for deciding to hold the men's world championship semifinals in the United States and the United Arab Emirates.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS COFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT

title: SENATE'S ROLL-CALL ON ABORTION PLAN
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today rejected a proposed constitutional amendment that would have allowed Congress and the states to ban or restrict abortions. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, an abortion foe, voted ''present.''

title: RECIPES FOR MORELS, ENOKIS, SHIITAKES
description: Grilled Shiitake (Oak Mushrooms) 12 large fresh shiitake mushrooms 3 tablespoons light soy sauce 3 tablespoons lemon juice 2 teaspoons mirin (see note) 2 teaspoons finely chopped scallions 1/4 teaspoon Japanese powdered chili mixture (hichimi togarashi) or more to taste.

title: ELLIS MARSALIS'S SOLO PIANO
description: ELLIS MARSALIS'S hourlong solo piano concert Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall alternated between original compositions and jazz standards like ''Caravan'' and Fats Waller's ''Jitterbug Waltz.'' Mr. Marsalis, who is based in New Orleans, treated each piece more as a piano composition than a vehicle for jazz improvisation. The post-impressionistic harmonic idiom that informed most of the arrangements recalled both George Gershwin and Erik Satie.

title: MRS. KING GAINS SEMIFINALS
description: Billie Jean King reached the singles semifinals at Wimbledon today for the 14th time, and Ivan Lendl made it for the first time.

title: The Polish Question
description: The Polish pilgrimage that began with exclamation points has ended with question marks.

title: 'Dry Sack' Trademark
description: Williams & Humbert Ltd., the British subsidiary of Rumasa-Ruiz Mateos S.A., said it had agreed to the appointment of a receiver of the British ''Dry Sack'' sherry trademarks. The company said the move would allow the property to be held in neutral hands pending a judicial action to determine the ownership of the trademarks.

title: HOW BRIDGES ARE INSPECTED AND WHAT IS BEING DONE TO MAKE THEM SAFER
description: The sudden collapse of a section of a bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike here today raises questions about the condition of Connecticut's bridges and highways and how the state inspects them for potential safety hazards.

title: Texas Adopts a Law To Avoid Cattle Boycott
description: Gov. Mark White has signed into law a compromise bill on the threat of brucellosis to the state's cattle industry that he said would end the threat of a Federal quarantine on Texas cattle.

title: EMERSON RADIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIRST U.S. ADVOCATE OF A NUCLEAR ARMS FREEZE
description: To the Editor:

title: Race Car Driver Denies Shooting
description: John Paul Sr., a two-time world endurance driving champion who turned himself in to the police Monday, pleaded not guilty today to charges of attempted murder of a Federal witness.

title: SAFETY OF NEW CONTRACEPTIVE SPONGE IS QUESTIONED
description: A New York Congressman has raised questions about the safety of a synthetic sponge approved April 1 for use as a contraceptive, but the Government and the manufacturer respond that they still consider the product to be safe.

title: PUBLIC RADIO STATIONS BACKING NETWORK AID PLAN
description: The president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting said today that initial indications were that public radio stations were overwhelmingly endorsing a plan to keep the debt-ridden National Public Radio in operation.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cat's Ascent From Rubble To the Broadway Stage

title: PRETORIA EXTENDS BAN ON MRS. MANDELA
description: The black nationalist Winnie Mandela was handed an order today extending her banishment to a small farming community about 200 miles south of here for another five years.

title: REPORT URGES TRANSFER OF INMATES TO L.I. PRISON CUOMO WANTS SHUT
description: A draft of a court-ordered report recommends that some inmates at the crowded Nassau County Jail be transferred to the state prison on the grounds of the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in Brentwood, L.I. The report, by David K. Kadane, a professor of law at Hofstra University, was made public today by the county.

title: SELECTING A DESK FOR A COMPUTER
description: THEY stand on snack tables, card tables, coffee tables. Home computers are often plunked wherever it is handy. But unless you are a champion gymnast, such improvised arrangements for work at a video display terminal usually turn out to be uncomfortable and fatiguing.

title: Fire Interrupts Power Service In Much of Downtown Miami
description: A fire at an electric substation knocked out power in four square miles of downtown Miami and outlying areas at rush-hour today, officials said.

title: A NUCLEAR WEAPON SHORT OF 'INTOLERABLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPANDING CONTRACTS WITH SOVIET: SHULTZ AND DOBRYNIN MAKE A START
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, have met privately almost a dozen times since the beginning of the year, and top Administration officials say President Reagan is now considering whether to broaden the contacts and press to meet with Yuri V. Andropov.

title: CUOMO VETOES RESTRICTION ON LOCAL GUN LAWS
description: A bill that would have curbed New York City's power to regulate handguns was vetoed yesterday by Governor Cuomo. ''I want to discourage the profligate use of weapons,'' Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference at the World Trade Center. ''The fewer weapons the better.''

title: Accounts
description: * The Denver Post to the Richards Group, Dallas.

title: STAFF BUILDERS INC (NY) reports earnings for qtr to May 27.
The U.N. Today; June 30, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: SELECTIVE SERVICE CITING 70,000 FOR NOT REGISTERING
description: The Selective Service System plans to send the Justice Department the names of 70,000 young men for possible prosecution for failing to register for potential military conscription, Selective Service officials said today.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for year to March 31.
IN STERLING, ELEGANCE ENDURES AS TASTES CHANGE
description: these names conjure up the courts of Europe. In America they designate the bestselling classic designs in sterling-silver flatware, which have endured for generations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST; The Economy
description: The Republican-controlled Senate defeated a bill that would have limited each taxpayer to a maximum of $720 in tax reduction under the 10 percent tax-rate cut that takes effect on Friday. The House had approved such a ceiling despite President Reagan's promise to veto any limit on the third year of his reduction in income tax rates. (Page A1.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IMAGES OF THE CITY

title: Warner in Talks On Music Venture
description: Warner Communications Inc. said it was discussing joint ventures in recorded music with two European companies, N.V. Philips Gloeilampenfabrieken of the Netherlands, and Siemens A.G. of Berlin.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS RELEASE AFTER SUCCESSFUL PLEA ON INSANITY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the length of a possible prison sentence is irrelevant to the length of time a person who successfully pleads not guilty by reason of insanity can be held in a mental hospital.

title: THE 'LEGISLATIVE VETO'-NOW THAT IT'S GONE
description: The United States Supreme Court's crucial role rarely has been more dramatically illustrated than by its decision last week striking down the so-called legislative veto, under which Congress could annul executive action by simple resolution. At one stroke, the Court cast more than 200 laws containing legislative veto provisions into legal limbo. According to the Court, the Constitution requires that all legislation be presented to the President for his signature or veto and does not permit Congress to enact what amounts to veto-proof ''legislation'' that infringes upon the President's authority and thus violates the separation of powers.

title: HERS
description: IT'S been a long time since I last saw a grandmother wearing a gold charm bracelet that dangled fobs engraved with name, date of birth and, for all I know, weight at birth for each grandchild. Perhaps it went out with the black Persian lamb coat. It's even possible that grandmothers aren't buying grandmotherhood with the fervor of yore. Maybe they've found other things to be.

title: TV: 'INSIDE STORY' LOOKS AT THREE PAPERS
description: ''INSIDE STORY,'' the public-television series that examines both print and electronic journalism, ends its season tonight by once again doing what it has been doing awfully well all along: getting a substantial amount of content into a half-hour program. The episode tonight has three segments. All are about print journalism; all involve particular cases; all touch on larger issues. The program will be seen on WNET-TV, Channel 13, at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Bridge: Crane Picked Up the Pace For the Players at the Top
description: The first player to achieve a total of 10,000 master points was Oswald Jacoby of Dallas. When he reached that mark in 1967, it had taken him slightly more than 30 years to do so. But for the players at the top of the rankings the pace then accelerated.

title: How to Catch Fish Using Light Tackle
description: A lmost inevitably, an angler wishing to increase his skill and his enjoyment of the sport will turn to lighter tackle.
