The phrase light-tackle angling is fuzzy; 30-pound test line could be considered light for the broadbill swordfish, which can weigh over half a ton, but it would be grossly heavy for yellow perch, which rarely go over a pound.

title: End of Trail for Fidrych
description: Mark (the Bird) Fidrych, the American League rookie of the year in 1976, retired from baseball yesterday, ending a two-year comeback struggle in the minor leagues. The former Detroit Tiger right-hander left the Boston Red Sox' Pawtucket, R.I., farm team rather than face an anticipated cut to make room for a pitcher coming off the disabled list.

title: PRESIDENT, ON WAY WEST, PRESSES EDUCATION DRIVE
description: President Reagan, taking his campaign on education issues to a Kentucky vocational arts fair and a suburban high school in Kansas, said today that the solution to the crisis in the country's schools could be found far from Washington.

title: TV Deregulation Plan Proposed by the F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission today proposed allowing television stations to make their own decisions on how much news and advertising they present.

title: HOUSE MOVES TO RECOUP ON LOST VETO
description: The House tonight adopted two sweeping restrictions on the powers of the Consumer Product Safety Commission in an effort to regain the authority it lost when the Supreme Court struck down Congress's veto over certain executive actions.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for year to March 31.
INVOLVE SYRIA IN PEACE
description: For the past year, the Reagan Administration has centered its Middle East policy on two objectives: first, removing all foreign forces from Lebanon and strengthening its central Government, and, second, resuming negotiations on the future of the West Bank and Gaza with Jordan in the starring role. Neither goal is at hand - in large measure because Syria has stood in the way.

title: WHO MAY RUN FOR PRESIDENT: A PROPOSED CHANGE
description: Neither Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser in the Carter Administration, nor former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, much as he might wish otherwise, is eligible for the Presidency.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including gains from the sale of real estate investments of $195,000 for the quarter and $369,000 for the 6 months. c-Including gains from the sale of real estate investments of $50,000 for the quarter and $199,000 for the 6 months.

title: Back on the Ice
description: Wearing shorts and a T-shirt, Mike Eruzione looked like a normal Colorado Springs summer tourist at first glance - until a further look, down past his bare knees, showed he was also wearing his bulky, black hockey skates.

title: BIG TEACHER UNION IS WILLING TO DISCUSS MERIT PAY PLANS
description: The National Education Association, which has been intensely criticized by President Reagan for what he characterized as inflexibility on merit pay, has opened the door to possibly approving such an approach to teacher salaries.

title: CORRECTION
description: A map in Metropolitan Report on June 22 with an article about downtown Brooklyn incorrectly depicted the boundaries for proposed housing and the extent to which the land would be developed. Housing has been recommended only for parking lots or vacant parcels in the area bounded by Boerum Place, Flatbush Avenue, Atlantic Avenue and Livingston Street.

title: INTERMETRICS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
STARS IN SALUTE TO COLEMAN HAWKINS
description: COLEMAN HAWKINS was always a hard act to follow and, though he died in 1969, on Tuesday evening his filmed image was still challenging all comers at the Kool Jazz Festival salute to him, ''The Body and Soul of the Tenor Saxophone,'' in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
5 More Labor Leaders Exiled to Chile's South
description: Chile's military Government today sent five more people into internal exile, bringing to 10 the number of anti-Government labor leaders banished to the wintry south in the last few days.

title: ALLERTON D. TOMPKINS
description: Allerton de C. Tompkins, a partner in the law firm of Tompkins & Davidson in New York City, died of cancer Tuesday Tuesday at his home in Worthington, Mass. was 76 years old.

title: A.H. Belo to Sell Two TV Stations
description: To satisfy Federal Communiciations Commission rules on multiple ownership, the A.H. Belo Corporation, of Dallas, has decided to sell two of its stations, KFDM-TV in Beaumont, Tex., and WTVC-TV in Chattanooga, Tenn., as well as WISH-TV (Indianapolis, Ind.), a station it is about to buy from the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: Required Reading Bush's Batting Average

title: ON AIR-CONDITIONERS IN LANDMARK AREAS
description: WITH temperatures high, tempers have been rising in some historic districts in Manhattan as residents have learned that they are not permitted to install air-conditioners through the walls of their apartments without permission from the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: Advertising; Parade Extends Penetration
description: OF all the publications that should have been in an ideal position to take advantage of any erosion of television network audiences, Parade, the Sunday newspaper supplement, should have been the one. Getting into more than 22 million homes a week is just the kind of mass reach that broadcasters love to use for their sales pitch.

title: CUMO RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $278,719 for the latest year and $362,745 for the previous year.

title: DEVELCON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about purloined Carter campaign documents misidentified the source of the book shown. It was made available to the White House this week by Patrick H. Caddell, a Carter aide.

title: RULING TOUCHES OFF NEW DEBATE ON PROSPECTS OF TUITION TAX CREDIT
description: Supporters and opponents of President Reagan's proposal to give tax relief to the parents of children in private schools disagreed sharply over whether today's Supreme Court decision would improve the chances for Congressional approval of the legislation.

title: MATURE PLANTINGS TRANSFORM A CITY YARD
description: GARDENERS may be famous for their patience, but there is nothing as delightful as instant gratification: a garden completed in two days. That is what happened when Signe Nielsen, a Manhattan landscape architect, designed a 25-by-20-foot terraced yard and had it planted with mature trees and shrubs.

title: Norwegians Fire At a Suspected Sub
description: A navy frigate fired six missiles today in a hunt for what was thought to be an unidentified submarine in a fjord in northern Norway, a military spokesman said.

title: DODGERS' HOWE FINED $54,000
description: Steve Howe, the Los Angeles Dodger relief pitcher who has been treated twice because of a drug problem, has been fined one month's pay, about $54,000.

title: Bell Expands Its Data System
description: The American Bell division of American Telephone and Telegraph announced an expanded version of its office information system, used by relatively large offices to transmit voice and data messages.

title: FOR THE 4TH: GAS PRICES STABILIZING
description: With the prospect of a long weekend certain to draw millions of motorists to local roads for the long Fourth of July weekend, officials said that gasoline prices in the metropolitan area were lower than they were a year ago and that the prices in New Jersey were the nation's lowest.

title: IN AN UPSTATE CITY COURT, A FEELING OF QUIET, EFFICIENT JUSTICE
description: City Court in this quiet upstate community sometimes looks very much like Criminal Court in New York City. The Public Defender meets his clients for the first time in the courtroom. Much of the judicial action takes place briskly before the bench. And the prosecutor is amenable to ''down charging'' for first offenders.

title: COAST UTILITY TELLS OF SAFETY DEFECT IN ATOMIC PLANT
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has notified the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of defective welding in the cooling system piping of its Diablo Canyon nuclear plant, the reactor's primary safety system against a nuclear accident.

title: Detroit Orders a Curfew To Avert Youth Crime
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young, warning that ''we will nail'' violent youths, said today the city would, for the first time in eight years, enforce a curfew on teen-agers in an attempt to crack down on crime.

title: Polish Party Paper Scolds Writers' Union
description: Poland's Communist Party newspaper denounced Poland's suspended writers' union today, charging that prominent literary figures had helped provoke the upheaval that gave birth to Solidarity.

title: Couple on Target
description: Amateur psychologists often say that husbands and wives who spend their working time as well as their leisure time together create a marriage risk. Jerry and Eileen Pylypchuk of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, members of the United States national archery team, disagree.

title: Largest Quake Felt In San Diego County
description: The largest earthquake to strike San Diego County shook people out of bed and objects off shelves, made a water heater explode and burst some pipes early today, but no injuries were reported.

title: Japan Tilts West
description: The modest electoral gains of Japan's Liberal Democratic Party appear to strengthen the energetic Prime Minister, Yasuhiro Nakasone, and that is good news for the Western allies.

title: WHAT O.M.B. ASKED OF THE CIVIL RIGHTS PANEL
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: THREE IMPROVISERS
description: GEORGE CARTWRIGHT, Michael Lytle and David Moss offered an amusing and original program of improvised music at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation last Friday night. This trio, based in lower Manhattan, revels in the offbeat: over the course of the evening, saxophones were played backward - the performer's face buried in the instrument's bell -groans and gurgles were amplified through a glass of water and broken records skipped and clattered in a jumble of sound.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Police Add 4 Launches

title: EXCERPTS FROM COURT'S RULING ON MINNESOTA TAX LAW ON SCHOOL EXPENSE
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision today upholding Minnesota's tuition tax deduction plan: From the Opinion By Justice Rehnquist

title: Susan Perl, Artist, Dies at 60; Illustrations Widely Published
description: Susan Perl, an illustrator, died of kidney failure Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Rotan Mosle Link Set
description: Paine Webber Inc. and the Rotan Mosle Financial Corporation said yesterday that they had executed a definitive agreement to merge Rotan Mosle and a subsidiary of Paine Webber.

title: Refundable Bottles May Appear Early
description: While beer and soft-drink containers need not require a nickel deposit in New York State until September, the first of the new refundable bottles and cans may appear on shelves as early as tomorrow, according to the New York City Department of Sanitation.

title: G.O.P. Presidential Bid
description: Benjamin Fernandez, a Los Angeles businessman, announced today that he was a candidate for the 1984 Republican Presidential nomination. He said he would to do better than he did in 1980, when he spent $180,000 campaigning in 18 primaries and won three delegates to the Republican nominating convention. Mr. Fernandez was a fund raiser for Richard M. Nixon in 1972.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IN keeping with steady demand, many new or improved tools and other home-improvement and repair products have been introduced in recent months. Here are some of particular interest. Compact Bandsaw

title: Clergymen Urge Drug Crackdown
description: A group of Brooklyn clergymen charged at a demonstration yesterday that District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman had not vigorously prosecuted so-called smoke shops that sell illegal drugs.

title: Technology; Bubble Policy: Pros and Cons
description: SINCE 1979, when the Environmental Protection Agency adopted its ''bubble'' policy, a number of companies have avoided costly changes at their plants to meet air quality standards. While the economic advantages to private companies are clear, not everyone is pleased with the way the policy is being applied.

title: RITE-AID reports earnings for qtr to May 28.
A Hostage in the Sudan Flies on Brief Errand
description: Rebels holding five aid workers hostage in the southern Sudan have allowed one of the captives to fly a wounded woman to Kenya and threatened to kill the others if he does not return, diplomats said today.

title: Father Held in Killing of Baby
description: A veterinarian watched the birth of his deformed son and less than half an hour later seized the baby and smashed his head against the delivery room floor, the authorities have charged.

title: A NEW KIND OF SECRET
description: If the Secretary of Energy has his way, millions of documents in libraries around the country - books and papers on nuclear matters, long available to the public - could become official secrets. A librarian who circulates one, not even knowing of its new status, would be subject to a fine of up to $100,000.

title: TELLING A STORY: THE ART TAKES PRACTICE
description: and the 150 or so characters they portrayed - stood in the garden behind Miss Simms, talking to planters and trees, feathers and fences. One told a blade of grass the myth of Persephone and Demeter, while another rendered a Haitian folk tale to a large rock.

title: BANKS RESCHEDULE PART OF MEXICO'S PRIVATE DEBT
description: Mexico's Finance Ministry announced today an agreement to reschedule about $2 billion of the $14 billion debt owed by private Mexican businesses to foreign creditors. Under the plan, some payments would be delayed as much as six years.

title: A Dutch Town Votes To Ban Cruise Missiles
description: The possible placement of cruise missiles at a base near this southern Dutch town has been rejected by the Woensdrecht municipal council.

title: Key Rates
18 Injured as Tornado Hits Burlington, Iowa
description: A tornado hit this Mississippi River city as many residents were sitting down to lunch today.

title: FOLK-ROCK: STEVIE NICKS
description: WHEN Stevie Nicks, the high priestess of Southern California rock, appeared at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, one was reminded of how quickly pop trends come and go. In the age of synthesizer pop and of a tougher post-punk stance among female rockers, Miss Nicks is something of an anachronism.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,879,219 from debt restructuring. c-Including a gain of $6 million on the sale of assets.

title: CALENDAR: CARNIVAL AND CRAFTS
description: African Street Carnival, 1700 Fulton Street at Utica Avenue, Brooklyn. 212-789-1459.

title: Plumber Guilty In Drug Trial
description: A Federal jury today convicted John Schultz, a Cincinnati plumber, of 20 counts of drug trafficking, including cocaine sales to two Cincinnati Bengals - Pete Johnson and Ross Browner.

title: Head of Actuarial Firm Adds Role of Chairman
description: James A. Curtis has added the post of chairman to the titles of president and chief executive that he currently holds at Milliman & Robertson Inc. of Seattle, the nation's sixth-largest consulting actuarial firm. He replaces Stuart A. Robertson, who is retiring from active management at the firm's mandatory retirement age of 65.

title: RHODES SCHOLARSHIP PARTY IS A DISTINGUISHED BASH
description: It was one of those occasions when the great and the near-great were quite happy to be ordinary. More than 750 former Rhodes scholars gathered Monday afternoon in the leafy garden of Wadham College at Oxford University, most of them with their spouses, waiting patiently for more than an hour beneath a lowering sky. Through the crowd snaked a broad path, marked out by ropes against which the more eager guests pressed.

title: William W. Caudill Dies at 69; Houston Architect and Author
description: William W. Caudill, an architect, educator and author, died at his home in Houston on June 25.

title: ARCHITECT OF MEXICO OIL BOOM NAMED IN FRAUD
description: In a dramatic step-up of its campaign against official corruption, the Mexican Government charged the former head of Petroleos Mexicanos tonight with defrauding the state oil monopoly of $34 million during the last administration.

title: ARAFAT LOYALISTS RETREAT IN BEKAA UNDER PRESSURE FROM REBEL FORCES
description: Guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat are retreating northward from the central Bekaa under pressure from rebels opposed to the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Looking Beyond A Football Field
description: Eddie Robinson may have more victories than any other active college football coach, but he seems concerned about more than piling up victories with his Grambling Tigers every weekend in the fall.

title: HOME SALES ROSE 4.3% IN MAY
description: Sales of new single-family houses climbed by 4.3 percent in May, reaching their highest level in nearly three years, the Government reported today.

title: Creamer Fills Position
description: A former Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn man, Joseph M. McNeil, is returning to New York, the scene of former triumphs, to take over the creative helm of Creamer/New York as an executive vice president. He fills a spot that has been open since the departure of Peter Lubalin, who left for Doyle Dane Bernbach last month. Mr. McNeil, 45 years old, has been senior vice president and creative director of Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis. Before joining B.B.D.O., where he worked on Pepsi-Cola assignments, he worked at N.W. Ayer and Campbell-Ewald.

title: CARING FOR LAWNS: MISTAKES TO AVOID
description: A university professor whose academic turf includes yard care says most American lawns are grown too green, chopped too short and choked by weeds and disease.

title: COMMON MARKET SPLIT ON MORE S.D.R.'S
description: The European Economic Community is deeply divided over a proposal for the International Monetary Fund to increase the supply of world financial reserves through a major new issue of special drawing rights.

title: GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 28.

CREDIT MARKETS;
Funds Rate Stays Below 9%
description: The second day of a Federal funds rate below 9 percent lessened market apprehension yesterday about a tight Federal Reserve policy and prompted lower interest rates on United States Government securities. Trading activity, however, continued to be moderate, with minimal interest from institutional investors.

title: Brakettes Lose In Festival Final
description: Tracy Compton pitched a fourhitter and the Glomati Blazers of Sepulveda, Calif., capitalized on shoddy fielding by the Raybestos Brakettes for a 3-2 victory tonight in the championship game of the women's softball tournament at the National Sports Festival.

title: CANCER GENE LINKED TO NATURAL HUMAN SUBSTANCE
description: For the first time, a close similarity has been discovered between a cancer gene and a natural substance that has a known function in the human body.

title: Carolina Housing Issue at 6% to 9 7/8%
description: A $45.8 million bond issue for the North Carolina Housing Finance Agency was tenatively priced by Salomon Brothers with yields ranging from 6 percent to 9 7/8 percent.

title: DANCE: JACOB'S PILLOW FESTIVAL OPENS
description: Dance and music spilled out across the grounds of Jacob's Pillow as that venerable little summer dance festival and school celebrated the opening of its 51st season Tuesday. Drums sounded across the wooded campus as the Art of Black Dance and Music, a company from Boston, made its way through the chill late afternoon to a studio to perform.

title: Dispute Over Gloves
description: The gloves with which Luis Resto outpointed previously undefeated Billy Collins Jr. in a 10-round fight June 16 at Madison Square Garden each had about an ounce of horsehair padding removed, according to a report from the New York State Police Laboratory at Newburgh. ''We have scientific proof that the gloves were tampered with,'' said Jack Prenderville, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, which conducted a two-hour hearing yesterday on the fight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Return Visit to U.S.

title: DEMOCRATS DEFEAT G.O.P. INQUIRY MOVE
description: The Democratic-controlled House of Representatives today rejected a Republican proposal for a special committee to investigate allegations that official committee transcripts were altered.

title: HERCULES, SIMMONDS SET MERGER
description: Hercules Inc., a major manufacturer of plastics, fibers, aerospace and military-related products, has agreed to acquire Simmonds Precision Products Inc. in an exchange of stock valued at $325 million, the companies announced yesterday.

title: U.S., 2 Banks Sue J. Butcher
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and two Tennessee banks sued today to force Jake F. Butcher into bankruptcy, claiming that the financier and former Tennessee banker owes them more than $12.8 million.

title: MCRAE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
SHULTZ SEES P.L.O. FOLLOWING LEAD OF SYRIANS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Syria's expulsion last week of Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, probably increased the chances that guerrilla forces would leave Lebanon if Syria withdrew its troops.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Barnett Banks of Florida Inc.'s Netherlands Antilles subsidiary, Barnett Overseas Finance N.V., is issuing $30 million of convertible Eurobonds due in 1998 through Shearson/American Express International Group; prices for the bonds, which are guaranteed on a subordinated basis by the parent company, are to be set next week. Common Stock

title: Life Insurance Changes Judge's Mind on Sentence
description: A judge today revoked the work-release sentence he had given to a man who killed his wife, saying he changed his mind after learning that the woman left $82,000 in life insurance.

title: G.O.P. Political Aide Replaced
description: Richard N. Bond submitted his resignation today as political director of the Republican National Committee, and Linden H. Kettlewell, an associate of Senator Paul Laxalt, Republican of Nevada, was appointed to succeed him. Mr. Bond's resignation is effective Sept. 1.

title: COMMODITIES FUTURES COMMISSION NOMINEES
description: Susan M. Phillips, acting chairman of the Commodities Futures Trading Commission since May 1, has been nominated by President Reagan to become chairman. If the Senate approves the nomination, which was tendered last Thursday, Miss Phillips, a 38-year-old economist, would become the first woman to head a Federal financial regulatory agency.

title: Kenya Cabinet Official Faces An Inquiry on 'Irregularities'
description: President Daniel arap Moi suspended one of the most powerful members of his Cabinet today. Mr. Moi ordered the Constitutional Affairs Minister, Charles Njonjo, suspended pending a judicial inquiry into ''serious irregularities'' alleged against him. Mr. Njonjo was once considered part of a governing triumvirate with the President.

title: HOW TO HELP PEOPLE BECOME HOMEOWNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: State Dormitory Issue Priced at 6% to 10.17%
description: The $21.3 million New York State Dormitory Authority issue for the City University was tentatively priced yesterday by Salomon Brothers with yields ranging from 6 percent to 10.17 percent.

title: 'A SALUTE TO SWING ERA'
description: MEL TORME'S fearless use of his multitude of talents brought a unique personal quality to ''A Salute to the Swing Era,'' the jazz festival program in Carnegie Hall Tuesday evening, which he coproduced with George Wein.

title: JAYS TOP TWINS WITH 2 IN 9TH
description: Cliff Johnson hit a tiebreaking two-out double in the eighth inning tonight to help the Toronto Blue Jays score a 4-2 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: OXYGEN ENRICHER CO reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: DEBATE ON DAYLIGHT SAVING TIME LEADS TO TALK OF THERMOMETERS
description: Scarcely anything so stirs the oratorical flights of fancy of farm state Congressmen as proposals for expanding daylight saving time.

title: BANK RATES UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates on bank money market accounts rose sharply in the week ended Wednesday, the Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday. The Monitor's nationwide average, based on a weekly survey of 50 large institutions in the five largest United States markets, rose to 8.34 percent, from 8.28 percent last week and 8.23 percent the week before.

title: PHILHARMONIC MUSICIANS COMPLAIN
description: Members of the board of the New York Philharmonic have been informed by the orchestra's artistic committee of morale problems and dissatisfaction among the musicians.

title: Excerpts from opinions, page D22.
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a state tax deduction for education expenses is constitutional even though parochial schools reap most of the benefits.

title: KNICKS TRADE WILLIAMS
description: Sly Williams is an Atlanta Hawk, but Marvin Webster is still a Knick. In a series of moves yesterday, the Knicks, under the right of first refusal, matched the Boston Celtics' offer sheets to Williams and Webster, each for three years at $450,000 a year in guaranteed salaries. They then traded Williams to the Atlanta Hawks for Rudy Macklin, a forward and guard. The Knicks will pay $250,000 of Williams's total salary and keep Webster, unless they later trade him.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE OXFORD BOOK OF DEATH. Edited by D.J. Enright. 351 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: NEW FARM PRICES URGED ON AFRICANS
description: Africa, threatened with another widespread famine, was urged today by the United States and 32 other nations to raise fixed farm prices to restore incentive and avoid choked food production.

title: AFTER MUCH IN COMMON, A SPLIT ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick have much in common: ideological roots in the neoconservative movement, reputations in the academic community that have enhanced their public policy positions, strong support for Israel.

title: CITY AND COALITION PLAN A FOOD BANK
description: Faced with the challenge of trying to feed ''untold thousands'' of New Yorkers who cannot afford to feed themselves, city officials said yesterday, they have joined with a private coalition to start a food bank for gathering, storing and distributing donated food.

title: Sedition Charges Filed In Chicago Bomb Plot
description: Four people suspected of being members of a Puerto Rican nationalist group were arrested today and charged with seditious conspiracy in a plot to bomb a Government military installation in Chicago over the Fourth of July holiday weekend.

title: DON PULLEN IN PIANO CONCERT
description: DON PULLEN'S piano concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday was a study in transformations and extremities. Mr. Pullen would set up a rolling rhythm vamp, add a melodic topping as light as whipped cream and then sprinkle on dissonances. Gradually, cunningly, he piled up these dissonances until the music's tonal center had been entirely subsumed in pulsations of sheer noise.

title: MUSIC: GEORGE CRUMB
description: FOR 20 years, George Crumb has been turning out scores that have commanded attention for their exotically sensual sound colors, their extravagantly mystical allusions and their impeccable craftsmanship. Long before the present polemics about a New Romanticism in music, Mr. Crumb was appealing to conservative audiences without alienating too many academic progressives. And although the fanfare seemed to abate a bit after its peak around 1970, he remains a fascinating, idiosyncratic American artist.

title: TV Spot Uses Reagan To Promote 007
description: The White House is unhappy that a local television station has used part of President Reagan's appearance on a program about the fictional spy hero James Bond for a spot to promote the show.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Goodbye Alvin, Hello Simon ANeil Simon play playing at the Neil Simon. Yesterday that became a reality when the 56-year-old A lvin Theater on West 52d Street, where Mr. Simon's ''Brighton Beach M emoirs'' opened in March, was renamed. The renaming paired Mr. S imon with the late Eugene O'Neill as the only playwrights with B roadway theaters named for them.

title: PAKISTANI-AFGHAN AREA LEADS AS SUPPLIER OF HEROIN TO U.S.
description: Pakistan and adjoining areas of Afghanistan have surpassed Southeast Asia as the biggest supplier of heroin to the United States and the rest of the world, according to authorities here and in Washington.

title: STAUB PINCH-HIT STREAK ENDS
description: No one over the last three weeks has taught timely hitting better than Rusty Staub. But tonight the St. Louis Cardinals put an end to Staub's pinch-hitting success and also taught the Mets a lesson in timely offense.

title: HEILEMAN ACCUSED OF INSIDER TRADES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that the G. Heileman Brewing Company illegally acted on inside information last year in acquiring stock in the Olympia Brewing Company. That action earned Heileman nearly $1 million, the commission said.

title: SATINWOOD: REPAIRS CAN BE NOTICEABLE
description: Furniture made from satinwood has been prized for many years. The wood became very fashionable in the last quarter of the 18th century and was popular until the end of the Regency period in 1820.

title: News Analysis
description: The Carter Administration documents that found their way to President Reagan's 1980 campaign staff have raised a flurry of questions about what is standard practice and what is unethical behavior in Presidential races.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: LATIN AMERICA: THE CAUSES WASHINGTON CHOOSES TO SUPPORT
description: To the Editor:

title: GUATEMALA OFFERS DATE FOR ELECTION
description: The Government of Efrain Rios Montt, under pressure from military and political leaders, tonight proposed a timetable for elections to a constituent assembly, the first step toward turning the Government of Guatemala over to civilian rule.

title: Record Contract for Fouts
description: Dan Fouts, who ranks 15th on the all-time passing list, signed a six-year contract with the San Diego Chargers today that could make him the highest-paid player in pro football, team officials said.

title: YANKS TOP ORIOLES' ON RIGHETTI 5-HITTER
description: Don Mattingly, in his second visit to the Yankees this season, was talking the other day about his status. ''I don't know what's going to happen,'' he said. ''All I can do is make a statement with my play.''

title: Military Analysis
description: Senior officers in the United States Defense Department say they are increasingly concerned over the drive begun last week in Chad by rebel forces armed and equipped by Libya and supported by Libyan aircraft. They say the objective appears to be a Libyan penetration of the Sudan, with subsequent pressure on southern Egypt.

title: Barclays Bank To Retrench
description: Barclays, one of Britain's big four commercial banks, will phase out 150 branch offices over the next two years to streamline operations and cut costs, a spokesman said today.

title: EASTERN TIMBER WOLVES NEED A FRIEND AT INTERIOR
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HOME HEALTH CARE BOOM
description: A little over a year ago, John Sweet got stomach cancer. After his surgery, he developed a narrowing of the esophagus, and his weight dwindled from 176 pounds to 110. To prevent him from starving, doctors in early May implanted a catheter in a vein near his heart so he could be fed intravenously.

title: GREYHOUND SELLING ARMOUR
description: The Greyhound Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Armour Food Company to Conagra Inc. for about $166 million in stock and cash.

title: ACID RAIN PANEL URGES CURB ON POLLUTANTS IN EAST
description: The National Academy of Sciences, in a report likely to weigh heavily in forthcoming policy decisions, said today that acid rain could be curbed by reducing sulfur dioxide emissions from coal-burning power plants and factories in the eastern half of North America.

title: American Can, Paine Reports
description: A spokesman for the American Can Company said that the company would not discuss reports it had acquired up to about 5 percent of Paine Webber Inc.'s shares through large block purchases. Paine Webber also had no comment.

title: MORE PROBLEMS FOR PAUL BROWN
description: A s the United States Football League approaches the final weekend of its regular-season schedule, it is preening over the capture by the Tampa Bay Bandits of the wide receiver Cris Collinsworth from the Cincinnati Bengals for 1985 delivery. If there is a 1985 for the new league. Much more certain, judging by Paul Brown's aversion to anathema, is that Cris Collinsworth as well as the Bengal tight end Dan Ross, who has signed with the Boston Breakers for the 1984 season, will be traded to the highest bidder in the National Football League by the Bengals' boss, whose stripes never change.

title: Article 004808 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury has awarded more than $11 million to World Airways and the wives of three men killed in a plane crash in Alaska in 1973. The award was issued Monday against Jeppesen & Company after the jury found that the concern had sold a defective approach chart for instrument flying to the Cold Bay Airport in the Aleutian Islands. The wives are Nancy Evans of Cupertino, Norma Chapman of Portola Valley and Barbara Brockelsby of Fremont.

title: A CHOICE: OLYMPICS OR PROS
description: Brian Lawton emerged from the locker room after ice hockey practice here Tuesday wearing jeans and a gray T-shirt with the slogan: ''Property of the New York Rangers.''

title: U.S. Alters Eights For Henley Races
description: ON-THAMES, England, June 29 - United States participation in the 134th rowing of the Henley Royal Regatta has been altered even before the first strokes of the event begin Thursday.

title: Con Ed Local on S.I.  Rejects Contract Offer
description: Union employees of the Consolidated Edison Company on Staten Island, by a mail vote of 417 to 44, have rejected a proposal for a new three-year agreement, according to a report yesterday by James J. McCarren, a business representative of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. The proposal provided wage increases of 19.7 percent over the term of the agreement.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Soviet Maneuvers in Baltic
description: Soviet ground forces and naval units began military maneuvers in the Baltic today only 50 miles from where a United States-led Western exercise is being carried out.

title: GENERAL MOTORS CLOSING FOUNDRY AT TONAWANDA
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would close a casting foundry in the economically depressed city of Tonawanda, N.Y., and permanently eliminate 2,130 jobs there over the next year.

title: ECONOMIC FORECAST IS REVISED
description: Despite President Reagan's assurance last night that ''America's economy is beginning to sparkle,'' his top economic advisers see little hope for much improvement in the nation's high unemployment anytime soon. They also believe that the rate of inflation has stopped declining and will soon begin rising slightly.

title: Guerrillas Are Under Control, Colombian Army Chief Says
description: The acting commander of the Colombian Army, Gen. Jose Maria Arbelaez Caballero, said today that security forces had neutralized leftist guerrillas in the southwest of the country.

title: COSMOS SET BACK WHITECAPS
description: Matched against the team with the best record in the North American Soccer League, the Cosmos responded by defeating the Vancouver Whitecaps, 3-0, tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
AIDES TO REAGAN CONTINUE SEARCH FOR CARTER PLANS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they would probably find more material obtained in 1980 from President Jimmy Carter's campaign and would turn it over to the Justice Department for review.

title: HIGH SCHOOL STAR MEETS HIS HERO
description: Although he was impressed by the Statue of Liberty, and taken with the pace of midtown Manhattan, Hiawatha Francisco conceded that one of the best moments of his trip to New York was meeting O.J. Simpson.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I owe a lot to luck, loyalty and a short name.

title: Rhode Island Unit To Pay 6% to 9.8%
description: A $51.2 million Rhode Island Housing Mortgage Financing Corporation bond issue was tentatively priced Monday by Kidder, Peabody with yields ranging from 6 percent to 9.80 percent.

title: ITEMS IN THE SMITHSONIAN TOTAL 100 MILLION OR SO
description: The Smithsonian Institution, which has been tallying its holdings, said today that it possessed 100 million items, give or take a couple of hundred snails and a few thousand protozoa.

title: Cordero Wins 5,000th Race
description: With a victory in the last race at Belmont yesterday, Angel Cordero became the fourth jockey to ride 5,000 winners.

title: Article 006146 -- No Title
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee, showing more budgetary restraint than the Reagan Administration wanted, today sent to the floor a bill that would authorize $199.9 billion in military spending for the fiscal year 1984.

title: ENGINEERING MEASUREMENTS reports earnings for qtr to April 30.
KOCH WILL PRESS UNIONS TO AGREE ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: Mayor Koch warned yesterday of a major uncertainty in next year's New York City budget - a failure so far by the city to win agreement from labor unions on ''productivity'' savings of $50 million.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Someone apparently used the wrong kind of paint on my concrete patio and it is peeling. I want to repaint it, but first I have to get all of the old paint off. Scraping with a hand scraper doesn't seem to be a sensible answer. Is there an easier method?

title: Baker International
description: The Baker International Corporation announced it would establish reserves during the third fiscal quarter ending June 30 that would reduce after-tax earnings by about $98 million, or $1.40 a share.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Baltimore Orioles at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Ray Fontenot, a left-hander up from Columbus, makes his Yankee debut against Dennis Martinez of the Orioles in the final meeting between the teams before the All-Star break. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Cardinals at St. Louis. Neil Allen, who beat the Mets in his first start for the Cardinals after being traded for Keith Hernandez, faces the Mets again. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8:30 P.M. Radio -WHN, 1050; 8:30 P.M.).

title: Woman Abducted At a Bronx Garage
description: The 27-year-old wife of a special assistant to Mayor Koch was abducted Tuesday night by a man who held her captive for about 20 minutes before releasing her unharmed, the police said.

title: Joe Delaney, Football Player, Drowns in a Rescue Attempt
description: Joe Delaney, a running back with the Kansas City Chiefs who was one of the National Football League's top rookies in 1981, drowned today after jumping into a pond to rescue three boys who were floundering in the water, police said. He was 24 years old.

title: Miss Taylor's Absence Halts 'Private Lives'
description: ''Private Lives,'' starring Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, has been suspended at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater because Miss Taylor is ill with bronchitis and laryngitis, Zev Bufman, the producer, said yesterday. Mr. Bufman said he expected performances to resume next Tuesday.

title: RE-EVALUATIONS OF WEBERN'S MUSIC
description: THIS year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Anton Webern, and a good amount of the Austrian composer's music has lately been heard in New York. An ecstatic crowd filled Avery Fisher Hall to hear Maurizio Pollini's brilliant exegesis of the Piano Variations, Opus 27, and the new-music group Continuum devoted an entire evening to Webern's chamber pieces. A re-evaluation of the composer would seem to be taking place.

title: Realignment Of Peru Debt
description: Peru is scheduled to sign a refinancing agreement with its international creditor banks today, covering about $2.4 billion of the country's $11.6 billion of external debt, it was announced yesterday.

title: ODD MAN OUT IN AFRICA: MALAWI VOTES
description: The citizens of this landlocked Central African country voted today in a parliamentary election that will probably cause little change in either their lives or in the way this country has been governed for the last 19 years.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
Profit in Period For MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company reported operating income of $2.4 million, or 5 cents a share, for the third fiscal quarter ended May 31. It had posted a loss in the 1982 period of $4.4 million.

title: 'LEADING' INDEX UP 1.2% IN MAY
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge rose 1.2 percent in May, its 11th consecutive monthly increase. The gain prompted Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige to predict today that the recovery would ''remain vigorous in the months ahead.''

title: SHORTAGE OF DOCTORS IN HAMPTONS LIMITS MEDICAL CARE FOR POOR
description: While the Hamptons may be a popular spot for wealthy doctors to summer, the resort area has not been a popular spot for doctors to practice.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
2 Die in Airport Collision
description: A flight instructor and student pilot returning from a lesson were killed today when their single-engine plane was struck broadside by a business jet on a taxiway at Hobby Airport and both planes burst into flames, the authorities said. The two people aboard the jet escaped serious injury. The jet, which had had mechanical problems in trying to take off, veered off the runway, left a scorched path across the grassy infield, then slammed into the Grumman Cheetah, which was on a taxiway.

title: TOWERMARC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
COMMUNITY PSYCHIATRIC CENTERS INC reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: Year-ago results have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split.

title: METRO GOLDWYN MAYER/UNITED ARTISTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.6 million for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Market Place; Mutual Funds: A New Twist
description: THE front-end load, or sales charge, has disappeared from many mutual funds in recent years as investors became more sophisticated about what they pay for investment company products. This attitude was encouraged by various studies indicating that no-load funds often perform as well as load funds, where commission charges typically start at 8 1/2 percent.

title: MISSILE POLITICS, EAST AND WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET: TWO NEW FACES
description: ANEW Prodigal and a new Albrecht enacted their dramas of repentance at recent performances by the American Ballet Theater in the Metropolitan Opera House.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
TRAVELERS' SAFETY AIDS
description: MINDED travelers have several devices to choose from when considering what to take along for protection away from home. There are two smoke alarms, for example, that are small enough to fit in a suitcase.

title: Frazier to Get $1 Million
description: Marvis Frazier has accepted a $1 million offer to fight Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council heavyweight champion, in September or October. Holmes, unbeaten in 43 fights, will get $3.1 million for the 15th defense of his title.

title: Just a Second
description: ''When I discovered that June 30 will last longer than yesterday or tomorrow,'' says a friend whose birthday is today, ''I thought of it for a moment as a small gift from the official timekeeper at the Naval Observatory. But only for a moment, which is all it will be. One second to be precise, a 'leap second' to be observed at 11:59:59 tonight, Greenwich time (7:59:59 P.M., E.D.T.). One second is long enough to say 'happy' or 'birthday,' but not both.

title: Senate Confirms Latin Post
description: Without debate, the Senate today confirmed President Reagan's nomination of Langhorne A. Motley as Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs. Mr. Motley succeeds Thomas O. Enders, who was reassigned as Ambassador to Spain after disputes over Central American policies.

title: Bill Halts Spending on Reactor
description: Congress passed and sent to the White House today a $14.1 billion appropriations bill that may finally kill the controversial Clinch River breeder reactor project in Tennessee.

title: No.1 Louis Fan
description: Since 1940, when his father bought a movie projector and showed a film of Joe Louis's fight against Tony Galento, Angelo Prospero has been collecting memorabilia - programs, posters, ticket stubs, magazines - concerning Louis.

title: Met Museum Schedules Egyptian Film Series
description: ''The Mummy,'' a 1932 film starring Boris Karloff, will open a five-part film series dealing with ancient Egypt on July 5 in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street. The films are being shown in conjunction with the reinstallation of the museum's entire Egyptian art collection.

title: Crash That Killed 6 Occurred in 'Drop' Test
description: Six men aboard an Air Force cargo plane were killed when the plane, a C-130, crashed into an 8,500-foot mountain in a training exercise at low altitudes, a military spokesman said today.

title: SCOTTISH & YORK HOLDINGS LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Turnstile Justice: The Breakdown of Criminal Court Third of four articles.
description: The breakdown of New York City's Criminal Court begins with facilities that are often filthy and dilapidated. It ends with a pattern of case disposition that most participants agree is unpredictable and unfair. In eight key areas, according to the judges, prosecutors and defense lawyers who work there, Criminal Court has become a mockery of what was intended when it was created 21 years ago to judge lesser crimes and begin the legal process in the most serious ones. The areas of failure are these:

title: Judge in Scotland Bars Fluoridation of Water
description: The longest and most expensive case in Scottish legal history ended today with a ruling that fluoridation of the water supply was illegal. The suit was brought by a 69-yearold woman with no teeth.

title: Carter Papers, Reagan Ethics
description: Who me? says President Reagan about the Carter campaign papers: I didn't see them, I didn't know about them, I didn't use them, and besides, even if somebody used them, they couldn't have been much use.

title: BRIEFING
description: Ring of the Red Phone

title: BRIEFINGATE
description: As the President now knows, it is not midsummer media madness, or ''much ado about nothing.'' Briefingate - the penetration of the Carter campaign by the Reagan campaign, in order to give the Republican candidate an edge in 1980's televised debate - raises a legitimate issue of right and wrong.

title: SOUTHAMPTON SHOW HOUSE TO OPEN DOORS
description: THE grand resort mansions, hidden down tree-lined driveways or behind tall privet hedges, are as enticing and romantic as they are exclusive and unvisitable.

title: McEnroe in Semifinals
description: A John McEnroe-Ivan Lendl men's singles semifinal was assured today when the second-seeded McEnroe powered past Sandy Mayer, 6-3, 7-5, 6-0.

title: SAN JOSE SCHOOLS DECLARE INSOLVENCY IN WAKE OF TAX REVOLT
description: The San Jose Unified School District, in the heart of California's high-technology industrial complex, declared itself insolvent Tuesday night.

title: CODE-SCANNER RACE QUICKENS
description: For the past nine years, many retailers have relied on computerized scanners to read the tiny black and white coded lines on everything from soft drinks to cassette tapes. All too often, however, cashiers have cursed the scanners -the only ones on the market - for functioning slowly or misreading the zebra-stripe patterns.

title: Bribe Case Plea
description: Ernie Cobb, the former Boston College basketball star, pleaded not guilty to Federal charges stemming from a point-shaving scheme. Cobb, 26 years old, of Stamford, Conn., refused to make any comment at the arraignment.

title: Bonn Backs Loans to East
description: The West German Government agreed today to guarantee $396.8 million in private bank loans to East Germany, the largest such credit ever underwritten by Bonn.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING TO ACQUIRE TERRA
description: In line with the trend for utility concerns to further expand into other energy fields, the Pacific Lighting Corporation announced an agreement yesterday to acquire Terra Resources Inc., of Tulsa, Okla., for $300 million.

title: REPAIRS START ON I-95 SPAN AMID INQUIRY
description: Crews started to unload a temporary two-lane span here today as state and Federal inspectors began investigating the fatal collapse of a 100-foot section of a Connecticut Turnpike bridge early Tuesday.

title: SKIPPER'S FISH & CHIPS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 12.
Reagan on Court Rulings
description: President Reagan, asked in Kansas City about the Supreme Court decision that a state tax deduction for education expenses is constitutional, said, ''Yes, yes, I'm happy about it.'' On the Court's setting aside of a Minnesota ruling that male college students must disclose draft registration to get Federal aid, Education Secretary T.H. Bell said on the flight here with the President: ''In my opinion, there are going to be students very vigorously resisting this.''

title: MASTERS MERCHANDISE MART INC reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $799,038 for the latest year and $167,400 for the previous year.

title: CARDIAC RESUSCITATOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for year to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Charterhouse Chief Sets New Venture
description: Merril M. Halpern, 49-year-old president and chief executive of Charterhouse Group International, says he has completed financing for a new company being set up to invest in American takeover deals, especially leveraged buyouts.

title: 2 CHIEFS TO BE PROMOTED TO TOP POLICE POSTS TODAY
description: Two field commanders are to be promoted today to top posts in the city's Police Department, according to department officials. The two commanders are Robert J. Johnston Jr., who is to become chief of patrol, and Raymond L. Jones, who is to become the acting chief of organized-crime control.

title: SENATE APPROVES FARM FUNDS DESPITE REAGAN VETO THREAT
description: The Senate, ignoring warnings of a Presidential veto, adopted a 1984 agriculture appropriation bill today that would provide about $6.2 billion less than is being spent this year but could require increasing funds for food stamps and emergency loans for farmers, which the Administration opposes.

title: U.S. BLOCKS BANK LOAN FOR NICARAGUA ROADS
description: The United States today vetoed a $2.2 million loan by the Inter-American Development Bank to build roads that would serve a region of small coffee farms in Nicaragua. The 42 other members of the bank voted for the loan.

title: HONDURAS CHARGES BORDER WAS MINED
description: The Honduran military said today that a land mine laid by Nicaraguans had killed two American journalists driving on road near the border, not gunfire from Nicaragua as had been believed.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
News Summary; THURSDAY, JUNE 30, 1983
description: International High-level American-Soviet talks have been held since the beginning of the year, according to senior Reagan Administration officials. They said that Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin had met privately almost a dozen times. (Page A1, Column 2-3.) The biggest supplier of heroin to the United States and the world is now Pakistan and adjoining areas of Afghanistan, according to officials in Islamabad and Washington. In the last six to nine months, they said, the region has surpassed Southeast Asia in heroin exports and has become the source of up to 85 to 90 percent of the drug sold in New York City. (A1:1-2.)

title: I.M.F. Short of Money For Loan Commitments
description: The International Monetary Fund, which has approved a record amount of credit in the past year because of the foreign debt crisis, is now $2 billion short of the money it needs to finance its lending commitments, monetary officials said today.

title: ART MADE OF WINDOW BLINDS
description: IT was a coincidence of sorts that led Harry Umen, above, an artist in New Hampshire, to try his hand at making what he describes as his ''tapestry compositions,'' using industrial materials. Levolor Lorentzen happened to offer the artist a stock of aluminum miniblinds, which are more likely to be seen concealing windows than decorating walls. Mr. Umen combined the metal strips with pieces of sheet glass and painted vinyl to make his colorful collages of bundled materials.

title: ODEAN POPE AND LIBRE
description: IT'S hard to imagine a group with more raw power than the Odean Pope Trio, which played Sunday at Soundscape. Mr. Pope has a huge tenor saxophone tone, strongly influenced by John Coltrane. Cornell Rochester's furious drumming and Gerald Vesley's versatile electric bass lines provide added muscle.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On the Coal Slurry Bill Farmers' Bad Pipe Vibes To the Editor: Your June 14 editorial ''Turn on the Coal Faucet'' misses the mark by a country mile. We would be interested in knowing to whom you talked among the farmers.

title: DOW, IN MILD RALLY, RISES 4.61
description: Stock prices staged a brief and uninspired rally late yesterday on buying of glamour stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average, off about 2 points through much of the session, was up three points at 3 P.M., when it began climbing steadily. Ahead 7.42 points at 3:30 P.M., the Dow then retreated, closing up 4.61 points, at 1,213.84.

title: Myopic Officials
description: One-fourth of those who officiate at college and other amateur sports events lack normal vision, according to a Philadelphia optometrist who specializes in the vision problems of athletes. Dr. Arthur Seidemar, in a report presented at the annual meeting of the American Optometric Association in Washington, said he had studied the vision of 40 umpires and referees between the ages of 27 and 57 who officiated at all types of amateur sports competition. ''Thirty percent of those studied had problems visualizing distance and the position of objects in relation to other objects,'' he said.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CARTER PAPERS INVESTIGATOR
description: Twice in his political career Donald J. Albosta, a seemingly mild-mannered farmer from Michigan, has surprised both friend and foe.

title: Anna Maskin Is Married
description: Anna Maskin, widow of Dr. Israel Maskin, was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El of Long Beach, L.I., to Jesse J. Levy of Long Beach. Mr. Levy is a retired inspector of food with the Comptroller's Office of the City of New York. His first wife died.

title: Ecuador Oil Pact
description: Ecuador's state-owned oil corporation will sell 24,000 barrels a day of oil to Belen Interprise International Inc., a United States company, at $28 a barrel, the Government said. The year-long contract, retroactive to May 1, can be renewed for another year or for a different period according to market conditions, the government said in a statement.

title: HELP FOR SICK PLANTS IN DOWNTOWN CLINIC
description: THE leaves of my peperomia are turning yellow, what should I do? My lawn is growing brown, how can I revive it? Insects are attacking my garden, how can I control them?

title: U.S. to Investigate Charges on Police
description: The Justice Department will investigate charges that New York City police officers violated the civil rights of some black residents, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: Senate Roll Call
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today defeated, 55 to 45, a plan to limit to a maximum of $720 the effects of the reduction Friday in personal income tax rates. A vote ''for'' was a vote to limit the tax cut; a vote ''against'' was a vote to leave the tax cut intact.

title: Olivier 'Lear' Scheduled For U.S. TV in 1984
description: ''King Lear,'' the 1982 television production starring Laurence Olivier that was presented in England in April, will make its American debut next year as part of the Mobil Showcase Network's 1984 season.

title: CSX Delays Buying Shares
description: The CSX Corporation said that it had postponed last night's scheduled purchase of shares under its tender offer for the Texas Gas Resources Corporation because of a temporary restraining order issued late yesterday by a Federal judge in Washington.

title: EASTGROUP PROPERTIES reports earnings for qtr to May 31.
description: b-Including gains of $1,292,000 for the quarter and $1,505,000 for the 6 months on the sale of real estate investments. c-Including a gain of $1,666,000 on the sale of real estate investments.

title: MCI Searching For an Agency
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, already a major thorn in the side of dear old Ma Bell when it comes to consumer long-distance telephoning, is planning similar positioning with her descendants in the business-to-business area, once the divestiture of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company becomes effective in about six months.

title: BROWN, TOM, INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: PRECEDENT FOR CUOMO
description: To the Editor:

title: A 6TH MAN IS HAPPY OVER HIS SELECTION
description: A fter a morning spent wrestling with an examination in quantitative analysis, the last thing Kevin Williams needed to hear was the determination of his basketball future. While the fanatics gathered for the National Basketball Association draft at the Felt Forum, a subway ride from the Williams home at 115th Street and Madison Avenue, Williams chose to spend Tuesday afternoon with a friend.

title: Roll-call vote is on page D8.
description: The Republican-controlled Senate, by a vote of 55 to 45, today defeated a bill that would have limited to $720 the maximum amount any taxpayer would receive from the 10 percent income tax cut that goes into effect Friday.

title: BIRDVIEW SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-The company reported that it had no sales for the year-ago periods. c-Net loss.

title: ERRANT SATELLITE NUDGED INTO ORBIT
description: One of the most difficult salvage operations in space ended successfully yesterday when a $100 million communications satellite fired a few thruster jets no bigger than thimbles and finally reached its destination, a circular orbit 22,236 miles above the Equator.
